name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Srebrenica commemoration (2015/2747(RSP)).

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Commission thanks Parliament for allowing this debate to take place, and we welcome it.  Talking about Srebrenica and your request to have the resolution on the table is an important, common and signative activity of the European institutions. On the 20th anniversary of this terrible event, our thoughts are with the families of the families who lost their closest relatives in this tragedy.  We remember the victims and we must also acknowledge that Europe and the world – including us – failed to do everything possible to protect the victims. The Srebrenica genocide exactly twenty years ago left wounds and traces not only in south-eastern Europe, but throughout Europe. He has suffered deep wounds in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and he continues to place a moral obligation on us not to forget this. It calls on all of us, including the elected politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the whole region, to take responsibility for preserving the memory – which we are doing here today – that the judiciary be supported in punishing war crimes and, finally, that steps are taken towards reconciliation – for reconciliation throughout the region in the interests of present and future generations. In order to alleviate the pain of the relatives, it is essential to bring the perpetrators to justice and to find out the truth and fate of the many people still missing. This is also a necessary conditio for gradually achieving lasting reconciliation in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in the whole region between the various peoples, the people.  For those responsible on the part of the European Union, one of the most important lessons of the Balkan wars was not just to commit to reconstruction. Furthermore, we have clearly advocated a future for the countries of the Western Balkans in the European Union. They are candidate countries and we, for our part, should continue to make a credible offer. It is now a question of working to restore trust between the people and ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the whole region. I would like to express the Commission's wish that the commemoration of Srebrenica, which is primarily intended to honour the victims of the genocide, must also provide the impetus for a comprehensive reconciliation. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, as in all countries in the region, the Commission expects the authorities and societies to work resolutely towards the European Union. This is the best way to get over the tragedies of the past – not to forget them, but to get away – and to ensure that crimes like this genocide twenty years ago in Srebrenica can never happen again. We thank the European Parliament for today's resolution. The Commission regrets that, at the same time, a similar resolution proposed by the United Kingdom had not been possible in the UN Security Council by a veto by the Russian Federation. We believe that such tragic events, which lie in the history of our continent, should not be used for current political measures.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, today's discussion and the text we are going to vote on are very important, especially in a context where the UN Security Council failed yesterday to adopt a resolution. We have a duty to commemorate the victims of these heinous crimes, which took place twenty years ago, during the fall of Srebrenica. Our thoughts are with the victims and their families today. It is a duty of remembrance for us Europeans, as well as the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region. Without this work of memory, there can be no reconciliation, just as there can be no reconciliation without the restoration of the truth, however painful it may be. The truth is that 20 years ago a genocide occurred in Srebrenica. We strongly condemn it, just as we reject any desire to put it into perspective or to deny it. Not only does it damage the memory of the victims, but it also undermines the reconciliation process. That is why I appeal to the political leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina and those in the region to lead by example and help society to recognize and accept this difficult past so that their country can move forward. As for us, we must do everything we can to ensure that such events do not happen again and show our support for the integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Western Balkans into the Union. This is the best way to help them overcome their divisions.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. Poverty and the burning of war have laid the foundations of today's European Union, united in peace, equality, solidarity, democracy, tolerance, respect for human rights. (Short interruption, repetition of speech from the beginning.) Reconciliation must begin where it hurts the most. I believe that the painful memory of the genocide, the massacre of more than 8,000 Bošnjaks 20 years ago in Srebrenica, is that persecution and agony are an opportunity for reconciliation. On the 60th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, former German Chancellor Schroeder said: "The temptation to forget is extraordinary, but we will not succumb to this temptation." Together, we must pay tribute to all the victims of the Srebrenica massacre and the wars on the territory of the former Yugoslavia. There will be no freedom, justice and human dignity if we forget or turn a blind eye to crimes. Srebrenica must serve as a reminder that such horrific crimes must not happen again. More than 1,000 people are still missing today. On Saturday, we will pay our respects in Srebrenica in their memory. I welcome the joint resolution in which we will vote in this House today. Regional cooperation and the convergence of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the Union is the best way of reconciliation and overcoming hatred and division. I regret that the resolution was not adopted yesterday by the United Nations Security Council. In discussions about history, we must go beyond political boundaries. And memory, acknowledging terrible crimes is a moral obligation for all of us, as is our shared moral commitment to help Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path to Union membership.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, this week in this house we remember the genocide in Srebrenica. We are focused on the sacrifices and suffering of their families, but I would like us to take advantage of this sad anniversary and to remind us of the no less sad role of the international community in this terrible bloodshed.  For almost four years, they shared two of the biggest tragedies that marked the war in the former Yugoslavia: Vukovar and Srebrenica. But unfortunately, that time was not enough for images to the ground of ruined Vukovar and information about the mass liquidations of civilians and disarmed Croatian defenders and the existence of camps for Croats on Serbian soil that opened their eyes to the free world about the true character of Serbian aggression against neighbouring states. As a result of the inertia of the international community, the worst that could have happened happened – Srebrenica. And all those who want to relativize these horrors should know that only truth leads to justice and justice leads to lasting peace.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, genocide took place in Srebrenica 20 years ago, the most horrific war crime since World War II on European soil. The motive for the crime is that someone is a member of another nation or other faith. That is why we must be grateful to European fathers for living in values that unite us in diversity. Politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina should also accept this. It is time to stop the divisions in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is time to understand that Europe wants you in its arms, and therefore it is time for everyone to bow down in Bosnia and Herzegovina. To bow to the victims and to bow to all those who perished and to the families who are still suffering today. All sides in Bosnia and Herzegovina committed war crimes, committing atrocities. Unfortunately, so are members of my people. That's why we need to tell the truth, and we should be brave enough to accept such a truth.  Srebrenica remains a symbol of the suffering and tragedies of all the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and that is why I believe we should mark this day permanently. This should be the anniversary when all those sufferings that took place in the former Yugoslavia and elsewhere in the world will be truly commemorated. Each of us has to question ourselves whether he could have done something, if he could have prevented anything. That is why, unfortunately, I must note that the international community completely failed to do what we all expected at the time, which is to prevent the massacre that took place in Srebrenica. We have to punish the criminals to the end, and that's why I expect The Hague tribunal to do its job to the end. I'm sorry the United Nations didn't have the courage to pass a resolution because we expected it to pass a resolution. That is why it is good that we have a common resolution here today, but it is also good that Vucic decided to go to Srebrenica. And that is why we should say here: this is not a resolution against Serbia, let alone against the Serbian people. This is a resolution that wants to help Serbia face the truth and that in the end we all become members of this great European family of ours.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to confine myself to two remarks. The first is that war at all and these tragedies might not have happened if the Americans had not forced Aliya Izetbegovich to rescind his signature under a peace agreement negotiated by European diplomacy in 1992. The second point concerns the fact that, although radko Mladic and Radovan Karadzic are presented to us in the texts that are presented to us, there is no mention at all in this connection of the man who actually unleashed the whole series of provocations that led to the tragedy, namely Naser Orič. A businessman from Tuzla who was released in The Hague in 2006 because witnesses were either murdered or disappeared or did not have the courage to speak. So he was released for lack of evidence. That's all. I think that the reminder of this matter certainly does not end with what we are currently discussing in the European Parliament.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – I cannot name everyone who was killed in Srebrenica in one minute. We cannot and cannot run from the truth and acknowledge responsibility. And this is where international organisations bear particular responsibility. Let the courts do their job and pay our respects to the victims.  Let us pay tribute to the mothers who lost their children, the wives who lost their husbands, the sisters who lost their brothers. no one can repay them for their loss, but we can help them by preventing forgetting and attempts to relativise or forget this crime. Let us insist on truth and justice for the victims and their families, but also for those who are prevented by the crime committed on their behalf, but without their responsibility, in the fight to reverse a new leaf, to live together in a multiethnic community and to actually bring Bosnia to where, including, in this international community, the Community of the European Union belongs.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, days of remembrance such as srebrenica are intended to remind and teach younger generations the extent of human atrocities that feed mainly on extremism, to exemplify and act as a deterrent. Unfortunately, however, such heinous crimes are now being committed by the jihadist killers of Al Qaeda, Boko Haram and the Islamic State.  But Srebrenica was not a random event. It was the result of the blunt intervention of the Americans and Germans, who wanted the dissolution of the united Yugoslavia for geopolitical self-interest. It was a criminal attack on a sovereign state made up of Slavic ethnic groups.  The bad results of this policy are seen to date: in Bosnia and Herzegovina the three different ethnicities that hate each other, in Kosovo, where there has been violent displacement of Serbs and illegal settlement by Albanians, in FYLOM, a state of a patchwork of ethnicities with dreams of stealing the Greek name of Macedonia.   Remembrance Days is history. History must not be told or falsified.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, on the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide, I express my condolences and solidarity with the families of the victims, many of whom still do not know the final fate of their loved ones. With today's resolution, we strongly condemn the genocide committed by Serb forces under the command of Ratko Mladic after the fall of the UN protected zone in July 1995, when some 8,000 captured Bosniak men, young men and civilians were systematically executed.  We also recall the 2007 Tribunal's 2007 ruling that established Serbia's responsibility for failed to prevent genocide in Srebrenica and for not cooperating in the prosecution of perpetrators, and we stress the need to complete the process at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia as soon as possible.  We saw that in New York yesterday Russia vetoed, and China, Venezuela, Nigeria and Angola abstained on the UN Security Council resolution. This makes it more significant that our resolution rejects denial, relativization and mis interpretations on which certain political options in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia insist continuously.  I am firmly convinced that reconciliation and a common future, a European future, can only be reached by establishing the truth, accepting international judgments, apologizing and regretting the victims of the greatest crime in Europe after World War II, not the policy of denying the crimes of the Milosevic regime, and not only in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this week we are commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide. We honour the memory of the victims and pay tribute to the fortitude of their families in seeking justice. It shames the world that it failed to protect innocent civilians. It is disappointing that the UN failed to pass this resolution, especially when the International Court of Justice (ICJ), its own court, had acknowledged the genocide. Lessons of the past must be learned. We renew our determination never to let forces of prejudice, hatred and evil go unchecked. While we commemorate the past, we keep our eyes firmly on the future of Bosnia. Reconciliation remains a fundamental objective. This path leads to justice and truth. Our duty is to strengthen our efforts to promote education, remembrance and research about Srebrenica and other genocides. Future generations must understand the causes of such massacres and build societies based on trust, inclusivity and the celebration of diversity. We remain fully committed to Bosnia and Herzegovina being part of the EU, together with other Western Balkan nations. The European path is the best way to move forward beyond the tragedies of the past. We urge the leaders of Bosnia to work together to make the country a safe and prosperous place, for this will be the lasting tribute to the Srebrenica victims. Our hearts and thoughts will always be with them.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, this Saturday I will be representing this Parliament on behalf of  President Schulz, along with tens of thousands of others, in Srebrenica at the commemoration, and I will take the honour and the respect expressed to the victims today here in this Parliament, and the grief and the condolences to those who have survived, with me in my heart and express it there. Remembering this genocide – the greatest atrocity since the Second World War – is important, and I am so glad that this Parliament is doing this, and I really regret that the resolution was blocked in the UN Security Council. That is why our resolution is even more important. Peace comes only with talking about cruelties, with commemorating and with putting perpetrators on trial and in jail – and with reconciliation, of course. Let me also nevertheless remember all the women who have become victims of war rape, also in the Balkans, and whose grief is still not recognised all over the country. Never again, it needs also to be said here, must anything similar to the genocide of Srebrenica happen on this continent or elsewhere in the world.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we really don't have to wait for the so-called historical distance to be able to assess the scale of a particular event. Genocide in Srebrenica certainly is. What we need to prevent is that such a past has a future.  Today we know that a series of tragedies of the 20th century began 100 years ago in Sarajevo, a town not far from Srebrenica. And the European 20th century, full of wars and destruction, ended in the same way in 1995 in Bosnia and Herzegovina, in Srebrenica. Yet what makes the suffering of eight thousand people all the more tragic is that at that time, unlike the beginning of the 20th century, there was a European Union, the United Nations and a system of collective security that had to prevent the common man from becoming a victim of warlessness, and nothing controlled hatred.  Victims were gunned down 20 years ago as victims today try to kill themselves with silence or high-politics cynicism. However, Srebrenica victims will not and cannot be killed by oblivion. This is why the European Parliament can be proud of its contribution to this fight – a resolution we will adopt today.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, the message of the European Union is united in diversity. This is precisely the message that needs to be conveyed to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Because of its citizens, the future of its youth, peace in the region, for the future. And for the future of the European Union.  We must not forget, it has been 20 years since one of the biggest crimes took place: genocide and ethnic cleansing in Srebrenica. Because of the peace of all those 1200 or more, which we still cannot find, in Srebrenica, in other parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also in Croatia. For the sake of the peace of future generations, we must make every effort to find all the dead, to reconcile all the peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to have a secure future.  That is why I call on the European Union, all institutions and all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina to make maximum efforts to find a solution to lasting peace.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – We remember with deep respect those who died in Srebrenica 20 years ago today and express our condolences to those who have lost loved ones. Their grief is also our European grief today. The Serb genocide must not fall into oblivion. It is our human and moral duty to commemorate these events and to make it clear that nothing like this can and must not happen again. Colleagues, I would like to thank all of you who still have the Srebrenica flower pinned today as a symbol of memory, but also of hope. I believe that together we will be able to contribute to finding reconciliation and bringing hope for a better future for Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we commemorate today in the European Parliament what happened in Bosnia and Herzegovina when those human beings were killed. Unfortunately, the United Nation troops failed to protect the people there. This was their main duty. We have to check with the United Nations peacekeeping activities so that this does not happen again. We have to deplore the vote by Russia against the UN resolution on genocide. It is unbelievable how a country can deny that such a situation is genocide. The guilty have to be brought to justice. Reconciliation is so important for Bosnia and Herzegovina in its path towards European integration. This kind of genocide must not happen again.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, on the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica massacre, it is important that this genocidal attempt against 8 000 Bosnian Muslim men and boys is remembered as the worst atrocity of its type since World War II. It must never happen again. A thousand boys and men are still missing, presumed dead and buried in unmarked graves, after summary executions in cold blood by Bosnian Serb forces and irregular militias. The UN was sadly negligent in its function to protect civilians in its designated territory. I also wish, along with other colleagues, to express my absolute shock at the Russian veto of the British Government’s attempt to get a Srebrenica resolution through the UN Security Council. Tragedies of this type should never be a political football. Has Russia not learned its lessons from the Katyń massacres during World War II, when Stalin lied and blamed this on the Germans? Surely this should not happen again either.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the horrific events of twenty years ago in Srebrenica may be interpreted by many countries, but they must remind us most importantly: that the transition from totalitarianism to democratic civil societies in the Balkans has been marked by bloody ethnic conflicts. Against this background, my country the Republic of Bulgaria has been able to make a bloodless transition, known in bulgaria as a Bulgarian ethnic model - one of the brightest regrets on our path to membership in NATO and the European Union. With the active role of the liberal party DPS, the expectations of many analysts that the first bloodshed ethnic war will take place in Bulgaria because of the forced change of the names of Bulgarian Muslims have been refuted.  Twenty years after the events in Srebrenica and the tragedy of Bosnian Muslims, it becomes clear how difficult and painful the Balkans have come.  The memory of the tragedy in Srebrenica tells us that Europe continues to be a moral debtor in the Western Balkans. In two decades, the countries of this region have gone from irreconcilable enemies to partners and like-minded people of the Euro-Atlantic cause. They have the right to live in a truly European multicultural union.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, given the scale of the Tragedy of Srebrenica 20 years ago, we must have the courage today to say that there are no innocent people. The only innocent were the victims and their families. And, as is always the case in these kinds of situations, the international community has been deceitable in recognizing the crime and has been deceitable. Therefore, any tribute to the victims of this massacre today runs the risk of being interpreted as an exercise of hypocrisy, until the perpetrators of this heinous crime are punished. The non-punishment of its perpetrators prolongs the most harmful effects of this crime, which is impunity. It is therefore necessary for the international community to punish the perpetrators of this crime, because only then can the victims of it have peace again.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been Today's debate is a sign of the European Parliament's credible commitment to remembering the tragic moment in the history of our continent, the Srebrenica genocide twenty years ago.  By taking part in this debate, the Commission joins Parliament in paying our respects to the victims of the genocide – and also to all the victims of the war – in bosnia and Herzegovina between 1992 and 1995. The commemoration of this dramatic past in our immediate neighbourhood reminds us of what the European Union has been really about since its inception. First of all, it was a peace project: the Peace Union. A peace project that helped to overcome deep divisions in Europe after the Second World War and after the fall of the Berlin Wall. A peace project to achieve a better future for us and our children and grandchildren across the continent, both inside and outside the European Union. Bosnia and Herzegovina and the other countries in the region have a clear European perspective. We – the EU, Parliament, the Commission, the Member States and the Council – have repeatedly stressed this.  The Commission will spare no effort to help the countries of the Western Balkans to progress on their path to the European Union, to achieve the conditions and thus to secure a better future for the next generations.

name: President. –
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The official story of the Srebrenica massacre is biased and distorted. Indeed, the violent conflict in the Balkans has been reclaimed in favour of an American strategy to demonize exclusively the Serbian camp. Yet, twenty years later, and as the United Nations prepares to commemorate Srebrenica, there is no evidence to establish the responsibility of Bosnia's Serb minority for the massacre of thousands of Bosnians. Moreover, as Jean-René Ruez, head of investigations in Srebrenica, admitted to a french National Assembly commission of inquiry in February 2001, there is no evidence to support the existence of planning for mass executions with ethnic motivation. Only a fair recognition of the responsibility of each side will make it a lasting reconciliation of the torn peoples of the Balkans. That is why the commemorations of Srebrenica should no longer be used as an anti-poison release in the service of American interests alone.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. Twenty years after the Srebrenica massacre, this event has become a political weapon in the hands of Euro-Atlanticists to intervene in a sovereign country, which thus violates the Dayton Accords and tries to bring the Serbian Republic to its knees with the main aim of diminishing Russia's influence in the region. Through this demonization of Serbs by the Euro-Atlanticists, radical Islamists extend their doctrine among Bosnians without any difficulty, thus calling "shahîd" (martyr for Islam) the victims of Srebrenica. Let us recall here the deadly terrorist attack of Zvornik and the 300 Bosnian citizens who went to wage jihad in Syria! It is high time to stop using the victims of Srebrenica as an instrument of Euro-Atlantic geopolitical interests and to seriously combat Islamist radicalisation in the Balkans. It is time to work on solutions that will enable real reconciliation of peoples and improve the economic situation of the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today, here at the European Parliament, we honour the memory of the over 8 000 innocent men and boys – brothers and husbands, fathers and sons – who were brutally murdered in Srebrenica in a brazen act of genocide that shocked the world.  The name Srebrenica will forever be associated with some of the darkest acts of the 20th century. We know that Srebrenica’s future, and that of Bosnia and Herzegovina, will not be held back by its painful recent history. We reject efforts to distort the scope of this atrocity, rationalise the motivations behind it, blame the victims, and deny the indisputable fact that it was genocide. We all desire continued reconciliation and peaceful coexistence for the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Balkans, because achieving that will be the ultimate repudiation of the evil that started the wars in Bosnia and Herzegovina and elsewhere in the region and that led to the Srebrenica genocide. Our hearts and deepest sympathies are with them, and we pledge our enduring commitment to support their aspirations for a better tomorrow.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. – During this plenary session, we are commemorating the 20th anniversary of the genocide in Srebrenica. In July 1995, 8 372 men and boys were killed in the massacre in the Muslim enclave of Srebrenica. This massacre is considered the worst in Europe since the end of the Second World War. Saliha Osmanovic, the woman who lost her husband and two sons, also spoke at the EP commemoration. It was an honor to meet her and the other survivors. During the interview, Saliha Osmanovich told me that despite the great tragedy, she did not feel hatred in herself. And most of all, she gave me the heart to never forget what happened in Srebrenica 20 years ago, and to pass on this memory to future generations, so that nothing like this would ever happen again.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Esther Herranz García, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a Council regulation laying down maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or any other case of radiological emergency (COM(2013)0943 – C7—0045/2014 – 2013/0451(NLE)) (A8—0176/2015).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Deputy Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am taking the place today of my colleague Herranz García, who cannot be here and whom I would like to thank, of course, for her work on this dossier. The report concerns the European Commission's proposal to recast 3 regulations: No 3954 of 1987, which sets maximum permissible levels of contamination for foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or in any other case of radiological emergency; Regulation No 944 of 1989 setting maximum permissible levels of contamination of secondary foodstuffs following a nuclear or other emergency accident and Regulation No 770 of 1990, which also lays down the maximum levels permitted in food for animals contaminated as a result of nuclear accidents or in the event of a radiation emergency. We believe it is important for the European Union to have up-to-date legal instruments, which contain decision-making procedures that are agile and adapted to all circumstances, in order to deal with situations such as those experienced after the Chernobyl accident or the Fukushima accident. The legal basis of the 2010 proposal only required consultation of the European Parliament. In its explanatory statement, the Commission acknowledges that, taking into account the development of primary Community law on food safety and the need to ensure the consistency of all legislative measures concerning the conditions for imports of foodstuffs and feedingstuffs from third countries affected by a nuclear accident or radiological emergency, the measures which have been drawn up in the post-Chernobyl context will have to be brought into line with the system of implementing powers and procedures defined in the in this Regulation. This could also lead, if necessary, to a change in the legal basis. The rapporteur, Mrs Herranz, therefore proposes an amendment to the legal basis of the regulation, which gives Parliament the power of codecision. Food safety is the ultimate objective of the European Commission's proposal and the regulation must reflect the evolution of Community law, all the more so after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. The proposal sets out in its annexes the maximum permissible levels in the event of an accident or radioactive emergency, which were confirmed in 2012 by a group of experts set up under the Commission's Euratom Treaty. In the event of an accident or radiological emergency, the Commission shall adopt an implementing act to make the maximum permitted levels of radioactive waste in food applicable. The Commission will therefore have great flexibility to adapt, if necessary, the values set out in the annexes if circumstances so require. According to the new comitology, for the first time the Commission will have to be assisted by the section of the Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed, toxicological safety of the food chain dealing with radioactive contamination. The author of the draft report considers that the use of implementing acts to deal with critical situations arising from a nuclear accident is the most appropriate way of acting quickly. Where the immediacy of the action is essential to ensure consumer safety, the Commission shall provide for a specific emergency procedure. With regard to implementing acts adopted in the event of an accident, the draft report provides for the possibility that they may be reviewed as often as necessary to reflect the development of contamination. The text proposed by the Commission must be supplemented by the introduction of certain procedures for general principles of food law in order to introduce, among other things, an early warning system that allows for an agile exchange of information. In the light of this, I naturally ask you to support Mrs Herranz García's report.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am today representing my colleague and friend, Commissioner Arias Caete, who, for compelling reasons – the annual ACER conference is taking place in Ljubljana – cannot be in Strasbourg. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Esther Herranz Garcia, and your colleague Giovanni La Via for a positive, comprehensive, knowledgeable and balanced report. Today's proposal aims to update or adapt the current regulation establishing maximum levels of radioactivity in food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency. Serious accidents such as those at Chernobyl or Fukushima cannot be completely ruled out in any technical effort to improve the safety of nuclear installations as much as possible.  It is therefore important that clear and efficient procedures are put in place at EU level and that further development is developed in order to set maximum levels of radioactivity in food and feed for the European market in the event of a nuclear accident.  Procedures must be in line with the new rules governing the exercise of implementing powers by the Commission. However, they must also allow the Commission to react quickly if it is informed that the maximum levels in food and feed could or are even exceeded.  The Council has already set these maximum levels after the Chernobyl accident. In the meantime, however, they have been reviewed several times by scientific experts. In the interests of the highest level of protection of the EU population, the Commission has proposed a recast of the existing legislation, firstly, to consolidate the existing regulations, secondly, to adopt the new system of comitology procedures in order to ensure that the maximum levels are set in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon and, thirdly, to introduce more flexible procedures that allow targeted responses to all nuclear accidents or radiological emergencies. The Mranz Garcia report lists constructive changes aimed at greater flexibility if, in the interests of targeted responses to nuclear accidents, lower than those set out in the annexed regulation must be applied.  In the light of the experience gained in connection with the Fukushima accident, this aspect was raised and discussed during the negotiations in the Council. Apart from that, the Commission also believes that the proposal must clarify the relationship between the proposed Euratom Regulation and the existing food safety legislation on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The Commission can support some aspects, but not all, of the amendments. Firstly, we cannot support the change in the legal basis proposed here. The Commission's proposal is based on the Euratom Treaty as a Lex specialis. The Euratom Treaty is the legal basis for all acts to be repealed by the proposed regulation. The Court of Justice of the European Union recently delivered its judgment on the Drinking Water Directive and confirmed our legal view that Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty is the correct and only legal basis. Another legal basis – in particular the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Treaty basis there – instead of the Euratom Treaty, is not acceptable to us. The request that there be a report to the European Parliament on the review of the maximum levels of radioactivity in order to take due account of the current scientific progress achieved worldwide must be answered as follows: this review of the basic standards is indeed a common practice. Once the international panel of scientific experts – the International Commission on Radiation Protection ICRP – has presented a new list of dose coefficients for ingestion, in three to five years, for example, the Commission will ask the expert group for its opinion on the validity of the current maximum levels and, on the basis of this opinion, will decide whether to revise the Regulation. We are happy to come back to that. With regard to the proposal to include tritium and C14 in the list of radionuclides, the expert group has already stated that the maximum values for this nuclide may be ten times higher than for cesium 137, for example. Furthermore, taking into account such a type of contamination does not normally make any practical sense. However, if an event were to occur, for example with tritium in a fusion reactor, it would set maximum values by the Commission on an ad hoc basis by implementing regulation in accordance with the comitology procedure. We will also pay attention to this. Your report says that the maximum levels should be set in such a way as to protect the most vulnerable groups of the population – children, people working in agriculture.  I would like to point out that the Commission's proposal specifically provides for maximum values for children. However, we believe that the maximum levels of radioactivity for the population in the EU as a whole should be set.  It would make little sense to regulate the food market in the EU on the basis of the situation of a minority of people who, for example, farm subsistence farming. For these categories of people, the Commission may, on the basis of current legislation, adopt specific recommendations addressed to the Member States concerned, as has already been done after the Chernobyl accident – at that time for people who wished to eat large quantities of wild mushrooms and berries or game in certain regions particularly affected by persistent contamination with radioactive cesium.  Overall, we thank you for your expert report. He supports our work and we are happy to continue with the appropriate steps.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we have heard from your speech a firm defence of the Commission's position and proposal on the legal basis. In this Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, too, the subject has been the subject of extensive in-depth study and debate. there was no clear vision and we will certainly hear the relevant positions from the other political groups as well. However, the prevailing position has been that, as the European Commission has also envisaged in its texts, a possible revision of the legal basis, a new legal basis that takes account of the fact that, with codecision, food issues, such as the one we are talking about, are obviously the subject of the ordinary legislative procedure and therefore subject to codecision with the full involvement of Parliament. Without prejudice, therefore, to the diversity of position, which will then be the subject of negotiations in the future and after the vote, regardless of the outcome of the vote in this House today, I wanted to return to the issue of the level of radioactivity provided for in the annexes. This too has been the subject of extensive discussion between the political groups, with different positions on certain issues, but I particularly wanted to point out that the final vote in the ENVI Committee was based on a sound precautionary principle, because, as provided for in the values indicated by the FAO, as provided for in the values of the World Health Organisation, we have adhered to values that are one tenth of the maximum values tolerated. We have therefore kept to much lower values, precisely because the precautionary principle is a sound principle that we in Europe want to continue to apply.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is extremely important to support the change of legal base to give Parliament the power of co—decision and a say in ensuring a high level of protection for the health of EU citizens. The European Parliament is being consistent in its support for a change in the legal base from Euratom to the TFEU. It has done so on previous occasions on previous files concerning the threats to public health from radioactive material. We now have a good report asking the Commission to review the maximum levels and to allow for the adoption of implementing acts for swift action in emergency situations. We also call for consultation with independent experts when the maximum levels need to be reviewed. The annexes laying down maximum levels, as well as the radioactive substances concerned, will be reviewed as and when new scientific data become available. Therefore, I would like to ask for your support with a positive vote later today.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I find myself in a position where it has never been easier to make a one-minute speech in this Chamber, because I absolutely agreed with the Commission’s proposal and felt that it really was not necessary for us to make much of a change. My group believes in better regulation, and that means we do not believe in over—regulation. We believe that the Commission proposal is correctly based on the legal basis of Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty. I think Parliament’s proposed amendments are inconsistent with the principle of keeping Euratom as a separate organisation responsible for the functioning of the nuclear energy sector. Among the shadows during the discussions, I heard nothing to convince me that the safety of citizens would be improved by the involvement of Parliament in detailed scrutiny, substance by substance. Indeed, during much of the debate and particularly in the detail of many of the recitals which were decided upon, it became absolutely clear to me that many of my colleagues were motivated by a philosophical belief in the danger of nuclear energy, as opposed to any particular regard to this proposal. So my group’s position is – and will remain – that the legal basis is correct and that we support the Commission’s proposal as put forward.

name: Marit Paulsen
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for After 16 years in Parliament, I have to say that the tendency is palpable for us to try to make political, emotional decisions rather than stick to scientific accuracy when it comes to details. It goes without saying when it comes to guidelines, objectives and organisations, because guidelines are our responsibility and our political decisions. But when we come to physical exact details such as the level of radioactive content, the levels in food and feed, in this case, then it is clear that it is experts with scientific backgrounds who have to make decisions that are proof-based. They're the ones who have to make the detailed decisions. So we will vote for a great deal, but we do not want to agree to the change in the law. I know there is a majority in ENVI in favour of this, but there is a clear majority in the AGRI Committee in favour of maintaining Euratom as a legal basis, and the European Court of Justice has also taken a decision on drinking water, so we and the ALDE Group will vote against the change in the law.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I firmly believe that, if necessary, the legal basis should be able to be changed, i.e. I believe that the European Union should have up-to-date legal instruments incorporating much more agile and more adaptive decision-making procedures. Only in this way can we act so that in the territory of the Union, for example in the obsolete nuclear power plant in Garoña, very close to my country, there will be no situations such as those experienced after the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents. As shadow rapporteur and in order to promote legislation, in our view, more appropriate and up-to-date we contacted a number of experts in this field, experts who quickly stressed that the levels and guarantees proposed in the food security report were not sufficient. Hence the proposed amendments, in line with the Codex Alimentarius, revised in 2013, and where specific criteria for radionuclides in food are proposed, criteria that are more restrictive and that propose to change the levels established in case of emergency. It is also proposed that other radioactive isotopes which are not included in Annex I be included. However, these proposals were left out, because it was not accepted that the maximum levels of radioactive contamination allowed were questioned. At the meeting with the shadow rapporteurs, it was agreed to hold a meeting with experts, but that meeting never came. We understand that without the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, together with other forces in this House, the safety of the European population in the event of a nuclear accident will not be sufficiently guaranteed. That is where we encourage this House to support these amendments.

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, I welcome this debate, because normally it should not take place, and the environmentalists have insisted that it take place.  I believe that the problem is not that of a pro or anti-nuclear positioning, but that tomorrow a nuclear accident can happen in Europe or elsewhere and that we must protect the population. I would like to go back to the terms of the report. I think he was sloppy. What for? Because there was only one meeting of the shadow rapporteurs. As my colleague said, there must have been one with the Experts at Euratom, but it was cancelled because these experts were not available. You must also know one thing: when we asked the Commission for the names of the experts and their links of interest, it refused to give them to us. This is the first time this has happened! In all health agencies, we have the names of the experts. And then we're told, "Ah, but these great experts are going to set the standards for food contamination." However, when we had this file assessed - the report of these famous invisible experts - we realized that it contained at least fifteen errors! This document indicates that in the event of a nuclear accident, only 10% of food will be contaminated. I live near a nuclear power plant in the most nuclear-armed country in Europe. If there is an accident, all food (water, milk, etc.) will be contaminated. When I did the dose calculation, I found that we would be well over the one-millisievert ceiling announced by the rapporteur. We, as MEPs, have a responsibility to bear. We cannot accept the proposed standards. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to vote for Article 56, which will lower the standards by a factor of 10. Thus, the population will be truly protected in the event of a nuclear accident, which can occur today as well as tomorrow in Europe.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we too have supported the proposal to change the legal basis, which gives Parliament more power in the codecision phase. We are therefore in favour of this amendment, a point which we believe is crucial for us to support the report, but together with the amendment we have requested and aimed at reducing the permissible limits set out in the table in the report and also supported by the rapporteur. This is because, while it is true that it is the experts who must give us these indications, it is also true that the experts are also based on assumptions and those adopted in the report on radiation protection 105 of the ICRP Committee are assumptions based on the Chernobyl accident, an event that has taken place very far from the borders of our Europe and which instead must be reshaped in order to apply them to what is our reality. , to the possible accident within our territory, as Mrs Rivasi said. The possible doses of radiation accumulation have not been taken into account either, nor are separate particles in the table which can be released in a possible accident. This is indeed a risk element which has not been taken into account and which is very important. That is why we wish to support this measure only if a table with the limits reduced by up to 10% passes.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this report on the limits of radioactivity in food and feed is not acceptable as it stands. The proposed levels of radioactivity are identical to those of 1987, after the Chernobyl disaster. The limits proposed by the Commission are calculated for an accident occurring more than 1,000 kilometres from Europe's borders. This assumption allowed experts to bet on a low contamination rate: 10%. However, this rate would be much higher if the accident occurred in the very heart of Europe. The protection of populations is therefore not assured. This protection is even paltry when compared to that applied in Japan. In this country, the limits of radioactivity in food are 8 to 20 times lower than ours. It is this example that we must follow in order to better protect our people. After all, if you want to increase your powers, you have to accept the duties that go with it. For our part, there are only two possible options. Either the European institutions set standards that really ensure our food security, like Japan, or they refuse to do so and, in this case, the Member States must be able to do so for them, under Article 36 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. That is the meaning of the amendments that our group has tabled.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, I would like to thank commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has As you have already mentioned, there are a number of problems in history that we remember very well, be it the Chernobyl disaster or, more recently, the Fukushima nuclear power plant disaster. For years and decades, these effects of radiation have been felt, and these effects have very much an impact on human health and on our environment. To date, the European Parliament has only cooperated in setting the limit values for radioactively contaminated food and feed through a consultation procedure. The report proposed by my colleague, Mrs Esther Herranz Garcia, would change this legal basis. I would really support that. The maximum levels of radioactivity would thus be set within the framework of a proper legislative procedure, that is to say, also with the cooperation of Parliament, the Council and the Commission. It is really our first task as a chamber of citizens to take care of the interests of European citizens. We in our committee do the same on a daily basis. Highest quality should be guaranteed. Accordingly, I think it is really logical that we should have a say in tried and tested cooperation on this issue, which I believe we all agree on again – with the experts from the Commission and also from Euratom. Only in this way can we ensure that the strictest maximum levels are set and that the necessary controls are carried out for imports from the regions concerned. In the field of food safety in particular, we cannot afford to take even the slightest risk. I would really ask colleagues to vote in favour of changing the legal basis. I do not believe that nuclear power stations, nuclear power stations and other and the associated dangers are a philosophical debate. I believe that the only means we should consider the next reactor accident is a complete phase-out of nuclear energy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the European Union must have at its disposal up-to-date legal instruments, which contain flexible and appropriate decision-making procedures to deal with emergency situations, such as those experienced after the Chernobyl or Fukushima accidents. I believe that the use of implementing acts to respond to nuclear accidents and other types of radioactive emergency is the most appropriate way of acting immediately and quickly. With regard to the maximum permissible levels of radioactivity for foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or in cases of radiological emergency, I believe that, although the European Union currently has an adequate level of radioactive protection in food, these levels are well below those acceptable at international level. , you have to go a little further, further reducing the limits. Parliament must be given the right of codecision to change these limits if they need to be examined in the light of new scientific knowledge. The risks of nuclear accidents and the consequent risk of food contamination must lead us to step up the monitoring of maximum permissible levels of radioactivity, in order to better protect the health of European consumers.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the risks of nuclear energy, which, in addition to not being renewable, pass on the problem of waste to the next generations, are in the eyes of society as a whole. The issue of nuclear security cannot be addressed in isolation by each country, as if the effects of a nuclear catastrophe were stopped at the border of each State. Therefore, strict common rules are needed, based on rigorous scientific criteria, that allow us to know whether or not plants, animals or feed from countries where radioactive leaks have occurred are a threat to our health. We must also increase transparency in relation to nuclear energy production in the European Union, especially in cases of accidents, as the population has the right to be duly informed by the authorities of the risks and dangers they are taking. Therefore, while our choice will always be to defend the development of renewable energy, we will support with our vote all the amendments that go in the sense of increasing security standards and democratic control of nuclear energy in the European Union.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The report refers to the Commission's 2013 proposal number 9/43. As a nuclear physicist, I have been involved several times in the approval procedures of nuclear installations. So I know from my own experience what I am talking about. According to this report, 626 becquerels of radioactivity may be present in the infant formula after a nuclear accident. By comparison, before Chernobyl, milk had to be thrown away for adults if it contained more than 500 becquerels. Now you seem to be baby 626 Becquerel. Ladies and gentlemen, this report is an incitement to murder. Such figures are not necessary for the nutrition of infants. The diet can be ensured in a completely different way. I stand by this: the Commission's proposal with these values is a scandal!

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, nuclear fission energy is a very risky way of obtaining energy. In the last thirty years, we have witnessed two of the biggest nuclear disasters, those in Chernobyl and Fukushima, and we have been aware of other, perhaps publicly known, nuclear accidents. What we know from both of these accidents is this: each nuclear power plant has one weak point that is inherent in all technological advances of the nuclear reactor from the beginning of the nuclear era to the present day, and it is a continuous cooling of the primary circuit. The effects of a nuclear disaster have been felt in a wide area for years and centuries.  I welcome this report as an expression of awareness of the necessity of prescribing appropriate measures in cases of nuclear accidents, as well as the rapporteur's position that Parliament should be given the power to decide on food and feed. Experts should be left to determine the maximum level of radioactive contamination of food and feed that can be placed on the European Union market after a nuclear accident or any other radiological hazard.  I want to use this address to publicly call for an end to the nuclear programme in the European Union. Accidents occur due to a lack of accountability of both plant workers, plant management companies and governments and states that ignore risks and put themselves and the neighborhood at unnecessary risk. I welcome the decisions of all states that want to end their nuclear programmes in due course, and I urge those that have not yet been invited to do so as soon as possible.   (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, dear colleague, you have spoken of the experts who must develop contamination standards in the event of an accident. An association asked the Commission for the names of the experts in the Euratom Treaty. Do you think it is normal that, on the one hand, these experts refused to come to the European Parliament to discuss their scenarios and, on the other hand, we do not have access to the list of their names? Do you think that is normal? You say that the experts should be trusted, but if these experts are paid by nuclear, what confidence can we give them? I would like your opinion on that.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleagues, I have asked parliament to engage in co-decision in decision-making, but these decisions must be based on the data that will be provided by the profession, because we come here in the European Parliament from different professions and will ultimately make a political decision. I agree with you that experts must be available to us parliamentarians, that they must give us all the relevant information and that in the end the final decision always falls on policy, and I want as a politician who is a member of this Parliament also to have the opportunity to decide, which we have not had before. That's why I support the reporter's position.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, this report is of crucial importance in ensuring food safety in the event of a nuclear accident or radioactive emergency. I would like to stress the fact that the maximum levels of food contamination shown in the annexes to this proposal for a Regulation are not the limits that must be applied automatically in the event of an accident, as they seem to imply the messages we have received — all orchestrated and managed by a single NGO — but must be modulated according to the extent of the accident , since the Commission must adjust the reference levels to the actual pollution conditions through the implementation costs provided for in this proposal for a Regulation. I think it is important that we all keep in mind that these reference levels have been set by the recommendations of the Euratom expert group, which I deserve all due respect, even if I do not know their name or face. In addition, its recommendations follow the advice provided by the International Commission on Radiological Protection, which is the highest scientific authority worldwide, made up of non-governmental and independent experts. I think it is important to recall this in order to counter alarmist messages and I also think it is important to stress that the reference levels set out in the proposal for a Regulation have been established in accordance with the same assumptions as those set by Codex Alimentarius and that these levels are ten times lower than those advocated by the International Atomic Energy Agency for international trade. And finally, as this is an issue concerning food security, I also think, like the rapporteur, that this Parliament must have co-decision power. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I wanted to say to my colleague that these levels are precisely defined to be extremely effective in the event of a nuclear accident. We will not have time to set other levels. They must ensure people's health in the event of radioactive contamination. They are far too high, contrary to what you say.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Madam President, I trust the experts. I've worked in scientific research and I know how they work and how they work. They deserve all due respect to me. But here in this Parliament, there is a tremendous tendency that, if we do not like one thing, we question the expert and question his independence, and here the European Food Safety Authority, euratom experts and all kinds of experts are questioned. And I don't question them.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! As the discussion shows, we are actually debating two issues today. The first is acceptable levels of radioactive contamination – in this respect, I consider it reasonable to accept standards set by experts on the assumption that they can be amended if necessary. A separate issue, on the other hand, is the question of the legal basis for food safety in the European Union – here I also agree with some of the speeches.  It should be noted that the European Parliament has already been given the right of codecision on food and feed under the Maastricht Treaty. I am therefore of the opinion that, on these important issues, we should be fully involved as an equal partner and not as an advisory body to the Commission or the Council. I am also pleased that the European Commission recognises this need and seems open to changes to the legal basis used. Food safety issues introduced within the European Union concern the health of our citizens. Let us remember this and give priority to this issue in all future discussions on legislative changes.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I must appreciate the fact that today we are discussing something so important, because this report is, in fact, about people's lives. I believe that the maximum permitted level of radioactive contamination of food and feed is extremely important for the future of the world, after all.  Of course I also support, as has been discussed here, that the European Parliament should have co-decision, and I support working with experts. But I find it strange to find out here in Parliament that we cannot know who the experts are! I very much believe that transparency in terms of, if you will, the curriculum vitae, the work of experts, gives confidence to Parliament, gives us confidence to those who need to analyse and vote informedly. I don't think it's normal for these experts not to be known.  I also believe that it is very important that the debate up to us in the European Parliament is made public in each of the Member States. There are countries that are more affected, due to the development of danger, so to speak, in that country. I believe that, as Parliament, we must also take into account how we develop – because, behold, we have a project of energy union – how we are developing the other areas so that we do not get to situations of accidents that contaminate food and feed.  In principle I agree with the report, but with the exception of this: experts. We need to know them and know their work!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, it is important that the European Union has legal means to deal quickly with accidents that can happen with nuclear weapons, as happened in Chernobyl or Fukushima. But the question is who will take the decisions, and I think that the role of the European Parliament in this regard must be important and decisive.  Secondly, the proposal brought here by the Commission raises many concerns. It is based on a report 1998 which takes account of a fact that we will have a possible accident a thousand kilometres away from the centre of the European Union. But here, around Strasbourg and around Brussels, there are too many nuclear power plants. What happens if we have an accident? What if we have an accident in Koslonduy? What if we have an accident at the new factory, which they want to do in Turkey, on the border with Greece? Therefore, the terms and conditions that you take into account are incorrect. The boundaries must go too low. The limits you set are too high and have nothing to do with reality. The fact that you set the limits and say that only 10% of food and 1% of drinking water will be affected is wrong.  Change these limits down.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin this speech with an issue which we often forget. And you don't play with food. We know that it is indispensable in our day to day and decisive for our health. We also know that radioactive materials are carcinogenic and mutagenic substances and that there is no particular safety threshold. That's why we should work towards zero tolerances. And I would like to remind Mrs Ayuso here that, as far as scientists are, everyone knows very well about the revolving doors. I would also like to say that the maximum permissible levels introduced in this report are in question because they pose unacceptable levels of risk. The Independent Committee on Research and Information on Radioactivity reports that the Euratom opinion detects serious anomalies that underestimate dose and risk levels. I therefore ask the Commission to do serious and responsible work to place our right to health and a meal that does not make us sick above the interests of any business.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is critically important to have legal instruments that include flexible incident—specific decision—making procedures to address situations like those that occurred in the wake of the accidents at Chernobyl and Fukushima. I welcome the inclusion in the report of the reference to the need for consultation with independent experts when reviewing maximum levels. Moreover, full information must be made immediately available to the general public. Food safety is the ultimate objective of the Council Regulation. Therefore, I strongly support the change of legal base under the Lisbon Treaty. It is appropriate to give the European Parliament an appropriate say in the protection of public health in line with its co-legislative role.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been You mentioned that the experts who work here and who have been appointed by the Member States on the basis of the Euratom Treaty should be published. However, this is not provided for under the Treaty, the primary law. That is why we do not currently have the opportunity to publish these names without or against their will. Sorry, I am sticking to the law. Secondly, I myself have been a Member of a Parliament in my own country of Baden-Württemberg for more than 25 years. A strong Parliament is important to me. That is why I take the debate seriously today and I will report on it to my colleague Arias Caete. We will also incorporate these proposals and these critical approaches. However, our primary law creates a clear order of competence. The decision on the technology of energy is a matter for the Member States. The decision on nuclear energy yes or no was and is a matter for our Member States. France has therefore decided to use more than 70% nuclear energy and, contrary to what its President has said, none is currently being shut down, even though this was announced for Fessenheim, for example, and the share of nuclear energy is not now being reduced, even though the reduction to 50% has been announced. Fourteen Member States have no nuclear power, 14 have nuclear power. We – The Commission, also Parliament – have to respect this, because the decision under our contract law is a matter for the Member States. According to the Euratom Treaty, which is clearly responsible for this as a Lex specialis, this also applies to today's debate, to our Commission proposal today. You are involved in this, your co-advice and participation is planned. Unfortunately, codecision is not possible. I believe that, with all our interest in the matter and also of all understanding and emotion, we should not bend paragraphs, articles and treaties, but should endeavour to amend the Treaties, but on the basis of these Treaties we should accept that Parliament is called upon to participate here and not to codecision. I can accept one final point concerning Mr Buchner: I can accept scandal. For me, this is part of a sporting debate culture. What I do not accept, even if it was performed in a charming Bavarian dialect, is to speak here of incitement to murder. I reject this in all its forms. I am not prepared to accept that I should be an instigator of murder. I consider these accusations to be untenable and impossible.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Deputy Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you first of all for the opportunity of this debate because it has enabled us, here, to discuss publicly an issue that is extremely sensitive for European citizens. We have spoken and discussed a subject which concerns the safety of the future in terms of food in the event of a nuclear accident. It is clear that the prevailing position in committee has been to change the legal basis, which means, Commissioner, a review of the route, because we are talking here about food safety, we are not talking about issues relating to atomic energy. The view of this Parliament is therefore linked to the fact that the subject of the regulatory proposal is an issue in which the characteristic feature is the characteristic of food for food or animal feed. So it is clear that, from our point of view, the issue is different. I would also like to thank all my fellow Members for the debate that has taken place, during which different positions have emerged, but I would like to stress one thing to those who have raised concerns about radioactivity levels: it is clear that the one formulated is a proposal on hypothetical grounds. It goes without saying that what we need to define precisely is the path to be taken, if necessary, to change them, in conjunction with the Commission, because it is obvious that there could be nuclear accidents next to the front door, much further away and, of course, the levels of radioactive contaminants should be different depending on the conditions of the accident. We must therefore define a path and that path must be applied with the participation of this Parliament.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 9 May 2008. Adopted on 17 July 2015.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Julia Reda, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the harmonisation of certain features of copyright and related rights in the information society on 22 March. The Commission adopted a proposal for a Directive on the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2001 (A8-0209/2015).

name: Julia Reda
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, there are two ways to look at this copyright evaluation report. On the one hand, it is a great step forward. It recognises that users of copyrighted works have rights – a foreign concept to the current Copyright Directive. According to the Directive, rights holders have rights and users have exceptions to those rights. These exceptions are optional to the Member States. They can simply be disabled by a contract or by technological restrictions. Circumventing those restrictions is illegal, even for legitimate purposes. So it is illegal to make a book that has a technological lock available to a blind person, but the terms of service that simply erase an exception to copyright are completely legal. The Copyright Directive, so far, protects digital locks more than it protects the people. This report calls for a clear set of European consumers’ rights. It states that copyright exceptions must not be overridden by a contract, and that you cannot charge a levy for private copying on the one hand, but then, on the other hand, use technology that makes private copying impossible. This report calls for interoperability and cross-border access, so you should be able to buy and to use works on any device or in any country. It sides with the right to education and with allowing libraries, museums and archives to do their jobs in the digital world and to make our shared cultural heritage accessible to anybody, regardless of their social status. But, at the same time, this report is also a tragically-missed opportunity. Just a year ago, thousands of Europeans participated in a public consultation on copyright, and they expressed how they come into daily conflict with a law that is unfit for the digital age. Then Commissioner Kroes recognised that copyright must be radically reformed so that it would not become irrelevant. President Juncker announced his goal to tear down national silos in copyright, and Commissioner Ansip boldly took on geo-blocking. The message was clear: now is the time to act decisively. Not from this Parliament. Parliament recognises, in the report, that 28 different copyright laws are too complicated, but still it considers our cultures to be so different that we cannot possibly agree on simple things like the fact that drawing a caricature should not require permission, a rights holder should not forbid a journalist from quoting a work in order to criticise it, or public pictures of public space should remain royalty—free. This Parliament is at its best when it is the voice of the people. It has rejected the ACTA Treaty because the people we represent embrace the internet as an integral part of their reality. With copyright, you have seen tens of thousands of your young people on the streets opposing ACTA and holding signs saying ‘this video is not available in your country’. You have had thousands of responses to the consultation on copyright asking for more Europe in copyright law. You have had half a million petitioners demanding freedom of panorama. Now you have the chance to take up this call and to update copyright law to the digital age. Personally, I wonder if this report, as it stands, is really the best that we can do if this is what European leadership looks like. I also hope that you, my colleagues, will wonder why people considered it necessary to form a party that is solely based on reforming copyright, to give it the ridiculous name of the Pirate Party and to elect me here to the European Parliament to tell you that copyright reform is urgently needed. I am hoping that, when the reform from the Commission comes, my colleagues will be bolder in demanding European copyright and common rules for everybody. I also hope that we can make sure that Parliament is not just following the Commission proposal but is also a decisive player in making sure that copyright is fit for the digital age and understandable to ordinary people.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Yes, the Commission has formulated a priority, namely to adapt copyright at European level to the digital age, in other words to modernise it and harmonise it and to create as much European rules as possible for consumers, for authors in the European digital single market. I would like to thank Mr Reda, but also many colleagues here in Parliament, for an intensive discussion of this in retrospect, but also with outlook. We will include your report in the next final steps in drawing up a legislative proposal from the Commission. Ladies and gentlemen! There are several objectives at stake here. It is a question of taking up digital technologies and, building on this, reviewing and modernising our existing copyright package at European level. Secondly, it is a question of a fair balance, some of which is based on different interests. We see the interest expressed by Mrs Reda in our information society, our citizens, our users, our consumers – on the one hand. That is why we want access to content to be maintained or created as far as possible across borders. A European market without national territorial borders must be the principle and portability – the right to take away without borders – in parallel. On the other hand, we are strongly called upon to stabilise Europe's creative industries and their entrepreneurial career prospects. I am not saying to preserve, but to restabilise. It is about our cultural heritage, but also about our cultural future. If you take authors, screenwriters, writers, film directors, journalists who research and comment, composers, musicians and singers as examples as representatives of our cultural heritage, but also of our creative industries, who have the future, then if one then takes between the user in the information society and the author still publishers, transporters, formaturtes, distributors of corresponding content, then the balance is not easy to find. However, this is our aim, and our legislative proposal will serve this purpose. The principle is: no borders within Europe, as much internal market as meaningful and possible. But principles do not exclude exceptions and/or transitional periods. If we take European film, Europe's film industry would only have an internal market and the principle of territoriality would be gone overnight, not viable. European film, which has been strongly promoted in recent decades, with outstanding roots in France, Italy, but also in new Member States, is built on our linguistic areas and built on the national film funding it calls for. And if it were exposed to a European market overnight, Hollywood, Bollywood, Google, and Amazon would sweep away this European film. This cannot be in the interests of our often cultural European society.
