That is why we will be making proposals on how, knowing the objective of the internal market, by creating portability, we can nevertheless enshrine territoriality in our proposal. I could mention a second exception: the sports sector. Both football and sports such as basketball, volleyball, tennis and others are also built on territoriality in their business model. This cannot be changed, at least overnight, perhaps in transition, and developed. But in one fell swoop, the implementation of the principle would certainly be a blow to our sports federations and our athletes in the European Union. Principles and exceptions will be the guiding principle of our proposal. The key word is exceptions in the opposite sense: if education, research and science are taken seriously, we will also have to create opportunities for access, unlimited or even free access to content in the digital world. Here we are still examining whether research carried out under public law, or industrial research, should be covered by this exemption of free access at no cost. In recent weeks, freedom of panorama has played a major role. There is certainly an objective interest behind this, but also a bit of marketing. Allow me to make a clear statement: the Commission does not intend to restrict freedom of panorama. For me, the following principle applies: what one can see with one's eye as a citizen in public places and streets in Europe should also be allowed to be photographed with the camera. I make no distinction between the eye and the storage of the eye by camera and pictures. That is why some of the excitement here was unnecessary, at least as far as the Commission is concerned. We do not encint: on this issue, some proposals from Parliament and the Technical Committee. We believe that the existing basis that a free Europe should also be given free electronic photographs of European cities, buildings and monuments must not be restricted. We will continue to make use of this principle in the future. That is why I want to give a warning here, at least as far as the Commission is concerned. There are no plans for any restriction on our part.

name: José Blanco López
text: Drafts member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, during the very hardest part of the crisis, European cultural industries have continued to create jobs.  That speaks of his vitality and his strength. And at the core of that strength are the authors, who are the engines of the cultural industry and who are the drivers of culture, and copyright are also the ones who have to guarantee remuneration for that work crucial to our diversity and to our cultural wealth.  We all want to develop cultural industries in the new digital environment, harness their potential to generate new jobs, drive innovative industries. But let no one consider the copyright reform announced to us by the Commissioner as a confrontation between authors and users, in which some must lose for others to win. Protecting authors is protecting everyone, because it is protecting cultural creation, it is protecting content. If we don't, we'll all lose. Europe needs, it has already been said, to revise its legislation, but to strengthen its cultural industries, not to weaken them. Content is, in my view, the new black gold of the internet, and what Europe has to do is precisely strengthen that role, strengthen the content, strengthen our leadership.

name: Catherine Stihler
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, shadows, and also to the Committee secretariats for all the work on this dossier. I know it has not been an easy task, but I think we have a good compromise in front of us. I thank the rapporteur and others for taking on so much from the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO). I think Commissioner Oettinger is right about the balance that we need to strike between the new digital world that we exist within and the rights of the creators of content. This is the challenge if we want to make our digital single market work effectively. So the challenge is there, and we will meet it. The key points I wanted to raise are on e-book access, the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty, and text and data mining. There are still too many barriers to libraries being able to provide books in electronic format, and I hope that we will see concrete proposals from the Commission later this year to try to address some of these problematic issues. Publishers and libraries have been working together to seek solutions, and these discussions must continue. Leading on from this, the ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty is no further forward than when we last discussed this in this House. The book famine, which visually impaired and blind people still face, is a clear breach of human rights. Let us remind ourselves that less than 5% of the books published in Europe are available in a format that is accessible. I urge Member States to take action and ratify this treaty. Finally, on text and data mining, which the Commissioner just touched upon in his speech: currently in the UK, as you know, we have got an exemption for non-commercial purposes under the current rules. The impact this is having on research is phenomenal. What would have taken years can now literally take hours, and for scientific discoveries and historical analysis the benefits are endless. I hope that we will see a new exemption for text and data mining at EU level and an assessment about the extension of this for commercial purposes too.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture, Youth, the Media and Sport. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report and all the shadow rapporteurs from the Committee on Culture. I regret that the Commission has not been able to present its opinion and therefore the text lacks and will miss the point of view of this important committee. I also proposed resubmit the compromise agreements that were reached at the last meeting of the shadow rapporteurs, and I have to say that I was also reprimanded for my initiative. I hope that this will not happen again in the future and that the Committee on Culture will be able to make its voice heard loud and clear, better if as an associated committee and not just with a simple opinion.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia
text: f’isem il-grupp PPE. – Sinjura President, ir-rikkezza Ewropea fid-diversità kulturali u lingwistika tagħti dinamika differenti lis-settur Ewropew kreattiv. Din id-diversità hija opportunità biex is-suq uniku diġitali joffri kontenut kreattiv esklużiv. Dan jista’ jintleħaq tramite bilanċ ġust bejn id-drittijiet u t-tneħħija tal-ostakli għat-tgawdija ta’ kontenut ġa eżistenti u l-ħolqien ta’ kontenut ġdid. The report being presented today reflects the balance necessary for end users to benefit from enhanced access to creative content, as well as this Parliament’s role in continuing to foster investment in the sector, encourage employment and job creation and give the industry an opportunity to embrace digital technologies. With these aims in mind, I have considered challenges experienced by users, as well as by creators and other rights holders. Together with other shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur, whom I thank for their efforts, I worked to ensure that opportunities in the creative sector are not lost to the creators or to the users. This report seeks to make copyright work in both the analogue as well as the digital world by giving users and creators the full possibility of drawing on the potential of both these worlds. It emphasises the importance of portability of content across borders, further remuneration for creators, respect for contractual freedom, market—driven solutions that reflect the ever—changing expectations of users, and the provision of solutions which are evidence-based. With this report, Parliament continues to show its belief in creators, as well as its aspirations to continue to make avenues available to make European cultural and creative works more accessible, by seizing the opportunities that the digital age provides. I look forward to a favourable vote on this report. I also thank the Commissioner for indicating that Parliament and the Commission seem to be following the same principles, and I look forward to the Commissioner’s proposals.

name: Mary Honeyball
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, my thanks to the rapporteur and to everybody who worked on this report. Ms Reda’s report, as we all know, reviewed the 2001 Information Society Directive and as such, or perhaps not as such, it has achieved some notoriety. For an own-initiative report of this kind it has certainly received more attention than perhaps we would have expected. But the report, as a result of that, is both wide-ranging and forward-looking. We had lengthy negotiations amongst all the political groups in the Committee on Legal Affairs, and I believe – and I think my colleagues also believe – that we did eventually achieve a fair balance between the competing interest groups – between consumers and creators. And it is not either consumers or creators: both need to be taken into consideration and both need to be in the reforms that eventually come forward for copyright. But my focus, and I believe the focus of the Socialist and Democrat Group, has always been on creators – to give creators fair remuneration, to make sure that they are adequately paid. Because if they are not, we will not have music as we know it, we will not have much in the way of television and radio, and we will have very few new books. This is really a matter for our culture across the European Union, and we need to see it in that light. That is why I welcome very much what the Commissioner said earlier. I do not believe, as Ms Reda said, that we have missed an opportunity. I think what this report, as amended by the committee, does is to put forward constructive proposals which I very much hope the Commission will take on board. And although, of course, we would eventually like to see pan-European laws, at the moment we simply have to take account of Member States’ cultural diversity and we too must ensure that diversity is carried out. One final word on freedom of panorama. I urge you all to vote to delete the whole of paragraph 46 tomorrow because if we do that, with one press of our button in the European Parliament, it will mean that photographers across Europe can safely continue to press their buttons.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, honourable Representatives of the Commission, honourable Members, as shadow rapporteur, let me speak on my colleague's report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. I would like to thank the colleagues with whom we have worked continuously and stubbornly to achieve one, in my view, a well-balanced report. This fragile balance, the result of protracted talks and controversies on many topics that we have managed to achieve, is the result of long and difficult negotiations, and I hope that during today's vote we will be able to keep what we have achieved so far. It is important to highlight the existing sensitive topics and send the right message to the European Commission. I am convinced that the report will serve as a good basis for the Commission ahead of an upcoming revision of the existing legal framework in the area of copyright and related rights, which is expected by the end of this year. We need to make sure that the revision and modernisation of the legislation existing today will strike the right balance between the interests of consumers in the Member States of the European Union, but will also protect the rights and legitimate interests of creators and rightholders.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, this highly commented report is the result of the collective work of almost all the political groups in this Parliament, which has enabled it to be adopted in the Legal Committee by 23 votes to 25, including that of the rapporteur, which is not nothing. I am therefore in line with what Ms Comodini and Mrs Honeyball have said, among others, which I thank publicly.  The result is satisfactory and the text is balanced. This report, which will be voted on today, is a far cry from the original text, which would have had the effect of reducing copyright without actually defending the consumer. What is a consumer defence in which the diversity of cultures in the 28 member countries would not have real legal protection to last? I support all the interesting avenues that raise the future of copyright and I consider that we are going back quite far, because the level of protection of creators necessary for innovation and especially for the powerful European cultural industry has been maintained. I am therefore pleased that the influence of economic competitiveness, on the one hand, and the singularity of cultural Europe, on the other, have been recognised and even clearly protected.  I am pleased that this report has also taken a first step towards the accountability of hosts, a sensitive subject, because these platforms cannot continue to tell us that they are just motorways. Their responsibility is increasingly high. We can see it now with another area, which is cultural freedom, security to be protected, and even the fight against financial crime. It is time for the Commission and our Parliament to look at what I call the three responsibilities rule, which will be discussed, Commissioner, when you return in December. I would also like to take this opportunity to invite all colleagues to vote against Amendment No 3. I should point out, as Mrs Honeyball and Mrs Comodini said, that I naturally agreed, at the rapporteur's request, to vote against paragraph 46, which was the result of an amendment which I myself had tabled. I emphasize the consensual nature of this document and thank you very much for all participating in it.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to join in the thanks to the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs who have been involved in this drawn-up report through demanding and quality work. Since the adoption of the Information Society Directive in 2001, technology development, digitisation and the development of social networks have been constantly taking place. We can conclude that technology is ahead of the law. Personally, however, I have convinced myself that it is very difficult, if not impossible, to find a consensus on how to respond. This is due to the long-term existence of cultural and legal traditions in the copyright of individual Member States. Today we are evaluating the implementation of the Information Society Directive. The rapporteur originally came up with an ambitious proposal for greater harmonisation. However, our faction is concerned that such proposals would favour solutions based on the functioning of the invisible hand of the market and would bring additional benefits to large companies such as Google. After several months of intensive work, as shadow rapporteur for our faction, I have come to the conclusion that we are not yet ready to create a truly unified European copyright law to replace national copyright in the Member States. This is perhaps best evidenced by the heated debate on the so-called freedom of panorama, which is regulated differently in different Member States. Finally, after complex negotiations, we managed to formulate a compromise proposal across the political spectrum, which represents a balanced adjustment between the protection of authors and their remuneration, as well as the protection of users and citizens' rights.

name: Max Andersson
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, my first computer had 3 583 bytes free – not kilobytes, bytes. The world has changed a lot since then. Culture has changed. But copyright is still basically in the old paradigm. The computer I have in my hand has a memory that is two-and-a-half million times larger than my first computer, but the sense of change is far greater than that. My first computer was connected to a tape recorder. This one is connected to the world. I would urge you, everyone, to vote for the good things in this report. They are a sign that the political system is waking up to the enormous change that has already taken place, and I would also urge you to consider the changes that are going to take place in the coming decades and the world we will be living in then.

name: Joëlle Bergeron
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that good intentions do not necessarily lead to good political measures or good legislation. Rapporteur Reda was no doubt driven by a great deal of goodwill and generosity in her person when she tackled this thorny copyright issue. But she has clearly forgotten some principles that are urgently needed.  Defending culture also means defending copyright, which is both the fair remuneration of artistic creation and the protection of the moral right of artists. I regret that this moral right has never been mentioned throughout this report, it is the moral right of artists that determines everything else. The creator must be able to ensure that his work is not devalued or distorted artistically, politically or ideologically. However, the panorama exception, which the rapporteur defends at all costs, opens a gap in the protection of this economic and moral right. And if authors are derpowered to control the exploitation of their work, they no longer have any respect for their person. Contrary to the crazy rumors circulating on the internet, this control does not hinder the possibility for everyone to photograph public works. It only offers the indispensable guarantee that the work will not be exploited for obscene, political or ideological purposes by wacky or malicious people. We must therefore reject this so-called panorama exception en masse and vote against Amendment 3 and paragraph 46. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – I have the slight impression that we have read a different text because, as far as I could see from reading Mrs Reda’s report, there is a great deal about the rights of authors. The whole issue of harmonising authors’ rights in Europe is a crucial issue in order to treat the authors and creators properly, which does not mean locking everything. We cannot lag behind the times. Is that what you are asking for?

name: President. –
text: Madam Bergeron has left the Chamber before replying to the blue-card question.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the Reda report wanted to enshrine the freedom of panorama, that is, the right to freely disseminate photographs of monuments without the permission of the architects concerned and without copyright. Fortunately, an amendment removed this disastrous initiative, which did not sufficiently protect the copyright of architects. This deletion will allow each state to find a more reasonable balance between copyright and photographers' rights. France, for example, does not recognize the freedom of panorama, but has a much more subtle system that it calls the "theory of the accessory". This theory protects the copyright of architects, but nevertheless allows the free dissemination of photographs of a building when it is only the accessory element of a larger landscape. Thanks to the amendment to the Reda report, France will be able to maintain this beautiful system and I am delighted.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In an open society, bans should be the exception. Copyright follows an opposite logic. The phrase "All rights reserved" actually means: anything that is not permitted exceptionally is prohibited. The use of photographs, videos, images that are permanently in public places should continue to be possible without restrictions. Copyright extremism must be stopped. The freedom of panorama must be ensured. Centuries-old cultural assets belong to the general public and should continue to be freely accessible.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Let me make some explanatory remarks, which are worth doing in this report, because our citizens need clear, reliable, extremely clear information about what we are doing here and what the documents we are actually working on are concerned with. I believe that this report has certainly caused a great furore, but it has also caused and caused a great deal of confusion throughout the creative world. I have received such information from the media that this is a report that introduces copyright reform. We are well aware that this report is not a copyright reform and we can expect to receive a proposal from the Commission at the end of this year. I thank the Commissioner for his initial comments on this subject.  I have also received information from the media that this is a panoramic law, clarifying that this is a document that will introduce a provision that any citizen who wants to take a picture of himself, for example, against the background of the Colosseum, will have to pay for it: it is not known how much and do not know to whom. I understand that everyone wants to raise their political capital where possible, but above all we owe reliable, clear information to our citizens. Therefore, firstly, it must be said that this is an own-initiative report which has no legislative effect and, after today's vote, nothing will actually change.  Secondly, it is worth saying what this report is and, in fact, what it should be: it should be a report that assesses the implementation in the Member States of the InfoSoc Directive of 2001. Unfortunately, I regret to say that this content has just been missing from this report. But one thing we can say is that, after months of difficult negotiations, we can regard this text as a common text and a good text. A text that is very balanced, which, on the one hand, defends the rights of persons, consumers, in accessing legally acquired content, and on the other hand guarantees creators and authors the opportunity to defend their rights. If that is how we approach copyright reform, I am calm about it. (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising the 'blue card' (Article 162(8))

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Zwiefka, thank you very much for your contribution. Would you kindly just provide some further details as far as the right of panorama is concerned? It is of course right that – providing we deal with the voting in the way that we feel the large groups in this House are about to – we will arrive at a situation where the national positions of each of our Member States remain protected, so that they can deal with that in the way that they feel is appropriate. That is the best way to proceed.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much to your colleague for this question and the statements made. Of course, I believe that freedom of panorama is an exception that Member States can benefit from in any way they can. It is our duty to ensure that this is the case, so that no one can impose on anyone how to create this very area of civil liberties.

name: Dietmar Köster (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The report could be headlined: free access and fair remuneration. The report has succeeded in striking a balance between the interests of cultural workers in fair remuneration and the free access of Internet users to online services. In the digital age, artists must be able to live off their work, and at the same time we do not want to criminalise – in whatever form – Internet users. Other important findings of the report are: the rights of cultural workers will be strengthened in relation to other rightholders. It calls for Europe-wide minimum standards for exemption rules on copyright. Exceptions are laid down for educational purposes and also for libraries.  The topic of freedom of panorama has recently been the subject of much public debate. Here, some of the media produced sensational stories, which unfortunately had nothing to do with reality and in some cases served rather anti-European prejudices. These widespread reports are now dissolving in the good. Today, Parliament must send out a clear signal here: freedom of panorama will not be affected. That is why we should, we must, vote against paragraph 46.  For future legislation, consideration should be given to maintaining best national practices on freedom of panorama.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – The construction of the Digital Single Market still requires the removal of many barriers to the flow of digital information. The digital space is changing rapidly, so the laws that regulate it need to change. However, these must be changes that realistically meet the needs of the information society and respect the right of all of us to move in public space.  I have received hundreds of messages, requests to vote against restricting the right to a panorama today, and I intend to listen to that voice because it is a voice of reason. The voice of people who really move in the digital space. The storm that this topic has caused reminds me of acta. In my country, hundreds, thousands of people took to the streets to protest against the restriction of freedom in the digital sphere. Today, too, let us not allow our privacy to be unnecessarily restricted. We need to distinguish between the use of photographs for private and commercial purposes. Let's take care of copyright, we guarantee creators profits, but let's do it in a smart way! Let us not introduce any more meaningless rules! Let us not open the door to absurdities!

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the rapporteur's work and congratulate her on that work. Personally, I will support Amendment 46 tabled by my colleague Marietje Schaake. I can only accept limits on the freedom of panorama that come from the State itself for reasons of security or reasons of national defence, never on the basis of copyright. What is public is democratic, it is everyone's, and it cannot be restricted on the basis of private rights. Moreover, I believe that it is an abuse of law to seek to limit the freedom of panorama on the basis of copyright, because it is to protect copyright beyond the limits imposed by the social and economic purposes of one's own law and by the principles of good faith. What does it really protect with copyright? What right does the author have to prevent someone from photographing a monument that is on the public road? So unless the photos are taken to make illustrated postcards and market them, then yes...  (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cuirim fáilte roimh an tuarascáil seo a dhéanann iarracht cothromaíocht agus cosaint a bhaint amach idir cearta na n-ealaíontóirí agus na gcruthaitheoirí. Tá cearta luach saothair cruthaitheoirí thar a bheith tábhachtach, ach caithfear iarracht a dhéanamh a chinntiú nach bhfuil an fearann poiblí teoranta.  I láthair na huaire cuireann an dlí cóipchirt teorainn le sreabhadh na maoine intleachtúla – ealaín, cultúr agus eolas – trasna na mBallstát. Anois is féidir linn iarracht a dhéanamh fáil réidh leis na srianta sin agus deimhneacht dhlíthiúl do tháirgeoirí agus úsáideoirí a chur ar fáil. Tá an Pharlaimint ag léiriú inniu gur chóir cearta na dtomhaltóirí agus an phobail a chur san áireamh in athchóiriú cóipchirt.  Ach ní mór dúinn a admháil chomh maith go gcaithfear na cearta ar luach saothair atá ag táirgeoirí maoine intleachtúla a chosaint le dlí. Ní mór cosaintí den sórt sin a chumhdach sa dlí ionas nach féidir luach saothair cothrom a sheachaint i gconarthaí. Ní chuirfidh an tuarascáil seo deireadh leis an díospóireacht, ach is céim thábhachtach í chun coimeád suas leis an athrú sa teicneolaíocht.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the fact that the situation has changed quite well since the Information Society Directive in 2001 is reflected in the fact that when the notion that Parliament was somehow going to restrict panoramic law spread, 500 000 people appealed to us not to do so. In 2001, it would have been out of the question for so many people to have been informed so quickly about what was happening in this House. However, everyone can be told that the end result will be happy in the sense that we are indeed leaving this matter to national decisions at this stage.  The fact that attention has been drawn to such a detail, which also has a great deal of false fears, is also a testimony that this report is extremely balanced. It will be a really good basis for future legislative work. It is actually a miracle that the committee has been able to reach such a good compromise between the authors, consumers and the rights of various intermediaries. That compromise should not now be undermined in the vote.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, over and above the various issues of substance that make us appreciate the Reda report as a whole, without prejudice to certain critical issues that undermine its effectiveness and our total sharing, it is not secondary in my opinion to recall that this report is the first concrete act of legislative initiative of a democratically elected Parliament in the field of copyright over the last 20-25 years. We all know that the intellectual property reforms of the last twenty years have not only been inspired but also carried out by the World Trade Organisation through the TRIPS agreements of 1994. All the various directives, regulations and laws that followed were mere applications, interpretations or developments of what was conceived in a forum that is not very dissimilar, perhaps even darker, to that concerning TTIP.  It follows that, for this reason alone, the Reda report, if it succeeds, will remain an initiative that will remain in the history of copyright and democracy. For this reason, I ask you not to compromise this good proposal with non-copyright predictions as the responsibility of intermediaries for protection ....... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: Madam President, while it is clear that new rules are to be implemented, this battle over copyright fits perfectly into the opposition between the defenders of the nation and the globalists. Indeed, the European Union seeks to eliminate national particularisms in favour of world trade without rules. Breaking down national barriers to copyright and data protection regulation, as Jean-Claude Juncker has called for, means fewer and fewer controls and restrictions. This would, of course, benefit large multinationals, such as Google or Amazon, which already blithely engage in tax evasion in Europe. I had previously questioned the Commissioner of Culture about the tax practices of video-on-demand platforms.  In addition, we will have to find a framework that protects creators and small authors while allowing free expression on the internet. Indeed, intellectual property has become a political weapon and it is under this pretext that we can ask Internet users to remove critical videos. This development should not pave the way for a Union without borders and should allow Member States to continue to legislate in favour of respect, conservation and promotion of their identity. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The European Copyright Directive dates back to 2001. We need to modernise copyright and adapt it to the requirements of the cross-border digital single market. For me, it is important to balance the interests of users and rights holders appropriately, sensibly. After all, that is what copyright is all about. Copyright must not only keep an eye on the perspective of consumers, but also of those who do creative work. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, I am once again asking you today for your support for Amendment No 1. It does not call – and I would like to emphasise this once again – for a European right to protection of benefits to be introduced. Anyone who claims this has not read the motion or deliberately wants to spread something untrue. Allow me to read the amendment again briefly. It calls on the Commission to 'consider how quality journalism can be preserved in the digital age and to present a proposal to ensure media diversity, in particular taking into account the important role played by journalists, authors and media service providers such as press publishers'. For me, media pluralism is not just that everyone can express their opinion and communicate. I appreciate the work of journalists, editors, authors, even those who carry out research, sort for their readers, classify, comment. For me, this is quality journalism. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, I have tabled this amendment and I would be very pleased if you could support it in the vote this afternoon. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8))

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Niebler, can you explain why your amendment calls for a last-minute Commission proposal, after we in the Committee on Legal Affairs , including your cooperation – have drafted a compromise amendment on this very subject, which the PPE-DE has also agreed to, and why your amendment should now be included in the report immediately after this compromise? Do you not see that this is jeopardising the compromise that we found in the Committee on Legal Affairs and citizens and putting the report in jeopardy?

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much for the question, Mrs Reda. First of all, I am pleased that you speak today in your mother tongue and not just in English. It shows that you have something left for culture. To answer your question: quality journalism, this term does not occur in your entire report. I therefore believe that this amendment can once again be supported. It does not at all contradict any statement in your report, but complements what i am concerned about, namely to once again attach particular importance to quality journalism and to call on the Commission to give a mandate to the Commission on how to resolve this issue constructively.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European creative and creative industries account for around 4.2% of the Union's GDP each year, creating more than 7 million jobs in the Member States, including many related to the digital environment. Unfortunately, the current procedures for respecting copyright on the internet are working poorly, if at all, which at the same time hinders the growth of innovation. The economic benefits of well-educated workers, cutting-edge research and knowledge exchange between universities and businesses are evident. Unfortunately, the European Copyright Directive, which regulates only non-commercial research objectives, practically excludes the transfer of knowledge from universities to the private industry sector. European companies cannot deal with their US competitors in this regard, who benefit from more flexible regulations existing overseas.  Although I have not succeeded in persuading Members to fully harmonise the exceptions to copyright, I am pleased that they are being mini-harmonised at the level of education and libraries, as well as the provisions on cross-border access. I hope that members from other political groups will keep their word on the rejection of certain harmful amendments restricting, inter alia, freedom of panorama and freedom of linking. In its current form, the report is, to the limit, a stretched compromise between the proponents of copyright harmonisation, to which I belong, and the conservative community. As such, it is not entirely satisfactory for either party. Nevertheless, I congratulate the enthusiasm and patience of rapporteur Julia Reda.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we do need to update copyright for the digital age, and people expect to be able to take their music, films and books with them when they travel. Consumers should be able to access legally-available content and know when they buy it how portable it is. But portability must not be an excuse for piracy – 8 million people work in the creative sector and they should be paid properly. Therefore, exemptions need to be clear and targeted. Text and data mining has brought huge benefits for science and research in the non-commercial sector in my Member State, and there are some interesting examples of e-lending in rural areas. So perhaps the Commissioner could build on the experience in the countries that are doing this in his work. In the UK and in other countries, the right to take pictures in public places of public buildings is a cherished freedom and an EU limitation is not appropriate. Incidentally, I would like to say to Ms Niebler that we do not need an internet tax across Europe either.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Europe needs competitive copyright policy. Europe needs to set up conditions for new innovative businesses such as Spotify and Netflix. At the moment, it is pretty difficult for these kinds of businesses to function in Europe in a single market. Creative industries today have created 8 million jobs for people linked to this sector in Europe. It could be much more. It could be 20 million. That is what we should aim for, but in order to be competitive we need to be innovative. Copyright reform has to be one of those innovative moves for Europe. I urge the Commission to be ambitious and to come up with a revolutionary copyright proposal in the autumn. Let us do it. We need to give cross border access to online content, we need to ensure portability, and we need to remove legal uncertainties and inconsistencies that affect the functioning of the internal market. I hope that Parliament will give clear guidance for the Commission today.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the debate on the protection of copyright in the information society recalls the need to achieve two objectives at the same time: on the one hand, to protect authors and their intellectual and property rights, that is to say, to actually protect the renewal of our common cultural heritage over time and, on the other hand, to create new opportunities for access to artistic and intellectual creation.  We have two challenges to face: firstly, new technologies, which create new possibilities for creation but at the same time many risks to the rights of creators. Secondly, the economic crisis and austerity, which also removes our peoples from art and letters and deprives spiritual people of the resources necessary to create. It is therefore necessary not only to regulate the protection of the rights of authors but above all to guarantee the continuity and pluralism of European culture.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when I see harmonisation in this place, it means one thing: making the free less free. You tried it once with the Anti-Counterfeit Trade Agreement, and you are trying it again with paragraph 46 to restrict the rights of panorama. I have had hundreds of emails and letters from graphic designers, Web designers, professional photographers, who fear for their livelihoods. They fear that the regulations coming out of this place are going to mean that their jobs are redundant. But my message to those people is not to listen to the blank reassurances from this Chamber. They have their chance to defend their interests, and that comes when our referendum comes. They can vote ‘no’. They can vote to leave this place and have a government at Westminster – a government they can vote out, instead of the Commissioners that they did not vote for – deciding their laws. We can break free of this place. My appeal to those people who have written to me and to every single British MEP is: defend your interests, vote ‘no’, let us leave the European Union and take back control.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that, in this area too, we need all the efforts that Europe must offer in order to give operators a framework of rules that will enable them to work with certainty and fair profit. We are aware that we live in a world that no longer even has to talk about the digital revolution, because art, culture, which are disseminated through the network, are also a reality that accompanies our lives on a daily basis. It is therefore necessary to make use of all the possibilities, but with great attention, always reminding us of our duty to protect, first of all, the intellectual property of authors and all the work that revolves around the world of publishing. So, let's not mess up from that point of view. Today's initiative is an initiative by Parliament, improved by the work of the Committee on Legal Affairs compared with the beginning, but which is only an indication to the Commission. Let us hope that, at least this time, it will refrain from wanting to harness, as usual, with a series of unnecessary legal constraints, European citizens and companies in the sector and will concentrate on a few clear instruments for the protection of work and rights.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, our starting position has not been easy. The original proposal for this report on the implementation of the Copyright Directive in the information society contained little information on such implementation, but there was mainly information on the future of this area. Information on how the state implemented the directive, what problems it had with it, what the legal challenges were around it, such information is there at least. The result was public confusion. The public does not know the difference between legislative and non-legislative reports, so they have been persuaded that we will harmonise something here today, make changes. I consider this confusion of genres and the subsequent political campaigns to be harmful. I certainly do not consider this report to be an example worthy of following when it comes to implementing anything. However, it is positive that the report has been put into an acceptable form. I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs for this. The proposal provides a good basis for the future debate on copyright reform that is necessary. The European Parliament must make it clear that it is aware of the challenges of the twenty-first digital century in the area of copyright, without jeopardising the creativity and quality of content.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Reda, all my fellow rapporteurs and colleagues from the other groups and committees for agreeing on a joint text in such a complex area. This report certainly takes a step forward, although not a final one, because we are finally arriving at a clear and, above all, very balanced indication for the European Commission, useful for an innovative framework for the development of the Digital Agenda, capable of protecting copyright, the right of access to knowledge, while promoting the role of the cultural and creative industries and without neglecting the responsibility of all operators. I hope that paragraph 46 will be abolished in the text, so that the principle of freedom of panorama is reaffirmed, and I would like to make a final appeal to the Commission and the Council to implement the Marrakesh Treaty in order to guarantee the right to information and culture for the blind.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – Photographers, newspaper editors and artists are following this debate today because the freedom of panorama may be replaced by a legal dictation. I am opposed to paragraph 46 in the report, because it states that all commercial use of images of public works must be approved in advance. In many European countries this is simply allowed. So why choose the strictest regime here? I don't understand that. My thesis is: hands off the public space. It's everybody's. Moreover, what is Europe interfering in? Member States can perfectly regulate how to deal with public space. I will therefore reject any attempt to reduce the freedom of panorama. That is a really crucial point for me. I call on the Commissioner, when he legislates this autumn, to guarantee the freedom of panorama.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, cultural industries are a significant generator of growth and jobs. Copyright is the cornerstone of cultural policy. However, the current regime needs to be better tailored to the digital environment in order to ensure fair remuneration to creators and to conform to consumer expectations. This is the reason why I welcome the Commission’s commitment on the modernisation of the Copyright Directive. The lack of harmonisation of exceptions in the EU creates legal uncertainties. At least a core of exceptions should be made mandatory. Restrictions linked to geo-blocking prevent European citizens from enjoying cultural diversity across borders and European companies from fully benefiting from the possibilities offered by the digital environment. We need to find legislative and market—driven solutions so that European citizens can access any work available in a Member State from anywhere in the EU. Last but not least, I also believe strongly in freedom of panorama.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament, in the imagination, should be a progressive institution that is close to the interests of the citizens and fights to defend them. Today, however, it shows all its weariness, preparing to laboriously dismiss a text that I would describe as reactionary to say the least, containing principles that are contrary to the digital single market and imbued with a neoliberal ideology: the points of GDP are repeated as a cantilena, the figures on jobs are quoted with much approximation and the mantra of growth is constantly trumpeted.  You have even felt the need to emphatically reaffirm that the right to private property is the foundation of modern society. But should we not have given directions for the modernisation of copyright and made it adapted to new technologies and the nascent digital single market? What have we done instead? We carefully chose adjectives, so that everything would change without changing anything, afraid that even a breath of wind could bring a breath of freshness. The call for the introduction of the responsibility of digital intermediaries and service providers, as well as robust enforcement, which is likely to be, first of all anachronistic, given its frequent ineffectiveness, as well as dangerous for fundamental rights, is unacceptable.  The rights of authors are then mentioned instrumentally to justify the maintenance of pension positions on the market, which no longer make sense given the opportunities offered by new technologies. As a member of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Industrial Policy, I am horrified when I read that culture is regarded as a product to be sold and those who want to benefit from it – and I quote – 'have to pay to do so'. But should we not have built a Europe for the citizens? Should the free dissemination of culture and knowledge not be the polar star of a reform that wants to define itself as such and in step with the times? Why be afraid of the introduction of exceptions and restrictions on copyright, in order to protect fundamental rights and the public interest?  Ladies and gentlemen, I am not satisfied with this text and I still believe that we have a duty to all European citizens to do more. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure to Mrs Isabella Adinolfi. – If you do not support the report and say that no one should pay, how do you think authors who are currently struggling to recover their copyright can be remunerated? How will they be remunerated? Where will the money be taken from?

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I have never said that authors or creators should not be paid. We'd miss him! I myself come from a humanistic field. I am in favour of authors and creators.  But I also believe that there must be exceptions and restrictions on culture, because citizens need access to culture, all of them.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF).
text: Madam President, first of all, I am opposed to any harmonization in the area of copyright, if only because of the ambiguity of the term copyright, in the English version, when the two concepts fall under different philosophies. The Infosoc Directive exists, either. This directive has not allowed for the harmonization of copyrights. Good! The work of the mission carried out in France by Pierre Sirinelli, a leading law professor, presents an overview of what would entail the revision of this directive proposed by my colleague Julia Reda: the weakening of copyright, which I strongly oppose.  Secondly, no revision of the e-commerce directive, which guarantees a very protective regime for internet providers, is proposed. We can even talk about irresponsibility. With this draft revision, you risk giving birth, once again, to a stillborn text to the detriment of the authors.  Who can predict what the internet will be like in 5 years? The European Union is an obsolete software that produces only floppy disks. We still have proof of that today.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. The digital challenge also requires adjustments to copyright, and we must address them, but at the same time take advantage of the opportunities that arise from it. We should therefore also work to improve the cross-border portability of content for consumers, to respond appropriately to this issue of geo-blocking in the various areas, but also to better meet the needs of industries or citizens. In the last few days, as my fellow Members have already mentioned, we have had the excitement about the freedom of panorama that it is in danger – that is not the case, and this has already been sufficiently discussed. However, we should ensure that the freedom of panorama – and this is the first step we can take today – is maintained, as it is in Germany or in the other Member States, and that the improvements in the future will perhaps be voted on here. But, and this is crucial, we must also ensure with enthusiasm and determination that the rights of artists, authors, authors and exploiters remain protected in the age of digitalisation.  The text we are voting on today is a more or less balanced solution that takes into account the interests of both artists and consumers. That is why we must continue to ensure a European legal system and ensure that copyright is well designed. I am sure that is in good hands.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I recognise that this progress report on the revision of the Copyright Directive provides a good basis for the Commission's legislative proposal, and I also appreciate what Commissioner Oettinger said. Many of the demands of the Committee on Culture are gathered, and this is a work that is the result of a great campaign of high mediation, Mr Adinolfi. I am a little surprised that you, the draftsman of the opinion in the CULT Committee, are critical of the fact that there was no consensus on your report.  However, what we have been saying for a long time is demonstrated here, namely that the portability of cultural content is compatible with territoriality, and we recognise the cultural specificity between the extension of access to culture and the recognition of the moral and economic rights of authors, as well as economic sustainability for the cultural and creative industries, especially audiovisual industries. I would like to add just two comments. Firstly, I shall vote against Article 3(46), but I have a duty, quite honestly, to say that there was no question of freedom of panorama, that is, the freedom to photograph freely, but, if anything, the commercial use and exploitation of the relevant images. The proposal on the responsibility to be clarified of the over-the-top is a good one.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: –  Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work and also for the good cooperation that we had. I am just sad that the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) took the wrong approach to this report. Banning the freedom of panorama exclusion, for example, was exactly the wrong way to look at the digital single market. I am glad that the groups and the author have agreed now to remove it, but I have huge concerns that the committee thought it was a good idea in the first place. It shows that there is little understanding of the immense changes that the digital environment is bringing to consumers, users, right holders and businesses. That is not the only problem. The call to reopen the E-commerce Directive is also unwelcome, as is the very wide educational exemption, the study into the pan-European licence and the amendment for a new internet tax. But my final point is on geo-blocking.  One of Europe’s biggest sporting events is taking place right now: it is the Ashes cricket series between England and Australia, and it has a global audience of billions. Yet if you bought access to watch this in the UK, you are blocked from accessing it here in France or on holiday in Spain, even though the right to work is there. I do not want a pan-EU licence, but I want portability of legally-bought content. However, on this, as in so many other areas, the report simply does not recognise how the modern digital market works.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – I am pleased that we have coordinated the text in the largest political groups. The original proposal received a lot of complaints from artists and representatives of cultural industries. Today we are opening a new debate to encourage the emergence of updated legislation in this area. As with many other issues, there is a need to find a certain balance on the issue of copyright. We must respect the rights of employees in culture, while allowing wide access to cultural good people to the widest possible public.  In the report, we have identified exceptions where copyright can be ignored. In the European People's Party, we are in favour of respecting the principle of subsidiarity in the area of copyright, so that each Member State can retain some autonomy in this area. This is particularly important in view of the preservation of cultural diversity in the European Union and because of the specific needs of individual countries, especially for smaller members. There have been recent accusations in public that the European Union is trying to restrict the right to publish so-called panoramas - private footage of well-known cultural creations, for example, on Facebook or other social networks.  That's just not true. The text on which we are going to vote today is a good one. It takes into account the needs of end-users, while insisting on the protection of intellectual property. Thank you to all the authors.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to say that I regret that the issue of the panorama monopolises the debates so much, simply because many untruths have been said. I will restore things as they are. In no way, it is not a question of prohibiting the publication of vacation photos on the internet or elsewhere, but simply of saying that it is not fair that an artist, because he chooses to produce his works in public space, cannot receive a fair remuneration when it is made a commercial use.  The aim of this report was to adapt the issue of culture and copyright to the digital world. Indeed, the upheavals induced by digital uses are numerous: they change the relationship of our fellow citizens to culture, but not only to culture, because they also change the way trade and services work. They even change the way we think about social relations and work today. Why special treatment for culture? After all, it is true that culture is of great economic importance: it is the third largest sector of activity in Europe, and it represents more than 500 billion turnover per year, but I reject this purely mercantilist view of culture. It is also of political, symbolic and humanist importance. When we talk about barriers, obstacles, obstacles and copyright, personally, it offends my conception of European culture. Is it necessary to remember that there is no culture without an artist, that copyright is a fundamental right and that it is right and good that everyone can make a living from their work? I welcome the fact that the text proposed to us, unlike the one that was originally on the table, puts artists back at the centre of the debate, a place they should never have left. Our copyright system allows for a diverse and thriving culture. I hope that the Commission... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the right to the landscape is a right such as a fundamental right. The demands to restrict the filming of public spaces, albeit only for commercial purposes, are, in my view, part of the past decades. I have received a great deal of feedback on this report, particularly from young Internet users, for whom the mere idea of restricting the use of public space seems incomprehensible.  There is high unemployment in Europe. Unemployment is particularly affected by young people, at least some of whom can employ themselves in the creative industries, taking advantage, for example, of the unlimited opportunities offered by the Internet. Therefore, there should be no restrictions and new barriers to self-employment for young people, but rather the barriers should be dismantled and thus lower the threshold for becoming an entrepreneur. In recent years, there has been talk of much better and lighter regulation. I hope that this objective will be achieved, and I hope that the right to the landscape will be a broader fundamental right in the future.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is not about copyright or just about how it affects the digital environment. This document is about the economic model that we want to promote, especially in the online space in Europe.  We Social Democrats believe in a safe and fair internet, and new technologies must allow citizens more freedom and more rights. For us, the digital space should not be dominated or controlled by anyone, but for a free internet, we must protect those who create and use the online environment to develop.  Copyright must not restrict the development and affirmation potential of digital space, especially for education, culture or entrepreneurship, but we must also protect the work of real authors. The European digital economic sector needs a harmonised copyright system that allows it to be competitive with its competitors on other continents. I am pleased with the compromises reached for this report, but I honestly believe that we could have done more for the European online environment.  We need freedom of panorama. We need a well-developed, sustained and harmonised digital system.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Madam President, by voting for this report after it was adopted in the Committee on Legal Affairs, we have the opportunity to send a strong message to the Commission.  We have the opportunity to tell the Commission, as part of its preparations for the revision of the Copyright Directive, that we are in favour of adapting copyright to the digital age, but against its demolition or questioning.  In the Committee on Legal Affairs, we have substantially reoriented and rewrote the initial draft report presented to us by Mrs Reda and, on this occasion, affirmed and reaffirmed strong priorities and principles: fair remuneration for the work and talent of authors and creators, respect for European cultural diversity, affirmation of the principle of territoriality, the need to make progress in terms of portability - this is perfectly compatible , the need to combat piracy and counterfeiting, which are real scourges, the need to establish a regime of responsibility for platforms, hosts, all intermediaries who are currently in a system of irresponsibility, the need to adapt copyright to the digital age and not to dismantle it, to strengthen it and not to weaken it. All this is possible, because the report, as we have amended in the Committee on Legal Affairs, contains concrete ways in which this is the case.  We are firmly awaiting, Commissioner, the proposal to revise the directive that you will present to us, but we will be committed to respecting the principle of the intellectual property of artists and creators.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is an important own-initiative report that we are discussing, because it requires policy to take on the task at stake; both to give citizens the opportunity to share in culture, knowledge and contacts online, but also to give creators, creators, and distributors the right to compensation for their hard work. Legislation must be able to balance this balance. I think it is important that politics should also take responsibility for a vibrant culture, and then we must ensure that cultural practitioners have good conditions, but we must also be able to spread the culture and take advantage of the opportunities offered by e-books, for example; to children and give children the opportunity to read early. I see great opportunities with that. I would like to mention two things about this balance. One is education. From the outset, I thought that the report contained the view that educational practitioners could spread anything without paying the cultural practitioners. We have put a stop to that and done better. The second is freedom of panorama. It must be safeguarded. This is the balance at stake in a concrete example.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Reda for her extraordinary patience in this work, which allows us to have a vast area of sharing a very delicate task, namely to rewrite and give a legislative definition to copyright in the network system. The material production of goods and services is outdated and, in many ways, changed by the use of technologies and new languages, and it is therefore important what we are doing precisely for this purpose: redefining rights for both producers and users. I also consider the elements relating to the promotion of the digitisation of everything that can be considered to be Europe's cultural heritage to be very important for this reason and, in the same way, it is important to strengthen the exception for education and libraries. Then, as far as freedom of the scenery is concerned, there should be no need to comment on it either: freedom should not be called into question. Another thing is, of course, to counteract undistint or even worse distorting behaviour. For this reason, I too believe that it is very important to delete paragraph 46.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We agree that a reform of copyright is necessary. What we have on the table at the moment is absolutely out of date. Almost everyone is on the Internet and social networks every day. For all of us Social Democrats, there are some things that should allow access for people, citizens, citizens, those who are better off, those who do not have it so easy, namely full access to information. That is why i am particularly interested in the exception of educational institutions such as schools, universities and libraries, and this is included in the report. Another important good element that we want to give them is the ban on geo-blocking, which is actually a peculiarity in a Europe, in a European internal market. In the last few days there has been a lot of excitement about the freedom of the panorama. I am just saying so much: I personally am in favour of unrestricted freedom of panorama. Everything else is alien to the world. However, we probably still have to work together here in this House, to ensure that this is also socially acceptable. Finally, however, I would like to draw attention to an amendment that I am really opposed to now, namely the introduction of a so-called right to protect the rights of press publishers, as called for by an amendment in plenary from the conservative side. Such a law has already led to significant restrictions on referrals or linking in Germany or Spain. It is a huge hurdle to the innovative power of the Internet. That is why we should definitely vote against it.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – The biggest copyright challenge in the 21st century is striking a balance between the interests of consumers, authors, distributors and rights holders. Changes should also be made carefully after exhaustive consultations. Each even small step forward reflects entire technological eras.  Adequate intellectual property rights are one of the factors for the fastest and most seamless transition to the new digital economic model. A model that does not divide countries into small and large and gives equal chance to both large and small and start-ups. One of the greatest riches we have in Europe is the products of our creators, and we all know that talent is not born in a straight way only in the largest, but also in smaller countries. Therefore, the new rules in the digital single market should provide a field for the expression of composers, artists, directors and architects and newer member states, such as Bulgaria.  I believe that with the vote today we will make a strong request for the introduction of working and balanced rules on copyright on the Internet.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, the digital single market still does not exist in Europe. European consumers are still often denied access to certain digital services because of their location. It is not normal for cross-border access to video-on-demand content to be guaranteed for less than 4% of all its content. Consumers need more access to services from other Member States, wherever they may be.  It is imperative to define consumers' rights more clearly and fully in the context of copyright. I welcome the exception proposal for education and libraries, which will allow a wider audience to access digital content.  We want access to culture for everyone, including in the digital world. This relationship is a balance between consumer rights and the necessary protection of copyright, which is the guarantor of diversity. It is a wealth, moreover in cultural matters, which must be preserved.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the Charter of Fundamental Rights protects freedom of expression and information. At the same time it protects the freedom of art, science and therefore the right to intellectual property. We must therefore find a way to strike a delicate balance between copyright and the consumer, and we are having this debate today. The first question to be asked is what is the appropriate level to regulate these issues. Is it the level of the European Union? Is it the level of the Member States? How is the principle of subsidiarity shaped? What measures should we take? The next issue concerns the Internet itself, freedom on the Internet. Creators must be protected, because creators are a huge social capital for Europe. If they are not motivated to protect themselves, it is obvious that they will not produce work, we will not have support for the digital economy, technologies, information and innovations. So we have to find solutions to all these issues.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the discussion on copyright is far too black and white. It does not take into account the way behaviour has changed in the internet age. It is not as though the creators are going to win and the users are going to lose or  vice versa. In the internet age there is no longer any clear division between the authors and the users, because every author is also a user and every user is an author. We cannot stop progress and we cannot stop innovation, no matter how hard we try. Our role is not to protect any vested interest but to create laws that actually make sense today in the internet age.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the European Union gets pilloried and attacked for coming out with stupid ideas from time to time. The most famous one – and I suppose, like a lot of urban myths, it might not necessarily be true – was the story of the fight for straight bananas, for some reason. Well, the idea that you would restrict someone’s ability to distribute views of panoramas, whether that be for commercial or personal use, is completely and utterly ridiculous. The people who designed these buildings – let us say they are buildings – got paid for those designs. We have been contacted by many people who believe this is just another way for big business to make more money. Technology was meant to improve our lives. I hope it does. When I was growing up, I could listen to any sporting event in the world on BBC radio. Even though I am from Ireland, we tune into it. I fear in the future that my grandkids will not have access to similar things because of the progress of technology and blocking. That is not what we are looking for. We are looking for progress and spreading culture.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We are all working to get the best legislation. It's Commissioner Oettinger's turn.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am very grateful for your dedicated speeches, which prove your expertise and which show that the copyright issues are in good hands with you. I note that we see a large majority here among Members who encourage us. It is time to modernise copyright. There was hardly a speech that said: leave your fingers off, do not take action. I believe that the option of not making a proposal would be the worst option. Secondly, we want to take account of technological development and market change in our copyright package and the interests of citizens and consumers.  Thirdly, we are trying to achieve a balanced proposal. The balance is crucial – the balance, which was also depicted in your speeches, between the legitimate interests of those who create spiritual works, who writes, who writes, who composes, who has contributed his time and competences for intellectual work, and, on the other hand, a wide access, preferably no limit or, if possible, narrow limits that are necessary. If we want to deviate from the principle of portability and open access throughout Europe, we must provide evidence for this – and i too have to show that this is necessary in the interests of authorship. I mentioned the film and sports sectors for this. We have received suggestions that we should analyse platforms in order to decide whether to include new providers in our regulatory framework. That is another way of doing this. Preventing piracy as best we can is our goal.  The subject of freedom of panorama took up a relatively wide space – it seems to me that it is a pure phantom. That is why we should not have phantom debates. Restricting freedom of panorama was not the Commission's idea. This was apparently a misunderstood idea in a parliamentary technical committee, but no one was represented today. That is why we could also say to the public here: it was a misunderstanding in the technical committee, it was never the will of a number of Members.  We do not want to restrict the existing rules. Freedom of panorama will continue to be preserved on the basis of national laws and will not be restricted at European level. What remains would then be a clever marketing move by Wikipedia, to whom it may be granted. From now on back to the essential issues and no longer the phantom, which I think is done.

name: Julia Reda
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank all my colleagues for their contributions to this very vibrant and balanced debate. I would especially like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their very hard and continuous work over the several months that we have been working on this report. I also greatly appreciate the commitment from the Commission to take the results of the report into account. Even though it is only an evaluation of the status quo of the Copyright Directive, the public attention to this debate and to the negotiations shows that Europeans are anxiously waiting for an ambitious copyright reform. I am also very glad to hear the Commissioner’s comments that photos are an extension of vision and that freedom of panorama must be preserved. I think the great public support freedom of panorama. Even though the debate has been blown a bit out of proportion, it does show that we need a new balance in copyright, that we should not hold onto ideas that have already failed the practice test, and that exceptions and limitations are not harmful to authors. They quite often give a necessary breathing space for new creation to take place, and they give aspiring authors the necessary access to culture and education. Not everybody in the future will be a Victor Hugo, but Victor Hugo – the initiator of the Berne Convention himself – famously said, and I quote, ‘Literature is the secretion of civilisation, poetry of the ideal. That is why literature is one of the wants of societies ... That is why there must be a vast public literary domain. That is why all poets, all philosophers, all thinkers, all the producers of the greatness of the mind must be translated, commented on, published, printed, reprinted, stereotyped, distributed, explained, recited, spread abroad, given to all, given cheaply, given at cost price, given for nothing’.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, July 9, 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. –  The cultural and creative sector accounts for up to 4.5% of the EU GDP and gives work to 8.5 million people, meaning it does not just contribute to cultural development and diversity but is also crucial for the real economy. Yet in many parts of the creative sector, people still do not receive fair pay for their work. Half a million performers across the EU are not fairly rewarded when their performances are exploited via online on-demand services, and many of them are in too weak a position to negotiate better terms. Technology has advanced, but copyright is still stuck in the past. I urge the Commission to ensure that authors and performers enjoy an unwaivable right to remuneration when their products become available on digital platforms, in order to safeguard the important role they play both in terms of culture and education and for the real economy.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright is an own-initiative report and therefore has no legislative force, and is a kind of initiative, with the aim of paying attention to certain problems. In general terms, the document promotes the liberalisation of copyright, but an amendment has been tabled which implies that the creator or office must agree to the commercial use of photographs with paintings, works of art or monuments. Currently, such photographs, without the owner's consent and payment of any fees, may also be published for commercial purposes (in book publications, television publications or online materials).  If that report were a binding legal act, the introduction of such an amendment would force the withdrawal from the market of existing products or for authors to obtain permission to use the panorama in their publications, which would certainly require a wade through complex administrative and legal procedures and would incur appropriate costs. I hope that the European Parliament will vote against today's vote against restricting the freedom of panorama, as there are no indications that the lack of harmonisation of the rules in this area constitutes any obstacle for creators.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The report on the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2001 on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society is an own-initiative report. The text has no legislative force, but it gives an image of what changes to the protection of rights should, in the opinion of the European Parliament, be introduced in the EU. The report emphasises that copyrighted content is accessible across borders. The report stresses the importance of territorial licences, in particular for the financing of the production of films and audiovisual works. The report includes a controversial amendment to restrict the freedom of panorama, but there is no reference to this issue in the final text of the report. After months of negotiations, the Committee on Legal Affairs has proposed a common balanced text which, on the one hand, defends consumers' rights to legally acquired content and, on the other hand, gives authors the opportunity to protect their rights. The report is a good basis for the European Commission's proposals on copyright reform, which are likely to be presented later this year.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Libertarian prey should be particularly protected. Unfortunately, the attempt to include in julia Reda's report on the restriction of the so-called freedom of panorama is, unfortunately, a repeated practice of spoiling the legislative process, but also of parliament itself.
