I would remind you, on this occasion, that most of the Countries of the European Community have implemented the InfoSoc Directive with the exception of 'Freedom of panorama'. Poland, in Article 33 of the Copyright Act, has included the freedom to distribute "works exhibited in public collections", on publicly accessible roads, streets, squares, etc.  I know that even the adoption of an unreasonable solution in the report would not result in a change in the law, but would unfortunately undermine the credibility of ourselves and the stability of the solutions that create the fundamental canon of citizen's freedom. As you can see, the call for the success of common sense is again needed.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The following point is a brief description of the following report prepared by Andrzej Grzyb on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs: Evaluation of the activities of the European Foundation for Democracy (2014/2231(INI)) (A8-0177/2015).

name: Andrzej Grzyb
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to thank very much all those who have been involved in the process of preparing this report on my initiative. I would particularly like to thank my colleagues in the shadow rapporteurs, who are supporting us with secretariats, colleagues, including the Executive Director of the European Fund for Democracy, representatives of the European External Action Service and the European Commission. First of all, I thank the NGO sector, which has very much supported us in assessing and looking at the work of the EED so far. What is the European Fund? It is a foundation established in 2012 under Belgian law by the Union and the Member States, also with the participation of other countries outside the European Union. The Polish Presidency took the initiative of setting up this fund in 2011. Since then, 4 have passed and the fund itself has been in place for 2 years. At the heart of the initiative is the fact that the classic instruments for promoting democracy have not worked, for example, during the Arab Spring or in the events that took place east of the European Union, in neighbouring countries. Furthermore, the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, as well as the experience of the peaceful transformation of the Member States from Central and Eastern Europe, including the experience of Polish Solidarity, also help us in this regard. The Fund aims to react more quickly, more flexibly than through classical instruments. It is also intended to support those who have not yet been supported. The Fund emphasises the involvement of actors on the ground, in countries that are going through this process of change, transformation. It has so far supported more than 186 initiatives in virtually all of the European Union's neighbourhood countries, both the Eastern Partnership and the Union for the Mediterranean. It is worth quoting one of the beneficiaries who said this: after the revolution, everyone disappeared. The EED brings with it a breath of freshness and hope, providing political and moral support not only to old well-established organizations, but also to new actors – these are the words of one of the activists from Egypt. The EED-backed parties are also undergoing positive checks in democratic elections over time – as was the case with Euromaidan activists in Ukraine. They are currently members of the Wierchowna Council. Of particular note is the ability of the EED to finance bridging, the so-called bridging, that is to say, financing, which persists between the end of one and the start of the second funding from the European Union, for example from the EDHR Fund. These procedures are more complex, longer, and therefore often this period of funding interruption proves difficult for those who are supported. Therefore, in such cases, bridging funding is very important. As part of the work on the evaluation report, we have held a number of debates and hearings so far to find out how the European Endocracies for Democracy are assessed. Among other things, we met with NGOs who reported on how they used the EED, what their experiences are. We have also conducted a number of consultations, both with representatives of the EED and with the cooperating institutions, the European External Action Service and the Commission. The report assessed the two-year action so far and made a number of recommendations. The key conclusions are that the EED is meeting the tasks set out in the Statute and, most importantly, in the European Parliament's recommendations of 29 March 2012 on the establishment of the EED. It brings important added value to the instruments available to the European Union for democracy in the world. At the same time, we call for the EED to be guaranteed sufficient and stable in the long term, both from the Member States of the Union and from the Commission itself. It made a positive decision as the fund received another three-year funding.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank very much the author of this report. I think it is terribly important that the European Union is trying to financially support NGOs in countries where the political transition is taking place. I myself am a Member for the Czech Republic, which has a communist past. In the 1990s I was in various youth organisations and I am aware that if it were not for the money from foundations that worked in Western Europe, we would hardly be able to do educational projects and conferences, we would hardly be able to get young people, the younger generation into Czech politics. I therefore consider this to be terribly important, it is not simply a distribution of money. It is our moral duty to help, especially the countries of the former Soviet Union, the countries of the Middle East, countries where democracy is still not strongly entrenched.  So thank you again, and I hope that the 12 countries that have not yet paid their contributions will provide money after today's report. Because like I said, it's very important.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) has shown, after two years of existence, that it has fulfilled the purpose for which it was created. Its promotion of European values, of freedom and democracy, has achieved very good results. The EED remains an independent private law foundation that delivers through fast, flexible, bottom-up and demand-driven funding. It provides these funds directly to beneficiaries in a financially-efficient manner that compliments other EU means, doing so with minimal administrative burden and simpler procedures. To sustain and further develop the effectiveness of the EED, it is vital that long-term, sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding for it is ensured. I support a stronger emphasis on groups that suffer from social exclusion or political marginalisation by supporting, among others, groups such as women’s movements, LGBTI, human rights activists, emerging political movements, trade unions and bloggers.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: I would first and foremost like to congratulate Mr Grzyb on his report. Like him, I am also a member of the efd's board of directors. I am therefore very enthusiastic about the extension of the mandate area to countries just outside the neighbourhood. Although the EFD is not part of this neighbourhood, it has shown in recent years that it can play an important role in countries where space for civil society is extremely limited. For example, we see that the EFD in Ukraine has been able to assist small local media partners in their coverage of the Euromaidan movement in Kiev. I am a former international journalist and I know that the EFD is a perfect tool to assist human rights activists, journalists and bloggers. In countries such as Turkey, Russia, Egypt, Azerbaijan, etc., the room for manoeuvre of such independent media is still under pressure. Today, in countries of the neighbourhood and around them, the European Union is the subject of a propaganda war being driven by the Kremlin. The EFD can play an important role in countering it.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, let me express my great satisfaction at the beginning that the European Foundation for Democracy was established because I am one of those people who had the opportunity to establish various foundations and I was in a situation to understand how much foundations can really help. I think it is this European Endowment for Democracy that needs to play its key role among our neighbours and what I want to emphasize in this case is: don't forget our neighbours who are candidate countries or potential candidate countries. I think here first and foremost about the countries of the Western Balkans because I know the situation with civil society and NGOs and especially what the situation is in the media. The media generally do not have money, especially small media, independent media and please keep an eye out and help with such demands if they come. I believe that this strengthens democracy in these countries, and they are likely to become members of the European Union among the first.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I want first of all to say thank you in three directions: thanks to the original Polish originators of the concept; thanks to the people who work within the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) to make it function; and, by no means least, thanks to our rapporteur Mr Grzyb, who has cooperated with all of us to put forward a very adequate and positive report. The flexible instrument that the EED provides to the European Union is of particular importance in a situation where an increasing number of countries is making it even more difficult for civil society organisations and non-governmental organisations to play the vital role that they should play in a democratic society. Through the EED we can support those organisations, and that is very important for the promotion of democracy. Lastly, I would add my voice to those colleagues who are calling upon Member States to help finance ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as shadow rapporteur for the own-initiative report, I have already had the opportunity to discuss with colleagues the potential goodness of this fund. There is, however, a small problem on which we should try to draw attention, because at the moment, this funding is being decided within a Bureau whose composition does not reflect the forces present in this Parliament. Therefore, with an amendment we have asked that the board that decides on the fund in question should include all the groups. The GUE/NGL, EFDD and the new ENF Groups are currently missing. I believe that if we want to demonstrate how democracy is to be done, we should first respect the composition of Parliament democratically, because otherwise we are making fun of it. I therefore expect this amendment to be supported, because that is why we support it, but also the credibility of this fund, which we will not be strongly critical of.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate my fellow Member Grzyb on his excellent work and welcome the report on the review of the EED, which demonstrates that we have succeeded in creating a tool that can respond flexibly, quickly and help where it is most needed. I am pleased that, on my initiative, ethnic and linguistic minorities appear in the text of this report as one of the priority target groups for this instrument. In this way, we can, among other things, provide effective assistance to minorities in Ukraine so that their communities can be strengthened at both local and national level. In the light of recent events, I also consider it very important that this instrument can also be used to protect religious freedom. It is the responsibility and responsibility of all of us to use this instrument to protect christians who are most persecuted.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I would like to raise three points. First of all, the establishment of the European Fund for Democracy is an important activity, because through the actions of the Fund there can be support for fundamental rights and other actions; : I am surprised that one hundred and eighty-six actions have been taken by this fund and none of these actions have dealt with the brutal violation of human rights in the countries of the Memorandum. We have a special report from our Parliament in March 2013 that says that the troika is violating human rights in Greece, Portugal, Ireland and Cyprus. I didn't see any Fund activity about it! Let us restore the functioning of democratic rights in the European Union and we are happy to deal with issues similar in other countries.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it gives me great pleasure on behalf of the Vice-President/High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to thank the rapporteur and everybody else who has been involved for the important work they have been doing in evaluating the activities of the European Endowment for Democracy (EED). It is very good to see that there is broad support across the plenary for the important work that the EED does and that the partnership we have with Parliament is very important: the work Members do on the Board and the way they take an active role in debating and spreading the work of the EED. I share the view expressed in the report that the Endowment plays a very important role by supporting democracy in our neighbourhood, and it has been a useful complement to the existing EU instruments. The EED has been proved, as you say in your evaluation, to be able to provide fast and flexible support in restrictive and repressive environments where often the EU cannot act efficiently to reach human rights defenders. The EED can also quickly deliver emergency funding and provide small grants as well as core and bridging funding to new democratic actors with limited capacity to apply for larger EU grants. I also believe that, whilst coordination and complementarity is key, the EED must remain independent and enjoy the latitude which is necessary to address the most challenging circumstances. In the report you make a number of suggestions regarding the ENP review. Let me assure you that the EED has been closely involved in discussions around the review of the neighbourhood policy and it has been given the opportunity to submit very concrete and pertinent recommendations based on feedback from the grantees. This has greatly contributed to ensuring that civil society in our neighbourhood has followed, and has been able to feed into, that debate. Taking into account the positive results of the EED evaluation and also the recommendation of your report to the European External Action Service and the Commission, we remain fully committed to supporting the work. Let me give you the good news that the Commission has just adopted a decision to grant an additional EUR 12 million for the next two years, 2016 to 2018. That is a considerable increase compared with the previous grant. Let me conclude by saying that it is important that the EED focuses on being complementary to the other instruments and tools to fund beneficiaries that are not eligible for other EU funding. I am very pleased with the pragmatic and very operational approach adopted by the EED and its focus on demand—driven assistance. We will continue to disseminate information about the EED among our staff and to use it to complement the support offered through the EU instrument. So thank you to the rapporteur and we are looking forward to continued good cooperation on this.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, July 9, 2015. (The sitting was suspended until polling time at 11.55 a.m. and resumed at 12.00 p.m.)

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, President Schulz promised us yesterday, and I talked about it with him last night, that we would have a one-minute silence in memory of the many, many children and civilians killed in Gaza last year.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Auken, I have just re-insured myself. The President has said that such a thing cannot be broken over the knee and that it is being considered and prepared. We are not going to do that now.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I just want to ask you how that decision stands against the decision taken on the spot yesterday to have a minute’s silence?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Madam President, thank you very well If you had just listened to me, you would have known why. You can contact me privately afterwards. I will no longer accept a speech in this direction and I will interrupt anyone who speaks again on this subject.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this is just a procedural issue after yesterday’s explanation of votes. Could the President explain what will happen after this debate with yesterday’s explanation of votes and today’s explanation of votes? Could you explain what will go on, please?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: After the votes, we will first begin with the remaining explanations of vote yesterday and then continue with today's.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I just wanted to ask whether it is true that the votes today will last more than two hours and whether it is not possible to postpone a vote until after the summer. Two hours of voting scheduled today!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Rübig, I would like to thank Mr Rübig for his Two hours is not the number I know. It is planned to last about an hour and a half. It has not been taken into account that we have already lost four minutes.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I wanted to inform my colleagues that there were major shortcomings in this report. You know that this text relates to the standards of radioactivity in food in the event of a nuclear accident.  We invited the experts from Euratom, who did not want to come. We had asked the Commission to give us the names of the experts and their links of interest. She told us that she could not do that. Now, the scenarios are very important and the standards very high, so I ask you to be very critical about... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I want to propose that we take the Reda report next and that all other votes are postponed until September. With your permission, I would like to explain why. It is unreasonable for you to have 25 minutes of voting on a Tuesday and to have scheduled two hours on a Thursday of own initiative reports and resolutions, none of which are time-critical. Mr President, the services should arrange our voting more carefully. We should have more on a Tuesday and less on a Thursday. I therefore propose that we take the Reda report next and postpone the rest until September. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Fox, I would like to thank Mr Fox for his I shall deal with your request. But I would now like to reject once and for all, in all its forms, that the services are responsible for this planning. Firstly, the agenda is made by the Conference of Presidents and by you. Secondly, you can see this from today's voting list: the length of the votes is largely determined by the number of split votes requested by the political groups. Since we do not employ clairvoyants in the services, it is not possible to pre-plan how many split votes and roll-call votes will be requested. So the whole thing, the length of the vote, is influenced by the House. You can criticize administration, but not unplanned administrative bashing! (Parliament rejected the request to postpone the vote)

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask that the vote on the Commission's work programme be postponed to September, with a view to trying to reach an agreement with a higher level of consensus and with greater representation of the shared and balanced priorities of the various political groups.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Guerrero. I assume that you made this request on behalf of your group. Then the conditions under Article 190(1) are met, and I will allow a statement in favour and a counter-speech on the request.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – (microphone off) …importance of the issue, and already in January we suffered a defeat in the vote on the Work Programme for 2015. I think we want to prevent that happening once again, and therefore it would be good to have a bit more time to find consensus in the Chamber for this important topic, so I support shifting it to September.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, having chaired the negotiations between the groups on this matter, it is a great shame that we walked away from that negotiating table on Monday night, with the S&D and EPP both agreeing that they were substantially there with a joint text, and then one group refusing to sign that deal. So, having been there, I do not know what more will be gained by coming back in September.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to table the following oral amendment to Amendment No 2. Paragraph 9a would look like this: 'It expresses its concern at the intense arms trade of EU Member States with several countries in the region; requests the Council in this regard to verify that the Common Position of the European Union on arms export control has not been breached and to take measures to ensure that all Member States fully respect that Common Position'.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, a very small amendment: in the second line of paragraph 7, the word ‘for’ is deleted and instead, the words ‘with willing’ are inserted, so that the text reads ‘Calls on the Vice-President/High Representative to develop proposals for cooperation with willing European neighbours based on the model ...’. I hope that everyone can accept this.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to add at the end of this paragraph: ‘Believes that, where artists’ and performers’ exclusive making-available rights are transferred, there should be an unwaivable right to remuneration subject to collective management.’ Essentially this is so that artists and performers can actually receive remuneration when their content, which would usually be music, is streamed over the internet.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think the Chair is doing a brilliant job this afternoon, trying to make this happen as fast as possible. So presuming that they do not want to spend the whole of Thursday afternoon in this Chamber, I would just ask everyone to raise their hands when the President asks for a vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Vielen Dank, Herr College Sarvamaa. Sie haben was gut!

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to table an oral amendment, in order to update the text, since the elections in Burundi have taken place. I therefore propose to replace the words "is gravely concerned" with the word "condemns".

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I just want to invite colleagues to support two oral amendments, because yesterday two important decisions were taken and we have to include them in our resolution: ‘6a. Regrets that the UN Security Council, which has the primary responsibility for maintenance of international peace and security, failed to pass a resolution commemorating the Srebrenica genocide. This is especially regrettable as the International Court of Justice – the UN primary judicial body – has determined that the crimes committed in Srebrenica were a genocideʼ. This is the first oral amendment. The second one: ‘Strongly welcomes the decision of the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina taken unanimously to proclaim 11 July as a day of mourning in Bosnia and Herzegovina’. Please vote in favour.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the vote. I would like to thank everyone. (Applause) We have now done it in 84 minutes. And if we had saved the four minutes with the uprising, we would have come out at 80 minutes.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, yesterday we did not vote on TTIP. Yesterday we voted on the parameters being set down by the Parliament for the negotiations. We outlined our requirements – our red lines, as it were. I voted against ISDS, but the Parliament voted for an alternative – to replace it with a better system. This is a real improvement, but it did not go far enough for me. So, while I voted against ISDS, I abstained on the final vote. I did not want to support a text that is not crystal clear. However, the text contained many positive things, such as strong statements on workers’ rights, on maintaining EU standards in the areas of food, chemicals, labour law etc., and – crucially – the exclusion of public services from the deal. Those were all strong messages that I wanted to send to the Commission. In the final analysis, if we get a good TTIP I will support it. If we do not, I will not. That decision will not be taken for some time yet. It may even be years away. In the meantime, I said ‘no’ to ISDS, but I also sent a clear message to the Commission on other crucial areas.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the trade agreement between the European Union and the United States of America. I consider it very important, as do the 62% of Europeans who voted for it in opinion polls. A number of myths have sproached around this agreement. I believe that the Commission is negotiating in the sense of the mandate it has received from the Member States, and the European Union will certainly not have to sacrifice its standards in the areas of data protection, health, food safety and the environment.  As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Culture and Education, it is essential to me that this agreement will not affect the european Union's ability to provide subsidies and financial support to cultural sectors.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this material, i supported, say, the constraints that the European Parliament gives the Commission. I believe that any free trade agreement is always beneficial to the economic prosperity of the partners who conclude it. The debate that has been conducted here and has been very instructive, I have listened very carefully to it, unfortunately it has been burdened with many ideological clichés and has not always been conducted on specific aspects of the negotiations. I am glad that the material finally passed, that the European Parliament supported the resolution on TTIP. I will wait for the Commission to negotiate the final form of this Treaty, and I am ready to support it. Of course the detail is important to me, I will wait for specific details. There is also some concern in my region, for example in the Pilsen Region, of American gold miners in šumava, so all these details need to be further discussed.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted with conviction against the Lange resolution, for a fundamental reason called democracy. Yesterday we heard a lesson in democracy from Alexis Tsípras, Manolis Glezos, about how important it is to respect popular sovereignty at European and national level.  Well, TTIP is the negation of all this. It is a Trojan horse of multinationals, through mechanisms such as regulatory cooperation or the new ISDS formula, invented by the Schulz-Malmström compromise. Above all, the resolution that was adopted yesterday ignores the concerns that activists and researchers have raised on the issue of the precautionary principle, on the issue of rights and jobs, on the issue of health and agri-food production. There are many reasons to say "OXI" at TTIP. It is no coincidence that I am the first signatory of an amendment, which unfortunately was rejected, calling for the negotiations to be suspended. I believe that yesterday the European Parliament made a serious mistake.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report on TTE because Parliament cannot legitimise a treaty which, in its conception, in its elaboration, in its content and objectives is an attack on each and every social right, without which democracy cannot even be talked about. It is not time for vagueness, of confusing public opinion with phrases full of good intentions that disguise the political content of this agreement. Free trade already exists between the European Union and the United States, and the remaining tariff barriers are necessary to keep sectors as critical as agriculture alive. TYC is actually the excuse for institutionalizing the primacy of large capital over workers. It is the large capital that wants to intervene, have an opinion and even denounce the recognition of labour rights and environmental and economic standards that may diminish their benefits, forcing States to pay fines for defending the common good. Democracy cannot submit to markets. Listen to the people, who have already shouted "no!" to the ATCI.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we voted against this document which gives legitimacy to the negotiations on the free trade agreement between the European Union and the United States, known as TCI. And we have done so because we do not like the secrecy with which the negotiations are taking place and because we consider the treaty to be basically a deregulation project. Legal deregulation, with the imposition of private arbitration courts that will operate outside public courts and thus create parallel justice. Deregulation of work, because independent reports warn of the massive loss of jobs and the deterioration of working conditions. Environmental and health deregulation, because we fear that outdated and dangerous energy options such as fracking will be imposed and that American food products, with much lower production sanitary standards than our own, will reach our markets. At a time when the European Union is going through a major economic and social crisis – we were here yesterday debating the situation in Greece - and while the European single market is not yet a reality, TIC is a forward flight from a runaway, unsustainable and socially unacceptable economic model.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, when I had to vote on the infamous TTIP on the EU-US Free Trade Agreement, I imagined a European family farm, ideally Hungarian, where healthy, high-quality food is produced, livestock farming, crop production, farmers live in dignity, consumers are healthy and satisfied. All of a time, the whole company, the farmers, and the consumers are starting to demand that, but that's not what they want, but they want to bring in frozen, genetically modified chicken and other food from the United States instead. Having concluded that this is completely unrealistic and harmful and obviously serves the interests of some very small group, I voted against, of course, and I propose that the Hungarian people object to this outrageous, secretly prepared draft agreement.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – I voted against this report, firstly, because in democracy decisions affecting most people are neither opaque nor secret, nor should their consequences be concealed, but also because of the content of the treaty itself, which poses enormous risks to employment and working conditions, as many reports by independent experts say; because it opens the door to the privatization of our public services, necessary for the welfare of citizens;  because it puts at risk our environmental standards, our field, our agriculture; because it is a treaty that opens the door to the interests of multinationals being all over the interests of citizens. When we talk about trade barriers, when TTE talks about trade barriers: for a multinational a trade barrier is high wages, a trade barrier is collective agreements, a trade barrier is labour rights and social rights. Because we're with social rights, we don't want TTE.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, already because of its 50% share of the global social benefits, the European Union must be proactive in shaping them at the time of the creation of new global economic rules. It is irresponsible at first to reject the challenges of change, considering that everything will remain the same. Instead, we need to constructively, without mystifying, contribute to the content of TTIP and clearly inform citizens.  I talked to negotiators from both sides, read negotiating positions in the safe room, wrote inquiries to the Commission, tabled amendments. The paper delivers results because Parliament's report adopted amendments calling for visa waivers, the retention of our food safety standards, energy security, but also facilitation of access to sources of funding for our small and medium-sized businesses so that they can be set out towards the US market in the first place.  We have a good text that if it is converted into TTIP content can develop a model of economic partnership for the 21st century.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – I voted against TTE, because I think it is a clear attack on democracy. In democracy you can't negotiate in secret. Citizens need to know what we're playing with this agreement. It is essential to put light and stenographers to the ATCI. I also voted against it because I think it is a very clear attack on popular sovereignty. It is a very clear attack on our social rights, on our labour rights, on public services. It is essential to build a wall against the Trojan horse that they are trying to get into Europe with the free trade agreement. And it is also unforgivable that someone in this House can vote in favour of justly creating extrajudicial courts operating in Europe against the sovereignty of the people. We'll stop him on the streets and stop him in Parliament. And above all, to the ATCI, Dracula's strategy: to give it the air, to give it the light, to know it by people. And it won't pass.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, first of all a little clarity. We did not approve TTIP yesterday. Yesterday, Parliament gave the European Commission its recommendations for the continuation of negotiations with the United States. If the Commission does not respect the priorities that we have made clear, we will also be prepared to vote against the agreement.  I believe that the report we have voted on responds in a timely manner to the concerns of european citizens, which I consider to be absolutely legitimate in view of the lack of transparency with which the negotiations began. We have put it in black and white that the agreement must lead to the recognition of greater protection of geographical indications and must improve the access of our agri-food products to the American market and must not undermine European social and environmental standards, as well as having to guarantee a high degree of consumer protection. As far as ISDS is concerned, the compromise reached remains too ambiguous, not providing for a firm rejection of the inclusion of ISDS mechanisms in the TTIP, which could give foreign investors more procedural rights than domestic investors and jeopardise the sovereign rights of the European Union, its Member States and regional and local authorities, referring to often opaque international arbitration tribunals.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted against this motion yesterday for the simple reason that the improvements to the so-called arbitration procedures do not really solve the problem. The situation is that the so-called arbitrators are not bound by any law, but explicitly only by their common sense. This is a throwback to what we had in the Middle Ages. This is a lawless state of affairs. Even in the Middle Ages we had the law. The second point is that, in so-called regulatory cooperation, we give international corporations a very important say in the drafting of new laws. This, too, is a major erosion of democracy. One cannot agree to such a proposal as a democrat and as a representative of the rule of law.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I did not support the TTIP report for two main reasons: my country is one of the few people discriminated against by the US as regards visa policy. The text we voted on calls only for political pressure on the US on the issue, but without a concrete and clear recommendation for a fair solution and the abolition of visas for all European citizens before the possible entry into force of TTIP. Disproportionality in this area means the possibility of limiting the economic interests of the United States against my country Bulgaria.  The investor-state dispute settlement mechanism is the other aspect that I do not approve of in the text finally adopted. My country Bulgaria is one of the few Member States in the European Union with such a mechanism signed more than twenty years ago. It is time for this degrading tool to be removed. Until this is achieved, I will not support a report that does not defend this position. I will also not support an agreement with such clauses.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have, of course, supported the TTIP and I would like to explain a few aspects. Firstly, I believe that free trade, of course, contributes to the development of the economy and the development of jobs. It is clear that this value, which is linked to our most important partner, that is, the US, with which we certainly share a number of other values, must also be redeemed somewhere. That is why I was not very happy when, for example, a protected agricultural designation of origin would not be subject to such protection as, for example, on the soil of the European area. Nevertheless, I believe that free trade should have a chance – despite these restrictions in some other commodities or areas – to develop the economy. I therefore supported this proposal with my vote on the mandate for the TTIP negotiations.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, I voted against, of course, on the document allowing for a free trade agreement between the EU and the US. That is, of course, because if one takes seriously the fact that we directly elected Members represent the interests of the public, then they could only vote 'no', because whoever voted 'yes' represents the interests of multinationals. The two economies are not in the same league, Europe can only be a loser. It is a great desiment that small and medium-sized European enterprises come to the fore, 87% of them produce for the domestic market, the internal market. I wonder if they're going to make it to America. No, american companies with capital-strong, aggressive marketing are taking the opportunity away from here. And, by the way, it is a misdirection that the dispute settlement mechanism has now been resolved. It's not a private court, it's a vague proposal, we don't know what court allows these companies to sue sovereign states for lost profits.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yesterday’s vote was not for or against TTIP; that vote will only come when the negotiations conclude. This was our chance to show what we really think about TTIP, and to tell the public who filled our inboxes with their concerns how we will respond to them in TTIP. This is the best tool to influence the negotiations, and this week we have sent a clear signal that we want a good TTIP which excludes our public services, however they are provided, organised or financed (including the NHS), which upholds and strengthens worker rights and our environmental standards and which ensures democratic scrutiny. For Labour MEPs, this can only be guaranteed with full rejection of separate courts and rights for foreign investors to sue governments. That was not achieved yesterday, and therefore Labour MEPs, including myself, voted against the resolution and will continue to defend democracy and the right to regulate.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, unlike most of the people who have just spoken, I have no problems at all with the principle of free trade. I think it has been the greatest advance of the last half-century. It has raised millions of people throughout the world in agrarian, as well as developed, economies. It has cut global poverty – extreme poverty – by two-thirds since 1990. But TTIP is not only about free trade. Part of it will involve uncontroversially good things like mutual product recognition. But it also allows corporations to erect barriers to entry to take control of the regulatory regime in order to make life harder for their smaller rivals – and therefore, by implication, for consumers. I do have to say one thing, though, to opponents of TTIP on the Left of this Chamber. The things that they are objecting to – the resolution of disputes mechanism, the contracting-out of public services – are not introduced by TTIP: they are intrinsic properties of the European Union. You should be honest about the origin of what it is you do not like. It is not something that suddenly becomes objectionable because it involves the United States. If you have a democratic objection – and I can see why you might – then it is really the entire EU you have your problem with.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted for this report. Europe needs the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership with its natural partner, the United States, for growth, jobs and development.  After two years of negotiations, let's conclude this treaty! The transatlantic partnership will lead to a 28% increase in the European Union's exports to the United States. It will remove obstacles that SMEs have when they want to enter the US market, such as export licences, labelling requirements or certification procedures. Customs duties and customs controls will be abolished. That means more trade, more money, more jobs.  In addition, the United States has cheap energy, and Europe has expensive energy. The partnership will liberalise trade, which will lead to cheapening energy and greater geopolitical independence from the Russian Federation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted against yesterday, because we need to find a balance between protecting sensitive interests and promoting the interests of the European Union. I would like to stress that an ambitious agreement has potential benefit for both the EU and the USA, but some red lines were not negotiable, especially on workers’ conditions and health standards. The main red lines, from my point of view, are: no lowering of EU standards on consumer safety or conditions for workers; no hormone—treated beef on our plates; no genetically-modified organisms; no meat cleaned using chlorine; no reducing of data protection in TTIP; no investor—state dispute system. It would be very dangerous to ignore the opinion of the European citizens in the process of the preparation of the agreement. The price of such an attitude may be very high. In 2012, the European Parliament refused to give its consent to the conclusion of the Anti—Counterfeiting Trade Agreement. If the final product does not satisfy the European Parliament, the result may be similar.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na Comhpháirtíochta Trádála agus Infheistíochta Tras-Atlantaí, agus mar a dúirt daoine cosúil le Jude Kirton-Darling agus Marian Harkin, níl aon chomhaontú saorthrádála againn go fóill, ach beidh le cúnamh Dé, agus anois tá bunús againn chun dul ar aghaidh leis an idirbheartaíocht.  Dar ndóigh bhí imní ar a lán daoine, agus is maith go raibh seans acu é seo a rá anseo sa Pharlaimint. Tá imní orainn in Éirinn go háirithe faoi chúrsaí talmhaíochta, cúrsaí mairteola ach go háirithe, agus caithfimid súil ghéar a choimeád ar sin. Agus ag deireadh an lae, beimid ag vótáil ina fhabhar nó ina choinne, go háirithe ag cur cúrsaí mairteola san áireamh.  Freisin, bhí daoine ag caint faoin gcóras réiteach conspóide idir infheisteoirí agus an stát, an ISDS mar a thugtar air. Tá dul chun cinn maith déanta air sin agus tá súil agam gur féidir linn teacht ar chomhréiteach nó comhghéilleadh ag deireadh na dála.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this has all been a bit of a mess from start to finish, has it not? We had the vote cancelled last time because of the sheer number of amendments. We then cancelled the four-hour debate, rescheduled it for a busier time, squashed it into an unrealistic timescale and prevented any interaction between speakers. Then we still voted on the same amendments, because that pretext was no more than an excuse to stifle debate. Millions of European citizens made their voices heard on TTIP and we chose in this place to squash debate rather than hold it. I believe that is a disgrace. We then watched as a string of amendments to make the text less bad were voted down. We saw the amendments to remove ISDS ignored altogether, because the President of Parliament chose to ignore the rules and to consider a different amendment first. Well, welcome to the European Union. If you want to know why UKIP believes these structures are not fit for purpose, this behaviour here is not the exception but, sadly, the rule. I would vote for free trade but TTIP is not free trade. It is a corporatist trade deal, and that is why I voted no.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, emotions have been running high over the Lange report – understandably, because TTIP has the ability to transform our economies. Whether the transformation will be for better or for worse will depend on whether the concerns of the citizens and the SMEs are taken into account. This report is about setting clear guidelines for the Commission on the negotiations, and better effort should have been made to explain this to the public. Whilst I welcome the overwhelming engagement shown by many of my constituents, many of them thought we were actually voting on the final deal. We are still many miles away from that. Let us be clear. It has always been a priority for me to ensure key protections on public services, labour and environmental safeguards, and clear language that dismisses the use of private courts for investment disputes. TTIP offers an opportunity to set global standards on health, labour and environment and to set them high.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) negotiations could only be negative. Amendments have been adopted which seriously endanger the health of citizens, reducing their protections in many respects, amendments that crush SMEs in favour of large multinationals, which, moreover, by having the benefits reserved for them by the ISDS clause, will be able to impose themselves on states with the threat of long and expensive legal odysseys. The amendments voted on are the result of pressure from lobbies, which, as puppeteers, have pulled the strings on both sides of this pointless treaty that protects strong powers to the detriment of the people of Europe. Voting in favour of these recommendations is, in my view, a crime against the fundamental principles on which the European Union is founded.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this atCI report to show my rejection of this association, as resounding as the United Left's position against TTE, against an agreement seeking to put democracy, public services and the rights and freedoms of people at the service of multinationals. The European Parliament, instead of clearly rejecting an agreement designed by and for the benefit of large corporations, denouncing the obscurantism of negotiations, demanding transparency and public participation, and defending the sovereignty and interests of the social majority, gives this report a full backing point to TTE and current negotiations. Moreover, the report, which was to have been voted on a month ago but whose vote was delayed by unilateral decision by President Schulz at the risk of rejection, gives the go-ahead to the establishment of the arbitral tribunals (ISDS), thus ignoring the majority rejection that these courts raise and which was reflected in the european Commission's consultation in which 97% of the participants were against this mechanism.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is Sinn Fein’s position that the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership being negotiated by the EU and US will have disastrous consequences for democracy, the environment, labour rights and public services. I voted in favour of several amendments tabled by my group, the GUE/NGL, and the Greens. These ranged from outright rejection of the TTIP project to amendments aimed at protecting workers’ rights, public services, and the environment. On the critical issue of the ISDS – investor-state dispute settlement – there were two key compromise amendments, 117 (proposed by rapporteur Lange) and 118 (proposed by the Greens). I voted against Amendment 117 and in favour of Amendment 118. Amendment 117 aims to create a ‘new’ ISDS along the lines of EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström’s recent proposal, which includes public hearings and an appeals mechanism. The proposal still retained the fundamental element of investors being able to sue states over public policy. The Greens’ compromise amendment calls on the Commission to reject the inclusion of ISDS in TTIP as other remedies are already available.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'The promotion of free trade between countries in the EU, as well as with the US, is a good thing. After all, economics does not necessarily have to be a zero-sum game in which one party loses and the other party wins. It can also be a win-win. TTIP, however, is a paragon of backroom politics. A gigantic treaty is being slashed over the heads of the citizens and the consequences are unknown. According to the European Commission, TTIP will benefit the European economy, but the Commission's analyses often lack a time horizon and decent econometric models. The US TUFTS University is already predicting the loss of 450,000 jobs in the European Union, and it is not alone. Academics from the British Royal Economic Society say: 'Ideology obscures reality'. Barring the arguments relating to public health, the environment, ISDS and transparency, it is already clear what lies ahead. At the micro level, SMEs will bear the brunt of TTIP. At the macro level, the northern Member States in particular will be disadvantaged by this Convention. As if the currency union with its unprecedented north-south transfers was not enough!

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. After a thorough discussion of the subject matter, I feel strengthened in my original feeling that I cannot support TTIP. First of all, I deeply regret that parliamentary control – one of the most important powers of this House – is being left out during the negotiations. The fact that we MEPs are only given a limited and incomplete insight into the negotiating texts is an unacceptable democratic deficit. I also categorically reject the use of extraordinary investor-state dispute settlement procedures (ISDS). Indeed, there are no compelling reasons why an ISDS process between sophisticated justice systems is necessary. That is why I have tabled an amendment explicitly rejecting the inclusion of ISDS in the TTIP. Finally, I have economic concerns. According to the study commissioned by the Commission, the projected additional growth of 0.5 percent will in fact only occur in a very optimistic scenario and will not be fully effective until 2027. Until then, and down to a single year, we would have an average growth rate of just 0.041 percentage points per year. For these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The economic partnership is not a partnership because the Member States would be the big losers while the United States of America would be the main beneficiaries. It would further reduce the economic sovereignty of the Member States and create a free trade area clearly unfavourable to the Union and its nationals. Being opposed to the transatlantic partnership, I therefore logically decided to vote against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I vote against the negotiating terms of a TTIP because I believe that the way the European institutions operate leads to an impasse. The treatment of the Greek crisis is the pathetic manifestation of Europe's lack of political leadership. In his time, Victor Hugo dreamed of a development of trade between the United States of America and the United States of Europe. In other words, he dreamed of a TTIP. And I share his dream. But we are still a long way from the United States of Europe. And that is why I am expressing a negative vote today. The serious situation we are going through calls us to lucidity.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The world’s biggest trade and investment partnership agreement is a big step towards deeper and more effective cooperation between the European Union and the United States of America. It is a good tool to make Europe stronger economically and geopolitically, to ensure jobs and prosperity for Europeans and Americans. However the agreement itself is not an inevitable success. We must be stubborn enough to make sure that the content of the agreement is based on our values, reflects our principles and requirements for a smart TTIP. Our standards cannot be lowered. This is why it is crucially important to adopt a strong European Parliament resolution where the interests of Europeans are well represented and which would help to achieve a desirable final outcome. I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that there are lots of concerns raised by our people regarding this agreement. They do not feel secure and so far there is no clear confidence. Thus, the lively public debate and transparent negotiations on TTIP are necessary. Our citizens should be better informed what is happening behind closed doors.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I did not support the resolution on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations because today's vote should have allowed the European Parliament to send a strong signal to influence the ongoing negotiations between the Commission and the United States. The compromise amendment on the Private Arbitration Mechanism (ISDS) remained unclear as to the wording of the rejection of this mechanism. This ambiguity about replacing the ISDS with a new system was not satisfactory.  In addition, the resolution inadequately protected both public services and the quality of European technical, social and environmental standards. For these reasons, I voted against this report, which leaves too many uncertainties about the demands of the European Parliament in the negotiations for a possible transatlantic free trade agreement.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A proper EU agreement with the US could enable industry to benefit from the market of 850 million consumers and increase its share of EU gross domestic product by up to 20% by 2020.  However, it must be acknowledged that the ambiguous conclusions of the impact study do not allow for a clear benefit of the agreement to the EU economy. It is important that transparency in the negotiations is ensured, which leads to an ambitious but balanced agreement, the benefits of which can be felt by all EU countries, to promote competition and to eliminate non-tariff barriers to trade. I support the calls for negotiators to ensure a high level of protection for EU consumers, their data, health and security, and to prevent social, fiscal and environmental dumping. The EU-US agreement should remove existing restrictions on trade in oil and liquefied gas, enabling the EU to increase energy security and reduce the cost of energy resources. It is proposed to agree in the negotiations on a specific list of sensitive agricultural products and industrial goods which would not be subject to trade liberalisation or a long transitional period. Mutual recognition of public health standards is also important. The integration of EU and US e-commerce and financial services markets must not affect EU data protection rules and not become the subject of concessions by negotiators.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The Lange Report on TTIP is an own-initiative report that has no legislative power whatsoever. It is merely a wish list of how the Committee on International Trade would like to amend TTIP. I promised my constituents that I would vote against TTIP on the basis that trade policy should be decided by our own democratic government and not the European Union. I also promised to vote to exclude the ISDS mechanism from TTIP. The voting list on the report contained about 126 separate votes. I did not vote on these amendments because I do not wish to be party to an alternative version of TTIP suggested by Parliament when I do not accept the EU’s democratic legitimacy to legislate on this or any other matter in the first place. I would have voted on Amendments 40 and 27 to exclude ISDS but Martin Schulz, President of the European Parliament, allowed an amendment to be voted on first that deleted these amendments from the voting list – despite protests from Members present. Therefore no MEPs were able to vote to exclude ISDS, but I did vote against the report as a whole in the final vote.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. One of the stated objectives of the TTIP proponents is to "converge" EU and US regulations. However, the United States refuses to ratify the main labour conventions, the Kyoto Protocol on global warming, the Convention on Biodiversity, the Unesco Conventions on Cultural Diversity, etc. In almost all cases, their regulations are less restrictive than those in Europe.  In fact, "convergence" suggests that the United States - which, unlike the EU, fiercely defends its interests - will seek to impose its own regulations on "partners" whom it tends to regard as their vassals. There is no question of accepting the low-cost products of North American agribusiness: hormone-fed beef, lactic acid-sprayed meat carcasses, bleach-washed poultry, meats with ractopamine hydrochlorinated, GMOs, animals fed with animal meal, products containing pesticides and other toxic additives banned from us. However, the Lange report establishes no red lines, no safeguards; it even validates the odious investor-state dispute settlement mechanism (ISDS), i.e. the "arbitration tribunals" that will allow American firms to subject our states to their diktat.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The PS beacons were and will remain very clear: - NO to the ISDS mechanism, because the European and American legal systems are perfectly equipped to ensure investment protection; - NO to the privatisation of the public service. We demand the total and unconditional preservation of public services of general interest and reject negative lists of liberalisation of services; - NO to social and environmental standards that would not be ambitious or binding;   - NO to regulatory cooperation, this mechanism which consists of making multinationals and other industrial lobbies a quasi-co-legislator and which leads to the short, medium and long-term lowering of our European standards (social, environmental, food security, etc.); - NO to abandoning the precautionary principle, data protection or cultural diversity. Despite all our amendments, they have not been respected, particularly with regard to the ISDS. We have therefore voted against and will remain extremely vigilant for the further negotiations. In any case, our Socialist delegation will be uncompromising and reject any free trade agreement that could endanger the general interest of European citizens.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. There has been significant progress on isDS that opens the door to a new improved system (Amendment No 117), but we abstained in the vote by not taking the expected steps on regulatory cooperation.  The text does not clearly define those regulations and sectors excluded from any negotiation. We hope that this will be clarified over the coming months, with full guarantees of our political rights and what European legislation stands for. We the following support Amendments Nos 93, 19 and 72. US and European standards are very different in the areas listed: pesticides, disruptors, food security, animal welfare, transparency in clinical trials... We understand that cooperation is necessary to remove barriers to trade, such as excessive bureaucracy, but we must not jeopardize what the EU is an example and a reference for. The agricultural and food sectors are key to ensuring food security, but they have also been strategic within speculative exchange dynamics and investment funds. Its liberalization is evident in the above and in the latest reforms. These sectors and the protection of our standards are red lines for UPyD and the vast majority of EU citizens, which is why we support them.

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: Written. 'TTIP is an important treaty for the development of transatlantic trade relations and that is why I support the negotiations. However, they are far from complete. A fair assessment is only possible on the basis of facts and the final result of the negotiations. This resolution sends an important signal to the European Commission about what the European Parliament thinks is important and what concerns exist. There are clear demands. We do not want to lower standards for, for example, the environment or food safety, no hormone meat on the European market, no chloric chickens and no genetically modified products. Commissioner Malmström has repeatedly guaranteed this to the EP. European citizens' and the environment protection laws will not be sacrificed for free trade. Harmonisation of standards and standards will only take place when they are already very close together. Investment is important to our economy. Providing a good investment environment, clear and reliable regulation and fair investment protection is important. The reform plans proposed by Commissioner Malmström provide good starting points for reforming the ISDS system and countering existing weaknesses. It clearly ens sets out the right of Member States to develop legislation. These proposals must be well reflected in the final outcome of the negotiations.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. The EU and the US are the world's largest trading partners, trading €2 billion worth of goods and services every day. The trade and investment agreement will stimulate growth and jobs. We call for a balanced agreement while respecting the highest social, environmental and health standards. That is a basic condition for us. The main guiding principle is that companies on both sides can fight with the same weapons, and at the same time ensure that certain standards are not met that are important to us. Parliament must keep the last word on what can and cannot be done. A clear list of services that can compete in each other's markets, excluding services of general interest such as education and health, must therefore be drawn up. In addition, we are sending a clear signal to the negotiators: investors must be protected when investing abroad, but the arbitration mechanism must be commemorated. Such a mechanism can only be provided that democracy is not compromised and as a stepping stone to an international arbitration court in the long term. We now expect the European Commission, which is conducting the negotiations on behalf of Europe, to follow our recommendations. We will monitor that closely.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Written. We have this week adopted parliament's opinion on the TTIP negotiations. I have voted in favour – it is NOW that we have the opportunity to set the standard for more than 800 million people on both sides of the Atlantic, whether it be the environment, consumer issues or working conditions. Standards that China and other emerging countries will also have to deal with. This is a historic opportunity. At the same time, we can create the jobs and growth that we need here in the aftermath of the crisis. The critics are nervous – I would compare it to when we expanded eastwards. But Poland has tripled their GDP, while Denmark has increased its exports in ten years from 10 to 19 billion kroner – it is a win-win situation for both parties.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The Lange report on the transatlantic treaty is a scandalous attack on democracy and demonstrates the non-representation of this Parliament. While 97% of European citizens expressed concern about TTIP, MEPs decided to override it to satisfy obscure interests.  While some courageous MEPs obviously supported the halting of the TTIP negotiations, the majority of the EPP, PES and ALDE groups managed to get the report adopted.  I have also tabled two motions for a resolution on this treaty, in particular for culture and education and for the consideration of animal welfare. I have supported others with my ENL colleagues in Parliament.  This treaty is questionable on several points and this document is a sham because it does not set any red lines for the European Commission on this treaty.  It will undermine all our French and European agriculture and it does not set any constraints on the alignment of American standards with European standards.  Worse, any multinational through the dispute settlement mechanism will be able to legally turn against a state if a standard does not suit it.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Lange report analysing the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP).  This Europe, after the disaster of the single currency, wants to impose an agreement that will go against the economies of our territories, against our agriculture, against a Venetian and Italian market model based on the quality of our excellence, which risks being wiped out by american multinationals ready to usurp our "know-how". With my no, I say no to TTIP, to Europe and to its treaties, I say no to a monstrous and unsuccessful system in which it is the strong powers that manipulate the Commission, the ECB and the Monetary Fund as puppets, leaving the citizens alone to face the consequences of these horrors.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system.  In short, because it requires an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote globally the values and principles we share with the US, making it clear that we will only support an TIC that regulates trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP decision that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the rejecting of the much-debated ISDS mechanism from the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. The european Hungary has taken a clear, positive position on all the public health issues that are important to the european union, the prohibition of hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's recommendations, which I supported last Wednesday, are aimed at the European Commission's TTIP negotiators. This gave us the green light for further talks, but at the same time gave very clear directions and warnings. The final decision will be taken by Members when the final version of the agreement is validated, but we are most of the time already known today about most of the concerns raised in public. I would like to stress, in this context, that the priorities of the agreement remain, in particular, the removal of bureaucratic barriers and customs duties, the relaxation of online trade, the unification of enterprise legislation and the simplification of procedures for the provision of services. Of course, there are areas in the EU that are particularly sensitive, such as agriculture, public services, consumer rights, environmental and labour standards, cultures, etc. Therefore, for example, it is not the first time that the commission  The AGRI Committee has given very clear guidelines that we cannot and cannot afford to lower food safety standards, because European agricultural policy has certain specificities that cannot be compared to the farming practices in the US. The agri guidelines are clearly set out in the proposal for an EP resolution in points J and K, in which it clearly states that the TTIP trade agreement must not jeopardise the current quality standards of European agricultural products and their future improvement, while preserving the European agricultural model and ensuring its economic and social viability.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Esteemed colleagues, I voted for the resolution because it highlights the potential of TTIP, but also warns what Parliament will not accept. This resolution is not to state whether we are in or against TTIP, but whether we, as a democratically elected institution, have a position on the course of negotiations. Socialists and Democrats know what they want from the agreement: economic growth and employment while preserving standards for protecting workers' rights, the environment, food security, health and democracy.  At TTIP, we do not want ISDS and we do not want to undermine the principles of democracy and sovereignty of Member States in organising critical public services such as health, education, water supply and others. The resolution is a way of clearly telling negotiators from the European Commission: "Gentlemen, these are the terms and positions of Parliament representing half a billion people who are first citizens and only then consumers. As you negotiate, remember that at the end of the negotiations you must come before us and ask for our approval for the negotiated."

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. At the previous session in Strasbourg, President Martin Schultz tried to prevent MEPs from voting on amendments opposing the transatlantic treaty. The Peoples of Europe and parliamentary representation are waking up.  Is the vote likely to displease? The solution is simple: no vote. A masterful lesson in democracy by elites disconnected from the difficulties of their peoples. This transatlantic treaty is dangerous in principle and the freedom offered to the European Commission as part of its negotiating mandate can only reinforce my concerns. This text carries with it a real and serious threat against French agriculture. In addition, we have no guarantees that our standards will be preserved. An alignment of these with North American designs is unacceptable. So I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is Sinn Fein’s position that the TTIP being negotiated by the EU and United States will have disastrous consequences for democracy in Member States, the environment, labour rights and public services. This report endorsed the TTIP negotiations, which have been carried out in secret. I voted in favour of several amendments which ranged from an outright rejection of the TTIP project to protection of workers’ rights, food and water standards, public services, and the environment. I voted in favour of the joint GUE-NGL/EFDD/Greens amendment calling for a ‘positive list’ approach when dealing with services. On the critical issue of the ISDS – investor-state dispute settlement – there were two key compromise amendments, 117 (proposed by rapporteur Lange) and 118 (proposed by the Greens). I voted against Amendment 117 and in favour of Amendment 118. Amendment 117 aims to replace the ISDS system with a ‘new system’ which still retained the fundamental element of investors being able to sue states over public policy that may curtail corporate profits, which I believe is unacceptable. On the other hand, Amendment 118 called on the Commission to reject the inclusion of ISDS in TTIP as other remedies are already available.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the European Union to try to conclude a good trade agreement with the United States, which is our main economic partner, which can bring immense benefits to all parties involved. I am also convinced that the compromise presented by President Schulz on the issue of ISDS is a solution that will make it possible to resolve the problems related to this issue.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Any criticism of ultra-liberal unique thinking cannot be accused of populism. With regard to the TTIP negotiations, a debate has developed in society which has raised many concerns, not only among NGOs, trade unions, farmers, producers and various trade associations, but also among ordinary citizens. And we have a duty to listen to and give voice to these demands.  As the S&D Group we have achieved important economic, social and environmental results, but not the most important one: a clear no to ISDS. That is why I voted no.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission is currently negotiating with the United States the terms of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP).  The European Parliament warns the Commission on a number of points to clarify, without clearly opposing this agreement which we have always fought against. It is in this context that MEPs recommend excluding culture, education and social protection systems from the scope of negotiations. They call for a ban on companies taking Member States to a private court but tout the benefits of public international arbitration. They call for greater food transparency and the exclusion of imports of agricultural products from third countries from the treaty, without addressing the danger that the U.S. food industry poses to farmers and consumers. They want to fight against all forms of dumping, but the agreement will lead to social harmonisation from the bottom up or a sharp increase in our trade deficits at best. These recommendations are merely blows of the sword in the water because they cannot improve the terms of an agreement whose foundations are harmful to Europeans. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and the US are the main players in global trade and investment (the EU is the world's largest economy, accounting for no less than 25% of GDP and 17% of trade, both globally, and the US ranking second, with 21% of world GDP and 13% of world trade).  Given the volume of economic interactions and the very large size of the EU and US markets, a transatlantic trade agreement can create important benefits for businesses and their consumers, generating jobs and growth on both sides of the Atlantic. I was in favour of this report because I am convinced of the strategic importance of the EU-US economic relationship in general and of TTIP in particular as a chance to promote the principles and values that the EU and the US share, thanks to common approaches to international trade policy, investment and trade issues, as well as high standards, rules and regulations to develop a broader transatlantic vision and a common set of strategic objectives.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the INTA Committee's own-initiative report, which contains suggestions to the European Commission for conducting the ongoing negotiations with the US. The Northern League's opposition to TTIP is well known. In particular, we are not convinced by a whole series of issues, such as risks to the agricultural and agri-food sector or tough competition with us companies that are much more dynamic and less taxed in the first place. The text of the report also contains interesting parts. It is by no means a contentless document, but there is no doubt that it does take a positive approach to TTIP. Clearly, we cannot approve a report that says little about the need for greater recognition and respect for our geographical indications on the part of the UNITED States (where there is a system based on brands that usurp our ability to do so). The report uses many paragraphs for a sinister issue, the ISDS mechanism. This is undoubtedly an important aspect, but the search for a compromise at all costs on ISDS by the main political groups has led to the loss of attention on other issues of concern and not a little, and not least the Northern League.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted its position on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. As the only institution directly elected by European citizens, Parliament must play an important role in monitoring negotiations with the United States. TTIP will not be at the expense of European standards and standards. We will not make any concessions on the European Union's social, environmental and health achievements. I am also opposed to private arbitration for investor-state disputes. We must protect European companies operating in the US market while preserving the right of states to regulate. It will be the red lines that will guide my vote when the European Parliament approves TTIP.
