I voted in favour of this resolution which reminds the Commission that the high standards of European standards are not negotiable.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is Sinn Féin’s position that the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership being negotiated by the European Commission and United States will have disastrous consequences for democracy in Member States, the environment, labour rights and public services based on the current mandate. I voted in favour of several amendments including some which I drafted which would, if enacted, have helped protect Irish interests. These ranged from an outright rejection of the current TTIP project to specific amendments aimed at protecting workers’ rights, food and water standards, public services, and the environment. Sinn Féin is opposed to any form of ISDS – investor-state dispute settlement – as this mechanism undermines democratic institutions and could potentially limit the potential of governments to enact legislation aimed at improving the lives of citizens when such legislation conflicts with corporate interests. There is massive public opposition to the secretive trade deal among my constituents. The TTIP will have a seriously detrimental impact in Ireland – on jobs, agriculture, the environment, workers’ rights and vital public services.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose the ISDS, any threat to public services, and the suggestion that this partnership will tip the scales still further towards big business. I therefore voted against this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a resolution for the continuation of negotiations of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) Agreement as I believe that the resolution has satisfactorily addressed all of our main interests. In particular, we ensured that the geopolitical importance of TTIP is emphasised; there is no International Labour Organisation (ILO) ratification as condition for concluding TTIP; market access for services is based on a hybrid approach; and ISDS is not excluded from TTIP, but should be reformed. On a personal level, I believe TTIP opens up a vast market, which would have otherwise been very difficult to infiltrate by SMEs from my own country, notably in the maritime and financial services sectors. As we know, due to their limited resources, trade and non-trade barriers tend to disproportionately burden smaller firms much more than their larger counterparts.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 TTIP, as designed so far, will have the effect of seriously endangering the health of citizens, safety standards as well as the social system and employment of all Europeans. Furthermore, the fact that the ISDS dispute settlement system is maintained in practice will remove any brake on the excessive power of multinationals, which will also be able to assert their interests on decisions taken by states. My vote on the report before us was therefore firmly against it.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that this text has fully complied with the Unesco Convention on the Protection of the Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions. Parties must reserve the right to adopt or maintain any measures concerning the protection or promotion of cultural and linguistic diversity in accordance with the articles on the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, taking into account the freedom and pluralism of the media regardless of the technology or distribution platform used and all this without losing sight of the mandate given to the European Commission by the Member States expressly excludes audiovisual services.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I strongly rejected this report, which enshrines the total submission of European parliamentarians to the opaque negotiations conducted by the Commission and the United States on the Transatlantic Partnership (TTIP). With the coal miner's faith in the positive effect that the TTIP would have on the re-industrialisation of Europe, Parliament, in this report, nevertheless continues to contradict itself, since it admits in this text that it is difficult to measure the positive impact that this agreement will have on the European and American economies. Of course, in line with the globalist ideology, the report acts to abolish all tariffs - thus preventing the protection of our industries - as well as the creation of Euro-American standards that are destined to become global.  Nor will we forget the famous arbitration tribunals: the European Parliament, after bitter debates, has not returned to this possibility which will be given to multinationals to attack sovereign states with impunity.  Finally, the European Parliament has an uncertain future for most of our public services. The elected representatives of the European peoples have therefore just said yes to the gradual impoverishment in favour of globalist ideology.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. Negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) are characterised by a number of factors which, on the whole, make the issue more controversial. The high technical complexity, the difficulty of predicting the real effects of a possible agreement, the limited transparency in the forms and content of the negotiations, the strong ideological implications of the subject, these and other elements explain the contrasts and lead to the negotiations being followed with great care and prudence. As Parliament will be called upon in the coming years to approve or reject the final text of the agreement 'collectively', it is appropriate at this stage, more than to make overall assessments of the TTIP and/or the negotiations that have taken place, to try to influence the progress of future negotiations as far as possible, with the aim of fully protecting the fundamental rights and principles of the Union.  The effective achievement of a fair and inclusive social model – which revolves around the person and work, rather than capital and profit – is a priority for the Union at this historic stage, and TTIP will only be acceptable if and to the extent that it is functional to this objective. On this basis, I voted in favour.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. As Social Democrats, we are in favour of free trade under democratic governance. We do not believe that the market itself takes into account either workers' rights, the environment, public health, animal welfare or sustainable development. We believe that the market should be a servant, not a gentleman. We have said very clearly that we will not open up the European market to chlorine chickens, GMO products and hormone steaks, that we do not compromise on food safety or people's health and that we will not accept any deterioration in working conditions or rights. We stand by that, and that is how we voted. We believe that it is essential for the European Parliament to make its official position on the TTIP negotiations. That is why we voted in favour of adoption. The alternative had been for the European Commission to negotiate without having to take into account the legitimate concerns raised. This is particularly true in the question of ISDS. We do not want the Commission to be free to negotiate and decide. We will not accept ISDS mechanisms as we know them from the agreements of the past. We want an open, democratic process that puts national courts at the heart of it, ensures equality between foreign and domestic investors and ensures our full freedom to legislate as we wish.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The central philosophy of the report is based on the fact that a trade agreement between the EU and the US should give European companies access to the US market, but at the same time should not undermine EU standards. It is also important that we call for a more transparent process, strong labour rights and the protection of personal data and public services. We have welcomed the continuation of the talks which must reach a balanced agreement for mutual benefit and in particular for the benefit of the peoples of the EU.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) negotiations.  Among the main points of the report: 1) the strategic importance of such an agreement in EU-US relations; (2) the protection and protection of investments; (3) the establishment of a democratic and transparent ISDS mechanism for resolving investor-State investment disputes; 4) the inclusion in the TTIP of specific chapters on energy, SMEs and intellectual property and 5) the recognition and strong legal protection of geographical indications. Finally, the report calls on the negotiators to ensure that future negotiations are transparent in order to reach an ambitious and transparent agreement

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By adopting this text, we are sending guidelines to the Commission to continue negotiations. I am convinced that in an increasingly globalised world, only through specific rules can SMEs, their activity and their commercial expansion be protected. Such an agreement serves the EU because it will become a good engine for its reindustrialisation: we are waiting for a proposal that protects the interests of entrepreneurs, consumers, families and the environment. The interconnection between markets is increasingly marked, up to 40% of industrial products are obtained from imported basic products, and this agreement can become a useful tool for creating shared standards and ensuring an anti-dumping policy so that free competition is implemented on an equal footing.  This does not alter the fact that the high principles and values that I personally am inspired by, such as food security, health, the social model, the environment and data protection, are not subject to compromise unless higher protection is achieved. Finally, a geopolitical consideration: without this agreement, the EU could find itself displaced by the main axis of world trade and development, namely the trans-Pacific partnership. In any case, before approving the Treaty, we will carefully assess every aspect of it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership between the EU and the US is very important in order to reach a beneficial agreement for both blocs and is an opportunity to cement commonly shared principles and values and establish a common vision and regulatory framework for trade, investment and related global issues. Given the complexity, interest and volume of views on this Agreement, coupled with a negotiation process that is not always transparent, a common position by the EP was not easy. I support the Lange Report because it considers it to be balanced and to express a number of concerns and recommendations that should be taken into account in the negotiation process. A good agreement for Europe can only be an agreement that combines reciprocal access to markets and reduced barriers, while respecting European standards and standards, not jeopardising the quality of public services, respect for environmental standards, health, social protection, data protection, consumer protection and food safety. I welcome the agreement reached to replace the dispute settlement system between investors and states with a new system subject to democratic principles and control.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 TTIP can represent a trade agreement with great potential and benefits for the European market and for European companies. Benefits in economic and commercial terms, growth and employment through the facilitation of entry into the American market by our economic realities.  Making our European businesses and products more competitive – especially those of excellence – must be one of the most important priorities on our political agenda. I therefore intend to vote in favour of this report. My hope is that, through this agreement, we can offer good opportunities for our SMEs, improve the agricultural market, and above all find appropriate rules for the indication of origin of products for the proper protection of our consumers. What some European governments still persist in not wanting to recognise and approve within the European Union.  Moreover, as an Italian MEMBER of Parliament, I make no secret of my wish to be able to better protect Made in Italy and put a stop to the enormous damage caused by Italian Sounding every year in our country. Damage caused precisely by the absence of shared rules.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report but insist that European citizens are given the necessary information about the negotiations taking place for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is a series of trade negotiations being carried out between the EU and US and this will directly affect the European citizens. It is very important that these negotiations do not lower EU standards but ensure that these are safeguarded for the best of European citizens.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution sets out a number of red lines for Parliament ahead of the resumption of negotiations on the possible TTIP agreement. The red lines make it clear that Parliament will not accept any threats to public services nor to regulatory standards, but it is not sufficiently clear in opposing the proposed ISDS privileged court for foreign investors, hence the negative vote of Labour MEPs.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 TTIP is an economic agreement on free trade and investment, which through the removal of trade barriers should facilitate the purchase and sale of goods and services between the EU and the US, create jobs and achieve a deeper interconnection between the two major economies.  Designed as a response to the economic and financial crisis we are going through, TTIP is increasingly becoming a tailor-made agreement made by and for the United States, calling for a downward harmonisation of the high standards that the EU and its Member States now have on sensitive sectors such as agriculture, cosmetics, the pharmaceutical sector, food, textiles and animal protection.  One of the main issues of confrontation is the inclusion of ISDS in the negotiating negotiations. Such a system would allow US multinationals investing in Europe to bypass any national or European court, and sue Member State governments directly before these new international private courts whenever they believe that national laws pose a threat. I voted against the final text, it is an agreement that the Socialists have made with the PPE, ALDE and ECR and against the will of those of us who opposed it from the outset.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the Lange report on the negotiations of the so-called Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTE) since I am against this Partnership on principle. The only recommendation of the European Parliament that could be acceptable in this case is to immediately halt negotiations on this text with the United States. The ATCI stimulates the concentration of power and resources in a few hands, makes it inevitable that the standards on labour rights that we have in Europe will be lowered and increases the precariousness of work, as it favours down competition. Moreover, TTE is another step in Europe's political subordination to the United States. If this partnership continues, US trade policy will condition European policy to the point that its foreign interests will be totally subjugated by what Washington dictates. TCE is an affront to the sovereignty and democracy of the peoples of Europe. That is why I voted 'no', and I will vote in the same direction every time I am presented to reject this threat.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I was and am convinced that the Treaty is an opportunity to be seized, for the sake of our companies, our production system and our workers. But, at the same time, I wanted to express my disagreement with the compromise on ISDS. The Treaty must become an opportunity and must not be wasted or sold off. I am convinced that there are no valid reasons, especially for the S&D Group, which has always opposed systems and arbitrations that are not exactly public, to forget that we are the Europe that is home to law and respect for the rule of law, so that no one can question the absolute impartiality of our courts, which are fully capable of settleing any issues that may arise. , without harming the rights of companies wishing to invest. I would like to remind you that one of the prerequisites for admission to the Union is also the impartiality of the courts and equality before the law. By voting for the Isds mechanism, it is as if Europe recognises that its own Member States are not complying with this requirement. I hope that this distortion can be corrected by bringing the judgments back to the relevant public bodies.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the idea of creating a common trade and investment space with the US to be a good idea in a globalising world, but negotiations will be lengthy. In many important areas, the EU's positions are not clarified, as evidenced by several hundred amendments to the resolution, which is why I cannot vote in favour of it at the moment.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the political importance and implications of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, I voted in favour of the report that gives guidelines on what we want the Commission to negotiate upon. I believe that a good and fair transatlantic agreement can be beneficial to European Union citizens and enterprises in terms of growth and jobs while avoiding a global race to the bottom on human rights, environmental and labour standards. With regards to critical areas such as public services and environmental and food safety standards, the Commission should commit to excluding public services such as water, health, social services, education, etc. from TTIP and to ensuring that national authorities retain full rights in these areas; upcoming negotiations must also ensure that EU-US regulatory cooperation in the future will not lower EU standards, including those on GMOs, labour and the environment.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union must ensure the conclusion of a comprehensive and ambitious agreement on TTIP, which stimulates fair competition for both parties, taking into account the values of the European social market economy, benefiting consumers, industry and investors and stimulating quality job creation and economic growth.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission as part of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. At present, no fundamental chapter is closed, and both sides conclude the first part of the negotiations before addressing the most essential issues. In this context, the European Parliament, which has a veto over the final adoption of the agreement, wished to define its priorities and red lines. I have been particularly involved in the agricultural side of these recommendations. Despite the real economic opportunities for our agriculture that will result from this agreement, I believe that the European agricultural model must be protected. The text of the recommendations takes up this position, namely no questioning of our health and plant health standards, full recognition of our quality signs and products under PDO and IGP and the special consideration of sensitive products, or their exclusion from the negotiations. For these reasons, I have voted in favour of these recommendations, which I believe are balanced and realistic, because they do not seek an agreement at all costs while leaving sufficient room for negotiators to reach a satisfactory agreement.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Ahead of a new round of transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) negotiations, it was important for Parliament to be able to pass on its recommendations and red lines to the European Commission. We must not lose sight of the ambitious objective of creating a large free trade area, which would be a major asset for the European economy. However, vigilance is needed: liberalisation must serve employment policy, not lead to social dumping. Moreover, Europeans are keen to maintain a high level of requirements for geographical indications or data protection. I supported the compromise that was passed, calling for the system of settlement of disputes between states and investors (ISDS) to be replaced by a mechanism where the concept of arbitration disappears, leaving room for full-fledged judges and subject to transparency rules.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on TTIP because I am convinced that closing a comprehensive deal on free trade and investment with the US will bring large benefits for both consumers and businesses – not only from bringing down tariff barriers, but also by harmonising our standards. Opening up trade will lead to lower prices for consumers, and increased export opportunities for our companies, and will certainly help our SME’s to export to the US. A strong dispute settlement mechanism should ensure that protection of companies – mainly SME’s – is provided.

name: Dennis de Jong en Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – In the case of the following amendments, the SP abstained: 89, 91, 17, 37, 94, 110, 55, 56, as the SP supports the intention of these amendments but opposes TTIP. In amendment 95, the SP voted against, since the SP is not in favour of TTIP and therefore does not support negotiations on TTIP. The SP supports Amendment 77, but is in favour of a foreign policy aimed at the EU and its Member States, and has therefore voted against Amendment 77.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Two fundamental reasons explain the justified mistrust of public opinion in this trade agreement.  The first is that people have not been involved in the debate and do not know what is going on. I regret that the Heads of State and Government have given the Commission a mandate without having previously debated it in their Member States. In fact, I hope that the national parliaments will ultimately have to give, or not, their agreement to these negotiations.  The second is that we are not on a level playing field with the Americans. Let us take the example of public procurement. In the United States, much of the public procurement is reserved for U.S. SMEs to promote growth and employment. The Americans are absolutely right to do it at home. But if we want to level the playing field, then we should do the same at home. Let us agree to face the reasons which underpin much of the doubts and concerns expressed by Europeans. Until we make progress on these two points, we will not be able to have a satisfactory agreement. That is why I did not approve this resolution.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. After much discussion in Parliament and the postponement of the vote in the previous session, mainly due to existing disagreements within the S and D group, we finally adopted an important text reminding the negotiators of our red lines. Indeed, it was imperative to recall that public services and audiovisual services should be excluded from the negotiations, as it was imperative to recall that we are against lowering our standards and that we wanted in particular the protection of our agricultural model, the exclusion of sensitive products, the recognition of geographical indications, the need for reciprocal access to public procurement... On the question of the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism, we categorically reject the mechanism as it stands. We call for this system to be reformed to function as a genuine public jurisdiction that meets transparency obligations and has an appeal mechanism. It will also have to respect the right to regulate states, which is essential in this regard. This agreement could be an opportunity for many of our sectors, but we must remain very vigilant and ensure that our red lines are not crossed.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP decision that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the rejecting of the much-debated ISDS mechanism from the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. I myself have proposed amendments to the alternative dispute resolution, such as that now adopted, which does not violate national sovereignty, during the debate – this part applies mutatis mutandis. It is reassuring that on this issue the People's Party has moved in the right direction and supported the compromise. The European Parliament has taken a clear resolution in favour of us on all the public health issues that are important for our country, the ban on hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Lange report on the Transatlantic Partnership (TTIP). I believe that the idea of stimulating trade between the European Union and the United States through a treaty is a good idea, which can have positive effects on growth and therefore on employment on both sides of the Atlantic. At this point, if I think it is useful to set guidelines, I see no reason to end the negotiations. However, I retain my total freedom to vote when it comes to voting on the final text. Thus, I will not vote in favour of TTIP if current European standards on health, environment or social protection are called into question or are at risk of being challenged, if the regulatory cooperation body set up in any way infringes on the sovereignty of European assemblies to enact their own standards, and if the mechanism for resolving disputes between investors and states does not at least correspond to what the amendment requires. compromise that excludes the use of private arbitration.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EP decision that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the much-debated ISDS mechanism to be rejected by the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. I myself proposed amendments to the alternative dispute resolution, similar to that adopted now, which does not violate national sovereignty. It is reassuring that on this issue the People's Party has moved in the right direction and supported the compromise. The European Parliament has taken a clear resolution in favour of us on all the public health issues that are important for our country, the ban on hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. I am opposed in bulk and in detail to this project. It is a question of submitting Europe, and therefore France, to the United States. It is unacceptable that they can dictate the rules, taking advantage of their collusion with a Union that dreams of Americanization. Trade policies must remain among the regal domains of each state, so that it can determine them, alone. If we say yes to cooperation, we strongly reject harmonization. This will lead to only disastrous consequences, including lower standards and health levels, especially in food. To reject this project is to stop the Union's unacceptable interference in national sovereignty. However, the Commission ignores the citizens who, across all the Member States, have come forward to put an end to this project. To vote against is also to remind the Commission that, although not elected by the people, it must submit to its wishes.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ After weeks of parliamentary ping-pong I am glad to be able to vote on TTIP. I have been clear from the start, ISDS needs to be modernized and improved to ensure that Scottish public services are protected and environmental standards maintained. The Commission’s commitment to this is encouraging, and I look forward to continued negotiations for an ambitious trade deal for Scottish small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as a whole because TTYP is the Trojan horse that will destroy Europe's economy and especially agricultural production and exports. Competition with US products, in the event of a trade association, will not only be tough but will break up the already tested EU economy.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP decision that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the rejecting of the much-debated ISDS mechanism from the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. I myself have proposed amendments to the alternative dispute resolution, such as that now adopted, which does not violate national sovereignty, during the debate – this part applies mutatis mutandis. It is reassuring that on this issue the People's Party has moved in the right direction and supported the compromise. The exception of sensitive agricultural sectors, which are also important for our country, from the reduction of customs duties, from respect for EU protection of origin, from non-GMO, from the prohibition of hormone treatment in the cattle sector, and from all related agricultural and public health issues, the European Parliament has taken a clear position that is favourable to us. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on TTIP because it is not in the interests of Wales. This trade agreement will have a huge impact yet there has not been a proper public debate on it. Some of the proposals threaten, rather than enhance, our democracy as well as our standards and values. I am in favour of trade agreements between equals which are of benefit to both, but TTIP is not that. I am pleased that many thousands of constituents contacted me urging me to vote against ISDS and TTIP. I am disappointed that the final report includes a form of ISDS under another name, which means the Commission will press ahead with its proposals. I will continue to campaign on TTIP and I have urged my constituents to keep lobbying to protect our services and our standards.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution because TTIP is a threat to the standards, safety and health of European citizens. I am concerned and indignant about these negotiations, which are a threat to democracy and the rule of law. In the resolution adopted by plenary, ISDS, one of the main points of confrontation in the debate, has disappeared, but it has been replaced by another system which, in fact, still favours multinationals by granting it the privilege of suing the governments of the Member States directly whenever they consider that national laws pose a threat to them. We consider the new system adopted to be totally inadequate to prevent it from having direct and indirect effects on the ability of States to legislate in the interests of citizens. Neither the Italian nor the American system needs an additional mechanism for resolving trade disputes. The European and US judicial system, in fact, are sound and guarantor systems that already offer the highest quality of protection for investors and citizens. Since neither this recommendation nor the ISDS surrogate is acceptable to us, my vote was against.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system.  In short, because it requires an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote globally the values and principles we share with the US, making it clear that we will only support an TIC that regulates trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I fundamentally oppose the conclusion of the transatlantic treaty

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is the First Official Position of the European Parliament on the negotiations of the so-called Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). TTIP's goal is to create even greater pressure on employment and wages by levelling social and labour rights. To overtake the public interest and respect for economic, social and labour rights, the interests and profits of monopolies and transnational nationals, in particular by the creation of specific judicial mechanisms aimed at safeguarding those interests by limiting the sovereignty of States and, consequently, disfiguring democracy itself. To overlap with environmental sustainability and the safeguarding of public health, the search for new markets at any cost and enable the market to advance the social functions of states, destroying what remains of important public services. Obviously, we voted against it. These are not manoeuvres which, in response to public pressure, to ensure that something changes so that everything stays the same, which will alter the core and objectives of this Treaty. Only their rejection will ensure the interests and rights of peoples. The alternative involves regulated trade, based on relations of complementarity and not competition – between countries, producers and productions, which respects and safeguards national sovereignty.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that Parliament needs to give a clear signal of support to the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership between the European Union and the United States currently under way. I believe that a good agreement between the EU and the US will expand trade and investment on both sides of the Atlantic, promote employment and competitiveness, create great opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises and allow for the establishment of trade standards and standards to be adopted later around the world.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the overall report because it is an insult to democracy.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that the TTIP negotiations are very important for both parties involved, because if the partnership in question were to be adopted, there would be a change in circumstances in many spheres in europe and the US. However, we must not forget the differences that are very significant between the European Union and the US, particularly in the area of worker protection. It is our task to ensure that an agreement is adopted that guarantees full respect for the European Union's fundamental rights standards through the Fundamental Rights Clause as a standard part of the European Union's trade agreements with third countries. It is important that this agreement not only benefits large multinationals, but that people who work in small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union do not lose their jobs.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have lashed out at this agreement many times. It will now pass through this House with your vote in favour and you will be responsible for another agreement that harms the most, the small, to the benefit of very few, the large.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union's trade agreement with the United States strengthens the defence alliance. American investment in Poland is among the most desirable. They concern the productive sphere in innovative fields, which means creating highly qualified and well-paid jobs. However, I would like to stress that the specificity of Polish industry and the 'sensitivity' of certain industries must be noticed in the ongoing negotiations. It is also an opportunity to regulate visa issues.  I have been professionally involved in the analysis of international trade agreements. Each of them contains some elements of arbitration. The ISDS mechanism contained in the bilateral Polish-American trade agreement, which is the subject of a European debate, has proved to be an acceptable solution. Of the 6 arbitration cases, 3 were won by the Polish side, 2 ended in a settlement and 1 investor won. TTIP further improves these conditions. I warn against replacing a well-functioning bilateral mechanism with a European arbitral tribunal. Paradoxically, isds, which is contained in bilateral agreements between the US and central and eastern European countries, has not had any negative effects. Its inclusion in the EU-US trade agreement increases the competitive position of my region's countries in the European Union.  I am in favour of the common market from California to the Black Sea, not from Lisbon to Vladivostok. Our voice must be clear – we want American investment in Europe and in our region in particular. They are not only a guarantee of development, but also of safety.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as a whole, because TTYP is the Trojan horse that will destroy Europe's economy and, above all, agricultural production and exports. Competition with US products, in the event of a trade association, will not only be tough but will break up the already tested EU economy.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s recommendations on TTIP. I recognise that many of my constituents have fears over the possible outcomes of this trade deal. However, free trade is something that we can all benefit from. Although these recommendations are not as ambitious as the ECR initially hoped for, the important core message of the removal of barriers to trade and investment remains.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the latest developments in negotiations for the TTIP, I would like to express my content that the report contains important S&D Group demands, namely strong protection of labour rights and ratification of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) conventions; high environmental standards; protection of public services, and also protection of our food and health safety standards. We consider that it is a unique opportunity for the EP to have a strong position in the negotiations between the EU and US by setting up standards on international trade. I congratulate the rapporteur on the compromise negotiated to oblige the Commission to exclude ISDS from the trade agreement and I support the compromise amendment which replaces the ISDS with a new public, democratic and transparent system that functions on an appellate mechanism where private interests cannot undermine public policy objectives. TTIP is a huge opportunity not only in the economic and trade issue, but a paramount historical political necessity between the two shores of the Atlantic that share common values – a matter of common values and interests.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Lange report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations to strengthen the Union's position in the eu-US rounds of negotiations.  These negotiations must conclude with an agreement between the parties which can have a big positive impact on both European and US economies and proposes what role we want to play in the world economy over the next fifty years. The European Commission has repeated on several occasions that worker protection, safety and quality standards and levels will in no way be jeopardized, so we will have to wait to see how the negotiation ends and what TCI's proposal is to assess it correctly and hold a debate on specific points rather than speculation.

I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system. text: in writing. I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system. name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted yes to this report as it gives a clear mandate to the Commission in the run-up to the negotiations for a transatlantic trade and investment partnership agreement. The agreement is a key instrument for bringing the pursuit of sustainable growth back to the centre of European actions, while making an important contribution to strengthening transatlantic relations with the United States.  We want this agreement to be transparent and reliable, only to bring benefits to European companies and investors, removing those barriers that still prevent them from making full use of our potential in the American market. We will continue to ensure that the negotiations are conducted in accordance with the mandate and that the negotiations are conducted with full protection of the interests of European citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained today in the vote on the non-legislative own-initiative report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), because I find the debate on this to be partly misleading: a debate inflated by others has given the impression, in part, that the European Parliament is thereby creating facts for a TTIP vote or even voting definitively on TTIP. The report contains some interesting critical elements, which are also necessary – but it is rather counterproductive at the moment.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The transatlantic trade and investment partnership agreement is to boost economic growth on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. Such a united market with a third of world trade turnover would be worth two trillion euros, which would also translate into significant employment growth. In order for such extensive cooperation to bring benefits, due protection must be ensured for citizens, consumers and employees of companies. I therefore supported the removal of the provision on the use of ISDS private arbitration in the agreement. Citizens are concerned about TTIP precisely because of ISDS, 97% of the nearly 150,000 surveyed from 28 Member States voted against ISDS in its current form. The fate of millions of citizens cannot be put into private arbitration.  ISDS as originally proposed is not needed in EU-US relations and foreign investors should not enjoy greater rights than domestic investors. Potential disputes should be treated transparently and dealt with by independent judges in public hearings where an appeal mechanism is in place, consistency of judicial decisions is ensured and the jurisdiction of the courts of the Member States is respected.  The reference to the re-examination of the amendments to the report by the INTA has changed little other than the "compromise of compromises" of President Martin Schulz. With the assurance that ISDS would disappear from TTIP, I have decided to support the whole resolution and I am pleased that most of us here have thought the same.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The TTIP agreement is a project of the world's largest free trade area, which for both sides, i.e. the US and the EU, is an event of historic importance. The question should be asked: does this agreement give the same impetus to economic growth for the Contracting Parties and will the number of jobs increase or decrease in the Eu countries? Undoubtedly, at the outset, both sides can benefit from the mobilisation of all previously unused reserves. Over time, however, the American side may become the dominant party. This is due to its competitive advantage – lower energy and labour costs, as well as the fact that numerous raw materials are available. Looking far-reachingly at global markets, it is clear that the EU can become a valuable partner for the US in its activities in the Far East markets, including China, the largest US creditor. Does Europe have other directions for the development of free trade? So. It can improve its global competitiveness by opening a free trade area with the Eurasian Free Trade Area at the same time as TTIP. Unfortunately, this direction has been quite effectively blocked for the EU, which involuntaryly raises the question of ttip's relationship with the unrest in Ukraine. The TTIP should be analysed holistically, m.in in terms of the development of the future global market. I therefore abstained.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Lange report on the Transatlantic Partnership. I believe that stimulating trade between the European Union and the United States can have positive effects on growth and employment in both the EU and the US. The Commission should take advantage of the negotiations on this agreement to ensure that European companies have better conditions of access to the US market, especially the government procurement market. However, European standards for health, environment and social protection should not be questioned, nor should the sovereignty of our Member States be questioned. With regard to the latter, I hope that at the end of the negotiations there will be a clear definition of the investor-state arbitration mechanism.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this European Parliament report on the transatlantic treaty negotiations. Once again, the European Parliament has chosen to abdicate in favour of the Commission, renouncing limits, even though any trade agreement must be approved by the European Parliament before being ratified.  In substance, the report argues, among other things, that an agreement with the United States should promote the re-industrialisation of Europe by strengthening transatlantic trade. Of course, this will not be the case since the transatlantic treaty is primarily tailored to the interests of the Americans.  I also draw the attention of my compatriots to the fact that, in addition to the economy and employment, it will also be their health, their manners and their quality of life that will be affected by this treaty. This will be the case in particular of our agricultural model, which will disappear when it competes head-on with the American agribusiness, whose standards are much more permissive than ours. However, this treaty will require a shift from European standards to US standards. Factory farms, injections of hormones and antibiotics, chlorine chickens, spreading Roundup on whole fields of GMOs: this is what awaits us if we let the European apprentice witches negotiate and sign this treaty.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), because I believe that the conclusion of this agreement is important from a geopolitical point of view. The effects of the Russian embargo, which are severe for Polish farmers, have shown the importance of creating permanent and robust trade partnerships. In this resolution, the European Parliament has given a clear signal to the Commission that agriculture should not be a bargaining chip in these negotiations. The report calls for a balanced and mutually beneficial agreement that does not jeopardise the quality standards of European food products.  I also supported this report because of the call for a list of sensitive products to be identified, although in my opinion this provision should not only call for transitional periods, but for the full exclusion of these products and not the application of this measure as a last resort.  It is good that this report calls for a safeguard clause that can be applied if imports increase to an extent that harms member states' economies. This resolution also includes an important call from Polish citizens for the Commission to put pressure on the US Government on the issue of visas.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. If I am, in principle, in favour of negotiating with the United States an agreement that would bring the trade rules of our two American and European areas closer together, and if I believe that such an agreement could have beneficial effects on growth in Europe, as in the United States, I nevertheless wish to abstain in the vote on this European Parliament resolution on TTIP.  There is, rightly, a great deal of mistrust and concern about the reciprocity of the agreement, issues of cultural exception, food security, health standards, protected geographical indications, protection of personal data, etc., or, above all, the arbitration mechanism, to which I am totally opposed). I fully share these concerns.  Therefore, at this stage of the proceedings and without knowing yet what will become definitively of this agreement and this arbitration mechanism, I preferred to abstain. However, this resolution contains clear red lines. It is now necessary for the negotiators of this agreement, both on the European and American sides, to hear and take into account the very strong demands of the European Parliament.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with fellow Labour MEPs, voted to protect the NHS, public services, workers’ rights and environmental standards in this vote on the TTIP negotiations. However, we voted against the inclusion of the compromise on Investor State Dispute Settlement (ISDS), which enables companies to sue governments.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system.  In short, because it requires an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote globally the values and principles we share with the US, making it clear that we will only support an TIC that regulates trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I wanted to express my very great reservation about the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. My position and that of the delegation of the French Socialists has been expressed many times without ever varying. One of the red lines regarding the exclusion of an Investor/State clause (ISDS) was not sufficiently explicitly included in the "Lange" resolution. I therefore voted against this text, because it does not definitively close the door to the establishment of this arbitration mechanism which would risk weakening democratic decisions in favour of private interests.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Today we have not voted for or against TTE. Today we voted to influence its negotiation by setting out Parliament's conditions and red lines for an agreement.  Today I voted for the European Commission to require the United States to ratify the ILO's fundamental Conventions and Decent Work Programme and respect for our environmental protection. I also voted to exclude public services such as water, health, social services or education from the TCI area, as well as to ensure that EU data protection legislation will not be compromised under any circumstances. Finally, I have shown my clear rejection of ISDS, calling for a new, transparent model with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system. In short, I have sent a clear signal to the negotiating team that I will only support an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote on a global scale the values and principles we share with the US, regulating trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP resolution that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the much-debated ISDS mechanism to be rejected by the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. It is reassuring that the People's Party has moved in the right direction on this issue and supported the compromise. The European Parliament has taken a clear resolution in favour of us on all the public health issues that are important for our country, the ban on hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it brings an opportunity to make improvements and create a new generation model that addresses the weaknesses identified in other agreements. There is no doubt that such a trade agreement will benefit the EU, and Ireland in particular, with our strong economic ties.  Irish exporters currently pay EUR 300 million in tariffs to the US Treasury. These barriers inhibit exports from Ireland and impose costs.  The shape of any investor and state dispute settlement (ISDS) system will ultimately be the subject of negotiation and agreement between the EU and the US. A major public consultation has taken place on this issue within the EU and the concerns which have been raised will feed into the negotiation process.  I am confident that any final deal will address those and any other concerns comprehensively and that the sovereign right of governments to legislate in the public interest will be safeguarded, as has been confirmed today by Parliament’s vote on TTIP.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Transatlantic Free Trade and Investment Agreement (TTIP) creates more free trade. This is nothing more than the "expanding of markets" and leads to greater product selection, more competition, higher productivity and cheaper prices. The theoretical ly sebes and risks of TTIP were discussed intensively in committee. "Red lines" are appropriately drawn against them in the 'Lange report' voted on here. One of these guidelines is to abolish old-style ISDS and create a new investor protection system for it. By approving this report, we want to provide constructive support for the process of creating TTIP without pre-incipiating a decision on the final agreement. On the negative note, Amendment No 1 ('Fiscal autonomy' instead of 'fiscal dumping') was not adopted. This amendment would have emphasised the fiscal autonomy of the Member States. However, this own-initiative report has no legally binding effect. After consultation with DG Trade staff, we assume that this point will not have a negative impact on the negotiations. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the report.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the much-debated ISDS mechanism to be rejected by the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. It is reassuring that on this issue the People's Party has moved in the right direction and supported the compromise.  The European Parliament has taken a clear resolution in favour of us on all the public health issues that are important for our country, the ban on hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as a whole because I do not believe that the EU should be negotiating trade deals on behalf of the UK.  I am absent from some roll call votes (RCVs) because I did not want to ʽimproveʼ legislation I fundamentally disagree with: I want it to be deleted. At the same time I was not prepared to vote in favour of any of the clauses which allow US companies to interfere in the NHS, which UKIP believes should be free at the point of access and not be exploited by benefit tourism.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The negotiation of the transatlantic partnership raises many fears that are natural. MEPs have a duty to protect the interests of the citizens they represent. They also have a duty to prepare them for a future. The systematic rejection and lack of perspective of far-left and right-wing groups is not an answer. Criticism is easy, action and risk-taking are less so. If we listen to extreme parties, what do we hear? A no to a Europe that remains in the top three of the world's economies, a no to a europe that spreads its standards, a yes to an isolated Europe that disappears from the radar. However, the other economic blocs are not waiting for Europe to join the globalization train. If it doesn't start, the distance will be hard to catch.  This agreement is an opportunity to put us back at the centre of the table. To do that, you have to negotiate. That is not to say that we can accept everything. This is exactly Parliament's message: protection of our agricultural model, social, health and environmental standards; exclusion of public services, respect for the sovereignty of states.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The supposed compromise text on ISDS retains the unacceptable features of ISDS, namely the establishment of a parallel system of justice for large-scale investors. The Socialist group in this House have behaved shamefully and they are very much mistaken if they believe that the citizens of Europe will accept their proposals.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it recommends to the European Commission lines of action which run counter to the interests of European citizenship, its rights, public services, democracy and sovereignty, which are red and common sense lines for PODEMOS. In addition, the amendment adopted on is clearly a toast to the sun since, although it advises, in the long term, the establishment of an international and public tribunal for investor-state dispute settlement, the US Government has publicly stated that it will not accept it. We therefore consider it a hoax to the public to claim that the private arbitration system is over. That is why we understand that transnational corporations will continue to have a veto on the legislating capacity of States, which is a frontal attack on democracy.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report, of this proposal for a trade and investment partnership which will help the European Union to grow, as it will create jobs and a favourable economic dynamic.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I am against further EU-US TTIP negotiations as it stands. The secrecy of the negotiations is the best medium for the interests of European citizens to be hijacked by lobbyists and multi-corporate groups. The ISDS mechanism, on the other hand, deprives the state of its sovereignty in the area of justice. It is also unacceptable to lower certain European standards, particularly in the area of food safety. I am convinced that negotiations should start anew, with the active participation of national parliaments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament with the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on negotiations on the Partnership for Transatlantic Trade and Investment (TTIP), since I think the partnership is good for the European and Croatian economies. In the same way as for producers and exporters, joining the EU has contributed to increasing the market and strengthening the attractiveness of Croatia as a tourist destination, in the same way the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership increases opportunities for Croatian companies and improves opportunities for tourism.  In addition, opportunities for foreign investment are increasing, which unfortunately there are too few in Croatia. I support ensuring transparent negotiations on TTIP through these recommendations; which would lead to an ambitious, comprehensive and balanced agreement on trade and investment of high standards; which would promote sustainable growth with shared benefits in the Member States and mutual and mutual benefits for all partners; to seek the abolition of all customs tariffs; to take into account that visa simplification for European service providers and goods is an extremely important element; to ensure full recognition and strong redress of geographical indications in the EU, as well as measures to deal with improper use; to continue efforts to increase the transparency of negotiations by making more negotiating proposals available to the public.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this draft resolution on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership negotiations.  The rapporteur, Mr Lange, is clearly in favour of the negotiations currently being carried out. However, we know that Europe, and France in particular, would suffer seriously from such a treaty and thus from the creation of an adjoining free trade area.  Indeed, the mandatory establishment of arbitration tribunals will not be done in the required transparency, nor will the decisions rendered by the latter be. This is just one example of the harmful effects of a transatlantic free trade treaty. While some of the amendments were positive, they are unfortunately too cosmetic or have simply been rejected by the European Parliament.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system.  In short, because it requires an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote globally the values and principles we share with the US, making it clear that we will only support an TIC that regulates trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TTIP interim report which will help Commissioner Malmström deliver tangible results. In the report the European Parliament backs the Commissioner’s negotiating position on maintaining the current standards we have in the EU especially in the area of food safety and environment. I believe that a strong TTIP would bring benefits for entrepreneurs, SMEs and consumers while at the same time creating a fruitful environment for investment and innovation in the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Bernd Lange's resolution on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. The aim of this text was to set out Parliament's red lines for these negotiations, including the need to preserve European levels of health, environmental and consumer protection, as well as the protection of European cultural diversity. The text also supports a new approach to investor-state dispute settlement, calling for the replacement of private ISDS arbitration with a system based on professional judges, an appeal system and guaranteeing the right of states to legislate. The potential of the agreement for the European economy is finally being recalled. Although the outcome of these negotiations is still a long way off, it was necessary for Parliament, which will have a veto over the agreement to be reached, to make its position on the subject. This resolution was adopted by a large majority of 436 votes in person, 241 against and 32 abstentions, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is well known that atCI's explicit objective is not to use a trade agreement. The aim is not to alleviate tariffs or fiscal pressure on imports or exports, which are themselves quite low, but to eliminate the different 'situations' and 'regulations' that may exist on both sides and to achieve 'market unification'. While it is true that what was voted on today in the plenary session of the European Parliament is not the agreement itself, but an opinion of the House for the Commission to take into account in the negotiations, EH Bildu remains unchanged in its position and has given a 'no' categorical to the Lange report.  The public debate and resistance on the part of society have made the drafting of the report in relation to the ISDS modified and improved;  Transaction Amendment 117 calls for replacing ISDS and its arbitration systems with judges, but does not specify the nature of these courts. EH Bildu remains firm in its position contrary to ISDS or any other similar formula and, in general, contrary to TTE; that is why he voted against this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations, because while a transatlantic trade agreement can be the engine of job creation and economic growth in Europe, it must be fair and equitable for both sides. In order to achieve a treaty in favour of the European Union, we must maintain our red lines and be very vigilant in particular on the opening of public procurement in the United States to our European companies, whose access is now very limited. The European Union must fight to end the current asymmetry that allows American companies to have very wide access to our European public procurement.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the EU trade agreement with the US because it clearly sets out the EP's vision of what agreement would be desirable to create the world's largest free trade area. It must be ambitious and balanced and the negotiation process transparent. It should also give EU businesses greater access to the US market for goods, services and public procurement, but this must not lower EU standards in the areas of data protection, food security and other areas. It is important that this agreement creates an effective, competitive economic environment and removes barriers to trade. I also support the establishment of a new private arbitration system for the resolution of investor and public disputes involving publicly appointed judges and subject to transparency requirements.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. While there are some improvements in the report, such as Parliament's position on private arbitration, the repeal of discriminatory rules on public procurement, the protection of public services of general interest, nothing changes in the reservations that have been made so far. That is why I am voting against the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution with the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The report makes recommendations to the European Commission during the negotiation process on a trade agreement between the EU and the US. It is important for the European Parliament that free access to the US market in the area of goods and services is ensured. The European Parliament is also calling for europe's high standards on the environment, food and data protection to be safeguarded. I believe that this agreement will make it more important for the Latvian economy, as it will become easier for our exporting companies to sell their goods and services in the US. Negotiations are still ongoing between the eu's proxy negotiator, the European Commission, and representatives of the US, but once this is the case, MEPs will have to give their consent to the treaty.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the negotiations of the TTIP. Indeed, I support any good economic agreement which would bring opportunities and employment in our countries. At the same time, the European negotiator really must take into account the legitimate concerns about the potential consequences according to the outcome of these negotiations. The concerns are related in particular to the consequences of the 40% drop in customs duties on agricultural and industrial products (to match US rates) and the reduction of income for our producers. There are also concerns on standards of production (animal welfare, meat with hormones and GMOs, animal meal, chicken washed with acid and chlorine, food containing banned pesticides), on strategic and health sectors (services of water, emergency, energy, weapons, personal data, aeronautics), on the cultural sector (appellations of origin, filmmaking, the audiovisual sector, the artistic sector, theatre, opera, museums, libraries, etc.), on the social framework (labour law), on public services (hospitals, schools, universities, social security), and on financialisation. To overcome national resistance, an arbitration court (ISDS) would be set up and multinationals would be able to sue the recalcitrant States to obtain damages in unlimited amount. Free trade can only be truly free if it is a just, fair and beneficial trade for everyone.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Parliamentʼs support for TTIP is a crucial message to the Commission and its US counterparts and sends a strong signal to the Commission team engaged in  further negotiations.  I firmly believe that between friends and allies, one cannot have any taboos. On the contrary, if needed, we can frankly argue our differences to find the best suitable compromise. This report, which has experienced serious turbulence since June, was finally adopted on the basis of satisfactory compromise and with a clear majority. Aided by the efforts of the PPE Group, no additional red lines were created. At the same time, Parliament wants to ensure that European standards on health and consumer safety would not be lowered. A variety of concerns from society are now addressed in the report. Parliament’s report also asks for the disputed ISDS to be replaced with a reformed version that provides  an acceptable solution for all sides.  I underline once more the importance of TTIP in managing globalisation on the basis of democratic values and fair competition. Not only the EU and the US, but also everyone else would benefit from an open, democratic and legally regulated global market.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report together with more than five dozen European Socialists and Democrats. This is partly because many of the wording symths contained therein allow negotiators to disregard the original positions of our faction from last year. This applies, for example, to the so-called Arbitration Supplement, which does not preclude the practice of arbitration under a different heading from being practiced to date. I believe that the lack of clear wording at this stage of the negotiations may lead to a failure to respect the balanced position of the Socialist and Democrat factions at the beginning of this term.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. As Social Democrats, we are in favour of free trade under democratic governance. We do not believe that the market itself takes into account either workers' rights, the environment, public health, animal welfare or sustainable development. We believe that the market should be a servant, not a gentleman. We have said very clearly that we will not open up the European market to chlorine chickens, GMO products and hormone steaks, that we do not compromise on food safety or people's health and that we will not accept any deterioration in working conditions or rights. We stand by that, and that is how we voted. We believe it is vitally important for the European Parliament to make its official position on the TTIP negotiations. That is why we voted in favour of adoption. The alternative had been for the European Commission to negotiate without having to take into account the legitimate concerns raised. This is particularly true in the question of ISDS. We do not want the Commission to be free to negotiate and decide. We will not accept ISDS mechanisms as we know them from the agreements of the past. We want an open, democratic process that puts national courts at the heart of it, ensures equality between foreign and domestic investors, and ensures our full freedom to legislate as we wish. We voted for that today.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have been closely following the progress of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations for several months, so I was not at all indifferent to Wednesday's vote.
