On the basis of available information or leaks, my concerns about the future of Europe and European citizens have been growing and the approved proposal has not given me much hope. I was hoping for a much greater emphasis on protecting workers' rights, the environment and health. Instead, All I got were empty phrases and promises that the European Union would not lower its standards. Most seem to believe that Europe has such great negotiators that the US will give way to us in everything and nothing will change for the EU, except that we will have a more lively transatlantic trade on which we will all earn. I am no longer believing in the judgment of European representatives, and I fear that they are lost in the visions of a happy future implanted in them by multinational corporations. I do not agree with TTIP not only as a commercial treaty, but also as a geopolitical one, for which it is increasingly rightly referred to. I reject the notion that Europe and the US must go hand in hand to create an economic giant that will at least try to dominate the world again to prevent the rise of China and other world players. TTIP is a fear treaty, which is why I voted against the proposal.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP resolution that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the much-debated ISDS mechanism to be rejected by the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. I myself have proposed amendments to the alternative dispute resolution, such as that now adopted, which does not violate national sovereignty, during the debate – this part applies mutatis mutandis. It is reassuring that on this issue the People's Party has moved in the right direction and supported the compromise. The European Parliament has taken a clear resolution in favour of us on all the public health issues that are important for our country, the ban on hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) negotiations, because the restrictions we are struggling to maintain relate to the most important social issues and some of the most important environmental rules, such as labour rights, safe food rules, regulations on the use of chemicals and laws on the protection of personal data.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the TTP was not aimed at supporting the agreement or not; this decision will be taken later in time and will be based on the text of the Treaty when it is concluded. It was a vote to define the framework and conditions for a good agreement that does not lower our European standards on the environment, social standards, animal welfare and cultural diversity. That is why I voted in favour. The text states, in an inescapable way, that our standards are non-negotiable unless the aim is to achieve a higher level of precautions. On the protection of personal data, it is explicit that the confidentiality of data should not be put at risk and the TTIP should have a clause within it for the protection of personal data. In addition, the resolution adopted includes a request for ratification and implementation of the basic standards indicated by the International Labour Organisation.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the TTIP report because: 1. I want a solution that is in the interest of the citizens of the European Union and which will strengthen our global position. 2. The new global economic challenges oblige us to support the idea of enhancing EU-US cooperation through a trade agreement. Our economies are the most open and democratic in the world and we share many common values. 3. TTIP may serve as a model for high standards for other emerging economies, but also return lost investor confidence.  4. Economically, the Agreement also has a strong geopolitical dimension. Moreover, TTIP has the potential to become the most significant project between Europe and the US since the establishment of THE UNITED STATES to the present day. I think at this point it is very important to concentrate on the type of agreement.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The fact that the EP has finally reached agreement on recommendations to the Commission in the TTIP negotiations is to be welcomed. On the other hand, protracted negotiations and stormy debates in the Plenary Chamber only show that we can sometimes stop seeing the ultimate goal through emotions. It is long time for the EU's free trade agreement with the world's other largest economy. In the EU, this is an opportunity to boost economic growth, job creation and new opportunities for European consumers and businesses.  It is not permissible that some politicians are playing with public fears. The EP reaffirmed that the agreement must not come at the expense of reducing EU standards or increasing the vulnerability of the most sensitive sectors. The EP listened to the position of various groups of public and interest. On the other hand, the myths promoted by someone who matures the hostility of groups in society must not be omitted inaudible, and must be strongly denied. I would call for this now, because the most important decision on TTIP is still at the forefront.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of Mr Lange's report. This report sets out the strategic importance of economic relations between the European Union and the United States as an opportunity to promote its principles and values, anchored in a framework based on rules shared by both parties. Defines common strategies and visions with regard to world trade, investment and trade-related issues, such as strict standards, standards and regulations, so as to develop a broader transatlantic vision and a common set of strategic objectives; TTIP is an opportunity to shape and regulate the international trading order in order to ensure that both blocs thrive in an interconnected world, protecting the prerogatives and peculiarities of our excellence.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the transatlantic agreement because it calls for continued negotiations with the United States even though the stakes of these negotiations have not been raised and citizens have not been consulted. The decision whether or not to pursue trade negotiations with the United States on the current basis is a choice of civilization. First of all, it is a geopolitical choice: do we want to be part of a West grouped in this trade agreement? It is a choice of social model: do we want to put our social, environmental, precautionary standards in competition with the absence of American rules? Finally, it is a choice of society: are we ready to give up popular sovereignty, human rights in favour of a transatlantic business law? Instead, this resolution returns a blank cheque to the Commission, which negotiates, and maintains the investor-state dispute settlement system, which allows a company to attack a state through a private arbitration system. I therefore regret, and this vote and the way it was imposed on us by the President of Parliament, who clearly influenced his result by abusing his prerogatives.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This european Parliament's motion for a resolution on TTIP is a soft text that sometimes says everything and its opposite, but a text that never sets red lines for the Commission.  This text does not call for the abolition of the ISDS - the arbitration tribunals - but, if possible, calls for an appeal mechanism and a permanent international court (possibly but not necessarily, in the medium term, disputes could be settled at an international arbitration court with professional judges). This text proposes to exclude services of general interest (such as water, health, social security, education, social services) from the scope of TTIP so that states can continue to provide them. For other public services, we do not know what will happen (SNCF, EDF ...). This text proposes the establishment of regulatory cooperation between the United States and the EU, a structured cooperation with the aim of economic efficiency, without undermining the competences of American and European legislators (!). Conclusion: the European Parliament has focused on almost every subject, draws almost no red lines to the Commission on TTIP and only makes declarations of intent. I'm voting against it.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I abstained on Mr Lange's report on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). The last-minute compromise on ISDS proposed by the rapporteur meant that I did not vote against this report. Many of my doubts remain about small and medium-sized enterprises, GMOs and access to the air and maritime transport market.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. There are many unacceptable points in this text, including the desire to abolish tariffs, to facilitate free trade in services, the establishment of regulatory cooperation, which can be harmful in the medium term for the European Union, especially in terms of standards. I believe that French agriculture, a sector already in a major crisis, has everything to lose with this kind of agreement.  This report does not stress enough the necessary protection that should be enjoyed by certain sectors of the European economy, and as a farmer, I believe that agriculture is one of those sectors to be protected.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report includes labour and environmental objectives that are mandatory — namely the ratification, implementation and implementation of major international conventions, such as the eight ILO Conventions; the exclusion of public services from TTE; and full respect for government capacity to decide how services of general interest (whatever their current form of financing and management) are financed, managed and provided. In addition, an amendment calls for the elimination of the ISDS and its replacement by a new system with sufficient guarantees and necessary democratic controls. By agreeing on these aspects, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. After more than a year and a half of negotiations, the European Parliament must be able to continue to express itself on the possible TTE. Thanks to the adoption of the report, it is possible to resume dialogue between the US and the European Union to achieve terms that benefit citizens of both regions. At the current juncture, such a bilateral treaty with the U.S. has positive geopolitical implications, as it allows us to project our regulations globally, rather than conforming to a passive role. Subjecting the agreement to EP scrutiny through debate is the only way to reduce uncertainty around the agreement and consolidate citizen support. The next step following the adoption of the report is to clarify, through the Commission, the functioning of the investor-state dispute settlement system (ISDS).  Voting in favour of this report is the only way forward in negotiations for a more competitive European Union.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) creates more free trade. This is nothing more than the "expanding of markets" and leads to greater product selection, more competition, higher productivity and cheaper prices. The theoretical ly sebes and risks of TTIP were discussed intensively in committee. In the Lange report voted on here, 'red lines' are appropriately drawn against them. One of these guidelines is to abolish old-style ISDS and create a new investor protection system for it. Since the report requires that foreign investors do not have special rights, it is ensured that they cannot appeal to international arbitration tribunals. By approving this report, I want to provide constructive support for the process of creating the TTIP, without pre-incipiating a decision on the final agreement.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The fundamental question with the TTIP agreement is whether it will improve our competitiveness, whether it will be an opportunity or a threat to businesses and consumers. Looking at the various statistical analyses, we cannot formulate a clear answer to these questions. Nevertheless, the agreement, which aims to liberalise trade between the Union and the United States, will undoubtedly lead to increased competition from large American corporations, which most small and medium-sized enterprises may not be able to meet. As a result, the beneficiaries of this agreement may be mainly large European corporations, which are already preparing for its implementation. Without reasonable protection of our market and regulations ensuring the protection of consumers and the public interest, we condemn ourselves to the dominance of commercial and financial interests, in which only economic profit matters. The TTIP agreement may also entail the risk of harmonisation of standards and standards, unfortunately by equating to a lower, but cheaper, US level. This poses a major threat to m.in food safety, workers' rights or the further relocation of production to countries with lower costs. The mechanism for resolving disputes between states and investors is also of great doubt. In view of the above doubts, I abstained from voting on the resolution on the negotiation of the TTIP agreement.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement (TTIP) has important geopolitical significance for both the European Union and the US. It will improve bilateral relations between the world's two largest economies, but will also have an impact on the multilateral trading system. The purpose is to improve economic growth, boost job creation and achieve better trade conditions.  TTIP will also have an impact on the Republic of Croatia, especially small and medium-sized entrepreneurs. Reducing unnecessary costs, simplifying administration and procedure, will significantly facilitate the placement of Croatian products on the US market. The Republic of Croatia has a bilateral treaty with the USA dating back to 1996. However, TTIP creates better conditions, i.e. a better investment protection framework, so I supported this Report.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the TTIP resolution, the EP made its recommendations regarding the Negotiating Mandate of the European Commission, agreed among 14 of its committees.   For us MEPs, the priority in the negotiations is to achieve a new dynamic in the European economy and a guarantee for the opening up of markets and access to capital for European business overseas, as well as the preservation of European standards in terms of competition, health, food quality, environmental and labour standards. The EP stands firmly behind the rights and interests of European citizens, as well as the right of states to set public policies at national and local level, to be protected and guaranteed.   Most importantly, the EP issued an extremely strong warning to the negotiating leaders, namely that it would not support the agreement if the arbitration mechanism were maintained in its current form. Without revision or even removal and replacement by a new, much more transparent mechanism, the agreement cannot be adopted by the European Parliament. I hope that this will be heard, because this resolution was supported by two-thirds of the colleagues who want this dispute to become part of the EU-US relationship. The revision of this mechanism is the only opportunity to give this agreement a chance to achieve a historical common market.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We have given a mandate to the Commission for further negotiations on an agreement aimed at ensuring growth and jobs on both sides of the Atlantic. Today, both in the EU and in the US, there are bureaucratic obstacles that are equivalent to tariff barriers of 10-20% and hinder access to markets, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are unable to bear the additional costs. By removing trade barriers, we will facilitate trade in goods and services, we will bring new investments to Europe and the US. For Europe, the agreement will bring in almost EUR 120 billion a year and more than a million new jobs. All negotiations on the part of the EU are conducted on one strict condition: we will not reduce the levels of protection that we have in Europe today. This applies to health, the environment, consumer protection, but also to social standards and employee protection. U.S. companies will not be favored over domestic businesses, as has been the case since 1991 in Slovakia. The investor-state dispute settlement system will be subject to democratic principles and control. Any disputes will be approached by publicly appointed, independent professional judges at public hearings. The jurisdiction of the COURTS of the EU and the Member States will be respected and private interests cannot outweigh the public.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin strongly opposed the vote. TTIP, TAFTA, PTCI, whatever it is called this partnership agreement with the United States is a threat to France. Despite the Union's fine rhetoric, this agreement can only have negative consequences for the French: the American health, safety, environmental and social standards are much lower than ours and portends, in the long run, a levelling down to "satisfy" our partner. Their 'ISDS', this arbitration tribunal, will resolve disputes between investors without the Member States having a say.  This text is a long litany of wishful thinking of the European institutions, which cover themselves by proposing a text without any requirement and without criteria for negotiation. We do not condone the sale of our standards, values and interests in this way.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the transatlantic partnership on trade and investment. The proposed objective is to integrate, through a free trade agreement between the US and the EU, the two markets in order to break down customs duties and remove non-tariff barriers and barriers. It should be remembered, in fact, that micro-enterprises suffer significantly from sectors and non-tariff barriers - ONT -. Given that small and medium-sized enterprises represent the most significant part of the European economy, opening up the US market to SMEs, without compromising COMMUNITY standards in any way, will be a reason for Europe's GDP to grow. The resulting benefits in a free trade area will therefore also be reflected in local communities with a subsequent increase in the employment rate.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the TTIP – Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. Its alleged aim is to remove barriers to trade in order to make it easier to buy and sell goods and services between the EU and the US. But what are the obstacles? Differences in laws, technical regulations, standards and approval procedures. The aim of the agreement is, inter alia, to get as close as possible to the elimination of all tariffs on transatlantic trade in industrial and agricultural products, says the European Commission. So we're going to accept American genetically engineered corn? Investment protection is also to be part of the agreement. However, this also means arbitral settlement of investor-state disputes, excluding state courts. Among other things, the state is to be responsible for labour disputes under national law – that is, for trade union strikes and demonstrations. They must pay the investor damages for these disputes. Regardless of their legitimacy. Another problem with TTIP is the need for agreement on intellectual property law, where the European and American models differ strongly and a separate chapter is the regulation of data protection. The negotiations take place behind closed doors. No one has invited representatives of European trade unions, for example, the voices of citizens who oppose the agreement are also not being listened to. I say that this agreement is only beneficial to one party and does not do Europe any good. I voted against it.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this document, the European Parliament has had the opportunity to express its position on the ongoing negotiations between the European Commission and its US counterpart on the establishment of a transatlantic trade and investment partnership, better known as TTIP. In view of the fact that the conclusion of this agreement would benefit the European economy, as well as easier integration of national small and medium-sized enterprises into the international market, I have decided to support this report with a vote in favour.  My support for this document also stems from the awareness that the conclusion of the partnership agreement would create the conditions for an increase in the employment rate in all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that these recommendations do not safeguard the rights and interests of European citizens and call into question public services, democracy and sovereignty.  The amendment on the ISDS (State-Investor dispute resolution) that was adopted is just a scheme to camouflage another form of ISDS and thus say that private arbitration has ended, which is nothing more than an attempt to manipulate public opinion. With the new ISDS, companies and multinationals will continue to have a right of veto over the legislative capacity of states, which is an attack on democracy that we cannot afford.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. After many twists and turns, MEPs were finally invited to vote on the Lange resolution, which was intended to define the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission in its negotiations with the US authorities on the transatlantic treaty (TTIP/TAFTA).  For weeks, in the INTA committee as in the plenary session, I have been constantly reminding me of my credo: in order to gather my support, the resolution should be strong and strictly frame the negotiations. A hollow resolution, on the other hand, would have every chance of allowing negotiators to break free from Parliament's view and further distance themselves from the legitimate expectations of civil society. Despite the introduction of strong safeguards in several areas (for example, protection of workers' rights, the environment or geographical indications), the resolution remained too ambiguous and insufficiently firm on points that do not seem to me to be negotiable: the unconditional, clear, clear and precise refusal of private arbitration (ISDS/RDIE), the protection of public services and the right of States to legislate in areas of general interest. Regretting that the parliamentarians, representing European citizens, were not able to give the TTIP negotiators a sufficiently demanding mandate, I voted against the resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This agreement was rejected by me. All my previous reservations about the partnership have been cosmetically altered, but not abolished. As long as our objections are not dealt with and the competences of the companies of the nation states are not heard, I will not give my assent to the agreement.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement is a major recent EU-US project. TTIP is expected to have a positive impact on job creation, growth and competitiveness in both economies affected by the crisis.  However, it is important to stress that this agreement is not only important for trade aspects. Strengthening the transatlantic partnership is important for us and from a strategic point of view, especially in view of the current geopolitical situation.  I share the view of the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs that TTIP negotiations should be conducted as transparently and openly as possible in order to avoid unnecessary speculation and mistrust.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership and the compromise on ISDS which calls for a new, open and accountable system of dispute settlement. This will ensure that foreign investors are treated in a non-discriminatory fashion, while benefiting from no greater rights than domestic investors, and will replace the ISDS-system with a new system for resolving disputes between investors and states which is subject to democratic principles and scrutiny, where potential cases are treated in a transparent manner by publicly appointed, independent professional judges in public hearings and which includes an appellate mechanism, where consistency of judicial decisions is ensured, the jurisdiction of courts of the EU and of the Member States is respected, and where private interests cannot undermine public policy objectives.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I have been fighting against the project of a large transatlantic market for 10 years now. An initiative report on the subject is now submitted to us. It broadly validates the draft treaty, further maintaining the principle of arbitration tribunals, which is widely condemned in Europe and around the world. A survey organised by the Commission found that 98% of Europeans surveyed oppose this private justice system. So much so that in June, the coalition of the right and the Social Democrats had postponed the vote for fear of losing on this point. Today, always with clarity and coherence, I oppose the great transatlantic market and the arbitration tribunals, and I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Lange's resolution is a document in support of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. The transatlantic partnership would further reduce the economic sovereignty of EU Member States and create a free trade area clearly unfavourable to the EU and its citizens. Some of the proposed amendments are very interesting and go in the right direction, but do not sufficiently modify the text. Being opposed to the transatlantic partnership, I vote against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report contains the recommendations to the Community executive negotiating the agreement with us-american partners on behalf of the EU. It aims to take the view of the eu-US talks since July 2013, indicating the European Parliament's position on certain key issues. It has become clear that the trade and investment agreement between the EU and the US should increase access to the US market, but without compromising European Union standards or the right to regulate in the public interest. In this regard, I have presented my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on Parliament’s recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) because it is a workable compromise between the major political groups within Parliament. It is important that the Commission takes note of Parliament’s position regarding TTIP when negotiating the details of this trade agreement.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's TTIP resolution contains the mandatory red lines to be imposed on negotiators. It is undeniable that TTIP will have a positive impact both geopolitically and economically.  Too often the desire to establish common standards with the United States is wrongly criticized. However, this is much more positive than negative. The world is changing, that is a fact. But Europe too often takes its power for granted. However, the meteoric rise of new world powers is directly competing with us. We need to create a bloc that shares the same values and norms.  If we stand by and hold back our anchorage in the world, others like China or India will do so for us and ultimately dictate their standards on the international stage. If we do not strengthen our standards today with the United States, who will we be able to do it with tomorrow? Only together will we be strong enough to maintain our global standards and avoid the race to the bottom.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU Member States are getting closer and closer to a huge agreement with the US on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership to promote trade between them in goods and services. However, the negotiations cannot focus solely on improving economic indicators and trade statistics. We must stick to the EU's high standards of environment, health and food safety, which are now a model for the whole world, even at the cost of not having an agreement adopted.  Nor do I strongly agree with the slightest reduction in high standards of consumer and employee protection or a reduction in social standards, and I also reject the restriction of the regulatory powers of the Member States. In the name of trade cooperation, it is not possible to deny the protection of citizens' health in key areas. In my opinion, therefore, the agreement should not include at all certain areas relating to citizens' health, such as public health services, genetically modified food, the use of hormones in cattle farming.  Finally, I would like to express my regret that the negotiating recommendation to the European Commission is only non-binding and that the European Parliament has no official powers to enter into or forcefully influence trade negotiations. However, at the end of the negotiation process, we will have to comment on the final form of the agreement only by flat-rate approval or rejection.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I think that this agreement – if and only if negotiated properly – could be of benefit to our economies and could open up new opportunities for European companies, especially small and medium-sized ones. Therefore, I voted in favour of the Report containing the European Parliament’s recommendations to the European Commission on the negotiations for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), which is not a ‘Yes or No’ vote on TTIP, but instead outlines our priorities and main conditions of the European Parliament for a good future agreement, ones that respect European citizens.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted today for a comprehensive and ambitious TTIP. As shadow rapporteur for the TTIP opinion in the Committee on Industry, Research and Industrial Affairs, I have witnessed the lengthy and difficult negotiations from the outset and Am all the more pleased that the European Parliament has today voted in favour of an ambitious and well-negotiated agreement with the United States. I also voted in favour of the compromise, which provides for ISDS to be replaced by a new system for resolving disputes between investors and nation states. This system should be based on democratic principles and ensure that foreign investors do not have more rights than domestic investors. All dispute resolution cases must be handled transparently by publicly appointed independent judges with the possibility of appeal. This will ensure that political objectives are not undermined by private interests.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am an unethical supporter of TTIP, and I see it as a great opportunity for Europe to emerge from the economic crisis. At the same time, the agreement under negotiation has received a number of critical comments from the European public, and its public acceptance is woefully low. I agree with the rapporteur that this can be helped above all by the transparency of the negotiations, and I see that the report is seeking to achieve the highest possible level of transparency.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union and the United States of America are two natural allies, historically cooperating in various thematic areas, from combating terrorism, promoting human rights, freedom and democracy in third countries, or the promotion of trade relations. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is of the utmost importance for both geographical blocs, as it aims to create a single market for trade and services, regulate world trade rules and remove barriers and customs tariffs that still exist. In economic terms, it is important to highlight the future creation of a market with 800 million citizens and the fact that trade contributes to boosting European GDP by 0.5% and that of the United States by 0.4%. I am fully in favour of this new Transatlantic Agreement which could place Portugal and, especially the Autonomous Region of Madeira, at the geostrategic centre of world trade.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Lange report on the transatlantic treaty is a scandalous attack on democracy and demonstrates the non-representation of this Parliament. While 97% of European citizens have expressed their concern about TTIP, MEPs have decided to override it to satisfy obscure interests. And all this for a hypothetical increase in growth over the long term (0.4% growth spread over ten years according to the studies funded by the Commission), whose estimate is lower than the cost of sanctions against Russia. Faced with the threat posed by this treaty to French farmers who will have to face competition from products with hygiene standards and particularly critical production conditions, the National Front MEPs had raised their concerns through several motions for a resolution. The dispute resolution mechanism that will allow a private company to legally turn against a state if a standard does not suit it is also sustainable. This treaty would therefore organise the playing field of multinationals in defiance of the sovereignty of the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report due to the inclusion of ISDS in the text, which enables companies to sue governments.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership between the European Union and the United States. The European Commission is responsible for conducting the negotiations, but the European Parliament has significant responsibility and power, as it will have to approve the agreement and can give its political guidance to the Commission to influence the negotiation.  The TTIP will increase trade and thus job creation through the prospect of additional opportunities for our businesses, especially our SMEs. Nevertheless, I will remain very vigilant to ensure that it does not weaken the European standards that protect us and to which I am attached. That is why I voted in particular for Amendment 117, which calls for the replacement of the Investor-State Dispute Settlement Mechanism (ISDR) with "a new system subject to democratic principles and control, where any cases will be dealt with transparently by independent professional judges, appointed by the public authorities, in open court, and which will include an appeal mechanism. , a mechanism that will ensure the coherence of court decisions and respect for the jurisdiction of the european Union and its Member States and prevent public policy objectives from being undermined by private interests."

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European Union to continue negotiations with the United States, with a view to establishing a trade and investment agreement that looks forward-lookingly to the near and near future. As you know, the current negotiations are also the subject of justified criticism: criticisms taken up by Parliament, which has considered them in the report, making and giving the Commission clear indications on the basis of the safeguards to be guaranteed to European consumers: principles of transparency, protection of standards, supremacy of the general interest of citizens. In a way that is not at all ambiguous, Parliament is calling for European standards not to be 'lowered', because they are necessary to ensure sustainable and inclusive growth.  It is no coincidence that the report clearly states that no American multinational will enjoy greater protection or more favourable rules in the EU than its European counterparts. In the context of the many decisive challenges that are already facing Europe, we need a strategy of greater sharing with our allies overseas. TTIP, when it is defined and approved, will mark a very important step in the relaunch of the EU at all levels, starting with the political level, within the international framework.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament today managed to send an important signal, and recalled its red lines on TTIP.   The exclusion of public and audiovisual services from negotiations, the protection of our standards and our agricultural model, the protection of our choices of society, the recognition of geographical indications, the need for reciprocal access to public procurement, these are some of the red lines for which I am proud to have voted. The European Parliament has managed to get out of a deadlock by demonstrating not only the need to protect our investors abroad, but also to abandon the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism in its current operation. The latter must be reformed in order to respect the right to regulate states. It must function as a true public jurisdiction. In this regard, it will have to meet transparency obligations and include an appeal mechanism. We must tell the truth to the citizens who are too often exploited by dishonest political machines. Today we sent the negotiators a message of vigilance: Parliament will not accept anything.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We express our support for this draft resolution on the ongoing negotiations between the European Union and the United States on a trade and investment treaty. We express ourselves in this way because we firmly believe that the Treaty can bring benefits to citizens on both sides of the Atlantic.  Similarly, a successful conclusion of the agreement could place the EU and the US as standard-setters in the context of globalisation. The Treaty presents potential critical issues, but the rapporteur's resolution, thanks to important mediation work between the political parties and the bodies of civil society and thanks to the opinions of the other competent committees, is an ambitious text that safeguards European principles and standards, creates opportunities for SMEs, but above all honours the role and new competences acquired by the European Parliament. , as a full co-legislator with the Council, on international trade.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, When the world around us concludes agreements on common markets, when Russia is allied with China, China is allied with India and Indochina, and even the free trade agreement between South America, the Pacifikum and the United States of America is about to be concluded, the European Union simply cannot pretend that it does not need to expand its markets. These are two equivalent economic systems, mostly with balanced trade indicators, which would only increase if the legislation of the two major powers were gradually harmonised with each other, thereby removing unnecessary licensing, customs and administrative obstacles. In practice, this would mean more supply and better prices for users, and it is true for traders that it would bring increased competition, but also a double internal market. Now we have the opportunity to create the strongest bilateral economic bloc that can then set international standards.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report so that the TTIP agreement will have the highest possible level of transparency and will guarantee that only a good agreement will be adopted, an agreement which respects European values, stimulates sustainable growth and contributes to the well-being of all citizens.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is Sinn Fein’s position that the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership being negotiated by the European Union and United States will have disastrous consequences for democracy in Member States, the environment, labour rights and public services. This report endorsed the TTIP negotiations, which have been carried out in secret. I voted in favour of several amendments tabled by my group, the GUE/NGL, and the Greens. These ranged from an outright rejection of the TTIP project to specific amendments aimed at protecting workers’ rights, food and water standards, public services, and the environment. I voted in favour of the joint GUE-NGL/EFDD/Greens amendment that called for the negotiations to adopt a ‘positive list’ approach when dealing with services. On the critical issue of the ISDS – investor-state dispute settlement – there were two key compromise amendments, 117 (proposed by rapporteur Lange) and 118 (proposed by the Greens). I voted against Amendment 117 and in favour of Amendment 118. There is massive public opposition to the secretive trade deal among my constituents. The TTIP will have a seriously detrimental impact in Ireland – on jobs, agriculture, the environment, workers’ rights and vital public services.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Right from the start I have outlined that the TTIP process should be transparent and that it is paramount that our public services are not opened up to multinational private interests. The compromise which I voted for explicitly calls the negotiators to go back to the drawing board with investor protection – it removes ISDS and calls for a reformed process. It also calls explicitly for protection of our public services. The debate on TTIP has moved on considerably over the past six months. Thanks to pressure from the public and from MEPs, the Parliament has now recommended against ISDS as we once knew it. But the extremely important thing to remember is that this vote is not on TTIP – no final deal is close to being agreed. It is a vote on the Parliament’s recommendations to the negotiators. If or when a final deal is agreed, it has to be ratified by 28 Member States and by the European Parliament. If that final deal risks dismantling our NHS, I will not be voting in favour.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I have certain reserves towards the TTIP project, I certainly support the European Parliament report on this issue and I can only hope the EU negotiators will take these recommendations to heart. They need to remember that whatever they negotiate with the US needs to pass a vote in plenary and that their work needs to be focused on opening up markets and not de-regulating important EU health rules. They need to focus on generating mutual prosperity and not allow unfair market and investor practices to detrimentally affect the citizens of Europe. This is because the European Parliament will not allow just any type of TTIP to be adopted.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the TTIP recommendation not only because I support the negotiation of the agreement, but also because the EP has expressed some views in it that should lead to a better TTIP. The old Investor-State Dispute Settlement Mechanism (ISDS) should be replaced by a new system with publicly appointed and independent judges, public hearings and an appeal mechanism. I welcome this, thanks to my experience, I consider this a welcome shift. The new ISDS should ensure greater predictability, independence and impartiality of decision-making. A safeguard clause should also be included in the TTIP, which would apply in the event of an increase in imports of a product which would pose a risk of serious harm to domestic food production. With today's vote, the EP has been able to bridge ideological divisions and take an important step towards a better and better TTIP agreement with the widest possible support. I thank my colleagues who supported the agreement.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D)
text: Writing. I welcome in principle the work on a resolution by the representation of European citizens on the ongoing negotiations on TTIP. This gives the European Parliament the opportunity to provide the European Commission with clear guidelines for further negotiations. Many of the points contained in the resolution are worthy of support: compliance with the ILO core labour standards is just one of them. Nevertheless, I made my vote in favour of the resolution conditional on the rejection of compromise amendment 117. The compromise reached does not go far enough for me and allows too much room for interpretation. National legal channels, both in the US and in Europe, are perfectly sufficient for investment disputes. I reject a new system that does not clearly exclude any form of arbitration. Consequently, I voted against the whole resolution.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report shows purely cosmetic changes. The report tries, with a few phrases, to deceive voters into consumer protection and food quality. On the whole, this report remains a sham. I remain opposed to the agreement in my previous reservations and have therefore voted against it.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against the European Parliament's resolution on the negotiations for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, known as 'TTIP', simply because the adoption of this resolution means support for the continuation of the negotiations.  However, for more than two years now, European citizens, as well as many communities and SMEs, have strongly opposed this agreement which directly threatens existing rights and protections in Europe. The large transatlantic market poses a threat to the construction of a political Europe, which has become absolutely essential today if we are to hope to save the Union.  We know all too well that common markets without political and democratic institutions that are able to impose rules on markets only strengthen competition between states. A free trade agreement of this magnitude cannot be achieved without objectives of respect and implementation of the economic, social, environmental and cultural rights of European and American citizens.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (DP) is essential for the further development of EU-US relations. This agreement also has significant political and security implications. In the current world, strong cooperation between the EU and the US is very important and therefore a new agreement must also be reached as soon as possible. The EU-US Free Trade Agreement must help to promote economic growth. The agreement must help to increase our international competitiveness and create new opportunities for EU companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and to support the creation of quality jobs for European citizens and to bring direct benefits to European consumers. A free trade agreement would create a European-US free trade area with greater opportunities.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. There has been significant progress on isDS that opens the door to a new improved system (Amendment No 117), but we abstained in the vote by not taking the expected steps on regulatory cooperation.  The text does not clearly define those regulations and sectors excluded from any negotiation. We hope that this will be clarified over the coming months, with full guarantees of our political rights and what European legislation stands for. We the following support Amendments Nos 93, 19 and 72. US and European standards are very different in the areas listed: pesticides, disruptors, food security, animal welfare, transparency in clinical trials... We understand that cooperation is necessary to remove barriers to trade, such as excessive bureaucracy, but we must not jeopardize what the EU is an example and a reference for. The agricultural and food sectors are key to ensuring food security, but they have also been strategic within speculative exchange dynamics and investment funds. Its liberalization is evident in the above and in the latest reforms. These sectors and the protection of our standards are red lines for UPyD and the vast majority of EU citizens, which is why we support them.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report of the Committee on International Trade because it promotes the conclusion of the TTP. The European Parliament is under an error to sign the agreement to recover the profits of European monopolies. The Jrc did not take part in the vote on the amendments concerning various sub-parties to the agreement under negotiation, because it refuses to participate in its legitimacy operation in the popular consciousness, under the illusion that it can supposedly be changed or corrected. The amendments and the eu euro-one-way parties that deposit them reflect the particular interests of parts of the chapter, which seek to strengthen their positions in the negotiations on international competition. TTIR is the economic NATO, which is why it cannot be improved or corrected. The jrc's position is clear. TTIR is by its nature and character deeply unpopular. The people must reject it along with the exploitative system it serves. With their struggle to thwart it, to free themselves from imperialist wolf alliances, opening their own path of development with their own power that at its center will have the satisfaction of popular needs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the TTIP negotiations, I support the report proposed by the Committee on International Trade, as I believe that the Treaty has the potential to greatly benefit the European economy and in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, without affecting the level of standards currently in force in the EU. I am pleased that, despite the difficulties, an agreement has also been reached in my group and I voted according to the parameters that I think it would be appropriate for the EU to have in the negotiation of TTIP.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the European Parliament’s recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations for TTIP, which presents a more balanced account of the important advantages and opportunities offered by the agreement. The Parliament’s recommendations reflect key arguments in support of TTIP and its potential to unlock a billion-dollar market. This is particularly the case for countries like Bulgaria, which, as part of the EU, will be able to play a greater role on the global trade market. For such countries, TTIP also means enhanced mobility, recognition of professional qualifications on the foreign labour market and access to the US public procurement market, which is the largest in the world. We need to focus on these advantages and avoid equating the debate on TTIP to a debate on the negative effects of globalisation. Europe must be driver and a main beneficiary of these processes, instead of attempting to circumvent them, and TTIP can aid us in this regard.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to waive the provisions relating to the ISDS mechanism (investor-state dispute resolution) under the treaty negotiated with the US. On this occasion, an important message was also given by the S&D rapporteur, Bernd Lange: ISDS must be removed from all bilateral agreements, with more than 1,300 agreements containing such provisions and mechanisms here. S&D has once again proven that it wants equal rights for both European and non-EU investors.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. This agreement is one of the answers to a changing world. It seems to me right that such an important and ambitious project with long-term implications for transatlantic cooperation should pay particular attention and a high degree of transparency. I am not surprised that the general public is so intensely interested in this agreement and requires political and legal assurances to maintain standards related to health, food, the environment and culture. Insisting on maintaining the standards in question seems to me to be too little, and the common ambition should be to improve such standards further through a common regulatory framework for the good of the people. I therefore agree that the agreement is not only for increased trade volumes and geo-strategic interest, but also for the quality of goods on which the quality of our lives depends.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is the most important EU-US project in recent times and the most significant global trade agreement negotiated today by the EU-US negotiating groups. The political significance of this agreement is also invaluable for strengthening transatlantic co-operation in other areas as well. With the adoption of the Resolution, the European Parliament supported the negotiations, but at the same time clearly expressed its disagreements, fears and wishes to the EU negotiating team. I supported amendments that make it clear that it is necessary to accept the fact that in cases where the EU and the US have very different rules, there will be no agreement, especially when it comes to public health services, genetically modified organisms, the use of hormones in the bovine breeding sector, REACH and its implementation, and animal cloning for breeding, and therefore these issues cannot be negotiated.  A compromise has also been reached seeking to replace the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism with a new system that includes an appeals mechanism that ensures consistency of court decisions and respect for the jurisdiction of EU courts and Member States and where private interests cannot jeopardise public policy objectives.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Lange report on the transatlantic treaty is a scandalous attack on democracy and demonstrates the non-representativeness of this Parliament. While 97% of the citizens of the Member States expressed their concern about TTIP, MEPs decided to override (after delaying debate and vote in order to agree discreetly behind the scenes) to satisfy obscure interests, all for a hypothetical increase in long-term growth (only 0.4% spread over ten years according to the studies funded by the Commission!) , whose estimate is lower than the cost of sanctions against Russia.  Faced with the threat posed by this treaty to French farmers who will have to face competition from products with hygiene standards and particularly critical production conditions, the National Front MEPs had raised their concerns through several motions for a resolution. The dispute resolution mechanism that will allow a private company to legally turn against a state if a standard does not meet it is also sustainable. This treaty would therefore organise the playing field of multinationals in defiance of the sovereignty of Member States and peoples. Of course, I voted against it.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution approved by Parliament is intended in part to correct the overly benevolent mandate for the European Commission that it has received from the Member States. However, it is essential to stress that this is a non-legislative resolution, a recommendation for the European Commission, it is not a vote on TTIP itself. The resolution is intended to draw attention to areas where there must be no compromises and where European standards must be accepted. It would be irresponsible to prefer populism if it is still possible to intervene realistically in the negotiations. The European Parliament is the eu's only democratically elected body, so it has a responsibility to outline what kind of agreement it will or will not accept. For example, not emoticaking a resolution would mean unspoken support for ISDS in its original version and other problematic parts of the agreement. The resolution is the result of several months of cooperation involving 14 committees. This is not a perfect text, but it clearly outlines what the Commission should focus on in further negotiations. Parliament, for example, has set tough limits on data protection and financial services and rejected any form of private arbitration within isds. From my point of view, the report could have contained more recommendations in the areas of the environment, health and food, but, as I have already mentioned, this is a compromise that is simply the best that this Parliament could agree on by a majority. However, this is by no means the green light for the approval of TTIP as such.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is undoubtedly true that the EU needs a better trade agreement with the US. However, it is also true that such a treaty must reflect both commercial and citizens' interests, especially in the field of health and consumer protection. The draft report from the pen of S&D MEMBER Bernd Lange was withdrawn from the agenda of the June plenary session, as a number of right-wing Members had clearly declared their rejection of the report in the event of acceptance of the Social Democrats' request to set aside an investor-state dispute resolution system in the form of private arbitrations (isds) because there were legitimate concerns about the disadvantageous position of states vis-à-vis private firms. Eu President Martin Schulz has therefore proposed, as part of the renegotiation, a compromise proposal that has received majority support from the Social Democrats and which calls for the replacement of the ISDS mechanism, the private arbitration mechanism, with a new, public, democratic and more transparent mechanism. I am glad that the European Parliament, thanks to my vote, supported both the compromise proposal on the dispute resolution mechanism and the whole document. I consider this to be a clearly positive step in the process of further negotiating the Treaty, which is undoubtedly very much needed for the EU's competitiveness on a global scale. Of course, the European Parliament will vote on the final text of the Treaty and all the proposed measures will certainly be scrutiny in detail.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) is without a doubt one of the most important dossiers on which the European Parliament is called upon to express its opinion. The UNITED States remains the EU's main trading partner and export market. According to the available data, 88% of the companies exporting to the United States are small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and 10 million jobs in Europe depend on exports to that country. On the other hand, it should be borne in mind that there are still a number of aspects that I believe deserve special attention during the negotiations, such as geographical indications (GIs) and consumer health protection. Following lengthy negotiations, the Committee on International Trade (INTA) approved a draft recommendation, in which it reiterated its wish to conclude an ambitious agreement with the aim of ensuring market access in the areas of trade, services, investment and public procurement. At the same time, the INTA Committee calls for a balanced approach, providing for transitional periods, quotas or even exemptions for a number of sensitive products. I believe that this draft report is a good compromise and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of its adoption.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. After the long debates and melodramas of the Socialists, in particular on the dispute settlement mechanism, we have finally adopted the report on TTIP, which specifies Parliament's interests in the negotiations between the European Commission and the US authorities.  I voted in favour of this report, on which I tabled 50 amendments, most of which were taken up. However, if we have succeeded in including our red lines, we must continue to be vigilant as negotiations continue to be held to defend the interests of our citizens and our businesses. Europe cannot be the only continent immobile in a world in motion. Yet the far left and right have managed to find French Green and Socialist allies to maintain a status quo in our relations with the United States. Are they so happy to see our companies in trouble on the U.S. government markets? Are they satisfied that trade disputes are going on forever (Boeing vs. Airbus)? Why would you refuse to even negotiate to put all the issues on the table? Making the politics of the ostrich is not worthy of the first trading power that we are. Those who voted against underestimate Europe and overestimate the United States.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Today, Parliament adopted a resolution on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). This text does not constitute a final vote on TTIP but declines the recommendations made by the European Parliament to the European Commission in the context of negotiations with the United States.  Although this resolution incorporates recommendations that go in the right direction on the protection of social rights, I have decided to vote against this text, because it does not sufficiently clearly reject the establishment of private arbitration tribunals. The French Socialists have always strongly rejected the creation of such private courts between state and investors, which undermine the democratic foundation of our courts and call into question the legislative sovereignty of public authorities.   Finally, on the protection of public services, I regret that the resolution does not guarantee that only the services explicitly mentioned are covered by the agreement in order to strictly frame the scope of the TTIP. On this fundamental issue, as well as on regulatory cooperation on social, environmental or agri-food standards, the adopted resolution does not go far enough in its recommendations to the Commission for the continuation of negotiations.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the vote of this report which makes firm demands for reaching a transatlantic trade and investment partnership beneficial to both blocs. I voted in favour of this report because it does not put the quality of public services at risk and also insists on respect for environmental standards, health, social protection, data protection, consumer protection and food safety. I support a new investor-to-investor dispute settlement mechanism, which is fully public and transparent, with impartial professional judges.  Portugal will be one of the countries to benefit first from the TTIP as the national strategic sectors (such as footwear and textiles) are one sofa with the highest customs fees. As far as my region, the Autonomous Region of the Azores, the archipelago's GDP would increase by 0.35%, according to a study by the Centre for Economic Policy Research (CEPR).

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This afternoon, like 436 MEPs, I took responsibility by voting in favour of the Lange resolution calling for the continuation of the TTIP negotiations. This is a vote that confirms the vote cast on 23 May 2013, when a large majority of the European Parliament had already said YES at the opening of the negotiations. But let's be clear, it is not a yes or no to TTIP that we are talking about today, but rather to clarify our recommendations, our concerns, our red lines to the American partner. The European Union essentially shares the same values as the United States, but the approaches are very different in some areas: audiovisual, agriculture and food, social protection and services of general interest. The Lange resolution has incorporated these fundamental differences that the possibility of an agreement tomorrow cannot erase.  Without succumbing to the demonisation that is taking place in certain regions of Europe and in the head of certain political parties, such as Wallonia and Brussels, the European Parliament has, on the other hand, sent a message of hope: it hears the concerns expressed by two million citizens who signed the TTIP petition and responds by strictly highlighting the negotiations but not insulting the future.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, better known by the acronym TTIP, is a free trade agreement between the European Union and the United States, with the aim of generating additional reciprocal economic growth.  Nevertheless, the absolute need to preserve our way of life, and therefore our exacting European standards, hardly seems to be compatible with certain aspects of the American model, hence the discrepancies, notably on the famous arbitration tribunals or the application of environmental and food standards. In addition to disagreements over the substance of the treaty, the asymmetry between the two parties (the United States being an "imperialist" federal state speaking with one voice to the European Union, which often speaks with 28 dissonant voices) should encourage us to be very cautious. This was not to vote for or against TTIP; such a choice is still premature given the progress of the negotiations. Therefore, as this report may go in the direction of a "smart TTIP", I have chosen to abstain.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not comfortable with everything that will be included in this Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement (TTIP). The negotiation process should be more transparent. Globalisation needs rules, but workers' rights, public services, environmental rights, cultural diversity, data protection or conflict arbitration by recourse to public courts that guarantee equal rights for domestic and foreign investors must be safeguarded. These are some of the points that cannot be negotiable. TTIP cannot mean a give-up on the EU's social and moral standards, but it should translate into more benefits for European citizens and businesses. Of course, this was not a vote on TTIP, but of trying to show the Commission the importance of including the European Parliament's point of view and the contributions of the S&D Group.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution because it clearly sets out the European Parliament's position on the TTE negotiations, meeting the main demands of the Socialist Group; because I believe that the market economy is the best way to ensure progress, growth and employment if it is well regulated and confined to a social state that corrects its flaws and redistributes fairly; because trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates the ISDS of private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system.  In short, because it requires an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote globally the values and principles we share with the US, making it clear that we will only support an TIC that regulates trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the transatlantic treaty because I did not, in my view, offer sufficient guarantees for compliance with European standards. Moreover, an amendment compromise advocating the establishment of public instruments has been adopted, while it does not completely close the door to the possible interference of private companies in the settlement of disputes between them and a state.  Without being opposed to the principle of negotiation with the United States, nor to the market economy, provided it is socially regulated, nor to free trade, provided it is fair, I defend a strong Europe, capable of negotiating on an equal footing with other world powers, and a full-fledged player and partner in a multipolar world. I am convinced that the European Union cannot be reduced to the expansion of an economic market dependent on the United States. The priority must be the strengthening of our unity and the establishment of genuine economic and social governance to boost investment and employment.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the free trade treaty between the European Union and the United States, in particular because of the clause on the mechanism of private arbitration, known as 'ISDS', which remains, despite a vague compromise amendment, still included in the resolution.  The ISDS could allow for arbitration in which multinationals would question the choice of European or French legislators and their jurisdictions. Private justice has no place in trade disputes between democratic states. That is why I say that if, at the end of the negotiations, private arbitration were to be included in the agreement between the European Union and the United States, I would reject TTIP.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. In July 2013, the EU and the US began negotiations for a comprehensive, ambitious, balanced and binding trade and investment agreement capable of strengthening transatlantic ties from a regulatory, economic, financial and even geopolitical point of view. This Resolution makes a number of recommendations from the European Parliament to the European Commission on the negotiations of this 'Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)' on the various chapters of the mandate: free access to the market for goods, services and investment, the removal of non-tariff and regulatory barriers, access to public markets, the need to protect our geographical indications and the liberalisation of the energy market. After a record of amendments tabled, long debates and concessions on ISDS, it was possible to achieve a comprehensive text reflecting the balanced and majority position of the European Parliament.  In national terms, I am sure that this agreement will bring a number of advantages and opportunities, especially in terms of exports and job creation, which will make it possible to leverage various sectors of our economy, generating wealth and economic growth.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which addresses the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations of the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership with the United States (TTIP).  Among these recommendations, we were able to recall the red lines that we have always defended, namely the protection of our standards and choice of society, the exclusion of sensitive agricultural products, the exclusion of audiovisual services and public services, reciprocal access to public procurement or the recognition and protection of our geographical indications.  With regard to the Investor-State Dispute Settlement Mechanism (ISDS), we reject the ISDS in its current state. As the text states, it must be reformed, it must respect the right of states to regulate, respond to transparency rules and include an appeal mechanism. It must function as a true public jurisdiction. We will remain attentive to the concerns expressed by European citizens and vigilant about the progress of the negotiations.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Lange report on the 'negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership' better known as TTIP, a dossier that remained unresolved amid a thousand controversies during the June plenary session. I believe that TTIP represents a challenge and an opportunity for European businesses, creating the world's largest free trade area, but environmental, social and safety standards must always be guaranteed to guarantee European citizens.  Specifically, the report voted on presents the state of the art made by the EP's Committee on International Trade on the current negotiations and its prospects two years after the start of the work – a conclusion of the negotiations seems to be still a long way off – and highlights the priorities that the EP believes should be taken into account in the further negotiations. Last but not least, the most important aspect for the Italian system, namely the recognition of indicators of geographical origin, the fight against counterfeiting and Italian sounding and the protection of the agri-food sector.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against as I do not agree with the positive approach to TTIP that emerges from the text.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it recommends to the European Commission lines of action which run counter to the interests of European citizenship, its rights, public services, democracy and sovereignty, which are red and common sense lines for PODEMOS. In addition, the amendment adopted on is clearly a toast to the sun since, although it advises, in the long term, the establishment of an international and public tribunal for investor-state dispute settlement, the US Government has publicly stated that it will not accept it. We therefore consider it a hoax to the public to claim that the private arbitration system is over. That is why we understand that transnational corporations will continue to have a veto on the legislating capacity of States, which is a frontal attack on democracy.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TTIP resolution on the understanding that care will be taken to ensure that the outcome of negotiations will not serve to further increase the economic divergence that is happening between different regions of the European Union and the eurozone. If TTIP serves to further erode the competitive position of SMEs in different parts of the Union, such divergence could grow. Claims have been made in favour of TTIP that it would promote greater trading opportunities for SMEs. Such arguments are, however, backed by flimsy evidence. It is much more likely that the greatest beneficiaries of TTIP will be the larger multinationals on both sides of the Atlantic. It is therefore equally important that European negotiators ensure that private investors are not enabled under TTIP to access arbitration and legal decisions that circumvent national and European legal jurisdictions while having the power to reverse or compensate for national policy decisions taken by governments in the national interest. My vote in favour is also conditioned by a belief that this point too is firmly covered in the terms that will continue to be set for the TTIP negotiating mandate.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. As Social Democrats, we are in favour of free trade under democratic governance. We do not believe that the market itself takes into account either workers' rights, the environment, public health, animal welfare or sustainable development. We believe that the market should be a servant, not a gentleman. We have said very clearly that we will not open up the European market to chlorine chickens, GMO products and hormone steaks, that we do not compromise on food safety or people's health and that we will not accept any deterioration in working conditions or rights. We stand by that, and that is how we voted. We believe that it is essential for the European Parliament to make its official position on the TTIP negotiations. That is why we voted in favour of adoption. The alternative had been for the European Commission to negotiate without having to take into account the legitimate concerns raised. This is particularly true in the question of ISDS. We do not want the Commission to be free to negotiate and decide. We will not accept ISDS mechanisms as we know them from the agreements of the past. We want an open, democratic process that puts national courts at the heart of it, ensures equality between foreign and domestic investors and ensures our full freedom to legislate as we wish. We voted for that today.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported today's resolution on rapporteur Lange's TTIP, given that it significantly clarifies the political input and demands of social democratic Members of the European Parliament towards the negotiators of the agreement. Today's vote does not mean automatic agreement with the final text of the agreement, which remains under negotiation. Today, the European Parliament has clearly signed up to specific points without which it will not support the resulting agreement. These include, for example, the exclusion of public services, ensuring the protection of workers, the environment or respect for product safety and consumer rights regulations.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the TTE negotiations because it does not include the vast majority of the points of disagreement that my group and I raised in our committees. The geopolitical consequences (increased reliance on the U.S.), the risk of massive job losses and deteriorating socio-labor conditions (the U.S. has not ratified the main ILO Conventions), the establishment of private courts favorable to large corporations through the ISDS system or similar, the non-defence of the precautionary principle, the liberalization of public services , the absence of demands for greater privacy protection, lack of transparency in negotiations...
