There are many conditions that directly attack the sovereignty of peoples. As regards agriculture, TTE will involve the destruction of small and medium-sized holdings, both in the EU and in the United States. In addition, it is an even more serious impairment of the food sovereignty of the peoples and the living conditions of farmers, as well as the dire impact on the environment and animal welfare.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new EU-US trade agreement better known as TTIP (Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership), currently under negotiation, represents a great opportunity for our companies. A comprehensive and ambitious agreement between the EU and the US could, in fact, make it easier for businesses and especially smaller ones to export to the US, import services, goods and inputs and compete in new markets. Some estimates also show that TTIP could lead to an overall overall gain of around 0.5% of GDP for the EU and 0.4% for the US between now and 2027. This would amount to an addition of as much as EUR 86 billion to the EU economy and EUR 65 billion to the US economy. It is important, however, that we reach a balanced and transparent agreement that favours an economic environment that is beneficial to both parties without compromising the health and safety of consumers and the competitiveness of our industrial system. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The negotiations for a Transatlantic Partnership with the United States must be consistent with the policies of Europe and its Member States. The best levels of social, health and environmental protection should be the benchmark for the progress of the talks between the parties, not the lowest common denominator. Farmers in the European Union cannot serve as a bargaining chip for the benefit of other sectors and tariff quotas representing adequate protection in this area should therefore be established. The protection of quality names of European agricultural products, such as geographical indications, should also be guaranteed, as well as European plant health standards. Also important are the safeguard clause and an appropriate arbitration mechanism.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the European Union-US Trade and Investment (TTIP) negotiations because the European Parliament makes firm demands for a good TTIP agreement. This safeguards the concerns of many citizens, including respect for high standards of protection of social and labour rights, the environment, food security and consumer rights; the defence of public services of general interest (such as water, health and education); respect for the privacy of personal data; the protection of European geographical indications; transparency of negotiations and the end of the controversial private investor-state dispute arbitration system (ISDS). The ISDS has allowed abuse and has raised legitimate concerns. Therefore, the approved text excludes private arbitration from TTIP negotiations, requiring a completely new, public and transparent system, with professional judges appointed by states (rather than lawyers appointed by private investors) and an appeal mechanism. This report gives the negotiators a clear message: there will only be TTIP if these demands of Parliament and citizens are respected. It is a very important step towards a good TTIP and so it deserved my vote in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with fellow Labour MEPs, I voted to protect the NHS, public services, workers’ rights and environmental standards in today’s TTIP vote. However, we voted against the compromise inclusion of ISDS (Investor-State Dispute Settlement), which enables companies to sue governments.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report making recommendations on the TTIP negotiations. EU-US trade cooperation can also bring more economic growth and more jobs for our citizens. However, negotiations must be transparent, which is an essential condition for a democratic process in our society. Otherwise, the negotiations will be accompanied by suspicions and mistrust in the eyes of EU citizens. Furthermore, the equivalence of the two partners must be a condition for the functioning of the agreement and there should in no way be a weakening of states or a reduction in product quality and safety standards.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. TTIP will have a major impact on the removal of non-customs barriers, but most of the quantitative studies that have been carried out so far clearly predict that national incomes of states as well as wages will rise by less than 1% over a period of 15 years. Of course, it should be pointed out that we are talking about a one-off increase and not growth at an annual level. This is the most optimistic scenario that will apply if non-customs barriers are completely removed. Despite the renaming of the ISDS mechanism, it still remains in the TTIP agreement, which I strongly oppose, as this will make member states lose part of their legislative autonomy. I seriously wonder why we would need a mechanism that is literally deteriorating the situation of the EU Member States. In addition, the effects of the TTIP agreement on the Slovenian economy – as noted by the Centre of Business Excellence in a study prepared by the Ministry of Economy – will be negligible or negative (Slovenian GDP – growth between -0.010% and + 0.015% of GDP, and may also lead to a loss of 218 to 1,500 jobs). For the reasons set out above, and many other negative amendments brought about by TTIP, I voted against the adoption of the European Parliament's report recommending to the European Commission on the TTIP negotiations.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Transatlantic Free Trade and Investment Agreement (TTIP) creates more free trade. This is nothing more than the "expanding of markets" and leads to greater product selection, more competition, higher productivity and cheaper prices. The theoretical ly sebes and risks of TTIP were discussed intensively in committee. "Red lines" are appropriately drawn against them in the 'Lange report' voted on here. One of these guidelines is to abolish old-style ISDS and create a new investor protection system for it. By approving this report, we want to provide constructive support for the process of creating TTIP without pre-incipiating a decision on the final agreement. On the negative note, Amendment No 1 ('Fiscal autonomy' instead of 'fiscal dumping') was not adopted. This amendment would have emphasised the fiscal autonomy of the Member States. However, this own-initiative report has no legally binding effect. After consultation with DG Trade staff, we assume that this point will not have a negative impact on the negotiations. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This EU-US agreement is of great benefit to us. Trade traditionally creates jobs and such a large common market will bring 27,600 to Slovakia. That's why he has my support.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Reducing regulatory barriers to trade is an important tool to help TTIP strengthen the European and US economies. Studies show that between 2/3 and 4/5 the benefits of a future agreement would result from cutting red tape and greater coordination among regulators. The US is the EU's largest export market. The new agreement would give European Union companies new opportunities to export to the US and encourage US companies to invest more in Europe.  Research shows that this agreement would bring up to €100 billion a year to economies across Latin America, Africa and Asia, helping to fight poverty in developing countries.  The impact of the agreement on SMEs, which is the main driver of economic growth and development in the EU, is essential. Predictions are that 6/10 of entrepreneurs will increase earnings by 20% and 4/10 will hire more people. A comprehensive trade agreement should include a chapter on investor protection, as security is one of the cornerstones of attracting investment. The European Union has developed a number of mechanisms involving citizens and the interested public in public consultation procedures, which are also supported by serious analyses of how the proposal for change will affect the economy, the environment and human rights, and I therefore support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs took the decision to vote against the report as a whole due to it not explicitly rejecting ISDS.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ TTIP is an economic contract that would mean more economic growth and greater benefits for all countries. With the EU heavily dependent on trade and exports, its GDP would increase by 15% to 20% by 2020. It would improve europe's position and foster greater connectivity between the world market. Small and medium-sized companies would significantly ease their position and also eliminate unnecessary costs, various obstacles and complicated procedures.  TTIP creates the basis for the creation of the largest free trade zone resulting in both ECONOMIC growth in the EU and the US, as well as job creation. To make the conclusion of the agreement as cautious as possible, the EU strives to have as transparent negotiations as possible in order to correct all errors in a timely way and to reach an agreement favourable to both sides. A key item of TTIP is the reduction of tariffs and the protection of workers and the environment.  With this agreement, the US and the EU can really take a big step forward. I am also aware that many EU citizens fear that this agreement could open the door to imports of GMO food. However, the EU has declared itself and protected its citizens with clear allegations that it has made it clear that it will not sacrifice the safety of its food, health and social standards, the environment and data protection and cultural diversity standards.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with all calls for the removal of administrative barriers between the EU and the US, as well as calls for greater transparency in the TTIP negotiations. I also agree that TTIP should not lead to a reduction in social, environmental and other standards. While I consider many of these standards to be harmful to consumers themselves (from banning standard light bulbs to banning 'strong' vacuum cleaners), I believe that the review of these standards and regulations should take place in standard legislative processes, which are also much more directly affected by EU citizens themselves, and not through TTIP. However, I fundamentally disagree with many of the proposals in the present report aimed at weakening the break-up of administrative barriers or even calling for the creation of new administrative barriers. For this reason, I abstained from voting on TTIP.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report with recommendations from the European Parliament to the European Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). In the process of globalisation, the European Union must not only be a passive observer, but must co-shape it. TTIP gives people, entrepreneurs and consumers new opportunities. We want better access for our businesses in America. However, we do not want rules and standards to be arbitrarily abolished. Nor will we agree to lower our standards in any area. I also welcome the compromise reached on the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), in particular because TTIP will ensure a level playing field for Member States' investors and, in particular, make the EU more attractive to foreign investment, which has the main benefits for our economic growth and employment. TTIP aims to facilitate mutual trade and investment.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Huge numbers of constituents have been in touch with me regarding today’s vote. Given the volume of emails I have received, it has unfortunately not been possible to respond individually to everyone. Therefore, I would like to take this opportunity to clarify my position and reassure those who contacted me that their concerns have been taken into account. I am extremely pleased to see the European Parliament give its clear backing to the TTIP negotiations. An ambitious transatlantic trade agreement would provide a huge boost to our economy and deliver real benefits for businesses of all sizes, making it easier for them to export and giving them access to a marketplace of 300 million US consumers. TTIP, with adequate safeguards for public services, will not just be good news for businesses, it will also deliver greater choice of products and savings for consumers, without lowering standards. Investor protection is a necessary component of all trade deals, and I welcome the agreement reached that TTIP should be accompanied by a suitably reformed and highly transparent investor protection mechanism. I hope that with Parliament’s support for TTIP now officially on record, a swift and successful conclusion of the negotiations can be reached.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 TTIP is the Trojan horse that will destroy Europe's economy and especially agricultural production and exports. Competition with US products, in the event of a trade association, will not only be tough but will break up the already tested EU economy.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP resolution that has just been adopted is a breakthrough because it calls for the much-debated ISDS mechanism to be rejected by the European Commission, which is negotiating on behalf of the Union. Instead, the EP supports a conflict resolution system that must respect the decisions of national jurisdictions and that disputes should not interfere with member states' public policy objectives. I myself have proposed amendments to the alternative dispute resolution, such as that now adopted, which does not violate national sovereignty, during the debate – this part applies mutatis mutandis. It is reassuring that the People's Party has moved in the right direction on this issue and supported the compromise. The European Parliament has taken a clear resolution in favour of us on all the public health issues that are important for our country, the ban on hormone treatment in the cattle sector and all the public health issues in this matter. The issue of the protection of personal data is also developing favourably, with which the EP imposes strict conditions on the online activities and data security of people and companies in the resolution that has just been adopted. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a resolution because I am convinced that the European Parliament must exercise active political control and control throughout the process of negotiating TTIP, and today's decision is an important element. TTIP can become an important tool in regulating globalisation processes and improving the EU's international competitiveness, but this requires a number of legal, political and economic framework conditions, which are properly set out in this resolution and thus guide the Commission's negotiations with the Us side. I believe that, as the negotiations progress, the EP will have to conduct further similar debates and take resolutions, in particular in order to make the agreement a better global competitiveness position for the EU, ultimately generating real European jobs and growth, without prejudice to EU labour, social, environmental and consumer protection standards.  Furthermore, an important virtue of this resolution is that it contains a compromise solution to eliminate the existing ISDS mechanism and its opaque methods, which adversely affect certain investors or governments, essentially by creating a new public system of transparent and democratic control. In doing so, we have agreed, on the part of the EP, to have a clear negotiating framework for the next round of negotiations on this highly contentious issue, in the interests of Europe.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The free trade agreement currently being negotiated between the European Union and the US, once implemented well and efficiently, should benefit not only the contracting parties, but also the global market. It is important that the provisions of this trade agreement support companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, in equal access to the US and European market. However, I believe that TTIP can become a landmark factor in the globalisation of prosperity. It is not the people of the United States who emigrate to Mexico or other Latin American countries, and it is not Europeans who emigrate to countries in the Middle East or Africa, but vice versa. This process is proof that democracy and prosperity-giving economic growth in Europe and North America serve people. If so, the leaders of the countries of both contracting parties should strive for the globalisation of the market, which will be followed not only by the process of standardisation of economies, but also by the process of improving the living standards of people in the world. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation to the European Commission and hope that there will be no obstacles to its implementation through the agreement being negotiated.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. I shall not dwell on the procedural tightrope walkers adopted by President Schulz in order to prevent the compromise from which this text is based from being undermined. I note that the ISDS clause is alive and well, but it is no longer called that. I call for the negotiations on TTIP to be interrupted: the Treaty will change the standards of goods and services by bypassing the will of the citizens and the sovereignty of states; in return we will have a ridiculous increase in GDP of 0.03% per year. It is an official figure: the impact study that the European Commission uses to justify the need to conclude TTIP states that it will increase European GDP by 0.48% by 2027. Between now and 2027 there are 13 years: the bill is soon done! The same study says that 0.6% of existing jobs will be wiped out, because some production sectors will be penalised by the Treaty. The calculation of the new jobs created by TTIP in that study does not exist. To assume that they will be created is contrary to any common sense: the NAFTA Free Trade Treaty has destroyed one million jobs in the USA and Canada, without creating any jobs in Mexico.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ There has been much scare-mongering by those on the extremes of either side of this House to the discredit of a deal that would be hugely beneficial to the UK and to Europe. Trade between the US and EU Member States is substantial and the economic benefits of a free trade agreement would be a further boost, creating the largest free trade area in the world. Many of the aspects of the agreement that have been attacked, ISDS being a prime example, are common features of most trade agreements and there to protect investors. They are not there to allow investors to privatise the NHS by stealth as has been disingenuously claimed by critics. The immediate economic benefit to the UK of the agreement is estimated to be anywhere in the region of UKP 4-10 billion. I am pleased to have voted in favour of today’s report and would encourage my constituents with concerns to look at the details of this agreement and not be misled by the myths being peddled by the likes of UKIP who, as a supposedly free-market, Atlanticist party, are opposing this deal for cynical political gain.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that the negotiation process of this trade agreement takes into account the development of the European industry sector, as well as the fulfilment of the commitments made by the Member States under the Europe 2020 strategy to increase the share of industry in GDP from 15% to 20%.  The European Parliament has given a negotiating mandate to the Commission, which must be executed in a democratic and transparent manner, because only in these circumstances can the objectives of the European Union and the Member States be achieved: promoting sustainable growth, developing the small and medium-sized business sector, creating and protecting jobs for citizens, and ensuring a higher degree of protection and satisfaction for European consumers. The negotiating mandate must aim to achieve an agreement capable of creating safe jobs for European citizens, in line with the provisions of the Europe 2020 strategy, which aims to achieve a level of employment of 75% at Union level. It is also important that the negotiation process does not in any way affect the key values of the European Union. An agreement is needed to facilitate transatlantic trade without, however, leading to a decrease in food safety standards or the high level of protection of personal data.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has voted on a resolution on the Free Trade Agreement between Europe and the United States (TTIP). This resolution is not binding, but it had to have two main objectives: first, to show the citizens that we are defending their interests and that we take their concerns seriously and, secondly, to give a clear political message to the Commission that trade is not just about the interests of multinationals. Despite all the amendments tabled to strengthen it, this resolution remains halfway because it gives no guarantee to the citizens and it sends a scrambled message to the Commission. That is why we voted against it. There are at least two years left to correct the situation.

name: Keith Taylor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ There are many issues that alarm me about TTIP, beyond the ‘new’ system proposed to replace ISDS, which still provides for a separate, parallel legal framework solely for investors. Another major concern that prompted me to vote against the recommendations to the Commission on the TTIP negotiations is regulatory cooperation, which mainly aims to reduce trade barriers in the form of differing laws, regulations and standards. Many of these differences have been adopted by countries to pursue policy goals unrelated to trade, such as the protection of the environment, public health and consumers. Under TTIP these democratic decisions are simply known as ‘non-tariff barriers to trade’ (NTBs). The resolution failed to convince me that appropriate measures will be taken to ensure that TTIP will not put downward pressure on a host of important regulations, thereby eroding hard-won social, environmental and health protections. As Vice-Chair of the European Parliament’s animal welfare intergroup, I am also worried about the threat TTIP poses to animal rights and protection. As the EU’s animal welfare regulations are much more advanced than those of the US, I fear that another negative result of reduced NTBs would be the lowering or undermining of standards that regulate animal welfare.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on negotiations between the EU and the US on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. As a shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the committee for Industry, Research and Energy I closely followed the report and negotiations within the EP and I also gave my recommendations to the leading committee. The important aim of this vote was to deliver a strong mandate for the European Commission to conduct negotiations with the US side. After many weeks of delays due to divisions within the Socialist Group the EP adopted the text calling for ambitious negotiations to continue. I strongly support four main priorities outlined by the ALDE Group: TTIP must remove bureaucratic hurdles for European businesses and create market access; advantage Europe’s small and medium-sized enterprises; ensure high environmental, labour and food safety standards at the global level; and introduce a modernised investment protection mechanism.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Negotiations between the European Commission and the United States to conclude a general free trade agreement are taking place in the greatest opacity. This treaty would lead to the dismantling or weakening of all the standards (social, environmental, etc.) that protect European citizens. Above all, it puts investor rights above that of the states. The freedom to legislate and the sovereignty of peoples, protected from the interference of multinationals worried about their profits, must not be questioned. However, the private arbitration mechanism between states and investors has not been clearly removed from this resolution, which serves as a negotiating mandate for the Commission. This is at a time when our national courts have perfect jurisdiction to try such disputes.  The European Parliament has missed the opportunity to assert itself as the voice of European citizens and to echo their concerns about the ISDS by adopting a resolution that still contains too much ambiguity. An agreement cannot be concluded at any cost, that is the message sent by the French Socialist delegation and that is why I voted against this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. When the European Union negotiates international agreements such as TTIP, it is essential that the European Parliament also expresses its views at all stages. At this meeting, we voted on the recommendations that the European Parliament makes to the European Commission. As the TTIP is a geopolitical agreement that indicates the strengthening of a strategic alliance between two developed parts of the world and will strengthen economic activity on both sides and also allow a higher standard of people with new jobs, I supported this report.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main problem with the negotiations is opacity. It is still unclear whether or not European producers will benefit from this agreement. The partnership poses many risks, such as the low cost price of American production due to different legislation on their labour law, access to the European market for GMO food, etc.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it recommends to the European Commission lines of action which run counter to the interests of European citizenship, its rights, public services, democracy and sovereignty, which are red and common sense lines for PODEMOS. In addition, the amendment adopted on is clearly a toast to the sun since, although it advises, in the long term, the establishment of an international and public tribunal for investor-state dispute settlement, the US Government has publicly stated that it will not accept it. We therefore consider it a hoax to the public to claim that the private arbitration system is over. That is why we understand that transnational corporations will continue to have a veto on the legislating capacity of States, which is a frontal attack on democracy.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) creates more free trade. Free trade provides more competition, cheaper prices and better choice. But it is also my assessment that it leads to structural change and difficulties in adaptation. The theoretical ly sebes and risks of TTIP were discussed intensively in committee. In the Lange report voted on here, 'red lines' are appropriately drawn against them. One of these guidelines is to abolish old-style ISDS and create a new investor protection system for it. By approving this report, we want to monitor the process of creating the TTIP critically but constructively, without pre-incipiating a decision on the final agreement. Yesterday's own-initiative report has no legally binding effect. Only when a final version is available can a meaningful decision be made.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to increase our presence in international markets, to ensure that our return to growth is sustainable. Moreover, I deeply regret the misinformation campaign against TTIP. No agreement has been reached yet, and much of what is being said gets ahead of the events for purely ideological reasons. This is why I support the opening of negotiations to reach a deal for TTIP, and I would like to point out four issues that will decide my vote: 1.  Consumer protection and European food safety standards are maintained, as you said in your joint statement with Ambassador Froman, making clear that public services are excluded from TTIP. 2.  European SMEs are helped in increasing their exports by lowering non-tariff barriers. Multinationals already operate in both sides of the Atlantic without TTIP. 3.  American public procurement is open to European enterprises. 4.  A reformed ISDS that gives juridical safety to investments, based in the Malmström proposal for an international public court for investments, which is the right idea for me. I hope that soon we can advance on the talks for TTIP in the most transparent manner possible and that we can achieve a good deal for all European consumers and SMEs.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a statement of intent. Despite the attempt of certain amendments to contain the scope of the text and to try to force the Commission to reduce the scope of this TTIP agreement in the making, we can only oppose the principle of this agreement. On this issue, the National Front is at the forefront of opposition to this agreement, which is taking very large risks from many traditional sectors (or not necessarily) of our country.  Most of the amendments limiting the text were rejected. The text as a whole was approved by a very large majority of Members, which in my humble opinion is a betrayal of the elites. I therefore vote AGAINST this text with major implications for the future of our children.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. My vote has been contrary to TIC, contrary to attempts to rigged the debate and contrary to the secrecy and democratic disrespect with which the negotiations continue to take place. Unfortunately, the text was adopted after agreement had been reached by conservatives, Social Democrats and liberals to ensure private arbitration mechanisms outside judicial systems. Thus, Parliament's message has not served to question the serious risks of a treaty which can lead to unprecedented deregulation, as well as the creation of a large economic bloc without any democratic control.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution in so far as it sets out the position of the Group of Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament in the face of the TTE negotiations. Trade between the EU and the US already amounts to almost one trillion euros per year and we need a good treaty to regulate them; because, in addition to the removal of unnecessary trade barriers, which mainly affect SMEs, the Resolution calls for the strengthening of labour rights, with the ratification of the main ILO Conventions, and environmental protection; because it eliminates private arbitration and calls for a new, transparent model, with independent career judges, public hearings and an appeal system.  In short, because it requires an agreement that guarantees the standards of protection we enjoy in the EU and serves to promote on a global scale the values of fair economic relations, making it clear that we will only support an TIC that regulates trade for the benefit of citizens.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The De Lange report was aimed at making stringent recommendations to the European Commission on the content of the TTIP agreement, but the text we voted on today is the result of an indecent watered-down compromise between socialists and the people that actuallyes the Commission in conducting the negotiations. In fact, all the amendments supported by civil society that committed the Commission not to water down high European standards, including our amendments calling, among other things, for the exclusion of public services, the adoption of a positive list for services, so as to exclude all those not expressly indicated, and the maintenance of high standards of product control, were blocked.  Furthermore, I find it unacceptable that, quite arbitrarily, we have been prevented from putting to the vote a crucial amendment, which we proposed, which excluded any form of arbitration, both public and private, and that the ISDS mechanism was approved, thus allowing multinationals to sue states if the adoption of new laws results in a decrease in their profits. For these reasons, I voted against this report and will continue to oppose this dangerous agreement which, in order to defend the interests of lobbies, tramples on the general interest and the rights of millions of citizens.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report on TCI because Parliament cannot legitimise a treaty which, in its conception, in its elaboration, in its content and objectives is an attack on each and every social right, without which democracy cannot even be talked about. It is not time for vagueness, of confusing public opinion with phrases full of good intentions that disguise the political content of this agreement. Free trade already exists between the European Union and the United States, and the remaining tariff barriers are necessary to keep sectors as critical as agriculture alive. TYC is actually the excuse for institutionalizing the primacy of large capital over workers. It is the large capital that wants to intervene, to have an opinion on labour rights and environmental and economic standards that may diminish their benefits, and even to denounce those rights and rules, forcing States to pay fines for defending the common good. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. The trade treaty that will form the largest free trade area in the world is of exceptional importance. That is why the European attitude must also be crystal clear. The EU has developed a whole range of standards that protect its population from randomness and blind profit. The people of Europe are attached to these achievements, as has been demonstrated by the Commission's public consultation. In it, the Europeans overwhelmingly indicate that they do not want an ISDS procedure. The compromise resolution on the table today is already responding to our criticisms in many respects. She even reports that the ISDS procedure needs to be replaced. However, the text before us does not guarantee indisputably that ISDS will disappear. The creation of a new investment court can be put on hold, which in theory allows the ISDS procedure to continue to exist indefinitely. We in Parliament must send a clear signal, namely that we do not want private courts to be able to undermine democratically adopted regulations simply to secure their profits. We require citizens to follow the rules. Well, citizens also require investors to abide by the rules. I support these citizens and vote against the resolution.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: in writing. – If we want Europe to remain at the forefront of global trade for the next decades, deals such as TTIP are essential. The reduction of trade barriers will benefit all parts of the supply chain as well as consumers. Across Europe citizens will see a reduction in costs as well as a simultaneous boost to the economy. SMEs, which are crucial to our economic recovery, will particularly benefit from the removal of red tape. Despite the political manoeuvrings of the Left it was a triumph for democracy that this vote occurred in an appropriate timeframe and without further delays. For such a landmark deal, reform of the investor protection mechanism was the most appropriate course of action as it is still affording European businesses protection from discrimination as well as allowing governments to regulate as they deem suitable and in the interest of their citizens. For these reasons I voted in favour of the resolution and hope that such a decisive result in the European Parliament gives the TTIP negotiations fresh impetus. It is worrying to see that UKIP has now joined the French National Front, the Communists and Greens in their instinctive anti-Americanism and antipathy to so-called ‘big business’.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues I voted against this resolution because Labour MEPs wanted to rule out ISDS from TTIP. This, unfortunately, did not get the support of a majority of Tory and right-wing MEPs. Therefore as the Agreement included ISDS, we voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has managed to vote on TTIP (TAFTA), the large transatlantic market that wants to put emerging countries on the market. Deluding itself as to the opening of public procurement in the United States or the possibility of better regulation of financial services, this resolution even aligns the untruths about the purely technical role of the Regulatory Cooperation Council, the maintenance of current plant health or environmental rules , when their change is already underway - or the protection of the cultural and audiovisual sectors. , regardless of digital. Martin Schulz, President of the European Parliament, has put all his weight in the balance, multiplying procedural scams to ensure the support of the "grand coalition" by even proposing a last-minute compromise made of convoluted formulations on the private arbitration mechanism ISDS (investor-state dispute settlement). As a result, it remains integrated into the negotiations and could, like everything else, serve as a global model.  Ignoring the mobilization of European public opinion, 436 voted in support, 31 abstained. Needless to say, I am one of the 241 who voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement, which has sparked a wave of protest and indignation in various European social and economic sectors, will have very serious impacts. The consequences for agriculture will be catastrophic for both producers and consumers. From an economic point of view, the implementation of this agreement could mean the end of our production model based on family farming, which is considered to be the safest and most sustainable for food production in the world. But consumers will also be hit hard. While prudence prevails in Europe, only substances that manifestly attack public health are prohibited in the United States.  Finally, I conclude with the dispute settlement mechanisms provided for in these agreements which provide for the establishment of private arbitral tribunals to which multinationals may resort by proseling national states to pay large damages if they believe that they maintain any unnecessary and harmful obstacles to free competition.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This agreement was rejected by me. All my previous reservations about the partnership have been cosmetically altered, but not abolished. As long as our objections are not dealt with and the competences of the companies of the nation states are not heard, I will not give my assent to the agreement.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Mr President, the free trade agreement between the United States and the EU will offer a great deal of new opportunities for European companies if it is implemented. The aim must be an ambitious agreement that will improve the export potential of SMEs in particular and, at the same time, the international competitiveness of the EU as a whole and its Member States. It is estimated that the TTIP agreement will increase trade in EU countries by up to EUR 122 billion per year and increase European employment in millions of jobs. This growth would be necessary for Europe. It is particularly important to dismantle trade restrictive standards and barriers, then to facilitate access to the US market for European products and services.  Thank you to all the negotiators for the common vision that has now been found among the groups as a follow-up to the free trade negotiations. This strong support from the European Parliament will enable The Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström and the other negotiators to take the negotiations forward.  Although an agreement on free trade is to be reached, the negotiations must not compromise on the level of food safety and environmental standards that are important to Europe. The TTIP agreement has not only economic but also a major political significance. The United States is an important partner for us Europeans. If we are now able to agree on common standards and principles on a transatlantic basis, this is likely to guide world trade in the future.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership (TTIP) negotiations. I am very much in favour of free trade. However, there is no need for an agreement to do so. You can simply unilaterally remove customs duties and import taxes. That would benefit consumers. With regard to mutual investment, I see the European Union and the United States as the part of the world in which states respect the property rights of investors the most. Special investment protection alongside the respective state jurisdiction is superfluous and is a violation of the hayectian and Canticprinciple principle that laws must have a general and equal effect. I also see more light than shadow in regulatory harmonisation. It amounts to a concreting of high regulatory standards for the particular benefit of large companies. But both the US and the EU need less regulation to allow more competition – especially from small and medium-sized enterprises – to revive the bureaucratically paralyzed economy.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This was not a vote on TTIP itself but on Parliament’s opinion. MEPs cannot start or stop trade negotiations; we can only approve or reject TTIP once negotiations are concluded. This resolution is our best tool to influence the negotiations. Today we have sent a clear warning: we can only accept TTIP if certain conditions are met. Labour MEPs voted to reject the inclusion of any public service in TTIP, regardless of how they are funded or organised, and to protect workers’ rights, environmental standards and food safety. We also voted to rule out ISDS (Investor-State Dispute Settlement), which enables companies to sue governments, from TTIP, though this did not get the support of a majority of MEPs.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – A transatlantic agreement negotiated with professionalism and to the benefit of all Europeans, although it may seem paradoxical, will speed up the process of EU integration of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, including my country, Romania.  The concrete provisions of TTIP, which is a trade and investment agreement, are very important and must be negotiated with maximum attention. The big picture is as important as the technical details. Although not a champion in bilateral trade with the USA, Romania will have direct benefits as a result of TTIP ratification. And through our most important trading and economic partners, which are the founding states of the EU, we will also indirectly become beneficiaries of TTIP.  Romania has a relatively modest bilateral trade with the US of about 2 billion USD, but the indirect advantages become apparent if we consider that Germany is our first trading partner with a bilateral trade figure of over 21 billion euros. This is one of the reasons why I support the negotiations for the conclusion of TTIP and which led me to vote today on the report on the EP recommendations on the TTIP negotiations.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This economic agreement on free trade and investment aims, through the removal of trade barriers in a wide range of economic sectors, to facilitate the purchase and sale of goods and services between the EU and the US, to create jobs and to achieve a deeper interconnection between the two major economies.  It was designed as a response to the economic and financial crisis we are going through, but it is increasingly becoming a tailor-made agreement to and from the United States, calling for a downward harmonisation of the high standards that the EU and its Member States now have on sensitive sectors such as agriculture, cosmetics, the pharmaceutical sector, food, textiles and animal protection. One of the main problems is the inclusion of the investor-state dispute resolution system in the negotiating negotiations. Such a system would allow US multinationals investing in Europe to bypass any national or European court and sue directly the governments of the Member States, which could be led to water down or even refrain from enacting laws protecting work, health, the environment, etc. Further liberalisation that would harm Italy, more than other European countries.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is essential for the European Parliament to express its opinion on the conditions necessary to obtain a good agreement. With today's resolution, the Socialist Group has achieved important victories, including that of reiterating the need that in a possible agreement no lowering of EU standards and no reduction in the legislative power of democratic bodies would be allowed.  I also believe it is crucial that we have called for the ISDS system to be replaced by a new system of investor-state dispute resolution, subject to principles and democratic control, in which disputes will be resolved transparently by civil servants, professional judges and independents, in public hearings. An appeal mechanism will also be included in the new system, ensuring the coherence of judicial decisions, where the jurisdiction of EU courts and Member States is respected and where private interests cannot undermine public policy objectives.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report of the Committee on International Trade because it promotes the conclusion of the TTP. The European Parliament is under an error to sign the agreement to recover the profits of European monopolies. The Jrc did not take part in the vote on the amendments concerning various aspects of the agreement under negotiation, because it refuses to participate in the operation of its legitimacy in the popular consciousness, under the illusion that it can supposedly be changed or corrected. The amendments and the eu euro-one-way parties, which deposit them, reflect the particular interests of parts of the chapter, which seek to strengthen their positions in the negotiations on international competition. TTIR is the economic NATO, which is why it cannot be improved or corrected. The jrc's position is clear. TTIR is by its nature and character deeply unpopular. The people must reject it along with the exploitative system it serves. By fighting to thwart it, to disengage themselves from imperialist wolf alliances, opening their own path of development with their own power that at its core will have the satisfaction of popular needs.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that this report has been approved and I supported it despite all my reservations. I consider it a unique opportunity for us Members to comment on this negotiation between the European Commission and the US and thus to participate in the content of the treaties concluded.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the European Parliament's proposals for the European Commission's negotiations on the establishment of the US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). This type of agreement between the world's two most influential economies plays a very important geopolitical role, as it will generally strengthen the development of western values and the western economic model. While looking at the Russian embargo on imports of EU-produced food products and the consequences of this embargo, the positive geopolitical features of such a treaty will also allow the agricultural sector to create new outlets without jeopardising European standards. While there is disagreement in the European Parliament over the mechanism for regulating possible disputes between investors and countries, I believe it is important to separate the idea of protecting honest and transparent investors from the idea of a potential lobby of multinational corporations. In addition, many EU countries, including Latvia, have already had experience with the demands of US corporations. It is significant that this Treaty is voted against by the political forces of the extreme left, including the supporters of the Greek referendum, as well as by the far-right forces with Marin Lepen, who support the free market but do not support TTIP. Question: In their sense, the free market is only necessary to trade with their party donors in Russia?

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In plenary, we endorsed recommendations for Commission negotiators on further negotiations with the US on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). I welcome the fact that many contentious issues have been clarified during the discussion regarding the agreement in question. In its opinion, the Commission confirmed that TTIP will not affect EU public services and 'will not undermine the strength of the EU or the national parliaments of the countries of the Union'. TTIP will also not jeopardise basic EU legislation in areas such as food safety or environmental protection. On the contrary, the conclusion of this agreement will open the door to a new market for Europe and therefore Slovakia, which will bring, among other things, new jobs.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Free trade without barriers and borders is an extremely important thing that can benefit all parties to trade. However, it is often the case that negotiating partners enter into talks from different positions. The United States is still an economic power that identifies well and can effectively protect its interests. The European Union is not always able to deal with this well enough to take account of the expectations and objections of all the Member States.  I believe that negotiating a trade agreement with the US is an opportunity that the EC should use to create conditions of economic cooperation that will provide an opportunity for development not only for large corporations, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises. On many issues, we must be very vigilant, especially where important sectors of the economy, such as Polish the chemical industry, may fall victim to compromise.  There are also concerns about the final shape of ISDS, or the issue of geographical indications of origin of products. In these areas, the European Parliament must constantly look at the EC's hands and recall the concerns that the citizens of the Member States have about this agreement. I voted in favour of this report because the EU needs new economic impulses to break the thud of the last decade. This is not, of course, unconditional consent, but a mandate to negotiate for the EC, from which it will be settled at the right time.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Lange report "containing the European Parliament's recommendations to the European Commission on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations" because I believe it is essential that the European Parliament has a mandate to the European Commission that reflects strong and explicit the values of environmental, labour, human rights and consumer protection in the TTIP negotiations. On the other hand, the report contains clear recommendations on the need to end the system of private arbitration between States and private investors (ISDS) and to replace it with a public, transparent and independent system where private interests cannot jeopardise the democracy of EU Member States. The Lange report also makes it clear that ttip cannot be achieved at any cost and calls on the European Commission to demand that the Transatlantic Partnership be a cornerstone in promoting European values for fairer and more integrated globalisation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The goal of TTIP is to create even greater pressure on employment and wages by levelling social and labour rights. The approval of this treaty implies not only the total liberalization of international trade between the two continents, but also the opening to the market and competition of large portions of the so-called social functions of the State, aiming at its privatization and commercialization.  Furthermore, to overtake the public interest and respect for economic, social and labour rights, the interests and profits of multinationals, in particular by establishing a dispute settlement mechanism above national legal institutions, which allows states to be prosecuted if multinationals feel harmed in their interests, thus limiting the sovereignty of States and, consequently, , disfiguring democracy itself.  We have voted against this report and will continue to demand the definitive rejection of this Treaty by the defence of regulated trade, based on relations of complementarity and not competition – between countries, producers and productions – as well as respect for and safeguarding national sovereignty.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against the recommendations on the TTIP negotiations because the position that emerges does not sufficiently reflect the need to protect the interests of European citizens. We are well aware that TTIP is in danger of containing agreements that damage Europe's position in a large number of key sectors, particularly in sensitive sectors such as agriculture, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, food safety, animal protection and respect for the environment. There was a need for Parliament to send a strong signal to the Commission, which is currently negotiating with its US counterpart, that European legislation should not be watered down in order to reach a compromise. That was not the case. I regret in particular that the ISDS clause has not been completely censured, which would introduce a system where by which large multinational companies directly sue the governments of the Member States before international arbitrators whenever they consider that national laws constitute a threat to their investments. The compromise voted on, although it calls for this mechanism to be replaced by a different but similar system, does not seem to sufficiently protect national democratic interests.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval for the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the Agreement in question entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In July 2013, Croatia became the 28th Member State to join the EU. It is the second country of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to join the EU, after Slovenia. This protocol is an important, albeit formal, step towards long-term peace in the Balkans. I sincerely hope that the peace process will continue throughout the Balkan region.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this report on the stabilisation agreement with Macedonia. The report calls for the stabilization agreement with Macedonia to be validated. The National Front opposes this reckless and infinite policy of enlargement, especially with the countries of Eastern Europe and The Balkan. However, I have chosen not to participate in a systematic opposition. The purpose of this text is simply to bring into line the association and stabilization agreements concluded and ratified previously. Negotiations began in December 2012 and culminated in the signing of a protocol on 25 October 2013. To oppose this protocol, which is merely a legislative adjustment, would be a sterile opposition. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is customary for UKIP MEPs to vote against such protocols, as we opposed the agreements themselves at the time.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because since Croatia is a full member of the European Union, it is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols. Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to support the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which takes into account Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. If I oppose the unlimited enlargement of the European Union and the so-called 'association agreements', which are usually only the first step towards the accession of a new Member State, this text is only a legal compliance agreement, the association agreement with Macedonia having already been concluded and ratified. This is, therefore, a fairly logical legal adjustment.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It is a matter of approving a protocol adapting the stabilisation and association agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to include Croatia's accession to the Union. I voted in favour of that point.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the approval of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Even if the National Front is fiercely fighting any possible enlargement of the European Union and the agreements of associations of this type, this text is in fact aimed at logical compliance.  Indeed, the Association and Stabilization Agreement with Macedonia has already been concluded and ratified.  So for a matter of form, I voted for this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Vajgl report contains unclear and non-acceptable passages. That is why I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these two reports. For me, this is a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the European Union, so it becomes a formality that it also forms part of the stabilisation and association agreements that exist with Macedonia and Serbia.  That is not to say that I support everything contained in these agreements, or all the demands placed on Serbia and Macedonia in these agreements. However, this vote is only about the consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU, and that it is therefore part of the CONTRACTING PARTY that is the EU.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Croatia's participation in the Agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which takes into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. These negotiations started on 18 December 2012, following technical consultations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on this issue. Further rounds of negotiations took place on 25 January and 10 April 2013. The Protocol has been updated to take account of the EU customs tariff 2013 and the phasing-out of customs duties under the AA. The Commission proposes that the Council adopt a decision on the signing and provisional application of the Protocol on behalf of the European Union and to conclude a Protocol on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Having regard to the draft protocol annexed to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, and having regard to the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I agree with the conclusion of the Agreement and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Similar to the agreement with Serbia, the report by my colleague Vajgla also provides for a change in the Protocol for the Republic of Macedonia upon Croatia's accession to the European Union. Here, this report had my support.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe it is important for Croatia to acquire Member State status as soon as possible, including with regard to third countries with which bilateral agreements have been concluded.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text gives the European Parliament the approval of the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities, the Member States and Macedonia to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.  Although we oppose the unlimited enlargements of the Union and the so-called association agreements, we can only approve the legislative adaptation of this agreement, which has already been concluded and ratified, the text itself which is mainly aimed at legal compliance. To vote against this recommendation would therefore be a sterile opposition. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I vote against. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, is called for.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is customary for UKIP MEPs to vote against such protocols, as we opposed the agreements themselves at the time.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this Protocol in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union in relation to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the European Communities and their Member States and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which was concluded before Croatia’s accession to the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because of the political analysis that has already emerged regarding Croatia's accession.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the council's draft decision on the conclusion to be validated, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, from the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Of course, I am opposed to the logic of the unlimited enlargement of the European Union and the so-called 'association agreements', which have been made between the Union and most of the states of the former communist bloc. However, this text itself is mainly aimed at logical compliance, as the Association and Stabilization Agreement has already been concluded and ratified; negotiations began on 18 December 2012, following prior technical consultations with FYROM on the subject. The country confirmed its agreement with the protocol on 25 October 2013. This protocol therefore aims to adapt the agreements into legislation. In this sense, formally voting against it would be a sterile opposition.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. , as the 28th Member State, on 1 July 2013.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because the entry of the Republic of Croatia into the Union made it necessary to revisit it. This agreement is important in the light of its aims: it aims to consolidate the political, economic and institutional stabilisation of individual countries and the entire region through the development of institutions and the reform of public administration; stepping up trade and economic cooperation; strengthening national and regional security; greater cooperation in a number of areas, including justice and home affairs. The basic objective is to 'prepare the ground' for the accession of these countries to the European Union, which is no longer a clear prospect for the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, although it is not likely to take place in the short term.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement reflects the Union's willingness and commitment to integrate potential candidate countries into europe's political and economic context. In this context, the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia was the first country in the region to successfully conclude negotiations and sign this agreement with the EU. It is an important prospect to be able to include the balkan countries in Europe one day. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote reflects the accession of Croatia to the EU, which as a Member State is to enjoy the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the technical nature and executive nature of the recommendation in question, I voted in favour of the adoption of the resolution, not also because of the political analysis that has already emerged with regard to Croatia's accession.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval for the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the Agreement in question entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a procedural vote which I supported since it updates the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in order to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to conclude a protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. Considering that it is normal for Croatia, now a full member of the European Union, to become a party to this agreement, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Relations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are formalized by a stabilization and association agreement that came into force in 2004. Since then Croatia has joined the Union and its status as a Member State must be taken into account in its trade, particularly with Macedonia. That is the purpose of this protocol.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Council must, on behalf of the European Union and take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, approve the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other. This decision follows Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013. Croatia has a privileged position vis-à-vis FYROM and will be able to play a strategic role within the Union to help the country, which is currently experiencing security difficulties.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of a protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other hand, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Like the report on the Stabilization and Association Agreement with Serbia, this agreement has already been ratified. It is only a matter of voting in favour of a legislative adjustment of the latter.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a purely technical measure taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU in July 2013. Members are asked to give their consent to the conclusion of the protocol between the two parties in this regard.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because this is a purely technical solution. The need for such a vote was croatia's accession to the EU and the need for certain amendments to macedonia's EU association documents to reflect the change in the number of EU member states.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the plan as we are not given the opportunity to amend the association agreement with Skopje.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is primarily a legal compliance.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a technical document which aims to include Croatia, following its integration into the EU, as part of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU, its Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The procedure itself does not alter the EEA already in force, making some adjustments in the agricultural aspect, in particular under the condition of the movement of goods and their tariff quotas. We do not, however, disregard the broader framework of the EEA signed between the EU and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, including particular aspects such as the creation of free trade areas, the imposition of economic, political, judicial, fiscal, public sector reforms, nor do we fail to take into account the historical and political framework of this whole process (dismemberment of Yugoslavia and the role of the EU and NATO powers , in particular in the conflict of the Balkan region), already expressed on other occasions. For the reasons expressed, we abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's neighbourhood and enlargement policy is one of the failures of this Europe. To continue in this direction is counterproductive.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the plan, as we are not given the opportunity to amend the association agreement with Skopje.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the request for consent submitted by the Council, I voted in favour of the European Parliament consent to conclusion of the Protocol.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EPP delegation of the Fidesz People's Party, in agreement with the People's Party, stands by the strengthening of the contractual relations with the European Communities since 1996 between the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the easternest republic of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia with a population of 2 million. Since becoming independent, the country has faced enormous challenges in terms of its political stability. As to the Ohrid Framework Agreement signed on 13 August 2001 and its implementation, the commitments of the governments in office after 2001 have once again created stability. The Government will continue to implement the new legislative framework effectively, which will further enhance the stability and confidence of the country and help create an increasingly favourable climate for EU integration. The European Union has consistently supported this process. The EU's commitment to peace and stability in the country has been heightened by the EU. This was also the aim of the report adopted today for stability and sustainable development.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the Protocol on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on the occasion of Croatia's accession to the EU, because it is a technical act on the occasion of Croatia's accession to the EU, which also strengthens relations with the EU's neighbour Macedonia.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Vajgl report, given it concerns a simple recommendation amending existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote. On 26 March 2001 the European Council adopted the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), on the other. This Agreement formalizes the Parties' commitment to economic matters, creating a free trade area. It stresses the need to create a new climate in economic relations between the EU and EMA, which serves mainly to promote trade and investment development. We abstained because of certain ambiguous technical aspects that form part of the Agreement.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a simple and non-controversial recommendation amending existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and the Republic of Macedonia, but at the same time I hope that the European Union will have a swift, effective and authoritative response to events in Macedonia. I find it timely, precisely in the European Year of Development and with increasing dynamic changes in the political environment globally, to review the European Union's neighbourhood policy, including with regard to the Western Balkans. In our production, we build on the general principles enshrined in the Treaties of the Union, but we also take into account the current circumstances in the region. And we should always keep in mind that while enlargement policy and neighbourhood policy are separate policies with different objectives, countries that have started membership negotiations overlap to a large extent, and this makes the EU's increased responsibility to them to maintain and aspiration for membership.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote. On 26 March 2001 the European Council adopted the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), on the other. This Agreement formalizes the Parties' commitment to economic matters, creating a free trade area. It stresses the need to create a new climate in economic relations between the EU and EMA, which serves mainly to promote trade and investment development. We abstained because of certain ambiguous technical aspects that form part of the Agreement.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this document which aims to consolidate and improve relations with its new Member State, Croatia.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
