text: Written. ‒ I voted for a recommendation on the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement Protocol between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, since it is a harmonisation of the Agreement with the fact that the Republic of Croatia has become a member of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this report on the stabilisation agreement with Macedonia. In the text, the rapporteur calls for the approval of this agreement, despite the continued and sustained reference to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. National Front MPs denounce this policy of thoughtless and infinite enlargement, especially in the countries of the former Eastern Bloc.  However, our opposition is intelligent, contrary to the attitude of our opponents towards us. This text is simply intended to bring into logical and legal conformity the association and stabilization agreements concluded and ratified previously. Negotiations that began in December 2012 resulted in the signing of an agreement with the protocol on 25 October 2013. To oppose this protocol, which is, let us recall, a simple legislative adaptation, would be a sterile opposition, which we refuse to embody.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am against any treaty that facilitates the expansion of the European Union. Given that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has already been identified as a potential Member State, and this report encourages increasing the European Union’s legal relationship with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, I therefore voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ivo Vajgl's report on the stabilisation and association agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This purely technical text makes it possible to update the existing agreement by including Croatia, the last state to join the Union. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other hand, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a technical codification of an existing convention. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Despite the fact it is a technical report, abstaining on the recommendation to give consent was my decision. In my view, this position makes it possible to express criticism towards the EU-FYROM Stabilisation and Association Agreement (creation of a free trade area and economic and political reforms) without opposing a technical adjustment due to the EU accession of Croatia.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcomed Mr Vejgl's proposal. With this report, Parliament gives a positive opinion on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the conclusion of the protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I am opposed to the logic of the unlimited enlargement of the European Union. However, this text is only a legal compliance. Croatia's accession is a reality that must be taken into account.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it only updates an association agreement already ratified with Macedonia. On the substance, however, I would like to point out that I am opposed to the unlimited enlargement of the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. Although I and my colleagues in the group are opposed to any form of enlargement of the European Union, this is a legal compliance process since the association agreement has already been signed. It is therefore logical that this legislative "update" should take place.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. As this is a simple technical issue, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval for the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the Agreement in question entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia was approved in 2001 with a view to developing contractual relations with Macedonia and the Member States of the European Union. Croatia must be included as a new signatory to the Agreement following its accession to the EU in July 2013. Once the twenty-eight Member States have ratified the pact and Macedonia has complied with the Copenhagen criteria, Macedonia's future accession to the Union may be envisaged. Similarly, this update of the Agreement makes it possible to implement the 2013 rules for the phase-out of customs tariffs with candidate countries to join the EU, including Macedonia. For this reason, I approve those amendments to the Protocol.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is a newer version of the agreement for candidate countries and regulates the rules for comprehensive cooperation between the European Union and its Member States with the candidate country. By signing the Agreement, more precisely the "evolution clause" the state becomes a potential member of the European Union.  This Agreement covers countries from southeast Europe, and so far only the Republic of Croatia has become a full member. The biggest difference between previous European Agreements and Stabilisation and Association Agreements is a greater focus on regional cooperation. In addition, the Agreement regulates a number of trade regulations, harmonisation of legislation, respect for rights and freedoms, regulatory finances and many others.  I support the report of Representative Ivo Vajgla, who gives his consent to the signing of the Protocol, which takes into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union and thus adds as a member to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement of the Republic of Macedonia and regulates the rules of cooperation between Croatia and Macedonia.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The incorporation of Croatia in 2013 requires amendments to a number of basic EU treaties. The agreement for accession with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia amends Croatia's status. I voted for it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the signing and provisional application of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, as Skopje continues its provocative attitude towards Greece , with the altruism of Skopje expressed by the counterfeiting of history and the burning of the name of our Macedonia. Also, Greece does not recognize the education of Skopje. The Greek people will not accept the burning of the name of our Macedonia from Skopje. Nor is it the name of Skopje to accept a complex name by any geographical designation. I am strongly opposed to any future accession of Skopje to the European Union.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this protocol, which is a simple compliance with the Association and Stabilization Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in 2012, following Croatia's accession in 2013. Although I am against any enlargement, this is a simple legislative adaptation of an agreement already concluded and ratified.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of the draft decision on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The conclusion of this agreement aims to establish close and lasting relations which will enable the former Republic to strengthen and further expand existing relations with the European Union, with a view to supporting initiatives aimed at promoting the country's rapprochement with the Member States of the Union.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document, which gives a favourable opinion on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, since I consider it essential that Croatia , the last Member State to be accepted into the Community family, participates in the agreements concluded by the European Union before its accession.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this protocol with my vote. It is merely a technical approximation and it must therefore be supported.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This technical report is simply intended to bring European law into line in order to take account of Croatia's accession. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has signed a stabilization and association agreement with the European Union, of which Croatia has been a member since July 2013. This agreement, of course, aims to create a free trade area in the Western Balkans and requires respect for neoliberal doxa with major structural reforms. So, although it is a purely technical report, I object to it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In the text, the rapporteur calls for the approval of this agreement, despite the continued and sustained reference to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. National Front MPs denounce this policy of thoughtless and infinite enlargement, especially in the countries of the former Eastern Bloc.  But this text is simply intended to bring into logical and legal conformity the association and stabilization agreements concluded and ratified previously. Negotiations that began in December 2012 resulted in the signing of an agreement with the protocol on 25 October 2013. To oppose this protocol, which is, let us recall, a simple legislative adaptation would be a sterile opposition, which we refuse to embody.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. We deal here with the ratification of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this recommendation which concerns the inclusion of Croatia in the European Union’s existing Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, following Croatia’s accession to the Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, like other Western Balkan countries, was selected as a potential candidate for MEMBERSHIP of the European Union at the European Summit in Thessaloniki in 2003. However, the shortness of the European project and the lack of real prospects in the European Union, despite the Thessaloniki declaration, open up spaces for manoeuvre, especially for Russia, which is looking not only towards Greece but also towards all the Balkan countries. It was necessary to send a positive political signal to the yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and beyond the Balkan region. The Balkans require an active policy in accordance with European criteria.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support and consent to conclusion of the Protocol for the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and the protocol to take account of the accession of Croatia.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The previous Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and Macedonia should, as appropriate, be amended and supplemented after the EU has been extended to a new Member State, namely Croatia. The proposal is for the ratification of the Protocol on this.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approve this Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia aims to endorse the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other , to take account of Croatia's accession to the Eu-Union. The main objective of this report is logical compliance. Although I strongly oppose any enlargement of the Union, I have decided to vote in support since it is a purely technical text since the Association and Stabilization Agreement with Macedonia has already been concluded and ratified.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is a simple and non-controversial recommendation simply amending existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text, which consists of taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union in the negotiations conducted by the European Commission with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in order to conclude a Memorandum of Understanding for Stabilisation and Association.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this measure, which has become necessary to adapt the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and its Member States with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to Croatia's accession to the EU. The recommendation is simply one of the steps needed to update the European Union's system of international agreements when access to a new member occurs. In view of the very low political conflict and the large majority in favour of the measure, we whole much support the work of the rapporteur, whom we support in calling on the President of the European Parliament to convey Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report so that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia takes account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I salute the work done by my colleague Mr Vajgl on this issue. Macedonia deserves to have its European aspirations confirmed, and to have all the efforts it has made so far rewarded. I believe they still need to reinforce European values and to better improve their judiciary, but certainly Macedonia needs to be a part of Europe and to come ever closer to the European Union!

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely formal act in the form of a legally necessary response to Croatia's accession to the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The conclusion of the Protocol is necessary because of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour and I hope I have made my contribution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and Macedonia on the other is the first step Macedonia must take on its way to the EU. The protocols, however, regulate the ways of communication and the ways of implementing this Agreement between its signatories, and in view of the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, this Protocol must be amended accordingly. I support this decision, just as I support Macedonia on its journey to the EU. Macedonia is fully ready to start EU accession negotiations, much more prepared than other countries wishing to join the EU, but also from some who are already members of the EU. I believe that the 10-year wait is demotivating for the Macedonian people and does not contribute to the stability of the region. I therefore call on the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council to take a political decision to open negotiations with Macedonia, as the decision to block the opening of negotiations is purely political.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the stabilisation and association agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia endorses the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, from the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the Union. The purpose of this report is logical compliance. Although I strongly oppose any enlargement of the Union, I have decided to vote in support, since it is a purely technical text since the Association and Stabilization Agreement with Macedonia has already been concluded and ratified.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the draft Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (05547/2014), as well as the request for consent submitted by the Council in accordance with Article 217 and Article 218(6) of the second sub-paragraph (a)(s) and the second sub-paragraph of Article 218(i) and the second sub-paragraph of Article 218(i). Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8-0127/2014) I support the granting of consent for the conclusion of this Protocol. I also hope that the remaining CEFTE member states will adapt their legislation to European practices and Croatia's accession as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I support the conclusion of the Protocol with the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Macedonia, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. With this Protocol, Croatia becomes a party to the EU-Macedonia SSP, signed in Luxembourg on 9 April 2001 and adopts and takes note, in the same way as other Member States of the European Union, the texts of the Agreement, as well as joint declarations and unilateral declarations, annexed to the Final Act signed on the same day.  As a Croatian MEP, I want to express my support for Macedonia on its European path. Croatia is a country that has been passing with Macedonia in parallel with Macedonia, and on this occasion I regret that Macedonia, which initialled the SAA at the Zagreb Summit back in 2000, did not open accession negotiations with the EU 15 years later despite six recommendations from the European Commission.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the European Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia with a view to concluding a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The protocol to the Stabilisation Agreement has been signed and today the European Parliament is deciding to approve it. I believe that this is an important step along the road to the process of integrating our continent.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is symbolic that we are discussing the issue of the relationship between the EU and Macedonia today, when we have the problem of the Greek crisis as the most high-profile issue. Personally, I am sorry that accession negotiations between the EU and Macedonia have not yet started, even though the Commission has repeatedly recommended their opening. Of course, Macedonia still needs to take a number of steps towards future membership of the Union, but it deserves to be on a level playing field with the rest of the region and accession talks are finally started. Relations between the EU and Macedonia are all the more important because this Balkan country now faces both security and political risks. In the interest of the Member States of the Union, there is no doubt a stable and European Macedonia. Supporting today's rather technical standard, which is a projection of Croatian membership in the EU into an association agreement with Macedonia, is only a small and important step in supporting the aforementioned objective.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol on the Stabilization and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. This is the ratification of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I voted in favour of this report because it only makes the necessary adjustments to that agreement because of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, following the recommendations of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. It is linked to the return to normality in Skopje, capital of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, as the four main political parties are about to finalize an agreement to end the political crisis in the country. The role played by Commissioner Johannes Hahn and some MEPs in the process of resolving this crisis is to be welcomed. The organisation of elections, which will take place on 24 April 2016, by a new government and the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate the problem of interception of communications, which is the source of political disagreement, are all factors in favour of stabilizing the political situation in Macedonia. The country must now implement the reforms expected if it wants more advanced Euro-Atlantic integration.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is only a question of making the necessary adjustments to that agreement as a result of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Croatia's participation in the Agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By voting for this report, the European Parliament approves the conclusion of the Stabilization and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Today, the President of Parliament is responsible for conveying Parliament's position to the Council, the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in order to conclude the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the European Communities and their Member States—of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The protocol is updated to reflect the 2013 EU customs tariff and the phasing-out of duties under the EEA.  The Commission proposes that the Council decide on the signature and provisional application of the Protocol on behalf of the European Union and conclude the Protocol on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.  With no reason to approve it, I voted this document in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Vajgl on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote. On 26 March 2001 the European Council adopted the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), on the other. This Agreement formalizes the Parties' commitment to economic matters, creating a free trade area. It stresses the need to create a new climate in economic relations between the EU and EMA, which serves mainly to promote trade and investment development. We abstained because of certain ambiguous technical aspects that form part of the Agreement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval for the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the Agreement in question entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation giving consent for the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Accession Agreement between the EC and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a legislative resolution on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, as the aim of this resolution was to introduce simple technical adjustments to this agreement. At the same time, the signing of the Additional Protocol was necessary in order to allow the Republic of Croatia to become a Party to the EU-Macedonia Stabilisation and Association Agreement.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the adoption of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. It is merely a technical change that needs to be adapted given that Croatia has been a member of the EU since 1 July 2013.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The enlargement of the EU has proved to be a success story, and I therefore support its continuation to the countries of the so-called Western Balkans. The accession of one of them, Croatia, is both an incentive for others and proof that the Balkans are evolving democratically and peacefully.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Recommendation because on 24 September 2014 the Council approved the opening of Macedonia's negotiations in order to conclude the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and Macedonia, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The Protocol on behalf of the European Union must be approved.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation as it was simply to amend existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report on the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement Protocol between the European Communities and their Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to start negotiations on behalf of the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Croatia with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other. Negotiations have been successfully concluded and I support the European Parliament's consent to conclude this agreement. The Republic of Croatia is the last Member State to join the European Union and therefore we encourage further rapprochement of countries in the environment of the European Union.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the agreement only reflects the changed legal situation and thus Croatia's accession to the EU, I supported the proposal.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are not given the opportunity to amend the association agreement with Skopje.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The process of enlargement of the European Union is a natural phenomenon, aimed at reuniting all the states on the European continent that share European democratic values. These values include interethnic and religious tolerance, especially in relation to minorities. Macedonia is recently going through a major political crisis, which affects the fragile balance established in 2003 by the Ohrid Agreement, regulating the right of ethnic minorities to their due representation in national political institutions. However, compliance with this agreement is increasingly difficult, given a precarious economic situation and quite distant prospects of the European integration process.  The European Union has a duty to support Macedonia in achieving as much compatibility with European rules as possible, with a view to its accession, in the not too distant future, to its structures. Ensuring this perspective is likely to contribute to the normalisation of the current volatile political situation and to the resumption of progress towards strengthening national democratic institutions. The adoption of the current Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is only a first step towards a positive development of this country on the path of European integration.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other hand, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia establishes the framework for the relations and a free trade area between the two entities. Following Croatia’s accession to the EU, it was necessary to formally adjust the agreement, therefore I voted in favour of the text.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which denotes technical measures to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union.  The 2001 agreement confirmed Macedonia's status as a potential candidate for EU membership, and one of the main goals is to provide an appropriate framework for political dialogue, which is nowadays in dire need of Macedonia. Upgrading this Agreement should be a reminder to the European Union that it has committed to participate in Macedonia's political, economic and institutional stabilisation through civil society development and democratisation, institution building and public administration reforms.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. In September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia with a view to concluding a protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, taking into account the accession of Croatia to the European Union. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is only another step towards the convergence of Macedonia with the EU, which is why I supported this Protocol.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote. On 26 March 2001 the European Council adopted the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), on the other. This Agreement formalizes the Parties' commitment to economic matters, creating a free trade area. It stresses the need to create a new climate in economic relations between the EU and EMA, which serves mainly to promote trade and investment development. We abstained because of certain ambiguous technical aspects that form part of the Agreement.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the approval of the Council's draft decision on the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Of course, we oppose the logic of the unlimited enlargement of the Union and the so-called 'association agreements' between the European Union and most of the states of the former communist bloc. However, this text is mainly aimed at logical compliance, as the Association and Stabilization Agreement has already been concluded and ratified. The country confirmed its agreement with the protocol on 25 October 2013. It therefore aims to adapt the agreements as a legislative one and, in this sense, to vote formally against it would be a sterile opposition. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote. On 26 March 2001 the European Council adopted the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), on the other. This Agreement formalizes the Parties' commitment to economic matters, creating a free trade area. It stresses the need to create a new climate in economic relations between the EU and EMA, which serves mainly to promote trade and investment development. We abstained because of certain ambiguous technical aspects that form part of the Agreement.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Recommendation to conclude the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Macedonia to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU. It is a purely formal Protocol that is updated to reflect the changes introduced with the 2013 EU Customs Tariff and with the gradual abolition of duties under the SAA, as a consequence of the entry of Croatia into to the EU. It is a normal procedure involving countries that have signed Stabilisation and Association Agreements with the EU, in view of their potential future membership of the Union.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs of this Parliament (47 votes in favour, 3 against and 5 abstentions) and the Council's approval of that protocol in February 2014, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of the Protocol.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval for the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, as Croatia acceded to the EU in July 2013 and the Agreement in question entered into force in 2004. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement takes into account the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (05547/2014). It therefore stems from the normal functioning of the treaties and concerns the sovereign will of the peoples of these countries.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this protocol with my vote. It is merely a technical approximation and it must therefore be supported.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I agreed with my group on Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union and its Member States of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on the other, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This is a purely technical measure, taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU in July 2013.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a technical document which aims to include Croatia, following its integration into the EU, as part of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU, its Member States and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The procedure itself does not alter the EEA already in force, making some adjustments in the agricultural aspect, in particular under the condition of the movement of goods and their tariff quotas.  We do not, however, disregard the broader framework of the EEA signed between the EU and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, including particular aspects such as the creation of free trade areas, the imposition of economic, political, judicial, fiscal, public sector reforms, nor do we fail to take into account the historical and political framework of this whole process (dismemberment of Yugoslavia and the role of the EU and NATO powers , in particular in the conflict of the Balkan region), already expressed on other occasions. For the reasons expressed, we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since Croatia was not a party to the Agreement until now. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In July 2013, Croatia became the 28th Member State to join the EU. It is the second country of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to join the EU, after Slovenia. This protocol is an important, if only formal, step towards long-term peace in the Balkans. I sincerely hope that the peace process will continue throughout the Balkan region.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is not a major political agreement, but a legislative compliance through the addition of the protocol. In September 2012, negotiations were reopened between Serbia and the EU to establish this protocol taking into account Croatia's new accession to the Union, which changed some aspects of the original agreement.  As a member of the National Front, I am opposed to the enlargement of the Union and therefore fight these association agreements. However, this is simply a matter of endorsing a common-sense legislative development and compliance. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is customary for UKIP MEPs to vote against such protocols, as we opposed the agreements themselves at the time.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because since Croatia is a full member of the Union, it is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols. Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to support the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia, which takes account of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. If I oppose the unlimited enlargement of the European Union and the so-called association agreements, which are usually only the first step towards the accession of a new Member State, this text is only a legal compliance agreement, the association agreement with Serbia having already been concluded and ratified. This is, therefore, a fairly logical legal adjustment.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It is a matter of approving a protocol adapting the stabilisation and association agreement with Serbia in order to integrate Croatia's accession into the Union. I voted in favour of that point.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The McAllister report contains unclear and non-acceptable passages. That is why I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these two reports. For me, this is a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the European Union, so it becomes a formality that it also forms part of the stabilisation and association agreements that exist with Macedonia and Serbia.  That is not to say that I support everything contained in these agreements, or all the demands placed on Serbia and Macedonia in these agreements. However, this vote is only about the consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU, and that it is therefore part of the CONTRACTING PARTY that is the EU.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia. Croatia's participation in the Agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the European Union necessitates an update of the additional agreements. Having regard to the draft protocol annexed to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Serbia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, and having regard to the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I agree with the conclusion of the Agreement and voted in favour of the adoption of the Recommendation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The protocol annexed to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and its members and the Republic of Serbia also made it necessary to supplement the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and its Members and the Republic of Serbia. As a member of the delegation accompanying Serbia's progress in the European Parliament, I was also happy to support the draft decision.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that it is important for Croatia to acquire member state status as soon as possible, including in respect of third countries with which bilateral agreements have been concluded.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text gives the Approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities, member States and Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.  Although we oppose the unlimited enlargements of the Union and the so-called association agreements, we can only approve the legislative adaptation of this agreement, which has already been concluded and ratified, the text of which is mainly aimed at legal compliance. To vote against this recommendation would therefore be a sterile opposition. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report takes a stand in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. As with the agreement with Macedonia, this is a simple compliance, especially since the agreement is ratified. I have therefore decided to vote in force, on form, while remaining opposed to the enlargement of the Union.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, is called for.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report. This is a technical report and the purpose is to provide a technical adjustment to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and Serbia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union. The Council can only adopt if the Parliament provides consent to the act. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is customary for UKIP MEPs to vote against such protocols, as we opposed the agreements themselves at the time.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this Protocol in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union in relation to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the European Communities and their Member States and Serbia, which was concluded before Croatia’s accession to the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the political analysis already made during the debate on Croatia's accession, I voted in favour of this recommendation, also given its technical nature and its executive nature.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes a position on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other hand, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. In the same vein as Mr Vajgl's report, the Council's proposal is to bring a protocol into compliance by adding a protocol following the association agreement between the Union and Serbia. Once again, although I am formally opposed to the bulimia of enlargement that the Union suffers from and to the principle of association agreements, which fall within a globalist matrix, here it is not a question of voting for or against these already ratified agreements, but of making a common-sense legislative adaptation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Rightly, having regard to the draft Council Decision and the Draft Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, it instructs its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council, the Commission, as well as the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of Serbia.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and Serbia, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union, as the 28th Member State , july 1, 2013.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia because Croatia's accession to the European Union made it necessary to revise it. This agreement is the framework for Serbia's efforts to achieve a stable democracy and market economy with a view to its accession to the European Union, although this event is not likely to take place in the short term.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Council's authorisation to conclude a protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Republic of Serbia, in order to take account of Croatia's recent accession to the European Union, I wished to vote in favour of the text of this recommendation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote reflects the accession of Croatia to the European Union. I have thus voted in favour of the report which is technical in nature and which makes the existing provision clear on the accession of Croatia to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the Member States and the Republic of Serbia.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since Croatia was not a party to the Agreement until now. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a procedural vote which I supported since it updates the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Serbia in order to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to conclude a protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities, its Member States and Serbia, to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union. Considering that it is normal for Croatia, now a full member of the European Union, to become a party to this agreement, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Croatia joined the European Union on 1 July 2013. Therefore, it must be integrated into all the agreements previously signed between Member States and third countries. Parliament has thus approved the conclusion of a protocol to add Croatia to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Serbia.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Council must, on behalf of the European Union and take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, approve the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and its Member States on the one hand, and Serbia on the other. This decision follows Croatia's accession to the European Union. A Serbia-Croatia partnership shared with the rest of the UNION contributes to the stability of the Balkans.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This is a simple legislative adaptation of the agreements, as well as a question of legal clarity and coherence in the system of EU law.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a purely technical measure taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU in July 2013. Members are asked to give their consent to the conclusion of the protocol between the two parties in this regard.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia because this is a purely technical solution. The need for such a vote was croatia's accession to the EU and the need for certain amendments to Serbia's EU association documents to reflect the change in the number of EU member states.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the plan as we are not given the opportunity to amend the association agreement with Serbia.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is primarily a legal compliance.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a technical document which aims to include Croatia, following its integration into the EU, as part of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU, its Member States and the Republic of Serbia. The procedure itself does not alter the EEA already in force, making some adjustments in the agricultural aspect, in particular under the condition of the movement of goods and their tariff quotas. We do not, however, disregard the broader framework of the EEA signed between the EU and the Republic of Serbia, including particular aspects such as the creation of free trade areas, the imposition of economic, political, judicial, fiscal, public sector reforms, nor do we fail to take into account the historical and political framework of this whole process (dismemberment of Yugoslavia and the role of the EU and NATO powers , in particular in the conflict in the Balkan region), already expressed on other occasions. For the reasons expressed, we abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the Council's proposal for a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and the Republic of Serbia to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's neighbourhood and enlargement policy is one of the failures of this Europe. To continue in this direction is counterproductive.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Republic of Serbia (protocol to take into account Croatia's accession to the EU), as we are not given the opportunity to amend the Association Agreement with Serbia.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the request for consent submitted by the Council, I voted in favour of the European Parliament consent to conclusion of the Protocol.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I supported the agreement in line with the direction of the European People's Party, which, in my opinion, strengthens the existing close bond between the EU and Serbia and establishes a contractual relationship between the two parties. The agreement re-establishes political dialogue, stabilises the free trade area and strengthens bilateral economic relations, thereby tended to bring serious economic benefits to Serbia. Furthermore, I think it is important to point out that the agreement will encourage reform processes that will contribute to the growth of the Serbian economy and help Serbia to develop a fully functioning market economy.  The agreement also lays the foundations for enhanced cooperation between the EU and Serbia in a number of areas in the future. Not least in the fight against organised crime and cross-border illicit trade and in terms of improving existing environmental standards. This was also the aim of the report adopted today for stability and sustainable development.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the Protocol on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia on the occasion of Croatia's accession to the EU, because it is a technical act on the occasion of Croatia's accession to the EU, which also strengthens relations with Serbia.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the McAllister report given it concerns a Recommendation simply amending existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. On 24 September 2012 the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States and Croatia, with Serbia, in order to conclude a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and Serbia, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Protocol was drawn up by the Commission and the Government of Serbia on 10 December 2013. It is now necessary to conclude the Protocol. In this procedure, the role of the European Parliament is to decide whether or not to give its approval to the act.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the McAllister report as it is a simple and non-controversial recommendation amending existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. On 24 September 2012 the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States and Croatia, with Serbia, in order to conclude a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and Serbia, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Protocol was drawn up by the Commission and the Government of Serbia on 10 December 2013. It is now necessary to conclude the Protocol. In this procedure, the role of the European Parliament is to decide whether or not to give its approval to the act.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a recommendation on the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, since it is a case of aligning the agreement document with the fact that the Republic of Croatia has become a member of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Serbia, in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.  This is not a major political agreement, but rather a legislative compliance through the addition of the protocol. Indeed, in September 2012, negotiations were reopened between Serbia and the Union in order to establish this protocol taking into account Croatia's new accession, which changed some aspects of the original agreement.  As an MEP for the ENL Group, I oppose the EU's reckless enlargement policy, and therefore speak out against association agreements. However, on this vote, it is not a question of voting for or against the agreements, but simply of endorsing a change and a common sense legislative compliance.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am against any treaty that facilitates the expansion of the European Union. Given Serbia has already been identified as a potential Member State, and this report encourages increasing the European Union’s legal relationship with Serbia, I have therefore I have voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague David Mc Allister's report on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia. This purely technical text makes it possible to update the existing agreement by including Croatia, the last state to join the Union. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a technical codification of an existing agreement with Serbia. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr McAllister's report. Parliament delivered a positive opinion on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and the Republic of Serbia, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the conclusion of the protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I am opposed to the logic of the unlimited enlargement of the European Union. However, this text is only a legal compliance. Croatia's accession is a reality that must be taken into account.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it only updates an association agreement already ratified with Serbia. On the substance, however, I would like to point out that I am opposed to the unlimited enlargement of the European Union.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. As this is a simple technical issue, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since Croatia was not a party to the Agreement until now. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia was approved in 2008 with the aim of developing contractual relations with Serbia and the Member States of the European Union. Updating this document to include Croatia as a signatory, the latter being the last EU Member State following its accession in July 2013, would allow progress in negotiations towards Serbia's future accession to the Union. Similarly, customs tariffs on agricultural and fisheries imports originating in Serbia to any EU Member State are lifted and minimum tariffs are set for exports from the EU to Serbia. Bidding for the amendment of the Protocol is not only a formality in terms of Croatia's accession to the Agreement, but also revitalizes trade with the Balkan region, which will generate benefits for both parties. For these reasons, I strongly support the updating of the pact.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Since Croatia has become a full member of the European Union, it should also be taken into account its accession to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia, so I supported the Report of Representative David McAllister, which gives its consent to the signing of the Protocol. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is a newer version of the agreement for candidate countries and regulates the rules for comprehensive cooperation between the European Union and its Member States with the candidate country.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The incorporation of Croatia in 2013 requires amendments to a number of basic EU treaties. The agreement for accession with Serbia amends Croatia's status. I voted for it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Serbia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, because this report is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement, which is a simple legislative adaptation of compliance as part of Croatia's integration into the European Union. I would like to remind you that we oppose any form of enlargement under a globalist matrix that destroys the sovereignty of peoples.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft decision concluding the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia. This agreement will enable Serbia to consolidate and further extend its relations with the Union and its Member States, with the aim of integrating and strengthening trade relations, with particular reference to trade development and investment.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is essential that Croatia, a member of the European Union from 2013, participates in the agreements from the latter contract, during a phase prior to its entry into the Community family. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this document, which reaffirms the validity of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, taking into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This protocol is also a purely technical approximation to Croatia's accession to the European Union, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This is the same type of approval procedure as in the case of the report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia voted on the same day. This technical report is simply intended to bring European law into line in order to take account of Croatia's accession in July 2013. Serbia has signed a stabilization and association agreement with the EU, of which Croatia has been a member since July 2013. Serbia was granted state status as a candidate for entry into the European Union on 1 March 2012.  The negotiations have always been tough as the Union seeks to humiliate its Balkan "black sheep", both in terms of economic and foreign policy. I have already expressed my position in the committee vote on this almost funny affair which leads Croatia to approve the strengthening of the Union's ties with Serbia, despite the still fresh scars. I am voting to help Serbia break its current isolation and allow it to defend itself against the threats of other countries of the movement linked to the German conservatives, particularly docile in the region.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is not a major political agreement, but rather a legislative compliance through the addition of the protocol. Indeed, in September 2012, negotiations were reopened between Serbia and the Union in order to establish this protocol taking into account Croatia's new accession, which changed some aspects of the original agreement.  We oppose the policy of thoughtless enlargement which is that of the European Union. However, on this vote, it is not a question of voting for or against the agreements, but simply of endorsing a change and a common sense legislative compliance.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. We deal here with the ratification of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this recommendation which concerns the inclusion of Croatia in the Union’s existing Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia following Croatia’s accession to the Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In June 2013, the European Council decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia. This is an initiative that deserves our full attention at a time when Russia is increasingly looking towards the Balkans to expand its area of influence, not hesitating to exploit the uncertainties about Serbia's European future. Russian policy in the Balkans, particularly in Serbia, is carried out in conjunction with regional energy investments such as the purchase of power plants and refineries, etc. Therefore, any action taken by Europe, in accordance with European criteria and its values, showing the Union's interest in the Balkan countries is positive.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support and consent to conclusion of the Protocol for the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia and the protocol to take account of the accession of Croatia.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The previous Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States and Serbia should be amended and supplemented, as appropriate, after the EU has been extended to a new Member State, namely Croatia. The proposal is for the ratification of the Protocol on this.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approve this Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Serbia, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia, as the precedent for the Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, aims to conclude the Council's draft decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union and its Member States of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand and the Republic of Serbia, on the other hand, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Since this is a purely technical report, I have decided to vote in support, although I am opposed to any enlargement of the Union.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is a simple and non-controversial recommendation simply amending existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text, which is to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union in the negotiations conducted by the European Commission with Serbia with the aim of concluding a protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this measure, which has become necessary to adapt the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and its Member States with the Republic of Serbia to Croatia's accession to the EU.  The recommendation is simply one of the steps needed to update the Eu ropean Union's system of international agreements when a new member is accessed. In view of the very low political conflict and the large majority in favour of the measure, we whole much support the work of the rapporteur, whom we support in calling on the President of the European Parliament to convey Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of Serbia.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report so that the Republic of Serbia takes account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely formal act in the form of a legally necessary response to Croatia's accession to the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The conclusion of the Protocol is necessary because of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour and I hope I have made my contribution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia on the other is the first step Serbia must take on its way to the EU.
