In view of the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, this Agreement must be amended accordingly. For this reason, I support this Decision changing the Protocol to the Agreement in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  The path of the Republic of Croatia towards the EU was lengthy and demanding, especially after the still visible wounds from the Homeland War. On its way to the EU, Serbia must be as committed as Croatia is to this goal. This means the need to align the national legislative framework with the EU acquis, which will certainly be extremely challenging when it comes to Chapters 23 and 24. Croatia has fulfilled its task, and these necessary steps are to reach European standards before the Republic of Serbia.  That is why I take the opportunity to reiterate Serbia's obligation arising from the European Parliament's 2014 Resolution on the Progress of the Republic of Serbia to consider its Law on the Organisation and Competence of State Organs in the War Crimes Procedure of the Republic of Serbia in the spirit of reconciliation and good neighbourly relations, in cooperation with neighbours and the Commission.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia, as the precedent for the Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, aims to conclude the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union and its Member States of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand and the Republic of Serbia, on the other hand, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Since this is a purely technical report, I have decided to vote in support, although I am opposed to any enlargement of the Union.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the draft Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (06681/2014), as well as the request for consent submitted by the Council in accordance with Article 217, Article 218(i) and Article 218(8) of the Second Sub-Paragraph (A)(i) and Article 218(8) of the Second Sub-Regulation of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8-0098/2014), I support the granting of consent to the conclusion of this Protocol. I also hope that the remaining CEFTE member states will adapt their legislation to European practices and Croatia's accession as soon as possible, of which two years have passed.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I support the conclusion of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  With this Protocol, Croatia becomes a party to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Serbia signed on 29 April 2008 and thus adopts and takes note, in the same way as other Member States of the European Union, the texts of the Agreement, as well as joint declarations and unilateral declarations, annexed to the Final Act signed on the same day. The almost unanimous support of the Foreign Policy Committee speaks of the importance of adopting the Protocol in the context of the EU enlargement policy and Serbia's continued accession to the EU.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As in the case of the Protocol to the Association Agreement with Macedonia today, this standard is rather technical. Nevertheless, it gives us the opportunity to demonstrate once again support for the rapprochment between Serbia and the European Union, which is not an easy story, but i think it is a story that is now developing successfully. Serbia belongs to Europe and we must appreciate its actions to cooperate with Europe. Personally, as an alternate in the delegation with Serbia, I am happy to express my support for today's proposal.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I spoke in favour of the protocol on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. This is the ratification of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I voted in favour of this report because it only makes the necessary adjustments to that agreement because of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is only a question of making the necessary adjustments to that agreement as a result of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution so that the Republic of Croatia can participate fully as a member of the European Union in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia. Croatia's participation in the Agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the EU and therefore approval should be given to the conclusion of this Additional Protocol.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In voting for this report, the European Parliament approved the stabilisation and association agreement with Serbia. The President of the Parliament is now responsible for conveying Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of Serbia.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 24 September 2012 the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations on behalf of the European Union, its Member States and Croatia with Serbia in order to conclude the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, of the one part, and Serbia, of the other part, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Protocol was initialled by the Commission and the Government of Serbia on 10 December 2013. With no reason to support the conclusion of this protocol, I have voted in favour of the council's draft decision.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Mr McAllister(S).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. On 24 September 2012 the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States and Croatia, with Serbia, in order to conclude a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and Serbia, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Protocol was drawn up by the Commission and the Government of Serbia on 10 December 2013. It is now necessary to conclude the Protocol. In this procedure, the role of the European Parliament is to decide whether or not to give its approval to the act.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since Croatia was not a party to the Agreement until now. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation giving consent for the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Accession Agreement between the EC and the Republic of Serbia to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and Serbia, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. It is merely a technical change that needs to be adapted given that Croatia has been a member of the EU since 1 July 2013.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The next step in bringing Serbia and the EU closer, following the accession of another of the countries of the so-called Western Balkans, Croatia, to the EU is, on the one hand, an incentive for others and proof that the Balkans are evolving democratically and peacefully.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Recommendation because the Council approved the Commission for opening negotiations with Serbia in order to conclude the protocol for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their countries and Serbia, in order to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union. For this reason, the Protocol must be approved on behalf of the European Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I also supported this recommendation as it was simply to amend existing agreements to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement Protocol between the European Communities and their Member States and the Republic of Serbia. I support the European Parliament's consent to conclude this agreement. The Republic of Croatia is the last Member State to join the European Union and we encourage further rapprochement of countries in the environment of the European Union.  I take the opportunity to point out that when approaching the European Union, the Republic of Serbia must abide by all the rules and values represented by the European Union. I highlight concerns about recent warmongering statements and provocations by Serbian Minister Aleksandar Vulin that clearly do not respect the Republic of Croatia, a full member of the European Union. In addition, the recent rehabilitation of Draza Mihajlovic and the Chetniks by the Belgrade Higher Court is causing great concern. I support Serbia on its journey to the European Union, but it is clear that it cannot become a member with such statements and judgments that go against the fundamental values on which the European Union is founded.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are not given the opportunity to amend the association agreement with Serbia.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The enlargement of the European Union is a process that cannot bypass an area as sensitive as the Balkan region. Croatia's European integration has shown that countries in the region are able to achieve the convergence standards needed to successfully complete this difficult and arduous process. Of course, each of these countries has its own peculiarities, stemming from recent developments.  Serbia has experienced dramatic moments over the past two decades, which have undoubtedly affected the morale of its citizens, generating attitudes against Western values that are hard to erase in the short and medium term. Despite these problems, Serbia has seen an upward trend in recent years both politically and economically that has enabled it to gain candidate status for EU integration.  In the current international political context, however, Serbia has become the site of intense geopolitical rivalries between European structures and those promoted by Russia. In these circumstances, it is necessary to accelerate the European integration process of this country, the only guarantee that it will successfully complete the eu accession process. For these reasons, I believe that the adoption of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia is an essential step towards achieving this.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia establishes the framework for the relations and a free trade area between the two entities. Following Croatia’s accession to the EU, it was necessary to formally adjust the agreement, therefore I voted in favour of the text.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Serbia, as it is only a technical measure, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  As the central point of the stabilisation process, the Agreement highlights international and regional peace and cooperation, the development of good-social relations and respect for and protection of human rights and minorities, which Serbia has not respected lately, and therefore I believe that this vote should also be a reminder of the determinants of which the Agreement consists.  Namely, although the Agreement obliges Serbia to foster co-operation and good-neighbouring relations with countries in the region, this is not put into practice. On the contrary, the actions and statements of Serbian politicians have the opposite effect and cause tensions in regional relations. After war criminal Vojislav Seselj burned the Croatian flag in Serbia, Serbian authorities did not disasse his actions or condemn them, but with their statements further fueled the tensions caused, thus undermining the development of good neighborly relations and co-operation.  Shortly afterwards, the rehabilitation of Chetnik Commander Drasa Mihailovic, known as the creator of the programme of ethnic cleansing and the creation of The Great Serbia, followed. Following these facts, I believe that the European institutions should warn the authorities in Belgrade of violations of the provisions of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which are a key factor in achieving stability in the region.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. In September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with Serbia with a view to concluding a protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and Serbia, of the other part, taking into account croatia's accession to the European Union. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is just another step towards serbia's rapprochement with the EU, which is why I supported this Protocol.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. On 24 September 2012 the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States and Croatia, with Serbia, in order to conclude a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and Serbia, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Protocol was drawn up by the Commission and the Government of Serbia on 10 December 2013. It is now necessary to conclude the Protocol. In this procedure, the role of the European Parliament is to decide whether or not to give its approval to the act.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In line with Mr Vajgl's report, the Council's proposal aims to bring a protocol into legislative compliance by adding a protocol following the association agreement between the European Union and Serbia. On 24 September 2012, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Serbia on behalf of the European Union, its Member States and Croatia in order to conclude a protocol to the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and Serbia, on the other, with a view to taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union. These negotiations culminated in the signing of the protocol on 10 December 2013. Although we are formally opposed to the patriarchy of enlargement that the Union suffers from and to the principle of association agreements which fall under a globalist matrix, it is not a question here of voting for or against these agreements, which have already been ratified, but of making a common-sense legislative adaptation. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour. On 24 September 2012 the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States and Croatia, with Serbia, in order to conclude a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States, on the one hand, and Serbia, on the other, to take account of Croatia's accession to the European Union. The Protocol was drawn up by the Commission and the Government of Serbia on 10 December 2013. It is now necessary to conclude the Protocol. In this procedure, the role of the European Parliament is to decide whether or not to give its approval to the act.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Recommendation to conclude the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the EU and Serbia to take account of the accession of Croatia to the EU. It is a purely formal Protocol that is updated to reflect the changes introduced with the 2013 EU Customs Tariff and with the gradual abolition of duties under the SAA, as a consequence of the entry of Croatia into to the EU. It is a normal procedure involving countries that have signed Stabilisation and Association Agreements with the EU, in view of their potential future membership of the Union.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs of this Parliament (51 votes in favour, 2 against and 2 abstentions) and the Council's approval of that protocol in March 2014, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of the Protocol.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Serbia to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU, since Croatia was not a party to the Agreement until now. Thus, although it is a technical amendment which does not affect the substance of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, I abstained in the vote, since by principle I oppose such agreements, which are in the interest of multinationals and political-financial elites and to the detriment of the peoples of the parties concerned.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement takes into account the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Serbia, on the other, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (06681/2014), it therefore results from the normal functioning of the treaties and concerns the sovereign will of the peoples of these countries.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This protocol is also a purely technical approximation to Croatia's accession to the European Union, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a technical document which aims to include Croatia, following its integration into the EU, as part of the Protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the EU, its Member States and the Republic of Serbia. The procedure itself does not alter the EEA already in force, making some adjustments in the agricultural aspect, in particular under the condition of the movement of goods and their tariff quotas.  We do not, however, disregard the broader framework of the EEA signed between the EU and the Republic of Serbia, including particular aspects such as the creation of free trade areas, the imposition of economic, political, judicial, fiscal, public sector reforms, nor do we fail to take into account the historical and political framework of this whole process (dismemberment of Yugoslavia and the role of the EU and NATO powers , in particular in the conflict in the Balkan region), already expressed on other occasions. For the reasons expressed, we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific Cooperation signed between the EU and India in 2002. The Agreement has had a positive impact on the scientific development of both sides and its renewal can serve to enhance economic, social and cultural relations between the two blocs.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In 2001, the agreement with the Indian Government on scientific and technical cooperation was concluded for the first time. This agreement was extended for a further five years in 2010. The agreement has promoted cooperation in nutrition and solar research, among others. I support the extension of the agreement with India and hope that this cooperation will continue to bear fruit.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I welcome this proposal for a scientific cooperation agreement with India. The Indian Prime Minister, from the nationalist party, is concerned about his people and intends to reasonably accompany a great transformation of society, now mainly focused on agriculture, to direct it towards a reasoned and reasonable industrialization. This agreement provides reciprocal opportunities for access to the programme of settlement projects, exchange of information and adequate protection of intellectual property. At the end of the day, the exchange of research for mutual economic development will be a guarantee of lasting peace through development. So I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure because of the impact upon the EU Budget, and therefore on taxpayers’ money.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of renewing the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with India.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Although I challenge the EU's right to substitute for Member States in the conclusion of treaties, India is destined to become one of our preferred partners in the multipolar world of tomorrow. As the heir to a multi-millennium civilization, India is of ever-increasing geostrategic importance.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement concluded in 2002 between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on "scientific and technological cooperation with India" aims to renew the agreement on scientific and technical partnership with India.  India occupies an extremely important geostrategic position for the future, especially for the necessary rebalancing that must take place against the United States and this country like the other BRICS must be an indispensable partner for France and Europe.  Although I am opposed to the Union's exclusive competence in partnership, since I believe that foreign policy must be the responsibility of the Member States, I voted in favour of this report in order to send a positive signal to India.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Buzek's report is balanced and well developed. I believe that scientific cooperation agreements with third countries are necessary to support the progress of our companies and their inclusion in foreign markets. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India was signed in New Deli on 23 November 2001 for an initial period of five years extended by the parties provided that in the last year of validity they agreed on its extension. After the last extension, both sides have proposed their renewal for a new five-year period in order to continue scientific and technological relations between India and Europe, so I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on scientific and technological cooperation with India.  The Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India was signed in New Delhi on 23 November 2001, which is being updated every five years. The Agreement provides that Indian research entities shall participate in horizon 2020 framework programme and other cooperation activities. Regular meetings and bilateral contacts are held, allowing for a systematic exchange of information.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the renewal of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with the Government of the Republic of India in 2001. I think it is important to ensure continuity, such as an extension of 5 years.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of past cooperation that has borne fruit and brought India closer to the European Union in a number of areas, the extension of the Agreement for Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India makes more than reasonable, and therefore my support for these recommendations is therefore also appropriate.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report, which aims to renew the Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement between Europe and India. The Parties to the Agreement consider, which I personally agree, that the swift renewal of the Treaty will be in mutual interest.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that India is a fundamental partner both in the economic field and in the scientific-technological field. I am therefore very much in favour of renewing the current agreement between the Eu ropean Union and the Republic of India.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Federal Republic of India is one of the most populous countries in the world, with a large market that has not yet expressed its full potential and which represents an opportunity for an estimated turnover of over seventy billion euros and is able to expand further.  For years, relations between the European Union and India have been generally positive, although there has been no lack of political and economic friction. The European Union remains India's main trading partner and can contribute to the cultural, scientific and technological advancement of this great country. Collaboration in the medical-diagnostic, biological and hydro-engineering fields and in the FIELD of ICT are already bearing fruit. It is necessary to support and relaunch these efforts, testifying to the goodwill of the Union and reaffirming the presence in a strategic geographical area and potentially heralding important developments.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this text is to vote on the renewal of the scientific and technology cooperation agreement between the European Union and India, which was signed in November 2001. The aim of this initiative is to intensify the exchange of knowledge and the transfer of know-how to the scientific community, industry and European citizens. For the past fourteen years, experience has shown us that reciprocal access to the other party's programs and activities allows us to benefit from scientific progress in promoting the competitiveness of our companies. Although we are opposed to the European institutions negotiating agreements with third countries instead of the Member States, we consider that the links between France and India are geostrategic in the face of American leadership and that it is therefore essential to protect this partnership. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The traditional vote in favour of scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries by the Lega Nord is confirmed.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. India's growth is particularly evident in the field of scientific research, where the country has established itself as one of the leaders of recent years. The European Union signed a mutually beneficial scientific and technological cooperation agreement in 2002. It has led to increased cooperation in the area of innovation-enhancing research. The purpose of this report is to approve the renewal of this agreement in order to continue a lasting agreement between the two parties. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the renewal of the Agreement for Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and India. Indeed, I consider it of great interest, for the development of European research, to continue cooperation between India and the EU, through the participation of Indian research centres in European R&D programmes, the definition of joint projects and the exchange of information and knowledge. In particular, the initiative will improve and intensify research cooperation, as well as the transfer of know-how, and strengthen access to each other's markets. The principles are those of non-discrimination, the protection of intellectual property, the distribution and exploitation of results.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure because of the impact upon the EU Budget, and therefore on taxpayers’ money.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have followed the recommendation of the European Parliament Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and gave my consent to renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation with India, following the request for consent by the European Parliament that was submitted by the Council in accordance with Article 186 and Article 218(6), second subparagraph, point (a)(v), of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote against is due to India's non-accession to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT). India has between 80 and 100 nuclear warheads, and the issue of nuclear non-proliferation is of considerable political importance to us in the 5-Star Movement.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with India. Of course, although I do not credit the European Union with sufficient legitimacy to conclude, instead of France, strategic partnerships of this kind with foreign powers, collaboration with India allows us to rebalance the balance in the game of nations, especially against the United States. The agreement in question specifies that it is concluded for an initial period of five years and can be renewed by mutual agreement between the parties. Since its signing in New Delhi on 23 November 2001, this initiative has enabled a genuine exchange of specific knowledge and a transfer of know-how to the benefit of the scientific communities, industry, since the agreement is based on the principles of mutual benefit, reciprocal access to the programmes and activities of the other party in relation to the object of the agreement, non-discrimination , effective protection of intellectual property and equitable sharing of intellectual property rights, as well as effective exploitation of results.  This is a necessity for the influence of European researchers and strategic cooperation at the diplomatic level.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation agreements between the European Union and India have been ongoing for over a decade. India invests around EUR 2.5 billion a year in research and is a very important scientific partner for Europe, especially in certain areas such as information technology, where the country has made such progress that it can impose itself on the international scientific stage. The renewal of the agreement for the next five years will allow India to continue to be a partner associated with EU research programmes, with the consequent possibility for European researchers to access Indian research programmes with obvious mutual scientific advantages. I am of the opinion that this type of agreement should be encouraged and initiated, especially in the scientific field where collaboration between researchers and scientific institutes has always been a source of novelty and innovative solutions that transcend national borders. In order to benefit from advances in science, collaboration and mobility between European and international experts is needed. The Union has long led the way by promoting mobility in the field of research, not only intra-Community but also with associated third countries.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Rightly and positively supporting the draft Council Decision renewing the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, it instructs the President to forward Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the renewal of the Agreement for Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first scientific and technological cooperation agreement between India and the European Union was initialled in New Delhi on 23 November 2001. At its end it has always been renewed because only through the sharing of research, projects, ideas and capital can important results be achieved. I voted in favour of the project although it still has doubts following the tormented international events regarding the situation of our compatriots Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone. Indeed, on this occasion, my solidarity with the two servants of the fatherland and my closeness to their families remains high. The exchange of information and projects we consider to be a stimulus for all our students and researchers: we try in every way to encourage cooperation and the possibility for our citizens to access international structures.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Buzek Report on the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with India. In addition to updating the legal pleadings of the International Agreement in order to accommodate the amendments resulting from the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, this is the extension for another 5 years of this Agreement which was signed on 23 November 2001 and which has an extended period of validity of 5 years. It is certainly in the interest of both the EU and India to step up cooperation in science and technology in areas that are in the common interest, not least because scientific knowledge leads to better market access opportunities. The Agreement is based on the principles of mutual added value, reciprocal access to programs and actions of the other party, non-discrimination and effective protection of intellectual property.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it appropriate to abstain in voting on this draft resolution not so much the subject under discussion, but because I am saddened by the umpteenth postponement of the Indian Supreme Court on the issue of Italian marò unjustly detained in India since 2012 without charge. Long delays and restrictions on the freedom of movement of riflemen are unacceptable and represent a serious violation of human rights. I hope that a reasonable solution to the situation can soon be found once and for all.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The initiative of renewing the Agreement on cooperation in science and technology between the European Community and India will allow both parties to improve and intensify their cooperation in science and technology in areas of common interest. The Agreement is based on the right principles, including mutual benefit, non-discrimination and protection of intellectual property. The renewing of this Agreement will allow for increased scientific knowledge leading to market access opportunities and is thus being done in the best interests of the scientific communities, industry and citizens.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 3 March 2015, the Council transferred to Parliament the draft decision on the renewal of the Agreement for Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.  The current agreement expired on 17 May 2015 and can be renewed for a period of five years, by mutual agreement between the EU and India. The new agreement would not introduce any changes to the previous one, but the term 'European Community' is expected to be replaced by the necessary 'European Union' following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. The scope of the agreement covers all research and development activities under the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, as well as EU participation in Indian projects.  The costs incurred for cooperation between the parties will not result in any transfer of funds from one party to another. Scientific and technological cooperation on India's status as a developing country is exempt from the agreement. I am voting against because of India's non-accession to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. India has an estimated 80 to 100 nuclear warheads. The issue of nuclear non-proliferation is of great importance to the M5S and therefore, for this reason too, I am voting against it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific Cooperation signed between the EU and India in 2002. The Agreement has had a positive impact on the scientific development of both sides and its renewal can serve to enhance economic, social and cultural relations between the two blocs.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the renewal of the agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European community and the Government of India as I believe that such co-operation can be beneficial to both sides.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to renew the science and technology cooperation agreement between the European community and India, signed in New Delhi on 23 November 2001 and already renewed in 2009 by the 2009/501/EC decision. The agreement stipulates that it is concluded for an initial period of five years and can be renewed by mutual agreement between the parties, after review in the last year of each successive period. Considering that India is a strategic partner for the European Union and that it is necessary to maintain the continuity of scientific and technological relations with that country, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union has a fruitful relationship with the Republic of India in terms of scientific and technical cooperation. An agreement was first reached in 2002 and is now renewed for five years. It enables research projects to be conducted by pooling the resources of our universities and businesses. Our engineers also meet and exchange best practices.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – The EU is a leading region in terms of research and innovation. It is important that we maintain and even improve this position. In an ever more globalised world, more and more knowledge and expertise is being built up in developing countries, such as India. For the EU it is crucial that we keep in touch with developments abroad, that we can tap into the knowledge created elsewhere and keep close contacts with researchers across the globe.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Cooperation in science is beneficial for both the European Union and India. The participation of Indian universities and companies in European framework programmes has been increasing since the conclusion of the cooperation agreement in 2001, which is a step in the right direction.  Today, the Horizon 2020 programme offers more funding opportunities for research or technology design programmes developed by European and Indian partners, which is a vehicle for growth and competitiveness for our companies, and is a development aid for India. That is why we call for the renewal of the science and technology cooperation agreement between the European Union and India for an additional five years.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In agreement with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the renewal of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with the Government of the Republic of India in 2001. I think it is important to ensure continuity, such as an extension of 5 years.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. The Indian power favours a counterweight to the power ceded to the United States of America by the Commission. Indeed, in its desire for increasing Americanism, the Union omits that other partners are possible. My vote reminds us that India is not meant to be excluded from the international political scene but must be one of France's preferred partners.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This technical measure is to renew the EU’s scientific and technological cooperation agreement with India for a further five years having previously been renewed in 2009.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision renewing the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, because the results of the already existing cooperation show good results for all participating countries. That's why I supported the renewal of the agreement with India. By February 2014, 258 EU research programmes had been signed. One of the great and important partnerships is that between the Indian Republic and the Euroatom agency. Other areas of partnership are computer technology, solar energy, water resource challenges, and agriculture. The total budget provided by the EU and India is EUR 60 million. With the EP's support for the renewal of the agreement with India, we continue to develop scientific and technological cooperation, which is of utmost importance in the 21st century. The exchange of experience is a path to further progress.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the draft resolution as this cooperation agreement looks forward to the exploitation of the Contracting Party, in this case the Republic of India.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the renewal of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with the Government of the Republic of India in 2001. I think it is important to ensure continuity, such as an extension of 5 years.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between India and the European Community expired on 17 May 2015 and with this vote it was decided whether to renew it. The spectrum of activities of this agreement is to be traced within the framework of the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme and, although the renewal does not make any changes to the status quo, if not formal, nor does it require a transfer of funds, I have decided not to give it my favourable opinion; In fact, India has not yet signed the NTP, the non-nuclear non-proliferation treaty, and appears to have between 80 and 100 nuclear warheads. For the 5-Star Movement, this is a fundamental difference.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I am opposed to the agreements concluded directly by the European Union, I believe that a high strategic level relationship with a country like India is necessary, notably for France.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes the renewal of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. It aims to approve the continuation and financing of the Agreement, which was initially established for a period of five years, which can be renewed by agreement between the parties and after evaluation during the year prior to its termination. As a Cooperation Agreement, it aims at the development on both sides of research capacity and technological development in various fields, including other activities that can promote the dissemination and/or exploitation of project results and coordination activities. We voted in favour. It is positive and desirable that cooperation links can be established and deepened in these areas, with a view to a joint approach to important social and environmental challenges, with a view to pursuing the public interest. This may result in unquestionable mutual benefits. This does not, however, preclude particular attention to the need for a fair and equitable distribution of the results of this cooperation and its benefits, from the outset between the different Member States – combating trends towards a marked divergence, also in this area – and between them and India.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the interest generated by scientific-technological cooperation with India. At this new stage, the Commission's interest is focused on the areas of water, health and energy. In addition, all Member States have unanimously supported the renewal of the Agreement, which I think is a positive thing.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Council proposal on the renewal of the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Government of the Republic of India, as well as taking into account the Council Decision of 25 June 2002 concerning the conclusion of this Agreement, I agree to renew it.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I confirm my support for the renewal of this scientific and technological cooperation agreement with India, an essential global partner in this field.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, as this cooperation agreement looks forward to the exploitation of the Contracting Party, in this case the Republic of India.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the request for consent submitted by the Council, I voted in favour of the European Parliament consent to renewal of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with India.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the renewal of the agreement. As Vice-President for the South-East Asian Region, I think it is important to point out that South Asia is facing the biggest development challenges of the new century. Poverty, overpopulation, civil wars and environmental problems place a heavy burden on the countries of the region. I welcome the European Union's close commitment to peace and stability in South Asia. It persistently encourages the Indian-Pakistani dialogue, condemns all forms of terrorism and violence and expresses its readiness to support the peace process. Furthermore, I support the development of an approach that examines how the EU could contribute to peace, security and prosperity and support regional integration. strengthening civil society cooperation between the EU and India is the long-term objective.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of extending the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with India, because I am genuinely concerned about the exchange of research and education issues with other regions of the world.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the Buzek report given the a renewal of our agreement on scientific and technological cooperation is an important instrument that adds to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the European Community and the Republic of India.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and India, based on Mr Buzek's recommendation, because cooperation in this area with a country with so much potential seems to me to be essential. This Resolution deals with the renewal of a first Agreement, signed in 2001 and extended in 2009, which has enabled India to become one of the EU's most important partners in the framework programmes for research and technological development. We have seen many cases of mutually beneficial cooperation projects in fields such as food, energy or water resources. Given the speed with which the Indian economy is developing, the beneficial effects of this Agreement, which allows the EU and India to strengthen and increase vital cooperation for our economic growth, seem evident.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of India's inclusion in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement which is a renewal of a previous Agreement and adds to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the European Community and the Republic of India.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the renewal of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with the Government of the Republic of India in 2001. I think it is important to ensure continuity, such as an extension of 5 years.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this sends a strong signal that we need to develop and encourage further cooperation between the EU and India in terms of scientific and technological issues. India is one of the fastest growing countries in the world and the EU needs to keep pace with significant technological and scientific developments in India.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. As someone who has lived in India for many years and is very attached to him, I have watched the country for decades. I have often said that the next decade will be the Indian decade. I often had to correct myself. For the first time, my repeated prognosis seems to be confirmed. With Modi, the country is carrying out bold reforms and liberalizing the economy. That is why I voted in favour of extending the agreement.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ India is Scotland’s second biggest international market for further and higher education students and the Scottish government’s India Plan specifically encourages cooperation in science and technology.  The renewal of this agreement is important for both Scotland and the wider EU and I was happy to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of India's inclusion in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this draft Resolution which aims to renew the important agreement between the European Union and India, which is beneficial for scientific and technological cooperation between the two.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to extend the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India because of the importance that science and technology have in today's globalised world.  It is absolutely necessary to improve the current capabilities, skills and resources that the European Union has in this sector to ensure global competitiveness and sustainability. In this context, it is crucial to establish cooperation with other countries and world powers in order to exchange good practices and experiences.  I believe that the extension of the Agreement allows for the maintenance of continuity in relations in the field of science and technology with the Republic of India, and the continuation of the cooperation initiated in mutual interest. Moreover, the extension of the Agreement does not change the substantive content of the Agreement currently in force and which I support.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jerzy Buzek's report on scientific and technological cooperation with India. This report validates the renewal of this essential partnership agreement for India and the Union. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I support the renewal of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement with India. It cannot be a disadvantage for Europe to join forces with an emerging economic power in research efforts.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Agreement for scientific cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India has been initially signed in November 2001 for a period of five years. The possibility of renewals by mutual agreement has been foreseen, with the latest renewal ending on the 17 May 2015.  I have voted in favour of the report giving my consent to the renewal of the Agreement for a third term so as to ensure the smooth continuation of the aforementioned cooperation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Buzek's proposal. Parliament given its assent to the draft Council Decision renewing the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council's draft decision on the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with the Republic of India. As a sovereignist party, the National Front denies the European Union the right to conclude treaties instead of France. However, India's strategic and geostrategic importance will make it an indispensable partner for France. This deserves a favourable vote, a positive sign sent to the government of this state.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it renews the scientific and technical partnership with India. India has a geostrategic importance that justifies working with it, in order to counterbalance the influence of the United States. I would like to say, however, that I would prefer that this type of partnership be concluded by France and the other Member States rather than by the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. It is a report that renews the scientific and technical partnership with India. As this country has a particularly important geostrategic role, it seems necessary to support this kind of partnership. Although I and my colleagues are still critical of the fact that the European Union can sign agreements that commit Member States. But in this case, It is in France's best interest to develop close ties with India, hence my positive vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific Cooperation signed between the EU and India in 2002. The Agreement has had a positive impact on the scientific development of both sides and its renewal can serve to enhance economic, social and cultural relations between the two blocs.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the second renewal, for a period of five years, of the Agreement concluded with the Republic of India for the first time in 2001. We have seen in the past that our Agreement with India, based on equitable benefit-sharing and the absence of discriminatory practices in the field of research, has resulted in more market access opportunities. Encouraging increased scientific knowledge while ensuring effective protection of intellectual property and reciprocal access to programmes and activities on the other side generates added value for the EU. Having reassessed the project after successful years of operation, I consider it essential that the Agreement is not interrupted so that both the European Union and India continue to enjoy its fruits.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU-India Cooperation Agreement, which prioritised strategic partnership under the so-called 'Joint Action Plan', opened the door to a broad political dialogue. The data showing that bilateral trade has doubled in the last five years, while investments have increased tenfold in the same period of time, is of utmost importance, so I supported this Report on the Extension of the Agreement.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the draft Resolution. In number of people, India doubles the EU: more than one billion people. Cooperation with India opens up new perspectives on technology and science; India is the EU's most important partner and the horizons of such collaboration are widened every year.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision renewing the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, because this recommendation is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this renewal of agreement. While we do not appreciate the Union, as an entity, negotiating this kind of agreement with a third country, we do recognise the geostrategic importance of relations with India. We encourage France to move closer, individually, to India, but until then we support this agreement.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the proposal of the EPP rapporteur, I gave my favourable opinion on the proposal for a decision on the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. We need agreements of this kind for the development of competitive technologies that can improve access to technological goods and increase research and then lower prices while guaranteeing the same quality as the product. Of course, we hope that the renewal of the agreement will bring capital to the EU for the growth of technological research in Europe.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this proposal with my vote, as I think it is a good idea to exchange views with one of the world's most emerging economic powers on joint research efforts and to find common solutions here.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's recommendation on the renewal of the Agreement for Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. This agreement will enable EU and Indian researchers to carry out various R&D programmes in areas of common interest, exchange of experience and develop progress.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India was signed in New Delhi on 23 November 2001 for a period of 5 years.  This agreement was extended in 2009. The areas of cooperation concern the research and technological development sectors. The report proposes to extend this agreement again. I am voting for continued cooperation.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Of course, we supported this proposal for a scientific cooperation agreement with India. The world's first democracy, its people-minded president intends to reasonably accompany a major transformation of society mainly oriented towards agriculture in order to steer it towards a reasoned and reasonable industrialization. An agreement as planned today with reciprocal possibilities of access to the programme of installation projects, exchange of information and the proper protection of individual property suits us perfectly.  At the end of the day, the exchange of research into mutual economic developments will be a guarantee of lasting peace.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the renewal of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this recommendation that concerns the renewal of the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. This cooperation agreement is mutually beneficial to the Union’s Member States and India as all parties continue to build Indo-European research initiatives that focus on tackling larger scale and common societal challenges.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union and the Republic of India have a long and fruitful common history. Thus, relations have been maintained for nearly 50 years and many agreements have been signed in areas such as peace, sustainable development and cultural exchange. Since 2005, a scientific and technological cooperation agreement has also linked the two sides to establish enhanced cooperation in technological research and development activities. These privileged relationships involve information exchanges, joint research and development programmes, and visits and exchanges of researchers. As a central player on the international stage, the European Union must extend and strengthen its links with its privileged partners and that is why I support this proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, as in my opinion extending the period for an additional five years will be in mutual interest of all parties.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation concluded in 2002 between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India is in need of renewal under the original Treaty. I agree with the Convention and have therefore supported its renewal in the committee on Industry, Trade and Research.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse this Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the renewal of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. The Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India was signed in New Delhi on 23 November 2001 and entered into force on 14 October 2002. The agreement was valid for five years and may be renewed by common agreement between the parties after the evaluation to be carried out during the last year of each successive period. In November 2006, at the meeting of the EC-India Steering Committee for S&T cooperation, both sides expressed their interest in renewing the agreement.  I am voting in favour, because I am advocating a rapid renewal of the agreement for a period of five years, for meeting the interests of the parties and for maintaining a continuity in the scientific and technological relations between India and the European Community.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on "scientific and technological cooperation with India" aims to renew the agreement on India's scientific and technical partnership.  Although fiercely hostile to the exclusive competence of the European Union in this matter and denying any possibility for it to conclude treaties in the place of France and the Member States, it turns out that India occupies an extremely important geostrategic position for the future, especially for the necessary rebalancing that must take place against the United States. It is clear that India (as well as the other BRICS countries) must be an indispensable partner for a strong and independent France. These reasons are sufficient to motivate a vote in favour of this text, intended to send a positive signal to the authorities of India.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement which is a renewal of a previous Agreement and adds to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the European Community and the Republic of India.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on scientific and technological cooperation with India. The aim was to renew the agreement between the European Union and India for a period of five years, which expired on 17 May. The agreement covers all Horizon 2020 research and development activities as well as EU participation in Indian projects. The costs of this cooperation will not result in additional remittances.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. It is important to sustain and strengthen our partnerships with third countries, particularly in sectors that call for innovation and creation. This agreement already signed required the approval of the European Parliament to be effective, and it was important to vote for it in order to encourage cooperation between our industries and research centres as well as between the citizens of the European Union and those of the Indian Republic.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this draft legislative resolution, which represents a step forward in the creation of a relationship of mutual trust and fruitful cooperation between the European Union and the Federal Republic of India.  The renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement, while not significantly extending the fields of cooperation between the EU and India, must be supported as it stabilises and strengthens the relations established so far and leaves room for deepening the bilateral relationship. We hope that this renewal will support the announced relaunch of trade negotiations between the EU and India, and we therefore join the rapporteur in calling on the President of the European Parliament to convey this Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of India.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the agreement on the renewal of scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. India is an emerging regional power with enormous potential in research and development. I expect great benefits from working together. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which validates the five-year renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and India. This agreement, which covers all research, technological development and demonstration activities, is a valuable tool for the much-needed cooperation between India and the European Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The extension of the agreement is important, but I abstained from the vote because I consider it important that India resolve the issue of Estonian and British ship defenders and allow them to come home. It is important to raise the issue of Estonian ship defenders also in meetings with India. The subject must be on the table at all EU-India meetings.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Science and technological advances are of great importance for both the EU and the rest of the world. Each country can contribute to the development of technology with its knowledge, money opportunities or otherwise. India has very cautiously allowed foreign investors to penetrate through the privatisation of leading state-owned companies, banks and insurers. Since the agreement signed in New Delhi in 2001 to the present day, cooperation between the European Union and India has been very successful. In recent years, India has been increasingly contributing technologically to the European Union market.  In my view, the renewal of the treaty for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and India is of great importance. I believe that the next 5 years on which the treaty is planned will be useful both for the European Union and for India. The contract is of mutual interest and I welcome the decision to extend it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I do not recognise the European Union's ability to negotiate and sign a cooperation agreement with a third state. Nevertheless, cooperation with India will be one of the major challenges of the coming decades, due to the importance of India and its development. Wanting to show my interest in this power and my desire to develop France's ties with it in order to balance the weight of our various strategic partners, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the rapporteur's recommendation on the draft Council decision extending the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India to which the European Parliament has given its consent taking into account the draft Council decision on the extension of the Scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India (05872/2015) and Council Decision 2002/648/EC of 25 June 2002. conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I support the Council's decision to extend the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, which aims to enable both parties to continue their cooperation in the fields of science and technology of common interest. Guided by these multiannual objectives, the Commission proposes to extend the Agreement, which will further strengthen relations in the field of science and technology between India and the European Union. It is evident from all of the above that continuing this cooperation would increase scientific achievements and allow greater access to the Indian market.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the proposal to renew the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with India, I have decided, together with other party colleagues, to abstain from voting. This choice was dictated by the firm desire to emphasize that to date a satisfactory solution has not yet been found to the story that has as protagonists the two Italian soldiers, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone. With this abstention, we wanted to reiterate that, before continuing along the path of bilateral cooperation, the whole Union should send a strong and clear message to the Indian Government that a solution can be found quickly.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Faced with the rapid growth of emerging countries, such as India, the EU has decided to conclude cooperation agreements with these strategic countries covering various areas. With this in mind, the EU concluded a scientific and technological cooperation agreement with India in 2002. The European Parliament voted in favour of renewing the agreement. I voted in favour of this text and I would like to stress the importance of these agreements in supporting dialogue and exchanges between the Union and third countries.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively for this Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the renewal of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. It is now, more than ever, in the interests of both sides not only to continue good relations in the scientific and technological fields, but also to intensify this cooperation. In this sense, I support the renewal for another 5 years of the agreement with the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. By adopting Jerzy Buzek's report this afternoon, MEPs gave a favourable opinion on the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. It has been a few years since a privileged strategic partnership between the European Union and India, a continent-country with a population of nearly one billion three hundred million people. Already during the sixth research programme, closer cooperation had emerged in key sectors relating to the information society, transport, energy, biotechnology, Galileo system and space. The adoption of the new research and innovation programme, Horizon 2020, is an opportunity for Europe to strengthen this strategic partnership with the country which will be in 2015, barring an accident, with 8% growth, the most dynamic economy in the world.  European know-how in the space field, for example, will be perfectly able to marry with the Indian excellence that was achieved in 2014 by the launch into orbit around the planet Mars of its scientific spacecraft called Mangalyan. India thus became, after the USA, the second nation to achieve such a feat.  Cooperation with India may allow Europe to see the stars.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a simple renewal of the agreement (another 5 years) with the Government of the Republic of India, and it is in the interest of both parties the continuity of good relations in the scientific and technological fields.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India was signed in New Deli on 23 November 2001 for an initial period of five years extended by the parties provided that in the last year of validity they agreed on its extension. After the last extension, both sides have proposed their renewal for a new five-year period in order to continue scientific and technological relations between India and Europe, so I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has given its approval to the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and India. The President of Parliament is now responsible for conveying Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of India.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
