text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation on the draft Council decision on the renewal of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India, signed in New Delhi in November 2001. This Agreement stipulates that it may be renewed by mutual agreement between the parties every 5 years after an evaluation carried out during the last year of each successive period. By its Decision 2009/501/EC of 19 January 2009, the Council approved the renewal of the agreement for a further period of five years until 17 May 2015. The renewal of the agreement for another five years is objectively in the interest of the scientific and technological communities of both parties, due to the possibility of sharing experiences and projects that it allows. It should be noted that the assumptions and content of the agreement remain unchanged, with the exception of tenuous changes in terminology, due to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presented by Mr De Clercq on behalf of the Committee on The Buzek is concerned with the draft Council Decision renewing the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. The agreement, signed in 2002, has enabled Indian and European researchers to participate in mutual research programmes, achieving significant goals, such as the implementation of joint research projects under the 'Development Cooperation' programme, which are part of the EU's research framework programmes. In the fourth and fifth framework programmes alone, the Commission financed 53 projects. For its part, India allocates 2.5 billion euros, 0.72% of its GDP, annually to research and technological development, sectors that are managed by the government-funded Scientific and Industrial Research Council, to the point where it can be considered the largest publicly funded industrial research and development agency in the world. In the field of research, India is an important partner for the European Union, which is why I voted in favour of renewing the cooperation agreement.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as I recognise the importance of scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of India's inclusion in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific Cooperation signed between the EU and India in 2002. The Agreement has had a positive impact on the scientific development of both sides and its renewal can serve to enhance economic, social and cultural relations between the two blocs.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a scientist, I have been involved in scientific and technological cooperation with India and I am very supportive of this agreement of scientific and technological cooperation. However, I have to share two concerns. On the one hand, I don't think the monitoring metric is the most efficient. We can have numerous joint projects and not produce a line of science or technological products. These, yes, are the results that are intended at the end of this cooperation. Therefore, I suggest that tracking metrics include in the future the number of publications and the number of patents generated. On the other hand, I believe that direct investment values are very low, not reaching EUR 200,000 per year. The European Union must make a greater effort and be more ambitious in this cooperation with India, which is a very advanced country from a scientific and technological point of view.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement which is a renewal of a previous agreement and adds to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the European Community and the Republic of India.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important for the EU to develop cooperation in science and technology with its partners in the world. EU-India cooperation in this area has improved in recent years, resulting in India's participation in Horizon 2020 (2014-2015). I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which gives its consent to the renewal of this agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU and India.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Recommendation on the Council's draft decision to extend the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India on the basis that on 25 June 2002 a Council Decision on the conclusion of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India was adopted as recommended by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support the report on the draft Council decision on the extension of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. This cooperation is extremely important and I support giving consent for the renewal of the agreement.  Cooperation under this Agreement covers all research and development activities with an appropriate level of protection of intellectual property rights. We must encourage and facilitate the cooperation of research and development activities in the field of science and technology, and in particular in areas of common interest between the European Community and India. Research and development and joint cooperation with other countries in the field of science and technology are fundamental preconditions for economic growth and development. R&D is among the main objectives of the 'Europe 2020' strategy, where 3% of the EU's GDP should be invested in R&D.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I agree that scientific and technical cooperation between India and the EU can continue unhindered.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical measure which renews the EU’s scientific and technological cooperation agreement with India for a further five years, having previously been renewed in 2009.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This cooperation agreement looks forward to the exploitation of the Contracting Party, in this case the Republic of India.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the renewal of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the renewal of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with India. The first agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU and India was signed in 2001; this year the EU decided to renew the agreement until 2020. It is very important to spread the knowledge and scientific cooperation within Europe as well as in other countries. Scientific cooperation with India is a very important step in this respect and serves as an example of long-lasting cooperation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Given the successful cooperation in the field of science and technology between India and the European Union since 2001, I voted to renew this Agreement because I believe it is in the interests of both sides to maintain continuity in relations in these areas.  I support the proposal to enable both sides to improve and strengthen cooperation, as well as to encourage further exchange of specific knowledge and knowledge transfer and experience for the benefit of scientific communities, industry and citizens. Appropriate examples of the benefits of this Agreement are certainly joint proposals from the European Union and India under the 7th Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development carried out in the fields of computer materials, food research, solar energy and the like; total value of €60 million co-financed by India and the European Union. It is for these reasons that I supported the Agreement, which recognised India as a partner for cooperation in horizon 2020 in areas such as water, nanotechnology and agriculture.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament has adopted an extension of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation with India aimed at promoting research and development activities in science and technology in areas of common interest between the European Community and India. In view of the positive impact of the agreement on the scientific and technological development of the Union, I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of India's inclusion in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement renewing the scientific and technical partnership with India. While denying the European Union the right to conclude treaties in place of France, India's geostrategic importance in the concert of the equilibrium powers in the United States will make it an indispensable partner for a strong and independent France. The Front National delegation wishes to send a positive sign to this state.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of India's inclusion in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the Council to renew the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation with India. This agreement has been in force since 2001, and it is important that it is renewed for the next five years considering that the EU and India are pursuing common research and technological objectives in a number of areas of common interest, and mutual benefits may be therefore derived if the Parties continue to engage in a cooperative manner.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the renewal for another five years of an Agreement which was signed in November 2001 and which is of great interest to Europe. Further cooperation with India in the scientific field is needed, especially on issues of interest such as water, health and energy, and I therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific Cooperation signed between the EU and India in 2002. The Agreement has had a positive impact on the scientific development of both sides and its renewal can serve to enhance economic, social and cultural relations between the two blocs.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document deals with the renewal of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. It belongs to the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). The document was not shadowed by the GUE/NGL. The report was assigned to the Chairman of the ITRE Committee in accordance with Article 50(1) - simplified procedure without amendments. This is a report to approve the continuation and financing of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement established between the European Community and India in November 2001. The agreement established a period of five years, which can be renewed by agreement between the parties and after evaluation during the year prior to its termination.  This Cooperation Agreement aims at the development on both sides of RTD (Research and Technological Development), including other activities that promote the dissemination and/or exploitation of project results and coordination activities. Support.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this proposal with my vote, as I think it is a good idea to exchange views with one of the world's most emerging economic powers on joint research efforts and to find common solutions here.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in agreement with my group on Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the extension of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. The framework conditions for cooperation in research and innovation between the EU and India are relatively satisfactory, resulting in a stable and reliable climate for cooperation. The overall success of EU-India cooperation is to be ensured. Following the successful cooperation so far, India is also seen as a partner for cooperation on the first Horizon 2020 work programme (2014-2015). Thethematic is cooperation with Indian researchers in areas such as water, nanotechnology and agriculture, which are supported.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the renewal of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Community and the Government of the Republic of India. The report advocates the continuation and financing of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation established between the European Community and India in November 2001. The agreement established a period of five years, which can be renewed by agreement between the parties and after evaluation during the year prior to its termination. This Cooperation Agreement aims at the development on both sides of RTD (Research and Technological Development), including other activities that promote the dissemination and/or exploitation of project results and coordination activities. We voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the conclusion of an Agreement on scientific cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. The Agreement can have a positive impact on the scientific development of both parties and therefore improve relations between them.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Faroe Islands are an autonomous part of Denmark, but not part of the EU. In the past, the EU has already signed other agreements (fisheries agreements and free trade agreements) with the Faroe Islands. This association will allow the Faroe Islands to participate in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation. Through this association, the EU and the Faroe Islands can support their competitiveness and also promote their scientific skills. That is why I voted in favour of this decision

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a scientific and technical partnership with the Faroe Islands. This cooperation is part of the Horizon 2020 programme, which I and my colleagues on the National Front oppose. Only Member States can conclude international agreements and it is not for the European Union to decide national diplomatic interests. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure because of the impact upon the EU Budget, and therefore on taxpayers’ money.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding an agreement on scientific and technological cooperation to make the Faroe Islands an associated country of horizon 2020 (2020) framework programme for research and innovation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In addition to the uniqueness of the Faroe Islands, Denmark's autonomous territories, having a very special legal status, it is difficult to see the value of this scientific and technological cooperation demanded by Mr Buzek. It is not for the European Union to conclude these kinds of treaties anyway, so I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which includes the latter in the framework programme for research and innovation "Horizon 2020" (2014-2020).

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This Buzek report on "scientific and technological cooperation with the Faroe Islands: Horizon 2020" calls for the consent of members of the European Parliament to the agreement of scientific and technical partnership with the Faroe Islands.  Although I am opposed to the Exclusive Competence of the Union in Partnership, since I believe that foreign policy must be the responsibility of the Member States, I voted in favour of this report since the Faroe Islands, Denmark's autonomous territory, are in a particular situation and do not fall under a major geostrategic and political situation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this text because I believe that scientific cooperation agreements with third countries are necessary to support the progress of our companies and their inclusion in non-EU markets.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, whereo by which they are associated with Horizon 2020, Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020).

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with the Faroe Islands.  The Faroes, as an associated country, participate in Horizon 2020, established in 2013, under the conditions set out in this Agreement. From the date of application of this Agreement, the Faroes shall make a financial contribution to the annual budget of the European Union for each year of implementation of Horizon 2020. The Financial Contribution from the Faroes shall be added to the amount allocated each year in the EU annual budget to the commitment appropriations necessary for the implementation of the financial commitments relating to Horizon 2020, to manage and act on the various forms of instruments necessary. Faroese representatives shall participate as observers in the committees set up under Horizon 2020. These committees shall meet without faroese representatives during the vote. The Faroes are informed of the results.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the Association of faroe Islands belonging to the Kingdom of Denmark for horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme. In addition to joining the programme, mutual visits by researchers and engineers and joint symposia were agreed. I trust that both sides will be able to draw as much from cooperation as possible.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Projects emerging within Horizon 2000 are also joined by the Faroe Islands. I support the recommendation in the hope of further cooperation with this island state.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe it is essential for the progress of the Union to invest heavily in scientific and technological cooperation, with as many partners as possible. I am also convinced that the inclusion of the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 programme is a good signal to a people and a nation belonging to the European cultural family.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In March 2014, the European Council concluded the agreement, which resulted from negotiations between the Commission and the Faroe Islands, on scientific and technological cooperation under the Horizon 2020 programme. This agreement provides that, in return for a financial contribution, the legal entities of the Faroe Islands may participate in the indirect actions and activities of the European Commission's Joint Research Centre under the same conditions as those applicable to the legal entities of the Member States of the European Union. We have always opposed the EU replacing Member States in negotiating treaties or agreements with third countries. Moreover, the Faroe Islands are in a particular legal situation and are not of particular importance to French diplomacy. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Horizon 2020 is a financial instrument that implements the initiatives contained in the Innovation Union, being the most important cooperation and innovation programme financed by Community funds and private investment. With the aim of promoting research and innovation, Horizon 2020 aims to strengthen scientific and technological cooperation with third countries, to develop the exchange of knowledge and technology and to ensure the freedom of movement of researchers. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the EU's research and innovation agenda must address the issue of international cooperation as a priority, because innovation needs are common and research knows no borders.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Association of the Faroe Islands in Horizon 2020. The traditional vote in favour of scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries by the Lega Nord is confirmed.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The fields of scientific and technological research are essential for the economic and social development of states. As such, the European Union has set up the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme. It focuses funding on three priorities: scientific excellence, industrial primacy and societal challenges. As research and innovation are global issues, it is necessary to forge scientific cooperation agreements for our future. The European Union has signed an agreement with the Faroe Islands to include them in the Horizon 2020 programme. This cooperation will enable mutual benefits to support our development. I voted in favour of this cooperation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU and the Faroe Islands. In my opinion, it is very productive that legal entities established in the Faroe Islands should also be eligible for the financial instruments established under Horizon 2020 under the same conditions as legal entities established in the Member States of the Union. In fact, Faroese researchers have already participated in projects funded by the Union and the importance of the synergy that comes with it is appreciated, first and foremost for the strengthening of innovation in the context of the creation of the European Research Area. The small territorial dimension must be seen as a favour and not a limit to scientific research in those lands.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure because of the impact upon the EU Budget, and therefore on taxpayers’ money.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have followed the recommendation of the European Parliament Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and gave my consent to the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands associating the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020), following the request for consent by the European Parliament that was submitted by the Council in accordance with Article 186 and Article 218(6), second subparagraph, point (a)(v), of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I preferred to abstain because, despite the talk of a research programme, the text presents two issues that could not have my support, namely the periodic hunting (Grindadráp) of globicephala melas cetaceans, disapproved of by the International Whaling Commission (IWC), and the commercial exploitation of overfishing practices.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which aims to engage in scientific and technological cooperation with the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. Not only do I refute the European Union's ability to conclude such agreements in place of France, but it is of little strategic interest to our country. The Faroe Islands are in fact only an autonomous territory of Denmark, which is also in a particular legal situation. In this sense, I find this draft agreement unrealistic, which contains modalities on the conditions for the Faroe Islands to participate in indirect actions and the activities of the Commission's Joint Research Centre under the same conditions as those applicable to the legal entities of the Member States of the European Union. Furthermore, I am opposed to the Horizon 2020 programme, which is part of a multi-year framework, to the detriment of the reality of the Union's economic and budgetary situation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the draft agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, linking the Faroe Islands to the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands. This measure associates the Faroe Islands with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme (2014-2020) in the field of research and innovation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands because I believe it is important that they should be able to participate in the framework programme for research and innovation, given that Faroese researchers have already successfully participated in other projects financed by the Union and their territorial proximity to the Union in the past. With the conclusion of this international agreement, which has retroactive effect from 1 January 2014, on the basis of Article 7 of the Horizon 2020 Regulation, legal persons from the associated countries will be able to participate under the same conditions as the legal entities of the Member States. It is particularly important to conclude this agreement now that scientific and technological cooperation is to be enhanced and increased with a view to the creation of a European Research Area, all the more so with a contracting party which shares with the Union the desire to promote mutual access for the respective research bodies to scientific and technological research and development activities.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 7 of Horizon 2020, the specific terms and conditions of the participation of the Faroe Islands as countries associated with Horizon 2020 are set in an international agreement. Both sides show an interest in encouraging reciprocal access of their research bodies to the research and development activities of the Faroe Islands and to the Union's framework programmes for research and technological development.  The importance of ongoing scientific and technological cooperation between the Faroe Islands and the Union strengthens the mutual interest in strengthening research and innovation in the context of the establishment of the European Research Area. This Recommendation contributes to facilitating the free movement and residence of researchers participating in the activities, as well as the cross-border movement of goods intended for such activities.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution as it is a mere endorsement at the conclusion of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU and the Faroe Islands.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The conclusion of the Agreement on cooperation in science and technology between the European Union and Faroe Islands associating the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 will allow both parties to improve and intensify their cooperation in science and technology in areas of common interest. The conclusion of this Agreement will allow for increased scientific knowledge leading to market access opportunities and is thus being done in the best interests of the scientific communities, industry and citizens.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Research and Innovation Programme provides for the conditions for the participation of associated countries to be determined by an international agreement between the Union and the associated country.  In view of the importance of scientific and technological cooperation between the Faroe Islands and the Union and the interest in strengthening research and innovation in the context of the establishment of the European Research Area, the agreement will establish the participation of the Islands as an associated country. All its legal entities will participate in the indirect actions and activities of the European Commission's Research Centre and in research activities under the same conditions as legal entities in the EU States. The established legal entities will participate in faroe research programmes.  From the date of application, the Islands will pay a contribution to the Union's annual budget for each year of the programme's validity. The Financial Contribution of the Faroe Islands will be added to the amount allocated annually in the EU budget for commitment appropriations to meet financial obligations arising from different forms of measures for the implementation, management and operation of Horizon 2020. Although we are talking about the research programme, I am abstaining for these reasons: the periodic hunting of globicephalous cetaceans, disapproved of by the International Whaling Commission, and the commercial exploitation of overfishing practices.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the conclusion of an Agreement on scientific cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. The Agreement can have a positive impact on the scientific development of both parties and therefore improve relations between them.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the conclusion of the agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands associating the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 – the framework programme for research and innovation spread between 2014 and 2020 – can be beneficial to both sides.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to involve the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme. The agreement, signed on 17 December 2014, gives the Faroe Islands the status of country associated with the Horizon 2020 programme and the rules for disseminating results. In addition to this agreement, regular discussions have been held on policy guidelines and priorities, research forecasts in the Faroe Islands and the EU, and on the conditions for the Faroe Islands to participate in indirect actions and activities of the Commission's Joint Research Centre under the same conditions as those applicable to legal entities of the Member States of the European Union. Considering that it is necessary to strengthen the links between the Union and the Faroe Islands in this area, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Faroe Islands are an autonomous entity of the Kingdom of Denmark. Having not joined the European Union, however, they cooperate with the European Union, particularly in scientific and technical matters. The conclusion of a new protocol will allow the Faroe Islands to participate in the Horizon 2020 programme. It is the EU's most important research programme, with 80 billion euros available over the period 2014-2020.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – The EU is a world leader when it comes to research and innovation. Horizon 2020 is the flagship programme aimed at securing the EU’s competitiveness. The agreement will give the Faroe Islands full access to the Horizon 2020 programme, on equal footing with Member States. In return, the Faroes will financially contribute to the Horizon 2020 budget. We have to make sure that we keep our region on the cutting edge of research and innovation, and to associate other countries with the Horizon 2020 programme is a way of doing so.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Parliament has approved the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands. This territory will now be associated with the European Union's "Horizon 2020" framework programme for research and innovation.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the association of the Faroe Islands belonging to the Kingdom of Denmark for the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation. In addition to joining the programme, mutual visits by researchers and engineers and joint symposia were agreed. I trust that both sides will be able to draw as much from cooperation as possible.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands linking the Faroe Islands to the "Horizon 2020" framework programme for research and innovation. Since my election, I have made a commitment to preserve the sovereignty of states. I therefore do not want the Union to sign a partnership on behalf of France. It is up to the State alone to assess the relevance of this agreement in order to serve the interests of these citizens. Moreover, the Faroe Islands do not have any particular advantage in encouraging France to engage in close cooperation through the signing of a partnership. There is therefore no need to vote in favour of a report of dubious usefulness and which impinges on what should be the prerogatives of States.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement sets in place rules to enable the Faroe Islands to participate in the EU’s research and innovation programme, Horizon 2020, as an associated country. As part of the agreement provisions will be established to enable joint meetings, visits and exchanges of research workers, engineers and technicians as well as participation of experts in seminars and workshops.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on eu-Faroe Islands cooperation because I support the devoting of funds to scientific and technical programmes in the belief that in the 21st century this is one of the most strategic areas of development and as such is of the utmost importance for the future. It is also of great importance that we partner and exchange experience with specialists from other countries with whom we can develop and work on common projects together. Through the support of the EP, we support the Islands Association to the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.  It is the largest ever EU framework programme in this area, with its 7-year budget worth almost €80 billion. European. The majority of research funding in the EU is provided on the basis of calls for proposals on a competitive basis. By giving access to the Faroe Islands program, we are expanding cooperation and creating the potential for more projects. The strategic location of the islands, on the other hand, is a prerequisite for water research.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation as the EU must give priority to meeting the needs of its Member States' national economies before taking cooperation with third countries.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the Association of faroe Islands belonging to the Kingdom of Denmark for horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme. In addition to joining the programme, mutual visits by researchers and engineers and joint symposia were agreed. I trust that both sides will be able to draw as much from cooperation as possible.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union's 'Horizon 2020' Research and Innovation Programme provides that the modalities and conditions for the participation of the associated countries are governed by an international agreement. Membership of the joint research programme by an associated country shall ensure that all its legal entities may participate in the research activities of Union programmes under the same conditions as the legal entities of the Member States of the Union. From the date of application of the agreement, the Faroe Islands will pay a financial contribution to the Union's annual budget which will be added to the amount allocated each year in the Union's annual budget for commitment appropriations to meet the financial obligations arising from various forms of measures necessary for the implementation, management and operation of Horizon 2020. Although, in principle, there is no question of the possibility of welcoming the Faroe Islands into the countries associated with Horizon 2020, two aspects that I believe are central to the relationship with this nation remain uncovered, namely the annual slaughter of globicecephales and the insular fishing practices. it is to point out the distance of these practices with the conservation policies within the EU that I have decided to abstain from a vote that would otherwise have been positive

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because this agreement, in addition to being concluded directly through the European Union, is concluded with a territory under Danish sovereignty and, therefore, contributes to a fragmentation of national sovereignty.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the conclusion of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands.  In March 2014, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations on behalf of the European Union with the Faroe Islands for an agreement linking the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 (2014-2020). The Faroe Islands shall participate as an associated country, under the terms and conditions laid down by Horizon 2020 and Council Decision 2013/743/EU. The cooperation agreement will include regular discussions on the prospects for cooperation and development, regular information on the implementation of research programmes and projects, meetings and visits with exchanges of views between researchers and technicians, participation of experts in seminars, symposia and workshops. An EU-Faroe Committee for Research and Innovation should be formed, consisting of representatives of both parties. We voted in favour. However, it should be noted that, with no objections in principle to the extension of the Framework Programme to other countries, we continue to denounce the very unequal allocation of resources of this Programme – of which, in the light of it, Portugal was a net contributor in the period 2007-2013. We continue to demand measures to change this situation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the draft Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, on the basis of which the Faroe Islands have been associated with Horizon 2020, and in the context of the Council's request, as well as the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I agree with the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I confirm my support for this agreement, for scientific and technological cooperation, with the Faroe Islands.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU must give priority to meeting the needs of the national economies of its Member States before taking cooperation with third countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the request for consent submitted by the Council, I voted in favour of the European Parliament consent on the conclusion of the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands associating the Faroe Islands with Horizon 2020.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision, given the effective participation of Faroe Islands researchers in EU-funded projects and the importance of ongoing scientific and technological cooperation between the Faroe Islands and the Union, I consider cooperation to be of the utmost importance. In my opinion, both parties have a mutual interest in strengthening research and innovation in the context of the development of the European Research Area. In my view, it is in our common interest to encourage mutual access by their research legal parties to the research and development activities of the Faroe Islands, on the one hand, and to the Union's framework programmes for research and technological development on the other. In view of the particular situation of the Faroe Islands, their small territorial area and population, and the fact that they are close neighbours of the Union in northern Europe, I saw the association with the Framework Programme as the most appropriate direction, in line with the objective of today's capture.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Buzek Report as I believe it will add to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the EU and the Faroe Islands. I welcome that this agreement allows for closer cooperation with the Faroes in the area of research and innovation and provides the Faroes with the possibility of benefiting from and contributing to the development of research and innovation in Europe.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of the inclusion of the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement as it will greatly add to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the EU and the Faroe Islands. This Agreement allows for closer cooperation with the Faroes in the area of research and innovation and provides the Faroes with the possibility of benefiting from and contributing to the development of research and innovation in Europe.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the Association of faroe Islands belonging to the Kingdom of Denmark for horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme. In addition to joining the programme, mutual visits by researchers and engineers and joint symposia were agreed. I trust that both sides will be able to draw as much from cooperation as possible.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and welcome the Faroe Islands’ continued cooperation with the EU in the field of research and development.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of the inclusion of the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faeroe Islands, which join Horizon 2020, as this strengthens research and innovation in the context of the European Research Area and improves the free movement and stay of research staff in the activities subject to this Agreement.  Scientific and technological progress is of utmost importance for the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale and further participation of entities across the Union in research projects and programmes should therefore be encouraged. I believe that this Agreement will achieve mutual benefits that are in the common interest and will improve the Union's capacities and capabilities in the sector.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a scientific and technical partnership with the Faroe Islands. This cooperation falls within the framework of the Horizon 2020 programme, which we are opposed to. Only France can conclude international agreements and it is not for the European Union to decide French diplomatic interests. I have therefore decided to vote against this report on scientific and technological cooperation with the Faroe Islands.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jerzy Buzek's report on scientific and technological cooperation with the Faroe Islands. This report validates the agreement that has been reached between the EU and the Faroe Islands on scientific cooperation under the Horizon 2020 programme. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which combines the Faroe Islands with the Horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. There is no objection to the continuation of the research agreement with the Faroe Islands. I am voting in favour of this continuation.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Since this a procedural report that aims to establish the Scientific and Technical Cooperation of the EU with the Faroe Islands and define the elements of the cooperation I have voted in favour, in order to facilitate the conclusion of the agreement and the participation of Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 as an associated country.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of Mr Buzek's proposal for a recommendation. This proposal decides to give a favourable opinion on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Scientific Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which associates them with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which includes the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation. As a sovereignist party, the National Front denies the European Union the right to conclude treaties in place of France and other Member States. The Faroe Islands, Denmark's autonomous territory, are in a special situation. In addition, we are opposed to the Horizon 2020 programme.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it concerns the conclusion of a scientific and technical partnership agreement with the Faroe Islands. However, I believe that the conclusion of such agreements should be the responsibility of the Member States and not of the European Union. On the other hand, I am particularly against this agreement, because the Faroe Islands are not a sovereign state, but an autonomous Danish territory that has no diplomatic importance to French interests.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the conclusion of an Agreement on scientific cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. The Agreement can have a positive impact on the scientific development of both parties and therefore improve relations between them.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Scientific and technological cooperation between the Union and the Faeroe Islands within Horizon 2020 is of utmost importance and represents a mutual interest in strengthening research and innovation within the European Research Area. The Faroe Islands, as Europe's neighbours in the north, meet all the requirements for participation in Horizon, so I supported the Report of my colleague Buzek.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Support Resolution. Although the Faroe Islands are a relatively small EU partner, in my view, the EU must reach every corner of the world to make our planet better.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands linking the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 - framework programme for research and innovation, because this recommendation is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this cooperation. Since the Faroe Islands do not represent a major geostrategic interest for France and this cooperation is done within the framework of the Horizon 2020 strategy, which we reject, we cannot support this cooperation. Other partners seem to deserve our interest and support more.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Industry, Research and Energy has approved the agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, thus associating the Danish islands with the Horizon 2020 programme, the Union's framework programme for research and innovation, which makes considerable funds available, thus being among the 12 countries associated with the research and innovation programme. The European Union assesses research and innovation as fundamental to its competitiveness, as well as tools for dealing with the recent economic crisis in Europe, so under this agreement legal persons from the associated country – the Faroe Islands – can participate in this research programme, under the same conditions as legal entities in the EU Member States. For these reasons, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this document, the European Parliament gives its favourable opinion on the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which associates the Faroe Islands with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation. In the knowledge that such an agreement will benefit research and development, I have decided to support mr Buzek's report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this proposal because it is merely a continuation of an existing research agreement with the Faroe Islands and there is no objection to it.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to support the Agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands on scientific and technological cooperation.  On the basis of this agreement, the Faroes will be able to participate as an associated country in horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation. It is hoped that the programme will promote mutual cooperation between research institutions, participation in development programmes in this field, and exchange of researchers, engineers and technicians. The conditions for cooperation provided for in this Agreement will provide greater clarity and specificity for researchers and scientific institutions wishing to participate in Horizon 2020.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The text proposes to establish a scientific and technological cooperation agreement with the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. The main purpose of this program is to put research at the service of the market. Research and scientific cooperation cannot and should not follow a short-term commercial vision. I am voting against the establishment of cooperation in such a framework.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a scientific and technical partnership with the Faroe Islands. This cooperation falls within the framework of the Horizon 2020 programme, which we are opposed to. Only France can conclude international agreements and it is not for the European Union to decide French diplomatic interests. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which links the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 – Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020) (14014/2014).

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report that concerns the scientific and technologic cooperation between the Union and the Faroe Islands under the remit of Horizon 2020. This means that legal entities from the Faroe Islands can participate with research entities from Member States in projects that respond to calls for proposals under Horizon 2020. The Faroe Islands will also contribute financially to Horizon 2020.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Faroe Islands have decided to contribute to the common goals of the entire scientific and technological community. The advantage of such an agreement lies in the great opportunities it offers to research institutes, universities and companies in this country as it covers both basic and applied research. With Horizon 2020, the entire value creation chain of research and innovation is covered. Any agreement on scientific and technological cooperation is an additional step in favour of the knowledge economy in Europe, which aims in particular to improve the well-being of all of us.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the purpose of this proposal, which is to conclude the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands associating the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020).

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims at ratifying the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands and the Association of the Faroe Islands with horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme (2014-2020). As a supporter of international scientific and technological cooperation as widely as possible, I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Horizon 2020 – Community Framework Programme for Research and Innovation is the European Community's largest instrument specifically targeted at research support through co-financing of research, innovation and demonstration projects, and its general objective is to contribute to the creation of a knowledge and innovation-based economy, the creation of new employment opportunities and Europe's sustainable economic growth.  By advocating that Horizon 2020 – PQC is aimed at ensuring industrial leadership in the European Union by 2020 and contributing to the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, strategy focused on smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, I approve this Recommendation on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which links the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 – Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020).

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Buzek report on "scientific and technological cooperation with the Faroe Islands: Horizon 2020" calls for the consent of members of the European Parliament to the agreement of scientific and technical partnership with the Faroe Islands.  I believe, as a matter of principle, that it is up to the Member States, and in particular France, to negotiate and conclude international agreements and not to the European Union. Being rather hostile to the Horizon 2020 programme, and the Faroe Islands, Denmark's autonomous territory which is in a particular legal situation, not under a major geostrategic situation, these elements are not likely to constitute a compelling necessity justifying voting in favour of this text. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement as it will greatly add to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the EU and the Faroe Islands. This Agreement allows for closer cooperation with the Faroes in the area of research and innovation and provides the Faroes with the possibility of benefiting from and contributing to the development of research and innovation in Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text on the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands. The European Union and the Faroe Islands are already practicing important cooperation and have expressed interest in continuing to strengthen joint research and innovation. The vote was to approve the agreement signed on December 17 between the two entities.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this draft legislative resolution, which represents a step forward in the creation of a relationship of mutual trust and fruitful cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands.  The conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement, which associates the Faroe Islands with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, must be supported as it stabilises and strengthens the relations established so far and leaves room for deepening the bilateral relationship. In view of the very low political conflict and the large majority in favour of the measure, we agree with the rapporteur in calling on the President of the European Parliament to convey this Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Faroe Islands.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands associating the Faroe Islands with Horizon 2020 – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report as it is possible to achieve forward-looking research results with comparatively little financial resources.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The purpose of the Agreement is to enable the Faroe Islands to participate in Horizon 2020 under similar conditions with EU Member States.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider cooperation with the Faroe Islands to be important in achieving the Horizon 2020 objectives and, as a member of the ITRE Committee, I can only express my support for the work done.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the desire of the Directorate of the Faeroe Islands, an autonomous island under the Danish crown, to open up to its young people the opportunities for cooperation with the EU offered by Horizon 2020, one of the EU's highly promising programmes. This cooperation includes, inter alia, discussions on cooperation and development, the timely provision of information on the implementation of faroe and EU faroe and eu programmes and research projects, and the results of the work undertaken under this Agreement, visits and exchanges of scientific workers, engineers and technicians. The Agreement includes regular and ongoing contacts between the programme and project managers of the Faeroe Islands and the EU and the participation of experts in seminars, symposiums and workshops.  In order to stimulate the economy and involve young people from predominantly fishing areas in horizon 2020 cooperation, I welcome this Agreement, which will be delivered in improving science and technology cooperation between the Faeroe Islands and the EU.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I do not want to give the European Union the ability to conclude treaties instead of states. These attacks on national sovereignty are not acceptable because it is up to democratic governments to determine their foreign policy and the international agreements signed by their country. I am also opposed to the entire Horizon 2020 programme. Finally, the situation of the Faroe Islands, Denmark's autonomous territory, is quite specific but does not make it an issue of prime interest to France. For all these reasons, I am opposed to this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the recommendation of the draft rapporteur to whom the European Parliament has given its consent taking into account the draft Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faeroe Islands, which joins Horizon 2020. - Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020) (14014/2014) and the Recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (A8-0180/2015).

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ 18 March 2014 The Council authorised the Commission to enter into negotiations with the Faeroe Islands on behalf of the European Union in order to conclude a Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Faeroe Islands, which join Horizon 2020.  To strengthen its position in a global context, the European Union has decided to conclude this agreement within which both sides would benefit mutually and would ultimately contribute to the EU's scientific excellence and competitiveness. In doing so, it should be borne in mind the successful participation of Faroe researchers in Union-funded projects and mutual interest in strengthening research and innovation in the context of the establishment of the European Research Area. It also recognised the specific situation of the Faeroe Islands with regard to its small area and small population, as well as its immediate proximity to the EU as its European neighbour to the north. Taking into account all these arguments, I support the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faeroe Islands.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the framework of scientific cooperation between the EU and third countries, the EU has concluded a scientific and technological cooperation agreement with the Faroe Islands to involve them in the framework programme for research and innovation "Horizon 2020". I voted in favour of this agreement. The Union has developed a high-level research programme and it is important to encourage EU cooperation in this area with other countries.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. Horizon 2020 – Community Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, with an overall budget of more than EUR 77 billion for the period 2014-2020, is the largest instrument of the European Community specifically aimed at supporting research, thereby stimulating the boosting of the economy. I have approved the conclusion of this agreement with the Faroe Islands, as I support the establishment of a borderless research area in which scientific resources will be better used to increase employment and competitiveness in Europe.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I, like the almost unanimous part of MEPs, voted in favour of the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands. In practice, the aim is to involve the Faroe Islands in the "Horizon 2020" framework programme for research and innovation (2014-2020). So, of course, this small archipelago in northern Europe, which is part of the Kingdom of Denmark and is located about halfway between Iceland and Norway, will be a very small beneficiary of European research policy. The latter has a substantial multi-year budget of 80 billion euros, of which more than 15 billion are planned for the first two years. It is still questionable what is the point of the Union signing such an agreement with a territory of 50,000 inhabitants, unless it reads future partnerships to better exploit the resources of hydroelectricity and possible oil and gas reserves.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, linking the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 - Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands. The Faroe Islands are associated with Horizon 2020, Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has given its approval to the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with the Faroe Islands. The President of Parliament is now responsible for conveying Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Faroe Islands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. We are looking at a proposal for a recommendation to conclude a scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, while linking the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 2012 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020). In addition to the association with Horizon 2020, cooperation may also include regular discussions on the guidelines and priorities of the policies and research plans of the Faroe Islands and the Union, discussions on prospects for cooperation and development, visits and exchanges of researchers, engineers and technicians, participation of experts in seminars, symposia and workshops, among others. The draft agreement also lays down the conditions for the participation of the Faroe Islands in indirect actions and in the activities of the European Commission Research Centre under the same conditions as those applicable to the entities of the Member States of the Union.  For the reasons put forward above, I voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. Horizon 2020 is the European Union's new Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, which provides for a funding framework of around €77 billion for research and innovation investments and for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, thus increasing cooperation between industry and research.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as I recognise the importance of scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of the inclusion of the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the conclusion of an Agreement on scientific cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. The Agreement can have a positive impact on the scientific development of both parties and therefore improve relations between them.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The Horizon 2020 programme is a powerful tool for stimulating scientific research and, indirectly, boosting the economy, environmental protection and promoting the values we hold most in Europe. The European Union is devoting large amounts of money to this programme and this will bring benefits in terms of competitiveness and quality of life for all. I therefore congratulate the Faroe Islands on being one of the beneficiary regions of this instrument. However, I have to emphasize that I am against the use of marine mammals that is made in this territory. For this reason, I am concerned that European funds may be being used for any purpose that includes the persecution and death of cetaceans. We must not forget the sad images that result from the annual killings of the local communities of the Faroe Islands. As a corollary, I ask the European Commission to be particularly judicious in allocating and monitoring the use of funds under this agreement, ensuring that it does not contribute, directly or indirectly, to the death or suffering of species protected by International Conventions to which it is a signatory.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Agreement as it will greatly add to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the EU and the Faroe Islands. This Agreement allows for closer cooperation with the Faroes in the area of research and innovation and provides the Faroes with the possibility of benefiting from and contributing to the development of research and innovation in Europe.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The Faroe Islands have successfully participated in the SEVENTH EU Framework Programme for Research since 2010. The new agreement will allow the Faroe Islands to participate in most of the challenges of Horizon 2020, which are an appropriate instrument for developing research and innovation, so I welcome this resolution.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Recommendation Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the Conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faeroe Islands, which joins Horizon 2020. - Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020) recommended by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Draft Council Decision.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it will greatly add to the development of scientific progress and the exchange of knowledge and ideas between the EU and the Faroe Islands. This agreement allows for closer cooperation with the Faroes in the area of research and innovation and provides the Faroes with the possibility of benefiting from and contributing to the development of research and innovation in Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I agree with this Recommendation, given that since 1 January 2010 the Faeroe Islands have been linked to the previous FP7 framework programme for research and innovation and that the participation of the Faeroe Islands has been very successful, although they only became involved in half of the programme. During this period, the Faroe Islands gained access to large international research networks, and the European Research Community benefited from the excellent contribution of Faroe researchers. The areas where their participation was most relevant are food, agriculture and fisheries, bio-tourism and the marine environment, aquaculture and climate change. One of the FP7 projects with the participation of the Faeroe Islands is the Thermohaline Overturning: At Risk project? (THOR). During the four years within the THOR project, the dynamics of the North Atlantic Circulation of Ocean Thermohalines (THC) were investigated, which carries heat from the tropics to the shores of Europe, which strongly affects Europe's temperate climate.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I welcome the further deepening of cooperation between the EU and the Faroe Islands.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement which sets in place rules to enable the Faroe Islands to participate in the EU’s research and innovation programme Horizon 2020 as an associated country, establishing provisions to enable joint meetings, visits and exchanges of research workers, engineers and technicians, as well as participation of experts in seminars and workshops.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU must give priority to meeting the needs of the national economies of its Member States before taking cooperation with third countries.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the scientific cooperation agreement with the Faroe Islands. Science, technology, research and innovation need no borders, but these islands are certainly not a partner that the EU can be proud of. Deaf to international disgust, they carry out repeated massacres every year of hundreds and hundreds of globicephalus which, like all cetaceans, are strictly protected by the EU through Annex IV to the Habitats Directive. The inhabitants of the Faroe Islands argue that the hunt for globicephales is part of their ancient "cultural traditions". These traditions, however, did not include the use of motor boats, reconnaissance aircraft, GPS and mobile phones: hunting turned into the barbaric and useless extermination of a huge number of animals. The meat of globicephals - once valuable for feeding - is thrown away. Perhaps the maintenance of 'cultural traditions' could be tolerable if a very small number of animals were killed by traditional methods, but the Faroe Islands' habit of slaughtering hundreds of globicephalus cruelly and needlessly reverberates its horror at anyone in the international community who has relations with them. No agreement between the EU and the Faroe Islands will ever be able to get my approval unless it contains the prerequisite for banning globicephalus diseases.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which links the Faroe Islands to the "Horizon 2020" framework programme for research and innovation (2014-2020).

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU and Faroe Islands. The Faroe Islands were granted the status of ‘associated country’ in 2010, in 2014 the negotiations by the European Commission led to a new agreement to maintain the status of ‘associated country’ for participation in Horizon 2020. This agreement, as well as the other two agreements on the cooperation between the EU and Switzerland and EU and India, aims to tackle global challenges and support EU’s external policies. I can fully support this approach: it is necessary to focus more on the external dimension and to continue with cooperation especially in field of science.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a new Agreement that will allow the Faeroe Islands to participate in most horizon 2020 programmes, while in return they will make funding to the European Union budget each year. I take particularly useful part of the Agreement that the EU-Faroe Islands Research and Innovation Committee will have the right to oversee the implementation of the Agreement, i.e. to assess and revise its implementation.  I also believe that regular discussions need to be had on the future direction and priorities of research policies and plans in the Faeroe Islands and in the European Union and on future cooperation opportunities, as outlined in the Agreement. I support the Agreement's position to allow the Faeroe Islands to use financial instruments under Horizon 2020 under the same conditions as legal entities established in the Member States, with the Faeroe Islands regularly informing the Union of existing Faroe programmes and opportunities for legal entities established in the European Union, as this shows the reciprocal benefits of both Contracting Parties.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has approved the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands, which joins the Faroe Islands to the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.
