In view of the positive impact of the agreement on the scientific and technological development of the Union, I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of the inclusion of the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. I vote against this scientific and technical partnership agreement with the Faroe Islands. We deny the European Union the right to conclude treaties instead of France. The Faroe Islands already enjoy a special legal status as the autonomous territory of Denmark. They are not of particular diplomatic importance to French interests.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Convinced of the need to strengthen the area of scientific and technical cooperation with third countries, we voted in favour of the inclusion of the Faroe Islands in the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 It is necessary to vote in favour of this Resolution in order to continue scientific and technological cooperation between the Faroe Islands and the EU through the current R&D&I framework programme, Horizon 2020.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because scientific cooperation between States respecting international law is an important asset for improving the living conditions of their respective peoples. The recommendation is in favour of the conclusion of an Agreement on scientific cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands under the Horizon 2020 programme. The Agreement can have a positive impact on the scientific development of both parties and therefore improve relations between them.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 18 March 2014, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the European Union, with the Faroe Islands for an agreement linking the Faroe Islands to Horizon 2020 – Programme—Framework for Research and Innovation (2014-2020). The Faroe Islands should participate as an associated country under the terms and conditions set out in Horizon 2020 and Council Decision 2013/743/EU. The cooperation agreement will include regular discussions on the prospects for cooperation and development, regular information on the implementation of research programmes and projects, meetings and visits with exchange of views between researchers and technicians, participation of experts in seminars, symposia and workshops. An EU-Faroese Committee for Research and Innovation should be formed, consisting of representatives of both parties. We think it is positive and we support this initiative.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this proposal because it is merely a continuation of an existing research agreement with the Faroe Islands and there is no objection to it.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document deals with the conclusion of the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the Faroe Islands.  On 18 March 2014, the Council authorised the European Commission to open negotiations on behalf of the European Union with the Faroe Islands for an agreement involving the Faroe Islands with Horizon 2020 2012 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020). The Faroe Islands shall participate as an associated country, under the terms and conditions laid down by Horizon 2020 and Council Decision 2013/743/EU. The cooperation agreement will include regular discussions on the prospects for cooperation and development, regular information on the implementation of research programmes and projects, meetings and visits with exchange of views between researchers and technicians, participation of experts in seminars, symposia and workshops. An EU-Faroe Sea Committee for Research and Innovation should be formed, consisting of representatives of both parties. We voted for it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the Cofferati report is a balanced text which focuses on delivering full transparency where there is real benefit to both shareholders and stakeholders. At the same time, I think we struck a balance between the protection of personal data and existing EU corporate governance structures. In particular, I was very pleased to be able to support the proposal on country-by-country reporting in order to help ensure full transparency on tax payments. The call to the Commission to instigate country-by-country reporting will affect all companies who trade across borders in all sectors. In my opinion, this entails a significant change in EU taxation policy. It will assist the Commission in fighting tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning at both EU and global level.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to explain my vote in support of this proposal. Not only because of the transparency of the flow, as my colleague said in the pre-debate, but also because amendment number one extended the original proposal, so that it will also apply to large companies, large enterprises. And I think that's crucial. Those companies whose shares have been admitted to trading on a regulated market.  At the same time, I would like to appreciate that, in the context of this proposal, shareholders are more involved in company management, because this is undoubtedly a value that shareholders have clearly lacked so far. In the Czech Republic, this was probably seen in the biggest fraud in the control of water companies, where shareholders were actually downright weaned, so I am glad that the proposal is heading in a good direction.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the gap between theory and practice is turning into a yawning chasm. We have had a record voting session, and here we are now talking about shareholder rights and corporate governance and ignoring the crisis that we have created with our own policies – a crisis which we are now exacerbating by feeding the patient more of the medicine that sickened him in the first place. In all the hours of debate in this Chamber, one question was never asked: how do you help a stricken country in Greece’s situation by forcing more loans on it? This is not about the EU bailing out Greece, this is about Greek taxpayers bailing out the eurozone.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, long-term shareholder engagement and corporate governance will stimulate long-term investment.  The financial crisis has highlighted that shareholders took excessive short-term risks that have led many companies to bankruptcy. The voted proposal makes European companies much more attractive because they offer incentives to shareholders through special voting rights and dividends. Administrators will also have to disclose all information related to potential conflicts of interest, investment strategy, turnover. Citizens need to know why a company has raised or lowered a price.  The general meeting of shareholders shall also be introduced on a mandatory basis. That's how we make sure a director doesn't pay himself. Transparency is the key to tax fraud and conflict of interest.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the promotion of long-term shareholder involvement and Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the declaration on corporate governance because it is a very important step in the fight against tax evasion and in favour of the transfer of listed companies.  With this proposal, Europe has a great opportunity to create a fairer and more transparent tax system. Among the novel elements included, it should be noted that large companies have an obligation to declare "country by country reporting" the profits obtained, the taxes paid on profits and the subsidies received. Thus, citizens and authorities will be able to know where large companies actually pay their taxes, as they will have to clarify whether they pay taxes in tax havens or where they carry out their economic activities. The Directive also provides that shareholders of a listed company can vote on the remuneration of their directors, which should reflect their contributions to the long-term interests and results of companies.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the adoption of a Directive which contains important obligations for shareholders of anonymous undertakings, so that they can be better controlled by the different competent authorities of the Member States. This directive represents a very important step forward in the field of European commercial law by including for the first time the obligations of shareholders in their long-term linkage in the participating undertakings. There are numerous mechanisms by which this Directive will not solve many of the problems relating to the ownership of public limited companies; however, it is an undeniable step forward in imposing obligations on employers. For all this, I've decided to vote for it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This report contains good approaches, for example on the remuneration policy for managers, which is intended to explain how it serves the long-term interests of the company and to establish clear criteria for the granting of the fixed and variable components of remuneration, including all bonuses and all benefits in any form. The share value should not be a priority in the financial performance criteria and share-based remuneration should not be the most important part of their variable remuneration for senior staff.  However, I abstained on the proposed obligation for large companies and listed companies to disclose information on profits, taxes paid and state aid received, broken down by Member State, as I question the effectiveness of this proposal. The first reading is not yet complete, as the European Parliament wants to reach a compromise on the final version of the law in negotiations with the Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Cofferati report aims to promote long-term shareholder engagement and transparency in the governance of European companies. Two important aspects were voted on: - large multinational companies as well as public interest bodies, which therefore manage public funds, should publish country-by-country information related to revenues, profits taxes and subsidies received. It is clear that this system would effectively combat corruption and tax evasion; - the elected representatives also decided to give shareholders the power to vote on the remuneration policy of company executives. With the National Front having a very clear policy on these two points, I voted in favour of them.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this measure because: 1.  it is legislative, and I vote against EU legislation in general; 2.  this is a matter best suited to the United Kingdom; 3.  it interferes with the free market; 4.  of the implications for company competitiveness; 5.  of the regulatory burden imposed; 6.  this moves towards harmonisation and EU Companies Legislation.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament's negotiating position with the Council. The increased transparency of boards of directors for shareholders is commendable, this regulation could ultimately allow a better understanding of tax tourism. I supported the defeated amendment to allocate additional CA votes to shareholders who are concerned about the long term.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the shareholder rights resolution and the corporate governance statement because it is about introducing more transparency and fostering longer-term shareholder engagement within companies. It is indeed necessary to supervise large companies as best as possible by requiring them to disclose all the activities of their subsidiaries, country by country. This accounting reporting requirement would provide accurate data, such as turnover in each state, overall wages, asset value and number of full-time positions. Finally, I would like to commend the excellent work of my Socialist colleague Sergio Cofferati, without whom such a result could not have been achieved.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to give shareholders more power in determining the remuneration of directors. The new rules would give shareholders of companies the right to vote on directors' remuneration policies at least every three years. The draft rules would also oblige some large companies and insurance companies to disclose how much they pay taxes, profits and state subsidies in a given country.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As Article 2 (-1a) was approved, I voted in favour of this report, as recommended by my colleague Gilles Lebreton, who closely followed the drafting of this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report will make it a major step forward towards transparent operation of listed companies. This will be done without adding procedures or obligations that would increase the burden on the companies concerned or increase their costs. This report is also consistent with our desire to reduce tax evasion and tax avoidance. The European Union must play a leading role in bringing as many countries as possible in its wake.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Written. It is with satisfaction that I have today voted in favour of the negotiating mandate on the Shareholder Rights Directive. I am a strong advocate of shareholder involvement in companies and of transparency in companies' pay policies and major commercial transactions. It's good for shareholders and for the company. The Commission's proposal for a directive was both unduly burdensome for our businesses and based on a 'one-size-fits-all' principle, in which the British model is dragged down over all European business models. We should not be part of the adoption of rules that are so burdensome and rigid that companies are weakened in the global market. Fortunately, we corrected this, and the starting point we have adopted today ensures the influence of shareholders. I'm sticking to that is important. I believe that we have reached a reasonable compromise in Parliament and I believe that we can also reach a good solution in the negotiations with the Council. I am a little annoyed that we have clouded our message of shareholder involvement by adding elements on tax policy. Let me stress that I am in favour of combating tax evasion and tax evasion. However, tax policy should be tackled where it belongs - in tax legislation, where we are already introducing similar rules.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed directive entitled "Long-Term Shareholder Engagement and Statement on Corporate Governance" aims to facilitate long-term shareholder engagement, including shareholder identification, information transmission and facilitation of shareholder rights, as well as ensuring transparency of the engagement policies of institutional investors and asset managers, and finally setting certain requirements for compensation and transactions with related parties. I am in favour of this spirit of corporate governance and the commitment of shareholders over the long term, so I voted in favour of this report which goes in this direction.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the promotion of long-term shareholder involvement and Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the declaration on corporate governance because it is a very important step in the fight against tax evasion and in favour of the transfer of listed companies.  With this proposal, Europe has a great opportunity to create a fairer and more transparent tax system. Among the novel elements included, it should be noted that large companies have an obligation to declare "country by country reporting" the profits obtained, the taxes paid on profits and the subsidies received. Thus, citizens and authorities will be able to know where large companies actually pay their taxes, as they will have to clarify whether they pay taxes in tax havens or where they carry out their economic activities. The Directive also provides that shareholders of a listed company can vote on the remuneration of their directors, which should reflect their contributions to the long-term interests and results of companies.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which amends and improves the Commission's proposal for a directive on long-term shareholder engagement. The proposal for a Commission Directive lays down requirements for the exercise of certain shareholder rights by voting shares at general meetings of companies whose registered office is situated in a Member State and whose shares are admitted to trading on a regulated market situated or operating in a Member State. This Directive should also apply to large companies and large groups as defined in Directive 2013/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council whose shares are not shares admitted to trading on a regulated market, as they also carry out activities with a significant impact. Although shareholders do not belong to companies which are separate legal entities and which they cannot fully control, they have an important role to play in the management of those companies. The financial crisis has revealed that shareholders have in many cases agreed that management would take excessive short-term risks. In addition, increased shareholder participation in corporate governance is one of the levers that can help improve their financial and non-financial performance. Since shareholder rights are not the only long-term factor to be taken into account in the management of the company, these rights should be supplemented by measures to ensure greater involvement of all actors, in particular employees, local authorities and civil society.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the report on promoting better cooperation between shareholders and corporate governance. In many ways, shareholders are purely passive owners who are purely focused solely on the movement of the share price, and too little in what they could achieve to grow the company healthily, thereby benefiting even as owners. In particular, institutional investors are particularly troubled, who, in a bid for short-term returns, forget that their clients' money is managed in the long term. Speculative trades also bring instability to the financial markets, and the lack of control in this area is even a serious economic shock, according to experience. Therefore, legal incentives to invest in securities in the long term and in a responsible way are more than welcome.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Long Term Shareholder Participation Report and corporate governance report. The proposal includes key elements such as shareholder identification for companies, transparency of institutional investors and managers' assets, as well as additional controls on the remuneration system. Stakeholders, especially workers, would have the right to express their position on the report before it is submitted to shareholders, which I also consider a good move.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that encouraging the long-term commitment of shareholders of listed companies will lead to greater stability in their management and, consequently, to the entire economic and financial system.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greater transparency on the ownership and management of shares by the controllers of listed companies is an important element in ensuring stability in the markets and in ensuring real competition, based not on opaque manoeuvres, but on a real capacity to improve the supply of their products and the efficiency of production and marketing systems. We need clear, binding, identical legislation across Europe to allow investors full knowledge and control of corporate dynamics, managers' remuneration and the production chain. A non-binding opinion would risk damaging the most virtuous companies, thus failing to affirm that principle of equality before the law, the application of which is fundamental for the good health of the market and, above all, for the civil coexistence of our society.  The review of shareholders' rights, however agitated it may be in the world of intermediary entities, is necessary to improve the functioning of the stock market, to make it fairer and more transparent and to ensure loyalty in relations between the company and shareholders. That is why we must all ensure that the European Parliament speaks out clearly and authoritatively in this direction today.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the European Parliament's proposed directive promotes long-term shareholder engagement and improved corporate governance. Increasing shareholder and stakeholder involvement would thus help to improve the financial and non-financial performance of our companies. The report also plans to increase transparency between investors and businesses. The financial crisis has shown that institutional investors (financial institutions, hedge funds, pension funds) and asset managers are favouring short-term returns, leading to underperformance of our productive apparatus. The growing divergences between the interests of investors and those of companies lie in the fact that shareholders are over-risking because of the profitability of their investments. While this report does not further explore the issue of existing tools to combat speculation in financial markets, we consider it to be a step in the right direction. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Encouraging shareholder participation in corporate governance of companies is intended to increase their financial performance, empower decisions and, at the same time, defend the private interests of companies.  In this respect, a balance should be struck between the exercise of shareholder rights, confidentiality and the protection of personal data.  Furthermore, the Commission should set out clear rules on the setting of specific requirements for the transmission of information on the identity of shareholders. I was in favour of this report because I believe that more active shareholder participation in companies contributes to increasing the transparency of decision-making and strengthening dialogue.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The desire to better regulate the activity of listed companies is meritorio. The encouragement of the long-term commitment of shareholders could simply be encouraged without giving them favour positions over other shareholders, without creating dominant positions of any kind within the company. For the rest, however, the report is very positive. Commitments for stakeholders to ensure greater transparency in the notes to financial statements (on information to external parties, list of subsidiaries, information to customers, nature of activities and geographical location, etc.), taking into account the differences between Member States, are very important. These rules could help to increase confidence in citizens/consumers and investors (including institutional ones), thus eliminating a certain veil of opacity that often surrounds the activities of large companies whether they are listed or not.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the encouragement of long-term shareholder engagement and Directive 2013/34/EU with regard to certain elements of the corporate governance report. With this report, Parliament has taken an important step forward in steering companies and investors towards oriented decision-making and ensuring greater transparency in the governance of European companies. Furthermore, with this vote, important instruments have been approved to combat tax evasion and avoidance, such as the obligation to provide information country by country, so that multinationals publicly declare the taxes they pay in each country in which they operate. I therefore believe that Parliament has given an important signal, particularly since Luxleaks and the other scandals.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this measure because: 1. it is legislative, and I vote against EU legislation in general; 2. this is a matter best suited to the United Kingdom; 3. it interferes with the free market; 4. of the implications for company competitiveness; 5. of the regulatory burden imposed; 6. this moves towards harmonisation and EU Companies Legislation.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The revision of the shareholders’ rights Directive is part of the initiatives foreseen in the European Commission’s Action Plan to review European Company law and corporate governance. In my view the Commission proposal has always been controversial as it would unnecessarily over burden businesses. The main stumbling points from my side in this discussion were the elements related to remuneration policy, comply and explain in identification of shareholders, deletion of long term incentive obligation and the country-by-country reporting (CBCR). I voted against the text on incentives for long-term shareholding obligation and abstained on the text related to CBCR and tax rulings. I agreed with the Rapporteur to postpone the final vote on the legislative resolution in order to start negotiations for a first reading agreement.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's report giving a mandate for negotiations with the Commission and the Council on the revision of Directive 2007/36/EC on requirements relating to the exercise of certain shareholder rights in listed companies. The aim is to improve and increase long-term investment. In particular, the elements of transparency in the report are a particularly positive element.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this directive in plenary when I rejected the report in the Committee on Legal Affairs. I welcome the fact that the compromises proposed in plenary, in a spirit of appeasement by all the political groups, have resonated with the rapporteur. This text now provides for the possibility of an advisory vote on remuneration policy and no longer refers to the ratio between the average remuneration of directors and employees. It provides for the possibility for Member States to ensure that shareholders have an advisory right to vote on the remuneration report, but excludes the participation of employees in this procedure. Finally, I welcome the fact that the text has provided for a departure from the rule that the value of shares should not play a predominant role in the financial performance criteria. This text is now balanced. All this goes in the right direction, in the interests of our companies, their development and the development of the European economy.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report, which concerned long-term shareholder engagement and corporate governance. Indeed, while the report itself made positive changes to the Commission's draft, parliamentarians in plenary refused to vote on provisions necessary for transparency, such as Article 2-1a, which obliged large companies to communicate to Member States the nature of their activities and their geographical location. However, I could not totally object to this report, which proposed to amend the directive by adding sound measures, such as the protection of minority shareholders, or the fact that Member States can ensure that the relevant stakeholders, particularly employees, are empowered to express, through their representatives, their views on the remuneration policy before it is passed on to shareholders.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council with regard to the encouragement of the long-term commitment of shareholders and certain elements of the report on corporate governance. The aim of the proposal is to strengthen the long-term perspective in the management of listed companies by giving minority shareholders, and in particular institutional investors, a more transparent and easy-to-manage role. The idea is that if investors are more involved and their engagement is more long-term oriented, companies will give greater priority to long-term issues, which in turn will benefit end-users of institutional investors and asset managers, as well as businesses and society as a whole.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis we are experiencing was the result of another crisis, the financial crisis, which in turn was caused by the disconnect between the long-term objectives of society and those, much more short-sighted, of a significant part of the financial world. The problem is that, following the logic and dynamism of the stock exchange, we run the risk of losing sight of the fact that behind each stock there is a company that produces goods and services, employees, customers, one or more reference territories, an induced person and each of us is involved in that world. With this report, which I voted in favour of, the European Parliament wanted to take a first step towards realigning the objectives of medium and large investors with those of the economy as a whole in seeking to create widespread and sustainable well-being. Congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Cofferati report represents an improvement on the Commission's original proposal and the General Position of the Council, despite the important points on which we have had to give in in order to reach a compromise acceptable to all groups. The reference to country-by-country reporting on taxes paid is a major step towards greater transparency of listed companies to avoid future cases such as the recent Lux leaks. For these reasons, I voted in favour, in order to mandate the rapporteur to start negotiations with the Commission and the Council.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the adoption of a Directive which contains important obligations for shareholders of anonymous undertakings, so that they can be better controlled by the different competent authorities of the Member States. This directive represents a very important step forward in the field of European commercial law by including for the first time the obligations of shareholders in their long-term linkage in the participating undertakings. There are numerous mechanisms by which this Directive will not solve many of the problems relating to the ownership of public limited companies; however, it is an undeniable step forward in imposing obligations on employers. For all this, I've decided to vote for it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the People's Party, I support the development of the economic environment in the European Union. The aim is to achieve cost-effectiveness and to reduce the administrative burden on enterprises in order to increase competitiveness. Job creation is primarily the responsibility of companies and not of governments, which requires clear rules, but achieving transparency should not mean increasing the operating costs of European enterprises. It is essential to create framework conditions, both on economic and legal grounds, that will enable and facilitate the recovery of the economy and the creation of new jobs. That was also the aim of the report adopted today, especially when it comes to remuneration policy and long-term shareholder engagement. However, I did not support the so-called country-by-country report contained in the report, as the OECD's reporting obligation, similar to the rules on the avoidance of tax avoidance (BEPS) by large companies, has no place in 'sectoral' legislation such as this Directive.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to revise the 2007/36/EC Directive on Shareholder Rights with a view to improving the governance of companies listed on EU stock markets and strengthening their competitiveness and long-term viability. The purpose of this text is to increase the engagement of institutional investors and asset managers, strengthen the link between remuneration and directors' performance, improve shareholders' control over transactions with related parties, and increase the transparency of voting advisors. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted for it.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. As investors, shareholders must have their financial interests protected. However, this should not be at the expense of consistent long-term corporate governance. The text we voted on contains many provisions aimed at establishing transparency on shareholding and reducing information asymmetries. The ultimate goal is to promote growth, employment and competitiveness in the internal market. For my part, I wanted to speak out in favour of rules requiring multinationals to report tax countries by country, which I believe should enable them to combat tax evasion and corruption.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it represents a strong compromise between the main groups of the European Parliament. More importantly, the report avoids the tsunami of unnecessarily detailed regulations which was initially being proposed by the Socialist rapporteur. Europe needs simplified rules and a common market that functions more effectively than today. We need to provide business owners and entrepreneurs the possibility to use more of their time on running and developing their businesses, rather than dealing with bureaucracy. I believe this report is important if Europe is to address the roots of the financial crisis and corporate governance shortcomings. The report aims to contribute to long-term shareholder engagement. It calls for more transparency on internal business transactions which could possibly jeopardise the company, but protecting at the same time business sensitive information. I specifically welcome the flexibility clauses of the text and the comply or explain approach, leaving enough leeway for the management boards of companies.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. \u2012 The SP delegation voted in favour of Amendments 25 and 26 of the S&D, which included exceptions for asset managers who do not disclose certain information about their investments. Although the amendments are not ideal, they contain improvements to the European Commission's proposal, which described the information to be disclosed much less extensively and specifically.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the encouragement of long-term shareholder engagement and Directive 2013/34/EU with regard to certain elements of the corporate governance report has made a number of steps towards harmonising the management of listed companies. In particular, the long-term perspective in their management has been strengthened. One of the main problems not yet addressed by the European body of legislation was the excessive focus of companies solely on short-term returns, and on profits. In this way, paying attention to the short term, long-term planning was 19 and therefore investment was insufficient and suboptimal. The solution is to give minority shareholders, and therefore institutional investors, a more influential role in a context of greater transparency. In addition, the participation of all the actors present who revolve around companies such as employees, consumers and local communities has also been encouraged. For these reasons, both the dialogue between shareholders has been encouraged and the provisions relating to the faster identification of shareholders have been promoted. I therefore believe it is important to support these initiatives aimed at promoting the European economic fabric at this sensitive time.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The revision of the Shareholder Rights Directive must be an opportunity to achieve greater transparency. Large European listed companies will now have to publish information related to revenues, profits taxes and country subsidies. In this way, the EU will be able to combat tax evasion and illicit financial flows in developing countries more effectively.  Large companies will also need to tell their shareholders how they contribute to their group's interests over the long term, and put in place clear criteria for paying compensation.  This very important step towards greater transparency, initiated today by the European Union, will have to continue tomorrow at the international level.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EPP delegation of the Fidesz People's Party, in agreement with the People's Party, stands for the development of the economic environment in the European Union. The aim is to achieve cost-effectiveness and to reduce the administrative burden on enterprises in order to increase competitiveness. However, I did not support the so-called 'country-by-country' report contained in the report, as reporting obligations such as the OECD rules on the avoidance of tax avoidance (BEPS) by large companies have no place in 'sectoral' legislation such as this Directive.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I gave strong support to the compromise that led to this resolution because it aims to increase transparency and encourage long-term shareholder engagement with companies. This text helps to put an end to the disparity in legislation that existed until now. Currently, 13 Member States allow shareholders to decide on remuneration policy. Fifteen EU countries communicate on remuneration policy and 11 require the publication of directors' remuneration on an individual basis. Europe needs simplified, harmonised and transparent rules, which should make it possible to better guide companies and investors towards long-term decision-making and will also enable them to combat tax evasion and evasion more effectively. In addition, by providing for large companies and publicly traded companies to publish country-by-country information related to revenues, income taxes and subsidies they have received, this text should help to fill some gaps in corporate governance and address the root causes of the financial crisis.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EC proposal aims to contribute to the long-term sustainability of companies, create an attractive shareholder environment and strengthen cross-border voting in order to contribute to eu growth, job creation and competitiveness. However, the report also contains problematic topics such as the mandatory reporting requirement for all large and listed companies in each EU Member State in which they are established. That's why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal because, although it brings about key changes to the European Commission's proposal, it has serious legislative gaps, while at the same time the interests of companies remain the guiding factor in decision-making.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission's proposal on certain elements of the Declaration on Corporate Governance was published in April 2014. The revision of the Shareholder Rights Directive is part of the initiatives provided for in the Commission's Action Plan 'European Company Law and Corporate Governance - a modern legal framework for greater shareholder participation and the viability of companies'. The most important provisions proposed are: the identification of shareholders; facilitating the transmission of relevant information between the company and shareholders and the exercise of shareholder rights; transparency provisions for institutional investors, asset managers and voting advisors; new rules on directors' remuneration; new rules on transactions with related parties (RPTs). In this regard, the report should contain some priorities such as remuneration policy, complying with and explaining in the identification of shareholders and the abolition of the obligation of long-term incentives.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This text, which is fundamental in many respects, is the result of a compromise that has necessarily ruled out certain issues, but which has also made it possible to bring to plenary a valid text to shift the governance of companies towards more ethically sustainable working methods. For example, unless changes are negotiated with the Commission and the Council, it will be mandatory for companies to declare in which countries they pay taxes, avoiding future Lux Leaks scandals, or, again, the control mechanisms of managers whose remuneration will therefore be linked to the results will be increased. Therefore, although I regret the absence of certain relevant elements such as, for example, the obligation to disclose the relationship between the remuneration of directors and the average remuneration of employees, I have decided to vote in favour of this text for the other many steps forward that it envisages.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because I believe that corporate law must remain the sole jurisdiction of states.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to improve the functioning of the EU's financial markets by implementing standards aimed at minimising the effects of identified inefficiencies, which relate mainly to insufficient shareholder involvement and the lack of an adequate level of transparency.  Among others, the following objectives are advocated: to increase the involvement of owners and asset managers in their subsidiaries; create a better link between the remuneration and performance of company directors; increase transparency and oversight by shareholders of transactions with related parties; stimulate a more long-term-oriented perspective. We voted in favour of all amendments calling for more transparency, identification of shareholders, better information and the possibility of employees' representatives having the right to vote on the remuneration policy of directors. However, the report's approach is frankly reductive. Without understitling the problem of diminished shareholder involvement or the lack of adequate levels of transparency, the fundamental issue is another and relates to the essence of globalised capitalism, the free movement of capital and the growing inequalities in income distribution. Some of these aspects are simply ignored by the report. Any gains stemming from the implementation of the guidelines now adopted will not serve to ensure a fairer redistribution of the wealth created.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Aim of the European Commission's Proposal of April 2014 on shareholder involvement was to strengthen the long-term perspective in the management of listed companies. In particular, it was about ensuring that the role of minority shareholders in corporate governance is more transparent, influential and easier to manage. The basic idea was to curb demand for high short-term profits and focus on the long-term perspective and put emphasis on the long-term interests of companies. It is precisely the promotion of greater shareholder involvement that is one way to gain a long-term perspective for companies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the proposal to amend Directive 2007/36/EC as regards encouraging long-term active shareholder participation and Directive 2013/34/EU with regard to certain elements of the corporate governance statement as, although it makes key changes to the European Commission's proposal, it presents serious legislative gaps, while at the same time the interest of companies remains the driving force for decision-making.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Based on our S&D values, I believe that the Report on Shareholders’ Rights Directive approved in the Legal Affairs Committee with the support of our group, will improve economic stability, foster long-term shareholding and boost long-term investment. I support the idea that it is a necessary instrument in order to ensure more transparency in company management and in the activity of financial intermediaries. In particular, it sets the mechanism and the policy on directors’ remuneration with yearly reporting on its implementation. I would also like to welcome the importance of the report in fighting tax evasion and tax avoidance, and most importantly, the introduction of the country-by-country reporting obligation on taxes paid for large and listed companies. I would like to thank and praise the rapporteur Sergio Gaetano Cofferati as well as the shadow rapporteurs for the great job done.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the promotion of long-term shareholder involvement and Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the declaration on corporate governance because it is a very important step in the fight against tax evasion and in favour of the transfer of listed companies.  With this proposal, Europe has a great opportunity to create a fairer and more transparent tax system. Among the novel elements included, it should be noted that large companies have an obligation to declare "country by country reporting" the profits obtained, the taxes paid on profits and the subsidies received. Thus, citizens and authorities will be able to know where large companies actually pay their taxes, as they will have to clarify whether they pay taxes in tax havens or where they carry out their economic activities. The Directive also provides that shareholders of a listed company can vote on the remuneration of their directors, which should reflect their contributions to the long-term interests and results of companies.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's position on the Shareholder Rights Directive, because I consider it essential to legislate at Community level on substantial aspects of the governance of listed companies, transparency and how to define directors' remuneration, transactions with related parties with a view to fostering relations with shareholders. I personally believe that the introduction of country-by-country reporting, which is not provided for in the Commission's initial proposal, on the initiative of the rapporteur for the European Parliament, Cofferati and strongly supported by the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), is a real innovative element and characterises the legislation being drafted. Listed companies, which in most cases have activities in other countries other than those where the registered office is located, will therefore have to report their activities and the taxes paid in each country, thus becoming a real instrument of transparency. Finally, I hope that all the results for which the EP has fought and therefore: greater transparency in the commitments of investors and asset managers, the remuneration of the directors of listed companies and its link with the performance of the companies they manage will be vigorously defended during the trialogue with the Council.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the Cofferati report, because it is high time we took decisive steps to clamp down on tax havens once and for all. In this context it is crucial we introduce country-by-country reporting (CBCR) on taxes paid for large and listed companies, demanding of multinationals to break their information down by country of operation so that citizens and authorities can see where large companies actually pay their taxes.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. We understand that your result is positive and that its possible effects will be positive. The text tries to deal with tax havens and tax evasion by understanding them as one of the key problems in contemporary capitalism. In addition, it includes a number of positive points, such as the need to justify premiums or the request to establish, in a mandatory manner, the transmission of tax information by companies. At the present stage, the JURI Commission is trying to find the legal keys to the possible development of a tax system in line with contemporary needs. We understand that this report is a step forward in this regard, and that we must continue to delve into the question of tax evasion and how it compromises the social economies of the different countries of the Union.

name: Sylvie Goulard (ALDE)
text: In writing. One of the questions asked in this report on shareholder rights concerns the requirement that large European companies publish commercial and tax information on all countries in which they operate ("country by country reporting"). I voted in favour of these amendments.  Nevertheless, I hope that these requirements will be implemented in two phases. This information should first be passed on to national tax authorities and the European Commission. Second, once a global framework has been developed, they should be made public. I am in favour of transparency, as companies must contribute fairly to the financing of the countries in which they operate, provided that global competition is fair.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrat group voted in favour of this report. Shareholders should be able to know where their companies make profits and crucially where taxes are paid. In order to have certainty that the company is paying its correct share of tax, shareholders need to understand the health and the prospects of the company they are investing in. As such, public country-by-country reporting for major international companies would represent an important step forward.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I supported this report I abstained on a number of votes regarding country-by-country report for transnational companies. First of all, country-by-country reporting does not fit into the scope of this directive where the focus is on shareholders. Secondly, negotiations are still ongoing in relation to this issue and I do not think Parliament should take a preliminary position on this without due regard to the final negotiations.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission's objective of promoting transparency and greater shareholder participation is, in principle, to be welcomed. The text that has now been adopted in plenary represents a considerable improvement on the report adopted in committee. Particularly positive is the freedom of action granted to Member States, for example.B in relation to the regulatory framework for remuneration policy or in transactions with affiliated companies, and the more flexible exercise of shareholder control, which is to be considered more practicable than a rigid focus on the annual general meeting. Negative is the hasty introduction of a paragraph on country reporting, which, in addition to the actual scope of the directive, includes not only public limited companies but also large companies or companies of public interest. The call for greater involvement of employees and civil society in corporate governance, as well as the demand for the focus of these on unspecified environmental and social policy objectives, also dilutes the bill aimed at shareholders. It was therefore not possible for me to vote in favour of the draft report. I abstained.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian People's Party delegation, in agreement with the European People's Party, advocates the development of the economic environment in the European Union. The aim is to achieve cost-effectiveness and to reduce the administrative burden on enterprises in order to increase competitiveness. Job creation is primarily the responsibility of companies, not governments. You need clear rules for that. However, achieving transparency should not mean increasing the operating costs of European entities. It is essential to create framework conditions, both on economic and legal grounds, that will enable and facilitate the recovery of the economy and the creation of new jobs. That was also the aim of the report adopted today. However, I did not support the so-called country-by-country report in the text. In my view, an obligation to report similarly to the OECD rules on the avoidance of tax by large companies (BEPS) should not be subject to 'sectoral' legislation such as this Directive.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that we must ensure better participation of shareholders in the governance of their companies. I firmly believe this will lead to a more sustainable and long-term focus, as well as increased accountability of directors to those who choose to invest. Shareholders should be able to know where their companies make profits and, crucially, where they pay their taxes. In order to have certainty that the company is paying its correct share of tax, shareholders need to understand the health and the prospects of the company they are investing in. For this reason, public ‘country-by-country’ reporting for major international companies would represent an important step forward.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This House has today voted in favour of greater transparency in tax affairs of large companies. The Member States must take heed of this vote and I trust that this will be reflected in the outcome of the trialogue negotiations.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very important file. The objectives of the revision of the Shareholders’ rights directive are to improve stability and to boost long-term investment. The Report introduces country-by-country reporting on taxes paid for large and listed companies. Multinationals would have to break their information down by country of operation so that citizens and operations can see where large companies actually pay their taxes. It is our duty to fight against tax havens and for tax justice.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC to encourage long-term shareholder participation and Directive 2013/34/EU on certain elements of the corporate governance report (COM(2014)0213 - C7-0147/2014-2014/0121(COD)) (in the ordinary legislative procedure - first reading), since the proposed text, to which I have minor objections to some provisions, constitutes a compromise document enabling the continuation of the legislative process, taking into account that at the previous session of the European Parliament the adoption of the document was postponed due to the impossibility of reaching a compromise solution and the risk of its non-adoption. I would like to point out that the Commission's base document is a good basis for further action. The intention of the document is to reinforce the long-term effects in the management of stock companies with regard to insufficient development results of management if it is focused on short-term profits, which is why there is a deficit in good planning and sub-investment in relation to opportunities. This further aims to achieve greater transparency, greater influence in the corporate governance of minority shareholders and institutional investors. The intention is to achieve greater investor involvement and to include them in the long term, which will give companies more priority to the long-term interest.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to promote long-term shareholder engagement and transparency in the governance of European companies. Two main points were voted: - large companies and public interest entities should publish information, by country, related to the revenues made, taxes paid on profits and subsidies received. The publication of these figures will help combat the tax optimization practices of multinationals, a topic that recently made the front page with the LuxLeaks scandal; - MEPs also wanted to empower shareholders to vote on the remuneration policy of company executives. I have decided to vote for this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sergio Gaetano Cofferati's report on long-term shareholder engagement and the corporate governance statement. This report proposes several ways to improve corporate management and governance, such as simplifying shareholder identification, and improving transparency in the activities of institutional investors and asset managers. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Long-Term Shareholder Engagement Directive and the Corporate Governance Statement. Indeed, while transparency is an essential element of the business environment, excessive bureaucracy must not harm the competitiveness of European businesses. It is essential to find a balanced legal framework for job creation and economic growth.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report represents a good compromise on the reward of long-term shareholders. Greater participation rights for shareholders with long-term goals, higher dividends and tax breaks can bring more stability. There is also no objection to greater transparency. Unfortunately, the report has been postponed, but it has my agreement in principle.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 July 2015, we voted on the Sergio Cofferati report on the proposal for a directive amending Directive 2007/36/EC to promote long-term shareholder involvement and Directive 2013/34/EU on certain elements of the corporate governance statement. The revision mainly regulates the management of companies and their administration. In particular, it is intended to increase the incentive for shareholders to participate more voluntarily in companies in which they have invested by buying shares. Discussions on the proposal in the context of the rapporteurs' negotiations have been very complex from the outset. The original draft report was of high quality and contained a number of important provisions for our faction, the importance of which, however, was gradually diminished by the rapporteur during the discussions in order to give thanks mainly to right-wing factions. However, with the help of votes from other smaller factions, we finally managed to vote on key points on the committee, such as, above all, the so-called country by country reporting and the regulation of the remuneration of company bodies. That is why I finally decided to support this report in plenary.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EPP delegation of the Fidesz People's Party, in agreement with the People's Party, stands for the development of the economic environment in the European Union. The aim is to achieve cost-effectiveness and to reduce the administrative burden on enterprises in order to increase competitiveness. Job creation is first and fore most of all the responsibility of companies and not of governments, which requires clear rules, but achieving transparency should not mean increasing the operating costs of European enterprises. It is essential to create framework conditions, both economically and legally, that enable and facilitate the recovery of the economy and the creation of new jobs. That was also the aim of the report adopted today, especially when it comes to remuneration policy and long-term shareholder engagement.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the principle of transparency that large companies publish information on their activities in each country where they operate, as I have supported transparency obligations for the activities of so-called extractive industries and credit institutions. Nevertheless, I, like the entire EPP Group, abstained on the complex scheme as presented in this report, in order not to anticipate the position that the special committee TAXE will take on the specific case of tax information, which is at the heart of its work.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's Parliamentary decision to support the introduction of country-specific reporting obligations for large multinational companies is an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. Country-specific reporting leads to greater transparency in taxes paid by companies and helps to ensure that tax revenues reach the country where the company actually generates income. Especially after the LuxLeaks scandal, it is clear that Europe needs a fairer and more transparent tax system.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Cofferati's report. At the heart of the document is the desire to ensure greater transparency in the activities of companies in order to regain the confidence of the citizens of the Union and to promote shareholder engagement. The approved text contains important instruments for combating tax evasion and avoidance and also provides for the introduction of rules obliging companies to explain how their remuneration policy for directors contributes to the long-term interests of the company.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In this report on shareholder rights, we have succeeded with the left-wing forces in introducing the obligation for multinationals to disclose the taxes they pay in each country. This country-by-country tax return allows us to see where taxes are paid and therefore, theoretically, where profits are made. Therefore, when you see very large disparities in taxes paid or very low taxes compared to the size of the business, it is easy to assume a pattern of transfer or tax evasion.  This country-by-country reporting system will facilitate work to combat tax evasion. That is why I supported this report against the manoeuvres of the right, which first tried to put this aspect back in the way before slowing down its adoption as much as possible.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to promote long-term shareholder engagement and transparency in the governance of European companies. It helps to combat the tax optimization practices of multinationals, a topic that recently made the front page with the LuxLeaks scandal. In addition, it gives shareholders the right to decide on executive compensation. The Council and the European Parliament will engage in a dialogue on this text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. It is a report aimed at improving stability and encouraging long-term investments, encouraging shareholders to be more active and more committed to company results. It also introduces, in order to ensure greater transparency of large companies, the obligation for companies to declare 'country by country' the profits obtained, the taxes paid on profits and the subsidies received. This proposal is part of a legislative design aimed at strengthening business transparency and shareholder rights. The country-by-country return will allow citizens and authorities to know where large companies actually pay their taxes, as they must clarify whether they pay taxes in tax havens or where they conduct their economic activities. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the adoption of a Directive which contains important obligations for shareholders of anonymous undertakings, so that they can be better controlled by the different competent authorities of the Member States. This directive represents a very important step forward in the field of European commercial law by including for the first time the obligations of shareholders in their long-term linkage in the participating undertakings. There are numerous mechanisms by which this Directive will not solve many of the problems relating to the ownership of public limited companies; however, it is an undeniable step forward in imposing obligations on employers. For all this, I've decided to vote for it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal for a Directive, as originally presented, did not include any mechanism for monitoring transparency in relations between European companies and their shareholders. The lack of clarity in the process would inevitably have undermined citizens' confidence in the way business is conducted, in turn damaging the competitiveness of our businesses. Thanks to the final proposal, a series of rules are introduced that facilitate the identification of shareholders, investors, asset managers and voting advisors involved in the process, thus sanctioning the dissemination of information in this regard. It ensures in the same way that the acquired rights of the parties involved are respected and the remuneration of the directors is regulated, all in order to promote a system less opaque and better adapted to the interests of shareholders. For these reasons, I vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Long-term shareholding provides greater stability for companies and encourages them to focus their strategies on long-term financial and non-financial performance. This is why it is necessary to put in place mechanisms to encourage long-term shareholding contained in The Cofferati Representative's Report, so I supported it. Shareholder participation in corporate governance of companies is a lever that can improve the financial and non-financial performance of companies. However, given that shareholder rights are not the only long-term factor to be taken into account in corporate governance, it is imperative that they are accompanied by additional measures to ensure a higher level of participation of all stakeholders, in particular employees, local authorities and civil society.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC on encouraging long-term active shareholder participation and Directive 2013/34/EU on certain elements of the corporate governance statement, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Cofferati report concerns a proposal to revise 2 commercial law directives that regulate corporate governance and, in particular, to encourage shareholders to participate in companies in which they have invested in the long term. The financial crisis has shown that in many cases shareholders have encouraged trustees to take excessive short-term risk, focusing only on short-term returns. The proposed measures are intended to affect around 10 000 European companies with listed shares. Despite the complexity of the negotiations and a number of concessions in order to find a compromise, a number of important positive elements have been included in the report, including the so-called country by country reporting, which should help in the fight against tax evasion, as well as the first efforts to adjust remuneration at European level. That is why I decided to support the report in the final vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report strengthens transparency by creating country-by-country reports, which require companies to provide a list of all shareholders with more than 0.5 % of the company's available shares, or by promoting companies to disclose on their websites the drafts of their general meetings and the results of the votes, which is an important step in combating tax havens and tax evasion. In addition, it includes the need to justify the bonuses paid. All of these are important measures to combat tax evasion and tax havens. So I voted for it.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Sergio Cofferati's legislative project aims to introduce more transparency and encourage longer-term shareholder engagement in the company, by involving them more in the governance of the company. The text provides incentives for executive compensation to be more likely to be linked to the company's long-term performance. It also ensures the protection of the company's interests, and provides for Member States to put in place mechanisms to promote long-term ownership and business sustainability. Finally, the Socialist Group won a major victory by introducing an obligation (country-by-country reporting) for companies to disclose all the activities of their subsidiaries, country by country - including taxes paid, including in tax havens. This is an essential point in detecting and understanding tax optimization manoeuvres in front of citizens, and before states. I therefore voted enthusiastically for this report, which is in line with my political commitment and my parliamentary work in the special committee on tax rulings.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal was supported by me as it generally stands for greater transparency and disclosure of profits of corporations and large companies. Unfortunately, however, it is somewhat vague in some areas.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report states that "in many cases, shareholders favour excessive short-term risk-taking by managers." This behaviour "undermines the long-term financial and non-financial performance of such companies and leads to insufficient levels of investment". To address this, the report proposes to promote long-term shareholder engagement and increase transparency between companies and investors. The intention is laudable but the means used for its implementation are still too weak. The report proposes to publish the turnover rate of asset managers' portfolios, or to take measures that favour long-term shareholders, whose floor is set at 2 years, which is lower than the average turnover rate of pension funds: tax benefits, loyalty bonuses and additional voting rights... It would have been more effective to remove the voting rights of shareholders in the short term. Nevertheless, to encourage awareness of the harmful effects of financialization of the economy I vote for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The overall objective of this proposal to revise the Shareholder Rights Directive is to contribute to the long-term sustainability of EU companies, the creation of an attractive environment for shareholders and the increased exercise of cross-border voting rights by increasing the efficiency of the chain of equity investments to contribute to the growth, job creation and competitiveness of the EU. The proposal also responds to the commitment made in the framework of a renewed strategy for long-term financing of the European economy. It contributes to a more long-term shareholder perspective, which guarantees better operating conditions for listed companies. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as we succeeded in securing assurances that businesses would not be overburdened by the measures proposed by Parliament.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report to approve plans to re-write the EU’s eight-year-old Shareholders’ Rights Directive that would require listed companies to publicly report financial information, including profits and losses, tax payments, and public subsidies received on a country-by-county basis. I believe that shareholders should have the right to vote on the company’s remuneration policy for its directors and that the new rules would be better than what we have now, which should help improve stability and boost long-term investment by encouraging shareholders to be more active and engaged and to steer their focus to long-term performances of companies.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed amendments to certain elements of Directives 2007/36/EC and 2013/34/EU. This can be possible by drafting a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council. The proposal is aimed at the content of this Directive.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2007/36/EC of the European Parliament and the Council lays down requirements for the exercise of certain rights of shareholders associated with voting shares at the general meetings of companies having their head office in a Member State and whose shares are admitted to trading on a regulated market situated or operating in a Member State.  I support that, although the shareholders are not the owners of the companies, which are separate legal entities outside their total control, they have a relevant role in the governance of those companies.   I am voting in favour of this proposal for a Directive, because I argue that greater participation of shareholders in corporate governance is one of the instruments that can contribute to an improvement in both financial and non-financial performance of the latter.  However, given that shareholder rights are not the only factor likely to contribute to long-term accountability in corporate governance, I believe that this factor should be accompanied by additional measures to ensure greater involvement of the different actors involved, in particular workers, local authorities and civil society.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed directive amending directive 2007/36/EC to promote long-term shareholder engagement and the 2013/34/EU directive on certain elements of the Corporate Governance Declaration aims to facilitate long-term shareholder engagement, including identifying shareholders, passing on information and facilitating the exercise of shareholder rights, as well as ensuring transparency in the engagement policies of institutional investors and asset managers, and finally setting certain requirements for directors' compensation and transactions with related parties. Being in favour of long-term shareholder behaviour (through tax incentives or more rights and decision-making powers), I have decided to vote for this report which is a step in the right direction.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour MEPs believe multinationals should pay their fair share. I support EU plans for businesses to publicly report the taxes they pay in each country they operate in. Boosting transparency will help prevent tax dodging.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal for a directive adopted today is undoubtedly to improve financial stability and encourage long-term investment. We believe that greater involvement of shareholders in the governance of companies is one of the levers that can contribute to an improvement in the results, both financial and non-financial, of the latter. Since shareholder rights are not the only long-term factor to be taken into account in the governance of companies, additional measures should be envisaged to ensure greater involvement of all stakeholders, in particular employees, local authorities and civil society.  In order to facilitate the engagement of shareholders in listed companies, they should have the opportunity to know the identity of their shareholders and to communicate directly with them. That is why we are calling for greater transparency both in order to guarantee and improve the identification of shareholders themselves, and in relation to the activities of large companies, and in particular the profits made, the taxes paid on profits and subsidies received, the salaries and compensation of directors, a requirement that is essential for regaining confidence and promoting the commitment of shareholders and citizens of the European Union to companies.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will sustain greater involvement of shareholders in companies’ corporate governance.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I deeply support the initiative to better encourage long-term shareholder engagement in their respective investments. Their rights and influence in businesses and companies need to be properly safeguarded and new ways need to exist to ensure a better engagement of shareholders, at more market levels, in the major decisions of the companies they are invested in. This can only improve competition and development and should be seen as a positive step towards better financial and non-financial performance of companies!

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Writing. The CDU/CSU group in the EPP Group voted against country-by-country reporting in today's vote on Sergio Cofferati's report. In principle, we do not reject country-specific reporting. For example, we welcome the provisions in the Accounting Directive (2013/34/EU) to be evaluated by the EU Commission by 2018, as well as in the Directive on access to the activities of credit institutions and the supervision of credit institutions and investment firms (CRD IV, 2013/36/EU). However, before these provisions are extended to other sectors, we call for a thorough impact assessment by the European Commission. Developments on country-by-country reporting must also be taken into account under the OECD Action Plan against Profit Cuts and Profit Shifting by Multinational Enterprises (BEPS) in order to ensure a level playing field. It is also essential that SMEs and medium-sized enterprises are exempted from additional bureaucratic reporting requirements.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
