text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because it contains useful changes leading to better shareholder position and greater transparency of public limited liability companies. 0 On the contrary, I am disappointed that the report included, in addition to the Commission's initial proposal, public information on company revenues and the publication of tax rulings. To this extent, I consider this to be wrong and I hope that the amendment will not enter into force in this text. Setting up an increase in the transcription of tax rulings and the introduction of CBCR companies must be done in such a way that the objectives of these measures are achieved at a reasonable cost and without jeopardising the competitive position of European firms. It is much more appropriate to deal with this systemically in the tax reports now being prepared by the ECON Committee and the TAXE subcommittee, where I will be happy to support the well-reasoned proposal.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because large companies need to be more transparent about their activities and profits. Transparency in the taxes paid on profits and on the aid received is crucial to ensuring that shareholders and other European citizens have confidence in businesses.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report concerns the amendment of two directives on shareholder participation and corporate governance in the European Union. More concretely, it deals with new shareholder rights and obligations to promote long-term investment, compensation regulation and the fight against short-term speculation. It also aims at a number of measures to ensure greater transparency in the sector. It specifically asks companies to publish their tax obligations in each of the countries in which they operate. This is a major step forward on tax transparency, which is contributing to the fight against tax havens in Europe.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Giving shareholders a more transparent, easily manageable and influential role in corporate governance will help to foster a longer-term perspective on corporate governance. This is essential because at the moment too many companies are overly focused on meeting the demand for large short-term profits and yields. This dynamic leads to long-term planning shortcomings, underinvestment and optimal results.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank Mr Cofferati for his work and support him as it puts a long-term perspective on the management of listed activities not only focusing on shareholders but also on employees, consumers and local communities who play a very important role.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Experience shows that the current management of companies and supervision of their activities is insufficient. The biggest problems occurred in the context of a lack of rapid flow of information towards shareholders and potential investors, as well as control of the work of directors of management and a lack of information and identification of all shareholders.  It is necessary to enable each shareholder to have information on the identity of each shareholder and investor in the company, in particular in the context of a possible loss of profit due to cooperation with the affiliated company, which are also investors in the company. The biggest challenges are the lack of opportunities for the company to identify investors, the lack of timely transfer of information and rights in the investment chain, and price discrimination against cross-border investments. The aim is to ensure that investors have clear, comprehensive and comparable information at their disposal, which, in particular for cross-border investors, removes barriers to participation. There was a need for greater transparency in the operations of listed companies, but also a lack of above all the accumulation of regulations and reporting obligations of all stakeholders, as well as the constant fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance.  With the Directive, we can improve competitiveness and economic growth by creating a stable business environment, reducing administration, reducing taxes, deregulating markets. I supported the continuing negotiations on this issue in order to achieve the best possible solutions.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to promote long-term shareholder engagement and transparency in the governance of European companies. Two main points were voted: large companies and public interest entities should publish information, by country, related to revenues made, taxes paid on profits and subsidies received;  shareholders will be empowered to vote on the remuneration policy of company executives. We voted for those two points. The publication of the figures should help to combat a little better against the tax optimization practices of multinationals, a topic that recently made the front page with the LuxLeaks scandal. The Council and the European Parliament will engage in a dialogue on the text in order to reach agreement on the final version of the legislation. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which is moving in the right direction.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Directive 2007/36/EC of the European Parliament and the Council lays down requirements for the exercise of certain shareholder rights. This Directive should also cover large companies and large groups of companies, whose shares are not listed on a regulated market, as their business also has a major impact. Although they do not own corporations, which are separate legal entities that are not subject to their full control, shareholders play an essential role in managing them.  The financial crisis showed that in many cases shareholders supported management in over-taking short-term risk. A higher level of shareholder participation in corporate governance of companies is one leverage that can improve the financial and non-financial performance of these companies. However, as shareholder rights are not the only long-term factor to be taken into account in corporate governance, they should be accompanied by additional measures to ensure a higher level of participation of all stakeholders, in particular employees, local authorities and civil society.  I therefore support the Report on the proposal for a Directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC to encourage long-term shareholder participation and Directive 2013/34/EU with regard to certain elements of the corporate governance report that underlines this correctly.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support colleague Cofferati's report on the proposal for a directive amending Directive 2007/36/EC to encourage long-term shareholder participation and Directive 2013/34/EU regarding certain elements of the corporate governance report. Within the Commission's broader efforts to modernise the legal framework in relation to European company law, regulation of issues such as shareholder participation in corporate governance, management remuneration policy and distribution of relevant information between company and shareholders has a special place. As long-term shareholding has a positive impact on the stability of companies, disincentives to excess risk and reducing excessive focus on short-term returns, establishing and improving mechanisms that encourage it are in the interest of economic development. It therefore appears that long-term shareholding can contribute to achieving more optimal company performance, while recognising significant differences in the legal frameworks of the different Member States. Adequate participation of all stakeholders, primarily employees, can also increase the quality of company management. The existence of a high level of transparency, including the possibility of establishing shareholder identity and direct communication by listed companies, is a prerequisite for an effective system of shareholding. Particular attention should be paid, however, so as not to place undue burdens on companies' operations.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report by the rapporteur, Sergio Gaethan Cofferati, represents a major shift in the field of business and transparency. I voted in favour of it in particular because it offers solutions in the fight against tax avoidance and evasion. It contains a requirement for large corporations and public interest groups to submit financial reports every year in a country where they are active. I welcome the fact that large companies will thus have to provide the public with information about the number of employees, the size of turnover, profits, subsidies, but mainly the tax paid on profits or losses. I believe that it is this procedure that will help prevent cases like Luxleaks and contribute to a fair distribution of wealth in Europe. Even in the context of the current financial and economically unstable situation in the European Union, it is absolutely obvious that we cannot tolerate the practice of circumventing tax and other laws. I supported with my vote a provision that encourages greater and long-term involvement of shareholders in the management of listed companies. I believe that the long-term involvement of these entities will contribute to a more stable situation on the financial market. At present, investors are often driven by the vision of rapid wealth, but in the long run it does not have such beneficial effects for the economy. I also voted in favour of greater scrutiny of the remuneration of directors. The time has come for sustainability policy to finally play a crucial role in distributing generous remuneration to managers.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the European Parliament has adopted with a very strong majority the report from the social democratic rapporteur Cofferati, which aims, in particular, to promote the role of shareholders in large enterprises. Parliament has sent a clear message that companies and companies listed on the stock exchange should publish all information on profits made, income taxes and public subsidies received in individual countries. In many EU countries, this is still completely untreated and non-transparent. The proposed amendment to the Shareholder Rights Directive also includes proposals to ensure that listed companies are able to identify their shareholders, asset managers and institutional investors, such as pension funds or insurance companies. In the proposal for a directive, we have pushed through the requirement that shareholders be able to vote every three years on a management remuneration policy, which, in my opinion, can have the impact of more responsible and effective behaviour of their managers and their orientation on the long-term prosperity of the business. However, Member States will be able to decide whether this vote will be decisive or merely recommendative. The proposal also includes measures to combat tax evasion and avoidance, mainly related to multinational enterprises, but also to public-interest entities such as insurance companies. They will have to openly report losses, losses and taxes reported in each country where they operate.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The financial crisis has created a need for transparency in financial markets on the part of governments and public opinion. The Commission and Parliament have been very involved in these issues and have called for a number of measures to reform the financial markets and avoid certain excesses.  With this in mind, the European Parliament has adopted the Commission's proposal on long-term shareholder engagement and the declaration on corporate governance. This text stresses greater transparency in the activities of institutional investors, as well as on executive compensation. I voted in favour of the Commission's text.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report requires large companies and public interest entities to disclose information, country by country, on the profits obtained, taxes paid and subsidies received. I voted in favour of this report because this proposed revision aims to ensure greater shareholder involvement in the companies in which they invest and thus contribute to their long-term competitiveness and sustainability. The rules on the identification of shareholders, the transmission of information, the mandatory reporting and the involvement of workers are also strengthened. In addition, Portugal is one of the 15 EU Member States that already requires the disclosure of the remuneration policy of directors. Hence my positive vote.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. After long and bitter negotiations between the political groups and the compromise reached, the European Parliament supported the Cofferati report encouraging the long-term involvement of shareholders in the project of publicly traded companies, rather than speculation. The financial crisis has revealed some deficiencies in corporate governance in publicly traded companies, including insufficient long-term shareholder commitment and a lack of transparency.  Thanks to the struggle of my political group, the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals for Europe, the compromise text adopted today is the right balance between full transparency when there is a real benefit to shareholders and other stakeholders, and the protection of sensitive corporate information, while guaranteeing sufficient leeway on corporate boards.  For the single market to work better, Europe needs simplified rules. We need to provide bosses and entrepreneurs with the opportunity to spend more of their time on running and developing their businesses, rather than on bureaucracy. The text adopted by MEPs this lunchtime goes in this direction.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the financial crisis, loopholes have been detected in the regulation of European companies, in particular the lack of a favourable tax system for long-term investor engagement and a lack of financial transparency. Through a series of proposals, such as the publication of shareholder lists written in English, the report responds in an appropriate way to these problems. If the initial report could lead to a lack of flexibility within companies, I welcome today the adoption of a balanced and coherent text.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. After the Luxleaks case and others, this report represents a good opportunity to introduce transparency in large companies and large economic groups and thereby combat tax evasion and fraud. In addition to greater involvement of shareholders in business life, with a say, for example, on remuneration policy, the report also requires large companies and public interest entities to disclose information, country by country, about the profits obtained, taxes paid and subsidies received. It is therefore clarified, with citizens and competent authorities, whether companies pay the appropriate taxes where they actually carry out their economic activities.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the promotion of long-term shareholder involvement and Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the declaration on corporate governance because it is a very important step in the fight against tax evasion and in favour of the transfer of listed companies.  With this proposal, Europe has a great opportunity to create a fairer and more transparent tax system. Among the novel elements included, it should be noted that large companies have an obligation to declare "country by country reporting" the profits obtained, the taxes paid on profits and the subsidies received. Thus, citizens and authorities will be able to know where large companies actually pay their taxes, as they will have to clarify whether they pay taxes in tax havens or where they carry out their economic activities. The Directive also provides that shareholders of a listed company can vote on the remuneration of their directors, which should reflect their contributions to the long-term interests and results of companies.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. At the July plenary session, the European Parliament voted in favour of a country-by-country tax return for multinationals. I fully supported this measure, which is designed to force multinationals to be more transparent to the general public. Two things seem particularly important to me: 1) Parliament requires large companies to publish once a year a report outlining the following country-by-country information: list and social purpose of all legal entities owned by them, number of workers, turnover, profits (or losses) before tax, taxes paid, public subsidies received; 2) Parliament also requires that these large companies provide once a year the essential elements and information of the tax rulings (which has been much talked about in the wake of the LuxLeaks case), again, country by country. It is now up to the Council of the European Union to position itself, but it cannot ignore a proposal voted with such a large majority (556 in, 67 against and 87 abstentions).

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the shareholder rights report. This text is a real text of progress, to encourage long-term investment and transparency in the management of companies. As part of the major advances, the implementation of country-by-country reporting will enable the detection - finally - of tax optimization manoeuvres! In this time of crisis and tax evasion - I am thinking in particular of the LuxLeaks scandals - this directive is of paramount necessity in order to put an end to the fraudulent schemes of multinationals to the detriment of our citizens and SMEs.  Multinationals will now have to openly declare the taxes paid in each country where they operate - including tax havens - so that citizens and the authorities can see where they actually pay their taxes, despite the temptation of our colleagues on the right of this Chamber to abolish these transparency measures. I the result of the majority obtained to support these measures, which we European socialists and democrats have carried out.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2007/36/EC of the European Parliament and the Council lays down requirements for the exercise of certain rights of shareholders associated with voting shares at the general meetings of companies, which are established in a Member State and whose shares are admitted to trading on a regulated market situated or operating in a Member State. Although they are not the 'owners' of the companies, the shareholders have a relevant role in the governance of these companies. However, the financial crisis has shown that, in many cases, shareholders have supported excessive short-term risk-taking by managers.  For this reason, a greater shareholding of shareholders in corporate governance is one of the instruments that can contribute to an improvement in both financial and non-financial performance of the latter and that is why I agree with this proposal for a revision of Directive 2007/36/EC on the exercise of certain rights of shareholders of listed companies, as I believe that this is also the case to contribute to their long-term sustainability.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Focus on the long-term commitment of shareholders and the corporate governance report, which aims to contribute to the long-term sustainability of EU companies, create favourable conditions for shareholders and improve the cross-border exercise of voting rights, increasing the efficiency of the equity investment chain in order to contribute to eu growth, job creation and competitiveness. The central themes of the text presented are the remuneration of managers, the identification of shareholders and the publication of certain data such as the tax reporting of companies: it is necessary to find the right balance between transparency and industrial secrecy.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. We understand that your result is positive and that its possible effects will be positive. The text tries to deal with tax havens and tax evasion by understanding them as one of the key problems in contemporary capitalism. In addition, it includes a number of positive points, such as the need to justify premiums or the request to establish, in a mandatory manner, the transmission of tax information by companies. At the present stage, the JURI Commission is trying to find the legal keys to the possible development of a tax system in line with contemporary needs. We understand that this report is a step forward in this regard, and that we must continue to delve into the question of tax evasion and how it compromises the social economies of the different countries of the Union.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the adoption of a Directive which contains important obligations for shareholders of anonymous undertakings, so that they can be better controlled by the different competent authorities of the Member States. This directive represents a very important step forward in the field of European commercial law by including for the first time the obligations of shareholders in their long-term linkage in the participating undertakings. There are numerous mechanisms by which this Directive will not solve many of the problems relating to the ownership of public limited companies; however, it is an undeniable step forward in imposing obligations on employers. For all this, I've decided to vote for it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Large enterprises must have a tax conduct consistent with the service provided to them by their employees and by society. There is a disproportion between the ability of a large company to finance and adapt to adverse market conditions and between that which is the capacity of each individual in the same circumstances. It is up to the public authorities to correct this disproportion through the moralization of the behaviors of large companies that, after all, are not amorphosed entity: they are made up of individuals and for individuals. Private initiative should be promoted and rewarded, but proportionate to the creation of jobs and capital gains for the society in which it is part and this principle should be enshrined in the respective regulations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside my fellow Labour MEPs I today backed country-by-country reporting to help end corporate tax dodging, ensuring businesses publically report the taxes they pay in each country they operate in. Multinationals should pay their fair share. This report will help boost transparency and prevent tax dodging.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting. I find it unfortunate that a large number of amendments have been introduced into the text of the document, which are understeering the rights of shareholder groups and, moreover, seeking to introduce burdensome obligations that are contrary to the current set-up of member states' legal systems.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because the approved resolution contains important instruments to combat tax evasion and avoidance. The obligation for large enterprises to disclose, in the financial statements in their countries of operation, information on the amount of profits and losses before tax, tax on profits or losses and public subsidies received is one step to combat tax evasion. With the resolution, we amended the Commission's text to allow the shareholders of listed companies to vote at least every three years on the remuneration policy for directors. It shall be up to each Member State to decide whether the vote of the General Assembly is binding or advisory. This is an important step because the corporate policy on directors' remuneration should be in line with the interests of the company and should set criteria for a fixed and variable component of remuneration, including any bonuses, bonuses and benefits.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission's objective of promoting transparency and greater shareholder participation is, in principle, to be welcomed. The text that has now been adopted in plenary represents a considerable improvement on the report adopted in committee. Particularly positive is the freedom of action granted to Member States, for example.B in relation to the regulatory framework for remuneration policy or in transactions with affiliated companies, and the more flexible exercise of shareholder control, which is to be considered more practicable than a rigid focus on the annual general meeting. Negative is the hasty introduction of a paragraph on country reporting, which, in addition to the actual scope of the directive, includes not only public limited companies but also large companies or companies of public interest. The call for greater involvement of employees and civil society in corporate governance, as well as the need to focus these on unspecified environmental and social policy objectives, also dilute the draft directive aimed at shareholders. It was therefore not possible for me to vote in favour of the draft report. I abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the involvement of shareholders in corporate governance. I agree that they play an important role in corporate governance both in improving companies' financial performance and in increasing transparency.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This proposal contributes to the long-term sustainability of companies in the European Union and creates an attractive framework for company shareholders and contributes to greater efficiency for the purpose of creating new jobs, which is essential for all Member States, especially for the Republic of Croatia where the unemployment rate is 18.4% (April 2015, CBS).  Furthermore, shareholders play an essential role in the management of corporations, and the financial crisis has shown that in many cases shareholders have supported corporate management in excessive risk-taking. We must strive to improve the transparency of companies and their financial and non-financial performance. In addition, a higher level of participation by all stakeholders, such as employees, regional and local authorities and consumers, should be ensured.  The topic of investment of institutional investors is also important here. Institutional investors are often not transparent about investment strategies and a clearer transparency and public disclosure of this information would have a positive impact on investor awareness such as future pensioners and pension system beneficiaries, for example. In total, there are more than 1.1 million beneficiaries of pension systems (HZMO, 01/2015) in the Republic of Croatia, which is more than 25% of the total number of Croatian citizens. A greater level of information and transparency is essential to ensure trust and facilitate the participation of EU shareholders and other citizens in societies, and I therefore support this initiative.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on long-term shareholder participation and the corporate governance statement, which would allow shareholders to vote at least every three years on the rules on the level of salaries and remuneration of directors of a public limited company. Amendments and amendments to the Directive promoting long-term shareholder engagement require large companies operating in the EU to publish information on where they declare their profits and where they pay their taxes. Small and medium-sized enterprises are at a disadvantage compared to multinational companies, which are tax havens. This will also lead to the growth of competition, as there will be known data on where monopoly profits are made, and companies will know which markets are better and safer to invest in.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal, although making key changes to the European Commission's proposal, presents serious legislative gaps, while at the same time the interests of companies remain the guiding factor in decision-making.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EPP delegation of the Fidesz People's Party, in agreement with the People's Party, stands for the development of the economic environment in the European Union. The aim is to achieve cost-effectiveness and to reduce the administrative burden on enterprises in order to increase competitiveness. Job creation is first and fore most of all the responsibility of companies and not of governments, which requires clear rules, but achieving transparency should not mean increasing the operating costs of European enterprises. It is essential to create framework conditions, both economically and legally, that enable and facilitate the recovery of the economy and the creation of new jobs. That was also the aim of the report adopted today, especially when it comes to remuneration policy and long-term shareholder engagement. However, I did not support the so-called country-by-country report contained in the report, as the OECD does not, in my view, have a reporting obligation similar to the rules on tax avoidance (BEPS) of large companies in 'sectoral' legislation such as this Directive.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the promotion of long-term shareholder engagement in Directive 2007/36/EC and the amendment of Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the Corporate Governance Statement. These are essential directives that encourage shareholders to be more involved in long-term planning rather than short-term planning, often resulting in serious damage and underfunding. I approve of the fact that the directive calls for greater transparency on the identity of shareholders in support of this, since direct contact and closer cooperation can only be achieved by identifying shareholders.  I welcome the addition of the additional disclosure requirement that, in the comments of the financial statements, large companies should include relevant data on tax treatment, broken down by Member State and third countries where these large companies have subsidiaries. Another contribution to sustainability is the amendment which requires the issuer to disclose on a consolidated basis annually additional data for the financial year (e.g. turnover, profit before tax, profit or loss tax or state aid received) broken down by country. Its participation in the report is one of the most important achievements achieved by the Socialists. In any case, the amendments aimed at strengthening the exercise of share rights will have a positive impact on the system of capital investments within the Union.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Directive on shareholder engagement and corporate governance statements is another example of the specific process of continuous administrative interference in the Free Market, Competition and Freedom of Establishment observed in the European Union. I believe that this kind of philosophy, which dominates the Community, should be changed. Fortunately, many of the very controversial provisions in the draft directive have been amended or amended in the course of parliamentary work, so I did not vote against this proposal. For the future, however, I would have preferred the European Parliament and the other institutions of the European Union to deal with more important issues that require real intervention rather than interfering with the free operation of companies in a competitive market.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Tax transparency is one of the objectives undertaken, including by this resolution, by the European Parliament. We need to reach a deeper level of integration when we are talking about corporate taxation in Europe. The right principle for international companies to pay taxes where they make a profit can change the tax paradigm in Europe. Reporting at Member State level of profits, subsidies received and taxes paid is essential for increasing the quality of public information available to shareholders of large companies, public authorities and, last but not least, European citizens in areas where corporations operate. Corporate social responsibility must not remain just an expression. It must become a way of operating cross-border businesses operating and making a profit in Europe. I voted for this resolution because I am a supporter of fair taxation in Europe and the elimination of tax fraud and evasion. I am convinced that transparency is a necessary step, but not enough on the road to effective and fair taxation for all EU Member States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of. Currently, too many companies are over-focused on meeting demands for high short-term profits and returns.  In order to solve, at least in part, these problems, we wanted to give minority shareholders, and in particular institutional investors, a more transparent, manageable and influential role in corporate governance. The idea is that if investors become more engaged and more long-term focused on their commitment, companies will give higher priority to long-term concerns. This new direction will in turn benefit the end consumers of institutional investors and asset managers, businesses and society as a whole.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with my agenda on better regulation, I supported the report on long-term shareholder engagement. The report aims at encouraging long-term shareholder engagement as a way to contribute to the long-term sustainability of EU companies, but also to create an attractive environment for shareholders. I am in favour of full transparency and disclosure of information that can be beneficial for shareholders; however, rules we establish should not be too detailed and put a disproportionate burden on businesses. I opposed the provisions on submitting the remuneration policy to a vote and imposing a set ratio between Directors’ pay and employees’ salaries. Such requirements would impose a high administrative burden on the businesses while they are of a minimum benefit for the markets and the shareholders; today shareholders already have the right to ask for this information during the general meeting.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The use of tax dumping by companies in Europe is a burden that threatens the European project and puts Member States in competition. I voted for the Cofferati report because it is an expression of a European political will to combat the abuses of multinationals. There is an urgent need for the European Union to mobilise to put an end to such practices. Companies will now have to report on the activities of their subsidiaries country by country, revealing their turnover, the number of full-time positions, the overall salaries... This is a real step forward: multinationals will no longer be able to hide their profits behind opaque accounts. The left-wing forces of Parliament, and in particular the S and D group, fought for these amendments to be voted on. It is a question of avoiding a new "LuxLeaks", but above all to affirm our European project based on solidarity between countries. On the contrary, the Conservatives of Parliament, in fighting country-by-country reporting, showed which side of the tax struggle they were on. The report also calls for greater transparency and dialogue. This should allow us to get out of the short-term logic of companies.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the LuxLeaks scandal, it is necessary to ensure a very high level of transparency that includes ambitious measures against tax evasion and avoidance. In the meantime, it is important to have defined, thanks to this report, what the long-term orientation of companies and shareholders will be and, above all, to have established the key elements of the management of the company and its corporate governance. For the transparency of the tax strategies of large companies, it is necessary to include the country-by-country reporting requirement for large companies and listed companies and to clarify the activities and taxes paid. In addition, it is essential to ensure a good level of transparency for the commitment of institutional investors and asset managers in the companies in which they invest, ensuring an effective link between the pay of directors and their contribution to the success of the companies entrusted to them in the long term. The fight against tax evasion can and must be done through the use of new tools: the annual reporting for publicly traded companies is one of them.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal on certain elements of the Corporate Governance Statement was published in 2014. The revision of the Shareholder Rights Directive is part of the initiatives envisaged in the European Commission's action plan "European company law and corporate governance - a modern legal framework for better shareholder engagement and sustainable businesses". The most important proposals are shareholder identification, the provision of relevant information between the company and shareholders and the exercise of shareholder rights, transparency provisions for institutional investors, asset managers and proxy advisers, new rules on remuneration for directors, new rules on Related Party Transactions (RPTs) and so on. Since many of our Group's proposals have been taken into account, I supported this proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. We understand that your result is positive and that its possible effects will be positive. The text tries to deal with tax havens and tax evasion by understanding them as one of the key problems in contemporary capitalism. In addition, it includes a number of positive points, such as the need to justify premiums or the request to establish, in a mandatory manner, the transmission of tax information by companies. At the present stage, the JURI Commission is trying to find the legal keys to the possible development of a tax system in line with contemporary needs. We understand that this report is a step forward in this regard, and that we must continue to delve into the question of tax evasion and how it compromises the social economies of the different countries of the Union.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome very much this report that should help to strengthen the capacity of shareholders to keep the boards of corporates accountable. Moreover, the strong position on country-by-country reporting is a step forward in corporate transparency that in my view will help governments to ensure that multinational companies pay taxes in the countries where they make the profits.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. We understand that your result is positive and that its possible effects will be positive. The text tries to deal with tax havens and tax evasion by understanding them as one of the key problems in contemporary capitalism. In addition, it includes a number of positive points, such as the need to justify premiums or the request to establish, in a mandatory manner, the transmission of tax information by companies. At the present stage, the JURI Commission is trying to find the legal keys to the possible development of a tax system in line with contemporary needs. We understand that this report is a step forward in this regard, and that we must continue to delve into the question of tax evasion and how it compromises the social economies of the different countries of the Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which greatly reinforces the obligation to publish certain information, such as a detailed study of tax burdens in each country, which can contribute greatly to the fight against fraud and unfair tax competition.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Involve shareholders more in the management of the company. General meetings should take place on a regular basis. Shareholders should have more rights.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for an EP and Council directive concerning several aspects of corporate governance because it represents an important step towards greater transparency in the governance of European companies. Large firms will have to disclose information, country by country, on profits made, tax paid on profits and public subsidies received. These new provisions will empower shareholders to vote at least every three years on directors’ pay policy and, on a general note, they will foster shareholders’ long-run commitment to companies. The country-by-country reporting principle will oblige multinationals to openly declare the taxes they pay in each country they operate: these are significant instruments to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC as regards the promotion of long-term shareholder involvement and Directive 2013/34/EU as regards certain elements of the declaration on corporate governance because it is a very important step in the fight against tax evasion and in favour of the transfer of listed companies.  With this proposal, Europe has a great opportunity to create a fairer and more transparent tax system. Among the novel elements included, it should be noted that large companies have an obligation to declare "country by country reporting" the profits obtained, the taxes paid on profits and the subsidies received. Thus, citizens and authorities will be able to know where large companies actually pay their taxes, as they will have to clarify whether they pay taxes in tax havens or where they carry out their economic activities. The Directive also provides that shareholders of a listed company can vote on the remuneration of their directors, which should reflect their contributions to the long-term interests and results of companies.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Cofferati report because, although it has significant shortcomings, it introduces two important innovations: the obligation for multinational companies to declare the profits generated and the taxes paid in each country in which they operate, and a system of incentives to promote long-term participation and the social sustainability of companies. However, in negotiations between the groups, the text has been significantly weakened, sacrificing important provisions on corporate governance. In the final text, all references to the involvement of employees and their right to express an opinion on the remuneration policy of managers have disappeared, on which a majority of shareholders can vote, with a non-binding vote. Also eliminated the cap on managers' bonuses and the obligation to disclose information about the relationship between average remuneration of managers and employees.  The directive is even in danger of further watering down by the Member States because of the wide margin of discretion that has been left in the transposition phase.  However, this directive represents an important step forward in combating tax avoidance and short-term finance. I therefore hope that in the implementation phase and, before that, in the negotiation phase with the Council, the Member States will not further undermine its effectiveness.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it entails the adoption of a Directive which contains important obligations for shareholders of anonymous undertakings, so that they can be better controlled by the different competent authorities of the Member States. This directive represents a very important step forward in the field of European commercial law by including for the first time the obligations of shareholders in their long-term linkage in the participating undertakings. There are numerous mechanisms by which this Directive will not solve many of the problems relating to the ownership of public limited companies; however, it is an undeniable step forward in imposing obligations on employers. For all this, I've decided to vote for it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my fellow Socialist MEPs I voted in favour of this report because the inclusion of an amendment enables shareholders to vote at least every three years on a company’s remuneration policy for directors. The policy should say what the criteria are for, fixed and variable remuneration, including all bonuses and benefits. However, after the vote, there is now no specific requirement that the remuneration policy has an upper limit, but the effect is to allow shareholders to create one.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive aims to ensure better shareholder involvement in the company's decisions. It identifies a certain myopia on the part of business administrations that are very focused on short-term profitability, including calling into question the long-term sustainability of companies. However, this directive is paradoxical because it ignores or pretends to ignore the rights of shareholders who want short-term profits, as is also fully identified in the theme of the conflict between the principal and the agent. In this sense, in addition to not guaranteeing the involvement of shareholders to the extent that they are completely pulverised through investment funds, this directive puts the question the other way around. The solution to align business decisions with long-term sustainable management is to engage workers and local actors in strategic business decisions. The Directive places the problem of the salary gap within the company, but once again there is nothing substantial to solve the problem.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal was supported by me as it generally stands for greater transparency and disclosure of profits of corporations and large companies. Unfortunately, however, it is somewhat vague in some areas.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36/EC with a view to promoting the long-term involvement of shareholders and Directive 2013/34/EU with regard to certain elements of the corporate governance statement. The left-wing majority of Parliament has voted in favour of implementing country-specific reporting. This forces companies to include information intended for the tax office in the information to their shareholders and thus to publish it. It is hard to imagine for many these days, but even a publicly traded company is not a public asset, but private property. Country-specific reporting does not help shareholders, but serves the erroneous reflex that companies are committed not to their owners, but to the public. Tax-relevant information may be collected by the tax office – and then owes confidentiality. Anything beyond that permeates private property and does not belong in an economic order that describes itself as a market economy.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted for this Directive because it aims to improve corporate governance in the EU after risky investments led to the financial crisis. The report will make it easier for shareholders to monitor the companies they invest in, and to encourage long-term investment rather than short term risk. It also calls for country-by-country reporting of tax payments, meaning that multinationals would break their information down by country of operation – including tax havens – so that citizens and authorities can see where large companies pay their taxes.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial crisis highlighted the need to reform the internal governance system of listed companies as short-term risk-taking has been identified as a key factor in the current economic crisis and the high rate of share buying and selling. The revision of Directive 2007/36/EC on requirements for the exercise of certain shareholder rights in listed companies therefore aims to improve stability and increase long-term investments, encouraging shareholders of listed companies to be more active and committed and to focus on the long-term performance of the company.  The Cofferati report represents an improvement on the Commission's original proposal and the General Position of the Council, especially as regards the reference to country-by-country reporting on taxes paid; This is a major step towards greater transparency in listed companies in order to avoid cases such as the recent LuxLeaks in the future.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text on the revision of the Shareholders' Rights Directive because I believe that revising these rules can be decisive in increasing long-term investment and restarting the European economy. I particularly welcome the introduction of Country-by-country Reporting on taxation by large companies. Mechanisms must be introduced to ensure absolute transparency of taxation for multinational companies, in the context of the wider battle for the abolition of tax havens. I would remind you that the provision of this mechanism was a priority for us Socialists and Democrats and I regard the CBCR's forecast as a great political victory for my group. In conclusion, I agree with the need for shareholders to be able to express their opinion on the remuneration of managers of listed companies.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is necessary to focus primarily on long-term objectives, which should encourage greater shareholder involvement in the future. It is important to have a dialogue with them on corporate matters. Another equally important aspect is transparency, which I think should concern the activities of larger companies, particularly with regard to profits achieved, income taxes and subsidies received. This form is necessary in order to ensure the trust of shareholders and other companies in the EU business sphere.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report under consideration relates to the amendment of Directives 2007/36/EC and 2013/34/EU, and proposes to improve the functioning of EU financial markets by identifying the following objectives: to increase the level and quality of the involvement of asset owners and managers in their participating companies; create a better link between the remuneration and performance of company directors; increase transparency and oversight by shareholders of transactions with related parties; ensure the reliability and quality of the opinions of voting advisers; cross-border information transmission throughout the investment chain.  We voted in favour of all amendments calling for more transparency, identification of shareholders, better information, the possibility for employees' representatives to have the right to vote on the remuneration policy of directors. We believe that the problems of the financial sector are not due to the diminished involvement of shareholders or the lack of an adequate level of transparency. They are the fruit of the essence and logic of capitalism, of the search for greater profit. On the other hand, any gains that come from the application of the rules now adopted will not serve for a fairer redistribution of the wealth created but rather to increase the fortune of the masters of money. We voted against it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, albeit with some reservations. This report more or less notes that the creation of a system of market stability reserve, i.e. a new emission allowance trading scheme, is due to take place as early as 2019. However, the Czech Republic, which I represent here, as well as the other countries of Visegrad, wanted this date to be two years later, that is, only in 2021. The countries of Visegrad, and thus the Czech Republic, were concerned that this change in the allowances market could, to some extent, weaken, damage industry in the Czech Republic and other Visegrad countries. In the end, compromise is 2019. I supported it because I am aware that some change in the market must have occurred when the current situation is not sustainable in the long term. So I will be watching to see if this change will harm or damage the industry, and I will hope that there will be no damage to the industry.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, the European Union finally decides to improve the greenhouse gas emissions trading system. The period of recession and the allocation of emission allowances have for a long time led to an excess of allowances, resulting in a fall in the price of carbon.  It goes without saying that a low carbon price does not stimulate industry to make its plants more efficient and to avoid the use of polluting fuels, such as coal, and the transition to cleaner energy funds is an obstacle.  The surplus quota will finally be placed in a reserve, the so-called market stability reserve, which will aim to stabilise the carbon market, lead to an increase in the price of carbon and thus push industries to pollute less and invest in more efficient infrastructure and cleaner energy sources.  It would have been preferable to have provided for the introduction of the reserve in 3017, so as to correct the functioning of the market as soon as possible. Considering, however, that the Commission's proposal provided for 2021, the beginning of 2019, as provided for in the agreement, is, after all, a good result. This is an important signal from the European Union, especially in view of the forthcoming Conference in Paris.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur I supported this very important document because, in my view, the market stability mechanism is one of the most important instruments in climate change prevention policy. This will enable greenhouse gas emission reduction targets to be achieved, colleagues. But this mechanism requires serious adjustments. By automatically transferring allowances to the reserve at the time of overproduction and allowing them to be used when production is reduced, it will be possible to give the system some flexibility and avoid costly mistakes. Our vote, colleagues, is very important and sends a positive signal ahead of the December talks on the challenges of climate change in Paris. Thank you!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus dar ndóigh caithfidh mé an-mholadh a thabhairt don rapóirtéir, Ivo Belet, agus a chomhghleacaithe a rinne an-jab teacht ar réiteach ag deireadh an lae. Ní raibh sé ró-fhuirist, ach d’éirigh leo é a dhéanamh; agus glacadh leis sa Pharlaimint.  Maidir leis an dáta, beidh athrú ar an gcóras ETS. Bhí daoine ag rá gur ceart é a dhéanamh chomh luath agus is féidir, agus bhí daoine ag rá nach ceart a dhéanamh go dtí 2021. Is dócha go bhfuil an comhréiteach 2019 sásúil. Déanfaidh sé sin difríocht mhaith, go háirithe nuair a chuimhnímid go bhfuil an cruinniú ollmhór ag teacht suas i bPáras ag deireadh na bliana seo, agus ba chóir go gcabhródh sé linn teacht ar réiteach domhanda. Sin é an focal is tábhachtaí: teacht ar réiteach domhanda maidir le hathrú aeráide. Beidh sé sin an-tábhachtach.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change. The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it is an amendment aimed at make the emissions trading system more effective in the European Union, market mechanisms cannot be the only ones available to reduce business emissions. These market mechanisms are the EU's only proposal for action in this area and have proven to be completely failed, as they allow large polluters to increase pollution and even their speculative benefits. Action in the field of emissions is about strengthening public, binding and coercive measures that make the polluter pay.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission’s so-called ‘cornerstone’ of its climate-change policy, the Emissions Trading Scheme, has been an objective and unmitigated failure. Its aim to promote reductions of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically efficient manner has clearly not been achieved. The surplus of allowances has had a major impact on the carbon price. The intention of the Market Stability Reserve is to reduce the number of allowances in the market if there are too many and introduce new ones in the event of a shortage. It is a vital but insufficient step to improving this deeply flawed scheme. We now need the Commission to come forward with a proposal for a permanent mechanism which will see any unused allowances removed at the end of each trading period.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the establishment and application of a market stability reserve for the EU greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme. Among other things, this is intended to counteract the fall in prices and the current oversupply of allowances. This surplus is currently estimated at two billion. This did not create a strong incentive to invest in low-emission technologies.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Emissions Trading Scheme introduced by the Kyoto Protocol in 1997 has been interpreted as a "right to pollute". It has therefore had the opposite effect to that expected. Carbon dioxide emissions have not decreased, as previous forecasts and modelling have shown. Stateless multinationals take advantage of this system by using their financial power to buy back emission rights from smaller companies. It is therefore small and medium-sized enterprises that suffer the most from this system, while they are not, by far, the most polluting.  A stability reserve, as envisaged in this text, would be only a modest remedy for a system in crisis because of its inefficiency, which, moreover, penalises the industry of the Member States, which is already in difficulty. For all these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the introduction of a Market Stability reserve, and the Emissions Trading Scheme.  Therefore I voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the EU. However, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to a phenomenon: countries that are experiencing a significant relocation of their industries are correspondingly experiencing a reduction in their greenhouse gas emissions. This quota policy should not be organised as an instrument of extermination of our industries and therefore of our jobs.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. This reform aims to reduce the excess emissions allowances and prevent their price depression.  The new system would take effect from 2019. Under the updated rules, if the number of emission allowances on the market were to exceed a certain threshold, some of these allowances would be automatically withdrawn from the market and redirected to reserve. They would be returned to the market in the event that the number of emission allowances on the market would fall sharply to the next limit. The excess emissions allowances, which have accumulated since 2009, are currently around EUR 2 billion. Contrary to what the European Commission has suggested, the market stability reserve will become operational from 2019, not from 2021.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. It is now clear to everyone that the ETS is not working. But rather than question it, the technocrats so dear to Mr Schulz prefer to create a "market stability reserve" in order to compensate for this proven dysfunction. This deviation from the principle of market self-regulation, to which Eurobenates are usually attached, thus appears to be a terrible admission of failure. But for our industries, this solution is akin to creating a new indirect tax. And this will be all the more damaging to them if their non-European competitors are not subject to it. In fact, this system only benefits speculators who unscrupulously use the ecological pretext of reducing CO2 emissions to make pollution a market value like any other.  So it should come as no surprise that high-flying crooks are taking advantage of this flawed system that you have put in place: this is what seems to have done a group of rogue businessmen with a gigantic fraud estimated at more than 5 billion euros.  I of course voted against this report just as I opposed the Tajani report in the ITRE committee.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The rapporteur supports the Commission's proposal to create a market stability reserve, as this is a structural reform that will introduce rules in the Emissions Trading System Directive to govern market fluctuations, including the supply of quotas. The Council had stressed in October 2014 that this would be the main instrument for achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. I approved this report.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE)
text: Written. I am very pleased with the agreement that we have today approved on the market stability reserve for the European CARBON emissions trading system, ETS. The reserve will give new life to the ETS, which is very necessary if we are to give incentives to industry to help reduce our CO2 emissions in Europe and thus become sustainable. The analyses show that the previous reserve start date, which we have now adopted, will make the price trend of CO2 allowances more stable, and this is crucial when industry and the energy sector have to make long-term investment decisions. I am pleased that we have put a thick line , in cooperation with the Member States in the Council, that the sustainability and competitiveness of businesses can go hand in hand. I look forward to being able to share the same constructive and forward-looking approach when we negotiate a comprehensive overhaul of the ETS system in the autumn. Thank you to the rapporteur, Ivo Belet, for the hard work and the excellent result.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, which is to create a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme, was motivated by falling prices on the GHG emission allowance market (the polluting rights of the 1997 Kyoto Protocol).  Forecasts of changes in CO2 prices have therefore been thwarted by the reality of falling prices.  This reserve that we want to create does not fundamentally challenge the system. In addition, it will, of course, favour large companies in polluting sectors, which have the necessary funds to buy back emission rights, to the detriment of mid-sized industries and SMEs.  This report does nothing to resolve the situation and reproduces market failures in this ETS system while making companies less competitive and adding complexity that only large multinationals can understand and finance to pollute more.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Belet report is unclear and contains passages that I consider critical, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change.  The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which amends and improves the Commission's proposal on a market stability reserve, together with the Communication on a climate and energy policy strategy for 2020-2030. The aim of this Commission proposal is to implement a structural reform of the Ets in order to reduce the surplus of allowances accumulated in the system, which is currently more than EUR 2 billion, according to estimates, and to correct its shortcomings in order to achieve the objective of promoting cost-effective and cost-effective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.  While the 2020 greenhouse gas emission reduction target is guaranteed by the overall maximum allowable emissions target, the surplus emission allowances have a negative impact on the long-term cost-effectiveness of this system. Thus, the surplus hinders the proper functioning of the carbon market and has a particularly negative impact on the carbon price, thus reducing the incentive to invest in low-carbon technologies. If no solution is sought, the cost of reducing greenhouse gas emissions will increase significantly in the future.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that the EU ETS encourages low-carbon growth and that the competitiveness of EU sectors that are significantly at risk of carbon leaking is protected. The Conclusions of the European Council on the 2030 climate and energy framework provided clear guidance on the need to maintain the provisions on the free allocation of allowances and carbon leaks after 2020. Building on these strategic guidelines, the Commission should review Directive 2003/87/EC, and in particular Article 10a the following, and propose a revision of that Directive within six months of its adoption.  In order to ensure a level playing field, the review also includes an examination of the harmonised rules for compensating indirect costs at Union level. The review should also consider whether it is appropriate to use up to 50 million une allocated allowances before 2021 to support the projects referred to in Article 10a(8) of that Directive and low-carbon industrial innovation projects, covering all Member States, including small-scale projects. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. At first reading, I supported my colleague Belet's report, which has extensively modified the European Commission document on the establishment and functioning of the market stability reserve in the context of greenhouse gas emissions trading. In particular, in the context of the allocation of free allowances to co2 migration rules, it is necessary to determine what will happen after 2020, when the current CO2 migration regime expires. At this stage, I agree with the rapporteur that there is certainly a need for further discussion on how to improve the allocation of free allowances, especially in view of the changing levels of production.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report and text on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the European Council on the market stability reserve in the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme are a useful step in getting a system adopted by the European Union back on track in 2003. Since the beginning of the economic crisis, the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) has suffered in particular from the beginning of the economic crisis, which has gradually led to an imbalance between supply and demand.  The risks of leaving out such dysfunctions are high, affecting the harmonised and economically effective achievement of the emission reduction system. The amended text has the advantage of intervening on the key points that must ensure the transition to a low-CO2 economy, acting directly on the supply and demand side to ensure the true value of quotas.  This report, which I fully support, must be a way of operating with the overall reform of the ETS that the Commission is about to present. A reform that must combine environmental sustainability, technological innovation and industrial competitiveness.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading System is an ambitiously conceived project that has not proven fully enforceable in practice. It was set up to meet the EU's emission reduction targets in a coherent and cost-effective manner. Nevertheless, at the beginning of the third trading period, the system was characterised by a major imbalance between the supply and demand of allowances, which led to the creation of a surplus of around 2 billion allowances. This number is expected to grow to more than 2.6 billion allowances by 2020 over the coming years. The impact assessment has shown that establishing a market security reserve could help address current imbalances and make ets more resilient, and that's why I support this document.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission’s so-called ‘cornerstone’ of its climate-change policy, the Emissions Trading Scheme, has been an objective and unmitigated failure. Its aim to promote reductions of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically efficient manner has clearly not been achieved. The surplus of allowances has had a major impact on the carbon price. The intention of the Market Stability Reserve is to reduce the number of allowances in the market if there are too many and introduce new ones in the event of a shortage. It is a vital but insufficient step to improving this deeply flawed scheme. We now need the Commission to come forward with a proposal for a permanent mechanism which will see any unused allowances removed at the end of each trading period.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal because I am convinced that the introduction of a market settling reserve in the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading system will allow the system to function better by giving it that flexibility and ability to cope with changes in market conditions or protect the ETS from unforeseen and sudden shocks in demand.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greenhouse gases are a major factor in altering the planet's environmental balance and are the main culprits of climate warming. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions means not only halting pollution, but also preventing the tropicalisation of the climate and containing the impact of natural disasters, with positive consequences for the health and safety of citizens, the environment and economic savings. We must not only reduce emissions of polluting gases (the goal of reducing them by 40% by 2030 is certainly positive, it is an important step on a path towards full environmental sustainability, certainly not the final goal), but also improve electricity networks, integrating them and supporting interventions capable of making them more efficient. The implementation of energy-saving technologies is useful for reducing the union's high energy demands, making consumption more efficient and less expensive for citizens to use electricity.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to Parliament's vote provides for the creation of a market stability reserve for the European Union's Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) in order to address weaknesses in the previous system. The system was designed to set a carbon price high enough to encourage companies to reduce their CO2 emissions in the most cost-effective way. However, the solution proposed by the Commission does not guarantee that the system will work optimally. The price of carbon remains too low for large companies in the most polluting sectors that have sufficient financial resources to buy these emission rights, while SMEs and PMIs do not. The changes made by the text are derisory and do not address the heart of the problem. That is why I voted against this project.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Structural imbalances in the European carbon market have imposed the need for demand and supply correction measures because, without prompt intervention, these imbalances will continue and deepen in the medium or long term. The revision of the Emissions Trading Scheme to reduce the accumulated surplus to date involves a set of rules to rectify the deficiencies of emission allowances and to create a more fluid framework for their trading. The Union must continue its carbon reduction policy contained in the 2020 Strategy. I was in favour of this report because I am convinced that emission allowances are the main tool for achieving the 30% carbon reduction targets by 2020.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This is the definitive elimination of emission allowances already set aside (see back-loading) in order to cause an artificial increase in the price of the quota, which is considered too low. The Commission's blind belief in the self-balancing capacity of the market is well known. It is therefore rather strange that it considers the ETS to be the only market which is not naturally optimal and resilient, presumably as a result of the particularly artificial and ideological essence of this same market.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Aim of the European Emissions Trading System is to reduce carbon emissions in the EU in an economically efficient way. This should enable the European Union to meet the criteria of the Kyoto Protocol. However, the system has shown its limitations. It was time to reform it so that it could achieve its ambitious goals. The introduction of a market stability reserve will reduce supply-demand imbalances and leave more flexibility in the quota market. Investors will then start investing in low-carbon technologies again, resulting in lower greenhouse gas emissions in the EU. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission’s so-called ‘cornerstone’ of its climate-change policy, the Emissions Trading Scheme, has been an objective and unmitigated failure. Its aim to promote reductions of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically efficient manner has clearly not been achieved. The surplus of allowances has had a major impact on the carbon price. The intention of the Market Stability Reserve is to reduce the number of allowances in the market if there are too many and introduce new ones in the event of a shortage. It is a vital but insufficient step to improving this deeply flawed scheme. We now need the Commission to come forward with a proposal for a permanent mechanism which will see any unused allowances removed at the end of each trading period.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the introduction of a Market Stability reserve, and the Emissions Trading Scheme. Therefore I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report, which includes the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on a far-reaching reform of the European Emissions Trading System (ETS). An automatic correction mechanism (Market Stability Reserve or MSR) that will enable the ETS to function much more effectively will start operating in 2019. This reform puts Europe on the right track to achieving its ambition of 40% less CO2 emissions by 2030 and in a leading position for the upcoming Climate Conference (COP21) to propose concrete plans to reach the 2030 climate targets. On the other hand, we need to ensure that the upcoming Commission proposals include sufficient guarantees that energy-intensive industries in steel, chemicals, glass, etc. do not delocalise their production facilities to countries outside the EU that have less stringent climate policies (‘carbon leakage’). This will be a crucial element in the next step of the ETS reform.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure compliance with the obligations to reduce climate-changing gas emissions under the Kyoto Protocol, the EU has created an emissions credit trading market through the Emission Trading Scheme (Directive 2003/87/EC).  The very idea that the price of gas emissions can be entrusted to the laws of the market is wrong. Moreover, to date, the main beneficiaries of this market – treated like any other market – have been stock market speculators, large banking groups, financial companies and insurance companies. Then, no measures were included in the text that we had proposed in order to increase the price of CO2 quickly, so as to potentially speed up the stimulation of innovation in the energy sector. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report because it does not draw the consequences of the failure of the "right to pollute" promoted by the Kyoto Protocol. The report encourages the creation of a stability reserve following falling prices on the greenhouse gas emission quota market.
