The target, which was a downward regulation of carbon dioxide emissions, missed its target, and the market stability reserve fails to transform this system. On the other hand, the larger companies, the most polluting, have proven to be able to afford the buyback of emission rights, with mid-sized companies being in fact the most upset by these measures. The failure of the ETS system, which reproduces market failures and aligns with the objectives of financialization of the environmental sector, has therefore led me to reject this text.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Rightly, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme, it asks the Commission to resubmit a proposal if it intends to make significant amendments or replace it with a new text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of Parliament and the Council on the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve in the EU greenhouse gas emission allowance trading system (ETS). On 22 January 2014, the Commission presented a proposal for a market stability reserve, together with a communication on the framework for energy and climate policies in the period 2020 to 2030. The Commission's proposal aims to make structural changes to the Emissions Trading System (ETS) in order to cope with the currently estimated surplus of more than 2 billion allowances and to remedy the system's shortcomings so that it can achieve the objective of greenhouse gas emission reductions in accordance with cost-effective and cost-effective criteria. , as required by the ETS Directive. As the surplus quotas are detrimental to the long-term effectiveness of the system, action is needed to correct the shortcomings of the ETS.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision because I believe that the agreement reached with the Council is an appropriate and balanced agreement. In order to achieve the objectives set for a real reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, the Emissions Trading System (ETS) needs to be made more effective.  Unfortunately, the surplus allowance jeopardises the effectiveness of this system in the long term, making the trading mechanism obsolete and therefore an effective reduction in emissions. Moreover, the lack of flexibility in the supply side of quotas does not, at this time, adequately address market fluctuations and unforeseen demand-side shocks.  The aim of this proposal is therefore to correct the mistakes that have been made in the construction of this trading system. Introducing a market settling reserve will therefore make it possible to guarantee industry a more stable and predictable market where fluctuations in supply will be regulated by appropriate rules.   For all these reasons, I welcome this proposal because I believe it is important to insist and try to improve a European system for regulating emissions that is efficient and at the same time guarantees companies to be competitive on the market.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The reform of the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change by addressing the imbalance between supply and demand for allowances, an imbalance that undermines incentives for investment in green innovation. The surplus allowances are estimated at 2 billion, which undermines the cost-effectiveness of the long-term scheme, so that the ETS does not work as originally envisaged, and the Commission has (and very well) proposed a market stabilisation reserve introducing rules in the RELE Directive to govern market fluctuations and the offer of allowances. Oversupply would reduce incentives for green investments and the effectiveness of the EU ETS in combating climate change. I therefore support the Belet Report, which reflects the compromise reached with the Member States after three trilogues, providing that if the surplus reaches a certain value, licences are withdrawn from the market and placed in a reserve to avoid imbalances, promoting the need for operators to invest in reducing CO2 emissions, a mechanism to start as early as 2019, rather than the proposed date of 2021.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. There was an urgent need to strengthen EU emissions trading. I therefore voted in favour of the establishment and application of a market stability reserve for the EU greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme. The introduction of the market stability mechanism on 1 January 2019 is intended to counteract the fall in prices and the oversupply of emission allowances. Investments in climate-friendly technologies should thus be worthwhile again in the future. The decision also prevents the brain drain from emigrating to regions outside the EU with less stringent environmental standards, as energy-intensive state-of-the-art companies are protected and receive free allowances. This is an important approach to preserving Europe as an industrial location.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ETS is the main instrument for reducing greenhouse gas emissions according to cost-effective and cost-effective criteria. However, the current surplus of quotas is detrimental to the long-term effectiveness of the system, undermining its proper functioning and significantly increasing the price of carbon.  From this point of view, the proposal for a market stability reserve, correcting a structural deficiency of the ETS, would guarantee the industry a medium- to long-term perspective. Therefore, on the basis of these considerations, I wished to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The fact that the Commission’s intention is to make structural changes which will in turn address the surplus of emission allowances is positive. The Commission also sets out to rectify the shortcomings which prevented it from achieving its purpose ‘to promote reductions of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically efficient manner,’ this too is a positive step forward in itself. It is positive to see the Commission responding to the calls made by the EP to correct the failed measures of the ETS and to allow it to function as originally envisaged. The proposal to also have rules which govern the fluctuations of the market as well as supply of allowances is a step in the right direction. This will improve the medium to long-term predictability of the industry. It is important that reform enables us to reach our CO2 emission reduction targets.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The M5S challenged the idea that the price of climate gas emissions could be entrusted to market laws. Stock market speculators, large banking groups, financial companies and insurance companies have profited. In addition, there is the risk of the carbon market being exposed to tax fraud such as that which has led to evasion by European taxpayers of at least EUR 5 billion.  Our amendments aimed at ending the ETS by 2020 have not passed. We supported the amendments suggested by environmental NGOs with the aim of limiting the activation of the reserve mechanisms with a narrower range; increase from 100m to 50M the dimensions to be moved from/to the reserve; cancel the 900M of quotas blocked by backloading ahead of the entry into force of the reserve in 2017. These measures would have made it possible to create a higher CO2 price quickly by speeding up the stimulation of innovation in reducing emissions. Despite the fact that the amendments aimed at the advance date of the start-up date and the cancellation of part of the surplus quotas were passed in the ENVI Committee by a majority, the final text does not take this into account. None of the points supported by our amendments have been incorporated into the agreement, and for these reasons I am voting against it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it is an amendment aimed at make the emissions trading system more effective in the European Union, market mechanisms cannot be the only ones available to reduce business emissions. These market mechanisms are the EU's only proposal for action in this area and have proven to be completely failed, as they allow large polluters to increase pollution and even their speculative benefits. Action in the field of emissions is about strengthening public, binding and coercive measures that make the polluter pay.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the MSR mechanism because I believe that this can help in re-balancing the ETS. It is a fact that the EU-ETS needs fixing urgently. I want to see stability and predictability in the ETS. Stability is crucial so that the proper investments that can ensure sustainable economic growth can be carried out. Moreover today’s vote sends also a strong signal toward climate negotiations that are to take place during the COP 21 this year in Paris in December.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the price of the certificate will have an effect on most industrial sectors in some Member States that do not have all of the high-performance and carbon-efficient technologies. In such a situation, for compliance, operators will have to buy certificates from the market, since the allocation for the period 2013-2020 was calculated on the basis of benchmarks established by the European Commission on the basis of the best performing 10% carbon emissions installations at EU level in the period 2007-2008.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to establish a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. With the entry into force in 2019, such a scheme aims to stop the fall in the price of a tonne of carbon and to introduce elements of flexibility in a market defined by a rigid offer. I had advocated an entry into force in 2021 to give the industry time to get used to the idea that licences frozen during the last term of office should not be cancelled but placed on the reserve as soon as it was put in place. I also defended the idea of an innovation fund, which was included in the final agreement for up to 50 million permits before the launch of a new fund in 2021. Finally, the question of the competitiveness of European companies in the globalised market and carbon leakage have been raised and will be addressed in the revision of the ETS Directive before the end of 2015. Fully supporting the agreement reached with the Council, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union has established an Emissions Trading System (ETS) to reduce carbon emissions while taking economic realities into account. However, this system suffers from a surplus of "rights to pollute", which weighs down the price of carbon and discourages investment in green energy. Thanks to this vote, the functioning of the ETS will be reformed from 2019: in order to reduce the total supply of quotas, the surplus will be placed in a reserve of market stability. The European Union is thus showing its determination to achieve its environmental objectives in the run-up to the 21st Conference of the Parties on Climate in Paris.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Market Stability Reserve compromise because I believe the ETS system did not deliver what it was expected to do. Carbon prices are too low and do not offer a sufficient incentive for companies to invest in more carbon-efficient techniques. At the same time we have to prevent carbon leakage by safeguarding companies that are price takers on the global markets from additional costs. The innovation fund should also support companies in making the move to more carbon-efficient technologies.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 22 January 2014, the European Commission presented a proposal for a market stability reserve for energy and climate policies in the period 2020-2030. The Commission's text aims to make structural changes to the ETS trading system in order to cope with the surplus emission allowances and to remedy the shortcomings of the system so that reductions in greenhouse gas emissions can be achieved. The Commission's proposal responds to the european Parliament's invitation, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament on Wednesday approved a reform of the European CO2 emissions allowance system (ETS). An automatic market stability reserve is expected to support the price of emission rights from 2019. This will allow a portion of the quotas to be automatically withdrawn from the market and placed in a reserve fund if the surplus exceeds a certain threshold.   This amendment to the 2003/87/EC Directive will make it easier to regulate one of the pillars of our climate policy and to more easily meet our targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. However, it will be essential to monitor the application of these rules, particularly by the industries that consume the largest energy.  This reform is also a signal given by Europe to its international partners ahead of the COP 21 conference to be held at the end of the year in Paris. We call for an ambitious agreement on environmental preservation and global climate change.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the proposed decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the creation and operation of a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. Beyond its inadequacy, this stability reserve favours large industrial groups, which are the only ones with the financial capacity to buy back emission rights. As is often the case, this report consists of creating financial instruments whose effects have not been previously measured. Therefore, it is a matter of being responsible and voting against this report, which builds much more on appearances than on any substantive change.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on a market stability reserve to the EU Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading System for a number of reasons. Although I am a supporter of the idea of reducing greenhouse gases, this report promotes concepts for the unification of standards for all Member States, without taking into account the specifics of some countries such as Bulgaria. As a result of the adoption of this report, we may find ourselves in a situation where our country may be subject to sanctions because of the EU's difficult requirements. Unlike the countries of Western Europe, Bulgaria, as well as countries such as Romania, Poland and the Czech Republic do not have as much experience in greenhouse gas trade. For this reason, the above mentioned parties also reject the idea that the stability reserve should become operational earlier than 2021. However, with this change in the start date, Bulgaria and a number of other countries will not be able to meet the requirements in time for the full functioning of the reserve to begin. It is for this reason that I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, which, as above, concerns the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme, as it does not create a coherent and compact environmental protection grid for this activity.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome an agreement that takes into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies , such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it neglects the real tools to fight global warming.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is another demonstration of the rotund and glamorous failure of the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading System (ETS) (GHG), in view of the objectives set out. Since its inception in 2005, it has failed to reduce GHG emissions or boost any energy paradigm transition, quite the contrary, it has proved ineffective and perverse. It was clear during the debate that carbon market supporters – those who, in the face of their failure, now want to introduce a few patches – have no answer to simple questions, such as the absence of examples of structural changes, significant from an environmental point of view, achieved using market instruments such as emissions trading. That would therefore be the opportunity to change approach – from a market approach to a regulatory, environmentally and socially-effective approach and environmentally effective – instead of putting patches on worn cloth. What's left is born, late or never straightened out. There will be those who win with this path. It won't be the environment. Let us remember, for example, the enormous permeability to fraud already demonstrated by the ETS (ThyssenKrupp and Salzgitter cases, among others) and the fabulous profits achieved by some of the biggest polluters.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to make structural changes to the emissions trading system, which would address the excess emission allowances, currently estimated at more than EUR 2 billion, and thus support the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically advantageous manner. With its proposal, the European Commission thus accepted the European Parliament's call to remedy the shortcomings of the ETS, in particular its inflexibility in the supply of allowances necessary to adapt to changes in market conditions or to protect the ETS against unexpected shocks in demand.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report dealing with the definitive elimination of emission allowances (already set aside) in order to cause an artificial increase in the price of the quota, which is considered too low. Given the belief in the market that the EU follows on a daily basis, dissociation in this area is not understood.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report on the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme, because it does not create a coherent and compact environmental protection grid for this activity.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Emissions Trading System needs urgently be fixed in order to address the surplus of emission allowances which has been building up in recent years. The economic crisis and the over-allocation of allowances have led to a significant destabilisation of the system. Through the adoption of this report, we will promote low-carbon industrial innovation projects, we will compensate for indirect costs at Union level, and we will have addressed the concerns of the industry. I strongly support the creation of the market stability reserve, since I believe it will send a strong signal to the markets and already begin to influence long-term investment decisions, avoiding costly mistakes and technology lock-in.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report because I find the importance of a well-functioning and stable EU ETS to be key. I welcome the ambition of the scheme to fulfil its objective of 'encouraging cost-effective and economically effective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions'. This is also the aim of the report adopted today for stability and sustainable emissions trading. I consider it of the utmost importance to address the surplus of allowances and to eliminate the shortcomings of the system with a view to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 and achieving long-term cost-effectiveness.  Furthermore, in agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that there is a need for further debate on improving the allocation of free allowances so that the most efficient installations do not have to bear unjustified CO2 costs, as this would lead to carbon leaks.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change. The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change. The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Mr Belet's report on the proposal for a decision of Parliament and the Council on the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve in the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. The goal of reducing carbon dioxide emissions is one of the main challenges for the Europe of the future, for a Europe that acts as a guide in climate negotiations and is a leader in environmental protection. I therefore agree with the idea of remedying the dysfunctions of the ETS system by setting up a market-stabilizing reserve, which will address the imbalance between supply and demand for emission allowances, incorporating surplus allowances, which currently amount to around EUR 2 billion. Thanks to the efforts of the Socialist Group, the instrument will enter into force in 2019, two years earlier than foreseen in the Commission's proposal, and there is a commitment to review the entire ETS legislation in the light of the Outcome of Paris. In the meantime, the new system will ensure that flexibility in allocating the necessary quotas to European industry.  I also welcome the launch of initiatives to stimulate new low-carbon technologies and innovative industrial processes.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the Market Stability Reserve for the EU greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme. Europe has made global advance payments with emissions trading. But that also means that we must be prepared to develop this instrument.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Belet report given the system for trading greenhouse gas emissions (ETS) needs fixing urgently following the severe destabilisation caused by the economic crisis and the over-allocation of allowances. I believe the Market Stability Reserve will send a strong signal to the markets and is vital for  influencing long-term investment decisions, avoiding costly mistakes and technology lock-in.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the creation of a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme.  This polluting emissions market was established by the Kyoto Protocol in 1997. It was in fact interpreted as a "right to pollute" and had the opposite effect to that expected. Again, hell is paved with good intentions. A CO2 market has been created from scratch, based on no reality, on the satisfaction of any need and has therefore experienced a price crisis that makes it ineffective. The reductions in emissions in Europe in recent years are mainly due to the economic crisis and the relocation of the most polluting industries to countries less concerned with the environment and the health of their populations.  Faced with the failure of this false carbon market, the measures envisaged in this text are merely a palliative to an incoherent system producing elsewhere what is consumed here, casting a modest veil on the social and environmental conditions of production. "Buy this pollution that I can't see" is not a responsible posture.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the ETS and the setting of a 'reliable price' for carbon, as we understand that carbon favours the oil and gas industry in the long term. Fossil fuel-dependent companies use the existence of the ETS as an argument for the elimination of EU energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. However, the European Union's emissions trading scheme aims to prolong dependence on fossil fuels and to expand and strengthen the role financial markets play in people's daily lives. These fossil energy sources not only generate a considerable volume of un quantified emissions, but also have significant negative impacts on the environment, social aspects and health.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the current EU Emissions Trading Scheme is flawed and fails to address to problem of oversupply of carbon allowances in the market which enable industry to emit greenhouse gases. It is crucial we take action to repair the ETS and turn it into a mechanism that controls emissions and promotes investments in clean technologies. I believe the Market Stability Reserve is the right instrument to achieve stability in the market and I fully support its introduction as soon as possible. By transferring allowances to the MSR in times of oversupply and releasing them in times of undersupply, the EU ETS will be more flexible and more stable and therefore better placed to achieve our climate goals. We must have a balanced system that will benefit our industries and enable a transition to a sustainable and green economy in Europe which will provide a model to other countries worldwide. We, as Europeans, owe this to our citizens, our industries and future generations.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The creation of a ETS stability reserve encourages both companies to invest in low-PRODUCTION CO2 technologies and at the same time allows them to remain competitive on the international stage. This structural change was necessary to give investors visibility. This reserve as proposed takes into account the concerns of sectors exposed to CO2 leakage. Indeed, the competitiveness of our industries, which are already making considerable efforts, cannot be undermined. Some companies have halved their CO2 emissions in 30 years, but the potential for reduction in the next 30 years is not as great. I therefore prefer to combine ambition and pragmatism to encourage our industrialists to enter a virtuous circle of innovation and competitiveness, and thus to maintain our jobs in Europe.  Finally, I welcome the Commission's commitment to create an innovation fund of at least EUR 50 million, which is funded by the auctioning of emission allowances. This is a concrete way to support the technologies of the future!

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change. The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report for the establishment of a Market Stability Reserve (MSR) for the EU greenhouse gas emission trading system. The setting up of the Market Stability Reserve in the EU emissions trading system will help put the EU’s climate policies back on track. It is needed to address the surplus of emission allowances that have built up over the years, and which will remain in the system for decades unless we take steps to correct this. The MSR will act as an objective mechanism which will be triggered if a surplus of more than 833 million allowances is reached and 12% of the allowances (100 million) will then be set aside. Conversely, if the liquidity on the market falls below 400 million allowances, 100 million allowances will be released from the reserve into the market. Parliament calls for a much earlier establishment and operation of the MSR by 2019 compared to the Commission’s 2021, and I think this is the right approach.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Yesterday we voted on the Market Stability Reserve for the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading system. The European Commission has proposed to reform the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) by introducing a Market Stability Reserve (MSR) from 2021. The MSR allows the Commission to issue or deny additional CO2 allowances in order to protect the EU Emissions Trading Scheme from cyclical fluctuations and to cancel the oversupply of allowances that have accumulated in recent years. However, European industries have sounded the alarm by pointing out the competitiveness, the deindustrialisation of Europe and the impact of the Ukrainian crisis, which is focusing attention on energy security. However, in October 2014, EU leaders reached an agreement on the 2030 climate and energy package. They are strongly in favour of the Commission's proposal on MSR and that additional CO2 allowances be issued beyond 2020 for the industrial sectors particularly affected by the carbon leakage. The report includes the following compromises: (i) entry into force in 2019; (ii) Carbon leakage: the Commission should draw up a proposal; and (iii) Innovation Fund: An additional fund to support breakthrough technologies will be set up. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today’s vote marks an important step in rebalancing Europe’s carbon market.  Nevertheless, more work need to be done, and I await with interest the Commission’s proposals for revising the ETS market post-2020.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the ETS and the setting of a 'reliable price' for carbon, as we understand that carbon favours the oil and gas industry in the long term. Fossil fuel-dependent companies use the existence of the ETS as an argument for the elimination of EU energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. However, the European Union's emissions trading scheme aims to prolong dependence on fossil fuels and to expand and strengthen the role financial markets play in people's daily lives. These fossil energy sources not only generate a considerable volume of un quantified emissions, but also have significant negative impacts on the environment, social aspects and health.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote in favour of a reformed and properly functioning Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) with the aim of further reducing greenhouse gas emissions; this is an important tool to combat environmental change and CO2 emissions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment and functioning of the Market Stability Reserve for the Union Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading System and on the amendment of Directive 2003/87/EC, as such a report would contribute to the effective reform of the Emissions Trading System (ETS), which is necessary to achieve the Union's greenhouse gas reduction target. The system should act as an orderly market with stable and competitive prices, and reflect the true value of allowances, which is currently not the case and this needs to change. I voted for this Report in order to adopt further measures to strengthen the ETS as early as possible and move towards increasing its effectiveness.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the proposed decision by Parliament and the Council on the creation of a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme.  The emissions trading system introduced by the Kyoto Protocol in 1997 was in fact interpreted as a "right to pollute" and therefore had the opposite effect to that expected. Carbon dioxide emissions have not decreased as previously anticipated. As a result, larger firms benefit from this system because they have the cash to buy back emission rights from smaller companies. It is therefore small and medium-sized enterprises that suffer the most from this system, while they are not, by far, the most polluting.  A stability reserve, as envisaged in this text, would be only a modest remedy to a system in crisis because of its inefficiency which further penalizes our industry, already in difficulty.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ivo Belet's report on the market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. The Emissions Trading Scheme encourages EU countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by offering to sell them to other countries with lower quotas. However, the unusually low price of Carbonne (7 euros per tonne) no longer made these quotas attractive. A reserve has therefore been created to reduce the auctioning of these quotas and thus to increase the price.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) aims to prolong dependence on fossil fuels and to expand and strengthen the role of financial markets.  The EU ETS is not intended to issue a 'price signal' capable of influencing long-term investments, as even the most insignificant price signal will be immediately dampened by aid. This is the case with the new State aid rules which allow Member States to reimburse the most polluting undertakings for increases in energy costs arising from the possibility of acquiring emissions duties at auction under Phase III of the ETS. In addition, the new reform proposals that allow new sources of funding for extractive industries are another step backwards. Instead of investing more time in trying to reform the ETS, the European Parliament should focus on phase out fossil fuels and adopting effective policies in the areas of energy, finance and trade capable of dealing with climate change. For this reason, EH Bildu abstained in the ETS vote.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the creation and operation of a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. The creation of a market stability reserve will, on the one hand, support the price of carbon per tonne and, on the other hand, promote innovation in the field of energy efficiency as well as help energy-intensive companies, in particular to avoid relocation to regions less environmentally demanding. Moreover, this reform of the quota system puts the European Union at the forefront of the Paris Climate Conference and the 2030 climate targets.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although I am in favour of a market stability reserve, it is not sustainable for me in this form. On the one hand, the second part of the major ETS reform – the measures relating to the relocation of CO2 emissions – is still unclear, and on the other hand, the position in the current report is not conducive to Europe as an industrial location. That is why I am voting against the report.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Market Stability reserve is considered to be a correction mechanism to the emissions trading system (ETS) with regard to the surplus of allowances. The surplus is an obstacle to a balanced carbon market functioning undermining thus investment in low carbon technologies. As the main aim of the ETS Directive is to promote reductions of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically efficient manner, it should be further supported. The report unfortunately does not provide a clear and detailed framework for longer term solutions, however I have voted in favour with a view of supporting the ETS implementation as a tool for avoidance of a further increase of CO2 emissions.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I understand the uneasiness that many feel regarding the market-based mechanism of ETS. I would also personally prefer a straightforward carbon tax, if we were to build a completely new system from scratch. However, the ETS has been the main instrument of European climate policy for ten years, and it is widely accepted within the industry. The EU emissions trading system is the largest ETS programme in the world, and, although it has structural shortcomings, we have been reaching our targets of reducing our greenhouse gas emissions so far. Now the question is how to fix the system so that it will function efficiently also in the future. I would rather fix the way the system works and keep up the good work to push for really ambitious 2030, 2040 and 2050 targets. The modifications, as adopted in the trilogue with the key contribution of the EC, could help the ETS implementation to prevent increasing CO2 emissions and the misuse of allowances by Member States.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Ivo Belet, and all my fellow Members who have worked hard to achieve a great result on such a sensitive issue. The Market Stability Reserve is an efficient tool that will help us stabilise the Emissions Trading System (ETS) and thus save the pillar of European climate and energy policy.  The agreement reached will allow us to put Europe back on pace in achieving the ambitious CO2 emission reduction targets we have set ourselves (40% less by 2030). The new legislation is satisfactory to all parties involved in the negotiations, and this has been achieved through balancing the protection of climate prerogatives with the competitiveness of our businesses, focusing on innovation and efficiency.  The reform confirms the European Union as the main player in the fight against climate change, with concrete facts to be presented in the run-up to the next COP 21 in Paris, and we hope that an ambitious agreement will be reached.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the creation and operation of a market stability reserve for the greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. This stability reserve is motivated by the fall in prices on the market for GHG emission allowances, polluting rights promoted by the Kyoto Protocol, causing the opposite of the expected effect, namely downward regulation of carbon dioxide emissions. Forecasts and forward-looking models of the evolution of carbon prices in eligible sectors have therefore been thwarted by reality.  The market stability reserve is therefore a palliative that does not fundamentally transform the system, reproduces market failures, pursues the objectives of financialisation of the economic and environmental sectors, and helps to make Member States' industries less competitive.  It also turns out that large companies in the most polluting sectors are doing well with the financial base for the purchase of emission rights. The allocation of quotas thus plays against mid-sized industries.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme will not solve the problem. Its original objective has not been met, namely a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions. Added to this is the fact that it does not have the ability to force major polluters (some large industries) to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions because of their financial capacity to buy back emissions. This text accentuates the financialization of the environment, which is not a desirable way.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission presented a Decision implementing a reserve fund to stabilise the European emission allowance market by easing the supply of allowances based on changes in market conditions, the thus protecting the ETS from unexpected and abrupt disruptions in demand. The report establishes a solidarity clause (the possibility of exchanging or transferring up to 10% of rights between Member States) until the end of 2025 as an aid measure for countries with lower GDP. The basis for the creation, in the new revision of the ETS (2021), of an innovation "fund" for which a limited number of rights will be allocated to the promotion of low-carbon, CCS, renewable or industrial innovation technologies. A amount equivalent to 50 million rights is proposed. Reinforced measures should also be included to prevent carbon leakage and promote competitiveness and employment. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it is an amendment aimed at make the emissions trading system more effective in the European Union, market mechanisms cannot be the only ones available to reduce business emissions. These market mechanisms are the EU's only proposal for action in this area and have proven to be completely failed, as they allow large polluters to increase pollution and even their speculative benefits. Action in the field of emissions is about strengthening public, binding and coercive measures that make the polluter pay.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The integration of a market stability reserve offers a range of structural reforms to strengthen the existing Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS). To name a few of the changes, some of the emission allowances will begin to be reinvested in a new Innovation Fund, which will promote the industry's transition to the use of low-carbon technologies. It will also include a monitoring mechanism for the operation of the reserve which will assess at three years its contribution to job creation, carbon leakage prevention and the Union's industrial competitiveness.  Reform of the regime makes it possible to move towards a less ambiguous and more sustainable system, and I therefore vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by MeP Ivo Belet aimed at correcting the shortcomings of the greenhouse gas emissions trading system with a view to promoting emissions reductions in a financially and economicly efficient manner. The purpose of the amendments, i.e. to establish reserves for the emissions market, is to ensure market stability and emissions reductions by 2020.  The current imbalance in the market is due to the mismatch between the supply of allowances fixed due to the nature of the EU ETS, and the other side of the demand for them, which depends primarily on economic cycles, fossil fuel prices, climate policy on renewables and energy efficiency.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting in the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing and operating a reserve for market stability with regard to the greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme and amending Directive 2003/87/EC, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which endorses a system that reproduces market failures. This system of quotas once again financializes the economy and the environment. It plays against intermediate industries that do not have the financial base of large companies in the most polluting sectors to buy rights to pollute.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of the draft resolution on the establishment of a market-stabilizing reserve in the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. The aim of this proposal is to establish a market reserve in order to set a gas emission reduction target of 40 % by the year 2030.  We also share the rapporteur's view on the identification of new ways of allocating free quotas, with particular reference to production levels and more efficient installations. It is considered appropriate, in fact, to give a favourable opinion to the proposal presented by the rapporteur to provide for the allocation of part of the allowances integrated into the reserve in order to use them in the investment of low-carbon industrial technologies and processes.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Belet's report proposes a corrective system, the aim of which is to address a structural deficiency of the ETS, which has so far not been able to allow sufficient flexibility in the supply of greenhouse gas emission allowances to cope with changes in market conditions. Believing that the introduction of a reserve will help to ensure stability for industries in the medium and long term, I have decided to support this report.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In 2012, the european carbon market failed: given the glut of quotas, the low carbon price had no effect. The Belet report provides ambitious elements to reduce the surplus of carbon available for trade, in order to support the price of emissions. Each year, a portion of these quotas will be set aside if the available volume is too high. When the available volume is lower, a portion of the allowances set aside will be released and offered to operators through auctions. This stability reserve will create an incentive framework for low-carbon investments.  To reinforce this logic, the text provides for the creation of an innovation fund of 50 million quotas to promote more environmentally friendly industrial innovation projects. An essential step has been taken. The European Union must continue work to give investors visibility and credibility of its commitment to the Paris Climate Conference (COP 21). I voted for this compromise, as it is resolutely committed to a value dear to the Socialists - sustainable development.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against the proposal for the Market Stability Reserve because I believe that there is no point in rejecting the Commission's proposal. In addition, there is no satisfactory solution to the previously deferred allowances and the system offered for trading allowances seems too opaque.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the reform of greenhouse gas emission allowances today is one of the most important issues in terms of climate change policy. I believe that the solution proposed by the European Commission to create a market stability reserve will help to solve the current problems of the emissions trading system by reducing the excess allowances generated by the economic crisis on the market, regulating their price, and encouraging industry to invest in modern, environmentally friendly technological solutions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report which aims to make structural changes to the emissions trading system addressing in particular the surplus of emission allowances which have built up in the market since 2009. This Report addresses the issue of the ‘back-loaded’ allowances, commits to reviewing the ETS Directive and the issue of carbon leakage and supports the establishment of an Innovation Fund generated by the auctioning of 300 million allowances to help industry’s transition to low-carbon technology.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal aims to make structural changes to the Emissions Trading System (ETS). The main aim is to remedy the problem of the quota surplus, which is currently estimated at more than 2 billion. The report proposes to freeze the next batches of quotas and include them in the reserve so as not to have too much impact on the price of these quotas. While the problems inherent in this system seem to be identified, the finding does not go so far as to call into question the principle of the commodification of polluting rights. Yet this is where the incompatibility of financial logic with ecological logic is expressed. I vote against this text and call for planning for the exit of carbonated energy, which will probably be much more efficient than the market in this area.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The emissions trading system established by the Kyoto Protocol in 1997 was in fact interpreted as a "right to pollute" and therefore had the opposite effect to that expected. Carbon dioxide emissions have not decreased as previously anticipated. As a result, larger firms benefit from this system because they have liquidity to buy back emission rights from smaller companies. It is therefore small and medium-sized enterprises that suffer the most from this system, while they are not, by far, the most polluting.  A stability reserve, as envisaged in this text, would be only a modest remedy to a system in crisis because of its inefficiency, which further penalizes our industry, which is already in difficulty.  I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Council conclusions of 23 and 24 October 2014 on a 2030 climate and energy action framework state that an operational and reformed emissions trading scheme (ETS), equipped with an instrument to stabilise the market, will be the main European instrument for achieving the Union's greenhouse gas emission reduction target. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that supports the Commission’s proposal to make structural changes to the emissions trading system (ETS). Parliament called for measures to correct the failings in the ETS, and the Commission responded positively. The proposal corrects structural issues that did not adequately cater for changes to market conditions or protect the ETS against unexpected and sudden demand shocks. Parliament suggested the inclusion of clear protection within the ETS for the Union’s industries that are at risk of carbon leakage.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully endorsed the reform of the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS), which is intended to reduce the surplus of carbon credits available for trading in order to support the price of the emission rights. Without structural changes to the emissions trading system (ETS) we will not be able to address the surplus of emission allowances which has been building up in recent years. The market stability reserve is an efficient, market-driven tool that will stabilise our ETS system.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 2009, the ETS has estimated a surplus of more than 2 billion allowances. This surplus appears as a supply on the emissions market, thereby reducing the price of CO2 emissions, which is holding back investment in low-carbon technologies. Back in 2012, the European Parliament called on the Commission to adopt measures to correct the failures of the ETS. The Commission's corresponding 2014 proposal to create a market stabilisation reserve is a structural reform that complements the ETS Directive with new rules to control market fluctuations and, in particular, the supply of allowances. I support this reform.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission, on 22 January 2014, presented a proposal for a market stabilisation reserve, together with a Communication on a climate and energy action framework for 2030. I would point out that the objective of the Commission's proposal is to make structural changes to the Emissions Trading System (ETS) to address the issue of the surplus of allowances, currently estimated at EUR 2 billion (which have been increasing in the system since 2009 (during phase 2)) and to rectify its shortcomings in order to achieve its objective : "promoting the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions under cost-effective and economically efficient conditions" (Article 1 of the ETS Directive). Although the 2020 greenhouse gas emissions target is guaranteed by the global emissions limit, I would remind you that the surplus allowances are undermining the cost-effectiveness of the scheme in the long term. The surplus is thus undermining the proper functioning of the carbon market and fundamentally the price of carbon, thereby reducing the incentive to invest in low-carbon technologies.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme aims to offset falling prices on the GHG emission allowance market. Indeed, the 1997 Kyoto Protocol established a market for polluting rights that is interesting on paper, but which suffers from many shortcomings, the first of which is the non-participation of the world's major polluters. This reserve of market stability to cope with changes in carbon prices does not call into question the system but will favour large polluting companies at the expense of SMEs, ETIs and environmentally virtuous enterprises. It makes companies less competitive, while complicating the system, thus strengthening the situation of multinationals alone able to deal with them administratively and financially. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The market needs assurances, and this ought to be agreed if we want to move to the next set of reforms; and secondly the innovation fund represents a significant improvement on earlier deals and will represent a decent investment in future de-carbonisation.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this measure, which has become necessary in order to achieve the objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This report shows that the proposal presented by the Commission goes in exactly the direction that Parliament has outlined in this matter and therefore deserves strong support.  The reform of the Emissions Trading System (ETS) is a step in the direction of correcting the shortcomings of the system and allowing it to function as originally planned. And, in fact, the proposal on the market stability reserve as such would correct a structural deficiency in the original construction of the ETS which did not allow sufficient flexibility in the supply of quotas to cope with changes in market conditions or to protect the ETS from unforeseen shocks and sudden demand.  In the light of all this, we strongly support this report, which proposes structural reform, so that the ETS continues to be at the heart of the EU's CO2 reduction policy. We therefore agree with the rapporteur in asking the Commission to present the proposal to Parliament again if it intends to amend it substantially or replace it with a new text and instructing the President of the European Parliament to forward parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to the national parliaments.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, Firstly, I would like to declare my support for reforming the emissions trading system through the introduction of a market stabilisation reserve. I believe that the market stabilisation reserve will act as an incentive for companies to invest in research and development. I trust that the market stabilisation reserve will offer organisations the opportunity to develop a solution and overall work that will not encourage companies to move their production to regions outside the EU, where the requirements for gas emissions are much lower, but to develop new technologies that reduce CO2 emissions, positively affect the level of pollution, thereby contributing to a more livable environment for our citizens. It is crucial that we reach our 2030 goals on climate change more easily.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will use a reformed Emission Trading System with an instrument to stabilise the market in line with the Commission proposal to achieve the greenhouse gas reduction target.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission’s so-called ‘cornerstone’ of its climate-change policy, the Emissions Trading Scheme, has been an objective and unmitigated failure. Its aim to promote reductions of greenhouse gas emissions in a cost-effective and economically efficient manner has clearly not been achieved. The surplus of allowances has had a major impact on the carbon price. The intention of the Market Stability Reserve is to reduce the number of allowances in the market if there are too many and introduce new ones in the event of a shortage. It is a vital but insufficient step to improving this deeply flawed scheme. We now need the Commission to come forward with a proposal for a permanent mechanism which will see any unused allowances removed at the end of each trading period.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme, as it is contrary to the interests of Romania and Romanian citizens.  Romania supported this mechanism in the form proposed by the Commission, whereby the price was set automatically and transparently, and it was to enter into force in 2021.  However, the amendments made in the negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council run counter to the national interest and will affect all sectors of industry in Romania by increasing the price of these certificates. The free allocation of these certificates in relation to the best performing 10% of installations at EU level means that industries in Romania, without strong financial resources and without state-of-the-art technologies, will have to buy them from the market at a very high price. In this respect, I supported Romania's position in these negotiations and voted against this report.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the compromise resulting from the trilogue between the EP, the Commission and the Council. It includes the establishment of a market stability reserve as of 1 January 2019 and an exemption for so-called solidarity allowances allocated annually to new Member States, which will be exempted from the market stability reserve until 2025. I know that the compromise was hard to come by, there has long been a blocking minority in the Council, which is why I am glad that a solution has finally been given way to unlocking the situation on the emission allowance market, which will once again be able to fulfil its purpose of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in an economically efficient way. At the same time, I am glad that the future of EMS will soon be on the table. A late response to the system's weakening is not good for the economy. It penalises companies responsible and long-term thinking and rewards speculation or irresponsible treatment of resources.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Trade in these allowances could have been an effective system for reducing greenhouse gases. Momenatan, however, is only a system for shaking up our industry, often in locations that have already invested a lot of money in environmental protection in recent years and decades. I am strongly opposed to a "continued as before" in the trade in certificates and a further burden on our industry. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft to correct the structural flaw in the system and allow it to function as a normal market with stable and competitive prices. The Market Stability Reserve should also ensure synergies with other climate policies, such as renewable energy and energy efficiency.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The stability reserve provides for a cut in the surplus of greenhouse gas emission allowances, promoting the stabilisation of the carbon market and allowing the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions efficiently. The reform of the quota trading system is an important pillar on the challenging path towards a better environmental sustainability policy.  With this report, the European Union reiterates its commitment to the environment, taking a pioneering role in the fight against the greenhouse effect and climate change; That is why I voted in favour.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the committee's report on the benefits of introducing a stabilising reserve to the market and agree that it is necessary for ETS to continue to be at the heart of the EU's CO2 reduction policy, while, if not, the ETS would reach the limit of collapse (without an incentive to invest in carbon pricing) and there would be nothing left but a return to the 'nationalisation' of climate policy. In my view, this would be a failure for all the intentions and progress made by the Union, and above all I believe that the common climate policy is essential if we are to achieve the international objectives set.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the lack of conformity of the final compromise text with the position of the country I represent - Bulgaria, I voted against changing the entry date for the measure from 2021 to 2017.  The date of entry into force of the PCA and the treatment of quotas in backbloop build the architecture of este's structural change. I would support the measure if the date of entry into force 2021 was maintained and the conditions agreed in the Backbloding Decision and Regulation (EU) No 176/2014 were respected. In its current form, the measure could lead to possible shocks in the auction market for greenhouse gas emission allowances, which may also have an effect on the price range.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I regret the adoption of this report by the European Parliament, given the negative impact on the mining and energy industry both in Romania (the energy complexes in the Jiului Valley and beyond) and in the rest of Central and Eastern Europe. Thousands of jobs are at risk. I will ask the European Commission for support for the professional retraining of these people. Again, we risk dealing with a Europe divided in two!

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The market stability reserve mechanism will create a better ETS, by ensuring that the prices of CO2 have the right balance to incentivise a low carbon economy on one hand and on the other hand avoid too low or too high prices because of over-supply or over-demand of emission allowances. The ETS is one of the basic building blocks which will allow Europe to effectively fight against climate change and also create a positive incentive for the transition from fossil fuels. I am a big supporter of the initiative and I consider the negotiations with the Council a fair compromise.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I welcome the establishment of a market stability reserve for the Union Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading System (EU ETS). The greenhouse gas emissions trading system is working, unfortunately not the best, and therefore needs to be changed, and Europe is achieving its objectives and meeting the commitments it has made to its partners in the world.   Based on past experience, the establishment of this reserve provides several elements. The first is the continuity of successful implementation of the EU's climate and energy policy towards the 2030 target and then by 2050. Second, greater market predictability and resilience to distortions. It is the words security and resilience that are key when it comes to the economy. With a wide range of risks and uncertainties of the normal economic performance of each company, achieving the objectives of the European Energy and Climate Policy must not pose a new risk to the European economy and the transition between the stages of trading allowances must go painlessly for our economy.  I want the establishment of a reserve for the stability of the greenhouse gas emissions trading market to ensure this necessary stability, as I want our industry to continue to be among the world leaders, but at the same time be based on responsibility for the planet and generations to come. By example, the EU can also influence other global economies to join the joint effort and learn from our positive experiences.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme aims to offset falling prices on the GHG emission allowance market. Indeed, the 1997 Kyoto Protocol established a market for polluting rights, which is interesting on paper but suffers from many shortcomings, the first of which is the non-participation of the world's major polluters. This reserve of market stability to cope with changes in carbon prices does not call into question the system but will favour large polluting companies at the expense of SMEs, ETIs and environmentally virtuous enterprises. It makes companies less competitive, while complicating the system, thus strengthening the situation of multinationals alone able to deal with them administratively and financially. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to establish and function a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emissions trading system and amend Directive 2003/87/EC aims at structural changes to address the surplus of two trillion tolerances allowed, and to promote the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in an economically sound and efficient manner.  I support the Commission's proposal to implement a market stability reserve based on structural reforms to avoid short-term interventions in favour of long-term predictability and industry stability. I also believe that further discussion on improving the allocation of tolerances will be necessary, especially regarding the change in production levels.  As a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, the Republic of Croatia is obliged to establish a national system for monitoring greenhouse gas emissions in the country and on an annual basis to create a Report on Greenhouse Gas Emissions and submit to the UNFCCC Secretariat (until 30 April of the current year) and the European Commission (until 31 January of the current year) what it is committed to.  In conclusion, I support the Commission's efforts to take into account the creation of a harmonised mechanism within the Union to compensate for carbon costs and to ensure equal application in this regard both at European Union and global level.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support colleague Ivo Belet's report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council establishing and functioning a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emissions trading system and amending Directive 2003/87/EC. A Commission report to the European Parliament and the Council on the state of the European carbon market in 2012 found that measures were needed to address structural imbalances between supply and demand. The impact assessment of the 2030 climate and energy policy framework has established that the imbalance is expected to continue and that this issue cannot be sufficiently addressed by adjusting the linear flow towards a more stringent objective within this framework. Changing the linear factor only gradually changes the upper limit. Accordingly, the surplus would only gradually decrease, and the market would have to continue to function for more than a decade with a surplus of allowances of around 2 billion or more. In order to address this problem and increase the resilience of the European Emissions Trading System (ETS) to imbalances, a market stability reserve needs to be established. In addition to establishing a market stability reserve, appropriate amendments to Directive 2003/87/EC are also needed, as the application of it can lead to large quantities of allowances to be auctioned at the end of each trading period, which may jeopardise market stability.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that the current system of regulation of greenhouse gas emission allowances has not met the expectations that have been put into it and that it needs to be significantly reformed. I am glad that the European Parliament has supported the introduction of a mechanism for the so-called market stability reserve, which should stimulate investors to make long-term sustainable investment decisions. The mechanism will be based on the automatic transfer of allowances to reserves during periods of oversupply in the market and their release in times of shortage. I consider a functioning and, above all, stable allowance trading system based on high flexibility to be an essential part of EU climate policy and sustainable economic growth in general. The legislative proposal approved today is also favourable to the Czech Republic, as the final text includes compensation for the shortfall in auction revenues for the Czech Republic. These outages are related to the earlier launch of the market stability reserve than expected.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In January 2014, the Commission adopted the ETS-MSR proposal with the aim of making structural changes to the Emissions Trading System (ETS) to address the emissions trading surplus (currently estimated at over two billion). In particular, the Commission has proposed that a market stability reserve be created from 2021.  I believe that this proposal is a step in the right direction in order to stabilise the emissions trading market, and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted against the Belet report because its assumptions are contrary to the Polish national interest. Attempts to raise carbon prices are a blow to Polish and the economy, which are characterised by a specific energy structure, strongly based on coal. Electricity production in Poland is 90% based on this raw material. There is therefore no doubt that this will result in a change in the choice of energy source across the country and will exacerbate the economic collapse of Polish mines. It should be emphasised that the level of emissions in Poland is only slightly different from the EU average.  However, the old Member States, such as Germany, Luxembourg and Belgium, are doing significantly better in this respect, but it is not these economies that will experience changes in the price of allowances as severely as Poland. Each Member State has the right to shape its own energy mix according to its capabilities and needs. I believe that EU interference in this area is too far-reaching.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission has set new climate targets for 2030, including a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. In order to achieve this objective, the Commission has developed specific measures and instruments. In this context, the European Parliament adopted the report on the Market Stability Reserve for the greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme.  I voted in favour of this text, which reflects the position of our political group. We have succeeded in including in the text the Commission's commitment to the creation of a fund of at least EUR 50 million to promote industrial innovation projects and to help sectors exposed to carbon leakage. Because we must weaken our competitiveness.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to create a market stabilisation reserve introducing rules to govern market fluctuations and the offer of allowances, as today the surplus allowances are estimated at 2 billion. The Market Stabilisation Reserve (EMR) is an efficient tool that will stabilise our Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and thereby save the central pillar of Europe's sustainability and climate policy. The Market Stabilisation Reserve is a crucial element in helping to ensure that the price of carbon stimulates innovation in the field of energy efficiency. This reform puts Europe on track to achieve its goal of 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and also sends a strong signal to the climate negotiations that will take place in December during COP21 in Paris.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this lunchtime Ivo Belet's report on the creation and operation of a market stability reserve for the EU's greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. Behind this barbaric title is a subject of the utmost importance: the use of a market instrument to reduce CO2 emissions. And there is much to be done, not least because the carbon market is not functioning well, tainted by the mistakes of the departure: surplus free allocations of carbon allowances and inability to stabilize the price of carbon so that it constitutes an incentive to invest in clean technologies. In the face of this, it was essential that the European Parliament support the Commission's proposal to create a market stability reserve, including the provision of allowances and the reserve of 900 million emission allowances. This is a good way to clean up the market, to remedy the problem of the excess quota, currently estimated at more than 2 billion, and thus to stay the course that the Union has set itself: 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) is a "carbon exchange" aimed at reducing global CO2 emissions and meeting the targets set for the European Union in the Kyoto Protocol. It introduces a limit on the gases to be emitted and a carbon market, allowing each company to buy or sell its "right to pollute". However, this system, which has already been proven and served as a model elsewhere in the world, does not provide for a flexible quota offer that would have allowed us to respond to changes in market conditions and protect the ETS from sudden and unexpected changes in demand. Indeed, the recent dramatic decline in quota prices threatened to undermine the usefulness of the system. I therefore voted in favour of this report insofar as it aims to remedy a structural gap by allowing a certain amount of quotas to be set aside in situations that are too excessive.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change. The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This vote in Parliament on Wednesday will pave the way for structural reform of the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) by creating an operational market stability reserve from 1 January 2019. MEPs overwhelmingly confirmed the inter-institutional agreement reached last May to remedy the excess of quotas in the market, which had significantly lowered the price of a tonne of carbon and prevented the system from playing its role as an incentive for investment in clean technologies and renewable energy. This is therefore a first step towards the longer-term reform of the ETS that the European Commission is preparing for the post-2020 period (the fourth ETS exchange period) with a view to presenting a proposal expected on 15 July. The ball is now in the eu's Council's court, which will formally adopt the text (amendment to Directive 2003/87/EC) next September.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has presented a legislative proposal to revise the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS), in line with the 2030 climate and energy action framework agreed by EU leaders last October.  The proposal wants a more resilient energy union with a future-facing climate policy – which is, moreover, one of the Juncker Commission's priorities.
