As part of the contribution to the new global climate agreement, due to be adopted next December, this is undeniably the first step towards the goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% domestically by 2030. It is also intended to establish a market stabilisation reserve for the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) as part of the 2030 framework for climate and energy policies, given the current imbalance between supply and demand for allowances. As a whole, we will be strengthening the functioning of the internal energy market at European level and ensuring that it works in an economically efficient manner, so I voted in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which deals with the revision of the European Union's emissions trading system by reducing the surplus of available carbon credits to support the price of carbon which had fallen to around EUR 7 per tonne.  The creation of a market stability reserve will come into effect on 1 January 2019 and will allow quotas to be withdrawn from the market if the surplus exceeds a certain threshold. The reserve will allow us to draw on the quotas on the market each year in order to reduce the supply of quotas and to enable an increase in the price of carbon in Europe, without compromising the competitiveness of our companies. This reserve will ultimately stabilize the carbon market.  In parallel to this reform, the EPP Group has managed to secure the Commission's commitment to create a fund of at least EUR 50 million to promote industrial innovation projects and protect sectors exposed to carbon leakage.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the position of my group, the PPE, I voted in favour of the final report of the negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the introduction of the 'market stabiliser reserve in the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme'. Despite the initial fears, the compromise reached will not be too bad for industries, especially energy-intensive industries, although it will certainly lead to an increase in the price of emission allowances. The new instrument introduced is part of the review of the ETS, the first proposal of which is expected to come from the Commission in mid-July.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the ETS and the setting of a 'reliable price' for carbon, as we understand that carbon favours the oil and gas industry in the long term. Fossil fuel-dependent companies use the existence of the ETS as an argument for the elimination of EU energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. However, the European Union's emissions trading scheme aims to prolong dependence on fossil fuels and to expand and strengthen the role financial markets play in people's daily lives. These fossil energy sources not only generate a considerable volume of un quantified emissions, but also have significant negative impacts on the environment, social aspects and health.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU carbon market must be a fair system which does not disproportionately affect some Member States. Those countries with large tertiary sectors are less exposed to the effects of the ETS, whilst countries like Romania with an important manufacturing base face higher costs and usually have fewer resources to protect against carbon leakage. The existing compensation measures, including Article 10c of the ETS Directive and the so-called ‘solidarity allowances’, are not enough if the carbon price is to be increased by withholding credits from the market. However, if harmonised compensation for indirect costs were to be introduced at EU level, a fairer system could be developed.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it is an amendment aimed at make the emissions trading system more effective in the European Union, market mechanisms cannot be the only ones available to reduce business emissions. These market mechanisms are the EU's only proposal for action in this area and have proven to be completely failed, as they allow large polluters to increase pollution and even their speculative benefits. Action in the field of emissions is about strengthening public, binding and coercive measures that make the polluter pay.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The innovation fund represents a significant improvement on earlier deals and will represent a decent investment in future decarbonisation.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are currently approximately 2 billion emission allowances on the market. As we know, the consequences of the economic crisis are behind this, but so are other factors. This negatively affects not only the auction price of the allowances themselves, but also the incentive for operators to invest in more environmentally friendly measures. It is for this reason that I have decided to support the proposal for a decision on the creation of a market stability reserve. From the reserve, I promise that it will significantly improve the predictability and stability of the market and will also provide an incentive to invest in eco-innovation. As a result, emissions should also be gradually reduced. Last but not least, it will present today a welcome and, above all, desirable alignment between industrial and environmental policy. Finally, I would like to say that I also appreciate the final form of this report in the context of the final content negotiations, which included compensatory conditions important for the Czech Republic.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Yesterday, we voted on the market stability reserve for the EU greenhouse gas emissions trading system. The European Commission has proposed to reform the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) by introducing a Market Stability Reserve (MSR) from 2021. The MSR allows the Commission to issue or deny additional CO2 allowances in order to protect the EU Emissions Trading Scheme from cyclical fluctuations and to cancel the oversupply of allowances that have accumulated in recent years. However, European industries have sounded the alarm by pointing out the competitiveness, the deindustrialisation of Europe and the impact of the Ukrainian crisis, which is focusing attention on energy security. However, in October 2014, EU leaders reached an agreement on the 2030 climate and energy package. They strongly support the Commission's proposal on the Market Stability Reserve (MSR) and that additional CO2 allowances be issued beyond 2020 for those industries particularly affected by the carbon leakage. The report includes the following compromises: (i) entry into force in 2019; (ii) Carbon leakage: the Commission should draw up a proposal; and (iii) Innovation Fund: An additional fund to support breakthrough technologies will be set up. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal to establish and function a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emissions trading system and to amend Directive 2003/87/EC, as this is a structural decision that should reinforce the European Union's decision to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and trade them. I believe that the new directive will contribute to market stability and predictability in the future. Controlling greenhouse gas emissions is a key part of the European Union's climate policy and it must be in all our interests to develop the economy sustainably in the future.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council establishing and functioning a market stability reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emissions trading system and amending Directive 2003/87/EC.  In January 2014, the Commission adopted an ETS-MSR proposal aimed at structural changes in the Emissions Trading System (ETS) to address the surplus allowances.  As regards carbon leakage, the proposal should be presented within 6 months of the adoption of the MSR. As regards the Innovation Fund, it is planned to promote industrial innovation projects in all Member States.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I reject the Manipulation of the Emissions Trading Market by the Commission. Emissions permits were supposed to aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions globally. This is precisely what is happening, and emission permits thus fulfil their purpose. The Commission should therefore certainly not intervene in this market simply because the price of these licences does not meet its expectations.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the establishment and functioning of the Market Stability Reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. It's a compromise. A compromise between climate policy and industrial policy. On the one hand, we are all working to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and CO2 emissions, and on the other hand, we all want us to preserve European industry without which there are no jobs. We must maintain competitiveness at global level. I believe that the report is ambitious enough.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report is incomplete with regard to the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the greenhouse gas emission allowance trading scheme. It does not create a structured and compact grid to protect the environment from this activity.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I consider the establishment of a reserve to be a good solution. As we know, emissions trading is designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, the supply-demand balance of emission quotas has been overturned and is now hampering green investment. Power plants, airlines and companies are free to trade with emission quotas, which determine how much pollutants can be released into the air. Quotas are currently very cheap because demand for them has decreased, including because of the economic crisis. However, there has been no movement on the supply side. In 2013, there was a surplus of more than 2 billion in the quota market compared to the current output, which could exceed 2.6 billion by 2020. A quota is the emission of one ton of CO2. The surplus reduces the willingness to invest in greens, thereby jeopardising the efficiency of the ETS. In my opinion, this step sends a strong message in the EU's climate policy, which is of the utmost importance in view of the forthcoming climate summit in Paris. I believe that we need a stable and flexible system, so that a more predictable situation is created for the Member States and the market. I would like to draw attention to the importance of encouraging further investment in the creation of the stability reserve and of creating consistency with further climate and energy policies.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Striving to improve the quality of the environment is a necessity that humanity cannot give up, but not this process should be a goal, but a human being. For in all the initiatives that we are taking in Europe and in the world, we should remember people.  A clean environment, of course, serves them, but pursuing the goals set should be a process, and therefore an evolution, not a revolution. The idea is to improve the quality of life while avoiding the current negative effects of the measures taken. Radical changes, economic constraints, including industrial one, do not have immediate effects on the environment, but they are clearly deteriorating not only the situation of companies and their competitiveness, but also the quality of life of people.  I therefore voted against this decision, considering it to be too far-reaching, with no chance of improving the environment in the short term, while seriously endangering the economic development of the European Union and its individual Member States.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal. We will not find the solution by correcting a failed system at the bases. The problem is at the root: by still extracting fossil fuels, we inevitably create a problem and then rush to find a solution. The ETS was conceived at a time when CO2 emissions were much more closely related to the production territory. Today, with emissions being relocated, it is difficult for the ETS to meet global emission reduction targets.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text of my colleague Ivo Belet. An effective and reformed Emissions Trading System (ETS) with an instrument to stabilise the market, in line with the Commission's proposal, will be the European Union's main instrument for achieving this target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, as indicated by the conclusions of the European Council of 23 October 2014.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on establishment of the Market Stability Reserve for the Emissions Trading System. The Emissions Trading System was supposed to be an important step towards lowering the CO2 emissions and was expected to serve as a best example of a system to fight against air pollution. But instead it became poorly functioning and led to a large surplus of allowances. Establishment of the Market Stability Reserve should help to tackle the over-supply of allowances and to find a better balance within the ETS. In trialogue the European Parliament and Council agreed on the start date for the MSR (2019, two years earlier than proposed by the Commission) and on placing the ‘backloaded’ allowances directly into the MSR. I agree with this review and I hope this step will help to bring about a well-functioning system incentivising innovation and the competitiveness of our industry.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Since I oppose manipulating emissions trading prices because I think it's the market that should set the price, I cannot support this report. I also consider it unfair to be non-compliance with the agreement of the last parliamentary term under which 900 million allowance trading was to be withdrawn from the market and returned to it in 2019-2020 and the current decision that they would instead go into reserve, which is extremely unnattractive.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the establishment and functioning of the Market Stability Reserve for the Union greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. In January 2014, the Commission adopted the European Union Emissions Trading System Stability Reserve (ETS-MSR) with a view to introducing structural changes to the emissions trading scheme. In doing so, it addressed the issue of excess emission allowances collected in the scheme since 2009 (currently estimated at more than two billion). The Commission has proposed to create a market stability reserve from 2021 to which refunds would be collected and could be released under certain conditions. More specifically, the Commission has proposed that the compensation would be added to the reserve if the surplus exceeds EUR 833 million and released in the event of a fall below EUR 400 million.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the ETS and the setting of a 'reliable price' for carbon, as we understand that carbon favours the oil and gas industry in the long term. Fossil fuel-dependent companies use the existence of the ETS as an argument for the elimination of EU energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. However, the European Union's emissions trading scheme aims to prolong dependence on fossil fuels and to expand and strengthen the role financial markets play in people's daily lives. These fossil energy sources not only generate a considerable volume of un quantified emissions, but also have significant negative impacts on the environment, social aspects and health.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Personally, I am one of the skeptics that further administrative adjustment will solve and stabilize the allowance system in the long term. The problem lies already in the system of man-made market itself. I believe that, despite the pre-defined rules on intervention in the market from allowances, the system is unsustainable in the long term. Moreover, I also have reservations about the administrative interventions themselves, which may be economically very dangerous for many business entities in the future. I agree with the rapporteur that the Commission needs to have a fundamental debate on the redistribution of free allowances, but I also recommend addressing the very essence of the emission allowance trading scheme.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The creation of a stability reserve was motivated by falling prices on the market for greenhouse gas emission allowances, which were promoted by the Kyoto Protocol (1997), causing the opposite of the expected effect of downward regulation of carbon dioxide emissions. Forecasts and pre-prediction models of changes in carbon prices in eligible sectors have therefore been thwarted by reality. The market stability reserve then appears to be a palliative that does not fundamentally transform this system. It also turns out that large companies in the most polluting sectors are doing well by having sufficient financial base to buy back emission rights. The allocation of quotas thus plays against mid-sized industries.  In view of the unsatisfactory nature of the ETS system, which reproduces market failures, pursues the objectives of financialisation of the economic and environmental sectors and contributes to making The sectors of the Member States less competitive, I voted against this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the ETS and the setting of a 'reliable price' for carbon, as we understand that carbon favours the oil and gas industry in the long term. Fossil fuel-dependent companies use the existence of the ETS as an argument for the elimination of EU energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. However, the European Union's emissions trading scheme aims to prolong dependence on fossil fuels and to expand and strengthen the role financial markets play in people's daily lives. These fossil energy sources not only generate a considerable volume of un quantified emissions, but also have significant negative impacts on the environment, social aspects and health.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of the agreement reached on a market stability reserve for the CO2 emissions trading scheme before the current period for its operation has expired. The aim of the reform is to increase the price of emission permits and therefore to directly increase the price of electricity from fossil fuels, from which most electricity comes. Today, as we struggle to achieve growth and greater competitiveness of the economy, higher energy prices will undersle efforts for economic recovery and better positions of European companies on the global market. I do not consider excessive favouritism of climate policies to be justified at the expense of growth policies, where Europe is neither the largest co2 issuer nor can climate targets be achieved if there is no global agreement and commitment from larger polluting countries. I therefore take the view that the European institutions are acting hastily with the reform of the emissions trading scheme, with their desire for earlier generation of financial resources from this trade for investments in low-carbon technologies.  While the agreement contains safeguards for industry, it is unlikely that companies will be able to adapt to the new system without significant new costs and loss of competitiveness from the inevitable increase in the price of electricity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text which concerns a reform of the EU Emissions Trading Scheme. The reform, which will start operating in 2019, aims at reducing the surplus of carbon credits available for trading in order to support the price of the emission rights. The main idea behind the reform is that it is necessary to ensure sufficient guarantees for energy-intensive industries (for which achieving less CO2 emission requires very large investments), in order to prevent them from delocalising their production facilities to countries outside the EU that have less stringent climate policies. This reform goes in the right direction towards achieving the goal of a 40% reduction of CO2 emissions by 2030 that Europe has set itself. It is also positive that this reform will start operating earlier than initially foreseen by the Commission (2019 instead of 2021).

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about an issue that has been the subject of several tripartite dialogues and on which a compromise agreement has been reached through collaboration between the ENVI and ITRE Commissions. The People's Group, the Socialist Group, the Liberals and ECR supported the outcome of the negotiations, so I think it appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the stability reserve for the emissions market because, although the ETS is a system that needs to be modified and corrected, I have no doubt that it remains an excellent instrument for combating climate change. The stability reserve is a good solution for better managing allowances, but it is true that other aspects remain that need to be improved to increase the efficiency of the system. Until the European Commission submits its proposal to amend the Directive, we must ask those who are asking interested doubts about the ETS to be liable. Our criticism must always be constructive in order to correct the inadequate, but by remaining united against climate change and working to meet our objectives, both eu and globally agreed. On the other hand, and at a time when European innovation, research and science are being punished by cuts, I welcome the agreement taking into account our idea of allocating reserve funds to industrial innovation actions and demonstration projects for low-carbon technologies, such as CO2 capture and storage.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it is an amendment aimed at make the emissions trading system more effective in the European Union, market mechanisms cannot be the only ones available to reduce business emissions. These market mechanisms are the EU's only proposal for action in this area and have proven to be completely failed, as they allow large polluters to increase pollution and even their speculative benefits. Action in the field of emissions is about strengthening public, binding and coercive measures that make the polluter pay.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. After freezing 900 million CO2 emission allowances under the CO2 Trading Scheme (ETS, or carbon market) for the period 2014-2016, the Commission proposed in February 2014 the creation of an additional reserve of 600 million unallocated CO2 allowances to be implemented in 2021. After months of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council have reached a compromise that appears to be a glass half empty or half full, even though the new reserve will come into force in 2019 instead of 2021.  This reserve system is a back-and-forth to prevent speculation in the carbon market. So I abstained. It is a complete overhaul of the system that is needed to finally encourage industrialists to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. This is urgent at a time when the Commission recognises the increase in the quota surplus from the current 2 billion to 2.6 billion in 2020. It was announced by the Commission on 13 July. This is good news just a few months before the Le Bourget conference.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since its inception in 2005, the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) has failed to reduce emissions in European countries, with no real change in the way energy is produced and spent by industry.  The ETS is not an incentive to promote investments in clean energy solutions. On the contrary, it closes the door to really effective climate policies, discouraging regulations that are seen as interfering with the price of carbon.  Given the massive number of existing permits to pollute, the market concluded that continuing to pollute is the cheapest option. Thus, no investments are made in clean technologies or low carbon solutions, since there is a Carbon Market, which was designed to be attractive to the industry, and try to reform this system and provide it with instruments for its stabilization is not that a profitable cosmetic operation for it to continue to seem attractive.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against the proposal for the Market Stability Reserve because I believe that there is no point in rejecting the Commission's proposal. In addition, there is no satisfactory solution to the previously deferred allowances and the system of certificate trading offered seems too opaque.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 From the outset, I have opposed the introduction of emission allowances, which put European businesses at a disadvantage in global competition, but when this has already happened, the rules set must be respected and the system should not be constantly interfered with. I reject the creation of a market stabilisation reserve that regulates the supply of auctioned allowances, as well as rejecting the process of backloading emission allowances, which I consider to be a non-systemic market intervention that will only artificially affect the price and lead to damage to the competitiveness of industry. The EU must wake up from the illusions of zero emissions, complete decarbonisation and 100% renewable energy.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report introducing a market stability reserve in the context of the greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. The ETS system needs immediate corrective measures in order to re-establish the proper functioning of the mechanism. The economic crisis, together with excessive parking of free permits, had reduced the price of emissions to a level that made the entire emissions market completely ineffective. I think it would be appropriate to introduce a market reserve to support the prices of allowances. I claim, in particular, the decision to place backloading permits directly in the reserve and the decision to bring forward the entry into force of the MRS to 2019. Both of the provisions adopted today stem from proposals first supported by my political group.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today approved the reform of the European Emissions Trading System (ETS), which aims to reduce the surplus of emission rights for the market in order to support its price and thus facilitate the reduction of CO2 emissions.  This is a very important vote as the economic crisis and oversupply of allowances under the EU's Emissions Trading System (ETS) has led to a significant destabilisation of the system.  The creation of a market settling reserve will allow a strong signal to be sent to the markets as well as having already begun to influence long-term investment decisions, thus avoiding costly mistakes and a technological lock-in.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is yet another demonstration of the rotund and glamorous failure of the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading System (ETS), which since its inception in 2005 has failed to reduce GHG emissions or boosted any energy paradigm transition.  It was clear during the debate that carbon market supporters – those who, in the face of their failure, now want to introduce a few patches – have no answer to simple questions, such as the absence of examples of structural changes, significant from an environmental point of view, achieved using market instruments such as emissions trading. That would therefore be the opportunity to change approach – from a market approach to a regulatory, environmentally and socially-effective approach and environmentally effective – instead of putting patches on worn cloth.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is committed to improving the situation and labour rights of sea people. The reality of these workers is subject to a high degree of discretion on the part of the Member States of the European Union because of the exceptions allowed to the application of the Conventions. This report aims to improve their rights, calls for compliance with ILO Conventions and refers to agreements reached by the social partners, as well as requesting, inter alia, an improvement in the safety of these workers. All these measures are absolutely necessary to improve the conditions of workers in this sector and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The adoption of this Directive by the European Parliament is an important step in the improvement of seafarers’ employment rights, including safeguards if redundancies are proposed, protection for workers when shipping companies are transferred to new owners, and rights to be informed and consulted on matters affecting key working conditions. European level employers and trade unions are in favour of the new rights and were responsible at the outset for agreeing the content of the Directive. Despite this clear consensus, UK Conservative MEPs were amongst the very few members of the Parliament who voted against. Along with my Labour and other colleagues in the Socialists and Democrats Group in the Parliament, I supported this sensible and progressive measure to help protect quality jobs and decent standards in the shipping sector. It is also welcome that we secured a reduction in the proposed implementation period for the new Directive from five to two years. In its ongoing review of the Maritime Strategy to 2018, the European Commission should take full account of the significance of fair terms and conditions of work and the positive contribution of collective bargaining for the success of the maritime sector.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report from the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, which amends five existing labour-related Directives aimed at providing a minimum safety net for workers. All five exclude seafarers from these protections and the aim of the report is for seafarers to receive the same protections as other workers as set out in the Directives. The relevant Directives address: - the protection of employees if their employer becomes insolvent; - the safeguarding of employees’ rights in the event of transfers of undertakings; - the establishment of European Works Councils; - establishing a general framework for informing and consulting employees; - the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies. The proposal from the Commission has been strengthened and improved in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee under the current rapporteur – after an earlier draft report was rejected as it tried to even further exclude seafarers from these protections. This report will help strengthen protections at work for seafarers, which is why I supported it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Less and less nationals of the Member States of the Union are moving towards the trades of the sea, due to the harshness of these occupations, but also to a lower social protection than other employees. As a result, jobs on European vessels are increasingly being filled by third-country nationals. The main objective of the project is to include all crews in the Directive on Collective Dismissals, as long as the transferred vessel is registered or flies the flag of a Member State. All Member States that have already chosen to apply the current directives find that they do not entail any particular extra cost. In addition, the impact on small businesses and micro-enterprises is limited, as they were already excluded from most existing guidelines. France fully implements the current directives and seafarers already enjoy a certain level of protection. With the 'seafarers' directive, nothing will change for our country, except that we will be less exposed to social dumping from other Member States. So I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a particularly complex issue: I support anything which increases safety, but also have concerns about EU involvement.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers working on ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specificities inherent in this sector of activity. Improving the working conditions of seafarers will give this sector a new lease of life.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of any of the 28 Member States of the European Union, taking full account of the specificities of this sector of activity.  This proposal for a directive edits five previously adopted directives, the scope of which has not been included in the scope of which has not been included in the scope of the directive. The five directives referred to are Directive 2008/94/EC on the protection of workers in the event of the insolvency of their employer, Directive 2009/38/EC establishing a European Works Council, Directive 2002/14/EC establishing a common framework for informing and consulting workers, Directive 98/59/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies and Directive 2001/23/EC on the protection of workers' rights in the event of the transfer of undertakings, businesses or parts of undertakings or businesses.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported this text which provides for standardising the social protection of seafarers: a levelling down that will bring all the Member States of the European Union to the same level as France and thus help to combat social dumping and unfair competition.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The proposed directive put to the vote puts an end to the possibility of exclusion for seafarers from the application of certain labour law directives (information and consultation of workers, collective dismissals, European business committees, etc.). I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposal for a seafarer directive seems to me to be positive. Indeed, this proposal for a directive aims to amend six other European directives which previously excluded seafarers from their scope. As it stands, it is the States that are free to include seafarers or not in the scope of those directives. In practical terms, eight Member States do not exclude seafarers from these directives. If the reports on the consequences of the inclusion or exclusion of seafarers are to be believed, it seems necessary to generalize their inclusion. Indeed, the States that apply these directives to seafarers have demonstrated that there is no extra cost and, moreover, that the economic consequences are positive. Moreover, French seafarers can only support this directive. By aligning the standards of protection of the Member States of the European Union with those of France, competition would therefore no longer be unfair, thanks to the increased fight against social dumping. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Morin-Chartier report is balanced and I support the setting of common minimum standards for improving the working conditions of employees employed in this sector throughout Europe.  That is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report incorporates sea earners into five Directives from which it was excluded, in order to protect their rights and ensure equal treatment: Directives 2008/94/EC on the protection of employees in the event of the employer's insolvency, 2009/38/EC on the establishment of a European Business Committee, 2002/14/EC for a general framework relating to the information and consultation of workers, 98/59/EC on the approximation of laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies and 2001/23/EC on the protection of workers' rights in the event of transfers of undertakings. As a result of the difficult balance struck between European social actors, its objective is to increase the protection of sea people in accordance with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and to ensure a level playing field. It also contributes to the objectives of Article 151 TFEU for the promotion of employment, improvement of living and working conditions, adequate social protection and social dialogue. The current situation creates inequality between States since they do not apply the same exceptions. Spain, for example, none. Minimum requirements are now included which allow for more favourable conditions in the various legislations. This is a review consistent with the treatment of sea people in Spanish law: the same as other employed persons.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which amends and improves the Commission's proposal on seafarers. The purpose of this Commission proposal is to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of any of the 28 Member States of the European Union, taking full account of the specificities of this sector of activity. Thus, this proposal for a directive edits five previously adopted directives, the scope of which has not been included in which seafarers have not been included. The Commission notes that the provisions on their exclusion from seafarers laid down in the five Directives were not included in the Commission's initial proposals and that those provisions were included after negotiations with other partners. The European Parliament thanks the social partners for their joint work, which will open up opportunities to increase the attractiveness of the maritime sector, which has been lacking popularity for several years. It must be emphasised that improving the working conditions of seafarers will provide new incentives for this sector. In addition, Parliament considers that this will help to achieve this on 10 October 2007. The objective set out in the Blue Paper published by the Commission to quantify the number of workers in the maritime and fisheries sector and improve their working conditions qualitatively, cannot be achieved by achieving the first objective without reaching the second objective.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, including taking into account the specificities of the sector. The proposal was made in order to unify the six directives on work and social dialogue, which have not yet been covered by seafarers. Thus, the directives on the insolvency of employers, the European Works Council, collective redundancies and the protection of workers' rights in the event of a transfer of undertakings have been reviewed. The EP amendments mainly concern the area of social dialogue and cooperation. The amendments adopted may also be important to me and to Hungarian citizens working abroad at sea, despite the fact that the regulations have no significant direct territorial impact on Hungary. The PEOPLE's approach was particularly important to us in the following areas and issues of principle: disproportionate costs, administrative or legal restrictions that would hinder the creation and development of small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses are not eligible; seafarers should not be discriminated against on the basis of their EU nationality, the security of on-board communication devices should also be increased.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 My support for this report, I welcome the strengthening of the right of seafarers to fly one of the 28 flags of the Member States by amending five directives concerning workers' rights so that seafarers are included in their scope. An agreement has also been reached with the social partners, and this is closer to eradicating unfair competition between Member States. A level playing field and social security and the protection of the competitiveness of the maritime sector in the EU are the cornerstones of the industry within the EU.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report because it wants to protect maritime workers from exercising their rights. Until now, some Directives have led to the potentially different treatment of the same categories of workers in different EU member states. The proposed Directive aims to put an end to this and ensure equal rights and equal treatment for maritime workers as well.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which can enable French sailors to fight against a form of social dumping, encouraged by the European Union. Indeed, only a small number of Member States, including France, give seafarers the benefit of the European Union's directives on labour law. It is unacceptable that this Europe encourages unfair competition, to the detriment of a sector already in great difficulty.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report from the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, which amends five existing labour-related Directives aimed at providing a minimum safety net for workers. All five exclude seafarers from these protections and the aim of the report is for seafarers to receive the same protections as other workers as set out in the Directives. The relevant Directives address: - the protection of employees if their employer becomes insolvent; - the safeguarding of employees’ rights in the event of transfers of undertakings; - the establishment of European Works Councils; - establishing a general framework for informing and consulting employees; - the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies. The proposal from the Commission has been strengthened and improved in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee under the current rapporteur – after an earlier draft report was rejected as it tried to even further exclude seafarers from these protections. This report will help strengthen protections at work for seafarers, which is why I supported it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is important for the European Union to take care of improving the working conditions of seafarers employed on a ship flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States, including this category within the perimeter drawn up by the five European directives on workers' rights.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Voting in favour of this directive undersoes our commitment to defending fair treatment of all workers in all sectors. Despite the general application of EU labour law to all sectors and categories of workers, seafarers in some Member States are excluded from the application of European directives, particularly in the areas of safety at work, the right to information and consultation and the right to fair and fair working conditions. In addition to having a negative impact on the rights recognised by the Charter of Fundamental Rights, this heterogeneity of application of European discipline actually causes clear discrimination in the same category of workers who are treated differently in the various Member States.  With the adoption of this directive, we intend to put an end to the exclusion of seafarers from the five existing directives with the aim of protecting their rights and guaranteeing them equal treatment.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal proposes to amend six existing EU directives that exclude seafarers from their fields of application. However, their application varies widely from one Member State to another, favouring unfair competition within the EU. French seafarers are disadvantaged compared to other states that implement the exclusions provided by these directives, because France does not apply them. By accepting the report's recommendations all European countries would be subject to the same rules and would be put at the same level as France. I therefore voted in favour of this draft directive, because it helps to limit unfair competition and to combat social dumping.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Common European minimum standards for improving the working conditions of seafarers.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. There were significant gaps in EU legislation on workers' rights in the sea sector. De facto, seafarers were discriminated against workers in onshore companies. It was completely unjustified to exclude certain categories of people from social rights intended to protect them. This report thus amends the European directives which included aspects that were directly or indirectly discriminating against seafarers. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on seafarers, amending Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC.  The report welcomes the Commission's proposal, which aims to strengthen the rights of seafarers by amending five directives on labour law, in order to integrate workers in the maritime professions into the scope of these directives.  I believe that the attempt to create truly uniform conditions for those affected by the derogations in force is to be welcomed. Furthermore, in addition to providing for the full application of the relevant directives to seafarers, seafarers should enjoy the same rights as ground workers in terms of equal pay for work of equal value, regardless of nationality, place of residence, race, gender, sexual orientation, disability or age.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report from the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, which amends five existing labour-related Directives aimed at providing a minimum safety net for workers. All five exclude seafarers from these protections and the aim of the report is for seafarers to receive the same protections as other workers as set out in the Directives. The relevant Directives address: - the protection of employees if their employer becomes insolvent; - the safeguarding of employees’ rights in the event of transfers of undertakings; - the establishment of European Works Councils; - establishing a general framework for informing and consulting employees; - the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies. The proposal from the Commission has been strengthened and improved in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee under the current rapporteur – after an earlier draft report was rejected as it tried to even further exclude seafarers from these protections. This report will help strengthen protections at work for seafarers, which is why I supported it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a particularly complex issue: I support anything which increases safety, but also have concerns about EU involvement.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as whilst I fully support measures aimed at enhancing seafarers’ living and working conditions on board vessels and to increase the attractiveness of maritime employment, I believe that extending the same EU legislative framework applicable to land-based workers to seafarers is not the right means to attain these objectives.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the Maritime Workers Directive is to increase the protection of their rights by ensuring that they are no longer excluded from the scope of certain key social rights. These include, firstly, fair working conditions in the broadest sense, i.e. the right to protection, information and consultation on decisions affecting the category.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report by my compatriot, Mrs Morin-Chartier, which is in the direction of increased social protection for seafarers. This text provides for support for Parliament and the Council's proposal for a directive to amend six existing EU directives, including on workers' rights, which exclude seafarers from their scope. It should be noted that eight Member States, including France, have already included seafarers in these provisions. Despite the concerns of the States practising these exclusions, these eight Member States stressed that there were no additional costs and that this had a positive impact on the maritime sector.  Personally, I am in favour of such measures, which will combat unfair competition and social dumping of companies from states that do not apply these directives to seafarers.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Quite rightly, with regard to the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning seafarers, it asks the Commission to resubmit a proposal if it intends to make significant amendments or replace them with a new text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on seafarers. The Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers employed on board vessels flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specific characteristics of the sector of activity in question. The proposal for a directive therefore provides for the revision of five directives previously adopted, which excluded seafarers from their scope. In addition, the improvement of the working conditions of seafarers will give new impetus to the sector, which will contribute to the achievement of the two objectives set out in the Blue Paper published in 2007 by the Commission, namely the quantitative increase in the number of workers employed in the maritime and fisheries sector and the qualitative improvement of their working conditions.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it will allow a general improvement in the working conditions of all seafarers working on board ships in one of the twenty-eight Member States of the Union. Before this agreement was reached, the category of seafarers was excluded from the application of as many as five European directives which recognised important protections in fundamental areas of labour law.  Their exclusion was caused by the obstructionism carried out by the main European social partners, thus taking advantage of the different levels of protection granted by European countries. This agreement will now put an end to discriminatory situations for seafarers and unfair competition between Member States. In fact, some of them, by giving priority to improving working conditions, did not take these exclusions into account, extending the provisions of these directives to seafarers as well, or took them into account at least in part, while other countries observed them in their entirety.  At last we will be able to offer uniform working conditions to all those employed in the sector and to make it more attractive even in the eyes of the youngest.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this directive, as I believe it is appropriate to improve the working conditions of seafarers by including this category in certain directives from which they were previously excluded. I therefore welcome the agreement between the social partners, which will put an end to a discriminatory situation and make the maritime sector more attractive.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is committed to improving the situation and labour rights of sea people. The reality of these workers is subject to a high degree of discretion on the part of the Member States of the European Union because of the exceptions allowed to the application of the Conventions. This report aims to improve their rights, calls for compliance with ILO Conventions and refers to agreements reached by the social partners, as well as requesting, inter alia, an improvement in the safety of these workers. All these measures are absolutely necessary to improve the conditions of workers in this sector and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to integrate personnel working on boats, known as "seafarers," into six directives from which they were previously excluded. These European social and employment laws concern employer insolvency, collective redundancies and the transfer of companies. In addition, they set out specific provisions, in particular with regard to the information and consultation of workers and the protection of their rights. Considering that this report was designed in consultation with the social partners and that it helps to put an end to a form of discrimination and an exceptional regime concerning seafarers, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the legislative resolution since in its revision this resolution includes also the role of social partners. Furthermore, it is important to take into consideration the effects of such a proposal on the global industry, which I believe will be positive.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. For too long, seafarers have been excluded from EU legislation protecting workers, even though we have developed a strong common fisheries policy. By the vote of this text, this gap is now corrected. Seafarers are now included in six working conditions guidelines. They enjoy the same consultation rights as the rest of the workers in the event of employer insolvency or collective dismissal. I expect member States to implement these provisions as soon as possible.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Proposal for a European Commission Directive aimed at improving the working conditions of seafarers employed on board ships flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union.  Improving working conditions will give new impetus to this sector and will contribute to achieving one of the main objectives set out in the Blue Paper published by the Commission on 10 October 2007, namely the quantitative increase in the number of workers employed in the maritime sector.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. European social legislation for sailing personnel suffers from too many exceptions, depriving seafarers of most of their social rights. Improving the application of European social legislation for sailing personnel will help to restore a balance between the rights of seafarers and that of other employees, in particular with regard to information and consultation rights within the framework of an enterprise committee.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, including taking into account the specificities of the sector. The proposal was made in order to unify the six directives on work and social dialogue, which have not yet been covered by seafarers. Thus, the directives on the insolvency of employers, the European Works Council, collective redundancies and the protection of workers' rights in the event of a transfer of undertakings have been reviewed. The EP amendments mainly concern the area of social dialogue and cooperation with regard to the working conditions and safety of seafarers. I followed the People's Party position because the report has succeeded in incorporating amendments that may be important to me and to Hungarian citizens working abroad at sea, despite the fact that the regulations have no significant direct territorial impact on Hungary. The PEOPLE's approach was particularly important to us in the following areas and issues of principle: disproportionate costs, administrative or legal restrictions that would hinder the creation and development of small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses are not eligible; seafarers should not be discriminated against on the basis of their EU nationality, the security of on-board communication devices should also be increased.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed directive by the European Parliament and the Council on seafarers. French seafarers enjoy high protection and are not excluded from the directives that are the subject of this proposal. My vote in favour therefore means my desire to preserve the security of French seafarers. It is unthinkable to degrade working conditions and therefore the quality of life of seafarers, on the grounds that other European states do not grant them a high level of protection. Let us not be fooled, however: this proposal reveals the evils of European gigantism. It denounces the unfair competition that the Union itself has installed.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The nature of seafaring was seen as an obstacle to informing and consulting workers, which is a key component of a number of the directives – electronic means of communication (for example, internet and satellite phones) with vessels on the high sea were considered at the time to be expensive and difficult to justify. Conservatives maintain our concerns that further regulatory measures could put EU flags at a competitive disadvantage with third-country flags and could lead to flagging out to non-EU flags. Finally we have concerns that such regulatory measures may actually result in poorer employment conditions for seafarers in European waters.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In principle, I am always in for when talking about regulations and other documents that protect Community producers from unfair competition, whether from companies inside or outside the Community. I follow with particular care the shipbuilding business not only because Bulgaria was leading it years ago, but also because Europe is a major producer of ships, which on the one hand is an industry with huge added value and on the other, in which a very large number of workers are employed. Our main competitors the US and China are well behind us in shipbuilding, you know that even european shipyards have to complete one of the major US cruise ships – Sea of America, and for this reason we need to protect our European producers and help them with whatever we are capable of. I therefore support this regulation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because, although it brings about key reforms in the maritime labour sector, it has legislative gaps.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, including taking into account sectoral specificities. name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation, because it goes in the direction of strengthening social protection for seafarers and could thus put all European countries on the same plane.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to remove the exclusion to which seafarers were subject to EU labour law. There is nothing in this particular report that contradicts our positions defending workers' rights. The changes induced are therefore positive for these workers, which is why we voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal improves the working conditions of seafarers working on ships flying the flag of one of the Member States of the European Union and corresponds to the revision of the five Directives from which seafarers were initially excluded. Today, in view of the improved situation and the agreement of the main social partners at European level, we can eliminate this discrimination and thus prevent unfair competition between Member States. I also welcome the balance that has been struck between better protection of workers and maintaining the competitiveness of the navy, which represents one of the European Union's important challenges for the future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which contains indications of common minimum standards for improving working conditions for seafarers.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Directives on minimum requirements for gradual implementation aiming at improving working conditions, the protection of workers where their employment contract is terminated, and information and consultation of workers and the working environment to protect workers’ health and safety must avoid imposing disproportionate costs and administrative and legal constraints in a way that would hold back the creation and development of small and medium-sized undertakings and family businesses, which are the drivers of sustainable and inclusive growth, and the source of 85% of all new jobs in the European Union.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amending directive aimed at improving the level of protection of seafarers because, finally, after years, an unfair unequal treatment of workers has been brought to an end. EU labour law so far applies to all workers in all sectors; However, the directives in force made it possible to exclude seafarers from certain provisions relating to the protection of workers. The aim of this important change is to level the protection of workers and to increase the quality of jobs in the maritime sector as a whole and to allow a level playing field. The maritime sector is very important for many regions and Member States, but the lack of an integrated approach between the different components has prevented a situation of equal treatment. With the integrated maritime policy, the Commission reviewed exemptions under EU labour law with the social partners and, following the identification of areas where inequalities persisted (collective redundancies, information and consultation, business transfers, employer insolvency and the European Works Council), made a proposal for an amendment with the full support of the EP.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As my group's responsible rapporteur, I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC with regard to seafarers. This dossier brings valuable progress towards increasing the rights and safety of workers on the high seas. I would like to thank the European Commission and the rapporteurs of the other groups for their good, constructive cooperation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Morin-Chartier report because I believe seafarers should be able to enjoy the same employment rights in the EU as land-based workers. I also welcome that the report provides a sensible balance of protecting seafarers against regulatory burden. All workers deserve equal treatment and equal rights and the EU can play a crucial role in bringing this about.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides a minimum level of social protection for sea-workers.  There are fewer and fewer EU nationals who are moving towards the sea trades, because of the harshness of these trades, but also because of less protection than other employees. As a result, jobs on European vessels are increasingly being filled by third-country nationals. The main objective of the project is to include all crews in the Directive on Collective Dismissals, as long as the transferred vessel is registered or flies the flag of a Member State. All Member States that have already chosen to apply the current directives find that they do not entail any particular extra cost. In addition, the impact on small businesses and micro-enterprises is limited, as they were already excluded from most existing guidelines. In our country, which fully enforces the guidelines in force, seafarers already have a certain level of protection. With the 'seafarers' directive, nothing will change for our country, except that we will be less exposed to social dumping from other Member States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we believe that this new Directive is a step forward in the recognition of labour rights and in promoting employment in a declining sector, as well as improving the quality of life and work and adequate social protection for seas. We welcome this Directive, as it avoids a situation of unjustifiable inequality within Europe, in which the same category of sea workers can be treated differently in each Member State. This was allowed because States, in certain aspects of labour rights contained in five specific directives, were eligible for exceptions in their application to seas. The exceptions in those directives, which provide for vital aspects for the protection and recognition of the labour rights of the common workers, relate to improving the level of information and consultation of workers, the establishment of a European business committee, protection in the event of insolvency of the employer, the maintenance of rights in the event of transfers of undertakings and the approximation of laws between Member States in the event of collective redundancy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a directive on seafarers is designed to give seafaring workers the same employment rights enjoyed by those who work in land-based employment throughout the EU. It offers a sensible balance of protecting seafarers against regulatory burden. The Labour Party will monitor the application of the directive vigorously.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The working conditions of seafarers must be improved and seafarers should be stopped from being excluded from part of EU labour law legislation. In terms of information and consultation in particular, workers must have the same rights on land and at sea.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very pleased to support this Report for a Commission proposal for a Directive on seafarers. This new directive will amend five existing directives in order to give seafarers the same rights as their on-shore colleagues who, until now have been excluded under certain labour directives by some Member States from their right to information and consultation. Fair and equal treatment across the EU is a fundamental right of its citizens and it is positive that this new directive will go towards remedying this gap. Given the sector has continually declined over the last number of years I hope enhanced working conditions will attract new workers, particularly young people who could reenergise the sector. It will also be positive from a competitive perspective by ensuring all operators across the EU are on a level playing field.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, including taking into account the specificities of the sector. name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ It has been an unfortunate anomaly that Europe’s seafarers have not benefited  from the full protection of EU labour laws. This report seeks to rectify this situation and I was happy to vote in favour.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I am against this resolution because I believe that it should be up to the Member States to decide on the conditions of employment of seafarers. I also consider the regulation of this sector to be superfluous because it creates excessive bureaucraticisation and administrative constraints. It is, to say the least, ridiculous that the Union is engaging hundreds of Members and tens of thousands of officials to decree the right of seafarers to access the internet on board.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on Seafarers and Amendments to Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC, as I consider that that proposal for a directive seeks the necessary changes for a level playing field at international level. The changes strongly highlight that seafarers are entitled to a protected workplace, safety standards, fair employment conditions, decent living and working conditions, with social protection and vocational training, which I certainly stand behind. I also welcome the involvement of social partners who have contributed to improving the attractiveness of the maritime sector, which has weakened over recent years.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides a minimum level of social protection for sea-workers. name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier's report on seafarers. The aim of this report is to improve the working and living conditions of people working on ships flying the flag of an EU Member State. This directive will also allow seafarers to be included in five social laws from which they have so far been excluded. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft law resolution on the law on seafarers, because it is important to support decent working conditions and the application of Eu social legislation for people working on ships flying the flag of an EU Member State. There is a need to make the maritime sector more attractive, especially in terms of employment conditions.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains good proposals on how to adapt the legal situation of seafarers so that they can enjoy European labour standards due to the specificnature of their profession. I am therefore voting in favour of the report.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I support with my vote the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on seafarers, amending Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC, because it ensures in a sound way the protection of workers, the right to safe work and the improvement of working conditions.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. My vote on this report was positive. The Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of maritime operators employed on board vessels flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight EU Member States. The proposal for a directive therefore provides for the revision of other directives which excluded seafarers from their scope. Seafarers have the right to a safe and secure workplace where safety standards are respected, in order to benefit from fair working conditions, as well as decent living and working conditions.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on seafarers, because the Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers working on ships flying the flag of one of the Member States, while taking into account the specificities inherent in this sector of activity. This text will standardise the social protection of seafarers and thus bring all Member States to the same level as France. This will help combat social dumping and unfair competition. We can only hope that improved working conditions will help breathe new life into the maritime sector.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Despite the application of EU labour law to all sectors and categories of workers, seafarers have until now been excluded from the scope of the following Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC. Depending on the situation at national level, this exemption may have a negative impact on the rights contained in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, in particular as regards the right to information and consultation and the right to decent working conditions. As only some Member States have benefited from these exemptions, this has led to the same categories of workers being treated differently in different Member States. I voted in favour of the Morin-Chartier report because it is important to ensure equal treatment and rights for all workers.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. It is a text that aims to improve the social protection of seafarers. Although I am opposed to any excessive form of uniformity at European level when it jeopardises the sovereignty of States, I have supported this proposal, because I believe that it will have a positive result for French professionals, since it is a question of combating the disparities which have the main consequence of social dumping and unfair competition.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is committed to improving the situation and labour rights of sea people. The reality of these workers is subject to a high degree of discretion on the part of the Member States of the European Union because of the exceptions allowed to the application of the Conventions. This report aims to improve their rights, calls for compliance with ILO Conventions and refers to agreements reached by the social partners, as well as requesting, inter alia, an improvement in the safety of these workers. All these measures are absolutely necessary to improve the conditions of workers in this sector and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Seas are a collective excluded from a series of European Directives designed to protect workers' rights and are now being reformed. These amendments formally recognize your work and provide job security applicable to different situations. For example, sea workers are legally and economically shielded in the face of the possibility of their employer declaring the himself insolvent. The same is true if an ERE is carried out and they lose their jobs. His position would also not be prejudiced if there was a transfer of companies and their situation was in any way at risk. For these reasons, I support these changes, as this is a basic issue to end the inequality of labour rights of sea people.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Commission communication entitled 'Blue Growth - Sustainable Growth Opportunities in the Marine and Maritime Sectors' points out that the 'blue' economy represents 5.4 million jobs and generates an added value of almost €500 billion a year. The aim of this document is to emphasize that seafarers have the right to a safe and secure workplace in accord with safety standards, fair employment conditions, decent working and living conditions, including social protection and vocational training.  It is also particularly important that these benchmarks are entered into national legislation as soon as possible so that the objectives set out can be met as soon as possible. It is also important to protect the rights of seafarers as part of communication systems in order to ensure freedom of communication on board vessels as well. All of the above should improve the position of seafarers and ensure adequate protection in this occupation and that is why I supported the Report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must legislatively ensure the same minimum basis of rights and obligations for all employees. Pursuant to Article 153 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), it is for the European Parliament and the Council to adopt, by means of directives, minimum requirements aimed at improving working conditions, protecting workers at the end of their employment, informing and consulting workers and creating an environment of work in order to protect the health and safety of workers. However, disproportionate costs must not be passed on to employers which hinder the development of small and medium-sized enterprises and could therefore also have a negative impact on employment in this sector. This directive will help to improve the working conditions of seafarers in all EU Member States and will contribute to their equal treatment and the elimination of discrimination in their employment by employers in the Member States.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on seafarers amending Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC, since this report aims, on the one hand, to improve the working conditions of seafarers working on ships flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the inherent specificities of this area of activity and, on the other hand, to correct a situation of discrimination against seafarers.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting for this proposal amending six European directives that excluded seafarers from their fields of application. The guidelines cover topics such as protection, information and consultation with workers. This proposal has no effect and no extra cost for France, which already provided seafarers with a high level of protection.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
