text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on the amendment of directives previously adopted in relation to the exclusions of seafarers engaged on board vessels flying the flag of one of the EU Member States from their scope. The proposal aims to improve and maintain the rights and conditions of workers in order to remedy a discriminatory situation for seafarers. Given that the attractiveness of the maritime sector is a fundamental issue for the future of the European Union, this proposal will give new impetus to a sector that has been drastically reduced, thus reaffirming the safeguarding of competitiveness and better protection of workers.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Morin-Chartier's report refers to the European Commission's proposal to improve the conditions of workers employed on board ships flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union.  Aware that, in general terms, an improvement in workers' conditions goes hand in hand with more rational economic development, I have decided to support this document.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. As this report is intended to stabilise the legal situation of seafarers and prevent further discrimination on the basis of their profession, I have given my assent to it. In general, it should be noted that the report is very detailed and very well coordinated.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to amend specific directives governing matters relating to the protection of employees in the event of the insolvency of the employer or in the event of transfer of undertakings, as well as collective redundancies. In the absence of clear justification, the scope of those Directives does not include or may exclude seafarers. This proposal aims to improve the level of protection of the rights recognised by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in European Union labour law and to ensure a level playing field throughout the European Union. In addition, the proposal contributes to the general policy objectives set out in Article 151 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, namely the improvement of employment, better living and working conditions, adequate social protection and dialogue between administrations and workers.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal which will include seafarer workers in the six directives from which they were previously excluded including the Insolvency Directive, the Collective Redundancies Directive and the Transfer of Undertakings Directive. The Report also establishes specific provisions, particularly regarding information and consultation of workers and regarding protection of workers’ rights.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. While Europe has the strengths to become a global maritime power, it favours deregulation and competition as the engine of its development. Environmental protection and social policies are relegated to declarations of intent. This business model is not working. The text presented puts an end to an incongruity and an injustice. It included seafarers, who had been excluded, in the scope of EU directives on workers' rights. The ambition of the relevant directives is short-lived, however. The topic of voting is about the integration of sailors in their perimeters, I vote for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In France, seafarers already enjoy a high level of protection. Therefore, the application of these directives to all European countries would limit unfair competition from other countries and combat social dumping. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have tabled my vote in agreement with the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on seafarers, amending a number of legislative texts. I welcome the Commission's proposal, presented on 19 November 2013, on a directive aimed at improving the rights of seafarers by amending five directives on workers' rights to cover seafarers in their respective scopes.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I am in agreement with the Union’s efforts to increase seafarers’ living and working conditions, I did not support this resolution as extending the same legislative framework regarding onshore workers is not, in my opinion, the best way to achieve this goal.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The fishing sector is an important provider of jobs in Europe. The most recent figures highlight the creation of nearly 150,000 jobs. These positive prospects should not make us forget that it is necessary to ensure safe and fair working conditions for all Europeans, including seafarers. For example, the directive aims to improve living and working conditions on board boats and to exploit the innovation potential of the maritime sector in order to make it more attractive, especially for young people who are hard hit by unemployment. My support for this report is therefore clear.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the general application of EU labour law to all sectors and categories of workers, seafarers are still excluded from the scope of the various EU Directives. These exclusions have a negative impact on the rights recognised under the Charter of Fundamental Rights, in particular with regard to the right to information and consultation and the right to fair and just working conditions. I have always been a strong advocate for better working conditions and rights for seafarers and therefore I will always support measures aimed at enhancing seafarers’ living and working conditions on board, which will help increase the attractiveness of the European maritime employment sector worldwide. Seafarers should not be discriminated against or treated differently from any other categories of workers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to adopt the Directive is about the revision of five directives previously adopted which exclude seafarers from their scope. The proposal aims to improve working conditions for seafarers on board ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specificities of the sector. The agreement recently reached at European level by the main social partners makes it possible to eliminate discriminatory situations for seafarers and unfair competition between Member States, strikes a balance between enhancing the protection of workers and safeguarding the competitiveness of the maritime sector, one of the future challenges of the European Union. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the European Commission's proposal, which aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board vessels flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specificities inherent in this sector of activity. This proposal for a Directive thus corresponds to the revision of five directives previously adopted which provided for the exclusion of seafarers from their scope. The European Commission recalled that the exclusions provided for seafarers in the five Directives were not present in the Commission's initial proposals and that they resulted before negotiations with the other partners. I am voting in favour because it argues that improving the working conditions of seafarers will contribute to giving new impetus to this sector and believes that this will contribute to achieving the objective set by the European Commission's Blue Book published on 10 October 2007 and which has set the target for an increase in the number of workers in the maritime and fisheries sector and a qualitative increase in their working conditions , the first objective cannot be achieved without the second.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Morin-Chartier report on seafarers aims to standardise the social protection of seafarers and bring the whole Of European Union into line with France's standards in this area. Although I am usually opposed to all standards imposed on states by the EU, I believe that this text effectively combats social dumping and unfair competition. Indeed, France has not excluded people from the sea from the application of the directives since it enjoys a high level of protection. These recommendations therefore amount to subjecting the rest of the European Union to the same rules as France.  I have therefore decided to vote for this report with the sole aim of avoiding unfair competition.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a directive on seafarers is intended to give seafarers the same employment rights as those workers who are land-based in the EU. It provides a sensible balance of protecting seafarers against regulatory burden. The Labour Party will monitor the application of the directive vigorously.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Seafarers Directive. The aim is to improve the working conditions of persons engaged on ships flying the flag of a Member State of the European Union. The directive will amend five texts of European social legislation whose scope did not include seafarers.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. As soon as I was appointed rapporteur on this issue, my objective was simple: to improve the working conditions of seafarers and to end these exclusions which deprived seafarers of a large part of European labour law legislation. This overwhelming majority vote (642 votes in favour, 38 against and 24 abstentions out of 704 voters or 91% of the vote in favour) is emblematic: it reflects the European Parliament's full support for a more social Europe. Once again, the European Parliament is at the forefront of social Europe. At sea and on land, workers must have the same rights, especially with regard to information and consultation. We are moving social Europe forward and we will not back down from the Member States which tend to want to cut it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We fully support this draft legislative resolution, which has become necessary to improve the working conditions of seafarers employed on board vessels flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union. Taking into account the specificities of the sector of activity in question, it is clear that the rapporteur's work is moving in this direction. This proposal for a directive provides for the revision of five directives previously adopted.  The agreement recently reached between the European social partners has made it possible to make progress and to put an end to a discriminatory situation for seafarers and to unfair competition between Member States which favoured the improvement of working conditions and therefore did not apply or apply to a very limited extent the exclusions on the one hand and the Member States which applied them in full. , on the other hand.  We therefore congratulate the social partners and the rapporteur on the work they have done, which will improve the working conditions of seafarers and will give new impetus to this sector, including by increasing the number of workers employed in the maritime and fisheries sectors.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this Commission proposal that seeks to improve working conditions for seafarers working on vessels flying the flag of one of the 28 EU Member States.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo ón gCoiste um Fhostaíocht agus um Ghnóthaí Sóisialta. Leasaíonn an tuarascáil seo cúig threoir atá ann cheana féin a bhfuil baint acu le gnóthaí saothair agus atá dírithe ar íosleibhéal sábháilteachta a chur ar fáil d’oibrithe. Sna cúig threoir sin, níl trácht ar bith ann faoi chosaint do mharaithe agus mar sin is í an aidhm atá leis an tuarascáil seo ná a chinntiú go bhfuil na cosaintí céanna ag maraithe agus atá ag na hoibrithe eile atá luaite sna treoracha. Tugann na treoracha aghaidh ar na nithe seo a leanas: cosaint d’fhostaithe má éiríonn a bhfostóir dócmhainneach; cosaint a thabhairt do chearta fostaithe i gcás aistriú gnóthas; Comhairle Oibreacha Eorpach a bhunú; creat ginearálta a bhunú chun fostaithe a choinneáil ar an eolas agus comhairle a chur ar fáil dóibh; comhfhogasú de dhlíthe na mBallstát a bhaineann le comhiomarcaíochtaí. Tá an togra ón gCoimisiún neartaithe agus feabhsaithe sa Choiste um Fhostaíocht agus um Ghnóthaí Sóisialta dar leis an rapóirtéir atá ann faoi láthair – diúltaíodh dréacht-tuarascáil níos luaithe mar rinneadh iarracht inti gan na maraithe a chur san áireamh do na cosaintí seo. Neartóidh an tuarascáil seo cosaintí do na maraithe agus mar sin bhí mé sásta tacaíocht a thabhairt di.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I deeply believe the EU needs to allow for proper safeguards and regulatory protection measures for seafarers. This trade is one of the lifelines of Europe, being a source of exponential prosperity generation, and the people involved in this need are a key professional base that needs the full support of the Commission. I certainly hope the Member States will do their best to quickly implement the new proposals to this directive.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report as it contains some positive approaches to improving the legal situation of seafarers and could indeed bring positive benefits to this profession.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The directive aims to improve the rights of seagoing workers working on board ships flying the flag of an EU Member State, taking into account the specificities of the maritime sector.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The directives to which seafarers belong are anti-labour abortions that essentially serve the interests of the employer. The regime in which they seek to include seafarers is none other than what is characterized by: collective redundancies, manipulation and integration of workers by false participation in councils and consultation with capitalists on how much they will lose, no protection of the rights of seafarers in the event of sales of shipowners' ships. Seafarers not only have no interest in being included in such directives but, on the contrary, they are led to a reduction in their requirements and needs through arrangements that substantially intensify and keep their exploitation of the shipowner's capital. The JRC supports the demands and struggle of the class-based seafarer movement for full, stable work with rights for all, replacement of losses, Collective Labour Agreements that meet modern needs, exclusively public, universal social security, Health and Welfare, effective protection of the unemployed, abolition of exemptions for seafarers from labour law. Meeting labour-popular needs requires a fight against the shipowners' capital, monopolies, the EU and all imperialist wolf alliances, so that the ships and the wealth that workers produce become popular property, with the working people in power.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is very positive that the social partners have finally managed to reach agreement on the seafarers employed on the boats, because I believe that this type of discrimination is absolutely to be eliminated by the European Union.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The old European saying about "seven-crust bread" is used in Croatia to describe the painstaking work of seafarers. The life of seafarers with the existing technologies of today can and should be easier for all who deal with it. The dangers that seafarers face daily, from natural disasters to piracy, make this difficult occupation risky enough anyway.  The amendment to this Directive seeks to ensure seafarers the right to a safe and secure job in line with safety standards, should have fair employment conditions, decent living and working conditions, including social protection and necessary vocational training. The Union needs to look to improve working and living conditions on board vessels and harness the potential of innovation to make the maritime sector more attractive to Union seafarers and young workers. Therefore, the Commission needs to develop a programme to encourage young workers to engage in the sector. There should also be efforts to improve online communication on board ships, for example by improving the availability of the Internet and ensuring its justified use on board. In order to improve the rights of seafarers, the creation of maritime clusters should be promoted, while encouraging the inclusion of young people in the maritime and fishing sectors. There is a need to continue to encourage the training of seafarers in all sectors. Improving the working conditions of seafarers requires a multi-sectoral approach and implies an understanding of the specifics of each sector.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Morin-Chartier report on seafarers aims to standardise the social protection of seafarers and to put the whole European Union on France's standards in this area. Although I am usually opposed to the standards imposed on states by the EU, I recognise to this text the will to effectively combat social dumping and unfair competition. Indeed, France has not excluded seafarers from the application of the directives since it enjoys a high level of protection. These recommendations therefore amount to subjecting the rest of the European Union to the same rules as France. I have therefore decided to vote for this report with the sole aim of avoiding unfair competition.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support my colleague Moric-Chartier's report on the proposal for a Directive from the European Parliament and the Council on Seafarers and Amendments to Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC. I welcome the fact that the Directive is fully aligned with the Blue Paper, which emphasises the need to increase the number and quality of maritime jobs for European citizens, and the importance of improving working conditions on board vessels, including by investing in research, education, training, health and safety. The current legal situation, partly due to the specific nature of the maritime profession, allows for different treatment of the same category of workers by different Member States, but according to whether those Member States apply the exemptions and derogations allowed by the current legislation. A significant number of Member States partially apply these exemptions and derogations and eight Member States do not apply them at all, but seafarers are covered by collective bargaining agreements that give them a certain degree of protection, which is why as a representative from a maritime country I am particularly pleased that the issue is also regulated.  Social partners in the maritime and fisheries sectors have reached an agreement of critical importance for the correct implementation of this Directive. This agreement strikes a good balance between the need to improve the working conditions of seafarers and the need to take into account the specificities of the sector.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier's report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on Seafarers and Amendments to Directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC, given that the type of amendments, the nature of the sector and the principle of procedural economy, the directives listed are better amended by a single directive. As the current legal situation allows for different treatment of the same category of workers by different Member States, but whether or not those Member States apply the exemptions and derogations allowed by the current legislation, this proposal for a directive would ensure the same rules of market play for all, at least at the level of vessels flying the flag of a Member State of the Union. The proposal introduces amendments to the five applicable directives. In particular, it recognises the unconditional right of workers on long-haul ships to be announced and consulted in all directives that have previously allowed exemptions and derogations from this right (the European Works Council Directive, the Notification and Consultation Directive, the Collective Reduncies Directive). Procedures for informing and advising workers contribute to improving corporate governance and reducing the negative consequences of sudden restructuring. Companies will benefit from a better flow of information about the company's strategy and justifications of certain decisions to employees, especially at times of change, at no significant cost to the employer.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always been committed to increasing attention to the protection of workers, in particular for those categories that are excluded from certain levels of social protection.  I also voted in favour of this report in the light of my particular attention to the activities of all maritime operators. The Commission's proposal, in fact, includes seafarers in six directives from which they had previously been excluded, namely Directive 2 008/94/EC on the protection of employees in the event of the insolvency of their employer (hereafter referred to as the "Insolvency Directive"), Directive 2009/38/EC on the establishment of a European Works Council (hereafter referred to as the "European Works Council Directive"), Directive 2002/14/EC establishing a general framework for the information and consultation of (hereafter referred to as the "Information and Consultation Directive"), Council Directive 98/59/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies (hereafter referred to as the "Collective Redundancies Directive") and Directive 2001/23/EC on the maintenance of the rights of employed persons in the event of transfers of undertakings (hereafter referred to as the "Directive on transfers of undertakings").

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to contribute to the significant improvement of working conditions for seafarers, MEPs adopted the Commission's proposal. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board vessels flying the flag of one of the 28 EU Member States, while taking into account the specificities inherent in this sector of activity.  This improvement will contribute to achieving the objective set by the EC Blue Book (2007) which has set a qualitative increase in working conditions in the maritime sector as a target, achieving better protection of workers and protecting competitiveness in the maritime transport sector, which poses a challenge for the future of the EU.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament overwhelmingly backed the Morin-Chartier report (642 in support, 38 against and 24 abstentions) amending five directives on workers' rights to improve the protection of seafarers in EU labour legislation.  Generally, EU labour law applies to workers in all sectors. Today, however, several directives allow Member States to exclude seafarers from certain provisions relating to the protection of workers. This inevitably leads to unequal treatment of these workers across Europe and has implications for competition in the shipping and fishing sector.  The aim of this directive is to bring the right of workers in the sector in line with that of workers on land in terms of equal pay for equal work, regardless of nationality, place of residence, race, gender, sexual orientation, disability or age.  The proposal also aims to increase the number of jobs in the maritime sector and to make working conditions more attractive to encourage young Europeans to pursue a maritime career at a time when the sector is in real decline.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This report incorporates sea earners into five Directives from which it was excluded, in order to protect their rights and ensure equal treatment: Directives 2008/94/EC on the protection of employees in the event of the employer's insolvency, 2009/38/EC on the establishment of a European Business Committee, 2002/14/EC for a general framework relating to the information and consultation of workers, 98/59/EC on the approximation of laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies and 2001/23/EC on the protection of workers' rights in the event of transfers of undertakings. As a result of the difficult balance struck between European social actors, its objective is to increase the protection of sea people in accordance with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and to ensure a level playing field. It also contributes to the objectives of Article 151 TFEU for the promotion of employment, improvement of living and working conditions, adequate social protection and social dialogue. The current situation creates inequality between States since they do not apply the same exceptions. Spain, for example, none. Minimum requirements are now included which allow for more favourable conditions in the various legislations. This is a review consistent with the treatment of sea people in Spanish law: the same as other employed persons.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. It was anomalous that workers in the maritime sector, better known as seafarers, should be excluded or excluded from the scope of several European labour law directives. Among these guidelines is the one relating to information and consultation with workers, a right that is dear to me.  Therefore, I voted in favour of the report of my colleague, MEP Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER, which supports the European Commission's legislative proposal to improve the working conditions of these people. We must put an end to these possibilities of exclusion which penalise seafarers in relation to a significant part of European labour law legislation.  It should be noted that this report was voted by a large majority since 624 MEPs supported this text (38 against and 24 abstentions). This result shows the injustice experienced by workers in the maritime sector in recent years.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this legislative resolution is to amend several European directives in order to improve the level of information and consultation of workers linked to the sea sector. Eu labour law directives generally apply to all sectors of activity and to all categories of workers. However, seafarers are excluded or may be excluded from the scope of some directives and there is no express justification for this situation. As a result, this proposal provides for the scope of the Insolvency Directive of the employer, the Collective Redundancies Directive and the Business Transfer Directive, as well as to lay down specific provisions, in particular on information and consultation of workers and protection of workers, and protection of their rights.  The proposal for a Directive on seafarers is still in line with the Europe 2020 strategy and its employment objectives, respects fundamental rights and observes the principles recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report of my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, which improves the working conditions of sailing personnel and ends the exclusions that deprived seafarers of much of the European labour law legislation. It is essential that workers have the same rights, particularly in terms of information and consultation. This report once again helps to move social Europe forward.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on seafarers. The Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers employed on board ships flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specific characteristics of the sector of activity in question.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I support an initiative aimed at ensuring greater protection for a category of particularly at-risk workers such as seafarers.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we believe that this new Directive is a step forward in the recognition of labour rights and in promoting employment in a declining sector, as well as improving the quality of life and work and adequate social protection for seas. We welcome this Directive, as it avoids a situation of unjustifiable inequality within Europe, in which the same category of sea workers can be treated differently in each Member State. This was allowed because States, in certain aspects of labour rights contained in five specific directives, were eligible for exceptions in their application to seas. The exceptions in those directives, which provide for vital aspects for the protection and recognition of the labour rights of the common workers, relate to improving the level of information and consultation of workers, the establishment of a European business committee, protection in the event of insolvency of the employer, the maintenance of rights in the event of transfers of undertakings and the approximation of laws between Member States in the event of collective redundancy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is committed to improving the situation and labour rights of sea people. The reality of these workers is subject to a high degree of discretion on the part of the Member States of the European Union because of the exceptions allowed to the application of the Conventions. This report aims to improve their rights, calls for compliance with ILO Conventions and refers to agreements reached by the social partners, as well as requesting, inter alia, an improvement in the safety of these workers. All these measures are absolutely necessary to improve the conditions of workers in this sector and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote will put an end to a discriminatory situation for seafarers and combat situations of unfair competition at EU level. The removal of seafarers' exclusions from the scope of five European directives will ensure that workers employed on board ships flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States have better and more homogeneous working conditions.  I therefore voted in favour of the agreement reached, satisfied that a specific reference has also been introduced to the use of new information and communication technologies, which can allow the exchange of information and dialogue with seafarers. Improving personnel policy is certainly an important step towards increasing the quality of jobs and making maritime careers more attractive, the popularity of which has been greatly reduced in recent years.  Despite this important development in labour law, however, much remains to be done to ensure the rejuvenation and future of the European maritime and fisheries sector.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 From the region where I come from, the Autonomous Region of the Azores, is all known and recognized the special requirement of the profession of seafarers, be they fishermen or workers in maritime transport. I therefore see in this legislative initiative of the European Commission as an opportunity to dignify and, essentially, to improve the working conditions of those who have to face the sea. I agree with the proposal in general terms and agree with some amendments proposed by the European Parliament, namely those which speed up the implementation of the Directive in the Member States, promote safety, improve working conditions through the implementation of new technological tools and promote land-to-board communication and vice versa. Finally, I stress the importance of collecting data relating to the activity of seafarers to identify further possibilities for improvement. Very important and consequential steps have already been taken with regard to fishing activity, but it is necessary to extend this attitude to all activities that take place at sea.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a directive on seafarers is intended to give seafarers the same employment rights as those workers who are land-based in the EU. It provides a sensible balance of protecting seafarers against regulatory burden. The Labour Party will monitor the application of the directive vigorously.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The maritime sector has certain specificities that needed to be taken into account in order to improve the conditions for seafarers working on ships flying the flag of an EU country. Recently, the social partners at European level have managed to reach agreement on this EC proposal. This makes it possible to make some progress and to eliminate discrimination against seafarers and unfair competition between Member States. It is positive that a balance has been struck between better protection of personnel and maintaining the competitiveness of the Navy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The social partners at European level have reached an agreement under which we can record some progress and eliminate discrimination against seafarers. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that, like employees of other professions, seafarers have the same right to a safe and secure workplace that respects safety standards, fair employment conditions, as well as decent living and working conditions, including social protection and vocational training. I welcome this attempt to create a level playing field for all employees affected by the existing exemptions, and I believe that these measures will also help to put an end to the growing shortage of experts in the maritime sector, officers and naval crew members in the next period. In order to make conditions in this sector more attractive, I expect the Commission to find other ways of incentivise young people to work and thus reverse the further reduction in the number of young People of the Union working on ships flying the flag of one of the 28 EU Member States.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal to amend Directive 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC as it is about improving the working conditions of seafarers and seafarers and in small and family maritime enterprises. I believe that they deserve a better and more level playing field as this change in directives achieves.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on seafarers and amendments to directives 2008/94/EC, 2009/38/EC, 2002/14/EC, 98/59/EC and 2001/23/EC.  This Commission proposal seeks to improve working conditions for seafarers on ships flying the flag of one of the 28 EU Member States, taking into account the specifics rule of the maritime sector.  The Employment and Social Affairs Committee rejected the draft report on this proposal for a directive, mainly due to the fact that the draft report was drafted in great haste due to lack of time. The situation has since changed, as an important agreement was reached a few weeks ago on a Commission proposal between the social partners. The rapporteur warmly welcomes the progress that led to this agreement, which addresses a situation in which seafarers were discriminated against. She also thanks the social partners for their joint efforts, which she will do for the maritime sector, which has lost a lot in the past few years.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal because I do not agree with the withdrawal of exemptions for seafarers in relation to EU labour law. This proposal not only increases the EU's powers to the detriment of the Member States, but also necessarily harms the seafarers themselves whom it is supposed to protect.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the directives relating to seafarers. The directive aims to increase the number of jobs and improve working conditions on ships by investing in research, education, training and health. In Slovenia, we have been facing a decline in interest in seafarer's work in recent years, which is why I support increasing the attractiveness of maritime transport work, which we will achieve through better jobs and better conditions of competition, for the benefit of both workers and employers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report, while bringing about key reforms in the maritime labour sector, presents legislative gaps.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, including taking into account sectoral specificities. The proposal was made in order to unify the six directives on work and social dialogue, which have not yet been covered by seafarers. Thus, the directives on employers' insolvency, the European Works Council, collective redundancies and the protection of workers' rights in the event of a transfer of undertakings have been reviewed. The EP amendments mainly concern the area of social dialogue and cooperation with regard to the working conditions and safety of seafarers. I followed the People's Party position because the report has succeeded in incorporating amendments that may be important to me and to Hungarian citizens working abroad at sea, despite the fact that the regulations have no significant direct territorial impact on Hungary. The People's Party approach was particularly important to us in the following areas and issues of principle: disproportionate costs, administrative or legal restrictions that would hinder the creation and development of small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses are not eligible; seafarers should not be discriminated against on the basis of their EU nationality, the security of on-board communication devices should also be increased.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The lack of harmonisation in the implementation of the 5 directives governing working conditions for seafarers in the maritime sector has led to unfair competition between Member States and a lack of fairness towards workers in the sector. It is right that the specific nature of the maritime sector has made finding an umbrella solution difficult, and I am pleased that, on the second attempt, we have been able to reach agreement with the social partners on a framework for governing working conditions for seafarers. I believe that improving working conditions will have a leverage effect: in addition to fulfilling our mission to these workers, to provide them with protection and an improved working environment, we are able to make the maritime sector more attractive to the workforce and increase its competitiveness.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Commission's proposal aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers working on ships flying the flag of one of the 28 Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specificities inherent in this sector of activity. This proposal for a directive therefore corresponds to the revision of five directives previously adopted which provided for the exclusion of seafarers from their scope. The European Commission was keen to point out that the exclusions for seafarers in these five directives were not present in the Commission's initial proposals, but were the result of negotiations with the other partners. I agree with the rapporteur and therefore voted in favour.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the Commission proposal and the corresponding European Parliament position. Until now, the workers’ rights for seafarers varied from one Member State to another. I believe that considering the challenges faced by the maritime sector, especially labour shortages, harmonizing seafarers’ rights across the EU is an important step to take. Both access to information and consultation rights are fundamental rights and should be guaranteed for off-shore and on-shore workers. Ensuring a level playing field between workers in the fisheries and shipping sectors would result also in fairer competition.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal for a directive reflects the line of the Europe 2020 strategy and its employment objectives. Within the European Union, it is important to establish a legal framework with an integrated approach to all policies aimed at improving competitiveness in the maritime sector as well. The agreement reached between the main social partners at European level makes it possible to make progress and to put an end to a discriminatory situation for seafarers. The text adopted allows a balance to be struck between better protection of workers and safeguarding competitiveness, which is a fundamental issue for the future of the European Union.  I also agree with the rapporteur's approach and call on all the institutions and the Member States to make a decisive contribution to improving working and living conditions on board ships and to exploiting the sector's potential for innovation, not only to promote youth employment in this area.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 As a representative from Croatia, I am aware of the fact that the nature of maritime affairs was considered an obstacle to informing and advising workers and the use of electronic means of communication on high-seas vessels seems expensive and unjustified, which is why this sector is unattractive to citizens of the European Union.  While in principle I support the part of the Directive that encourages the improvement of working and living conditions on board vessels and the innovation of the maritime sector to make it more attractive to young workers, considers that the global nature of the maritime sector, combined with the practical difficulties of defining competences relating to a given group of seafarers, hinders the application of labour laws at national and EUROPEAN Union level, and therefore I consider that deepening and extending legislative measures could put Member States at an unfavourable competitive position towards third countries; which could eventually result in poorer employment conditions for seafarers in European waters.  For these reasons, I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission proposal includes maritime workers in 6 directives from which they have previously been excluded. These are the directives: Directive 2008/94/EC on the protection of workers in the event of the insolvency of their Directive 2009/38/EC establishing a European Works Council, Directive 2002/14/ EC establishing a general framework for information and consultation of workers, Directive 98/59/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies and Directive 2001/23/EC concerning the maintenance of workers' rights in the event of transfers of undertakings. It is important to ensure the basic conditions for all workers, regardless of the sector in which they are employed, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we believe that this new Directive is a step forward in the recognition of labour rights and in promoting employment in a declining sector, as well as improving the quality of life and work and adequate social protection for seas. We welcome this Directive, as it avoids a situation of unjustifiable inequality within Europe, in which the same category of sea workers can be treated differently in each Member State. This was allowed because States, in certain aspects of labour rights contained in five specific directives, were eligible for exceptions in their application to seas. The exceptions in those directives, which provide for vital aspects for the protection and recognition of the labour rights of the common workers, relate to improving the level of information and consultation of workers, the establishment of a European business committee, protection in the event of insolvency of the employer, the maintenance of rights in the event of transfers of undertakings and the approximation of laws between Member States in the event of collective redundancy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed directive provides for the amendment of six existing EU directives that exclude seafarers from their fields of application. The application of these directives varies widely from one Member State to another: eight Member States (Austria, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Spain, France, Portugal, Sweden and Slovenia) have not excluded seafarers, others have excluded them only from a directive. The social partners of the maritime transport sector have differing opinions on the abolition of exclusions, some are in favour of these exclusions, others do not. The exclusions provided by these directives are not applied in France: French seafarers already enjoy a high level of protection. By accepting the report's recommendations, all European countries would be subject to the same rules and would be put at the same level as France. This will limit unfair competition from other countries and help combat social dumping. I voted for this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we believe that this new Directive is a step forward in the recognition of labour rights and in promoting employment in a declining sector, as well as improving the quality of life and work and adequate social protection for seas. We welcome this Directive, as it avoids a situation of unjustifiable inequality within Europe, in which the same category of sea workers can be treated differently in each Member State. This was allowed because States, in certain aspects of labour rights contained in five specific directives, were eligible for exceptions in their application to seas. The exceptions in those directives, which provide for vital aspects for the protection and recognition of the labour rights of the common workers, relate to improving the level of information and consultation of workers, the establishment of a European business committee, protection in the event of insolvency of the employer, the maintenance of rights in the event of transfers of undertakings and the approximation of laws between Member States in the event of collective redundancy.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This proposal seeks to eliminate exceptions or exclusions applicable to seas in the five amending Directives. All the groups voted in favour of the report in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs of the European Parliament. It is necessary to vote in favour of a report which aims to increase the level of protection of the rights referred to in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and to ensure a level playing field across the EU.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is committed to improving the situation and labour rights of sea people. The reality of these workers is subject to a high degree of discretion on the part of the Member States of the European Union because of the exceptions allowed to the application of the Conventions. This report aims to improve their rights, calls for compliance with ILO Conventions and refers to agreements reached by the social partners, as well as requesting, inter alia, an improvement in the safety of these workers. All these measures are absolutely necessary to improve the conditions of workers in this sector and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union's labour law directives must apply to all sectors of activity, to all categories of workers and regardless of the country of the Union. This report helps to address the unfair exclusions that have hitherted down to seafarers in terms of the application of labour law directives. Some countries, including France, had chosen not to apply these unjustified exclusions. I voted for this report, which helps to eliminate exclusions that impede the rights of seafarers. It is necessary to improve the working conditions of seafarers, while taking into account the specifics of this sector of activity, but this must not be done under any circumstances at the expense of their rights. Seafarers, like all workers, have the right to social protection and to safe and adequate living and working conditions on board ships.  The attractiveness of a sector, as they say, does not mean the deterioration of living, working and employment conditions, but rather their improvement. This is how young people can be given the desire to work in this sector.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive thus corresponds to the revision of five directives previously adopted which provided for the exclusion of seafarers from their scope.  The European Commission recalled that the exclusions provided for seafarers in the five Directives were not present in the Commission's initial proposals and that they resulted before negotiations with the other partners.  The European Commission's proposal thus aims to improve the working conditions of seafarers on board vessels flying the flag of one of the twenty-eight Member States of the European Union, while taking into account the specificities inherent in this sector of activity.  Being in favour of this agreement, which makes progress and rectify a discriminatory situation for seafarers, it still falls far short of the recognition of a set of social and labour rights that we would like to see applied to all workers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. As this report is intended to stabilise the legal situation of seafarers and prevent further discrimination on the basis of their profession, I have given my assent to it. In general, it should be noted that the report is very detailed and very well coordinated.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Commission’s proposal to extend labour directives to seafarers.  Seafarers up until now have been excluded from several protective labour directives, including the Insolvency Directive, the Collective Redundancies Directive and the Transfer of Undertakings Directive. Having a well-qualified and experienced staff is vital for the health and growth of the maritime industry throughout the Union. As the number of seafarers is decreasing, ensuring that seafarers enjoy uniform rights across all Member States is essential to ensuring that  the European maritime industry is well staffed.  Extending the protection of these social policy directives to seafarers ensures their protection under the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. This measure will hopefully ensure that all labourers are treated fairly across Member States, leading to more interest in maritime careers, thus preserving the European maritime know-how for future generations.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The directives to which seafarers belong are anti-labour abortions that essentially serve the interests of the employer. The regime which they seek to include seafarers is none other than that characterised by collective redundancies, manipulation and integration of workers by false participation in councils and consultations with capitalists on how much they will lose, no protection of the rights of seafarers in the event of sales of shipowners' ships. Not only do seafarers have no interest in joining such directives, but instead they are led to a reduction in their requirements and needs by arrangements that substantially intensify and keep their exploitation of the shipowners' capital. The JRC supports the demands and struggle of the class-based seafarer movement for full, stable work with rights for all, replacement of losses, Collective Labour Agreements that meet modern needs, exclusively public, universal social security, Health and Welfare, effective protection of the unemployed, abolition of exemptions for seafarers from labour law. Meeting labour-popular needs requires a fight against the shipowners' capital, monopolies, the EU and all imperialist wolf alliances, so that the ships and the wealth that workers produce become popular property, with the working people in power.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report advocates an end to discrimination against other workers by removing the exclusion of seafarers from EU labour law. This increases the rights of seafarers who are now covered by legislation on relationships and working conditions, for which they were previously excluded. We voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it supports scientific collaboration with a country that influences the fiscal sovereignty of its neighbouring countries, as well as boosting the mobilisation of resources for THE financing of the ITER, a project which, beyond the risks it may entail, involves a massive mobilisation of the budget with very little return for European citizens. Without going into assessing the project and its implications, the European budget must alleviate emergencies in all countries, which are going through very serious public resource-requiring situations that are systematically denied. Because we believe that human beings should be the first priority, I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Switzerland has excellent research institutions, making it an interesting partner for the Horizon 2020 projects. I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we do not recognise, as a matter of principle, the possibility of the European Union concluding treaties, in diplomatic matters, in the place of the Member States. However, this agreement concerns the ITER programme, which is of strategic interest to the French nuclear industry. As this cooperation is favourable to French interests, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure because of the impact upon the EU Budget, and therefore on taxpayers’ money.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Switzerland joining the ITER project.  Having regard to the Agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, by which the Swiss Confederation becomes an associated country for the research and innovation framework programme for Research and Innovation under Horizon 2020 and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme supplementing Horizon 2020 and regulating the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the activities of the FUSION Energy Development Joint Undertaking in the ITER activities , the European Parliament shall give its assent to the conclusion of this Agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. While I continue to challenge the EU's right to conclude treaties instead of the Member States, I have chosen to vote in support of the very promising ITER project.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which endorses the draft scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which includes the framework programme for research and innovation "Horizon 2020" and the European Atomic Energy Community's research and training programme complementing the Horizon 2020 framework programme. and regulating the Swiss Confederation's participation in THE activities of ITER conducted by Fusion for Energy (15369/2014).

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the ECA, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, associating the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 and the European Atomic Energy Community's research and training programme complementing the Horizon 2020 framework programme , and regulating Switzerland's participation in ITER's activities.  The ITER program (originally "International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor") is an experimental tokamak-type machine project designed to demonstrate the feasibility of a nuclear reactor using the principle of fusion. The project involves thirty-five countries: those of the European Union as well as India, Japan, China, Russia, South Korea and the United States.  This agreement therefore allows Switzerland to participate in this programme and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries promote the industrial development of our companies and their inclusion in the market. For these reasons, I wanted to support with my vote the Buzek report, which analyses the cooperation agreement between the EU and Switzerland in Horizon 2020 and ITER.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. I am not against scientific and technical cooperation with Switzerland, but since this agreement also includes Euroatom and the ITER project, I will have to vote no.  Euroatom's aim is to promote nuclear power and the ITER project aims to generate electrical energy through the fusion of atoms. I am opposed to nuclear power and to the ITER project, which is why I am forced to vote against the agreement.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Agreement on scientific and technical cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other hand, through which Switzerland will participate as a full partner in Priority I and the horizontal programme on the dissemination of excellence, Euratom, and ITER, and as an industrialized third country in priorities II , III and Horizon 2020's horizontal science and society program.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on the R&D Cooperation Agreement with Switzerland.  Under this Agreement, Switzerland shall participate in the implementation of horizon 2020 objectives and the activities of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy in The Activities of the Swiss Joint Undertaking for the period 2014-2020. The Research Committee of Switzerland and the Communities established by the Framework Agreement shall verify, evaluate and ensure the proper implementation of this Agreement. The Committee shall be referred to the Committee for any matter relating to the implementation or interpretation of this Agreement.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union, Euratom and Switzerland all place great emphasis on scientific and technological research. It is therefore in their common interest to cooperate in order to make better use of resources and avoid duplication of work. The negotiated agreement sets out the conditions for Swiss participation in the implementation of Horizon 2020 Pillar I and the specific objective of "Spreading excellence and increasing participation", the Euratom programme activities 2014-2018 and the activities of the European Joint Undertaking for Fusion Energy Development and ITER 2014-2020. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement; I believe that the close relationship between Switzerland, the European Union and Euratom offers benefits to all parties.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of the recommendations of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I have approved the conclusion of an agreement with the Swiss Confederation, which joins certain research and development programmes within the EU.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report on the Cooperation Agreement on Science and Technology with Switzerland.  Under this proposal, the Council was asked to approve on behalf of the European Union the Agreement for Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) and the Swiss Association Horizon 2020. I believe that in the future we should constantly work on cooperation in the field of science and technology.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that Switzerland is a fundamental partner both in the economic field and in the scientific-technological field. I am therefore very much in favour of concluding this agreement between the Eu ropean Union and the Swiss Confederation which, I am convinced, will bring a great many benefits to all parties involved.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community envisages the integration of Switzerland into the Horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation and participation in ITER's activities carried out by Fusion for Energy. As a reminder, in November 2013, the European Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with Switzerland that led to an agreement in July 2014.  Although we are opposed to the European institutions negotiating agreements with third countries instead of the Member States, we consider that the ITER dossier is of paramount importance to France. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Agreement that associates Switzerland with Horizon 2020 and regulates its participation in ITER (nuclear fusion research). Our traditional vote in favour of scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries is confirmed.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Innovation is one of the factors that will enable the European economy to recover. The ability of European companies to innovate is very important, making our continent one of the world's leading technology companies. To reinforce this phenomenon, it is essential to highlight scientific and technological cooperation. Our partners have a great deal of knowledge to pass on to us in this area and vice versa. I voted in favour of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the Union and Switzerland.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the EU-Euratom Scientific Cooperation Agreement with the Swiss Confederation, which associates euratom with the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation - Horizon 2020. I have determined on the basis of the following considerations: - the close relationship between Switzerland, the Union and Euratom must also be exploited in relation to scientific and technological research, with the possibility of encouraging mutual access by the respective research bodies to research and technological development activities; - it is therefore strategic to allow participation in new research and technological development programmes under agreed conditions; - this participation must be achieved through appropriate agreements such as this one referred to in today's recommendation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure because of the impact upon the EU Budget, and therefore on taxpayers’ money.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent for the conclusion of this agreement following the recommendations of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With concerns about the ITER issue, I preferred to abstain.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with Switzerland. Indeed, this agreement allows Switzerland's participation in the ITER programme, which is a strategic contribution for the French nuclear industry. Of course, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to make such agreements on behalf of France. However, nuclear power is one of the most strategic sectors for France. This cooperation with Switzerland in the field of research and innovation will therefore be fruitful for our industry, our employees and our influence. I would, however, reiterate my opposition to the Horizon 2020 programme, which is part of a multi-year framework at the expense of the reality of the Union's economic and budgetary situation.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union, the European Atomic Energy Community and Switzerland. This measure associates Switzerland with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme (2014-2020) on research and innovation and with the European Atomic Energy Community research and training programme integrating Horizon 2020, which regulates the Participation of the Swiss Confederation in the activities of the Fusion for Energy Joint Undertaking for the implementation of ITER

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe it is important to increase scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union, the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation. A close relationship is beneficial to both sides and, given the quality of Swiss researchers and universities in the Confederation, I believe it is productive to combine efforts towards common objectives as this will produce broad and shared benefits. We must therefore continue to pursue the objectives set out in the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme and continue to work together to develop controlled thermonuclear fusion energy, as it could be a concrete solution to the problems of dependence and energy security.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential to promote transnational research activities in order to maintain and strengthen Europe's competitiveness. I believe that this agreement, by strengthening scientific and technological cooperation with the Swiss Confederation, clearly interprets this intention. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The conclusions put forward in this recommendation on the Agreement on cooperation in science and technology between the European Union and European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation associating the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020 will allow both parties to improve and intensify their cooperation in science and technology in areas of common interest. The conclusion of the Agreement will allow for increased scientific knowledge leading to market access opportunities and is thus being done in the best interests of the scientific communities, industry and citizens.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On November 15, 2013, the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations, on behalf of the Union and Euratom, with the Swiss Confederation with a view to concluding a scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation by associating the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 - the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme to complement Horizon 2020 and regulating the switzerland's participation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.  With regard to Switzerland's participation in the Erasmus+ programme, negotiations were suspended following the Swiss popular vote of 9 February 2014, which put the Federal Council in a position where it could not sign the protocol extending the EU-Switzerland agreement on the free movement of persons to Croatia.  The Swiss Government has put in place a transitional regime allowing the financing of student exchange. Switzerland would also like to participate in the successor of the Media and Culture, Creative Europe programmes. These negotiations on Switzerland's participation will not be concluded until a solution is found to the problem of free movement. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it supports scientific collaboration with a country that influences the fiscal sovereignty of its neighbouring countries, as well as boosting the mobilisation of resources for THE financing of the ITER, a project which, beyond the risks it may entail, involves a massive mobilisation of the budget with very little return for European citizens. Without going into assessing the project and its implications, the European budget must alleviate emergencies in all countries, which are going through very serious public resource-requiring situations that are systematically denied. Because we believe that human beings should be the first priority, I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Buzek report on the conclusion of the agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the EU, the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation with reference to Horizon 2020 and the latter’s participation in the ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy as I believe that this is an exercise which can be mutually beneficial.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to give Parliament's approval to the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the EU and the Euratom Community, on the one hand, and Switzerland on the other. Through this agreement, Switzerland is involved in the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme and Euratom's research and training programme. This agreement therefore allows Switzerland to be integrated into two major European programmes, but also to regulate its participation in the ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy. Considering that Switzerland is an indispensable partner of the European Union, despite the current negotiations in the wake of the referendum on free movement, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Switzerland and the European Union are long-standing partners. A new stage of our cooperation will be reached with this agreement on science and technology. It aims to combine our research efforts, particularly in the field of nuclear energy. Switzerland will be associated with the research and training programme of the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) and the European joint venture Fusion for Energy.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Innovation must be at the heart of EU policy and partnerships with third countries such as Switzerland. The Council must approve on behalf of the European Union the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the EU and the European Atomic Energy Community and Switzerland and involve switzerland in the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme and Euratom's research and training programme regulating Switzerland's participation in ITER's activities led by Fusion for Energy.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union, Euratom and Switzerland all place great emphasis on scientific and technological research. It is therefore in their common interest to cooperate in order to make better use of resources and avoid duplication of work. The negotiated agreement sets out the conditions for Swiss participation in the implementation of Horizon 2020 Pillar I and the specific objective of "Spreading excellence and increasing participation", the Euratom programme activities 2014-2018 and the activities of the European Joint Undertaking for Fusion Energy Development and ITER 2014-2020. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement; I believe that the close relationship between Switzerland, the European Union and Euratom offers benefits to all parties.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation for the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with Switzerland: Horizon 2020 and ITER activities. The nuclear industry is an important issue for France. Thus, it is necessary to be reasonable and not to omit that many French interests depend on nuclear power. My vote reminds us that Switzerland's participation in this agreement is intended to serve this strategic sector.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The enhanced participation of Switzerland in important programmes such as Horizon 2020 and other ITRE activities is a great step forward. Switzerland is not only a key contributor to the European economy, it has also proven to be a valuable addition in terms of scientific and technological advances. Cooperation will greatly add to improving innovation, skilled labour and other opportunities throughout Member States

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation as the Union's primary objective should be the recovery of national economies, especially the non-strong Member States. Energy fusion agreements are moving in the right direction but do not need immediate mobilisation

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union, Euratom and Switzerland all place great emphasis on scientific and technological research. It is therefore in their common interest to cooperate in order to make better use of resources and avoid duplication of work. The negotiated agreement sets out the conditions for Swiss participation in the implementation of Horizon 2020 Pillar I and the specific objective of "Spreading excellence and increasing participation", the Euratom programme activities 2014-2018 and the activities of the European Joint Undertaking for Fusion Energy Development and ITER 2014-2020. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement; I believe that the close relationship between Switzerland, the European Union and Euratom offers benefits to all parties.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I had to abstain on the possibility of associating the Swiss Confederation with the Horizon 2020 framework programme but above all with the activities of ITER. The latter is a large-scale scientific experiment aimed at demonstrating the validity of fusion as an energy source. Seven global partners participate in ITER: China, the EU, India, Japan, South Korea, Russia and the United States. The problem with this project is the costs: although the final result may be extremely important, the way to it is paved with huge disbursements of money that risk taking away resources from other areas of research. The 5 Star Movement has not yet taken a position on the ITER project and for this reason I abstained.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it allows Switzerland's participation in the ITER programme, the capital of the French nuclear strategy

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation.  The conclusion of this agreement with the Swiss Confederation relates to the prior agreement of the European Union with EURATOM and intends to involve the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 - The Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community which complements Horizon 2020 - and regularises the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the activities of the ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor). We have no objections in principle to the extension of the Research Framework Programme to the participation of other countries. But we continue to denounce the very unequal distribution of resources of this Programme – of which, benote, Portugal was a net contributor in the period 2007-2013. For example, Switzerland was able to multiply by about 4 to 5 times the resources it took advantage of the Programme in the face of what it contributed. We continue to demand measures to change this situation.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with Switzerland. Indeed, this agreement allows Switzerland's participation in the ITER programme, which is a strategic contribution for the French nuclear industry. Of course, I question the legitimacy of the European Union to make such agreements on behalf of France. However, nuclear power is one of the most strategic sectors for France. This cooperation with Switzerland in the field of research and innovation will therefore be fruitful for our industry, our employees and our influence. I would, however, reiterate my opposition to the Horizon 2020 programme, which is part of a multi-year framework at the expense of the reality of the Union's economic and budgetary situation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
