text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree with the draft agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and with the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Education Programme supplementing horizon 2020

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation on the Swiss Confederation's association with Horizon 2020 and the Euratom Research and Training Programme contributing to horizon 2020 and governing the participation of the Swiss Confederation in iter activities carried out by the Fusion for Energy Joint Undertaking.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I confirm my vote in favour of the research agreement with Switzerland.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the request for consent submitted by the Council, I voted in favour of the European Parliament consent on the conclusion of the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation associating the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Union's primary objective should be the recovery of national economies, especially the non-strong Member States. Energy fusion agreements are moving in the right direction but do not need immediate mobilisation. For the above reasons I am voting against the recommendation on Scientific and Technological Cooperation with Switzerland: Horizon 2020 and ITER activities.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the swiss confederation's association with horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme and the European Atomic Energy Community's additional research and training programme under horizon 2020, in line with the direction of the European People's Party. I also support the conclusion of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the regulation of Switzerland's participation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy. I consider it important to point out that, as part of its activities, the Joint Undertaking oversees, inter alia, the preparation of the site designated for the implementation of the ITER project, allocates material, financial and human resources to the ITER organisation, coordinates scientific and technological research and development activities in the field of fusion, and liases with the ITER organisation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on scientific and technological cooperation with Switzerland: Horizon 2020 and ITER activities, because I am keen to continue funding these important research projects and the recognition of foreign workers from Croatia is not affected in time.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement concluded by the European Commission on behalf of the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation to associate the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution as we consider the ITER project dangerous, costly and uncertain, with a huge opportunity cost in channeling public investment into highly polluting energy (the ITER nuclear fusion presents the same atomic waste storage problems as the current fission). We believe that what Europe urgently needs is a determined commitment to renewable energy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement concluded by the European Commission on behalf of the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation to associate the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020, including cooperation within the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community complementing Horizon 2020 and regulating the Swiss Confederation’s participation in the International thermonuclear experimental reactor (ITER) activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union, Euratom and Switzerland all place great emphasis on scientific and technological research. It is therefore in their common interest to cooperate in order to make better use of resources and avoid duplication of work. The negotiated agreement sets out the conditions for Swiss participation in the implementation of Horizon 2020 Pillar I and the specific objective of "Spreading excellence and increasing participation", the Euratom programme activities 2014-2018 and the activities of the European Joint Undertaking for Fusion Energy Development and ITER 2014-2020. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement; I believe that the close relationship between Switzerland, the European Union and Euratom offers benefits to all parties.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have longstanding objections to the EU’s ITER activities and therefore voted against this report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution as we consider the ITER project dangerous, costly and uncertain, with a huge opportunity cost in channeling public investment into highly polluting energy (the ITER nuclear fusion presents the same atomic waste storage problems as the current fission). We believe that what Europe urgently needs is a determined commitment to renewable energy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation with Switzerland: Horizon 2020 and ITER activities due to the utmost importance that science and technology have in today's globalised world. I believe that cooperation with Switzerland is in the interest of both sides, and will certainly have positive effects in the further development of this sector, while also representing cooperation that is important for the European continent as a whole. I also support the participation of the Swiss Confederation in Horizon 2020 and ITER, as they improve the global state of technologies and science, while further fostering the development and implementation of such activities by international and regional synergies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. We do not de-introduce the European Union to conclude treaties, in diplomatic matters instead of France. However, in the case of the ITER programme, in view of the strategic interest in the French nuclear industry, we are in favour of it. I have therefore decided to vote for this report on the scientific and technological cooperation agreements with Switzerland.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jerzy Buzek's report on scientific and technological cooperation with Switzerland. This report validates the agreement that has been reached between the EU and Switzerland on scientific cooperation under the Horizon 2020 programme and ITER activities. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which includes the Swiss Confederation in the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme and the European Atomic Energy Community's research and training programme complementing the Horizon 2020 framework programme. , and regulating the Swiss Confederation's participation in THE activities of ITER conducted by Fusion for Energy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. A research agreement with Switzerland is important, but ITER has produced few results as a project. I am abstaining from my voice.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I have voted against this report as it is a working framework for the participation of Switzerland in ITER and nuclear research, the implementation of which should not be supported in any circumstance.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Buzek's proposal for the conclusion of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the EU, the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation. This proposal associates Switzerland with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the European Union's Research and Training Programme.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation. In particular, this agreement allows Switzerland's participation in the ITER programme, a scientific project in terms of strategic fusion energy for the French nuclear industry. Even if the National Front defends national sovereignty and denies the European Union the right to conclude treaties instead of France, the importance of the ITER dossier for our country justifies a favourable vote

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. The ITER dossier, discussed in this agreement, is of paramount importance to the French nuclear industry. The European Union signs an agreement that commits the Member States, which I usually oppose, but, given the strategic importance of the issue to my country, it should be supported.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it supports scientific collaboration with a country that influences the fiscal sovereignty of its neighbouring countries, as well as boosting the mobilisation of resources for THE financing of the ITER, a project which, beyond the risks it may entail, involves a massive mobilisation of the budget with very little return for European citizens. Without going into assessing the project and its implications, the European budget must alleviate emergencies in all countries, which are going through very serious public resource-requiring situations that are systematically denied. Because we believe that human beings should be the first priority, I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: horiAntonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The draft Decision is designed to incorporate Switzerland into the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and at the same time euratom's training programme for atomic energy. This initiative allows our Swiss neighbours access to direct funding from the European Union, including the CERN Institute, a world leader in the field of nuclear research. Partnering with them would catapult us directly to the head and give us access to their resources, which would benefit researchers in the Member States. That is why I support the initiative.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union, namely the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, joins the European Atomic Energy Community Research, Innovation and Training Programme called Horizon 2020.  Given that previously both parties have expressed their desire to continue long-term cooperation in the field of controlled thermonuclear fusion and physics, and all the conditions of the treaty on the functioning of the European Union and the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community have been met, I supported the Report of my colleague Buzek.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Switzerland has been a de facto member for years: cooperation with this country is a long tradition and the Confederation's relations with EU member countries are exemplary. But we can do more for the good of every inhabitant of Europe. I voted for it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the association of the Swiss Confederation with the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation 'Horizon 2020' and with the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community , supplementing horizon 2020 and regulating the swiss confederation's participation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy because it is well documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement. This ITER dossier, a nuclear fusion programme, is of paramount importance to France. Therefore, while we do not appreciate the EU taking over the negotiations, we recognise that Switzerland's participation in this programme is an added value, and we support this approach.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the ITRE Committee has followed up the interim agreement on scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, which associates the Confederation with Horizon 2020, an integrated financing programme for research, innovation and technology activities. This is a very important agreement, born of the intensification of economic relations between the Union and the Confederation, which underlines the need to provide for a general framework within which to regulate cooperation between the European Commission and the Swiss Competition Authority.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report for disagreeing with the ITER project. I argue that in view of the serious risks long known from nuclear, and recalled to each nuclear accident, as was the case with the most recent in Fukushima, it is necessary to abandon this type of energy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. A research agreement with Switzerland would be in itself unobjectionable. Unfortunately, the proposal on ITER activities is not sufficiently formulated and can therefore easily lead to misunderstandings, especially in the area of nuclear fusion. That is why I abstained from voting here.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement that the Swiss Confederation becomes an associated country of horizon 2020 framework programme for research and innovation and governs Switzerland's participation in iter activities of the Fusion Energy Development Joint Undertaking.  The inclusion of Switzerland as an associated country in Horizon 2020 will strengthen scientific excellence and contribute to the creation of an Innovation Union. The agreement should allow Switzerland and the EU to benefit mutually with participation in Horizon 2020. The EU will be able to benefit from switzerland's excellent research and innovation capabilities, its nuclear fission and fusion laboratories and institutes; it is a great research partner for Euratom.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The text submits to the approval of MEPs the conclusion of a scientific and technical cooperation agreement with Switzerland. I am categorically opposed to any cooperation with tax havens. In addition, this would be done under the Horizon 2020 program, which focuses on subjecting research to market laws. Finally, the development of atomic energy in our neighbours poses a threat to France and Europe as a whole. I'm voting against this deal.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. We do not recognise the possibility of the European Union concluding treaties, in diplomatic matters, in place of France. However, in the case of the ITER programme and the strategic interest in the French nuclear industry, we are in favour of it. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have presented my positive vote to the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which associates the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it concerns the scientific and technologic cooperation between the Union and Switzerland under the remit of Horizon 2020. The Union will benefit from Switzerland’s position as a leading player in the fields of research and scientific innovation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Swiss research actors (universities, companies, individuals) will participate in the EU's research and technological development programmes, the most important project of which is Horizon 2020. It represents Europe's largest investment and research programme. I support this measure, as it will be beneficial for development, create jobs and support innovation, which is one of the key instruments of the economy.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims at concluding the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) and Switzerland associating this country to Horizon 2020 – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community complementing Horizon 2020, and regulating Switzerland’s participation in the ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Presentation on the association of the Swiss Confederation with horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme and the European Atomic Energy Community research and training programme complementing Horizon 2020, and the ratification of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the regulation of the participation of the Swiss Confederation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy. As a supporter of international scientific and technological cooperation as widely as possible, I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approve this Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which links the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020 – Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community which complements Horizon 2020 , and which governs the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the Activities of ITER carried out by the Joint Energy Fusion Undertaking.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other hand, associating the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 and the European Atomic Energy Community's research and training programme complementing the Horizon 2020 framework programme , and regulating Switzerland's participation in ITER's activities. This agreement therefore allows Switzerland to participate in the ITER research programme aimed at moving from nuclear energy based on the fusion process to fusion-based energy, which is strategic for the French nuclear industry (not least because its site is located in Cadarache). Even if we deny the European Union the possibility of concluding international agreements, the reasons that have just been invoked are sufficient to justify a vote in favour of this text. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement concluded by the European Commission on behalf of the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation to associate the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020, including cooperation within the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community complementing Horizon 2020 and regulating the Swiss Confederation's participation in the ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text which gives the approval of the European Parliament for the scientific and technological cooperation agreement signed on 5 December between the EU and Switzerland. This agreement strengthens cooperation with Switzerland in the field of controlled thermonuclear fusion and plasma physics, particularly in the context of participation in ITER.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote we give our firm approval to the conclusion of this agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and Switzerland. In fact, we believe it is essential to associate the Swiss Confederation with the Community Research and Innovation Programme – Horizon 2020 and with the Research and Training Programme for the activities carried out by the Fusion for Energy Joint Undertaking for the implementation of ITER. The latter, in particular, will serve as a basis for various joint research and development activities concerning new energy fusion policies.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, regulating the Swiss Confederation’s participation in the ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The purpose of the Agreement is to enable Switzerland to participate in Horizon 2020 under similar conditions to EU Member States.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a member of the ITRE Commission, I believe that this agreement has great potential both in terms of technological and political progress and that it can lead to ever closer cooperation with this country and for this reason I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Cooperation between EU countries and Switzerland in the field of nuclear research, as well as research into elementary particles, is the culmination of today's global science. Such cooperation sometimes has a global dimension, and the success of the projects implemented has long-term economic and political impacts on the internal (between the EU and Switzerland) and the global agenda.  With this new Agreement, Switzerland joins horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme.  which regulates Switzerland's participation in ITER activities. The ITER programme is one of the projects that enables the development of technology for low-cost energy production through controlled fusion. The only thing missing is the appropriate technical design on how to control plasma in the electromagnetic field and therefore the project is delayed. The results achieved so far have led to the desire and need to continue this cooperation, which speaks to the effectiveness of joint action in the field of science and technology. I therefore believe that continued cooperation will also lead to new valuable research (and of course results) useful for both sides, and I support the conclusion of the agreement on scientific and technological cooperation with Switzerland.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Although I do not recognise the right of the European Union to sign such treaties, in this case the issue of this agreement is essential for France: it is indeed a question of allowing Switzerland to participate in the ITER programme. It is therefore a strategic issue for the French nuclear industry and its importance is crucial. Therefore, despite my reservations in principle, I am in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the rapporteur's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which joins the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme. and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme complementing Horizon 2020 and regulating the participation of the Swiss Confederation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy , adopted on 28.5.2015.  As a representative from Croatia, a country whose citizens were directly discriminated against by the results on employment, I am particularly pleased that this issue is regulated and that Switzerland will participate fully in horizon 2020.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I support the Council's decision to conclude an Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union, the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation. The aim of this Agreement is to join Switzerland's Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme complementing Horizon 2020 and to arrange Switzerland's participation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.  I consider that fostering mutual access to research entities and research and technological development activities in Switzerland is in the full interest of both parties to the Agreement. They clearly reaffirm their desire to continue long-term cooperation in the field of controlled thermonuclear fusion and plasma physics on the basis of a new framework and instruments to support research activities.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the framework of cooperation in research, innovation and energy between the European Union and third countries, the European Parliament has approved the conclusion of the cooperation agreement between Switzerland and the EU. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text. This agreement links the Swiss Confederation with the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme, as well as the European Atomic Energy Programme, and governs its participation in ITER's activities.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which links the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020 – Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community that complements Horizon 2020 , and which governs the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the Activities of ITER carried out by the Joint Energy Fusion Undertaking.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Seven months after the official signing of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation under the Italian Presidency between Minister Stefania Giannini and the European Commissioner for Research, Carlos Moedas, the European Parliament gave its opinion this afternoon in favour of this agreement. It provides for the Swiss country's association with Horizon 2020 - the EU's framework programme for research and innovation - and Euratom, the EU's research and training programme, as well as participation in ITER activities. The scale of this scientific cooperation illustrates the importance of EU-Swiss relations and their seniority. For example, the first nuclear fusion agreement was dated September 14, 1978. The Swiss now want to be part of the adventure of the international ITER project for fusion energy concluded by Euratom on November 21, 2006. Another sign of confidence on the part of the European authorities towards the Swiss neighbour was that in 2004 he was granted the right to be represented on the steering committees of specific programmes and in various steering committees, an advantage in participating in the implementation of current research programmes.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Agreement on scientific and technical cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other hand, through which Switzerland will participate as a full partner in Priority I and the horizontal programme on the dissemination of excellence, Euratom, and ITER, and as an industrialized third country in priorities II , III and Horizon 2020's horizontal science and society program.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By adopting this report, the European Parliament has given its approval to the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement with Switzerland. The President of the European Parliament is now responsible for conveying Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Swiss Confederation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal refers to the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and the Swiss Confederation, linking this country to Horizon 2020 - Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme that complements Horizon 2020 and regulates the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the activities of ITER carried out the Joint Energy Merger Undertaking. It was on 15 November 2013 that the Council authorised the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluding this agreement and they were concluded on 24 July 2014. With no substantial reasons for the adoption of this proposal for a recommendation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation under the Horizon 2020 programme.  Cooperation between the EU and Switzerland will cover only parts of the programme, namely "excellent science", the first pillar of Horizon 2020, actions under the specific objective "Spreading excellence and widening participation", and the activities carried out by the Joint Undertaking (JU) "Fusion for Energy" for the construction of ITER (International thermonuclear experimental reactor), an international initiative for the construction and testing of a nuclear fusion reactor in Cadarache (France).

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I recognise the importance of scientific and technological cooperation agreements with third countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution as we consider the ITER project dangerous, costly and uncertain, with a huge opportunity cost in channeling public investment into highly polluting energy (the ITER nuclear fusion presents the same atomic waste storage problems as the current fission). We believe that what Europe urgently needs is a determined commitment to renewable energy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it supports scientific collaboration with a country that influences the fiscal sovereignty of its neighbouring countries, as well as boosting the mobilisation of resources for THE financing of the ITER, a project which, beyond the risks it may entail, involves a massive mobilisation of the budget with very little return for European citizens. Without going into assessing the project and its implications, the European budget must alleviate emergencies in all countries, which are going through very serious public resource-requiring situations that are systematically denied. Because we believe that human beings should be the first priority, I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Horizon 2020 and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme are important tools for stimulating scientific research. The European Union is devoting large sums to these programmes and this will increase knowledge and bring benefits in terms of competitiveness and quality of life for all.  Networking promoted by eu research programmes integrates and guides cultural diversity in achieving innovative and useful results for society. Extending these benefits to third countries under symbiotic conditions is something that I think is appropriate. For these reasons, I welcome the conclusion of this scientific cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation. The results of this cooperation in the past have supported some of the most important scientific research programmes, such as CERN.  By investing in this science, we are taking decisive steps to understand the infinitely small and distant in terms of space and time. Then some of the mysteries of the universe are unraveled.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement concluded by the European Commission on behalf of the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation to associate the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020, including cooperation within the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community complementing Horizon 2020 and regulating the Swiss Confederation's participation in the ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Recommendation looks at and welcomes the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on scientific and technological cooperation, which joins Switzerland to the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and regulates its participation in the activities of the ITER project. The agreement sets out the conditions for Switzerland's participation in the implementation of Horizon 2020, actions under the Objective "Promoting excellence and increasing participation", the Euratom programme and the activities of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the development of fusion energy for the period 2014-2020. Switzerland's participation in Fusion energy activities is of particular concern. The ITER project is one of the least sustainable programmes financed by the European Union and which may not bring concrete, practical and useful solutions at least until 2050.  Implementation delays and poorly identifiable results indicate that the future way in which this project is implemented should be considered in detail. Unfortunately, it does not seem to happen at this time, and I did not support the report on the draft Council decision on Switzerland's participation in the ITER project's activities in the vote.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which joins the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation. and the European Atomic Energy Community Research and Training Programme complementing Horizon 2020 and regulating the participation of the Swiss Confederation in ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy as recommended by the Council's draft decision and the recommendation of the Industry Committee , research and energy.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which approves the agreement concluded by the European Commission on behalf of the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation to associate the Swiss Confederation to Horizon 2020.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This agreement is of utmost importance to our scientific communities. EU researchers will benefit from access to excellent Swiss research institutions and institutions. At the same time, it is essential for Switzerland to have access to mobility programmes for researchers such as the Marie Curie Skłodowska Programme. Furthermore, with this agreement Switzerland renews its obligation to our long-standing and fruitful cooperation.  Cooperation in research and technology between the European Union and Switzerland began back in 1978 when a "historic partnership" for Euratom was achieved. In the last programme (FP7, 2007-2013), Switzerland had a very active participation with 4457 participants from Switzerland in 3404 signed grant agreements, putting Switzerland first among partner countries in terms of number of participations and budget sharing. As part of horizon 2020, Swiss users will be able to participate in actions under the pillar "Excellent Science", which include actions under the European Research Council, Future and New Technologies, Research Infrastructure and Actions Marie Skłodowska-Curie as well as activities under the specific objective "Spreading excellence and expanding participation". In addition, Switzerland will participate as a partner country in the Euratom programme and ITER project.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement which regulates the participation of Switzerland in Horizon 2020 and ITER activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Union's primary objective should be the recovery of national economies, especially the non-strong Member States. Energy fusion agreements are moving in the right direction but do not need immediate mobilisation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider scientific, research and innovation cooperation between the EU and EEA countries to be important. The comprehensive agreement, which also concerns horizon 2020 research and innovation framework programme and the European Atomic Energy Community's research and training programme complementing Horizon 2020, was preceded by a lengthy preparatory phase. As an alternate member of the delegation responsible for relations with Switzerland and Norway and delegated to the EU-Iceland Joint Parliamentary Committee and the EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee, I consider these types of agreements to be particularly important because they will enable us to achieve more effective cooperation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the scientific and technological cooperation agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation, which includes the Swiss Confederation in the framework programme for research and innovation, Horizon 2020, and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community complementing the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme , and regulating the Swiss Confederation's participation in THE activities of ITER conducted by Fusion for Energy.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As a shadow rapporteur I gave my consent to the agreement on scientific cooperation between the EU and Switzerland within Horizon 2020 and ITER activities. Switzerland gained the status of ‘associated country’ in 2004. This status enabled its participation in the EU’s Sixth Research Framework Programme, Seventh RFP and the eighth framework programme Horizon 2020. However, Switzerland held a referendum to reintroduce immigration quotas in February 2014, which had repercussions on the other agreements, notably on the agreement on the scientific cooperation within the EU framework programmes. A new agreement between the EU and Switzerland was reached during the negotiations in 2014, granting Switzerland ‘associated country’ status in some parts of Horizon 2020 (Excellent Science, nuclear energy research) until the end of 2016 in exchange for a financial contribution. I agree with a need to join the effort in the field of science and to extend this cooperation also to another countries. Therefore I support this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has approved the conclusion of the Agreement for scientific and technological cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community, of the one part, and the Swiss Confederation, of the other part, on the swiss confederation's association with the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme, the European Atomic Energy Community programme supplementing Horizon 2020, and participation in activities under the ITER project carried out by fusion for energy. In view of the positive impact of the agreement on the scientific and technological development of the Union, I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution as we consider the ITER project dangerous, costly and uncertain, with a huge opportunity cost in channeling public investment into highly polluting energy (the ITER nuclear fusion presents the same atomic waste storage problems as the current fission). We believe that what Europe urgently needs is a determined commitment to renewable energy.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have given my support to this agreement on scientific and technical cooperation at high level between the European Union and the European Community of Atomic Energy, on the one hand, and the Swiss Confederation, on the other, because the scientific development of excellence is the basis for growth that affects several sectors of the European economy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text would allow Switzerland to participate in the ITER programme, which is strategic for the French nuclear industry. Even if we deny the European Union the right to conclude treaties instead of France, the importance of the ITER programme for France leads me to a favourable vote. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution as we consider the ITER project dangerous, costly and uncertain, with a huge opportunity cost in channeling public investment into highly polluting energy (the ITER nuclear fusion presents the same atomic waste storage problems as the current fission). We believe that what Europe urgently needs is a determined commitment to renewable energy.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. After several years of negotiations, the European Commission has achieved a compromise solution that allows Swiss scientists to participate in European programmes and allows our researchers access to Swiss centres and facilities. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of that agreement in order for the Council, which has already taken two decisions on the subject last December, to ratify the Agreement by means of a decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it supports scientific collaboration with a country that influences the fiscal sovereignty of its neighbouring countries, as well as boosting the mobilisation of resources for THE financing of the ITER, a project which, beyond the risks it may entail, involves a massive mobilisation of the budget with very little return for European citizens. Without going into assessing the project and its implications, the European budget must alleviate emergencies in all countries, which are going through very serious public resource-requiring situations that are systematically denied. Because we believe that human beings should be the first priority, I have decided to vote against this Resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of this agreement with the Swiss Confederation relates to the prior agreement of the European Union with EURATOM and intends to involve the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 - Framework Programme for Research and Innovation - and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community, which complements Horizon 2020. It regulates the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the activities of the ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor). Negotiations were concluded on 24 July 2014.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A research agreement with Switzerland would be in itself unobjectionable. Unfortunately, the proposal on ITER activities is not sufficiently formulated and can therefore easily lead to misunderstandings, especially in the area of nuclear fusion. That is why I abstained from voting here.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on Scientific and Technical Cooperation between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and the Swiss Confederation on the Association of the Swiss Confederation to the Framework Programme for Research and innovation "Horizon 2020" and the European Atomic Energy Community programme for research and training in addition to Horizon 2020, as well as the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the ITER activities of Fusion for Energy, I have worked with my group on Agreed. The ECR supports the call for cooperation with Switzerland under the Horizon 2020 programme. EU-Switzerland cooperation on science does not violate subsidiarity and is worthy of support. Under the Horizon 2020 programme, Switzerland will have the opportunity to participate in scientific projects. In addition, Switzerland, as an associated country, will be able to participate in the Euratom programme and the ITER project.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report calling on the Council to approve, on behalf of the Union, the agreement on scientific cooperation between the EU, Euratom and Switzerland on the ITER project. I think it is important to involve Switzerland in the development of projects in the context of Horizon 2020, in particular with regard to the activities carried out by Fusion for Energy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of this agreement with the Swiss Confederation relates to the prior agreement of the European Union with EURATOM and intends to involve the Swiss Confederation with Horizon 2020 - Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the Research and Training Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community which complements Horizon 2020 - and regularises the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the activities of the International Thermonuclear Nuclear Reactor (ITER). The negotiations were concluded on 24 July 2014. We reaffirm that despite the controversy surrounding this project, we consider it important that energy research can continue to improve and overcome the risks and limitations of the forms of energy currently available, considering the multiplicity of options and focusing on renewable sources. We voted for it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the Agea report on employment guidelines provides a good template for EU policymakers. It provides a comprehensive overview, from requesting a reliable indicator for extreme poverty to identifying risks to the success of the Youth Guarantee. It asks Member States to cut red tape for small businesses, and it also talks about promoting entrepreneurship. Crucially, it talks about aligning training systems in Member States more closely to labour market needs and tackling precarious employment. But I also wish to reiterate the words of Commissioner Thyssen in the debate on this dossier when she said that all citizens want decent work – decent jobs – that will support them and their families. In the ALDE Group, we support the creation of decent jobs, as defined by the ILO. We want to use clearly-defined terms that can be understood and measured.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because mobility, employability, entrepreneurship, everything is named as if workers are unemployed for laziness, disability or lack of initiative. Data care little: that in Spain almost a third of workers had a job below their qualifications; that nearly two million are migrants today; that the number of self-employed people, many false, dependent on large business groups, does not stop growing in proportion to the labour population. Let's get out of the neoliberal framework that clouds these realities. Let's talk about public investment, the only one that can guarantee high value-added jobs. Let's talk about progressive wages and taxes, which sustain demand and employment, sunk by austerity policies. Let's talk about job sharing, because working less we all work. Let us finally talk about labour rights, without which work cannot be a dignified activity. Employment policies cannot be the social appendix to the neoliberal economic project. On the contrary, work is and must be at the heart of a distinct and authentically democratic society.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, our fellow Member Deva, who is also present in this Chamber, led a successful delegation a few weeks ago in South Korea, where I was convinced of the secret of a very poor, miserable country becoming one of the most successful nations and states in the world. They took the same path that my country, Hungary, should have taken after the so-called regime change, instead of being made a large assembly plant. In South Korea, they focused on training, innovation, technological development and the production of their own products produced in this way. That is what I would call a real employment policy and to have an economy that is appropriate to the characteristics of each Member State and to create corresponding jobs, for example in Hungary.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the economic crisis has highlighted weaknesses in the Union economy and we have learned that the economies of the Member States and employment policies, jobs, are interdependent. The report I voted on includes provisions that are about stimulating investment through structural reforms, combating poverty, promoting equal opportunities.  It also provides for mentions of early school leaving, the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people and the link between the labour market and education. These are measures that the Commission must take into account when setting out guidelines for employment policies in the Member States.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Citizenship income is a choice of dignity for citizens. With the report adopted by the European Parliament, we are not talking about welfare, but rather about stimulating concrete and direct action towards the weakest and most marginalised sections of society.  The warning coming from Brussels is addressed above all to those European countries such as Italy and Greece, which do not yet provide for livelihoods for those in poverty, even waiting for a job. There are 26 Member States that have income support measures in place. With this result on the report by the spokeswoman of the 5-Star Movement, Laura Agea, we hope that the whole of Europe will move in the direction of guaranteeing a minimum income of citizenship in employment policies, that is, in the direction of guaranteeing the right to survive with dignity. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite raising important priorities in the field of employment at European Union level, it does not propose true political action against neoliberal austerity policies and therefore does not provide a real solution to the problem of unemployment. This report highlights many positive points that need to be addressed in the European Union's employment policies, but the main problem is that neoliberal policies are a brake on economic activity at a time of global recession. It is necessary to end the austerity of the European Commission and boost the economy through the public sector, given that it is the private sector that has sunk the quality of life of Europeans.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report on Guidelines for employment policies of Member States. This report is certainly an improvement on the Commission proposal on this topic but it also includes several problematic elements that promote business interests at the expense of labour rights. The Commission proposal focused on reforming education systems in order to match skills with the demand of the labour market, modernising social security systems, reforming pension systems including linking retirement age to life expectancy, and shifting the tax burden from labour to other sources of taxation. The Agea report improved on this significantly by including references to decent working conditions and adequate wages, labour standards, adequate social protection, among other things. The report also widened the scope of the report to challenging poverty. I was in favour of many elements of the report. However, there were also several aspects of the report I had problems with, including removing important regulations for business, the promotion of entrepreneurship in the social care sector and skewing the Member States’ education systems to meet the needs of the labour market. I have serious concerns about these aspects of the report, which is why I abstained.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Since the crisis, many people have been in unemployment. Youth unemployment in the EU is over 20%. European solutions are needed to solve this problem on a permanent basis. These guidelines for employment policies are also reflected in the Europe 2020 strategy. Employment policy is listed there as one of the priorities for further promoting the EU's growth and finally overcoming the consequences of the crisis. I therefore support the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Employment policy guidelines are revised annually and are expected to coordinate national employment policies. However, the European Union does not have jurisdiction in this area under the existing treaties. These lines must respect the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy and these policy guidelines. The main objectives are improving labour flexibility, simplifying and modernising social protection, reforming labour taxation, combating long-term unemployment, introducing a minimum income and reforming education and vocational training. Since the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, Europe's labour markets have been deteriorating. These guidelines are a façade for showing good conscience, but the aim is liberal social reform, to the detriment of employment and social protection. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support the principle of an EU-wide minimum income scheme, however much I might support such measures in the Member States themselves.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported Laura Agea's report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies, because it is essential that the Union and all Member States take concrete steps to finally tackle unemployment and new forms of precarious work. The report stresses the importance of setting up a minimum wage and minimum income defined by Member States and combating the segmentation of the labour market. It also reiterates the need to invest in vocational training schemes, particularly for young people, and to better integrate people with disabilities into the labour market. I voted in favour of this report, because the European Parliament must set common priorities and ambitious targets to be achieved within the framework of the employment policies implemented by the Member States.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  Member States' employment policy guidelines must include measures to combat poverty, improve quality employment, social inclusion, education, public administration and public services. Member States should make full use of the support of the European Social Fund and other Union funds in a comprehensive and efficient manner. The European Fund for Strategic Investments and its investment platforms should also be mobilised to ensure the creation of quality jobs and that workers have the skills necessary for the Union to move towards a sustainable growth model.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The "guidelines" for Member States' employment policies are supposed to enable the coordination of reforms to be undertaken in order to "modernise" national labour markets. While many Member States are suffering from budgetary constraints imposed by the euro area and sinking into an unprecedented social crisis, the Commission continues to throw a lot of money in the eye by promising great promises, which it makes to impose ever more its governance.  Technocrats would be well advised to show some humility and question themselves rather than continue to teach us inoperative or even counterproductive lessons.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which contains several positive recommendations, namely: - the creation of sustainable and quality jobs for all (socio-economic security, adequate wages, decent working conditions, social protection, gender equality, vocational training, etc.); - convergence from the top of working conditions; - fighting poverty, etc. These are all priorities that must drive the Union's policies if we are to leave the blind austerity and regain the confidence of the citizens.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies are not only useless but could even prove harmful. Indeed, these guidelines are merely suggestions and are not coercive in nature, as employment policies are (still) the sovereignty of the Member States. The European Union does not have to dictate to the Member States what their policies should be. If we look at the substance of the guidelines, we are not more reassured by the European Union. Indeed, the dogma of ultraliberalism seems to be the norm of this text, between increased flexibility of the labour market, threats to social protection, etc. Moreover, since their inception in 2010, the situation on the employment front has continued to deteriorate. In reality, these guidelines seek to break jobs and social protection to pave the way for TTIP. For these reasons, I am voting against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the text contains interesting ideas and which I share, since Amendment No 47 calling for further 'structural reforms' and 'budgetary discipline', and therefore other troika sanctions, was adopted during the vote, I have decided to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament makes its proposals and recommendations to the Member States on employment policy. In particular, we call on the Member States, in cooperation with local and regional authorities, to improve their social protection systems by ensuring basic standards, ensuring effective, effective and sustainable protection at all stages of a person's life, ensuring a dignified life, solidarity, the right to social protection, full respect for social rights, justice and the elimination of inequalities. In addition, it is necessary to continue to combat rising poverty, particularly in relation to people excluded from the labour market and belonging to the most vulnerable groups. The problem of child poverty should be tackled with particular determination. Social policies need to be simpler, more targeted and more ambitious, including by providing affordable and quality childcare and education services, effective training and job search assistance, housing support and high-quality healthcare available to all, and access to essential services such as bank accounts and the Internet. Measures must also be taken to combat early school leaving, in particular extreme poverty, social exclusion and, more generally, all forms of poverty.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, the European Commission prepares the so-called Employment Directives for the Member States and the European Council discusses the so-called Employment Directives (in the framework of an EPSCO meeting). Since the public employment system was launched in Hungary, it has been constantly criticised by the European Commission, even though the legacy in this area is particularly serious. In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), which operates under European standards, found that the number of unemployed increased by 150,000 during that period. At the same time, the number of low-skilled people out of work has increased dramatically in the eu's most developed countries (e.g. Denmark, Luxembourg), which needs to be addressed in the short term. This is what the European Parliament recognised in this report. This is by ensuring that they are provided with work in order to ensure that as many people as possible work and that the employment situation improves. Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the employment policy guidelines drawn up by the Employment Committee, as I consider it crucial to be involved in the exchange of experience in the fight against unemployment in the EU. We know that some countries are more successful in this area than others, and mutual assistance comes in handy here. It is precisely the area of retraining and employment of the low-skilled workforce, which is the most helpless and vulnerable in today's globalised world, is the biggest challenge of employment policies.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report, which is positive and includes several key issues: sustainable and quality job creation, decent working conditions, decent pay set through collective bargaining, the fight against poverty. Quality job creation should be a European priority, and this allows people to have a decent standard of living.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report on Guidelines for employment policies of Member States. This report is certainly an improvement on the Commission proposal on this topic but it also includes several problematic elements that promote business interests at the expense of labour rights. The Commission proposal focused on reforming education systems in order to match skills with the demand of the labour market, modernising social security systems, reforming pension systems including linking retirement age to life expectancy, and shifting the tax burden from labour to other sources of taxation. The Agea report improved on this significantly by including references to decent working conditions and adequate wages, labour standards, adequate social protection, among other things. The report also widened the scope of the report to challenging poverty. I was in favour of many elements of the report. However, there were also several aspects of the report I had problems with, including removing important regulations for business, the promotion of entrepreneurship in the social care sector and skewing Member States’ education system to meet the needs of the labour market. I have serious concerns about these aspects of the report, which is why I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the guidelines for Member States' employment policies should be more geared towards growth and social cohesion taking into account all components of the economic system, from low-skilled workers to SMEs.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report attempts to find solutions to curb structural unemployment in EU Member States. It shows that the lack of coordination of national policies is causing tensions in the labour market. The Commission proposes in this text to harmonize labour laws and social protection systems as well as to promote the mobility of employees in order to unify the European labour market. Other avenues are also being considered, such as improving education and promoting learning, and reducing taxation on labour. The convergence of social rules and taxation within the Union would have the merit of preventing Member States from carrying out non-cooperative policies. Nevertheless, the solutions put forward in this report are illusory. While they would reduce unemployment, increase the competitiveness of large groups and mitigate the impact of asymmetric shocks on our economies, the harmonization of social conditions will be achieved from the bottom up for the benefit of multinationals and at the expense of the best-protected employees. We do not want to fight unfair competition in the EU at the cost of our social model. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objectives of the European Employment Strategy must be, first and foremost, to combat unemployment, especially among young people, worker security, information technology training measures and adapt to new economic trends. Member States should adopt common rules on economic and social policies and provide for a coordinated action plan with a view to implementing the employment strategy. The establishment of a coherent framework adapted to new realities should take into account the new benchmarks that have emerged and developed with technological advance and increased access to digital means. The digital economy has significant employment potential through its ability to create new jobs that are developing horizontally. I was in favour of this report because I believe that only a common framework undertaken by the 28 Member States is a response to the success of the European employment strategy.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. At the heart of the report is the call for all Member States to adopt guaranteed minimum income systems. The text contains other interesting ideas, but there is no mention in the report of the fact that setting a guaranteed minimum income in the context of wage deflation imposed by the euro is in danger of becoming an instrument of wage deflation, that is, of further incentive to ceiling income from work/pension downwards (the 'guaranteed minimum'). The adoption of Amendment No 47, which calls for further 'structural reforms' and 'budgetary discipline', i.e. other doses of the troika's misguided medicine, makes it impossible for me to maintain a favourable orientation.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The economic crisis has highlighted the need to increase convergence between Member States' economic and social policies. Unemployment is one of the most visible consequences of the crisis, as it directly affects European citizens. We need to coordinate our employment policy actions in order to be more coherent and effective in the fight against unemployment. We have created instruments at European level such as the European Social Fund that must be fully used. By adding these instruments together with ambitious policies, we can combat this scourge of unemployment. I voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies.  The guidelines for Member States' employment policies guide the coordination of national policies and are based on the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The Treaties stipulate that the Member States must regard the promotion of employment as a matter of common interest, and must therefore adopt draft broad economic policy guidelines and guidelines for employment policies, which must be consistent with each other. The guidelines therefore lay the foundations for Member States' action in these areas. I voted in favour of this report because it highlighted the importance of creating quality and sustainable jobs, decent working conditions and wages, promoting the fight against poverty, achieving the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy through the European Semester and succeeding in reducing the segmentation of the labour market and inequalities through the fight against job insecurity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report on Guidelines for employment policies of Member states. This report is certainly an improvement on the Commission proposal on this topic but it also includes several problematic elements that promote business interests at the expense of labour rights. The Commission proposal focused on reforming education systems in order to match skills with the demand of the labour market, modernising social security systems, reforming pension systems including linking retirement age to life expectancy, and shifting the tax burden from labour to other sources of taxation. The Agea report improved on this significantly by including references to decent working conditions and adequate wages, labour standards, adequate social protection, among other things. The report also widened the scope of the report to challenging poverty. I was in favour of many elements of the report. However, there were also several aspects of the report I had problems with, including removing important regulations for business, the promotion of entrepreneurship in the social care sector and skewing Member States’ education systems to meet the needs of the labour market. I have serious concerns about these aspects of the report, which is why I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support the principle of an EU-wide minimum income scheme, however much I might support such measures in the Member States themselves. This should be a matter wholly for national parliaments to decide on.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as it highlights a number of elements such as the prevention of early school leaving, the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people, an emphasis on the educational systems with a focus on skills, and the improved link between education and the labour market. I believe that job seekers need to be equipped with the skills employers are looking for not just in tackling youth unemployment, but also the overarching problem of long-term unemployment. It might be the time for adapting and updating the educational framework, possibly through more innovative teaching methods and equipping youth with skills broad enough to equip them with a solid basis for life-long employability.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring a sufficient wage for a dignified life across the EU is one of the biggest battles of mine and the 5 Star Movement. I could only vote in favour of my colleague Laura Agea's excellent report, which highlights the importance of policies to ensure that wages ensure an adequate subsistence income in order to create jobs and reduce poverty in the Eu ropean Union.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the Council's proposed decision on Member States' employment guidelines. These guidelines are merely declarations of good intentions, which allow the European Union to adorn itself with morality by pretending to be concerned about employment and social affairs. In reality, not only do these lines remain the domain of suggestion - the Union does not, fortunately, have competence in the field - but these orientations seek to push Member States towards convergence, that is, the standardisation of employment standards, to the detriment of national specificities. While the desire to promote the introduction of a minimum income or social dialogue can be welcomed, it is clear that all employment guidelines remain subject to the constraints of the Stability Pact, which introduces fiscal austerity that risks holding back these good employment initiatives.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The deep and long economic crisis continues to have serious effects on employment in all countries; the problems on which the institutions and the Member States must do more and better. Full employment, which the Treaty of Lisbon has re-proposed as an EU objective, must be the pillar around which policies can be built and planned for the coming years. If recovery and growth are not to remain in vain, bold and decisive choices will have to be made. The high rates of unemployment are now unacceptable and it is clear that we need a reversal that points in the only possible direction: growth and the revival of investment, without which it is unimaginable to start again and without which it will be difficult to revive employment. I hope that the Member States will be able to take useful pointers from the employment policy guidelines to review their internal policies to combat unemployment. The reduction of the tax burden on labour, as set out in Guideline 5, should be the element on which the Member States should be most committed. The report voted on here today supplements and improves, in my opinion, the text proposed by the Commission, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I support positively the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for employment policies of the Member States, where it asks to be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the Commission's proposal.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The aim of this proposal is to support the Europe 2020 strategy as part of the new approach to economic decision-making built on investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on employment, which remains one of the most discussed in times of economic and financial crisis. At European level, we are always trying to stimulate growth: getting out of the crisis also means reducing unemployment, increasing the number of jobs available and helping families in their daily lives. It is not easy, especially at this particular time in history when relocation continues to be an increasing phenomenon.  Promoting a skilled and qualified workforce also responds to the shared need to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress, objectives that have always been among the most promoted by the EU system. Creating jobs is one of the most important challenges facing us at the moment, and determined and coordinated political action is required at both national and Union level. Relaunching investment, funds for SMEs, support for businesses, start-ups, the agricultural sector, under all the priority topics on our agenda to try to increase the labour supply. Particular attention is paid to young people, encouraging their education and training to facilitate their access to the world of work.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
