text: in writing. \u2012 Although I voted in favour of Mrs Agea's report, I cannot but express my concern about certain points in this report aimed at creating forms of income support and social protection. Personally, I am opposed to welfare measures such as citizenship income.  In my opinion, action is needed to stimulate economic growth and to promote the creation of new jobs. At the moment, especially in Italy, youth unemployment and the relocation of many companies are major structural problems.  Rather, it would be necessary to channel public resources into concrete objectives such as promoting entrepreneurship among young people, improving training and education systems in order to avoid early school leaving and brain drain, and reducing bureaucracy in order to relieve SMEs of often unnecessary burdens.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is positive to see the work being done towards a Union where we tackle unemployment collectively. We must have a developed strategy which will promote having a workforce which is responsive to the needs of society today. It is positive to see work being done towards a union with less long-term unemployment. We should have policies which promote better wages, and decent working conditions. It is also good to see that equal opportunities for everyone are being promoted and social exclusion is to be reduced. For these principles and policies to be truly effective, there must be good governance of each Member State. It is important that bureaucratic measures are reduced to also make it easier for SMEs to contribute to job creation, this though must not leave room for abuse. Therefore employment policies must encourage the employment of individuals, they must enhance the skills of the unemployed so as to make them employable, they must be less bureaucratic and they must be fair, giving everyone an equal chance.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite raising important priorities in the field of employment at European Union level, it does not propose true political action against neoliberal austerity policies and therefore does not provide a real solution to the problem of unemployment. This report highlights many positive points that need to be addressed in the European Union's employment policies, but the main problem is that neoliberal policies are a brake on economic activity at a time of global recession. It is necessary to end the austerity of the European Commission and boost the economy through the public sector, given that it is the private sector that has sunk the quality of life of Europeans.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it promotes effective employment and education policies at Member State and Union level with the final aim of achieving full employment and social progress objectives. Having said that, my vote reflected also my belief that what is Member State competence should remain as such. Furthermore I believe that unemployment benefits should target unemployment whereas start-ups should have grants specific for them.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that a determined, coordinated, ambitious, but above all effective strategic action is needed, both at Union and national level, in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty and the economic governance of the Union, leading to the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises, innovative new enterprises and companies promoting environmentally friendly jobs. These actions should also contain social protection measures, such as a guaranteed minimum income, to be introduced in accordance with national practices and which must aim at combating extreme poverty and social exclusion.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The initiative report focuses on the Commission's recent adoption of new guidelines on Member States' employment policy. According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Member States have jurisdiction over employment, but their action can be coordinated by the Council of Ministers with the assistance of the Commission. As such, the new draft guidelines aim to stimulate labour demand, improve labour supply and skills, improve the functioning of the labour market and ensure equity, combat poverty and promote equal opportunities. The European Parliament supports these, while emphasizing the prevention of early school departures, the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people, the emphasis on the education system with a "practical" objective and a link between education and the world of work. Considering that better coordination of employment policies is needed to deal with unemployment particularly present in the countries of southern Europe and to offer European citizens stable, suitable, sustainable and quality jobs, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaties stipulate that Member States must regard their economic policies and the promotion of employment as a matter of common interest. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies because I consider it to be a good text, which satisfies the positions of the S&D Group and our country.  The report focuses on some important issues such as the creation of sustainable and quality jobs, decent working conditions and wages, the fight against poverty, the reduction of labour market segmentation, gender equality and the reduction of inequalities through the fight against job insecurity.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), which operates under European standards, found that the number of unemployed persons increased by 150,000 over the period 2001-2011. At the time of the change of government in 2010, almost 30% of the unemployed in Hungary had no more than 170,000 primary education, based on the highest level of completed education. Around 2001-2004, the situation of unskmarked people deteriorated by almost 100,000, and from 2008-2009 the situation of unskmarked people worsened, with 98 000 people becoming unemployed in one year. A year later, between 2009 and 2010, another 93,000 people lost their jobs among low-educated people. At the same time, the number of low-skilled people out of work has increased dramatically in the eu's most developed countries (e.g. Denmark, Luxembourg), which needs to be addressed in the short term, as the European Parliament recognised in this report. This is by ensuring that they are provided with work in order to ensure that as many people as possible work and that the employment situation improves. Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people. The amendment tabled by Adam Kósa drew attention to this, which was also supported by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, so I voted in favour of the report in its final form.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the Council's proposed decision on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The guidelines promoted by the Union are only incentives but do not seem to be going in the right direction. Indeed, even if social policies remain the domain of states, the Union sets itself the objective of harmonising them. These guidelines allow for gentle coercion to serve an objective that we refuse. France must preserve its levels of social protection which benefit workers. I therefore object to the Commission's desire to interfere once again in the affairs of States.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In principle I support the effort to improve employment guidelines by cutting red-tape and easing the burden on the private sector, often carried foremost by smaller- and medium-sized enterprises. Nonetheless, I would rather see an improvement of current conditions such as streamlining wages, economic governance and the introduction of guaranteed minimum incomes. What we need are structural reforms that take into account the different realities encountered throughout the Union. Of special significance are barriers to growth and employment. However, these may not be overcome by over-regulation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because, although this report has many positive elements and steps in the right direction, it cannot unfortunately escape the context of the austerity policies and logic that created the problem from the outset.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, the European Commission prepares the so-called Employment Directives for the Member States and the European Council discusses the so-called Employment Directives (in the framework of an EPSCO meeting). Since the public employment system was launched in Hungary, it has been constantly criticised by the European Commission, even though the legacy in this area is particularly serious. In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), which operates under European standards, found that the number of unemployed increased by 150,000 during that period. At the time of the change of government in 2010, almost 30 % of the unemployed in Hungary had no more than 170,000 primary education, based on the highest level of completed education. Around 2001-2004, the situation of unskmarked people deteriorated by almost 100,000, and from 2008-2009, when 98 000 people were out of work in one year. A year later, between 2009 and 2010, another 93,000 people lost their jobs among low-educated people.  Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people. The amendment tabled by Adam Kósa drew attention to this, which was also supported by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, so I voted in favour of the report in its final form.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by my M5S colleague Laura Agea on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies went beyond consultation, thus defining the European Parliament's position on the matter. The text was approved by most of the House (520 votes in favour, 116 against and 60 abstentions). This report sets out the employment guidelines, i.e. defines common priorities and objectives for labour policies; they follow the latest employment guidelines adopted in 2010 to define the Europe 2020 strategy. The key points of the report relate mainly to the need to combat social exclusion and all forms of poverty.  We voted in favour because this text contains key points for the M5S, such as the adoption of measures such as the guaranteed minimum income in all Member States, given that, at the moment, forms of income support and social protection already exist in 26 States. This key point, which has received the support of Commissioner Thyssen, expresses the need to ensure an adequate subsistence income in order to create jobs and reduce poverty in the Union, since economic policies cannot be based solely on the achievement of fiscal parameters.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 With these guidelines, the European Parliament clearly states that more needs to be done to help them furthest from the labour market and also highlights the need for effective policies to lift the regions that are particularly deprived. The investments made by the European Parliament should mainly promote green growth and the conditions for SMEs. The fact that the guidelines now being singled out by the European Parliament also point out the need for a tax change in which taxes on labour are reduced is positive.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it goes in the direction of greater constraints for the Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report defies a series of "good intentions" relating to employment policies. It introduces some improvements to the Commission's initial proposal, notably through references to good working conditions and adequate wages; social protection and the need to establish a minimum wage per Member State; references to the promotion of equality; combating precarious employment relationships; the fight against poverty. However, in addition to the duality that many concepts used have (flexibility, adaptable, etc.), it fixaises on the mythical and sacrosanct "entrepreneurship" as a way to reach their desiderates. Encouraged in multiple ways, including as a curricular component in the public education system - there is a reference to "necessary flexibility in education systems and practical guidance", revealing a professionalising drift - the logic inherent in the Europe 2020 strategy, the European Semester and other policies based on supranational interference and the imposition of austerity. This is a reductive view, of class (that of the ruling class), which we obviously repudiate.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which urges Member States to adopt guaranteed minimum income systems.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for member states' employment policies, because, although this report has many positive elements and steps in the right direction, it cannot unfortunately escape the context of the austerity policies and logic that created the problem from the outset.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it intrudes upon areas of Member State competence.  Too often this Parliament seeks to legislate where it has no power. These guidelines go far beyond what they should. It entirely ignores areas of exclusive Member State competency. I cannot support them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It looks like Europe’s job-rich recovery continues to fail to materialise. I strongly believe that quality job creation should be Europe’s number one priority. This would allow European citizens to have a decent standard of living and contribute to their well-being and to a robust economy. I believe this is a very positive report as it includes several of our S&D key issues: sustainable and quality job creation; decent working conditions; decent living wages set up through collective bargaining; the fight against poverty; the importance of delivering EU2020 targets through the European Semester; inclusive and rights-based labour markets with adequate social protection; reforms aiming at reducing inequalities and increasing the well-being of citizens; reducing labour market segmentation by tackling precarious employment, underemployment, undeclared labour and zero-hour contracts; ensuring quality employment for all in terms of socio-economic security, durability, adequate wages, rights at work, decent workplace conditions, social security protection, gender equality, education and training opportunities. This is why I believe that the review of Europe 2020 must be used as an opportunity to put quality jobs at the centre of European policy.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, the European Commission prepares the so-called Employment Directives for the Member States and the European Council discusses the so-called Employment Directives (in the framework of an EPSCO meeting). Since the public employment system was launched in Hungary, it has been constantly criticised by the European Commission, even though the legacy in this area is particularly serious. In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), which operates under European standards, found that the number of unemployed increased by 150,000 during that period. At the time of the change of government in 2010, almost 30% of the unemployed in Hungary had no more than 170,000 primary education, based on the highest level of completed education. Around 100,000 people joined the EU, and the situation of unskmarked people worsened.  At the same time, the number of low-skilled people out of work has increased dramatically in the eu's most developed countries, which needs to be addressed in the short term, as the European Parliament recognised in its report. They should be able to work in order to attract more people to work and to improve the employment situation. Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people. By my vote, I also supported the report in its final form.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, the European Commission prepares the so-called Employment Directives for the Member States and the European Council discusses the so-called Employment Directives (in the framework of an EPSCO meeting). Since the public employment system was launched in Hungary, it has been constantly criticised by the European Commission, even though the legacy in this area is particularly serious. In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), which operates under European standards, found that the number of unemployed increased by 150,000 during that period. At the same time, the number of low-skilled people out of work has increased dramatically in the eu's most developed countries (e.g. Denmark, Luxembourg), which needs to be addressed in the short term, as the European Parliament recognised in this report. This is by ensuring that they are provided with work in order to ensure that as many people as possible work and that the employment situation improves.  Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people. The amendment tabled by Adam Kósa drew attention to this, which was also supported by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, so I voted in favour of the report in its final form.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations for member states' employment guidelines because they are the legal, albeit non-legislative, instrument by which the EP can influence the future work of the EC and particularly makes it possible to moderate the very frequent tendency of the Latter to think that the creation of new jobs is not inseparable from the flexibility that is often synonymous with precariousness. On the contrary, as European Socialists and Democrats, we believe that we must create new quality and sustainable jobs and that this requires a more comprehensive economic strategy that promotes growth and restarts investment, not least that workers must be properly remunerated and protected in the workplace. From this point of view, the resolution adopted by the EP, with the substantial contribution of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), even earlier through amendments which I myself tabled together with other authoritative group colleagues, insists on the new indicators (on poverty, the guaranteed minimum wage) and to combat the segmentation of the labour market, precarious work, underemployment and the , against undeclared work and against the zero-hours contract mentioned in the resolution.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against today the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies, as it, modified by amendments, sets priorities that clearly fall within national competence. In addition, the report forgets one important area: the home work and parental performance of parents. Here I would like to see new accents and new fairness through an educational salary.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Agea report because I believe it is high time the cost of living crisis, that has been felt for too long in the UK and throughout Europe, was addressed. Too many people find themselves stuck on zero hour contracts or in precarious work. Labour wants to see wage growth and the protection of workers’ rights which this report achieves.  We owe it to our citizens to tap the full potential of instruments offered by the EU to invest in sustainable and quality job creation; decent working conditions; decent living wages set up through collective bargaining; rights-based labour markets with adequate social protection; reduced labour market segmentation; and quality employment for all in terms of socio-economic security. I furthermore agree that the review of Europe 2020 must be used as an opportunity to put quality jobs at the centre of European policy. Europe’s job-rich recovery has to materialise now.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the Agea report which presents a number of guidelines for Member States on employment policy. It is not possible to sufficiently underline the negative effect that unemployment has on society. This report covers a wide range of issues, from improving worker training and mobility to eliminating bureaucratic hurdes for businesses. These are useful guidelines for Member States to generate job opportunities and get citizens to find work. According to Eurostat, the unemployment rate in the EU was 9.9% at the end of 2014. Spain currently suffers from an unemployment rate of 22%. The EU institutions and the governments of the Member States must ensure the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which entail the setting of concrete and measurable targets for employment, innovation, education, social inclusion and energy. This is an effort shared by all and this report is one more step in the right direction.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The unemployment rate is the real indicator of how suffering Europe is. Europe cannot be united as long as there are countries with youth unemployment rates of more than 40% compared to a European average of less than half.  I voted in favour of this report because the aim must not just be to create jobs. More broadly, the objective of the Member States must be the creation of a more inclusive and rights-based labour market, accompanied by adequate social protection.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote. While references to 'education systems adapted to labour market needs', 'encouraging entrepreneurship — also from school age – as a solution to unemployment', 'encouraging Member States to convert unemployment benefits into business subsidies' or 'entrepreneurship in the social services sector' make our vote impossible in favour, the rapporteur has made a laudable conciliation effort in her report , which represents a substantial improvement in the Commission's text. Reference is made to decent working conditions, adequate wages and collective bargaining; adequate social protection, including a guaranteed minimum income; equality in the labour market, including affordable and quality child care; reducing labour market segmentation, addressing precarious employment, outsourcing and undeclared labour; the fight against poverty and exclusion; and measures to support social security.  In addition, it disassociates the retirement age from life expectancy and mentions labour mobility as a fundamental right of free choice. These aspects are necessary requirements for any employment guidance for Member States and essential guidelines for any employment policy.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. For me, employment is the major issue of the European Union at the beginning of the new Parliament. Europe is barely recovering from the crisis that has hit it hard since 2008. There are now more than 25 million unemployed in Europe, including 5 million young people. In recent months, progress has been made and many Member States have seen their unemployment rates fall as a result of efforts made in their employment policies. The European Union also supports these initiatives by regularly publishing 'employment policy guidelines', which contain advice and recommendations for Member States.   While the Council has put forward good proposals in these guidelines, they have often remained too vague. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which amends the guidelines in order to obtain more commitments from the Member States in an effective and coordinated fight against the scourge of unemployment for too many of our citizens.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I alongside my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party voted in favour of action to deal with abusive zero-hour contracts, which offer no job security and stop workers from being able to plan for their future, get credit or apply for a mortgage. Over 5 million people in the UK today are in low-paid jobs, many of these people are on zero-hour contracts. This report recognises and goes some way in tackling this problem. The EU gets it. But does Cameron’s Tory government?

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which stresses in particular that employment policies in the Member States must be part of a new economic approach based on investment, structural reforms and a more responsible approach to budgetary matters. The text we voted on today calls for improving and simplifying the functioning of the labour market in the Member States, ensuring fairness, combating precariousness and promoting entrepreneurship, while emphasizing the need to better adapt higher education to the labour market and the needs of businesses.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Agea report makes a number of proposals for Member States' labour market policies in the context of the European Semester. There are some positive signals, such as Amendment No 10, which denies the EU the power to create a Union-wide minimum wage, or Amendment No 21, which proposes cutting red tape for SMEs. Unfortunately, there are also many approaches to centralisation in the report. Among other things, it calls for the unification of social policy and an extension of area tariffs, but also complains of asymmetric shocks from the economic crisis elsewhere. In a monetary union, however, only labour market flexibility can replace the lack of a currency devaluation mechanism. The proposals therefore run the risk of labour markets becoming more flexible and shocks more severe. For this reason, the paper is not effective.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), operating under European standards, found that the number of unemployed increased by 150,000 during that period. At the time of the change of government in 2010, almost 30% of the unemployed in Hungary had no more than 170,000 primary education, based on the highest level of completed education. Around 2001-2004, the situation of unskmarked people deteriorated by almost 100,000 and from 2008-2009, when 98 000 people were unemployed in one year. A year later, between 2009 and 2010, another 93,000 people lost their jobs among low-educated people. At the same time, the number of low-skilled people out of work has increased dramatically in the eu's most developed countries (e.g. Denmark, Luxembourg), which needs to be addressed in the short term, as the European Parliament recognised in this report. This is by ensuring that they are provided with work in order to ensure that as many people as possible work and that the employment situation improves. Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people. Adam Kósa's amendment drew attention to this, which was also supported by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, so I voted in favour of the report in its final form.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the need to eliminate poverty across the EU through the promotion of decent, well-paying jobs.  My country has the misfortune of having many aspects of its employment policies governed by a Tory government for which the people did not vote.  Today’s vote sent out a strong message and the EU will play a valuable role if it is in any way able to mitigate the worst excesses of London Tory rule.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote. While references to 'education systems adapted to labour market needs', 'encouraging entrepreneurship — also from school age – as a solution to unemployment', 'encouraging Member States to convert unemployment benefits into business subsidies' or 'entrepreneurship in the social services sector' make our vote impossible in favour, the rapporteur has made a laudable conciliation effort in her report , which represents a substantial improvement in the Commission's text. Reference is made to decent working conditions, adequate wages and collective bargaining; adequate social protection, including a guaranteed minimum income; equality in the labour market, including affordable and quality child care; reducing labour market segmentation, addressing precarious employment, outsourcing and undeclared labour; the fight against poverty and exclusion; and measures to support social security.  In addition, it disassociates the retirement age from life expectancy and mentions labour mobility as a fundamental right of free choice. These aspects are necessary requirements for any employment guidance for Member States and essential guidelines for any employment policy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft Council decision proposal on Member States' employment policy guidelines, as this document contains very useful and concrete proposals on how the Union and the Member States need to move to implement reforms and harmonise employment strategies, increase labour market opportunities, combat social exclusion and all forms of poverty, create the necessary skills and knowledge needed in the labour market , encourage youth entrepreneurship, and set up micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, increase the employment rate for women, and promote the green, white and blue jobs sectors. Therefore, I voted for this proposal, and I believe that success in this area requires ambitious, effective and coherent political action at Union and Member State level.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The employment policy guidelines are revised annually and are intended to help coordinate national employment policies, but the European Union has no jurisdiction in this area. These lines must respect the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy and these policy guidelines. The main objectives are improving labour flexibility, simplifying and modernising social protection, reforming labour taxation, combating long-term unemployment, introducing a minimum income, education reform and vocational training. Since their inception, labour markets have been deteriorating. These guidelines are a façade for showing good conscience, but the goal is reform. So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Laura Aega's report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The aim of this report is to define the economic and employment guidelines with the aim of supporting the Europe 2020 strategy. These guidelines include the focus on stimulating job demand and improving the functioning of the labour market. The report also mentions several important points such as the prevention of school drop-out or the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. The European Union must encourage Member States to be active in employment policies and to create business-friendly conditions. Member States must give priority to education in order, in particular, to bring training in line with the need for the market and to prevent school drop-outs.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against the report because, in many areas, it aims at centralising competences, which are supposed to be a matter for the Member States. The labour market and social policy should not be communitised. I am therefore voting against the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the European Union's capacity to ensure growth and employment development is a more coordinated strategy and approach to employment development. This strategy and the national guidelines must be sustainable and be able to keep up with economic development. In the future, the European Union must ensure that the workforce in the Member States is skilled and that the number of unemployed is shrinking throughout the Union. In plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the final text of the report because I believe that the proposal for guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States would be a step closer to reducing unemployment in the EU. It seems particularly important to me that the report highlights initiatives to promote youth employment, which is a huge challenge for the EU, given that statistics in this area are not very encouraging at present in several Member States. However, I believe that the system of gender quotas in the workplace should be left to the Member States, so I voted against the amendment to this report, which provides for the introduction of a system of gender quotas in the workplace, although I strongly support gender equality and its promotion in the European Union.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 July 2015, we voted on the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the employment guidelines of the Member States. The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU stipulates that Member States consider their economic policies and employment promotion to be a matter of common interest and therefore coordinate their activities within the Council. In the Commission's proposal, we will find, inter alia, the reform of education systems so that skills meet labour market demand, the modernisation of social security systems, the reform of the pension system, including the link between retirement age and life expectancy, and the shift of the tax burden from work to other sources of taxation that are less harmful to employment and growth. In general, the AGEA report was much better than the Commission's original proposal, as it also contains references, inter alia, to decent working conditions and adequate wage levels, references to adequate social protection, including a guaranteed minimum income, and a reference to the importance of focusing on the increasing shortage of public sector workers, such as healthcare and social services. However, the final text of the report was strongly negatively affected by the proposals of colleagues from the EPP and alde and thus weakened significantly, in particular as regards social security arrangements. That's why I was forced to abstain.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, the European Commission prepares the so-called Employment Directives for the Member States and the European Council discusses the so-called Employment Directives (in the framework of an EPSCO meeting). Since the public employment system was launched in Hungary, it has been constantly criticised by the European Commission, even though the legacy in this area is particularly serious. In its most recent analysis in April 2015, the Hungarian Central Statistical Office (CSO), which operates under European standards, found that the number of unemployed increased by 150,000 during that period. At the time of the change of government in 2010, almost 30% of the unemployed in Hungary had no more than 170,000 primary education, based on the highest level of completed education.  Around 2001-2004, the situation of unskmarked people deteriorated by almost 100,000, and from 2008-2009, when 98 000 people were out of work in one year. A year later, between 2009 and 2010, another 93,000 people lost their jobs among low-educated people. At the same time, the number of low-skilled people out of work has increased dramatically in the eu's most developed countries (e.g. Denmark, Luxembourg), which needs to be addressed in the short term, as the European Parliament recognised in this report.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for member states' employment policies. The financial and economic crisis and its social impact justify the need for a new wording of employment guidelines for Member States' policies. One of these concerns promoting equal opportunities and combating poverty and social exclusion, which are at risk for 120 million Europeans. The fight against poverty and exclusion must be based primarily on economic growth and employment and on modern and effective social protection. In order to ensure such effective, efficient and simplified social protection, it should be combined with a broad set of social policies including: targeted education, promotion and promotion of social justice, health, housing, anti-discrimination, reconciliation of private and professional life by ensuring high-quality care for children and adult inseparable adults and family policy. Reforms of pension systems ensuring decent living conditions and equal opportunities for women and men are also important.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Agea's report. Member States and the Union should work to develop an effective and coordinated employment strategy to counter the serious effects of unemployment, as well as to promote a skilled and qualified workforce and labour markets capable of responding to economic, social and environmental changes. Unfortunately, high unemployment in several EU countries must be strongly combated and support for employment, especially among young people, is the priority of our political action.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. Employment policy is the responsibility of the Member States. It is therefore not for the European Union to deal with them, even if the measures recommended are not binding and some of them use common sense.  In reality, it is a matter for the Commission to buy a social conscience at a low cost, and growth would have to be more tangible in order for some of the proposed measures to be applicable. Many Member States are suffering from budgetary constraints imposed by the euro area and are sinking into an unprecedented social crisis. They do not need to be imposed a course of action by the European Commission.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported this report because job creation and the respect for workers' rights should be a priority of European policy. Economic recovery in Europe, which is conducive to employment growth, has still not materialise, and this is a prerequisite for ensuring decent living standards for people and strengthening the economy. The review of the Europe 2020 strategy provides an opportunity to create quality jobs and improve working conditions as one of the pillars of EU policy.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The sovereignty of the Member States is still being undermined in this area in several areas. Moreover, the measures described do not appear to be effective because of weak economic growth. It is therefore more of a report of intentions, but the main problem is that these projects can only be implemented if Member States follow restrictive measures well defined by the European Union. However, the economic situation of many of these countries pushes them to follow policies of fiscal constraint. They do not need the European Union to add other obligations.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Parliament's report contains many positive elements: the creation of sustainable and quality employment, decent working conditions, decent wages achieved through collective bargaining, the fight against poverty, the importance of achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy through the European Semester, inclusive and rights-based labour markets with adequate social protection (including minimum income) , reforms aimed at reducing inequalities and increasing the well-being of citizens, reducing the segmentation of the labour market, addressing employment contracts, underemployment, precarious undeclared labour and zero-hour contracts. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. A number of guidelines are offered under Horizon 2020 to increase labour demand; improve workers' skills and therefore job supply; improve the functioning of the labour market; and ensure impartiality in the recruitment process while combating poverty and promoting a level playing field. Specific guidelines included in the Decision take into account measures to prevent school drop-out. These have a particular emphasis on educational alternatives with a hands-on approach to providing more training opportunities for young people. I believe that in this way we are approaching a fairer system, and that is why I am undoubtedly in favour of this initiative.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the context of the debate on European employment policy, I draw attention to two issues: how this policy is conducted and how it is monitored. The European Union is taking a number of actions and presenting a number of guidelines for job growth, as referred to in the reports adopted today, which are unfortunately presented to Europeans as national measures. In turn, they are considered less popular arrangements and are presented as European recommendations. Such rhetoric is wrongly causing the reluctance of Union citizens to join the European institutions.  It is therefore important that citizens are adequately informed about what actions and initiatives we are proposing for them. So that, on the one hand, they can be effectively involved in them and, on the other hand, to strengthen their trust in our work. Furthermore, it is important that the development and implementation of employment policies should be consulted with local authorities and take into account local and regional disparities.  In the context of monitoring the effects of this policy, we need to strengthen the ways in which the measures taken are assessed. As proposed by Parliament, monitoring and evaluation should be carried out with the participation of authorities at every level, social partners and civil society.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ongoing crisis has led to the loss of many jobs. In addition, increasingly complex political and economic relations are a threat to the possible loss of even more jobs. For example, analyses by Austrian experts have shown that an additional 2 million jobs may be killed due to the extension of restrictive measures to Russia. The purpose is to ensure effective governance when it comes to the design and implementation of national policies. Effective management and implementation of the measures outlined is a very important item especially in developing countries. The guidelines focus on the proper functioning of the labour market, labour supply and demand, but also on promoting equal opportunities. I supported the Ageae Report, which highlights the importance of combating youth unemployment, preventing early school leaving, encouraging entrepreneurship among young people, building education systems with a focus on practice and improving links between education and the labour market.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eurostat estimates that 23 815 000 people were unemployed in the Union in January 2015, of which 18 059 000 were in the euro area. This is a consequence of the economic and financial crisis, as well as not of the timely adoption of effective measures. This has an impact on population poverty in the EU, their social exclusion and quality of life. It is therefore essential that the employment strategy in the EU and its Member States responds flexibly to the evolution of unemployment and its consequences. Employment policies must be prepared for all groups of employees, with an emphasis on persons with reduced qualifications and reduced or reduced working capacity. Investment must be directed to sectors that will bring sustainable jobs. Member States must closely monitor employment in their country and take measures in advance that will reduce unemployment and prevent social exclusion. Part of the process is cooperation with the social partners, which will lead to an appropriate evaluation of the work, solving the problems of health care, social and transport services. It is a demanding but necessary process that begins with education in schools, by supporting the training of young and adults, and ends with due care for disadvantaged and elderly people. At the same time, Member States must make effective and efficient use of EU instruments, in particular the ESF and EFSI.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for member states' employment policies for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015 and also because Mercely austerity has filled Greece with armies of unemployed people, with millions of poor, with the unemployment rate at 25.1% and the youth unemployment rate at 50.1%. I would point out, however, that I have some reservations about certain points in the report, while expressing my opposition to the report's references to active ageing.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal on the yearly revised employment guidelines, which are symbolic and only put employment policies on the back burner. These suggestions, mainly in the area of social reforms, tend to give the EU a good conscience, which does not even have expertise in this area.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gives a favourable opinion on the report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies. In order to achieve this objective, Member States must encourage participation in the labour market and make employment more attractive, improve and ensure the quality of education and training systems and the possibility of lifelong learning.  The European Union must continue to take all necessary measures to give priority to activating an effective strategy for full employment.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Member States, with the support of the European Union, should work towards developing a coordinated and forward-looking strategy for employment. The latter should aim to promote a competent workforce, which can be used in the labour market and able to respond to economic change.  For these reasons, I have chosen to support this report, which outlines guidelines for the definition of successful employment policies by the Member States of the European Union.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this report has improved the Commission's proposal, in particular through references to decent working conditions or adequate wages, or adequate social protection (including the minimum wage), equality in the labour market, combating precarious work, etc., the final report was greatly influenced by the amendments proposed by the EPP and ALDE. The inclusion of references to the promotion of entrepreneurship from school age as a means of combating unemployment, or the idea that Member States can convert unemployment benefits into subsidies for entrepreneurship, or entrepreneurship in the context of social services, are sufficient reasons to abstain.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Despite some good proposals, the proposal tends to centralise competences, which must remain a matter for the Member States. In particular, the labour market and social policy cannot be regulated uniformly, but are exclusively subject to the Member States themselves.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission sends "guidelines" to states on employment each year. This year, in the right neoliberal logic, it is necessary to "strengthen growth through structural reforms" and "make public finances more sustainable". Parliament makes some amendments. It stresses decent working conditions and the need for adequate social protection. Our group has managed to ask to guarantee a minimum income at a level equivalent to at least 60% of the median income in the Member States concerned. However, the report also proposes to be able to convert unemployment benefits into start-up subsidies for a company! Against youth unemployment, he proposes to strengthen the links between education and the labour market "from the most basic level".   I'm voting against it. I cannot validate the budgetary supervision of states by the technocrats in Brussels, which this report, which has been widely amended by the right, endorses.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The employment policy guidelines are reviewed annually and are supposed to help coordinate national employment policies, but the European Union has no jurisdiction in this area. These lines must respect the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy and these policy guidelines. The main objectives are improving labour flexibility, simplifying and modernising social protection, reforming labour taxation, combating long-term unemployment, introducing a minimum income, education reform and vocational training. Since their inception, labour markets have been deteriorating. These guidelines are a façade for showing good conscience, but the aim is social reform, at the expense of jobs and social protection. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for employment policies of the Member States. In order to ensure a more democratic decision-making process on guidelines affecting citizens and labour markets across the Union, it is important that the European Parliament and the Council jointly examine employment guidelines and broad economic policy guidelines. Such guidelines should allow Member States to adopt sustainable economic models.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current integrated guidelines for the employment policies of the Union’s Member States underpin the overarching Europe 2020 strategy which focuses on investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility. Parliament’s report also highlights the importance of including regional and local authorities in combating unemployment and quality job creation. The report emphasises the importance of promoting entrepreneurship amongst the Union’s youth as well as the provision of the necessary support to our small and medium enterprises. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union stipulates that Member States must consider economic policies and the promotion of employment as issues of common interest and coordinate their action in the Council. Access to meaningful employment for all EU citizens is a prerequisite not so much for their development as an individual and for a return to intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth. As a federalist, I am firmly convinced that the extensive cooperation of Member States in a growing number of areas will enable the recovery of a Europe still too often the sum of its national interests.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the report on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States, the basic priorities are, in my opinion, unequivocal. The first priority of all EU and Member State employment policies remains the elimination of woefully high unemployment, particularly in the regions. Giving people the right jobs is the best way to create economic growth and combat poverty and social exclusion. I believe that a variety of types of job creation need to be developed and promoted flexibly responding to changing demand and supply, including increasing investment aimed in particular at the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises and also family businesses. The second priority is to ensure that wages in all Member States bring an adequate income for sub-life and a decent life. In the long term, there is a need to gradually reduce the often unjustified but significant differences between Member States.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Today, Parliament agreed to a Council decision on The Guidelines for Member States' Employment Policies in 2015. Eight of the guidelines proposed by the Commission include stimulating investment, removing barriers to employment, stimulating demand and improving the supply of jobs. The focus is also on fighting poverty and promoting equal opportunities. Member States are called upon to ensure better access for women to the labour market, to promote entrepreneurship among young people and to combat discrimination in the labour market, including discrimination against people with disabilities or older workers. The adopted text also stresses the importance of teaching and preventing school drop-out as well as adult training programmes. Improving the correspondence between demand and the supply of jobs is crucial in order to optimize the functioning of the labour market. Employment, the fight against poverty and education are inherently linked policies that must be considered and implemented together.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In general, I fully support the Report on the Guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States, which underpins the Europe 2020 strategy within the context of the new approach to economic policy and supporting the achievement of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The report refers to areas which are of particular importance for me, such as investment, growth, barriers to growth and jobs, sustainability of public finances, demand for labour, skills, functioning of the labour markets, poverty and equal opportunities. Even if this is a very positive report and I voted in favour, I could not support certain paragraphs which in my opinion impinge negatively on the policy areas that fall strictly under Member State competence.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns the European Parliament's amendments to the Commission's proposal for a decision on guidelines for employment policies in the Member States and for which it approves it. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to support the States—Member States and the Union should endeavor to develop an effective and coordinated employment strategy aimed at countering the serious effects of unemployment, in promoting a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce, as well as labour markets capable of responding to economic, social and environmental developments with a view to achieving the objectives of full employment and social progress set out in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union.  I believe that special efforts should be made to increase the employment of workers with very low levels of education or skills and those who are unable to train or acquire skills quickly, as well as to reduce the growing large-scale and long-term unemployment, with particular attention to regions that are lagging behind.  I am voting in favour of this report because I believe it is essential that the promotion of employment be defined as a strategic priority, an inclusive and integrated labour market, as well as decent working conditions throughout the Union, including adequate wages resulting from collective bargaining.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is completely unnecessary in more ways than one. Firstly, because the European Parliament is only consulted and it is really up to the Commission to propose the guidelines and then to the Council to approve them. Secondly, because the EU has, in principle, no competence in the field of employment. But, as always, the EU is finding ways to interfere in the sovereignty of the Member States, particularly through the broad economic policy guidelines (the "recommendations"). Indeed, in the context of the European semester, the Commission preaches to states deemed unsensitous and demands structural reforms, such as the flexibilisation of the labour market, the "modernization of social protection" (which, in technocratic language, means: lowering social protection) etc. However, since the introduction of these guidelines in 2010, labour markets have been deteriorating. And for good reason: even the IMF's research department is sounding the alarm: the famous labour market flexibilization reforms have, in times of crisis or low economic cycle, a negative impact on growth and thus employment! So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There has been a cost of living crisis in the UK and throughout Europe. Too many people find themselves stuck on zero hour contracts or in precarious work. Labour wants to see wage growth and the protection of workers’ rights which this report achieves. That is why today I voted in favour of the report on guidelines for employment policies of the Member States which will support the achievement of sustainable growth and quality job creation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the new guidelines for employment policies of EU Member States. Proposed by the Commission and approved by the Council, they require the agreement of the European Parliament. Important common priorities and objectives include preventing school drop-out, promoting entrepreneurship among young people, better aligning education and training with labour market needs, mobility, implementing the Youth Guarantee and effectively using the ESF to combat poverty and social exclusion.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis revealed the serious shortcomings in Member States' economies and coordination mechanisms at EU level. It also stressed the close interdependence between the economies and labour markets of the Member States. We voted in favour of this report, which aims to contribute to the definition of the next guidelines for European employment policies.  Bringing the European Union into a state of strong, sustainable and inclusive growth and job creation, thereby eliminating the large pockets of unemployment in certain parts of its territory, is the most important challenge facing it at the moment. This requires determined, coordinated, ambitious but above all effective political action, both at Union and national level, in line with the provisions of the Treaty and the economic governance of the Union. These actions should include the revival of investment, especially those aimed at the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises, innovative start-ups and companies promoting research and technological innovation.  Our ultimate objective must be the creation of a more inclusive, rights-based labour market accompanied by adequate social protection.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Eures database was a good idea, a real opportunity to reduce unemployment, especially for young people under the age of 25. However, the fact that the unemployment rate in many Member States is well above the EU average of 9.7% is facing the fact that the situation has become increasingly difficult since the crisis began. The root of the problem often lies in the incompatibility. Our education system is simply not in line with the needs of the market. Further propagation of dual training could be a solution. This would allow young people and employers to really find each other.  I also think it is very important to support small and medium-sized enterprises. Let's not punish them for creating jobs. In Slovakia, for example, it is the case that many private entrepreneurs only informally employ their employees or do not want to be paid higher than the minimum wage, specified 100% because of the large wage-linked tax and social insurance and compulsory health insurance burdens. I think that this is a huge problem and it could be a challenge for us to embrace this issue as well.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report so that Member States and the Union can work together towards developing an effective and coordinated strategy for employment.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report on Guidelines for employment policies of Member States. This report is certainly an improvement on the Commission proposal on this topic but it also includes several problematic elements that promote business interests at the expense of labour rights. The Commission proposal focused on reforming education systems in order to match skills with the demand of the labour market, modernising social security systems, reforming pension systems including linking retirement age to life expectancy, and shifting the tax burden from labour to other sources of taxation. The Agea report improved on this significantly by including references to decent working conditions and adequate wages, labour standards, adequate social protection, among other things. The report also widened the scope of the report to challenging poverty. I was in favour of many elements of the report. However, there were also several aspects of the report I had problems with, including removing important regulations for business, the promotion of entrepreneurship in the social care sector and skewing Member States’ education systems to meet the needs of the labour market. I have serious concerns about these aspects of the report, which is why I abstained.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As unemployment is one of the major risks for the prosperity of our economies and social systems, I strongly supported this resolution. The amendments found within should act as a basis for legislative and financial reforms in Member States, in particular towards creating more vocational and skill training resources available to unemployed citizens. Education is key, as well as public-private partnerships which can contribute to active job creation and market growth.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Economic and employment policy is primarily a matter for the Member States. As this report is a further step towards the leveling of national competences, I voted against it.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States. In January 2015, there were 23,815,000 unemployed in the European Union. The European Union needs an effective and coordinated employment strategy designed to tackle the serious consequences of unemployment. Member States should address their economic policies together with social policies. Particular efforts should be made to increase employment among workers with very low levels of education or qualifications.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the guidelines for Member States' employment policies because I believe that all Eu ropean States must open their eyes above all to the fact that some countries have remained significantly affected by the crisis that has hit Europe, and that this is why the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy have not yet been achieved.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on guidelines for member states' employment policies, which calls for the development of an effective and coordinated employment strategy designed to combat the consequences of unemployment, to promote skilled, skilled and flexible workers and fast-adaptive labour markets. In order to achieve the objective of full employment and social progress, it is also necessary to adapt education systems and, in particular, to encourage training in technical and natural sciences skills.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Economic and employment policy is an issue that Member States should see as a matter of common interest. Therefore, the guidelines for the two policies were presented together in the 2010 "integrated package" as two different but intertwined policies.  These guidelines support the Europe 2020 strategy, as they are based on investment and fiscal responsibilities. The most important thing is to achieve the objectives of European economic policy in order to achieve and maintain constant growth, which is of great importance for each of the Member States of the European Union. Any boost to investment and implementation of reforms can lead to this goal, as well as a strengthening labour market and a greater supply of jobs. I believe that it is primarily necessary to increase the supply of jobs so that the inhabitants of the European Union can work and improve their skills and become competitive in the labour market.  Promoting equal opportunities and ensuring fair employment contributes to achieving the objectives, but also to creating a real market that includes the fight against poverty within the guidelines, which I think is an essential segment in the employment aspect of the Member States.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is completely unnecessary in more ways than one. Firstly, because the European Parliament is only consulted and it is really up to the Commission to propose the guidelines and then to the Council to approve them. Secondly, because the EU has, in principle, no competence in the field of employment. But, as always, the EU is finding ways to interfere in the sovereignty of the Member States, particularly through the broad economic policy guidelines (the "recommendations"). Indeed, in the context of the European semester, the Commission preaches to states deemed unsensitous and demands structural reforms, such as the flexibilisation of the labour market, the "modernization of social protection" (which, in technocratic language, means: lowering social protection), etc. However, since the introduction of these guidelines in 2010, labour markets have been deteriorating. And for good reason, because even the IMF's research department is sounding the alarm: the famous labour market flexibilization reforms have, in times of crisis or low economic cycle, a negative impact on growth and thus employment! So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Union must combat social exclusion, all forms of poverty and discrimination, ensure equal access to fundamental rights and promote social justice and protection.  Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal that would ensure more democratic decision-making by the European Parliament and the Council through employment guidelines and general economic policy guidelines that affect citizens and labour markets in the Union. The integrated guidelines must enable Member States to adopt sustainable and integrated economic models at Union and national and local level in the first place. Member States, taking into account national practices relating to the responsibility of employers and workers, should consider the promotion of employment to be one of the priorities and a matter of common interest and to align their actions in this regard within the Council. The Union should accompany these efforts with policy proposals in order to achieve the objectives of the Treaties and to ensure an inclusive and integrated labour market as well as satisfactory working conditions in the Union, including adequate pay, which would be made possible through collective bargaining. Croatia has focused its attention on human capital and positive steps have been observed in the recovery of its economy. In the first quarter of this year, the average number of employed persons was 1.543 million, which is almost 9 thousand less than the previous quarter (-0.6%), while year-on-year there was a 34 thousand increase in the number of employees (+2.2%).

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Rapporteur Ageae's report on the Council's proposal for a decision on Member States' employment policy guidelines. It follows from the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union that the Council should adopt general economic policy guidelines (Article 121) and employment guidelines (Article 148) explicitly stating that the latter must comply with economic policy guidelines. Accordingly, employment guidelines have been adopted. These guidelines aim to support the Europe 2020 strategy in the context of a new approach to economic policy-making based on investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility.  At the same time, the integrated guidelines should support the achievement of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and the objectives of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. These guidelines are: boosting investment, increasing growth through structural reforms, removing major barriers to growth and job creation at EU level, increasing the sustainability of public finances and benefiting growth, increasing labour demand, increasing labour supply and jobs, improving the functioning of the labour market and ensuring fairness, combating poverty and promoting equal opportunities.

name: Marek Plura (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by Laura Agea because I believe that this is a good and material document. I fully agree with the rapporteur that Member States' policies at both central, regional and local level should foster job creation by removing bureaucratic barriers, promoting and educating entrepreneurial capacities among young people, developing micro and small enterprises and promoting employment in the white and green sector and the blue economy.  I am also convinced that the implementation of policies aimed at levelling the playing field for disadvantaged people, in particular children and young people from poverty-stricken families, the unemployed, immigrants and people with disabilities, is socially viable and leads to an increase in the employment rate of these groups of society.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of the consultation process, the European Parliament approved amendments to the text of the proposal for a Council Decision on the employment guidelines of the Member States. It amended the european commission's original proposal in order to make it even more effective, in particular by strengthening the social and environmental dimension of the text. I consider it necessary, in view of the unemployment rate in the EU and the increasing number of people living in poverty (we are now estimated to be around 20 million people), to establish reliable poverty indicators and to continue to combat all forms of poverty and discrimination, with an emphasis on extreme poverty. The interdependence of member states' economies and labour markets is a fact across the EU, which is why we call for decisive, coordinated, ambitious and effective policy action at both Union and national level. In this respect, investment needs to be strengthened, in particular aimed at developing SMEs, micro-enterprises, innovative start-ups and enterprises that promote green employment.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the main priorities of the European Union's political action must be to combat unemployment and create jobs. In particular, millions of young Europeans are facing a situation of lack of job prospects. We therefore need timely action on the part of the various nation states, which should comply with common guidelines. The TFEI provides that Member States shall regard their economic policies and the promotion of employment as a matter of common interest and coordinate their action in the Council.  The current set of 'integrated guidelines' supports the Europe 2020 strategy and is part of the new approach to economic policy. I hope that the latter will be able to provide common ground on which to work to overcome the fight against unemployment. Having said that, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In January 2015, according to Eurostat, the number of unemployed in the EU stood at 23,815,000, and 18,059,000 in the euro area. These figures are alarming and the Union must work with the Member States, respecting the principle of subsidiarity, in order to try to reverse this trend. In this context, the Commission has published new guidelines for Member States' employment policies. MEPs adopted this text and wished to stress the following points: effective fight against unemployment, support vocational training and reintegration of workers through training, and propose long-term measures. I voted in favour of this text and I stress the importance of reducing youth unemployment in the Union in a sustainable way.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the guidelines for member states' employment policies, which together with the Economic Policy Guidelines already adopted in July constitute the Integrated Guidelines, which represent the main instrument of the Europe 2020 strategy for jobs and smart growth sustainable and inclusive.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Every year at the same time, since 2005, the guidelines for Member States' employment policies have been proposed by the Commission and approved by the Council. 2015 is no exception and each capital has received a notice outlining national employment policies and common objectives.  Some Member States, such as Belgium led by Charles Michel's government, are doing well, a trend confirmed by the OECD, which stated in its report "OCDE360" that "Belgium is performing well, especially with an above-average gross domestic product, which is important for well-being". Other Member States, not just Greece, are struggling to undertake the structural reforms that are necessary to revive growth and bring about the concomitant decline in unemployment: almost 24 million people are unemployed in the EU in January 2015, 18 million of them in the euro area alone. This is unworthy of European society. All efforts in the years to come must focus on one goal: access or return to employment for working-age citizens.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report aimed at coordinating economic and employment policies between Member States and the Council in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. I know that, in times of crisis and divergencebetween Member States, these seem to be objectives that are increasingly distant.
