However, we must continue to work to achieve them, reiterating the importance of investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, but also smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, fair wages and pensions and greater attention to inequalities. Only a responsible employment policy will lead to the EU's social progress.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The employment guidelines were adopted for the first time in 2010 in order to support the Europe 2020 strategy. While these guidelines remained stable between 2010 and 2014, the Commission has proposed a series of new guidelines for 2015 for Member States' employment policies. These new guidelines must contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. By voting in favour of the report on the guidelines for Member States' employment policies, the European Parliament is calling on the European Union to support the creation of quality jobs. As a proponent of a socially regulated market economy, I advocate a reduction in precarious jobs, underemployment, unreported work and zero-hours contracts. Through this report, the European Parliament also recommends that Member States, in accordance with national practices, implement a minimum wage commensurn with the country's socio-economic situation. This is indeed a possible measure to combat poverty. Here is one of the reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union states that Member States should consider their economic policies and the promotion of employment as issues of common interest and coordinate their action in these areas within the Council. The economic and employment guidelines were first adopted together (as an 'integrated package') in 2010 as the basis of the Europe 2020 strategy. However, contrary to the economic guidelines, the employment guidelines need to be recast every year. They define the scope and direction of member states' policy coordination and also form the basis for country-specific recommendations in their respective fields.   The current integrated guidelines should serve as the basis for the Europe 2020 strategy, in the context of the new approach to the design of economic policies based on investment, structural reforms and budgetary responsibility. At the same time, they should contribute to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as well as to achieving the objectives of the European Semester of economic policy coordination. Given that the eight guidelines in the report are in line with the above assumptions, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Agea on the proposal for a Council Decision on guidelines for Member States' employment policies.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote. While references to 'education systems adapted to labour market needs', 'encouraging entrepreneurship — also from school age – as a solution to unemployment', 'encouraging Member States to convert unemployment benefits into business subsidies' or 'entrepreneurship in the social services sector' make our vote impossible in favour, the rapporteur has made a laudable conciliation effort in her report , which represents a substantial improvement in the Commission's text. Reference is made to decent working conditions, adequate wages and collective bargaining; adequate social protection, including a guaranteed minimum income; equality in the labour market, including affordable and quality child care; reducing labour market segmentation, addressing precarious employment, outsourcing and undeclared labour; the fight against poverty and exclusion; and measures to support social security.  In addition, it disassociates the retirement age from life expectancy and mentions labour mobility as a fundamental right of free choice. These aspects are necessary requirements for any employment guidance for Member States and essential guidelines for any employment policy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite raising important priorities in the field of employment at European Union level, it does not propose true political action against neoliberal austerity policies and therefore does not provide a real solution to the problem of unemployment. This report highlights many positive points that need to be addressed in the European Union's employment policies, but the main problem is that neoliberal policies are a brake on economic activity at a time of global recession. It is necessary to end the austerity of the European Commission and boost the economy through the public sector, given that it is the private sector that has sunk the quality of life of Europeans.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 According to Eurostat data for 2015, the number of unemployed in the EU is 23 815 000, of which more than 18 million come from the euro area. Efforts should be made to develop absolute poverty indicators and to combat poverty and social exclusion. In this context, it is also important to take into account the role and problems of education. Member States should jointly take action to combat the effects of unemployment, support the training of science-related workers and the employment of lower-skilled workers, as well as an open EU labour market. When developing policies that have an impact on the employment market in the EU, it is important to bear in mind the protection of incomes, social guarantees and compliance with labour law. It is also important to work towards making the EU labour market more attractive in order to stimulate the activity of citizens of different age groups. There is also a need to combat the social impact of unemployment by collecting reliable data on absolute poverty, welfare systems and removing administrative barriers. Of particular note on our part are actions aimed at accessing quality education and seeking to address weaknesses in education systems and to ensure that as many people as possible are properly trained. It is also imperative that all actions resulting in discrimination on the labour market are combated.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs today voted for action on abusive zero-hour contracts that offer no job security and prevent employees from being able to financially plan for their future or apply for a mortgage. Five million people in the UK are in low paid jobs, often on zero-hour contracts or in precarious work. Today’s report recognises and attempts to tackle these problems. The EU gets it. But does Cameron’s Tory government?

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting. Although positive aspects have emerged in the report, such as reducing the bureaucratic burden on small and medium-sized enterprises, the report does not bring new solutions to reduce high unemployment in the EU, especially among young people. It mentions only a number of existing measures. I find gender ideology problematic in the document in the form of a duty to ensure gender equality, including across-the-board equal pay for men and women.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the Greek crisis demonstrates so well, economic policies of Member States are indeed a matter of common concern and now, more than ever, there is a strong need for intra-EU policy coordination. Also, beside the common fiscal and macro-structural policy measures that are already well established in the EU legal framework, social and employment measures must be given similar emphasis. Therefore I am hopeful that the streamlining of the European Semester process, including the Annual Growth Survey and the Joint Employment Report, will see improved results in these areas. In particular, I am glad to see that education concerns were given strong emphasis in the last Commission reports, as I believe that well designed and flexible education systems are essential in solving long-term structural unemployment and labour market mismatches – just as intelligent traineeship, vocational training and start-up support for youngsters help in fighting the youth unemployment plaguing Europe today.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Agea report makes a number of proposals for Member States' labour market policies in the context of the European Semester. There are some positive signals, such as Amendment No 10, which denies the EU the power to create a Union-wide minimum wage, or Amendment No 21, which proposes cutting red tape for SMEs.  Unfortunately, the report also contains many approaches to centralisation and collectivisation. Among other things, it calls for the unification of social policy and an extension of area tariffs, but also complains of asymmetric shocks from the economic crisis elsewhere. In a monetary union, however, only labour market flexibility can replace the lack of a currency devaluation mechanism. The proposals therefore run the risk of labour markets becoming more flexible and shocks more severe. For this reason, the paper is not effective.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the decision to maintain the principle of subsidiarity on tax and social matters at Member State level.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Council's proposal for a decision on Member States' employment policy guidelines, as Member States and the European Union must have strategies in place to combat unemployment and their consequences. In particular, the aim is to achieve full employment and social progress and to promote training in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics sectors. In addition, it is also necessary to increase the employment of low-level workers, as well as those who cannot complete their education quickly and acquire skills. In particular, all forms of poverty should be tackled, so Member States should also align their social policies within the Council. The Republic of Croatia, from which I come, is also struggling with the problem of unemployment, especially for young people, which is why it is important to start implementing measures that will change this as soon as possible.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this proposal for a Council decision on Member States' employment policy guidelines because this Council decision encourages the reduction of unemployment that is necessary to get out of the economic crisis and increase economic growth. The EU needs to advocate for an integrated labour market, in particular for satisfactory working conditions. Also, this Decision would significantly reduce poverty and improve the picture of the EU economy overall and in the long term.    This Decision would encourage and increase the employment of workers with lower qualifications. The decision prescribes plans to hire young educated people so they can get involved in the labour market. Other objectives of the Decision are, among other things, combating discrimination in the labour market especially in relation to people in older age, women, people with special needs, foreigners and dealing with problems such as undeclared work, zero-hours contracts, etc. Such changes create a positive impact on eu economic growth and development, reduce unemployment and encourage employment for both older and young people.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fundamentally disagree with the proposal tabled. The centralisation of labour law at European Union level is a guaranteed way to reduce the EU's already low employment and competitiveness.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on guidelines for member states' employment policies. For the first time since 2010, the employment policy guidelines will be revised. In recent years, the economic crisis has seen high unemployment, especially among young people, and increasing poverty. These are important topics that we need to address. I welcome the Commission's priorities, which I believe are properly set: the creation of new jobs through structural reforms and a responsible financial policy. We must promote entrepreneurship among young people, youth mobility within the European Union and improve the transition from school to employment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report has many positive elements and steps in the right direction. Unfortunately, it does not escape the context of the austerity policies and logic that created the problem from the outset.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, the European Commission prepares the so-called Employment Directives for the Member States and the European Council discusses the so-called Employment Directives (in the framework of an EPSCO meeting). Since the public employment system was launched in Hungary, it has been constantly criticised by the European Commission, even though the legacy in this area is particularly severe, but the number of low-skilled people out of work in the EU's most developed countries (e.g. Denmark, Luxembourg) has increased dramatically, which needs to be addressed in the short term, and this is recognised by the European Parliament in this report. This is by ensuring that they are provided with work in order to ensure that as many people as possible work and that the employment situation improves. Hungary is now europe's forefront of reducing unemployment, which is already being acknowledged by more and more people. The amendment tabled by Adam Kósa drew attention to this, which was also supported by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, so I voted in favour of the report in its final form.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has useful employment policy proposals for the European Commission and the European Council. The report highlights the need to coordinate training in different sectors at EU level and to develop a common strategy. I agree that the Union should accompany these efforts with policy proposals in order to achieve the objectives of the Treaty and to ensure an inclusive, integrated labour market and decent working conditions, including adequate wages in collective bargaining across the Union. The report notes that at least 20 million people need to be rescued from the risk of poverty and exclusion – and it still seems necessary to establish certain indicators of the conditions of extreme poverty that many EU citizens have lived in. I believe that it is important to have such indicators, and I regret to say that the Government of Hungary is refusing to measure indicators reflecting the situation of people living in poverty in the opposite direction. I share the view that one of the EU's most important tasks is to create a more inclusive, rights-based labour market based on fair social protection. Furthermore, I think it is important to note that, in order to combat extreme poverty and social exclusion, these actions should include social protection measures such as guaranteed minimum income to be introduced in line with national practices.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European unemployment makes the Union's economic future shaken by at least gloomy forecasts. Employment, poverty reduction, development of social services and benefits are objectives for which we must continue to invest in the EU. The lack of equal opportunities in Europe is a persistent effect of the economic and financial crisis, but also a challenge for europe of the future. That is why the Europe 2020 targets must be achieved, including the minimum employment rate of 75%. A social Europe is a system that takes care of vulnerable groups by including them in education systems coordinated with the labour market and, in particular, with the SME market. At the beginning of 2015, there were almost 24 million unemployed in Europe. Unemployment is causing poverty, and we are seeing more and more statistics, which are incomplete, which put some 20 million Europeans below the poverty line. What we need to do: increase the inclusion of vulnerable groups, increase the efficiency of social services and benefits and reduce the phenomenon of absolute poverty in the EU. This voting explanation is, in fact, a plea for strong measures to combat poverty in Europe, for the future of Europeans who are today deprived of equal opportunities for education, development and employment.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of our rapporteur's amendments on this issue. Special efforts should be made to increase the employment level of workers with very low levels of education or qualifications, and those who are unable to acquire training or skills quickly, and to reduce unemployment on a large scale and in the long term, constantly increasing, with particular attention to regions that are lagging behind in development.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these guidelines which ask for more specific actions to reduce unemployment and support job creation by SMEs. On one side, labour demand must be boosted, especially for young people, and on the other side we need to ensure the labour offer matches the need of the European businesses. On the job creation side, I supported all provisions which intend to cut red tape for SMEs to hire people. On education and training, I am in favour of measures to enhance the entrepreneurship skills of the European workforce and measures enabling it to diversify its skills and so better adapt to a fast-changing labour market. More specifically, to tackle youth unemployment, I supported the overall strategy to consistently implement the Youth Guarantee at national level. EU funding should be targeted to improve their skills and assist them throughout the starting up of their own businesses, with better access to information and funding. I opposed provisions on setting up a Union minimum wage in the EU as it is a regulatory competence of the Member States.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I support the part of the report that focuses on relieving the burden on SMEs in the European Union, I cannot possibly agree with the provisions in the report that constitute a direct violation of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity. The requirements contained in the report, such as the creation of a labour market based on workers' rights, guaranteed minimum wage, decent working conditions across the Union, including adequate subsistence reached through a collective settlement, economic governance in the European Union...; I consider it completely unacceptable and excesive to encase that segment which should be within the exclusive competence of the Member States of the Union. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The TFEU requires Member States to address their economic policies and promote employment policy as a common theme and coordinate their activities within the Council. In the legal basis (Article 121 and Article 148 TFEU), the guidelines are defined as two legal instruments: - Council Recommendation on broad guidelines for the economic policies of the Member States and of the Union, and - Council Decision on guidelines for member states' employment policies. The integrated guidelines were first adopted in 2010 and are based on the Europe 2020 strategy. In March 2015, the Commission published a new proposal for integrated guidelines based on increasing labour demand, increasing labour supply and skills, better functioning labour markets and ensuring fairness, combating poverty and promoting equal opportunities. The Member States must take appropriate measures in the field of employment policy, which is why I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote. While references to 'education systems adapted to labour market needs', 'encouraging entrepreneurship — also from school age – as a solution to unemployment', 'encouraging Member States to convert unemployment benefits into business subsidies' or 'entrepreneurship in the social services sector' make our vote impossible in favour, the rapporteur has made a laudable conciliation effort in her report , which represents a substantial improvement in the Commission's text. Reference is made to decent working conditions, adequate wages and collective bargaining; adequate social protection, including a guaranteed minimum income; equality in the labour market, including affordable and quality child care; reducing labour market segmentation, addressing precarious employment, outsourcing and undeclared labour; the fight against poverty and exclusion; and measures to support social security.  In addition, it disassociates the retirement age from life expectancy and mentions labour mobility as a fundamental right of free choice. These aspects are necessary requirements for any employment guidance for Member States and essential guidelines for any employment policy.

text: Writing. The Agea report makes a number of proposals for Member States' labour market policies in the context of the European Semester. There are some positive signals, such as Amendment No 10, which denies the EU the power to create a Union-wide minimum wage, or Amendment No 21, which proposes cutting red tape for SMEs. Unfortunately, the report also contains many approaches to centralisation and collectivisation. Among other things, it calls for the unification of social policy and an extension of area tariffs, but also complains of asymmetric shocks from the economic crisis elsewhere. In a monetary union, however, only labour market flexibility can replace the lack of a currency devaluation mechanism. The proposals therefore run the risk of labour markets becoming more flexible and shocks more severe. For this reason, the report is not effective.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The employment guidelines are part of the European Employment Strategy.  Revised annually, they help coordinate national employment policies and represent only suggestions, since the EU has no expertise in this area. On the other hand, they must meet the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and prepare the recommendations by country. Finally, these integrated lines must be compatible with the broad economic policy directions. Employment measures should encourage investment, structural reforms, and fiscal responsibility. Objectives include: - improving labour market flexibility; - simplifying and modernising social protection; - reforming taxation on labour; - fostering social dialogue; - combating long-term unemployment, poverty, inequality of opportunity; - introduce a minimum income; - reforming education and vocational training, etc. Since their inception in 2010, Europe's labour markets have been steadily deteriorating. These guidelines allow the EU to display a moral conscience, but above all encourage convergence in social reforms.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the provisions of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Council should adopt the general guidelines on economic policy and general guidelines on employment. The general guidelines on economic policies remain in force for an indefinite period of time, while the employment policy guidelines must be drawn up each year. , regional and local, through close association with parliaments, as well as with social partners and representatives of civil society. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote. While references to 'education systems adapted to labour market needs', 'encouraging entrepreneurship — also from school age – as a solution to unemployment', 'encouraging Member States to convert unemployment benefits into business subsidies' or 'entrepreneurship in the social services sector' make our vote impossible in favour, the rapporteur has made a laudable conciliation effort in her report , which represents a substantial improvement in the Commission's text. Reference is made to decent working conditions, adequate wages and collective bargaining; adequate social protection, including a guaranteed minimum income; equality in the labour market, including affordable and quality child care; reducing labour market segmentation, addressing precarious employment, outsourcing and undeclared labour; the fight against poverty and exclusion; and measures to support social security.  In addition, it disassociates the retirement age from life expectancy and mentions labour mobility as a fundamental right of free choice. These aspects are necessary requirements for any employment guidance for Member States and essential guidelines for any employment policy.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because it includes a call for a decent minimum income in the EU, addressing rising poverty and inequality, and it calls for more democracy in shaping European employment policy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which approves the proposal put forward by the Commission to have a Council decision on the future guidelines for the employment policies of Member States. The report highlights the current high levels of unemployment in the EU and calls for an effective and coordinated strategy to counter the effects of unemployment, placing particular emphasis on youth unemployment. The report finds it essential to come up with reliable indicators of poverty and to develop tools to reduce it. An important aspect that is highlighted is the need for Member States to closely coordinate their economic policies and social policies within the Council in order to achieve more concrete results.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. With more than 121 million people at risk of poverty and more than 7 million jobs lost since the start of the crisis, these guidelines should continue to indicate how to move towards the employment, education and social inclusion goals to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy. That is why I voted in favour of this report: because it stresses that we must improve aggregate demand and clearly calls for the EU to tackle the serious problem of rising inequalities, as well as to invest in quality employment and to ensure living wages; because it calls on States to establish minimum standards of social protection with measures such as a guaranteed minimum income. It also sends a clear message to the Member States and the Union: that we rebalance economic governance towards its social dimension in order to achieve the objectives of full employment and social progress.  Recovery must reach every corner of Europe, every citizen. The proof of the development of a society is not that it is able to increase the wealth of those who have the most, but that it provides enough to those who have too little.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The employment guidelines proposed in the report set out priorities and objectives that we can certainly support. The Member States and the Union must, in fact, ensure that an effective and coordinated strategy for labour policies is developed to combat the two serious problems that currently afflict many Member States: poverty and unemployment. The 5-Star Movement has always aimed to create an inclusive labour market that includes measures to reduce poverty, such as the guaranteed minimum income. According to the European Social Observatory, forms of income support and social protection already exist in 26 Member States and must also be introduced in the remaining European countries in order to cope with the current serious employment situation, exacerbated by the current economic crisis.  The tax burden must be shifted from labour to other sources of taxation that are less harmful to growth and employment, and it is essential to promote youth entrepreneurship and the revival of investment, especially those aimed at the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, innovative start-ups and companies that encourage green employment. For the reasons described, I therefore supported the report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite raising important priorities in the field of employment at European Union level, it does not propose true political action against neoliberal austerity policies and therefore does not provide a real solution to the problem of unemployment. This report highlights many positive points that need to be addressed in the European Union's employment policies, but the main problem is that neoliberal policies are a brake on economic activity at a time of global recession. It is necessary to end the austerity of the European Commission and boost the economy through the public sector, given that it is the private sector that has sunk the quality of life of Europeans.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my socialist colleagues in favour of this report because there has been a cost of living crisis in the UK and throughout Europe. Too many people find themselves stuck on zero-hour contracts or in precarious work. Labour wants to see wage growth and the protection of workers’ rights which this report achieves. That is why today we voted in favour of the report on guidelines for employment policies of the Member States which will support the achievement of sustainable growth and quality job creation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report does not put forward any proposal to foresee a minimum amendment of what the EU's position on this matter has been. A positioning of complete commitment to employers, creating increasingly favorable conditions to increase exploration. In this way, it will continue to increase unemployment, precariousness and low wages. Working conditions will continue to worsen, with more flexibility and more versatility. In the name of improving the functioning of the labour market, one class over the other is ensured. However, we believe that it should not always be so.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Despite some good proposals, the proposal tends to centralise competences, which must remain a matter for the Member States. In particular, the labour market and social policy cannot be regulated uniformly, but are exclusively subject to the Member States themselves.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I and my group have refused to vote in favour of Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on guidelines for member employment policies in the Member States. The resolution violates the principle of subsidiarity in many ways.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support this initiative because I believe that we still need to work on the development of an employment strategy, in particular by promoting the qualification and retraining of employees. Great attention should be paid to regions where there is excessive unemployment and from which people are currently fleeing precisely because of a lack of employment opportunities.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The guidelines aim to help Member States combat unemployment. Although the report also makes good recommendations on improving the position of people with disabilities in the labour market, the importance of inclusive education and reducing the administrative burden on entrepreneurs, I was unable to vote in favour of it. In fact, in the report, we call on Member States that do not have a minimum wage institute in place to implement it. However, the problem is that wage policies are the responsibility of the Member States, not the European Union, and therefore the European Parliament does not have a mandate to do so.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report has a number of "good intentions" on employment policies, in particular when it introduces references to good working conditions and adequate wages; social protection and the need to establish a minimum wage per Member State; promoting equality; or combating precarious employment relations and poverty. However, many of the concepts used - such as "adaptability" and "flexibility" - entail changes in relationships and working conditions that lead to the deterioration of workers' rights. On the other hand, the main solution recommended is entrepreneurship, which is encouraged in multiple ways, including as a curricular component in the public educational system. There is also the reference to the "necessary flexibility in education systems and a practical orientation", revealing an essentially professionalizing educational paradigm and the concept of subjugation of educational policies to the needs of companies. We are not yet in agreement with the logic inherent in the Europe 2020 strategy, the European Semester and other policies based on supranational interference and the imposition of austerity. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal on the employment guidelines defining common priorities and objectives for labour policies.  A number of issues have been introduced, including: the adoption of measures to combat absolute poverty and social exclusion such as the guaranteed minimum income, to be established in all Member States; ensuring wages that ensure an adequate living income to ensure a decent life across the EU; the development of micro-enterprises, small and medium-sized enterprises, innovative start-ups and companies promoting green employment; monitoring and evaluation of employment guidelines, on the basis of accurate data; the promotion of youth entrepreneurship and active ageing strategies; and ensuring access to quality early childhood education and care at a reasonable cost. In addition, EUR 10 million is earmarked for the launch and organisation of the European Investment Advisory Centre, a structure provided for by EFSI and considered by us to be superfluous. Finally, although the text nevertheless states that efforts will be made in the annual budgetary procedures to reinstate the cuts made to these programmes (CEF and Horizon), to date there is no guarantee that this will actually be done.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an improvement in the situation of workers. The report provides for the provision of EUR 1 365 000 for workers affected in Finland's telecommunications sector, in order to invest in their training and rehabilitation following an industrial conversion process. It is a tool to enable workers in the telecommunications sector to adapt to the changes that are scouring the productive structure of the European Union. The making available of these public funds for training and conversion is clearly insufficient support for workers across Europe, but it is a minimal mattress that makes it possible to improve their situation.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which supports the Commission’s proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in order to grant € 1 365 000 from the EGF to Finland. The Finnish grant will apply to 600 Finnish workers who have lost their jobs with electronics company Broadcom. Some 3 000 Broadcom jobs have been lost altogether globally as a result of its decision to end one aspect of its work (cellular baseband). The company is completely ending its Finnish operations and continuing operations in the US and Asia. The EGF can be used to assist workers in situations of mass lay-offs arising from economic contractions, and has previously been used to assist workers in this situation in Ireland. The circumstances in the Broadcom case meet the requirements for the EGF to be applied, so I voted in favour.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Globalisation Fund was launched in 2006. It is intended to support workers who have fallen victim to the negative effects of globalisation and have become unemployed in this context. In 2014, Broadcom announced that it was closing its production facilities in Finland. A total of 568 employees were subsequently terminated. I support the Finnish Government's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The measures thus made possible are intended to help workers find their way back into the labour market in the long term.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on adjustment to globalisation proposed to provide eur 1.365 million in aid following layoffs in the industry sector. It is true that this sector is being hit hard by Asian competition, as was the case for Finnish industrialist Nokia, for example. In the very difficult economic context that many of our fellow citizens are experiencing, I believe that this offer of aid can only help our citizens to overcome the difficulties they face on a daily basis. As this proposal is reasonable, I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Finland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I regret the establishment of this instrument at European level and I await the planned revision of the legal basis. Nevertheless, as this arrangement is widely requested, on a case-by-case basis, I allow myself the opportunity to vote in favour of its mobilization.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the granting of financial support from the European Glogalisation Fund to Broadcom Communications Finland in Finland.  January 30, 2015 Finland submitted an application to EGF/2015/001 FI/Broadcom for the mobilisation of the EGF as the number of redundancies was made redundant from Broadcom Communications Finland and its two suppliers or downstream companies in Finland. The application was supplemented by additional information in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. This application complies with the requirements for determining the amount of the financial contribution from the EGF as laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 and the EGF should therefore mobilise an amount of EUR 1 365 000 for the financial contribution submitted by Finland.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In the past, Finland was able to claim to have seen the flagships of the electronics industry bloom on its soil. However, competition from the Asian and U.S. markets has knocked them down.  I voted in favour of providing EUR 1,365,000 in aid to Finland to help former employees of Broadcom Communications Finland and two of its suppliers find new jobs. Although I voted in favour of the release of this aid for employees who are victims of ultraliberalism, I continue to denounce the inconsistency of this European Union, which is acting as an arsonist fireman.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Broadcom Communications Finland, a wholesale company based in Finland, has had to lay off 568 people as a result of the economic crisis and global trade restructuring. I have obviously approved this intervention by the WEF, which will help the retraining of these laid-off workers.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report follows a request from Finland for a financial contribution of EUR 1.365 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to assist its telephony and radio transmission industry following the dismissal of 568 people from Broadcom Communications Finland and two downstream suppliers or producers. Finland's telecoms sector has always been a leading and forward-looking sector, thanks in part to Nokia, but it is currently facing a serious crisis fuelled by competition from emerging and particularly Asian countries.  Although this Fund provides the necessary resources to help employees who are victims of globalisation and unfair competition from low-cost countries, the EU is playing the arsonist fireman here by putting out the fire it has set on by its liberal, free-trade and globalist policy.  However, I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote, the mobilisation of the EGF worth EUR 1 365 000 in favour of the 568 workers made redundant at Broadcom Communications Finland and two of its suppliers due to the continuing crisis in the electronics industry in Finland. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a key instrument for supporting the internal market, but this Europe should combat the underlying malfunctions by halting the uncontrolled relocation and ruthless competition from Asia and China.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. I therefore do so that, in the present case, workers should be given financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 568 workers laid off by Broadcom Communications and two suppliers or processor products in Finland, as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation. During the 2000s, the number of employees in Finnish subsidiaries on all continents increased, until Asia prevailed as the largest employer in the electrical and electronics industry in 2004. This led to a reduction in staffing in Europe. This trend affected the entire Finnish electronics industry and culminated in Nokia's announcement that large-scale redundancies would take place in 2011. The personalized services to be financed from feAG include vocational guidance, training, recycling and job search activities, as well as grants to create new companies and promote entrepreneurship. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of rising unemployment in the Finnish electronics industry, they do constitute good assistance and enable training to be provided for the reintegration of workers concerned.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to receive support from the European Globalisation Fund (EGF) for Broadcom Communications Finland, finland, after 568 redundancies. Finland's application fulfils all the criteria, as this is very much related to the fundamental structural changes in the world trade system resulting from globalisation. The Finnish authorities argue that the increase in redundancies from Broadcom is due to the closure of all its activities in Finland. They link this closure to the significant structural changes in world trade trends resulting from globalisation and recall that the number of employees of Finnish subsidiaries established abroad in the first decade of this century increased until 2004. Asia has become a clear leader in the electronics and electrical appliances industry in terms of number of employees. As a result, the number of workers in Europe has started to decline. As regards the domestic situation, the Finnish authorities highlight the trend that affects the entire Finnish electronics industry and which reached its climax when Nokia announced large-scale redundancies in 2011.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 2 June 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Broadcom and 2 suppliers or further processing companies. According to the Finnish authorities, the redundancies at Broadcom led to the discontinuation of all activities in Finland. This closure is tied to significant structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation, recalling that Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical sectors in 2004. This has caused a reduction in the number of European workers. As far as the domestic situation is concerned, the Finnish authorities point to the trend affecting the Finnish electronics sector as a whole, culminating in the mass redundancy announced by Nokia in 2011. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute an active labour market measure within the eligible activities. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the allocation of €1.36 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the Finnish province of North Ostrobotnija, which is already under great pressure from the once-large multinational Nokia. At this point, I can only regret once again that my country, Slovenia, where certain redundancies are also taking place as a result of globalisation trends, is practically uneasy about the use of these funds that the EU offers for adaptation.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Broadcom Communications Finland's request for financial assistance complies with EU rules. 568 laid-off workers should be assisted.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which supports the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in order to grant € 1 365 000 from the EGF to Finland. The Finnish grant will apply to 600 Finnish workers who have lost their jobs with electronics company Broadcom. Some 3 000 Broadcom jobs have been lost altogether globally as a result of its decision to end one aspect of its work (cellular baseband). The company is completely ending its Finnish operations and continuing operations in the US and Asia. The EGF can be used to assist workers in situations of mass lay-offs arising from economic contractions, and has previously been used to assist workers in this situation in Ireland.  The circumstances in the Broadcom case meet the requirements for the EGF to be applied, so I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Finnish workers who have lost their jobs in recent years as a result of changes in the overall shape of the electronics industry must be supported, including financially.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft is to provide a financial contribution of EUR 1.365 million to Finland, which applied to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the dismissal of 568 employees in the electronics sector. This assistance is intended to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. As a reminder, this sector is particularly affected by Asian competition and these layoffs are the result of the termination of all Broadcom's activities in Finland.   On the one hand, this application meets the conditions for the granting of financial contributions from the WEF. On the other hand, we believe it is important to help finnish laid-off workers who are suffering, as in France, the disastrous consequences of savage globalisation.  That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in the structure of world trade. Major changes in the electrical and electronic appliances industry over the past 15 years have led to a transfer to the Asia area, where manufacturing costs are much lower than those in Europe. Although the production of electronic devices in Asian countries has led to a significant drop in prices, including in EU markets, the negative effects of these transformations have not been expected, with many EU factories and firms having to either move their operations to Asia in recent years or close all their business in the field, which has regrettably led to , to massive redundancies. Finland is currently one of the most affected countries in the EU in terms of redundancies in the electronics industry. I was in favour of this report because I believe that it is necessary to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support Broadcom's 500 former employees, who have been made redundant as a result of the recent cessation of the company's activities, with a view to their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. € 1,365,000 for 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland and two suppliers, to be blamed for the continuing crisis in the electronics industry in Finland (Nokia crisis)

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of 2,275,000 euros for sacked employees of Broadcom communcations in Finland. The Fund's mobilization was justified given the impact of globalization on the electronics industry, which in this case results in the company being relocated to the United States. Dismissed workers will now be able to benefit from training to reintegrate into the workplace. I voted in favour of this report, which is a solidarity response to the harmful consequences of globalisation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to finland's application for 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland, a company operating in the electronics and electrical engineering sector. In recent years, Asia has established itself as the largest employer in this sector. On the other hand, the number of employees in Europe has begun to decline. This trend seems to affect the entire electronics industry sector in Finland, as demonstrated by Nokia's announcement in 2011 of large-scale redundancies.  Redundancies therefore appear to be linked to changes in the structure of world trade. I therefore voted in favour of this measure. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from the EGF because of the lack of support from local and national institutions, which submitted only 14 requests in total between 2007 and 2014.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which supports the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in order to grant € 1 365 000 from the EGF to Finland. The Finnish grant will apply to 600 Finnish workers who have lost their jobs with electronics company Broadcom. Some 3 000 Broadcom jobs have been lost altogether globally as a result of its decision to end one aspect of its work (cellular baseband). The company is completely ending its Finnish operations and continuing operations in the US and Asia. The EGF can be used to assist workers in situations of mass lay-offs arising from economic contractions, and has previously been used to assist workers in this situation in Ireland.  The circumstances in the Broadcom case meet the requirements for the EGF to be applied, so I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Finland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising funds from the European Globalisation and Adjustment Fund through the EGF Regulation in respect of the application submitted by Finland as all the conditions were met. I particularly welcome the complementarity of the proposed EGF interventions with other actions funded by national or Union funds. Another poignant point is the fact that enterprise surveys and visits may not only benefit dismissed workers covered in this application, but may also contribute to building knowledge about employment issues within this sector for future redundancies.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We had to vote on the report by my colleague Petri Sarvamaa concerning the request for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund amounting to EUR 1 365 000 to help 500 redundant workers (out of a total of 568) affected by the crisis of a Finnish company operating in the trade sector.  The M5S delegation is in favour of mobilising this fund as a general rule, but we are also aware that it is certainly not the instrument that can best help workers. However, in the absence of alternatives, it must still be supported, so I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will help 500 of the 568 Finnish workers at Broadcom, a company that specializes in the development of smart games for cell phones. The wave of redundancies affected all Finnish regions, particularly following Nokia's decision in 2007 to outsource this production, which has since relocated mainly to Asia. Broadcom's employees are therefore hit hard by the play of transnational productions in favour of low-cost production. The layoffs have a significant negative impact, particularly on the regional economy of North Ostrobothnia, where 424 of the 568 layoffs took place. In this region, the unemployment rate is still a few percentage points higher than the national average.  The most scandalous is that the laid-off workforce is a highly skilled workforce, which puts Finland in a dire situation, that of a country rich in young unemployed experts. It therefore seemed fair to grant Broadcom employees the meagre compensation for the ravages of globalisation caused by the EGF's contribution of EUR 1,365,000.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree with the mobilisation of the European Adjustment Fund in the context of the 2015 budget, amounting to EUR 1,365,000, in favour of Finland. The application concerns 500 of 568 employees made redundant by Broadcom and two of the suppliers or producers of the next stages of the product.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of the Finnish company Broadcom. This measure refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the Fund totalling EUR 1 365 000. It covers 500 of the 600 workers made redundant at Broadcom and two suppliers or producers downstream. The request is based on the professional relocation of redundant workers from Broadcom, an economic company classified in NACE Rev. 2 Division 49 and two downstream suppliers or producers.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. The Finnish authorities state that the event at the origin of the redundancies at Broadcom is the decision to cease all its activities in Finland. Among the causes, asia's assertion in the electronics and electrical engineering industry and the negative development of the Finnish domestic market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because the situation in Finland has the characteristics that justify the disbursement of the Fund and technically its request complements the dictates contained in Article 12 of Council Regulation (EU) No 1311/2013.  This European Fund was set up to support workers who have been affected by changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation and who have been aggravated by the continuing global economic and financial crisis.  Broadcom Communications Finland considered that 568 workers were to be considered redundant, further aggravating the problem of unemployment. Through the use of these funds, Finland will be able to support these workers in their not-so-simple reintegration into work.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 1365 000 for Finland with the aim of supporting the 568 workers made redundant, in Broadcom Communications Finland and in two suppliers or producers downstream.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Finnish authorities have submitted a specific application for financial assistance from the EGF in order to support the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant at Broadcom.  I believe that the changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation have had a major impact on the company's decision to scale back its activities. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of mobilising the Fund.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Here 568 personnel working in the communications sector in Finland have been made redundant. Such redundancies are linked to events directly linked to the global financial and economic crisis. Now 500 redundant workers will receive advice and guidance from a team of expert consultants. These personalised services consist of three types of measure (i) help them to find a new job, (ii) help them start a business and (iii) provide training and education. I have thus voted in favour of this report to support workers’ integration back into the labour market.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an improvement in the situation of workers. The report provides for the provision of EUR 1 365 000 for workers affected in Finland's telecommunications sector, in order to invest in their training and rehabilitation following an industrial conversion process. It is a tool to enable workers in the telecommunications sector to adapt to the changes that are scouring the productive structure of the European Union. The making available of these public funds for training and conversion is clearly insufficient support for workers across Europe, but it is a minimal mattress that makes it possible to improve their situation.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the application from Finland for the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It concerns 500 out of 568 workers made redundant in Broadcom and 2 suppliers or downstream producers.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help Finland, which is facing numerous layoffs in the mobile phone chip sector. Finland submitted the EGF/2015/001/FI/Broadcom application for a financial contribution from the WEF. The Committee proposes to mobilise the EGF in response for EUR 1,365,000, or 60% of the total cost of the proposed shares. Considering that the well-informed application meets the Fund's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the major consequences of changes in the structure of world trade. I supported the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland in order to support the reintegration into employment of 500 workers made redundant at Broadcom, a wholesale company hit hard by the global crisis.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Since 2004, Asia has become the largest employer in the electronics and electrical sector, resulting in losses of staff in Europe and particularly in Finland, where, as early as 2011, the Nokia Group had to lay off on a large scale. Recently, the Broadcom Communications Group ceased all operations, resulting in the loss of 568 jobs. In this context, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, set up to provide rapid assistance to workers affected by the crisis, finds its usefulness. It is justified that the European Union should provide EUR 1.3 million to help these laid-off workers, in order to finance new vocational training, the upgrading of their skills or even programmes to support entrepreneurship. Finland will need to ensure that measures taken at national level complement EU funds so that people who have lost their jobs can actually be reintended in the labour market.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 2 June 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Broadcom and 2 suppliers or further processing companies. According to the Finnish authorities, the redundancies at Broadcom led to the discontinuation of all activities in Finland. This closure is tied to significant structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation, recalling that Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical sectors in 2004. This has caused a reduction in the number of European workers. As far as the domestic situation is concerned, the Finnish authorities point to the trend affecting the Finnish electronics sector as a whole, culminating in the mass redundancy announced by Nokia in 2011. Personalised services for redundant workers are made up of three types of measures: (i) to help them find new jobs; (ii) to help them start their own business and (iii) to provide them with training or education. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute an active labour market measure within the eligible activities. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It is a matter of common sense by allocating eur 1.365 million in aid as a result of redundancies in the electronics industry.  However, this aid should be handled with caution. It is not granted free of charge to help affected employees, but is only the right return of what the Union owes them. She is trying to find a cure for the evil for which she herself is responsible. Indeed, trade liberalization and the intensification of technological flows in a context of globalization have the direct consequence of increased competition. However, it can only be beneficial if it is not unfair, which is not the case, especially with Asian countries whose working conditions of employees are weighing down on product prices. This example, among many others, must alert the Commission as soon as possible, so that it understands that the policy it pursues benefits many States, except those in Europe.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the request that Finland has made on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund despite the fact that I fully support the measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies nor do we believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into labour market.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed, and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 2 June 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Broadcom and 2 suppliers or further processing companies. According to the Finnish authorities, the redundancies at Broadcom led to the discontinuation of all activities in Finland. This closure is tied to significant structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation, recalling that Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical sectors in 2004. This has caused a reduction in the number of European workers. As far as the domestic situation is concerned, the Finnish authorities point to the trend affecting the Finnish electronics sector as a whole, culminating in the mass redundancy announced by Nokia in 2011.  Personalised services for redundant workers are made up of three types of measures: (i) to help them find new jobs; (ii) to help them start their own business and (iii) to provide them with training or education. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute an active labour market measure within the eligible activities. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I have doubts about the added value of this fund at EU level. I am therefore voting against its use.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it provides substantial aid following numerous layoffs in the industry.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application under consideration relates to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), following finland's request for 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications, and two of its suppliers/producers downstream. These companies operated in the development sector of integrated circuit sets for telecommunications. At the root of the redundancies at Broadcom is the decision to shut down all the company's activities in Finland, and this closure is related to the usual "major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalization", euphemistic designation of the crisis of capitalism.  Once again, redundancies take place in a region already affected by unemployment. The North Ostrobótnia Region, where almost all laid-off workers are, the current unemployment rate (14.1%) is already 2 percentage points above the national average and was already the region most affected by Nokia redundancies in 2011. It is due to support for these workers, but this mobilisation does not erase the EU's deep responsibilities in pursuing policies that generate drama so far.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on budgetary discipline and having regard to the Council Regulation, as well as the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, I support the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 1365 000 to Finland, namely Broadcom. 568 workers were made redundant. This redundancy is partly linked to a trend affecting the entire Finnish electrical industry.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting EUR 1 365 000 for the 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland and two suppliers.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people. That is why I do not support the movement of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application from Finland - EGF/2015/001 FI/Broadcom).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Union’s financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible. The application by Finland fulfils the eligibility criteria set up by the EGF Regulation. The enterprise surveys and visits are actions which may benefit not only dismissed workers covered by this application, but may also contribute to building knowledge about employment issues within this sector for future redundancies.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland. It is of key importance that this is the twelfth request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 1 365 000 from the EGF is in favour of Finland. It affects 500 of the 568 workers made redundant from Broadcom and its two suppliers. It should be noted that, according to the Finnish authorities, the redundancies at Broadcom led to the discontinuation of all activities in Finland. This closure is tied to significant structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation, recalling that in the 2000s the number of finnish subsidiaries increased on all continents, while in 2004 Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical sectors. This has caused a reduction in the number of European workers.  As far as the domestic situation is concerned, the Finnish authorities point to the trend affecting the Finnish electronics sector as a whole, culminating in the mass redundancy announced by Nokia in 2011. The report adopted today was also intended to remedy this situation and ensure its sustainable functioning.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Sarvamaa's report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of a contribution of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to Finland's application for EGF/2015/001 FI/Broadcom. This contribution is intended to remedy the redundancy of 568 workers decided by Bradcom, a company active in the electronics sector, which has suffered from competition from Asian industrial operators and major changes in the electronic products sector due to globalisation. I believe it is right that the EU should concern itself, including financially, with those territories, as in this case, which are already suffering from high rates of unemployment and which suddenly see the disappearance of important employment realities. I am therefore in favour of measures to promote the new employment, through incentives to recruit redundant workers, as well as the financing of training and skills development measures and the promotion of entrepreneurship, in consultation with the social partners. Europe must look to work with a new impetus to achieve the full employment provided for in the Treaties.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this vote on the view that blocking these funds would harm the workers concerned and because otherwise the funds could be used in less socially uplifting matters. We propose, as in previous votes on the mobilization of these funds, a critical 'yes' to such funds, as we believe that it would be much better to use them in investment and job creation policies while working on upward harmonizing international labour regulatory mechanisms, which prevented unprotected work in developing countries and relocations in developed countries.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Labour Party and the Socialist and Democrats group, voted in favour of this report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, or as a result of a new global financial and economic crisis. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. My vote in favour of this mobilisation in Finland of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is part of the general framework of the Socialists' commitment to the principle of European solidarity, a true foundation constituting the EU and the reason for our work here.  This mobilisation of EUR 1 365 000 will support the reintegration into the labour market of 568 workers laid off by Broadcom Communications and two suppliers or processors of products in Finland. Socialists across Europe work for a true society united in adversity and a model of social justice, and the Finnish people and their workers must know that they have our efforts and support in the search for decent living conditions and quality employment for all citizens.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this application for mobilisation of the EGF by the Finnish government in relation to 568 redundancies in Broadcom Communications as well as two affected suppliers/downstream producers. These workers will receive a 60% contribution of EUR 1 365 000 from the EGF to assist these workers to transfer to a new job through counselling and guidance with applications etc., start up their own businesses or access tailored training and education.  I think the authorities have devised a very good package of coordinated and personalised services, in consultation with representatives of the beneficiaries, and I particularly welcome the proposal for a start-up grant for aspiring entrepreneurs of approximately EUR 6 000 on average which will be of real, practical assistance to those wishing to establish new businesses following their redundancy.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this vote on the view that blocking these funds would harm the workers concerned and because otherwise the funds could be used in less socially uplifting matters.
