We propose, as in previous votes on the mobilization of these funds, a critical 'yes' to such funds, as we believe that it would be much better to use them in investment and job creation policies while working on upward harmonizing international labour regulatory mechanisms, which prevented unprotected work in developing countries and relocations in developed countries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. The Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as I consider that support is needed for workers, who need to be reintegrated into the labour market after a lost job. Major structural changes in global flows, globalisation and the financial crisis have resulted in the redundancies of a large number of employees at Broadcom, a company whose negative developments affect the entire electronics industry in Finland. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should certainly be mobilised to provide a financial contribution of EUR 1 365 000 in the form of benefits, subsidies, travel, accommodation costs and other means to assist redundant workers.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this report on the adjustment to European globalisation for Broadcom.  Indeed, this sector of the industry has been hit hard by Asian competition, as is the case with Nokia, the flagship of the Finnish industry. The report recommends that Broadcom be paid 1.365 million euros to facilitate the retraining of its recently unemployed employees. At a time when the economic environment is very unfavourable to European industry and the Commission's legislation does not help it either, it is necessary to support our entrepreneurs in the face of the unbridled globalisation imposed by the EU, which we are the only ones to suffer head-on. This aid is therefore beneficial for our fellow citizens, who every day struggle to overcome the crisis and the daily difficulties.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Petri Savarma's report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Broadcom Communication in Finalnde. The Fund will provide EUR 2,275,000 for the 568 sacked employees, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for a request from Finland. In the face of structural changes in world trade linked to increasing globalisation of trade, it is important to show solidarity and support European jobs. This is the Finnish electronics industry, which has been suffering from Asian competition for ten years and for which I think it is legitimate to allow European aid so that Finland can adapt to the new trade conditions.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. There is nothing against mobilising the Adaptation Fund if, as in this case, the criteria are met. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 It was easy to vote in favour of this Commission proposal. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund helps many regions that are losing significant jobs in the turmoil in the world. Unfortunately, no EU territory has escaped this development. Previously, funds have been distributed to Perlos, Nokia and STX Finland through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In the Committee on Employment, we were unusually unanimous in their support, as were the other committees as the debate progressed. Broadcom Communications' support of EUR 1.36 million will be needed in the Oulu region. The region has already suffered losses and, among other things, nokia engineers who have already been reemployed were left unemployed again. Jobs in the ICT sector have been in great turmoil. Broadcom and its two subcontractors laid off a total of 568 employees, including more than 400 from Oulu. One can only imagine what such a sudden change will do to the region. The ICT sector is important in today's world, and training and support for the unemployed, if well supported and efficiently managed, can lead to new employment relationships, businesses and innovation ideas.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I gave my favourable opinion on this proposal. The Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market.  Finland submitted its EGF/2015/001 FI/Broadcom application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland. This is concrete support for workers in difficulty as a result of the crisis.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I am in favour of providing EUR 1.365 million in aid following redundancies in the electronics industry in Finland. Globalization, and Asian competition in particular, has severely affected companies such as Broadcom, Nokia and the entire electronics sector. The personalised services that will be offered to laid-off workers consist of three types of measures: measures to help them find a new job, measures to help start-ups and training measures.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Finland. The application concerns 500 workers laid off at Broadcom Communications in Finland and two suppliers or product transformers. Redundancies have occurred as a result of globalization in trade. The EGF contribution of EUR 1 365 000 will help finance the costs of reintegration into the labour market of the 568 laid-off workers. The package includes measures such as employment services, vocational training and recycling, services for new entrepreneurs, etc. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an improvement in the situation of workers. The report provides for the provision of EUR 1 365 000 for workers affected in Finland's telecommunications sector, in order to invest in their training and rehabilitation following an industrial conversion process. It is a tool to enable workers in the telecommunications sector to adapt to the changes that are scouring the productive structure of the European Union. The making available of these public funds for training and conversion is clearly insufficient support for workers across Europe, but it is a minimal mattress that makes it possible to improve their situation.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established in 2013 to economically compensate citizens suffering the consequences of significant structural changes with respect to global trade trends. This has been the case for employees of Finnish Broadcom, in the telecommunications sector, who have not been able to continue afloat in the face of competition from their analogues in other regions of the world. Broadcom's extra-bars are estimated to need around EUR 1.3 million, which will be mostly reinvested in education/training programmes to target other, more viable sectors. The rest will be used to help those affected find a new job or to get their own companies up and running. Following Nokia's plummeting in recent years, it is clear that the Finnish market needs transformation and I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of the pre-Finnish funds being allocated.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. On 30 January 2015, the Finnish authorities applied for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of €1.3 million to help former Broadcom employees. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to help former employees find a new job, educate or self-employment, who lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and the financial and economic crisis. Finland's Broadcom Communications had to lay off 568 employees due to Asian countries that have become leaders in electrical engineering and other structural changes caused by globalisation. The Funds are dedicated to programmes to help transition to a new workplace, self-employment and training and education. I support the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to Finland's Broadcom and welcome the messages of the Report, which recall the importance of the Fund and the programmes it funds.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour with other 588 MEPs, because we have to help each worker in the EU. This story is very interesting. Mobile chipset developer Broadcom closed down all its activities in Finland when its manufacturing was relocated to Asia and the United States. The company made 568 workers redundant across Finland, over 400 of whom live in the worst-hit region, Northern Ostrobothnia. The redundancies are part of a trend hitting the entire Finnish electronics industry. Now the EU resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will finance coaching for 500 of the redundant workers, grants to start their own enterprises, and hiring incentives. The overall cost of the operations, co-financed by Finland, is EUR 2.2 million. My country – Latvia – has to support our people the same way as Finland does it!

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland has applied for support for reintegration into the labour market of 568 workers made redundant from Broadcom under the conditions set for granting assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The economic and financial situation of the company was adversely affected by the fact that Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical industries, leading to a decrease in the number of employees in Europe. Finland's electrical industry was also negatively affected by widespread redundancies in Tokyo in 2011. Finland has complied with the requirements of the EFG and will receive aid amounting to EUR 1 365 000 for reduced impact. In particular, the funds will be used to assist in the transition to a new job, to help start their own business and to provide training or education.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in financial matters and sound financial management (Application EGF/2015/001 FI/Broadcom from Finland), since the Finnish authorities decided to start providing personalised services to affected workers on 11 August 2014, well before the decision, even before the application for EGF support for the proposed coordinated package was submitted.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as I had already done in the EMPL committee. The Fund provides $1.365 million in assistance to licensees in the electronics industry, victims of Asian competition.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the EGF. The proposal focuses on the need to identify incentives to support redundant workers at Broadcom, a Finnish company operating in the economic sector classified under the heading "Wholesale excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles". The final purpose of this report is to disburse the sum of EUR 1 365 000 to cope with the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant by that company, as requested in finland's application.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an EU instrument set up to provide support to workers affected by changes in the structure of world trade due to the advance of globalisation.  Considering that such an instrument should be implemented as quickly and efficiently as possible, I have decided to support the report signed by Mr Sarvamaa, which enshrines the mobilisation of the EGF for the benefit of 500 workers made redundant at Broadcom, a Finnish company.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported the application for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the applicant meets all the eligibility criteria. It is particularly positive to note that the Finnish authorities and the Commission have carried out the evaluation of the application very quickly.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Another European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a guarantee of the relocation of multinationals! Finland had already experienced a major redundancy plan in 2011 with the acquisition of Nokia by Microsoft. It is now the turn of another company specializing in the design of mobile and electronic products, Broadcom Communications Finland, to lay off more than 500 qualified engineers, as the North American headquarters has decided to bring design places closer to interesting markets like China. No questions questioned about the preservation of jobs and know-how in Europe. European industrial policy continues to be a sieve. This European Fund should be used to protect SMEs from the structural crises of capitalism. Here he comes to heal the wounds of capitalism after the fact to satisfy the Finnish government. Nevertheless, I abstain so as not to deprive Finnish workers of this fund.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on adjustment to globalisation proposed to provide 1.365 million euros in aid following layoffs in the industry sector. It is true that this sector is being hit hard by Asian competition, as was the case for Finnish industrialist Nokia, for example. In the very difficult economic context that many of our fellow citizens are experiencing, I believe that this offer of aid cannot help our citizens to overcome the difficulties they face on a daily basis. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation, and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, It is now appropriate to give that aid to Finland, which submitted the application 'EGF/2015/001 FI/Broadcom' to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland, which operates in DIVISION 46 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Wholesale, except for motor vehicles and motorcycles'), and in two suppliers or producers in the running.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools in the Union’s arsenal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 568 workers in the communications sector in Finland due to significant structural changes in the world trade patterns.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Finland is currently facing recurrent layoffs in the telecom sector due to increased global competition in this area. Recently, 563 people lost their jobs with Broadcom Communications Finland; enable the mechanism of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be activated. The Fund helps laid-off workers seize new employment opportunities in order to reintegrate quickly into the labour market. Supporting sustainable employment is essential. By funding professional and preparation measures, training and retraining, entrepreneurship enhancements, wage subsidies and various types of allowances, this Fund is a response to the economic crisis, demonstrating the Union's solidarity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing € 1.36 million in job search aid for 500 redundant workers in Finland. The redundancies are part of a trend hitting the entire Finnish electronics industry. The EU resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) will finance coaching for 500 of the redundant workers, grants to start their own enterprises, and hiring incentives.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, to support their reintegration into the labour market. Finland submitted its request for a financial contribution from the EGF following 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland and two suppliers or downward processing companies. As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy. I support the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1,365,000 for Finland for 500 of the 568 workers made redundant from Broadcom and two suppliers or producers downstream.  I am voting in favour of mobilising this financial money to cover the bankruptcies in Finland and to support workers to move to a new job, to help them start their own business and to provide them with training or education.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report follows a request from Finland to provide a financial contribution of EUR 1.365 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to assist its telephony and radio transmission industry following the dismissal of 568 people from Broadcom Communications Finland and two downstream suppliers or producers. This Finnish sector is indeed going through a serious crisis fuelled by Asian competition, which has affected the Nokia telephone company in particular.  This WEF was set up to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or by changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. Its principle seems hypocritical to say the least, since it timidly overcomes the ravages of globalisation wanted by the WTO and followed zealously by the EU. Increased openness of a profession to international competition is often associated with lower wages, and leads to a reallocation of workers outside manufacturing jobs (higher wages) to service jobs (less remunerative). However, as this assistance is essential, I decided to vote for it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of 1.4 million euros to help reclassify 568 employees of the Finnish mobile phone chip manufacturing company Broadcom Communications and two of its suppliers. During the 2000s, the number of Finnish subsidiaries on all continents increased, but from 2004 Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical sector, while the number of employees in Europe began to decline. The layoffs at Broadcom are partly related to the trend in the Finnish electronics industry as a whole, which led to the announcement of large-scale layoffs at Nokia in 2011.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the Finnish company Broadcom, as it is a question of providing additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.  Specifically, it is a question of supporting the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant at Broadcom, an economic company classified in NACE Rev 2 Division 46 ("Wholesale trade, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles"), and at two downstream suppliers or manufacturers. Unfortunately, the decision to cease all activities in Finland is due to major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation: during the 2000s, the number of employees of Finnish subsidiaries operating on all continents increased, until Asia established itself as the largest employer in the electronics and electrical engineering industry in 2004.  This has led to a drop in staff in Europe. The funds disbursed will be used for retraining and training of redundant staff and relocation to the labour market.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in the Broadcom company that is closing down all its activities in Finland.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Beidh an deontas seo ar fáil do 600 oibrí san Fhionlainn a chaill a bpost sa chuideachta leictreonaic Broadcom. Timpeall an domhain, cailleadh 3 000 post in Broadcom cheana féin, mar gheall ar an gcinneadh a rinneadar chun deireadh a chuir le gné amháin dá gcuid oibre (cellular baseband). Tá an chuideachta ag cur deireadh iomlán lena cuid oibre san Fhionlainn agus ag leanúint ar aghaidh leis an obair sna Stáit Aontaithe agus san Áise. Is féidir úsáid a bhaint as an gCiste Eorpach um Choigeartú don Domhandú (CECD) chun cabhair a thabhairt d’oibrithe i gcásanna áirithe nuair a chailleann líon mór díobh a bpost de bharr cúiseanna eacnamaíochta. Baineadh úsáid as cheana féin in Éirinn. Sásaíonn na cúinsí sa chás seo na riachtanais atá ag teastáil do CECD agus mar sin vótáil mé i bhfabhar.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to provide eur 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the Finnish State in order to help people who became unemployed as a result of the financial crisis.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Finland, I fully agree that there are no procedural defects in the first place, and above all because these funds will benefit Broadcom workers, who no longer have the financial capacity to provide for their remuneration.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Thanks to its political and economic impact as a market of 500 million inhabitants on the global market, the European Union ensures a favourable position for Member States' economies. However, from time to time due to globalisation, some European companies cannot keep up with the pace of the global market.  The European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes in global trade flows and global financial and economic crises and to help them re-enter the labour market. This is about the problems that have affected Broadcom Communications from Finland and their two suppliers and manufacturers and have made these companies 563 workers redundant. With a resolution on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Parliament, in accordance with its powers, provided assistance to Finland as a result of the redundancies of workers.  The redundancies at Broadcom are thought to be partly linked to negative developments affecting the electronics industry in Finland, highlighted by No tokyo's announcement of large-scale redundancies in 2011. The layoffs will further hamper the problem of unemployment, especially in the Pohjois-Pohjanmaa region, where 424 of the 568 workers were laid off. I supported the decision because it meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and as an expression of the necessary solidarity with workers in Finland.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report calls for assistance of EUR 1.365 million to partially offset the effects of layoffs in the electronic sector. Nokia, in particular, has suffered considerably from competition. I regret this silly policy of the European Union which consists of providing financial assistance to the unemployed, often too weakly, instead of allowing Member States to develop genuine industrial policies and use protectionism wisely. Unable to refuse assistance to employees, I vote for this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 in order to provide €1 365 000 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations with a view to reintegration of the labour market for as many as 568 workers of the Finnish company Broadcom.  Member States should show solidarity with each other when necessary and the Commission must assist them in doing so in order to spend the funds in the most equest and transparent way.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. It is essential that the Union's financial assistance to laid-off workers is dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible. Following the redundancies of 568 broadcom communications finland workers, Finland applied to EGF/2015/001 for egf financial contributions. The report says these layoffs will further hamper the problem of unemployment, especially in the Pohjois-Pohjanmaa region, where 424 of the 568 layoffs occurred, and where the unemployment rate is continuously several percentage points higher than the national average.  In order to assist redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs, I support rapporteur Petri Savram's report on the mobilisation of €1 365 000.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Traditionally, I comment on the issue of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, so I can only sigh again: another company from the old Member State.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved this request. I have spoken in favour of this text and I hope that this aid will make a significant contribution to the reintegration of these workers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports the reintegration of European workers affected by redundancies directly from the profound changes in international trade. I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland, as 568 workers made redundant at Broadcom Communications Finland must be reinstated into the labour market. The application complies with the requirements for determining a financial contribution from the EGF and i therefore supported this report on mobilisation of EUR 1 365 000.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created precisely to support workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns. This is what was at stake here: the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 365 000 for Finland, to be used with broadcom's redundant workers.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 568 workers laid off by Broadcom Communications and two suppliers or processor products in Finland, as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation. During the 2000s, the number of employees in Finnish subsidiaries on all continents increased, until Asia prevailed as the largest employer in the electrical and electronics industry in 2004. This led to a reduction in staffing in Europe. This trend affected the entire Finnish electronics industry and culminated in Nokia's announcement that large-scale redundancies would take place in 2011. The personalized services to be financed from feAG include vocational guidance, training, recycling and job search activities, as well as grants to create new companies and promote entrepreneurship. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of rising unemployment in the Finnish electronics industry, they do constitute good assistance and enable training to be provided for the reintegration of workers concerned.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help newly laid-off Finnish electronics workers and corresponds in particular to a mobilisation request made by Finland on 30 January last, which was made following redundancies at Broadcom Communications. In fact, there has been a correlation between the 568 redundancies that have occurred and the structural changes in world trade patterns caused by globalisation, mainly due to the fact that the Asian continent, since 2004, has earned the status of the largest employer in the electronics and electrotechnical sector, with consequences for the reduction in the number of workers employed in this industry in Europe. Therefore, meeting the eligibility criteria, I voted in favour of this proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland, amounting to EUR 1 365 000.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, for example in the event of a company being closed down or a production relocated to a non-EU country, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. In particular, the report presented by Mr De Clercq, on behalf of the Committee on The Sarvamaa on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the demand in the 2015 budget for the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 1 365 000 for 500 of the 568 workers made redundant at Broadcom (Finland) and two suppliers or producers downstream.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of helping European workers affected by the crisis.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this vote on the view that blocking these funds would harm the workers concerned and because otherwise the funds could be used in less socially uplifting matters. We propose, as in previous votes on the mobilization of these funds, a critical 'yes' to such funds, as we believe that it would be much better to use them in investment and job creation policies while working on upward harmonizing international labour regulatory mechanisms, which prevented unprotected work in developing countries and relocations in developed countries.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an improvement in the situation of workers. The report provides for the provision of EUR 1 365 000 for affected personnel in Finland's telecommunications sector, in order to invest in their training and rehabilitation following an industrial conversion process. It is a tool to enable workers in the telecommunications sector to adapt to the changes that are scouring to the productive structure of the European Union. The making available of these public funds for training and conversion is clearly insufficient support for workers across Europe, but it is a minimal cushion that makes it possible to improve their situation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The UK Government has never applied for such funding to date.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides additional support to workers who are affected by major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. In June, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland in order to promote reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Brodcom. In particular, it concerns 500 of the 568 redundancies in that undertaking and two suppliers or downstream producers. By supporting the motion for a resolution, we agreed on a financial contribution of EUR 1.365 thousand. This amount will be used to provide personalised services to workers made redundant by assisting in starting their own business, assisting in the transition to a new job or providing training or education.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is intended to support redundant workers and self-employed people who have been made redundant or have ceased their activities as a result of major structural changes in world trade flows as a result of globalisation. The application for a financial contribution submitted by Finland to assist Broadcom Communications and two suppliers in which 568 redundancies were made in Finland as a result of the abandonment of all activities in Finland fulfils the eligibility criteria. The redundancies in these companies were the result of major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation. Since 2000, the number of employees in Finnish branches on all continents has increased until Asia became the largest employer in the electronic and electrical industry in 2004. This has led to a reduction in the number of employees in Europe. The Finnish authorities point out that the overall domestic electronics industry has been affected by this trend. The co-financed services package covers three important areas that will help workers reintegrate into the labour market: helping to find new jobs, helping to set up their own business and education or training, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I support the restructuring of companies and the education of employees and young people in the affected region. At the same time, I am aware of the importance of the right economic policy that precedes such situations.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment. In particular, there is a need for structural reforms to re-establish economic growth. The MEPs of the N-VA have therefore abstained on this dossier.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report to reintegrate workers affected by the effects of the financial and economic crisis into the labour market. Following the redundancies of 568 Broadcom Communications Finland workers, Finland submitted an application that meets all the criteria for financial contribution. In addition, the redundancies at Broadcom are linked to negative developments affecting the electronics industry in Finland, and these redundancies will further hamper the problem of unemployment.  Finland will prepare three measures to help redundanized workers, namely assistance in moving to a new job, helping to start its own business and providing training or education. Part of the costs will also focus on benefits and incentives in the form of subsidies on wages, travel expenses, accommodation costs. It is a positive example of finnish authorities consulting targeted beneficiaries, their representatives and social partners, and local and regional authorities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund primarily because it cares for workers' rights and improves them as well. The EU has both legal and financial instruments to deal with the consequences of the global market and to dispose of redundancy and reintegration into society. Such assistance should be dynamic and quickly accessible to anyone who asks for it.  I support the Commission's decision to contribute a total of €1 365 000 to Finland under the PROVISIONS of the EGF Agreement, and I also commend the speed of resolution of this situation in less than 5 months from the date of the request for funding. I would like to point out that Finland plans three types of measures to take care of redundancy, namely: helping to move to a new job, helping to start its own business and enabling retraining or education. I think it is very important that workers use what the state provides them in the form of education or training, for the purpose of finding a new job, because surplus workers can negatively affect both countries and the whole EU, and this is something that we have to fight together.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the proposed compensation for workers made redundant due to 'globalisation'. The redistribution of money from competitive workers and firms to less competitive is making the whole problem of job losses as a result of 'globalisation' worse, not better.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the broadcom role. The redundancies of 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications Finland began in 2004, when Asia became the largest employer in the electronics and electrical industries, peaking in 2011. The application thus suffices to all the criteria for granting assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as these events are to a large extent linked to significant structural changes in world trade flows as a result of globalisation.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies nor do I believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The layoffs will only worsen the unemployment situation in the North Ostrobothnia region (part of the NUTS-level FI1a region), where 424 of the 568 layoffs took place. In this region, the unemployment rate is still a few percentage points higher than the national average. We showed, as it should be, solidarity and voted in favour of the request.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the European Parliament resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the 568 redundancies which occurred in Broadcom Communications in Finland. These redundancies are the result of a larger trend affecting the Finnish electronics industry and hurt a region which already was affected by Nokia redundancies in the past. The Finnish assistance to the workers complies with all criteria for the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and consists of three measures: helping workers transfer to a new job, helping them start their own business and providing them with appropriate training.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I support european union measures to generate growth and job creation, I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not the right tool or effective tool to provide monetary assistance to countries to bring redundant workers back to the labour market.  Accordingly, I do not support measures to financially assist laid-off workers of the US company Broadcom in Finland. Namely, this company closed its facility in Finland, which clearly shows that there was no healthy business framework in that country. Despite the fact that the proposed funding of 500 redundancy workers includes active employment measures, I believe that this amount of EUR 1.3 million cannot solve the problem of rising unemployment in Finland or adequately help laid-off workers find a new job.  Unless Member States, including Finland, change the business framework and through tax relief and removal of bureaucratic barriers do not increase competitiveness on the global market, they will fail to retain foreign investors and companies. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The EGF is an instrument to support workers who have lost their jobs and provide career advice, job-search assistance and so on. The report talks about the proposal to mobilise funds for Finland's benefit, in support of the integration of Broadcom workers who have been left jobless, back into the labour market. Finland has applied for €1,365,000. This will help the labour market to integrate with just over 500 workers made redundant, which is why I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this vote on the view that blocking these funds would harm the workers concerned and because otherwise the funds could be used in less socially uplifting matters. We propose, as in previous votes on the mobilization of these funds, a critical 'yes' to such funds, as we believe that it would be much better to use them in investment and job creation policies while working on upward harmonizing international labour regulatory mechanisms, which prevented unprotected work in developing countries and relocations in developed countries.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this vote on the view that blocking these funds would harm the workers concerned and because otherwise the funds could be used in less socially uplifting matters. We propose, as in previous votes on the mobilization of these funds, a critical 'yes' to such funds, as we believe that it would be much better to use them in investment and job creation policies while working on upward harmonizing international labour regulatory mechanisms, which prevented unprotected work in developing countries and relocations in developed countries.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which in this case can alleviate the impact of job losses from the closure of Broadcom.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which acknowledges that this application made by Finland fulfils the eligibility criteria set up by the EGF regulation and therefore Finland is entitled to a financial contribution of € 1 365 000. Broadcom has had lots of redundancies since the early 2000s due to Asia emerging as the largest employer in the electronics and electrical industry. This situation arose in the context of a wider unemployment problem in the Finnish region of Northern Ostrobothnia. It is particularly positive that the application process was very speedy, taking only five months between submission and approval, meaning that workers will soon benefit from the financial relief envisaged by the EGF.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking again about the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to facilitate the return to the labour market of workers laid off at Broadcom in Finland. We are therefore faced with the correct use of this Fund, in line with the existing Regulation, and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an improvement in the situation of workers. The report provides for the provision of EUR 1 365 000 for workers affected in Finland's telecommunications sector, in order to invest in their training and rehabilitation following an industrial conversion process. It is a tool to enable workers in the telecommunications sector to adapt to the changes that are scouring the productive structure of the European Union. The making available of these public funds for training and conversion is clearly insufficient support for workers across Europe, but it is a minimal mattress that makes it possible to improve their situation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 2 June 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Broadcom. This is the twelfth application examined under the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 365 000 from the EGF in favour of Finland. It concerns 500 of the 568 workers made redundant from Broadcom and two suppliers or downstream producers.  It is ironic that this country, which was the mecca of neoliberalism, with its innovative growth model based on the export of technology, is now using this alms giving that helps workers, but does not solve the fundamental problem that constitutes capitalism.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported the application for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the applicant meets all the eligibility criteria. It is particularly positive to note that the Finnish authorities and the Commission have carried out the evaluation of the application very quickly.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application under consideration refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 365 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) following finland's request for 568 redundancies at Broadcom Communications, and two of its suppliers/producers downstream. These companies operated in the development sector of integrated circuit sets for telecommunications. At the root of the redundancies at Broadcom is the decision to shut down all of the company's activities in Finland, and this closure is related to the emergence in Asia of several employers in the electronics and electrotechnical industry, from 2004. This is making the situation worse in this country, as this trend affected the entire Finnish electronics industry and culminated in nokia's announcement of large-scale redundancies in 2011. While the objective of this Fund does not touch on the problem of regulating world trade, we have nevertheless supported this mobilisation.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal, which gives a mandate for further negotiations on the shape of the European Union budget for next year. Personally, I am not in support of increasing the European Union budget. I believe that countries should really consider to what extent they should be created and how large the central budget should be. On the other hand, in this situation, where the southern borders of the European Union are threatened, I very much welcome the fact that the chapter governing security and citizenship is being raised, so that more money goes into the European Union's immigration policy. More money will also go, at least I hope, to defend the southern border. It is not only my point of view, but also that we are debating in the Czech Republic, when citizens ask us what the European Union will do to make the southern borders of the European Union more guarded, so that we get at least a little closer to the Australian model.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report for a number of reasons, including because it represents a further ratification of the past agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. We insist that, in order to deal with the current economic crisis, we need an economic boost coming from the public sector, and ratifying the cuts in the European budget means approving the logic of austerity that is sinking the European economy. In addition, the report welcomes highly controversial headings to be used against human rights both in Europe and abroad, such as those for 'security and citizenship' and a 'global Europe'. The need for a shift in the logic of austerity is what has led me to vote against this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The mandate for 2016, while showing slight improvement, is still singing from the same hymn sheet – more austerity, the same old politics with a neo-liberal agenda that is re-enforced by the budget. It is time for a change of direction, a time to address the needs of the people and actually commit to decent and quality employment and a commitment to smart, sustainable growth. We need enhanced support of cohesion policies and it is crucial that we support the countries that are facing social and economic constraints. The hangover we have inherited from the 2007-2013 MFF is ongoing. 2014-2020 EU programs will not be really initiated before mid-2016. If we are genuinely looking to resolve some of the issues I believe we need to have a revision of the MFF. We have a duty to do the right thing on behalf of citizens. We need real investment in people, not profits. It is for the reasons outlined above that I abstained from this vote.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This report, which I supported, sets out a number of demands for the negotiations on the 2016 budget. In my view, it is important that the cuts in the Horizon 2020 programme and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) are reduced to a minimum in order to feed the EFSI Fund, as good infrastructure and the promotion of research and development play a key role in keeping Europe sustainable. Furthermore, the Youth Employment Initiative needs to be stepped up to combat high youth unemployment in Europe, and further resources must be earmarked for combating the refugee crisis. The loss of confidence in the EU, which has been caused by the many defaults, must also be counteracted in a sustainable way. These points must now be negotiated between Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. While the European Union is calling for austerity measures to be applied across all Member States, it is allowing itself to increase the expenditure of its bodies. Indeed, I see an increase in Parliament's expenditure, as well as a 2% increase in the salaries of Commission staff. I was in favour of a reduction in the operating budget of the European institutions and voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure: it is a more-of-the-same bloated EU budget; Europe should do less, not more.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support our rapporteur's proposal. Personally, my priorities will be immigration and learning.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The British Conservatives voted against this report. While we recognise that the Commission’s draft budget 2016 and this report are a step in the right direction in terms of re-prioritising EU funding on those areas where real EU added value can be identified, Conservatives have always been clear that we want to see real budget discipline and ensure that we have a budget that is fit for purpose and future proof. We believe that we must be prudent now more than ever in order to recoup previous years’ spending (e.g. mobilisation of the contingency margin of EUR 3 billion above the ceilings in 2014). We want to ensure that we make savings now for the future in order to react to unforeseen circumstances and, most importantly, that we deliver on the existing MFF agreement. Unfortunately, we are not convinced that this sentiment is reflected in this report, and for these reasons we voted against.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  The Commission presented a draft budget for 2016 proposing to accelerate and increase EU support to attract investment, improve the knowledge environment, learning, address job creation and employment. I agree with the European Parliament's position that the proposed budget takes into account the EU's current needs and is properly reflected. It is to be welcomed that the Commission has taken steps to take due account of the unrest in the EU's neighbourhood and other regions and to provide adequate funding for this.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this draft 2016 budget, which provides for yet another round of increases as the EU preaches austerity: a 2.2% increase in administrative expenditure, a 2.4% increase in Parliament's expenditure, a 2% increase in the salaries of Commission staff and a 5.4% increase in the pensions of its retired civil servants. All shame drunk.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved the motion for a resolution on the 2016 budget mandate for the trilogue, in which Parliament recalls, among other things, priorities for creating quality jobs, promoting investment and growth. Vigilance must, however, remain in place for these priorities to be cross-cutting in the Union's policies so that austerity is replaced by a real policy of recovery.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft 2016 budget presented by the Commission is a wonderful reflection of the attitude of the European Union. On the one hand, it demands more and more sacrifices from peoples and imposes more and more austerity measures, on the other it increases its spending. Staff salaries are expected to increase by 2% and pensions for retired public servants by 5.4%.  At a time when the single currency has become a burden for many countries and budgetary and political decisions are essentially dictated by Germany, the peoples of the EU member countries will be happy to know that it will provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, a non-member country, while the Greeks are being asked to kneel.  I have obviously voted against this report since I do not support the guidelines of the 2016 budget.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not share the views of the Fernandes report. The text contains too many unnecessary and unnecessary items of expenditure and does not constitute a budget based on employment growth in the EU. For all these reasons, I did not support him with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The mandate gives the right to negotiate a budget that is too large and comprehensive.  There should be substantial cuts.  Agricultural policy is just one example. It results in overproduction and negative effects on the environment, climate and animal husbandry. Another example is the incalculable regional and structural funds, where there is widespread fraud, as confirmed by the Commission itself.  I am also opposed to efforts to protect the external borders, which involve the continued construction of Fortress Europe, forcing people fleeing war and oppression to risk their lives to get to sanctuary.  In principle, I also think it wrong that the European Parliament has power over the budget. The Member States that pay the EU budget should have full decision-making power over Union expenditure. It is more democratic for the governments of the Member States, and the national parliaments, to decide on the long-term budget. It is the taxpayers in the Member States who pay and therefore it is their directly elected representatives in each country who should be in power.  These are some of the reasons why I choose to vote against the budget mandate.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is Parliament's first response to the draft budget for 2016 and which stipulates Parliament's mandate for the negotiation with the Commission and the Council of a draft budget amounting to EUR 153.5 billion in commitment appropriations (+2.4%) EUR 143.5 billion in payment appropriations (+1.6%). With this mandate, Parliament expresses its position in favour of maximising the impact on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility of the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments in the draft budget, securing and increasing the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative, as well as increasing funds to address migration challenges.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the draft budget for 2016 and the budgetary procedure. The European Parliament welcomes the fact that the Commission's draft general budget for the financial year 2016 of the European Union sets out Parliament's priorities and proposes to increase EU support for investment, knowledge, job creation and growth-oriented programmes, and in particular a representative mobility programme such as Erasmus+. The draft budget for 2016 is a positive step to help Member States address structural problems, in particular the loss of competitiveness. Parliament also welcomes the fact that the Commission has not only provided more funding for security and citizenship and Europe's role in the world, but is also determined to respond to new developments, such as the crises in Ukraine, Syria and the Mediterranean, meeting the needs of the EU and the Member States in the areas of security and migration, demonstrating strong political will in the field of external action and making a budgetary commitment towards countries of origin and transit. However, Parliament reiterates its concern about the financing of the YOUTH Employment Initiative, as it is a key tool in the fight against youth unemployment in the EU, which is a top priority for all EU policy-makers. The European Parliament therefore calls for the further implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative through all the flexibility provisions provided for in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and intends to ensure that the 2016 budget contains the necessary amounts.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority its mandate in the negotiations on the EU budget for 2016. In the preparation for the negotiations with the Council, MEPs confirmed that cohesion policy remains a priority for the European Parliament. As a Member of the Hungarian People's Party, I believe that the EU must quickly eliminate its billions of euros in arrears over development projects, and the 2016 EU budget can also be an important tool for this. In the mandate to negotiate with the Council, as in previous years, the preservation of cohesion policy and the resources of the Common Agricultural Policy is of paramount importance. If these are reduced by the Council during the budgetary procedure, we are prepared to defend the budget lines that are important to Hungarian interests by submiting amendments. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. By supporting this report, we have given a mandate to my fellow Fernandez on behalf of the European Parliament to negotiate with the European Council and the European Commission in the drafting of the 2016 budget. The guidelines he has proposed are also very important because, in the end, parliament will have the final say when accepting the budget. The main challenges will be mainly the regulation of outstanding year-end payment claims, which have now ceased to rise, but still reached an outrageous level of EUR 24.7 billion at the end of 2014.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As shadow rapporteur for the budget of the Gender Equality Committee on trilogue mandates, budget opinions and the budget itself, I support this proposal.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Cé go bhfuil feabhas de chineál éigin sa mhandáid i gcomhair 2016, ní féidir a rá go bhfuil go leor athraithe: tuilleadh déine, polaitíocht dhiúltach, agus clár nualiobrálachais atá á neartú ag an mbuiséad. Tá gá ann an treoir dhamáisteach seo a athrú. Ba chóir dúinn díriú ar riachtanais na ndaoine, fostaíocht d’ardchaighdeán a chur ar fáil, agus gealltanas a thabhairt maidir le fás inbhuanaithe, cliste. Is é an rud atá uainn chomh maith ná níos mó tacaíochta don bheartas comhtháthaithe, agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid tacaíocht do na tíortha sin atá ag streachailt de bharr srianta sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta. Tá an tinneas póite a leagadh orainn mar gheall ar Chreat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil 2007-2013 fós le mothú. Ní bheidh cláir AE 2014-2020 tosaithe roimh lár 2016. Ba chóir athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. Tá sé de dhualgas orainn an rud ceart a dhéanamh ar mhaithe lenár saoránaigh: fíor-infheistíocht i ndaoine, ní brabús. Mar gheall ar na fáthanna thuasluaite, staon mé ón vótáil seo.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the main objectives of the Union, which it must therefore pursue, including through its own budget, must be full employment, the development of businesses and entrepreneurship and smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft 2016 budget focuses on the desire of the European institutions to create decent and quality jobs and to increase the competitiveness of our businesses in favour of sustainable growth. The text that is put to the vote also incorporates a response to the challenges that Member States face, such as the massive influx of migrants into our shores or the dangers of terrorism. While we can only welcome the increase in the budget for competitiveness for growth and employment of 6.1% and the 10% increase in security budget allocations, we regret the inflation of administrative expenditure. As such, staff salaries increased by 2%. The EU should start by applying austerity to itself before administering it to others. The same applies to the 5.6% increase in the budget dedicated to solidarity with third countries.  So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. The text cannot reflect a budget that can be based on growth and full employment in the EU; there are still too many budget items on unnecessary expenditure and criticism, even when expressed, runs counter to the macro-economic reality in Europe, which is mainly based on austerity policies.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Lisbon Treaty has given the European Parliament important budgetary prerogatives. Every year the European budget is negotiated with the Council to meet the priorities of the European Union for the year. This report is a first review of the European Commission's draft budget by Parliament. Parliament's priorities on immigration and security, youth employment and the European Fund for Strategic Investments have all been taken into account. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the mandate for the trialogue on the 2016 draft budget. With this report, Parliament has stressed the crucial importance of creating decent and quality jobs and the development of business and entrepreneurship, which must be at the heart of the European Union's 2016 budget. The reference to sustainable growth in the European Union is fundamental.  In restarting investment, Member States should see the environment and climate policies as an opportunity to promote growth. In particular, the correct application of environmental legislation and projects funded under Horizon 2020 will foster green job creation and economic growth among SMEs. Furthermore, given my role as co-chairman of the European Parliament's working group on the LIFE programme, I cannot but agree with the report in welcoming the increase in the appropriations, both commitment and payment, for the LIFE programme for the environment and climate action.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Cé go bhfuil feabhas de chineál éigin sa mhandáid i gcomhair 2016, ní féidir a rá go bhfuil go leor athraithe: tuilleadh déine, polaitíocht dhiúltach, agus clár nualiobrálachais atá á neartú ag an mbuiséad. Tá gá ann an treoir dhamáisteach seo a athrú. Ba chóir dúinn díriú ar riachtanais na ndaoine, fostaíocht d’ardchaighdeán a chur ar fáil, agus gealltanas a thabhairt maidir le fás inbhuanaithe, cliste. Is é an rud atá uainn chomh maith ná níos mó tacaíochta don bheartas comhtháthaithe, agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid tacaíocht do na tíortha sin atá ag streachailt de bharr srianta sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta. Tá an tinneas póite a leagadh orainn mar gheall ar Chreat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil 2007-2013 fós le mothú. Ní bheidh cláir AE 2014-2020 tosaithe roimh lár 2016. Ba chóir athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. Tá sé de dhualgas orainn an rud ceart a dhéanamh ar mhaithe lenár saoránaigh: fíor-infheistíocht i ndaoine, ní brabús. Mar gheall ar na fáthanna thuasluaite, staon mé ón vótáil seo.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure: it is a more-of-the-same, bloated EU budget; Europe should do less, not more.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as I believe it is a good way forward for the discussions at trilogue. Of particular interest are elements concerning the financing of the COSME programme, security and migration and the creation of employment and the development of enterprises and entrepreneurship across the Union (EEEs).

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the text of the mandate for a number of reasons. Firstly, the figures proposed by the European Commission once again widen the gap between commitments and payments, making it difficult to solve the problem of late payments, which has been going on for some years now. Furthermore, in order to finance EFSI, cuts are being introduced to programmes such as Horizon 2020, which are of great importance.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I refused to support this report on the draft 2016 budget. The proposals it contains are indeed disastrous: an increase in EU administrative expenditure of 2.2% or an increase of 2.4% in Parliament's expenditure, even as Brussels continues to place a mortal austerity on the shoulders of the citizens of the Member States of the Union. Worse, the draft budget calls for a 2% increase in the salaries of Commission staff and a 5.4% increase in the pensions of its retired public servants. Reading such proposals, one would almost come to believe that there is no crisis in Europe, that the Union does not constantly ask its Member States to make efforts to reduce their institutional structure and reform public policies. This report is a typical example of the shameless hypocrisy of the Eurocrats.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree and support positively the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments in the draft budget for 2016 and, in particular, the mobilisation of the overall commitment margin to cover part of the costs required to finance the EFSI, amounting to EUR 8 billion, instead of the exclusive application of cuts to horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe mechanism, and quite rightly Parliament has sought to minimise the impact on these two programmes and with the agreement reached to limit even more cuts, by EUR 1 billion.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the mandate for the trialogue on the 2016 draft budget. The draft budget for 2016 amounts to EUR 153.5 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 143.5 billion in payment appropriations. Furthermore, as stated in its resolution of 11 March 2015, the European Parliament has placed the creation of decent and quality jobs and the development of business and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union, together with internal and external solidarity in a secure Europe, at the heart of its priorities for the 2016 budget.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft budget because the creation of decent jobs as well as the development of business and entrepreneurship are at the heart of the Union's policies, which are only activated through sound and prudent budget planning. The multiannual financial framework provides flexibility to enable Member States to fulfil their legal obligations and respond to specific needs arising within the budgetary period. As a priority, we have set out to strengthen and support investment, knowledge and employment.  Funding has also been allocated to demonstrate the high degree of solidarity with third countries. These values are reflected in the budgets, not only numerically but also socially, because without a vision geared to the growth and development of European operators, the meaning of the Union would be lost.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate Mr Fernandes on his important report on the political priorities for the 2016 EU budget. I welcome the focus on the 3 E's (Employment, Business and Entrepreneurship). I applaud the intensification of EU support for investment, knowledge, employment and growth-oriented programmes such as the flagship Erasmus+ mobility programme. I agree with the increases that allow the Commission to tackle the new crises in Ukraine, Syria and the Mediterranean. I applaud the proposals to mobilise the Juncker Plan, including mobilising the overall margin for commitments to cover part of the expenditure needed to finance €8 billion from the Guarantee Fund. I fear that the funding of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) is insufficient as an essential tool in the fight against youth unemployment in the Union.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft EU general budget for the financial year 2016, which aims first and foremost to help Member States address structural challenges: creating new jobs, so as to combat unemployment, especially among young people; investing in businesses and the green economy for smart growth; supporting the promotion of social inclusion and actions aimed at erasing poverty and emancipating those in precarious conditions, especially those with multiple disadvantages, such as the long-term unemployed, the disabled, those belonging to minorities and inactive and demotivated people. I regret the reductions in appropriations for major infrastructure projects and the Horizon 2020 and COSME programmes due to realaware of EFSI, as well as the reduction in funding for the agricultural sector. I very much hope that the objectives set will be maintained and achieved, so that all those programmes which have had to suffer budget reductions will once again be given breathing space.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to ensure that there is adequate funding for humanitarian aid especially for those Member States providing refuge to migrants. There must also be adequate funding to combat the migration issue. It is important to also inform the people on how the EU is allocating the budget to funding humanitarian aid. We must allocate enough budget to the creation of jobs and social inclusion programmes for those individuals who are in a disadvantageous position. This will enable us to prosper and to grow further. Vocational training should be budgeted for together with apprenticeships. We must also keep in mind the goals of achieving a low-carbon economy and must budget appropriately for this. Seeing as all the points mentioned are present in the report, it only means that we are moving in the right direction.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report for a number of reasons, including because it represents a further ratification of the past agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. We insist that, in order to deal with the current economic crisis, we need an economic boost coming from the public sector, and ratifying the cuts in the European budget means approving the logic of austerity that is sinking the European economy. In addition, the report welcomes highly controversial headings to be used against human rights both in Europe and abroad, such as those for 'security and citizenship' and a 'global Europe'. The need for a shift in the logic of austerity is what has led me to vote against this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This draft report constitutes the first formal response of the European Parliament to the draft Budget 2016 unveiled by the Commission on 27 May 2015. The Socialists and Democrats Group, of which I am a Member, has looked closely at this proposal and has managed to include a number of important points in this report which is Parliament’s response to it.  Amongst them is the point that the effect of the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI) in the Draft Budget for 2016 on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) shall be minimised to the largest possible extent. Another point is that the funding of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) as a key tool for the fight against youth unemployment in the European Union needs to be increased. Another point that S&D pushed for, and which is important to Malta, is extra funding in the 2016 budget to allow for full financing of the Commission’s relocation mechanism and resettlement programmes with regard to immigration. For these reasons I voted in favour of the mandate for trilogue.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This budget report aims to define the European Parliament's position for the upcoming budget negotiations on the draft budget presented by the European Commission (153.3 billion in commitment appropriations, or 2.4% and 143.5 billion in payment credits or 1.6%. The priority must be on job creation, boosting investment and business development with the budgetary implementation of the Juncker Plan, including the contribution of the Horizon 2020 programmes and the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe, and the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative for 2016. The Union's internal and external solidarity must also be ensured, particularly in the area of security and migration management. In addition, with the new programs currently reaching cruising speed, it is necessary that a sufficient level of payment credits be provided to meet funding requests. However, one question remains: the Bill for unpaid debts in the European Union, which undermines the Financial Credibility of the Union and which needs to be paid. This will be a tough point in the negotiations for Parliament. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The 2016 budget will have to be the subject of trilogue negotiations between the Council and Parliament, which have shared this competence since the Lisbon Treaty. The 2016 budget must, in line with previous budgets, highlight investment and in particular the Juncker plan, without cutting certain programmes such as Erasmus, or Horizon 2020. This is a necessary balance to be struck between investment and budgetary rigour. The implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe (EFSI) is one of the challenges of this mandate. We will be judged on its success.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority its mandate in the negotiations on the EU budget for 2016. In the preparation for the negotiations with the Council, MEPs confirmed that cohesion policy remains a priority for the European Parliament. According to Hungarian Ps, the EU must quickly eliminate its billions of euros in arrears over development projects, and the 2016 EU budget could also be an important tool for this. In the mandate to negotiate with the Council, as in previous years, the preservation of cohesion policy and the resources of the Common Agricultural Policy is of paramount importance. If these are reduced by the Council during the budgetary procedure, we are prepared to defend the budget lines that are important to Hungarian interests by submiting amendments. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because I particularly appreciate the very clear priority it gives to stimulate growth and jobs. Europe needs growth as well as bread. It is in this context that I fully support the expressed desire to ensure the guarantee of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, while preserving as much as possible the resources planned for Horizon 2020 and for the mechanism for interconnection in Europe.
