I also support the commitment to work to strengthen the means to be allocated to migration policy, in particular, in the immediate future, to the equitable distribution of asylum seekers between Member States. It is a scandal that some Member States greedyly pocket the funds of the Structural Funds and selfishly refuse any solidarity in the care of asylum seekers. I also support our rapporteur's request to provide the necessary means to finance the European security agenda. The terrorist threat is real and it will last. To combat it, European instruments, in particular Europol, must be given the necessary means. More generally, we must put an end to the idiotic system that wants to mechanically plan the resources of agencies without taking into account priorities or emergencies.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority its mandate in the negotiations on the EU budget for 2016. In the preparation for the negotiations with the Council, MEPs confirmed that cohesion policy remains a priority for the European Parliament. According to Hungarian Ps, the EU must quickly eliminate its billions of euros in arrears over development projects, and the 2016 EU budget could also be an important tool for this. In the mandate to negotiate with the Council, as in previous years, the preservation of cohesion policy and the resources of the Common Agricultural Policy is of paramount importance. If these are reduced by the Council during the budgetary procedure, we are prepared to defend the budget lines that are important to Hungarian interests by submiting amendments. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the mandate for the trilogue on the draft budget for 2016. This text is based on a paradox between respect for the principle of subsidiarity and national parliaments and a desire for a pervasive Union. We cannot take the risk of assigning the Commission additional roles, given the place it already holds in national policies. We must therefore not favour ambivalent postures but send a clear message: that of stopping the Commission's repeated interference.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In principle I welcome some of the changes introduced to the draft budget for 2016. Nonetheless, there are still some considerable issues that remain to be addressed. It is, as the report rightfully reflects, important to recognize past under-budgeting and to note the importance of tackling this issue. However, we cannot simply recognise this fact and move on, so to speak. There are still fundamental structural challenges that require proper analysis and sound financial solutions. Another concern is that we need to maintain a clear overview in terms of budgetary expenditure. It is a known issue that the distribution of funds is not always equal or financially justified, especially in the light of recent political activities in and around the Union. Thinking long-term strategy, in terms of budgetary efficiency, waste management and proper allocation of taxpayers’ money, it is crucial for maintaining a political equilibrium as well as ensuring economic longevity and productivity. Without this, we will encounter serious difficulties.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the objective of the Union budget should be primarily to solve the problems of its Member States plagued by poverty and unemployment, before carrying out heed subsidised solidarity programmes with third countries.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority its mandate in the negotiations on the EU budget for 2016. In the preparation for the negotiations with the Council, MEPs confirmed that cohesion policy remains a priority for the European Parliament. According to Hungarian Ps, the EU must quickly eliminate its billions of euros in arrears over development projects, and the 2016 EU budget could also be an important tool for this. In the mandate to negotiate with the Council, as in previous years, the preservation of cohesion policy and the resources of the Common Agricultural Policy is of paramount importance. If these are reduced by the Council during the budgetary procedure, we are prepared to defend the budget lines that are important to Hungarian interests by submiting amendments. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it is part of a significant increase in budgetary expenditure.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report sets out the mandate for the European Parliament's negotiating team to negotiate the proposed EU budget for 2016 with the Council, a negotiation which will begin on 14 July before the draft EU budget for 2016 is presented at the end of July. The mandate for 2016 shows, at least semantically, some improvements over recent years. Many of these improvements are due to the fact that some of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL have been accepted. In particular, the report is asked to support EU social programmes; promoting decent and quality work; increased support for cohesion policies and the need to reduce disparities, whether at local, regional or national level; the need to strengthen support for countries facing social, economic and financial constraints; increase support for the development of migrant integration by critical of the positions of both the Commission and the European Council. But it is not the case given to the Rapporteur of the European Parliament to negotiate this budget, despite a slight semantic improvement, will deal with a budget at the service of the great corporate and financial interests that the EU serves, and not at the service of the peoples of Europe.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mandate for the trialogue. The text does not reflect a budget that can be based on growth and full employment in the EU.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Union budget should be primarily to solve the problems of its Member States plagued by poverty and unemployment, before carrying out heed subsidised solidarity programmes with third countries. I do not agree with the mandate for the tripartite debate on the draft 2016 budget, which is why my vote is against.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the draft budget mandate because the aims of the ECR to have a budget that is fit for purpose and future-proof have not been entirely met.  I am glad to see that the budget has not increased from 2015. Accountable spending should be a priority for the EU. Although this budget is a step in the right direction it still has too many failings.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The effect of the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI) in the Draft Budget for 2016 on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) shall be minimized to the largest possible extent. A concentration of cuts in Horizon 2020 and CEF during the budgetary years 2016-2018, as proposed by the Commission, needs to be avoided. The funding of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) is a key tool for the fight against youth unemployment in the European Union and needs to be increased and secured as from EU budget 2016. Moreover, the report includes a call for reinforcements in the area of external aid programmes, in particular for the assistance to Palestine and to UNRWA, and Humanitarian aid. Considering the fact that this draft report includes all key points put forward by our Group, I voted in favour of its approval.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft budget in line with the direction of the European People's Party. I welcome the fact that the European Union's general draft budget for the financial year 2016 drawn up by the Commission confirms the creation of decent and quality jobs for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, the development of entrepreneurship and entrepreneurship, and the creation of a secure Europe as priorities. I also supported the proposal to increase EU support for investments, knowledge, job creation and growth-oriented programmes, in particular widely known mobility programmes such as Erasmus+. I believe that the draft budget for 2016 is a welcome step towards helping Member States address structural challenges, in particular the deterioration of competitiveness. I welcome the Commission's attempt to meet the challenge of responding to new developments, such as the crises in Ukraine, Syria and the Mediterranean, by responding to the needs of the EU and the Member States in the areas of security and migration, as well as by showing strong political will in the area of external action and in terms of the commitment to the cost of countries of origin and transit.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the mandate for the trialogue on the draft budget for 2016 because, after intensive negotiations, it provides an important basis and framework to allow the representatives of the European Parliament to negotiate with the Council in a targeted manner.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in this vote and reaffirm our general criticism of this draft budget. The draft presented by Mr Fernandes has improved the unacceptable proposals of the Council and the Commission and sought to bring forward positions between the Groups. Our group has tabled numerous amendments which have been introduced and improve at least in part, in our view, the document: mainly, the need to increase the financing of cohesion policies and thereby contribute to the reduction of inequalities between States, regions and localities, and the need to support with particular emphasis those countries experiencing social difficulties , economic and financial. However, we consider that the budget is clearly too rigid and insufficient, and that it does not live up to the challenges of the economic model crisis implemented by majority political flows so far and that policies of austerity, financial and trade deregulation and cuts have only aggravated.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I alongside my colleagues in the Labour Party in the European Parliament voted against this report. We do not support such increases which are above the rate of inflation to the EU budget.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. On the one hand, the ECR Group welcomes the fact that, for the first time in a long time, the European Commission has presented a draft budget for the coming year that takes into account issues such as efficiency and economy. However, this draft is still far removed from the eCR Group's ideas. The mandate negotiated for the budgetary procedure for a trialogue between the three EU institutions, Parliament, the Council and the Commission, does not lead to the objectives of a sustainably balanced, efficient and economical budget. In particular, the problem of the large gap between commitments and disbursements is being pushed further forward with this mandate. That is why I rejected it.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we have heard from the Greek Prime Minister, and the treatment he received from some Members of this House was appalling. It is clear that the austerity agenda pursued by some governments and institutions has failed, and in negotiating the 2016 budget we should have regard for more progressive policies.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in this vote and reaffirm our general criticism of this draft budget. The draft presented by Mr Fernandes has improved the unacceptable proposals of the Council and the Commission and sought to bring forward positions between the Groups. Our group has tabled numerous amendments which have been introduced and improve at least in part, in our view, the document: mainly, the need to increase the financing of cohesion policies and thereby contribute to the reduction of inequalities between States, regions and localities, and the need to support with particular emphasis those countries experiencing social difficulties , economic and financial. However, we consider that the budget is clearly too rigid and insufficient, and that it does not live up to the challenges of the economic model crisis implemented by majority political flows so far and that policies of austerity, financial and trade deregulation and cuts have only aggravated.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on a mandate for a trilogue on the 2016 draft budget, as concrete solutions need to be provided that will be able to counter the loss of competitiveness and structural challenges. I fully support the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments in the draft budget for 2016 and the promotion of cohesion policy, which represents the largest investment policy within the European Union. In planning the budget for the coming year, it is essential to take into account the financing of SMEs, strengthen overall entrepreneurship, improve agricultural and security and migration policy in order to enable the growth of the economy and boost competitiveness. However, it is also necessary to take into account the fact that some programmes under the multiannual financial framework have not yet been developed as planned due to certain technical and other problems, such as the adoption of operational programmes, and further attention should be paid to this as well. The better planned and structured the budget, the greater the chance that the objectives and policies set by the European Union can be achieved in line with economic and social challenges.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. We are seeing an increase in Parliament's expenditure, including a 2% increase in the salaries of Commission staff. While the European Union is calling for austerity measures to be applied across the Member States, it is increasing its spending. I am in favour of good expenditure management, so I have decided to vote in favour of this report on the mandate for the trilogue.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague José Manuel Fernandes' report on the 2016 budget. This report assesses the budget proposal for 2016 and outlines the main points of Parliament's mandate for the trilogue. The report favourably assesses the Commission's proposal for the 2016 budget with an increase in commitment appropriations in key areas such as economic cohesion or security. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mandate for the trilogue on the draft budget 2016. Given the economic and political challenges that animate the international scene today and given Europe's limited resources, it is important to properly target the objectives of the European Union. By focusing on growth, employment, internal and external solidarity and security, the Union would give itself the means to face the current challenges while anticipating the achievement of the Horizon 2020 targets.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 July 2015, I abstained from voting on the report on the mandate for trilatenate talks on the draft budget for the financial year 2016. This report is intended to establish a mandate for the negotiations of the European Parliament's team with the Council on the 2016 budget. The draft EU budget for 2016 foresees EUR 153.5 billion in commitment appropriations, including EUR 4.5 billion from the 2014 surplus. This is an overall increase of 2.4% in commitment appropriations. In the 2016 mandát negotiations, our faction has seen several partial successes with its amendments, e.g. in terms of integrating the requirement to create decent and quality jobs and increasing employment and business and business development. However, despite these partial victories, the main aspects of the mandate entrusted remain the same as in previous years. Thus, the emphasis on the policy of cuts, the direction of the EU and its citizens in the service of large multinational corporations has been maintained, as has the apparent promotion of their financial interests. However, the current text of the mandate is demonstrably the best text in a decade, because even the most hardened European institutions have finally begun to acknowledge the number of mistakes they have made in previous years, but this is still not enough, which is why I also had to abstain.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the mandate for the tripartite dialogue on the draft budget 2016, as despite the improvements incorporated the spirit of the text does not change significantly. Austerity and neoliberal politics are at the heart of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to give a favourable opinion on this proposal. The Union must aim for important objectives, and voting for this mandate means paving the way for the new budget year. The EU must promote employment, and support businesses, especially SMEs, by encouraging entrepreneurship.  All actors involved in the decision-making process must ensure that the 2016 budget has the appropriate resources for the proper implementation of all European policies, with a particular focus on priority and high-impact policies and programmes for growth and development, for the benefit of all European citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft 2016 budget presented by the Commission is a wonderful reflection of the attitude of the European Union: do what I say, not what I do. It is therefore planned to increase administrative expenditure by 2.2%, parliament's by 2.4%... And the Commission is not left out, as staff salaries are expected to increase by 2%, and pensions for its retired civil servants by 5.4%! Brussels should start by applying austerity to itself before administering it to others. Meanwhile, the internal demand of the Member States continues to be foolishly reduced. And it is not with the Juncker plan - expected as the messiah by the delights of the European crèche, and which is just a smokescreen - that things will get better. But the EU does not stop in such a bad way, since it is welcome to provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, a non-EU country, when it is reluctant to give any aid to Greece. The solidarity of the Europeanists has a good back! So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. Many negative points in this report, including the desire to increase the European Union's budget. This can only be done at the expense of the financial situation of the Member States. We are already in a period of austerity. The policy advocated by this report will result in an increase in the expenditure and remuneration of Commission staff. This is not acceptable in the current economic context. On the contrary, the European Union should lead by example and reduce its spending while imposing austerity policies on member states.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report is Parliament's first formal response to the draft budget for the 2016 financial year submitted by the Commission on 27 May 2015. It will serve as a mandate to Parliament's delegation in the tripartite negotiations scheduled for 14 July with the Council and the Commission and prior to reading in the Council of that draft budget. The report includes many positive elements: the effect of the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) in the draft budget for 2016 in Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility will be minimized; ensures and increases the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative from the 2016 budget as a key tool for combating youth unemployment in the European Union; the strengthening of external aid programmes, in particular aid to Palestine and UNRWA and humanitarian aid, has also been strengthened. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report for a number of reasons, including because it represents a further ratification of the past agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. We insist that, in order to deal with the current economic crisis, we need an economic boost coming from the public sector, and ratifying the cuts in the European budget means approving the logic of austerity that is sinking the European economy. In addition, the report welcomes highly controversial headings to be used against human rights both in Europe and abroad, such as those for 'security and citizenship' and a 'global Europe'. The need for a shift in the logic of austerity is what has led me to vote against this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. On the one hand, I welcome the fact that, for the first time in a long time, the European Commission has presented a draft budget for the coming year that takes into account issues such as efficiency and economy. However, this draft is still far from my ideas. The mandate negotiated for the budgetary procedure for a trialogue between the three EU institutions Parliament, the Council and the Commission does not lead to the objectives of a sustainably balanced, efficient and economical budget. In particular, the problem of the large gap between commitments and disbursements is being pushed further forward with this mandate. That is why I reject this mandate.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Draft Budget 2016, which contains objectives for compliance with commitments and financial priorities. Good budget management is particularly important so that all default commitments can be met in a timely way and that payments are not delayed.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the mandate for the tripartite dialogue on the draft budget 2016, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this draft budget for 2016. The EU, a major lesson-giver, intends to apply austerity to Member States to overcome the crisis, but in the same institutions budget increases are voted: 2.2% in administrative expenditure, 2.4% in spending on Parliament, a 2% increase in the salaries of Commission staff, a 5.4% increase in the pensions of its retired civil servants. The EU should follow its own advice and start by applying budgetary restrictions to its own spending. We strongly oppose this draft budget.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the mandate for the trialogue on the draft budget for 2016. The EU budget needs to ensure that the state of implementation of payments for the whole of 2015 is closely monitored and that the commitments made jointly by the three institutions (Parliament, Council and Commission) are met, and that the development and reduction of the amounts of backlog are constantly monitored. In this connection, it should be recalled that the primary objective of the budget is to achieve the EU's objectives and priorities. The budget does, in fact, provide financial support for all programmes, such as the European Structural and Investment Funds, Cosme, Erasmus+, aimed at encouraging investment in youth employment, through job creation, social inclusion for the disabled and the elderly and improving competitiveness and promotion through support for incentives to support entrepreneurship in EU countries.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Setting annual spending priorities for the European Union is a crucial moment.  In view of the complexity of the institutional procedure which forms the background to the adoption of the Union's budget, it is important that the European Parliament sits at the negotiating table with the other institutions involved, being able to take account of sustainable and cross-cutting proposals that we can support.  I believe that the text signed by Mr Fernandes is a good starting point in this respect. That is why I have chosen to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I rejected the mandate for the trialogue because it is essentially a disempowerment of the nation states and calls for more powers and higher levies from net contributors. Despite some positive aspects, such as .B rejection of new EU accessions, I had to reject this proposal.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This budget report is as inconsistent as the precedents that pile up without solving any of the problems raised. Thus he "again asks the institutions to keep their promises". Already in March, the first report on the 2016 budget called for the problem of unpaid debts to be "resolved without delay". This is not the case, and this report even recognizes that, as payment credits are currently under-budgeted, unpaid debts will not have decreased by 2020. It is discovered in passing that the bulk of the payment appropriations for the 2014 and 2015 budgets were used to pay arrears from the 2007-2013 programs. As a result, new backlogs are piling up on the 2014-2020 programmes, despite the Commission's efforts to curb its implementation. These austere artifices are even described as "deferring calls for proposals and reducing pre-financing" to deter states, communities and businesses from using EU funds. This absurd logic leads to the paralysis of the Union's policies. However, the report proposes to blindly support the Commission in the further negotiations. I am voting against this crazy logic of austerity that will end up killing the EU.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. We are seeing an increase in Parliament's expenditure, including a 2% increase in the salaries of Commission staff. While the European Union is calling for austerity measures to be applied across the Member States, it is increasing its spending.  Being in favour of savings, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament approved its priorities for negotiations with the EU Council of Ministers on the EU budget for 2016. I accompany the rapporteur in defending certain key points: that no cuts are made to the programme for the competitiveness of enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME), the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative and the need to reduce the unsustainable delay of pending settlement payments for cohesion programmes by the end of 2016. I have presented my vote in favour.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I chose to support this report as the Union needs to move forward in its budgetary planning in order to deal with the backlog of payments that need to be made. These cover a wide variety of the Union’s core projects and it is essential that outstanding payments are dealt with to prevent further shortfalls in programmes that are part of the 2014-2020 budget.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This draft report constitutes the first formal response of the EP to the draft Budget 2016 unveiled by the Commission on 27 May 2015 and it will serve as a mandate for the EP delegation. I voted in favour of this mandate because it sets as its main priorities an increase in funding of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) as a key tool for the fight against youth unemployment in the European Union; reinforcements in the area of external aid programmes, in particular for the assistance to Palestine and to UNRWA, and Humanitarian aid; and last but not least because it suggests a proper response to the challenges posed by migration trends and the exceptional situation in the Mediterranean, and pushes for extra funding in the 2016 budget to allow for full financing of the Commission’s relocation-mechanism and resettlement-programmes, to improve reception and integration conditions for asylum seekers and refugees, and to support all front-line Member States experiencing migratory pressure.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal proposes the position of the European Parliament to be represented in the trialogue (Parliament, Council, Commission) on the EU budget for 2016. I support the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of the report that job creation must be worthwhile and quality, business development and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the Union, together with internal and external solidarity in a secure Europe should be the centre of priorities for the 2016 budget. I would also like to point out the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) in the 2016 budget and, in particular, the mobilisation of the overall commitment margin to cover part of the expenditure needed to finance the EUR 8 billion of the EFSI Guarantee Fund, rather than relying solely on reductions in Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF).  The broad consensus on the assessment of draft amending budgets in 2015, as well as the negotiation of the payment plan so far, demonstrates a shared willingness to respect the MFF, implement carefully negotiated legal bases and ensure the financing of new programmes.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft 2016 budget presented by the Commission is a wonderful reflection of the attitude of the European Union: do what I say, not what I do.  It is therefore planned to increase administrative expenditure by 2.2%, parliament's by 2.4%...  The Commission is not left behind, as staff salaries are expected to increase by 2%, and pensions for its retired public servants by 5.4%! Brussels should start by applying austerity to itself before administering it to others.  Meanwhile, the internal demand of the Member States continues to be foolishly reduced. And it is not with the Juncker plan - expected as the messiah by the delights of the European crèche, and which is just a smokescreen - that things will get better.  But the European Union does not stop in such a bad way, since it is welcome to provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, a non-MEMBER country of the Union, when it is reluctant to give any aid to Greece. The solidarity of the Europeanists has a good back!  So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report which represents the first step for Parliament in the annual budgetary procedure. It sets out Parliament’s broad aims and priorities for the 2016 budget. I believe that the Commission proposal is constructive, but I support proposals which seek to cut the budget not increase it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which assesses the Commission's 2016 budget proposal and outlines the main points of the European Parliament's mandate for future trilogue negotiations on 14 July 2015. This text recalls that, in its resolution of 11 March 2015, Parliament has focused its priorities for the 2016 budget on the creation of decent and quality jobs and on the development of businesses and entrepreneurship for intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth in the Union as well as on internal and external solidarity within a secure Europe.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, hoping that the results of the trialogue on the 2016 draft budget will be as rapid and fruitful as possible. We welcome the fact that the draft general budget for the financial year 2016, as presented by the Commission, proposes to increase The European Union's support for investment, knowledge, employment and growth-oriented programmes. This is certainly a positive step forward to support Member States in meeting the economic and financial challenges, in particular the loss of competitiveness in recent years.  We cannot fail to take this opportunity, however, to reiterate our strong concern about the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative, as a fundamental instrument for combating youth unemployment in the Union, which is a top priority for all European policy-makers. In fact, although it provided for an advance on the supplementary budget for 2014 and 2015, no new commitments were proposed for 2016.  We therefore call, as far as possible, for the flexibility provisions of the MFF to be used to achieve the political objectives linked to growth and employment, in particular youth employment, thus guaranteeing the amounts necessary for the full implementation of the Initiative.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the Budget – Mandate for the trilogue report so that the Commission will assess the 2016 payment needs for the 2014-2020 programmes in the 2016 Draft Budget.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – In rural Europe, depopulation and ageing trends continue at an alarming rate. These areas have the potential to be a generator of jobs, of economic growth. I therefore believe that in 2016 the Commission should provide additional resources for programmes and initiatives that increase the attractiveness of rural and remote areas.  I draw attention to paragraph 4 of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development of 28.5.2015, by which we call on the EC to provide additional resources to stimulate organic farming and quality schemes for geographical indications and traditional specialities guaranteed. These schemes increase the economic growth of remote regions by focusing on the specific qualities of unique agricultural products and by enhancing the attractiveness and identity of those areas. I therefore strongly believe that the Commission should pay particular attention to these schemes and support them even more actively in 2016.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Cé go bhfuil feabhas de chineál éigin sa mhandáid i gcomhair 2016, ní féidir a rá go bhfuil go leor athraithe: tuilleadh déine, polaitíocht dhiúltach, agus clár nualiobrálachais atá á neartú ag an mbuiséad. Tá gá ann an treoir dhamáisteach seo a athrú. Ba chóir dúinn díriú ar riachtanais na ndaoine, fostaíocht d’ardchaighdeán a chur ar fáil, agus gealltanas a thabhairt maidir le fás inbhuanaithe, cliste. Is é an rud atá uainn chomh maith ná níos mó tacaíochta don bheartas comhtháthaithe, agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid tacaíocht do na tíortha sin atá ag streachailt de bharr srianta sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta. Tá an tinneas póite a leagadh orainn mar gheall ar Chreat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil 2007-2013 fós le mothú. Ní bheidh cláir AE 2014-2020 tosaithe roimh lár 2016. Ba chóir athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. Tá sé de dhualgas orainn an rud ceart a dhéanamh ar mhaithe lenár saoránaigh: fíor-infheistíocht i ndaoine, ní brabús. Mar gheall ar na fáthanna thuasluaite, staon mé ón vótáil seo.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the ep's endorsed mandate for the trilatelent negotiations on the 2016 budget, which includes strong support for increased spending in the security and citizenship chapter, including asylum and migration. This chapter should thus result in a relatively significant increase in commitment expenditure of 12.6% compared to 2015 and payment expenditure by 9.7% compared to the 2015 budget. Given the urgency of the problem of increasing migratory flows to Europe and the difficulties of some states, it is necessary for Europe to seek a common solution supported by adequate funds, the use of which will be strictly controlled.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it does not take into account austerity to the extent that I would consider appropriate in the current tense situation. Furthermore, the report is an extension of the EU's competences, which I will not agree to.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill. The 2016 draft budget is a welcome step towards helping Member States address structural challenges, in particular the loss of competitiveness. The Commission has taken the right course of addressing new developments such as crises in Ukraine, Syria and the Mediterranean, responding to the needs of the EU and its Member States in the area of security and migration. However, more resources should be directed towards combating youth unemployment.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the mandate for the 2016 trialogue because I believe that it is consistent with the amount necessary to implement all the actions to achieve the objectives that the Union has set itself.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Resolution of 11 March 2015 set guidelines for job creation within all Member States, development of SMEs and sustainable and inclusive growth across the European Union. In particular, it highlighted the strengthening of support for the development of youth programmes, such as Erasmus+, and the creation and implementation of various initiatives that need to lead to more open and more youth employment.  I supported this trilogue mandate resolution, as it highlights the need to help those in need and because it promotes the fundamental values of the European Union such as equality, transparency and the fight against poverty. I support the trilogue mandate, as it focuses on asylum security, migration and external border management, which are currently some of the most important issues facing the European Union and need to be addressed constructively.  Achieving higher employment, involving young, able and educated people in the labour market and supporting SMEs and developing entrepreneurship across the European Union will ensure and help economic growth across the EU in the coming year.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The draft 2016 budget presented by the Commission is a wonderful reflection of the attitude of the European Union: do what I say, not what I do. It is therefore planned to increase administrative expenditure by 2.2%, parliament's by 2.4%... And the Commission is not left out, as staff salaries are expected to increase by 2%, and pensions for its retired civil servants by 5.4%! Brussels should start by applying austerity to itself before administering it to others. Meanwhile, the internal demand of the Member States continues to be foolishly reduced. And it is not with the Juncker plan - expected as the messiah by the delights of the European crèche, and which is just a smokescreen - that things will get better. But the EU does not stop in such a bad way, since it is welcome to provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, a non-EU country, when it is reluctant to give any aid to Greece. The solidarity of the Europeanists has a good back! So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The impact of the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) in the draft budget for 2016 and Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) from which funding is allocated should be reduced to the fullest extent possible. Funding for the Yei initiative should be a key tool in the fight against youth unemployment in the European Union, for which funding needs to be increased and clearly provided as part of the 2016 budget. The 2016 budget should also cover concrete measures to address the backlog of payments, but also a specific budget line for migrants and asylum seekers who are increasingly trying to reach the European Union. Member states must express solidarity among themselves so that the financial burden of caring for these people does not fall only on certain member states, already affected by the financial crisis.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The trialogue mandate contains an assessment of the draft budget, adopted by the Commission on 27 May, and defines Parliament's positions for the trialogue scheduled for 14 July 2015. I voted in favour of this report, which corresponds to the second stage of the annual budgetary procedure, so that we can proceed with the legislative process.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. MEPs have adopted the draft 2016 budget. I am pleased that the European Commission has taken parliament's demands into account: the creation of decent and quality jobs, business development, strengthening solidarity with the Union, supporting the Erasmus programme. I voted in favour of this report and I believe that it reflects the priorities and objectives set out by the Commission and Parliament. This report will be used during trilogue negotiations from mid-July 2015.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report by my colleague José Manuel Fernandes, with a favourable vote, because he opposes cuts in the programme for the competitiveness of enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME), advocates the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative and reiterates the need to reduce the unsustainable delay of outstanding settlement payments for cohesion programmes to a level of around EUR 2 billion by the end of 2016.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The mandate of the European Parliament's negotiators for the 2016 budget was voted on this week. For such a year of uncertainty, it was essential that European funds were properly allocated.  As such, I voted for this report which incorporates the political priorities of the Democrats and Liberals, namely the Digital Single Market and the Energy Union. In addition, the lines essential for renewed growth such as employment and competitiveness have also been highlighted. I regret that the funding of the European Fund for Strategic Investments has necessitated the rescheduling of the MIE and Horizon 2020, key programmes for a more integrated and competitive Europe, and I therefore count on our negotiators to minimise this impact as much as possible in the negotiations that are about to take place.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is Parliament's first response to the draft budget for 2016 and which stipulates Parliament's mandate for the negotiation with the Commission and the Council of a draft budget amounting to EUR 153.5 billion in commitment appropriations (+2.4%) EUR 143.5 billion in payment appropriations (+1.6%). With this mandate, Parliament expresses its position in favour of maximising the impact on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility of the inclusion of the European Fund for Strategic Investments in the draft budget, securing and increasing the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative, as well as increasing funds to address migration challenges.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. By adopting the report on the Mandate of the European Parliament for inter-institutional negotiations on the draft 2016 budget, Parliament broadly welcomes the project proposed by the European Commission: EUR 153.5 billion in commitment appropriations (including EUR 4.5 billion from the 2014 budget) and EUR 143.5 billion in payment appropriations. These amounts represent an increase of 2.4% in commitment appropriations and 1.6% in payment appropriations compared to the 2015 budget. Parliament insists that these "overall moderate" increases, which respect the trajectory set by the multi-year financial framework and take inflation into account, "are virtually no increase in real terms, underscores the importance of expenditure efficiency". Parliament also welcomed the fact that, in addition to the expected increases in headings 3 (Security and Citizenship) and 4 (Europe in the World), the Commission is working to respond to the latest current events such as the crises in Ukraine, Syria and the Mediterranean by meeting the needs of the Union and Member States on security and migration and by displaying a strong political will in the area of external action and fiscal commitment. countries of origin and transit. Important.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution corresponds to the second phase of the annual budgetary procedure.  The report assesses the Commission's draft 2016 budget and also assesses the main points of the EP's mandate for the June trilogue, identifying the EP's budgetary priorities in 2016 by heading. Among the problems of particular interest to the EP are job creation and business development and entrepreneurship across the Union (the "three Es"), internal and external solidarity in Europe, security and migration and the inclusion of a final agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI). It should also be stressed that there is a sufficient level of payment appropriations to cover the growing needs for new programmes, to allow the financing of new priorities (e.g. migration, asylum, security), and to be able to ensure a level of funding for the competitiveness of enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME programme). It is also essential to ensure the continuity of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) in the 2016 budget. Since I agree with these priorities, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the trialogue that will take place on 14 July, the rapporteur for the 2016 budget, Mr Syr. Mr Fernandes presented his report on the mandate for the trialogue. This is the second stage of the budgetary procedure as far as Parliament's activities are concerned.  In the report presented to plenary, for which I voted in favour, Parliament's priorities are affirmed and it will fight for it during the negotiations. Among the most important points are: employment, business development and entrepreneurship across the EU; solidarity within and outside Europe's borders; security and migration; inclusion of a final agreement for EFSI in the 2016 budget and compensation for the cuts that major programmes such as Horizon 2020 and CEF have had to endure; sufficient level of funding to promote the competitiveness of all enterprises with particular regard to small and medium-sized enterprises; extension of the "Youth Employment Initiative" programme.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because there are still too many budget items on unnecessary expenditure and the criticisms, although present in the text, clash with the macro-economic reality of Europe, which is mainly based on austerity policies.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in this vote and reaffirm our general criticism of this draft budget. The draft presented by Mr Fernandes has improved the unacceptable proposals of the Council and the Commission and sought to bring forward positions between the Groups. Our group has tabled numerous amendments which have been introduced and improve at least in part, in our view, the document: mainly, the need to increase the financing of cohesion policies and thereby contribute to the reduction of inequalities between States, regions and localities, and the need to support with particular emphasis those countries experiencing social difficulties , economic and financial. However, we consider that the budget is clearly too rigid and insufficient, and that it does not live up to the challenges of the economic model crisis implemented by majority political flows so far and that policies of austerity, financial and trade deregulation and cuts have only aggravated.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report for a number of reasons, including because it represents a further ratification of the past agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. We insist that, in order to deal with the current economic crisis, we need an economic boost coming from the public sector, and ratifying the cuts in the European budget means approving the logic of austerity that is sinking the European economy. In addition, the report welcomes highly controversial headings to be used against human rights both in Europe and abroad, such as those for 'security and citizenship' and a 'global Europe'. The need for a shift in the logic of austerity is what has led me to vote against this report.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In the 2014-2020 financial period, the European Union aims to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 economic growth strategy. Funds will be invested in promoting innovation, creating jobs, managing migration more effectively and further strengthening the EU's role as a global player. To this end, the draft budget for 2016 included, inter alia, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is financed through part of the overall margin difference and from Horizon 2020 and CEF. The reallocation of funds from these two programmes is risky, e.g. Horizon 2020 is generally recognised as a top priority in the current MFF. Efforts should therefore be made to further balance the proposed reduction in funding for these programmes by increasing the application of the remaining margin up to the ceiling.  What concerns me most is the fact that the 2016 budget and the report express support for the ITER programme and highlight the need for adequate funding. ITER is one of the least sustainable EU-funded projects. Delays, constant cost increases and poorly identifiable results should be sufficient indicators to call the programme into question even in the 2016 draft budget. For this reason, in particular, I abstained in the vote on the draft budget for 2016.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. - Mandate for Trilogue On the one hand, the ECR Group welcomes the fact that, for the first time in a long time, the European Commission has presented a draft budget for the coming year that takes into account issues such as efficiency and economy. However, this draft is still far removed from the eCR Group's ideas. The mandate negotiated for the budgetary procedure for a trialogue between the three EU institutions, Parliament, the Council and the Commission, does not lead to the objectives of a sustainably balanced, efficient and economical budget. In particular, the problem of the large gap between commitments and disbursements is being pushed further forward with this mandate. That is why the ECR Group rejects this mandate.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the definition of the creation of decent and quality jobs and the development of enterprises and entrepreneurship as a priority of the 2016 budget.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft budget for 2016 on the grounds that the proposals and projects proposed by Parliament in its resolution on 11 March 2015 have been accepted. I am pleased that the Commission has included in its draft job creation, development of entrepreneurship and business creation.  I support the continued funding of priority projects highlighted by Parliament in previous proposals. I regret that the Commission has decided to nominally reduce funding for the Competitiveness Programme for businesses and SMEs. I believe that this programme remains of high importance for the development of the Economy and Entrepreneurship of the European Union. I also believe that more resources should be addressed to the YeI, as this is the main means of combating youth unemployment in eu countries.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fundamentally disagree with the proposal tabled. In next year's budget, I welcome the 5.3% fall in commitments, but I consider the proposed 1.6% increase in expenditure to be completely out of the question. The European Union budget needs major cuts, as the vast majority of its resources serve exclusively for redistribution, whether through Eu funds or through an inefficient common agricultural policy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mandate for the trialogue on the draft budget for 2016. I welcome the fact that the budget places great emphasis on investment. As much as 94% of the budget is earmarked for investment and only 6% for the administrative part. I am pleased that the budget places great emphasis on youth employment, strengthening the Youth Guarantee programme. In the next year, we must continue to finance Horizon 2020 and the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (COSME), which are the driving force behind the European economy. I also welcome the fact that the report sees cohesion policy as the EU's main investment policy, which aims to reduce disparities between European regions by increasing economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Union budget should be primarily to solve the problems of its Member States plagued by poverty and unemployment, before carrying out heed subsidised solidarity programmes with third countries.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In May 2015, the Commission presented the EU draft budget for 2016. In its proposal, the Commission puts forward EUR 153.5 billion in commitment appropriations (+2,4% compared to EU budget 2015) and EUR 143.5 billion in payment appropriations (+1,6% compared to last year’s budget).  The current report, which I voted in favour of, asks for the following key points:  1. Minimising, to the largest extent, the effect of financing the EFSI Guarantee Fund by the 2016 Draft Budget. Cuts in Horizon 2020 and CEF for the Guarantee Fund shall be further redistributed via negotiations on the annual EU budgets, starting from EU budget 2016.  2. Increasing the funding of the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) to fight the high rates of unemployment among young people.  3. Securing a long-term perspective in the payment plan. 4. Providing extra funding in 2016 to respond to the challenges posed by migration and asylum seekers trends.  5. Reinforcing external aid programmes, in particular for UNRWA, and humanitarian aid. With the approval of the report by the Parliament, we give the EP delegation a mandate for trilogue with the Council and the Commission.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out for the 2016 budget. It is now up to the Commission to assess precisely the budgetary impact of the measures presented under the European migration programme and the European security programme with regard to Europol, and the additional tasks induced by these measures, so that the budgetary authority can properly adapt Europol's needs for appropriations and human resources.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the mandate for the trilogue on the 2016 draft budget. In the current context, it is of utmost importance to ensure that our priorities, and among them competitiveness and growth, receive the appropriate funding. The European Fund for Strategic Investment is a new tool to boost the European economy and its innovative potential. It must be sufficiently funded to trigger a leverage effect. However, the level of funding for other key programmes such as Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility must be kept as high as possible: these mechanisms are not intended for the same type of projects, but they are complementary and will bring real added-value to our economy if combined.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I believe that this report has a multitude of useful determinants, such as, for example, focusing on investment, knowledge, promoting entrepreneurship and job creation and growth, it is important to note that limiting spending and reducing losses and inefficiencies is essential to ensure proper and efficient spending of taxpayers' money.  A positive point of this report is the transfer of funds that could not be used in 2014 due to the late adoption of rules and programmes, but this report is also not making sufficient progress in encouraging spending reduction measures. I believe we must be extremely careful to be able to offset last year's spending increased by unexpected mobilisations, and to create savings to respond to unforeseen circumstances.  This proposal does not achieve the purpose for which it was made, namely prudent consumption. In this regard, the report failed to provide an adequate, forward-looking budget.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the mandate for the trialogue. The report corresponds to the second stage of the annual budgetary procedure. The mandate for the trialogue contains an estimate of the draft budget adopted by the Commission on 27 May and sets out Parliament's views on the trialogue scheduled for 14 July 2015 and for future negotiations on the EU budget for 2016 starting in the autumn.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in this vote and reaffirm our general criticism of this draft budget. The draft presented by Mr Fernandes has improved the unacceptable proposals of the Council and the Commission and sought to bring forward positions between the Groups. Our group has tabled numerous amendments which have been introduced and improve at least in part, in our view, the document: mainly, the need to increase the financing of cohesion policies and thereby contribute to the reduction of inequalities between States, regions and localities, and the need to support with particular emphasis those countries experiencing social difficulties , economic and financial. However, we consider that the budget is clearly too rigid and insufficient, and that it does not live up to the challenges of the economic model crisis implemented by majority political flows so far and that policies of austerity, financial and trade deregulation and cuts have only aggravated.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. On the one hand, the ECR Group welcomes the fact that, for the first time in a long time, the European Commission has presented a draft budget for the coming year that takes into account issues such as efficiency and economy. However, this draft is still far removed from the eCR Group's ideas. The mandate negotiated for the budgetary procedure for a trialogue between the three EU institutions Parliament, the Council and the Commission does not lead to the objectives of a sustainably balanced, efficient and economical budget. In particular, the problem of the large gap between commitments and disbursements is being pushed further forward with this mandate. That is why the ECR Group rejects this mandate.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in this vote and reaffirm our general criticism of this draft budget. The draft presented by Mr Fernandes has improved the unacceptable proposals of the Council and the Commission and sought to bring forward positions between the Groups. Our group has tabled numerous amendments which have been introduced and improve at least in part, in our view, the document: mainly, the need to increase the financing of cohesion policies and thereby contribute to the reduction of inequalities between States, regions and localities, and the need to support with particular emphasis those countries experiencing social difficulties , economic and financial. However, we consider that the budget is clearly too rigid and insufficient, and that it does not live up to the challenges of the economic model crisis implemented by majority political flows so far and that policies of austerity, financial and trade deregulation and cuts have only aggravated.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. My abstention from voting is justified because the budget is not the tool the EU needs to get out of the crisis, and sensitive items such as Erasmus or asylum policy are also preserved and increased.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mandate to start trilogues on the 2016 budget because the Commission proposal addresses a series of key priorities, such as an effective Energy Union and the delivery of a Digital Single Market. It also foresees additional funding to tackle the challenges of migration as well as a fairer distribution of asylum seekers between Member States. Overall, the new budget satisfactorily addresses crucial issues, such as employment, enterprises and increasing competitiveness.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report assesses the Commission's draft budget for 2016 taking into account the guidelines adopted by the European Parliament in March 2014 and makes recommendations of interest. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report for a number of reasons, including because it represents a further ratification of the past agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. We insist that, in order to deal with the current economic crisis, we need an economic boost coming from the public sector, and ratifying the cuts in the European budget means approving the logic of austerity that is sinking the European economy. In addition, the report welcomes highly controversial headings to be used against human rights both in Europe and abroad, such as those for 'security and citizenship' and a 'global Europe'. The need for a shift in the logic of austerity is what has led me to vote against this report.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 As N-VA, we continue to oppose the savings in, among other things, the successful Horizon 2020 research programme to finance the Juncker Plan. The programme is one of the examples where Europe offers a clear added value. Flanders is one of the European leaders when it comes to research and innovation, not least thanks to European support, and we are proud of that. We therefore continue to call for this support to be safeguarded. As a delegation, we will do this again every year. We would also like to stress that the procedure should not be misused to increase the European budget. Like the Member States, the EU must make a move. Because these elements are not or are not sufficiently reflected in the report, we as an N-VA delegation are voting against.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP colleagues I voted against this report. Even though, this report represents the first step for the Parliament in the annual budgetary procedure. It sets out the Parliament’s broad aims and priorities for the 2016 budget. However, Labour MEPs note that the Commission’s proposal represents only +2.4% in commitments and +1.6% in payments as compared to the 2015 budget. This is, however, above inflation and not a position the Labour Party can support at this time.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This text sets out the mandate of the European Parliament for the negotiations of the 2016 budget with the Council and the Commission.  At this stage of the negotiations, this budget is expected to amount to 153.5 billion commitments (up 2.4%) 143.5 billion payments (up 1.6%). When we recall the decrease in the multi-year financial framework, these increases are rather positive, especially since the mandate given is stronger than in previous years. The text highlights priorities such as the quality of jobs, support for social programmes, solidarity, cohesion and aid to countries in difficulty.  I believe that the European Parliament's rather positive mandate to this negotiation should not be discouraged. I have chosen to abstain, but without illusions about the outcome of the negotiations with the Council. So to follow.  The European Union budget should be more than ever a solidarity budget. I see some progress on this side of the European Parliament and I welcome that.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report recognises a number of shortcomings in the budget and therefore intends to start trading with a set of important assumptions that we follow.  However, given the narrow limits of the budget, as well as the Council's traditional position on this issue, we have doubts about the possibility of improving a budget that is very negative and in which no conditions are met for a fruitful negotiation.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I rejected the mandate for the trialogue because it is essentially a disempowerment of the nation states and calls for more powers and higher levies from net contributors. Despite some positive aspects, such as .B rejection of new EU accessions, I had to reject this proposal.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much appreciate Commissioner Georgieva's efforts to make the Eu ropean Budget more credible and I think her intentions are the best. There is, however, a reality that is in fact a long way from the intentions, including in this text for the trialogue: I wonder, for example, how mce and Horizon 2020 are to be given priority and then applaud the EFSI agreement, which in fact cuts the very foundations of these two programmes.  If we want to be consistent, we must be consistent to the end, and so I believe that the supporters of the European budget should have countered the EFSI agreement, as it undermines the same priorities as those set by the EU. There is very little money available, both for individual states and for Europe: we must be able to make bold choices, and the next review of the MFF is the right opportunity. Pre-accession funds, for example, could perhaps be reduced in order to concentrate these essential resources elsewhere; Of course we need the political will to make choices like this, and I wonder if we have it.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report sets out the mandate for the EP negotiating team to negotiate the EU 2016 budget with the Council, a negotiation which will begin on 14 July before the draft EU budget for 2016 is presented at the end of July. The 2016 Mandate shows, at least semantically, some improvements vis-à-vis in recent years. Many of these improvements are due to the fact that some of the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL have been accepted.  In particular, calls for the strengthening of EU social programmes, the promotion of decent and quality work; there is calls for greater support for cohesion policies and advocates the need to reduce disparities at local, regional or national level; the need to strengthen support for countries facing social, economic and financial constraints; increased support for the development of the integration of migrants. Despite the semantic improvements, we know that the EU budget embodies the materialisation of a political project that is at the service of the great corporate and financial interests and not at the service of the peoples of Europe.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this report on tapping into the job creation potential of the green economy is a most worthwhile contribution to the debate, and in particular I support Jean Lambert’s stance on investing in energy efficiency. As an employment tool, it can certainly promote local job creation and local economic development. Energy poverty affects 125 million people at European level, and investing in energy- efficient homes achieves a quadruple win. It helps alleviate energy poverty. It helps to create new jobs. It ensures a significant reduction in dependence on the use of fossil fuels and in particular on imported fossil fuels, and crucially it helps to reduce CO2 emissions and fight climate change.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, of course, I support so-called green employment, the creation of green jobs, but I find it particularly cynical that it is initiated and forced by the European Union, which has destroyed agriculture in so many countries, as it has in my own country, Hungary. Recently, as I have already mentioned, I have been to Hortobágy, where I have been able to see how direct subsidies, i.e. land-based subsidies, manipulations with them, destroy the ecological balance, destroy livestock and even more destroy agriculture, other than the destruction that the EU has already done by opening up, throwing our markets and inging food from the other side of the world to Hungary and other European countries. In these circumstances, talking about green employment can be considered cynicism.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, mar a dúirt mo chomhghleacaí, Marian Harkin, is tuarascáil an-tábhachtach é seo, agus dar ndóigh, tá sé an-tábhachtach gach gríosadh a thabhairt don tionscal glas.  Mar a deirtear sa tuarascáil anseo, tá seansanna againn chun rudaí a fheabhsú ach ag an am céanna caithfimid díriú ar rudaí áirithe: go háirithe, nach bhfuil dóthain daoine ann le scileanna IT agus STEM. Freisin níl dóthain mná ag dul isteach sna jabanna seo agus sna cúrsaí seo, agus ba chóir dúinn é sin a athrú mar má fhaigheann siad an gríosadh déanfaidh siad é. Táim cinnte de sin.  Dar ndóigh, is féidir linn mórán a dhéanamh don chomhshaol agus do chúrsaí fostaíochta trí fhuinneamh a úsáid i gceart, trí é a shábháil agus trí é a úsáid go héifeachtach. Dá bhrí sin, is tuarascáil thábhachtach í seo, agus tá súil agam go n-éireoidh linn níos mó a dhéanamh.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because 'green employment', while not the only solution needed for economic recovery in Europe, has a fundamental job creation potential for the transition of our economies to more sustainable models. This economic sector, despite the risks posed by its indefinition, is an umbrella for many activities necessary for an environmentally sustainable economic recovery. In addition, the report is committed to the development of quality jobs in the sector, so that it becomes a strategic axis of the continent's economic development.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will help us realise the job-creation potential of the green economy in the future across Europe, including in Ireland. It aims to ensure that the transition does not leave working people and their communities behind. The report stresses the importance of ensuring the economic transformation we need to achieve is a ‘just transition’. A just transition means ensuring targeted skills training and assistance is provided for workers and students – including workers dislocated from declining polluting industries – in emerging green technologies and energy efficiency. The new jobs created in the green economy should be decent, secure and well-paid. We need workers and their unions to be deeply involved in the transition. I voted against the wording in §62 relating to tax, as it appeared to be that the wording amounted to an infringement of the tax sovereignty of Member States. I am disappointed that some parliamentary groups banded together to weaken important elements of the report, such as the commitment to creating quality, secure jobs. Despite this, the report is still a progressive and valuable step forward.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission expects 20 million jobs to be created by exploiting the potential of the green economy. I believe that the EU should make consistent use of this potential and I therefore support this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective of green growth is to achieve a low-carbon, resource-efficient economy. One of the direct consequences of this type of growth is a structural economic change, mainly driven by the more or less artificial scarcity of resources, technological change and innovation, the opening of new markets, the evolution of the industrial fabric and consumer demand. This change, like all changes, would inevitably lead to all-out transformations in the economy, the destruction of jobs and the creation and re-qualification of other jobs. The green economy will increasingly weigh on the circular economy, and therefore on prices. It should be remembered that resource prices have increased by 147% in 15 years. It is very clear that all these changes are part of the process of change in society, in favour of an otherwise dematerialized consumer society of human activities.  Europe, which is largely absent from this major change, is not giving itself the means to respond to all these changes, which is probably why Europe now has 24 million unemployed.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Where jobs are gained through the introduction of inefficient measures, jobs are correspondingly lost in industry due to higher prices.  The job creation is a mirage, and I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which highlights the EU's ambitions for the development of jobs linked to the green economy. To meet this objective, we need a comprehensive and joint response, from the political level to basic training. Time is running out, because today we are missing opportunities that other parts of the world are taking.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  The Commission's Green Employment Initiative was announced in July 2014. together with the Green Action Plan for SMEs and the Communication on a Circular Economy. The aim of the initiative is to build on the The Commission Staff Working Document "Unlocking the potential for green jobs for growth", which is part of the employment package and stresses that up to 20 million jobs could be created in the green economy by 2020. employment guidelines, which call on Member States to promote job creation, including in the areas of welfare and green employment. The transition to a sustainable society and economy, including sustainable consumption and production models, can create opportunities to create new quality jobs and turn existing jobs into greens in virtually all sectors and throughout the value chain, from research to production, distribution and servicing, and in new green high-tech sectors such as renewable energy and traditional industries such as manufacturing and construction , agriculture and fisheries, as well as in services sectors such as tourism, catering, transport and education; stresses, at the same time, that investments in renewable energy sources and energy efficiency not only contribute to the creation of many jobs, but also contribute to maintaining the competitiveness of the European economy and industry and reducing Europe's energy dependency.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. There are exceptions that confirm the rule: this is a good report that I have not hesitated to support. There are indeed many bold proposals that go in the right direction. I also believe that the so-called "green economy" will create stable, sustainable and non-relocable jobs, all in sectors where we are often one step ahead of our non-European competitors.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which stresses that a transition to sustainable societies and economies, including sustainable consumption and production patterns, can provide the opportunity to create new, quality jobs while converting existing jobs into green jobs in almost all sectors and throughout the value chain. In addition, the report calls for the introduction of social and environmental criteria in public procurement policies and the reduction of employment burdens in favour of environmental taxation (without impact on the financing of social protection).

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report for the Employment Initiative aims at green growth, which must lead to an economy based on the efficient use of resources.  As a result of economic and climate change (including the scarcity of certain resources) and innovations, transformation into the green economy will create, redefine and replace new jobs, and that is why action must be taken now to support this economy for greater efficiency and to support citizens in this transformation.  Several sectors are as many non-relocable job areas: waste treatment, insulation and energy efficiency, biomass, organic agriculture, etc. The development of these non-relocable jobs must, of course, be accompanied by training, but industrial employment, which is the strength of our economies (we must not only become a service economy) and which must be safeguarded. The transition will therefore have to be supervised and pragmatic and green workers will have to be supported in this transition. I voted for this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Lambert own-initiative report examines how to exploit the potential of the green economy to create new jobs. Although I agree with my colleague's intentions, I have some reservations about the ideas contained in the text; the positions supported are over-emphasised with the risk that, behind the positive intention to create new 'green' jobs, there will be a desire to replace them with the 'traditional' ones with an overall balance for workers of break-even or even negative. For all these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission's Green Employment Initiative was published in July 2014, together with the SME Ecological Action Plan and the Circular Economy Communication. This Initiative underlined the challenges and employment opportunities posed by the current transition to the use of environmentally friendly and low-carbon energy sources and to a resource-efficient economy.  This initiative report, on which I voted in favour, contains a first position by Parliament which supports the Commission's approach to the transition to sustainable societies and economies. This transition, with equally sustainable consumption and production patterns, can create opportunities for quality job creation and transform existing employment into green employment in virtually every sector and throughout the value chain. To make the most of these opportunities, it is necessary, inter alia, to establish an integrated framework for labour policies and the promotion of skills and skills among workers in such a way that they play an active role. Finally, I welcome the need for the report to introduce environmental and social criteria in public procurement policies.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses the Green Employment Initiative announced by the Commission. Green jobs could be defined as decent work to reduce energy and raw material consumption, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, reduce waste and pollution, and protect and restore ecosystems. The inclusion of labour in the transition to a green economy is particularly important.
