Studies have shown that investment in energy and resource efficiency, the creation of a supply chain through a clear industrial strategy, as well as the shifting of the tax burden from labour to other sources have a positive impact on job creation. It is clear that the labour market is already affected by major global trends, but so far the EU's response has not been comprehensive. The European Parliament notes that in order to make sure that we can maintain and expand employment opportunities and job creation potential, we need to take comprehensive, joint responses, from policy level to basic training. Time is very important, because we are now losing the opportunities that are being exploited in other regions of the world and we are not fully preparing our workers so that they can deal with the difficulties we are already facing. The Commission Communication provides some answers, but it will require the contribution of all EU institutions if we really want to implement the necessary transition.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. One of the biggest challenges is that it is estimated that 95% of fresh products from certain food chains will be threatened by climate change and one third will be at serious risk. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training.  In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills. I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the own-initiative report on incentives for the green economy, because it is very clear that investment in the green economy and in the use of renewable energy also bring new jobs. A nice example from my country, Slovenia, is the use of wood biomass, which, with greater use, would further reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels and, at the same time, with its side effects (electricity, heat for agricultural activity ...) would lead to lower costs and, consequently, jobs.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report because it supports the European Commission's approach to the transition to a green economy. The Green Employment Initiative is an integrated framework that enables the labour market to play an active role in the transition to a green economy and establishes adequate policies that allow workers to adapt to structural changes. The aim is to create sustainable and quality jobs.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the job-creation potential of the green economy in the future across Europe, including in Ireland. It also aims to ensure that the transition does not leave working people and their communities behind. The report stresses to the Commission the importance of ensuring the economic transformation we need to achieve is a ‘just transition’. A just transition means ensuring targeted skills training and assistance is provided for workers and students – including workers dislocated from declining polluting industries – in emerging green technologies and energy efficiency. The new jobs created in the green economy should be decent, secure and well-paid. I am disappointed that some parliamentary groups banded together to weaken important elements of the report, such as the commitment to creating quality, secure jobs. Despite this, the report is still a progressive and valuable step forward. When it comes to an economic transformation of the scale we are discussing, we need workers and their unions to be deeply involved in the transition – an aspect of the report I was strongly in favour of. Public procurement can also play an important role in the transition by including proactive environmental and social criteria.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that a transition to the green economy would bring enormous benefits not only to the environment but also to employment and the European labour market, especially through the creation of local jobs that cannot be relocated, in areas that cannot be transferred abroad and in sectors affected by the crisis such as the construction crisis.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution on the Green Jobs Initiative calls for an interesting and important idea for the European economy. Even the Commission, which is behind the project, admits that green growth is as much a challenge as an opportunity for the dynamism of the labour market. We are encouraged to encourage the transition to a green economy, which would lead to profound transformations in several sectors. The impact on employment is direct: new jobs will be created but more will be replaced, eliminated or redefined. Although there are advantages for the French economy, this text still threatens the employment of low-skilled workers. I therefore abstained from voting on this proposal.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the measure. There is a risk that green jobs will be seen as a substitute for traditional jobs, rather than complementary ones. With negative final balance.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Up to 20 million jobs could be created by 2020 thanks to the 'green economy' initiative. The definition of the concept of 'green' jobs has created a current of contradictions at European level, especially in trying to use this concept for statistical purposes. A 'green' workplace is a decent workplace that has the potential to reduce energy and raw material consumption, limit greenhouse gas emissions, minimise waste and pollution, protect and restore ecosystems. I voted for this report because we need a comprehensive response to ensure that we can maintain and expand employment and green job creation opportunities. Time is a key factor, given that we are losing opportunities and are failing to provide our workforce with all the skills we need to address the challenges we already face. The Commission Communication provides certain answers, but it will be necessary for all EU institutions to fulfil their role in order to be able to achieve this necessary transition towards a greener economy.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This report is a response from the European Parliament to the Commission's communication on the Green Jobs Initiative. One of the European Union's priorities is to fully exploit the potential of the green economy and green growth. Environmental protection and competitiveness are not separate objectives. We must be careful not to enact overly restrictive environmental rules that would have a negative impact on the competitiveness of businesses and prevent job creation. However, like blue growth, green growth has significant potential for innovation and job creation. It is our duty to fully exploit this potential by creating appropriate structures at European level and in the Member States with full respect for the principle of subsidiarity. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on 'Green employment initiative: exploiting the potential of the green economy to create jobs'. I consider this issue to be absolutely fundamental: the reckless use of natural resources, climate change and the stresses to which the environment is subjected risk leading to irreversible consequences for our ecosystem and our society. The development of new sectors focusing on innovation and how to reduce pollution, recycling, energy efficiency and the use of renewable energies must therefore be absolutely encouraged, bearing in mind that it can make an important contribution to job creation.  As the report points out, in parallel with the development of these sectors, initiatives must be made to retrain workers. Facilitating the transition to a green economy therefore requires targeted investment in education, training and research and development, in order to train qualified staff in the transition to a green economy model.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will help us realise the job-creation potential of the green economy in the future across Europe, including in Ireland. It aims to ensure that the transition does not leave working people and their communities behind. The report stresses the importance of ensuring the economic transformation we need to achieve is a ‘just transition’. A just transition means ensuring targeted skills training and assistance is provided for workers and students – including workers dislocated from declining polluting industries – in emerging green technologies and energy efficiency. The new jobs created in the green economy should be decent, secure and well-paid. We need workers and their unions to be deeply involved in the transition – an aspect of the report I was strongly in favour of. I voted against the wording in §62 relating to tax, as it appeared to be that the wording amounted to an infringement of the tax sovereignty of Member States. I am disappointed that some parliamentary groups banded together to weaken important elements of the report, such as the commitment to creating quality, secure jobs. Despite this, the report is still a progressive and valuable step forward.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Where jobs are gained through the introduction of inefficient measures, jobs are correspondingly lost in industry due to higher prices. The job creation is a mirage, and I therefore voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the green economy provides significant opportunities in the labour market, with new kinds of jobs created and others replaced or redefined. On the other hand, the transition to green employment will also present its challenges. I believe that it might be time to adapt and update the educational framework, possibly through more innovative teaching methods and equipping youth with skills in the emerging new green job sector. The forecast for this sector of the economy remains quite strong. I also supported the view that new burdens on SMEs should be avoided when discussing their role in this new sector.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is a good text and incorporates many of our demands, such as the development of a database of training and work offers and best practices for the development of green employment, the centrality of research and the introduction of criteria to favour companies with a virtuous and sustainable waste disposal cycle.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report, which supports, among other things, initiatives to create jobs for the green economy. Indeed, the measures taken by the Commission to support green growth should promote job creation: the development of the biomass and biofuels sectors, the organic farming sector, the increase in insulation and energy efficiency in the construction sector are all initiatives that should indeed contribute to the creation of green jobs. However, these innovations will have to be accompanied by real workforce training and transition management: the effect on employment will be nil if skills do not follow. The creation of these green jobs should be supported by the use of several European funds, such as the ESF or the ERDF, which should in particular push the regions to invest in green measures.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the Green Growth Initiative, stressing that the transition to sustainable societies and economies, including sustainable forms of consumption and production, can lead to opportunities to create new quality jobs and transform existing employment into green jobs in almost all sectors, as well as in new green high-tech sectors such as renewable energy sources.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the green employment initiative. The initiative was published by the European Commission in July 2014 together with the Green Action Plan for SMEs and the Circular Economy Communication. Among the main points of the report: 1) environmental tax reform; 2) energy and resource efficiency and 3) the development of the supply chain and the role of SMEs.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that climate problems are one of the most important challenges at this time. This report appropriately highlights the opportunities linked to 'green' employment by highlighting the most critical points and trying to find appropriate solutions. Published in July 2014 by the Commission, the Green Employment Initiative promotes the creation of new jobs and business opportunities that are linked to a transition to new sustainable economic and corporate models.  An effort in this direction would make it possible to address, in addition to climate-related issues, other equally important challenges such as unemployment and energy dependency. At a time of economic crisis such as the current one, I believe it is important to invest and encourage new high-tech sectors, such as renewable energies, and at the same time to promote 'green' innovation in traditional sectors such as manufacturing, construction, agriculture and tourism.  This proposal is therefore an important step towards a sustainable economic transition that will produce concrete benefits in all sectors and is a starting point for reducing unemployment and encouraging economic growth.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. In the face of the challenges of globalisation, ineffective resource management and climate change, the consolidation of a greener and more environmentally friendly economy is a priority. A serious and coherent policy is increasingly needed to address common challenges and enhance sustainable job creation in all its aspects. In a context of global competition, Europe is at the level and has an obligation to invest in new green economies in various sectors and across the value chain, from research to production, distribution, service delivery, high technology and even traditional sectors such as agriculture, fisheries, tourism, construction and restoration, translating into medium and long-term economic gains and according to estimates generating 20 million new jobs. I therefore support Mrs Lambert's report, which holistically addresses investment in sustainable job creation, calling for the full use of Community funds to this end and not forgetting in particular small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The transition to a society and an eco-sustainable economy offers the possibility of creating new green jobs in almost all sectors, such as renewable energy, agriculture, fisheries, manufacturing and construction. Not only that, but also in the service sector, such as tourism, transport, catering and education. Although this transition will, on the whole, have a positive impact, it is also true that the European Union is still unprepared for this development for a number of reasons: companies that would like to take action to make their business environmentally sustainable are not sure that they can manage the risk or the process of change; it is not said that we can find workers with the necessary skills because even today there are few students who acquire skills in the technological, scientific, engineering and mathematical fields. I therefore agree with the rapporteur on encouraging Member States to make full use of the wide range of European funding, including the Structural and Investment Funds, by giving priority to financing SMEs that support the development of the green economy and job creation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Green growth sectors offer great economic and ecological benefits for workers in the EU, and is estimated to grow considerably in the coming years. The report also calls for the creation of more entrepreneurial mind-set, a strengthening of the entrepreneurial culture in the EU, and also calls on all Member States to make the transition from traditional jobs to green jobs. The report highlights the fact that a green and a circular economy can provide solutions for the environment as well as for the economy. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because 'green employment', while not the only solution needed for economic recovery in Europe, has a fundamental job creation potential for the transition of our economies to more sustainable models. This economic sector, despite the risks posed by its indefinition, is an umbrella for many activities necessary for an environmentally sustainable economic recovery. In addition, the report is committed to the development of quality jobs in the sector, so that it becomes a strategic axis of the continent's economic development.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Green Employment Initiative report presents a framework to allow labour market and skill policies to support workers in coping with labour market transitions. This report works together with the Commission’s Green Employment Initiative and the Green Action Plan for SMEs to help in the transition towards a greener economy. While I fully support the focus on creating jobs from the green economy I also believe that we need to help our workforce to adapt to the requirements of this niche, hence I voted in favour of this report. However I must emphasis that matters related to taxation should remain the competence of Member States.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy is the EU's main policy, where the objective of sustainable growth goes beyond the issue of climate change and covers a wider range of issues, aiming at transforming the EU economy into a smart, green economy. As the creation of green jobs for women will strengthen efforts to achieve the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy, I am convinced that women's entrepreneurship in the green economy is needed and needed, with a focus on more cooperative business models such as cooperatives and social enterprises, but also paying attention to women farmers and family farms, access to microfinance for women , green job creation in public services and pilot projects on gender quality criteria for businesses in the context of public procurement.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's position on the European Commission's communication, published in July 2014 on the "Green Jobs Initiative" as well as a green action plan for SMEs. The report focuses on reforming environmental taxation, energy efficiency, developing supply chains and highlighting the role of SMEs. Considering that the transition to 'green jobs' presents important opportunities for the European economy, but also challenges in the labour market, including the transition time between job creation, job replacement and redefinition, it is necessary to reflect on the support of this transition. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission's Green Employment Initiative was published in July 2014 together with the SME Action Plan and the Circular Economy Communication. In achieving the transition to a green economy, the involvement of the workforce will be essential. Some sectors will be subject to considerable changes, which is why the efficient use of EU funds is necessary.  The Commission communication makes a number of positive proposals, but it is right that all European institutions should make their contribution to an effective transition to employment offered by green growth.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This initiative report supports a green growth model and green employment initiative. Parliament wants to close the skills gap in green technologies, support job creation through efficient and intelligent environmental taxation.  It is estimated that some 3 to 4.2 million green jobs were created between 2002 and 2011. This sector is clearly growing. We must do everything we can to encourage and support it.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report, also included in this report, is based on the concept of a circular economy published last year, which aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. One of the biggest challenges is that it is estimated that, for example, 95% of fresh products from certain food chains will be threatened by climate change and one third will be at serious risk. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training.  In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills. I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I supported the report, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Commission's green employment initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the concept of a circular economy published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. One of the biggest challenges is that it is estimated that, for example, 95% of fresh products from certain food chains will be threatened by climate change and one third will be at serious risk. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training.  In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills. I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the Green Jobs Initiative report. This text aims at a necessary transition to a more environmentally friendly economy by reducing carbon emissions. It aims to create jobs as well as to redefine others for an ecological purpose. As a member of the Parliamentary Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I will ensure that this text, of course, has a second objective: the preservation of human health. It is therefore a question of voting in favour for a three-way approach: ecological, economic and health. One caveat, however, will be to ensure a measured and gradual change without societal and economic upheaval that could have serious consequences.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While the ECR can support the general sentiment of this report, it cannot support a number of specific paragraphs which we believe go above and beyond the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality including calls for a new directive on musculoskeletal disorders and carcinogens; the introduction of a financial transaction tax; the creation of decent and inclusive jobs by leveraging the power of public procurement via social and environmental clauses; and the introduction of a legal obligation on employers to include workers’ representatives in green workplace programmes.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this initiative as I do not believe the solution lies in simply implementing new reforms and tackling challenges without a profound understanding of the implications these might hold for the labour market. I believe that we should focus primarily on thoroughly assessing the current challenges and potential opportunities and how these may be dealt with best. It is foremost a question of efficiently targeting the challenges the existing workforce is already experiencing and ensuring the correct matching of labour and opportunities.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against because, while green growth may indeed boost the economy, the report's approach nonetheless follows the logic of previous already failed strategies.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. One of the biggest challenges is that it is estimated that, for example, 95 % of fresh products from certain food chains will be threatened by climate change and one third will be at serious risk. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training. In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills.  I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I can only welcome this report on green employment because, in addition to being an excellent report, it has welcomed the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, for which I was rapporteur, in particular aimed at: progressively eliminating direct and indirect subsidies harmful to the environment, including those in favour of fossil fuels; develop models to shift taxation from labour to environmental pollution, as well as to take into account the environmental impact of goods and services in line with the 'polluter pays' principle; introduce tax exemptions and/or targeted subsidies for start-ups, micro-enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises providing products and services with high environmental added value, including a low overall carbon content. By closing the product lifecycle circle, it is also possible to create millions of jobs at all stages, from product design to production and consumption to maintenance, repair, modernization and reuse. Specifically, improving resource efficiency could generate between 1.4 and 2.8 million jobs, and waste prevention, eco-design and re-use could save our businesses EUR 600 billion net.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. This report highlighted important questions about how we can move to a more sustainable economy and job creation. That is why I voted in favour of the text of the final vote. However, I would like to point out that some elements relating to taxation and labour law did not receive my support.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it could create stable, sustainable and non-relocable jobs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report presents positive concepts, proposals and perspectives - towards economic revitalization, training, gender equality and sustainable development practices. However, the promotion of this development is based on measures, policies or resolutions which are essentially opposed to the principles of "green" development, namely: tax policies that remove taxes from work – removing proportionality to taxes, in particular by distrusting irs for the application of universal taxes (VAT) on consumption; the application of the polluter pays principle, which is a dubious concept; trade in CO2 emission allowances; dependence on strategies and directives that are generally opposed to what we advocate.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's Green Jobs Initiative of July 2014 seeks to build on the 2012 working document entitled 'Exploiting the employment potential of green growth', which highlighted the fact that up to 20 million jobs could be created in the green economy by 2020. It is the involvement of the workforce that is an important point towards the transition to green hosing. European Union funds play an important role in this area when used efficiently. If we want to build a truly green economy, we must also not forget the fundamental importance of investment and appropriate incentives, along with a stable political environment. I support this initiative and call for a more dynamic approach to those who are currently unemployed and for which green jobs could be a new job opportunity.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are obviously in favour of employment and the environment, but this text has been used with an objectively excessive emphasis on green seats and unrealistic considerations. That is why I will not be able to support the text, but I will abstain.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Green Employment Initiative, although green growth can indeed boost the economy, but the report's approach follows the logic of previous already failed strategies.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it does not respect the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. The initiative would only increase the regulatory burden on businesses and involve higher costs. This is unacceptable since many SMEs already struggle with applying EU legislation. Additionally, social and environmental clauses should not be the portal through which these burdensome and costly measures are brought to Parliament.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is very important to outline the employment challenges and opportunities of the current transition towards a green, low-carbon, energy and resource-efficient economy. The Green Employment Initiative Communication presents an integrated framework to allow labour market and skill policies to play an active role to support this transition and focuses on the importance of anticipating and establishing adequate skills policies to support workers in coping with structural change, of securing labour market transitions, and of strengthening governance and partnership-based initiatives. This is a positive report which supports the Commission approach regarding the transition towards a greener economy.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings. Further efforts should be made in the field of environmental education and training, in particular to develop science, technology and maths skills. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills. I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Last May, unemployment rate data unfortunately showed that the situation is still difficult and that the recovery is slow to arrive: 11.1% in the euro area and 12.4% in Italy. In order to change this dramatic situation, we must pursue every effort.  We have today voted on a report indicating that green growth is a way of fully exploiting this situation. I voted 'yes' to this report, hoping that the EU will increasingly have a reforming spirit focused on the needs of its citizens, combining work, business and the environment positively and pragmatically.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report on the green employment initiative because, although it has a sectoral perspective, it is part of a broader discourse that is aimed at the Commission to consider that the creation of new quality jobs in the EU can take place by increasing not only flexibility and precariousness but above all the protection of workers and decent work.  Today, the EU is facing a fundamental problem, common to many Member States, due to the reduction in workers' purchasing power, which can be helped by increasing wages or, as the S&D Group has been claiming for a long time, with the creation of a guaranteed minimum wage across the EU. The EU has been going through a deep crisis for more than seven years. in many countries it has resulted in the loss of millions of jobs, an increase in precariousness, in terms of social exclusion. Therefore, work and the creation of new quality jobs must regain the place they deserve in the European debate, together with other emergencies, not least because we are currently facing a structural problem, which requires structural solutions in every sense and not only in the unilateral sense of flexibility.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against today the report on the Green Employment Initiative: Exploiting the potential of the green economy to create jobs, partly because it has excessive entitlements, sets false impulses and violates subsidiarity.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Lambert report because it is imperative we increase the employment potential of jobs in the green sector. I welcome the Green Employment Initiative, given it presents an integrated framework to allow labour market and skill policies to play an active role to support the transition towards a greener economy and focuses on the importance of anticipating and establishing adequate skills policies to support workers in coping with structural change, of securing labour market transitions, and of strengthening governance and partnership-based initiatives. The green sector offers huge opportunities for future job creation and we owe it to the 23 million people in Europe who are currently out of work to make sure Europe can maximise this potential.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because employment opportunities must be created where there is room for growth and room for growth. The green economy is an opportunity that can create a virtuous circle that can stimulate growth.  Support for SMEs investing in a green economy, creating jobs and ensuring sustainable well-being, must be a policy of all states.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour, convinced that the green economy is a sector with strong potential to create jobs and that it must be exploited and driven at European level. Our decision is based on three ideas contained in the report: (1) guarantees for a fair transition and that this principle serves as the basis for negotiation at the Paris Climate Conference COP 21; (2) the ultimate objective of promoting the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, integrating displaced and low-skilled workers into the strategy; (3) the transition cannot have a negative impact on social security systems or low-income people. I list some positive proposals envisaged in the Initiative: creating new job opportunities in the green economy; promotion of the acquisition of professional skills, typical of green employment, oriented, free and accessible to uns qualified personnel; public investment to generate sustainable employment; prominence of social workers (green trade union representatives) and participation of workers; environmental and social clauses in government procurement; reducing insecurity arising from the displacement of workers; and support for SMEs in this green transition.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. Just over a year ago, on 2 July 2014, the European Commission presented measures to make the most of the employment potential of the green economy. It is therefore only natural that the European Parliament has voted on this initiative, in order to insist on the necessary revitalisation of this sector of the future for the European economy. This sector already accounts for nearly 500,000 jobs in France and it is also estimated that more than 20 million jobs could be created in Europe by the end of the decade in the renewable energy sector alone. A strong advocate of employment, the major issue for our citizens, I voted in favour of this report, which recommends supporting companies and in particular "green" SMEs which represent, such as digital, high-tech or "silver-economy", one of the key sectors and drivers for the economic future of our territories.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I alongside my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party voted in favour of a report which aims to increase the employment potential of jobs in the green sector. Across Europe there are 23 million people unemployed. There needs to be strong investment in quality jobs and a real focus on growth. There is huge potential in the green sector for job creation in the future, we must make sure that the UK and the EU together work to maximise this.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the transition to a greener and more sustainable economy has great potential for innovation and job creation (up to 20 million by 2020) and seems inevitable in a world threatened by climate change and waste of resources. However, it is necessary to ensure that this transition gives our companies time to adapt and that it does not come at the expense of the competitiveness of our manufacturing industry. The EU must also protect its industrial fabric from possible distortions of competition with third-country companies that are not subject to the same environmental rules.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Green Employment Initiative because I believe that it raises important issues for the EU economy today.  The so-called green economy is a growing sector with great potential for growth and job creation. However, the transition to green employment is not only an opportunity, but also a challenge. I believe that the final version of the report, which was the result of negotiations between all the political groups, has maintained an appropriate balance between these two aspects and a number of important issues have been addressed. I am pleased that the role that small and medium-sized enterprises can play in the green economy has been emphasised and that it has been emphasised that any changes must not result in additional burdens for entrepreneurs. Furthermore, I believe that the transition to a green economy must take place not only by increasing investment in new technologies or by introducing new legislation. Above all, we must invest in social capital and equip workers with the appropriate skills sought by employers in a changing labour market, where certain new positions will certainly be created, but others will inevitably be changed.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. One of the biggest challenges is that it is estimated that, for example, 95% of fresh products from certain food chains will be threatened by climate change and one third will be at serious risk. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training.  In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills. I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The creation of ‘green jobs’ has the potential to boost future job creation and we must ensure that Europe can maximise this opportunity. This important report aims at increasing the employment potential of jobs in the green sector. With 23 million people unemployed in Europe, it is vital that we seize this opportunity to invest in decent work. We need a fair transition roadmap on green jobs which combines environmental goals with green skills development strategies and targeted investments. This will in turn support green SMEs and lead to much needed job creation.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The debate on this report coincides with the UK government’s announcement that it intends to privatise  the Green Investment Bank.  It is vital that the government retains a stake in this bank and that it continues to operate under its original purpose, namely as a green bank.  The bank is vital for investments in the green economy which are in turn important for the creation of green jobs.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour, convinced that the green economy is a sector with strong potential to create jobs and that it must be exploited and driven at European level. Our decision is based on three ideas contained in the report: (1) guarantees for a fair transition and that this principle serves as the basis for negotiation at the Paris Climate Conference COP 21; (2) the ultimate objective of promoting the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, integrating displaced and low-skilled workers into the strategy; (3) the transition cannot have a negative impact on social security systems or low-income people. I list some positive proposals envisaged in the Initiative: creating new job opportunities in the green economy; promotion of the acquisition of professional skills, typical of green employment, oriented, free and accessible to uns qualified personnel; public investment to generate sustainable employment; prominence of social workers (green trade union representatives) and participation of workers; environmental and social clauses in government procurement; reducing insecurity arising from the displacement of workers; and support for SMEs in this green transition.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against because I find the whole project absurd and unnecessary. The whole climate package, green energy and green employment are just an expression of the ideology of economic life. This green ideology translates into economic difficulties, many times more expensive than, for example, energy in the US, additional fiscal and administrative burdens. I find the proposals for additional fiscal burdens particularly damaging.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Employment Initiative Report: harnessing the potential of the green economy to create jobs, because at the moment, when the limit of unsustainable pressure on the environment and climate change is being reached, and at the same time inefficient use of resources, such initiatives to promote the green economy are not only laudable, but extremely necessary. Facts and statistics clearly show that the green economy sector is increasing and creates a lot of jobs every year. The European Environment Agency states that between 2000 and 2001 more than 1.3 million jobs were created due to the rise in services and the green goods sector. Creating much-needed and sustainable jobs, in particular by encouraging SMEs, increasing labour market opportunities, strengthening the competitiveness of the European economy and industry, and reducing Europe's energy dependency – are just some of the positives of this Initiative and the Reports I voted for.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The goal of green growth is to achieve a low-carbon, resource-efficient economy. It reflects a structural economic transformation, mainly driven by the more or less artificial scarcity of resources, technological change and innovation, the opening of new markets, the evolution of the industrial fabric and consumer demand. This change would lead to a profound transformation of the entire economy and a wide range of sectors. Jobs would be created, others replaced, others redefined. This green economy would be doubled by the circular economy, a veritable urban mine that would weigh heavily on prices. Resources, let's remember, have increased by 147% in 15 years. These two aspects of the new economy are part of the great transformation of society brought about, moreover, by the dematerialization of human activities. Europe, for 50 years, has not given itself the means of this profound change in the labour market. This is evidenced by the 24 million unemployed in Europe.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jean Lambert's report on the Green Jobs Initiative. The aim of this report is to promote the exploitation of job creation potential in the green economy. Green jobs are beneficial in many ways because they reduce energy and raw material consumption, limit greenhouse gas emissions, create new jobs and are often non-relocable. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Green Employment Initiative. Indeed, the transition to sustainable economies is an opportunity for the creation of new jobs, which we must seize. To be effective, however, this transition must meet certain conditions. As one of the engines of job creation in Europe, access to financing and training in the area of sustainable development is essential for the transition of SMEs to green jobs.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Under the heading "green" a lot can be demanded, for example a strengthening of the European Semester, new requirements and goals, adjustments in the tax systems, etc. I therefore reject the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Green Employment Initiative: exploiting the potential for job creation in the green economy at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The European Union is gradually moving towards the development and promotion of the green economy and the circular economy. The initiative emphasises and supports the need for high-skilled and professional workers to be highly skilled and professional in the green economy. Such a move is welcome, but it is important not to forget the role of industry sectors in providing growth and sustainable employment. However, I voted against the paragraph of the report, which provides for the introduction of a financial transaction tax, as this would probably lead to higher prices for consumers. The introduction of such a tax may also pose a risk to the industry, making it uncompetitive and thus slowing down growth. Fair and healthy competition is the key to the growth of industry sectors.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 July 2015, I supported the Report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the Green Employment Initiative, which was presented by the Commission back in July 2014. This document was part of the employment package and was based on the assumption that up to 20 million jobs could be created in the EU by 2020 through the so-called green economy. This report rightly adopts the definition of 'green jobs' developed by the International Labour Organisation, which refers to them as decent jobs that reduce emissions, reduce energy and raw material consumption, minimise waste and pollution generation, and protect and restore ecosystems. The proposal put forward by the Greens and the rapporteur, Jean Lambert, was strong, for the environment and for the benefit of workers, and aimed to ensure that workers and their collectives were not left behind in the transition to a low-carbon or carbon-free economy. The proposal calls for the targeted development and teaching of green technology skills for both workers and students, including workers who have lost their place by curbing the development of polluting industries. It states that the jobs created in the green economy must be of good quality and sustainable. Since the original strong aspects of the text have been protected in subsequent negotiations, I have decided to support this report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including in the areas of health and the so-called green profession. One of the biggest challenges is that it is estimated that, for example, 95% of fresh products from certain food chains will be threatened by climate change and one third will be at serious risk. Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training.  In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills. I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – As ‘Green Economy’ is measured to be able to deliver 20 million jobs, the promotion of the Green Employment Initiative is very important, especially in countries where unemployment is on the rise. The report emphasises some elements in relation to job potential like environmental taxation, social partnership for transition, greening workplaces and energy efficiency, among others.  I have voted in favour, hoping that the report is another milestone to a paradigm shift of green job creation in modern economies.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. In its 2015 report, the European Environment Agency highlighted the inadequacy of certain current measures to achieve the objectives of protecting biodiversity, reducing the use of fossil fuels, combating climate change and preventing their impact on human health and the environment.  This report stresses that a transition to sustainable societies and economies, including sustainable production and consumption patterns, can create new quality jobs.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. Lots of interesting things in this text. The goal is to create jobs and support the industry. Having said that, we must not have everything based on the green economy. It is interesting to see that local authorities are seen as the level that is recognized as being the most competent in making a difference. However, it is important to monitor the sustainability of these jobs, which must not be false solutions to combat unemployment. There are many areas that will be supported by this project, including agriculture, which I can only support. I therefore support this report, which should lead to the creation of stable, sustainable and non-relocable jobs.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a positive report supporting the Commission's approach to the transition to a greener economy. The report calls for the introduction of environmental and social criteria in government procurement policies, as well as the transfer of the labour burden to other sources of taxes, such as environmental taxes. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because 'green employment', while not the only solution needed for economic recovery in Europe, has a fundamental job creation potential for the transition of our economies to more sustainable models. This economic sector, despite the risks posed by its indefinition, is an umbrella for many activities necessary for an environmentally sustainable economic recovery. In addition, the report is committed to the development of quality jobs in the sector, so that it becomes a strategic axis of the continent's economic development.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The initiative in question allows employment and environmental agendas to converge satisfactorily. While it is true that this objective presents a number of difficulties, I believe that adapting to a green economy is practically imperative if we are to reinvent ourselves and thrive. I think it is necessary for us to focus on the strategic development of the environmental tax for businesses, provided that this does not place an excessive burden that hinders the growth of SMEs. Voting in favour of this proposal is to bet on the Horizon 2020 programme, and as such, I support the initiative.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Green Employment Report to exploit the potential of the green economy to create jobs. To achieve our objective, we primarily need the implementation and implementation of the Green Growth Action Plan, which provides guidance to all Member States on how to help entrepreneurs benefit from the resources provided by the European Union to move towards a green economy. According to the latest statistics in May 2015, there were more than 23 million unemployed in the European Union. Within this, the big problem is youth unemployment, and the Republic of Croatia is one of the member states with the worst statistics and more than 75 thousand under the age of 30 without a job. On the other hand, we are witnessing climate change and weather disasters caused by long-standing neglect of the environment and irrational use of resources. I supported MEP Jean Lambert's report linking the Two Priorities of the European Commission, and also two major problems – unemployment and environmental protection. In April 2012. The European Commission has published a package of employment measures that has defined the green economy as a key source of job creation. The two biggest challenges we have not yet addressed are the development of green jobs in environmental industries and support for the "greening" of traditional industries.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour. Some regions in the EU are facing more challenges than others because of the geographical concentration of energy- and resource-intensive and polluting industries, or of higher levels of poverty or unemployment. That is why we have to support a green economy – opportunities for the labour market in the EU.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Green jobs are an important element in creating new and sustainable jobs with a positive impact on the environment and the quality of life of EU citizens. They will contribute to reducing energy and raw material consumption, minimising waste and pollution, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and helping to restore ecosystems. Self-sufficiency in resources and raw materials that affect economic security requires a transition to a circular economy and thus a reduction in the consumption of raw materials and resources, their more efficient use and processing. This will lead to the creation of new sustainable jobs and will positively affect employment and economic growth. Therefore, concrete measures need to be taken as soon as possible, in particular economic, financial, tax and social, which will present clear, unambiguous and transparent rules for employers in promoting the creation of such jobs.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Green Employment Initiative: exploiting the potential of the green economy to create jobs', for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Report which ‘highlights the fact that full implementation of environmental legislation, as well as the improvement of environmental integration and policy coherence across different sectorial polices in the EU, are essential for a full deployment of the potential linked to the green economy and therefore for the creation of green jobs.’

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting for this initiative, which will allow for a transition to the green economy, which is as much a challenge as an opportunity to boost the labour market. It will be necessary to remain vigilant about the implementation of these drastic changes where the skilled workforce will have to meet the new skills needs or risk having a great impact on employment. Its positive impact should lead to the creation of stable, sustainable and non-relocable jobs.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal concerning the initiative to exploit the potential of a green economy in order to create new jobs. On the basis of forecast estimates, in fact, it is highlighted that up to 20 million jobs could be created by the year 2020 with "green employment". At the 2010 Cancún Conference, EU Member States committed themselves to combating climate change and taking concrete and targeted action, with particular regard to training and retraining for workers, innovative approaches and business investment and incentives. We fully support the rapporteur's proposal to implement coherent policies, with respect for sustainable growth, aimed at exploiting the potential of a green economy, and above all for fairer social inclusion.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the green economy is to reduce the consumption of energy, and raw materials, in favour of a renewed well-being of ecosystems.  I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Lambert, because I believe that it provides an informed evidence of the benefits that a transition to green employment would bring to the labour market.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe that the green economy is an important sector for boosting job creation at European level. In addition, the report argues that jobs created in the green economy must be quality and sustainable, and describes the need for an EU-wide industrial strategy to develop the renewable energy sector. Other very important aspects are the strengthening of workers' participation in transition management, ensuring that a shift to environmental taxation should not have disproportionate impacts on lower incomes.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Green Employment Initiative aims to interfere with the Tax System of the Member States. In addition, many new targets and targets for the nation states will be drawn up, which will lead to a further burden on the states. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I welcome this report of Parliament's initiative, which notes the environmental challenges and irreversible damage to the consumption and production patterns of productive capitalism, but also the potential for green job creation. The ecologist rapporteur points out that the "just transition" model could increase GDP by 1% while creating more than 2 million jobs. It attaches great importance throughout its relationship to the defence of decent, quality and sustainable jobs. It calls for supporting the ecological conversion of SMEs, the main suppliers of jobs and ecological innovation. Finally, it calls for the development of training and skills in these sectors. All this with a follow-up of statistical data to assess the quality of the jobs created. The report focuses on employment-related aspects and therefore does not call into question the carbon market. It calls for a reorienting of the Juncker plan, including strengthening social and environmental clauses in public procurement. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The goal of green growth is to achieve a low-carbon, resource-efficient economy. It reflects a structural economic transformation mainly motivated by the more or less artificial scarcity of resources, technological change and innovation, the opening of new markets, the evolution of the industrial fabric and consumer demand. This change would lead to a profound transformation throughout the economy and a wide range of sectors. Jobs would be created, others replaced, others redefined. This green economy would be doubled by the real circular urban mining economy, which would weigh heavily on prices. Resources, let's remember, have increased by 147% in 15 years. These two aspects of the new economy are part of the great transformation of society brought about, moreover, by the dematerialization of human activities. Europe, for 50 years, has not given itself the means of this profound change in the labour market. This is evidenced by the 24 million unemployed in Europe.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I presented my vote in favour in the report on the Green Employment initiative.  The lack of existing measures to achieve biodiversity protection objectives, reduce the use of fossil fuels, combat climate change and prevent its impact on human health and the quality of the environment have led to the need for a comprehensive strategy in this area, with a significant impact on the creation of new jobs. It is imperative to redirect Europe to investment in renewable energy, thereby contributing to maintaining its economic and industrial competitiveness and progressively reducing its energy dependency.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it presents an ambitious set of proposals regarding the potential employment opportunities that are linked to a switch to a greener economy. The report took into account the burdens faced by SMEs by a shift towards a green economy and presented a more gradual development plan, starting with information and awareness campaigns about moving to greener products and processes as well as incentives to make the move.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Europe can achieve a new period of economic growth if it resolutely opts for the transition to a low-carbon and sustainable economy. A 'green' economy brings solutions for the climate and the environment, but also for society. A structural transition to a green growth economy will enable us to transform existing traditional employment and create new job opportunities. A green transition will have a positive impact on employment. Nevertheless, a number of processes need to be initiated to support and accelerate the transition to a green growth economy. Without new skills, there are no opportunities for high-quality new jobs. Education is best prepared for this by closing the gap between the training it organises and the skills that will be needed for the jobs of the future. For industry, high-quality innovations must prepare the economy for a low-carbon and energy-efficient future. Particular attention should also be paid to SMEs, which are the main drivers of job creation in Europe. SME-oriented measures should aim to further stimulate innovative green entrepreneurship.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 High unemployment in many regions of the EU requires imaginable and flexible solutions. One of these is the creation of so-called green jobs that meet the requirements of sustainable development. According to the Commission's estimates, the renewable energy economy alone will create around 20 million new jobs in Europe by 2020.  The European Commission's 2014 green jobs initiative therefore responds correctly to new conditions in a dynamically developing sector that contributes directly to reducing energy and raw material consumption, greenhouse gas emissions and pollution.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report outlines the employment challenges and opportunities of the current transition towards a green, low-carbon, energy and resource-efficient economy. The Green Employment Initiative Communication presents an integrated framework to allow labour market and skill policies to play an active role to support this transition and focuses on the importance of anticipating and establishing adequate skills policies to support workers in coping with structural change, of securing labour market transitions, and of strengthening governance and partnership-based initiatives. Tapping the potential of the green economy offers a unique opportunity to provide jobs and green growth. This is a positive report which I supported, but I voted against some parts that are impinging on policy areas that are strictly national competences related to tax on capital and corporate gains and tax on financial transactions.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission estimates in 2012 that up to 20 million jobs could be created in the green economy within the EU by 2020. These are decent jobs that reduce the use of energy and raw materials; limit greenhouse gas emissions; minimise waste and pollution; protect and restore ecosystems. This requires the development of a coherent, comprehensive policy framework that provides a predictable training and investment environment. The report shall take into account the conditions and possibilities for doing so. I consider the issue discussed in this report to be extremely important, which is why I supported it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse the 2015 European Environment Agency report which highlights the inadequacy of existing measures to achieve biodiversity protection objectives, reduce the use of fossil fuels, combat climate change and prevent its impact on human health and the environment. I would point out that without a coherent policy response capable of addressing these common challenges, a significant part of the sustainable job creation potential of the transition to an inclusive green economy could be overtaken. I am voting in favour of this own-initiative report advocating an ambitious and coherent policy on the part of the European Union in renewable energies, forest management, sustainable agriculture and soil protection. Only in this way will we be able to create the "20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020".

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Lambert Report on the Green Jobs Initiative aims to create a green economy based on the efficient use of resources. It is recalled the various benefits that green growth is supposed to bring in terms of jobs, innovation, transformation - benefits that must be accompanied and encouraged through an effective transition. However, this report does not at all question the main reasons for ecological changes such as globalization. It still focuses on certain sectors such as waste treatment, insulation, biomass, organic agriculture, which I think is important to support because they are not relocated. This transition must be accompanied by the necessary training, but should not be at the expense of our industrial base. I voted for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of an important report aiming to increase the employment potential of jobs in the green sector. There are 23 million people unemployed in Europe. We need to invest in quality jobs and focus on growth. The green sector offers huge potential for future job creation and we have to make sure the UK and Europe can maximise this.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this green employment initiative. The aim is to create new green jobs and reduce energy and raw material consumption and greenhouse gas emissions through action along the value chain. According to the Commission, the green goods and services sector grew by more than 50% between 2000 and 2011, generating more than 1.3 million jobs. Similarly, the renewable energy sector is expected to create 20 million new jobs in Europe by 2020.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we stressed the need to establish a coherent and long-term policy framework, in order to stimulate a sustainable economy, capable of providing a predictable environment for investment in renewable energy. Inconsistent policy and incentives have often been cited as the cause of the interruption of progress and as factors limiting employment potential.  Indeed, there is no denying the need for an industrial strategy that directs and encourages investment in the renewable industries that could create more jobs. We therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to adopt ambitious, long-term and integrated regulatory, fiscal and financial frameworks for sustainable investments and to encourage innovation, thus making full use of the employment potential of these changes.  The transition to sustainable societies and economies will offer the opportunity to create new green jobs and make existing ones environmentally friendly in almost all sectors and throughout the value chain, from research to production, from distribution to assistance, in new high-tech environmentally friendly sectors, such as renewable energy, and in traditional sectors such as industry, construction, agriculture and fisheries. , as well as in the service sectors, such as tourism, catering, transport and education.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to stress that in order to create a green economy within the EU in the long term, it is essential to implement reforms. We also have high hopes for the introduction of an environmental financial motivation system, but also for the transformation of the labour market. We need to take bold steps. We need to assess which occupations are outdated or which need to be modified, preferably by using green methods, and which are the new areas where we can create new – green jobs in return for jobs lost during the economic crisis. Europe and Europeans must react flexibly to the word of changing times. We can't get caught up in a stagnant system just because we're afraid of change, even if it can result in casualties in the short term.  I believe that these proposals could help us to build a green economy that can also contribute to our long-term climate change goals.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s Green Employment Initiative was published in July 2014, together with the Green Action Plan for SMEs. I have voted for this report to support jobs that reduce consumption of energy and raw materials, limit greenhouse gas emissions, minimise waste and pollution, and protect and restore ecosystems.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo. Cabhróidh sé linn na féidearthachtaí fostaíochta a aithint sa gheilleagar glas ar fud na hEorpa sa todhchaí. Leagtar béim ar an tábhacht atá ann gan daoine nó pobail a fhágáil taobh thiar agus an trasdul ag tarlú. Cuireann an tuarascáil seo béim ar an tábhacht atá ann a chinntiú go bhfuil an trasdul eacnamaíochta seo cóir. Ciallaíonn seo go gcaithfear traenáil a thabhairt d’oibrithe agus do mhic léinn i dteicneolaíochtaí glasa agus éifeachtúlacht fuinnimh a chur ar fáil. Ba chóir do na poist nua seo a bheith go maith, sábháilte agus le pá maith. Ba chóir go mbeadh ról lárnach ag na hoibrithe agus ag na ceardchumainn sa trasdul seo. Bhíos go láidir i bhfabhar na gné seo den tuarascáil. Chaith mé vóta i gcoinne na foclaíochta i Mír 62 a bhí bainteach le cáin, mar bhí mé buartha go gciallódh sé sárú ar cheannasacht chánach na mBallstát.  Tá díomá orm gur tháinig grúpaí sa Pharlaimint le chéile chun gnéithe tábhachtacha den tuarascáil seo a lagú – an gealltanas a bhí ann, mar shampla, chun poist d’ardchaighdeán agus sábháilte a chruthú. Ina ainneoin seo, tá an tuarascáil seo fós forásach agus is céim dhearfach chun tosaigh í.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it is very much aimed at influencing the national level. Priority is given to strengthening the European Semester through targets and objectives and interfering in the tax system of the Member States.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report which gives an ambitious vision on the job creation potential of the green economy in the European Union. It is estimated that around 4 million green jobs were created between 2002 and 2011, despite the financial crisis in Europe. By adopting innovative solutions to save resources and reduce our carbon emissions, by streamlining production methods, by creating new business models compatible with sustainable development, the green economy is a future economy for our continent.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Sustainable growth requires the efficient use of resources, the saving of nature and social balance. The initiative addresses various ways to achieve all this, including through the creation of green jobs, the training of people and the exchange of information.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the green economy, as it supports sustainable economic activities aimed at creating quality jobs. In particular, I stress the need for nation states and local governments to promote a social and inclusive dialogue, which will enable us to respond to the challenges in the process of transition to a green economy. It is also necessary to invest in the development of specific skills aimed at increasing professional opportunities through training programmes, research and qualified apprenticeships, which will help to alleviate the problem of youth unemployment. Finally, I support Parliament's call for greater coordination between the Commission and national ministries, with a view to introducing a unified and long-term regulatory framework.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think the green employment initiative is of great importance as it concerns a long-term vision where jobs are created that do not harm ecosystems. Nowadays we must take responsibility for the environment with a view to guaranteeing a better future for future generations and, thanks also to the continuous progress of technologies, I think that there are no longer any excuses for not acting in this dignified direction.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report because it emphasises that the transition to sustainable societies and economies, including sustainability patterns of consumption and production, can create potential both in the area of job creation and in turning existing jobs into green, virtually in all sectors and throughout the value chain, and in new green high-tech sectors such as renewable energy sources, and in traditional industries , agriculture and fisheries and in the services sectors. The report also points out that investment in renewable energies and energy efficiency can create many new jobs, contribute to the competitiveness of the European economy and industry and help reduce Europe's energy dependency.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Today's system faces many obstacles and becomes unsustainable, so there is a need for innovation and a system that will create new jobs and encourage consumer society to circular economy. One of the opportunities for job creation is the Green Employment Initiative, which, in addition to new jobs, creates the potential growth of the green economy.
