Green employment requires a quality strategy in the form of support that will contribute to green employment opportunities in rural areas through support to women farms and family farms, as well as in creating new green employment through better management of natural resources, environmentally friendly economic instruments and through support for better policies in agriculture, water management and waste management. Croatia has a great chance in this segment because the Green Jobs Initiative connects green growth and job creation and stimulates the circular economy. Green employment should recognise SMEs that need to be protected from additional financial burdens. Therefore, I am committed to supporting those economic activities that create new jobs, protect the social security of employees and protect the environment.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Lambert Report on the Green Jobs Initiative aims to create a green economy based on the efficient use of resources. It is recalled the various benefits that green growth is supposed to bring in terms of jobs, innovation, transformation - benefits that must be accompanied and encouraged through an effective transition. However, this report does not at all question the main reasons for ecological changes such as globalization. It still focuses on certain sectors such as waste treatment, insulation, biomass, organic agriculture, which I think is important to support because they are not relocated. This transition must be accompanied by the necessary training, but should not be at the expense of our industrial base. I voted for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. In its 2015 report, the European Environment Agency highlighted that the current measures are insufficient to achieve biodiversity conservation objectives, reduce fossil fuel use and combat climate change, and prevent their impacts on human health and the environment. Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal to propose measures to exploit the potential of the green economy for job creation, as there is a risk of inefficient use of resources, unsustainable pressure on the environment and climate change that could cause irreversible effects for society and its natural environment. The renewable-based economy has already performed well as the green goods and services sector grew by more than 50% between 2000 and 2011, creating more than 1.3 million jobs and the Commission's calculations will enable the renewable-based economy to create 20 million new jobs in Europe by 2020. In Croatia too, the link between the increase in the number of jobs with the environmental protection segment has been recognized, which, according to research, would allow the number of jobs to be doubled in the short term from 6,000 to 12,000, and the development of a low-carbon economy would create 80,000 new, green, jobs by 2050.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Lambert's report on the exploitation of the green economy for new jobs. In order to reach the Commission's target of creating 20 million jobs by 2020 using renewable energy sources, Member States need to create a new regulatory, fiscal and financial framework – geared towards innovation and sustainable use of natural resources. The big challenge will be preparing for a low-carbon future, effectively tackling climate change and effectively transitioning jobs to sustainable societies and economies. As a representative from Croatia, I consider it important to develop social awareness of the green economy through two elements – sustainability and the creation of new value. I believe that local units of the highest quality can make the transition to a green economy in the field of infrastructure, support for local businesses and stable employment. In doing so, they need to strengthen their financial capacity and enable faster financing through European funds, for green investments. Tax breaks for start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises offering goods and services with ecological added value would also be useful. Action by the Commission and the Member States should be consistently correlated with the Juncker Plan to create a European Energy Union. Greater coherence between national policies and the removal of barriers to an integrated energy market is needed. The final impact will be a geostrategic substantial reduction of the Union's energy dependency, and on the other hand more affordable and cheaper energy.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. According to the International Labour Organisation, "green jobs are decent jobs that reduce energy and raw material consumption, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, minimise waste and pollution, and protect and restore ecosystems." However, the European Parliament has supported the broader concept of green employment and is considering it in the general context of greening the economy. "Green" employment seeks to respond to the biggest challenges: inefficient use of resources, unsustainable pressure on the environment and climate change, as well as social exclusion and social inequality. I fully agree with the need for a comprehensive policy framework that provides a predictable environment for both training and investment. These include investments in energy efficiency and energy poverty, which are topics that I have been dealing with for a long time in my parliamentary work. For example, estimates of the effect of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive on employment have pointed to the creation of a possible two million jobs, many of which would not by their very nature be transferred abroad. In order to promote so-called green employment, it is necessary to further reform the environmental tax, to make efficient use of energy and resources, as well as to develop an industrial strategy that encourages investment in innovation in EU industrial policy with the ambitious aim of making the EU an economy with the most efficient use of resources in the world.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Last July, the Commission published the Green Action Plan for SMEs and the Circular Economy Communication. Within these texts, the Commission aims to define the strategic framework conditions for supporting employment and job creation in the green economy. In my opinion, this is an area which could play a leading role in reviving the European economy.  The report, on which I have chosen to vote in favour, was created precisely in response to documents published by the Commission. It focuses on a number of key issues, including energy efficiency, the development of the supply chain and the role of small and medium-sized enterprises. With this vote in favour, I think it would be useful to point out that the transition to the world of green work presents unprecedented challenges and opportunities for the current labour market and for regions, such as Sicily and Sardinia, which are able to focus on renewable energies.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted this Green Employment Initiative. I voted in favour of this text and I stress the importance of having a coherent and comprehensive framework for action so that our reforms are applicable and implemented.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Lambert's report, because the initiative aims to exploit the employment potential of green growth which stresses that by 2020 20 million jobs could be created in the green economy. According to the ILO, green jobs are decent jobs that reduce energy and raw material consumption, limit greenhouse gas emissions, minimise waste and pollution and protect and recover ecosystems, where workforce involvement is essential to achieve the transition to a green economy. To this end, Member States should more effectively explore the wide range of European funds and financial instruments available in order to support the creation of green and sustainable jobs and not to forget in particular small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In July 2014, the Commission published its "Green Jobs Initiative: Harnessing the Job Creation Potential of the Green Economy", showing its undeniable interest in the European Union's transition to an economy characterized by low carbon emissions. The European Parliament responds this afternoon with the adoption of Jean Lambert's report which highlights the potential to be drawn from the green economy in terms of job creation. In an internal discussion paper in 2012, the Commission had certainly gone a little excited by trumpeting that "up to 20 million jobs could be created by 2020 in the green economy", the continuing economic and social crisis in Europe no longer allows us to aim for such ambitious targets, but the trend is indeed there. Investing in the circular economy and renewable energy seems obvious, if not a necessity for Europe if it is to quickly return to the path of sustainable growth and quality jobs.  The report also gives an appointment to European leaders at the end of 2016 to take advantage of the mid-term revision of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF) to promote the greener transition of our post-industrial economies.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission's Green Employment Initiative was published in July 2014, together with the SME Ecological Action Plan and the Circular Economy Communication. This Initiative underlined the challenges and employment opportunities posed by the current transition to the use of environmentally friendly and low-carbon energy sources and to a resource-efficient economy.  This initiative report, on which I voted in favour, contains a first position by Parliament which supports the Commission's approach to the transition to sustainable societies and economies. This transition, with equally sustainable consumption and production patterns, can create opportunities for quality job creation and transform existing employment into green employment in virtually every sector and throughout the value chain. To make the most of these opportunities, it is necessary, inter alia, to establish an integrated framework for labour policies and the promotion of skills and skills among workers in such a way that they play an active role. Finally, I welcome the need for the report to introduce environmental and social criteria in public procurement policies.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Through its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union aims to develop a smart, sustainable and inclusive economy. To do this, the EU has set five ambitious targets to be achieved by 2020. These targets include 75% of the population aged 20 to 64 who are employed in 2020. In order to achieve this goal, Europe is banking on promoting sustainable and inclusive growth. Between 2002 and 2011, it is estimated that some 3 to 4.2 million green jobs were created. In order to continue on this path and achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, the report discussed here proposes concrete ways to make the most of the potential for green job creation. Given the importance of promoting sustainable and inclusive growth to create jobs, but also not to undermine the living conditions of future generations, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. This proposal is the result of a legislative initiative to carry out the Green Employment Initiative in order to exploit the job creation potential of the green economy. In fact, inefficient use of resources, unsustainable pressure on the environment and climate change, as well as exclusion and social inequalities pose challenges to long-term economic growth. As such, it is necessary to adopt a green growth model - with low carbon emissions, resistant to climate change and a resource-efficient economy. It is also necessary to present solutions and tools aimed, on the one hand, at supporting and creating jobs in the green economy and, on the other hand, contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. I agree with the rapporteur on the strategy to be adopted, which should focus in particular on closing skills gaps, anticipating change, promoting mobility and improving the quality of statistical data. Finally, social dialogue and international cooperation with the various stakeholders, such as the Global Green Growth Institute, the OECD, UNEP and the World Bank, should be promoted. I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Lambert, which focuses on a number of key issues including environmental tax reform, energy and resource efficiency and the development of the supply chain, also emphasising the role of SMEs. The Commission's initiative to promote green employment was presented together with the Green Action Plan for SMEs, voted on during the May part-session.  I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal, as it aims to provide the means to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 plan, creating new opportunities for the labour market, with new jobs created and others replaced or redefined.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because, while I agree with the effort to create new jobs, I find that the ambiguity of the text leads me to fear that jobs linked to the green economy are intended as substitutes for traditional rather than complementary ones.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour, convinced that the green economy is a sector with strong potential to create jobs and that it must be exploited and driven at European level. Our decision is based on three ideas contained in the report: (1) guarantees for a fair transition and that this principle serves as the basis for negotiation at the Paris Climate Conference COP 21; (2) the ultimate objective of promoting the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, integrating displaced and low-skilled workers into the strategy; (3) the transition cannot have a negative impact on social security systems or low-income people. I list some positive proposals envisaged in the Initiative: creating new job opportunities in the green economy; promotion of the acquisition of professional skills, typical of green employment, oriented, free and accessible to uns qualified personnel; public investment to generate sustainable employment; prominence of social workers (green trade union representatives) and participation of workers; environmental and social clauses in government procurement; reducing insecurity arising from the displacement of workers; and support for SMEs in this green transition.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because 'green employment', while not the only solution needed for economic recovery in Europe, has a fundamental job creation potential for the transition of our economies to more sustainable models. This economic sector, despite the risks posed by its indefinition, is an umbrella for many activities necessary for an environmentally sustainable economic recovery. In addition, the report is committed to the development of quality jobs in the sector, so that it becomes a strategic axis of the continent's economic development.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. I am interested in this category of employment called "green" that benefits from new attitudes towards scarcity and sensitivity of resources. We are providing well-paid employment solutions that contribute to improving the quality of life of current and future generations. As mentioned in the report we are discussing, I also regret the European Commission's hesitations with regard to the circular economy. There are tens of thousands of green jobs waiting for high-level regulation.  For the seas and oceans, with investment in blue growth, new opportunities for "green jobs" are opening up. After hundreds of years, where the basis of employment at sea was limited to fisheries and transport, there is now room for alternative energies, biotechnology and marine tourism. The European Maritime and Fisheries Fund must be particularly dedicated to these alternative and potentially very lucrative routes.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today Labour MEPs voted in favour of an important report aiming to increase the employment potential of jobs in the green sector. There are 23 million people unemployed in Europe. We need to invest in quality jobs and focus on growth. The green sector offers huge potential for future job creation and we have to make sure the UK and Europe can maximise this.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in this case in accordance with the EKR Group. Within the EKR Group, we have put forward a number of amendments that have highlighted the need to ensure that our existing workforce should be able to acquire the right skills. Such as measures that improve the quality of information, advice and guidance on career opportunities in the green economy, together with information on skills related to the green economy. We stressed the need to ensure that all costs to businesses (linked to the transition to green employment) are eligible in view of the expected impacts. There should also be an effort to avoid unnecessary burdens, especially on small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises, so as to give all businesses room to innovate, grow and create new jobs. I support the general idea of this report, but I cannot support a number of specific paragraphs that I believe go beyond and go beyond the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy defines the transition of the economy towards a green low-carbon economy that, in my opinion, can contribute to long-term, sustainable and inclusive growth. Green growth can become a very good challenge and an opportunity for the labour market, which can create up to 20 million new quality jobs in Europe by 2020. I am aware that the creation of new jobs will require new skills profiles and qualifications, but in my opinion this transformation process could lead to significant changes in both the labour market and within individual sectors. Although many existing jobs and industrial areas will face the difficult challenges of adapting to the new requirements, I consider this to be a good opportunity for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, which are one of the most important job creators. I also consider the role of the social partners, which has improved significantly in recent years, to be very positive. However, it is important that we continue with this strategy and do even more work to build a lasting and sustainable social dialogue that can meet the challenges of transitioning to a competitive, low-carbon and resource-efficient economy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support reducing dependence on fossil fuels and energy coming from outside the EU, while at the same time creating alternative sources within the EU and using them effectively (for job creation). I agree that green jobs have proven to be more resilient to the crisis than other jobs, and I therefore support such an approach to employment.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the Green Jobs Initiative Report because the European Environment Agency has found that current measures to preserve biodiversity, reduce fossil fuel use and combat climate change and prevent their impacts on human health and the environment are insufficient. Attention should be paid to the workforce in the context of re-employment or training in areas prioritised by the Commission programme.  According to the European Environment Agency, the green goods and services sector grew by 50% leading to job creation, while calculations put the economy at a renewable energy market with another 20 million jobs by 2020. It is also necessary to make the transition to an environmentally sustainable economy taking into account sustainable and long-term employment for all, taking into account social inclusion and poverty eradication.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because it fundamentally ignores economic reality. The creation of green jobs will necessarily come at the expense of creating other jobs, just as with all other efforts by politicians to create jobs.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Green Employment Initiative: harnessing the potential of the green economy to create new jobs. The European Union needs new jobs. Green jobs are not a cost, but they are a future and an opportunity. They are the answer to global challenges, sustainable development and climate change. The green economy has a very high potential, which we are under-aware of and under-utily.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. Green growth can indeed boost the economy, but the report's approach follows the logic of previous already failed strategies.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's Green Employment Initiative report on the Green Action Plan for SMEs (also included in this report) and based on the circular economy concept published last year aims to create up to 20 million jobs in the green economy by 2020, including health and un. green profession.  Significant progress is also needed in the field of energy efficiency, just as our country is making efforts to increase the energy efficiency of residential buildings, and further efforts need to be made to raise awareness, such as in the field of environmental education and training. In this context, education in general should also be strengthened, in particular in order to develop science, technology and maths skills.  I also support the approach of aily a part of disadvantaged workers in creating such jobs. At critical points, I supported the People's Party position, in particular in order to reduce the burden on SMEs and thus family businesses, and to ensure an adequate and equitable preparation time for the transition to a green economy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it makes useful proposals to improve employment while taking into account global environmental challenges. I agree that inefficient use of resources, unsustainable pressure on the environment and climate change are on a scale beyond which irreversible effects on our society and the natural environment cannot be prevented, and increasing social exclusion and inequality are challenging societies.  I believe that much of the potential for a green and inclusive transition to create sustainable jobs remains untapped and even varies considerably from one Member State to another. I agree that investments in renewable energies and energy efficiency, in addition to creating a large number of jobs, contribute to maintaining the competitiveness of the European economy and industry and reducing Europe's energy dependency. The proposal calls on the Member States to commit to a roadmap for a just transition and to set ambitious environmental targets. All this by ensuring adequate social protection and wages; healthy and safe working conditions; directed investments in education, training and skills development programmes; respect for labour rights and strengthening workers' right to information, consultation and participation. I believe that the Hungarian Government currently does not meet almost any of the points, so I recommend the recommendations of this report as a suitable recipe.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Any crisis is also an opportunity for society to rethink the ways in which it organises production activity. The green economy is one of the sustainable alternatives for the recovery of economic growth in the European Union. This can also lead to the creation of new jobs for European citizens. With the structural changes in the labour market, it is necessary to support the retraining of citizens in order to acquire the necessary skills in the new type of economy.  At the same time, this type of economy can be supported by measures to strengthen environmental criteria in the area of public procurement and lower taxes for green enterprises. The promotion of the Green Jobs Initiative and the Green SME Action Plan by the European Commission over the past year has been an important element for the development of this sector, limiting the consumption of fossil fuels and making resource consumption more efficient. However, these documents are just the beginning of a coherent investment policy for creating sustainable jobs in the green economy and supporting SMEs in the sector.  The current report is a decisive new step in this direction, and its adoption will create the prerequisites for a positive development towards sustainable economic growth within the Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported Mrs Lambert's text. While it is clear that the world of work is already affected by major international trends, so far the European Union's response has not been comprehensive. In order to ensure that we can maintain and develop employment opportunities and job creation, we need a comprehensive and joint response, from the political level to basic training. Time is running out, because today we are missing opportunities that other parts of the world are taking, and we are not fully preparing our workforce to face the challenges we are already facing.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This initiative aims at supporting the much-needed shift to green growth and ensure Europe maximises the job creation opportunities it brings. In the respect of EU competence in the employment sector, the EU should focus on boosting job creation through an appropriate use of existing EU funding. In order to bridge the skills gaps in Europe by providing for instance necessary trainings, the EU should be able to foresee the changes in the job market. SMEs will need special attention in this respect: the combination of the Green Action Plan for SMEs and an intelligent use of the new EFSI programme should provide them with effective incentives and the appropriate framework to move to greener products and processes. During the votes I opposed references to ‘creating quality long-term jobs’ because the report already included provisions on ‘sustainable employment’.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is heading in the right direction, which is why I wholely supported it. Our objective of supporting the transition to a low-carbon and sustainable society must be combined with equally sustainable production and consumption models, which are potentially capable of creating new quality jobs and transforming existing employment into green jobs in almost all sectors and throughout the value chain in order to help maintain Europe's economic and industrial competitiveness. The development of new employment models would make it possible to anticipate future needs on the basis of skills, which is why I believe it is necessary for curricula and training courses to include awareness-raising programmes on respect for the environment. We now have the opportunity, within the framework of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, to promote investments that will act as a catalyst for a green transition. From the point of view of social policy, this Fund can alleviate energy poverty by promoting energy-efficient housing and promoting job creation, particularly for young people.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I strongly oppose too invasive and disproportionate measures in this report, such as e.g. creating a financial transaction tax, decent jobs through the impact on the power of public procurement through social and environmental clauses, a legal obligation on the employer to include representatives of employees in green employment programmes, etc.  For those above, I firmly believe that they unnecessarily encroach on the competences of individual Member States of the Union and aggressively undermine the principle of subsidiarity, by which problems should be addressed at the lowest level, i.e. where they arise where possible.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission also published a Green Action Plan for SMEs and a Communication on the Circular Economy last year, together with the Green Employment Initiative. The aim of the report is to define strategic framework conditions that will enable the labour market and skills policies to support employment and create new jobs in the green economy. The report proposes tools to ensure that employment and environmental agendas contribute to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives, while focusing on a number of issues such as tax reforms, environmental and energy and resource efficiency, drawing attention to the role of SMEs and so on. As the transition to a green economy will also mean creating new jobs and transforming existing ones, I supported the initiative.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour, convinced that the green economy is a sector with strong potential to create jobs and that it must be exploited and driven at European level. Our decision is based on three ideas contained in the report: (1) guarantees for a fair transition and that this principle serves as the basis for negotiation at the Paris Climate Conference COP 21; (2) the ultimate objective of promoting the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, integrating displaced and low-skilled workers into the strategy; (3) the transition cannot have a negative impact on social security systems or low-income people. I list some positive proposals envisaged in the Initiative: creating new job opportunities in the green economy; promotion of the acquisition of professional skills, typical of green employment, oriented, free and accessible to uns qualified personnel; public investment to generate sustainable employment; prominence of social workers (green trade union representatives) and participation of workers; environmental and social clauses in government procurement; reducing insecurity arising from the displacement of workers; and support for SMEs in this green transition.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am worried about the report of the European Environment Agency 2015 which highlights the inadequacy of current measures to achieve the objectives of protecting biodiversity, reducing the use of fossil fuels, addressing climate change and preventing their impact on human health and the environment. Having detected the problem, we can give conclusive solutions to reverse this situation. With the involvement of all the institutions and promoting the concept of ‘education for sustainable development’ we will have in the future social and environmentally friendly growth, including non-economic aspects of welfare and gender equality, reducing poverty and reducing emissions of greenhouse gases.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The measures taken by the Commission to support green growth should directly and indirectly promote the creation of jobs that are not subject to fluctuations in economic conditions and therefore stable. However, all these anticipated successes in the text will depend primarily on the availability of a skilled workforce.  In principle, the National Front delegation is not against it. However, these changes are drastic and could have serious consequences for employment if skills do not keep up (there is a lot of talk about the jobs created but nothing is said about the jobs saved). It will therefore be necessary to ensure that the transition is pragmatic and supervised and that green workers are effectively supported in the transition.  I am voting for this because, from the point of view of employment and social affairs, this green jobs initiative should enable the creation of stable, sustainable and non-relocable jobs.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As global warming and biodiversity loss reach limits beyond which irreversible effects on our societies and the natural environment cannot be avoided, the exploitation of the green economy in terms of jobs appears as a source of hope to improve the well-being of the human being and social equity. Moreover, the development of new technologies, new, less polluting sectors, renewable energies and new modes of production can represent a potential for growth in Europe and the world. In this case, I believe that the transition to a green economy can have the effect of creating new jobs, as sustainable economic activities involve more labour than they are replacing. Moreover, waste prevention, eco-design and reuse could generate net savings of EUR 600 billion or 8% of annual turnover for EU businesses, while reducing the annual level of greenhouse gas emissions by 2-4%. In view of these circumstances, I voted in favour of the report on the Green Jobs initiative.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour, convinced that the green economy is a sector with strong potential to create jobs and that it must be exploited and driven at European level. Our decision is based on three ideas contained in the report: (1) guarantees for a fair transition and that this principle serves as the basis for negotiation at the Paris Climate Conference COP 21; (2) the ultimate objective of promoting the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, integrating displaced and low-skilled workers into the strategy; (3) the transition cannot have a negative impact on social security systems or low-income people. I list some positive proposals envisaged in the Initiative: creating new job opportunities in the green economy; promotion of the acquisition of professional skills, typical of green employment, oriented, free and accessible to uns qualified personnel; public investment to generate sustainable employment; prominence of social workers (green trade union representatives) and participation of workers; environmental and social clauses in government procurement; reducing insecurity arising from the displacement of workers; and support for SMEs in this green transition.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which gives recommendations in a positive way in six areas: employment opportunities, just transition, skills for green employment, policy coherence, investment and SMEs.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it supports the Commission proposal to foster employment creation linked to the production of energy from renewable sources, energy efficiency, waste and water management, air quality, restoring and preserving biodiversity, and developing green infrastructure. The key aspect is that through the increase in the efficiency of production processes, through adopting innovative solutions to save resources and offering more sustainable products and services, companies can at the same time expand their markets and create new jobs. Structural changes in the wider economy will create demand for new skills and occupations. The report endorses the view that adequate EU funding must be guaranteed to support this green transition and that the European Structural and Investment Funds will be the key sources of investment to promote sustainable growth and job creation.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. After the publication in July 2014 of the Green Employment Initiative together with the Green Action Plan for SMEs and the Circular Economy Communication, the European Parliament expresses its vision of the issue through this report, which highlights the challenges and difficulties that the transition to green employment can pose to the labour market. We are therefore talking about an opinion report which seeks to assess opportunities and challenges in this area. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because 'green employment', while not the only solution needed for economic recovery in Europe, has a fundamental job creation potential for the transition of our economies to more sustainable models. This economic sector, despite the risks posed by its indefinition, is an umbrella for many activities necessary for an environmentally sustainable economic recovery. In addition, the report is committed to the development of quality jobs in the sector, so that it becomes a strategic axis of the continent's economic development.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my fellow Labour MEPs and Socialist colleagues in favour of this important report aiming to increase the employment potential of jobs in the green sector. There are 23 million people unemployed in Europe. We need to invest in quality jobs and focus on growth. The green sector offers huge potential for future job creation and we have to make sure the UK and Europe can maximise this opportunity.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Waste of resources, climate change, various pollutions, as well as inequality and social exclusion are obstacles to growth. To make up for this, this European Parliament report makes proposals to promote job creation in the so-called green economy, thanks in particular to the efficient use of resources (re-employment and recycling). In other words, try to counter the consumerist and at all disposable model. Concrete proposals are put forward, such as support for ecological conversion, especially for SMEs, the implementation of targeted programmes to train workers, their participation in the evolution of jobs in order to promote their quality and sustainability. The resolution also highlights the potential of sectors, such as energy efficiency through building insulation, or the need to develop a European industrial strategy, among others in the renewable energy sector. This goes beyond the Commission's proposal for the Green Jobs Initiative. I therefore voted in favour, without illusions as to the will to implement such measures to go beyond the fine speeches of the Commission and the Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report states that the green economy is set against the backdrop of a number of challenges highlighted by the Commission: "The ineffective use of resources, unsustainable pressure on the environment, climate change, social exclusion and inequalities...".  It recognises the need to integrate the concept of green economy, reflected in a need for a coherent and comprehensive policy framework that offers a predictable atmosphere for training and investment.  Sharing many ideas, we think, however, that sustaining the entire economy in renewable energy is a somewhat naïve and to some extent counterproductive approach, as it can divert some of the attention from the real problem, which stems from a mismatch between the EU's current production capacity and the solveable purchasing capacity of consumers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Green Employment Initiative aims to interfere with the Tax System of the Member States. In addition, many new targets and targets for the nation states will be drawn up, which will lead to a further burden on the states. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the 'Green Employment Initiative: Exploiting the potential of the green economy to create jobs'. It is based on the erroneous assumption of man-made climate change, the consequences of which must be combated through policy-making.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not in any way want to challenge efforts to better protect the environment and climate, but I fundamentally reject artificial efforts to green the economy, especially in the form of state interventions and subsidies that will not lead to greater economic growth, but will mean an increase in bureaucracy, controls, increased costs and will ultimately translate into a deterioration in the EU's competitiveness on world markets. Artificial greening efforts will also lead to a subsidy-based bubble. In the case of the Czech Republic, this applies, for example, to solar power plants or biofuels, where there is even a conflict of interest, where the dominant producer of biofuels is a company owned by the current member of the government, which decides on the subsidy system.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Lambert report on the Green Jobs Initiative: Exploiting the job creation potential of the green economy because I believe that a smart bet on the green economy will create wealth and create quality jobs in a sustainable way.  Sustainable consumption and production, in the context of a green economy, will trigger multiplier effects on the economy, which will enable new productive opportunities and unlock new frontiers for research and innovation.  Combined with the possibilities offered by information and communication technologies, the new industrialization will have to have a pressing focus on environmental sustainability.  The Lambert report clearly articulates the challenges, opportunities and objectives that job creation faces in the context of the green economy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report presents concepts, proposals and perspectives that we consider to be positive - towards economic revitalization, training, promoting gender equality and sustainable development practices. However, the promotion of this development is based on measures, policies or resolutions which are essentially opposed to the principles of "green" development, namely: tax policies that remove taxes from work - which can remove proportionality to taxes, in particular by distrusting in irs to stop the application of universal taxes (VAT) on consumption - the application of the polluter-pays principle , with which we are at odds or trade in CO2 emission allowances. On the other hand, it presents the idea that so-called green employment is the panacea for solving the problem of employment, which seems to us excessive. We abstained.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, but I would have been even more supportive if you had changed your name, your title, a little bit. In my native Language, the title was 'Report on tax avoidance and tax evasion as a challenge for the governance, social protection and development of developing countries'. I would very much like us to vote next time on a report where we would look at the same for EU countries. All the more so because the Commission, one of the main institutions of the European Union, is led by none other than Mr Juncker, who is the chief tax evader master in the world, so I hardly believe that the European Union has a legal basis to educate developing countries, so-called developing countries, on this issue. Not to mention the fact that, of course, the rescue of revenues to off-shore locations is a very common practice in Europe, which should be addressed here.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Commission must prioritise an ambitious action plan to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion, to establish fair, balanced and transparent tax systems. Information about beneficial owners of companies and other institutions must also be made public in a format accessible to all.  We also need an international definition of tax havens. We need sanctions for operators using these tax havens and creating a blacklist of those countries. The Commission's revised 2015 plan on tax evasion is good, but Member States need to agree on a consolidated, corporate-common tax base.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, tax evasion and avoidance is probably something that is in every country and not only developing countries; it happens within the European Union as well. Certainly, where developing countries are concerned, it is one thing to give development aid, but we must also help them to get proper tax systems within their countries. It is estimated that the developing countries lost about EUR 5.5 billion between 2003 and 2012 because of tax evasion and avoidance, and obviously this is not a good situation for anybody. It is not fair and they cannot develop as a result of it. If they could cut out evasion and avoidance and plug the loopholes, then I think a lot of progress could be made. The point made by my colleague, Ms Macovei, regarding tax havens is very relevant too.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP as a party does not condone tax evasion of any sort, but we also do not believe that this is the European Union’s responsibility to address. We believe that tax evasion in developing states should be an issue of compliance between Member States and international tax bodies.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by considering positive the call for a concrete action plan to combat tax avoidance and evasion in impoverished countries, which would help to better redistribute and control resources by their governments.  Tax havens, banking secrecy and the designation of "tax-free zones" to supposedly attract foreign capital and investment are nefarious for achieving sustainable, inclusive and social justice-based development and respect for the sovereignty of peoples, which requires fair progressive tax systems to address inequality. While there are improveable aspects and the approach is not as ambitious as it should be, it is positive that it calls for the implementation of assessments of the impact of European fiscal policies on impoverished countries, noting the need to monitor, annually and country by country, the activities of multinationals and their possible direct or indirect contribution to tax avoidance and capital evasion.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Report was concerned with tax avoidance and tax evasion and the effect that this has on developing countries. Moreover, this report feeds into the UN agenda on Financing for Development which will hold a high-level summit in Ethiopia next week. It builds on important measures and instruments such as public listing of ultimate beneficial owners of companies and transparency in tax reporting. These are necessary measures in combating the illicit capital flows from developing countries to anonymous multinationals who purposely manipulate legislation in order to take advantage of tax loopholes. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Many developing countries do not have the resources to provide sufficient public goods (education, infrastructure, etc.). The lack of public funding is due to a significant part of the massive tax avoidance and evasion in the countries concerned. I support the proposed action plan to combat tax avoidance and evasion in developing countries, so that European development aid can also be stepped up in this area.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Many of the amendments tabled were in the direction of more harmonization and financial transparency in order to really combat tax evasion and evasion. The report provides for the adoption of an official definition of the concept of "tax haven". It also plans to make public information on companies exploiting natural resources in developing countries. Another positive point of this report is the desire to create effective tax administrations for greater financial autonomy for developing countries in the coming decades. Despite these good initiatives, many other parties are either too vague or not restrictive enough, which explains my abstention.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly oppose tax avoidance and evasion.  However, these issues – in countries outside the EU – are not the responsibility of the EU itself.  This should not be a European Union matter, and therefore I had to vote against – however laudable the principles might be.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the need to strengthen financial and technical assistance to developing countries and regional administrative and tax frameworks to adopt solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax evasion, such as an automatic mechanism for the exchange of information and the publication of country-by-country information. , taking into account the needs and constraints of developing countries.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome and strongly support this report on tax avoidance and tax evasion as challenges in developing countries. It is not only very timely due to the fact that this year is the European Year for Development, but also since the European Union is the world’s largest donor in the development policy it is of our greatest interest to make sure that development policy works well and our investment bears fruits. The figures of an annual illicit capital flight from developing countries of an estimated USD 1 trillion and a loss of an estimated USD 189 billion in tax revenue annually (as noted in the report), are very worrying and explains why many developing countries cannot attain even the minimum tax level necessary to finance their basic functioning, public services, poverty eradication and sustainable development. There is no doubt that Europe must not only remain the leader in providing development assistance to the developing countries but at the same time make sure that the aid is absorbed to its fullest potential by addressing tax evasion, tax fraud and combating tax havens.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Domestic resources are and will continue to be the largest source of financing for developing countries. Despite the fact that their share of GDP has been increasing over the last decade, the average tax-to-GDP ratio in developing countries is still too low: developing countries generate relatively much less income than developed economies. The tax-to-GDP ratio in low-income countries ranges from 10% to 20%, and in many such countries it is below 15 %,which is generally considered to be a threshold that makes it difficult for governments to finance their basic functions and services. It is between 30% and 40% in OECD countries. Experts agree that there is ample scope to increase tax revenues: Oxfam estimates carried out in 52 developing countries have shown that a significant improvement in tax collection could bring together an additional EUR 269 billion. usd to fund public services. It is therefore essential to ensure that national tax collection becomes more predictable, stable and reliable and that all groups in society – individuals and companies – pay according to their own.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to promote the development of efficient tax administrations with a view to greater financial autonomy for developing countries in the coming decades. This objective is all the more legitimate as we are in the context of a decline in EU endowments.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report provides an overview of taxation in developing countries. Tax evasion is a scourge that affects all countries of the world. These means of evading tax by moving all or part of the heritage or activity to another state, illegally, fraudulently or unconsled, represent a significant lack of revenue for the state budget, revenues that could be allocated to vital needs for all populations: social security, health care or education. Tax revenues must help build public investment capacity in developing countries. The importance of these countries effectively raising fair and equitable taxes to finance infrastructure, public services, health care and education should be emphasized. It is also an essential tool in the fight against poverty. That is why we need to support the transfer of knowledge and skills to help the development of their tax administrations. The OECD provides an effective example of good practice through its Tax Inspectors without Borders initiative.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. While a development conference is being held in Addis Ababa, the fight against tax evasion seems to be a major issue for the countries of the South. Indeed, at a time when rich countries' contributions to development aid are declining due to fiscal austerity, tax evasion has become a major issue for the tax revenues of developing countries. This would cost them about 100 billion euros per year, which greatly reduces their already low tax revenues (between 10 and 20%). Because developed countries did not have the financial means to contribute to the development of developing developing countries, it was necessary to find alternative sources of financing to help them build infrastructure, create jobs, stabilize politically, etc. As such, I regret that this report does not go far enough to demand necessary transparency measures such as country-by-country information or the establishment of a list of tax havens. It even excludes the advertising of essential information from natural resource companies in developing countries.  Even if what is proposed to us to fight tax havens is encouraging, the text does not go far enough. I have therefore decided to abstain since it does not go far enough in the fight against money laundering, corruption and shell companies.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Schlein report, which analyses the future challenges to be faced with third countries, aimed at improving transparency and tax cooperation in order to combat harmful tax competition affecting all Member States, is acceptable and balanced, and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on tax evasion and avoidance. Illicit financial flows, i.e. all unregistered, private, financial flows related to capital unlawfully received, transferred or used, are generally linked to tax avoidance and tax fraud activities, such as abuse of transfer pricing, in breach of the principle that taxes should be paid when profits are made. Illegal flows are just one way developing countries are losing their corporate tax revenues. Illegal tax avoidance, where companies try to avoid taxes through complex internal structures and tax loopholes, is another important problem. Corporate taxes around the world are falling. This particularly affects developing countries because they are heavily dependent on corporate tax: corporate tax revenues account for a large proportion of their national income.  In order to combat tax evasion and avoidance, the European Parliament proposes to increase the financial and technical assistance provided to developing countries and regional tax administration systems. Considers, furthermore, that reasonable solutions need to be adopted in order to increase transparency and strengthen cooperation in the fight against tax avoidance, such as the automatic information exchange mechanism and country-by-country reporting, taking into account the needs and constraints of developing countries. carry out an assessment of the impact of tax policies on developing countries at EU and Member State level.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. At my July meeting, I supported an extremely complex and detailed resolution on tax evasion in developing countries. Effective tax collection is one of the cornerstones of the normal functioning of the state and its system. Even in the EU, as developed communities of countries, we still have quite a few problems with this. It is therefore necessary, with experience, to help developing countries deburise their tax legislation as much as possible, while simplifying their tax policies, thus also making it easier to control tax collection and stabilising tax inflows.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because it makes significant recommendations regarding payment avoidance and tax evasion issues in developing countries. I assess in particular the recommendations for financial and technical support to developing countries in addressing this problem, the exchange of information between countries and the creation of an intergovernmental body in which developing countries would participate equally in the global reform of existing international tax rules.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Report was concerned with tax avoidance and tax evasion and the effect that this has on developing countries. Moreover, this report feeds into the UN agenda on Financing for Development which will hold a high-level summit in Ethiopia next week. It builds on important measures and instruments such as public listing of ultimate beneficial owners of companies and transparency in tax reporting. These are necessary measures in combating the illicit capital flows from developing countries to anonymous multinationals who purposely manipulate legislation in order to take advantage of tax loopholes. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is the EU's task to support developing countries in creating efficient and sustainable tax systems that will enable them to effectively combat the phenomena of tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to promote greater efficiency of tax administrations in developing countries in order to strengthen their financial autonomy. The measures outlined in this project will enable them to better collect taxes and thus better cope with the decline in EU endowments. The aim of these proposals is also to combat tax dumping between Member States. In its entirety, this report is very uncritical. In detail, we reiterate that we are in favour of making information on the actual ownership of companies public in open formats. This helps to combat money laundering and the opacity that prevails around shell companies. On the other hand, we want the concept of a tax haven to be defined at the international level and we believe that sanctions are needed for those who use this kind of practice. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Domestic resources are and will remain the most important source of funding for developing countries as well as for developed countries. Although the level of these resources, as a percentage of GDP, has increased, the average share of taxes and taxes in GDP in developing countries is still too low, leading to basic services of far too low quality for the citizens of those countries, as well as to a growing financial dependence on international aid from the EU and other international donors. Thus, the share of taxes and taxes in GDP in low-income countries is between 10% and 20%, and in many of these countries it is below 15% (this amount is generally considered as the minimum threshold on which governments can finance their basic functions and services). I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary for the process of collecting internal taxes to become more predictable, more transparent, more stable and better managed.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Given the importance of better mobilisation of national resources and the problems faced by developing countries in combating tax evasion and avoidance, a number of recommendations are suggested in the report. These include strengthening financial and technical assistance to developing countries and the regional tax administration frameworks; the adoption of decisive solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax fraud as a tool for the automatic exchange of information and the publication of information country by country, taking into account the needs and limitations of developing countries; conducting an impact assessment of tax policies on developing countries at EU and Member State level; the maintenance of the taxation rights of countries of origin when negotiating tax treaties and the creation of an intergovernmental body in which developing countries can participate on an equal footing in the comprehensive reform of current international tax rules.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade, the informal nature of the economy, together with political, administrative and economic constraints, is an obstacle to income mobilisation, especially in developing countries. Internal resources are and will remain the most important source of funding for developing countries. The loss of tax revenue can be exacerbated by tax agreements, a key component of international tax law. The OECD-approved tax base erosion and profit shift action plan (BEPS) aims to redefine international tax rules in order to combat profit-shifting practices and ensure that companies pay taxes where economic activity is carried out and economic value is created. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that an action plan to combat tax evasion and tax fraud in developing countries is necessary.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The third international conference on development finance will be held in Ethiopia in July 2015. With this in mind, the European Parliament has prepared a report on the challenges of tax evasion and tax evasion in developing countries. The European Union is working to eradicate these two phenomena within its borders. Tax transparency is an absolute necessity. In our globalised economy, it is important that EU partners have the same tax transparency provisions to ensure fair trade competition. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on tax avoidance and tax evasion as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries, which calls on the Commission to present a communication to support developing countries in the fight against illicit financial flows and tax evasion. Tax evasion and avoidance are among the main obstacles to mobilising national revenue for development. The report therefore calls on the Commission to strengthen financial and technical assistance to developing countries, to adopt decisive solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax fraud and to publish information country by country, taking into account the needs and limitations of developing countries.  The report also stressed the importance of the OECD Action Plan on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS), which aims to redefine international tax rules, particularly for developing countries, which are heavily dependent on corporate tax revenues, but stressed that BEPS is too limited in scope and focuses too heavily on the interests of rich countries.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Report was concerned with tax avoidance and tax evasion and the effect that this has on developing countries. Moreover, this report feeds into the UN agenda on Financing for Development which will hold a high-level summit in Ethiopia next week. It builds on important measures and instruments such as public listing of ultimate beneficial owners of companies and transparency in tax reporting. These are necessary measures in combating the illicit capital flows from developing countries to anonymous multinationals who purposely manipulate legislation in order to take advantage of tax loopholes. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly oppose tax avoidance and evasion. However, these issues – in countries outside the EU – are not the responsibility of the EU itself. This should not be a European Union matter, and therefore I had to vote against – however laudable the principles might be.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the need to strengthen developing countries’ capacity to deal with challenges, including in the field of taxation as many of these aspects are indeed global phenomena, and consequently require global coordinated action. For this reason I fully agree with the idea that developing countries are equally engaged and participate in this process, but I disagree with the need of including the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) in this report. I fail to recognise the relation with developing countries. In this regard I voted against this Report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the report is ambitious and serves as a complement to the report on financing development. It is required to carry out impact assessments of tax policies on developing countries, in order to strengthen the Coherence for Development Policy, as well as to pay particular attention to gender issues, as the misappropriation of resources to these countries is primarily reflected in women.  It also stresses the importance of having complete and public information on the owners benefiting from the profits of companies, in order to prevent the theft of public funds, corruption, tax evasion or the financing of illicit trafficking or terrorism from hiding behind networked complexes. The Commission is also asked to continue and strengthen support for developing countries by providing financial and technical assistance and for good governance in tax matters to be part of the political dialogue with them.  I voted strongly in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. Promoting the development of efficient tax administrations for greater financial autonomy for developing countries is obviously a necessity, all the more so in a context where the European Union, due to economic and fiscal conditions, is increasingly reducing its allocations to these countries. This report therefore promotes a legitimate objective, in addition to the fight against unfair competition in taxation between states. Some of the measures brought about in this report are quite beneficial, such as the adoption of an internationally recognised definition of tax haven by the end of 2015, a need for simplification that should also go hand in hand with the establishment of sanctions for transactions using this evasion. However, I am more measured against other suggestions in the report, such as the incentive for Member States to agree on a consolidated common corporate tax base: on the surface, this may seem like a legitimate simplification, but this is in line with a harmonisation which carries within it the logic of increasing the Union's powers, and thus a loss of sovereignty for the Member States.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every year the revenues of developing countries are impoverished, for over a billion dollars (equal to about 10 times the total economic aid received!), from illicit financial flows and from phenomena of tax evasion and avoidance, money laundering, corruption (even in agreements, often "tailor-made" and opaque, on natural resources, not only in the mining sector) , the use of anonymous fictitious companies. And, again, unfair tax conventions, tax incentives and exemptions, and a general "race to the bottom" in corporate tax rates, which has benefited foreign investors more than the countries in question. The resolution voted on calls for a series of concrete measures of considerable impact, such as country-by-country reporting by multinational companies, to make public all relevant tax information (subsidiaries with financial results, taxes paid, assets and number of employees...); the automatic exchange of information between countries; the establishment of public registers on the effective ownership of companies, trustees, foundations and other bodies, without restrictions of access; the equal participation of developing countries in the reform of global fiscal policies, the fight against "tax havens". I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance and evasion as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries. In these countries, illicit financial flows generally result from tax evasion and avoidance activities; however, they are not equipped to combat such illegal activities. It is important for developing countries to obtain public revenue through taxation and taxation. At European level, the European Investment Bank (EIB), the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and the financial institutions of the Member States provide substantial aid to private enterprises in developing countries.  This report calls on the Commission to rapidly propose an ambitious action plan, in the form of a communication, to support developing countries fighting tax evasion and avoidance and to help them establish fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems, taking into account the work undertaken by the OECD Development Assistance Committee.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The benefits of effective and transparent taxation go beyond increasing the resources available to the state, creating a link between political institutions and public and private services that is necessary to achieve the soundness and good governance of developing countries.  Together with these objectives, the economic and financial crisis requires an increase in national revenues in order to cope with the growth of public debt.  We are aware that developing countries have considerable administrative, political and technical constraints with regard to the collection of taxes; the fight against corruption, evasion and circumvention is one of the first objectives for growth and international cooperation.  The Commission should take concrete and effective measures to support these countries and their regional tax administration structures in order to make tax policies fair, balanced, transparent and efficient. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although domestic resources are the largest source of financing for developing countries (SDP), the ratio of taxes levied in relation to their GDP is on average very low.  Taxation can be a viable and sustainable source of revenue in SDCs, presenting the advantage of stability compared to traditional development financing mechanisms. Experts estimate that $269 billion could be mobilised if tax collection is improved. It is therefore necessary to treat with acuity the phenomena of tax evasion (through VAT fraud, non-declaration of personal and commercial income, or bribery of tax officials), as well as the phenomena of tax avoidance practised, for example, through profit transfers by multinationals that move their assets. I support the measures provided for in this report to combat these phenomena in sts by strengthening their tax systems, making them fair, balanced, efficient and transparent. Good governance in tax matters must therefore be on the priorities of concluding cooperation agreements between the EU and third countries. The definition of a globally accepted list of tax havens and countries accepting tax evasion should also be a priority.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think we are all well known about the situation in many developing countries, which cannot even achieve the minimum tax level necessary to finance their basic functioning as well as public services. Many of these attract investment by offering tax incentives and exemptions that are neither transparent nor based on proper cost-benefit analysis, thus achieving unfavourable results in terms of tax systems and causing harmful tax competition. It is therefore necessary, and this is why I voted in favour of this report, to take concrete and effective measures as a matter of urgency to support the developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, as well as in the development of fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax policies. There is also a need to strengthen the judiciary and anti-corruption agencies in these countries. Furthermore, in view of foreign investments, it would be appropriate to establish a database with all the easily available information concerning the effective ownership of companies, trust funds and other institutions, in order to prevent other anonymous fictitious companies and similar legal entities from being used to launder money, finance illegal or terrorist activities, conceal the identity of corrupt individuals or for the concealment of public funds and profits from illicit trafficking and illegal tax evasion.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ While the report does bring out some positive points I am not in a position to vote in favour of this report as the points referring to a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base are not ideal for greater investment within the Union’s states. Tax laws should be issues which are left up to the Member States; there cannot be the convergence of a tax law without a negative impact on the economy of certain Member States. Even though there is support for certain proposals put forward in this report, there cannot be the support for the harmonisation of a consolidated tax base.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by considering positive the call for a concrete action plan to combat tax avoidance and evasion in impoverished countries, which would help to better redistribute and control resources by their governments.  Tax havens, banking secrecy and the designation of "tax-free zones" to supposedly attract foreign capital and investment are nefarious for achieving sustainable, inclusive and social justice-based development and respect for the sovereignty of peoples, which requires fair progressive tax systems to address inequality. While there are improveable aspects and the approach is not as ambitious as it should be, it is positive that it calls for the implementation of assessments of the impact of European fiscal policies on impoverished countries, noting the need to monitor, annually and country by country, the activities of multinationals and their possible direct or indirect contribution to tax avoidance and capital evasion.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I am in favour of strengthening developing countries’ capacity to deal with challenges, including in the field of taxation. I support the idea that developing countries are equally engaged and participate in this process. However, I am not in favour of duplicating standards or increased administrative burdens brought upon business operators as a result of duplication.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance and evasion as challenges in developing countries, because the adoption of this report is of strategic importance in view of the International Conference on Financing for Development to be held next week in Addis Ababa, in which Europe will have to play an important role. Official Development Assistance (ODA) should be used more effectively and transparently. Effective mobilisation of domestic resources, which continue to be the main source of funding for developing countries, and the strengthening of national tax systems should be at the heart of the Conference's discussion. The availability of resources will then have to be accompanied by more efficient and fair tax systems, so as to help overcome dependence on foreign aid in the long term, reduce inequalities, eradicate poverty and consolidate good governance in the tax sector.  Finally, a reform of the global tax system in the name of greater inclusiveness, greater transparency and a more effective fight against tax havens and international fraud can certainly contribute to a more effective implementation of the post-2015 framework that will replace the Millennium Development Goals.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, together with Silva PEREIRA's report on development finance adopted in May 2015, produces a "package" outlining Parliament's position for the 3rd International Conference on Financing for Development to be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The report proposes to address the tax and tax governance challenges facing developing countries, and the need to strengthen the transparency and effectiveness of national and international tax systems. The report also calls on the European Commission to present without delay an ambitious action plan to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and the establishment of fair, balanced, effective and transparent tax systems. Considering that it is necessary to reach a comprehensive agreement on the post-2015 development agenda, which includes credible mechanisms for mobilising national funds and combating illicit financial flows, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on tax avoidance and evasion addresses the main challenges facing developing countries for governance, social protection and development.
