Indeed, a new strategy for these countries must be set up in such a way as to overcome dependence on external aid in the long term, and it is therefore necessary to develop efficient and fair tax systems. These measures are aimed at promoting good governance and state consolidation.  In addition, it is necessary to prevent certain measures aimed at increasing capital mobility from encouraging the use of tax havens. In this context, it is important that transparency measures in public administration are increased, reducing the level of corruption. In fact, in these countries, the share of revenue relative to GDP remains low.  The report contains a number of interesting proposals to combat these practices, such as the initiation of procedures for access to sensitive information such as those concerning the effective ownership of the company and trust funds. In fact, corrupt individuals could be hidden, concealing the misappropriation of public funds or profits from illicit trafficking.   For this reason, I am voting with conviction in favour of this text, in order to build a virtuous path on these issues in developing countries.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Illicit financial flows, according to a February 2015 UN report by President Mbeki, amount to 50 billion euros per year in Africa. We must therefore address this challenge of tax evasion and evasion in developing countries in order to ensure greater effectiveness of official development assistance.  That is why EU financial institutions will have to act vigorously to ensure that EU-backed companies do not "participate" in tax evasion. This is in line with the transparency report that we voted for during our session.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While the UK Government has been at the forefront of tackling international tax avoidance and evasion, we cannot support a number of initiatives called for in this report. In particular we cannot support calls for country-by-country reporting to be made publically available, nor can Conservatives support calls for a swift agreement on an EU wide Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance and evasion as challenges in developing countries, as the report contains many recommendations to be taken into account at the upcoming meeting in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The report also talks about developing countries' tax systems and the need to tackle existing problems such as corruption and opaque public administration.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it calls on the Member States to reach an agreement quickly on a common consolidated corporate tax base

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Considering the importance of better mobilisation of national resources and the problems faced by developing countries in combating tax evasion and avoidance, Parliament presented this report with a view to the set of existing international initiatives to reform the global tax system and, above all, the conference on financing development to be held in Addis Ababa. Among the proposed measures are the strengthening of financial and technical assistance to developing countries and the regional tax administration's frameworks; the creation of a truly intergovernmental body in which developing countries can participate on an equal footing in the comprehensive reform of current international tax rules. Since I believe it is essential to ensure that the collection of national taxes is more predictable, stable and sound, and that all members of society, citizens and businesses, pay according to their own means, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because some measures lack clarity and brevity.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report considers that taxation is a sustainable and reliable source of revenue in developing countries, with the advantage of stability compared to traditional development financing mechanisms. Given the political, technical and administrative constraints faced by developing countries to increase tax revenues, the report considers that EU Member States should support these countries in training their tax authorities' frameworks. This is the point with which we agree, despite the need to respect the sovereignty and legitimate choices of these countries in the field of taxation – an area that goes to the heart of state sovereignty. All attempts to condition countries' options in this area, which are often insinuated under the cover of technical cooperation, must be firmly rejected. The report also advocates measures to combat money laundering, the financing of illegal or terrorist activities and tax evasion – common practices, often involving multinationals, that so much harm these countries. The report also addresses the problem of tax havens in a generally correct way – at the level of the recognised negative impacts of them – although insufficient. Disagreeing with one point or another, we generally agree with the content of the report.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax avoidance and tax evasion as challenges in developing countries pose a major problem for local government garrisons precisely because domestic resources represent the largest source of funding for developing countries. It is essential that these countries vigorously increase tax collection, thereby helping to improve public services for people. The European Parliament should therefore support a set of strong recommendations to improve the mobilisation of domestic resources in developing countries, such as strengthening financial and technical assistance to developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks and adopting strong solutions to increase transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax evasion.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the report because I agree with the need to help developing countries with measures in the field of taxation such as strengthening financial and technical assistance to the regional tax administration's reference frameworks, adopting decisive solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax fraud, an instrument for the automatic exchange of information and the publication of information.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Because this report calls on the Member States to quickly reach agreement on a common consolidated corporate tax base, which I do not agree with, my vote is against.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I firmly support tax as a Member State competency.  Although my own Government has been at the forefront of tackling international tax avoidance and evasion it has done so through its own initiatives and bilateral methods. This, without a doubt, encroaches on Member States’ competence of tax. Furthermore, it completely ignores the principle of subsidiarity by calling for an EU-wide Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a considerable potential to increase tax collection in developing countries, which right now, in comparative prospective, raise substantially less revenues than advanced economies. I strongly believe that Domestic Resource Mobilisation is key to achieve the new sustainable development goals and at a time when ODA is not sufficient in that regard. Better tax justice will help reduce inequalities and eradicate poverty, while also bringing an end to tax havens for multinational companies, including European companies. I welcome the recommendations included in the report, such as the importance of strengthening financial and technical assistance to developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks; the adoption of strong solutions to enhance transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax dodging, such as an Automatic Exchange of Information mechanism and country-by-country reporting, taking into consideration developing countries’ needs and constraints; the conducting at EU and Member States’ level of an impact assessment of tax policies on developing countries; the preservation of source countries’ taxation rights when negotiating tax treaties, and the creation of a truly intergovernmental body where developing countries could participate on an equal footing in the global reform of existing international tax rules. I thank the rapporteur Elly Schlein and the shadows for the great job done.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report raised and provided the proposed answers to questions that I believe require special attention on our part. It examined the problems and their consequences in relation to the current system. Administrative constraints, economic constraints and negative competition can all have negative long-term consequences.  It is crucial to point out that illegal financial flows, i.e. private financial flows involving unregistered capital that have been illegally sought, transferred or used, have increased significantly. In 2011, domestic resources lost by developing countries due to illegal financial flows amounted to more than $630 billion, which represents 4.3% of developing countries' GDP Unfortunately, this has a particular impact on developing countries, as they are heavily dependent on corporation tax: corporate tax revenue accounts for a significant part of their national income. I welcome the call to strengthen financial support and technical assistance to developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks.  Furthermore, I believe that in the fight against tax evasion, solid solutions and an action plan are needed to increase transparency and cooperation.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. EU support for the mobilisation of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their poverty and inequality rates

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on 'tax avoidance and evasion as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries' because the European Parliament intends to combine its position on development finance with a clear position on these issues, with a view to the third Conference on Financing for Development on the agenda on 13-16 July 2015 , in Addis Ababa. On that occasion, global donors, including the European Union, will be called upon to discuss financing for development in the coming years, with a view to adopting a stronger and more inclusive financial framework, but also realistic with a view to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs), the negotiations of which will begin in September. Official development aid is still an important pillar for the budgets of many developing countries. Consequently, I supported this report, which calls on the Commission to present a new action plan to support developing countries in the fight against illicit financial flows and tax evasion, with a view to the creation of sound tax systems, the call for greater commitment to technical assistance beyond finance and, finally, the inclusion of good governance in tax matters in the dialogue with the developing countries.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As coordinator of my group for the ACP delegation, I voted today in favour of the report on tax avoidance and evasion as a challenge to governance, social protection and development in developing countries, because I consider this issue to be a very important one. Every year, an estimated EUR 1 trillion is lost in emerging markets through tax fraud. We need functioning tax offices in these countries. That is why I am calling, among other things, for a separate 'Devetax 2020' programme to create at least 2020 new tax offices in African countries by 2020.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Schlein report because it is high time we send a strong message on the need to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries. Knowing that a small increase in tax revenues in developing countries would dwarf the amount of aid they receive, it is imperative we take strong measures in the post-2015 development framework to support these countries in mobilising domestic resources and tackling tax avoidance. It is vital that multinational companies pay their fair share of tax in developing countries. We need to bring an end to tax havens for multinational companies, including for those who are based in Europe. We will only bring an end to poverty and inequality if we support fair taxes at home as well as abroad.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because next week's Addis Ababa Conference is an important event, from which everyone expects effective responses and the definition of a serious and at the same time ambitious policy line for development funding.  There is no point in defining new sustainable development goals without real agreement and a strategy on the resources that the community will put in place to achieve them.  The countries involved cannot be excluded from this process, so it is certain that much needs to be done through the so-called 'mobilisation of internal resources'. It is the developing countries themselves that need to improve their national institutions and tax systems. However, we cannot deny that these processes are hampered by illegal funding and transfers by multinationals.  Europe must have a role, it must be at the side of the countries it helps and it must have a voice within the international community in order to continue a global and coordinated process against illicit financial flows, to which not only developing countries are targeted.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report, as the report calls for an effective action plan to combat tax evasion and, in particular, tax evasion in developing countries: a plan that facilitates better mobilization of national resources for the sake of equitable and sustainable development. In addition, the report calls on the European Union and its Member States to ensure that, in fiscal and investment agreement negotiations with developing countries, income or benefits resulting from cross-border activities are taxed in the country of origin in which value is extracted or created, and urges the EU and Member States to exceed the OECD framework and ensure that the creation of a true intergovernmental body for tax issues within the United Nations.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament adopted a resolution dealing with tax evasion and avoidance as challenges in developing countries. I alongside my Labour colleagues voted for the EU to do more and work harder to help developing countries clamp down on tax dodging. Such measures will enable governments to better resource healthcare, sanitation and education. This report called on the European Commission to put forward a plan on assisting developing countries in fighting tax dodging and setting up fairer tax systems, financial and technical assistance to developing countries; enforce country-by-country reporting for multinationals; and ensure the UN taxation committee has teeth. Action on tax avoidance and evasion will help developing countries work towards the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which aim to complete the task of the Millennium Directive and provide healthcare and education to all children.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this report and believe it raises the key issues in the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries. With the forthcoming conference on Financing for Development, the summit on the Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris climate negotiations later this year, this is a very timely report. Just a small increase in tax revenue in developing countries could overshadow the amount of aid received. It is therefore vital that multinational companies pay their fair share of tax – at home and abroad. As we mark the European Year for Development, by voting for this report we are showing our commitment to fighting extreme poverty and inequality.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tax evasion is a global problem and it can have a serious impact on the economies of many developing countries. I supported this report and urge the Commission to come forward with recommendations at the earliest opportunity.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report, as the report calls for an effective action plan to combat tax evasion and, in particular, tax evasion in developing countries: a plan that facilitates better mobilization of national resources for the sake of equitable and sustainable development. In addition, the report calls on the European Union and its Member States to ensure that, in fiscal and investment agreement negotiations with developing countries, income or benefits resulting from cross-border activities are taxed in the country of origin in which value is extracted or created, and urges the EU and Member States to exceed the OECD framework and ensure that the creation of a true intergovernmental body for tax issues within the United Nations.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission should take concrete measures to support developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks. Listed or unlisted multinational companies of all countries and sectors must adopt country-by-country reporting (CBCR) as a standard. They should publish as part of their annual reporting and on a country-by-country basis for each territory in which they operate. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on tax avoidance and evasion as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries because this proposal insists that tax policy processes be based on credible financial data, regular and complete reports, and the principle of transparency to improve the global system in the sector. I agree with support for developing countries and regional tax administrations in the form of the fight against tax avoidance and evasion, and additional financial and technical measures to ensure that tax policies are subject to fairness, efficiency and balance. In this context, it is of particular importance to mobilise domestic funds and strengthen tax systems that lead to combating inequalities, reducing poverty and establishing an effective state.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this report on tax evasion and evasion in developing countries. This report is still very vague in many respects, not always specifying possible legal initiatives. Similarly, the proposed measures are often non-binding, whereas it would be appropriate, on the other hand, to be firm on the issue. Nevertheless, this text proposes very positive progress on, for example, financial transparency or by giving a legal and precise definition of the "tax haven". The report also advanced the publicity of information on companies that exploit natural resources in developing countries, all of which must be supported by a streamlined and efficient tax administration.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not condone tax evasion of any sort, and I also do not believe that this is the European Union’s responsibility to address. I believe that tax evasion in developing states should be an issue of compliance between Member States and international tax bodies.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on tax avoidance and tax evasion in developing countries. I was the shadow rapporteur of the ECON opinion on this report. The final text includes the recommendations we defined for the economic side and it takes into account the specificities of developing countries. It is important to keep in mind that those countries do not have the same administrative and technical capacities as European countries to fight tax avoidance. That is why it is crucial that we give them a transitional period for the implementation of the OECD standard on automatic exchange of information. Although developing countries do not always have the capacity to send the required information, it is of utmost important that they receive tax information from developed countries so that they can detect and correct abusive tax practices.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elly Schlein's report on tax evasion in developing countries. This report highlights the various problems facing developing countries in terms of tax evasion, such as the informal economy, political and economic constraints. According to a study by Global Financial Integrity, the developing world lost $6.6 trillion between 2003 and 2012 in illicit financial flows, hence the need for states to fight them effectively. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on tax evasion and tax evasion in developing countries. Indeed, the phenomena of tax evasion and evasion contribute to corruption and undermine the Union's development policy. In the face of these challenges, Europe must respond in a way that establishes a stable tax system that ensures a reliable and sustainable source of income for developing countries and thus promotes the strengthening of their democratic institutions and the rule of law.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The scheme is worthy of support as it can help to improve the situation in developing countries in a sustainable way. I am voting in favour of this contribution.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax evasion and avoidance affects both developing countries and EU Member States. However, this problem is particularly noticeable in developing countries, where, for various reasons, the administrative structures of countries are too weak to ensure efficient and fair tax collection. Corruption and tax evasion and, consequently, illegally obtained funds can serve to finance terrorist financing and criminal activities. It is particularly important to increase the funding of governments in developing countries, which they very much need to ensure that citizens have access to basic services, such as education and health care. Account should also be taken of the fact that political instability and technical constraints, such as lack of human resources, often prevent the effective collection of taxes. This resolution also calls on the European Commission to support developing countries in taking measures to strengthen their tax administration. At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 July 2015, I voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance and evasion, social protection and development in developing countries. Tax havens and the principle of absolute banking secrecy, combined with zero taxation, always attract capital and income to countries that should be taxed in other countries, thus creating harmful tax competition, undermining the fairness of tax systems, which mainly affects the environment in developing countries. Tax evasion also does not help the whole situation, thanks to companies that try to avoid taxation by creating complex internal structures and by exploiting loopholes in tax laws. The report presented calls for an action plan to combat tax avoidance and evasion in developing countries. The report also urges the Commission and the Member States to carry out an impact assessment of European tax policies in developing countries and to eliminate practices that have a negative impact on developing countries. Since many of the amendments we have tabled have been reflected in the compromises adopted, I have decided to support the document tabled.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance and tax evasion as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries, because I believe that cohesion policy, thorough country-by-country control and a comprehensive action plan can eradicate tax havens, which undermine the impartiality of the tax system.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Efficient and fair tax systems are essential to eradicate poverty, tackle inequalities, promote good governance and consolidation of the rule of law, and overcome dependence on foreign aid in the long term. That is the thrust of the report adopted today. Our appeal is for the Commission to present, as soon as possible, a strategy to support developing countries fighting evasion and avoidance and to help them establish fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems. It is essential for us that multinationals operating in developing countries publish all relevant tax information, including financial results and taxes on them. In addition, we have achieved an excellent result by demanding the creation of an intergovernmental body to ensure that developing countries participate on an equal footing in the reform of the global tax system.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mrs Schlein's report. Illicit financial flows generally result from tax evasion and avoidance activities, such as abuse in the determination of transfer prices, contrary to the principle that taxes should be paid at the place where profits are generated.  This proposal calls on the Commission to rapidly propose an ambitious action plan, in the form of a communication, to support developing countries fighting tax evasion and avoidance and to help them establish fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems, taking into account the work undertaken by the OECD Development Assistance Committee.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the principle of transparency that large companies publish information on their activities in each country where they operate, as I have supported transparency obligations for the activities of so-called extractive industries and credit institutions. Nevertheless, I, like the entire EPP Group, abstained on the mechanism presented in this report so as not to anticipate the position that the special committee TAXE will take on the specific case of tax information, which is at the heart of its work.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report underlines the importance of improving the mobilization of national resources to address the problems faced by developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. It proposes a list of recommendations for the Conference on the Financing of the Development of Addis Ababa aimed at reforming the global tax system. The Commission is requested to communicate to assist developing countries in establishing fair, balanced, effective and transparent tax systems by strengthening financial and technical assistance to these countries; the adoption of effective solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax evasion, such as an automatic country-by-country information exchange mechanism, taking into account the needs and limitations of each; an assessment of the impact of EU fiscal policies on developing countries and the creation of a truly intergovernmental body for taxation issues, in which developing countries can participate on an equal footing in the comprehensive reform of existing international tax rules. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by considering positive the call for a concrete action plan to combat tax avoidance and evasion in impoverished countries, which would help to better redistribute and control resources by their governments.  Tax havens, banking secrecy and the designation of "tax-free zones" to supposedly attract foreign capital and investment are nefarious for achieving sustainable, inclusive and social justice-based development and respect for the sovereignty of peoples, which requires fair progressive tax systems to address inequality. While there are improveable aspects and the approach is not as ambitious as it should be, it is positive that it calls for the implementation of assessments of the impact of European fiscal policies on impoverished countries, noting the need to monitor, annually and country by country, the activities of multinationals and their possible direct or indirect contribution to tax avoidance and capital evasion.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In a globalized context such as in which we live, we must develop convergence programmes between different regions of the world to combat illicit fiscal flows together. We need more transparency and for both national and international tax systems to be more efficient in combating tax evasion and avoidance. The proposals compiled in the report offer alternatives to reshape our institutions as agents of change. Among other points, an incentive system is suggested, advertising a list of companies whose leaders are truly committed to eradicating tax fraud in a freely accessible database. Moreover, through this Resolution, we would be forced to reach conclusive agreement on the universal definition of what constitutes a tax haven and set sanctions at the global level in cooperation with the United Nations for which they violate established regulations. I support this project as an alternative to an already out-of-the-box model that needed change urgently.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Tax Avoidance and Evasion Report as challenges for governance, social protection and development in the developing countries of Rapporteur Elly Schlein. The report detects a number of problems that are important to solve and minimizes this issue. For example, in the Republic of Croatia, the largest number of crimes relates to economic crimes involving tax evasion.  A plan should be developed to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance and to strengthen the tax systems of developing countries. In this way, the stability of the welfare state and the solidarity system for all citizens can continue to be ensured.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The EU and its Member States should make multinationals report their financial performance, tax details, assets and employee numbers country by country, so as to help fight tax evasion and illicit money flows in developing countries. We must call on EU financial institutions to ensure that companies receiving EU support do not ‘participate’ in tax evasion. The Commission must put forward an ambitious action plan to support developing countries in fighting tax evasion and tax avoidance and in setting up fair, well-balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on tax avoidance and tax evasion as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015, and also because the UN resolution of September 2014 on the write-off of the state debt of developing countries should be implemented immediately.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the importance of better mobilisation of domestic resources and the problems that developing countries face in tackling tax evasion and tax avoidance, the rapporteur suggests a list of strong recommendations that the EP should support, in view of the FfD Conference to be held in Addis Ababa and the range of existing international initiatives to reform the global tax system. Among them, strengthening financial and technical assistance to developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks; the adoption of strong solutions to enhance transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax dodging, such as an Automatic Exchange of Information mechanism and country-by-country reporting, taking into consideration developing countries’ needs and constraints; the conducting at EU and Member States’ level of an impact assessment of tax policies on developing countries; the preservation of source countries’ taxation rights when negotiating tax treaties and the creation of a truly intergovernmental body where developing countries could participate on an equal footing in the global reform of existing international tax rules.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Votes in favour of the report on tax avoidance and evasion as challenges in developing countries. The aim of the proposal is to support, through appropriate tax policies, such as the reduction of corporate tax rates and the increase in tax incentives and exemptions, with the main objective of also attracting investors to promote economic growth, developing countries, to combat tax evasion and avoidance.  We fully support the rapporteur's proposal to enter into concrete agreements to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax fraud.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report urges the European Commission to implement concrete measures to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. It also calls for fair, balanced, efficient and transparent fiscal policies with a view to promoting sustainable and long-term administrative reforms within this category of countries.  For all these reasons, I have decided to support mrs Schlein's signature document.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because it is undeniable that tax havens and tax evasion have been responsible for the capital flight that should have been taxed in other countries and generating harmful practices of tax competition that have greatly undermined a more equitable and sustainable development. This report calls on the European Commission to establish a policy promoting tax justice and to carry out a study of the impact of European tax policies on developing countries, including country-by-country reports for multinationals.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In the preamble to her excellent report, my Italian colleague Elly SCHLEIN recalls eloquent figures: illicit financial flows amount to a loss of $1 trillion annually for developing countries (DEVELOPING countries), ten times the amount of aid they receive to eradicate poverty. His report, voted by a large majority, puts forward very ambitious proposals, some of which I defended in the TAXE Committee on Aggressive Tax Optimization. He also invites the Commission to put forward a proposal for companies operating in Europe and in developing countries, whether listed or not, to disclose, including in the eyes of the public, their country-by-country accounting (country-by-country information). It also calls for the adoption of an internationally recognised definition of tax havens by the end of 2015, the establishment of sanctions for operators who use them, and the development of a blacklist of countries, including members of the Union, that do not fight or tolerate tax evasion. Finally, with this report, the Commission is called upon to urgently adopt an action plan to help developing countries combat tax evasion and evasion in practice. Satisfied that the lines are finally moving in Europe, I voted for without hesitation.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this scheme as the impact can help to improve the situation in developing countries in a sustainable way. It would therefore also be a prevention for European companies wishing to be established in these countries. However, the additional revenue generated by each country should be earmarked.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report notes that "tax resources remain low in most developing countries, making them particularly vulnerable to tax evasion and evasion by taxpayers and businesses." It therefore promotes "fair, balanced, rational and transparent tax regimes" that "provide essential funding to governments to cover citizens' rights to basic public services, such as health and education for all" and "contribute to lessening the effect of inequality". To help these countries combat tax evasion, the report calls for the publication of country-by-country information by multinational companies. For each jurisdiction in which they operate, they will have to indicate the names of all subsidiaries and their respective financial performance, relevant tax information, assets and the number of employees. The report also calls for the adoption of an international definition of tax havens, the establishment of sanctions for operators who use them and the development of a blacklist of countries, including EU Member States, that do not fight tax evasion. I am voting for this text which dares to attack multinationals.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Many of the amendments tabled were in the direction of more harmonization and financial transparency in order to really combat tax evasion and evasion. The report refers to adopting an official definition of tax haven or making public information on companies exploiting natural resources in developing countries. Another positive point of this report is the desire to create the development of efficient tax administrations with a view to greater financial autonomy for developing countries in the coming decades.  Despite these good initiatives, many other parties were either too vague or not restrictive enough. I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is important, in the role of the European Union in the world, for the European Commission to take concrete steps to support developing countries in the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion, in the development of tax policies, fair, balanced, efficient and transparent, in promoting structural reforms.  The European Commission should assist these countries in building capacities to combat tax fraud, corruption, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning, including providing technical assistance in training in human resources and developing administrative structures.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though I support the Union’s efforts to help developing countries establish or alter their tax systems to tackle illicit financial flows, I could not support this report as it contained unnecessary references to the creation of a common consolidated corporate tax base. Such taxation issues do not fall under the EU’s competence.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. National revenues are and will continue to be the major financing tool for sustainable development. The mobilization of national revenues is a prerequisite for promoting the exit from aid dependency and universal access to public services. Developing countries (DEVELOPING countries) are rich in important natural resources, but they generate a tiny share of national revenues. Although the proportion of national revenues in developing countries' GDP has increased in recent decades, it is still very low. In the majority of countries, it is below the threshold below which governments are struggling to finance basic public services (15%). Strengthening tax systems and combating tax evasion and tax evasion in developing countries is essential. I welcome the adoption of the report on tax evasion and tax evasion. This is a strong message to negotiators at the international conference on development finance, as optimal taxation allows, beyond increasing the resources available for development, strengthening good governance and consolidating the state by promoting the stability of government budgets and allowing them to take ownership of their policy choices.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of tax obligations and tax evasion has recently resonated, especially in the case of multinationals – legal entities that, due to their lack of transparency, unclear international rules and instability in developing countries, are not fulfilling their obligations towards the states in which they do business. I therefore support the action plan to prevent base erosion and profit shifting, which will force multinationals to pay taxes where they carry out their economic activities. I also agree with the proposal to define tax havens and create a blacklist of countries that allow the use of tax evasion by legal persons. Tax evasion at the expense of the population in developing countries is a punishable crime that prevents the suppression of extreme poverty. I believe that more effective collection of taxes from multinationals operating in developing countries should contribute to economic development in these countries and to improving the living conditions of their populations.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report, which stresses the importance of strengthening developing countries’ capacity to deal with challenges, including in the field of taxation. The issues currently on the EU and OECD agendas are equally relevant for developing countries, as many of these aspects are indeed global phenomena, and consequently require global coordinated action. Nevertheless, I could not agree to some provisions, which in my opinion may not necessarily be helpful in progressing work in this area and goes within the sovereign right of Member States. Last but not least, I have my reservations with regard to a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) proposal.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Domestic resources are the main source of funding in developing countries. In these countries, the average tax rate as a share of GDP is between 10% and 20%, and in many countries it is less than 15%, while in OECD countries it is 30-40%. However, the effective mobilisation of domestic resources and the strengthening of tax systems are essential in order to achieve the development goals that make it possible to combat the dependence on foreign aid in the long term. Effective and equitable tax systems are also crucial for eradicating poverty, combating inequalities, good governance and state building.  The report therefore calls on the Commission to present an action plan that supports developing countries in the fight against tax fraud and tax avoidance and in establishing fair and transparent tax systems. It also calls for concrete and effective measures to support developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks in the fight against tax fraud and tax avoidance and in the development of fair, balanced, effective and transparent tax policies. I agree with the findings and recommendations of the report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support that illicit financial flows (FFI) – i.e. all unregistered private financial flows involving capital obtained, transferred or used illegally – usually result from tax avoidance and tax avoidance activities, such as abusive transfer pricing, which is contrary to the principle of taxation of profits where they are carried out, and that tax evasion and avoidance have been identified in all major international texts and conferences on financing of development as the main obstacles to mobilising internal revenues for development. I am voting in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to ensure that domestic tax collection becomes more predictable, stable and sound and that all members of society - both individuals and companies - pay according to their possibilities. I argue that a fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax regime allows governments to access essential funding to maintain citizens' right of access to basic public services, such as health care and education for all, and that an effective redistributive tax policy helps mitigate the effects of growing inequalities in the most needy people.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. While a development conference is being held in Addis Ababa, the fight against tax evasion seems to be a major issue for the countries of the South. Indeed, at a time when the contributions of rich countries to development aid are stunting due to fiscal austerity, tax avoidance has become a prominent issue for the tax revenues of developing countries. This would cost them about 100 billion euros per year, which greatly reduces their already low tax revenues (between 10 and 20%). However, this report does not go far enough to require necessary transparency measures such as country-by-country reporting or the establishment of a list of tax havens. It even excludes the advertising of essential information from natural resource companies in developing countries. While everything proposed to combat tax havens is encouraging, this report does not give a deadline on the official qualifications of tax havens. So I decided to abstain since it does not go far enough in the fight against white and shell companies.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report sends an important message on the need to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries. We know that a small increase in tax revenues in developing countries would dwarf the amount of aid they receive. Domestic resources and international finance both form important pillars of the new global development framework after 2015. It is vital that multinational companies pay their fair share of tax in developing countries. In the European Year for Development, Labour MEPs continue to show their commitment to the fight against extreme poverty and inequality. We should promote fair taxes abroad as we do at home.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on tax evasion and evasion, which has a particularly negative impact on developing countries. According to Global Financial Integrity's 2014 report, foreign direct investment (FDI) and official development assistance (ODA) between 2003 and 2012 amount slightly less than illicit capital outflows of about US$1 trillion. It is important to combat these scourges if these countries are to develop and meet the needs of their populations. The migrant crisis in Europe is one of the many consequences of this development differential.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we call on the Commission to rapidly propose an ambitious action plan to support developing countries fighting tax evasion and avoidance and to help them establish fair and balanced tax systems. We are convinced that only in the presence of efficient and transparent tax systems can poverty be eliminated, inequalities combated, good governance and state consolidation promoted.  We have always supported the need for the EU to take a leading role in combating tax havens, fraud and tax evasion, setting a good example, cooperating with developing countries to counter aggressive tax avoidance practices adopted by certain transnational companies. We hope that it will be possible, by the end of 2015, to draw up a blacklist of tax havens and countries, including those located in the EU, which distort competition by granting more favourable tax conditions.  Finally, we reiterate the urgent need, both for developing and developed countries, to tax profits in the place where economic activities take place and to work towards a compulsory and automatic exchange of information between national tax authorities on a global scale.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that tackles the need for an action plan in the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion in developing countries.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this report as the impact can help to improve the situation in developing countries in a sustainable way. It would therefore also be a prevention for European companies that are or want to become established in these countries.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report addresses the problems of tax avoidance in developing countries and possible EU action to help them combat it. Domestic resources are the largest source of financing in developing countries, but the average ratio of taxes to GDP is too low in developing countries. It is important that the EU also contributes to helping developing countries to make tax collection more stable and secure. It is important to address this issue both in the political dialogue with developing countries and in development cooperation agreements.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the issue of tax avoidance and evasion in developing countries is of great importance as it aims to counter the primary issues that prevent these countries from having stable growth. I hope that the European Union can make a fundamental contribution to supporting the emergence of new practices that can significantly improve the current situation.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of this Report as a stronger commitment by the EU Member States to enhance transparency and cooperation would provide vital support for developing countries in the fight against tax dodging. This report urges the Commission to support developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks, and urges that information on beneficial ownership of companies, trusts and other institutions be made publicly available in open-data formats. I believe that these are important steps and although this report is not a binding regulation, it is still very encouraging as it shows that it is possible to get cross-party support for tax justice issues.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Tax payment is an obligation of citizens of the Member States of the European Union but also a show of genuine respect for the homeland, and concern for the well-being of society and its overall progress. Paying taxes is also an obligation for companies to which the state guarantees real security, and the European Union opens up opportunities for better business both globally and in developing countries. However, some companies do not behave in this spirit and hide their ownership and co-ownership in different ways. To the detriment of citizens, they seek to avoid paying taxes through financial and legal malfeasance and are often linked to various tax evasions, evasion and money laundering.  In order to prevent the exploitation of citizens, taxpayers, and avoid opaque flows of money, the resolution calls for the establishment of reporting that companies, in addition to their annual billing, would also publish the names of all subsidiaries or companies in which they have a stake in the ownership, their results individually, tax charges, the number of employees and assets.  I support this resolution, as it calls for measures aimed at preventing these negative phenomena, and I welcome the additional requirements covering the drafting of a blacklist of tax havens and countries that distort equal competition, human resources development and administrative structures to combat tax evasion in developing countries through their tax policies.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. While a development conference is being held in Addis Ababa, the fight against tax evasion seems to be a major issue for the countries of the South. Indeed, at a time when the contributions of rich countries to development aid are stunting due to fiscal austerity, tax avoidance has become a prominent issue for the tax revenues of developing countries. This would cost them about 100 billion euros a year, which greatly reduces their already low tax revenues (between 10 and 20% of GDP). However, this report does not go far enough to require necessary transparency measures such as country-by-country reporting or the establishment of a list of tax havens. It even excludes the advertising of essential information from natural resource companies in developing countries. While everything proposed to combat tax havens is encouraging, this report does not give a time limit on the official qualifications of tax havens. I have therefore decided to abstain since it does not go far enough in the fight against money laundering and shell companies.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Illicit financial flows involving capital illegally acquired, transferred or exploited, most commonly stemming from tax evasion and avoidance activities, such as abuse of transfer pricing, have been identified as major obstacles to the mobilisation of domestic revenues. The major problem of the impact of tax avoidance and evasion is seen mainly in developing countries, as the amount generated by illicit financial flows is approximately ten times higher than the financial assistance received by developing countries, which should be earmarked for poverty eradication, prosperity growth and sustainable development, representing an illegal capital flight from developing countries of around USD 1 trillion per year. Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal, which aims at measures and clear guidelines for governance, social protection and development, including supporting the potential to increase tax revenues offered by extractive industries, thereby supporting developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks. By revising fiscal and extractive industry activities, the EU would increase assistance to developing countries with a view to adequately taxing the extraction of natural resources, strengthening the bargaining position of host governments to generate greater profits from their own natural resources, and encouraging the diversification of their economy.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Schlein's report on tax avoidance and evasion for developing countries. The countries' fiscal systems are unsustainable because foreign investment and development aid amount to less than illicit outflows of money and tax revenues account for only about 10% of GDP. EU solidarity must not be questioned in reaching the target of 0.7% of GNI development aid. In order to ensure the effectiveness of assistance, it is up to the Commission to develop a quality catalogue of measures to address administrative and political barriers in developing countries, strengthen institutional capacity and fight corruption, in order to increase tax revenues and reduce dependence on foreign aid for a long time. The implementation of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive and the Transfer of Funds Regulation should allow publicly available information on the beneficial ownership of companies, to prevent various forms of illicit financing. It is necessary to develop an efficient automatic exchange of information and define tax havens to sanction countries that do not prevent illegal capital outflows. The ultimate goal should be greater economic autonomy for developing countries. Therefore, taxation of income or profits from cross-border activities in the source country, where the value was created, should be guaranteed. Also, the focus should be on achieving higher taxation than the extractive industry, which is absent due to opaque agreements between governments of developing countries and extractive companies.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tax evasion is always an important problem we need to tackle, but in this case especially for developing countries regarding their high illicit financial flow levels, high dependency on corporate taxation and low tax-to-GDP ratios. These countries are in most need of tax revenue for infrastructure, welfare, education and many other things, but struggle to achieve it, with a prevalence of the rich and powerful easily dodging tax payment. I am, therefore, rejoiced that this resolution is adopted by a clear vote. The EU must engage actively in supporting developing countries for a fair and efficient tax system with a transparent and responsible administration to eliminate exploitation of the existing loopholes. The fact that most global solutions at present are prioritising benefits on developed countries, or in many cases on the OECD countries, this must be balanced. Hence I very much support the ambitious proposals in the report, among which country-by-country reporting, the creation of an inter-governmental body where developing countries participate equally in reforming the existing global tax system, and other things. In the light of the upcoming Addis Ababa conference, I look to further solutions that put tax justice into practice.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support, through a vote in favour, this report which aims to analyse the challenges faced by developing countries with regard to tax issues and tax governance, as well as the need for greater transparency and effectiveness in national and international tax systems.  I believe that, in the context of the discussions that should lead to a global agreement on the post-2015 development agenda, the fight against illicit financial flows in developing countries should receive greater attention.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on tax evasion in developing countries is a very important issue, especially in the light of the forthcoming UN Conference in Addis Ababa, and deserves full support. This is not only an effort to increase and streamline tax collection, but also methods of achieving these objectives in coordination with development aid. Development aid does not yet have a single commitment in the EU, but after unification it could become a very important means of leveraging developing country governments to give them a stronger incentive for effective and enforceable tax legislation. The question of human rights must not be neglected either. All development aid must be conditional on respect for generally accepted principles, such as the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to combat tax evasion and evasion, the European Parliament has taken the lead in proposing an initiative report on the fight against tax evasion in developing countries. The report was adopted by a large majority and proposes measures that offer greater transparency on European investment and the activities of European companies in third countries. I voted in favour of this report. However, I would like to stress that the measures that could be put in place should not carry too many financial and administrative burdens, at the risk of being ineffective. In particular, the country-by-country reporting mechanism would be too difficult to put in place.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as the need for an action plan to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion in developing countries, such as: strengthening financial and technical assistance to developing countries and regional tax administration frameworks, stands out; the adoption of sound solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax fraud; the development of an impact assessment at EU and Member State level on tax policies in developing countries; the preservation of the tax rights of the countries of origin in the negotiations on tax treaties and the establishment of a genuinely intergovernmental body in which developing countries can participate, on an equal footing, in the comprehensive reform of the tax rules in force at international level. Fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems should be imposed!

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In preparation for the Development Finance Conference in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from 13-16 July 2015, the European Parliament adopted an important and detailed report this afternoon to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. It is true that the lack of fair, effective and transparent tax systems is often glaring in developing countries. I think it is important that MEPs have insisted on the establishment of tax collection systems as an indispensable factor in achieving the post-2015 framework which will replace the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Another advantage of good governance in the area of taxation, it would allow many developing countries to overcome their long-term dependence on foreign aid and to follow suit in a logic where tax revenues would be reinvested in the consolidation of the state and public infrastructure. A new approach that will obviously require good European cooperation with the recipient countries, in terms of training sessions, expert missions or other forms of accompanying activities.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on combating tax evasion and illicit financial flows, which is essential to eradicate poverty and growing inequality in developing countries. Multinational companies must adopt a country-by-country reporting regime, which would require them to publicly report on their financial performance, the names of all subsidiaries, their tax data, assets and numbers. Information about ownership of a business should also be made public in order to prevent anonymous shell companies from participating in money laundering or the financing of illegal activities. We also call on EU financial institutions to ensure that EU-backed companies do not participate in tax evasion.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Better justice is essential in reducing social inequalities. Internal resources are the largest source of funding for developing countries. Although they have increased as a percentage of GDP over the last decade, the tax-to-GDP ratio is still very low. The European Parliament, through this report, calls on the Commission to present an action plan to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion by creating fairer and more transparent tax systems and, consequently, enhancing investment capacity and financing of infrastructure, public services, health and education.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have of course voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European Commission to present without delay an ambitious action plan on supporting developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and the establishment of fair, balanced, effective and transparent tax systems and which urges that information on the effective ownership of companies , trusts and other institutions are made public in open formats. The text also calls on the European Union and Member States to impose compliance with the principle that multinational companies in all countries and sectors, listed or not on the stock exchange, must make the publication of country-by-country information a standard and welcomes the adoption of an automatic exchange of information mechanism. Finally, the voted report calls for a global definition of tax havens and the establishment of sanctions for operators who use them and the development of a blacklist of countries.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Together with Mr Silva Pereira's report on Financing for Development, adopted in May 2015, this report is a "package" on the EP's position before the 3rd International Conference on Development Financing, to be held in Aldits Ababa in July 2015. Its main objective is to address the challenges faced by developing countries in relation to tax and tax governance matters, as well as the need for greater transparency and effectiveness of national and international tax systems. The added value of this report is, inter alia, the adoption of an automatic information exchange mechanism, the creation of an internationally agreed definition of tax havens, sanctions for operators making use of them and a blacklist of countries and the need for an action plan by the Commission that is ambitious in supporting developing countries , in the fight against tax evasion. The fact that this report was adopted unanimously reflects well the willforency in finding a solution to these tax crimes.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report 'Tax avoidance and evasion as challenges in developing countries'. On the whole, I agree with Therendt's position. Schlein, the rapporteur for the text, although I remain doubtful as to how certain rules are to be applied in the proposal, rules which, moreover, have no legal basis in EU legislation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report, as the report calls for an effective action plan to combat tax evasion and, in particular, tax evasion in developing countries: a plan that facilitates better mobilization of national resources for the sake of equitable and sustainable development. In addition, the report calls on the European Union and its Member States to ensure that, in fiscal and investment agreement negotiations with developing countries, income or benefits resulting from cross-border activities are taxed in the country of origin in which value is extracted or created, and urges the EU and Member States to exceed the OECD framework and ensure that the creation of a true intergovernmental body for tax issues within the United Nations.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to set out the objectives to be pursued in the area of tax evasion and the fight against icing in developing countries in the run-up to the Third Development Finance Conference in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The report calls for greater transparency and efficiency in national and international tax systems. The European Parliament invites the Commission to put together an ambitious action plan to achieve these objectives. I agree with the above objectives, so, in line with the position of the Group of the People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by considering positive the call for a concrete action plan to combat tax avoidance and evasion in impoverished countries, which would help to better redistribute and control resources by their governments.  Tax havens, banking secrecy and the designation of "tax-free zones" to supposedly attract foreign capital and investment are nefarious for achieving sustainable, inclusive and social justice-based development and respect for the sovereignty of peoples, which requires fair progressive tax systems to address inequality. While there are improveable aspects and the approach is not as ambitious as it should be, it is positive that it calls for the implementation of assessments of the impact of European fiscal policies on impoverished countries, noting the need to monitor, annually and country by country, the activities of multinationals and their possible direct or indirect contribution to tax avoidance and capital evasion.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP as a party does not condone tax evasion of any sort, but we also do not believe that this is the European Union’s responsibility to address. We believe that tax evasion in developing states should be an issue of compliance between Member States and international tax bodies.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome today’s resolution adopted by the European Parliament on tax evasion and tax avoidance as challenges in developing countries. I voted for the EU to do more to help developing countries clamp down on tax dodging, measures which will give governments resources to improve healthcare, sanitation and education. Today’s report calls on the European Commission to put forward an action plan on supporting developing countries in fighting tax avoidance and evasion and setting up fairer tax systems; financial and technical assistance to developing countries; enforce country-by-country reporting for multinationals; and ensure the UN taxation committee has teeth. Action on such tax dodging will help developing countries work to towards the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which aim to complete the task of the Millennium Development Goals and provide healthcare and education to all children.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. It is estimated that illegal financial flows stem from tax avoidance, corruption and aggressive tax avoidance cost developing countries almost USD 903 billion each year. This is significantly more than the funds allocated from the EU budget for development aid. This report contains a list of recommendations with a view to the forthcoming Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The report does not interfere with the competences of developing countries by regulatory a specific tax model, but merely stresses the importance of a 'fair, well-balanced, effective and transparent tax regime'.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax evasion is a very serious problem for all countries around the world. Although we have made some progress in this area, this topic is one of the key issues that also needs to be addressed in the EP. Many developing countries, where domestic resources are among their largest incomes, are currently facing serious political and administrative obstacles to obtaining tax revenues. However, I think that one of the reasons for tax evasion is the huge amount of money deposited abroad, as a result of which hundreds of billions of dollars are escaped from developing countries every year. Based on statistics, overall, in the world, tax evasion amounts to between $250 billion and $300 billion annually. I supported the resolution because I believe that only fair, balanced and transparent tax regimes in developing countries can help them combat illegal financial machinations and tax evasion. I agree with the opinion of the experts who say that if tax collection in developing countries were improved and the massive leakage of funds stopped, the governments of these states could use these funds for social projects, the development of health infrastructure, education and other public services that are vital for combating poverty.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the fiscal sphere, I support three fundamental approaches: fairness, fairness and transparency, as well as in the case of the Slovak Republic, the entire European Union and developing countries. I therefore support the call to combat tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the Report because most illicit financial flows stem from activities related to tax evasion. The 2014 Global Financial Integrity report shows that foreign direct investment and official development assistance between 2003 and 2012 together amount to slightly less than illicit outflows of money.  In developing countries, agreements are reached without transparency and clear guidance between governments and extractive companies. Taxation should be a reliable and sustainable source of income in developing countries if there is a balanced and effective taxation system, but also with an effective tax administration that will promote tax payments. Developing countries face obstacles of a political and administrative nature to increase tax revenues due to insufficient human and financial resources, corruption, lack of legitimacy of the political system, unequal distribution of revenues and mismanagement of taxes.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report sends an important message on the need to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries. We know that a small increase in tax revenues in developing countries would dwarf the amount of aid they receive. Domestic resources and international finance both form important pillars of the new global development framework after 2015. It is vital multinational companies pay their fair share of tax in developing countries.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it does not bring any new regulatory obligations to developing countries or increase expenditure, but mainly provides technical assistance to these countries.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax evasion and avoidance as challenges for governance, social protection and development in developing countries. Support for developing countries needs to be strengthened. However, in doing so, we need to find out what the real needs of the countries are and analyse the causes of all these problems. It's not enough of a financial aid, because we haven't done anything if it doesn't get into the right hands. I welcome the Commission's call to present an ambitious action plan as soon as possible in order to support developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance and to help them establish fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Calls on the Member States to quickly reach an agreement on a common consolidated corporate tax base.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance and fraud as a challenge for the governance, social protection and development of developing countries. The fight against tax fraud and avoidance is also challenging in the European Union. The report detailed the significant political, administrative and technical constraints that developing countries face in increasing tax revenues. In order to reverse this trend, I support the Commission's proposal for an action plan as soon as possible to support developing countries in the fight against tax fraud and tax avoidance and in the creation of balanced and transparent tax systems. At the same time, I stress that we should focus even more on the problem of tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and tax evasion within the EU, establishing an exemplary system for developing countries. Failure to do so risks discrediting the Union.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the most important source of aid for the development of the world's poor countries.
