This stems from the principle of solidarity, which underpins the founding of the Union and which is also applied in its relations with developing countries. However, development aid often does not meet its target because of the incoherence of the tax system in these countries, which stimulates the underground economy, corruption, tax evasion, organised crime. Some states don't even have tax systems, representing tax havens for laundering black money from developed economies or exploiting their mining resources. The legitimacy of their governments is very fragile because they do not fulfil this side of the social contract, which should bind them to their citizens and which translates into the use of public funds to provide public goods and services. In these circumstances, the European Union, which has more experience in this area, can help combat tax evasion in developing countries. This measure would contribute both to the sustainable development of those countries and to the fight against negative phenomena, which feed on the lack of the tax system, such as terrorism, piracy and the illegal trafficking of goods and people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Given the importance of better mobilization of domestic resources and the challenges facing developing countries in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, a list of recommendations that Parliament should support is needed, in view of the International Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa and in light of the range of international initiatives that exist to reform the global tax system.  These include: strengthening financial and technical assistance to developing countries and regional tax administrative frameworks; adopt solutions to improve transparency and cooperation in the fight against tax evasion, such as an automatic mechanism for exchanging information and publishing country-by-country information, taking into account the needs and constraints of developing countries; conduct a study at EU and Member State level on the impact of tax policies on developing countries. The tax rights of the source countries must be preserved in the negotiation of tax treaties and a truly intergovernmental body must be created in which developing countries can participate equally in the comprehensive reform of existing international tax rules.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on tax avoidance and tax evasion in developing countries. It is essential that we support those countries in implementing the OECD standard on automatic exchange of information. It is of utmost important that they receive this tax information from more advanced countries so that they can detect and correct abusive tax practices.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The issue of tax evasion is of particular importance to developing countries: illicit financial flows represent a loss of resources far greater than the aid received to eradicate poverty. The Schlein initiative report identifies two aspects of the European Union's support for developing countries to combat tax evasion. The Union would have a first lever: to ensure the tax exemplarity of its companies. The report calls on the relevant institutions (EIB, EBRD, etc.) to ensure that companies supported by their support do not participate in tax evasion. The report also calls on the Commission to require multinationals operating in Europe and developing countries to publish an information report, country by country. A second means of action would be to mobilise member states: for example, no cooperation agreement should be signed without the concept of good governance; a weak democracy fuels tax evasion and increases the burden on the poorest.  It is essential that the Union, to the extent of its capacity, help developing countries to establish better governance at the fiscal level; that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The year 2015 is the year of development and various initiatives, throughout the European Union and in third countries, are taking place to establish the new goals for sustainable development. All ambitious targets set at national, European and international level will only be achieved through adequate funding and more efficient use of resources; It is therefore essential that Parliament too, with this report, reiterates that fair taxation and the fight against tax evasion and avoidance are fundamental. The illicit financial flows out of developing countries, according to some estimates, amount to around a thousand billion every year, figures which, if confirmed, are worrying because they are resources taken away from essential services for many citizens.  The adoption of this report is a first step towards supporting concrete initiatives. We call for an action plan to support developing countries in creating stronger and fairer tax systems, providing financial and technical assistance, which is still insufficient, and ensuring that developing countries participate on an equal footing in the reform of the global tax system.  We must reiterate that we are at the forefront of the fight against evasion, otherwise we will not be able to maintain our commitment to eliminate poverty and inequality.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Together with the Pereira report (on financing for development from May 2015), this report forms a package on the European Parliament's position ahead of the third international conference on financing for development to be held in July 2015. The reports aim to address the challenges faced by developing countries in tax matters and tax governance, as well as the need for greater transparency and efficiency in national and international tax systems. As tax evasion and tax avoidance pose a problem facing all countries and can have negative consequences for the national budget, employment, productivity, working conditions and so on, I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report, as the report calls for an effective action plan to combat tax evasion and, in particular, tax evasion in developing countries: a plan that facilitates better mobilization of national resources for the sake of equitable and sustainable development. In addition, the report calls on the European Union and its Member States to ensure that, in fiscal and investment agreement negotiations with developing countries, income or benefits resulting from cross-border activities are taxed in the country of origin in which value is extracted or created, and urges the EU and Member States to exceed the OECD framework and ensure that the creation of a true intergovernmental body for tax issues within the United Nations.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, as I think it is very important for developing countries to be able to build a solid tax base that allows them to create a stronger and efficient state. In this sense, fighting against tax avoidance and tax evasion is fundamental.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report, as the report calls for an effective action plan to combat tax evasion and, in particular, tax evasion in developing countries: a plan that facilitates better mobilization of national resources for the sake of equitable and sustainable development. In addition, the report calls on the European Union and its Member States to ensure that, in fiscal and investment agreement negotiations with developing countries, income or benefits resulting from cross-border activities are taxed in the country of origin in which value is extracted or created, and urges the EU and Member States to exceed the OECD framework and ensure that the creation of a true intergovernmental body for tax issues within the United Nations.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Third International Conference on Financing for Development will be held in Addis Ababa (Ethiopia) from 13 to 16 July 2015. It should constitute an important contribution to and support the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Considering that revenue mobilization of domestic resources in developing countries represents another key issue at stake to implement SDGs, this specific and complementary report fixes the EP position on the Addis Ababa conference.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to promptly develop an action plan to support developing countries in fighting tax evasion and tax avoidance and to help them set up fair, well-balanced, efficient and transparent tax systems. The report furthermore calls on the EU to increase its assistance to developing countries in support of the aim of taxing adequately the extraction of natural resources. Another key aspect of the report is that it calls on the EU and its Member States to enforce the principle that listed or unlisted multinational companies of all countries and sectors, and especially those companies extracting natural resources, must adopt country-by-country reporting (CBCR) as a standard, requiring them to publish, as part of their annual reporting and on a country-by-country basis for each territory in which they operate, the names of all subsidiaries and their respective financial performance, relevant tax information, assets and number of employees, and to ensure that this information is made publicly available.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report is one of the parts of the position that the European Parliament will defend at the Third International Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa in July 2015. We are talking about a report which contains important recommendations for the European Commission and the Member States for that conference and which has had unanimous support in the Committee on Development, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of more national and international responsibility in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as against corruption, which in developing countries annually accounts for one trillion dollars less for the fight against poverty. The EU must lead by example, fighting tax havens and corruption and imposing sanctions on companies that make non-transparent contracts in third countries, as well as prioritizing financial and technical assistance for the creation of national and local tax administrations in developing countries. Our support for the mobilization of national resources in the countries most in need is key to them overcoming their dependence on foreign aid and reducing their rates of poverty and inequality.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it sends an important message on the need to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries. We know that a small increase in tax revenues in developing countries would dwarf the amount of aid they receive. Domestic resources and international finance both form important pillars of the new global development framework after 2015. It is vital that multinational companies pay their fair share of tax in developing countries.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report addresses issues of tax evasion and evasion in third countries as well as opaque tax haven-type territories.  It is a criticism of tax-free regimes that attract capital that should have been taxed in other countries and generate ferocious tax dumping. This report contains a good analysis of a system that allows banking and financial information to remain private The report therefore calls for a comprehensive action plan in the fight against tax evasion in developing countries with measures such as the generalisation of the tax treaty model developed under the auspices of the UN, the strengthening of financial and technical assistance to developing countries , the adoption of automatic information-sharing mechanisms and the creation of an international body to promote comprehensive reform of existing international tax rules.  This does not go very far and one might want to say that the EU Member States could start by sweeping their doors. Nevertheless, I voted in favour, considering that beyond the list of good intentions, this was a good way.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report states that a fair, balanced, efficient and transparent tax regime and an effective and efficient tax authority need to promote compliance with tax obligations and responsible use of public finances. It recognises that, in the face of the administrative and technical political constraints faced by developing countries in order to increase tax revenues, EU Member States should support these countries in training the frameworks of their tax authorities. It recognises the urgency of making public and free access all information on the effective ownership of companies, funds and other institutions in order to combat money laundering, the financing of illegal or terrorist activities, concealing the theft of public funds and the profits of illegal trafficking and tax evasion. We recognize very positive elements.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this scheme as the impact can help to improve the situation in developing countries in a sustainable way. It would therefore also be a prevention for European companies wishing to be established in these countries. However, the additional revenue generated by each country should be earmarked.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the resolution on 'Tax avoidance and tax evasion as challenges to governance, social protection and development in developing countries'. The report should touch on supposed tax problems in developing countries. However, it serves as a pretext for criticising the tax policies of developed countries. On my group, I was shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. None of my suggestions for a sound tax policy was included in the opinion. Both the committee and Parliament are wrong to believe that tax competition has a detrimental effect on developing countries and want to restrict it. The opposite is true: tax competition restricts the access of the state and thus secures property rights. Safe and stable property rights that remain untouched by the state are the be-all and end-all of economic growth. A state that makes it difficult for entrepreneurs to plan the economy through erratic tax rules prevents small and medium-sized enterprises from flourishing in particular. They cannot afford tax advisers.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  This report sends an important message on the need to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance in developing countries. We know that a small increase in tax revenues in developing countries would dwarf the amount of aid they receive. Domestic resources and international finance both form important pillars of the new global development framework after 2015. It is vital that multinational companies pay their fair share of tax in developing countries. In the European Year for Development, Labour MEPs continue to show their commitment to the fight against extreme poverty and inequality. We should promote fair taxes abroad as we do at home.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the fight against tax havens and tax evasion in developing countries, because taxes should be paid where profits are generated. However, the proposed report is unacceptable given the reference to the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base, which is a risky step towards a single EU tax policy, which will undermine tax competition within the EU and impose huge ancillary costs of taxation on businesses, in particular SMEs.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report considers that taxation is a sustainable and reliable source of revenue in developing countries, with the advantage of stability compared to traditional development financing mechanisms. Given the political, technical and administrative constraints faced by developing countries to increase tax revenues, the report considers that EU Member States should support these countries in training their tax authorities' frameworks. This is the point with which we agree, despite the need to respect the sovereignty and legitimate choices of these countries in the field of taxation – an area that goes to the heart of state sovereignty. All attempts to condition countries' options in this area, which are often insinuated under the cover of technical cooperation, must be firmly rejected. The report also advocates measures to combat money laundering, the financing of illegal or terrorist activities and tax evasion – common practices, often involving multinationals, that so much harm these countries. The report also addresses the problem of tax havens in a generally correct way – at the level of the recognised negative impacts of them – although insufficient. Disagreeing with one point or another, we generally agree with the content of the report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur I wanted to say that I voted in favour because, colleagues, we must avoid the 'take, make, consume and discard' principle. With the circular economy, we will save resources, create new jobs, support the introduction of new technologies. This is very important, and I therefore support the objectives recorded in this strategic report, in my view. I think that the target of increasing resource efficiency by 30% by 2030 is realistic and achievable. The goal is set, and now, colleagues, start realizing it. Thank you!

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the report, because resource efficiency offers an opportunity for the European Union to get more for less. Through better use of our raw materials and energy, we can reduce our carbon footprint and lower our consumption of finite resources. By developing more durable and reparable products, we can have goods that have a longer lifespan and end planned obsolescence. By improving the design of products, we can make our recycling more efficient, thereby reducing waste in landfills. At the same time, we will be strengthening our economy and creating the millions of decent jobs that we urgently need in regions like my own. Resource efficiency is a chance we simply cannot afford to miss, and today’s report is an important step towards creating an effective policy framework to deliver it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, my colleagues in the PPE from Ireland voted in favour of this report, because we think it is a very important one. There are many exceptionally good elements in it. It is estimated that a properly-functioning circular economy could create anything up to two million jobs and be worth EUR 250 billion to 465 billion to the economy. Obviously, apart from the economic benefits, there are the environmental benefits. We have just talked about waste. The word waste means that you are wasting something. Obviously the less waste we have, the more use we make of our resources and the more efficient we are. Obviously it costs less. This is a very good proposal. I think we should try to follow it through and give the lead, particularly in Europe, on how this can be done. But the final point is that we must do so without putting too many burdens on SMEs. I think we can do that in a practical manner.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is a major step forward in the consideration and treatment of waste as resources for the European economy. This proposal is fundamental to the reshaping of the European economy, seeks to boost an activity based on greater sustainability of the economy, and even seeks sanctions for cases of programmed obsolescence. Tackling the debate on waste generation and its management is necessary to put an end to the environmental madness of capitalist industrial development in European countries. Since the report puts this issue on the table so forcefully and broadly, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the circular economy and I am pleased that the majority of the European Parliament has as well, especially in light of the Commission’s decision to withdraw the waste proposal earlier this year. This vote by Parliament will hopefully put pressure on the Commission to come forward with an ambitious proposal by the end of this year. Whilst I would have preferred to see a mandatory 30% target for overall resource use in the EU instead of a temporary one, overall this report sends out an ambitious signal to the European Commission. The Commission must now seize the opportunity to build upon the Parliament’s recommendations and come forward with legislation which is stronger than their original proposals. It is essential that we end our overconsumption of natural resources now. Any such move will not only benefit our environment but also contribute to significant cost-savings whilst creating an estimated 2 million new jobs by 2050.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The global economy uses resources equivalent to one and a half times the value of the planet's resources for global production and waste absorption. It is estimated that this amount will rise in the 1930s to a level that makes up the resources of two planets. Europe is more dependent on imported resources than any other region in the world, and many resources would be depleted in a relatively short period of time. I welcome this report because it highlights, among other things, this problem and, in addition, the fact that improving the use of resources could bring significant net savings to businesses, public authorities and consumers in the Union, estimated at EUR 600 billion, or 8% of annual turnover, while at the same time reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2-4%. Moreover, increasing resource productivity by 30% by 2030 could lead to GDP growth of almost 1% and 2 million additional permanent jobs. Resource efficiency therefore remains one of the most important components of sustainable living.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The principles and beliefs behind this report appear to be rather positive. The increase in pollution must provoke a reflection on our way of life and consumption. The proposals put forward in this report aim to influence the Commission's work by the end of 2015. These include incentives to move towards a policy of "eco-design" of products and towards "zero waste", thus developing the recycling of these products. The report wants to impose very restrictive standards on new buildings and would like to start a plan to renovate the existing building.  These demands do not address the main cause of materialistic liberal ideology and its cult of infinite growth. This report is ultimately akin to a quitus given to the Commission to enact new unnecessary requirements. So I objected.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this is an own-initiative report, it proposes changes to the EU Waste Directive and for further EU legislation. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Union to set ambitious targets for the efficient use of resources and to leave a wide range of possible options for innovative economic models and policy choices.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported Sirpa Pietik-inen's initiative report on the transition to the circular economy, because we need to develop a new model of consumption to preserve natural resources and improve the quality of life.  This requires binding targets to reduce waste, increase product sustainability, promote eco-design, and create a mandatory European passport to facilitate product monitoring, repair and recycling. I voted for this report because Parliament must remind the Commission of the need to present a new 'more ambitious' strategy on the circular economy before the end of 2015.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Unsustainable use of resources causes environmental damage and economic risks. The amount of resources used by the global economy for global production and waste absorption corresponds to 1.5 planetary resources. By 2030, this figure is expected to reach the resources of the two planets. Annual consumption of mineral raw materials, fossil fuels and biomass is projected to double by 2050, reaching EUR 140 million. Tons. This is due to population growth, the possibility of higher incomes, greater product diversity than before, and a shorter life cycle of products. We need to use fewer resources to avoid these changes in our biosphere. We can and must achieve at least the same level of living and well-being as it is now, using a tenth of the resources currently in use. By decoupling economic growth from resource use alone, we can increase our competitiveness, reindustrialise Europe and improve our standard of living. Better resource efficiency would benefit our economy and security. More efficient use of resources would reduce resource dependency and save costs on raw materials.  In addition, new business activities and jobs would be created in Europe. According to the European Commission's estimates, an annual increase in resource efficiency by 2% would create 2 million jobs in the EU by 2030. new jobs.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to achieve a viable circular economy, which I would like to call for, we should start by promoting short circuits, labour and production at home and thus limiting international trade by relocating our economies. In short, quite the opposite of what the free-trade technocrats in Brussels are promoting.  That is why I voted against this text which, taking the problem upside down, does not deal with the real issues. This text seems to me to be both derisory and harmful, since it is only a blank cheque to the Commission to enact new unsuccessful demands for Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report in favour of the transition to the circular economy. This approach is, of course, based on a model that favours sustainable investments. The Commission must quickly submit ambitious proposals on the circular economy in order to limit the environmental impact of the extraction, processing, production, use and removal of raw materials. Sustainable waste management incorporating recycling methods is also essential.  On the other hand, I am obviously very much in favour of the provision to ask the Commission to set targets for the reduction of food waste. The donation of unsold food must make significant progress within the Union and the Commission must create a favourable context in this regard. I will continue to take initiatives in this context in the wake of my work as a Walloon Mp.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the transition to the circular economy is an initiative report by Parliament, in which it makes the Commission aware of the nature of the proposals it must make by the end of 2015. The circular economy aims to produce goods and services while severely limiting the consumption and waste of raw materials and non-renewable energy sources.  If the development of the circular economy like everything related (green economy, conversion, etc.) is a good idea, this model is the opposite of that of the EU. It is a globalist and free-trade model that favours sustained growth, often in defiance of environmental, fiscal or social standards. The circular economy that is based on short circuits, local preference and local production by avoiding imports too far away to contain pollution has nothing to do with our model, but it is a form of economy that we should support without going into imposing excessive standards as is the case here for the building. I therefore voted against this report, which should allow the Commission to legislate on this point instead of the States.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Pietikäinen report, which analyses the efficiency of resources as part of a transition to a circular economy, is unbalanced and I believe that there are critical aspects in many of its crucial passages, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In July 2014, the Commission presented its communication 'Towards a circular economy: a zero waste programme for Europe', which contained ideas to contribute, through existing legislation and new initiatives, to creating a circular economy by optimizing all the life processes of a product and minimizing waste. This initiative report, which has earned my vote in favour, sets out a first position by Parliament on the priorities to be set to move towards this circular economy, namely the need to set mandatory targets for the reduction of different types of waste (2025), a specific target for organic waste (2020), the gradual reduction of waste dumping, the adoption of the principle of cascading use mainly for biomass , increasing recycling and reuse targets to at least 70% for RSU and 80% for packaging (2030), strict incineration limitation by 2020, a target of 50% reduction of marine litter by 2025, a binding target of 30% resource efficiency by 2025 and the strengthening of ecodesign measures in all types of products.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because unsustainable use of resources causes environmental damage and economic risks.  The amount of resources used by the global economy for global production and waste absorption corresponds to 1.5 planetary resources. By 2030, this figure is expected to reach the resources of the two planets. Annual consumption of mineral raw materials, fossil fuels and biomass is projected to double by 2050, reaching EUR 140 million. Tons. This is due to population growth, the possibility of higher incomes, greater product diversity than before, and a shorter life cycle of products. If this trend persists, we will find ourselves in an ecological and economic impasse. The negative ecological consequences are of a very diverse nature and are in many cases irreversible: climate change, deforestation, desertification, soil erosion, biodiversity loss, loss of genetic diversity and weakening of ecosystem services. We need to use fewer resources to avoid these changes in our biosphere. We can and must achieve at least the same level of living and well-being as it is now, using a tenth of the resources currently in use. By decoupling economic growth from resource use alone, we can increase our competitiveness, reindustrialise Europe and improve our standard of living. Better resource efficiency would benefit our economy and security.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased to have been able to support the report on the circular economy, the main purpose of which is to develop a strategy for the efficient and sustainable use of natural resources. I am also pleased with the views of Mr Timmermans and Mr Katainna, two Vice-Presidents of the European Commission, who are working on an ambitious plan on a circular economy – on the road to a waste-free Europe. Europe is the continent that is most ambitious about environmental objectives. We have the highest standards in the field of environmental protection and human health. We must use these standards as a competitive advantage. One of the key areas of the circular economy is resource saving, recycling and reuse. In adopting this method of resource management, it is very important to involve local and regional authorities in it, because without their active role there will be no results. Real life takes place between people on the ground. It is also important that young people are involved in understanding the circular economy. The education system must contribute to spreading awareness of the importance of saving resources. I also see new opportunities for new jobs, for innovation in the circular economy. Energy saving and efficiency is also important, which is one of the EU's key objectives.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The circular economy is the new economic model that Europe must commit itself to in the coming years. Its fulfilment presents us with obstacles and challenges that will, however, have to be faced with confidence and determination in order to create a new system that can offer benefits to all.  The European Commission and the Ellen MacArthur Foundation estimate that more than 2 million new jobs could be created, and that businesses could save between EUR 250 billion and EUR 465 billion per year. In addition, human health, ecosystems and biodiversity would benefit. The report before us sets ambitious targets such as increasing resource efficiency (30% more by 2030) and higher waste recycling targets (70% of municipal solid waste and 80% of packaging materials). As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I wholeheartedly support the text we have voted on today, which is a first step in this complex but essential transition process.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the circular economy, because I believe that the work done is a step in the right direction, although in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy (ENVI) no major amendments have been passed concerning, for example, the ban on incineration and the introduction of mandatory national plans on waste management.  The text as a whole represents an ambitious package and a good starting point for the European Commission to provide a serious legislative proposal that will allow, in the long term, the adoption of an alternative economic model to the utilitarian model. The final text approved by Parliament unequivocally calls on the European Commission to formulate a proposal that can replace the current model of development based on unlimited growth, while knowing that resources are limited, and that it can initiate the process of transition to a circular economy, based on sustainable consumption.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report because the implementation of the circular economy can contribute to addressing key European Union programming challenges such as job creation, smart reuse of resources and reindustrialisation. The report contains a number of key proposals such as binding targets to reduce commercial and industrial waste by 2025, mandatory separation of biological waste by 2020, mandatory reduction of all landfills and the like.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the circular economy and am pleased that the majority of the European Parliament has as well, especially in light of the Commission’s decision to withdraw the waste proposal earlier this year. This vote by Parliament will hopefully put pressure on the Commission to come forward with an ambitious proposal by the end of this year. Whilst I would have preferred to see a mandatory 30% target for overall resource use in the EU instead of a temporary one, overall this report sends out an ambitious signal to the European Commission. The Commission must now seize the opportunity to build upon the Parliament’s recommendations and come forward with legislation which is stronger than their original proposals. It is essential that we end our overconsumption of natural resources now. Any such move will not only benefit our environment but also contribute to significant cost-savings whilst creating an estimated 2 million new jobs by 2050.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the transformation of our economic system into a circular economy system would bring enormous benefits to the Union both in environmental terms and in economic and employment terms, allowing a clear reduction in CO2 emissions and the creation of a large number of new jobs.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Raising targets in existing waste treatment directives is useful for accelerating the transition to the circular economic model. In the circular economy there is no waste: waste is no longer a simple waste but becomes a resource. Raw materials are no longer extracted, used once and thrown away. With the circular economy, waste disappears through reuse, repair and recycling applied at every stage of the commercial chain.  Prolonging the productive use of materials, reusing them and increasing their efficiency is useful not only in addressing waste management issues from a perspective other than that of the emergency, but also in strengthening the EU's competitiveness on the world stage.  The effects of this attitude on the real European economy are positive because research and innovation, fundamental to the success of the plan, are closely linked to green economy investments in the territory: a positive synergy is therefore created in which not only is what until yesterday a problem turned into a resource, with obvious environmental and economic savings benefits. , but it also encourages the development of highly specialised jobs in territorial SMEs in the sector, improving European competitiveness in an innovative and environmentally sustainable way.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's initiative report calls on the Commission to formulate proposals on the circular economy. This is a series of measures aimed at moving towards the eco-design of products and the "zero waste". In addition, the report calls on the Commission to impose very restrictive energy consumption standards in buildings to be renovated and in new buildings. If a long-term policy that respects the environment is to be undertaken, it is unthinkable to increase the burden of environmental standards without any consideration for the players in the economy. The success of a viable circular economy is inseparable from the establishment of intelligent protectionism at least at European level and the promotion of short-producer-consumer circuits.  In the absence of these two conditions, this new legal arsenal will only harm the competitiveness of our businesses and once again encourage imports from countries that do not meet any basic social and environmental standards. This text, which is derisory for the environment and harmful to our businesses, must be combated. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Resource efficiency is an extremely important issue in the current European and international context. Europe depends on imported resources more than any other region in the world, as more than 40% of all materials used in the EU come from imports. Increasing the efficiency of resource use by using them more coherently would reduce the level of dependence, both in terms of costs and in terms of human security. According to European Commission estimates, an annual 2% increase in resource productivity by 2030 would create two million new jobs in the EU. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we can increase Europe's competitiveness and reindustrialisation and strengthen living standards only by decoupling economic growth from the use of resources, thus making the transition to a more circular economy.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The concept of the circular economy, like other similar ones (such as "cradle to cradle", industrial ecology and natural capitalism), suggests, through innovation, the development on an industrial scale of strategies aimed at an absolute decoupling between the physical growth of throughput and the non-physical (financial) growth of GDP (the so-called "green growth" or "sustainable growth"). The main current of the sustainable development movement is based on the deep conviction that, with the right technological innovations, economic growth and environmental protection can be complementary rather than conflicting; however, this view ignores, misrepresents or underestimates the biophysical limits to human production and consumption traced by system dynamics and thermodynamics. Finally, it should be noted that a constant process of efficiency in the use of resources thanks to innovation has been in place since the beginning of the Modern Age at least, but that this relative decoupling has not prevented the neutralisation of the overall growth in the production and consumption of raw materials; there is a risk that a sharp increase in relative decoupling could, by virtue of the Jevons paradox, lead, on the contrary, to an intensification of the exploitation of raw materials, made less expensive by the acceleration of the movement of capital brought about by the reduction in the unit cost of production obtained thanks to the most efficient technologies.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe depends on imported resources more than any other region in the world, and a transaction towards a circular economy would reduce this level of dependence on raw materials resources and costs. In addition, new businesses and jobs would be created in Europe, all of which would be a way of increasing resource efficiency. Financial statements, accounting rules and integrated reporting should take better account of systemic risks caused by environmental degradation, overuse of resources and the lack of measures involved in short-term market trends, and therefore a new and clear policy framework is needed to enable private and institutional investors to steer their investment paradigm towards sustainable investment. I voted in favour of the report, as current policies do not sufficiently focus efforts on this paradigm shift, blocking Europe in a system where valuable materials, many of them with high environmental and social costs, end up in landfills or are incinerated.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on resource efficiency and the transition to the circular economy. It is very important that we make progress on environmental protection and recycling in Europe. However, we must understand that our economy is in crisis and that some restrictive measures can stifle our businesses. Remaining competitive in the global economy and respecting the environment are two compatible objectives, between which a balance must be struck to be as effective as possible. In this report, I also supported the proposal to encourage the creation in the Member States of conventions whererability for the retail food trade sector to distribute products not sold to charities. This is a provision already planned in France and which will have to be applied throughout Europe to combat food waste.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on resource efficiency today. With the text adopted, the European Parliament is pushing for the modification of the economic model to which we have become accustomed, namely the one based on 'take, produce and throw'. Change can be made, and the request to the Commission to set binding targets this year to increase resource efficiency by 30% by 2030 compared to the situation in 2014 shows that Parliament has high expectations of the action of the European executive.  The reference to the proposal announced by the Commission on the revision of waste legislation is fundamental: the Commission must feel obliged to present it by 2015, including clear and unequivocal definitions, the development of waste prevention measures, the application of the 'pay how much you throw' principle and the strict limitation of incinerators. I hope that the Commission will be able to grasp these inputs and will be able to push The Member States towards a paradigm shift leading to an economic system in which the materials and energy used to manufacture the products maintain their value for as long as possible, thereby reducing waste and the use of resources and at the same time creating economic opportunities and competitive advantages on a sustainable basis.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the circular economy and am pleased that the majority of the European Parliament has as well, especially in light of the Commission’s decision to withdraw the waste proposal earlier this year. This vote by Parliament will hopefully put pressure on the Commission to come forward with an ambitious proposal by the end of this year. Whilst I would have preferred to see a mandatory 30% target for overall resource use in the EU instead of a temporary one, overall this report sets out an ambitious signal to the European Commission. The Commission must now seize the opportunity to build upon the Parliament’s recommendations and come forward with legislation which is stronger than their original proposals. It is essential that we end our overconsumption of natural resources now. Any such move will not only benefit our environment but also contribute to significant cost-savings whilst creating an estimated 2 million new jobs by 2050.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this is an own-initiative report, it proposes changes to the EU Waste Directive and for further EU legislation. I therefore voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I am not in favour of an increase in binding and more ambitious waste targets. I believe that the right way forward should rather be to improve the implementation of the current legislation rather than proposing new targets. I believe that changing the proposed legally binding target of 30% ‘resource productivity’ by 2030 to become voluntary among Member States was a good way forward.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleague's report indicates to the Commission actions to be included in the proposal that the Commission itself is preparing on the circular economy and the revision of European waste legislation.  The own-initiative report is ambitious and highlights that the unsustainable use of resources is causing enormous environmental damage and represents, at the same time, an important economic risk. More efficient use of resources is therefore absolutely necessary. In addition, it could be a significant source of employment in Europe. I voted strongly in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which deals with the transition to a circular economy consisting of decoupling economic growth from the use of resources. If the stated objective seems legitimate, the initiative report calls on the Commission above all to take very restrictive measures for The Member States, in particular in the adoption of extremely restrictive standards for buildings. While it is to be welcomed that parliamentarians are developing a certain conservatism in the direction of reducing waste and preserving our ecosystem, it is clear that these proposals and this will make no sense in a European Union cemented by globalist ideology, which does not allow for the development of short production circuits in a way that reduces pollutants.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic development based on the linear growth model is no longer sustainable or viable, not only because of the scarcity of available raw materials but also because of the amount of waste that this type of system, based on "take, produce, disposable" generated. A reversal of the trend is therefore inevitable to trigger a new process that considers waste as a resource to be reused in the production cycle. There are around 600 million tonnes of waste in Europe with the potential for reuse, and if we want to build an economic system based on sustainable growth and efficient use of resources, we must necessarily encourage the reuse and recycling of products. The transition to a circular economy will entail the need to redesign a new production model which will give a strong boost not only in terms of technology, but also in terms of the organization of society, financing methods and policies. New targets and targets for waste recycling must therefore be identified. We therefore hope that the Commission will soon present an ambitious package of circular economy measures necessary to stimulate growth and safeguard the environment. For these reasons, I voted in favour of

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the strategic initiative report on the circular economy. This text contains a number of proposals aimed at ensuring a more efficient use of resources and minimising the volume of waste. Among the main points: (1) binding targets of 30% and the creation of indicators for resource efficiency; (2) the revision of the Eco-Design Directive; and (3) the introduction of a tax on landfills and incinerators.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that this report adequately encourages more efficient use of resources and contains sound proposals to steer the economy towards a necessary reduction in the volume of waste. Given that Europe still imports most of the energy it consumes from third countries, I believe that in order to move towards greater energy independence, it is necessary to promote a more efficient use of resources. This process will bring greater environmental, social and economic benefits.  If we want to reverse the trend towards unsustainable waste and if we want to avoid causing irreversible damage to the environment, it will be important to identify where the weaknesses of our production system are and to try to find appropriate solutions. As the report states, investing in the circular economy is not economically counterproductive but rather, in the long term, investments of this kind will lead to an increase in savings, which must be added to the possibility of reducing unemployment levels and creating new business opportunities. European companies will therefore increase their competitiveness, their profits and will be the key to the process leading to the circular economy. It will therefore be important to establish common rules and effective implementation mechanisms in such a way as to ensure a transition to greater sustainability of the European economy, in all its Member States.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mrs Pietikäinen's report on the circular economy. This is a policy-making document addressed to the European Commission and not to a legislative text. This justifies a number of ambitious proposals leading the Commission to maintain the EU's leadership in matters relating to waste management, energy efficiency and green growth. I am sympathetic to the rapporteur in the proposal to set binding targets and I regret that this has not been accompanied by a majority of the European Parliament.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important to anchor a functioning circular economy across Europe, enabling future generations to use raw materials from primary and secondary sources in a sustainable and efficient manner. That is why I voted in favour of this own-initiative report. I am in favour of the circular economy factors being integrated into many areas of our daily lives. We must be ambitious, albeit realistic!  The measures to be taken must not lead to over-standardisation and the introduction of disproportionate mandatory requirements, which would be too burdensome, especially for our small and medium-sized enterprises. Against this background, the motion for a resolution is unfortunately not balanced. I do not think it is appropriate at this stage to revise the Eco-Design Regulation. I am also opposed to the inclusion of environmental risks in ratings and capital requirements for banks. That is why we, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, have requested separate and separate votes on these passages, and I voted against it! As a result, I am pleased that the PPE-DE amendments on measures in the construction and renovation sector have been adopted.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Pietikäinen's report, which draws attention to the need to address the global challenge of depletion of resources, and the EU – as we know – is very dependent on imported resources, more than any region in the world. Unfortunately, unsustainable use of resources entails serious risks such as climate change, desertification, deforestation and the loss of biodiversity. To overcome this, it is necessary to design a policy framework to support resource efficiency combined with ambitious environmental objectives and strict rules. Firstly, it is essential: to stop the continuous extraction of raw materials, such as water, which is used not only during the production cycle but also as a public good; increase the life cycle of products, their suitability in terms of durability, reuse and recycling; review waste legislation, seeking to combat the illegal export of post-consumer waste and formulating clear targets for collection and recycling; develop a strategic framework related to resource efficiency in buildings as well as indicators, standards, methods and quality requirements for spatial and urban planning; last but not least, to train a skilled workforce that takes account of ecological skills needs.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is a major step forward in the consideration and treatment of waste as resources for the European economy. This proposal is fundamental to the reshaping of the European economy, seeks to boost an activity based on greater sustainability of the economy, and even seeks sanctions for cases of programmed obsolescence. Tackling the debate on waste generation and its management is necessary to put an end to the environmental madness of capitalist industrial development in European countries. Since the report puts this issue on the table so forcefully and broadly, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the circular economy model, drawn up by this report, existing materials and products are continuously re-used, repaired, re-furbished and recycled, and thus the waste quantities are minimised. Moving towards a circular economy is essential to deliver on the EU’s resource efficiency agenda, which can also bring major economic benefits to Europe. It must be highlighted that resource efficiency is a solution to the economic and ecological challenges that Europe is struggling with. Moving to a more resource-efficient economy is a major opportunity for the EU that must not be missed. Producers and the business community have a tremendous role to play, with an increasing number of companies recognising the business case for improved resource efficiency as a way of giving their businesses and the EU as a whole a unique competitive advantage. I vote in favour of this report, because what we need in Europe is a more circular economy, where all resources are managed more efficiently throughout their life cycle, taking note of the fact that using resources more efficiently would reduce European resource dependency, would bring savings in material costs, would generate new business activity, and would create new jobs in our Member States.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This strategic report follows the withdrawal and preparation by the European Commission of a new circular economy package to support the gradual transition of our economies to more efficient use of resources, including the reduction of waste production and increased collection and recycling targets. This text also proposes to put in place indicators to measure the effectiveness of the resources of our economies. I support this approach, which I think is necessary. However, if the targets are ambitious, it will be necessary to ensure that the Commission's new proposals are realistic and do not have a negative impact on the position of our European companies subject to global competition. Finally, I welcome the adoption of an amendment, tabled by the French delegation, in favour of combating food waste by setting up agreements between supermarkets and food aid associations so that they can benefit from the unsold goods.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resource efficiency report because I believe we have to make a change in the way we use our resources. As I also wrote in my report on green growth opportunities for SMEs, making the transition to a more efficient economy can lead to advantages for our businesses, in addition to the large environmental benefits that it will bring.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. \u2012 The SP is in favour of an economy in which as much waste as possible is reused. But that is not a task that Brussels must impose on us, that is a responsibility of the countries themselves.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report calls for the introduction of circular economy systems that retain value added in products for as long as possible and thus eliminate excessive waste production. It is estimated that prevention, eco-design, re-employment and similar measures could save EU businesses some EUR 600 billion, or 8% of their annual turnover.  Innovation in this new "recycling" is essential for intelligent use of resources.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which sends good signals to the Commission. However, we must remain cautious. Always wanting to lead by example, we risk shooting ourselves in the foot by killing the competitiveness of our businesses and SMEs. In this resolution we should have talked about the efficient consumption of our resources instead of the misuse of them, which is a biased and non-proactive approach, which I regret. On the other hand, I am pleased that clear support for our companies, but also for research and innovation, is included in the proposals, because that is how we will lead by example. In addition, we need a comprehensive vision for effective legislation, a European vision of the circular economy. Before a European-level target for waste is set, we absolutely need to have harmonised calculation methods for all Member States, a proposal adopted in the text. Finally, I welcome the broad support for my proposal to promote at Member State level the establishment of conventions between supermarkets and food aid associations so that they can benefit from the unsold goods.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the circular economy and waste recycling resolution. The European Commission has withdrawn a legislative proposal on the circular economy from its 2015 work programme, but is expected to return with a proposal in the coming months. I am pleased that Parliament is taking up this momentum to adopt a text supporting ambitious measures such as a 30% increase in resource productivity and a gradual and binding reduction in landfill.  This is a good initiative and I hope that the Commission will build on it. While Belgium is the world champion in recycling, other Member States have a significant margin of progress ahead of them. Personally, I support in particular the demand to develop the creation, in the Member States, of conventions that would require supermarkets to redistribute their unsold goods to food associations. This is obvious to me when we know that in Europe some 90 million tonnes of food are thrown away every year, while millions of people depend on food aid. However, I regret to note that food waste is not even a subject in some European states.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. I am divided about the report, whose intention I support in principle but which I fear will be too transgressive for the Member States. In Denmark, we are already implementing a new waste strategy, which is why I also believe that there are a number of areas described in the report that can easily be lifted at national state level without interference from the EU.  There are a number of elements in the report that I can support, while, conversely, I also believe that Parliament should be careful not to be too overambitious. Thus, the Commission itself considers that as many as 18 Member States are already failing to comply with the current requirements of the Waste and Landfill Directive. I am not sure that increasing the level of ambition in as many different areas as the report touches on is what is needed right now, when the EU countries as a whole cannot even achieve the current objectives.  I have therefore chosen to vote blank.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the efficient use of resources: towards a circular economy. Under the guise of good feelings, this text is actually a communication tool. It wants to ensure the preservation of the environment by the Union but sets untenable objectives. When will the members of the majority understand that these changes must be gradual in order to be implemented?   In addition, this report once again demonstrates the Eu's relentless approach to harmonisation in environmental policy. Particularly in proposals on waste recycling, the text aims at a single objective that ignores local and national realities.   I denounce by my vote the lack of coherence and precision of this report. People expect concrete but realistic goals from us. Finally, the establishment of a genuine circular economy depends above all on strengthening local structures and activities and limiting global trade without limits or borders.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In principle I welcome the resolution. However, there are still numerous insufficiencies. Aside from the fact that I consider it to be of the utmost importance that we recognise the relationship between the efficient use of resources and minimizing waste, this report is still rather descriptive and prescriptive. I believe that we need concrete and realistic proposals, such as a focus on efficiency, innovation, and transparency, rather than new regulatory proposals and increased targets, for example. It is the case EU-wide that often the current situation is not properly assessed and an additional burden is imposed by creating higher burdens and challenges. If we want a proper functioning of the European internal market we must first of all understand what the actual context is and improve communication/coordination between the public and the private sectors, before adding additional and unnecessary red-tape, which is only detrimental to the well-being of our citizens.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Savings are of course extremely important but, once again, the report's approach fails to move away from the reform and memorial policies that have proven to lead nowhere.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because more efficient use of resources would reduce dependence on resources and lead to environmental and economic savings through the creation of new green and local jobs.  I am pleased that Parliament has accepted the amendments proposed by the M5S aimed at eliminating direct and indirect subsidies to fossil fuels, and at eliminating all subsidies that are harmful to the environment. Through the resolution, we call on the Member States to increase resource efficiency by 30% by 2030, to fully implement the cascade use of resources and sustainable supply, the full application of the 'polluter pays' principle and producer responsibility, the use of renewable energies and a waste hierarchy, as well as the application of taxes for landfilling and incineration of waste. With regard to waste, I regret that there is no general ban on incineration and landfill in the resolution, despite the fact that incineration is a clear practice of linear economics. But on the whole the text is laudable and I could only vote in favour of it.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I supported this report because I am keen for the Commission to come forward with ambitious legislation to increase resource efficiency. However, I voted against a couple of elements that risk undermining the use of biomass and which could lead to a disproportionate amount of regulatory hassle.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report calls for significant improvements in relation to the proposal on waste controversially withdrawn by the Commission. Mandatory targets for reducing waste production by 2025 are called for, introducing the requirement for separate collection of bio-waste by 2020; recycling and preparation targets for re-use which are expected to reach at least 70% of municipal solid waste and 80% of packaging waste by 2030. Incineration is also called for incineration to be strictly limited until 2020 for non-recyclable and non-biodegradable waste, and for a binding, gradual reduction of all landfill waste in three stages (2020, 2025, 2030). The report highlights fair environmental concerns, including the durability, reuse and recycling of products, among other important aspects.  But, as you would expect, in a responsible approach to the way of organizing production and the dominant society on a global scale – capitalism. On the contrary, it abuses the market vision, instead of holding the State and public policies accountable, which would be especially important in areas as sensitive as the waste that is addressed here. The disastrous consequences of market entry and dominance of sectors such as this are well known. But the report says nothing about it. Despite some positive guidance, this is your original sin.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I believe developing a true circular economy is vital to our future on the planet.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly, it is time for society to realise that we are increasingly crossing the planet's limits and that if we continue to do so, we will not avoid negative ecological changes in the future. Therefore, if we want to preserve a healthy and viable planet for future generations, we must find a way to reduce the consumption of minerals, fossil fuels and biomass, which are constantly growing as a result of population growth, the expansion of product diversity compared to the past and the reduction in their lifespan. If the global economy continues its current set-up, we will reach an impasse around 2050. We need to create a market for secondary raw materials in Europe, because the valuable raw materials and materials that we obtain at a high environmental and social price end up in incineratories and landfills. We must focus on promoting innovation and streamlining the use of resources and focusing consumers' attention on such environmentally friendly products. Efficient management of resources requires the intermission of many factors. The European Union must develop a binding resource efficiency indicator. We need to set clear, clear and ambitious targets for resource efficiency and create an environment of legal certainty that ensures wide opportunities for innovative business models and policies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, which quite simply is too far removed from reality and proposes an economic and unsustainable development model.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on resource efficiency: towards a circular economy. Savings are, of course, extremely important, but once again the report's approach fails to move away from reform and memorial policies that lead nowhere proven.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In a circular economy model, existing materials and products are continuously re-used, repaired, re-furbished and recycled, and thus the waste quantities are minimised. Moving towards a circular economy is essential to deliver on the resource efficiency agenda, which can bring major economic benefits. The transition to a circular economy requires changes throughout value chains, covering product design, manufacturing, marketing and consumer behaviour, and the involvement of all relevant stakeholders. The committee report as adopted in the ENVI Committee sends an ambitious signal to the Commission with the aim of guiding the ongoing work on the new waste package which is expected by the end of 2015. Implementing a circular economy model responds to key policy challenges in the EU such as jobs and growth, innovation, the re-industrialisation agenda, and an intelligent use of resources.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PpE group and the Fidesz delegation welcome the Commission's strategy in this important area, since the unsustainable use of resources causes both environmental damage and economic risks.  It should be noted that the road we are now on is at an ecological and economic impec. Humanity already exceeds certain limits of our planet's tolerance, within which we must remain, if we do not want to reach the tipping point leading to adverse ecological changes. Improving resource efficiency would be beneficial from both an economic and a security point of view. Dependency on resources must be reduced. This requires a radical change of approach. I welcome the legislative and economic incentives that will bring about change. This was also the aim of the report captured today, innovation and sustainable development.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Unsustainable use of resources is causing environmental damage and also poses an economic risk to both the EU and the rest of the world, as, to generate global production and absorb waste, the world economy uses the equivalent of a planet and a half in terms of resources. There is no doubt that we will end up on this path in an ecological and economic impede-de-sac, so we must use fewer resources and use them more efficiently. Resource efficiency is a solution to the ecological dilemma we face and to the economic challenges with which Europe is being discussed. That's why I voted for it.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the structure of Mrs Pietikäinen's report on resource efficiency and the transition to a circular economy because I believe that the circular economy is one of the main challenges of the future and represents an urgent need for the EU and for all Member States.  Europe continues to produce and waste a huge amount of waste, causing the known environmental and disposal problems: some of this waste must be able to be reused.  The circular economy principle aims to turn waste into raw materials for other companies, and as such must be adequately supported. In addition, the circular economy helps to produce jobs and develop industries active in the recycling and reuse sector, while ensuring a less consumer-related approach.  I therefore agree with the request to the European Commission to present legislative proposals in the field not only of waste, but also of other key sectors of the circular economy such as food waste, eco-products, manufacturing and packaging, encouraging the reuse and recyclability of the products consumed. Finally, I agree with the targets for reducing solid municipal waste and recycled packaging and on the call for a 30% increase in the European level of efficiency in the use of resources by 2020.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on 'Resource efficiency: ways to a circular economy', because I believe that Europe can and must use its natural resources more efficiently. We have only borrowed our earth from our children. And it has great economic significance: a 30% increase in resource productivity could increase GDP by just under 1% by 2030 and create 2 million permanent jobs.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on resource efficiency: the transition to a circular economy. I believe that the pursuit of a circular economy requires two basic criteria: – the life cycle of a product; – easy to disassemble and recyclable. The former criterion depends on reliability, i.e. on physical wear and on the loss of performance, aesthetic or other qualities defining the so-called moral consumption. The latter depends on the design of the product, which facilitates (allows) easy disassembly, as well as the manufacture of such plastics, which are suitable for deliberate recycling, not forced disposal. A right should be created so that both of these criteria are fully met when products are placed on the market. An additional important criterion for the authorisation of products on the market should, of course, be full consumer safety, as well as safety and environmental protection (climate). For the latter purpose, it becomes necessary to introduce a differentiated environmental tax and an appropriate scrap tax.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Take - Manufacture - Consume - Throw away. In this traditional linear economic model, we have been wasting valuable resources for years. With a circular economy, we could make this process partly more efficient. In principle, this is a step in the right direction, but some of the proposals in Parliament go too far. They are an unreasonable burden on European businesses, municipalities and consumers. A concrete example is the proposal to apply environmentally sound procurement procedures. According to the original version of the own-initiative report, municipalities should have been obliged to always observe environmental impact criteria in all procurement procedures. Such over-regulation would have presented enormous challenges for municipalities. However, we have succeeded in taking this commitment out of this house in plenary. Unfortunately, a majority of Parliament called for the ecodesign directive to be extended. You may be familiar with this directive from the headlines on maximum performance for vacuum cleaners, light bulbs and other household appliances. Here, Europe should focus better on the big issues. I am in favour of the circular economy. However, this should be stimulated through incentives rather than over-regulation. Our small and medium-sized enterprises must not be forced into a bureaucratic corset again and again.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Pietikäinen report, which constitutes an important step towards the new progressive concept of a circular economy. Implementing a circular economy model responds to major policy challenges in the EU such as jobs and growth, innovation, and the re-industrialisation agenda. I therefore urge the Commission to take an innovative and sustainable approach to issues such as resource efficiency, recovery, reuse and recycling of materials, which will become key elements of the production processes. Europe’s ability to compete with others in the global economy with ever decreasing resources will depend on our success in pushing this agenda forward.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the supposedly efficient use of resources, calling for a move towards a "circular economy". As always, the principles and intentions justifying the Commission's proposals and the ENVI commission report are commendable: to review our mode of consumption and production which has led us to this destructive globalisation of our jobs and our environment.  However, the avenues envisaged do not even pretend to fight against the real cause: the uprooting of our economy and our industries, their relocation to less so-called social and environmental. "The circular economy" is therefore only a cautery on a wooden leg.  As usual, the European Union is draped in great principles to impose constraints on our territory, without compensating them with the protection of our markets. It thus delivers our economy to global competition. The jobs advertised for the recycling of products that we will therefore continue to import are far from compensating for those destroyed by relocations and, worse, they make us even more dependent on these imports.  For more responsible consumption and production, let us produce and buy locally and sustainably, let us give ourselves the means to re-industrialize.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we consider it necessary to extend the scope of the Eco-Design Directive, update waste standards and give visibility to certain areas, such as the construction of sustainable buildings. We are facing a paradigm shift and it is necessary to set binding targets for waste reduction, as well as gradually reduce all types of waste dumping. To address the problem of resource scarcity, we consider it necessary to reduce its extraction and use and break the direct link between growth and use of natural resources. Parliament calls on the Commission to promote a product lifecycle approach and to present in this area 'an ambitious work plan'. This should include the revision of eco-design legislation by the end of 2016 to expand its scope to cover all product categories. It also requests the Commission to determine requirements for the durability criteria of the products and in relation to the possibility of repairing, reusing and recycling them, and to propose measures to put an end to the programmed obsolescence. In addition, the Commission is urged to propose these objectives by the end of 2015.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With this vote we made an important step working towards the progressive concept of a circular economy. Issues such as resource efficiency, recovery, reuse and recycling of materials will become key elements of the production processes. The challenge to compete in the global economy we live in today with an ever-decreasing supply of resources will more increasingly depend on innovation and sustainability.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Thursday, July 9, I voted in favour of the report on resource efficiency and the transition to a circular economy. The measures adopted are a clear message to the Commission, which will deliver its proposals on the circular economy at the end of 2015. In the near future, we will have fewer resources for a larger population. Such a transition to more sustainable and resource-efficient economic models is a concrete solution to these challenges.  In concrete terms, the report calls for a binding target for waste prevention by 2025, a target of recycling 70% of municipal waste and 80% of packaging by 2030.
