It also proposes other targets, such as reducing marine waste by 50% or food waste by 30% by 2025.  If Europe is to perform better, it must make the most of its resources. It is also essential to ensure that we do not overburen existing legislative constraints, which would undermine the competitiveness of our businesses. For this, it is essential to find the right balance between environment and economy, ambition and realism.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report "Resource efficiency: A european Building a circular economy" because I think it is very important to look after our planet and nature. Mankind is already beyond many of the possibilities of our planet, causing negative ecological consequences such as climate change, deforestation and others. If such trends are projected to persist, we will find ourselves in an ecological and economic impasse. In order to avoid such changes, we need to use less resources. This report presents an action plan based on six key concepts: the circular economy, the cascading resource hierarchy, the waste hierarchy, increased producer responsibility, industrial symbiosis and new business models. I hope that it will be implemented effectively and that it will contribute to the union's ecological and economic security.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this report on resource efficiency: moving towards a circular economy. This was the Parliament’s contribution to this important initiative promoting the circular economy which the Commission will launch at the end of the year. Minimising waste generation and resource use will not only reduce costs but will also increase EU competitiveness. At the moment we are not reaching our full potential, but a 30% increase in resource productivity in the next 15 years could boost GDP by 1% and create over 2 million jobs. The Report had several strong demands by Parliament, including updated European waste and recycling targets as well as targets on food waste and the creation of economic incentives. I was particularly happy to support the inclusion of an indicator on resource efficiency in the European Semester and a proposal for green public procurement requirements.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today marks an important step in the move towards the circular economy. This is an innovative and progressive move away from the current linear economy and will incorporate resource efficiency, recovery, reuse and recycling of materials into the production process. The EU currently imports half of the resources it consumes and throws away around 600 million tonnes of waste that could be reused. This is unsustainable. The circular economy also presents a real opportunity for Europe to compete globally in the context of ever decreasing resources.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we consider it necessary to extend the scope of the Eco-Design Directive, update waste standards and give visibility to certain areas, such as the construction of sustainable buildings. We are facing a paradigm shift and it is necessary to set binding targets for waste reduction, as well as gradually reduce all types of waste dumping. To address the problem of resource scarcity, we consider it necessary to reduce its extraction and use and break the direct link between growth and use of natural resources. Parliament calls on the Commission to promote a product lifecycle approach and to present in this area 'an ambitious work plan'. This should include the revision of eco-design legislation by the end of 2016 to expand its scope to cover all product categories. It also requests the Commission to determine requirements for the durability criteria of the products and in relation to the possibility of repairing, reusing and recycling them, and to propose measures to put an end to the programmed obsolescence. In addition, the Commission is urged to propose these objectives by the end of 2015.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Resource Efficiency Report: transition to a circular economy, as it will contribute to changing the overall system, significant innovations in technology and business, and society as a whole at the ecological, ethical and economic level. For a successful transition to a circular economy, education and professional workforce should definitely be enabled, but the most important players are public opinion, awareness and involvement of citizens, and all relevant stakeholders, regions, cities, SMEs, NGOs, trade unions and others. Every day we see the consequences of unsustainable use of resources that lead to increasing environmental hazards, also creating economic risk. We must not allow Europe to use resources corresponding to the amount of two planets over the next 15 years, while the current situation is such that 40% of all the materials Europe uses are imported, making it the most vulnerable region in the world.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the efficient use of resources, calling for a move towards a "circular economy". The principles behind it and the convictions that support it seem rather positive since the catastrophic state of our environment must lead us to reflect on our way of life and consumption. The proposals put forward aim to influence the Work of the Commission by the end of 2015. These include incentives to move towards a policy of "eco-design" of products and towards "zero waste", thus developing the recycling of these products. Similarly, the report wants to impose very restrictive standards on new buildings, and would like to start a plan to renovate the existing building.  These claims are only cosmetic, since they do not address the source of the problem, which is the cult of infinite growth. This text is therefore finally a blank cheque to the Commission to enact new unnecessary requirements.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sirpa Pietik-inen's report on resource efficiency and the transition to the circular economy. This report improves resource use and recycling. In particular, this text calls for a redistribution of unsold food by supermarkets to associations helping the most needy. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The unsustainable use of resources is the cause of significant damage to the environment, while presenting an economic risk. Today the world economy uses the equivalent of 1.5 planets; if we continue like this, we will reach a dead end, with great and irreversible implications such as climate change, deforestation, desertification, land degradation or weakening of ecosystems. This report presents good criteria for addressing this situation, with a product lifecycle-oriented approach, eco-design policy and zero waste. Despite the amendments made to the text after the plenary session, EH Bildu welcomes the proposals contained in the Resolution, in particular: the binding nature of the waste reduction objectives; the application of selective-mandatory collection for paper, metal, plastic and glass, together with the introduction of mandatory selective collection for biological waste by 2020; the recycling and reuse target of 70% of urban solid waste and 80% of packaging; and that by 2020 incineration will be strictly limited to non-recyclable and non-biodegradable waste. EH Bildu has been betting on these objectives since its founding; that is why, in the face of this resolution, our vote has been favourable.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the efficient use of resources: towards a circular economy. In the face of the challenges of climate change, the transition to a circular economy that promotes the efficient and sustainable use of natural resources seems essential to me. Innovative initiatives, such as the fight against food waste, already implemented in France, must extend to the whole of Europe. However, such a transition must adapt to the current economic environment and ensure that it does not overwhelm transitioning enterprises, particularly SMEs, administratively and financially.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Mrs Pietikäinen's report contains good approaches to making excessive use of resources more efficient and more economical, but unfortunately some proposals are excessive, at least for the time being. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on resource efficiency: towards a circular economy, because I believe that the linear model based on the "take-make-reject" triptych has now been overcome. The transition to a circular economy will be resource-efficient for Member States, boost recycling, create new jobs and reduce costly and scarce resources.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled "Effective Use of Resources: Towards a Circular Economy". This report proposes a series of incentives, notably for a policy of "eco-design" of products, to move towards "zero waste", to impose very restrictive standards on buildings in terms of energy consumption and to renovate the existing building in this sense, to develop "industrial synergies" in order to use cascading resources. This policy, responsible and visionary at first glance, is at odds with the existing economic model. The basis for a viable circular economy would be to promote short circuits, as well as labour and production in the country. This text is therefore derisory and harmful since it is only a blank cheque to the Commission to enact new unsuccessful requirements for Member States.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the implementation of the circular economy model responds to key European Union policy challenges such as employment growth and growth, promoting innovation, re-industrialisation and smart use of resources. In the circular economy model, existing materials and products are constantly reused and recycled, and thus waste is kept to a minimum. This is a model necessary to maximise the efficiency of available natural resources, which will bring significant economic benefits.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report contains a number of positive proposals, such as the need to set mandatory targets for the reduction of different types of waste (2025), a specific target for organic waste (2020), the gradual reduction of waste dumping, the adoption of the principle of cascading mainly for biomass, the increase in recycling and reuse targets up to at least 70% for RSU and 80% for packaging (2030) , the strict incineration limitation by 2020, a target for the reduction of 50% of marine litter by 2025, a binding target of 30% resource efficiency by 2025 and the strengthening of ecodesign measures in all types of products. By agreeing with this approach, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is a major step forward in the consideration and treatment of waste as resources for the European economy. This proposal is fundamental to the reshaping of the European economy, seeks to boost an activity based on greater sustainability of the economy, and even seeks sanctions for cases of programmed obsolescence. Tackling the debate on waste generation and its management is necessary to put an end to the environmental madness of capitalist industrial development in European countries. Since the report puts this issue on the table so forcefully and broadly, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I am in principle in principle in place for the most modern and efficient treatment of waste and the use of raw materials. However, it does not show that the European Union or governments understand this issue better than the companies themselves, which themselves have the motivation to treat resources sparingly and effectively. The EU cannot think that by reducing the use of resources it will contribute to greater efficiency in their use in the future.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Resource Efficiency Report: transition to a circular economy by Rapporteur Sirpa Pietikӓinen. Resource scarcity is a fact that the modern world must face, especially a Europe that depends on imported resources more than other regions. Legislation and the impact on circular legislation need to be analysed. Efficient resource management is a prerequisite for long-term growth and development, which should be based on environmentally sustainable foundations. I also supported this because of the "zero waste" policy, which aims to streamline waste management at all levels.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to avoid an economic and environmental disaster, we must necessarily promote a more efficient use of current resources, while at the same time finding new alternative sources that do not harm the environment. Europe is dependent on external sources, more than 40% of all materials used in the EU are imported, and for some loss-made materials this proportion is even higher. This dependency impairs the economic position and security of the Union. Moreover, many materials end up in waste because there is no functioning market for secondary raw materials. It is therefore necessary to gradually change the economic, social and technical conditions of production, including the adaptation of the legislative environment and economic incentives, and the introduction of systemic measures in order to increase the more efficient use of current resources. It is also a way to create and maintain new jobs, with a simultaneous positive impact on the EU economy and the environment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on 'Resource efficiency: towards a circular economy', for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The unsustainable use of resources is both causing environmental damage and posing an economic risk. The global economy uses the equivalent of 1.5 planets’ worth of resources to produce global output and absorb waste. By the 2030s this figure is estimated to reach two planets. The annual consumption of minerals, fossil fuels and biomass is projected to double by 2050, reaching 140 million tonnes. This is a result of a combination of population growth, more disposable income, more product diversity than before and shorter product lifespan. To continue in this course would lead to an ecological and economic impasse.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. This text, which is intended to be revolutionary, goes against the French interests and the economic model of the Union and France. This is no more or less than a list of incentives for "zero waste" based on policies of "eco-design" of products, "industrial synergy". Big words to hide an empty shell! If a stable circular economy is to be promoted, France's short circuits, labour and production should be promoted by limiting international trade. That would be much more useful.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Very good approaches, but unfortunately some of them turn out to be excessive. Furthermore, given the vague outcome of the votes on the amendments, I am not sure how the report will develop. That is why I am advising you to abstain.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Parliament Own Initiative Report as natural resources need to be used more efficiently. This Own Initiative calls on the Commission to review legislation such as the Eco-design Directive and submit a new proposal on waste legislation. Moving towards a circular economy by increasing resource productivity by 30% by 2030 could boost the EU’s GDP by nearly 1% and create an extra 2 million sustainable jobs.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The circular economy corresponds to an economic and industrial system, on the one hand, low in carbon and energy and, on the other hand, low in natural resources not, little, difficultly, slowly or expensively renewable, based on the eco-design of products and services that must promote recycling at the best cost. The report before us defends this concept. It therefore calls on the Commission to improve the sustainability, reuse and recycling of products and to ban toxic chemicals and promote eco-design. It also calls for binding waste reduction targets to be achieved by 2025. I vote for this non-legislative text, with no illusions as to its effects.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The principles underlying and the convictions that support this report seem rather positive since the catastrophic state of our environment must lead us to reflect on our way of life and consumption. The proposals put forward aim to influence the Work of the Commission by the end of 2015. These include incentives to move towards an "eco-design" policy of products and "zero waste", thus developing the recycling of these products. Similarly, the report wants to impose very restrictive standards on new buildings and would like to start a plan to renovate the existing building.  These claims are only cosmetic, since they do not address the source of the problem, which is the cult of infinite growth. This text is therefore finally a blank cheque to the Commission to enact new unnecessary requirements. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe is dependent on more imports than any other region in the world: 40% of all materials used in the EU are imported. This percentage is even higher for some strategic resources, such as metal ores and nutrients: 92 % of phosphorus, essential for European agriculture, is imported mostly from Russia, Syria, Morocco and Tunisia. It goes without listing the dangers of this dependency for both the European economy and security. Rethinking the sustainability of resources through a circular economy that prioritises reuse, retransformation and recycling is the way forward. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is crucial that Europe moves away from its dependence on imported resources and imported materials. The shift towards a zero-waste economy would significantly decrease this dependence as well as aid in meeting the environmental targets that the Union has committed to on the international scene.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Today, only 40% of solid waste is reused or recycled. The rest of the waste is still going to landfill or incinerator. The circular economy offers a sustainable solution to the waste problem. Unlike in the linear system, where raw materials are converted into products that are destroyed after a short life, the circular economy aims to maximize products and raw materials and minimise value destruction. It is not only reducing the amount of waste, but also by choosing a circular economy which means creating new opportunities for growth and employment in Europe. The European Commission says it will boost up to 2 million new jobs by 2030. European companies and SMEs will also be less dependent on imports of raw materials in this economic system and will thus strengthen their competitive position globally. The European commitment to a better environment and a sustainable economy is not without obligation. In order to achieve the economic and environmental objectives, investments are needed to modernise production processes and manufacture better recyclable and sustainable products. A policy framework is required to support the companies that are driving this transition to a circular economy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The efficient use of our planet's often limited resources is the basis for good management. In order to ensure the long-term sustainability of the functioning of our economy, we must learn to use the resources available more efficiently and without wasting waste.  In this respect, the so-called circular economy offers a number of practical solutions and improvements, such as cascading resource use, the waste hierarchy, but also a reassessment of producer responsibility leading to new business models, products and services. In the context of the investigation, I would like to point out that buildings and buildings account for 40% of the total energy consumption, which is largely wasted due to poor insulation. In this and many other areas, I therefore encourage synergies between regional and environmental policy and the use of EU funds for these purposes.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. \u2012 The SP is in favour of an economy in which as much waste as possible is reused. But that is not a task that Brussels must impose on us, that is a responsibility of the countries themselves.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The unsustainable use of resources is both causing environmental damage and posing an economic risk and continuing in this course would lead to an ecological and economic impasse, therefore moving towards an ambitious circular economy and resource efficiency is a solution to the ecological dilemma we are faced with and to the economic challenges Europe is struggling with. On top of that it can bring major economic benefits for our citizens, improve our competitiveness, re-industrialise Europe and enhance our standards of living only by decoupling economic growth from resource use. Having said that, however, I also think that we need to ensure that any new targets and measures are realistic, feasible and implementable by the Member States.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The transition to a circular economy requires a systemic change that affects all actors in the value chain, as well as substantial innovations in technologies, enterprises and society at large. I am voting in favour of this report which aims to contribute to greater re-use of available resources, but I do not believe that these activities can be too costly for Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore believe that there must be a strong balance between the sustainable re-use of resources and the financial costs that companies should have, so that the idea at issue here does not seriously undermine the economic and financial sustainability of companies over the next few years.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the transition to the circular economy is an initiative report by Parliament, in which it makes the Commission aware of the nature of the proposals it must make by the end of 2015. The circular economy consists of decoupling economic growth and resource use. Its objective is to produce goods and services while severely limiting the consumption and waste of raw materials and non-renewable energy sources. However, this definition and economic model are the exact opposite of the economic model supported by the EU. Indeed, the circular economy is based on the short circuit, on local preference and not on the importation of products crossing the planet on cargo ships. The report envisages a range of measures such as the "zero waste" target, the imposition of restrictive standards in construction (at a time when the construction sector is in the midst of a crisis in France). I voted against this report, which is only intended to give the Commission a blank-seing to legislate instead of the Member States.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we made an important step towards the new progressive concept of a circular economy. Factors such as resource efficiency, recovery, reuse and recycling of materials will become key elements of the production processes. The challenge to compete in the global economy with ever decreasing resources will more and more depend on innovation and sustainability.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the efficient use of resources. It calls for a transition from the European economy to a circular model, with the establishment of a more coherent legislative framework for sustainable production and consumption. It is not only a question of combating the Union's dependence on dwindling resources, but also of reducing our waste, especially food. This is particularly important and I am pleased that this report calls on the Commission to encourage the creation in Member States of conventions where the retail food trade sector distributes products not sold to charities.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. The adoption of the report on the efficient use of resources stresses that the circular economy is a virtuous circle that we must absolutely encourage following the adoption of the report on the efficient use of resources. Reducing waste generation, using our resources efficiently, creating a new economy, the measures we have just adopted are a clear message sent to the European Commission, which will deliver its circular economy proposals at the end of the year.  Nevertheless, we must remain cautious, because many very ambitious proposals, if not too many, have been proposed in this report. Always wanting to set an example to the rest of the world, we risk shooting ourselves in the foot by killing the competitiveness of our SMEs and our businesses. We must not oppose the environment and the economy: we must support our companies and especially the most innovative in this area. We also need a global vision for effective legislation, a European vision of the circular economy. Before a European-level target for waste is set, we absolutely need to have harmonised calculation methods for all Member States.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 By adopting this report, we wanted to send a very important political message: the continuous unsustainable use of resources is causing irreparable environmental damage and represents a strong economic risk to the planet. The ecological implications are multiple and in many cases irreversible: climate change, deforestation, desertification, soil degradation, loss of biodiversity, reduction of genetic diversity and weakening of ecosystem services.  To avoid such changes in our biosphere it is necessary to use fewer resources. We can and must improve competitiveness, reindustrialise Europe and improve our standard of living by decoupling economic growth and resource use. Europe depends on imported resources more than any other region in the world. Improving resource efficiency would benefit our economy and our security. A more efficient use of resources would help to reduce dependence on resources, would lead to cost savings, and would also encourage the creation of new business activities and new jobs in Europe.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 If we want to achieve our plans for 2030 and 2050 and create a more livable and greener planet, we need to introduce exercises that are resource-efficient as soon as possible. All these steps can directly contribute to GDP growth, reduced waste generation and the creation of new green jobs. But care must be taken to avoid being found with the rule, so that the benefits are not consumed by bureaucracy and administrative duties. It is of the utmost importance that we must already prepare future generations for how they can participate in making the future economy resource-efficient. Education has a key role to play here. In many times, self-awareness goes further than the often non-realistic functioning of the planned, re-regulated economic policy, which can then discredit the original goal and will only be seen by our citizens as unnecessary, annoying and costly shackles. I therefore ask that we intervene only with the minimum, unavoidable standards and moderation of the functioning of the market.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today’s unsustainable use of resources is both causing environmental damage and posing an economic risk. The global economy uses the equivalent of 1.5 planets’ worth of resources, thus I have voted for this report to improve resource efficiency that will benefit our economy and security.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo ar an ngeilleagar ciorclach agus táim sásta gur chaith tromlach na Parlaiminte vóta i bhfabhar chomh maith, go háirithe tar éis an chinnidh a ghlac an Coimisiún níos luaithe sa bhliain go ndéanfaí an togra maidir le dramhaíl a tharraingt siar. Is dócha go gcuirfidh an vóta dearfach seo brú ar an gCoimisiún togra uaillmhianach a chur chun tosaigh roimh dheireadh na bliana seo. É sin ráite, b’fhearr liom targaid de 30% a fheiceáil i gcomhair úsáid acmhainní in AE in áit ceann sealadach. Ach seolann sé seo comhartha uaillmhianach chuig an gCoimisiún. Ba chóir don Choimisiún anois an deis seo a úsáid chun moltaí na Parlaiminte a neartú agus reachtaíocht atá níos láidre ná na tograí a bhí acu ag an tús a chur chun tosaigh. Tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go gcuirimid deireadh láithreach le róthomhaltas ár n-acmhainní nádúrtha. Buntáiste a bheadh ann don timpeallacht cinnte, ach mar aon leis sin, cabhróidh sé le sábháil chostais ollmhór a dhéanamh agus cruthódh sé timpeall 2 mhilliún post faoi 2050.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In March 2015, the Commission confirmed its decision to withdraw the waste proposals which it had published in 2014 as part of its Circular Economy Package. Broadly, I welcome elements of this report as it recognises the link between making better use of resources and minimising waste if we are to move to a more circular economy. This is vital and I do want it to be ambitious – not least if one considers the potential positive impact on Northern Ireland. But there are elements that are problematic. I am a firm believer in evidence-based policy making, and the report verges on a number of points towards being too prescriptive. It is important to have ambitious targets, but they should be underpinned by sound scientific analysis and assessment.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The optimisation of resource management is something I am very much in favour of so I supported this report. There is a wide variety of resources in Europe which are either scarce, or not present at all, and what we do have, we certainly need to use better, for a longer term. A circular economy in this sense should be a major medium- to long-term sustainability target for all the Member States and the Commission, in all available areas.  From fisheries to natural resources and manufacturing, from flora and fauna resources, all should be exploited in such a way so as to create even further benefit in the long run. And this is not simply about recycling and the jobs associated with that, but about many other products and their lifespans, their production and post-usage cycles. I believe all national governments should adopt this term for themselves very soon.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the circular economy, because I consider the circular economy to be an important building block for a sustainable economy and therefore an important and strategic area to which we should face up and not back. Europe can play a leading role in the world here, thanks to its technological edge, but only if it applies these technologies itself. I do not agree with the rejection of the energy efficiency and waste management targets simply because meeting them would be challenging. I believe that, in the interests of greater economic stability and the stability of raw material prices in Europe, there is a reduction in energy consumption and a more efficient management of resources. Circular economy stimulus can also be a catalyst for the development of new technologies and the creation of new jobs. It is precisely the clear setting of long-term goals and the non-dodging of them that is the best way to exploit the potential in these areas and to minimise the short-term costs of changing the economy towards a more responsible and sustainable functioning.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report certainly contains some interesting aspects with regard to better use of scarce resources, but seems to me to be too practical and immature in terms of possible implementation of the measures. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to make more sustainable use of existing resources, we must contribute to appropriate legal measures, economic incentives and research in this area. There is a need to involve different policy levels in order to make changes. Raising people's awareness of the need for a greener lifestyle is also key.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the transition to a circular economy is the best choice for the future of Europe but not only, and I hope that this important process in which we are involved will set an example for all the other regions of the world. Considering that the circular economy makes the product a resource for someone else at any stage of their "life", it will also be the starting point for the creation of new jobs and will certainly give the opportunity to create new models of sustainable business.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Report as I fully agree it is crucial for the EU to start using resources more efficiently and reduce our resource dependency. Saving natural resources will not only preserve raw materials for future generations but will create multiple benefits such as reducing waste and creating new innovative business opportunities. However, I call on the Commission to take a more cautious stand when looking into creating a binding target to increase resource efficiency at EU level, since the principle of subsidiarity must be respected.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'for', because all the studies and opinions of the experts to which I have had access indicate that this legislative package can transform Europe's economy into a sustainable system and lead to the creation of new jobs, especially among young people. At the same time, I believe that greater attention must be paid to regions and labour that are adversely affected by the transition to a circular economy, such as the 350 000 jobs in the mining industry in Europe. The European Commission must work with the social partners to create solidarity mechanisms, such as financial compensation, retraining and retraining for this workforce.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The package of legislation designed on the settings of the plagued economy is a legacy of work and a bold vision of the previous European Commission of its Environment Commissioner. This proposal has since been withdrawn by the new Commission, with the promise of a new, more ambitious and elaborate package of proposals due to be submitted to the European Parliament by the end of this year.  With this resolution, the European Parliament welcomed this promise, but also gave a very broad instruction on its expectations of the European Commission.  We are all aware of the growth of the number of dwellings in the world and the increased consumption of raw materials. Aware of the limits of such uncontrolled growth in the economy, such as the bold shift in energy efficiency, the time has come when we need to separate our economic growth from resource consumption.  It is this resolution that speaks very easily and openly about this, proposes objectives and guidelines and ways to achieve these goals. By supporting this Resolution, I will continue to advocate that the European Parliament, in cooperation with the national governments and parliaments of the Member States, and with the Council and the European Commission, put this idea into practice, responsibly and planningly, thus achieving full synergy with other EU policies towards further strengthening the economy on the sustainable and efficient use of raw materials, and further raising the quality of life of EU citizens.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the transition to the circular economy is an initiative report by Parliament, in which it makes the Commission aware of the nature of the proposals it must make by the end of 2015. The circular economy consists of decoupling economic growth and resource use. Its objective is to produce goods and services while severely limiting the consumption and waste of raw materials, and non-renewable energy sources.  However, this definition and economic model are the exact opposite of the economic model supported by the Union. Indeed, the circular economy is based on the short circuit, on local preference and not on the importation of products crossing the planet on cargo ships. The report envisages a range of measures such as the "zero waste" target, the imposition of restrictive standards in construction (at a time when the construction sector is in the midst of a crisis in France). I voted against this report, which is only intended to give the Commission a blank-seing to legislate instead of the Member States.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. —Europe depends on imported resources more than any other region in the world, which can result in a negative consequence of many resources being depleted in a relatively short period of time. Europe's competitiveness can only be significantly increased by increasing the added value gained from resources in the economy and promoting sustainable supply of raw materials from European sources. I therefore support the rapporteur's proposal, as the transition to a circular economy is essentially an economic issue, in terms of access to raw materials and sustainable availability of raw materials, reindustrialisation and additional digitisation of Europe, job creation and the challenges of climate change, energy insecurity and scarce resources. I see the importance of investing in the circular economy in that it can be fully aligned with the Commission's agenda for jobs, growth and competitiveness and has the potential to create a situation where all stakeholders involved benefit. The role of businesses, authorities and consumers in the EU by improving resource use through better design requirements and through waste legislation prioritising the waste hierarchy could generate significant net savings estimated at €600 billion; 8% of annual turnover, while reducing total annual greenhouse gas emissions by 2-4% which would ultimately lead to a 30% increase in resource productivity by 2030.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Increased demand for resources and competition have put a lot of pressure on the environment and the need to move to a circular economy that will preserve the environment, increase product efficiency and added value, contribute to new economic growth and job opportunities, and reduce waste, almost eliminating it. The unsustainability of the current system and the need for a major change is also evidenced by the fact that the global economy uses resources corresponding to the amount of one and a half planets for global production and waste absorpti0, and it is estimated that this figure will reach the amount of two planets by the 2030s. The transition to a circular economy is particularly important for Europe, as it depends on imported resources more than any other region in the world and that many resources will be depleted in a relatively short period of time. Likewise, its competitiveness can only be significantly increased by increasing the added value gained from resources in the economy and promoting sustainable supply of raw materials from European sources. It is very important to point out that the implementation of a full circular economy requires the involvement of all relevant stakeholders, regions, cities, local communities, SMEs, NGOs, industry representatives, trade unions and citizens. Consequently, I supported my colleague Sirpae Pietikäinen's report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A circular economy means the ability to increase resource productivity through recycling and re-use. I am glad that the strong text of the resolution was adopted, in particular, with the significant contribution of the Social Democrats, who managed to put a stronger tone into the text. I believe that the 30% increase in resource productivity by 2030 compared to 2014 is quite real and will lead, above all, to further growth and job creation. For this, it is necessary to clearly set targets and indicators (e.g. waste reduction target for 2025 for municipal, industrial and commercial waste), to revise ecodesign rules (lifetime, repairability, reuse and recycling), to renew the Waste Directive (new binding impact targets could lead to the creation of up to 180 000 new jobs) and to take measures to separate growth from the use of natural resources , which the Social Democrats strongly advocated. I am glad that the resolution also proposes specific recommendations, for example in the area of retail trade and its involvement in the distribution of unsathed goods to charitable organisations. We need to recognize the huge potential behind the term circular economy, just as we need to go through a change in conservative thinking, which often in charge of seeing things organic and innovative as expensive. The opposite is true, and I am glad that this view has prevailed in the European Parliament.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the European Commission presented the "circular economy package", containing the communication "Towards a circular economy: a zero waste programme for Europe". This is certainly an important legislative proposal which could have considerable repercussions not only in terms of environmental protection but also in economic terms.  However, the presence of certain controversial aspects, such as binding targets that are considered unrealistic and the introduction of bans and taxes that I believe can have a very negative impact on SMEs, has led me not to support the rapporteur's proposal. In particular, I believe that the proposal before us does not take due account of certain aspects relating to full respect for the principle of subsidiarity, since certain issues relating to the proper management of waste should, in my opinion, be able to be decided by the Member States.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the progress towards a circular economy, as this is without a doubt the only sustainable path to future prosperity in Europe in the long term. Only organic production, waste recovery, recycling and reduction of consumption can ensure a good environment for us and future generations. At the same time, however, these principles need to be implemented transparently and gradually, so that the EU does not lose competitiveness and that our legislation is legible and predictable for companies.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to abstain in the overall vote on this report, which deals with the circular economy. I support a number of ideas concerning the protection of our planet, but unfortunately, in the partial votes, some proposals have been approved which introduce such deadlines for certain steps that their application would lead to serious damage to the economy and thus also to the consequent impact on the number of jobs. I couldn't support that.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a text putting in place EUROPEAN legislation to combat the waste of food, products, energy and materials. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report. Europe is acting in this way to protect the consumer and combat a scourge that risks having long-term consequences for our planet. We throw away almost 90 million tonnes of food a year, an unacceptable waste that we want to stop.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. The global economy uses the equivalent of 1.5 times the planet's resources to achieve its total production and absorb waste. It is estimated that by 2030, this number will rise to twice the planet's resources. The definition of a binding waste reduction target, the revision of European legislation on green nutrition and the adoption of measures to decouple growth from the use of natural resources are some of the recommendations made in this report on the transition to a circular economy. For these reasons and because it is crucial to present a new and more ambitious circular economy legislative package by the end of 2015, so that new challenges can be addressed, I voted in favour of this document.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Pietik-inen report is an important text in the work of the European Parliament. It evokes a paradigm shift, that of the transition from an economy conceived for at least two centuries in a linear way, that is to say closely dependent on a line of production, consumption and exchange consisting of producing goods for consumption, and then throwing them, infinitely, to a circular economy. Based on a better valuation of the human or natural resources used and an expansion of the capital invested, the circular economy is the appropriate response to the scarcity of resources in Europe and the fact that 40% of the materials used in the European Union are imported. To take the example of an irreplaceable everyday object, the smartphone: at the end of 2013, its average lifespan in Europe was estimated at less than 2 years, compared to 8 years in India. However, e-waste, which is highly polluting, is still poorly recycled in the world: 80% end their lives in a landfill. It's not sustainable! It is therefore much more than the technique that needs to be changed, based in particular on the programmed obsolescence of products, it is the whole business model that needs to be revised in order to reach in the next few years a modular mobile phone!

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The unsustainable use of resources is not only a source of environmental damage, but also an economic risk. The global economy employs, in resources, the equivalent of 1.5 planets for global production and waste absorption. It is estimated that this figure will reach the equivalent of two planets by the 2030s. Continuing on this path would lead to an ecological and economic impasse. That is why I have chosen to vote for this report, which paves the way for a paradigm shift. Renovation of the housing stock, cascading use of resources and the elimination of environmentally harmful subsidies are all measures envisaged in this report. A common framework for assessing progress is also proposed with a view to a homogeneous and transparent progress within the Union.  Although of no legal value, this text encourages the Commission to commit itself to the ecological challenge.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the circular economy resolution, which encourages the European Union to manage its resources more effectively. Knowing that it would take a planet and a half to support the resource consumption of our global economy, it is time to find sustainable access to raw materials. The aim is to increase resource efficiency at European level by 30% by 2030. Beyond the environmental benefits, this improvement could help create two million sustainable jobs and lead to an increase in GDP, currently estimated at 1%.  To achieve this goal, legislative measures are needed, including new legislation on waste management before the end of the year. On the issue of food waste, through my vote, I supported an ambitious objective of reducing food waste and encouraged the establishment in The Member States of conventions to distribute food products not sold to charities. I have also asked the Commission to assess the possibilities of increasing the use of environmentally friendly and biodegradable food packaging. Finally, I recall my conviction that an extension of eco-design legislation is needed, as well as a plan of measures to combat programmed obsolescence.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In July 2014, the Commission presented its communication 'Towards a circular economy: a zero waste programme for Europe', which contained ideas to contribute, through existing legislation and new initiatives, to creating a circular economy by optimizing all the life processes of a product and minimizing waste. This initiative report, which has earned my vote in favour, sets out a first position by Parliament on the priorities to be set to move towards this circular economy, namely the need to set mandatory targets for the reduction of different types of waste (2025), a specific target for organic waste (2020), the gradual reduction of waste dumping, the adoption of the principle of cascading use mainly for biomass , increasing recycling and reuse targets to at least 70% for RSU and 80% for packaging (2030), strict incineration limitation by 2020, a target of 50% reduction of marine litter by 2025, a binding target of 30% resource efficiency by 2025 and the strengthening of ecodesign measures in all types of products.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Moving from a society of waste and waste of resources, be it food, energy or raw materials, to a society of repair, reuse, recycling and resource efficiency, is a rich need for opportunities for Europe. It is by resolutely committing to a circular economy that the Union can both reduce its dependence on imported resources, protect the environment, stimulate innovation and the competitiveness of its industry and create jobs.  The text voted urges the Commission to submit new legislation based on binding targets for reducing waste and phasing out landfilling and a policy that promotes the decoupling between economic growth and resource use. The text also calls on the EU to achieve a sustainable production model by 2050 and to set binding targets for reducing waste generated by 2025. MEPs also called for concrete measures to combat programmed obsolescence. To combat food waste, the European Parliament is calling for the creation in Member States of conventions under which the retail food sector would distribute products not sold to charities.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission presented a communication entitled "Towards a circular economy: programme to end waste in Europe", aimed at designing and innovation at the service of a circular economy, creating a policy framework that supports resource efficiency and the definition of a specific strategic framework enabling SMEs to transform environmental challenges into environmentally sustainable business opportunities. Moving towards a more circular economy is essential to meeting the europe 2020 strategy on resource efficiency, promoting smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With this system it will be possible to create added value to the products and eliminate waste. To that extent, I agree with the rapporteur's position on the need for legislative waste measures by the end of 2015, proposing ambitious resource efficiency targets and reliable indicators. With regard to targets, a word to say that the principle of subsidiarity must always be safeguarded when we set binding targets for Member States with a view to resource efficiency, as the specificities inherent in each country cannot be taken into account.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the circular economy and the measures that accompany it, such as reducing waste production or using resources efficiently.  With the adoption of this text, we have sent a clear message to the European Commission in view of its forthst possible proposals on the circular economy by the end of the year. In this context, it is important to support both our companies, by establishing ambitious but realistic proposals, as well as research.  Finally, I would like to underline the introduction in the text, thanks in particular to the French EPP delegation, of a request for the establishment of agreements between supermarkets and food aid associations so that they can benefit from the unsold goods. This measure is part of a more united Europe and represents a first step in the fight against food waste.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report "Resource efficiency: transition to a circular economy" is part of one of the most controversial dossiers on the circular economy at the July part-session. In July last year, the European Commission presented the 'circular economic package', which the European Parliament decided to follow up with an own-initiative report. In the meantime, however, the Commission has withdrawn its proposal with a promise to present another, better one, by the end of 2015 preceded by a public consultation that will end in mid-August.  The report presented by Mr De Clercq, on behalf of the Committee on The Pietikäinen presents several controversial points, including the proposal to introduce binding targets for the efficient use of resources and waste reduction, new legislation for ecodesign and measures to break the link between growth and the use of natural resources. The report has left many doubts and that is why, in line with the majority of my group, the PPE, I have chosen to vote against it.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because, while I agree with the need for greater environmental protection, I consider the text to be excessively unbalanced inso far as it does not take proper account of the needs of workers and businesses.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we consider it necessary to extend the scope of the Eco-Design Directive, update waste standards and give visibility to certain areas, such as the construction of sustainable buildings. We are facing a paradigm shift and it is necessary to set binding targets for waste reduction, as well as gradually reduce all types of waste dumping. To address the problem of resource scarcity, we consider it necessary to reduce its extraction and use and break the direct link between growth and use of natural resources. Parliament calls on the Commission to promote a product lifecycle approach and to present in this area 'an ambitious work plan'. This should include the revision of eco-design legislation by the end of 2016 to expand its scope to cover all product categories. It also requests the Commission to determine requirements for the durability criteria of the products and in relation to the possibility of repairing, reusing and recycling them, and to propose measures to put an end to the programmed obsolescence. In addition, the Commission is urged to propose these objectives by the end of 2015.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A transition to a circular economy, with greater emphasis on reuse and recycling, would relieve pressure on finite resources and create opportunities and employment in the expanding reuse and recycling industries. It would also reduce European dependence on imported resources and energy. To bring about the changes in consumption patterns necessary to create a circular economy, significant modifications will need to be made on many levels, including product design, manufacturing, marketing, and consumer behaviour. These changes will need to be encouraged by the right legislative framework. I urge the Commission to take note of Parliament’s recommendations, especially on the issues of landfill, green public procurement, biomass, and EU financial support for greater resource efficiency.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it is a major step forward in the consideration and treatment of waste as resources for the European economy. This proposal is fundamental to the reshaping of the European economy, seeks to boost an activity based on greater sustainability of the economy, and even seeks sanctions for cases of programmed obsolescence. Tackling the debate on waste generation and its management is necessary to put an end to the environmental madness of capitalist industrial development in European countries. Since the report puts this issue on the table so forcefully and broadly, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote calls on the Commission to review European directives and standards on eco-design, waste management, the construction sector and sustainable food to promote more efficient use of resources. We have a responsibility to future generations to use resources in a more sustainable way by trying, for example, to encourage the recycling and recovery of materials and to reduce the number of landfills and marine litter. However, we must prevent the imposition of new environmental protection rules from entailing additional costs and administrative burdens, undermining the competitiveness of our production system. I have therefore chosen to abstain from the final vote.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this report with optimism. Strengthening the circular economy in Europe is a contribution to improving the environment globally.  Every year, as a result of the still prevailing linear economy, huge amounts of waste enter the seas, degrade and become even more dangerous pollutants, including so-called microplastics. On the other hand, high concentrations of carbon in the atmosphere acidify the oceans to levels that destroy the efficiency of ecosystems. The strategies foreseen in this report are imperative for planetary food security. The circular economy must be a winning strategy in Europe and this model must be exported to the world.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Resource efficiency is a particularly important issue for the EU as resources are essential for the proper functioning of industry and many other sectors of the economy that provide eu citizens with different types of key products and services. We must not forget that Europe remains one of the world's largest importers of raw materials, and around 40% of the materials used in the EU come from the outside. For some substances, such as agriculturally important phosphorus, the dependence on imports is even greater. It is important to take a sensible approach to resource efficiency and savings, because we must not allow these measures to lead to a reduction in the security of supply of certain goods and services and a decrease in competitiveness.  Nevertheless, where possible and safe for the EU economy, the use of new waste management solutions, the creation of a closed cycle of non-renewable resources, greater use of renewable energy sources and water management measures should be promoted.  In addition, available data show that in some countries water supply issues may soon become one of the more serious problems. Better use of available resources would have a positive impact on both the economy and the environment and support the creation of new jobs.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we made an important step towards the new progressive concept of a circular economy. Factors such as resource efficiency, recovery, reuse and recycling of materials will become key elements of the production processes. The challenge to compete in the global economy with ever decreasing resources will more and more depend on innovation and sustainability.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from the report. Global economic production is currently consumed 1.5 times the capacity of the Earth's available resources. All the resources on our planet are a great gift from God. We therefore need to improve the efficiency of their use as well as waste material, thus reducing the EU's overall dependence on imports of raw materials. However, the report contains a number of normative regulations and regulations. In addition, it also talks about objectives for individual Member States. I do not consider these provisions appropriate. Any measures in the Member States should be taken on a voluntary basis.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because I believe that we should set ambitious targets for the circular economy. I feel, however, that it is important to emphasise that it is up to the Member States to deliver these, and too often the UK government has lacked ambition. I hope this report will encourage them to increase their efforts. The Scottish Government, in contrast, has pushed hard to achieve what it can within the powers it currently possesses. The government has already set ambitious targets such as aiming to recycle 70% of all waste by 2025; banning all biodegradable municipal waste going to landfill by 2021; and preventing any more than 5% of waste materiel going to landfill by 2025.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I believe that, in the interests of Europe's future economic development, we need to make better use of our resources smarter than before, designing products so that they can be reused and recycled. Only by using resources more efficiently can we improve the ecological and economic problems that Europe is currently struggling with. I assume that, as a result of the measures taken, the approach to waste management will change significantly, which could once again put us back on the path of green growth. I expect the EU to develop a binding headline indicator on resource efficiency, because many sectors are still characterised by great inconsistency and the comparison of the data provided is not sufficiently denunciable. By moving to a more circular economy, we can improve the competitiveness and standard of living of Europeans and contribute to economic growth, a better environment and the creation of new jobs. I also believe that the circular economy will offer consumers more durable and innovative products that will also improve their quality of life. Europe needs a successful transition to a circular economy, thereby contributing to a stronger Europe and reducing pressure on the supply of raw materials and the environment.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we made an important step towards the new progressive concept of a circular economy. Factors such as resource efficiency, recovery, reuse and recycling of materials will become key elements of the production processes. The challenge to compete in the global economy with ever-decreasing resources will more and more depend on innovation and sustainability

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the proposed measures, which can significantly increase the regulatory burden.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, which calls for binding targets for waste reduction, the addition of ecodesign legislation and measures to separate growth from the use of natural resources. The circular economy poses a challenge for the EU as it will ensure sustainability in the economic and social spheres and call for resource efficiency. Imports of raw materials of 70 % are too high and could be reduced by recycling and reusing the raw materials and products we discard. This would also more effectively preserve our environment. We need to establish higher standards for the circular economy and see an opportunity for new business models, investment and competitiveness.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Savings are of course extremely important, but once again the report's approach fails to move away from reform and memorial policies that lead nowhere proven.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we need to take immediate steps to achieve a circular economy. The substance affects all the instruments from which waste is generated today. The amount of these wastes is unsustainable, which is why we need to encourage environmentally friendly planning, recycling, repair and, ultimately, the achievement of a 'zero waste' state. The European Parliament wants resources to be used more efficiently, so that we can reduce our resource dependency and reduce financial costs. Improving resource efficiency means leaving behind the current linear economy, characterised by a buy-and-sell model of production and consumption. In the circular economy, virtually all non-renewable materials circulate in closed cycles.  An important element of the proposal is ecodesign, which makes it easier to repair, reuse and renovate products. Other important elements are waste prevention measures; mandatory local, communal, industrial targets by 2025; the polluter pays principle; higher recycling targets; minimising the incineration process and drastically reducing the amount of waste deposited. In terms of the latter Hungary, it is included in the last third of the EU-28 list, which absolutely needs to be changed.  With this package, we can not only save resources, i.e. money in the long term, but also reduce the annual greenhouse gas emissions level.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I am a supporter of an economy with a rationally polished circulation. The idea that we don't have to have everything, but we can borrow or repair aging products, is a good idea. However, I believe that the European Parliament's report, despite its proper objective, contained many solutions that could not be met for economic but also political and social reasons.  Furthermore, I believe that this report, if implemented in its existing form, could put part of the 350 000 jobs in European industry at risk, resulting in companies outside the European Union replacing the activities of our entrepreneurs. They are not burdened with such high environmental requirements as European ones. I have therefore chosen to vote against the Report by Sirpa Pietikäinen.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Finally positive news: the draft report on the circular economy has passed. The report includes a number of points that are very important to us in the M5S: the need for a tax framework in accordance with the 'polluter pays' principle is underlined and clear rules are called for on the application of extended producer responsibility (large companies are responsible for the disposal of the objects they produce).  In addition, the Commission is asked to include in its proposal for a revision of waste legislation a number of important points, including an increase in the recycling rate to at least 70% of municipal solid waste, binding reduction targets for municipal, commercial and industrial waste and a strict limitation of incinerators. A very important point, which remained in the report and proposed in the ENVI Committee by our spokesman, Mr Pedicini, urges the European Commission to phase out direct and indirect harmful subsidies to fossil fuels.  On a negative note, we rejected the amendment proposed by us in the M5S together with the Greens, aimed at introducing targets on the reuse of materials in order to prevent and reduce waste production.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are on the verge of changing the way we approach the use of natural resources and the traditional economic model. Without affecting living standards and the well-being of citizens, we have the opportunity to revolutionise the natural resources policy framework and support the reindustrialisation of the European Union by decoupling it from the irresponsible use of raw materials. The political signal given by the vote on it will lead to a leverage effect, which is so necessary to direct investment towards job creation and the generation of new business models. A resource-efficient economy is a cost-optimized economy, an economy based on redistribution and solidarity. I welcome the proposals for the development of indicators for resource use, optimisation of supply chains and waste ranking, which will have a considerable impact on environmental design. The creation of passports for products will increase responsible production on the part of producers, as well as consumer confidence.  The industrial symbioses generated by this communication will contribute to the global increase in the competitiveness of our companies, as well as to economic independence from those raw materials that come from areas of high geopolitical risk, but without which the digital economy loses momentum.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Every European citizen produces 5 tonnes of waste a year and consumes up to 14 tonnes of raw materials. We are consuming and producing more and more as planetary resources dwindle by the day. This must stop so as not to seriously handicap the lives of our children and grandchildren.  To avoid this waste of food, products, energy or materials, the European Parliament demands, in the text voted on Wednesday, ambitious and binding European legislation. More efficient waste management and product longevity must once again become European priorities. Reuse, repair or transform: these are the three key words of the circular economy. Without it, our society has no future.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament approved a report entitled ‘Resource efficiency: moving towards a circular economy’. As an ITRE rapporteur for the opinion on the legislative part of the package I was personally very much interested in this file and I submitted several amendments on the report. I am glad that the European Parliament approved the report by a comfortable majority and confirmed the importance of this issue. The report contains a number of recommendations on setting non-binding targets for energy efficiency, introducing common definitions and systems for waste sorting and waste management. It deals also with the production phase, supporting the emergence of the market for secondary raw materials and the energy efficiency of buildings. This report serves as an input for the European Commission, as the Commission will introduce a new, revised and more comprehensive package of measures for the transition to the circular economy by the end of 2015.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The fight for the environment requires better management of our waste and new consumption habits. It is with this in mind that the European Parliament adopted the Pietik-inen report on the circular economy. We would like to encourage the Commission to make proposals on this issue quickly. The main challenge of moving to a circular economy is the extension of the life of a product. This implies a fight against programmed obsolescence. It is also necessary to facilitate the reuse and processing of products by turning to eco-design. This serves two purposes: to reduce our waste and relieve the enormous pressure we put on our natural resources. Parliament has proposed concrete measures to initiate this transition, including: the introduction of constraints to reduce energy waste by 30% on resources compared to 2014; increasing recycling targets to 70% for municipal waste by 2030 and 80% for packaging waste by 2030.  While I welcome the collective awareness on these issues, I will remain vigilant to ensure that these proposals translate into action.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While in principle I support a call for a circular economy based on the link between better resource use and waste minimisation, I cannot support the overly restrictive nature of certain requirements in the report, such as the requirement to extend the scope of the Eco-Directive beyond energy-related products or the requirement to prevent producers from shortening the shelf life of products in order to increase sales. I believe that the proposed measures could lead to unnecessary additional administrative costs, both for the public and private sectors. I certainly believe that planning plays an important role in the efficient construction of the circular economy, however, projections aiming at a minimum of 70% recycled solid municipal waste and I consider 80% packaging waste to be too ambitious and disproportionate, and I am convinced that a significantly different approach, such as voluntary agreement with industry and rewarding positive developments and changes in waste treatment, would yield significantly better results. I consider that the report in the form voted on the committee is a step back in the Commission's efforts in the circular economy segment, and contains significant risks of imposing disproportionate burdens and unnecessary costs on the business sector, and I certainly support my parliamentary group's efforts to provide a more balanced report through plenary amendments that will offer strategic support to the Commission, rather than unrealistic and aggravating projections and deadlines.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I was unable to support the resolutions because of the adoption of points that are unacceptable to my political group. In view of the increasing level of pollution and inefficient use of resources, the EC presented a 'circular economy package' in 2014. The package includes the introductory idea of a waste-free Europe programme, a legislative proposal to review waste legislation, a communication on resource efficiency in the construction sector, a Communication on a Green Action Plan for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises and a Communication on Green Employment. The Communication calls for binding resource efficiency objectives and the development of resource efficiency indicators. I did not support this resolution because the demands of our political group were not taken into account. It is important to strike a balance between the challenges posed by the green (circular) economy and the associated costs.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we consider it necessary to extend the scope of the Eco-Design Directive, update waste standards and give visibility to certain areas, such as the construction of sustainable buildings. We are facing a paradigm shift and it is necessary to set binding targets for waste reduction, as well as gradually reduce all types of waste dumping. To address the problem of resource scarcity, we consider it necessary to reduce its extraction and use and break the direct link between growth and use of natural resources. Parliament calls on the Commission to promote a product lifecycle approach and to present in this area 'an ambitious work plan'. This should include the revision of eco-design legislation by the end of 2016 to expand its scope to cover all product categories. It also requests the Commission to determine requirements for the durability criteria of the products and in relation to the possibility of repairing, reusing and recycling them, and to propose measures to put an end to the programmed obsolescence.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the report. I find the requirement to introduce mandatory separate collection of bio-waste by 2020 problematic, the deadline is very difficult to meet. This is similar to the binding objectives of reducing and completely banning landfilling, while at the same time worsening the conditions for the operation of incinerators.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The circular economy is about decoupling economic growth and resource use. Ultimately, a new doctrine of development is at stake. This commissioned initiative report tells the Commission the content of the proposals it is due to make at the end of 2015. This is a series of incentives, including a policy of "eco-design" of products; to move towards "zero waste", to impose very restrictive standards on buildings in terms of energy consumption and to renovate the existing building in this sense, to develop "industrial synergies" in order to use cascading resources. This policy, which is responsible and visionary at first sight, is at odds with the economic model advocated by the European Union. The basis for a viable circular economy would be to promote short circuits, labour and production at home and thus to limit international trade. This text is therefore derisory and harmful since it is only a blank cheque to the Commission to enact new unsuccessful requirements for Member States. I voted against it.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Irresponsible use of resources can pose a danger to the environment, leading to climate change, biodiversity decline, loss of diversity and deterioration of ecosystem services. In the context where Europe depends on important resources, which will run out in a relatively short period of time, and at a time when, for global production and waste absorption, the world economy is using resources related to a planet and a half, I believe that a rapid transition to a circular economy is needed. This is an economic concept closely linked to sustainable development and whose objective is to produce goods and services while limiting the careless consumption of raw materials, water and energy sources. In order to avoid an economic and environmental impasse in Europe and globally, there is a need for an increase in resource efficiency, which implies the removal of today's linear economy, perfectly characterized by the phrase "we-use-produce-consume-throwaway". Furthermore, I argue that particular attention must be paid to territorial planning and transport solutions for the construction of a sustainable society.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour as we consider it necessary to extend the scope of the Eco-Design Directive, update waste standards and give visibility to certain areas, such as the construction of sustainable buildings. We are facing a paradigm shift and it is necessary to set binding targets for waste reduction, as well as gradually reduce all types of waste dumping. To address the problem of resource scarcity, we consider it necessary to reduce its extraction and use and break the direct link between growth and use of natural resources. Parliament calls on the Commission to promote a product lifecycle approach and to present in this area 'an ambitious work plan'. This should include the revision of eco-design legislation by the end of 2016 to expand its scope to cover all product categories. It also requests the Commission to determine requirements for the durability criteria of the products and in relation to the possibility of repairing, reusing and recycling them, and to propose measures to put an end to the programmed obsolescence. In addition, the Commission is urged to propose these objectives by the end of 2015.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
