text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a call for a truly more ambitious proposal on the circular economy from the Commission by the end of 2015. To summarise, the report calls for an inclusion of binding targets on waste reduction, increased targets for recycling, separate collection of biowaste, and ending the burning of recyclable and biodegradable waste. And for product policies it calls for binding an absolute reduction in the consumption of resources to sustainable levels and the phasing out of toxic substances.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that working towards a circular economy is a key step towards implementing the resource efficiency agenda established under the Europe 2020 Strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Circular economy systems keep the added value in products for a longer time and significantly reduce waste. The idea is to make use of resources more efficiently; once a product has reached the end of its life, these resources can be used several more times and thus continue to generate value. A circular economy is today an essential way to address the current and future challenges of global pressure on resources and rising insecurity of supply.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my EPLP colleagues I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls for further work on the package to include a focus on more sustainable design and innovation; the need for smarter regulation; the need to remove barriers to innovative business models; better exchange of information; and the need for cross-cutting measures that take account of the synergies between environmental policies and other actions aimed at encouraging growth and innovation.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The circular economy aims to reduce the consumption of resources and raw materials and the various pollutions by improving recycling, energy efficiency, reducing waste volume and better product design. Some amendments from the right have weakened the resolution, removing binding targets by 2030 to maintain only a vague benchmark for 2050. The reduction of food or industrial waste, representing a significant part of the waste, has been taken out of the scope, industrial lobby obliges. The Commission withdrew this issue from its work programme in December 2014. Instead, Parliament is calling for a proposal by the end of the year. This resolution is complementary to the resolution on green jobs. Without much illusions about the willingness to move forward on these ideas on both the part of the Commission and the Member States, I nevertheless see some avenues to work within the framework of the definition of another economy. So I also voted for no illusions. The EPP and the FN voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The legislative proposal on waste was controversially withdrawn by the Commission a couple of months later and was heavily criticised by the European Parliament, EU environment ministers and civil society.  The report calls for significant improvements compared to the commission's withdrawal proposal, as it has not made any proposal for binding reduction targets, and this report calls for mandatory targets for reducing waste production by 2025.  The Commission is urged to present a new, more ambitious proposal by the end of 2015, reflecting waste prevention measures, binding waste reduction targets for urban, industrial and commercial waste, to be achieved by 2025, and calls for the "pay as you throw" principle for waste waste to be applied, to be combined with mandatory selective collection systems for paper , metal, plastic and glass, introducing the requirement for separate collection of biowaste by 2020.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report contains very good approaches, such as the design of a policy in favour of sustainable food, the objectives are sometimes excessive. Given the unclear starting point as to how such an objective will prevail in the short term, I abstained from voting and hope for realistic and concrete solutions.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Circular economy creates significant business opportunities for European companies. Many of the resources we are now using carelessly are running out. Consumption is also increasing, especially in developing regions with young and growing populations. It is essential that existing resources be used more efficiently in the future. In Europe, raw materials account for 40% of production costs. High-tech products in particular require rare imported minerals. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Sirpa Pietikäinen, for her good work, and at the same time I encourage Vice-President Katainen to draw up a circular economy package so that we can make strong progress. At its best, the circular economy is a new model of the economy, where materials and value circulate and add value to them through services and intelligence. In my own country, Finland, it has been estimated that the circular economy could grow the economy by over EUR 2 billion per year. At European level, the circular economy would increase GDP by 1% a year.  The bioeconomy is an important part of the circular economy. It is of particular importance for achieving climate objectives. However, it should be noted that requiring cascade use in the circular economy would create many problems, as it is difficult to define waste and residues. Today's waste could be tomorrow's raw material. It is precisely the uncertainty in the regulatory environment that is currently significantly slowing down investment in Europe.  We need to take a pro-business approach. If the Ecodesign Directive is extended, it must be done in cooperation with companies. It is not appropriate to set common limit values; It is important to note that conditions differ across Europe. Sufficient room for manoeuvre must be left to adopt best practices.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on 'Resource efficiency: transition to a circular economy'. It is my belief that the Eu ropean Union must maintain its leadership in promoting the circular economy by developing innovative models for the reuse, repair, recycling and renewal of products and goods already in circulation. It is now crucial to maximise the efficiency of resources by minimising the amount of waste produced. I particularly support the provision of binding targets, to be respected by 2025, regarding waste reduction at the level of local governance, at the commercial and industrial level.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote because it is essential that the Commission adopts a package of circular economy legislative initiatives as soon as possible. We must commit ourselves to reversing the current trend as soon as possible thanks to a paradigm shift that sees the transition from a linear economy to a circular economy. The implementation of a circular economy model responds to key policy challenges in the EU such as job creation, innovation, a change in industrial policy and intelligent use of resources. Finally, I would like to stress that our group's contribution has been fundamental in achieving this important result.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Pietikäinen report "on resource efficiency: transition to a circular economy" because I believe that the commitment to a circular economy, which allows the creation of wealth by incorporating waste management into the value chain, is a smart and urgent bet on the environmental, economic and social challenges that societies face at the same time. Deregulated globalisation leads to an increase in inequalities and our environmental footprint. The circular economy is an integrated and holistic approach to the challenges of globalisation, combining economic competitiveness and environmental sustainability and enabling economic growth for current generations without compromising the development of future generations. To this end, this report clearly sets out the objectives and targets to be achieved to achieve the necessary transition to a circular economy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The physical limits of our planet are constantly being confronted by the largely dominant economic and social system on a global scale – capitalism. This report of course does not make any criticism of this self-destructive system. As far as the problem of waste is necessary today is a strong presence and role of states in this area, ensuring the prevalence of the public interest and public services over private business. This is the opposite of what is being done in several countries, such as Portugal, where, against the position of the people and municipalities, progress has been made for the privatisation of the waste sector.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report in which Parliament instructs the European Commission what to include in the legislative proposal on the circular economy and the revision of European waste legislation. My favourable position is justified by the fact that the no longer sustainable use of resources is causing damage to the environment and the ecosystem and also represents an economic risk. We therefore need a more efficient use of resources that decreases dependence on raw materials and leads to savings in material costs. This policy would also create new business activities and jobs in Europe.  Our delegation has tabled a number of amendments - many of which have been accepted - which aimed to facilitate the introduction of the certificate of origin; the reduced application or elimination of VAT to recycled and reused products; a separate target on the reuse of materials to prevent and reduce waste production; a ban on incineration; our demands in the field of construction, such as the introduction of mandatory national waste management plans in this area; environmental declarations for construction products and demolition methods that allow the recovery of materials to reuse or recycle them and, finally, to set a target on reuse at European level.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained from the final vote on the Pietikäinen report on resource efficiency, as the transition to a circular economy can bring many benefits both to the environment and to the economy, but at the same time many of the report's requirements represent an unnecessary increase in bureaucracy and are not sufficiently elaborate (e.g. the proliferation of eco-design requirements, which in some respects have proved bad in some respects in the past). Unlike a traditional linear economy based on a pattern: take-make-use-to-dispose, the circular economy is based on reuse, repair and recycling. The circular economy can reduce pressure on the environment, have a positive health impact and reduce Europe's dependence on raw material imports, and the European Commission estimates it could create as many as 2 million jobs by 2030. According to some research, increased energy efficiency of buildings could generate over €1 billion a year to save energy in the EU. Appropriately insulating buildings, the EU would save millions of tonnes of fossil fuels and CO2 emissions would be drastically reduced. According to some estimates, an efficient circular economy could bring between 12% and 23% savings to companies in purchasing materials.  I therefore expect the draft legislation to be drafted by the European Commission by the end of 2015 to be more elaborate, such as the Pietikäinen report, while taking into account all the advantages that a circular economy can bring to the European economy, the environment and people.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. We want an energy model based on renewables and without nuclear, but the report adopted today seeks to set safe limits for food in the event of a nuclear accident. The Parliament has requested to change the legal basis to Articles 168 and 114 TFEU, as I think it is appropriate. However, for the time being, we are returned to the role of mere consultants. We have to be practical. Without entering any expert warfare, the limits set by Euratom may be insufficient, but those of any other body (FAO, Codex or independent) are not linked to EU law and are therefore indicative. I am not against stricter limits, but under the Euratom procedure the only way we have to influence the setting and application of these limits is with a regulation on which we can hold the Commission to account. European experts will speak again on the right limits to our continent. The sensible thing to do is to review the Euratom limits on the basis of our needs, to make these law, European legislation, and to be able to intervene in the event of any non-compliance. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the Herranz García report on maximum tolerances for radioactive contamination because the proposed levels and guarantees for food safety are clearly insufficient. This has been denounced by many experts, whom the rapporteur never called a meeting, despite the initiative of my parliamentary group.  I am convinced that legal instruments are needed to prevent accidents such as chernobyl and Fukushima on EU territory, and the closure of outdated nuclear power plants such as Garogne is urgently urgent. It is also essential to establish, on the basis of strict scientific criteria, controls to allow us to discard contaminated food from places where there has been a nuclear leak.  Proponents of nuclear power have not been unable to find a minimally reasonable solution to this problem, which mortgages the future of our offspring. I therefore advocate strict controls on radioactive contamination, while dismantling nuclear power plants. Since this report neither ensures rigorous controls nor bets on the closure of nuclear, I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The aim of this report was to lay down the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident. However, I believe that the measures included are insufficient to provide adequate protection and the legislation proposes maximum levels which do not correspond to many experts’ recommendations.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2010 has once again shown that, despite the latest technology and safety precautions, a nuclear accident can never be ruled out. Such emergencies do not stop at borders, as the Chernobyl reactor accident, for example, has shown. We need pan-European strategies to be better prepared for such incidents. This includes clear provisions on the maximum levels of radioactivity in food and feed. They can help to ensure that consumers are protected from contaminated food more quickly when a nuclear emergency occurs. For these reasons, I support the report by Esther Herranz Garcia.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports several proposals in the event of a radioactive emergency, including giving the Commission the power to act urgently by implementing regulation to lower radioactivity thresholds or to punish Member States for allowing products to circulate beyond the permitted limits.  Despite the presentation of the report, the limits set there are the same as in 1987, even though Japan adopted new, stricter standards after the Fukushima disaster. I regret that the National Front was not heard when it asked that Member States be allowed to suspend the free movement of goods and people in an emergency, as the current limits are not satisfactory.  I consider this text to be mainly cosmetic and in no way a step forward on the nuclear security front. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the text as a whole because I believe that the overall power should lie with the Member States and not the European Union.   Nevertheless, I agree with the concept that there should be tough standards on these issues and therefore I voted accordingly on the amendments.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that this issue is not within the purview of the European Parliament but must remain within Euratom's competence.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The European Union should have updated legal instruments establishing flexible and case-by-case decision-making mechanisms to address situations such as those in the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents.  April 2010 The Commission has submitted a proposal for Regulation (Euratom) No 3954/87 setting maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or any other case of radiological emergency, Commission Regulation (Euratom) No 944/89 setting maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs in small quantities following a nuclear accident or any other case of radiological emergency and Commission Regulation (Euratom) No 770/90 setting maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of feedingstuffs in the event of a nuclear accident or any other radiological accident. In the event of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency, the Commission will adopt an implementing act to apply maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs. The Commission shall be given considerable flexibility to change the levels set out in the Annexes, where necessary, where circumstances so require.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this unacceptable text as the proposed limits have remained unchanged since 1989 and Amendments 53 and 56 have been rejected. Amendment 53, tabled by the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, proposed to allow Member States to use Article 36 to protect their people and livestock, and to prevent contaminated food from entering their territory.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The text on the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination after a nuclear accident aims to revise three regulations dating from the 1980s and 1990s that defined the limits of radioactivity allowed in food after a nuclear accident. This text with positive intentions, however, is a shambles. Indeed, if one looks at the text in question, the defined limits are the same as those set in a regulation almost thirty years old. This immobility and inaction is particularly damaging, even though countries such as Japan have introduced standards after the earthquake of 11 March 2011 up to twenty times lower than those of the European Union. The minimum would be to allow Member States to suspend the dogma of free movement in the event of a nuclear accident in order to guarantee the food security of the French. This text, cosmetic, could be improved and be really effective if amended. As it stands, I can only vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Herranz García report analyses the legislation on maximum levels of radioactivity, which are permissible for food, food and animals following a nuclear accident. I think it is inconceivable that this text should aim to maintain the same levels as those proposed in 1989, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We want an energy model based on renewables and without nuclear, but the report adopted today seeks to set safe limits for food in the event of a nuclear accident. The Parliament has requested to change the legal basis to Articles 168 and 114 TFEU, as I think it is appropriate. However, for the time being, we are returned to the role of mere consultants. We have to be practical. Without entering any expert warfare, the limits set by Euratom may be insufficient, but those of any other body (FAO, Codex or independent) are not linked to EU law and are therefore indicative. I am not against stricter limits, but under the Euratom procedure the only way we have to influence the setting and application of these limits is with a regulation on which we can hold the Commission to account. European experts will speak again on the right limits to our continent. The sensible thing to do is to review the Euratom limits on the basis of our needs, to make these law, European legislation, and to be able to intervene in the event of any non-compliance. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Union should update the legal instrument framework in order to deal with disasters such as the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents. The Commission has presented a new proposal for a regulation setting maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or any other case of radiological emergency. The new proposal, which was the subject of this report, includes certain new elements which establish clearer links with European Union food safety legislation. In the event of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency, the Commission will adopt an implementing act to apply maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs. The Commission shall be given considerable flexibility to change the levels set out in the Annexes, where necessary, where circumstances so require.  As regards the implementing acts adopted in the event of a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency, the European Parliament report shall provide for the possibility of modifying them where necessary in order to take account of changes in pollution. Parliament's report shall clarify the recitals by setting out the parameters used to set the maximum permitted levels specified in the Annexes to the Regulation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the report building on the 2010 legislation on the setting of maximum levels for radioactive contamination of foodstuffs intended for consumption in the event of nuclear accidents or other events which could lead to contamination. Parliament insists on this that it wishes to participate in any changes to these thresholds if, on the basis of future research, certain things would change, which seems to me to be the only right way to go.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The aim of this report was to lay down the maximum permitted levels of  radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident. However, I believe that the measures included are insufficient to provide adequate protection and the legislation proposes maximum levels which do not correspond to many experts’ recommendations.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is important for the health of European citizens to set maximum permissible levels of radioactivity in food, given that the high harmfulness of radioactive products has been demonstrated.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dangers of radioactive contamination cannot be overlooked. Since the Chernobyl disaster, the long-term effects of radioactive pollution have become known to everyone. Numerous and in-depth studies demonstrate the serious repercussions on humans, animals, plants and the environment in general. It is in the European Union's interest to prevent the risk of contamination and to have high safety standards in order to guarantee the health of citizens and the quality of agri-food products intended for trade and consumption within the Territory of the Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this text is to revise three regulations dating from 1987, 1989 and 1990 defining the limits of radioactivity allowed in food following a nuclear accident. Cosmetic in nature, it does not substantially change admission levels for contaminated food, which remains too high and no longer meets new public health requirements. In addition, the text does not provide for the authory of Member States to suspend the free movement of products in the event of radioactive contamination of certain foods. Finally, it entrusts the European Commission with a wider supervisory power which it does not seem capable of properly assuming.  For all these reasons and because the amendment tabled by the ENL group was rejected, I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The unfortunate events of Chernobyl and Fukushima, which have claimed thousands of lives and left a black spot in human history, must be reference points for both the European Union and the entire international spectrum in relation to the measures to be taken in the future in the event of a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency. The European Union has a duty to dispose of and provide up-to-date legal instruments, which include flexible and situation-specific decision-making procedures, in order to deal with situations of the type after nuclear accidents. That is why I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed after a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency because I believe that the European Union must be prepared to prevent such eminently unfortunate situations, which endanger the lives of its citizens.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This proposal is not acceptable in view of the proposed radioactivity limits, the same since 1989.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting maximum permissible levels of radioactivity for foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or in any other case of radiological emergency. As the report points out, it is absolutely essential that the European Union has up-to-date legal instruments that contain decision-making procedures capable of dealing with emergency situations such as those experienced after the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents.  The use of implementing acts to respond to nuclear accidents or other types of radioactive emergencies is the most appropriate way of responding adequately to this need. I therefore believe that in the event of an extreme emergency, the adoption of an implementing act without prior examination must be made possible. In addition, Parliament must reserve the right of codecision with regard to the modification of the maximum permissible levels of radioactivity for foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or in any other case of radiological emergency, should it be necessary to review them in the light of new scientific knowledge.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The aim of this report was to lay down the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident. However, I believe that the measures included are insufficient to provide adequate protection and the legislation proposes maximum levels which do not correspond to many experts’ recommendations.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the text as a whole because I believe that overall power should lie with the Member States and not the European Union. Nevertheless, I agree with the concept that there should be tough standards on these issues and therefore I voted accordingly on the amendments.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to replace the 1987 Regulation concerning the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed originating from within the EU or imported from third countries, according to the location and circumstances of the nuclear accident or emergency. This Regulation was first established following the Chernobyl disaster. The Report mainly calls for a change in legal basis, thus fully involves the Parliament as co-legislator and strengthens the role of the Commission in the implementation stage of the legislation

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal states that the maximum permissible levels of radioactive contamination established in 1987 and to be applied following a nuclear accident or in any other case of radioactive emergency which could give rise to significant contamination of foodstuffs and feedingstuffs are not yet in line with the latest scientific advice available at international level. It then lays down the adoption procedures. If adopted as proposed by the Commission, the regulation could lead to binding rules for all Member States, aimed at not allowing food and animal feed not to be brought onto the EU market that do not comply with the maximum levels of radioactivity. Of course, the fundamental problem relates to the method by which these limits are scientifically established and we intend to monitor the way in which these thresholds will be indicated.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution setting the maximum permitted levels of radioactivity in food and feed due to a nuclear accident or in the event of a radiological emergency.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting maximum permissible levels of radioactivity for foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or in any other case of radiological emergency. It is, in fact, desirable that the EU should have up-to-date legal instruments containing decision-making procedures that are agile and adapted to all situations to deal with situations such as those experienced after the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents. The proposal sets out, in its annexes, the maximum permissible levels in the event of an accident or radioactive emergency which were confirmed in 2012 by the Expert Group set up by Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe it is essential for the European Union to take the necessary measures to deal with the risks of contamination following a nuclear accident. As has been shown, prolonged consumption of food products with important levels of radioactivity has extremely harmful consequences on the cells of the human body. We must therefore endeavour to increase food safety within the Union in order to prevent radioactive contamination from increasing. That is why the European Parliament is promoting the establishment of appropriate maximum permissible levels in the event of an accident or a radiological emergency. These levels have already been confirmed in 2012 by a group of experts set up under Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty and have been included in the European Commission's Publication Radiation Protection 105. Finally, it will be necessary not only to monitor products from the country affected by the accident but also to increase control for neighbouring countries, since they are also at risk of radioactive fallout on their food. While we hope that disasters such as Chernobyl and Fukushima will not happen again, it is nevertheless important to do everything possible to prevent radioactive contamination.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which establishes the use of implementing acts to deal with critical situations arising from a nuclear accident or other type of radioactive emergency, and which requires swift action, especially to protect consumers. The general objective is to establish rapid and effective cooperation between the institutions in the event of urgency and to take account of developments in Community food safety law by establishing the conditions for importing food or feedingstuffs from third countries affected by a nuclear emergency.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this motion for resolution as it continues to further strengthen consumer protection within the European Union. Consumers have increasingly become more conscious of the food products they wish to acquire. Through these amendments the regulation is changed so as to give Parliament the power of co-decision. This right will enable the Parliament to be more effective and improve the lives of the citizens. In this case, the levels of radioactive contamination of food were set by Euratom experts while the legal basis was changed to reflect the Parliament’s power of codecision. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the Herranz García report on maximum tolerances for radioactive contamination because the proposed levels and guarantees for food safety are clearly insufficient. This has been denounced by many experts, whom the rapporteur never called a meeting, despite the initiative of my parliamentary group.  I am convinced that legal instruments are needed to prevent accidents such as chernobyl and Fukushima on EU territory, and the closure of outdated nuclear power plants such as Garogne is urgently urgent. It is also essential to establish, on the basis of strict scientific criteria, controls to allow us to discard contaminated food from places where there has been a nuclear leak.  Proponents of nuclear power have not been unable to find a minimally reasonable solution to this problem, which mortgages the future of our offspring. I therefore advocate strict controls on radioactive contamination, while dismantling nuclear power plants. Since this report neither ensures rigorous controls nor bets on the closure of nuclear, I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination following a nuclear accident. The EU is in strong need of up-to-date legal instruments that include flexible, incident-specific decision-making procedures to address situations like those that occurred in the wake of the accidents at Chernobyl and Fukushima. The EP report calls for the establishing of the lowest maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination, for more intense consultation with independent experts when reviewing maximum levels, for adapting classification following new scientific evidence and also for strengthening compliance controls and penalties for non-compliance. As this report aims at protecting human health in the aftermath of a nuclear accident I have given my support for it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report establishes the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food, smaller foodstuffs and feed that may be marketed after a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency that could result in or result in significant radioactive contamination of food and feed. , as well as procedures for making these maximum allowable levels applicable.  I support this report, which is balanced. Nevertheless, I objected to the rapporteur's amendment of the legal basis from a simple consultation of Parliament in the euratom Treaty to a codecision procedure under Article 168, paragraph 4, paragraph b), and Article 114 of the FUE Treaty. Indeed, under recent court jurisprudence and an opinion of the parliamentary committee in charge of legal affairs, such an amendment could be annulled in the event of a dispute with the Council. Having failed to succeed on this question of form, I nevertheless voted in favour of this important report for the public health of European citizens.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting maximum permissible levels of radioactivity following a nuclear accident, as I agree with the need for up-to-date legal instruments and appropriate decision-making procedures to enable these emergency situations to be addressed. I think it is important to change the legal basis of the regulation in order to give the European Parliament the power of codecision.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the Fukushima disaster, the European Union had to update its legislation setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination after a nuclear accident.  This report therefore incorporates the new data as defined by the International Commission for Radiological Protection (ICRP). The objective is twofold, namely to reduce as much as possible the exposure of populations to radioactivity following a nuclear or radiological crisis, while guaranteeing a gradual resumption of economic activities.  This legislative update should also help to consolidate existing Euratom standards in the area of health protection. Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty on the development of standards for the protection of the population and workers from the dangers of radiation forms, I believe, the appropriate legal basis for this regulation.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation supports the original proposal of the European Commission and therefore votes against Parliament's position. In its opinion of 31 March 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs clearly advocates the preservation of the Euratom legal basis, as proposed by the European Commission. This is also consistent with other legislation in this area. As regards rules for the protection of public health against radioactive substances in water intended for human consumption, the European Parliament also wanted to amend the legal basis. However, the Court of Justice disagrees and made it clear that the procedure laid down in Articles 31 and 32 of the Euratom Treaty takes precedence over more general provisions of the VWEU in the case of Union measures to protect public health from radiation and radioactive contamination. The Committee on Legal Affairs considers that, even in the present legislation, a change in the legal basis would most likely lead to annulment of the act if challenged before the Court.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the Council's proposed regulation setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food and feed after a nuclear accident or in any other radiological emergency. Once again, this text reveals the EU's inability to protect the citizens of the Member States. Indeed, despite a misleading title, this report does not change the permissible levels of contamination. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I know the importance of reducing these levels for a public health purpose. States are the only guarantors of the protection and security of their citizens, which is why the Union must restore their decision-making capacity to them. It is about the health of people.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On 10 January 2014, the Commission modified its proposal, but maintained Articles 31 and 32 of the Euratom Treaty as legal bases. In response ENVI adopted its position changing the legal basis once again, replacing it with Articles 168(4)(b) and 114 TFEU. Both our shadow rapporteur and the JURI committee, consider this approach to be inconsistent with the idea of maintaining the European Atomic Energy Community as a separate organisation responsible for the functioning of the nuclear energy sector. Therefore, the ECR shadow rapporteur believes that the original Commission proposal was sufficient and rejects the conclusions of this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report on the proposal for a Council regulation establishing maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or other case of radiological contamination. The main reason for this was that the text goes some way at odds with the original idea of Euroatom being a separate and independent organisation to control the sector.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because the nuclear risk is permanently present and the Union must prepare itself as best as possible to mitigate the consequences of a possible and inevitable future accident.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This regulation starts with a 2010 Commission proposal to bring together three pieces of legislation on radioactivity levels permitted in food and feed. Having been approved on a legal basis of the Euroatom Treaty, the European Parliament would have been involved only for consultation. In 2011, however, the parliamentary assembly in plenary decided to request a change in the legal basis invoking the nature of health protection of the measure on the basis of which the changes must take place by a joint decision between the Council and Parliament. This gives us parliamentarians the power to intervene in the substance of the proposals and thus to link support to the initiative to the transposition of specific requests. For these reasons, we supported the change in the legal basis, but we did not confirm our vote for the final measure, since the Commission, with the support of the large political groups, managed to maintain the maximum permissible levels of radioactivity in food and feed, set back in 1987 and well above those set by the FAO and in force in the UNITED States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We agree that legislation should be more appropriate and up-to-date, so that in the event of nuclear accidents, such as those in Chernobyl and Fukushima, swift and effective measures are taken to protect and ensure food safety for European consumers. The levels and guarantees proposed in the food safety report were not sufficient. In the Codex Alimentarius, revised in 2013, specific criteria for radionuclides in food are proposed, with more restrictive criteria, and the need for a change in the levels established in case of emergency. The levels proposed in this report, on the other year, fall short of what is necessary for effective consumer protection and the safety of Europe's people in the event of a nuclear accident. The Codex also proposes the inclusion of other radioactive isotopes that were not included in Annex I.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the evolution of primary Community law in the field of food security, as well as the need to guarantee the coherence of all legislative measures relating to the conditions of imports of food and feed originating in third countries affected either by a nuclear accident or another case of radiological emergency, it is necessary to align the measures adopted in the post-Chernobyl period with the new system of implementing procedures and powers defined in the proposal for this Regulation. I therefore agree with the change in the legal basis.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not support this report as the proposal is not acceptable given the proposed radioactivity limits: the same as in 1989, but with much changed environmental conditions to date in 2015.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the maximum permitted levels of radioactivity due to a nuclear accident, because the nuclear risk is permanently present and the Union must prepare itself as best as possible to mitigate the impact of a possible and inevitable future accident.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely important to have legal instruments that include flexible, incident-specific decision-making procedures to address situations like those that occurred in the wake of the accidents at Chernobyl and Fukushima. I welcome the inclusion in the report of the referral to the need of consultation with independent experts when reviewing maximum levels. Moreover, full information must be made immediately available to the general public. Food safety is the ultimate objective of the Council regulation: therefore I strongly support that the change of the legal base of the Lisbon Treaty is appropriate to give the European Parliament an appropriate say in the protection of public health, in line with its co-legislative role.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PpE group and the Fidesz delegation welcome the Commission's strategy in this important area, since, together with the rapporteur, it proposes to amend the legal basis of the regulation in line with the opinion adopted by the European Parliament in 2010, giving Parliament codecision powers. It is crucial that food safety is the ultimate objective of the Commission's proposal and that the regulation should reflect changes in Community law since the adoption of the Maastricht Treaty (1992). In my opinion, the most appropriate and quickest way to deal with critical situations resulting from a nuclear accident or other radioactive emergency is to use implementing acts. I also welcome the fact that the draft report also states that the European Commission is obliged to report to Parliament and the Council on measures adopted in the event of a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. We want an energy model based on renewables and without nuclear, but the report adopted today seeks to set safe limits for food in the event of a nuclear accident. The Parliament has requested to change the legal basis to Articles 168 and 114 TFEU, as I think it is appropriate. However, for the time being, we are returned to the role of mere consultants. We have to be practical. Without entering any expert warfare, the limits set by Euratom may be insufficient, but those of any other body (FAO, Codex or independent) are not linked to EU law and are therefore indicative. I am not against stricter limits, but under the Euratom procedure the only way we have to influence the setting and application of these limits is with a regulation on which we can hold the Commission to account. European experts will speak again on the right limits to our continent. The sensible thing to do is to review the Euratom limits on the basis of our needs, to make these law, European legislation, and to be able to intervene in the event of any non-compliance. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. We want an energy model based on renewables and without nuclear, but the report adopted today seeks to set safe limits for food in the event of a nuclear accident. The Parliament has requested to change the legal basis to Articles 168 and 114 TFEU, as I think it is appropriate. However, for the time being, we are returned to the role of mere consultants. We have to be practical. Without entering any expert warfare, the limits set by Euratom may be insufficient, but those of any other body (FAO, Codex or independent) are not linked to EU law and are therefore indicative. I am not against stricter limits, but under the Euratom procedure the only way we have to influence the setting and application of these limits is with a regulation on which we can hold the Commission to account. European experts will speak again on the right limits to our continent. The sensible thing to do is to review the Euratom limits on the basis of our needs, to make these law, European legislation, and to be able to intervene in the event of any non-compliance. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting maximum levels of radioactivity in food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency. I am a father of seven, I have children – which is also why the arbitrary limits do not go far enough for me.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I supported the Herranz - Garcia report given strong measures are needed to ensure swift action to protect public health from contaminated food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident.  The EU needs up-to-date legal instruments that include flexible, incident-specific decision-making procedures to address situations like those that occurred in the wake of the accidents at Chernobyl and Fukushima.  I do, however, believe MEPs should be given a stronger role in setting maximum limits on radioactive contamination of food and feed, and that the public has a right to be fully informed when measures are taken in reaction to a nuclear accident.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the proposed regulation setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food after a nuclear accident.  Despite more transparency with the public, this regulation does not go back to the essentials: the maximum allowable limit for radioactive contamination. Thus, the proposed limits are always those of 1987! This is all the more scandalous given that other countries, such as Japan, have more protective limits of 8 to 20 and the Union applies these more protective limits on products imported from Japan.  In the face of this absurdity, I have therefore proposed that each Member State should be able to set its own limits and suspend imports of food that does not comply with it. I also supported a proposal to drastically reduce limits.  These protection measures, however, were not followed by elected officials more committed to free trade than to the protection of the population, especially the so-called Republican and centrist French elected representatives. The French Socialists did nothing better by supporting a final text whose inefficiency they know is ineffective. As is often the case on public health issues, I could not give blank-seing to the Commission, whose priority is not to protect us.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In order to determine the concentrations of toxic products allowed in the diet of more than 500 million Europeans, including millions of children, we must be very rigorous and listen to the best experts in the field. However, in this case many recommendations have well not been taken into account, or have been rejected as the amendments containing them were not adopted. We consider radioactive materials to be carcinogenic and mutagenic substances for which there is no particular safety threshold. We support amendments which set maximum safety tolerances, but we cannot support a report which we do not consider sufficiently worked.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Myself and my fellow Labour MEPs support measures which ensure that swift action can be taken to protect the health of the general public from contaminated food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident. However, Labour MEPs would like to see MEPs given a stronger role in setting maximum limits and call for full information to be made publically available.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs and feedingstuffs following a nuclear accident or any radiological emergency, as I believe that the European Union should have updated legislative instruments establishing flexible and case-by-case decision-making mechanisms to address situations such as those of the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents Questions. This is not the first time that Parliament has been consulted on similar proposals. This new report includes new elements that establish clearer links with EU food safety legislation. I believe that it is very important to ensure the safety of Europeans.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In order to determine the concentrations of toxic products allowed in the diet of more than 500 million Europeans, including millions of children, we must be very rigorous and listen to the best experts in the field. However, in this case many recommendations have well not been taken into account, or have been rejected as the amendments containing them were not adopted. We consider radioactive materials to be carcinogenic and mutagenic substances for which there is no particular safety threshold. We support amendments which set maximum safety tolerances, but we cannot support a report which we do not consider sufficiently worked.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Council regulation establishing the maximum levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed after a nuclear accident or any other radiological hazard, as the new proposal introduces some elements more clearly linked to European food safety legislation. I support the application of a codecision procedure that further engages the European Parliament in decision-making in this particularly sensitive sector. It is important to mention that in cases of contamination it is crucial to ensure as quick and efficient action as possible in order to minimize the consequences. Food safety affects various aspects of everyday life, and therefore it is necessary to be especially careful and try to act preventively because the effects of nuclear and radiological accidents are very clear.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the proposed regulation setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food after a nuclear accident. This report supports several proposals in the event of a radiological emergency, including giving the Commission the power to act urgently by implementing regulation to lower radioactivity thresholds or to punish Member States for allowing out-of-bounds products to circulate.  Despite the presentation of the report, the limits set there are the same as in 1987, even though Japan adopted new limits after the Fukushima disaster. Unfortunately, the voices of the National Front have not been heard, and that is why we are calling for Member States to be able to suspend free movement, as the current limits are not satisfactory. This text is therefore purely cosmetic and is in no way a step forward on the nuclear security front.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Esther Herranz Garcia's report on the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination after a nuclear accident. The EU has legal instruments to respond quickly to a disaster such as Chernobyl or Fukushima. Among these instruments, food contamination thresholds are used to set a limit on the consumption of these foods. These thresholds must be regularly updated with the assistance of THE EURATOM agency. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on ‘maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident’ is a report to the effect that, in the case that a nuclear accident happens, the Europeans citizens would not be protected. This file will allow Europeans to consume food with radioactive contamination levels higher than what is recommended by most of the international agencies and experts. Moreover, the report doesn’t take on board many isotopes, and thus the legislation is poor.  EH Bildu strongly criticises the procedure by which the file was compromised, as the rapporteur clearly stated from the beginning that the maximum permitted shall not be modified, and as the agreed expert meeting never happened. The result of the plenary vote on amendments posed a situation in which important committee Amendments 1-3 on the legal basis of the text were carried, but Amendment 56 (RCV) on the levels of contamination and isotope types was rejected. Facing that situation, towards the final vote EH Bildu has abstained. For us it is unacceptable to have a legislation that doesn’t provide safety guarantees for the citizens, and since Amendment 56 was not carried, we were unable to vote in favour. Nevertheless, as Committee Amendments 1-3 were accepted which enables improved juridical instruments, we have considered the option of abstention.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food and feed after a nuclear accident or in any other radiological emergency. Indeed, following the serious accidents at Chernobyl and Fukushima, the European Union must be prepared to react quickly and effectively, particularly in view of the import conditions of food and animals which, affected, could seriously harm the health of European citizens.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report. In the context of the Fukushima disaster, a faster possibility of intervention in Europe is needed, in particular through implementing acts, in order to redefine maximum levels of contamination in food and feed. This would also strengthen the role of the European Parliament, as there is a say in setting new maximum values. Compensation is provided for affected farmers if their products are contaminated by radioactive precipitation. The text presented is therefore completely consistent and I agree with it.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Herranz Garcia's report, which set maximum levels for radioactive contamination of feed feed destined for the European market following a nuclear accident. It is necessary to set up a system enabling the Union, in the event of a nuclear accident or other case of radiological emergency which could give rise to significant radioactive contamination of foodstuffs and feedingstuffs, to set maximum permissible levels of radioactive contamination in order to ensure a high level of health protection.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the proposed regulation setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food and feed after a nuclear accident or in any other radiological emergency. Unfortunately, the proposal is only cosmetic. In fact, the defined limits, despite the title, remain the same as in 1987. This is all the more regrettable given that Japan set new limits in 2012, which are 8 to 20 times lower. The elected National Front of the Committee on the Environment had proposed to draw inspiration from it. We reissued this request in plenary, but our two amendments were not accepted.  There are positive points in the proposal, but it gives even more power to a Commission unable to set more protective thresholds, almost 30 years after 1987. In that case, how can we trust him?

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it does not really protect the people of Europe in the event of a nuclear accident. It sets permissible rates of radioactive contamination for food that are far too high, as the independent nuclear expert agency CRIIRAD points out. This is all the more unacceptable since Japan set allowable rates in 2012 20 times lower! Our ENL group has tabled an amendment to lower these too high rates, but the infernal Socialists/EPP couple (including Les Républicains) have agreed to reject it. Once again, the European Parliament is defending the interests of lobbies rather than the public interest.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of the Herranz García report on maximum tolerances for radioactive contamination because the proposed levels and guarantees for food safety are clearly insufficient. This has been denounced by many experts, whom the rapporteur never called a meeting, despite the initiative of my parliamentary group.  I am convinced that legal instruments are needed to prevent accidents such as chernobyl and Fukushima on EU territory, and the closure of outdated nuclear power plants such as Garogne is urgently urgent. It is also essential to establish, on the basis of strict scientific criteria, controls to allow us to discard contaminated food from places where there has been a nuclear leak.  Proponents of nuclear power have not been unable to find a minimally reasonable solution to this problem, which mortgages the future of our offspring. I therefore advocate strict controls on radioactive contamination, while dismantling nuclear power plants. Since this report neither ensures rigorous controls nor bets on the closure of nuclear, I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is known that after the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in 1986 and in Fukushima, Japan, in 2011, significant amounts of radioactive substances were dropped into the atmosphere, contaminating food and feed products in several European countries, which poses problems because a high degree of radioactive contamination is still present today. Worrying data suggests that 10 per cent of contaminated food is still consumed annually – one that has higher levels of radiation, destroys body cells resulting in the onset of cancer.   I supported Esther Herranz García's report and I believe it is necessary to set low thresholds for the maximum levels of radioactive contamination of food products to be monitored by each Member State and to take appropriate measures to reduce the amount of such food on the market in line with the results.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Council regulation setting the maximum permitted levels of radioactivity in food and feed due to a nuclear accident or in the event of a radiological emergency, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This proposal is all the more unacceptable because it is useless: far from proposing new levels or finally meeting the expectations of the Member States, it is content to maintain the limits established in 1989 and to give more powers to the Commission, which is known to be incapable of defining more protective thresholds almost 30 years later.  Our attempt to protect the sovereignty and interests of states through our amendments has failed. We therefore oppose this text.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this proposal because the new euratom regulation was urgently needed and Parliament is now having a say in setting the ceilings. Furthermore, farmers whose food has been contaminated by radioactive waste are now compensated by the 'polluter pays' principle.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Report which seeks to strengthen the requirements for the Commission to review and inform the Parliament about the implementing measures adopted in relation to a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to regulate the levels of radioactivity in food following a nuclear accident. It is indeed essential to protect European consumers from contaminated food as can be the case with products from Japan. However, the threshold is far above the scientific recommendations and, as it stands, does not adequately protect populations. Moreover, again, the issue is not seen as a whole. Indeed, this provision only accommodates the free trade in food, while the relocation of agriculture, which I defend, would allow the Member States to regain their food sovereignty and ensure the quality of their production. Finally, the other risks of radioactive contamination by air or water are avoided.  I vote against it to encourage awareness of the dangers of nuclear power, without endorsing the thresholds set.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports several proposals in the event of a radiological emergency, including giving the Commission the power to act urgently by implementing regulation to lower radioactivity thresholds or to punish Member States for allowing out-of-bounds products to circulate. Despite the presentation of the report, the limits set there are the same as in 1987, even though Japan adopted new limits after the Fukushima disaster. Unfortunately, the voices of the National Front have not been heard, and that is why we are calling for Member States to be able to suspend free movement, as the current limits are not satisfactory.  This text is therefore purely cosmetic and is in no way a step forward on the nuclear security front. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. It is important that the European Union has up-to-date legal instruments with simplified decision-making processes tailored to each situation to deal with situations such as those that occurred during the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents.  This proposal introduces some new elements that establish a clearer link with European food safety regulations.  There should therefore be stricter rules on imports of food from countries affected by nuclear accidents. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to apply the regular legislative procedure on matters of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs. As it currently stands, the Parliament needs only be consulted and this report would give the Parliament the power of co-decision on a matter of public health.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Chernobyl and Fukushima disasters are very much in our memories. The death toll from the Chernobyl tragedy is not yet complete. In Ukraine, radiation still affects more than 6 to 7 million people in contaminated territories 29 years later. In Fukushima, the radioactive threat remains everywhere. However, thanks to the government's prohibition and control measures, the contamination of most agricultural or livestock products is less than 10 to 20 becquerels.  It was essential to overhaul existing regulations in Europe on permissible levels of radioactive contamination for food in order to best protect people's health.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report because for me food safety is the ultimate objective of the Council regulation. Therefore a change of legal base is appropriate to give the European Parliament the power of co-decision and an appropriate say in the protection of public health.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In April 2010, the European Commission presented a proposal for a recast of Regulation (Euratom) No 3954/87 introducing the maximum tolerated levels of contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency. I am in favour of this Regulation setting the maximum tolerated levels of radioactive contamination of minor foodstuffs following a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency and also the maximum tolerated levels of radioactive contamination of feed following a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency. The legal basis for this proposal required only consultation with the European Parliament. I support the new proposal, which is the subject of this report, by introducing some new elements that establish a clearer link with European food safety regulations.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to re-found the three regulations defining the limits of radioactivity allowed in food after a nuclear accident. This proposal aims to enable the Commission to lower the allowable radioactivity thresholds in case of emergency, to improve transparency in the process, in particular by informing the population, to punish Member States for allowing off-limits products to circulate or to compensate aggrieved farmers. In essence, the limits set out in the directive are similar to those established by the 1987 directive, when the elected representatives of the ENL group had proposed to draw inspiration from the new Japanese limits taken in the wake of the Fukushima incidents, which are 8 to 20 times lower. This text therefore does not change much, while giving the Commission more power, while the Commission remains unable to establish more protective thresholds. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support measures to ensure that swift action can be taken to protect public health from contaminated food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident. However, we would like to see MEPs given a stronger role in setting maximum limits and call for full information to be made publicly available.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report setting the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food and feed after a nuclear accident or in any other radiological emergency. On the other hand, I voted against the measures of this text to challenge the legal basis of the Euratom Treaty. As with other nuclear regulations, this legal basis must be respected to increase legal certainty.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report because the European Union needs up-to-date legal instruments that include flexible and specific decision-making procedures to address situations like those that occurred in the wake of the accidents at Chernobyl and Fukushima.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Staon mé ón vóta ar an tuarascáil seo. An aidhm a bhí leis ná uasleibhéal ceadaithe d’éilliú radaighníomhach i mbia agus beatha a leagan síos tar éis do thimpiste núicléach tarlú. Measaim nach bhfuil na bearta seo maith go leor chun cosaint cheart a sholáthar agus níl comhfhreagairt ar bith sa reachtaíocht seo leis na moltaí a chuir an-chuid de na saineolaithe chun tosaigh.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I believe this document did not meet the level of expertise needed for it to pass a plenary vote in the European Parliament. It lacked an adequate amount of guarantees supporting its conclusions, the basis of its findings is not clear enough and its opinions are not truly endorsed by many key partners, for example Euratom.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Nuclear power poses unpredictable risks to man and nature, which has not only been painfully demonstrated to us since the Fukushima accident. Any approach to reducing these risks should therefore be welcomed. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support the draft maximum levels for radioactive contamination of food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency. The issue needs to be addressed further. Radioactive substances cause life-threatening diseases and health conditions, pollute air, water, soil and vegetation, and it is therefore necessary to take measures to protect the health of the population while maintaining market unity and not harming trade. This bill should have been supplemented further.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the recent Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan, I think we need to consider the potential for radioactive contamination for food and animal food. Setting a limit level and periodically reviewing that level is essential.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. Resolution on the proposal for a regulation sets maximum levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed that may be marketed in the EEZ after a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency. I supported the report because it puts ensuring a high level of protection of human health first in defining and implementing all the Union's policies and activities. In the report, we call for the impact of natural and cumulative radiation throughout the food chain to be taken into account and for regular inspections and other joint actions in the veterinary field aimed directly at protecting human health. It also calls for a change in the legal basis on public health and the internal market in the Treaty of Lisbon, so that the European Parliament is included as co-legislator under the ordinary legislative procedure and not just as a consultative body. I also support the reinforced requirements for the Commission to review the implementing measures relating to nuclear accidents and other radiological hazards, as well as to update the provisions laying down maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of foodstuffs.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Taught by experiences from Chernobyl and Fukushima, nuclear accidents or radioactive hazards can occur anytime and anywhere. In the case of nuclear disasters, the issue of public health protection arises, which is particularly true of food and feed products that may be contaminated. In such cases, it is necessary to act urgently and be sure to take into account the safety of food that has remained contaminated due to radioactive pollution. In order to react swiftly, a clear link between European legislation and food safety proposed in this report is important.  The maximum levels of radioactive contamination in foodstuffs are determined in the annexes, leaving flexible room for rapid change if the circumstances so will be required and in the case of new scientific knowledge. In the event of a nuclear disaster or radioactive hazard, implementing acts to be adopted by the Commission would be adopted as a matter of u emergency, with Parliament retaining the right to decide when annex changes occur.  I support this report precisely because it will facilitate a rapid reaction in the event of radioactive hazards or accidents, the way to protect human safety and determine the lowest levels of food contamination in the EU or third countries affected by the accident.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to re-found the three regulations defining the limits of radioactivity allowed in food after a nuclear accident. This proposal aims to enable the Commission to lower the allowable radioactivity thresholds in case of emergency, to improve transparency in the process, in particular by informing the population, to punish Member States for allowing off-limits products to circulate or to compensate aggrieved farmers.  In essence, the limits set out in the directive are similar to those established by the 1987 directive, when the elected representatives of the ENL group had proposed to draw inspiration from the new Japanese limits taken in the wake of the Fukushima incidents, which are 8 to 20 times lower. This text therefore does not change much, while giving the Commission more power while it remains unable to establish more protective thresholds. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ After an accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant on April 26, 1986, significant amounts of radioactive substances that contaminated food and feed in several European countries to levels that are significant from a health point of view and cause life-threatening diseases and health problems have been dropped into the atmosphere. A high degree of radioactive contamination is still present today.  Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal to adopt measures to ensure the introduction of certain agricultural products into the Union in accordance with common arrangements that protect the health of the population while maintaining the single market and avoiding the diversion of trade flows. I see particular importance in the role of Member States responsible for monitoring compliance with the levels set out in this Regulation, in particular through the monitoring of safety standards for foodstuffs and feed.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In light of the dangers posed by nuclear power plants, the European Union needs effective legal instruments that contain flexible decision-making procedures to deal with situations such as those that occurred in Chernobyl and Fukushima. The new proposal subject to this report introduces a number of new elements that establish a clearer link to EU food safety rules. In its explanatory statement, the Commission underlines that, taking into account developments in EU primary law with regard to food safety and the need to ensure coherence of all legal measures on the conditions for imports of food and feed from third countries affected by nuclear accidents or radiological hazards, it is necessary to align the measures laid down in the post-Chernobyl context with the regime of implementing powers and procedures laid down in this Regulation , which may also entail a change in the legal basis. This could be interpreted as a sign that the Commission may be ready to accept the change in legal basis it has pursued so far. Given the implementation of acts taken in the event of a nuclear accident or other radiological hazard, the draft report allows for actions to review decisions as many times as necessary to adapt to the way contamination develops. I support this report proposal.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 When it comes to preventing possible nuclear disasters, legislators' attention must be maximum. In my opinion, the European Union must commit itself to ensuring the highest safety standards for citizenship and the environment. The regulation proposed by the Council lays down the maximum permissible levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed which may be placed on the market in the European Union as a result of a nuclear accident or in any other case of radiological emergency. The proposal replaces Regulation (Euratom) No 3954/87, introduced in 1987 following the Chernobyl disaster and amended since then, although the maximum permissible levels remain unchanged. In addition to agreeing with the nature of the proposals put forward by the Council, I particularly agree with the report's intention to call for a change in the legal basis for the articles on public health and the internal market of the Treaty of Lisbon. This will ensure the full participation of Parliament as co-legislator, in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and not only as an advisory body.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. MEPs have adopted the Commission's proposal to set the maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food and feed after a nuclear accident or in any other radiological emergency. I voted in favour of this text. I stress that it is important to act in this area in order to ensure safe and quality consumption, and to protect the health of European consumers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the event of a radioactive accident or emergency, it is important that the European Union has up-to-date legal instruments with simplified decision-making processes adapted to each situation to deal with situations such as those that occurred during the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents.
