This Council proposal, the subject of this report, introduces some new elements which establish a clearer link with European food safety regulations. I voted in favour of this report because food security is the ultimate objective of the proposal.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The world has not been spared in recent decades by nuclear disasters, everyone remembers the terrible images of the Chernobyl and Fukushima accidents. If life gradually resumes in contaminated areas, it is of course essential that the government provide "safety nets" to protect local populations in the first place. Preventive measures include setting maximum allowable levels of radioactive contamination for food and feed after a nuclear accident. This is precisely the purpose of the Herranz Garcia report voted this lunchtime by MEPs. I have of course voted in favour of this text, which sets european permissible levels for food for both marketing, export and import, as I supported Amendment 56 tabled by the Green Group calling for a 10-fold reduction of the permissible thresholds for animal feed in the event of radioactive contamination or, more seriously, of any type of nuclear accident in Europe. If there is no such thing as zero risk, lowering the allowable thresholds for radioactive presence to the maximum is a public health imperative.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this draft Resolution on the Council Regulation establishing maximum tolerances for radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or any case of radiological emergency. The proposal for a Regulation seeks to adapt the rules to the new EU provisions on food security. To this end, the same maximum tolerance limits applicable in the event of an accident set out in Article 31 of the Euratom Treaty are adopted in the Annexes. These levels were confirmed in 2012 by the expert group established in Article 31 of that Treaty. The levels are also incorporated into the European Commission's Publication on Radiological Protection 105 (Radiation Protection 105). The decision also calls for the legal basis to be replaced by Article 168 TFEU, so that the Regulation, as well as subsequent revisions to the annexes to limits, are adopted by codecision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In general, the issue in this report was not so much the frequency of a particular food taken in isolation for a particular diet, but the accumulation of doses from various sources, whether food or not. I have therefore been vigilant on this issue and demanding a high level of public health protection.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation proposed by the Council lays down the maximum tolerated levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed that may be placed on the European market following an accident or any other radiological emergency.  It also lays down the procedures and implementing powers to make pre-established maximum levels applicable.  This proposal replaces Regulation No 3954/87, established in 1987 following the Chernobyl disaster, although the maximum permissible levels have not been changed. The maximum tolerated levels apply to food and feed from the EU or imported from third countries, depending on the location and circumstances of the nuclear accident or emergency.  The report therefore calls for a change in the legal basis of the Regulation to articles on public health and the internal market in the Treaty of Lisbon, to strengthen the implementing measures adopted in relation to a nuclear accident or other radiological emergency and to update the annexes to the Regulation setting the maximum permitted levels and the food list. I agree with the suggestions made by the rapporteur, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted in the Committee on the Environment on maximum permissible levels of radioactivity following a nuclear accident. The proposal replaces the 1987 regulation adopted after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and lays down maximum levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed intended for the European market following a nuclear accident. The EU's interest and attention to the issue of the safety of its citizens is clear in this context, so I fully support the text presented.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In order to determine the concentrations of toxic products allowed in the diet of more than 500 million Europeans, including millions of children, we must be very rigorous and listen to the best experts in the field. However, in this case many recommendations have well not been taken into account, or have been rejected as the amendments containing them were not adopted. We consider radioactive materials to be carcinogenic and mutagenic substances for which there is no particular safety threshold. We support amendments which set maximum safety tolerances, but we cannot support a report which we do not consider sufficiently worked.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the decision of the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs to change the legal basis to allow for the full involvement of the European Parliament in this legislation. It is vital that Parliament can exercise its full co-decision powers on an issue which has such great implications for human health. This change in legal basis allows Parliament to make important changes to the text which will improve safety standards and increase transparency.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report first because we demand to work towards zero tolerance. Secondly, it is important to note that during the debate we learned that, when the report was discussed in Parliament's Committee on the Environment, the European Commission refused to facilitate the identity of the experts who make up the Euratom expert group. Moreover, a public debate on the limits could not be organized either because these same Euratom scientists said they had no "availability" to participate. Although there were MEPs (from the PP) who said they had no need to know who the scientists were, we do need to know, because science is not neutral and often the results depend on who pays for them and, moreover, the revolving doors are unfortunately becoming more frequent. This regulation does not in any way establish health guarantees after an accident, but it is a text that aligns with the interests of the nuclear lobby, and I believe that the Commission must place our right to health and food that does not make us sick above the interests of any business.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support measures to ensure that swift action can be taken to protect public health from contaminated food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident.  However, we would like to see MEPs given a stronger role in setting maximum limits and call for full information to be made publicly available.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this legislative resolution in line with the position of the EKR. In this case, the ENVI Committee included in this report the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and in particular Article 168(4.b) and Article 114 thereof. However, in the past, the EC has declared incompatibility in this matter with 'new comitology'. It therefore proposed to remain on the legal basis resulting from the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community, in particular Articles 31 and 32 in this area, the establishment of maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination in food and feed caused by a nuclear accident or other case of radiological emergency. The EKR Group is of the opinion that Euratom, as a separate organisation, is responsible for the functioning of the nuclear energy sector. Among other tasks, he is in charge of setting uniform safety standards to protect the health of workers and the general public. It also ensures that these standards are also respected.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because the report comes up with some new elements that bring clearer rules and links with European food security legislation. I think that, although the overall safety balance is currently relatively favourable, the high level of radioactive contamination persists to this day. As the radioactive material leaking contaminated the air, water, soil and vegetation, I consider it important to create measures that do not pose a threat to human and animal health in the Union in the future. I also consider it no less important that, in the interests of the safety of the population, we harmonise all the measures taken so far following the Chernobyl and Fukushima disasters. I agree that we should ensure continuous monitoring of food products from countries affected by the radioactive fallout from a nuclear accident in another country, thus minimising the risks of consuming food products. At the same time, I expect that in the case of the deliberate export or sale of foodstuffs with a level of contamination exceeding the maximum permitted levels, harsh sanctions will be imposed on the infringers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Report and its amendments due to the necessary protection against hazards acesion from exposure to ionizing radiation. The Chernobyl nuclear accident caused significant amounts of radioactive particles to be released into the atmosphere, and contamination of food and feed in several European countries caused by radioactive particles causes diseases and health problems, while a high degree of contamination persists today. It is also dangerous that higher levels of radiation have been shown to cause cancer, which is why it is necessary to set a threshold of the maximum level of radioactive contamination for food products. It is also necessary to periodically review and modernise the maximum permissible measures in accordance with scientific opinion.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support measures to ensure that swift action can be taken to protect public health from contaminated food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident. However, we would like to see MEPs given a stronger role in setting maximum limits and call for full information to be made publically available.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency. We are all aware of the events in Chernobyl and Fukushima, which have resulted in great devastation, including in the food and feed sector. It is essential that, in the event of a radiological accident or radiological emergency in third countries, the European Union responds rapidly and effectively to ensure that food and feed meet the conditions for import. I also welcome the special emergency procedure without prior inspection, where it is necessary to take immediate action to ensure the safety of consumers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The nuclear risk is permanently present and the Union must prepare itself as best as possible to mitigate the impact of a possible and inevitable future accident.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that a high level of protection of human health should be ensured in the definition and implementation of all political activities. I agree that the European Union must have up-to-date legal instruments that include quick and case-specific decision-making procedures in order to confront situations such as those that have taken place following the Chernobyl or Fukushima accidents. As is known, following nuclear accidents, significant amounts of radioactive material are released into the atmosphere, which can cause significant health contamination of food and feed, thereby causing life-threatening diseases and health conditions. I therefore consider it important to have rules allowing certain agricultural products to enter the European market only if they comply with common provisions protecting the health of the population. The report's finding that higher doses of radiation have harmful and devastating effects on human cells and have carcinogenic effects should be highlighted. I therefore support the setting of low limits for the maximum permitted levels of radioactive contamination in foodstuffs exposed to such radiation, taking into account the cumulative dose that can be derived from prolonged consumption.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Nuclear accidents are a danger to the safety and security of European citizens. It has not been so long since 1986, when the Chernobyl power plant created one of the worst nuclear accidents in history, and the echoes of this tragedy must not go away, precisely to help us better prepare and prevent such situations. The procedures for responding to a nuclear event must be kept up to date. That is why I believe that both preventive measures and response plans in the event of a nuclear event must take into account the long-term effects on food and food safety. The security of European consumers is a matter of the prompt application of procedures for responding to any kind of nuclear event, but also of the continuous analysis and evaluation of radioactivity levels for food and feed by experts in the field.  In the same context, I agree that this analysis must also be carried out for food from non-European areas in order to ensure the safety and security of European consumers.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text, but I also voted in favour of the controversial Rivasi (Greens/GUE) amendment.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ On the basis of the legislative base of the Treaty of the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom), in 2014 the Commission drafted a revised proposal for a regulation on the maximum levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed after a nuclear accident, which should be approved or rejected by the European Parliament.  While I consider the Commission's proposal quite appropriate, the Rapporteur has proposed amendments giving the European Parliament greater powers to deal with critical situations in this area.  Those amendments are not consistent with the objective of preserving Euratom as a separate organisation responsible for the functioning of the nuclear energy sector, which should, inter alia, establish uniform safety standards to protect the health of workers and the general public and ensure their implementation. I believe that Euratom should remain an organisation responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the energy sector, including the consequences of possible nuclear accidents, as the European Parliament is not competent in this field.  Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed Council Regulation sets maximum levels of radioactive contamination of food and feed that may be present on the EU market following a nuclear accident or any other radiological emergency. It also lays down procedures and implementing powers in this respect. The maximum permitted rates apply to food originating in or imported from third countries, depending on the location and circumstances of the nuclear accident or other emergency. I supported the report because it is about protecting all of us as consumers and is therefore very important.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In order to determine the concentrations of toxic products allowed in the diet of more than 500 million Europeans, including millions of children, we must be very rigorous and listen to the best experts in the field. However, in this case many recommendations have well not been taken into account, or have been rejected as the amendments containing them were not adopted. We consider radioactive materials to be carcinogenic and mutagenic substances for which there is no particular safety threshold. We support amendments which set maximum safety tolerances, but we cannot support a report which we do not consider sufficiently worked.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on this report has been based on the belief that in order to protect our citizens’ health, it is of the utmost importance that decisions be taken by experts and not politicians. Delaying the procedure in cases like a nuclear accident would be a huge mistake.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In order to determine the concentrations of toxic products allowed in the diet of more than 500 million Europeans, including millions of children, we must be very rigorous and listen to the best experts in the field. However, in this case many recommendations have well not been taken into account, or have been rejected as the amendments containing them were not adopted. We consider radioactive materials to be carcinogenic and mutagenic substances for which there is no particular safety threshold. We support amendments which set maximum safety tolerances, but we cannot support a report which we do not consider sufficiently worked.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report as none of the amendments tabled by my group, which s aspired to ensure absolutely safe pollution limits (ten times lower than those proposed here) have been included.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report prepared by my colleague Esther Herranz warns of the need to transfer the legal basis to the articles of the TFEU which refer to public health and the internal market so that, in this way, the European Parliament participates as co-legislator in the negotiation of these matters in the ordinary legislative procedure. In addition, it calls on the European Commission to strengthen implementing measures in the event of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. We want an energy model based on renewables and without nuclear, but the report adopted today seeks to set safe limits for food in the event of a nuclear accident. The Parliament has requested to change the legal basis to Articles 168 and 114 TFEU, as I think it is appropriate. However, for the time being, we are returned to the role of mere consultants. We have to be practical. Without entering any expert warfare, the limits set by Euratom may be insufficient, but those of any other body (FAO, Codex or independent) are not linked to EU law and are therefore indicative. I am not against stricter limits, but under the Euratom procedure the only way we have to influence the setting and application of these limits is with a regulation on which we can hold the Commission to account. European experts will speak again on the right limits to our continent. The sensible thing to do is to review the Euratom limits on the basis of our needs, to make these law, European legislation, and to be able to intervene in the event of any non-compliance. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2013, the European Commission proposed a Council regulation on maximum allowable levels (NMA) of radioactive contamination of food after a nuclear accident or in any other radiological emergency. A large majority of the European Parliament has accepted high thresholds for radioactive contamination of food in the event of a nuclear accident in Europe. Maximum allowable levels of contamination cover only a small portion of food contaminated in a nuclear accident and exclude so-called smaller foods. These thresholds were established by the Euratom expert group on the basis of a November 2012 opinion. I regret that the amendment that we tabled jointly with the Greens to divide the maximum levels by 10 was rejected. This result is unacceptable because it endangers the health of the population, in contradiction with the Community's food security provisions and with the provisions of the Treaty calling for a high level of public health. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In April 2010, the European Commission presented a proposal for a recast of Regulation (Euratom) No 3954/87, introducing the maximum tolerated levels of contamination of food and feed following a nuclear accident. The legal basis for this proposal required only consultation with the European Parliament. However, during the submission of that proposal, it was found that the provisions of Regulation (Euratom) No 3954/87 were not compatible with the nose's comitology rules introduced after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. The European Commission has therefore decided to withdraw this project and submit a new one. The new proposal, the subject of this report, introduces some new elements that establish a clearer link with European food safety regulations. The proposal defines in its annexes the maximum levels tolerated in the event of a radioactive accident or emergency, confirmed in 2012 by the expert group.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this proposal because the new euratom regulation was urgently needed and Parliament is now having a say in setting the ceilings. Furthermore, farmers whose food has been contaminated by radioactive waste are now compensated by the 'polluter pays' principle.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support measures to ensure that swift action can be taken to protect public health from contaminated food and feed in the event of a nuclear accident.  However, we would like to see MEPs given a stronger role in setting maximum limits and call for full information to be made publicly available.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) is a comprehensive and independent body that oversees all aspects of the functioning of the nuclear industry, including setting safety standards for health protection and ensuring compliance. Questions on the use of nuclear energy should then remain in the hands of the Member States and the European Parliament should not interfere in things that do not fall within its remit.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this is again a very important resolution and I was pleased to support it. It is something that we have discussed many times both in Ireland and here, and I think it is part of the progression that we are making to get unity within Europe. We have the banking union, hopefully we will have an energy union, and the capital markets union is very important as well. All this is going to help our economy, provide alternative sources of financing for SMEs and also give clarity and regulation to the market. I think these measures are very worthwhile, and the sooner they can be implemented across the European Union, the better. It is one of those measures which have long been spoken about and now, hopefully, it can come into being as soon as possible.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. In particular, the possibilities for non-bank financing for SMEs need to be expanded, as well as barriers that persist at all levels, including the cross-border use of financial services.  A single European capital market will support investment, economic growth and employment. However, the European Commission's Green Paper on the subject is not sufficiently comprehensive. There is no single reference to the single currency which, in simplifying intra-European financial transactions, has been the traditional engine of integration, nor to the need for UNION public debt to play the risk-free asset role in the European economy.  We also know that non-bank financing is largely shadow banking. The creation of the CMU must be accompanied by adequate regulation, so that this sector does not operate as an exhaust valve for bad practices. The Socialists will be very vigilant so that the CMU does not become an excuse to deregulate and increase systemic risk.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it is trying to boost the Capital Markets Union, an instrument that will be used to avoid regulation of the banking sector and facilitate the speculative expoliating of the real economy in the European Union. This proposal is not in the interests of industrial enterprises or small and medium-sized enterprises, which are those that generate jobs, but responds to the demands of speculative capital, which aims to more easily access the real economy and thus generate new financial bubbles and greater speculation in the face of market shortages on a global scale. The very idea of forcing SMEs to finance themselves through the issuance of shares means preventing them from normal access to credit and being able to speculate on their income.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution on a future Capital Markets Union. The Commission argues that small and medium-sized enterprises should not rely too heavily on the conventional banking sector in order to obtain finance and that they should be able to access funding elsewhere. Furthermore, the Commission is attempting to duplicate the US model where companies are mainly financed by capital markets and shadow banking activities. They also fail to factor in the very real concern that the financial crisis has shown that traditional banking has provided more lending to the real economy than universal or investments banks. What is required is a focus on public banking and local banking and not a revival of shadow banking. Moreover, instead of a focus on Capital Market Union, what is required is a rejection of austerity policies. Anything else is a card trick. As we have seen, a focus on short-term growth is dangerous and as long as systematic risks have not been comprehensively addressed we have not truly reduced the risk of future crises and related costs on both the economy and citizens’ lives. Irish Citizens are still experiencing the results of such negligence and disregard in Ireland.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The creation of a European Capital Markets Union aims to increase investment in the real economy, as a Capital Markets Union will facilitate access to capital for SMEs and help to strengthen the diversification of sources of finance. I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to develop market financing at the expense of bank financing.  These proposals can be a factor of instability and risk. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This calls upon the Commission to establish EU ‘market infrastructure’ payment systems, increase regulation of credit rating agencies and of audit firms.  None of this should be done at EU level and therefore I voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because the Capital Markets Union (CMU) should provide new and more efficient ways to move savings to small commercial enterprises and protect cross-border investors in the EU.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution. In its resolution of 26 February 2014 on the long-term financing of the European economy, Parliament stressed the need to improve access to capital markets through new sources of financing, and noted that commercial banks are likely to continue to be one of the main sources of funding and that it is essential for Member States to develop new sources that complement well-established mechanisms and close the funding gap, while providing for an appropriate regulatory and supervisory framework tailored to the needs of the real economy.  The Capital Markets Union should be progressively operational and its priorities should be threefold: firstly, to promote the most efficient distribution of savings by deepening and diversifying the financial sources available to businesses and to offer savers and investors greater choice through investment, greater transparency and portfolio diversification; secondly, to help further mitigate risks by creating stronger cross-border markets, strengthening the resilience of financial systems to the negative effects of major financial crises and mitigating the effects of particularly serious shocks; thirdly, ensure that an effective additional source of financing for the real economy is found.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This capital markets union is supposed to develop market financing at the expense of bank financing, which can be a serious factor of instability and lead to many other risks, including securitization. I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Capital Markets Union is a european Commission project to further deepen and further integrate capital markets in the 28 EU Member States. The European Parliament has therefore decided to make a resolution in order to put its priorities forward on the subject. Its priorities are 7 points of action: a new legal framework for economic policy coordination, a simplified and more targeted semester process, an increase in the EU's investment capacity, the establishment of fiscal capacity within the euro area, a single market, a new social pact and, finally, a more democratic institutional framework.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Based on the constant that 75% of European business and SME financing comes from bank loans compared to only 25% in the United States, the European Union has set out to develop the financing of companies through the markets. The aim is therefore to promote a "quality securitisation" that is perplexing when we know that the securitized products of the Lehman Brothers were rated triple A a few weeks before the bank collapsed. This union of capital markets must also strengthen investment banks and thus, de facto, their weight in financing the economy, even though there is a deplorable over-reliance on bank financing.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution analyses the construction of a Market and Capital Union, although at first reading the text seems to be moving in the direction of identifying the prospects so that the phenomena that have contributed to the very serious economic crisis are not repeated in the capital market, to a more critical reading I believe that the whole text is extremely deficient and partisan. Firstly, there is no mention of the fundamental problem of the crisis, namely that of the single currency and the costs it represents for the Member States of the Union. , but deliberately fails to remember that it is precisely the banks that bear a great responsibility for the bankruptcy of a large number of companies that have been prevented from accessing credit. For all these reasons, I voted against the resolution.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The existence in the EU of a well-integrated financial system resulting from a Capital Markets Union can increase the resilience of Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) to sudden shocks, as well as being an effective tool for generating jobs, growth and investment.  Progress in this area will contribute to the smooth functioning of EMU in the short term. However, it remains necessary to define a long-term perspective on the necessary evolution of EMU and in which sectors further work is needed to develop stronger common governance. It is important to implement a coherent strategy around the triangle of structural reforms, investment and budgetary responsibility and, in this context, to move towards more effective commitments with the introduction of growth-pro-growth reforms in the euro area. The functioning of the single market must also be improved. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the construction of a Capital Markets Union.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because insufficiently regulated and controlled capital markets were the main cause of the outbreak of the financial crisis. At the beginning of the financial crisis, the Institutions of the European Union adopted a number of legislation to ensure that such crises do not arise in the future and to create an environment of financial stability, which is a prerequisite for sustainable growth. The European Parliament notes that, despite the well-groomed opportunities offered by the EU capital market, there are no major obstacles in other areas, such as taxation, in particular the practice of promoting the debt-to-equity ratio, insolvency and accounting rules. Europe's future depends on its ability to innovate. The creation of a regulatory framework conducive to smart, sustainable and inclusive growth is not only a regulatory framework conducive to innovation, but also a simple, appropriate and multi-faceted access to finance for businesses. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to examine in detail the current situation of capital markets in each Member State, to provide an assessment in a comprehensive economic study of where and to what extent barriers to investment through capital markets exist at EU level, and to indicate which measures, including non-legislative procedures and market-based strategies, could remove or reduce these barriers.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Green Paper "Building a Capital Markets Union" approved in February this year outlines the first piece of a strategy that will commit the Union in the coming years. A path that can and must cross the commitment of the Juncker Investment Plan. In September we are waiting for the Commission's action plan, today this resolution, which I support, has the merit of bringing to light the centrality of action in this area. In recent decades there has been an increase in the size of the financial sector on a global and European scale. In the face of this growth, investment in the real economy declined with a significant decline, particularly during the economic crisis.  A crisis that has weakened financial integration across the continent by segmenting and dividing the sector on the basis of fiscal barriers and regulatory barriers. The Capital Markets Union project aims to act on these issues. Through greater integration and harmonisation of markets, the aim is to free up all those unused resources in the system, seeking to direct them to the service of the real economy. In addition, it will be important to achieve effective diversification of funding channels in order to stimulate and strengthen the size of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the issue to the Commission by The Gualtieri Representative, as all the main priorities are included in the final text, and the text itself clearly indicates the need for legal action in the creation of a Capital Markets Union.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution on a future Capital Markets Union. The Commission argues that small and medium-sized enterprises should not rely too heavily on the conventional banking sector in order to obtain finance and that they should be able to access funding elsewhere. Furthermore, the Commission is attempting to duplicate the US model where companies are mainly financed by capital markets and shadow banking activities. They also fail to factor in the very real concern that the financial crisis has shown that traditional banking has provided more lending to the real economy than universal or investments banks. What is required is a focus on public banking and local banking and not a revival of shadow banking. Moreover, instead of a focus on Capital Market Union, what is required is a rejection of austerity policies. As we have seen, a focus on short-term growth is dangerous and as long as systematic risks have not been comprehensively addressed we have not truly reduced the risk of future crises and related costs on both the economy and citizens’ lives. Irish Citizens are still experiencing the results of such negligence in Ireland.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the creation of a Capital Markets Union, in addition to bringing enormous economic benefits, is also a further step towards the integration of the European continent.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution aims to establish a capital markets union. Indeed, the Commission wants to promote direct financing of SMEs by simplifying the rules of fund-raising and by relaunching securitisation or venture capital. The integration of SMEs into this type of financing mechanism risks fuelling the financial bubble and increasing the risk of a stock market crash in the image of the famous subprime crisis. Above all, the use of these mechanisms reflects the Commission's inability to redirect the activities of banking institutions towards corporate finance. Without a major law to separate investment banks and retail banks, coupled with an incentive legal and tax framework, the financial debit of banks to businesses will remain limited. That is why, pending concrete proposals, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the creation of a Capital Markets Union. In order to remain competitive and attractive on the international market, the European Union needs a deep approach to capital markets and, last but not least, it needs to take account of developments in capital markets at international level. The European Union is also defined by the diversity of Member States' business models and financial markets, which can be turned into assets and deserve to be protected at European level. I believe that, through supple legislation that takes into account the needs of each Member State, but also of the European Union as a whole, the major obstacles to investment and investment will disappear and the EU will unquestionably strengthen its position on the international market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the ECON resolution on the Capital Markets Union. The text, which is very technical, seems to identify prospects so that certain phenomena which have contributed to the very serious economic crisis are not repeated in the capital market. In truth, the document is seriously deficient because it does not mention the most important problem, that of the single currency and the costs it represents for the Member States of the Union. In addition, the report mentions as important the 'reforms' that Member States should carry out in order to reassure the markets. The text compliments the agreement reached on the so-called 'Juncker Plan' (a mere political marketing operation against which we voted with conviction). There are many references in the text to the needs of SMEs, but the report fails to mention that it is precisely the banks that bear a great responsibility for the bankruptcy of a large number of companies that have been prevented from accessing credit. Finally, we are not very convinced by certain calls too general for regulatory standardization of the sector, on the contrary, a genuine single market in capital.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The serious consequences of the 2008 crisis illustrated the fragility of the European financial system. It is now vital to boost investment in businesses, especially SMEs, in the long term. Building a genuine capital markets union covering the 28 Member States would be a significant step. It would help to mobilise more investment for SMEs and attract more international investment to Europe. Above all, it would make the financial system more stable by diversifying sources of financing, as the crisis has shown too much corporate dependence on the banking system.  This resolution lays the foundations for the construction of this union. I voted for it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Juncker Commission's strategic priorities are to encourage investment aimed at creating new jobs and strengthening competitiveness in Europe. The creation of a Capital Markets Union would lead to a reduction in the cost of capital and its more efficient allocation, which are essential for the growth of businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, and for job creation. Reducing the fragmentation of the capital market would also ensure better access to capital for companies and contribute to strengthening investor protection. The resolution on the construction of a Capital Markets Union highlighted these elements, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which forms part of the Commission’s public hearing process on a future Capital Markets Union which was launched in February this year. The Commission argues that small and medium-sized enterprises should not rely too heavily on the conventional banking sector in order to obtain finance and that they should be able to access funding elsewhere. Furthermore, the Commission is attempting to duplicate the US model where companies are mainly financed by capital markets and shadow banking activities. It also fails to factor in the very real concern that the financial crisis has shown that traditional banking has provided more lending to the real economy than universal or investments banks. What is required is a focus on public banking and local banking and not a revival of shadow banking. As we have seen, a focus on short-term growth is dangerous and as long as systematic risks have not been comprehensively addressed we have not truly reduced the risk of future crises and related costs on both the economy and citizens lives. Irish Citizens are still experiencing the results of such negligence and disregard in their daily lives.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This calls upon the Commission to establish EU ‘market infrastructure’ payment systems and increase the regulation of credit rating agencies and of audit firms. None of this should be done at EU level and therefore I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the scope of improving access to capital markets as a move towards supporting further investment and growth and I therefore voted in favour of this Resolution as I also fully support the principles that underpin the Capital Markets Union in order to improve access to finance for SMEs and access markets directly. On the other hand, I would not agree that in order to achieve this target, action would be needed by Member States relating specifically to taxation policy, as coordination of some tax reforms fall strictly under the exclusive competence of Member States.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is right to approach that, while, for example, the US has recovered faster from the economic crisis than the EU, which is partly due to greater diversification of the financial system, the EU must create a truly its own capital markets union, which can draw on experiences from other parts of the world in order to ensure compatibility between European and international financial markets.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motions for resolutions on the European Capital Union. On 18 February 2015, the Commission adopted the Green Paper entitled 'Building a Capital Markets Union'. It is therefore called upon to ensure that a European approach is adopted in the construction of a Capital Markets Union, with a view to the functioning of capital markets, and that favourable economic and regulatory conditions for SMEs are achieved.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 For many decades Italy has suffered the damage resulting from a relationship capitalism that favoured personal relationships over merit. We are not talking about the importance of the word given and the handshake, but about favour treatments for friends of friends, while mr. no one, even if good and gifted with good ideas, had to succumb. A Capital Markets Union, a priority for Commissioner Hill, would be a huge opportunity to increase competition in the financial sector, for the benefit of both businesses and consumers, and above all by improving the efficiency of the system itself, with advantages also for the shareholders of the banks (which in Italy, through foundations, are ultimately the public bodies to which we are all contributors). This architecture, described in the resolution, received my vote in favour.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of creating a Capital Markets Union to support growth and financial stability. A union that can first solve the problem of access to credit and the lack of investment. Unfortunately, most investors have no idea of the wide potential that European SMEs can offer. It is therefore necessary to create a tool that can collect and circulate information, thus creating a network linking entrepreneurs, SMEs and investors. It is also essential to commit ourselves to strengthening the diversification of sources of finance and investment in European companies, while maintaining its attractiveness to international investors and avoiding unnecessary divergences and duplications in legislation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it is trying to boost the Capital Markets Union, an instrument that will be used to avoid regulation of the banking sector and facilitate the speculative expoliating of the real economy in the European Union. This proposal is not in the interests of industrial enterprises or small and medium-sized enterprises, which are those that generate jobs, but responds to the demands of speculative capital, which aims to more easily access the real economy and thus generate new financial bubbles and greater speculation in the face of market shortages on a global scale. The very idea of forcing SMEs to finance themselves through the issuance of shares means preventing them from normal access to credit and being able to speculate on their income.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is the European Parliament’s feedback to the European Commission initiative on establishing a Capital Markets Union among the 28 Member States. It includes measures for the capital markets to finance long-term investment and to ensure the highest investor protection standards. As the Capital Markets Union is aimed at cutting the costs of raising capital, also for SMEs, and at helping to reduce our very high dependence on bank funding, I have supported the adoption of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution makes Parliament's contribution to the debate on the construction of a capital markets union launched by the European Commission. The Commission's observation clearly shows that investment in the real economy in Europe has been declining relatively for several decades, despite a significant increase in the size of the European and international financial sector over the same period. This situation persists even though there is a large reserve of inactive capital, particularly held by the insurance sector, which could be used more effectively.  In this context, the establishment of a capital markets union could create a coherent EU-wide regulatory environment and bring capital markets closer to SMEs in order to stimulate financing for the real economy. Such a project should be based on a more efficient allocation of savings, better mitigation of risks, particularly cross-border risks, and the existence of an effective complementary channel to finance the real economy.  Considering that it is necessary to revive investment, and therefore innovation and the creation of wealth and jobs in Europe, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution on Building a Capital Markets Union, which represents the democratic view from the European Parliament on the CMU initiative. The CMU initiative is very important as its objective is to create much-needed growth and jobs in Europe. The report recognises that we need to improve access to capital markets through new sources of funding and fill the funding gap especially for SMEs, while providing for an appropriate regulatory and supervisory framework geared to the needs of the real economy. At the same time it states that Europe will have to play to its own strengths but that compatibility with international markets has to be guaranteed so that investment can also be attracted from abroad. The role of savers and investors in CMU was correctly identified as one of the priorities, as without them there will be no deeper or broader capital markets.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Capital Markets Union represents a major challenge for both the European institutions and market players in the European context. In fact, the aim of this project is to develop a capital market in Europe that is complementary to the banking market. Therefore, long-term financing represents an opportunity for growth and job creation, which is crucial for a Europe that is only emerging from the economic and financial crisis that gripped it in the last year. In addition, these investments have far-reaching benefits throughout society, with important economic, social and environmental consequences compared to mere short-term speculation. In addition, emphasis has been placed on small and medium-sized enterprises, the real driving force behind our continent. The entry of institutional investors into the capital market has therefore been encouraged, and today they have a great deal of savings, but they have great difficulty in participating in them. I am voting in favour of this proposal because it allows for a reduction in the funding gap between countries, making it easier to transmit the monetary policies of the European Central Bank. Finally, the greater diversification of sources of funding will make it possible to reduce idiosyncratic risks within Europe.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament supports the pragmatic and proportionate approach pursued by the European Commission to establish a capital markets union by 2019. The union of capital markets will be a "decisive" element of a broader strategy to support growth in Europe through a "diversification" of the financing channels of the real economy.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECON Oral Question and Resolution represent a first reaction from the committee to the Commission green paper proposing a Capital Markets Union (CMU), led by Lord Hill. The resolution includes high-level compromises covering key topics such as the possible benefits of a CMU, the need for it to be a genuine 28 Member State European approach, and the identification of legislative barriers that might hinder success. The ECR has successfully added amendments pointing out that non-legislative measures have merit and market-led solutions are important.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on building a Capital Markets Union. The European Commission has published a Green Paper, i.e. a call for public discussion, on the establishment of a Capital Markets Union, launching a long-term project to integrate capital markets into the European Union. The aim is to mobilise the financing of the European economy through capital markets and to stimulate the growth rates of the 28 EU Member States. However, we believe from the European Parliament that the Commission needs to create a better approach to strengthen the diversification of sources of funding and investment in businesses. Similarly, the Commission should not rely solely on peer reviews with other jurisdictions. Last but not least, through the support of this resolution, we are sending a signal to the Commission about the need for differences between Member States to be taken into account so that there are no negative consequences. These are only some of the EP's recommendations to the Commission, but are among the main reasons why I agreed and supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against it because it sets as a regulatory factor the European Fund for Strategic Investments with whose role I disagree.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Capital Markets Union consists of a series of initiatives aimed at developing non-bank lending and capital market financing in Europe, the guidelines for the creation of the CMU are contained in the Green Paper of the same name. In the Commission's view, the creation of the Capital Markets Union would solve issues such as the difficulty of creating new jobs in view of the lack of credit, Europe's over-dependence on banks and the lack of credit for SMEs. I voted against this resolution because I cannot find it acceptable for Europe to think of resolving the crisis in which it has plunged with the same practice that caused it, namely excessive financialisation; It is absurd to think that, in order to restart the economy, we want to start with finance rather than with the fabric of small and medium-sized enterprises and therefore with the citizens, instead of thinking about creating a system of credit banks, we are once again trying to meet the demands, and therefore the interests, of the large ones.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. In particular, the possibilities for non-bank financing for SMEs need to be expanded, as well as barriers that persist at all levels, including the cross-border use of financial services.  A single European capital market will support investment, economic growth and employment. However, the European Commission's Green Paper on the subject is not sufficiently comprehensive. There is no single reference to the single currency which, in simplifying intra-European financial transactions, has been the traditional engine of integration, nor to the need for UNION public debt to play the risk-free asset role in the European economy.  We also know that non-bank financing is largely shadow banking. The creation of the CMU must be accompanied by adequate regulation, so that this sector does not operate as an exhaust valve for bad practices. The Socialists will be very vigilant so that the CMU does not become an excuse to deregulate and increase systemic risk.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a good example of the contradictions that mark the current process of capitalist integration in the European Union and, as well, of the lack of solutions to address the problems that plague European economies. The European Union remains mired in the crisis. A quarter of Europeans are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. That's 24 million unemployed. The youth unemployment rate doubled between 2007 and 2014. Instead of identifying the root causes of the crisis and the need to find public solutions to correct the monumental market failures, one focuses on the same solutions that undertake the current crisis.  Wanting to integrate capital markets will not solve any of the problems of our economies. Believing that it is possible to create a legislative framework with necessarily highly complex supervision that will ensure a market solution to the issue of the lack of funding of our thousands of SMEs is a dangerous illusion that reveals some blindness. And it is also a prejudice against public policies. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because we are far enough down this hellish road already. Time to turn back.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite a significant increase in the size of the European and global financial sectors, investment in the real economy in Europe has decreased over several decades. However, the large-scale public interventions that we have been providing since the beginning of the crisis, triggered by the failure of the financial sector, have not yet led to an increase in demand for funding also in the real economy. Despite the qualities of the European Union's capital market, there are still major obstacles in areas such as taxation and accounting law. We could resolve these areas with future harmonisation. However, I consider it our most important task to create the conditions to help SMEs attract investment. I support the proposals to improve this situation.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution on the Capital Markets Union. The report praises the EU's economic policy, which I believe is a failure.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Construction of a Capital Markets Union, because it sets as a regulatory factor the European Fund for Strategic Investments with whose role I do not agree.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report, representing the EP’s input into the green book of the European Commission. The Capital Markets Union can play a full part in financing economic recovery in the EU through deepening and broadening EU capital markets, alongside bank finance. I welcome the introduction of our main priorities in the report, which lay at the core of our social-democratic values, namely capital markets to finance long-term investment, the real economy and especially SMEs. I support the importance of developing the European capital markets to diversify funding and improve access to financing, restoring also the stability of the banking sector. We succeeded in improving the text, by defeating many amendments which aimed at making the CMU a deregulatory agenda for the financial markets; the text now clearly refers to the need for legislative action. In this sense, I am strongly in favour of the review of legislation in order to the ensure highest investor protection standards and the need to address taxation of capital markets because it might represent an obstacle, despite the opportunities offered by a well-designed EU capital market. I would like to thank the rapporteur, and shadow rapporteurs, for their approach.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this motion, which underlines that over the past several decades investment in the real economy in Europe has declined relatively despite the huge growth of the European and global financial sectors over the same period, and points out that the real economy continues to rely heavily on banks, making the economy vulnerable to tightening bank lending.  I also welcome the fact that, since the beginning of the crisis, a high level of state intervention due to the bankruptcy of the financial sector has resulted in ample liquidity, but this has not resulted in an increase in the demand for financing in the real economy. In line with the rapporteur, I believe that restoring the stability of the banking system in the Union has become a priority over the financing of long-term investments and the real economy. I consider it important to call on the Commission to analyse in depth the current situation of capital markets on a country-by-country basis, with a view to assessing, in a comprehensive economic analysis, where and to what extent there are barriers to investment at EU level through capital markets.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. It is a contrasting fact that investment in the real economy in Europe has declined relatively over several decades, despite a large increase in the size of the financial, European and global sectors over the same period. Further work is needed to improve the long-term financing of the European economy and improve access to capital markets through new sources of financing geared towards the needs of the real economy, as lack of access to finance for SMEs is one of the main obstacles to growth in the EU. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. In particular, the possibilities for non-bank financing for SMEs need to be expanded, as well as barriers that persist at all levels, including the cross-border use of financial services.  A single European capital market will support investment, economic growth and employment. However, the European Commission's Green Paper on the subject is not sufficiently comprehensive. There is no single reference to the single currency which, in simplifying intra-European financial transactions, has been the traditional engine of integration, nor to the need for UNION public debt to play the risk-free asset role in the European economy.  We also know that non-bank financing is largely shadow banking. The creation of the CMU must be accompanied by adequate regulation, so that this sector does not operate as an exhaust valve for bad practices. The Socialists will be very vigilant so that the CMU does not become an excuse to deregulate and increase systemic risk.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Capital Markets Union (CMU) because I believe that this is an important but symbolic act, in which the EP builds and reveals an embryo of a position on the future CMU.  The public consultation of stakeholders is over, so the European Commission will have to unveil its action plan, expected this autumn. I personally hope that the EC will take due account of suggestions from the real economy and market participants, because I believe that the CMU is a key piece of the EU's financial architecture, which is particularly important for the euro area in order to create the conditions for further strengthening. I am convinced of the need to create the conditions for capital to flow where it needs and to facilitate access to credit as part of a more comprehensive economic strategy, in favour of economic growth, employment and the stability of the financial markets. The CMU will be able to promote the internalisation of SMEs, which are the fabric of the economy in the various European countries, and if properly conceived and balanced, it can promote diversification of sources of finance for SMEs, which have so far been dependent on the banking sector, and encourage long-term investment, those that the EU needs in order to lay a solid foundation for sustainable growth.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the creation of a Capital Markets Union – partly because, as an expert on Small and medium-sized enterprises in my group, it is important to me that SMEs get better and cross-border access to affordable loans and thus support their development.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important to promote small and medium-sized enterprises. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we this week campaigned for the planned Capital Markets Union to give more and new financing options, especially to small and medium-sized enterprises. The EU Capital Markets Union aims to make it easier for companies to access more sources of money. To this end, barriers between investors and investment opportunities are to be removed. It is particularly important to us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats that small and medium-sized enterprises should be able to access credit just as easily as large corporations. In plenary this week, we have campaigned for this. We in Germany in particular benefit from our strong medium-sized enterprises.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution. The Capital Markets Union is one of the key initiatives of the new Commission, and in particular Jonathan Hill, Commissioner for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union.  The idea is that companies rely too heavily on bank financing, so it seeks to stimulate capital markets. Parliament's resolution is once again the product of the grand coalition between the S&D and PPE Groups. The Resolution is a criticism of capital markets and some of the instruments (e.g. securitisation) that have led to financial crises, and does not identify the root causes of bank credit shortages, linked to austerity measures. It is thus at the Commission's line, calling for the development of capital markets and the diversification of the financial system, praising the financial legislation already adopted rather than questioning it

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I alongside my Socialist and Democrat colleagues voted in favour of this resolution in support of building a Capital Markets Union with a strong supervisory role played by the ESMA.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of a Capital Markets Union because I believe that access to capital markets through new sources of financing needs to be improved. Parliament stressed that commercial banks would probably continue to be one of the main sources of funding and that it was essential for Member States to develop new sources that complement established mechanisms and close the funding gap. This report is one of the actions to diversify funding, develop European capital markets and improve access to finance. All this is essential for the Union's economic growth, job creation and entrepreneurship.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution for building a Capital Markets Union. A Capital Markets Union is an important step towards delivering the open and appropriately-regulated financial markets necessary to support Europe as an internationally competitive location for investment. This union will be accompanied by a strong EU-wide and national supervisory framework that could include a stronger role for the European Securities and Market Authority (ESMA).

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution. The Capital Markets Union is one of the key initiatives of the new Commission, and in particular Jonathan Hill, Commissioner for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union.  The idea is that companies rely too heavily on bank financing, so it seeks to stimulate capital markets. Parliament's resolution is once again the product of the grand coalition between the S&D and PPE Groups. The Resolution is a criticism of capital markets and some of the instruments (e.g. securitisation) that have led to financial crises, and does not identify the root causes of bank credit shortages, linked to austerity measures. It is thus at the Commission's line, calling for the development of capital markets and the diversification of the financial system, praising the financial legislation already adopted rather than questioning it.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the European Parliament's Resolution on the Creation of a Capital Markets Union, as a convinced supporter of the idea of Europe but also as a witness to a time in which it is increasingly clear that, in particular in the field of economy, success is determined by a willingness to be flexible, change, cooperate and integrate. Europe needs to continue to interact with its mrdar and financial systems in order to be competitive. There are still many barriers in the EU that are constraining the economy. I agree with the fact that the EU is slower to recover from the financial crisis than the US, which is partly due to barriers in the financial system, among other things. The EU must build its original version of the Capital Markets Union, where it can draw lessons from experiences from other parts of the world. A reasonable approach should be developed to recognise equal or similar standards of third countries in order to ensure the compatibility of European and international financial markets. I believe that the elements for establishing a fully functioning capital markets union should be realised no later than 2018. In this regard, a comprehensive analysis of the current situation in eu capital markets and barriers present at EU level is needed, and to prepare legislative and non-legislative proposals as soon as possible in order to achieve the objective of a fully integrated SINGLE EU capital market by the end of 2018.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. In particular, the possibilities for non-bank financing for SMEs need to be expanded, as well as barriers that persist at all levels, including the cross-border use of financial services.  A single European capital market will support investment, economic growth and employment. However, the European Commission's Green Paper on the subject is not sufficiently comprehensive. There is no single reference to the single currency which, in simplifying intra-European financial transactions, has been the traditional engine of integration, nor to the need for UNION public debt to play the risk-free asset role in the European economy.  We also know that non-bank financing is largely shadow banking. The creation of the CMU must be accompanied by adequate regulation, so that this sector does not operate as an exhaust valve for bad practices. The Socialists will be very vigilant so that the CMU does not become an excuse to deregulate and increase systemic risk.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the construction of a Capital Markets Union (CMU). This resolution notes that investment in the real economy has been declining for several years and is highly dependent on banks. The creation of a CMU would strengthen the diversification of corporate financing and investment through an independent UMC of the European banking system and would respond to the need for non-bank financing to stimulate growth. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the construction of a capital markets union, because, in the face of a decline in investment in the real economy in Europe, the creation of such a union would facilitate the financing of businesses and smes in particular, thus promoting their growth and job creation. Moreover, by establishing a regulated and controlled capital markets union, the European Union would give itself additional means to protect itself from a possible financial or economic crisis.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution tabled is full of balanced proposals for the creation of a Capital Markets Union. Especially in the current economic climate, this would create greater dynamism in the financing sector and thus growth and employment. Alternative forms of financing are necessary in order to provide companies with sufficient liquidity and stimulate investment. However, since a number of points in the report aim to give EMSA more powers, which would entail inefficiencies for the European capital market, I am abstaining.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's economy is gradually recovering from the financial crisis and virtually all Member States have returned to the path of growth. However, there are circumstances that prevent this growth from accelerating. In order for companies to develop, they need capital. Borrowing funds for development can mainly be banks that do not always want to take additional risks and the loan is refused. In this case, borrowing on the financial market is an alternative for an enterprise, but they are not sufficiently developed in the EU, especially in the new or small Member States. The European Commission has therefore proposed the creation of a Capital Markets Union to promote the functioning of financial markets in the EU and to break down existing barriers between countries, which could lead to a reduction in capital costs. For Latvian companies, the Capital Markets Union could mean additional opportunities to attract financing for development, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the creation of the Capital Markets Union at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported this proposal. Insufficient regulation and control of capital markets was one of the main reasons for the outbreak of the financial crisis. Investment in the real economy in Europe has declined relatively over several decades, although the size of the European and global financial sector has increased significantly over the same period. The report states that the Capital Markets Union must take a step-by-step approach and that its priorities must be of a three-pronged nature: firstly, to encourage a more efficient allocation of savings, to allow greater risk mitigation through the creation of stronger cross-border markets and to ensure that there is an effective complementary channel for financing the real economy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Capital Markets Union is a set of proposals to diversify the financing of companies, which are highly dependent on banks in Europe. The Commission intends to develop direct financing in capital markets, particularly for SMEs, by simplifying fundraising rules, relaunching securitisation or promoting venture capital. I am reserved about the opportunity to revive market financing, particularly securitisation, which has been the main factor in instability in recent crises. Banks need to return to their role as loaners to the real economy, which they no longer do satisfactorily. For banks to play their part, it is essential that there is a real separation of investment and retail banks, and a regulation of the markets that restores their vocation, raises capital to finance their development, not encourage speculation. We must therefore be reserved, pending the concrete proposals. So I abstained. On the other hand, I supported the amendments which denounce austerity and the risks of bubbles, which call for bank separation or even focus on SMEs.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained. The aim of the proposal is to diversify the financing of companies, which are too linked to banks, by developing direct financing in capital markets and simplifying the rules of capital raising. It is therefore a question of presenting the Commission's future plans in this area.  We believe that some of the measures envisaged are critical, including securitization, which has been a factor of instability leading up to the latest crises. Together with my colleagues, I am also reserved about the role of banks. They have in fact given themselves missions that should not be theirs. They should be content with their primary mission, lending to the real economy. To do this, it is necessary to separate investment and retail banks by regulating the markets. Speculation must be curbed.  It is therefore necessary, in order to get a more precise idea of the proposals, to wait for concrete projects. However, I have supported a few amendments, which I think are a step in the right direction, such as those who denounce austerity, call for bank separation and insist on the necessary assistance to SMEs.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it is trying to boost the Capital Markets Union, an instrument that will be used to avoid regulation of the banking sector and facilitate the speculative expoliating of the real economy in the European Union. This proposal is not in the interests of industrial enterprises or small and medium-sized enterprises, which are those that generate jobs, but responds to the demands of speculative capital, which aims to more easily access the real economy and thus generate new financial bubbles and greater speculation in the face of market shortages on a global scale. The very idea of forcing SMEs to finance themselves through the issuance of shares means preventing them from normal access to credit and being able to speculate on their income.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a Resolution to create a Capital Markets Union for MPs Robert Gualtieri and Burkhard Balz that aims to create jobs and grow the economy.  This creates the basis for sources of financing for the economy, i.e. the private sector. Investment in the EU, after reaching its peak in 2007, has seen a significant decline and is still below normal levels. The Capital Markets Union is in the back of small and medium-sized enterprises that should be the bearer of the economy. This way of financing creates a positive environment and preconditions for job creation. The aim of this Union is precisely to facilitate access to finance for all companies and SMEs in Europe, to increase and diversify sources of financing and to increase market efficiency and efficiency, all of which can give a positive impulse to the recovery of the real sector. In addition, this is an opportunity for start-ups which means that the concept of "let's start small" is encouraged. However, the most important thing is the reduction of administration, and the reduction of costs by 30-50 percent. Coordination at international level needs to be improved to further help businesses operating in EU Member States.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Support for the unification of capital markets in Europe is a logical step forward towards a pan-European financial policy, in line with commission directives and in view of recent developments in the Union. Due to the excessive dependence of business on the banking sector, the EU needs integrated channels and a variety of sources of business financing guaranteed by changes introduced by all Member States.
