The launch of such a long-term project gives a clear sign of the European Parliament's commitment to small and medium-sized businesses in Europe, and also to a better investment climate in the EU in general.  Unification of capital markets will help to promote small and medium-sized businesses through easier access to initial investment and job creation in key and as yet undeveloped parts of the economy – a move europe needs. An advantage of such a structure will be the promotion of innovation as a highly competitive instrument on the international market and the development of highly specialised sectors of the real economy in Europe. For me, the most important thing is that, without a doubt, the measures for the introduction of united capital markets will have a beneficial effect on foreign investment and the business climate in Bulgaria. A pan-European Capital Markets Union is certainly a necessary and correct step in further economic integration on the continent.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution on building a capital markets union, because this motion for a resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. This is a first step towards creating a capital markets union that could prove to be an asset or a threat. Pending concrete proposals, we prefer to abstain.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is totally uncritical of the role of capital markets and various financial instruments in the development of the financial crisis, and does not even take into account the effect of austerity policies. Parliament's resolution merely follows the line of the European Commission, which insists on deepening legislation without questioning the legislation already adopted.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal has received my opposition. Despite some good approaches and a possible revitalisation of the European economy, I reject the EMSA proposal and, with it, the whole proposal to create a Capital Markets Union.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Motion for Resolution as the Capital Market Union should provide a new, more efficient way to channel savings into small business ventures and protect cross-border investors in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution notes that "investment in the real economy in Europe marks a relative decline over several decades", despite "a significant increase in the size of the European and international financial sector over the same period". Unfortunately, it does not mean that the financialization of the economy is hurting the real economy. Stubborn in neoliberal mantras, the resolution calls for diversification of the financial system, following the example of the United States and further integration of capital markets.  I am voting against this resolution.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim is to develop market financing at the expense of bank financing. These proposals can be a factor of instability and risk. So I abstained.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim is to develop market financing at the expense of bank financing. These proposals can be a factor of instability and risk. I abstained, not yet wanting to weaken the European economic fabric, which is still struggling to recover from the crisis that began in 2008.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the creation of a Capital Markets Union in order to bring back volumes of investments to those markets that enable economic growth and job creation. Hence my sense of vote.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it stresses the importance of utilising a European approach to developing a capital markets union (CMU). The resolution stresses that the Commission should strengthen the diversification of funding sources and investments in European businesses. The Union should not merely replicate its CMU from other parts of the world but learn from their experiences of weathering the financial crisis.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Too often misled at the expense of multinationals, SMEs currently have access to very little credit. Therefore, the proposal to consider the construction of a Capital Markets Union (CMU) in order to improve access to capital markets through various sources of financing, I find it very interesting. I therefore fully support this measure, because I am convinced that it will lead to the development of SMEs, which will also contribute to the creation of jobs.  Nevertheless, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that we must remain vigilant in the control of these capital markets which were, as a reminder, at the origin of the financial crisis. In addition, it is also necessary to ensure the control of the rating agencies, which, without wanting to throw a pavement in the pond, have their share of responsibility in the crisis of 2008.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the final Parliament resolutions on Building a Capital Markets Union, which stresses that an EU Capital Markets Union (CMU) should provide a new, more efficient way to channel savings into small business ventures and protect cross-border investors in the EU. The resolutions also call for the strengthening of creditor protection and the provision of high-quality, easily comparable financial information on firms seeking crowd funding or peer-to-peer loans across borders. I also support the idea that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and retail investors need financial education to help them avoid risky investments and better inform them of the range of products on the market, such as equity or corporate bonds.  Last but not least, the resolution focuses on important issues such as helping SMEs to raise money on financial markets, making regulatory requirements SME-friendly, procedures simple and the administrative burden proportionate.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution presents the opinion of the ECON Committee on the Commission's forthness on the Capital Markets Union. The aim is to develop alternative financing methods for bank financing, particularly for SMEs, by facilitating access to capital markets (securitisation, venture capital, stock markets).  Market instability has been one of the main causes of the crises of recent years. In addition, banks have largely cleaned up their balance sheets since then and are receiving considerable support (ECB TLTRO) to fulfil their role as lenders to the real economy. They must be forced to do so, and to no longer play in the markets, by establishing a real separation of investment banking and retail banking activities. This would be the real way to revive investment, which is less risky than the Capital Markets Union. The report, while it provides some nuances in relation to the main thrusts of the Commission's Green Paper, does not call into question the principle of this policy. It is therefore prudent to abstain.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The union of capital markets is the latest fad of Europeanists who want to sing the American model. Based on the constant that 75% of European business and SME financing comes from bank loans compared to only 25% in the United States, the EU has set out to develop the financing of companies through the markets. The aim is therefore to promote a "quality securitisation", which is perplexing, when we know that the securitized products of the Lehman Brothers were rated triple A a few weeks before the bank collapsed. It deplores the fragmentation of the credit market, but it is only the consequence of a currency area which is inherently non-optimal, and against which a European directive can do nothing. Moreover, this text will strengthen investment banks to support capital markets and thus ultimately strengthen the weight of banks in financing the economy, in contrast to the initial problem of too much dependence on bank financing...  So I voted against it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this resolution to improve access to capital markets through new sources of funding.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which forms part of the Commission’s public hearing process on a future Capital Markets Union. The Commission argues that SMEs should not rely too heavily on the conventional banking sector in order to obtain finance and that they should be able to access funding elsewhere. Furthermore, the Commission is attempting to duplicate the US model where companies are mainly financed by capital markets and shadow banking activities. It also fails to factor in the very real concern that the financial crisis has shown that traditional banking has provided more lending to the real economy than universal or investments banks. What is required is a focus on public banking and local banking and not a revival of shadow banking. Instead of a focus on Capital Market Union, what is required is a rejection of austerity policies. As we have seen, a focus on short-term growth is dangerous and as long as systematic risks have not been comprehensively addressed we have not truly reduced the risk of future crises and related costs on both the economy and citizens’ lives. Irish Citizens are still experiencing the results of such negligence and disregard in Ireland.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support creating a genuine and truly European Capital Markets Union and this document represents a good step in that direction. Europe needs to find more means to ensure a stable and growing economy, with a particular European flavour to it, as the report duly notes. A Capital Markets Union could have a very positive impact on cross-border finance, including on savings or financing, as well as the development of SMEs and joint ventures. Still, it will need adequate studies and proper expertise for its implementation, and we need to ensure a lot more transparency and a level playing field of companies from different Member States.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the creation of a Capital Markets Union, because I believe that there is a need to make capital markets more efficient while creating a fairer and more economically justified link between risk and return on eu capital markets. I believe that, before presenting the relevant legislative proposals, the Commission should carry out a thorough country-by-country analysis of the current state of capital markets and, in a comprehensive economic analysis, evaluate areas where THERE are EU-wide barriers to investment through capital markets, assess the extent of these barriers and indicate by what means they could be removed or minimised. Where a non-legislative approach would suffice, this should be the way to go. Emphasis should be placed on defining and assessing the cross-border risks of financial and capital markets in the EU arising from institutional, legal and regulatory differences between Member States and on finding appropriate solutions to simplify cross-border capital flows.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree that banks need to be regulated to avoid excessive business and risks to citizens. The report also contained some good approaches in this direction. However, I ended up speaking out against it, as it would lead to a further restriction of national sovereignty, which I cannot well welcome.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Capital Markets Union, because, at the moment, it is essential to strengthen Europe's competitiveness and stimulate investment in the name of job creation. It should be taken into account that insufficiently regulated and controlled capital markets were one of the reasons for the financial crisis. The new legislation aims to prevent such a crisis from happening again by creating a stable financial environment for sustainable growth.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think that the creation of capital markets can make a significant contribution to the economic and financial stability of eu member countries and prevent speculation that can create difficulties for the various national governments. This step will lead the EU to act more uniformly and promptly in cases of market imbalances.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the Commission’s efforts for the creation of a true single market for capital, which would make it easier to channel available savings into the productive economy, enhance the funding sources for SMEs and break down barriers for investment across borders. The building of a true single market for capital – a Capital Markets Union for all 28 Member States – will unlock investment in Europe’s companies and infrastructure. A Capital Markets Union will have beneficial effects especially for smaller Member States like Bulgaria, where businesses remain heavily reliant on banks for funding. I fully agree that the Capital Markets Union will give more financing options first of all to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and strengthen investment for the long term. Therefore I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The proposal for this resolution to create a Capital Markets Union was created taking into account the Commission's green paper of 18.2.2015 entitled 'Creating a Capital Markets Union' and the question addressed to the Commission on the Green Paper on the creation of a Capital Markets Union which was the final step in its design. On 16 June 2015, the Council adopted conclusions on the development of the Capital Markets Union and stated that it considers that more integrated capital markets could contribute to job creation and make the financial system more efficient.  I believe that more integrated capital markets and greater availability of capital will enable employment growth, especially among young people, and encourage them to enter the world of entrepreneurship. The five Presidents' report entitled 'Completing Europe's Economic and Monetary Union' announced the establishment of a Single European Capital Market Supervisory Authority, which I certainly consider necessary, and I agree with the statement in the proposal for a resolution that under-regulated capital markets were one of the main reasons for the outbreak of the financial crisis. In particular, an action plan to create a Capital Markets Union is important and I join the Council and call on the Commission to work it out as soon as possible taking into account the needs of SMEs.  I am pleased with commission Commissioner Jonathan Hill's responses and clarifications, the support he has provided to this motion for a resolution, as well as the final content of the proposal itself and have therefore supported it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The capital markets union is the latest fad for Europeanists to take on the American model. Based on the constant that 75% of European business and SME financing comes from bank loans compared to only 25% in the United States, the EU has set out to develop the financing of companies through the markets. The aim is therefore to promote a "quality securitisation", which is perplexing, when we know that the securitized products of the Lehman Brothers were rated triple A a few weeks before the bank collapsed. It deplores the fragmentation of the credit market, but it is only the consequence of a currency area which is inherently non-optimal, and against which a European directive can do nothing. Moreover, this text will strengthen investment banks to support capital markets and thus ultimately strengthen the weight of banks in financing the economy, in contrast to the initial problem of too much dependence on bank financing...  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒in 2012, Parliament has already stressed in its resolution on the long-term financing of the European economy from 26 February 2014 the need to improve access to capital markets through new sources of financing and at the same time stressed that commercial banks are most likely to remain the main source of funding and that it is essential for Member States to establish new sources to complement the mechanisms in place and to fill funding gaps , providing an appropriate regulatory and supervisory framework addressing the needs of the real economy.  Despite the opportunities provided by a well-developed EU capital market, there is no escaping the fact that there are huge barriers in other areas such as tax policy, in particular debt-inducement practices rather than equity, insolvency and accounting law. It is necessary for the Commission to take into account differences in the economic and cultural composition of the SMEs sector by Member State in order to avoid unintended consequences arising from the implementation of the Capital Markets Union, which can further highlight existing imbalances in access to finance between Member States.  I agree with the requirement for a comprehensive analysis of the current situation in EU capital markets and the barriers present at EU level and the presentation of legislative and non-legislative proposals as soon as possible in order to achieve the objective of a fully integrated SINGLE EU capital market by the end of 2018.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker cites strengthening Europe's competitiveness and boosting investment to create jobs as the Commission's top strategic priority. The fact is that investment in Europe's real economy has weakened relatively over the past few decades despite a large increase in the European and global financial sectors over the same period. The EU's real economy continues to rely heavily on banks, making the economy vulnerable to difficult bank financing conditions, which was noticeable from the global economic crisis of 2007.  The priority is to restore stability in the EU banking sector in order to gain an advantage over financing long-term investments and the real economy. The insurance sector holds large stockpiles of uninvested funds that should be used more efficiently by improving the regulatory framework so that capital requirements for certain investments are reconsidered. Conditions should be created for the return of trust in the EU real economy on the basis of clear commitments at Member State and Union level to foster a positive investment climate and legal certainty for investors, formulate long-term objectives for a legislative framework that will work stabilising and boost competitiveness and growth. Europe's future is tied to achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Therefore, I support the proposal for a Resolution on the Creation of a Capital Markets Union.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to improve access to capital markets and develop sources of financing, while building on existing financing mechanisms (banks), the European Parliament has adopted a proposal to build a capital markets union. I voted in favour of this report and I stress the importance of this proposal in the wake of the financial crisis and because of the instability of the banking sector.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of creating a Capital Markets Union because the UMC aims to remove barriers that block cross-border investment in the EU and prevent businesses from accessing finance. One of the objectives is the unlocking of liquidity, putting it at the service of European companies, especially SMEs. The EC is therefore urged to establish a European approach to strengthening the diversification of sources of financing and investments in European companies through a BCU based on the characteristics and interdependence of the European banking and capital markets landscape.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. On 26 February 2014, the European Parliament stressed "the need to improve access to capital markets through new sources of financing" in its resolution on the long-term financing of the European economy.  The Galtieri-Balz text adopted this lunchtime goes into more detail and sets out the priorities of MEPs regarding the construction of a capital markets union. The steady decline in investment in Europe's real economy has to be addressed over the past decade. The latter remains highly dependent on banks, which makes the economy vulnerable in the event of a tightening of bank credit, as is the case in the post-financial crisis period, with a perverse effect: the difficulty of access to credit for SMEs, even the most innovative and therefore a direct consequence on job creation.  In Belgium, in 2014, almost 30% of small businesses did not get the bank financing they were seeking. This is why two types of reforms need to be carried out: one to simplify the rules on equity financing, which are too heavy for private companies, the other to remove barriers to access to finance for SMEs: the heart of European economic activity.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. With this motion for a resolution, the European Parliament has signalled its desire to create a coherent EU-wide regulatory environment to encourage the development of capital markets. I support such a project which would enable Europe to better respond to financial crises similar to the one we experienced in 2007 and to respond to the problem of long-term investment. This text sets out three priorities that constitute the project's development axis: more efficient allocation of savings, better risk mitigation through deepening cross-border markets, and the creation of complementary channels to finance the real economy.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. In particular, the possibilities for non-bank financing for SMEs need to be expanded, as well as barriers that persist at all levels, including the cross-border use of financial services.  A single European capital market will support investment, economic growth and employment. However, the European Commission's Green Paper on the subject is not sufficiently comprehensive. There is no single reference to the single currency which, in simplifying intra-European financial transactions, has been the traditional engine of integration, nor to the need for UNION public debt to play the risk-free asset role in the European economy.  We also know that non-bank financing is largely shadow banking. The creation of the CMU must be accompanied by adequate regulation, so that this sector does not operate as an exhaust valve for bad practices. The Socialists will be very vigilant so that the CMU does not become an excuse to deregulate and increase systemic risk.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In voting in favour of this report, I supported the pragmatic and proportionate approach pursued by the European Commission to establish a Capital Markets Union (UCMC) by 2019. The UMC project includes immediate initiatives including the revitalization of a simple and transparent securitized product market that would reduce bank balance sheets, the revision of the directive requiring capital raising companies to publish a standard prospectus, and changes to the prudential insurance rules ('Solvency II') to stimulate investment in infrastructure.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I am in favour of building a Capital Markets Union, which is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.  The union I want to support is the one that makes it possible to give more funding opportunities, especially to SMEs. That is why I agree with Mr Sleyley on behaving in this way. Balz when he says that we must be sure that SMEs will actually benefit from this union, which will have to improve the investment climate in Europe.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution. The Capital Markets Union is one of the key initiatives of the new Commission, and in particular Jonathan Hill, Commissioner for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union.  The idea is that companies rely too heavily on bank financing, so it seeks to stimulate capital markets. Parliament's resolution is once again the product of the grand coalition between the S&D and PPE Groups. The Resolution is a criticism of capital markets and some of the instruments (e.g. securitisation) that have led to financial crises, and does not identify the root causes of bank credit shortages, linked to austerity measures. It is thus at the Commission's line, calling for the development of capital markets and the diversification of the financial system, praising the financial legislation already adopted rather than questioning it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it is trying to boost the Capital Markets Union, an instrument that will be used to avoid regulation of the banking sector and facilitate the speculative expoliating of the real economy in the European Union. This proposal is not in the interests of industrial enterprises or small and medium-sized enterprises, which are those that generate jobs, but responds to the demands of speculative capital, which aims to more easily access the real economy and thus generate new financial bubbles and greater speculation in the face of market shortages on a global scale. The very idea of forcing SMEs to finance themselves through the issuance of shares means preventing them from normal access to credit and being able to speculate on their income.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted today is the European Parliament's first reaction to the Commission's Green Paper on the creation of a Capital Markets Union. I have decided to vote in favour of this text because I am convinced that a real European approach is needed to identify and remove obstacles to cross-border investment within the EU and thereby stimulate growth in the 28 Member States. I therefore hope that the action plan to be drawn up by the Commission following the public consultation will aim to maximise the benefits of a single capital market by improving access to finance for all businesses and especially for SMEs and by strengthening the competitiveness of the European Union, by creating a solid basis for financial stability.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the overall resolution on a Capital Markets Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the creation of a Capital Markets Union. Commercial banks are the main source of funding. However, recent years have shown that, despite regulation, they are a very expensive and risky element. I therefore welcome the positive intention to diversify funding, develop European capital markets and improve access to finance, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. A good example is the area of stock markets or corporate bond markets. However, priority must be given to ensuring an adequate regulatory framework. In fact, poorly regulated and controlled capital markets were the main cause of the financial crisis.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is important that we ensure better funding for small and medium-sized enterprises within the EU when creating such a union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the creation of a Capital Markets Union, as Parliament has considered and planned this resolution since February 2014. Taking into account that an uncontrolled capital market was one of the main reasons for the financial crisis, I think additional regulation of capital markets is needed.  Also, the creation of a Capital Markets Union would further reduce costs and contribute to the growth of SMEs. I am of the opinion that this resolution will facilitate the conditions of bank financing of the real economy in all member states.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the creation of the Capital Markets Union. Low economic growth in the EU does not provide new jobs, so I see a necessary step towards improving the situation in the creation of a single capital market. The purpose of creating a Capital Markets Union is to achieve optimal exploitation of capital markets for the interests of the economy, growth and jobs. The Single Capital Market is also crucial for the re-financial and development momentum of SMEs, as it provides better access to finance. The cross-border movement of capital plays a great role in this. The Capital Markets Union will be very helpful to SMEs.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Sets as a regulatory factor the European Fund for Strategic Investments, with whose role we do not agree.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the establishment of a Capital Markets Union. The proposal provides an excellent overview of the situation resulting from the inadequate functioning of the capital market. It rightly pointed out that, although large-scale state intervention has resulted in liquidity since the crisis, this has not increased the demand for financing in the real economy. I think it is right that the motion focused on the different economic and cultural composition of European SMEs from one Member State to another. I agree with the call on the Commission to encourage the most efficient distribution of savings, more investment opportunities, greater transparency and portfolio diversification for savers and investors by deepening and diversifying the sources of funding available to businesses. This is done by building on existing advanced European business finance structures. I particularly welcome the point in the motion which highlights the importance of expanding access to financial education, especially for small investors and SMEs, in order to strengthen their confidence in capital markets and to be aware of the advantages and disadvantages of capital market investment.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The financial trends of the past year have shown that investment in the real economy in Europe has relatively declined over several decades, despite a large increase in the size of the European and global financial sector over the same period.  In order to improve the efficiency of markets and ensure a fair, adequate and economically sound risk-return relationship in EU capital, a European Capital Market Union is needed. Such a union will provide better access for European businesses and SMEs to financing, increasing and diversifying the sources of funding and making the market more effective both within Member States and cross-border.  The final text, which I voted in favour of today, includes several of the S&D priorities to achieving our goal. Mainly: using capital markets for financing long-term investment and the real economy; making the Capital Market Union a deregulatory agenda for the financial markets; reviewing legislation to ensure highest investor protection standards and addressing taxation of capital markets.  A harmonised, pro-European approach that takes into consideration the different economic and cultural composition of the national financial sectors, is a constructive way to address the financial difficulties we are facing today.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. I am surprised, however, that the American example is mentioned so much. We call on the Commission to develop a European approach to strengthen the diversification of european business sources of finance and investment, through a CMU based on the characteristics and interdependence of the European banking system and the capital market landscape, while taking into account the specificities of the European business finance model and the need to develop non-bank financing sources for growth , and supplement them with procedures that allow market operators to raise debt capital, equity and venture capital directly from the market. The Commission should not necessarily be based on peer reviews in other jurisdictions. Cultural differences should not be ignored. It will be necessary, in order to overcome them, to formulate adequate responses.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this resolution because I believe it covers key topics on removing barriers to cross-border investment in the European Union, which is the main objective of building a Capital Markets Union. As many benefits can be achieved by opening up the markets of european Union Member States to foreign investors, I support a position that expresses the need to identify legislative barriers that could hinder the success of building a Capital Markets Union. In my view, removing these barriers would make it easier and more efficient to find investors for micro and small and medium-sized enterprises, which are drivers of the European economy, as they account for 99% of all businesses in the EU.  This would strengthen the European Union's venture capital market, which has great potential to create much-needed new jobs.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The Capital Markets Union aims to remove barriers that prevent cross-border investment in the Union and prevent businesses from accessing finance. The business environment is now unfriendly to businesses, as they are still highly dependent on banks and relatively less on capital markets. Elsewhere in the world, the opposite is true. With the Capital Markets Union, the Commission also wants to remove the barriers that prevent those in need of funding from gaining investors and to enable the provision of funds in the investment chain as efficiently as possible, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution. The Capital Markets Union is one of the key initiatives of the new Commission, and in particular Jonathan Hill, Commissioner for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union.  The idea is that companies rely too heavily on bank financing, so it seeks to stimulate capital markets. Parliament's resolution is once again the product of the grand coalition between the S&D and PPE Groups. The Resolution is a criticism of capital markets and some of the instruments (e.g. securitisation) that have led to financial crises, and does not identify the root causes of bank credit shortages, linked to austerity measures. It is thus at the Commission's line, calling for the development of capital markets and the diversification of the financial system, praising the financial legislation already adopted rather than questioning it.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It was great news when President Juncker announced the Capital Markets Union initiative. Without further diversification in the access to credit, the European economy would have difficulties to achieve its full potential. I hope that in September the Commission will make strong legislative proposals following our report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Capital Markets Union is a set of proposals to diversify the financing of companies, which are highly dependent on banks in Europe (nearly 80% of the total).  To this end, the Commission intends to develop direct financing in capital markets, particularly for SMEs, by simplifying the rules for raising funds, relaunching securitisation or promoting venture capital. Our position is reserved as to whether to revive market financing, particularly securitisation, which has been the main factor in instability in recent crises. Banks need to return to their role as loaners to the real economy, which they no longer do satisfactorily. However, they should be able to do so, having cleaned up their balance sheets since the end of the crisis. For banks to play their part, it is essential that there is a real separation of investment and retail banks, and market regulation that restores their vocation. The Capital Markets Union, led by Commissioner Jonathan Hill, a former City lobbyist, looks like a promotion of shadow banking and the investment banking model, which led to the subprime crisis. I abstained pending concrete proposals.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution. The Capital Markets Union is one of the key initiatives of the new Commission, and in particular Jonathan Hill, Commissioner for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union.  The idea is that companies rely too heavily on bank financing, so it seeks to stimulate capital markets. Parliament's resolution is once again the product of the grand coalition between the S&D and PPE Groups. The Resolution is a criticism of capital markets and some of the instruments (e.g. securitisation) that have led to financial crises, and does not identify the root causes of bank credit shortages, linked to austerity measures. It is thus at the Commission's line, calling for the development of capital markets and the diversification of the financial system, praising the financial legislation already adopted rather than questioning it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it refers to unifying the criteria for regulating capital markets. The EU needs Community tools to regulate this fully internationalised and global sector.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Jobs and growth in Europe are today’s top priority. I voted in favour of this report because a true Capital Markets Union is of the utmost importance in ensuring that long-term investment is secured and strengthened. European business relies heavily on banks for funding and much less so on the capital markets, which can serve the purpose of providing complementary investment sources. The goal is to remove barriers between investors’ money and investment opportunities, which means overcoming the obstacles that prevent businesses from reaching investors. One of the main priorities, for example, is to ensure that SMEs can gain access to funding as easily as large companies do. A Capital Markets Union for all 28 Member States should nevertheless be founded on financial stability and on an adequate level of consumer and investor protection.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is important to implement a coherent strategy around the virtuous triangle of structural reforms, investment and budgetary responsibility. In this context, progress needs to be made towards more effective commitments with the introduction of structural reforms that drive euro area growth. This motion for a Resolution is an important element in moving forward in this direction, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the so-called Capital Markets Union (CMU) because it is essential to increase financial integration in the Union. In particular, the possibilities for non-bank financing for SMEs need to be expanded, as well as barriers that persist at all levels, including the cross-border use of financial services.  A single European capital market will support investment, economic growth and employment. However, the European Commission's Green Paper on the subject is not sufficiently comprehensive. There is no single reference to the single currency which, in simplifying intra-European financial transactions, has been the traditional engine of integration, nor to the need for UNION public debt to play the risk-free asset role in the European economy.  We also know that non-bank financing is largely shadow banking. The creation of the CMU must be accompanied by adequate regulation, so that this sector does not operate as an exhaust valve for bad practices. The Socialists will be very vigilant so that the CMU does not become an excuse to deregulate and increase systemic risk.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The Capital Markets Union (CMU) aims to intensify the financialisation of the economic system through greater standardisation of financial products and greater use of financial instruments - such as securitisations - that were at the root of the 2008 crisis to replace the classic banking channel. This standardisation will necessarily benefit the real economy and SMEs which, on the contrary, need solutions that respect their specific characteristics and facilitate their business by reducing the bureaucratic and administrative burden on them.  That is why we rejected in plenary in Strasbourg the motion for a resolution supporting the implementation of the CMU. The development of finance does not have a positive correlation with economic growth. The result would be a financial system more exposed to systemic risks and without firewalls to deal with them. On the contrary, to return to growth, we need to solve the problem of credit crunch, relaunch aggregate demand and create an environment conducive to public investment, especially those in innovation.  In addition, timing is early. The CMU would enter into force when banking reforms – such as BSR and shadow banking regulation – have not yet been finalised and, ultimately, the necessary consumer protection measures are not envisaged.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the construction of the capital market within the European Union. A whole program... Unsurprisingly, the text adopts a neoliberal approach. While austere policies plunge the countries of the European Union into a recession that mainly affects the most fragile social categories, we are offered a text that only notes the crisis and proposes only a vague "moralisation" of financial capitalism, while calling for it to be further developed and to make it always "more attractive". Always the same dogmatism.    However, it is at the very least time to stop excessive speculation in financial markets that brings to the real economy only crises, mass layoffs and growing inequalities. Finally, a European approach should enable the regulation of these crazy capital markets and give priority to public infrastructure and investment, but also to SMEs, and promote long-term engagement for the benefit of all.  I obviously voted against this text.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The union of capital markets is a good example that illustrates, on the one hand, the contradictions of the current process of capitalist integration of the European Union and, on the other hand, the lack of solutions to address the problems that plague European economies. The European Union is facing a crisis of enormous severity. A quarter of Europeans are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. That's 24 million unemployed. Youth unemployment rates doubled between 2007 and 2014. Instead of understanding the causes of the crisis, identifying the root causes of the crisis and the need to find public solutions to correct the monumental market failures, one focuses on the same solutions that undertake the current crisis.  Wanting to integrate a capital market will not solve any of the problems of our economies. Believing that it is possible to create a legislative framework with necessarily highly complex supervision that will ensure a market solution to the issue of the lack of funding of our thousands of SMEs is a dangerous illusion that reveals some blindness and is a prejudice to public policies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This proposal has received my opposition. Despite some good approaches and a possible revitalisation of the European economy, I reject the EMSA proposal and, with it, the whole proposal to create a Capital Markets Union.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the resolution on the creation of a Capital Markets Union, considering that it is necessary to improve access to capital markets through new sources of financing. I welcome the rapporteur's concern, which pointed out in the resolution adopted by the EP plenary that reducing the fragmentation of capital markets could lead to lower capital costs, while improving their distribution, and could thus support the development of businesses, especially SMEs, and job creation in the EU. The resolution stresses that improving financing conditions for businesses in Europe must be based on enhanced economic and financial stability, which includes reforms in all Member States. It is also noted that imperfect capital markets have led to an erroneous risk assessment and a disconnect between the gains pursued and the actual risks assumed, which has made the markets very unfair to entities such as SMEs.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Instead of understanding the causes of the crisis, identifying the deep tails of the crisis and the need to find public solutions to correct the monumental market failures, one bets on the same solutions that underpded the current crisis.  Wanting to integrate a capital market will not solve any of the problems of our economies. Believing that it is possible to create a legislative framework with necessarily highly complex supervision that will ensure a market solution to the issue of the lack of funding of our thousands of SMEs, is a dangerous illusion that reveals a political project that rejects the centrality of public policies.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, I did not support the report on the European Security Strategy not because I do not want security in Europe, but precisely because I would like to. What happened during and after the debate was outrageous, because in the debate they tried to convince the obviously anxious European citizens that the European Union, for its part, was doing everything possible to protect the EU's external borders, to protect citizens from the threat of terrorism and from cross-border crime.  I asked the question that, obviously, there is no reason why Hungary, as a sovereign state, decides to use a fence to protect the currently completely vulnerable Serbian-Hungarian external Schengen border, and what the Commissioner thinks about this, what the EU thinks of this. He refused to answer, but I am going home, I am opening the newspaper, and there is the constant abuse of my country by Mrs Merkel, on the part of the EU, and the rest about why we want to build a fence. In order to comply with this particular security strategy and to protect Europe from the crime-related threats it face. That's one of the reasons. And that doesn't mean that people fleeing war shouldn't be...  (opposition interrupted)

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this year people in the United Kingdom and across the Anglo-speaking world, from America to Canada, will be celebrating the 800th year of the signing of the Magna Carta. This great charter of liberties was the culmination of an epic struggle between the people and an elite who wanted to have arbitrary authority over their lives and freedom. They fought for freedom of liberty, freedom from illegal imprisonment and freedom from the despot. Today those brave signatories will be turning in their graves as a cloud of authoritarianism floats over the citizens of Europe as, once again, this place votes for increased powers for a European police force, votes for a European security and justice system that will allow the European Union to have its own security services, and security services that will have the powers to look over and control the security services of nation states. I oppose this attack on the civil liberties of a nation state that once stood strong for Magna Carta and strong for the people.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution on the European Security Agenda as it delves into the cuts in rights and freedoms being carried out by both the authorities of the Member States and the European authorities. The solution to security problems cannot go through the mass espionage of citizens or by targeting entire groups of the population. At a time when espionage scandals and illegal files of social activists have been made public, this Resolution aims to give a varnish of legality to these policies and to the discrimination of population groups on the excuse of fighting radicalization.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Security threats have changed a lot in recent years. Terrorism has taken various forms and now often plays a threatening role in cyberspace. Many threats to Europe's security are also due to other factors such as poverty, racism, homophobia, etc. In a globalized world, a state alone can hardly guarantee the security of its own country. The European countries must therefore work together, and for these reasons I welcome the resolutions that have been adopted.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission will adopt a European Security Agenda for 2015-2020 in the coming months, which will touch on the various actions to be taken to increase security in Europe. Radicalism, the financing of terrorism, cooperation between Europol and other European agencies, and arms trafficking will be the main topics of this agenda. The topics covered in this agenda seem to be moving in the right direction, although I have very strong doubts about the issue of radicalism. While many young Europeans, including many French, are joining terrorist organisations, notably to fight in Syria, the European Commission's meagre attempts to put an end to this phenomenon have all failed.  Without giving states control of their borders, the Union is failing to effectively combat this scourge. As I was in favour of the re-establishment of internal borders as a prerequisite, I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This represents an expansionist EU foreign policy which I utterly reject, and therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this programme, which aims to provide the EU with a general framework to ensure the safety of European citizens.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The risks to the Union's internal security have become more complex, hybrid, asymmetric, non-traditional, transmissible, rapidly variable and difficult to predict and exceed the capabilities of any individual Member State, and a coherent, comprehensive, multi-faceted and coordinated EU response is needed more than ever, taking full account of respect for fundamental rights.  The development of an EU security policy is a matter of shared responsibility, which requires that the coordinated and unified efforts of all Member States, EU institutions and agencies, civil society and law enforcement authorities pursue common objectives and are based on the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. whereas, in order to achieve the best results, the concrete implementation of these common objectives and priorities should be linked to a clear allocation of tasks at EU and national level, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and through strict and effective parliamentary and judicial scrutiny.  I agree with the Commission's proposal for the period 2015-2020. the European Security Strategy and its priorities.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, whose angelism seems to me to be totally counterproductive.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this motion for a resolution in which Parliament welcomes the European security programme for the Commission's 2015-2020 period. It highlights measures to combat terrorism, terrorist financing, radicalisation, crime and cybercrime to ensure the safety of citizens. It also reiterates the need to address the causes of crime (poverty, inequality, etc.) and calls for a balance between prevention policy and repression in order to preserve freedom, security and justice. Finally, it welcomes the programme's special attention to fundamental rights and, in particular, the Commission's commitment to carry out a rigorous audit of any proposed security measures, not only with regard to the objectives to be achieved but also with regard to compliance with fundamental rights.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text must adopt a resolution on the European security programme. However, this resolution shows a naïve approach to the European Socialists and Greens who want to "perpetuate" the fundamental rights of criminals. It aims to limit the possibilities for the police to prosecute criminals and terrorists.  This well-meaning text testifies either to the real naivety of these MEPs or to the stupidity of such measures. Moreover, it only considers the problem of crime through inequality or poverty, finding an excuse again for criminals and terrorists (when it is not the extreme right...). On the contrary, we must strengthen the possibilities of prosecuting criminals, apply a zero-tolerance policy and severely control our borders. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions supported in the resolution being voted on, I believe that the proposed measures are not worthy of the purpose it proposes, and I do not in any way agree with the persistent denial of a direct connection between mass landings from the coasts of North Africa and terrorism; For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Security Agenda aims to set key priorities and actions for the period 2015-2020 on EU internal security, replacing the current EU Internal Security Strategy 2010-2015.  The three main priorities set are the fight against terrorism and radicalization, the fight against organized crime and the fight against cybercrime. This Agenda lays the groundwork for the cooperation and joint actions to be undertaken by European institutions and agencies, Member States and partners in civil and international society. For all this, and in view of the significance of these challenges, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because, at both European Union and Member State level, we must ensure freedom, security and justice, respect fundamental rights, and appropriate democratic supervision and accountability in the exercise of these rights.  The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's proposal for the 2015-2020 the European Security Strategy and its priorities, but this agenda does not take sufficient account of the fair dimension. The European Agenda on Security is crucial because the European Union is currently facing threats such as terrorism, radicalisation, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime, which require concerted action at national, EU and global level. Therefore, as regards the action plan on this agenda, it is necessary to strike the right balance between prevention policies and repressive measures in order to preserve freedom, security and justice.  Security measures should always be applied in accordance with the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, such as the right to privacy and data protection, freedom of expression and association and the right to due process. The Commission should therefore take due account of the recent ruling of the Court of Justice on the Data Retention Directive, which requires all measures to comply with the principles of proportionality, necessity and legality and include appropriate measures to protect accountability and judicial redress in the context of the Implementation of the European Agenda on Security.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PpE group and the Fidesz delegation welcome the Commission's strategy in this important area, but we believe that the European Parliament's response and recommendations to this are insufficient and appropriate to provide sufficient support to the EU and its Member States in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. The EU needs guiding principles, measures, resources, expertise and action. We need to talk seriously and concretely about how to protect our children from violence, how to stop the radicalisation of young people, how to improve the exchange of information in the field of law enforcement, how to prevent people smuggling and to ensure adequate funding for law enforcement agencies. Unfortunately, parliament's decision is not balanced enough. In the field of law enforcement, the protection of fundamental rights and data protection are of paramount importance. However, it is not enough to focus only on them in order to create an adequate, clean and coherent security strategy and protect our citizens. For all these reasons, I could not support this decision in its present form, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution deals with the European security programme. It contains elements beyond the powers devolved to the Union by the Lisbon Treaty and, with them, the sovereignty of each Member State. While security is a major issue that requires cooperation between nations, it must not become a pretext for the concentration of power in the hands of technocrats who have demonstrated their incompetence and failures. Indeed, the Union's immigration policy is a failure, as is the one against jihadist networks and the Islamic State. These criminal networks thrive mainly because of the lack of border controls within the Schengen area.  The European software is deficient and that is why it should be replaced with the one of the return to national sovereignty, combined with European cooperation when necessary. I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorism, radicalisation, organised and cyber-crime are currently the greatest threats to Europe, endangering the lives of citizens by limiting security, fundamental freedoms and human rights. Given that the post-Cold War world is a globalised one, characterised by a great interdependence, which makes it impossible to affect the other countries in one form or another, but also against the background of the current conflict in Ukraine, the instability of the European Union can be a real theme that will warn the EU Member States with a view to strengthening security. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Agenda on Security because I believe that the development of a roadmap in this area will exponentially increase operational cooperation in the field of internal security and will protect the rights and freedoms of European citizens, fundamental rights, which cannot be infringed in any way.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposed measures are certainly not worthy of the purpose of the report. Combating terrorism with PNR certainly seems ridiculous, not to mention the constant references to the non-relationship between Islamic immigration and terrorism. Vote against

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the European security agenda. In recent years, threats to the Union's internal security have become more complex and difficult to predict and have shown that it is difficult for a single Member State to respond to them. The report therefore stressed that terrorism, radicalisation, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime are serious threats that require coordinated action at European level. In responding to these challenges, the call to seek the right balance between prevention policies and repressive measures is important. In addition, security measures should always be implemented in accordance with the principles of the rule of law and the protection of fundamental rights, such as the right to privacy and data protection, freedom of expression and association and due process. In short, the European security agenda must not restrict the rights and freedoms of the European model.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This represents an expansionist EU foreign policy which I utterly reject, and therefore voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Resolution as I believe that in view of the challenges the EU is currently facing, EU security needs to be tackled seriously and the wording in the Resolution does not reflect in my view the best way forward. I believe that through this Resolution we are limiting the possibility for the police authorities to tackle criminality in all its forms including terrorism. Without legal instruments, the police cannot fulfil their job effectively.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agenda follows on from the internal security strategy and I voted in favour of the report presented by the LIBE Committee on this subject. The agenda focuses on the three pillars of organised crime, terrorism and cybercrime, and the relevant report provides for a fair balance between the need for security and the need to safeguard rights and freedoms. The emphasis is on prevention without going beyond repressive measures and, in particular, the usefulness of encrypted data for non-criminal purposes is affirmed and therefore the need for citizens to be able to continue to use this instrument. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is very important to stress that threats to the Union's internal security have become more complex, unconventional and international, are evolving rapidly and difficult to predict, thus exceeding the capabilities of any individual Member State and that they therefore require more than ever a coherent, comprehensive, multi-layered and coordinated response from the EU as a whole, but which takes full account of respect for fundamental rights.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain on the motion for a resolution on the European Security Agenda. On 28 April 2015, the Commission adopted a communication setting out the key security priorities and principles for the period 2015-2020. The report asks the Commission and the Council to indicate how they intend to implement the agenda, how they plan to cooperate with Parliament and whether they have received assessments from the agencies concerned of the necessary human and financial resources. However, the GROUP of the European People's Party considered the content of this report to be insufficient and not in line with its prerogatives.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Of the two motions for resolutions on the agenda, only one was adopted. What I supported because I thought it could be more effective, given the sensitive issue we are dealing with, was not supported by the majority. Threats to the Union's internal security are becoming increasingly complex, well-designed, asymmetrical, unpredictable and uncontrollable. The Member States alone cannot manage these constant attacks, let alone combat them. The response must not only be coherent, swift and effective, but must take account of the articulation of these terrorist associations on several levels and in several states. With regard to terrorism, we need to step up the prevention of radicalisation through dialogue with local communities and civil society at national level, in order to stop extremist ideologies. In the wake of the recent terrorist attacks in Brussels, Paris, Copenhagen and Saint-Quentin-Fallavier, there is an urgent need to focus on a number of priorities: strengthening EU border security, improving internet reporting capabilities, combating illegal arms trafficking and enhancing the exchange of information and operational cooperation between national law enforcement authorities and intelligence services. Other issues on which we are trying to find concrete solutions are cybercrime, cybercrime and organised crime.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Agenda for Security is an essential element for the legislative planning of the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice.  At a time when challenges like never before are posed in trafficking in human beings, terrorism, cybercrime, cross-border crime in a widespread manner, this resolution is Parliament's contribution in drawing up the internal security strategy for 2015-2020. This Resolution is not at all the most desirable to forget that without security there is no freedom, sometimes for forgetting that security without freedom is dictatorship. However, I would like to stress two fundamental points because I have been hit by it: on the one hand, to carry out a serious assessment of the instruments that are in place before amending them and, on the other hand, with regard to the Schengen Information Service, exploiting all the potential that it already has and which remain underused.   It is up to Parliament to ensure that in the next five years the implementation of this Agenda protects citizens without harming their freedom.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are well aware that threats to the Internal Security of the European Union have become increasingly complex, international, rapidly evolving and difficult to predict over time. Terrorism, radicalisation, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime are just some of the challenges facing the EU, acting in a timely, coordinated and flexible manner. I agree with what is set out in the European Security Agenda for 2015-2020, which has set very good starting objectives, first and foremost by helping Member States to further develop mutual trust and improve the exchange of information and good practices, as well as the inclusion of very strict human rights clauses in cooperation agreements and the protection of the principle of the best interests of the child in all security legislation. I also agree with the cooperation between Europol, Eurojust and the future European Public Prosecutor's Office, in order to ensure greater democratic control, law enforcement and justice throughout the territory. I hope that the EU will be able to achieve an excellent degree of autonomy in terms of security, including by developing devices and services for critical public infrastructure and services. In order to do this, it is essential to invest in research and innovation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution on the European Security Agenda as it delves into the cuts in rights and freedoms being carried out by both the authorities of the Member States and the European authorities. The solution to security problems cannot go through the mass espionage of citizens or by targeting entire groups of the population. At a time when espionage scandals and illegal files of social activists have been made public, this Resolution aims to give a varnish of legality to these policies and to the discrimination of population groups on the excuse of fighting radicalization.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PP group welcomes the Commission's strategy in this important area, but we believe that the European Parliament's response and recommendations to this are insufficient and appropriate to provide sufficient support to the EU and its Member States in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. The EU needs guiding principles, measures, resources, expertise and action. We need to talk seriously and concretely about how to protect our children from violence, how to stop the radicalisation of young people, how to improve the exchange of information in the field of law enforcement, how to prevent people smuggling and to ensure adequate funding for law enforcement agencies. Unfortunately, parliament's decision is not balanced enough. In the field of law enforcement, the protection of fundamental rights and data protection are of paramount importance. However, it is not enough to focus only on them in order to create an adequate, clean and coherent security strategy and protect our citizens.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is reacting on the European Commission’s Communication on the European Security Agenda for the period 2015-2020. It outlines the priorities for supporting Member States’ cooperation in tackling security threats and strengthening the common efforts in the fight against terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime. The Commission identified three pressing challenges it wants to specifically concentrate on: preventing terrorism and countering radicalisation, fighting organised crime, and fighting cybercrime. I believe that the EU’s focus on these particular aspects of security is crucial; hence, I voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the European Parliament's position on the European security programme for 2015-2020, as proposed by the Commission. Considering the complex, hybrid, asymmetrical, unconventional, international and difficult-to-predict threats to internal security, as recalled by the recent attempts at attacks in France, a European response that is coherent, comprehensive, multi-level and coordinated must be provided.  I believe that the priority of combating terrorism, violent extremism, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime, set out by the European Commission, is moving in the right direction.  In this type of debate, there is also a need to strike a balance between respect for fundamental rights and security requirements. However, this resolution seemed to me to be unbalanced in this respect and for that reason I abstained.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)

For all these reasons, I could not support this resolution in its present form, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European security programme. I believe it is important that the European Parliament expresses a strong and courageous position in favour of the safety of its citizens. The European Union has become more necessary than ever, as Member States are no longer able to deal with cross-border threats on their own. This resolution welcomes the creation of Europol's counter-terrorism centre, which I hope will actually be operational from 1 January 2016. It stresses the need to provide Europol with the financial means necessary to carry out its additional tasks and calls for the compulsory registration of terrorism suspects in the SIS (Schengen Information System), as well as the harmonisation of reporting criteria.  I would have very much liked to see it as a demand for real European governance of the union's security.  My conviction is that it would be necessary for us to have a head of external security in the Union, we should also have someone who takes responsibility for internal security. Unfortunately, this conviction was not accepted in the final text, although it was in the text voted in committee.

text: Writing. \u2012 On the pretext of security, internal issues of member cards will be interfered with

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text because of the importance of having a European security strategy. Given that the threats that currently undermine European security are almost always cross-border, Europe needs to understand that it must combat these challenges in a unified way, with an effective information sharing system that is the result of collaboration between the judicial and police forces. The proposal voted on in plenary focuses mainly on the fight against organised crime, terrorism and cybercrime, but, despite the high levels of concern usually raised on these issues, it manages to propose solutions that also aim at safeguarding fundamental rights.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report begins by congratulating "the European Agenda for Security for the period 2015-2020 proposed by the Commission" and the priorities set out therein. A lot is said. It is a document full of the usual apparent good intentions, permeated by concepts (vaguely enunciated) such as "terrorism", "radicalization" and "cybercrime". Inescapable are the proposals that open the door to restrictive measures of fundamental freedoms, actions for the control and repression of citizens and free democratic participation. It deliberately omits the reasons behind the current European and international situation, such as the implementation of neoliberal policies to attack workers' rights, the imposition of "austerity" measures in the so-called peripheral countries of the European Union, interference and participation in conflicts through NATO in third countries and the manifest inability to manage and respond to the flow of migrants and refugees seeking to reach Europe. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Agenda on Security 2015-2020. The European Union is currently facing major challenges that require coordinated action, not only at national and European level, but also at global level. These are, in particular, terrorism, radicalisation, organised crime and cybercrime, which pose the greatest threat to the security of the citizens of the European Union. Not only the recent terrorist attacks on the territory of the European Union, but also in other countries, place the urgency of the fight against terrorism before us. It is essential to use all the instruments, or to introduce new instruments to protect our citizens and their security.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because the proposed measures are certainly not worthy of the purpose of the report. Combating terrorism with PNR certainly seems ridiculous, not to mention the constant references to the non-relationship between Islamic immigration and terrorism.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the European Agenda on Security because, on the pretext of security, there will be an intervention in the internal affairs of the Member States.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against these oral questions to the Council and Commission. I broadly supported the Commission’s European Agenda on Security for 2015-2019 when it was first set out. However, Parliament’s final resolution has not mirrored the original priorities. I cannot support that ‘economic inequalities’ are the root cause of all criminal activity nor an EU-wide agreement on what constitutes ‘national security’.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the European Commission’s Communication on the European Security Agenda for 2015-2020, I support the key priorities formulated by the Commission as fundamentals to strengthen Member States’ cooperation in tackling security threats and increase the common efforts in the fight against terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime. I consider that, in view of the challenges the European Union is currently facing, these are the most serious issues which require coordinated actions at Union level in full respect of human rights and citizens’ rights. I strongly welcome the LIBE Resolution to the Plenary, which has adopted our S&D line, namely the full compliance with fundamental rights, more transparency, accountability and democratic control, better application and implementation of existing legal instruments, a more joined-up inter-agency and cross-sectoral approach, and a greater link between the internal and external dimensions of security. In line with the Resolution, I call on the Commission and on the Council to establish a Roadmap of the Agenda’s implementation in which to comply with them.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. It is of great importance to support the measures contained in the Agency to combat terrorism and prevent radicalization. Responding to the threat posed by foreign fighters and terrorism in general requires a multidimensional approach that globally addresses the factors underlying radicalization, as well as terrorist acts of any kind. The EU must work urgently to adequately assess the security threat and focus on areas of immediate priority for counter-terrorism. From the EU we must act more forcefully and urgently in the fight against terrorism. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Security Agenda because I believe that the implementation of EU security policy represents a shared responsibility among all the political and social actors of the European Union.  In the current geopolitical context, the threats to the security of the European Union are rapidly evolving and, above all, are no longer detectable according to traditional criteria but are becoming less and less conventional and unexpected.  I therefore welcome the European Commission's proposal for a European security agenda for 2015-2020, which will undoubtedly be an effective and efficient tool for combating new international challenges, such as terrorism, cross-border organised crime and information technology. I particularly appreciated the general set-up of the agenda, which places respect for human rights and the rule of law at the forefront and the need to strike the right balance between measures to combat international threats and respect for freedom and the principles of justice.  I agree with the call for the Commission to put on the agenda stronger measures to combat radicalisation, violent extremism and ideologies that are dangerous to the security of European citizens, and I call for initiatives aimed at integration and social inclusion.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Agenda on Security today because I believe that we need to improve Cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime in order to better protect our citizens.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the European Agenda on Security. We understand that the way in which the Agenda is built, a militaristic conception of the term security that does not correspond to the European Union project as a union for peace and sociality as articulating elements of the project is translating. We also understand that there is no prior work in defining the term security, or national security, prior work necessary to establish a solvent agenda. Similarly, the mention of human rights as a fundamental element of a European Security Agenda cannot take a secondary place in it, which makes it necessary to review the subordination of one term to another and the contingent to what is necessary, that is, the law in the social sense of the term.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing.
