Last April, the Commission adopted its European Security Programme, a key strategic document aimed at setting out the broad guidelines for the European Union's internal and external security policy. The European Parliament's resolution is our contribution to this programme. It clearly has what our Parliament's priorities are. In light of the challenges and serious threats - terrorism, violent extremism, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime - that the European Union is currently facing, the European Union must act in a coordinated manner and strengthen its efforts. In particular, our resolution calls for greater transparency, accountability and democratic control in security policies, optimising the use and implementation of the eu's legal instruments, a more unified cross-sector and interagency approach and a better reconciliation of the internal and external dimensions of security.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. While the Commission presented its safety roadmap last April, it was essential that Parliament contributed to this. I have therefore supported Parliament's resolution on the European security programme, as it is, in my view, a balanced response between security imperatives and fundamental rights requirements on the other.  Complex and scalable, the current threats to the Union's internal security require more than ever a comprehensive, coherent and coordinated response at European level, but also internationally. The unprecedented nature of the current crisis requires, among other things, an upgrade of European security and judicial arrangements, tools adapted to media and digital jihad that allows terrorists to reach every point of European and international territory, as well as an offensive against the financial flows that fuel the terrorist fight.  However, we cannot be content with the repressive at all as it is true that the causes of this phenomenon are complex and inseparably social, economic or even psychological. Any solution requires measures to prevent radicalization before it leads to violence.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Agenda on Security. I believe that the risks to the Union's internal security have become more complex, hybrid, asymmetric, non-traditional, transmissible, rapidly variable and difficult to predict and exceed the capabilities of any individual Member State, and therefore more than ever a coherent, comprehensive, multi-faceted and coordinated EU response is needed, taking full account of respect for fundamental rights. The development of an EU security policy is a matter of shared responsibility and common objectives and priorities need to be set. Their implementation should be linked to a clear allocation of tasks at EU and national level, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and through strict and effective parliamentary and judicial scrutiny. Only by working together and unitedly can we ensure the security of the Union in the future, and this report is exactly what it is about.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the European Agenda on Security. We understand that the way in which the Agenda is built, a militaristic conception of the term security that does not correspond to the European Union project as a union for peace and sociality as articulating elements of the project is translating. We also understand that there is no prior work in defining the term security, or national security, prior work necessary to establish a solvent agenda. Similarly, the mention of human rights as a fundamental element of a European Security Agenda cannot take a secondary place in it, which makes it necessary to review the subordination of one term to another and the contingent to what is necessary, that is, the law in the social sense of the term.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for a Resolution on the European Agenda on Security, as this Programme establishes priorities and main principles in the field of security, as well as Union measures aimed at improving information sharing, strengthening operational cooperation and providing support measures to Member States. Today, cooperation in this field is more important than ever. The EU faces a number of security problems crossing the borders of states and the EU. The example of security shows how much "more Europe" we need: more cooperation, more integration and coordination between national police and other national and EU bodies. Because crime and terrorism know no bounds. In particular, today the problem of cybercrime and all other forms of crime associated with advanced technologies has been highlighted. Europe must be safe for its citizens. The European security policy must be flexible, coherent, complementary and continuous.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this text on the European security programme. The programme aims to strengthen security in Europe. Indeed, even the Commission has realised the problems caused by Islamists and jihadists returning from the war zones of the Middle East. I have long been concerned about the european Union's inaction or, at least ineffective action, on these issues, as evidenced by its inability to stop the flow of illegal immigrants into Europe, or even to prevent Islamic State fighters from returning to our lands.  Radicalism, the financing of terrorism, cooperation between the police are certainly at the heart of this programme, but none of the measures or solutions put forward can convince me, whether they are staggered or unambitious.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the COM proposal for a European Agenda on Security. The text includes strong and balanced recommendations towards strengthening the European response to terrorism and the threats posed by foreign fighters and cyber-crime. The EU can bring added value in this area by helping Member States to adopt a coordinated approach. One of the aims of this agenda is to make sure all actors involved in the fight against terrorism effectively cooperate and improve information exchanges when necessary. In this respect, the mandatory registration of persons suspected of terrorism in the Schengen Information System is a good approach.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution calling for a European security programme. This resolution did not fulfil its primary purpose, namely the defence of European citizens. Its initial bias being that security is a danger to fundamental rights, this text was biased at the source and therefore could not be voted on as it stands. This resolution was adopted, which I regret.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the Socialist resolution on the European security programme, because the gullible and thoughtless approach of the Socialists and Liberals on the subject of security is very disappointing given the high level of threat that the Union unfortunately faces today. If we want to be able to fight crime effectively, we must first join forces and cooperate with the police, not beware of it as the Socialists suggest.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although there are some good proposals and demands on which the EU should really take action, I cannot agree with the report. Increased control in the interests of sovereignty, control of national intelligence by the EU, a trivialisation of the causes of terrorism, these are all points on the grounds on which I reject the text.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PP group and the Fidesz delegation welcome the Commission's strategy in this important area, but we believe that the European Parliament's response and recommendations to this are insufficient and appropriate to provide sufficient support to the EU and its Member States in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. The EU needs guiding principles, measures, resources, expertise and action. We need to talk seriously and concretely about how to protect our children from violence, how to stop the radicalisation of young people, how to improve the exchange of information in the field of law enforcement, how to prevent people smuggling and to ensure adequate funding for law enforcement agencies. Unfortunately, Parliament's resolution is not balanced enough. In the field of law enforcement, the protection of fundamental rights and data protection are of paramount importance. However, it is not enough to focus only on them in order to create an adequate, clean and coherent security strategy and protect our citizens. For all these reasons, I could not support this resolution in its present form, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the European security programme. This text is completely detached from this world. First, it aims to further undermine the sovereignty of Member States in terms of freedom, security and justice. In addition, it advocates unacceptable laxity in the fight against terrorism and illegal immigration. In paragraph 40 in particular, the text "rejects any link" between these two phenomena, when this link is obvious and the terrorists of the Islamic State themselves have themselves repeatedly announced that some of their members are infiltrating Europe through migrant boats in the Mediterranean. Paragraph 26 opposes the use of surveillance drones, particularly in North Africa, as an instrument in the fight against immigration and organized crime networks involved in human trafficking. Why rule that out? We're not told. It is clear that the left will oppose any effective measure in the fight against illegal immigration.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution on the European Security Agenda as it delves into the cuts in rights and freedoms being carried out by both the authorities of the Member States and the European authorities. The solution to security problems cannot go through the mass espionage of citizens or by targeting entire groups of the population. At a time when espionage scandals and illegal files of social activists have been made public, this Resolution aims to give a varnish of legality to these policies and to the discrimination of population groups on the excuse of fighting radicalization.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the European Agenda on Security. The effective implementation of this comprehensive agenda requires adequate financial resources. That is why we need clear declarations from the Council to support the actions being carried out at different levels within this agenda. In this context, I stress the role of education and integration programmes as tools to combat the causes of radicalisation. We also need new programmes that will contribute to raising awareness of radicalisation and help to extend cooperation in this area to all stakeholders. New innovative tools are also important to combat terrorist online propaganda and to develop critical thinking skills among young people.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted against it because I do not agree that the EU should centrally intervene in the competence of the Member States to determine their internal and external security policy. Moreover, the whole resolution is confusing as it seeks to bring security and social affairs together.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Threats to the internal and external security of the European Union have become more complex and increasingly difficult to monitor, so further efforts are needed to build security. Tools should be developed to monitor threats at EU level and develop a coherent security agenda.  Terrorism, radicalism of all kinds and cybercrime are key challenges increasingly encountered by the European Union on a daily basis, and for a decisive, valid and timely response, cooperation between all Member States is important, so I supported the European Parliament's Resolution on the Security Agenda.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 On the motion for a resolution on the European Agenda on Security, I stand by the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welomce this Report which "Stresses the gravity of organised crime, in particular in terms of human trafficking, including forced prostitution, organ trafficking, child sexual exploitation and work slavery; recalls the extreme degrees of violence and brutality criminals exert on particularly vulnerable groups such as women, children and migrants; welcomes the existing framework and agrees to the need for a post-2016 strategy that fully involves Europol and Eurojust, on account of their expertise in this field".

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution requires careful reflection and a few comments. The first concerns the overuse of the term 'radicalism' in the text presented, in a pejorative sense. It is not possible to gamble in this way with concepts that have a wide scope. For example, I would welcome the radicalisation of the fight against corruption in the European Union. More radicality would also be necessary to prevent companies from escaping into tax havens. Moreover, I fear that the radicalisation of social and political movements fighting poverty as a result of austerity measures or production cuts, for example as a result of outsourcing it, may not be preventable without the suppression of human rights. The second point concerns terrorism and crime. I will forget that the proposal completely eliminates the causes of the growing wave of terrorism and the danger of war, and I will recall the neglected motive associated with this issue. And that is the sale of small and light weapons. It is still subject to a lack of international regulation. Meanwhile, small and light weapons account for 60 to 90% of the victims of all conflicts. Weapons of terrorists and organised criminals are precisely weapons of this type. According to the Geneva-based Small Arms Survey, a number of EU countries are among the largest exporters of these weapons. This includes exports to markets and battlefields where any control over them is lost. Therefore, I could not support the text.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot hide the fact that threats to the Union's internal security have become more complex, composite, asymmetric, international, rapidly evolving, and difficult to predict. Just as we cannot fail to recognise the need on the part of the European Union to intervene in the field of security in a forward-looking manner. However, I believe that the content of this resolution loses its original purpose on several occasions, and ends up going into rhetorical and naïve considerations. That is why I have chosen to abstain from voting on it.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I was not able to give my assent to this request under any circumstances, because it is not sufficiently detailed and, on the other hand, it contains many introductions that would make the European Union a totalitarian monitoring apparatus.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution on the internal security programme reminds the European Commission of fundamental rights. It stresses the economic and social causes of organised crime and terrorism, including "austerity measures". It stresses the need for democratic and parliamentary control of the intelligence services or the "illegal transport and detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries".  However, it is not sufficiently critical of the internal security policy pursued so far, despite the strengthening of the European arsenal of means in the fight against terrorism and, to a lesser extent, organised crime. It did not reduce them. This is what Snowden explained to the European Parliament. In the end, the text calls for strengthening the powers of the Commission and Europol to better systematise the registration of citizens, in particular by a PNR on air passengers. The right jumps at the chance to call for "strengthening security at the Union's borders" and "improving the capacity to report content on the internet".  I vote against "harmonization" on the basis of all-security at the expense of the law and against strengthening the powers of institutions without democratic control.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission will adopt a European Security Agenda for 2015-2020 in the coming months, which will touch on the various actions to be implemented to increase security in Europe. Radicalism, the financing of terrorism, cooperation between Europol and other European agencies, and arms trafficking will be the main topics of this agenda. The topics covered in this agenda seem to be moving in the right direction, although there are very strong doubts about the issue of radicalism. Indeed, while many young Europeans and French join terrorist organizations to commit crimes, the European Commission's attempts to put an end to this phenomenon have all failed. It is also clear that the Union is not pursuing an effective line to combat this scourge. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the resolution on the European agenda for security. Organised crime in all its forms (such as facilitating illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings), but fundamentally terrorism, radicalisation, recruitment and associated funding, are a serious threat to the internal security of the European Union.  Serious crime and terrorism diminish the sense of security, without which people cannot effectively enjoy their freedom or exercise their individual rights.  The availability and exchange of information should be strengthened as a means of preventing and combating cross-border crime and terrorism, enhanced operational cooperation and coordination with regard to research, greater cooperation between third states and the development of strategic partnerships to combat this phenomenon.  Recognising the fundamental importance of the involvement of the European Parliament and national parliaments in this area, it stresses the need to allocate important mechanisms to Member States, such as a strong and structured EU PNR Directive, essential for carrying out their tasks and combating current threats such as terrorism.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support the resolution on the European Agenda on Security. The final text did not sufficiently safeguard citizens’ rights to safety and security.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Parliament Resolution on the European Security Strategy because I consider that in order to respond to the new pressing challenges and threats to the Union’s internal security, such as terrorism, radicalisation, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime, Europe needs to go beyond the capacity of any individual Member State and needs to coordinate EU security policy between all Member States, EU institutions and agencies, civil society and law enforcement authorities. Having said that, however, we should always have a clear division of tasks between the EU level and the national level, on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote is aimed at adopting a resolution on the European security programme. However, this resolution takes a naïve approach to European socialists and Greens who want to perpetuate the fundamental rights of criminals. It aims to limit the possibilities for the police to prosecute criminals and terrorists. It's an unbearable position.  In the face of this, of course, the legal possibilities for prosecuting criminals must be strengthened instead of prohibiting the authorities and the police from investigating. This text further practices the culture of excuses by explaining terrorism and crime only through the prism of inequality and poverty.  So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the European security programme because it is not up to the challenge. In particular, I objected to the provisions to reject or weaken the Passenger Name Record (PNR) directive on air passengers. Today, terrorists and jihadists benefit from the lack of PNR data sharing, favouring the least direct air routes possible to and from training and combat zones. The implementation of a European NRL in the shortest possible time is therefore vital.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this for resolution to support the Commission’s proposal of the European Agenda on Security for the 2015-2020 period.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Bhí gnéithe dearfacha sa tuarascáil seo, go háirithe béim láidir ar an ngá atá ann do pháirtithe stáit meas a thaispeáint ar chearta bunúsacha agus maoirseacht cheart dhaonlathach a chur i bhfeidhm. É sin ráite, sa tuarascáil seo táthar ag lorg tuilleadh de chomhoibriú sa tslándáil sheachtrach agus tugtar tacaíocht do bhunú rialachas AE maidir le hidirghabhálachas.  Ní féidir linne tacaíocht a thabhairt do rudaí mar sin, agus mar sin staonamar ón vótáil seo.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and I can only say I hope this new Agenda will be used properly by the Member States. It is a very fine line the EU and its members need to walk. A fine balance between adequate security and control measures and between not endangering private freedoms, human rights and trust between states and citizens. The data protection component is important, but also the tools needed to fight various threats, from organised crime, including cyber crimes, as well as all the other conventional risks.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Agenda on Security does not provide sufficient approaches to responding to current security threats, not to mention whether the EU should have the power to overlay national security strategies through its activities. Austria's neutrality, in particular, is at stake here. I have therefore spoken out against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The new Security Action Plan will map out key security priorities and provide for strengthening them by exchange of information and increase cooperation. Europe is facing increasingly diverse and rapidly changing threats, to which more cooperation and exchange of information between Member States are needed in response. It is important to address various aspects of the fight against terrorism, such as foreign fighters, the strengthening of the EU's external border controls, trafficking in human beings and cyberterrorism.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential to increase security standards within EU countries, reiterating its call on the Commission to rapidly present a legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 December 2006 on the establishment, operation and use of the Second Generation Schengen Information System (SIS II)(7), in order to harmonise reporting criteria and make it compulsory to report persons convicted or suspected of terrorism.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Rising inequality, poverty, racial and religious violence and hate crimes are some of the root causes of crime faced by Eu Member States, so these causes need to be further investigated. The Commission therefore adopted a document on 24 April 2015 entitled Communication on the European Agenda on Security for the period 2015-2020 replacing the Internal Security Strategy (2010-2014).  The new programme establishes priorities and main principles in the field of security, as well as Union measures aimed at improving information sharing, strengthening operational cooperation and providing support measures to Member States. I believe that this type of document is of utmost importance for the Union itself, as freedom and security are fundamental rights of every EU resident. This needs to create a coherent, comprehensive and coherent EU agreement that respects and ensures the fundamental rights of every man.  However, I remained reticent when voting on the Resolution, as it does not contain adequate answers and recommendations on key issues related to the fight against crime and the achievement of security in the fields of financing, cyber and organised crime and the fight against terrorism that are endangering the lives of its inhabitants across the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote aims to adopt a resolution on the European security programme. However, this resolution takes a naïve approach to European socialists and greens who want to perpetuate the fundamental rights of criminals. It aims to limit the possibilities for the police to prosecute criminals and terrorists. It's an unbearable position.  In the face of this, of course, the legal possibilities for prosecuting criminals must be strengthened instead of prohibiting the authorities and the police from investigating. This text further practices the culture of excuses by explaining terrorism and crime only through the prism of inequality and poverty.  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Threats to the Union's internal security have become more complex, hybrid, asymmetrical and unconventional and are present internationally, evolving rapidly and difficult to predict. As they go beyond the capabilities of each Member State, they are more likely than ever to demand a coherent, comprehensive, multi-dimensional and coherent EU response that fully takes into account respect for fundamental rights.  We need to strike a balance between preventive policies and repressive measures to preserve freedom, security and justice. Security measures must always be taken in accordance with the principle of the rule of law and the protection of fundamental rights such as the right to privacy and data protection, freedom of expression and association, and due process.  The European Union has not agreed on a definition of 'national security', which opens up undue scope for exceptions in EU legal instruments mentioning 'national security', so I join calls on the Commission to swiftly propose a definition of the national security exception referred to in Article 4(2) of the DG And its restriction to ensure that security measures respect democratic principles and fundamental rights.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a Resolution on the European Agenda on Security, as ensuring the security and freedom of European citizens is a shared responsibility of the Union and the Member States and a problem that requires full attention.  A number of threats have emerged in the EU's immediate neighbourhood in recent years, so I agree that the EU urgently needs to assess security threats and focus on the four main priority areas outlined in the Resolution - terrorism, radicalisation, cyber and organised crime. This should rely on the issue of security at the EU's borders due to threats of terrorism and radicalism and on the issue of cybercrime, as new technological developments often increase the impact of crime on citizens. More information sharing and operational cooperation between national intelligence and law enforcement services should also be made, with particular reference to organised crime posing a major danger and the most serious threat to the security of EU citizens.  In line with all of the above, I believe that this Resolution is the best way to ensure that citizens have their freedoms and security protected in accordance with fundamental human rights.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are at a time when threats to the Internal Security of the Union are becoming more complex and unpredictable, and this has the effect of losing the capacity of any state to fully cover them. This is particularly the issue of terrorism, violent extremism, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime. This therefore requires more coordination than ever at European level with respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. I consider the programme proposed by the Commission for the period 2015-2020 to be a quality and comprehensive document, with an emphasis on its expected flexibility and capacity to respond to future challenges. I believe that, at European level, we must first of all address the root causes of crime, such as inequality, poverty and discrimination, which are likely to always be present, but it is up to us to what extent. I am unequivocal in my view that more investment is needed in preventive policies, although punitive measures are also necessary. The European Union is not disconnected from the rest of the world, so there is a need for more intensive cooperation with third countries, logically and at economic and social level. In view of a number of past cases, I would like to make further referred to one of the priorities of the Position of the European Parliament, which is to improve democratic and judicial oversight of third-country intelligence services. The boundaries between security requirements and the protection of personal data exist and must be respected.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the European Security Agenda, although, as I have said here several times during this meeting, I consider security in Europe to be a priority today. Unfortunately, the left has pushed through some provisions in the report that undermine Europe's security, which is why I could not vote in favour of the report on principle.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Ensuring the internal and external security of the Union is one of the main priorities of the European institutions and the Member States. In this context, MEPs adopted a resolution on the European security programme.  However, I preferred to abstain on this report because the idea of security that is taking place does not fully correspond to the expectations of my political group in terms of security. This text focuses mainly on respect for fundamental rights at the expense of strengthening and enforcing security measures.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. This resolution, which takes a balanced and comprehensive approach to safety, is a victory for the group. The text calls for the establishment of a genuine European area of internal security, which ensures respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. In this sense, it is essential to carry out a regular evaluation of the implementation of the European security programme, through greater transparency and democratic control. Through this resolution, MEPs stress the added value of the European Union in supporting Member States in the face of complex and evolving threats, which require a coordinated response. They strongly reject any link between immigration, Islam and terrorism. They also point to the importance of addressing the root causes of crime and radicalisation (including inequality and discrimination), from the perspective of social, cultural, employment and education policies, not just security. While this text has made many progress, I regret the vote on two EPP amendments which welcome the priority given to border control and which advocate an approach based solely on urgency and repression in the fight against terrorism.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European security agenda in order to pay greater attention to developments in cross-border organised crime with regard to arms trafficking, trafficking in human beings and the production and sale of illicit drugs. Furthermore, the resolution calls on the Member States to ensure that the principle of the best interests of the child is respected in all safety legislation. I also support the launch of an awareness-raising and preparedness campaign for serious cybercrime-related risks, improving resistance to cyber-attacks.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament wanted to send a strong signal by adopting this lunchtime the new European security programme for 2015-2020, proposed by the Commission last April. This programme addresses the major security challenges facing the European Union.  Terrorism, radicalisation, organised crime and cybercrime are a growing threat to European citizens. The latest attacks in France, Denmark but also beyond our borders in Tunisia and Kuwait remind us of this. These attacks on the population, but also against our democratic values, have been coordinated on a scale beyond national borders and must therefore encourage us to cooperate better.  While it is above all up to any State to guarantee the safety of its citizens, the cross-border nature of this crime thwarts isolated efforts and clearly makes it necessary for intervention at EU level to strengthen trust and facilitate cooperation, information exchange and joint action. Parliament will not compromise on fundamental rights.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Security Agenda aims to set key priorities and actions for the period 2015-2020 on EU internal security, replacing the current EU Internal Security Strategy 2010-2015.  The three main priorities set are the fight against terrorism and radicalization, the fight against organized crime and the fight against cybercrime. This Agenda lays the groundwork for the cooperation and joint actions to be undertaken by European institutions and agencies, Member States and partners in civil and international society. For all this, and in view of the significance of these challenges, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The text of this resolution condemns the measures of mass surveillance and registration of innocent individuals and underlines the need for democratic control of security measures, at national and European level. The text also regrets that there is no Community definition of national security, a loophole that allows for a lack of clarity in the legislative instruments proposed or used. The resolution also calls for a legislative initiative to amend the second-generation Schengen information system to create an alert for terrorism suspects. MEPs also recognised the need to move forward on the European NRL directive, the passenger personal data file, which must be finalised before the end of 2015. Finally, the text condemns any amalgamation between terrorism, immigration and Islam, as well as serious violations of fundamental rights, illustrated in particular by the CIA's secret prisons in Europe.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I have chosen to abstain from voting on the report on the European Security Agenda, because the text presented reflects the too naïve and superficial approach taken by socialists, greens and liberals. The GROUP of the European People's Party cannot support a proposal which severely restricts the intervention of the police and armed forces against criminals and terrorists, as the left of this House wants. At a time like this, when the security of European citizens is under threat on a daily basis, we are increasingly in need of intelligence, police and legal instruments that can guarantee national security. Denying the correlation between waves of migration and the threat of security means deliberately and naively denying a problem that is before everyone's eyes. That is why measures must be taken to improve the exchange of information, strengthen cooperation and provide support actions to Member States. In order to do this, it is first necessary to consult the agencies that actually work in this field, asking above all what their needs might also be in terms of the staff and additional costs they have had to suffer, due to the growing needs. There is still a lot of work to be done on safety.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the European Agenda on Security. We understand that the way in which the Agenda is built, a militaristic conception of the term security that does not correspond to the European Union project as a union for peace and sociality as articulating elements of the project is translating. We also understand that there is no prior work in defining the term security, or national security, prior work necessary to establish a solvent agenda. Similarly, the mention of human rights as a fundamental element of a European Security Agenda cannot take a secondary place in it, which makes it necessary to review the subordination of one term to another and the contingent to what is necessary, that is, the law in the social sense of the term.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution on the European Security Agenda as it delves into the cuts in rights and freedoms being carried out by both the authorities of the Member States and the European authorities. The solution to security problems cannot go through the mass espionage of citizens or by targeting entire groups of the population. At a time when espionage scandals and illegal files of social activists have been made public, this Resolution aims to give a varnish of legality to these policies and to the discrimination of population groups on the excuse of fighting radicalization.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this case, I joined the EKR position and voted against. The 2015-2019 European Agenda on Security sets out certain challenges, principles and guidelines for advancing security threats related to organised crime, terrorism, extremism and trafficking in human beings. The EC adopted this agenda in April 2015. However, the European Parliament resolution failed to reflect the EC's priorities, which the EKR supported. Instead, the LIBE resolution focuses on human rights, data protection and economic imbalances as the root causes of crime. In addition, the EP resolution calls for the definition of European national security and other legal forms of migration.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The boundaries between internal and external security are becoming increasingly blurred, which requires closer cooperation and coordination between Member States in order to develop a comprehensive and multidimension-based security approach. I therefore welcome the European Agenda on Security 2015-2020 presented by the Commission, as well as the priorities set out therein, taking into account the challenges currently facing the EU – such as terrorism, radicalisation, cross-border organised crime, cybercrime, etc. These most serious threats require coordinated action at national, European and global level. It will not be possible to eliminate threats without examining the root causes of crime, including increasing social inequalities, poverty, discrimination and possible perceptions of unfair practices in the foreign policies of the EU and its Member States. In order for the Union to be a credible entity, I join the call for the right balance to be struck between preventive policies and punitive measures, in order to preserve freedom, security and justice, so that all measures are always implemented in accordance with the rule of law and the protection of fundamental human rights.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the European Agenda on Security. We have seen many crises and conflicts recently, including in our vicinity. We all want security and peace. Ensuring security and peace is a common task for all Member States, and the European Union must respond quickly and effectively to all crises and conflicts. We must also pay particular attention to the cybercrime facilitated by the evolving web and computers. I therefore join the call in the resolution for the Commission to provide law enforcement authorities with the legal capacity and technical capacity to effectively combat this type of crime, with full respect for fundamental rights.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. – I did not support today's motion for a resolution on the European Agenda on Security, because its final text is more dangerous than safe. The issue of security needs to be treated with the utmost seriousness these days, and it cannot be populistally abused either by restricting personal freedoms in the name of security, but also by treating the security authorities a priori suspiciously in the name of fundamental human rights, as the resulting text does. Supervision and control over the exercise of all national powers is one of the main components of a democratic state, and the currently advanced technical means are certainly a challenge to ensure proper supervision, in particular of the activities of the security forces. I believe that the solution is only parliamentary oversight, because the chain of different inspection bodies has to end somewhere, and parliament is the right place.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 On the pretext of security, intervention will be made in the internal affairs of the Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal for a resolution because it contains concrete action plans in an area where coordinated action by the European Union has been falling short of the requirements of new types of security challenges for some time. The Decision identifies areas such as terrorism, radical movements, cross-border organised crime and cybercrime and their financing, where prevention and response at national level has proved ineffective in the face of new criminal methods and phenomena and requires closer European cooperation. I also think it is right that the decision draws attention to the close link between the external and internal security of the European Union, calling for greater coordination and consistency between the two areas in order to act more effectively. While acknowledging the importance of all these factors, as a Member with a high commitment to democratic values, my decision in support of this resolution was also strongly emphasised by the fact that the proposal specifically warns of the importance of pseudo-transparency and the enforcement of human rights, social and data protection aspects in the implementation of security measures.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent times, threats to European security have diversified and multiplied, with new forms such as hybrid warfare, asymmetric conflicts and unconventional weapons. Terrorist threats, cybercrime, social tensions and racial violence have also increased. These negative phenomena require a coordinated response from the European Union, ensuring the security of all Member States, by adopting common standards in this area.  The European Commission has identified three key responses to the challenges for 2015-2020: preventing terrorism and countering radicalisation, combating organised crime and combating cybercrime.  The European Parliament must, in turn, provide solutions to these problems as a representative forum for European citizens. This can identify more nuanced remedies to security threats, such as decision-making transparency, democratic control, information exchange and database use, removing confusion between Islam, terrorism and immigrants, promoting religious tolerance, supporting the security industry.  In this respect, I support the adoption of the resolution on the European Agenda on Security, which is a necessary document both for the debate in this area and for ensuring the real security of the Member States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution. It is important to remember the crucial importance of locating and ending financial flows in the fight against terrorist networks and organised crime groups, including financial flows outside the SWIFT network. I am pleased with the efforts made to ensure fair and balanced participation in the U.S.-led terrorist financing surveillance program and reaffirm my commitment to this program. War must be waged at the financial level to deplete terrorist resources.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution for a European Agenda on Security. The text includes strong and balanced recommendations towards strengthening the European response to terrorism and the threats posed by foreign fighters and cyber-crime. The EU can clearly make a difference in the fight against terrorism. Cooperation between Member States is a key tool in this respect.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The 2015-2019 European Agenda on Security sets out challenges, principles and guidelines in addressing security threats related to terrorism, extremism, organised criminal, and smuggling. The Commission adopted this programme in April and Parliament failed to adopt the priorities of the commission's original proposal in the LIBE Committee. Instead, the amendments incorporated into the final resolution at the Committee focused on human rights, data protection, and economic inequalities as the roots and crucial causes of criminality. Also, the amendments went in the typical direction of calling for greater union in the security policy segment, directly violating the principle of subsidiarity through insisting on the EU's definition of national security and calling for more forms of legal migration. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU and its Member States face major security challenges. Terrorism and organised and cybercrime are increasingly a threat to society throughout Europe, and the nature and extent of these threats have also changed. There is a spillover of political instability in Europe's immediate neighbourhood, which threatens the EU's security interests. The new European Security Agenda fulfils the commitment made in the political directions of European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and replaces the previous strategy adopted in 2010. With the new European Security Agenda, the Commission is establishing a Strategy for responding to security threats in the EU for the period 2015-2020. The Agenda aims to create additional value to support eu information sharing between law enforcement authorities and EU agencies and to better operational police cooperation. As the proposals of the EPP were not adopted, I abstained from the vote.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the European Agenda on Security. We understand that the way in which the Agenda is built, a militaristic conception of the term security that does not correspond to the European Union project as a union for peace and sociality as articulating elements of the project is translating. We also understand that there is no prior work in defining the term security, or national security, prior work necessary to establish a solvent agenda. Similarly, the mention of human rights as a fundamental element of a European Security Agenda cannot take a secondary place in it, which makes it necessary to review the subordination of one term to another and the contingent to what is necessary, that is, the law in the social sense of the term.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the European Agenda on Security. We understand that the way in which the Agenda is built, a militaristic conception of the term security that does not correspond to the European Union project as a union for peace and sociality as articulating elements of the project is translating. We also understand that there is no prior work in defining the term security, or national security, prior work necessary to establish a solvent agenda. Similarly, the mention of human rights as a fundamental element of a European Security Agenda cannot take a secondary place in it, which makes it necessary to review the subordination of one term to another and the contingent to what is necessary, that is, the law in the social sense of the term.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which endorses the Commission proposal for a new European Agenda on Security, which aims to support better organisational cooperation between Member States in the fields of the fight against terrorism, cybersecurity and organised crime in the timeframe 2015-2020. The above-mentioned threats are particularly worrying for European citizens and their transnational nature requires EU-level intervention. An important but maybe overlooked aspect of this resolution is its strong call for very binding human rights clauses in cooperation agreements with third countries, especially in North Africa and the Gulf region, with regard to security cooperation. I find this an absolute priority and one of the leading principles in all types of cooperation arrangements between the EU and other countries.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is stated that threats to the Internal Security of the Union have become more complex, hybrid, asymmetric, non-conventional, international, rapidly evolving and difficult to predict, exceeding the capacity of any individual Member State, and therefore require, more than ever, a coherent, comprehensive, multidimensional and coordinated EU response that takes full account of respect for fundamental rights. It is assumed from this premise that the development of EU security policy is a matter of shared responsibility that requires coordinated and harmonised efforts by all Member States, EU institutions and agencies, civil society and law enforcement authorities, targeted at common objectives and based on the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. This is the usual step ive that aims to feed increasingly bellicose and repressive policies. Instead of understanding that conflicts and fundamentalism are a response to imperialism, it focuses on strengthening muscular solutions and at the same time taking measures that limit the individual freedom of citizens and reduce their right to privacy.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I was not able to give my assent to this request under any circumstances, because it is not sufficiently detailed and, on the other hand, it contains many introductions that would make the European Union a totalitarian monitoring apparatus.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I and my group have refused to support the motion for a resolution on the European Agenda on Security. The European Security Agenda for 2015-2019 aims to identify the challenges, principles and guidelines for dealing with security risks related to organised crime, terrorism, extremism and trafficking in human beings. However, the resolution does not manage to confine itself to the Commission's priorities. Instead, the LIBE Resolution also raises the issue of 'economic inequality' as the cause of crime. The resolution also calls for an EU definition of national security and more opportunities for legal migration. In doing so, it exceeds the powers of the European Parliament.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Security is a fundamental right in accordance with the provisions of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and at present this fundamental right is seriously threatened.  Today, the resolution on the European Agenda on Security was adopted in the EP plenary. I voted against this resolution because the amendments tabled and voted on by some political groups distort the vision of the initiators and can provide services to an effective common EU security policy.  The voted report presents the EP's vision of risk and threat management to our security, from those related to the terrorist threat to cybercrime, but unfortunately with certain uncertainties and elements likely to create confusion.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution of Claude Moraes's responsibility begins by congratulating "the European Agenda for Security for the period 2015-2020 proposed by the Commission" and the priorities set out therein. We consider that, under the pretext of combating 'terrorism', 'radicalisation' and "cybercrime", restrictive measures of the so-called fundamental freedoms - supposedly defended here - are advocated, paving the way for actions to control and repress citizens and to limit freedom of democratic participation. This report deliberately omits the reasons behind the current European and international situation, such as the implementation of neoliberal policies to attack workers' rights, the imposition of "austerity" measures in the countries of the European Union, interference and participation in conflicts, in partnership with NATO in third countries, and how repressively migrants are being treated.  We voted against it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The conflict in Yemen is causing terrible suffering to the Yemeni population (more than 20 million people urgently need humanitarian aid), but it also exemplifies the chaos of the area, chaos that came with the war by delegation and unilateral interventions. A coalition led by Saudi Arabia, the EU's much-friend theocratic dictatorship, is bombing with prohibited weapons and has imposed a naval blockade affecting civilians. Since the conviction that this situation cannot be left through the military, we have demanded an inclusive political solution, the lifting of the naval blockade, the ceasefire, the cessation of bombing, the cessation of arms supply and the investigation of the United Kingdom, France, Germany and Spain to find out whether they have breached the European Union Code of Conduct on arms exports. Since the resolution adopted stresses the need for a political solution to the conflict and condemns the airstrikes of the Saudi-led coalition and the naval blockade imposed on Yemen, pointing to the coalition as causing thousands of deaths and further destabilization of the country, I have given my vote in favour of the text.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The situation in Yemen is alarming. Given the geostrategic situation of this country, the situation could also have serious consequences for the security of the EU and the stability of the entire Middle East. The EU, as a champion of democracy and human rights, has a moral obligation in this crisis. Thousands of people are on the run. We are on the brink of a catastrophic humanitarian crisis. I therefore support the position of this motion for a resolution and hope that a political solution should be resolved soon, which should be done in cooperation with the UN.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the situation in Yemen contains very positive elements, including condemnation of interference in that country. Saudi Arabia has decided to intervene in defiance of Yemeni sovereignty by increasing its bombardment of its neighbour's territory. It also calls for an internal solution to the conflict, avoiding harmful foreign influences as much as possible. However, this report commits a serious fault by getting involved in French internal affairs by condemning the negotiations on arms sales between France and other regional powers.  This report is also sometimes too Manichaean. It is not for the Union to choose a side between Sunnis and Shiites, between Iran and Saudi Arabia. This text contains anti-militarist elements that are irrelevant, as international politics is a mess with angelism or ideology.  So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Yemen is a particularly concerning one, and I particularly note the terrible conditions in Aden and the surrounding areas. I support the right of the people of South Yemen to self-determination. This report has much to commend it, and addresses some of the issues in Yemen, but not all. Furthermore, it pushes European foreign policy which should be the preserve of the Member States.  I therefore decided on balance to abstain.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The current crisis in Yemen is the result of the failure of successive governments to justify the legitimate expectations of the Yemeni people in terms of democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. The current conflict in Yemen has spread to 20 of the country's 22 territorial units; whereas, according to the latest consolidated figures from the World Health Organisation (WHO), at least 1 439 people were killed and a further 5 951 injured between 19 March and 5 May 2015, many of whom were civilians; whereas more than 3 000 people have died and more than 10 000 have been injured since the conflict began. The EU reaffirmed its commitment to continue to support Yemen and the Yemeni people. The European Parliament strongly supports Yemen's unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity and supports the Yemeni people and expresses its full support for the efforts of the UN and UN Special Envoy for Yemen, Ismail Ould Cheikho Ahmed, to mediate peace talks between the parties. The solution to the conflict can only be political, inclusive and negotiated, and the European Parliament therefore calls on all parties to the Yemen conflict to seek a solution of disagreements through dialogue, with a view to achieving compromise and power-sharing, and enabling the formation of a government of national unity in order to restore peace, avoid economic and financial collapse and address the humanitarian crisis.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The situation in Yemen is eminently complex and if this resolution calls for an internal solution, the EU once again intends to avail itself of a right of interference which it is already abusing too much: I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution, which I have approved, urges all parties to put an immediate end to the use of violence and stresses that the European Union has reaffirmed its willingness to continue to support Yemen and its people. Parliament reiterates its full support for Yemen's unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity and expresses its solidarity with its people. It stresses that there can only be a political, inclusive and negotiated solution to the conflict, and therefore urges all Yemeni parties to seek to resolve their differences through dialogue, compromise and power-sharing, resulting in the formation of a government of national unity in order to restore peace, avoid economic and financial collapse, and address the humanitarian crisis.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. A hundred days after the start of the Saudi offensive against Yemen and the massacre of hundreds of innocent civilians, the European Parliament finally decided to speak out on these attacks and to demand their immediate end through a motion for a resolution.  Nevertheless, even if the resolution proposes an internal solution to the conflict and calls for humanitarian assistance, this is still impossible as it stands given the blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia. Moreover, as usual, it does not hesitate to interfere in the national affairs of countries when we should not take a position in a conflict of this kind between Sunnis and Shiites, nor condemn or support the actions of the saudi-led coalition or the Houthi revolution. I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. The resolution analysing the situation in Yemen is to be welcomed and I supported it with my vote. I believe that the current conflict can only be resolved by a political solution and that there is a need for coordinated action under the leadership of the United Nations, I strongly condemn any violence or discrimination based on religion and belief currently taking place in Yemen.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Yemen is the poorest country in the Arab world. 47% of its population lives on less than two dollars a day and four million Yemenis are malnourished or lack access to food. Military offensives and coalition bombardment have plunged the country into unprecedented political instability and economic collapse. Many challenges are ahead of the Yemeni government. The National Peace and Association Agreement is not supported by much of civil society. The government has been answered by the Houthis, who have seeded the power of half a country. Saudi Arabia has formed a coalition to restore the president to power, making Yemen the scene of the confrontation between the two rival regional powers, Saudi Arabia and Iran.  Parliament urges the ceasefire, to ensure access to humanitarian aid and humanitarian workers, and to the political solution of this crisis; it also urges all parties to implement UN Security Council resolutions and insists that all necessary measures must be taken to ensure respect for human rights.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on the current crisis in Yemen.  This crisis is the result of the failure of successive governments to justify the legitimate expectations of the Yemeni people in terms of democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. This failure led to violent conflicts in the cold, as a failure to form a proper government and fair share of power, and systematic disregard for disagreements between the various tribes in the country, insecurity and economic paralysis prevail in the country. These recent events pose a serious threat to the stability of the region, in particular the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East region. The European Parliament is deeply concerned about the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen, expresses its condolences to the families of the victims and calls on all warring parties to put an immediate end to the violence. The European Union supports yemen's unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, and supports the Yemeni people. Parliament also condemns the destabilising and violent unilateral actions carried out by a criminal group and military units loyal to the former president. It also condemns the airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition and the ongoing Yemeni maritime blockade, which has killed thousands of people.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament should express its firm support for the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen. I want to express my deep concern that 13 million people in Yemen are facing a food supply crisis and 9.4 million have little or no access to water. I call on all warring parties to immediately stop the violence and ensure the protection of civilians and to refrain from directing attacks on civilian infrastructure, especially health care buildings and water systems.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the Eu ropean Union to show its closeness and support for the Yemeni people and to work to put an end to the terrible civil war that is leaving Yemen.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The situation in Yemen is very delicate, as it is the receptacle of shocks of Sunni/Shiite powers. The Saudi-led coalition is made up of Egypt and Morocco (countries with which we wish to maintain good diplomatic relations). Across the street, the Houthi minority is backed by Iran. That is why, in this situation, we cannot take sides on this or that side. Moreover, Saudi Arabia's support has been requested by the President of Yemen himself, raising doubts about the existence of any interference.  The motion for a resolution, if it advocates an internal solution to the conflict, falls back into the cross-border with unilateral moral condemnation and a form of outdated anti-militarism.  I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Yemen. When we talk about human rights violations, violence and security limitations, it is to be welcomed that the European Union intervenes and reaffirms its firm commitment and determination to address the threat posed by extremist and terrorist groups which, in this case, endanger the lives of the citizens of Yemen. The European Union is campaigning for conflict resolution through dialogue and negotiation, and not through acts of violence, abuses and the use of weapons. The current context in Yemen is all the more serious in terms of limiting the humanitarian and medical aid that the population urgently needs. Restricting the right to liberty and medical care are the greatest abuses to which a citizen can be subjected. The situation in Yemen must continue to be overseen both by the Commission, the Council and Parliament, but also by all international bodies empowered to prevent and penalise such abuses.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. It stresses that the conflict can only be resolved by a political, inclusive and negotiated solution and the need for coordinated humanitarian action under the leadership of the United Nations; in addition, all countries are urged to help meet humanitarian needs; calls on the international community to contribute to the UN's revised humanitarian appeal and reiterates that freedom of religion and belief is a fundamental right. Any violence or discrimination based on religion and belief in Yemen is strongly condemned.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Tensions between the Yemeni government and Houthi rebels and the major democratic crisis have plunged the country into chaos. This situation is compounded by the intervention of a Saudi-led coalition, which imposes a naval blockade with dramatic effects. Nearly 3,000 people have been killed since the start of hostilities and an estimated 20 million people are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance. The country's historical heritage is also under threat.  As this situation poses a serious threat to the security of the region, it is more necessary than ever to act. This resolution underlines the extreme gravity of the situation and calls for the establishment of a humanitarian truce to help the civilian population, especially with regard to food vital to their survival.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current crisis in the Yemeni state is the result of the failure of successive governments to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy and economic and social development. The failures caused by the government of Abd-Rabbu Mansour, who failed to create an inclusive government and systematically ignored tribal tensions, have created the conditions for the rise of Houthi militias.  Since March 2015, an alliance of Arab states led by Saudi Arabia has launched a campaign to counter the gains of Houthi militias and to bring Hadi back to power. Airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition and the naval blockade imposed on Yemen have not only killed thousands of people, but have created conditions conducive to the expansion of terrorist organisations such as IS and Al-Qaeda, aggravating an already critical humanitarian situation. In line with the resolution I voted on, I believe that this conflict can only be resolved by an inclusive and negotiated political solution capable of leading to the formation of a government of national unity, in order to restore peace and deal with the humanitarian crisis.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Yemen is a particularly concerning one, and I particularly note the terrible conditions in Aden and the surrounding areas. I support the right of the people of South Yemen to self-determination. This report has much to commend it, and addresses some of the issues in Yemen, but not all. Furthermore, it pushes European foreign policy, which should be the preserve of the Member States. I therefore decided on balance to abstain. My amendments to this report were voted against by the Parliament. These included highlighting the need for the correct actors to be attending any peace negotiations, equal access for the distribution of humanitarian aid in both the north and south of the Yemen, as well as noting that the continued unity of Yemen, is not necessarily the approach to a securing a lasting peace.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution as I am seriously concerned at the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen and to underscore through this resolution the EU’s continuing commitment to support Yemen and the Yemeni people for its unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, and to stand by the people of Yemen. I particularly call on the VP/HR, together with the Member States, to gather support within the UN for a grand international plan to secure Yemen’s water supply, since such a move could be essential in bringing a potential peace process to a successful conclusion and giving the population the prospect of being able to improve agriculture, feed themselves and rebuild the country.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because the protection of human rights always has my full support.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We consider that the current crisis in Yemen is the result of the failure of successive governments to meet the legitimate expectations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. We therefore express serious concerns about the deteriorating situation in the political, security and humanitarian fields in Yemen, so we call on all warring parties to immediately stop the use of force.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's joint resolution on the situation in Yemen. The crisis has led to a violent conflict involving Huthi Al-Qaida rebels over the Arabian Peninsula and ISIS and has resulted in 3 000 deaths, 10 000 injured, 250 000 refugees and 335 000 displaced persons. 80% of the population - 22 million people - urgently need food, water and medicines. In addition, the situation has worsened as a result of the decision of Saudi Arabia (leader of a military coalition including Qatar, Bahrain, Egypt, Jordan, Kuwait, Morocco, Sudan and the United Arab Emirates) to impose a naval blockade. The armed conflict and its escalation threaten Yemen's cultural heritage. The EP calls for a peaceful solution to the conflict, strongly condemns THE ACTIONS OF ISIS and expresses its support for the work of the UN Secretary-General's Special Envoy for Yemen.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the situation in Yemen, because I believe that it is a country that needs the help of the international community in order to reach a negotiated political solution. The country is on the brink of collapse and is in the midst of a humanitarian emergency. , water and medical supplies.  So far, air raids have not had any respect for civilians and there are even fears that cluster bombs have been used in the conflict which are prohibited under international law. However, it is children who are most affected by the situation, and it is estimated that 9.9 million of them have been affected by the conflict, either because they have been killed or because they are injured, many have been recruited to fight. I therefore hope that Yemen will be able to find a compromise that will enable it to achieve a government of national unity where citizens can live in peace and see their democratic rights and expectations respected.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The instability of this country is unfortunately not recent. The situation has deteriorated over the past decade and since January this year has been virtually in an unprecedented civil war.  This vast territory, of enormous geostrategic importance, is in fact experiencing a power vacuum. It is home not only to what is considered the most dangerous cell of Al-Quaeda, but also due to international action, it has become a territory conducive to the development and expansion of other extremist and terrorist organizations, which include ISIS/DAESH.  At this time, however, as the resolution rightly states, it is crucial to deal with the very serious humanitarian emergency in the country, with millions of people without access to medical care, food or water. The European Union, through its High Representative, must in fact make efforts for a grand international coalition to end the conflict, provide humanitarian aid and thus be able to be able to start a genuine process of stabilisation of the country.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Yemen is a country on the brink of collapse, at the mercy of a humanitarian crisis born of the inability of successive governments to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the people for democracy, economic and social development. The international community must commit itself to finding a political and practical solution to the conflict, not least because recent developments will shortly pose serious risks to the stability of the entire region by involving the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the Middle East. Therefore, zero tolerance towards persecution and massacres against the civilian population, especially women and children, and against the use of weapons and terrorist attacks. Rather, we need to act quickly through humanitarian corridors to save children, to bring food, water and medicine to the more than 15.9 million people forced to live in precarious conditions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The conflict in Yemen is causing terrible suffering to the Yemeni population (more than 20 million people urgently need humanitarian aid), but it also exemplifies the chaos of the area, chaos that came with the war by delegation and unilateral interventions. A coalition led by Saudi Arabia, the EU's much-friend theocratic dictatorship, is bombing with prohibited weapons and has imposed a naval blockade affecting civilians. Since the conviction that this situation cannot be left through the military, we have demanded an inclusive political solution, the lifting of the naval blockade, the ceasefire, the cessation of bombing, the cessation of arms supply and the investigation of the United Kingdom, France, Germany and Spain to find out whether they have breached the European Union Code of Conduct on arms exports. Since the resolution adopted stresses the need for a political solution to the conflict and condemns the airstrikes of the Saudi-led coalition and the naval blockade imposed on Yemen, pointing to the coalition as causing thousands of deaths and further destabilization of the country, I have given my vote in favour of the text.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current crisis in Yemen is the result of the failure of successive governments in power that have failed to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. All warring parties must agree to take a humanitarian break, especially during the current Ramadan, to allow aid to the people in need (13 million people in Yemen are facing a food security crisis and more than 9 million have little or no access to water). At the same time, this pause is needed to be used as a first step towards a ceasefire that paves the way for a sustainable political solution. It is essential that all parties involved comply with their obligations under international humanitarian law and human rights and grant unrestricted access to humanitarian workers so that immediate assistance is provided to persons in need. Efforts must be made to resolve differences through dialogue, compromise and power-sharing, leading to the formation of a government of national unity, with the aim of restoring peace, avoiding economic and financial collapse and addressing the humanitarian crisis.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as it expresses the Parliament’s serious concern at the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen and urges all warring parties to put an end to the violence. The motion also reaffirms Parliament’s strong support for the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen. It condemns the destabilising and violent unilateral actions taken by the Houthis and condemns the air strikes and naval blockade imposed on Yemen, which have led to thousands of deaths. This violence has further destabilised Yemen and created conditions conducive to the expansion of terrorist organisations such as ISIS. Finally it also urges all Yemeni parties, in particular the Houthis, to work towards resolving their differences through dialogue.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution reiterates the European Parliament's support for Yemen and its people in the face of the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in that country, following a civil war between Shiite Houthi rebel groups and pro-government forces backed by a Saudi-led coalition.  The European Parliament urges all parties to put an immediate end to the use of violence and to resolve their differences through dialogue and consultation. It is also necessary for regional actors to establish constructive contacts with the parties present in Yemen in order to allow a de-escalation of the crisis and to avoid any worsening of regional instability.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the Gulf State is increasingly critical: air raids by the Saudi-led coalition continue throughout the country, as well as ground clashes between Houthi, pro-government troops and tribal militias. The possibility of a humanitarian truce is more necessary than ever, but it still seems a long way off. Since 19 March, according to the UN, the bombings have claimed more than 3,000 lives, half of them civilians and 14,000 wounded. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that the international community, the United Nations and Europe itself must do everything possible to try to find a solution for Yemen.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the joint resolution on Yemen because the rapid deterioration of the political, security and humanitarian situation in that country is extremely worrying.
