I join in condemning the destabilizing and violent unilateral actions of the Houthi and military units loyal to former President Saleh. Furthermore, I deplore the fact that the airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition and the naval blockade it imposed on Yemen have resulted in the deaths of thousands of people, created favourable conditions for the expansion of terrorist and extremist organizations and exacerbated an already critical humanitarian situation. I am convinced that there can only be a negotiated political solution to the conflict in Yemen. That is why I support the call for all parties to resolve their differences through dialogue, compromise and power-sharing, resulting in the formation of a government of national unity, the only one capable of restoring peace, avoiding economic and financial collapse, and facing the humanitarian crisis.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Yemen is in the midst of its most severe crisis in years, with spiralling violence and competing forces fighting for control. Already the poorest country in the Middle East, Yemen is wracked by soaring unemployment, dwindling oil and water reserves, and is home to the most dangerous branch of al-Qaeda. The country was thrown into further turmoil earlier this year after Houthi rebels forced President Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi to flee to Aden and then to Saudi Arabia.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With my support for the resolution on the situation in Yemen, I express my deep concern about what is happening not only in Yemen, but throughout the region. The crisis in Yemen is an additional security threat to the Somali Peninsula, the Red Sea region and the Middle East as a whole.  Above all, however, attention must be paid to the humanitarian aspect of what is happening in Yemen. As a result of fighting between different militant groups, as well as bombing, access to basic services for citizens has been cut off. With the humanitarian crisis deepening, one of the most affected groups in this situation is children. Unfortunately, the UN's attempts to deal with the situation have rather failed. Although I stand by the EU's position on a political solution to the conflict, I remain sceptical that one is possible. Yemen's strategic position between Africa, the Middle East and Asia makes it particularly attractive to terrorist groups linked to al-Qaeda. I hope that, by adopting the resolution on the situation in Yemen, we will draw the attention of both European and international society to what is happening there and the dangers it poses to the whole world.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Union, once again, is said to be acting as an unsolicited defender of the law, when in fact it is simply trying to influence in its interest the flow of developments. Moreover, her stance is unilateral and hypocritical because, while seemingly condemning Saudi Arabia's intervention, she still sees Hadi, who has fled to Saudi Arabia and called for airstrikes against his homeland, as a legitimate Yemeni president.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We condemn saudi Arabia's military aggression to Yemen with the support of the Persian Gulf and US dictatorial regimes, with an infamous use of cluster bombs. A military intervention that constitutes a violation of international law and an unacceptable interference, confirming an interventionist tendency of Saudi Arabia in countries in the region. This military aggression and the economic blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia has already claimed the lives of thousands of people, forcing 80% of yemen's population into food, water and health care deprivation, imposing a wave of hundreds of thousands of refugees. A situation that is not disconnected from the intention to impose the dominance of imperialism in the Middle East, crush yemen's sovereign affirmation and ensure control of Yemen's geostrategic position on energy raw material transport routes. The content of this resolution could well adapt several countries and peoples of the Middle East. It is an aggression that is a dangerous development in a region marked by great tension, various conflicts and the consequences of us policy of interference, division and war, nato powers and their allies in the Middle East.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen is deeply worrying for the European Union. I condemn any violence, attempts and threats relating to the use of violence to intimidate the participants in the UN-sponsored dialogue. In particular, we must fight fundamentally against the use, or rather the abuse of children, by all those involved in the conflict. Our humanitarian action must be well coordinated and we must call on all countries to contribute to addressing the humanitarian needs of the population in Yemen. I stress that the only solution to the conflict can only be political, diplomatic and inclusive, and that its aim is to form a government of national unity and restore peace.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution stressing that the conflict can only be resolved by a political, inclusive and negotiated solution and the need for coordinated humanitarian action under the leadership of the United Nations.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the situation in Yemen, because the Union is once again said to be acting as an unsolicited defender of the law, when in fact it is simply trying to influence the flow of developments in its interests. Moreover, her stance is unilateral and hypocritical, as, while seemingly condemning Saudi Arabia's intervention, she still sees Hadi, who has fled to Saudi Arabia and called for airstrikes against his homeland, as a legitimate Yemeni president.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Yemen is in the grip of its most severe crisis in years, caused mainly by conflicts on underlying problems of unequal access to power and resources. The recent developments carry grave risks for the stability of the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East region. I am seriously concerned about the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen; it can greatly exacerbate regional tensions and increase the possibility of a large-scale war in the area. According to the WHO’s latest figures, we are more than entitled to worry over the situation in Yemen. The unnecessary loss of lives cannot go on. We need to engage constructively with the Yemeni parties in order to enable the de-escalation of the crisis and support and encourage by all means the negotiations taking place. I welcome the efforts made by the UN and I highlight the need for coordinated humanitarian action to contribute to the UN’s revised humanitarian appeal. I strongly believe that only a broad political consensus among the parties through inclusive negotiations can provide a sustainable solution, restore peace, and preserve the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. After peace talks in Geneva ended without agreement on a truce, Yemen is in the grip of rising tensions in an already volatile region. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Yemen, which strongly calls on all parties involved in the conflict to put an immediate end to the use of violence. In the resolution, we insist that the NEGOTIATIONs under the aegis of the United Nations be conducted by Yemen in order to reach a political solution that is consensual and inclusive. We also recall the heavy toll paid by the Yemeni civilian population, deprived of running water and basic and emergency health care, and call for a humanitarian truce so as to allow the delivery, especially by sea, of vital humanitarian aid. Finally, we strongly condemn the recruitment of children, which, far from being a marginal or cyclical phenomenon, remains a widespread practice in the world and which requires awareness and concerted action.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion because I am deeply concerned that the political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen is deteriorating rapidly. I welcome the urgency of the warring parties to immediately cease the use of force. I also think it is important to offer our condolences to the families of the victims.  Crucially, the EU has reaffirmed its commitment to continue its support for Yemen and the Yemeni people. I also call for an independent international investigation into all alleged violations of international human rights and international humanitarian law.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The current crisis in Yemen is the result of an unjust power-sharing and the inability to carry out a fair power-sharing, systematically ignoring the country's many tribal tensions. Similarly, on 26 March 2015, a Saudi-led coalition along with various Arab states launched a military operation in Yemen against Houthi rebels at the request of Yemeni President Abd Rabu Mansur Hadi. The EU should urge all parties in Yemen to strive to resolve their disputes through dialogue and consultation and to call on all regional actors to work constructively with the Yemeni parties. It is imperative that all parties respect international humanitarian law and international human rights law to ensure the protection of civilians. For these reasons I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Yemen today because I have the bad impression that Yemen is facing a humanitarian catastrophe. Europe must act – humanitarian, technical and diplomatic. More than 80% of all Yemenis need help. The bitterly poor country is only one step away from famine. Let us help people.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on Yemen given the crisis is causing an appalling humanitarian crisis and is further destabilising the country, including by creating a breeding ground for the expansion of terrorist and extremist organisations like IS and Al-Qaeda. I therefore urge the High Representative to offer full support to the efforts of the UN to broker peace negotiations between the warring parties, as well as to Oman in its role as negotiator for achieving a cease-fire between the Houthis and the forces loyal to the government of Yemen as a first step towards a political solution.  The EU should also work with all stakeholders towards securing a humanitarian pause in order to allow life-saving assistance badly need by the Yemeni people and push for rapid, safe and unhindered access for humanitarian actors to reach people in need of humanitarian assistance.  Looking at the mid-term, Europe should champion a grand international plan in the UN to secure Yemen’s water supply, which could be instrumental in bringing a potential peace process to a successful conclusion, giving the population a perspective to be able to improve agriculture, feed themselves and rebuild the country. Fulfilling these conditions will be crucial for bringing sustainable peace to Yemen and the region.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. The adopted Resolution supports a militaristic stance on conflict resolution. It is quite clear in this Resolution that the EU's security priorities in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability are not based on the promotion of human rights in this region, but on a utilitarian view of how the EU can capitalize on economic gain and expand its geostrategic influence. This report does not seek to develop a logic by which the EU can contribute to the dialogue and development of human rights in the region, but to find a way in which the EU can leverage and use its support as an international player to promote its interests.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on Yemen as the current situation is causing an appalling humanitarian crisis which is further destabilising the country.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Yemen because I am concerned about the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen. I do not support the hostilities and I support the rapporteur, who calls on all warring parties to put an end to the violence immediately and expresses my condolences to the families of the victims. I believe that the European Union must fulfil its commitment to continue to support Yemen and the Yemeni people, the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen. It is important to ensure world peace and to exploit the Influence of the European Union in doing so.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's Resolution on the Situation in Yemen (2015/2760 (RSP)) due to the difficult war situation and the major humanitarian and political problems now reigning in the country. The ongoing conflicts in Yemen have spread to almost the entire country, with at least 1,439 people killed from March 19th to May 5th 2015, according to the latest World Health Organization figures. Violence by all involved in the conflicts needs to be stopped urgently. All parties should respect international humanitarian law and international human rights in order to ensure the protection of civilians and to stop the direct destruction of civilian infrastructure, health care buildings and water systems, and to launch cooperation with the UN and humanitarian aid organisations to assist those in need. It is imperative that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy urgently wins UN support for a comprehensive international plan to ensure the supply of water to Yemen, as such a measure could be crucial for the successful implementation of the potential peace process and for creating hope among the population for the possibility of improving agriculture, self-sufficient nutrition and the reconstruction of the country.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this report on the situation in Yemen. It contains eminently positive elements, such as condemnation of interference in this country. Thus, Saudi Arabia decided to intervene in defiance of Yemeni sovereignty by indiscriminately bombing the territory of a foreign state. It also calls for seeking a situation within the conflict, avoiding harmful foreign influences as much as possible.  However, this report commits a significant fault by ingesting the affairs of another sovereign state, France, by condemning the negotiations on arms sales of the latter with other regional powers. Nevertheless, this report is sometimes too Manichean: it is not a question of choosing one's side, between Sunnis and Shiites, between Iran and Saudi Arabia. Moreover, anti-militarist elements remain very prominent in this text, even though they have no place in it: international politics does not make angelism or ideology.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Yemen. The resolution reiterates concerns about the rapid deterioration of the country's political, security and humanitarian situation and reiterates its support for Yemen's sovereignty and independence. The resolution also condemns the actions of the Houthi tribes as well as the terrorist attacks perpetrated by Al-Qaeda and Daesh. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution on the situation in Yemen. The violence and terrorist attacks faced by civil society can no longer continue. Urgent humanitarian assistance measures must be organized for people who no longer have access to food or care. The various parties must, through dialogue and negotiation, respond to the people's calls for democracy, respect for human rights and tribal differences in order to restore lasting peace within the country.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution. The situation in Yemen is worrying and the condemnation is logical. But it is also necessary to point out the complicity of the Saudi-led coalition, which continues to fuel the conflict.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the situation in Yemen. It is true that the text advocates an "internal" solution to the conflict in Yemen and calls for humanitarian assistance. However, we can see that the interference is once again present and that the European Union is trying to mediate arrogantly.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The conflict in Yemen is causing terrible suffering to the Yemeni population (more than 20 million people urgently need humanitarian aid), but it also exemplifies the chaos of the area, chaos that came with the war by delegation and unilateral interventions. A coalition led by Saudi Arabia, the EU's much-friend theocratic dictatorship, is bombing with prohibited weapons and has imposed a naval blockade affecting civilians. Since the conviction that this situation cannot be left through the military, we have demanded an inclusive political solution, the lifting of the naval blockade, the ceasefire, the cessation of bombing, the cessation of arms supply and the investigation of the United Kingdom, France, Germany and Spain to find out whether they have breached the European Union Code of Conduct on arms exports. Since the resolution adopted stresses the need for a political solution to the conflict and condemns the airstrikes of the Saudi-led coalition and the naval blockade imposed on Yemen, pointing to the coalition as causing thousands of deaths and further destabilization of the country, I have given my vote in favour of the text.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ World Health Organization data shows that the conflicts in Yemen have killed more than 1,400 people and injured nearly 6,000. It is an internal conflict where the Houthis - Shiite rebels, and forces true to President Hadi - are involved, most of them Sunni from the south of the country. In addition to these two sides, extremists and terrorists – Al-Qaeda and ISIL - are involved in the conflict. This is a very difficult situation where control of certain parts of the country is almost impossible. It is important to stress that this is not only an internal conflict, but over time it takes on wider ranges. Saudi Arabia also joined the conflicts, leading several states. The attacks are directed at the rebels, and in favor of the president. Thus, the conflict particularly affectes states on the Horn of Africa and the wider Middle East.  Dialogue between the parties to the conflict should be started as soon as possible, to try to find common ground and to suppress the actions of extremists. In addition, measures to help the population need to be taken as urgently as possible, as a humanitarian crisis is on the way, as evidenced by the growing number of refugees. The priority must be to stop the spread of the conflict, establish dialogue and ceasefire and help the UN-led population. We must show solidarity towards the population suffering the consequences of this conflict, so I supported

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Several hundred thousand people in Yemen have become refugees. More than 130 thousand people have been killed. The situation is appalling. I voted in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Yemen for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This Resolution rightly reaffirms the European Parliament’s strong support for the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen, and stands by the people of Yemen.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. Although the text encourages the Yemeni authorities to find an internal solution to the conflict, what we support, the evidence of attempts to interfere with the affairs of that country is glaring, and we formally oppose it. So we prefer to abstain.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote in favour of this resolution I reiterated my firm support for the unity, sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity of Yemen. I particularly appreciated the reference in the document to the need to put an immediate end to the violence within the country.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report condemns the situation in Yemen and the human rights violations that go with it and has therefore been supported by me. The neutral reporting, which also gives the Saudi coalition a share of the blame, which continues to fuel this conflict and does not contribute to its mediation, is particularly positive.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The situation in the country has worsened since the Houthi captured the capital Sanaa; President Hadi has been confined to residence since 21 September. The resolution denounces the Saudi-led coalition airstrikes and its naval blockade of Yemen, which have killed thousands of people and further destabilized the country. This intervention has also created the conditions for the expansion of terrorist and extremist organizations such as Daesh. It stresses the need to coordinate humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations.  I vote for this resolution which clearly denounces the actions of Saudi Arabia and places itself within the framework of the United Nations.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report contains positive elements, such as condemnation of interference in this country. Thus, Saudi Arabia decided to intervene in defiance of Yemeni sovereignty by indiscriminately bombing the territory of a foreign state. It also calls for seeking a situation within the conflict, avoiding, as far as possible, harmful foreign influences. However, this report commits a significant fault by getting involved in the affairs of another sovereign state: France, by condemning the negotiations on arms sales of the latter with other regional powers. Nevertheless, this report is sometimes too Manichean: it is not a question of choosing one's side, between Sunnis and Shiites, between Iran and Saudi Arabia. Moreover, anti-militarist elements remain very prominent in this text, even though they have no place in it: international politics does not make angelism or ideology. I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Yemen. It is essential to achieve a lasting humanitarian ceasefire in order to enable urgent humanitarian assistance and the supply of essential goods. More than 100,000 people have fled their homes, mostly women and children, according to the United Nations agency.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The current crisis in Yemen is a major global concern. Already subject to geographical, sectarian and tribal divisions, Yemen has become a breeding ground between the terrorist groups of AQAP (Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula) and IS/Daesh. The conflict in Yemen has already left more than 3,000 people dead, 10,000 injured, 250,000 refugees and 335,000 internally displaced. It is taking on a regional scale and poses serious risks to the stability of the region and world peace, particularly in the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East.  The European Union and the international community must act strongly to stem this conflict enjoyed by terrorist groups such as AQAP and IS/Daesh, whose terrorist acts are a threat to world peace.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Parliament resolution on the situation in Yemen which addresses the current crisis as a result of a failure by successive governments to meet the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. I agreed with the argument that this failure has created the conditions for an outbreak of violent conflict by failing to establish an inclusive government and fair power sharing, and systematically ignoring the country’s many tribal tensions, widespread insecurity and economic paralysis. Therefore, I call on all parties to end the use of violence immediately and on the EU to reaffirm its commitment to continuing to support Yemen and the Yemeni people.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Yemen, one of the poorest countries on the Arabian Peninsula, is currently experiencing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis as a result of saudi-led coalition bombing sprees and fighting between Huti rebels and troops loyal to the government. According to United Nations data, between March and July 2015, 1,528 civilians have died and 3,605 have been on public holidays. More than 250 000 refugees and 335 000 internally displaced persons are counted. A country where the main political figures of the transitional government are exiled in Saudi Arabia.  In addition to the escalation of daily violence, there is a naval blockade with dramatic effects on the civilian population. There needs to be a global humanitarian aid strategy for Yemen, led by the United Nations. International organizations and donor countries should coordinate strategies. The warring parties must, in turn, accept the entry of aid. More than 15.9 million people in Yemen need support. Deteriorating security conditions have led to the departure of humanitarian organizations and opened up the number of terrorists, notably the self-proclaimed Islamic State.  I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. A hundred days after the start of the Saudi offensive against Yemen and the massacre of hundreds of innocent civilians, the European Parliament finally decided to speak out on these attacks and to demand their immediate end through a motion for a resolution. However, while the latter advocates an internal solution to the ongoing conflict in Yemen and calls for the delivery of much-needed and even vital humanitarian aid for the country's hundreds of thousands of refugees, which is now made impossible by the blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia and its coalition, it shows a futile and so unsuitable attempt to interfere in the internal affairs of a ravaged country.  It is not a question of "choosing a side" in a conflict of both ethnic and religious facets, between Sunnis and Shiites, both supported by external powers, nor of unilaterally condemning the actions of the coalition or the Houthi rebellion.  Interference, laudating and unravelling of national diplomacy, all reasons to refrain, as I have done, from a motion for a resolution which also contains good findings and calls for internal dialogue.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Yemen. The resolution condemns the terrorist attacks perpetrated by IS that have killed and injured hundreds of innocent people. It also recalls that Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) has been able to take advantage of the deteriorating political and security situation in Yemen by expanding its presence and increasing the number and scale of its terrorist attacks. Recent developments in the conflict in Yemen pose serious risks to the stability of the region, particularly in the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the Middle East more generally.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this resolution that shows its support for the people of Yemen.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Cáineann an rún seo an úsáid leanúnach a bhaintear as foréigean; iarrtar go mbeadh sos comhraic láithreach ann; cáintear an úsáid a bhaintear as páistí; déantar níos mó de chabhair dhaonnachtúil a lorg agus déantar tagairt don ghá atá le comhphlé láithreach chun teacht ar réiteach polaitiúil ar mhaithe le muintir Éimin.  Mar sin chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Yemen needs urgent help. 20 million people need humanitarian aid, almost half of whom are children. The international community must contribute to humanitarian aid. So far, this has only been allowed, but very little real money has been given. Humanitarian workers must be given access to those in need. The conflict in Yemen is a breeding ground for terrorists, and the use of children as combatants is very common. It is therefore extremely important that the UN Special Representative for Yemen acts to achieve a political solution in Yemen.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to the situation in Yemen, which continues to persist, considering that the population is experiencing a deep crisis and opposing all forms of war and discrimination, considering that the current crisis in Yemen is the result of the inability of successive governments to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, I express my outrage and my closeness to the Yemeni people.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Yemen was recently added to the UN list as the country facing the highest level of crisis. Yemen is in urgent need of major humanitarian aid as 80% of the population is starved due to lack of food. The United Nations needs to come up with a comprehensive international plan as soon as possible to ensure that Yemen supplies food and water. This is important in order to meet the basic human needs of the population, but it will also contribute to ending the potential peace process, and creating a perspective for the population by ensuring improved agriculture, self-sufficient nutrition and land restoration. Only sincere dialogue can lead to a way out of this crisis, so it is necessary to find a common effective solution that will ensure respect for fundamental human and humanitarian rights. Tolerance should be promoted and anti-hatred, sectarian and extremist radicalisation initiatives should be taken, but it should primarily be possible to help the Yemeni people reach food and water as soon as possible as they are threatened with survival.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. A hundred days after the start of the Saudi offensive against Yemen and the massacre of hundreds of innocent civilians, the European Parliament finally decided to speak out on these attacks and to demand their immediate end through a motion for a resolution. However, while the latter advocates an internal solution to the ongoing conflict in Yemen and calls for the delivery of much-needed and even vital humanitarian aid for the country's hundreds of thousands of refugees, which is now made impossible by the blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia and its coalition, it shows a futile and so inappropriate attempt to interfere in the internal affairs of a ravaged country.  It is not a question of "choosing a side" in a conflict of both ethnic and religious facets, between Sunnis and Shiites, both supported by external powers, nor of unilaterally condemning the actions of the coalition or the Houthi rebellion.  Interference, laudating and unravelling of national diplomacy, all reasons to refrain, as I have done, from a motion for a resolution which also contains good findings and calls for internal dialogue.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The current crisis in Yemen has been due to the inability of successive governments to satisfy the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security, and the failed transition, following the resignation of longtime President Ali Abdulah Saleh, succeeded by Vice-President Abd-Rabu Mansur Hadi, created the conditions for an outbreak of violent conflict because no inclusive government was formed and there was no fair power-sharing and systematic ignorance of numerous tensions among tribes in the state , widespread insecurity and economic paralysis.  I reaffirm my firm support for the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen and support its people and express serious concern at the sharp deterioration of the political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen. All parties involved in the conflict should participate in reaching an agreement on a humanitarian pause, at least now during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, in order to allow much-needed assistance to be delivered to the population, thereby taking the first step towards a lasting ceasefire that would prepare the ground for a political solution reached through the negotiations. Of particular concern is the fact that 13 million people in Yemen are facing a food supply crisis and 9.4 million have little or no access to water. It's a humanitarian catastrophe for which we need to find an answer as soon as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The accelerated deterioration of the security and humanitarian situation in Yemen is worrying. The escalation of the conflict between the authorities and the Shiite Hutus militia, but also the military intervention of a coalition of countries led by Saudi Arabia, has greatly hampered the already unfavorable situation in one of the poorest countries in the Arabian Peninsula. The conflict in Yemen also carries the risk of further destabilisation of the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea Basin and the entire Middle East. It also brings an increased danger of creating very fertile soil for preparing and carrying out terrorist actions. Given that over 20 million people need humanitarian assistance, it is essential to ensure the protection of the civilian population. Consistent respect for international humanitarian law is necessary to at least minimise material and human suffering. Air strikes by the military coalition do not contribute to defusing the conflict. Military action in itself will not resolve the conflict and therefore a cessation of military actions and violence is needed. A solution to the crisis needs to be reached through dialogue and the solution must be political. Consultations started in Geneva on 14 June must be resumed in good faith. The negotiations should cover a wide range of issues relevant to the end of the conflict, with full respect for the territorial integrity of Yemen and the legitimate Yemeni authorities. Only by reaching a peace agreement is it possible to restore peace and eliminate the risk of organizing terrorist groups that would further undermine the security situation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the country's worrying instability and the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen, the European Parliament has decided to respond. I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution denouncing the current situation and calling on Member States to react.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas 15.9 million people in Yemen need humanitarian aid; that the most vulnerable children will not have access to the health care or nutritional services they need and due to the current widespread insecurity, I voted in favour of this resolution. For these reasons and because it is crucial to coordinate humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations, I consent to all forms of violence and attempts or threats to use violence to intimidate participants in UN-mediated consultations.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. MEPs expressed concern about the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen and spoke of the urgent need to end the conflict that is dividing the country between government forces and the Shiite Houthi rebellion.  A climate of general insecurity and economic paralysis has set in, causing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis. 20 million people are currently in need of humanitarian assistance, including nearly 9.4 million children. This situation also poses serious risks to the stability of the region, particularly with regard to the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East.  With a health system on the brink and the upcoming announcement of a fuel shortage, which is already severely limiting the delivery of humanitarian aid and will soon lead to water shortages, Yemen is on the brink of collapse.  The European Parliament strongly condemns all the violence perpetrated in particular by the Houthi but also by the Saudi-led coalition, as well as the terrorist attacks of Daesh. The urgency now is to establish a coordinated political dialogue and humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Yemen is the poorest country in the Arab world. 47% of its population lives on less than two dollars a day and four million Yemenis are malnourished or lack access to food. Military offensives and coalition bombardment have plunged the country into unprecedented political instability and economic collapse. Many challenges are ahead of the Yemeni government. The National Peace and Association Agreement is not supported by much of civil society. The government has been answered by the Houthis, who have seeded the power of half a country. Saudi Arabia has formed a coalition to restore the president to power, making Yemen the scene of the confrontation between the two rival regional powers, Saudi Arabia and Iran.  Parliament urges the ceasefire, to ensure access to humanitarian aid and humanitarian workers, and to the political solution of this crisis; it also urges all parties to implement UN Security Council resolutions and insists that all necessary measures must be taken to ensure respect for human rights.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, which I voted on, the European Parliament called for a truce that must last until the end of Ramadan, at the same time calling on the EU and its Member States to work within the United Nations to ensure the country's supply of drinking water. This would be essential to pave the way for a potential peace process and to offer the people a perspective by enabling them to improve agriculture, feed themselves and rebuild their country, the text stresses.  According to Reuters, fighting and aerial bombardment continued last week, despite the truce. Shiite Houthi rebels shelled residential areas of Aden and continued to advance in the Hadramaut desert. Meanwhile, the Saudi-led Arab coalition carried out air raids on the capital, Sanaa.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Yemen. Since the beginning of the conflicts, in this Arab region, according to the International Red Cross in Sanaa and Aden, the population has been deprived of basic necessities. According to the United Nations, since the start of the coalition bombings, one hundred thousand people have been forced to leave their homes. These are numbers that show no sign of decreasing and in the face of which Europe cannot remain indifferent.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation in Yemen is underestimated by the international community and the EU should play a more active role, in particular with regard to stopping the export of Islamic terrorism. Security measures and financial capacity to combat terrorism and deal with the situation in Yemen are absolutely inadequate. I therefore had to vote against this resolution.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The armed conflict in Yemen has affected 9.9 million children since March 2015, at least 279 children have been killed, 402 injured, 1.8 million have lost access to education as a result of school closures. There is an additional risk of recruiting children to individual anti-combat armed groups, where children make up 1/3 of all fighters in Yemen, according to UNICEF. The health system is on the verge of collapse. 2.6 million children under the age of 15 are at risk of measles infection, 2.5 million are at risk of diarrhea, cases of dengue fever are increasing, chronic diseases are not being treated, medicine supplies have stopped, 160 health facilities are closed, others are without medicines for medical supplies and staff. As humanitarian aid is prevented by Saudi-led coalition troops and, moreover, a naval blockade, I strongly condemn such a move, and I join the call to immediately halt attacks for humanitarian purposes in order to enable the vital aid to reach the Yemeni people, to allow humanitarian actors and doctors safe and unhindered access so that they can safely reach the people in need of their assistance.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the motion for a resolution due to the high death toll, as well as the injured, including scores of civilians. Developments in the Horn of Africa, as well as the Red Sea and the Middle East, carry grave risks to the stability of the region. In addition, the unrest is caused by over a thousand escaped prisoners, including Al-Qaeda soldiers and insurgents who are often hurting the population. Millions of residents in Yemen are in such a situation that they need humanitarian assistance, and the most vulnerable is a group of children who may be denied access to foodstuffs and who reside in an inhumane environment to grow up. In addition, Yemen is a haven for Ethiopian migrants as well as refugees from Somalia living in unsafe conditions.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union is once again said to be acting as an unsolicited defender of the law, when in fact it is simply trying to influence in its interest the flow of developments. Moreover, her stance is unilateral and hypocritical, as while seemingly condemning Saudi Arabia's intervention, she still sees Hadi, who has fled to Saudi Arabia and called for airstrikes against his homeland, as a legitimate Yemeni president.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal for a resolution in order to contribute to supporting the EU's efforts to deal with the violence and humanitarian crisis in Yemen proposed and implemented by High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini.   I believe that, given the geographical proximity of the Middle East region, its crisis in many other areas and the threat of further spread of international terrorism, the escalation of the civil war and refugee situation in Yemen poses an immediate threat to the foreign policy and security interests of the European Union and its Member States, and therefore our joint position and action is important and timely. I trust that the Saudi leadership will consider the aspects of the decision and lift the naval blockade in the interests of the local population. I appreciate the fact that the political chaos and refugee crisis in Yemen is particularly worrying and requires effective action by the international community. For my part, I welcome the fact that this decision also draws the attention of the governments and international factors concerned with sufficient emphasis on the dangers of this.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted for this resolution, of which I am a co-signer. I condemn all the violence and attacks and the threat of violence aimed at intimidating the participants in the consultations organized through the good offices of the United Nations. Let us stress that the inclusive political dialogue established through UN mediation must be led by Yemen in order to reach a consensus-based political solution that ends the crisis in that country, in accordance with the GCC initiative and its implementation mechanism, the final report from the non-exclusive national dialogue conference , the national peace and partnership agreement and relevant UN Security Council resolutions.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I am seriously concerned at the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen. Yemen is on the brink of civil war. Since the Houthi rebels’ advancement into the capital Sana’a in September 2014, Houthi rebels have been exploiting the power vacuum and fighting has been ongoing. The first victims of this violence are the civilians and according to UN humanitarian agency more than 150 000 people have been displaced. The fighting has destroyed, damaged or disrupted at least five hospitals, 15 schools, Yemen’s three main airports, two bridges, two factories and four mosques, as well as markets, power stations and water and sanitation facilities, OCHA said. Furthermore, the consequences of instability in Yemen extend far beyond its borders, with terrorist cells such as Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula and the Islamic State thriving amongst the current chaotic environment. It is thus critical that the international community react to this situation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a resolution supporting the resumption of engaged and active political negotiations in Yemen due to the worrying deterioration of the political, security and humanitarian situation. In particular, I support the request made to paramilitary groups that, through the use of violence, destabilise the state to withdraw from busy areas, since I believe that conflicts between Shiites and Sunnis in Yemen can only be resolved through dialogue. The current situation in the south of the state surrounded by a group of Houthi Shiite rebels is disturbing - the militia prevents food and medicine from being delivered, hospitals are closed, leading to the spread of epidemics.  I believe that it is primarily necessary to provide aid workers with access to the most vulnerable areas in order to prevent further disasters, and then to address the threats of extremist and terrorist groups. In addition to the fact that famine threatens more than 10 million people, instability and mismanagement of the state, corruption and lack of resources, and the conflict between Sunnis and Shias are factors conducing to the actions of one of the most active branches of the al Quaide terrorist group. Therefore, I consider it in the interest of the people of Yemen, but also of the entire international community, to address such extremist and terrorist threats.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. The adopted Resolution supports a militaristic stance on conflict resolution. It is quite clear in this Resolution that the EU's security priorities in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability are not based on the promotion of human rights in this region, but on a utilitarian view of how the EU can capitalize on economic gain and expand its geostrategic influence. This report does not seek to develop a logic by which the EU can contribute to the dialogue and development of human rights in the region, but to find a way in which the EU can leverage and use its support as an international player to promote its interests.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The internal solution to the conflict in Yemen, which also calls for humanitarian assistance, is moving in the right direction. Only the arrogant interference of the mediators of the European Union in the affairs of sovereign states forces me to abstain.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a motion for a Resolution calling for greater understanding among the political forces of the country so that, through dialogue, agreements can be reached; which calls on the international community and the United Nations to lead humanitarian efforts and also expresses the EU's willingness to condemn violence and terrorism in the area. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Yemen is located in a strategic geographical and maritime area from which 40% of all the oil that the European world consumes is transported. It is also a zone of influence of the U.S. Squadron of the Persian Gulf, based in Bahrain. With a population fundamentally believing in Islam, it is divided into 52% of Sunni confession and 46 % Shiite.  Corruption, submission to Western policies in the framework of the "war on terrorism" as executor of Riyadh's policies were increasingly isolating the regime of ousted former President Ali Abdallah Saleh, who ruled between 1990 and 2012, as well as his successor Abd Rabbu Mansur Hadi. In this context, the struggle of the Popular Ansarolah movement, the internal divisions within the ruling nucleus and the chronic rivalries between north and south, paved the way for the lifting of its population against governments unable to realize the welfare of their peoples. Saudi Arabia, along with the United States, fears the triumph of Ansarolah because it sees in it the expansion of Iranian influence in the area, and seeks by force of bombs to prevent any alternative solution that does not go through the replacement of the regime that destroyed the country and left the population in misery.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report condemns the situation in Yemen and the human rights violations that go with it and has therefore been supported by me. The neutral reporting, which also gives the Saudi coalition a share of the blame, which continues to fuel this conflict and does not contribute to its mediation, is particularly positive.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We condemn saudi Arabia's military aggression to Yemen with the support of the Persian Gulf and US dictatorial regimes, with an infamous use of cluster bombs. A military intervention that constitutes a violation of international law and an unacceptable interference, confirming an interventionist tendency of Saudi Arabia in countries in the region.  This military aggression and the economic blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia has already claimed the lives of thousands of people, forcing 80 % of yemen's population into food, water and health care deprivation, imposing a wave of hundreds of thousands of refugees. A situation that is not disconnected from the intention to impose the dominance of imperialism in the Middle East, crush yemen's sovereign affirmation and ensure control of Yemen's geostrategic position on energy raw material transport routes.  The content of this resolution could well be adapted to several countries and peoples in the Middle East.  It is an aggression that is a dangerous development in a region marked by great tension, various conflicts and the consequences of us policy of interference, division and war, nato powers and their allies in the Middle East. We voted for it.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, there is almost no Hungarian person who is not deeply affected by the issue of those fleeing war. We'd like to help, but we can't. We think that the problems that these unfortunate people have to flee should be addressed in their roots. Yes, the European Union should look at who is actually funding the Islamic State, who is supporting it, who is arming it. Are they not, by chance, such as very good chums of the European Union? Yes, we should look at the causes of sub-Saharan African poverty. Are eu so-called investors who destroy their natural resources, exploit them, etc. not inadvertently part of this? What about Kosovo, which, you know, has been so supported by the European Union? What about the issue of Palestinian refugees? Our good buddy, the associate member, Israel shoots gaza every year for the second year, and then we have to take in the refugees.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because from a securitarian, interferenceian and neocolonial approach it believes that the European Union must increase, through all available instruments, including military instruments, its influence in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, in order to expand 'European values' and safeguard its values and interests, such as, among others, the defence of its energy security. This report by a French Socialist MP insists on the military approach to conflict resolution, even celebrating the bombing of the military coalition against IS. It is also fully interference in the countries of the region, as it calls for pressure on these countries to implement liberal economic reforms and accept new free trade agreements with the EU. I am convinced that the relationship with our neighbours cannot focus on the repression of migrants with aberrant instruments such as Frontex or the promotion of asymmetric economic relations. On the contrary, we will only have real security without being unseated, unstabilized and, above all, without an unequal economy and trade. This is quite the opposite of what this report contains, so I have not hesitated to vote against it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Middle East and North Africa have been shaken by numerous crises for years. Complicating matters is the growing presence of terrorist organizations such as Boko Haram, Al-Shabab, ISIS and Al-Qaeda. The situation in these regions is also crucial to the EU's security situation and should therefore not be underestimated or disregarded. The peaceful resolution of crises, the fight against radicalisation and the repression of terrorist militias should therefore be a high priority in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Peillon report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa does not advocate any change in external policy on the part of the Union. While the consequences of European diplomacy in the Middle East, particularly in Syria, are disastrous and it is crucial to change course, the Peillon report does not propose any change in foreign policy. After more than four years of war in Syria, it is time to re-establish diplomatic relations with the Syrian authorities, stop aiding and arming terrorist groups operating on Syrian territory, and help the Syrian army fight these groups, be it the Islamic State organization, the Syrian branch of Al-Qaeda (Al-Nusra Front) or others.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ An amendment passed suggesting that actions against ISIS would be usefully co-ordinated by the European Union. Consequently, irrespective of the remainder of the text, I had no choice but to vote against the resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ We are witnessing a dire security situation in the MENA region characterized by ongoing insecurity, rising extremism (with these countries, ISIL) and new waves of internal displacement. In my opinion, this resolution rightly states that political and economic stability of the region is of a crucial strategic importance to EU security. A holistic, ambitious and cooperative EU approach towards MENA countries is needed. We should remind ourselves that those countries share a common security interest with the EU in such fields as halting the spread of extremism, addressing migration and helping people who have been displaced. With democratic hopefulness in decline, economic cooperation needs to be complemented by a large-scale political and strategic partnership. The EU needs to promote conflict resolution along with gradual public and private sector reforms and civil capacity-building projects. While the emergency situation on an unprecedented scale is likely to continue for years to come, we need to sustain further mobilisation of our resources and scale up the EU humanitarian response while considering the specific political priorities of each MENA country.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The European Parliament calls on the EU and its Member States to address the root causes of the rapidly deteriorating situation in the Middle East and North Africa region through an overarching and ambitious approach, supports the international campaign against ISIL/Daesh and welcomes the commitment of coalition partners to cooperate in line with the joint strategy.  Welcomes in particular the actions of EU Member States that are part of the international coalition against ISIL, contributing to military intervention or providing logistical, financial and humanitarian assistance, but calls for greater coordination in all areas and stresses the need for more coordinated action. These actions could be coordinated under the supervision of the EU, as appropriate as part of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) actions, and to this end call on the EU to develop sufficient operational capabilities and to develop a truly common European defence. A tailored solution must be found to address the issue of the fight against ISIL(Daesh), the Al Nusra Front and other terrorist groups. The EU must act as a key mediator in regional dialogue, involving all stakeholders in the region, including the League of Arab States, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and Iran.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is quite revealing of the EU's risky diplomacy, to say the least: I therefore voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Middle East and North Africa face major security challenges, with the priority of these regions at the moment in the fight against IS. In this regard, the report stresses the need for the EU to encourage support for a transitional policy in Tunisia, to support the development of civil societies and an inclusive security environment. The report also addresses the issue of women's rights in these regions. It reminds us of the importance of involving women's organisations and organisations working for gender equality in the consultation of civil society carried out within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. I supported that report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability is concerned about the destabilization of the Middle East caused by ongoing conflicts in the region.  Nevertheless, it does not take into account at all the root causes of western-led interventions in Iraq and Libya. Moreover, the report treats Egypt in a way that does not see it as a partner, but rather by becoming involved in its national policy and its way of combating Islamism.  Of course, we are being offered ever more interference by the EU at the expense of the Member States, under the guise of humanitarian actions and the defence of human rights. The EU and its states would do well then to be more looking at their other partners also like Qatar or China in this case...  For all these reasons, I have decided your against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions supported in the resolution being voted on, I believe that the proposed measures are not worthy of the purpose it proposes, and I do not in any way agree with the persistent denial of a direct connection between mass landings from the coasts of North Africa and terrorism; For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The absence of democracy is one of the root causes of the instability of this region. The answer goes through a multidimensional approach. In this regard, it underlines the importance of the EU continuing to support civil society organisations and calls on the Commission to create a Euro-Mediterranean Erasmus programme.  Poverty and inequality are other causes of current instability. The report calls for more importance and encourages the EU to establish free trade zones and speed up procedures for sending financial aid.  With regard to the Syrian crisis, the report supports the actions of Member States participating in the international coalition against IS and stresses the importance of EU Member States increasing their efforts to accommodate asylum seekers. Egypt is asked to respect human rights and political freedoms. In relation to Iran, progress is being made in the negotiation on the nuclear program. In the case of Israel and Palestine, Parliament supports a new round of talks and expresses concern at the expansion of settlements and the serious humanitarian situation in Gaza.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is important and necessary to support capacity-building projects and activities of this kind in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, to combat radicalisation and violent extremism, to promote international cooperation, to address essential factors and ongoing crises and to strengthen partnerships with key countries.  The stability and security of the Middle East and North Africa region are essential objectives to ensure the security of the European Union. The European Parliament is concerned about syria's deteriorating humanitarian situation for four years. The possibility of providing humanitarian aid is diminishing due to deliberate obstruction of delivery, and these disruptions must be removed immediately. Over the last two years, the number of people living in hard-to-reach or out-of-reach areas has almost doubled.  The European Parliament considers that the lack of democracy is one of the main causes of political instability in the region and that respect for human rights and fundamental democratic principles is the strongest long-term protection against persistent instability in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa region. Parliament therefore calls on the EU and its Member States not to look at the Middle East and North Africa region solely in terms of short-term security threats and to actively and consistently support the democratic aspirations of societies in the region.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Stability and security in North Africa and the Middle East is essential for the union's security. That is why I call on the EU and its Member States not to look at the Middle East and North Africa region solely through a lens of short-lived security threats, but to provide active and sustainable support to the democratic aspirations of societies in the region. Furthermore, I call on the EU and the Member States to address, as part of a comprehensive and ambitious approach, addressing the root causes of the situation across the faster-growing Middle East and North Africa region.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe that a stronger EU presence in the MENA region is needed, as the stability of this region is one of the major challenges of the Union's foreign policy, in the light of the Syrian civil war, the rise of ISIL/Da'esh and the migration emergency.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Vincent Peillon's report looks at security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa. This text deplores the effects it cherishes: a right condemnation of the destabilization of the Middle East fuelled by the conflicts in Syria, Iraq and Libya, but praise for interference and the right-of-hommism, which are nevertheless two moral causes of the imperialisms that have been at the origin of these conflicts. Moreover, the security issues presented in this report are once again a pretext to strengthen the Union's military and diplomatic prerogatives to the detriment of the Member States. Finally, and full of irony and dual language, Egypt, a country that effectively fights against the development of Islamist terrorism on its soil, is also singled out for the famous cases of "violations of human rights" against the Muslim Brotherhood.  For all these reasons, I voted against this scandalous text which further discredits the European Union on the international stage.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa region and the prospects for political stability.  Countries such as Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the growing tensions in the Middle East and North African region are major sources of destabilisation of the region, which at all times endanger the security and right to life of the citizens of these areas. When we talk about human rights violations, violence and security limitations, it is to be welcomed that the European Union intervenes and reaffirms its firm commitment and determination to address the threat posed by groups using the ethnic and religious cause as a tool for pursuing political and power stakes. The European Union is campaigning for conflict resolution through dialogue and negotiation, and not through acts of violence, abuses and the use of weapons. Governments of these states must respect basic human rights and political freedoms, stop the systematic arrests of peaceful protesters and activists, and uphold the right to a fair trial. I also believe that all international bodies empowered to prevent and penalise such abuses must be vigilant to any attempt to violate the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Given the rapidly deteriorating situation characterised by an increase in conflicts and tensions in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), and its strategic and security importance to the European Union, the EU must increase its influence in order to stimulate foreign policy and long-term economic stability there. Regional actors should increase their involvement in addressing security problems and stresses that the European Union should not think about this region only through the lens of short-term security threats. EU Member States must increase their mobilisation in the military, logistical, financial and humanitarian spheres in dealing with conflicts in the MENA region and call for better coordination of their efforts, in particular in the fight against ISIS. The EU should become the main facilitator of a regional dialogue involving all operators in the MENA areas and High Representative Mogherini is invited to ensure a constant high-level dialogue with these countries. The EU must also increase its commitment to the Middle East peace process, which is now stalled.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The southern neighbourhood of the European Union is in a serious security crisis. The mass murders perpetrated on Christians along with Daesh's hegemony in the region are events of intolerable atrocity. We need to have a coordinated approach in the region, because an isolated Member State cannot change the situation. Stability in the region is crucial to the security of our citizens. I stress the importance of the Union for the Mediterranean in this context. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a common approach to restoring security and stability in the Middle East and North Africa.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and prospects for political stability. The conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the increase in tensions in the Middle East and North Africa region (MENA region) are major sources of destabilisation in that region. This situation has serious implications for the whole region, as it seriously damages its social, political and economic development. But the risks of this crisis are not limited in the region: the security of European citizens and the interests of the European Union linked to these territories are also at serious risk. The European Union and its Member States must therefore tackle rapidly the problems that are leading to an ever-increasing deterioration of the situation throughout the MENA region. In this respect, we need a holistic and ambitious approach. The international campaign against ISIL/Da'esh must therefore be pursued together with its international partners, in the context of a common strategy. At the same time, the EU must engage with the MENA countries in order to establish a dialogue that can contribute to achieving stability in the region.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this Report. I had a particular issue with the Roll Call Vote which called for a common European security-defence policy. All matters of security and defence should remain firmly within a Member State’s own competency and the EU should have no interference with this crucial area. Moreover, it welcomes military interventionism, reinforces Europol and FRONTEX and places considerable emphasis on free-trade agreements, which are all areas where I have raised a number of concerns.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ An amendment passed suggesting that actions against ISIS would be usefully coordinated by the European Union. Consequently, irrespective of the remainder of the text, I had no choice but to vote against the resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that this report aptly highlights the current alarming security situation which is developing in the Middle East. The Report highlights the need to address the root causes of the rapidly deteriorating situation across the MENA region through a holistic and ambitious approach and to support the international campaign against ISIL/Daesh. The stability and security of the MENA region are fundamental to the security of the EU. My main concern with voting against this Report was a reference to abortion in the text.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this is an excellent report, which seeks to take a regional approach to all the crises that have occurred in recent years in the MENA neighbourhood, the Peillon report contains some passages that could, in my opinion, be problematic. That is why I preferred to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I agree with the resolution's position that EU action in the Middle East and North Africa region needs to be reviewed in the light of the consequences of the Arab uprisings in these countries and the newly created complex situation. We believe that the Middle East and North Africa are in a state of geopolitical turmoil which will probably bring profound and unpredictable changes in regional balances.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa region (MENA Region) and the prospects for political stability. The stability of the MENA region is seriously called into question by the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya. In addition, in northern Iraq and Syria, ISIS/Da'esh and other terrorist organisations are perpetrating war crimes. In recent weeks, IN North Africa, ISIS has claimed bloody attacks on Islamists and Westerners in Tunisia. It is therefore necessary to take action against the threat posed by ISIS, to review the EU strategy in the MENA region in order to increase its influence, to promote respect for human rights, democracy and economic development.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour is linked to the continuing conflict in the MENA region (Middle East and North Africa) which leads to the deaths of innocent victims and are major sources of danger and destabilisation. The risks to the security of citizens and to the interests of the European Union are serious and are increasing. The violations of human rights and humanitarian law that are committed worry us, make us reflect and invite us to ensure a strategic political dialogue and a real debate with the states involved. The continuing fighting in Syria calls for an urgent political solution to end the conflict, taking into account the requirements of international humanitarian law. Cultural cooperation and diplomacy, together with religious dialogue, are essential to the fight against terrorism and radicalism: there is a high demand to promote a European response to combat jihadist propaganda and internal radicalisation, taking into account digital tools, the Internet and social networks. We will do all we can to ensure democracy, a source of political instability, and respect for human rights.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The humanitarian emergency that we experience in the Mediterranean, with a special focus on Greece and Italy, reminds us daily not only of the tragic reality on the African continent (especially in the north) and in the Middle East, but also makes us understand the intensity with which developments in this area directly affect the European Union. In the field of security, as this report addresses, the impact on the union is no less. For Europe, therefore, it is crucial to have a strategy for the security and stability of this region, as it has for other areas. From this report, I support, it is important to stress the emphasis it places on direct dialogue with society, on the Union for the Mediterranean, but also on the intransigence with which it calls for religious pluralism in this region. Much has yet to be done and Europe must contribute centrally to changing the current status quo.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that the destabilisation of the so-called MENA region has led to a major geopolitical upheaval, with severe repercussions in terms of political-economic stability and security of the entire region. The long-term political and economic stability of the region has always been of fundamental strategic importance for European policy, as demonstrated by the European Neighbourhood Policy. I therefore believe that it is necessary for the Union to address the causes of this situation, through the definition of global policies and medium and long-term cooperation with the countries concerned. Therefore, aware of the need to build a better dialogue with the countries of the region, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls on the EU Member States to mobilise their efforts to safeguard the European citizens from any threats from ISIS and other emerging terrorist groups. The report condemns the continued violation of the right to freedom of religion or belief in the region. Therefore, the report also stresses that there is a need to effectively combat terrorism and calls on the European Union to step up its efforts to safeguard religious minorities and providing a safe environment. Further to that, I am in favour of sustainable economic development in the area. The report stresses the fundamental importance of the fight against corruption in MENA countries to attract European investment in this area.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because from a securitarian, interferenceian and neocolonial approach it believes that the European Union must increase, through all available instruments, including military instruments, its influence in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, in order to expand 'European values' and safeguard its values and interests, such as, among others, the defence of its energy security. This report by a French Socialist MP insists on the military approach to conflict resolution, even celebrating the bombing of the military coalition against IS. It is also fully interference in the countries of the region, as it calls for pressure on these countries to implement liberal economic reforms and accept new free trade agreements with the EU. I am convinced that the relationship with our neighbours cannot focus on the repression of migrants with aberrant instruments such as Frontex or the promotion of asymmetric economic relations. On the contrary, we will only have real security without being unseated, unstabilized and, above all, without an unequal economy and trade. This is quite the opposite of what this report contains, so I have not hesitated to vote against it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and prospects for political stability gives high priority to the fight against ISIS and other extremist groups, and expresses the need for the EU to step up support for the political transition in Tunisia and the need to support the development of various other civil societies. The report in question gives importance to the situation in much of the South of Europe’s neighbouring areas and the consequences it can have on the region as a whole. Because I believe that this report properly identifies the major security challenges in the region and proposes balanced and realistic approaches I have supported it with my vote.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to provide a diagnosis of the various security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa, as well as current prospects for political stability in the region. The European Parliament calls on the European Commission, the European External Action Service and the Member States to address the causes of the rapid deterioration of the political and security situation in this region, whose stability is fundamental to the security of the European Union. Considering also that the persistent violations of the right of thought, conscience and religious freedom, including the situation of Eastern Christians, must call for resolute action by the governments of the region with the support of the European Union and its Member States. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This initiative report highlights the many challenges facing the world and Europe. The Union's foreign policy must take this new reality into account. It is by having coordinated policies with the other side of the Mediterranean that we will be able to respond to the various crises in this part of the world. Stability will depend on cooperation, especially with states in democratic transition, whose best example today is Tunisia. We must do everything we can to support and facilitate this transition, this anchoring of democracy.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which lists a series of recommendations on what European action should be in several countries: Tunisia, Libya, Iraq, Syria, Yemen. Being limited to 200 words, it is impossible for me to accurately list the measures I support. However, I would like to strongly express my support for calls to express more international support for the democratic transition, as well as for the strengthening of the political and administrative capacities of the countries concerned, in order to be able to respond to the challenges posed by the social and economic crisis and the inadequate protection of human rights. Another key element is the stabilization of areas liberated from terrorist groups, in order to guarantee sustainable security.
