With regard to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, I support the point of recalling the need to create the conditions for a resumption of peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority for a final settlement of the conflict, based on the solution of two States living side by side in peace and security, within the 1967 borders and with Jerusalem as the capital of both states.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report specifically examines the security challenges for the MENA region, including that posed by Islamic State forces, but also other areas including the civil war in Syria and the Israel-Palestine situation. While there are some parts of the report which the ECR can support in terms of international cooperation to address security concerns, there are other proposals which stray too far into areas of national competence. For these reasons ECR members abstained in committee.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The political stability of the region cannot be achieved in the economic interest of the powerful.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution pursues the EU's policy of destabilisation, interference and aggression in the Middle East and North African regions. Resigning from its responsibilities in the situation in those territories, the text continues the line of the so-called "democratisation" of the affected countries. We know very well what democratisation they are referring to, and how this process translates into the formation and support of authoritarian regimes pursuing the imperialist policy that the US, NATO and the EU have been imposing on the peoples. The path of militarization, warmongering aggression, securitization of relations with those countries continues, trampling on the legitimate will of peoples and their inalienable right to sovereignty. It supports the concept of Europe-fortress, seeking to strengthen mechanisms such as FRONTEX, one of the central pillars of the EU's criminalising, security, exploitative and elitist immigration policy. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to address the situation in the MENA countries, it is also important to address the situation of women, as their rights are indivisible and immutable, and it is also our job to reach out to peoples who suppress women's rights and do not respect gender equality. Political instability in the regions in question is leading to an increase in the number of refugees becoming victims of human trafficking. It is women and children who are the most vulnerable groups, which is why the participation of women, especially from religious and ethnic minorities, in peace negotiations is crucial for achieving satisfactory results in this area.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report given the dramatic tense situation in the Middle East and North Africa. The report calls on the EU to increase its influence in order to stimulate foreign policy and long-term economic stability there. I would remind you, however, that a great political responsibility for the degeneration of the situation in this area lies with the EU itself and its allies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and on the prospects for political stability, as the political stability of the region cannot be achieved in the economic interests of the powerful.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for the work done on the consensual outcome of the report. I am very pleased that it covers the most important issues related to the Middle East and North Africa region: high priority given to the fight against ISIS and extremist groups, the need for the EU to step up support for the political transition in Tunisia, and the support of the development of civil societies in MENA countries. I also support and agree with the need for an inclusive security environment, taking into account all sides’ legitimate concerns. I consider important the balance achieved on the Israel-Palestine issue. It underlines the EP’s position on the need for a political and peaceful transition to put an end to the civil war in Syria. And I welcome the highlighting of the Lausanne framework agreement’s role in ensuring an exclusively peaceful nature of Iran’s nuclear programme in exchange for Iran’s re-integration into the international community. I strongly share the hope that a final agreement can be achieved on Iran’s nuclear programme.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Peillon report, because it offers a detailed analysis of the security and political stability challenges in the countries of the region, and it places particular emphasis on the key to a sustainable solution: a comprehensive strategy for the construction of democratic states and for human rights. The deteriorating situation in the Middle East and North Africa region poses challenges not only for the countries of the region, but also for the European Union. The report has the merit of stressing three key elements: freedom of religion and the rights of religious minorities, the importance of developing direct dialogue and cooperation with civil society and, finally, the central and strengthened role that the Union should take for the Mediterranean. Finally, the report also focuses on building a shared area of security and stability, which also involves joint energy infrastructure projects and investments in job creation, especially for young people.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the same way as the report, I am of the opinion that restoring stability in the Middle East and North Africa should be a top priority. In view of the significant destabilisation of the region in the light of the conflict in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya, as well as the escalation of tensions in the Middle East and North Africa, the fight against terrorism is linked to the Middle East and Sahel fronts, and whereas these fronts are close to the sensitive region of the Horn of Africa; whereas the consequences of such a situation on the security of the whole region are catastrophic. I welcome the rapporteur's call on the EU and the EU Member States to take a holistic and ambitious approach to address the root causes of the rapidly deteriorating situation throughout the US and North Africa region; I also stress the importance of ensuring that the EU's permanent political presence at the highest possible level is important in order to ensure a long-term strategic political dialogue and to ensure that there is real common thinking with the countries of the Middle East and North Africa on their needs to promote regional stability.   Crucially, the European Union can only be an effective player on the international stage if it is able to speak with one voice; calls, therefore, on the EU to develop a genuine common foreign policy as soon as possible, closely coordinating its internal and external actions.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya, as well as rising tensions in the Middle East and North Africa region, are major causes of destabilization of this region and for the security of the entire region. Stabilization of the region is not only a matter of security, but also has economic, political and social consequences. The European Union was unable to anticipate the problems that arising in the region and to address the complexity of the situation. The EU must address the causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation in the Middle East and North Africa region through an ambitious approach, as well as support the international campaign against ISIS. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Peillon's report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa region and the prospects for political stability.  There is no doubt that the current situation in the MENA region is a matter of great concern for the stability of the entire continent and that the fight against terrorism is one of the most important challenges of our time. In particular, the escalation of violence in recent days in Tunisia should call on the European Union to pay greater attention to the Maghreb country, which has best been able to cope with the democratic transition of the Arab Spring.  I supported the call for the EU and the Member States to insist on the security and stability of the MENA region and I welcome the allocation of EUR 1 billion in humanitarian aid to the populations of Syria and Iraq occupied by the Islamic State. I would like to stress the importance of launching a European programme to support women and girls who are victims of sexual violence in the conflict zones of the MENA region, and I hope that agreements will be developed for cultural cooperation and for the creation of a Euro-Mediterranean Erasmus programme.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Peillon report given that it sends a clear message on key action points for EU policy in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA). The spate of terrorist attacks that have taken place over the past year and that are directly linked to the region show the need to prioritise the fight against terrorist groups as well as to support democratic reform. Decades of war in the MENA region have taught us that repression and lack of inclusivity are prime breeding grounds for terrorism and should be tackled head on. I also agree the Commission needs to take strong and structural measures to address the problem of young people leaving the EU to fight for terrorist organisations in Syria and Iraq. I furthermore concur with the report’s view on the merits of negotiations with Iran over its nuclear programme which, if successful, would constitute an historic achievement in advancing peace and stability. I am therefore deeply disappointed that groups on the far right want to see these negotiations fail, and would rather see tensions and mutual distrust continue instead.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The rise of radical Islam, particularly the Islamic State, in the Middle East and North Africa, has been a direct, predictable and catastrophic consequence of Western interventionism over the past 15 years. Under Atlanticist control, the European Union has helped to undo stable regimes, albeit unquestionably authoritarian ones, to systematically leave peoples plagued by tribalism and the emergence of terrorist movements.  The Peillon report, in its security aspects, makes no mention of the causes of a situation whose consequences now weigh on all citizens of the Member States of the European Union and draws no lessons from what has clearly unleashed the terrorist threat in recent years. Far from giving Member States the means to defend themselves against this threat, this report intends once again to entrust this role to the European Union, without any questioning, nor strategic, nor diplomatic, nor moral, nor ideological.  For all its reasons, I objected to this text.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I and my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats group voted in favour of this report. This report urges the Commission to work with countries in the MENA region, to address the problem of young European people leaving the EU to go and fight on behalf of terrorist organisations in Syria and Iraq.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on security challenges in the Middle East and the North African region and prospects for political stability. I believe that the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the increasing tensions in the entire region of the Middle East and North Africa are key factors for destabilising the region, and a strategy for resolving conflicts needs to be established and a legitimate and credible basis for inclusive dialogue with the various countries concerned needs to be established. This report seeks to restore peace by taking advantage of the European Union's influence in the region. The report aims to address threats and ensure the security situation, strengthen the overall strategy for democracy and human rights and strengthen cooperation for economic development.  I believe that these steps can help the Union restore stability and peace in the region.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats are concerned about developments in the MENA region and support the EU's review of how the Union can best contribute to the peaceful, stable and safe development of the population in the region. We believe that the European Union should contribute its specific skills to support regional actors in the fight against Daesh, but we do not believe that the EUROPEAN Union should be called upon to put together a genuine European defence. We support the report but have reservations about the wording in paragraph 1.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. The adopted Resolution supports a militaristic stance on conflict resolution. It is quite clear in this Resolution that the EU's security priorities in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability are not based on the promotion of human rights in this region, but on a utilitarian view of how the EU can capitalize on economic gain and expand its geostrategic influence. This report does not seek to develop a logic by which the EU can contribute to the dialogue and development of human rights in the region, but to find a way in which the EU can leverage and use its support as an international player to promote its interests.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorse this report with regard to the EU exerting a positive influence on the MENA countries, not only on the basis of economic cooperation but also through political and strategic partnerships. It is clear that the EU’s aid to MENA states has been fragmented and slow-paced, which has allowed the interference of terrorist groups even in Tunisia, a country with an exceptional record of democratic reform. Thus, it is of paramount importance to combat ISIS and other terrorist organisations by stepping up pressure on authoritarian regimes and developing cooperation with parties in the region.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability, as the security of these areas is of strategic importance for the European Union. A comprehensive approach and coordinated measures need to focus on addressing the growing underlying problems that are under threat to global stability. In this context, the European Union has the preconditions to become a mediator in establishing a strategic political dialogue, but this needs to be done with one voice. Terrorist organisations are further exacerbating an already complicated situation that is also affected by the financing of international terrorism. In the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, further efforts are needed by the European Union, but also by a whole international community, to prevent cruel torture and strengthen respect for human rights, and to advance democratic principles in the form of resolving political instability.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the future security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa. Indeed, the rapporteur never takes into account the past experiences of European Union diplomacy. Mr Peillon does not propose to change the Union's foreign policy, even though it is at the root of many disasters and diplomatic tensions, particularly with Russia.  Mr. Peillon is also the champion of interference, the pinnacle of the globalist and Europeanist ideology stemming from the distortion of human rights. Each time, the policy initiated by the proponents of this ideology has led to more instability than prosperity for third countries. This report condemns the violation of the sovereignty of the Middle Eastern States, which I would like to strongly oppose, considering that they represent partners, not countries to guide.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Vincent Peillon's report on the security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospect of political stability. Over the past several months, the situation in these countries has continued to deteriorate, largely due to fanatical Daesh terrorists. The report also welcomes the participation of some Member States in the international coalition against terrorist groups. It also calls on the Union to affirm its commitment to all stages of the region's economic development. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability. The destabilization of the region caused by conflicts in Syria, Yemen, Libya and Iraq has seriously deteriorated the living conditions of the population and threatens the security of neighbouring countries. In the face of this situation, the European Union must increase the pressure on authoritarian regimes and remain permanently present in order to establish a dialogue for the long-term stabilisation of the region, based on the principles of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the security situation in North Africa and the Middle East is like a powder keg that must be defused as soon as possible, I consider the content of this report to be wrong. Taking in more refugees and repeatedly stressing Europe's complicity will not help to build stable structures in the region.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report. The conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the increase in tensions in the Middle East and North Africa region (MENA region) are major sources of destabilisation in that region and eu action in that region needs to be reviewed. Action must be taken in the light of the consequences of the Arab uprisings for the countries concerned, the new and complex situation that has arisen and the imperative need to fight ISIL/Da'esh and other terrorist organisations. The EU and its Member States are invited to address the root causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation throughout the MENA region through a holistic and ambitious approach.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability. This report is a typical example of a European Union that curses the consequences of phenomena which it cherishes. Indeed, while the report is rightly concerned about the destabilization in the Middle East created by the conflicts in Syria, Iraq or Libya, the real causes of this situation , such as Western interventions in these countries - are never mentioned. Security issues are once again used as a pretext to increase the EU's prerogatives to the detriment of Member States.  Thus, the report "expresses its full support for the implementation of concrete actions by the Union within the framework of a strong PSDC to promote stability and security in the MENA countries", or "invites the Member States of the Union to pool their resources, to strengthen the existing arrangements (Frontex, Eurosur)". The text calls for the integration of MOAN countries into the common economic area and visa liberalisation. The aim seems to be the eventual accession of these countries to the EU.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. While he is rightly concerned about the progress of the Islamic State in Syria, Libya and Iraq, at no time does he recognise Europe's responsibility for destabilizing these three countries. Worse, he is asking Bashar al-Assad to "account" when he is one of our last shields against the deadly madness of the Islamic State. On the other hand, this report calls on the EU to establish a genuine foreign policy and thus infringes on the sovereignty of the Member States. Finally, he makes the mistake of criticizing Egypt when this great state has engaged in a merciless struggle against the Islamic State, and should be seen as a major ally.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported this report because it takes into account all the region's major problems and offers hope for a peaceful solution to the most important security problems in the Middle East and North Africa. The focus has been primarily on the fight against ISIS and other extremist groups and support for the political transition in Tunisia and for the development of civil society. The report also raises the issue of ending the Syrian civil war and ensuring the peaceful nature of Iran's nuclear programme in exchange for reintegration into the international community.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report says that the absence of democracy is one of the root causes of the region's instability. The answer to this challenge therefore goes through a multidimensional approach. In this regard, it underlines the importance of the EU continuing to support civil society organisations and calls on the Commission to create a Euro-Mediterranean Erasmus programme. Poverty and inequalities are two other causes of current instability. That is why the EU is encouraged to establish free trade zones with certain countries in the region and to speed up procedures for sending financial assistance to countries in a precarious financial situation. Regarding the Syrian crisis, the report supports the actions of Member States participating in the international coalition against IS and notes the allocation of one billion euros to the EU strategy for Syria and Iraq, including 400 million humanitarian aid. By agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because from a securitarian, interferenceian and neocolonial approach it believes that the European Union must increase, through all available instruments, including military instruments, its influence in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, in order to expand 'European values' and safeguard its values and interests, such as, among others, the defence of its energy security. This report by a French Socialist MP insists on the military approach to conflict resolution, even celebrating the bombing of the military coalition against IS. It is also fully interference in the countries of the region, as it calls for pressure on these countries to implement liberal economic reforms and accept new free trade agreements with the EU. I am convinced that the relationship with our neighbours cannot focus on the repression of migrants with aberrant instruments such as Frontex or the promotion of asymmetric economic relations. On the contrary, we will only have real security without being unseated, unstabilized and, above all, without an unequal economy and trade. This is quite the opposite of what this report contains, so I have not hesitated to vote against it.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in favour, since we really welcome the fact that the report calls on the European Union for taking the responsibility to fight against terrorism, but we oppose any recommendation for a common defence. We fully support the fight against terrorism!

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ MeP Vincent Peillon's report proposes guidelines and actions that the European Union should take to address fundamental problems in the Middle East and North Africa, and calls for unity between the Union and international institutions in implementing a common foreign policy.     Along with economic and political instability and numerous conflicts, the big problem is violations of human rights and freedoms and a humanitarian situation that is constantly deteriorating. In addition to political interventions, dialogue with civil societies, fostering cultural and interreligical cooperation is needed to raise awareness of the seriousness of the problem and find solutions. I supported the Report, which calls for greater involvement and a more serious role for the Union in addressing the situation in the Middle East and North Africa. In particular, I welcome the view that economic and social development is closely linked to strengthening democracy and justice and is necessary to achieve long-term stability.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, even though I was against the amendment that says that all migrants are potential terrorists. This cannot be said of people who are fleeing war themselves.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – Tensions in the MENA also threaten the security and stability of the European Union. Geopolitical tensions, acts of terrorism by the Islamic State and other operating terrorist groups in Africa, civil wars, dictatorial regimes, along with ethnic and religious divisions, the suppression of human rights and deepening poverty, are putting pressure on the populations, who will increasingly try to reach EU countries in all but one way. In doing so, the risk of undesirable persons entering the Member States of the Union increases, which threatens the safety of our citizens and, of course, increases the costs for Member States to protect their territories and to solve migrant-related problems. The European Union and its Member States must therefore use all legitimate and diplomatic means to calm the situation. Tensions need to be addressed as a matter of priority in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa themselves. Without the establishment of democratic regimes, it is not possible to solve the economic and social problems of these countries, quite the contrary. Through democratic change, the road to poverty eradication leads.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and on the prospects for political stability, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that this Resolution firmly opposes the use of drones in extrajudicial and extraterritorial killings of terror suspects, and demands a ban on the use of drones for this purpose.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text of risky diplomacy. It highlights the EU's interference in this geographical area, which goes against our principles. The real question is why we have come to this point in this part of the world.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report strongly condemns the continuing violations of the right to freedom of religion, conscience and thought in the Middle East and North Africa. I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of this document, because I believe it is necessary to stimulate a constructive dialogue, defining the conditions under which security and stability within the area in question are adequately guaranteed.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Peillon report is part of a context of great instability and upheaval in geopolitical balances in the Middle East and North Africa. Based on the alarming observation of the political weight of the European Union inversely proportional to its economic weight, the text provides essential elements for strengthening the EU and its values in a arc of close crises.  To achieve this objective, the report strengthens multilateral relations with regional partners, as well as bilateral relations through high-level political representation provided by the foreign ministers of member states. Added to this political dimension is the necessary cooperation in the fields of security, education and culture - without neglecting the urgent need for in-depth dialogue with civil societies, and the commitment of our democratic values and respect for human rights. I voted for this report, as it carries the imperative of the EU's political will for now missing on the political and international scene - while drawing the lines of strength of a stabilizing presence in the South of its close foreigner.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I was unable to support the motion for a resolution. The joint persecution of ISIS and the creation of a common foreign policy in this regard would be desirable, but I strongly reject the resulting uncontrolled migration and the formation of an EU army.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Despite some criticism of past policies and renewed political, economic and social approaches, Vincent Peillon's report remains stuck in the same rut, maintaining EU security and defence policy modelled on the us-US (and NATO) foreign policy model, with military solutions that are not even operational. , as the strategy against Daesh remains hesitant and led largely by coalitions with questionable reliability. It is a resolute war that must be waged against Daesh, under the auspices of the United Nations, with all the countries convinced that this organization represents the threat of a new denominational state in one of the regions where theocracy is multiplying.  The report supports strengthening free trade agreements as a solution to political instability in the Middle East and North Africa. The right has come to the final touch by welcoming the military strikes carried out by the international coalition and adding its concerns for the defence of the "interests of the Union", de facto at the expense of human rights, all to defend a "true common defence".  I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Peillon report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa does not advocate any change in foreign policy on the part of the EU. While the consequences of European diplomacy in the Middle East are disastrous and it is fundamental to change course, the Peillon report does not propose any change in foreign policy. This report, in addition to being a pure product of globalist thinking, proposes to follow the solution of interference that brings more instability than prosperity. This report is a typical demonstration of the EU's risky diplomacy in the Middle East by systematically violating the sovereignty of states.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability.  The European Union must take strong, one-key measures on the security and political stability issues affecting the COUNTRIES of MENA in the fight against terrorism and against the serious human rights violations that occur in these areas, which have long been massacred by armed conflicts. Only a united Europe with a genuine common foreign policy can make its contribution to the stabilisation of the region by strengthening security measures, strengthening the overall strategy for democracy and economic development of those countries, without which a lasting peace cannot be adportd.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Rising tensions in the Middle East and North Africa (MOAN) are having disastrous consequences for the stability of the entire region. These developments pose serious risks to the security of EU citizens and call for a concerted response from all Member States. This response must be based on three axes. Firstly, it seems to me fundamental that the Union should have a genuine common European defence, capable of responding quickly and effectively to the various crises at its borders. Second, democratic consolidation, respect for fundamental rights and support for civil society within MENA countries are key factors in stabilizing the region in the long term. Finally, deepening economic cooperation is an important vehicle for reducing inequality, and would reduce the risk of radicalisation and withdrawal, especially among young people, by promoting social progress. I support a coordinated implementation of these three aspects of our foreign policy, which will ultimately make the region safer and more sustainable in the future.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tensions in the MENA region are increasing sharply and the geopolitical situation is evolving rapidly and dramatically, bringing a number of threats and risks to the security of EU citizens and interests.  Among the many serious violations of fundamental human rights and the principles of democratic and rule of law, I would highlight the cleansing, which mainly victims of ethnic and religious minorities. Women, children and even toddlers are commonly among the innocent victims of the civilian population. I therefore consider it a priority to tackle the humanitarian crisis, which is closely linked to the problems with refugees. In parallel, however, development programmes need to be prepared to help address the devastating economic and social consequences of the conflict, particularly in Iraq and Syria.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this overall consensual report which covers the most relevant topics related to the Middle East and North Africa region, such as the fight against ISIS and other extremist groups, the need for the EU to step up support for the political transition in Tunisia, support the development of civil societies in those countries, and the need for an inclusive security environment which takes into account legitimate concerns of all sides. I also support the balance struck in the report on the Israel-Palestine issue and the recommendations calling also for a political, peaceful transition to put an end to the civil war in Syria (but Assad cannot be part of Syria’s future). Having said that, however, I did not support any references to abortion or ‘sexual and reproductive and health-care services’, as I think that this is strictly within the national competences of each country.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to point out that the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the escalation of tensions in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region are important sources of destabilization in this region.  I am in favour of this report and support the need to review the European Union's action in the Middle East and North Africa region in the light of the effects of Arab uprisings in the affected countries, the new and complex situation thus created and the imperative need to fight the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) and other terrorist organisations. I would remind you that in the past EU aid to the countries of the Middle East and North Africa has been overly fragmented and too slow to be able to adapt to the political and economic needs of the countries concerned, thereby compromising the EU's ability to play an important role in the region.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability is concerned about the destabilization of the Middle East caused by ongoing conflicts in the region. Yet it never addresses the root causes of this destabilization, namely Western - and self-interested - interventions in Iraq and Libya.  The solutions put forward by this text are only in line with a dramatic inflation of the powers and competences of the European Union at the expense of the diplomacy and defence of each Member State.  Rather than seeing Egypt as a necessary and effective partner in the fight against terrorism, we are trying here to interfere in its affairs and denounce the way in which the country treats the Islamist threat: yet another evidence of the EU's unbearable political interference under "moral" and "humanitarian" under-coverage, which, when it leads to military interventions, is precisely the cause of the region's chronic instability.  Federalist logic stripping Member States of their diplomatic prerogatives, political interference and disrespect for sovereign states, all of which explain my vote in opposition to this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which urges the Commission to address structurally, together with the countries in the MENA region, the problem of young people leaving the EU to fight for terrorist organisations in Syria and Iraq.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability. Indeed, this report, which is put to the vote of the European Parliament, calls on the Member States of the Union to redouble their efforts to welcome asylum seekers and to deal with the files already tabled without delay. For my part, I believe that it would be preferable if secure camps, under the aegis of the United Nations, could accommodate people fleeing conflict, close to their countries of origin, so that they do not risk their lives trying to cross the Mediterranean, are not handed over to unscrupulous smugglers and do not end up in slums in Europe.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that no responsible political leader now takes lightly the political problems of the countries of the Middle East and North Africa. Until, a few years ago, we thought that the manifestations of religious fanaticism would fade over time, we can now see that the crisis is only escalating. And for the EU, it is vital that this crisis is over. It is vital that there is political stability in the region, that the migration of people stops, that the struggle of cultures does not strike at our place. Like it or not, this requires concrete and strong steps. At the economic, ideological and even military level. Europe must stand up for its values and not stand by and watch a world burn escalate. It must be said that we will not tolerate persecution of Christians, enough of religious fanaticism! Because of temporary economic interests, we do not risk the future of our continent – we also owe so much responsibility to the peoples of the Middle East. And we must treat the security issue with maximum discipline.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that will address the root causes of the rapidly deteriorating situations across the Middle East and North Africa region.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the Peillon report contained some positive aspects – namely its opposition to migrant refoulement, its condemnation of drone use, its call to aid in the reconstruction of Kobane and reiteration of the EU position on Palestine – ultimately the drawbacks of the report were too numerous to support. Repeated calls for common European defence, security and foreign policies, support for military intervention in the MENA region, reinforcement of the roles of Europol and FRONTEX and calls for the widespread introduction of Passenger Name Records make the report impossible to support and therefore I voted against it.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it looks very fairly and complexly at the events and changes in the Middle East and north Africa. It is very important for the EU to adapt and respond to these new challenges in a coordinated and integrative way, which contains both the direct fight against terrorism and the causes of this radicalisation. I think it is extremely important to try to understand the causes of this radicalisation and to help combat these causes.  In this respect, the states of the region must be helped and supported in order to stabilise themselves both politically and economically. At the level of security, authorities must be assisted and supported in the development of counter-terrorism capacity. Without a holistic approach, all these threats to EU security cannot be combated.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it does not provide sufficient resources to combat the catastrophic situation in the Middle East and North Africa. Numerous failed states, the advance of Islamist fundamentalists, the systematic destruction of millennia-old cultural assets and, with it, mass emigration from these areas should make us aware that we can only change the situation for the better with a massive use of resources and not with fine words.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Conflicts in Syria, Yemen, Iraq and Libya and rising tensions in the Middle East and North Africa region are destabilising the situation both in the region and as a threat to European security. The EU must make its activities in the region more effective, review its neighbourhood policy programme, increase the fight against terrorism, contribute to the success of peace talks and continue to provide humanitarian aid and seek solutions to the situation of refugees.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa region and the prospects for political stability as I believe it is necessary to address threats and address the security situation, strengthen the global strategy for democracy and human rights and deepen cooperation for economic development. Firstly, I am convinced that the lack of democracy is one of the fundamental causes of political instability in the region and that respect for human rights and fundamental democratic principles is the main long-term protection against the chronic instability of the countries of the MENA region. Furthermore, I believe that balanced actions must be taken, within the framework of a holistic and ambitious approach to democracy, in order to combine security policy with human rights policy; I stress the importance of strengthening long-term stability in the MENA region through the EU's continued support for civil society. Finally, in order to achieve political stability, I would stress that we need socio-economic development, the strengthening of democracy and justice, as well as cooperation in the fight against corruption in the MENA countries.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Peillon has explained very well the actions that the EU and its Member States must take to ensure that the economic aid that is provided to the MENA countries is not wasted. The need to speak with one voice is a matter that needs to be resolved as soon as possible. We cannot afford the luxury of being divided internationally, especially now that neighbouring countries are going through wars and the terrorist threat is very real in our own home too.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the rising tensions in the Middle East and North Africa, the European Parliament calls on the EU and the Member States to address the root causes of the current situation across the Middle East and North Africa region as part of a comprehensive and ambitious approach. The consequences of these conflicts are devastating to the security of the region and permanently damage political and economic development, critical infrastructure and demographic cohesion, and pose serious risks to the security of Europe and its citizens. Furthermore, they trigger serious humanitarian crises that are responsible for displacement of large numbers of populations, so it is necessary to address the root causes so that the situation does not deteriorate even further and achieve economic and social development in order to achieve political stability.  While this document highlights the need to promote women's rights and gender equality, I was unable to support its final content, as Amendment Number 3 supported the financing of abortions of raped women with EU money. I believe that the EU should focus on detecting the causes and preventing such horrific crimes, rather than addressing the consequences in this way.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability is concerned about the destabilization of the Middle East caused by ongoing conflicts in the region. Yet it never addresses the root causes of this destabilization, namely Western - and self-interested - interventions in Iraq and Libya. The solutions put forward by this text are only in line with a dramatic inflation of the powers and competences of the European Union at the expense of the diplomacy and defence of each Member State.  Rather than seeing Egypt as a necessary and effective partner in the fight against terrorism, we are trying here to interfere in its affairs and denounce the way in which the country treats the Islamist threat: yet another evidence of the EU's unbearable political interference under "moral" and "humanitarian" under-coverage, which, when it leads to military interventions, is precisely the cause of the region's chronic instability.  Federalist logic stripping Member States of their diplomatic prerogatives, political interference and disrespect for sovereign states, all of which explain my vote in opposition to this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and rising tensions in the Middle East and North Africa are major sources of instability in the region. Taking into account the merger of Middle Eastern and Sahel counter-terrorism hotspots and the proximity of these hotspots to the sensitive Horn of Africa area. The consequences of such a situation could be devastating for the security of the entire region, as they would permanently damage political and economic development, critical infrastructure and demographic cohesion in the region. Such a situation poses serious risks to Europe's security, its citizens and interests. Of particular concern is the recorded high number of civilian casualties and acts of terrorism against them, and violations of human rights and humanitarian law are serious, especially with regard to ethnic and religious minorities. These conflicts are causing serious humanitarian crises that are responsible for the displacement of large populations and extremely difficult living conditions for refugees and the population of the countries that have accepted them.  Given that there are persistent obstacles to finding a coherent conflict resolution strategy and establishing multi-faceted dialogues with credible and reliable actors, I support the adoption of this revolution, and I join calls on the Union to contribute concretely to finding adequate answers to this situation and to partner with countries from the region that are not in its immediate neighbourhood.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report and I welcome the fact that we have addressed this issue here today. The security situation in the Middle East and North Africa region is a current priority for European policy, as developments in the region bordering Europe have a direct impact on European countries. These are, in particular, key threats to Europe, such as high and unregulated illegal immigration and terrorism. Today, when we look at the situation in the region, we see that there is a real risk of a broad conflict between the Sunni and Shiite countries of the region, which we must try to prevent, because it would lead to a further increase in suffering and further movement of refugees exiled from their homes. Finally, I would like to commend the role of those countries in the region that have joined the international coalition that is trying to counter the barbaric activities of the so-called Islamic State.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of increasing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa and growing political and social instability in these regions, the European Parliament adopted an initiative report on security challenges and prospects for political stability in these regions. I voted in favour of this text. It is important to identify possible actions to be taken and to encourage Member States to cooperate in order to help stabilise the political, economic and social stabilisation of these regions.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa (MOAN), for which Vincent Peillon is rapporteur, makes an alarming observation of the situation in the region, at war with the Islamic State group and hit by acts of terrorism. This resolution, which I fully support, calls on the European Union to strengthen its political support for this region, which is now under threat, when a wind of freedom had spread there during the Arab Spring. Strengthen its anchorage with an increased presence of its representatives, organize summits more frequently with the Arab League, establish better cooperation in many areas (prevention of radicalisation, culture, education, security), dialogue with civil society, defending human rights and women's rights are all challenges that the European Union must meet. It must now speak with one voice in order to exist diplomatically and become a major political player. This report envisages further and strengthening the Union's cooperation with the MENA countries and proposes a new paradigm: that of genuine political cooperation that goes beyond economic issues alone.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the stability and security of the Middle East and North Africa region are fundamental to the security of the EU. Countries in the region should refrain from exporting arms and terrorism to neighbouring countries, as this could further destabilise the situation in that area.  In addition, I strongly advocate the establishment of a special programme for the support and rehabilitation of women and young people who are victims of sexual violence and slavery in conflict zones, including In Syria and Iraq. To this end, I support the international campaign against ISIL and welcome the commitment made by coalition partners to work together within the framework of a common strategy.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament calls on the European Union to establish a clear and long-term strategic line for its security action in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. Conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya, as well as heightned tensions in the Middle East and North Africa, are an important source of destabilization for the region. The consequences of the Arab uprisings in the countries concerned, as well as the complexity of the new situation and the imperative need to fight the Islamic State group and other terrorist organisations, require a review of the Union's action. The European Union must now speak with one voice in order to exist diplomatically and become a major political player in this region.  The Middle East and North Africa are experiencing a geopolitical upheaval that could profoundly and unpredictably alter regional balances. The stability and security of the MENA region are fundamental not only for security, but also for the defence of the political and democratic values of the European Union. The European Parliament wanted to be ambitious and proposed a new paradigm: that of genuine political cooperation that goes beyond economic issues alone.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The absence of democracy is one of the root causes of the instability of this region. The answer goes through a multidimensional approach. In this regard, it underlines the importance of the EU continuing to support civil society organisations and calls on the Commission to create a Euro-Mediterranean Erasmus programme.  Poverty and inequality are other causes of current instability. The report calls for more importance and encourages the EU to establish free trade zones and speed up procedures for sending financial aid.  With regard to the Syrian crisis, the report supports the actions of Member States participating in the international coalition against IS and stresses the importance of EU Member States increasing their efforts to accommodate asylum seekers. Egypt is asked to respect human rights and political freedoms. In relation to Iran, progress is being made in the negotiation on the nuclear program. In the case of Israel and Palestine, Parliament supports a new round of talks and expresses concern at the expansion of settlements and the serious humanitarian situation in Gaza.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls on the European Union and its Member States to address the root causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation in the MENA region through a comprehensive and ambitious approach, which supports the international campaign against the Islamic State group and welcomes the commitment of the coalition partners to work together according to a common strategy. The text of the report also welcomes the allocation of EUR 1 billion under the EU strategy entitled 'Elements relating to an EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq and for the threat posed by Daesh', of which 400 million is directly spent on humanitarian aid.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a context of deep crisis and instability such as today's crisis in the North African region and the Near East, Europe is called upon to address the root causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation in these areas. While the report voted on in AFET openly condemns the continuing violations of the right to freedom of religion and, on the other hand, it insists on the importance of the energy issue in the Mediterranean, as a possible way to stimulate regional cooperation, promote its stability and guarantee environmental integrity. The European Union cannot confine itself to a role of mere spectator, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. The adopted Resolution supports a militaristic stance on conflict resolution. It is quite clear in this Resolution that the EU's security priorities in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability are not based on the promotion of human rights in this region, but on a utilitarian view of how the EU can capitalize on economic gain and expand its geostrategic influence. This report does not seek to develop a logic by which the EU can contribute to the dialogue and development of human rights in the region, but to find a way in which the EU can leverage and use its support as an international player to promote its interests.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the document. The document mentions a number of tools for resolving the situation in the area of security or migration. It also proposes a number of necessary diplomatic and security steps. I appreciate the support for the Kurdish regional government. Overall, it is under-emphatic, using insufficient tools to solve problems in conflict regions, resulting in migratory waves. These are only dealt with by the Member States when their problem affects them on their own territory. The document also places too much emphasis on human rights policy, which has been ineffective for a long time in relation to the Countries of the Middle East and North Africa. I explicitly reject the implementation of abortions as a way of dealing with women who have been subjected to sexual violence.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current conflicts of war in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya are destabilising the Middle East region, damaging the political and economic development of the region, undermining demographic cohesion and also causing a humanitarian, economic and social crisis for the peoples of these states. The problems of the Middle East have also become problems for the whole EU. Thousands of refugees are migrating to the EU, and we are not going to cope with this onslaught. Stability and security in the Middle East region are also threatened daily by terrorist organisations and Islamic State supporters. That is why EU leaders must urgently negotiate with the UN and other major powers to fight terrorist organisations and the Islamic State, so that the situation in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya is stabilized as soon as possible, so that the people of those states do not have to leave their homelands in order to save their own lives, even at the cost of losing their lives in the Mediterranean. The MENA region is particularly affected by poverty and major disparities, and only economic and social development will bring stability to these regions after the end of the war conflicts.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this comprehensive report on the situation in the MENA region (Middle East and North Africa). Especially the emphasis on vulnerable communities, in particular religious and ethnic minorities, is to be welcomed.  I would like to use this occasion once again to demonstrate a basic fact in today’s world: societies that treat their minorities with respect and appreciation tend to flourish on societal, cultural, political, security and economic levels. It is a pity that this dynamic only becomes clear when the opposite is happening, that is when societies collapse and minorities become the first victims of exploitation, persecution and inhumane treatment.  It is therefore high time for the European Union and other international actors to be conscious of this fact, and to work both inside and outside the Union on achieving inclusive, cohesive and robust societies that are less prone to become victims of disintegration, terrorism and absolute despair, as is the case now in many countries in the MENA region.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability, as the conflicts taking place are sources of instability in the region and at the same time a threat to security. It is necessary to protect human rights, especially the rights of minorities, both ethnic and religious, to prevent the increase in civilian casualties, to prevent the displacement of the population. For all this, it is necessary to develop strategic and global policy and promote democratic values.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it urges the Commission to address structurally, together with the countries in the MENA region, the problem of young people leaving the EU to fight for terrorist organisations in Syria and Iraq.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The political stability of the region cannot be achieved in the economic interest of the powerful.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a resolution because it gives a complete and comprehensive picture of all the challenges that I believe the EU should play a more meaningful and active role than before in promoting the Middle East peace process.  I believe that the activism and determination of High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini in this area should be welcomed, for which we must give all the support we can get from the EP. When assessing this issue, I have kept in mind that, in addition to the immediate geographical neighbourhood, this is also about a direct European interest, the external and internal stability of the EU, through the wave of refugees and terrorism. As a key issue for the security of the region, I have considered and agree with the objectives set out in point 11 of the resolution in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, but I would have welcomed the EP's more emphasis on the fact that a two-state solution, including the settlement of the status of Jerusalem, can only be reached through a mutually satisfactory agreement resulting from direct negotiations between the two parties, and that the EU can only help to achieve this through impartial political means.  In addition, I consider it a useful element of the decision to address, in addition to security and terrorism-related challenges, the potential room for manoeconomy of the EU in the region in terms of promoting human and democratic rights and economic development.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a comprehensive report which identifies many of the problems that are of strategic interest to the EU and its Member States. The destabilisation of the entire region poses grave threats to EU Member States and it is vital that governments work together to pursue policies that take account of our mutual interests in the region. As thousands of EU citizens travel to Iraq and Syria to fight with ISIS it is more important than ever to find joint solutions to the threat of terrorism that they pose back home, sharing intelligence and information. I am particularly pleased that the report refers to the introduction of a European Passenger Name Record, which would make it easier to track the movements of foreign fighters. I would also like to take this opportunity to welcome the references to the refugee and IDP crisis facing the Middle East, particularly the burden being placed upon Jordan, Lebanon and the Kurdistan Regional Government. More needs to be done to help them cope with the huge strain that is being placed on their infrastructure and resources – failure to do so risks weakening those entities and putting further migratory pressures on Europe.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Military conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya, terrorist attacks in Tunisia and Egypt, and other internal conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa area pose a threat to the security of the European Union and the Member States. The Arab Spring created the illusion of the possibility of democratization in the corpore of this region of the European neighbourhood. Instead, we are now facing the recrudescence of the terrorist phenomenon and the rise of the Islamic State, propagating extreme violence against every trace of humanity. Military action against the Islamic State is justified and must be supported by the European Union. However, particular attention must also be paid to dialogue between the various factions within those nations. The dialogue must also characterise the relationship between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, Iran and Saudi Arabia, respectively the Iranian nuclear program.  Without the collaboration of all democratic forces in the region, there is no way to conceive of a sustainable democratic development of these states. Cooperation between the EU and these countries in the areas of economy, trade, transport, education, culture, human rights, civil society, including through the Union for the Mediterranean, is likely to contribute to the normalisation of the situation. For these reasons, I support the current report, as the first phase of increased Union involvement in increasing security in this hot region.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the report of my eminent colleague Peillon. The Union and its Member States must address the root causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation in the MENA region with a comprehensive and ambitious approach. I support the international campaign against the Islamic State group and welcome the commitment of coalition partners to work together on a common strategy. The participation of some EU Member States in this international coalition is a good thing, both through military strikes and through logistical, financial and humanitarian participation. However, we call for increased engagement in all areas and stress the need for better coordination of actions taken.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report calling on the EU and its Member States to address the root causes of the rapidly deteriorating situation across the MENA region through a holistic and ambitious approach. Today, one of the main concerns in the region is the terror perpetrated by ISIS. This is why I strongly support the international campaign against ISIL/Daesh and welcome the commitment of the coalition partners to working together under a common strategy. But I also believe that there is no answer to the crisis in the region without a regional dialogue involving all regional stakeholders, in particular the LAS, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and Iran.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I appreciate the initial idea of the report to find a balanced and realistic solution for the relationship between the European Union and the Regions of the Middle East and North Africa, I voted with restraint as the incorporated amendments to the Foreign Affairs Committee instead of balances called for further strengthening of the Union's common security and defence policy and, in general, strengthening the Union's influence in foreign policy-making. I strongly believe that a common security and defence policy must respect the national sovereignty of individual Member States of the Union, and I oppose any further attempts to expand the influence in the Power of the Union in this segment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. In this report, Parliament calls on the EU and its Members to address the root causes of the rapidly deteriorating situation in the entire Middle East and North Africa region. Parliament insists that stability and security in this region are essential to the EU's security. Parliament reiterates once again that freedom of thought, conscience and religion is a fundamental human right and therefore an effective fight against all forms of discrimination against religious minorities is needed. The EU is actively involved in the international campaign against ISIS/Daesh, supports cooperation under the joint strategy and stresses the importance of cooperation with the region in the context of investment, the fight against corruption, direct dialogue with civil society and so on, which is why I supported this report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by Vincent Peillon on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa is a typical example of an EU that curses the consequences of phenomena it cherishes. Indeed, while the report is rightly concerned about the destabilization in the Middle East created by the conflicts in Syria, Iraq or Libya, the real causes of this situation are never mentioned. Despite an initial desire to address security issues and threats posed by IS and Islamist households to the security of citizens of Member States, the rapporteur prefers to take the path of right-of-hommist interference and imperialism rather than addressing the roots of the problem. Security issues are also once again used as a pretext to increase the EU's prerogatives at the expense of national diplomacy and defences. The text is also critical of Egypt, which, rather than being seen as a partner in the fight against Islamist terrorism, is being singled out for its "violations of human rights", which is far from constructive from a diplomatic point of view.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa region and on the prospects for political stability, as growing conflicts and tensions in the Middle East and North Africa are a source of destabilisation of the region, as well as a major risk to European security, to the citizens and interests of the European Union. Events in these regions have led to a humanitarian crisis, with serious human rights violations. I believe that, in the face of these threats, stabilising the region is not only a security issue, but also an economic, political and social one. In these circumstances, the European Union and its Member States must develop policies tailored to these risks and develop strategic cooperation with actors in the region in an attempt to combat threats. Furthermore, I believe that one of the main causes of instability in the region is the lack of democracy, as respect for human rights and democratic principles is the most important protection from recurring threats. Therefore, an important mission of the European Union and its Member States is to support the democratic aspirations of these regions, in particular by disseminating and explaining fundamental civic values.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it. The adopted Resolution supports a militaristic stance on conflict resolution. It is quite clear in this Resolution that the EU's security priorities in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability are not based on the promotion of human rights in this region, but on a utilitarian view of how the EU can capitalize on economic gain and expand its geostrategic influence. This report does not seek to develop a logic by which the EU can contribute to the dialogue and development of human rights in the region, but to find a way in which the EU can leverage and use its support as an international player to promote its interests.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it acknowledges the worrying challenges that the Middle East and North Africa are currently facing. The report expresses concern over the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Libya, Syria, Iraq, Egypt and Yemen, and warns against the threats of an expansion of terrorist activity by ISIS. The report finds that political instability in these regions mainly derives from a lack of democracy, and that the EU must actively offer support in ensuring that democratisation processes continue to develop. The EU must also work in close cooperation and dialogue with MENA countries in order to promote the highest standards of human rights. Cooperation should be also further deepened to foster economic development, considering that a lack thereof is one of the other main factors that contribute to instability.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, Parliament calls on the EU and its Member States to try to identify the root causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation in the Middle East and North Africa. It is necessary to promote stability and security in the area and for all stakeholders to work together in order to reverse the situation. This report highlights the need for respect for human rights and freedom of expression in the region, as well as for boosting investment in the area. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report is based on the EU's share of responsibility for the undeniable failure of policies in North Africa and the Middle East in recent years, with the increase in conflicts (Iraq, Syria, Libya, Yemen, etc.), the spread of jihadist settlements and the security turn of the governments in the region.  This is a good start, but it is the only point of agreement I could find there. Nothing is said about the responsibility of certain Member States or the "allies" of the European Union (United States, Israel, States of the Arabian Peninsula). Conflicts are mainly seen through the religious prism. The fight against terrorism is addressed only from the military perspective and the management of migration flows from a security perspective. Finally, the same economic revenues are always advanced: the establishment of free trade zones, the organisation of brain drain, the exploitation of natural resources... In the midst of a review of the European Neighbourhood Policy, it is therefore a blow of the sword in the water, far from the major challenges that are to be faced in this region. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report talks about the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the escalation of tensions in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region and notes that they are important sources of destabilisation in the Region. It mentions the importance of the confluence between the fronts in the Middle East and the Sahel in the fight against terrorism and the proximity of these fronts to the sensitive zone of the Horn of Africa. It regrets that such consequences of such a situation are disastrous for the security of the whole region. It forgets to point out that this conflict is a direct consequence of the intervention of Nato, the United States and the European Union, which once again set up opposition groups from the moment the governments of those countries ceased to serve the geostrategic interests of imperialism. For this, this is another shameful resolution that deserves only one possible destination: the dustbin of history.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report seeks, on the one hand, to solve the problem in the region with pure stimulation by proposing to take in more refugees in the EU, and, on the other hand, it also contains the proposal for an EU army, which I am convinced rejects. Although I firmly believe that ISIS must be combated at every level and that the situation in the Middle East and North Africa can only be resolved on the ground, I voted against this report because the solutions are the wrong ones.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I was unable to agree with Parliament's resolution on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and on the prospects for political stability. The report seeks to provide a general overview of the tensions and crises in the MENA region and to provide an EU response to these questions. The original draft of the report looked very promising. It included a fair and balanced approach to addressing the various crises in the MENA region. However, after amendments were tabled and accepted by the committee, the report now stands for a comprehensive Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and a greater role for the EU in foreign policy. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in favour, since we really welcome the fact that the report calls on the European Union to take the responsibility to fight against terrorism, but we oppose all recommendations for a common defence policy. We fully support the fight against terrorism!

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution pursues the EU's policy of destabilisation, interference and aggression in the Middle East and North African regions. Resigning from its responsibilities in the situation in those territories, the text continues the line of the so-called "democratisation" of the affected countries.  We know very well what democratisation they are referring to, and how this process translates into the formation and support of authoritarian regimes pursuing the imperialist policy that the US, NATO and the EU have been imposing on the peoples. The path of militarization, warmongering aggression, securitization of relations with those countries continues, trampling on the legitimate will of peoples and their inalienable right to sovereignty. It supports the concept of Europe-fortress, seeking to strengthen mechanisms such as FRONTEX, one of the central pillars of the EU's criminalising, security, exploitative and elitist immigration policy. We voted against it.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, reviewing the European Neighbourhood Policy, so it is really time for that. I could not support this report because I am a Hungarian man, and I would support with my heart and mind the Hungarians from the Southland who live in the present Serbia, as well as hungarians from Transcarpathia who live in the territory of the present Ukraine. Why is there so much silence about Ukraine these days? He was so silent in the suddenly of the European Union. In the framework of the neighbourhood policy, let us already look at all the suffering and deprivation that is going on in Transcarpathia, where Hungarians suffer on both sides, because they are citizens of a country currently at war and are a maximum deremied so-called minority, i.e. an indigenous national community. Look at their fate, that would be the neighbourhood policy.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Russian Federation supplies arms in eastern Ukraine. It has Russian military bases in Armenia, in Moldova, in Ukraine. The Russian Federation funds extremist parties, funds corruption, because a corrupt state is much easier to conquer and much easier to subdue. Everything the Russian Federation is doing is destabilizing democracy in the region, destabilising the region itself, destabilizing the European Union. Let's have a joint and firm action! Let's put an end to this financial involvement because we have a way to do it and speak in the same voice! But his voice isn't weak, don't be weak. Let her be strong! Also, in the Eastern Partnership we have many countries in various levels of development and relations with the Russian Federation. We need to approach them differently, depending on the country and the region.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I agree that a review of the neighbourhood policy was necessary in the face of its obvious failure.
