However, the EU continues its Eurocentric and asymmetrical vision, considering that its model of democracy must be imposed and maintaining a lack of self-criticism over the role of the European Union. Not to mention the incentive approach, rewarding effective, neocolonial-inspired partners. The European Union continues to seek stability based on relations with political elites, We have a common European security policy subordinate to US and NATO policies. Moreover, this report consciously eludes to refer to the conflict in Western Sahara and refers to Morocco as an ally. The Alawite regime is the main recipient of funds from the European Neighbourhood Policy of the European Union, while maintaining the occupation of Western Sahara. No state in the world recognizes Morocco's sovereignty over Western Sahara and the European Union, unfortunately, remains de facto complicit and a collaborator of the Moroccan occupation. That is why, among others, I voted against this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There were some positive aspects in this review of the ENP. It highlighted the importance of women’s rights, gender equality, human rights, cultural diversity, LGBTI rights, rights of minorities, rights of people with disabilities, etc. in the context of the ENP. Furthermore, the review referred to Article 2 of Association Agreements which bases these agreements on respect for human rights. It goes on to say that policies that jeopardise values, such as respect for human rights should not be adopted under the ENP and that the EU cannot compromise its values. I welcome these points. Unfortunately, in practice, we see that the EU’s relationship with Israel continues to jeopardise these values by failing to take action on Israel’s persistent violation of human rights in Palestine. This review calls for a strengthening of a Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for Member States to align their efforts so as to speak with a single voice on issues concerning the Eastern Neighbourhood countries. Sovereignty over Irish foreign policy is of utmost importance to the Irish people and to Sinn Féin. Therefore I abstained on this Review of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report underlines the importance of an EU foreign policy and therefore wishes to extend the competences of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This is an interference in the sovereignty of the Member States with the aim of depriving them of the possibility of conducting an independent foreign policy, subjecting it entirely to that of the Union.  Furthermore, this report extends the Union's "values" to its external partners on the grounds that fundamental universal values, the defence of human rights, equality and human dignity are at the heart of the Union's association agreements. It opens the door to new waves of mass immigration, declaring itself "favourable to increased mobility within the neighbourhood space [...] through visa facilitation and visa liberalisation."  I therefore objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support taxpayers’ money being spent on the European Neighbourhood Policy, and this proposal moves further in the wrong direction. I therefore felt it necessary to vote against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was designed to deepen relations, establish cooperation and strengthen the EU's partnership with neighbouring countries in order to develop a common area of stability, security and prosperity, as underlined in Article 8 TEU. As the neighbourhood is currently constantly changing and less stable and less secure due to the increasing number of old and emerging security challenges, it is also experiencing a greater economic crisis than at the beginning of the ENP.  The EU's revised policy must be based on a comprehensive accountability and a shared commitment to respect the EU's values and principles, including democracy, the rule of law, human rights and effective, accountable and transparent authorities, which is in the public interest of neighbouring countries, as well as the EU's own interests in ensuring stability, security and prosperity. Despite practical difficulties and challenges, the EU must continue to strongly support transition processes in all and any country, democratisation, respect for human rights and the rule of law.  Events in the region since 2004 and in particular over the last few years have shown that the ENP cannot respond adequately and quickly to rapidly changing and complex circumstances. For these reasons, the revision of the ENP must be carried out in order to strengthen it and in accordance with the principle of long-term progress towards a comprehensive and effective EU common foreign and security policy as a whole.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I challenge the will of the technocrats in Brussels to further encroach on the prerogatives of the Member States of the Union, all the more so since the foreign policy that Brussels follows seems to be decided in Washington.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Neighbourhood Policy aims to deepen relations and strengthen partnerships between the European Union and the countries in its neighbourhood. This resolution calls for a review of this policy in order to provide a rapid, flexible and adequate response to situations on the ground, while proposing a strategic vision for the development of relations with neighbouring countries. This resolution, which I approved, also stresses support for democracy, justice reform, good governance and institutional capacity building.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on European Neighbourhood Policy aims to increase the EU's powers in relations with neighbouring EU countries.   This neighbourhood policy is in fact to interfere in the internal affairs of neighbouring EU countries and to dictate to them the necessary reforms for potential and future accession to the Union.  Moreover, it calls for a strengthening of the Defence Europe, which I strongly condemn, since it remains and must remain a national competence, especially since it is a question of facing Russia. We thought the Cold War was over, it's coming back in another form thanks to the EU... Finally, of course, this policy calls for the free movement of people and goods within the neighbourhood area as if the EU already did not have all the difficulties in controlling movement within the Schengen area itself. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kukan report analyses the review of the neighbourhood policy, in many parts it is acceptable, but I believe that all too often third countries that have benefited from substantial European subsidies and facilities, then deliberately disregarded the minimum demands that the EU has always made of them, such as respect for human rights and a greater democratic process, for these reasons I abstained in this vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. The neighbourhood policy is important, and it is also important to provide support to people and organisations working to create and deepen democracy and human rights. However, I am choosing to abstain because, despite good wording in some parts, both of these reports are also woven together with a strengthened common foreign and security policy, which is becoming increasingly militarised and more closely linked to NATO, rather than focusing on mr, development, and partnership. Furthermore, I defend Sweden's nonalignment and believe that it is extremely important that our country can speak with its own voice in the world. I am opposed to the eu's federal great power building. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is necessary to reform the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) in order to establish strong, strategic and lasting partnerships with ENP countries based on the preservation and alignment of EU values and principles with them and the promotion of mutual interests. The Commission should, on the basis of common interests, focus on sectors identified together with its partners in terms of progress and global added value, as well as to progressively expand cooperation based on progress and ambition, in particular to contribute to economic growth and human development, with a particular focus on new generations. Economic reforms must be carried out in conjunction with political reforms and good governance can only be achieved through an open, accountable and transparent decision-making process carried out by democratic institutions. It is also important to build a thriving and active civil society through transformation and democratisation processes involving social partners and the business community. Civil society, local SMEs and other non-state actors should continue to be supported as a driving force in the reform process. In addition, dialogue and partnership between the various civil society actors and sectors in the context of the ENP should be stepped up.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Colleague Eduard Kukan has done a very thorough job and provides a broad summary of the current state of the European Neighbourhood Policy, its objectives and opportunities.  Recent events call for immediate solutions, to intensify the dialogue between the European Union and neighbouring countries, where, as equals, they must be treated according to the needs of countries, joint responsibility with partners should be raised, judicial, economic, social and cultural reforms in partner countries encouraged. Compliance with the principles of democracy and the rule of law and the protection of minorities, the independence of the judiciary in neighbouring countries and the fight against corruption should be continuously monitored. Enhanced regional cooperation, the strengthening of accountability and transparency mechanisms, the urgency of visa liberalisation and the promotion of closer cooperation in the fields of trade, education and culture can help to end conflicts in different regions and promote peace and prosperity within and outside the borders of our partner countries.  I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report of Members, which stresses that enp must remain a single policy, recognising that both eastern and Mediterranean partnerships are crucial. I also agree that the EU needs to provide sufficient funding for the further work of the ENP, and since the Report also accepted a number of important amendments by the S&D Group, it is of sufficient quality to support it on my part as well.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The Kukan report on the review of European Neighbourhood Policy is a dangerous leak forward. It was originally intended for the integration of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe during the enlargement of the European Union to this area. Today, Mrs Mogherini, Vice-President of the European Commission and the Eu's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, is taking this policy to the southern Mediterranean and Ukraine's eastern borders. This EU interference is dangerous and very reckless, given the geopolitical situation of many countries considered by the text. So I voted against Mr Kukan's report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There were some positive aspects in this review of the ENP. It highlighted the importance of women’s rights, gender equality, human rights, cultural diversity, LGBTI rights, rights of minorities, rights of people with disabilities, etc. in the context of the ENP. Furthermore, the review referred to Article 2 of Association Agreements which bases these agreements on respect for human rights. It goes on to say that policies that jeopardise values, such as respect for human rights should not be adopted under the ENP and that the EU cannot compromise its values. I welcome these points. Unfortunately, in practice, we see that the EU’s relationship with Israel continues to jeopardise these values by failing to take action on Israel’s persistent violation of human rights in Palestine. This review calls for a strengthening of a Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for Member States to align their efforts so as to speak with a single voice on issues concerning the Eastern Neighbourhood countries. Sovereignty over Irish foreign policy is of utmost importance to the Irish people and to Sinn Féin. Therefore I abstained on this Review of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we need a review of the European Neighbourhood Policy so that it becomes more solid, political and effective, while maintaining the centrality given to respect for fundamental universal values such as human rights, democracy and the rule of law, which alone can guarantee a real improvement in the living conditions of the citizens of our neighbouring countries.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Kukan Report on the Review of European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) aims to increase the UNION's foreign policy competences: "Considering that the ENP remains a strategic priority of the Union's foreign policy; that the revision of the ENP must be carried out with the aim of strengthening this policy and continuing efforts to achieve a common EU foreign and security policy which is, as a whole, comprehensive and effective."  The European Neighbourhood Policy aims both to increase the Union's projection into its area of influence, to prepare for the accession of new candidate states and to export the Union's "values" without taking into account geopolitical realities.  Opposed to the increase in the Union's foreign policy power, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy because I believe that the Neighbourhood Policy is intended to deepen and enhance the cooperation of partnerships between the European Union and neighbouring countries, with the aim of developing an area of common stability, security and prosperity. In view of the security and stability issues faced by many countries at EU borders, the review of the neighbourhood policy comes to the aid of partner countries, providing support for economic, social transformation and regional cooperation. By reviewing the European Neighbourhood Policy, the European Union practically reiterates support for the sovereignty, territorial integrity and political independence of partner countries and stresses the need for active promotion and aid for the peaceful resolution of conflicts, as well as to contribute to post-conflict reconciliation policies in the EU's neighbourhood. The revised version of this policy must be based on mutual responsibility and a shared commitment to EU values and principles, including democracy, the rule of law, human rights, as a large part of neighbouring territories remain affected by armed or frozen conflicts and crises.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The ENP – European Neighbourhood Policy – consists of 16 countries (for Eastern Europe: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine and Algeria, Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Morocco, Palestine, Syria, Tunisia for the Middle East and North Africa). The new financial instrument for the ENP – in the period 2014-2020 – is the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI), with a budget of EUR 15.4 billion. Tool too expensive and used inconclusively.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. One of the European Union's main priorities is to ensure the safety of its citizens. There have been no more armed conflicts inside Europe's borders for many years. Unfortunately, we cannot say the same about the neighbourhood. We are witnessing great tensions at the Union's borders, both in the North and in the South. The European Neighbourhood Policy is therefore a crucial element in stabilizing and securing neighbouring regions. For this reason, the European Union's strategy needs to be revised and modernised. We cannot stand in the way of the events taking place on our borders. It is about the security of our citizens and stability in those regions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). The Aim of the European Neighbourhood Policy is to deepen relations, strengthen cooperation and strengthen the European Union's partnerships with neighbouring countries. Its ultimate aim is to create a common area of stability, security and prosperity. At the moment, the Union's neighbourhood is particularly unstable and its balances are constantly changing. The number of challenges for the European Neighbourhood Policy is therefore much higher than in the past.  The report has therefore highlighted the need for a review of the ENP, it must become an instrument capable of giving faster responses, it must be more flexible and it must have an ambitious and strategic vision for the development of relations with neighbouring countries. I agree with these considerations and believe that a reformed and effective ENP could help to significantly strengthen the credibility and positioning of the Union's foreign policy, including by increasing European leadership in neighbourhood affairs and in relations with global partners.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There were some positive aspects in this review of the ENP. It highlighted the importance of women’s rights, gender equality, human rights, cultural diversity, LGBTI rights, rights of minorities, rights of people with disabilities, etc. in the context of the ENP. Furthermore, the review referred to Article 2 of Association Agreements which bases these agreements on respect for human rights. It goes on to say that policies that jeopardise values, such as respect for human rights should not be adopted under the ENP and that the EU cannot compromise its values. I welcome these points. Unfortunately, in practice, we see that the EU’s relationship with Israel continues to jeopardise these values by failing to take action on Israel’s persistent violation of human rights in Palestine. This review calls for a strengthening of a Common Foreign and Security Policy. It calls for Member States to align their efforts so as to speak with a single voice on issues concerning the Eastern Neighbourhood countries. Sovereignty over Irish foreign policy is of utmost importance to the Irish people and to Sinn Féin. Therefore I abstained on this Review of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support taxpayers’ money being spent on the European Neighbourhood Policy, as this proposal further highlights the expansionist aims and neo-colonialism ideals of the European Union. I unequivocally voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the Report and voted in favour as I agree with the views expressed on the review of the European Neighbourhood policy, with the exception of the reference to conditionality in relation to, for example, the reform process within the ENP countries. I believe that the revised ENP should also be able to provide a quick, flexible and adequate response to the situation on the ground, whilst also putting forward an ambitious strategic vision for developing relations with the neighbouring countries within both a bilateral and a multilateral framework. The ENP is also an essential part of the EU’s foreign policy and is a substantial part of the EU’s foreign policy credibility and global positioning.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain because this report, while framing the neighbourhood foreign policy in a truly conscious way, highlights, in my opinion, serious doubts when it aims to give a security dimension to the ENP, thus going beyond the limits of the framework for action of both the ENP and the EU, which does not yet have an army or a foreign or security policy that can be said to be common and binding.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 As the neighbourhood region is currently in reclassifications due to the increasing number of long-term and new security challenges and the fact that it is less stable and less secure and is facing a much deeper economic crisis than when the European Neighbourhood Policy was launched, we strongly support the position that the revised policy should be based on mutual accountability and a shared commitment to EU values and principles , including democracy, the rule of law, human rights and the existence of effective and transparent public bodies, and the EU must continue to promote the transition process in all countries as well as democratisation and the rule of law, respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was established to deepen relations and to strengthen cooperation and strengthen the EU's partnerships with neighbouring countries, with a view to developing a common area of stability, security and prosperity. However, in many neighbouring countries, violent conflicts are undermining the development of a genuine and effective multilateral dimension of the ENP. This proposal calls for greater attention to be paid to partnership with companies, differentiation and a 'more for more' approach. Lastly, Parliament called for closer coordination between the ENP and the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is vital to implement the European Neighbourhood Policy. Recent events have shown that greater instability in neighbouring countries also leads to greater difficulties and problems within the Union itself. In a globalised world such as today's, we can no longer turn a blind eye when human rights are violated within a short distance of us and, as a result of armed clashes and civil wars, poverty is increasing and entire populations face extreme living conditions. The European Union has a duty to play a decisive role in its relations with its neighbours in such a way as to encourage a transition to more transparent and correct democratic institutions. Greater stability of our neighbours would also bring economic and social benefits within the Union itself. We need only think of the problem of immigration, which creates so much disorder and disagreement within and between Member States. I therefore believe it is important to increase the efficiency of our neighbourhood policy because, by providing more assistance and incentives, it will be possible to spread respect for fundamental rights and create an area of prosperity, stability and security that will benefit the citizens of the Union and its neighbours.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy has been the framework for bilateral relations with partners east and south of the Union since 2004. Although it was revised in 2011, adjusting to the very different reality that resulted from the Arab Spring, it remained short of challenges and reality. That is why I welcome the new review process which has been initiated by the High Representative and which, through this report, Parliament makes its contribution. As pointed out in the report, the recast of the ENP will have to take into account the impact of foreign policy on the Union's internal policies, such as immigration policy or homeland security. On the other hand, it should have a sufficient degree of flexibility to allow for implementation that cannot be only technical or totally immune to political management and control.  I therefore hope that the concerns presented in this report will be integrated into the development of the new European Neighbourhood Policy

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was established to deepen relations, strengthen cooperation and strengthen the EU's partnerships with neighbouring countries. However, in the past this policy has fulfilled its task with an undifferentiated strategic approach, which has not made sufficient distinctions between the specific situations of the countries concerned.  I believe that the EU, the guardian of universally recognised fundamental values, should reshape the European Neighbourhood Policy by proposing an ambitious and strategic vision for the development of relations with neighbouring countries in a bilateral and multilateral context. To this end, the Union must play a more active role in the peaceful resolution of the ongoing conflicts and must continue to strongly support the transition processes in all countries. Therefore, in the hope of implementing a neighbourhood policy based on sound and lasting partnerships, I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on the importance of the ENP and stresses that the ENP is an essential part of the EU’s foreign policy. It must remain a single policy incorporating the vast range of diplomatic, security and humanitarian instruments. It also stresses the importance of safeguarding the fundamental values of human rights, the rule of law, democracy, freedom, equality and respect for human dignity on which the EU is founded. The report states that it must remain at the core of the revised policy. The Commission must also prepare a clear communication strategy in the ENP countries to increase its presence in the partner countries through social media and audiovisual means. I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I agree that a review of the neighbourhood policy was necessary in the face of its obvious failure. However, the EU continues its Eurocentric and asymmetrical vision, considering that its model of democracy must be imposed and maintaining a lack of self-criticism over the role of the European Union. Not to mention the incentive approach, rewarding effective, neocolonial-inspired partners. The European Union continues to seek stability based on relations with political elites, We have a common European security policy subordinate to US and NATO policies. Moreover, this report consciously eludes to refer to the conflict in Western Sahara and refers to Morocco as an ally. The Alawite regime is the main recipient of funds from the European Neighbourhood Policy of the European Union, while maintaining the occupation of Western Sahara. No state in the world recognizes Morocco's sovereignty over Western Sahara and the European Union, unfortunately, remains de facto complicit and a collaborator of the Moroccan occupation. That is why, among others, I voted against this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report gives the European Parliament’s reaction to the review of the European neighbourhood policy. It welcomes the initiative as timely and necessary and insists that the reviewed ENP must be more politically driven, strategic, flexible/focused/differentiated, and coherent with the EU’s values, principles and interests. It stresses that the ENP needs to remain a single policy, while calling for the appointment of EU Special Representatives for the East and the South dimensions. It also recognizes that while the neighbourhood and enlargement policies are separate, it considers that a membership perspective must be sustained. More so, in this report the Parliament emphasises the ‘need to focus on strengthening and consolidating ... respect for diversity and the rights of minorities, including ... the rights of LGBTI persons.’ Thus, as I agree with the various provisions called for I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The review of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) is particularly necessary because of the growing instability suffered by many countries in the Mediterranean and the Middle East, countries that are our neighbours and valuable partners.  As emphasised in the Kukan report, the EU should promote an active dialogue with all civil society actors, primarily citizens, who are decisive in kicking off and making sustainable those reforms, both economic and political, which guarantee not only economic development but also the full completion of the democratisation process in our neighbourhood countries.  The revision of the ENP must be based on an approach that takes account of the structural differences in these countries, characterised by assistance policies that stimulate employment and growth and thus guarantee better living conditions and levels of education, greater opportunities for the new generations. This will also make it possible to manage migratory phenomena better.  Only through political dialogue with neighbourhood partners and other neighbouring countries will the EU be able to find ambitious solutions to complex challenges such as immigration, the fight against poverty and discrimination, and the protection and promotion of human rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to present the European Parliament's position on the Ongoing review of the European Neighbourhood Policy launched by the European Commission. The European Parliament is clearly in favour of a renewed policy that is more strategic, targeted, flexible and coherent, able to respond adequately and quickly to the needs of neighbouring countries. Given the current economic and security strategic challenges in Europe's southern and eastern neighbourhood, The European Neighbourhood Policy must respond appropriately to fragmented national realities. The security aspect of this policy should also be strengthened while maintaining a budget allocation of two-thirds in favour of the Mediterranean and one-third in favour of the Eastern Partnership.  Considering this balanced report, I voted in favour.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This initiative report makes the right diagnoses of neighbourhood policy. It must be able to adapt to different situations. It cannot be the same in eastern Europe, the southern Mediterranean or the Caucasus. The issues, challenges and crises are not the same.  A more effective neighbourhood policy will therefore have to go through country-by-country-differentiated relations, in order to define and implement more appropriate and therefore more effective partnerships.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution calling for the EU to pursue a strategic, ambitious, forward-looking, coherent and focused Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) with objectives of creating an area of prosperity, stability and security. I believe that the ENP must be more political. Support for democracy, the rule of law, good governance, state consolidation, human rights and fundamental freedoms must be at the heart of the ENP.  Moreover, as the security environment tends to deteriorate in the EU's neighbourhood, we must give ourselves the means to expand the range of crisis management interventions, to assist our neighbours in building appropriate security structures and to promote the joint security initiatives of neighbouring countries.  Finally, the ENP must be part of a global foreign policy context. I am convinced that in the future the Union should provide sufficient funding in line with its strengthened commitment to its neighbourhood, particularly through the re-examination of its external financing instruments.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR is keen to foster strong relations with the countries which border the EU and will continue to work with partners to secure long-term stability and political reforms. But we also believe that under the ENP as it currently operates it is very difficult to deliver a ‘one size fits all’ approach to relations with the EU’s neighbours. The current review must ensure future policy is more effective. It should also consider the policy of less for less with regard to those countries which go into reverse in terms of governance, democracy and human rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as its text stresses the importance of strengthening Member States' political cooperation within the ENP, resulting in the depletion of sovereign rights.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The right-wing majority of this European Parliament reinforces the continuity of the European Neighbourhood Policy, continuing its central nature, the economic expansionof the EU, aggravating conflicts and tensions at its borders. The report calls for the financial strengthening of an instrument promoting the militarisation and securitisation of borders through the Common Foreign and Security Policy and the Common Security and Defence Policy; promoting the submission of neighbouring countries to eu neoliberal policies aimed at imposing political and economic reforms; whereas it favours the creation of free trade areas, which attacks human rights while hypocritically defending them and presenting the Union as an example in its implementation and defence; promoting an EU foreign policy that we do not recognise; promoting the discriminatory and elitist stance of its migration policy by strengthening instruments such as FRONTEX and EUROPOL; which is hostile, in particular Russia, on the basis of the energy policies that are in place. They're plenty of reasons to justify our vote against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy and, in particular, the good report presented by Mr Kukan. The ENP is an important part of the European Union's foreign policy and its potential lies in the ability to use a wide range of instruments in the areas of security, diplomacy, economy, trade, development, defence or humanitarian. The ENP is also crucial for strengthening the credibility of the European Union's foreign policy and our position on the world stage. The fundamental challenge of the ENP must be to bring concrete improvements to the citizens of partner countries. However, it must become more strategic, focused and coherent and politically managed.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against the report. The proposed amendments are not radical and, in my opinion, not decisive. We have been calling for a full review of the ENP for some time.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy, as its text stresses the importance of strengthening Member States' political cooperation within the ENP, resulting in the depletion of sovereign rights.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the review of the European Neighbourhood policy. Very often the EU is too slow in confronting a changing situation and so I welcome this review which takes into account conflicts along the border of the European Union. The ECR is keen to foster strong relations and links with these countries and help secure long-term stability.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report welcomes the initiative of the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy as timely and necessary and insists that the reviewed ENP must be more politically driven, strategic, flexible/focused/differentiated, and coherent with the EU’s values, principles and interests. I welcome the fact that the report takes on board and highlights the social dimension of the ENP, the need to fight against poverty and discrimination, and to promote human and women’s rights. Moreover, I support the review process and I would like to highlight the need to make it more strategic, efficient and flexible, always respecting the core values on which the EU is founded. The ENP should not be a bureaucratic process but a politically-driven one serving the purposes of peace and stability in the neighbourhood but also promoting democracy and the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Kukan report, because it proposes a strategic vision for the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy. The ENP is an instrument of the Union which has great potential, but which must now gain political strength and flexibility to respond to the challenges facing the European Union in its eastern neighbourhood, as well as in the Mediterranean.  The report has the merit of emphasizing a long-term strategic vision, but also an ability to better anticipate crises and manage emergencies. The European Parliament's major contribution to the revision of the ENP is undoubtedly the emphasis on democracy and respect for human rights as a priority in differentiated relations with neighbouring countries. The report also places an important emphasis on regional integration as a tool for stabilizing neighbourhoods, including the role of the Union for the Mediterranean, which, as a forum for dialogue, should enable better ownership of ENP projects. Finally, the visibility and intelligibility of the ENP in both the EU and neighbouring countries are identified as a key objective for the future.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Colleague Eduard Kukan has done a very thorough job and provides a broad summary of the current state, objectives and opportunities of the European Neighbourhood Policy.  Recent events call for immediate solutions, to intensify the dialogue between the European Union and neighbouring countries, where, as equals, they must be treated according to the needs of countries, joint responsibility with partners should be raised, judicial, economic, social and cultural reforms in partner countries encouraged. Compliance with the principles of democracy and the rule of law and the protection of minorities, the independence of the judiciary in neighbouring countries and the fight against corruption should be continuously monitored. Enhanced regional cooperation, the strengthening of accountability and transparency mechanisms, the urgency of visa liberalisation and the promotion of closer cooperation in the fields of trade, education and culture can help to end conflicts in different regions and promote peace and prosperity within and outside the borders of our partner countries.  I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution taking into account the need and importance of reviewing the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), and that the new revised ENP should be able to facilitate a quick and appropriate solution to the real situation. Also because of the scale of the ENP within the EU's foreign policy and its belief in the objectives of the ENP, as well as the permanence among the most important aspects of the revision of the universal fundamental values of human rights, democracy, the rule of law, among others, and the specificity, flexibility and coherence of the revised EU policy.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Kukan's report on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy because I believe that the ENP can be an important political and strategic instrument for creating an area of security and stability from which European citizens and their neighbours can benefit. However, the results of the European Neighbourhood Policy are currently poor: the ENP has not been able to adapt to the changing geo-political situations in the neighbourhood. I therefore believe that we need a restructuring of the ENP which defines the short, medium and long-term objectives and which is ambitious in achieving these objectives.  I fully agree with the need to focus on strengthening democracy and the rule of law, just as we cannot lower our guard on the multiple reports of human rights violations outside eu borders. It is essential that the EU, together with its partners, identify priorities for joint integration in the economic, political, environmental, conflict prevention and migration fields, which has been at the centre of an important debate at EU level in recent months. I am in favour of launching joint programmes for projects involving women, young people and future leaders, which can provide them with appropriate training.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy today because I firmly believe that Europe must adapt this instrument to the new challenges and geopolitical realities, particularly in its eastern dimension.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Kukan report, given that developments we have witnessed over the past years in both our Eastern and Southern neighbourhood impose the need for a thorough review of our neighbourhood policy (ENP). If the EU wants to bring stability and prosperity to its neighbourhood, it should develop a more flexible, strategic and politically driven approach tailored to the needs and contexts of individual countries covered by the ENP.  Given that the lack of freedom, prosperity and human rights have been a main breeding ground for the instability we have witnessed in countries both East and South of Europe, I welcome that the report underscores the importance of enhancing the social dimension of the ENP, including the need to fight against poverty and discrimination, and to promote human and women’s rights – points which were championed by my group.  I welcome the work that is undertaken jointly by the Council and Commission on this revision exercise and hope this report, which enjoys broad support in the European Parliament, will be taken as an important guiding line towards a stronger, more effective and result-oriented ENP.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it. I am opposed to the EU developing relations with other countries utilitarianly, for the sole purpose of defending its interests. Economic nearsightedness cannot determine the action of the EU, the same EU that talks about democratic values and social rights. The EU must be supportive not only in its words, but also in its actions.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report. Whilst in the AFET Committee, this report was amended by a number of Socialist and Democrat amendments and now highlights the social dimension of the ENP and the need to fight against poverty and discrimination and to promote human and women’s rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy because I believe that it is important and necessary to ensure a timely review of the ENP. The revised ENP should ensure the possibility of providing a rapid, flexible and appropriate response to the current situation, as well as a strong strategic vision for the development of relations with neighbouring countries, both bilaterally and multilaterally, in line with the commitment to promote the fundamental values on which the ENP is founded. This report calls on the Commission to focus, on the common interest, on the sectors identified together with its partners, where progress and global added value can be achieved, as well as to progressively expand cooperation based on progress and ambition, in particular to contribute to economic growth and human development, with a particular focus on new generations. The report also stresses that economic reforms must be carried out in conjunction with political reforms and that good governance can only be achieved through an open, accountable and transparent decision-making process carried out by democratic institutions.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats think it is good to have a review of the European Neighbourhood Policy and it is important that it is adapted to the political developments in the surrounding area. With regard to the wording on Russia, we think it is important that the EU underlines at all times the right of countries to choose their own future and that Russia must respect the Minsk agreements and stop destabilising the situation in eastern Ukraine. We think that this could have been underlined in Amendment No 1 to the report.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it. I am opposed to the EU developing relations with other countries utilitarianly, for the sole purpose of defending its interests. Economic nearsightedness cannot determine the action of the EU, the same EU that talks about democratic values and social rights. The EU must be supportive not only in its words, but also in its actions.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am a firm believer that Europe needs stability, security and prosperity as a result of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). Some regions are affected by armed or frozen conflicts and crises which have caused economic, social and political instability in the neighbourhood. The EU should take further action in finding peaceful resolutions for existing conflicts and the ENP must be reshaped to adapt adequately to rapidly changing and challenging circumstances.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Overview of the European Neighbourhood Policy, given the importance and sensitivity of this EU policy created to deepen relations, increase cooperation and strengthen the EU's partnership with neighbouring countries to create areas of common stability, security and prosperity. It is clear that uncertainty, instability and unfavourable socio-economic conditions in neighbouring countries can have a negative impact and reverse democratic developments. Large parts of the neighbourhood are affected by armed conflicts and crises and partner countries must seek to find a peaceful solution to existing conflicts that hinder economic, social and political transformation and regional cooperation, stability and security. The EU should play a more active role in finding a peaceful solution to existing conflicts. The revised European Neighbourhood Policy should be able to offer a swift, flexible and adequate response to the situation on the ground. I agree that the EU's European neighbourhood policy is a key part of EU foreign policy and must remain a single policy, the potential and uniqueness of which are the result of the ability to mobilise a multitude of instruments in the areas of diplomacy, security, defence, the economy, trade, development and humanitarian aid. The European Neighbourhood Policy needs to be reshaped to build strong, strategic and long-lasting partnerships with countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy, which are based on preserving and adhering to EU values and principles and promoting common interests.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy aimed at increasing the UNION's competence in relations with neighbouring non-EU countries.  The rapporteur stresses the importance of an EU foreign policy and therefore wants to extend the powers of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This is an unacceptable interference in the sovereignty of the Member States, which are to be taken away from the possibility of conducting their own foreign policy, or at least that it is subject to the EU. Not content with interfering in the policies of the Member States, the rapporteur also wishes to impose the Union's "values" on its external partners by affirming that fundamental universal values, the defence of human rights, equality and human dignity are at the heart of the Union's association agreements.  This report supports and defends an immigration policy that is completely irrelevant by declaring itself "favourable to increased mobility within the neighbourhood area [...] through visa facilitation and visa liberalisation."

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eduard Kukan's report on the review of European Neighbourhood Policy. The report aims to participate in the commission's ongoing review of the outdated European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) by demanding an ENP that is better adapted to today's challenges, with a clear and ambitious political vision as well as short-, medium- and long-term strategic objectives and priorities. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Indeed, in the face of new challenges in southern and eastern Europe, the European Union must adapt in order to avoid destabilization within its own Member States. Dialogue must intensify between the Union and its neighbouring countries in order to re-establish stable, secure and democratic areas for all populations. While stressing the need for mutual responsibility and a common commitment to the values and principles of the Union, the next steps will have to take a case-by-case approach with neighbouring countries.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The Neighbourhood Policy is an effective means of European foreign policy, which can certainly be applied and implemented more coherently. I am abstaining from this vote because the report identifies the problems, but is reluctant to propose solutions.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) because, while on the one hand it creates multi-level relations and strong interdependence between the EU and neighbouring countries, neighbouring countries are nevertheless treated more as energy suppliers than as real partners. Moreover, limited financial assistance and support for a liberal agenda create an uncertain relationship between the EU and enlargement.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I fully support – and I expressed this in the vote on the Eduard Kukan report – the calls for a review, revision and revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy. The objective of this policy – to develop an area of common stability, security and prosperity – remains as up-to-date as possible, as does the 'more for more' method of financing the Neighbourhood Policy.  However, the growing economic crisis and subsequent armed and political conflicts outside the EU show that the Union should be more dynamically and decisively involved in partnering to support the transition in our southern and eastern neighbours towards democratisation, the rule of law and greater respect for human rights. It would also be necessary to separate neighbourly policies from those of the EU's associated countries and to bear in mind the diversity and specificities of the EU's neighbouring countries, their differences in interests, motivations and different opportunities for change.  I therefore support the report's call for the appointment of high representatives specialising in the EU's eastern and southern foreign policy. Bilateral policies between the EU and the neighbourhood countries should also be coordinated and strengthened, particularly in the areas of security, border protection, the fight against trafficking in human beings and economic crimes. I also support the call for more funding for the Eastern Partnership, the importance of which is sometimes underestimated, and for the evaluation of procedures and the adequacy of spending existing resources on neighbourhood policy.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because the European Neighbourhood Policy is of paramount importance for the EU and the Riga Summit showed that the 28 Member States are able to make united decisions. The EU's neighbourhood is constantly changing due to the increasing number of old and emerging challenges, and this obliges us to take action. It is already clear that Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova want even closer engagement with the EU and we need to deepen our cooperation with them in all areas. The report clearly underlines the need to seek strategic partnership with the other Eastern Partnership countries and points to a more active EU involvement in resolving frozen conflicts in neighbouring countries. On the other hand, the events in the region over the past few years show that the European Neighbourhood Policy is not able to respond adequately and promptly to rapidly changing circumstances. This requires a fair and effective allocation of resources between the partnership in the south and east. A conceptual division in two dimensions is needed to develop in its own direction. Only this way will the objectives of the ENP be achieved.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The review of the European Neighbourhood Policy is necessary both because of the changing situation in the South and, as a result of Russian aggression, in the eastern neighbourhood of the EU.  The ENP is one of the most important elements of the EU's external policy. It must therefore be sufficiently flexible, diversified and inclusive, in line with the ambitions of partner reforms and convergence with the EU, both the EU's objectives and emerging challenges and challenges. We need to help the Eastern Partnership countries to reduce their vulnerability and dependence on Russia, which uses the levers at its disposal and creates artificial barriers to prevent these countries from making their own decisions about their economically, valuable and politically attractive deep cooperation with the EU.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to ensure peace, respect for human rights and economic well-being in the European Union's neighbourhood, it is of course necessary to increase funding for various cooperation projects and humanitarian aid, but it is not enough to increase funding alone. We need an even more coherent and decisive European Union foreign policy, and we need to change our trade policy so that it is easier for developing countries to sell their products to the EU market.  The EU's high defence customs are one of the reasons why it is very difficult for our neighbourhood countries to export their goods, increasing unemployment and dependence on EU humanitarian aid. Let us give North Africans and others the opportunity to work and reward for doing so, ensuring their human dignity. Otherwise, large flows of refugees will continue to move towards Europe, and young unemployed people will join terrorist organisations.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was established to deepen relations, strengthen cooperation and strengthen the EU's partnerships with neighbouring countries, with a view to developing a common area of stability, security and prosperity. The ENP must ensure tangible and concrete improvements for the citizens of partner countries and create relations at different levels and a strong interdependence between the EU and its neighbourhood partners. The report emphasises how the renewed policy must be more strategic, targeted, flexible and coherent and politically animated.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy, because this report is clearly designed with a view to EU enlargement. The rapporteur confirms this on several occasions, notably by tabling an amendment to strengthen the role of the Commissioner for Enlargement, or by calling on the High Representative to draw inspiration from the European Economic Area and gradually integrate the neighbouring countries. This is the well-known technique of small steps. Paragraph 58 is also revealing: "emphasizes the importance of the freedom of movement of people and supports greater mobility within the neighbourhood area, in a safe and well-managed environment, through visa facilitation and visa liberalisation, particularly for students, young people, artists and researchers; calls on the Commission to further encourage, in cooperation with Member States, partnerships for mobility within the neighbourhood and to develop the possibilities of circular migration schemes, which would open up safe and legal routes for migration."  We want even more immigration, while the people in Europe are opposed to it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report is the European Parliament's response to the consultation launched by the European Commission to review European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). The current review process responds to the need to adapt the ENP to the new context, marked by the Ukraine conflict in the eastern neighbourhood and by the instability of Syria and Libya in the southern neighbourhood.  The report underlines the strategic importance of the ENP and the centrality that must continue to be respected and promoted by human rights in the new ENP. The report talks about reforming the new policy with the aim of making it more flexible, focused and coherent. One of the key points of the report is also the defence of the principle of conditionality and the 'more for the most', where by which those countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan should receive more support from the EU. It also mentions the importance of promoting the rights of women and minorities, including LGBTI, and of combating poverty and exclusion. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I agree that a review of the neighbourhood policy was necessary in the face of its obvious failure. However, the EU continues its Eurocentric and asymmetrical vision, considering that its model of democracy must be imposed and maintaining a lack of self-criticism over the role of the European Union. Not to mention the incentive approach, rewarding effective, neocolonial-inspired partners. The European Union continues to seek stability based on relations with political elites, We have a common European security policy subordinate to US and NATO policies. Moreover, this report consciously eludes to refer to the conflict in Western Sahara and refers to Morocco as an ally. The Alawite regime is the main recipient of funds from the European Neighbourhood Policy of the European Union, while maintaining the occupation of Western Sahara. No state in the world recognizes Morocco's sovereignty over Western Sahara and the European Union, unfortunately, remains de facto complicit and a collaborator of the Moroccan occupation. That is why, among others, I voted against this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Terrorist attacks, armed conflicts, migration – are everyday topics of debate in Parliament. The problems we face are due to events in neighbouring countries, and serious security, economic and social impacts are also felt by our citizens. These processes violate the fundamental values on which the European Union was founded – peace, stability and prosperity with a focus on respect for democracy, human rights and equality. Long-term stable relations with neighbourhood countries are a strategic priority of the Union's foreign policy. We can assess the current foreign policy impacts as very weak since it is not successful in trying to respond to problems in the environment. I supported MEP Eduardo Kukan's report because I think we need a strategic, more active and consistently implemented European Union foreign policy that will be able to resolve conflicts in a timely and peaceful way and create a stable and secure international environment.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the European Neighbourhood Policy should work with all eu neighbours by differentiating these relations in the form of both resources and other intended incentives.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that this Report "Highlights the importance of developing the social dimension of the ENP, by engaging with the partners in the fight against poverty and exclusion, stimulating employment and fair growth, facilitating healthy labour relations and promoting education and decent work, thus also tackling some of the root causes of irregular migration"

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text attacking the sovereignty of states in foreign policy. We cannot accept an expansion of the Union's powers in such a strategic area. This is all the less acceptable when dangerous proposals, particularly on immigration, are put forward, such as the idea of strengthening legal immigration.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 At first glance from the right contains a number of positive thoughts and proclamations. For example, the rapporteur proposes – even with regard to tangible concrete improvements for citizens in partner countries – to strengthen the social dimension of the European Neighbourhood Policy, to step up the fight against poverty, to stimulate employment, to promote education. But it admits a lack of money for these eu objectives. Just as the document is unable to conceal the Union's 'affection' for ukraine's new leadership or the cluelessness of policy towards other enp countries. I will remind Libya, Israel and Palestine, Syria. The document had to admit that EU policy, for example, did not prevent "the doubling of networks for arms, drugs and human trafficking in Africa, with the consequence of jeopardising Europe's stability." It contains many sweet challenges, but perhaps even the rapporteur does not know how to fulfill them. The report calls for the promotion of bilateral relations, the strengthening of cross-border cooperation, contacts between people in the policy towards 'neighbours'. Do sanctions against Russia and specific individuals, including the paralysis of the work of parliamentary delegations, which have contributed, for example, to the development of cross-border cooperation between russia's Kaliningrad region and Poland, contribute to the fulfilment of these general statements? Since there are many more examples of failure or odd direction of the ENP than positive signals for its future, I cannot support this report in the EP.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report signed by Mr Kukan highlights the strategic importance of the European Neighbourhood Policy as a useful tool for the creation of interdependence relations between the European Union and the states that join the initiative. I particularly welcomed the reference in the text to the need to ensure tangible and concrete improvements for the citizens of the partner countries, as well as the reference to the need to make the neighbourhood policy more robust and effective. On the basis of previous considerations, I have chosen to vote in favour of this document.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European Union's neighbourhood strategy insists that I do not treat neighbouring countries as real partners, with a view only to obtaining advantages for the EU itself, and, if necessary, impose economic and political models. I voted against it because I believe that the EU must defend and respect, both internally, both in its Member States and for its partners, the values of democracy and solidarity.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The current upheavals in the neighbourhood of eastern and southern Europe require an ambitious and strategic redefinition of our neighbourhood policy. In the face of these new challenges, the EU must be able to think more politically about its action. This report responds to the plural expectations of European leadership, with neighbours at the crossroads of several "close foreigners". The Kukan report carries a real project to promote our values, through support for democracy and human rights, as well as the necessary revaluation of the attractive factors proposed by the EU. On the other hand, the text underlines the need for a reconfiguration of the intelligent approach of our neighbours. The deepening of the dialogue with civil society, and the strengthening of the action to control aid provided, are in this direction.   Finally, since the mere prospect of trade and free trade agreements is no longer a sufficiently effective lever to strengthen our partnership with the neighbourhood, the report opens up to the sharing of knowledge and the creation of networks at different levels, and thus goes beyond the economics of the Union. I voted for this report, which pushes further the establishment of a safer, democratic and prosperous neighbourhood space.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The EU's European Neighbourhood Policy aims to reward good students, such as Ukraine, in the service of its neoliberal agenda. Under the Eastern Partnership, the EU is continuing to work with Azerbaijan, where no elections have been described as free by international observers since 1993.  This policy has enabled European companies, through multiple free trade agreements, to plunder these countries, particularly in the Mediterranean, leading to population impoverishment, conflict development and migration. This report therefore takes no evidence of these failures.  Even the last revision in 2011 contained better passages calling for "helping partners build democratic, pluralistic and secular states" or stressing "the need to ensure a minimum wage".  I vote against this policy of economic and political enslavement of our neighbours in the service of the geopolitical interests of the EU and big business.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The rapporteur stresses the importance of an EU foreign policy and therefore wants to extend the powers of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This is an unacceptable interference in the sovereignty of the Member States, which are to be taken away from the possibility of conducting their own foreign policy, or at least that it is subject to the European Union. Not content with interfering in the policies of the Member States, the rapporteur also wishes to impose the Union's "values" on its external partners by affirming that fundamental universal values, the defence of human rights, equality and human dignity are at the heart of the Union's association agreements. This report supports and defends an immigration policy that is completely irrelevant by declaring itself "favourable to increased mobility within the neighbourhood area [...] through visa facilitation and visa liberalisation."  The congressman voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy. As set out in Article 8 OF the ETUs, the European Neighbourhood Policy was created to deepen relations, strengthen cooperation, strengthen the European Union's partnerships with neighbouring countries in order to create an area of stability, security and shared prosperity. Today, neighbouring regions continue to be affected by armed conflict and crises. The review of the ENP should be able to ensure a rapid and adequate response to the situation on the ground, while presenting an ambitious strategic perspective for the development of relations with neighbouring countries, in line with the commitment to promote the core values on which it is founded.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Since the events of 2011 (Arab Spring) and developments in the eastern neighbourhood, we have found that the EU is not responding sufficiently to rapidly changing conditions in neighbouring countries. In order to maintain lasting economic and political relations, an urgent and thorough redrawing of the European Neighbourhood Policy is required. The EU must be able to anticipate new developments quickly and adequately. The ENP must already be diversified and 'tailor-made'. Recent developments in neighbouring countries have shown that each neighbouring country has its own challenges and expectations. That is why the ENP must be targeted and coherent. An increased conditionality is also recommended. Cooperation with countries where real progress in democratisation, strengthening the rule of law and respect for human rights can be measured financially. At the same time, the EU must safeguard its own strategic interests in its relations with neighbouring countries, such as with regard to guaranteed energy supplies. An effective neighbourhood policy also includes enhanced cooperation on trafficking in human beings and cross-border crime. The OBJECTIVE of the ENP remains to achieve an area of prosperity, security and stability in the neighbourhood and to ensure these objectives for EU citizens.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the EU is a union of states that share common values and interests, the Neighbourhood Policy also needs to express the common position of eu states in a unified way. Naturally, this unified position must correspond to fundamental values and principles, such as, above all, democracy, the rule of law and the protection of human rights. I am convinced that it is precisely the transfer of these principles to concrete actions that will become a stable basis for favourable long-term relations with neighbouring states. However, in addition to continuing dialogue and cooperation in finding constructive solutions to the current challenges together with our neighbours, the current uneasy geopolitical situation requires the introduction of pragmatic security measures to protect EU citizens. I therefore support the strengthening of the EU's external borders, as well as the allocation of adequate funds for this purpose.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome and support the Kukan Report on the review process of the European Neighbourhood policy, which highlights the need to make European Neighbourhood policy more strategic, efficient and flexible, always respecting the core values on which the EU is founded. The ENP should not be a bureaucratic process but a politically-driven one serving the purposes of peace and stability in the neighbourhood but also promoting democracy and the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Report also stresses a very important point for me on the Mediterranean partnership, which is crucially important for the current situation in the region.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) remains an essential instrument of the Union's Foreign Policy, with a key objective: to create at the external borders a ring of security, stability, prosperity and good neighbourliness, based on the values and foundational principles of the Union itself. However, the diversity of countries to the south and east requires a reformulation of the ENP, as these same countries face different problems. A flexible ENP adapted to each region, and if necessary to each country. The Union has provided assistance and support in structural reforms on issues as diverse as economic and human development, conflict and natural disaster prevention, regional and infrastructure development, environment and trade policy, SMEs, migration, security and energy.  In the face of recent events, the Arab Spring, on the one hand, and the annexation of Crimea, on the other, the reformulation of the ENP has become a real necessity. As such two pillars have been strengthened. Firstly, the security component, with a link to the civilian and military missions of the Common Security and Defence Policy and the Common Foreign and Security Policy of the European Union. Second, a Neighbours-to-Neighbors policy in creating regional alliances.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on European Neighbourhood Policy aims to increase the EU's powers in relations with neighbouring EU countries. It follows the same logic of interference that characterizes the EU so much to avoid having to face its own turpitudes. Thus, this new policy encourages partner countries to submit to the structural reforms dictated by Brussels in the hope of future accession in order to satisfy, not the interests of the Member States, but those of the US external unifier.  These objectives must also involve strengthening Europe's defence with a designated enemy in the East. This is a real dispossession of the sovereignty of Member States in foreign affairs which are subject to the injunction to invest in the EU's neighbourhood policy "by harmonising their efforts". In short, an alignment with the American vision, that of neo-colonialism that imposes its values on its "partners" until implementing a free movement of people and mobility within the neighbourhood space.  Faced with this real madness, I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which follows the consultation process launched on 4 March 2015 with the joint consultation paper entitled ‘Towards a new European Neighbourhood Policy’. The report stresses that the Eastern Neighbourhood Policy needs to remain a single policy, recognising that both the Eastern and the Mediterranean partnerships are crucially important. It also calls for the appointment of EU Special Representatives for the East and the South dimensions and makes clear that, while recognising that the ENP and the enlargement policy are separate policies, a membership perspective must be sustained as an incentive for those countries with clear European aspirations that are eligible under Article 49 TEU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
