text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). According to this text, the ENP is now obsolete and must adapt to current security, economic and political challenges. The aim is for the EU to formulate an ambitious political vision with clearly defined strategic objectives and priorities to support democracy, the rule of law, good governance, judicial reforms and institution building in the EU's neighbouring countries.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report for a revised European neighbourhood policy that should be able to provide a quick, flexible and adequate response to the situation on the ground, while also putting forward an ambitious strategic vision for developing relations with the neighbouring countries in both a bilateral and a multilateral framework, in line with the commitment to promote the core values on which the European neighbourhood policy is based.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Bhí roinnt gnéithe dearfacha san athbhreithniú ar Bheartas Comharsanachta na hEorpa (BCE). Cuirtear béim ar an tábhacht a bhaineann le cearta na mban, le comhionannas inscne, le cearta an duine, le cearta LADT, le cearta na mionlach, le cearta daoine faoi mhíchumas srl i gcomhthéacs BCE. Ina theannta sin rinne an t-athbhreithniú tagairt d’Airteagal 2 den Chomhaontú Comhlachais a bhunaíonn na comhaontuithe seo ar mheas ar chearta an duine. Deir sé freisin nár chóir glacadh le polasaithe a téann i gcoinne na luachanna seo faoi BCE agus nach féidir le AE comhghéilleadh a dhéanamh orthu. Cuirim fáilte roimh na pointí seo.  Ar an drochuair, feicimid go bhfuil caidreamh AE le hIosrael ag comhghéilleadh ar na luachanna seo sa tslí is go bhfuil ag teip orthu aon rud a dhéanamh faoin sárú leanúnach atá á dhéanamh ag Iosrael ar chearta an duine sa Phalaistín. Tá an t-athbhreithniú seo ag iarraidh neartú ar an gComhbheartas Eachtrach agus Slándála. Iarrann sé ar Bhallstáit a n-iarrachtaí a ailíniú ionas go labhraítear le guth amháin ar shaincheisteanna atá bainteach leis na tíortha comharsanachta san Oirthear. Tá ceannasacht ar pholasaí eachtrach an-tábhachtach do mhuintir na hÉireann agus do Shinn Féin. Mar sin staon mé ón vótáil.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because I believe that it has succeeded in highlighting the urgency with which the European Neighbourhood Policy needs to be revised. Conflicts and events in the east and south of the EU have brought new challenges to foreign policy, and the European Neighbourhood Policy, as a key tool within it, needs to be reviewed to meet these challenges. It is very important that this review brings more vision, a faster response and greater flexibility for the EU in addressing new realities.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains some good approaches, but miserably misses some points, such as more pressure on Turkey. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The risks for the countries of the European Union have been exacerbated by the rapid deterioration of the security environment in both our eastern and southern neighbourhoods. It is therefore extremely important to review the principles of the Neighbourhood Policy so that they take account of the changed international situation. Certainly, the EU must also be more active in resolving existing conflicts and strengthening support for Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The review of the European Neighbourhood Policy is a key step in the security challenge and in building fruitful cooperation with our neighbours. The new neighbourhood policy must be based on greater flexibility and differentiation: the partners have different aspirations and the agreements must be tailored to the specific characteristics of each country. The main challenges of the new programming are the fight against radicalism, poverty and the strengthening of security. The goal is to have a prosperous and secure neighbourhood. The principle of more must be used, but in the knowledge that this can lead to contradictions if countries lagging behind in democratic transition receive less, this is to the detriment of the population. Aid needs to be balanced between the eastern and southern neighbourhoods and, in particular, I believe that specific attention should be paid to Tunisia, which has experienced real democratic progress that could be put into crisis by recent tragic events. It is important to maintain strategic dialogue, we must not separate the ENP from foreign policy because a safer neighbourhood means greater security in Europe.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Our security depends on that of our neighbors. Reformulating the European Neighbourhood Policy is necessary in order to reflect the current geopolitical situations in the area. I believe that the EU must do a minimum of self-criticism because it has failed to create the circle of friends that it proposed with the launch of the Neighbourhood Policy. We must increase technical assistance programmes and cultural exchange programmes which can facilitate better mutual compression.

name: Vincent Peillon (S&D)
text: In writing. Mr Kukan's report is part of the high representative's extensive consultation process to revise the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). While the ENP was created to promote the emergence of a "ring of friends" around the European Union, we are now faced with a "ring of fire". This situation of instability at our borders has dramatic humanitarian, economic and social consequences, and threatens our security. In this context, the voted text proposes several avenues for reflection. First, the ENP must be thought through in strategic terms. Despite our status as a leading trading partner and the support we offer our partners, the Union's influence in the region is declining. We need a clear and coherent policy, developed over the long term and implemented with a stronger political presence. Secondly, the European Union must not apply the same undifferentiated concept to all our partners: we must provide tailored aid according to the aspirations of each country, and assess the progress made in concreteo, by consulting more broadly with civil societies.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Neighbourhood Policy, has been by far one of the most successful European policies to date. Since the coal and steel community in the early days, this policy has been uniting the European continent into a single community with common values and diverse identities, by spreading the values and protecting the identities. It was this policy which made United Europe a reality after the fall of Communism. The ENP should become tailor made, with conditionality regarding the appliance of fundamental values and concrete progress, and on the other hand the ENP should be financially strong enough to influence the course of our neighbourhood. A renewed ENP should avoid everlasting blockades from Member States and we should particularly engage with our neighbours in projects which have a direct effect on the lives of their citizens, such as infrastructure, market access and free movement of people, by strongly supporting mobility within the neighbourhood.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Neighbourhood Policy was created to awaken relations, increase cooperation and strengthen the EU's partnership with neighbouring countries to create areas of common stability and prosperity, in particular due to the situation of neighbouring countries facing an increasing economic crisis. Many parts of the neighbourhood are affected by armed and frozen conflicts and crises, and this prevents economic, social and political transformation and regional cooperation, stability and security. That is why I think it is very important to create a flexible and appropriate response to situations occurring in parts of the neighbourhood, taking into account that everyone should benefit from this kind of policy, but that fundamental human values are not undermined.  I support this resolution, as it highlights the fight against root causes of instability such as unemployment, social exclusion, poverty and low levels of political and socio-economic participation of women. This will strengthen policy coordination and joint development of financial assistance programmes and provide mechanisms to strengthen cooperation between Member States and parts of the neighbourhood, which can lead to strengthening the Policy of the European Union and highlighting its core values such as uniqueness, solidarity and mutual assistance.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report calls for strengthening relations between the European Union and neighbouring countries, with the aim of future enlargements and in order to give the EU more foreign policy powers. The EU not only seeks to dictate its sacrosanct values and no less sacred economic principles, but also seeks to impose them on as many countries as possible.  The part on immigration is particularly worrying: while the Schengen area is already a source of trafficking of all kinds, the report would like to facilitate movement between the EU's neighbours and the EU. When one considers that Turkey is one of these countries and that it has a more than porous border with war zones in Syria, one can only wonder about the ideological blindness that presides over recommendations so clearly contrary to the fundamental interests of citizens.  I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Kukan's report, which outlines in a very comprehensive way the reforms that need to be implemented in order to structurally reform the attitude towards the neighbourhood and to deal effectively with the security challenges that are more at the southern and eastern borders of the Union than ever before. In addition to the eastern and southern dimensions, particular attention should be paid to the South East Neighbourhood of the Union. The European Neighbourhood Policy is strategically important as a policy that creates multilayered relations and strong interdeviousness between the EU and its neighbourhood partners. The fundamental challenge for a European neighbourhood policy is to make tangible and concrete improvements for citizens of partner countries. The NEIGHBOURHOOD's European policy should become stronger, more political and more effective policies by strengthening its positive elements such as a greater focus on partnerships with societies, differentiation and a more -for-more approach.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In March t.r., the European Commission called for a public consultation on the european neighbourhood policy, to which the European Parliament's report also responds. I consider the European Neighbourhood Policy to be a fundamental pillar of the EU's foreign policy and, at the same time, one of its greatest challenges. The EU must be far more ambitious in this area, inconsistent or underestimating has already led and can continue to lead to instability in the outside world. We are now seeing, in the case of Ukraine, what the consequences may be. Our approach must be strategic, coherent, but at the same time concrete, precisely coordinated and based on detailed knowledge of the specificities of the countries concerned. The text of the document we have adopted calls for the establishment of a position as the EU's special representative for relations with the south-eastern neighbours, which would undoubtedly lead to a strengthening of this policy and allow permanent account to be taken of the dimension of neighbourhood policy in the wider foreign policy context. Security must be an essential dimension of neighbourhood policy. It must include crisis management tools and support for the security structures of our neighbours. An ambitious neighbourhood policy, which is mainly and above all tied to our internal security, will not be without relevant financial resources, which will be the subject of debate in the context of the revision of the EU's external financial instruments in 2017.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) is an essential part of the European Union's foreign policy. I am convinced that it is of fundamental importance to support its objectives in order to create an area of prosperity, stability and security, on the basis of the common values and principles of the European Union. The EU must be able to identify, together with its partners, priorities for enhanced cooperation, integrating different policy areas such as the prevention of natural disasters, the strengthening of infrastructure and regional development, and migratory flows. I believe that the security component should be emphasised and this proposal for a revision calls for closer coordination between the European Neighbourhood Policy and the activities of the CFSP and the CSDP. In addition, the EU is invited to focus on strengthening the capabilities for border control by partner countries. I have therefore decided to support this proposal.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Since 2004, when the European Neighbourhood Policy was launched, we have seen a definite increase in threats in the immediate vicinity of the EU. There has been a war at the EU's eastern borders, ukraine, for months, and In Georgia and Moldova, Russia continues to fuel political conflicts for its own purposes. The southern borders, on the other hand, are experiencing the severe effects of the Arab Spring, devastating wars and an uncontrolled wave of emigration. The problem of war-ravaged Syria remains unresolved, and the Islamic State is growing in the area and is crossing more and more borders with its reach and criminal activities. An effective neighbourhood policy is needed today more than ever, which is why I voted in favour of the Kukana report. In order to ensure security in the EU, a firm and coherent position towards Moscow and concrete solutions to the challenges of the South are needed. This cannot be achieved without EU diplomacy, so I hope that Commissioner Mogherini and her European External Action Service will step up their efforts in this regard.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the Neighbourhood Policy to be particularly crucial today, when Russia is stepping up its pressure on the states between it and the EU. I am also pleased that the resolution makes it clear that the EUROPEAN Neighbourhood Policy is not based on persuading neighbouring countries what foreign orientation they will choose, which countries the policy is aimed at. Let us therefore continue to develop this policy and support the European future of these countries if they choose to do so.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission is currently reviewing the European Neighbourhood Policy in order to better adapt to the challenges and needs of the countries concerned and to develop an effective policy. The European Parliament wished to participate in this reflection by proposing a review of this policy. I voted in favour of this text and I stress the need for a differentiated and 'tailored' approach to the targeted countries. The countries under this policy have different his or her stories and different levels of development. A differentiated European approach would enable effective action.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. MEPs reiterated the importance and need to revise the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), which is clearly no longer appropriate in view of security problems at the EU's borders.  Events in the Middle East and North Africa in recent years have shown that the ENP does not allow for a prompt and adequate response to difficult situations and rapidly evolving armed conflicts. These neighbouring countries face different problems and demand specific answers.  The ENP should become a stronger, more effective, more focused policy with a greater political and strategic dimension. Its initial objectives of creating an area of prosperity, stability, security and good neighbourliness based on the common values and principles of the European Union must remain the guarantors of this policy.  The European Parliament regrets the modest resources provided by the European Union for its action as a "global partner" until 2020, which represents only 6% of the total budget. It also points out that the ENP is an essential component of the Union's foreign policy.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us that the original objective of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) is to create an area of prosperity, stability, security and good neighbourliness based on the common values and principles of the Union, by offering aid and incentives for deep structural reforms in neighbouring countries.  Having said that, I am convinced that strengthening the own development potential of partner countries requires going far beyond the political dialogue currently predominated in the ENP and extending it to a social, economic and cultural dialogue that takes into account all political, social, ethnic and cultural differences.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Since the launch of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), countries in the EU's neighbourhood have undergone significant changes and the Commission has recently launched a public consultation to conduct a thorough review of the ENP and the principles on which it is based. I supported this report, which is one of Parliament's contributions to the revision of the ENP. It is about developing an ambitious and forward-looking neighbourhood policy; THE ENP needs to be more strategic, focused, flexible and coherent. European support must be differentiated according to the recipient and better targeted.  In terms of defending European values, it is fundamental that support for democracy, the rule of law, good governance, state consolidation, human rights and fundamental freedoms should be at the heart of the ENP. At the same time, the EU and the States must continue to offer their help and know-how for the implementation of reforms.  The new ENP must also take into account the security dimension which has worsened and evolved considerably in the vicinity of the Union.  Finally, it is also a question of establishing strong partnerships with the Union's 'neighbours'.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. For a long time, the Assembly has been calling on the Commission to take action to make the necessary changes to the ENP, the European Neighbourhood Policy, which was set up in 2003 in order to cooperate with Europe's neighbours, by land and sea, by establishing a privileged relationship that would certainly bring stability, security and development for all those involved in this policy. Since 2011, when the 'more for more' clause was introduced - the more individual countries engage in cooperation and the more they receive benefits - the geopolitical situation has changed a great deal, which is why I voted in favour of the report proposed by the Committee on Foreign Affairs, which suggests the path that the EU will have to take within the ENP. Specifically, I agree with the call to maintain the principle of differentiation in relations with individual States, greater coordination between the ENP and activities included in the common foreign and security policy, and to support partners in implementing more and more stringent security controls in order to be able to have greater capacity to defend themselves against terrorist and criminal attacks.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it. I am opposed to the EU developing relations with other countries utilitarianly, for the sole purpose of defending its interests. Economic nearsightedness cannot determine the action of the EU, the same EU that talks about democratic values and social rights. The EU must be supportive not only in its words, but also in its actions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the review of the European Neighbourhood policy. I fully recognise that both the Eastern and the Mediterranean partnerships are crucially important to the EU.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the EU Neighbourhood Policy to be an important tool for ensuring peace and stability. Today, Europe cannot afford to ignore geopolitical, economic and social changes in its neighbours. It is important to improve cooperation with international organisations and to financially support projects that help alleviate suffering for people around the world. We also need to set up a well-set up control mechanism for these projects. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was established to prevent the creation of new dividing lines between the enlarged EU and its neighbours and to help consolidate the prosperity, stability and security of all the countries involved. I am glad, on the one hand, that the ENP is based on the values of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights, but on the other hand, I regret that, as a result of the current political and economic changes and under the influence of armed or so-called frozen conflicts, the neighbourhood is undergoing fundamental changes and that action is therefore needed. I supported the resolution because I believe that it is essential to restructure the neighbourhood policy and look for ways to change it in order to build a strong, strategic and lasting partnership that is able to respond quickly and flexibly in the pursuit of common interests. At the same time, I feel that the EU must play a more active role in peaceful solutions to existing conflicts that threaten the development of a genuine and effective multilateral dimension of the ENP. I expect that, on the basis of the measures taken, the Neighbourhood Policy will develop into a better adapted and flexible policy framework capable of adapting to the existing diversity of partner countries.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with one of the most important findings contained in my colleague Eduard Kukan's report: a differentiated approach and a tailor-made policy are needed in the European Union's neighbourhood policy. We must acknowledge that the situation in the countries concerned is very different, so we must adapt to this and not be too rigid.  Similarly, I welcome the fact that, according to the report, it is necessary to go beyond the current political dialogue and to expand it with a more complex social, economic and cultural dialogue, entrecing all elements of the political, social, ethnic and cultural diversity of partner countries, and by strengthening the direct role of local authorities. Most importantly, in addition to strengthening relations between the institutions, we must also encourage direct contacts between people, since the neighbourhood policy means strengthening relations not only between countries and their leaders, but also between societies and local communities.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Within the framework of the Neighbourhood Policy, Ukraine is the most key country for me and Slovakia. Its stabilisation and political, economic or economic involvement will be reflected in the prosperity of Slovakia, the region and the whole EU.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Overview of the European Neighbourhood Policy, as it deepens and strengthens the neighbourly relations of member states. Due to possible security crisis situations in the future, I believe that stronger cooperation between neighbourly countries and mutual responsibility are needed. I am of the opinion that the European neighbourhood policy is one of the foreign policy priorities and therefore I think it is necessary for the EU to play a more active role in applying and revising this proposal on the grounds that it portrays a united and more complex European Union. I believe that the European Union should consider the different external and internal issues of each country and adapt strategies for resolving possible conflicts.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the review of the European Neighbourhood policy as it stresses that the Eastern Neighbourhood Policy needs to remain a single policy, recognising that both the Eastern and the Mediterranean partnerships are crucially important. I also welcome the report’s call to sustain a membership perspective as an incentive for those countries with clear European aspirations eligible under article 49 TEU.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The text of the report stresses the importance of strengthening Member States' political cooperation within the ENP, resulting in the release of sovereign rights.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it serves the purpose of a comprehensive conceptual review of the EU's common European Neighbourhood Policy, with the broadest possible political and interinstitutional support, in the face of new international challenges and in the face of institutional changes in the EU. I have taken a positive decision despite the fact that the very thorough and professionally based report largely neglects to draw conclusions and to set priorities for the EU's future foreign policy activities.  Reci admitting the importance and dangers of new factors in our Mediterranean neighbourhood, I would have considered it appropriate to mark the Ukraine crisis as the EU's current primary neighbourhood policy task. In our most important eastern neighbour, which is looking for its future in the EU, there is practically a war going on, which is why I consider today that Putin's expansionary, violent policy is the most serious international challenge facing the Union and its Member States. The main test of the success and future chance of a renewed ENR, and indeed of the entire EU security and external relations policy, will be the management of the Ukrainian crisis and the EU's unity in the realisation of Ukraine's peace and European path. I trust that, in the course of my work as a representative of Ukraine, I will also strive to ensure that this aspect is applied in the future in the achievement of the objectives set out in the report and in further discussions on the revision of the ENP.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a timely report that provides a useful guide in reshaping the European Neighbourhood Policy. As Russia annexed the Crimea and invaded Ukraine, bullied Armenia into joining the Customs Union, and Libya was ravaged by Civil War, the ENP was left in a state of disarray by the end of 2014. Events in countries neighbouring the EU’s external borders affect all Member States and the migration crisis in the Southern Mediterranean is but one example of this. Reinvigorating the ENP and moving away from a ‘one size fits all’ model is imperative if its aims are to be achieved, and I am pleased that this report notes the need for more targeting and flexibility in its approach. The report is particularly good in noting the role that can played by individual Member States via their existing bilateral ties with certain neighbourhood countries. In the Southern Neighbourhood the ENP will be particularly valuable in the fight against terrorism and in restricting the movement of foreign fighters who may pose a threat to Member States. I am pleased to vote in favour of this report and encourage the High Representative to take heed of its messages in reinvigorating the ENP.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's relationship with the countries in its eastern and southern neighbourhood is an essential component of the Union's foreign and security policy. The European Neighbourhood Policy has been one of the instruments for improving the EU's relations with its neighbours, but has become insufficient in the context of developments at the level of the states concerned. In this respect, the present report proposes a resizing of the neighbourhood policy to take into account the differences in approach of the Southern Side with the Eastern Side and to place greater emphasis on supporting democracy, the rule of law, good governance, institutional capacity, ethnic and religious tolerance, strengthening civil society, cooperation in the field of security, support for regional integration, resolving internal or frozen conflicts. At the same time, those States that wish may conclude association agreements with the European Union and should be able to become candidates for accession to the Union under the conditions of convergence. The achievement of the full potential of the neighbourhood policy depends, however, on how we will succeed in promoting European democratic values in these countries. I believe that the current report is a step forward in this direction and deserves to be adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. It is important and necessary to revise the European Neighbourhood Policy. This new ENP should provide a rapid, flexible and adequate response to situations on the ground, while proposing an ambitious strategic vision for the development of relations with neighbouring countries within a bilateral and multilateral framework, in line with the commitment to promote the core values on which the ENP is based.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the review of European Neighbourhood Policy. Indeed I believe in the importance and the necessity of the review of the ENP. I also think that the revised ENP should be able to provide a quick, flexible and adequate response to the situation on the ground, while also putting forward an ambitious strategic vision for developing relations with the neighbouring countries in both a bilateral and a multilateral framework.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ European Neighbourhood Policy was created in 2004 with the aim of strengthening diplomatic relations with countries on the Union's eastern and northern borders - Algeria, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Morocco, Egypt, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Moldova, Palestine, Syria, Tunisia and Ukraine. I hold it of utmost importance to further cultivate relations with these countries bordering the Union in order to maintain long-term stability and political reforms in them. I also believe that neighbourhood policy should specialise in a way that, instead of a uniformed approach, it starts to cultivate an approach that respects and respects the individual characteristics of each state individually, with minimal interference by the Union in the internal affairs of sovereign states. This would increase efficiency and effectiveness in preserving democracy and the rule of law.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The main purpose of this report is to inform the European Parliament of the ongoing review of the functioning of the European Neighbourhood Policy initiated by the European Commission. It calls for the renewal of a more strategic, focused, flexible and coherent and politically oriented neighbourhood policy capable of responding appropriately and quickly to the needs of neighbouring countries. I supported the report.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Both the European Union's foreign policy projects – the Union for the Mediterranean and the Eastern Partnership – were unfortunately out of step. The most important thing is to avoid reckless political decisions in our relations with our eastern neighbours, which can lead to dramatic consequences (for example, in North Africa).

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it. I am opposed to the EU developing relations with other countries utilitarianly, for the sole purpose of defending its interests. Economic nearsightedness cannot determine the action of the EU, the same EU that talks about democratic values and social rights. The EU must be supportive not only in its words, but also in its actions.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to increase the competence of the European Neighbourhood Policy with the aim of establishing a genuine 'union foreign policy'. It follows the same logic as previous reports on the establishment of a Defence Europe. In addition, the report presents dangerous proposals on immigration, notably the idea of strengthening legal immigration has been put forward. In view of these attacks on the sovereignty of States in terms of foreign policy, it is a question of opposing the logic of increasing the Union's powers and the desire for marked interference in this text.  I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it. I am opposed to the EU developing relations with other countries utilitarianly, for the sole purpose of defending its interests. Economic nearsightedness cannot determine the action of the EU, the same EU that talks about democratic values and social rights. The EU must be supportive not only in its words, but also in its actions.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is a satisfactory reflection on the EU’s policy towards its immediate neighbourhood. The document seeks to assess the ENP and evaluate what has worked and what needs to be improved. It also addresses important changes that are taking place in the neighbourhood and sets out policy goals for the coming years. I do find myself in disagreement on a few points, especially on the EU’s stance towards Ukraine. More generally, I strongly believe that our Eastern partners should freely choose their foreign policy orientation and that their potential future entry in the EU should be based on their free choice. I endorse the report’s view that the EU must be more active in working towards the solution of ‘frozen conflicts’ and show stronger engagement in dealing with the difficult challenges in the Mediterranean.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Kukan report is an ambitious report showing the European Parliament's contribution to the revision of European Neighbourhood Policy. A neighbourhood policy that needs to be more strategic, more focused, more flexible and coherent, and able to respond faster and more effectively to the needs of neighbouring countries. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in the affirmative on this report on the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), launched by the European Commission, which marks the EU's relations with the nearest countries, the South and the East. The ENP needs to be adapted to new contexts, such as the Ukraine conflict and instability in Syria and Libya.  It highlights the centrality of respect and promotion of human rights in the new ENP, which must be more flexible and coherent. Conditionality is defended and that countries that move faster than agreed in the action plan receive greater EU support. Priorities should be agreed with each country, but specifically mentioned promoting the rights of women and the LGBTI collective, and combating poverty, exclusion and unemployment. This more social dimension has been introduced by our Socialist Group.  On migration, it supports the signing of agreements to facilitate and liberalize visas and the opening of legal immigration channels. On security, it is requested to strengthen countries' capacities to combat terrorism and organized crime, based on respect for human rights.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it stresses that the Eastern Neighbourhood Policy needs to remain a single policy, recognising that both the Eastern and the Mediterranean partnerships are crucially important. The report also calls for the appointment of EU Special Representatives for the East and the South dimensions and makes clear that, while recognising that the ENP and the enlargement policy are separate policies, a membership perspective must be sustained as an incentive for those countries with clear European aspirations that are eligible under article 49 TEU.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In the wake of the so-called Arab Spring events, the renewal of the European Commission and the Ukrainian crisis, a revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy was needed. Last March, the Commission therefore launched a public consultation on this subject, to which this report intends to contribute. Some of its recommendations are moving in the right direction: supporting the development of a flourishing and active civil society in the Union's partner countries; Establish genuine freedom of movement of people; go beyond the ever-present free trade zones to meet people's social aspirations... However, beyond good intentions, narrow and self-interested motivations soon reappear in the form of the 'principle of conditionality': if the countries of the European neighbourhood want to benefit from partnerships in any form, they must respect conditions including economic and migration. We know what that means. Enp countries are therefore first perceived according to their geopolitical interests, whether they are energy suppliers, markets for European products or migration gendarmes. For all these reasons, I chose abstention.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. There is a proverb Portuguese saying "To those who want evil to the neighbor, yours comes along the way". That is, when we harm the neighbors, we suffer consequences. And, in fact, the EU cannot, unfortunately, be considered a desirable neighbour for anyone. This report advocates strengthening the association between the EU Neighbourhood Policy and the Common Foreign and Security Policy and the Common Security and Defence Policy.  But what happens is that this policy is increasingly based on military intervention, in "the name of a more active role in the peaceful resolution of ongoing conflicts." This is paradoxical because the truth is that these interventions are the very cause of so many ongoing conflicts, such as the support for the so-called Free Syrian Army, when in this Parliament it was said in hysteria that everything should be done to end Assad. This was the case in Libya, or the case of Ukraine.  In these countries, it will certainly be thought that "with neighbors like these, it is better to be alone".

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It is true that the European Neighbourhood Policy is an important factor for good cooperation between the EU and neighbouring countries or third countries. Nevertheless, I believe that concepts such as association or the broad political-geographical view of the ENP go too far in some respects. That is why I abstained.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy, together with my group. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was developed in 2004 with the aim of strengthening relations with countries on the EU's eastern and southern borders. Some 16 of the EU's closest neighbours are currently within their remit – Algeria, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Egypt, Georgia, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Moldova, Morocco, Palestine, Syria, Tunisia, and Ukraine. The report assesses the ENP's current actions and argues that conflicts in Ukraine, Syria and Libya require a rethink of the way the EU works with its neighbours. The report then makes a number of recommendations, including increased politicisation of the ENP and the appointment of special representatives in the East and South. This is sustainable in an effort to promote strong relations with the countries on the eastern and southern borders of the European Union.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which emphasises that the EU is founded on respect for the universal fundamental values of human rights, the rule of law, democracy, freedom, equality and human dignity, and these principles must remain the Union's central objective, including in its neighbourhood policy. The report reiterates that strengthening the rule of law, supporting democracy and human rights are in the interests of partner countries and calls for stricter conditions in respect of compliance with these fundamental values. I also agree with the rapporteur's vision, which calls on the European Commission to have a better focused, more flexible, coherent and politically motivated Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). Moreover, the report calls on the EU to formulate a clear and ambitious political vision of the ENP and to pay particular attention to its political priorities in the eastern and southern neighbourhood, taking into account the different challenges faced by the countries of each region, as well as their different political aspirations and ambitions.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because, as the situation in neighbouring countries changes, so does our policy towards them. During this period, neighbouring countries are undergoing constant changes due to the growing number of long-term security problems, are less stable and face a deeper economic crisis. Partner countries should seek a peaceful solution to the current situation, mainly because conflicts are hampering the social, political and economic re-ediming of countries.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The importance of good and strong relations with our neighbours, whether on the eastern side of the Union's borders or on the opposite shore of the Mediterranean, was only realised by many during the recent discussions on migrants, when the conflicts in Ukraine, Syria or Libya began to directly affect all Member States. The report by MEP Eduardo Kukano hopes that the planned revision of the EU's neighbourhood policy will ensure more effective cooperation with these countries and offer them a vision for a better future. Each country must be viewed individually, as the application of one neighbourhood policy for all has not proved its worth in the past. I believe that, in addition to the 'more for more' principle, according to which the Union strengthens partnership with those neighbouring countries that are advancing on the path of democratic reforms, we should also consider applying a 'less for less' policy more often to those who go in the opposite direction.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The majority of this European Parliament - the right and social democracy - reinforces the continuity of the European Neighbourhood Policy, continuing its central nature, the EU's economic expansionism, exacerbating conflicts and tensions at its borders. The report calls for the financial strengthening of an instrument promoting the militarisation and securitisation of borders through the Common Foreign and Security Policy and common security and defence policy, which promotes the submission of neighbouring countries to eu neoliberal policies to impose political, social, economic and cultural reforms. A policy that focuses on the creation of free trade areas, which attacks human rights while hypocritically defending them and presenting the European Union as an example in its implementation and defence; promoting an EU foreign policy that we do not recognise; promoting the discriminatory and elitist stance of its migration policy by strengthening instruments such as FRONTEX and EUROPOL; which is hostile, in particular Russia, on the basis of the energy policies that are in place.  All of these, among many others, are plenty of reasons to vote against.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I finally voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the directive on the harmonisation of copyright. This directive has attracted interest in view of the so-called freedom of panorama. This provision, which was in the draft report in the Committee on Legal Affairs, was finally dismissed in the vote. This would mean a restriction on the taking of photographs or videos and their depiction in public spaces. I think it was a proposal that was not well thought out and would upset the balance between the authors' and consumers' relationships that we are looking for.  However, I think that this report otherwise contains important references to access to cultural heritage through online platforms, also in the context of the appeal to legislators to allow easier access to educational materials. I therefore think it was a good thing that this report was supported.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur I voted in favour because the fragmented system of protection of copyright in European countries makes it very difficult to create a single European market area. 28 states, 28 different copyright protection law packages, 28 justice systems with their own 28 procedural aspects. Colleagues, most entrepreneurs who would like to work throughout the European Union must abandon their ambitions only by thinking about the high costs that will be required to identify all copyright claims and payments. In particular, the harmonisation of copyright within the Territory of the European Union is a reality for the creation of a single digital market. Time is short, so courage and energy are needed to activate the process. At the same time, I would not want new, strict requirements to be imposed together with harmonisation, which would make it more difficult for business to operate and further restrict the rights of European citizens. Thank you!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí mé sa Pharlaimint ar maidin nuair a rinneadh díospóireacht ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo, agus bhí a lán pointí suimiúla á rá ag Feisirí.  I think everybody realises that, in the age of the internet, the laws have to be updated. In particular, we have to protect the rights of the artists and the creators. We must balance that with the need to have open access to the internet for people. We also have to be very conscious of the protection of schools and libraries, etc. I think that can be done with a balanced approach, and we will, hopefully, allow ourselves the freedom to get that eventually. I was also very pleased that Commissioner Oettinger, in relation to panorama freedom, said that the talk of it being restricted was a phantom and that it will continue on the basis of national legislation, etc. That is an important point to reassure people. Mr President, thank you. You did a fantastic job today. The voting was supposed to take two hours and you got it done in a little over an hour.

name: President. –
text: Thank you for the flowers!

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I re-echo my colleague’s work on the voting. I was very pleased today that the European Parliament confirmed the freedom of panorama. I was one of the 100-plus MEPs who submitted the amendment which reads: ‘Recognises the right to use photographs, video footage and other images of works which are permanently located in public places’.  A very significant number of citizens contacted me on this issue, and they were very concerned about it. In fact, of course, this was just an own-initiative report which means it had no legislative effect, none whatsoever, so their fears were unfounded. However, having said that, it is best that there is no mention anywhere of circumventing freedom of panorama.  If, in the future, Parliament looks at a legislative proposal from the Commission on copyright, obviously what we say there will have an impact in law. But what we voted on today has no impact, either at European or national level, on any law.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, intellectual property rights are one of the keys to economic growth. Without research, without innovation, we don't have economic growth and we don't have jobs. That is why intellectual rights must be invested in research, innovation and protected. Anyone who puts their intelligence to work and in the game to create something must be protected and their product must be protected. Copyright law must protect intellectual property and stimulate investment in creativity and innovation. Of course, it is desirable to have common rules at European Union level. This report examines the implementation of the Copyright Directive in the Information Society, a 2001 directive, and makes recommendations for its adaptation to the digital age. I add a very important recommendation: the application of laws in the Member States because, in many Member States, there are laws for copyright protection but they do not apply and, as such, research and innovation are not stimulated.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Today I would like to shout to the photographers, journalists and citizens: unpack your cameras, take advantage of the sunny weather and snap what holds the stuff! Because the freedom of panorama remains. This is good news for all of us in Europe. I am glad that in the end it was possible to convince all the political groups and a large majority of Members of my initiative and the request by my ECR Group to delete the critical paragraph 46. I too voted in favour of this today. I am even more pleased with commissioner Oettinger's clear statement. The EU Commission also stands by the freedom of panorama. Everything that can be seen from public places with the naked eye should also be allowed to be photographed. Commissioner, we will take you at your word.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists have always advocated the need to guarantee fair remuneration to authors because without it there is no sustainable cultural creation.  Europe has a thriving sector in its cultural industries, capable of continuing to create jobs in the midst of a crisis. And copyright is the basis on which cultural industries are based. Europe needs to revise its legislation to adapt it to the digital environment and harness its potential to generate new jobs and innovative industries. But copyright reform should be avoided as a clash between authors and users.  Following the profound changes made to parliamentary work, largely thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, the report is committed to ensuring fair remuneration to authors and improving their contractual position, as well as advancing citizens' better access to culture, improving the portability of legally acquired content; recognizes the importance of territorial licensing in the field of film and television, calls for reviewing the role of internet intermediaries, calls for solutions for the shift of value from content to services, and refuses to limit freedom of panorama, among other aspects. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained since the most negative aspects initially presented by the rapporteur were removed during the vote on the report; specifically, the possibility that the use of photographs, videos and other images that are permanently in public spaces should previously obtain authorization from authors, which would have been an intolerable restriction on cultural dissemination and knowledge. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of the final text, since, in essence, the idea of copyright is reinforced as a model that aims to find the greatest possible economic benefit for large companies rather than making a proposal aimed at a profound change in the current intellectual property model; one that prioritizes cultural dissemination and knowledge and gives relevance to the social and collective aspects of works and works.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aimed to bring the regulation of copyright up to date with technological advances in the digital age. This report aims to not only defend the rights of artists to be fairly remunerated for their intellectual property in the digital age, but also extends rights to the public and consumers. I am in favour of rights for consumers to access content without undue restrictions such as geo-blocking, provided that intellectual property creators are remunerated fairly. I voted against amendment 46, the so-called panorama amendment, which aimed to restrict the free use of images and photographs of public buildings. I also voted no to Amendment 1, ‘After § 57’. While this amendment was couched in the language of protecting quality journalism, it is better known as the ‘snippet tax’, or ‘Google tax’ and it was aimed at restricting the rights of internet users to hyperlink to other websites without paying a fee. If either of these two amendments had passed, I would not have been able to support the report. However, both fell, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the non-binding resolution on the modernisation of copyright adopted by the European Parliament, as it points out, among other things, that future proposals for reforming EU copyright law in the digital age must ensure an appropriate balance of rights and interests between authors and consumers. On the other hand, it calls for better cross-border access to online content, without denying the importance of territorial licences, particularly for TV and film productions. With regard to the right to produce and publish images and photographs of works (e.B. buildings or works of art) in public spaces, the current EU copyright law leaves it to the Member States to include a clause on "freedom of panorama" in the national provisions. However, I rejected the proposal in the draft resolution that the commercial use of such images should always be linked to the prior consent of authors or other authorised representatives and I hope that the Commission will present a proposal that convinces as many Member States as possible to include this 'freedom' in their own regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I agree that copyright and intellectual property must evolve to reflect technological and digital advances.  This report does not mention the issue of piracy or tax evasion by certain multinational firms such as Google or Amazon.  The harmonization of copyright would be at the expense of the protection of French authors, since French legislation is much more favourable. Finally, this report runs counter to respect for the sovereignty of the Member States.  For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Ultimately I had to vote against the Reda report, because there are far too many calls for harmonisation.  Nevertheless, I did feel that there were some positive aspects to the principles behind the report, and a recognition that copyright law is outdated.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it was the result of a collective effort that resulted in a balanced text, far from the original text which was intended only to null and void copyright without defending users. However, this initiative report, with no legislative consequences, allows us to draw the future issues of the directive which will be presented by the Commission in the autumn.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The European Parliament supports the Commission's commitment to further develop the EU's digital agenda, including the modernisation of copyright, recognises and recognises the need to review Directive 2001/29/EC in order to ensure adequate remuneration for authors, performers and other copyright holders, adequate protection of these rights and to ensure fair interaction between all actors involved in the European cultural economy (SMEs, consumers, users, creators and rightholders) in the digital age, which includes a constantly evolving technological environment in which user behaviour changes, opportunities and challenges.  Reforming the EU copyright system requires the necessary legal certainty, stability and certainty, as well as the flexibility needed to promote investment and growth in the creative and cultural sector, while eliminating legal uncertainties and inconsistencies that have a negative impact on the functioning of the Digital Single Market.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The report calls for copyright reform that includes proper remuneration for creators and increases consumer protection, which must have access to culture and information. Within the Union, we have a very rich tradition of music, art and literature, and the proposals for exceptions for education and libraries must allow the widest possible public to have access to them.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report was based on a simple and indisputable observation of the necessary evolution of copyright and intellectual property in order to take account, in particular, the rise of the Internet and new technologies, in particular.  This report raises several points, such as the reform of intellectual property rights, in particular the Infosoc Directive, or the concern for exceptions related to panoramas, but vigilance focuses mainly on the introduction of concepts derived from Anglo-Saxon law, such as copyright, and on respect for the French and continental conception of copyright.  We will have to find a protective environment towards creators and small authors while allowing free expression on the Internet as part of the neutrality of the latter.  Finally, the report does not mention the issue of piracy and tax provisions, including the evasion of large multinationals such as Google or Amazon.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the initial proposal of this report is decidedly problematic, the final compromise released by the Committee on Legal Affairs is improving and the Italian stakeholders themselves have accepted it, albeit with reservations. This report is intended to be a basis for the Commission, when it presents its proposals we will be able to get to the heart of more important and incisive issues for the Italian market and to protect the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises as well as consumers. I therefore believe that, all things considered, this text is a good starting point and I support it with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. I want different cultural expressions and technologies to be able to spread in a way so that as many people as possible can benefit. For example, we want file sharing (for private use) to be allowed and positive to open source and open standards and require state/government agencies to take the lead and exclusively use open-label systems and open source codes. Freedom on the internet and people's privacy, me and the Left Party have been fighting for for many years, both against ACTA and PNR. Requiring permission to take a picture of buildings, statues and skylines is preposterous at a time when almost every person owns a mobile phone with a camera. The Left Party is also a party that defends cultural workers and their right to be fairly paid for their work, and therefore we underline, among other things, the importance of one percent of the state's budget going to art expression. In motions in parliament, we have put forward proposals that we believe carry more weight, in this context, than to restrict freedom of panorama.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists have always advocated the need to guarantee fair remuneration to authors because without it there is no sustainable cultural creation.  Europe has a thriving sector in its cultural industries, capable of continuing to create jobs in the midst of a crisis. And copyright is the basis on which cultural industries are based. Europe needs to revise its legislation to adapt it to the digital environment and harness its potential to generate new jobs and innovative industries. But copyright reform should be avoided as a clash between authors and users.  Following the profound changes made to parliamentary work, largely thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, the report is committed to ensuring fair remuneration to authors and improving their contractual position, as well as advancing citizens' better access to culture, improving the portability of legally acquired content; recognizes the importance of territorial licensing in the field of film and television, calls for reviewing the role of internet intermediaries, calls for solutions for the shift of value from content to services, and refuses to limit freedom of panorama, among other aspects. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to consider measures contributing to the further development of cultural exchanges and increasing legal certainty in this sector, i.e. this directive on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society must be reviewed. It should be noted that the revision of that Directive should continue to ensure the principle that rightholders are paid fair remuneration. The European Parliament welcomes the new Commission's commitment to further develop the EU's digital agenda, including copyright issues, in the exercise of its mandate. Welcomes also the 2015 the Commission's work programme, as it promises to develop a Digital Single Market package, including a legislative proposal to modernise copyright rules to meet the needs of the digital age. Parliament is concerned that the number of illegal services and piracy provided online has increased and that infringements of intellectual property rights have increased in general, which is a serious threat to the economies of the Member States and the EU creative sector. Furthermore, any reform of copyright legislation should be based on a high level of protection, as rights are essential for intellectual creation and in order to ensure a stable, clear and flexible legal framework that promotes investment and growth in the creative and cultural sectors.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dissemination of culture in its broadest sense is one of the cornerstones of the Union, as is the legal protection of their authors and artists. These issues are very topical because it has now become necessary to adapt copyright law to the digital age. The report on the implementation of the directive on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society has given rise to a lively debate around it. The contents of the report on freedom of scenery have provoked strong public reactions. Today's vote concludes a healthy process of democratic dialogue in which political representatives respond to the concerns and needs of European voters.  For these reasons, I support the solutions and guidelines contained in this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I am very pleased that we have been able to secure the rejection of amendments to ban so-called panoramic photographs. It is important that the European Parliament sends a clear message to hear citizens' demands. The right balance needs to be found between copyright fees and consumer claims. I'm sorry my colleague Honeyball's oral amendment was rejected, but I believe the voted document provides a good basis for digital reform.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I am strongly in favour of ensuring that artists and creators are fairly remunerated for their intellectual property, and I believe that this right is protected in this report which clearly states that it must be protected in the digital age. I am in favour of rights for consumers to access content without undue restrictions such as geo-blocking, provided that intellectual property creators are remunerated fairly. I voted against amendment 46, the ‘panorama’ amendment, which aimed to restrict the free use of images and photographs of public buildings. The second part of amendment 46 called for prior authorisation to be required for the use of a picture of a public building, which I believe is absurd and impractical. I also voted no to Am1, ‘After§57’. While it was couched in the language of protecting quality-journalism, it is better known as the ‘Google tax’ and it was aimed at reducing the rights of internet-users to hyperlink to other websites without paying a fee, which would have been a major boost to massive search engines while limiting access to information online. If either of these two amendments had passed, I would not have been able to support the report. However, both fell.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I am convinced that, given the huge change in the technological context, which has profoundly changed the market for intellectual works of genius, it requires harmonisation of copyright, especially with a view to a single digital market, in which digital ingenuity works will play a fundamental role.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The digital revolution has radically transformed society, the way of life, travel, work and communication. The European Union must be at the forefront of this transformation by overcoming the digital divide and defending the fundamental rights of users of the digital world following the example of italy's Free Panorama rule. Citizens have the right to the protection of their personal data, the security and confidentiality of their communications. Together with this we must realize that the Internet has great creative potential that we can now unleash. The reduction of legislative differences between Member States in the field of copyright is positive for the free movement of images, the audiovisual market, the promotion of landscape and cultural tourism, the fluidity of the world of amateur and author photography. Researchers will have lower costs to sift through and analyze large amounts of data with positive effects on their work. Online courses may include more copyrighted material. We will have more transparency about copyright taxes and the destination of the money collected. Today, the world is similar to a large, deeply interconnected global city or a vast sea full of currents and information: it is up to us Europeans to decide whether to be the centre of it or to be pushed to the margins.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Intellectual property law reform has become a strategic and powerful issue. Indeed, France faces the challenge of preserving its internal conception of copyright in the face of intrusions of Anglo-Saxon concepts such as "copyright". The ENL Group, of which I am a member, has tabled two amendments which call for: - to pay particular close concern to the question of the legal regime of a single European title; - to ensure that the minimum durations prescribed by international standards are not less than those provided by French law.  Finally, the issues of piracy and tax provisions, two policy issues, are not addressed in the report.  For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Copyright and intellectual property have been and will be one of the priorities of the European Union, with the evolution of human society based on creativity and inventiveness. Profile industries contribute around 38.6% to the European Union's domestic product, and the defence of these rights aims to promote people's ability to create concepts and values that lead to the economic development of society and the increase in the number of jobs. Europe itself is attractive to investors because of the legislative framework that preserves and promotes intellectual property rights. I welcome and encourage any action taken at European Union level and come to this effect. I voted in favour of the report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights. I am convinced that both Parliament and the Commission will continue to support the progressive harmonisation of this sector.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The compromise reached by the Committee on Legal Affairs, which is better than the initial proposal, is 'accepted with reservation' by the main Italian stakeholders. The own-initiative report is intended to be a suggestion to the Commission; when it presents its proposals, it will be possible to go into more about the important issues (role of service providers and intermediaries, geo-blocking, use of recorded material in public places, etc.). In the field of copyright, priority must be given to the protection of works, preserving their intellectual property from the abuses and fraudulent uses that are often seen to proliferate on the net. At the same time, the wide dissemination of digital tools must make it possible to make full use (and, where appropriate, cross-border) use of content. Between exclusive rights and exceptions, the text appears to be a good starting point. On the whole, therefore, it gives a favourable opinion.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The digital age has created new copyright challenges. Adapting our legislation in the light of technological advances is essential. The digital revolution allows for continuous innovation that requires special attention. However, the digitisation of the European single market cannot be done at the expense of creators. We must ensure that authors protect their rights in the digital age. Nevertheless, it is important to be careful that authors are not stripped of some of their rights under the pretext of a revision of the legislation. I will remain vigilant when the revision of the directive on the harmonization of certain copyrights is published. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report examines very important aspects of intellectual property and goes much further, to the redefinition of borders and the way in which related rights are exercised in the information society. Our society aims to be 'fully intellectual property rights', and this must make us aware that we are acting on (as well as in) the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I am thinking of freedom of expression, the protection of personal data and intellectual property, and I am referring symbolically to the threat to freedom of panorama. Photographing a public place, monument or architecture and being able to share it must be the prerogative of every European citizen. The level of perception of the beauty - or even the problem - of our urban environment must be raised, not restricted, and freely transmitted and shared. Obvious correctives are imposed when violating privacy or trading what is taken or photographed. A massive effort is therefore required (given the breadth of the subject) but surgical at the same time, to redefine and rationalize, before even deciding how much and how to liberalize, protect, regulate, modify. We are close to a real redefinition of the artistic work and the intellect in general.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aimed to bring the regulation of copyright up to date with technological advances in the digital age. This report aims to not only defend the rights of artists to be fairly remunerated for their intellectual property in the digital age, but also extends rights to the public and consumers. I am in favour of rights for consumers to access content without undue restrictions such as geo-blocking, provided that intellectual property creators are remunerated fairly. I voted against amendment 46, the so-called panorama amendment, which aimed to restrict the free use of images and photographs of public buildings. I also voted no to Amendment 1, ‘After § 57’. While this amendment was couched in the language of protecting quality journalism, it is better known as the ‘snippet tax’, or ‘Google tax’ and it was aimed at restricting the rights of internet users to hyperlink to other websites without paying a fee. If either of these two amendments had passed, I would not have been able to support the report. However, both fell, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Ultimately I had to vote against the Reda report, because there are far too many calls for harmonisation. Nevertheless, I did feel that there were some positive aspects to the principles behind the report, and a recognition that copyright law is outdated.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It maps out the needs for the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and other related rights in the information society such as the need for a copyright reform, not only to improve the Digital Single Market, but also to facilitate access to knowledge and culture throughout the EU. As a precursor to the upcoming Copyright Reform proposal, it also calls on the Commission to consider a wide variety of measures to bring copyright law up to speed with changing realities and improve cross-border access to our cultural diversity. I also voted in favour of the deletion of the contentious issue concerning the requirement of consent to use photographs taken in the public domain when these are used for commercial purpose.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the vote of this report, so far removed from the original text, which was only intended to nullifying copyright without defending users.  I voted against paragraph 46, which was an amendment that I had proposed in committee and which had been voted on, but it was the most effective solution to ensure that the panorama exception was no longer included in this report. I believe that the status quo that prevails today and which is suitable for all Member States, as Commissioner Oettinger has pointed out, must remain the rule. Each country thus remains free to include this exception in its legislation according to its cultural particularities.  It is also for this reason that I formally opposed Amendment No 3, which was only intended to reinstate in the report a mandatory exemption from the right of panorama in the 28 Member States.  The responsibility of the hosts is also included in the report, which seems to me to be a good start to consider the future proposal for a directive under good auspices.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe it is necessary for copyright to be protected. However, if we do not recognise a coherent and harmonised approach within the EU, it will always remain easy to circumvent national rules.  The dissemination of culture and knowledge is in the public interest and it is necessary for their authors and performers to receive legal protection for the works they compose. It would be an excessive burden to ask them to pay 28 lawyers, one for each Member State to protect their works. It is precisely against this situation that I am fighting, supporting harmonisation in this area too, which is the lifeblood of national and European culture and ingenuity. The duration of copyright, for example, is still very different in the various Member States and harmonisation by the European legislator is urgently needed. With regard to the right of panorama, however, I maintain a different position: the commercial use of photographs, films or other images of works permanently located in public places cannot be subject to authorisation. It is in the interest of the whole community to be able to admire public goods and be able to photograph them without the need to ask for consent and without having to pay.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mrs Reda's report on European copyright rules. Not only does there also be a necessary harmonisation in the EU of the different national laws, but it is urgent to respond to the innovations that the Digital Agenda entails by modernising the framework for copyright and related rights in the information society. I also supported the exclusion of the reference to the "panorama amendment" which could excessively limit the freedom to collect private images of citizens and tourists. I regret that no rule has been adopted on the collective management of artists' copyrights.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society, because there is an urgent need to adapt copyright to today's digital world. I believe that freedom of panorama should be preserved, which is why I voted against restricting it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that this directive represents a further and important development of the ambitious Digital Agenda project. I believe that copyright and related rights protect and stimulate both the development and marketing of new products and services and the creation and exploitation of their creative content, thus helping to improve competitiveness, employment and innovation in various industrial sectors of the EU.
