I therefore believe that it is necessary to encourage the harmonisation in the individual Member States of the terms of copyright protection and related rights for all types of work and for all related rights.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained since the most negative aspects initially presented by the rapporteur were removed during the vote on the report; specifically, the possibility that the use of photographs, videos and other images that are permanently in public spaces should previously obtain authorization from authors, which would have been an intolerable restriction on cultural dissemination and knowledge. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of the final text, since, in essence, the idea of copyright is reinforced as a model that aims to find the greatest possible economic benefit for large companies rather than making a proposal aimed at a profound change in the current intellectual property model; one that prioritizes cultural dissemination and knowledge and gives relevance to the social and collective aspects of works and works.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report evaluates the implementation of the 2001 Directive on the harmonisation of certain aspects of ‪‎copyright. The report deals with a number of positive ideas including creators’ remuneration.  However in an earlier version of the report there was a controversial reference that in real terms would have restricted the Freedom of ‪‎Panorama, i.e. taking pictures of public buildings/spaces without prior authorisation. As promised, I voted against this restriction, namely the freedom of people to take photos in public spaces including photos of architectural sites when on holiday, and I voted so that people will be able to use these pictures freely even on the internet. However, I voted in favour of the report as a whole as the rest of the report gives fair rights to artists.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this initiative report, with a view to the forthness of the forthness of the forthward revision of the 2001/29/EC Directive on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and neighbouring rights in the information society within the framework of the digital internal market package, aims to provide the European Parliament's position on copyright reform.  This report clearly positions the European Parliament in favour of adapting copyright to the digital age, but also clearly opposes its questioning. I am pleased that this report maintains the necessary balance between fair remuneration for the work and talent of creators, respect for European cultural diversity, the fight against piracy and counterfeiting, on the one hand, and the easy access of consumers to its services by setting up a regime of responsibility for platforms, intermediaries and hosts, on the other.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – The increasingly digital way in which we work nowadays demands current copyright to be updated. There must be a fair balance between the rights of the creator on the one hand and the rights of the consumer on the other. This report should guide the Commission in its work when drafting the copyright reform, which is to be published in the autumn.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC as I agree with the need to adapt existing discipline in the light of developments in the digital age and to reduce regulatory fragmentation on important aspects such as the duration of copyright protection. It is important to address these challenges in order to contribute to the affirmation of the freedoms of movement that characterise the single market. I believe it is necessary to provide adequate protection for copyright and related rights, balancing the needs of users with the interests of the holders of these rights.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This initiative report was adopted by a large majority of the European Parliament. It provides a consensus, and therefore stronger, position to defend copyright and neighbouring rights, before the Commission puts its proposal for the Digital Single Market on the table.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on copyright and neighbouring rights. While the Commission will table a proposal for copyright reform in December, it seemed very useful for the European Parliament to be able to express its priorities and call for a review of ad hoc legislation in order to better adapt them to the digital environment. Several areas need to be explored: geoblocking and cross-border accessibility of copyrighted services and content, the portability of online services within the EU, the guarantee of fair remuneration for all categories of rights holders, including the digital distribution of their works, etc.  I also supported the amendment to strengthen the neighbouring rights of press publishers. With regard to the panorama exception, I voted against paragraph 46. I consider that, in the absence of a consensual solution, it is preferable to preserve the current situation and confirm that Member States have the option of introducing or not a so-called freedom of panorama clause into their legislation.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of saving panorama.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it also harms, in addition to the others, the freedom of panorama which is fully recognised and protected by law in a number of EU Member States. This is the self-evident right that allows all citizens to acquire and share photos, videos or other images of buildings, sculptures and other artistic creations that are permanently in public places.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Copyright reform should contribute to greater technology development, cultural exchange and improve legal certainty in the creative sector. Any reform of copyright law must provide a high level of intellectual property protection to encourage investment in creativity and innovation and to safeguard employment and encourage job creation. This position represents the right balance between user access and fair remuneration for creators, also taking into account the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises. The report adopted in committee reflects the balance of rights indicated in the commitments that have led to a positive vote in this report. Investment in the creative industry will continue to be encouraged, while at the same time giving the industry an opportunity to integrate digital technologies and giving end-users better access.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on copyright because it is an important step forward in reforming and updating the law. Especially important was protecting the Freedom of Panorama about which many of my constituents in Wales had contacted me. I hope that this report will now inform the Commission’s legislative proposals.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. This resolution on the revision of the Copyright Directive contained paragraph 46, according to which: 'the commercial use of photographs, films or other images of works permanently located in physical public places should always be subject to prior authorisation by the authors or a person delegated by them'. Since this amendment aimed to exclude freedom of panorama, I voted against it, bringing to plenary the voice of a large number of citizens who have mobilised in recent days in order to remove from the final text the proposal to restrict the right to photograph public space freely. Once this amendment had been removed from the text, I was able to vote in favour of the report as a whole. Apart from the amendment excluding freedom of the scene, the rest of the resolution provided the Commission with some valuable ideas to take into account with a view to the reform of the Infosoc Directive, which aimed to harmonise certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society, but which now needs - after 11 years - a review of the current arrangements for the creation of new technologies. , production and use of content at computer level, determined by technological progress.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report considers that Europe's cultural and creative "industries" are an engine of economic growth and job creation – a basic reason for the commercialisation of culture and knowledge, in which we do not see each other. It notes that around 39% of the EU's economic activity, with an approximate value of €4.7 billion per year, is generated by sectors with intensive use of Intellectual Property Rights, which also create 26% of direct jobs (i.e. 56 million jobs), representing indirect employment plus 9% of the total number of jobs in the EU. The report defends the public domain and involves internet operators in the problem, points with which we agree. It advocates limiting the use of works, considers private property as a pillar of creativity and, with regard to private copying, advocates harmonisation of schemes but does not clarify in what sense. These are things we don't agree with. As for the so-called "freedom of panorama", we consider that prior authorization of the authors of the works should not be necessary, even for commercial use. What is necessary is that the copyright is paid to them, but not that the authors give prior information.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against Amendment 3 original text because it restricts people’s right to take photos of public spaces.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report creates a precondition for providing authors and interpréts with legal protection for their creative and artistic activities. More than 7 million people are employed in the European Union in sectors with a significant role in intellectual property rights. I recognise that commercial activities infringing copyright pose a threat, for example, to the functioning of the Digital Single Market. However, I do not agree with restricting citizens' rights to present private audiovisual recordings on which a building or other historical monument protected by existing copyright legislation may occur.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this own-initiative report, although with some important reservations but on the whole the text appears to be a good starting point. The proposal serves as a stimulus to the Commission when it presents its proposals.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights, as it also harms, in addition to others, the freedom of panorama which is fully recognised and protected by law in a number of EU Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that the Parliament must have a clear position in view of the upcoming Commission proposal on the copyright reform. This report includes several paragraphs that are a priority for our Group, such as the ones on creators’ remuneration and the re-balancing of their contractual position. Although restating the principle of territoriality, the report promotes portability and also asks the Commission for solutions for cross-border access. I welcome this balanced report, which reaches a good compromise between ensuring the rights of authors and performers on the one side and access to culture and information on the other. It reinforces several exceptions and limitations, but tries as well to ensure a good climate for the creative sector and the preservation of European cultural diversity. As it stands, this report deserves the support of this Chamber.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission intends to modernise the copyright framework by proposing a revision of the Directive. This is a reform that must contribute to greater development of technologies and cultural exchange, while improving legal certainty in the creative sector, which must provide a high level of intellectual property protection, to encourage investment in creativity and innovation, and to safeguard employment and promote job creation. However, the modernization of the legislative framework cannot in any way entail the abolition of freedom of panorama. We need to be able to strike the right balance between copyright protection and access to knowledge of European citizens. That is why I voted in favour of the report and against the amendment on freedom of panorama.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists have always advocated the need to guarantee fair remuneration to authors because without it there is no sustainable cultural creation.  Europe has a thriving sector in its cultural industries, capable of continuing to create jobs in the midst of a crisis. And copyright is the basis on which cultural industries are based. Europe needs to revise its legislation to adapt it to the digital environment and harness its potential to generate new jobs and innovative industries. But copyright reform should be avoided as a clash between authors and users.  Following the profound changes made to parliamentary work, largely thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, the report is committed to ensuring fair remuneration to authors and improving their contractual position, as well as advancing citizens' better access to culture, improving the portability of legally acquired content; recognizes the importance of territorial licensing in the field of film and television, calls for reviewing the role of internet intermediaries, calls for solutions for the shift of value from content to services, and refuses to limit freedom of panorama, among other aspects. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists have always advocated the need to guarantee fair remuneration to authors because without it there is no sustainable cultural creation.  Europe has a thriving sector in its cultural industries, capable of continuing to create jobs in the midst of a crisis. And copyright is the basis on which cultural industries are based. Europe needs to revise its legislation to adapt it to the digital environment and harness its potential to generate new jobs and innovative industries. But copyright reform should be avoided as a clash between authors and users.  Following the profound changes made to parliamentary work, largely thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, the report is committed to ensuring fair remuneration to authors and improving their contractual position, as well as advancing citizens' better access to culture, improving the portability of legally acquired content; recognizes the importance of territorial licensing in the field of film and television, calls for reviewing the role of internet intermediaries, calls for solutions for the shift of value from content to services, and refuses to limit freedom of panorama, among other aspects. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Many letters have reached me about freedom from the panorama. At this point, I would like to make it quite clear that I am in favour of freedom of panorama and have also advocated this in the votes in Parliament.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PpE group and the Fidesz delegation welcome the Commission's strategy in this important area, since the revision of Directive 2001/29/EC is central to creativity and innovation, cultural diversity, economic growth, competitiveness, the promotion of the Digital Single Market and access to knowledge and information, while at the same time providing recognition for authors of literary and artistic works and protection of their intellectual property rights. I think it is important to point out that Article 167 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union states that the Union contributes to the prosperity of the culture of the Member States, while respecting their diversity, in particular by promoting artistic and literary creation. A top priority is the objective set out in the report, according to which Growth and Jobs in Europe is a priority for the Commission and is central to its 2014-2019 programme. I therefore welcome in the report the tangible instruments guaranteeing the remuneration of creators and the financing of the creative process, as well as the Commission's initiative to consult on copyright, which has generated huge interest from a wide range of stakeholders, including the cultural sector and civil society.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Reda report given it succeeds in striking a good balance between ensuring the rights of authors and performers, on the one side, and access to culture and information, on the other side.  The cultural and creative sector accounts for up to 4.5% of the EU GDP and gives work to 8.5 million people, meaning it not only provides a crucial contribution to cultural development and diversity, but is also vital for the real economy. Yet while the world has advanced to the digital age, copyright is still stuck in the past, meaning authors and performers do not receive fair pay for performances exploited via online media and many of them are in too weak a position to negotiate better terms. I hope that when the Commission comes forward with a proposal on copyright reform later this year, it will include strong measures to render copyright fit for the digital age, facilitate cross-border access to creative content on fair and reasonable terms across the EU, and ensure authors’ and performers’ rights as well as adequate remuneration.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. We need to adapt the intellectual property regime currently applied in the EU to an increasingly changing digital environment to ensure the remuneration of creators, meet citizens' expectations and promote innovation in the digital sphere. We also need greater harmonisation of exceptions and the implementation of a solution to combat geo-blocking so that we can move towards a true European digital market in which consumers can access European cultural diversity, regardless of where they live. I strongly defend the existence of exceptions to support research and education, as well as freedom of panorama. Imposing prior authorization for the use of images of monuments located in public spaces would unfairly limit the possibilities that new technologies offer to citizens. The copyright debate should not be tilted towards consumer criminalization. The development of new online services has allowed the multiplication of legal offers on the Internet, which should be promoted for the benefit of artists and creators, whose contractual position must be strengthened, but also for the benefit of SMEs and users.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on the report on harmonisation of specific copyright aspects. We understand that there has to be a tendency to homogenize the different intra-Community laws. However, this homogenization must take into account the different pillars on which the so-called knowledge society is based, it must take care of equal opportunities and access to the content that occurs and must also protect the authors of such content by ensuring legal spaces of dissemination that do not harm consumer access. The idea of a digital single market has its good points, but it also has its bad points. With a digital single market, copyright taxation can be pursued throughout the European Union, so specificities would be lost. These specificities are criticized for limiting access, but in some cases are necessary for fair remuneration from creators (emphasis on several sections of the document (25, 26 and 27)). They are also necessary to promote the management by each country according to the needs related to their own conditions.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which outlines the Parliament’s views on copyright which will be instrumental in making our views known to the Commission ahead of their proposals on copyright reform which is expected before the end of the year. I strongly believe in the right of creators to be fairly and appropriately remunerated for their work and was delighted to see this incorporated in this own initiative report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on the report on harmonisation of specific copyright aspects. We understand that there has to be a tendency to homogenize the different intra-Community laws. However, this homogenization must take into account the different pillars on which the so-called knowledge society is based, it must take care of equal opportunities and access to the content that occurs and must also protect the authors of such content by ensuring legal spaces of dissemination that do not harm consumer access. The idea of a digital single market has its good points, but it also has its bad points. With a digital single market, copyright taxation can be pursued throughout the European Union, so specificities would be lost. These specificities are criticized for limiting access, but in some cases are necessary for fair remuneration from creators (emphasis on several sections of the document (25, 26 and 27)). They are also necessary to promote the management by each country according to the needs related to their own conditions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the implementation of the Directive on harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society, because I consider modernisation of the copyright regime necessary. Together with creative industries, it generates growth and jobs within the European economy, representing 4.2% of Europe's GDP. In particular, I emphasise that I voted in accordance with the need for panoramic images to be freely used and that each Member State has the right to adopt specific rules on this matter.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report on the harmonization of copyright. Once again, there is a political will to move towards the standardisation of EU standards and law. However, in many cases, and in particular with regard to France, the European law advocated by this report is of a much lower quality than the existing national law. The report also suffers from many shortcomings, not dealing with crucial topics, such as computer hacking or the tax provisions of such harmonization of the law.  This report, in essence, runs counter to the principle of sovereignty of the Member States, which, of course, goes against the values I defend on a daily basis as a member of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report adopted today sends a signal to the European Commission that some of the copyright, existing exceptions or restrictions need to be reviewed and better adapted to a digital environment that is changing at a dizzying pace. Our priority should be to improve the protection of fundamental rights such as the fight against discrimination and the protection of freedom of the press, but also to adopt an exception allowing libraries to legally rent works in digital formats for personal use.  One of the most controversial topics of discussion was the so-called freedom of panorama, i.e. the possibility of unlimited shooting in public space against the background of buildings or works of art. I voted with all conviction today against paragraph 46 of the draft report, which restricted this freedom. I am pleased that this provision was not included in the final report, which is why I supported the final text of the resolution.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Copyright Reform Report. There are a number of strong ideas in the report, but most attention has centred on the so-called ‘freedom of panorama’. The text as adopted by the JURI Committee took what I would describe as an illiberal approach to this question. The amendment tabled to the paragraph by colleagues did not, in my opinion, clearly represent the sentiment of the many citizens who have taken an interest in this issue, so I felt that a better approach would be to delete the paragraph in its entirety.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Julia Reda's report on copyright, which was intended to propose improvements for future copyright reform. This report is the result of a complete rewrite of the text, the initial version of which was catastrophic for European culture, as the rapporteur did not know, voluntarily or not, the mechanisms governing cultural production. His proposals directly threatened artists, SMEs and the 7 million jobs that enable citizens to benefit from diversity in Europe's culture. Intense negotiation work has resulted in the extraction of all harmful parts of the text and a balanced report, guaranteeing both the defence of the authors and wide access to culture. This new version makes concrete proposals to adapt copyright to the challenges of digital technology, calls for greater accountability of technical intermediaries and recalls the importance for the European economy of the cultural and creative sectors, as well as the fundamental nature of the principle of territoriality of rights, at the heart of the financing of culture in Europe. The text has been adopted by a very large majority and will send a clear message to the European Commission.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and neighbouring rights in the information society. This resolution is the result of difficult negotiations which fortunately prevented the adoption of a text which called in its original version to demolish the very principle of copyright.  While it is necessary to adapt copyright legislation to the digital age, we must continue to protect our European creators and their work so that they get fair remuneration for their contributions. It is important to develop an environment in Europe that favours the cultural and creative sectors that contribute to increased growth and employment levels.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Europe has a huge cultural sector, but not the ability to market it across the continent, as copyright protection is regulated individually in each country. Harmonisation is therefore useful. I have made my vote in favour of this report conditional on the vote on paragraph 46 on freedom of panorama. It is essential to maintain freedom of panorama, otherwise the freedoms of citizens and artists would be subject to an unjustifiable restriction. In the end, I voted in favour of the overall report by maintaining freedom of panorama.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The digital age is taking a turn, more and more creative content is being published on the Internet, and there is an increasing demand for it from consumers. The European Commission already gave clear signals before presenting the Digital Single Market strategy that the modernisation and harmonisation of copyright on the EU market is necessary. A clear and transparent copyright framework is very important for copyright users, as transparent regulation would reinforce creativity and the further development of internet platforms; it would also ensure that copyright holders receive the remuneration they deserve. Copyright reform is an important part of the digital single market. However, I voted against paragraph 46 of the report, which would very much restrict the use of works, photographs and video recordings that are already permanently physically available in public places, the so-called 'freedom of panorama'. In general, I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution because I believe that legislation must keep up with the development of digital technologies.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: Written. I voted against Julia Reda's report because it does not adequately protect the interests of writers, songwriters, film producers, etc., especially in small and medium-sized countries such as Denmark. Global players will be the only ones who can benefit from this standardisation of copyright and other related rights, which undermines the creativity, economic development and competitiveness of the smaller Member States. With such standardisation, the European Union greatly damages the cultural, linguistic and artistic diversity that it is so important to preserve in the individual Member States.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 9 July 2015, we voted on a report on the implementation of the Directive on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society known by the media acronym 'freedom of panorama'. Unfortunately, this report has, quite senselessly, unleashed a huge media storm. We all probably agree that it is imperative that the law responds flexibly to the development of the outside world. This is not always the case. The issue of regulating unwanted behaviour and protecting copyright on the Internet is precisely the area where the law has been failing for a long time. It is very difficult to find a consensus together on how to respond to the latest developments. One of the main reasons is the existence of very different legal traditions in the legal systems of each Member State. The original text was a very ambitious proposal promoting greater harmonisation, the introduction of mandatory exceptions to copyright and the introduction of a so-called single European copyright title. After complex and difficult negotiations, my colleagues have managed to defend the compromise amendments, which represent a balanced adjustment between the protection of authors, users, citizens' rights to access cultural goods and information, as well as the protection of local cultures and traditions, but at the same time do not put a stop to the development of new technologies. Since the plenary session managed to remove the amendment on freedom of panorama, I decided to support the report.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution we have sent a strong message to the Commission: copyright must be adapted to the digital age by ensuring the right balance between the rights and interests of creators and consumers. We must ensure that there is a fair remuneration for those who create; we must provide users with legal certainty for their day-to-day actions; finally, we must ensure inclusive access to culture and knowledge. We managed to reject the proposal to restrict the right to photograph public space freely. Europe is a territory rich in cultural heritage that testifies to our history and the evolution of our culture and I firmly believe in the potential to share our panoramas and cultural heritage.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report on copyright reform, which seeks to strike a balance between the protection of authors' rights and the interests of internet users. This is an important guide for the European Commission, which has pledged to bring its draft copyright reform before the European Parliament by the autumn. The point of the so-called "freedom of panorama" restrictions, which raised the hottest controversy, was voted out of the bill. The emotional debate around the copyright report showed how controversial and complex it is to solve copyright problems in the digital market.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Reda's report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights. The InfoSoc Directive introduced minimum levels of copyright protection without laying down rules for the protection of the interests of users and the public, i.e. without harmonising copyright at European level, which led to a further fragmentation of national copyright systems. This report will make it possible to continue to promote investment in the creative sector, giving industries the opportunity to use digital technologies and end-users better access to them.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and neighbouring rights in the information society, because I am in favour of preserving the French and continental conception of copyright in the face of intrusions of Anglo-Saxon concepts in the report such as "copyright". Paragraph 28 of the report does not define or specify the legal regime of a 'single European title', which would constitute dangerous harmonisation. Paragraph 32, for its part, refers to the international standards set by the Berne Convention, which sets only minimum durations below those prescribed by French law.  The system of exceptions and limitations on copyright specific to each Member State should be protected. Authors must be guaranteed fair remuneration and moral rights to the fruit of their creation. However, in the light of the information society, the legitimate rights of end-users (including consumers) must be respected. This includes distinguishing between commercial and non-commercial use.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the REDA report because it promotes excessive and dangerous harmonization of copyright. The final version voted by Parliament is fortunately less catastrophic than the version originally proposed by MP Pirate (!) Mrs. Reda. For example, the dangerous "freedom of panorama" it enshrined, which would have been contrary to French tradition, was abandoned.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported this report because, on the one hand, it guarantees the protection of the rights of authors and performers and, on the other hand, it provides access to culture and information. It also reinforces a few exceptions and limitations, but provides good conditions for the creative sector and promotes the preservation of European cultural diversity.  I voted against paragraph 46 of this report, which restricts 'freedom of panorama', because the changes would result in a ban on the free use of images of objects in public spaces in photographs, which would significantly restrict access to information. I believe that such restrictions cannot take place in the modern information society.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Parliament has been in favour of a reform that ensures fair and adequate remuneration for creators and protects consumer rights, advances common standards while respecting the adaptability of the standard to European cultural diversity and demanding a review of the role of intermediaries, especially in the digital field , and the need for authors to receive an adequate return for their works to the extent that it is their content that contributes traffic and revenue to large digital platforms. In addition, freedom of panorama is guaranteed. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained since the most negative aspects initially presented by the rapporteur were removed during the vote on the report; specifically, the possibility that the use of photographs, videos and other images that are permanently in public spaces should previously obtain authorization from authors, which would have been an intolerable restriction on cultural dissemination and knowledge. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of the final text, since, in essence, the idea of copyright is reinforced as a model that aims to find the greatest possible economic benefit for large companies rather than making a proposal aimed at a profound change in the current intellectual property model; one that prioritizes cultural dissemination and knowledge and gives relevance to the social and collective aspects of works and works.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Directive 2001/29/EC prescribes a legislative framework on copyright and related rights in technological development, in particular information society. It is commendable to initiate the Commission's communication on amendments to the Directive, which have been necessary due to the extremely rapid developments in the digital environment since 2001, when it was signed. Also, as part of the Digital Agenda, the Commission plans to propose a copyright reform in the autumn that should simplify EU legislation and contribute to further technology development, foster creativity and innovation and copyright protection.  The latter should be a priority in implementing reforms. Copyright protection must be at a high level, as only such encourages creativity and innovation that will surely result in the development and promotion of new products and services, their use and thus contribute to greater competitiveness, job creation and economic growth. I supported the Report of Mep Julie Reda with the aim of adapting to the digital society and the protection of intellectual property, which is the basis of competitiveness and economic development, whose products and services are the result of creative reflection in order to simplify the lives of our citizens.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The report provoked turbulent emotions in Slovakia and the Czech Republic. Naturally, residents are concerned that incorporating this report into the directive, especially not the precise Article 46, will make it impossible for them to take routine photographs at monuments, and may not even know that they are covered by copyright protection. The freedom of panorama is regulated more freely in our countries and is therefore naturally understood as a step backwards. I respect the right of authors to protect their copyright, but in this case it is also necessary to protect ordinary residents who are not interested in the commercial use of such images. It is therefore necessary to specify what is understood by the commercial use of the depiction of the work, the way in which it is generalised that the work is protected by copyright and who is obliged to pay a fee to the author for such publication. I therefore voted against the restrictive paragraph restricting the freedom of panorama.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2001 on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/7/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting against this report which does not preserve the French conception of copyright in the face of the intrusions of the Anglo-Saxon conception. In this report is used the term "copyright" which is the English term for copyright, different from the French definition. It is de facto difficult to be able to vote positively for a text using an English-speaking semantics incompatible with a French-speaking semantics.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am fully aware of the importance of European copyright law. Annual turnover in the European cultural industry is around EUR 540 billion and generates more than 7 million jobs across the EU. The discussions surrounding Mrs Red's draft report have been very complex from the outset. Some fear for the fate of Europe's cultural industry, which they say threatens large global firms such as Google. Others point out that with the digitisation process, it is time for a change in copyright rules. I can agree with that, technology is outpacing the law! However, after several months of intensive work, I have come to the view that the EU is not currently ready for full harmonisation of copyright. This is due to traditional historical differences in member states' adjustments. After many meetings and bilateral negotiations with the shadow rapporteurs, I believe that we have managed to find a balanced compromise across the political spectrum that guarantees a balance between the rights of artists, producers and users, while allowing everyone access to culture through copyright, which must serve society as a whole and not just commercial interests. Moreover, since we have managed to defend the so-called freedom of panorama, which was crucial for me in the vote, I voted in favour of the draft report.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the implementation of the Infosoc Directive on copyright has not led to the harmonisation of copyright desired by many parties, I have decided to support this report, which calls for coordination of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I welcome the rejection of the Ppe amendment which meant restricting the freedom of street photography, or panorama photography. Although it is an own-initiative report, without binding power, including such an amendment, contrary to what the authors intended, it would give the committee a completely wrong signal as to what direction to legislate. However, the inclusion of several other right-wing proposals that misappropriate the initial report and the balance between copyright and consumer rights have led to my abstention.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I can only welcome the harmonisation of the copyright of the EU Member States. It was also important to me that paragraph 46 of the Reda report should have been omitted: if freedom of panorama had been abolished or restricted, I would have had to reject the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim of this resolution is to assess the implementation of the Infosoc Directive of 2001, which deals with "the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and neighbouring rights".  Written in a balanced manner, this compromise resolution defends copyright while allowing certain exceptions to promote the dissemination of information and artistic productions. The resolution thus proposes to "strengthen the exceptions available to public interest institutions, such as libraries, museums or archives" and also to allow "an exception for research and education purposes, which would concern not only educational institutions, but also accredited teaching and research activities".  The text also denounces geographical restrictions that block access to content for consumers depending on the country. Finally, the resolution denounces the extremely low remuneration granted to authors by content platforms.  I abstain not to condemn good intentions, but also not to approve so many inaccuracies.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union, through this report, is once again trying to harmonize at European level. It must be remembered that this European harmonisation of intellectual property law is unnecessary. In addition, many issues are not addressed, such as the issue of piracy, or the sensitive subject of tax provisions. In addition, certain provisions would reduce the sovereignty of states. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. Given that Europe's cultural and creative industries are an engine of economic growth and job creation, employing more than 7 million people and generating more than 4.2 % of the GDP of the European Union, it is imperative to harmonise, within Europe, all aspects necessary for the effective protection of the rights of authors of literary and artistic works, in order to reflect the technological developments operated in this market.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In Europe, culture is the third largest employment centre in the European Union, with just over 7 million jobs and a turnover of more than 540 billion euros per year.  Creators, authors, publishers, etc., call for vigilance. Copyright is by no way a limit to innovation. On the contrary, it allows authors, artists, etc. to be alive. It allows the creation and protection of the works of the mind.  The future of Europe is knowledge, innovation and culture. By finally including culture in the Europe 2020 strategy, we will highlight our most valuable assets. By promoting copyright, we will be able to secure Europe's place in the global knowledge economy. As Paul Ricoeur said: "No culture is universal, but each represents a path to the universal, a singular experience of humanity that, like language, exists only in the plural."

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the initial report on copyright, which aims to take the European Parliament's position on what direction future copyright reform in the EU is to take. In order to adapt copyright to the new challenges of the digital age, there is a need to modernise copyright rules in order to develop Europe's cultural and creative sector. The sector also deserves attention because it employs more than 7 million people and generates around 4.2% of GDP in the EU, and employment growth has not stopped there even during the economic crisis. In my opinion, the revision of the current directive should respect the principle of fair remuneration for rightholders. However, I support the affirmation of the principle of territoriality, on the basis of which each Member State will determine fair remuneration within the framework of its own cultural policy, as well as the principle of subsidiarity, which will enable a Member State to adopt specific legislation in accordance with its specific local conditions. These principles should mainly affect the disputed area of the so-called freedom of panorama: photography with sights or works of art and their subsequent publication on social networks.  I believe that photography and publication for private purposes should be free, but commercial exploitation for profit purposes involving companies should be clearly and fairly regulated so that copyright is taken into account.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The text of the Reda Report  is overall very progressive including paragraphs reinforcing the importance of copyright. The only element that was controversial was paragraph 46 that restricts the ‘freedom of panorama’. The paragraph requires that for commercial use any photographs, video footage or other images of works which are permanently located in physical public places should always be subject to prior authorisation from the authors or any proxy acting for them. This paragraph as it stands restricts the so-called freedom of panorama to non-commercial use only. My personal opinion was to support any amendment that aims to change the reference to non-commercial uses and to fix the issues with the EU freedom of panorama. I am in favour of absolute freedom to photograph and publish photos of public buildings, monuments and art and I will support any amendments or deletions in the report which will reflect this position, therefore I have voted against paragraph 46 but in favour if the final report.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. This own-initiative report by Parliament, which highlights the existing problems in European copyright law, aims at modernisation and harmonisation at European level. The aim is to strike a balance between the protection of artists and the rights of consumers. I also voted in favour of maintaining freedom of panorama, which ensures that images of works permanently in public spaces do not require the consent of rightholders for non-commercial purposes.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to support the revision of Directive 2001/29/EC is essential for the promotion of creativity and innovation, cultural diversity, economic growth, competitiveness, the Digital Single Market and access to knowledge and information, while granting authors of literary and artistic works sufficient recognition and protection of their rights. I believe that Europe's cultural and creative industries are an engine of economic growth and job creation in the EU and make an important contribution to the EU economy, thus voting in favour of this report.  I would also stress the importance of authors receiving a serious and fair remuneration from producers, and should receive a fair value and according to the digital views verified. I also find it unacceptable that there is a restriction on the freedom to photograph public buildings when it comes to their use for non-commercial purposes.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour MEPs are committed to ensuring that the Commission, when proposing its copyright reform, takes on board the views of creators, industry and consumers so that we can take forward a copyright system which works fairly for all. This includes enhanced rights for creators of cultural content, and increased possibility for portability of services and access to cross-border content.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and neighbouring rights. The EPP Group, of which I am a member, has set out to balance this text in order to reconcile the interests of creators and citizen-users. The aim is to strengthen and adapt copyright to the new challenges of the digital age while ensuring access to cultural content for as many people as possible. I am committed to the principle of fair remuneration for the work and talent of authors and to the maintenance of sustainable funding mechanisms for cultural creation. These are essential to continue to promote economic activity in the field of culture, which accounts for 7.1 million jobs in Europe.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The completion of the single market, including in its aspects of the digital economy, is of crucial importance to Europe. The benefits for consumers of an integrated digital society are well known.  Equally well known is the objective importance of the creative and cultural industry for the European economy, amounting to EUR 500 billion of GDP and 7 million workers in employment. For these companies and these workers creativity and culture are real "factors of production". Copyright is therefore the driving force behind the cultural and creative industries, so that they continue to be a strategic sector for competitiveness, growth and employment in Europe.  Consequently, in addition to ensuring fairer and easier access to cultural content for consumers, the report has protected the right of artists and producers to fair remuneration for the product of their work. A protection of cultural investment which – for a Europe 'united in diversity' – is essential. The preservation of Europe's 'cultural diversity' requires special attention to territorial specificities and customs, which is clearly reaffirmed in the report. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution in order to promote sustainable, inclusive and culturally plural growth in the EU.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Initially, this text was intended to provide an overview of the country-by-country application of the 2001 Copyright Directive, particularly in relation to the new digital environment. Through a long negotiation, we reaffirmed the principle of fair remuneration for the work and talent of creators, and the need to maintain sustainable funding mechanisms for cultural creation. The challenge is also to continue to offer in Europe an environment conducive to economic activity, that of the cultural and creative sectors, generating jobs (7.1 million jobs) that are not "relocable" and attractive to the younger generation. The European Parliament this morning sent a very clear message to the European Commission, which announced its intention to propose before the end of the year a revision of the 2001 Copyright Directive, in the context of the completion of the European digital market: yes to an adaptation of copyright in the digital age, no to its questioning.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report to support the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights like the freedom of authors in the public domain and online access to non-commercial works.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aimed to bring the regulation of copyright up to date with technological advances in the digital age. This report aims to not only defend the rights of artists to be fairly remunerated for their intellectual property in the digital age, but also extends rights to the public and consumers. I am in favour of rights for consumers to access content without undue restrictions such as geo-blocking, provided that intellectual property creators are remunerated fairly. I voted against amendment 46, the so-called panorama amendment, which aimed to restrict the free use of images and photographs of public buildings. I also voted no to Amendment 1, ‘After § 57’. While this amendment was couched in the language of protecting quality journalism, it is better known as the ‘snippet tax’, or ‘Google tax’ and it was aimed at restricting the rights of internet users to hyperlink to other websites without paying a fee. If either of these two amendments had passed, I would not have been able to support the report. However, both fell, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which supports the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the light of new technologies, development and the fact that much of the interaction is happening today at the computer level. In this respect, the legislation already in force has lost track of development, leading to situations where certain internet content cannot be accessed geographically, which is contrary to the objectives of the EU digital market. It is precisely this increasing use of the ROMANIAN IT domain and the lack of strong legislation and its failure to properly apply that makes those who have the right to be fairly remunerated for their creations not receiving anything, even their work being misused. For this reason, I felt that this legislation needed to be changed and I supported this report.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2001 on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society aroused considerable emotions because of one of the JURI proposals, which could have been a call for a break in the freedom of panorama. I supported the deletion of this point from the report and therefore the retention of existing legislation, which gives Member States the choice of whether to impose full panorama freedom in their legal systems or to restrict it with the consent of copyright owners. The heated, sometimes hysterically heated debate, in which myths prevailed over reality, might not have happened at all if the rapporteur had stuck to the original assignment and limited her report to analysing the implementation of the directive in force and not arbitrarily interpreted it as a concept of revising copyright law in the EU, which, in view of the dynamic development of modern technologies, is one of the most complex and sensitive areas of EU law.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report was previously highly controversial, but was then defused on key points. I see it as a step towards modernising our copyright and taking better account of the creative performance of artists and media people. I therefore supported it.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill after the restriction of panoramic photos was voted out. Copyrights need modernisation so that they do not get in the way of the opportunities of the digital age and meet the needs of both consumers and creators. I do not consider it reasonable or supported to restrict the taking and use of panoramic photographs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Harmonisation of copyright protection is of paramount importance to ensure that creative sectors in Europe continue to develop. In a context where infringement of intellectual property is on the agenda, I would like to thank Mrs Reda for her work and hope that I have contributed.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – As the EPP Group’s rapporteur for the Harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society in the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, I am happy to see that the final text reflects the EPP position and provides a more balanced account. This report does not include any compulsory legislative parameters, but is seen as a harbinger for the direction of future legislation. Our aim is to strike a balance between the interests of service users, distributors and copyright holders. This would also enable a quick and seamless transition to the new digital economic model. A harmonized approach to copyright in all 28 Member States will overcome divisions between large and small, central and peripheral countries, giving artists an equal chance to develop their ideas and promote their products.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported a non-legislative resolution assessing the implementation of key aspects of copyright law in the EU. European copyright rules must strike a fair balance between the rights and interests of creators and consumers. I am in favour of improving cross-border access to content and services, while respecting terrestrial licences, especially as regards audiovisual and film production. Authors and creators need to improve the starting point for correct remuneration when it comes to digital distribution and exploitation of their works, while improving their position towards other rightholders. As regards paintings of public buildings and works of art, the current European legislation leaves the Member States free to regulate them.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since we live in a digital age characterled by rapid development and the need for control, there is an emergency for the adoption of new modern copyright regulations in which all interested parties must be satisfied. The right to private property is one of the fundamental human rights, therefore photographs, poems, video content and other creative constructions must not be used and published without the prior authorization of the authors of this content.  Rapid development leads to many aspects of the existing copyright regulation not being regulated, so there is still a high possibility of theft and piracy. Furthermore, copyright protection is the basis for the quality functioning of the EU market and the development of this business segment, as it represents great potential, and it is of great importance that every consumer is familiar with all elements of the content they use, in particular the information whether they use authorized or illegal content.  I believe that it is necessary to harmonise certain aspects of copyright and related rights because it is of great importance to control the exchange and use of information which is not easy since we live in an accelerated information society. For this reason, I supported this resolution on the implementation of the Directive on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is based on concepts derived from Anglo-Saxon law such as copyright and thus threatens the French and continental conceptions of copyright. The problem of piracy and the issue of tax provisions are not addressed or too evasively. However, this is an area where unfair tax competition is raging within the European Union itself, as Mr Juncker is well placed to know. The other elements of the text (neighbouring copyright rights, the notion of originality , still not defined - or the issues of ownership) leave the great gap between the copyright regime and that of copyright.  It is therefore a mediocre text, as it is incomplete, and does not respect the legal tradition of copyright developed in many European Union states. So I'm voting against it.

name: RedaTonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support a report by colleague Redae that partially creates guidelines for future, undeniably necessary, copyright regulation. It is clear that the current system of regulation is completely incompatible with the technological developments that have taken place in recent years and it is necessary to find a new compromise between the legitimate rights of authors to receive compensation for the content they produce, but also the consumer's right to access the content regardless of their location. I do not agree with the suggestion that the commercial use of photographs, videos and other images or works permanently located in a public space should always be subject to prior authorization by the authors or their authorised representatives, and I am pleased that this part has been successfully removed from the report. In particular, I support the part of the report relating to blocking content depending on the geographical location of consumers, putting minorities across Europe at particular disadvantage. The European Union is in theory a single market and should also become one in practice, with adequate protection of the rights of authors who need to be compensated for their work.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the amendment to Directive 2001/29/EC on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society, in line with the opinions of the Legal Affairs Committee, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee.  At the same time, I welcome the Efforts of the Commission, which is committed to further developing the EU digital agenda, including copyright issues. Copyright and other related rights protect and encourage the development and promotion of new products and services, while at the same time europe's cultural and innovative economic sector is an important factor in technological progress and a driver of economic growth and job creation within the EU. This is supported by the fact that even during the last economic crisis, the sector employed more than 7 million people. In this way, authors and artists directly contribute to increasing competitiveness, employment and growth in the number of innovations in a larger number of economic sectors in the EU, and it is therefore necessary that authors of literary and other works of art are at the same time provided with adequate recognition and protection of their rights.  EU creative production is one of its more branded determinants and therefore amending this Directive is key to fostering the value of creativity and innovation, cultural diversity, economic growth, competitiveness, the uniqueness of the digital market and access to knowledge and information.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European artists undeniably deserve their position to be consolidated and their copyright better protected. However, this does not change the fact that we cannot allow the rights of European citizens to be literally ruthlessly restricted at the expense of this. That is why I voted against the amendment tabled by Jean-Marie Cavada in the context of the report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. As the media has reported abundantly, this part of the report could have enormous consequences if it were managed by the European Commission in the future. It is inconceived that, at a time of strong technological development, citizens' rights should be curtailed to such an extent that they simply cannot share the photos they take in public spaces. Not only could the adoption of this provision have led to a reduction in the dissemination of non-commercially acquired images on social media, but it may also have hit, for example, the still growing trend of blogging or the use of internet encyclopedia. Although I support the wider use of electronic libraries for better access to information or to limit the power of large corporations at the expense of artists, which are some of the positive aspects that the report contained and for which I voted, I still have a tinge to the language. The afterthest from the fact that the Committee on Legal Affairs allowed a meanness for citizens of this caliber to reach the plenary assembly.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Julie Red's report on copyright has rightly raised concerns among the European public, including the Czech public, in particular because of a paragraph proposing a restriction on the so-called freedom of panorama. If the principle of freedom of panorama is applied, it means in practice that the person who records or in some way expresses (photographically, drawing, film, etc.) a publicly placed work does not interfere with copyright and does not need to obtain a license. Different states have this right regulated differently, in the Czech Republic there is a relatively large freedom of panorama. Although this problematic paragraph restricted exclusively the commercial use of photographs, videos or other images of works, its impact could have a much broader implication. I am therefore very glad that, after internal discussions in the European Parliament, within the political group and across the political spectrum, we have reached a decision to remove the proposed measure from the text, and today we have adopted a useful document that will serve as the basis for the Commission's new legislative proposals. Our aim for the future should be better protection of copyright, but I consider and will always be unacceptable to make life more difficult for ordinary internet users.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this oft-misinterpreted proposal, as it aims to protect consumers and authors and strengthen the European single market. Harmonisation of copyright will open up the entire European market for national authors, make the same content available to all consumers and improve the competitiveness of European cultural production, which is essential for functioning in today's rapidly evolving technological world.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 9 July 2015, the European Parliament adopted Mrs Reda's controversial non-legislative report. The report focuses on aspects of the implementation of the Information Society Directive before the European Commission submits a proposal to reform copyright, to be presented at a later date. Among the provisions of the report m.in controversial issue of the panorama, which arouses great public dissatisfaction.  The ECC Group supports maintaining the status quo in the Member States and has voted in favour of removing any references to the 'panorama law' project, as the proposed solution is inappropriate and restricts citizens' rights. As a result, due to the fact that there is a difference of opinion on this issue between EU Member States, the report was adopted without any reference to the 'panorama law'.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 If the original draft report had passed today, it would have made it difficult, for example, to publish any calendar with photographs of modern architecture in my native Pilsen. I therefore voted in favour of the amendment, of which I was a co-author, which sought to preserve the so-called freedom of panorama, i.e. the possibility, for example, of photographing public buildings or permanently displayed works of art in public. Although the proposal did not pass, at least with my support, the whole mention of the limitations of photography was omed from the report, so that the freedom of the panorama was also withered thanks to public pressure.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Since 2001, a European directive has governed certain aspects of copyright and neighbouring rights. In autumn 2015, the European Commission will propose a further reform of this directive. In this context, Parliament adopted an initiative report on the implementation of the 2001 directive and proposing possible developments.  I voted in favour of this report, which has nevertheless been the subject of several criticisms of the freedom of panorama. I would like to reassure the public that the panorama exception was respected in the report. Freedom of panorama remains the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Today, MEPs adopted MEP Julia Reda's initiative report on harmonising certain aspects of copyright.  I voted for this report which, thanks to the work and involvement of the Socialists, proposes a whole series of balanced recommendations to the European Commission in order to protect cultural diversity and the remuneration of authors, while ensuring the viability of this sector in an environment rapidly evolving with new information and communication technologies.  Through this report, we call on the Commission to maintain the principle of copyright exception, which exempts users in some cases from applying for authorisation to reproduce copyrighted works, without expanding its application to the digital domain and leaving Some leeway for Member States to define their exceptions to copyright.  The text we voted on also reaffirms the possibility of negotiating rights on a territorial basis and clearly rejects the principle of "fair use" in the United States, which may limit and weaken the author's exclusive rights.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament overwhelmingly adopted the Reda report on copyright #x2028. At the heart of the discussions between Members in plenary is the proposal adopted by the Committee on Legal Affairs to restrict the freedom of panorama, this exception to the copyright by which it is permissible for any person to draw, photograph or film buildings or works of art in the public space and to disseminate the result without having to obtain the prior permission of the rightful holders. Today, each country legislates as it sees fit. Belgium is one of the few countries to restrict this freedom.  By their vote, MEPs have clearly expressed their opposition to this restriction. In principle, social media users will be able to continue to post selfies in front of public buildings or in front of works of art without being limited by copyright. Other amateur photographers will have to continue to rely on the tolerance of the rightful holders while waiting for a European harmonisation that I call for in order to make the freedom of panorama a reality.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The digitization and popularization of content exchange via virtual platforms has forced states to adapt their legislation by carrying out major copyright reforms.  By a directive, the Commission had signalled its willingness to harmonize these legislative frameworks at European level. This report, aimed at anticipating such work, initially proved to be a very unbalanced text leading to the destruction of copyright, without protecting users.  Finally, after a collective effort punctuated by bitter negotiations, we reached a compromise dealing in a reasoned way with the problems of geographical blocking (the practice of addressing content only to users of a given area), the single European title or private copies. I therefore welcome the adoption of this text, which preserves cultural wealth within the Union while creating a draft common framework for copyright.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists have always advocated the need to guarantee fair remuneration to authors because without it there is no sustainable cultural creation.  Europe has a thriving sector in its cultural industries, capable of continuing to create jobs in the midst of a crisis. And copyright is the basis on which cultural industries are based. Europe needs to revise its legislation to adapt it to the digital environment and harness its potential to generate new jobs and innovative industries. But copyright reform should be avoided as a clash between authors and users.  Following the profound changes made to parliamentary work, largely thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, the report is committed to ensuring fair remuneration to authors and improving their contractual position, as well as advancing citizens' better access to culture, improving the portability of legally acquired content; recognizes the importance of territorial licensing in the field of film and television, calls for reviewing the role of internet intermediaries, calls for solutions for the shift of value from content to services, and refuses to limit freedom of panorama, among other aspects. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. Copyright cannot be equated with obstruction, when it is precisely copyright that allows artists to make a living from their art. However, Ms. Reda's initial project threatened artistic creation and diversity in Europe: she wanted to challenge the European copyright framework, proposing the total harmonisation of exceptions or the reduction of the duration of rights.  However, the European Socialists and Democrats have succeeded in dismissing these dangerous proposals for the sustainability and vitality of creation in Europe by finding a balance between the various stakeholders, in order to strengthen a sustainable creative economy in Europe.  The compromises adopted exclude the introduction of fair use or a total harmonisation of exceptions, as Mrs Reda wanted. By avoiding this levelling down, the position of the authors in the cultural landscape and the sustainability of European creation are strengthened. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this resolution is to adapt copyright and related rights legislation to new technologies, in particular the information society, and to implement the international obligations arising from the two treaties adopted under the auspices of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) in December 1996. To this end, the resolution makes a set of recommendations for legislative reform that the Commission is expected to present by the end of the year, precisely to modernise legislation, making it more compatible with the new digital age we live in. The report deals with the new rules on the right of reproduction, the right of communication to the public and the right of distribution, which deserve my agreement and also addresses issues such as geo-blocking, the promotion of creativity and the remuneration of rightholders. A last reference to mention that I voted against the provision on freedom of panorama, because I do not consider it acceptable that the commercial use of photographs, video images or other images of works that are permanently exhibited in public physical places always lacks the prior authorization of their authors.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reaffirms the principle of fair remuneration for the work of creators and stresses the need to maintain sustainable funding mechanisms for cultural creation. The text also sets out concrete proposals to adapt copyright to digital challenges by strengthening it and ensuring a balance between respect for intellectual property and access to cultural content for as many people as possible.  The challenge is important as it is a question of building an environment conducive to the cultural and creative sectors that allows for job creation and remains attractive to the younger generation.  With the adoption of this text, we have sent a clear message to the Commission as part of the forthness of the forthness of the 2001 Copyright Directive.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Reda on the harmonization of certain aspects of copyright and related rights. A report that initially seemed doubtful to me, it was necessary to strike the right balance between the protection of copyright in the digital age, which also helps to ensure respect for European cultural diversity, and access to content and services by citizens. After several negotiations in committee, the PPE has managed to get a text adopted which reflects the balance of rights indicated in the compromises. One point in the text that I find particularly interesting is the ability of industry to embrace digital technologies to ensure that the end user has better access. The 'digital' game is a game that Europe is playing on several fronts and the creative sector will also benefit from important results.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on the report on harmonisation of specific copyright aspects. We understand that there has to be a tendency to homogenize the different intra-Community laws. However, this homogenization must take into account the different pillars on which the so-called knowledge society is based, it must take care of equal opportunities and access to the content that occurs and must also protect the authors of such content by ensuring legal spaces of dissemination that do not harm consumer access. The idea of a digital single market has its good points, but it also has its bad points. With a digital single market, copyright taxation can be pursued throughout the European Union, so specificities would be lost. These specificities are criticized for limiting access, but in some cases are necessary for fair remuneration from creators (emphasis on several sections of the document (25, 26 and 27)). They are also necessary to promote the management by each country according to the needs related to their own conditions.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I respect and admire artistic creation and I believe that it should enjoy a legislative context that simultaneously promotes and defends it. Digital platforms have brought a challenge, as it is necessary to find the ideal balance between artists' remuneration and democratization of access to artistic production. I believe that a new approach to copyright is urgently needed to address this new reality, without coarcting the rights of access and sharing of citizens in general.
