I regret, in this context, that it was not possible to vote and approve the notion of the right of irrepressible remuneration subject to collective management.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to ensure that images taken in public spaces remain free to use as part of a report on comprehensive copyright reform. I will always support the freedom of panorama.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. Copyright must adapt to the possibilities of the digital era. On the other hand, European culture must be protected and promoted, which necessarily means protecting the rights of authors. The forthcoming reform of copyright must strike a balance between the interests of creators, rightholders and, above all, consumers themselves.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the report evaluating the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2001 on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. The copyrights defined in this 2001 European legislation are not perfect. Since 2001, there has been a great deal of progress in the cultural and creative industries, making a significant contribution to the EU economy, employing more than 7 million people and, according to the latest estimates, making up more than 4.2% of GDP in the EU. Technological progress in the digital market is making great progress, so it is essential that authors and performers are given legal protection for their creative and artistic activities, while authors and performers in the digital environment must receive an appropriate remuneration to the same extent as in the analogue environment. The current differences in legislation between Member States also create legal uncertainty, which is an obstacle to the creation of the Digital Single Market and the cross-border availability of copyright-protected content. Therefore, the Commission should swiftly adopt a new Copyright Directive to address the current problems.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Julie Order report on copyright and related rights in the information society aims to improve the European copyright legal framework and bring them into line with digital progress and the environment. At the same time, the purpose of the report is to maintain a fair balance between rightholders, on the one hand, and users on the other. This report is the first so-called milestone by the European Parliament, which calls for mandatory minimum standards for users' rights in the field of copyright in the digital environment. The report also calls for a reduction in so-called territorial blocking measures, in particular with a view to enabling cultural minorities to have online access to content in their own language. The report also calls on libraries and scientists to comply with exceptions, particularly in the field of electronic publications, such as electronic borrowing of fixed-term material. I also believe that panoramic images of buildings and monuments should be accessible to all, and I am pleased that the proposed amendment was not supported by parliament. As Mrs Reda's report is well structured and represents a major step forward in the area of copyright in the digital environment, I voted in favour of its adoption in the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report on the Implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and the Council of 22 May 2001 on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society, as it is necessary to harmonise aspects of copyright and related rights while taking into account technological progress. It is invested heavily in digitalisation, allowing citizens to access online collections of European institutions from any device. In addition, Europe's cultural and innovative sector drives European growth and creates jobs and employs more than 7 million people. Copyright is a concrete means of ensuring the payment of compensation to creators, and thus finances creative processes. Creative works drive digital and information economy actors such as online search engines and social media.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this INI report setting out the European Parliament’s position on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. We need to ensure that right holders are fairly remunerated for their creative output. However, at the same time we need to adjust the copyright regime to digital realities and ensure consumers have access to services and content they have paid for wherever they are in the EU. I believe the report is quite balanced: it addresses these concerns and aims to introduce potential solutions to update the current copyright regime to make it fit for the digital age.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the final text of this report because I believe that, although the initial text of the report in particular has been missed by the commission, a balanced text has been reached as a result, allowing us to continue the debate on the reform of intellectual property rights in the European Union in order to achieve a modern regulation that respects the legitimate interests of creators, right holders and users.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome many of the ideas included in this report which support the creative industry and evidence-based improvements to the current legal framework. However at today’s vote one outstanding issue of concern remained regarding the freedom of panorama and a clause which would alter the status quo in the UK regarding commercial use exceptions. I believe that Member States should retain flexibility in this area and I do not support an EU-approach to this issue. I therefore voted to delete references to the freedom of panorama today.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report also harms, in addition to others, the freedom of panorama, which is fully recognised and protected by law in a number of EU Member States. This is the self-evident right that allows all citizens to acquire and share photographs, videos or other images of buildings, sculptures and other artistic creations that are permanently in public places.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Directive 2001/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2001 on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society'. The Commission's commitment to copyright issues is to be welcomed. The report will further help to make copyright and related rights fully in their role as invigorating innovation and competitiveness.  I think it is right that the report addresses the denial of access to content on a territorial basis and underlines that it runs counter to the objectives of achieving the four internal freedoms. I welcome the proposal by the Commission to develop solutions to improve consumers' cross-border access to services and copyrighted content. I also support the proposal to examine the impact of single European copyright protection on jobs and innovation. At the same time, I stress that, as important as copyright protection is, we must not overdo it and over-regulate the area in an extreme way, creating impossible situations in the digital world. This also justified my firm action against the intention to restrict the freedom of panorama and, more importantly, to ensure freedom of panorama at European level.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Mrs Reda's report has aroused a great deal of media interest and excitement among both creative circles and internet users, in particular on the issue of the so-called freedom of panorama, to which there is no reference in the final text of the report.  Nevertheless, I have decided to abstain from voting on the final text for two reasons. Firstly, it is an own-initiative report which will not change the rules in any Member State of the European Union, but merely indicates a wish list of what should be improved and in which areas the Commission should carry out analyses on the future harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights. As a result, we therefore maintain the status quo, according to which each Member State will, as before, decide for itself whether to impose restrictions on the so-called freedom of panorama.  Secondly, I feel that the report should focus on the implementation of the Information Society Directive, but very little space has been devoted to the final text of this issue.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against with conviction and regret. With regret, because Julia Reda had produced an excellent report. With conviction, because it has been modified to the point of becoming unacceptable. First of all, the basic 'philosophy' is unacceptable: culture is regarded as a commodity produced for profit. Michelangelo did not paint the Sistine Chapel to charge the entrance fee: this relationship suffocates in the cradle the artistic inspiration of any author. The ability to rework other people's content is also reduced to the possibility of making caricatures and pastiches. If ancient Rome had copyright rules like these, it could not have handed down buildings and statues to us, since greek models have frequently been reworked. Latin writers such as Plautus or Terentius, instead of occupying a prominent place in the history of literature, would have goed into trouble for copyright infringement held by Greek authors. With norms like these, the entire Italian Renaissance would not have been since the starting point and inspiration of artists and literates were the works handed down from ancient Rome and Greece. Unfortunately, the majority of the European Parliament, in approving this report, voted against art and culture.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current report intends to set Parliament’s position on copyrights, in view of the upcoming Commission proposal on the copyright reform, due to be released in the autumn. The text represents several key elements. Mainly:  1) restating the principle of territoriality; 2) safeguarding works that are in the public domain, and any digitisation of these works; 3) applying minimum standards across the exceptions and limitations; 4) providing accessibility of exceptions and limitations to people with disabilities; 5) revising the liability of intermediaries; 6) asking for more transparency regarding the private copying levies; 7) calling for a full scientific evaluation by the IPR Observatory on national legislations that introduced ancillary rights. The only controversial element in the report was a restriction on the freedom of panorama. Upon a mutual agreement between all political groups, the paragraph was deleted from the report and is not mentioned in the voted text.  This report provides a balance between ensuring the rights of authors and performers, on the one hand, and access to culture and information on the other. It ensures a good climate for the creative sector and the preservation of the European cultural diversity, therefore I voted in favour of it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. There are needed improvements in copyright, for creators and consumers. Through this future reform, we want to increase coherence between European legislation, improve the digital single market but also increase access to knowledge and information for all European citizens. For now, both authors and users face real uncertainty about the acquisition of works. It is necessary to preserve Europe's cultural and creative industries, but also to ensure everyone's access to culture, including in the digital world.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the initiative report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights. With the Digital Single Market, the European Union is jumping into the digital era which, for the cultural industry, is a challenge as great as the opportunities it brings. Therefore it is necessary to set out our intentions as regards the harmonisation of copyright across the EU, in prevision of a Commission proposal. I supported the provisions recalling the necessity of addressing geo-blocking and ensuring the portability of rights, in respect of the freedom of movement on which the internal market is built: consumers should not be denied access to certain content based on their geographical location in the EU. I opposed the provision restricting the freedom of panorama because I believe one should be able to record images of a public landmark and use it as one wishes. Public space is, by definition, public and its use should not be subject to any kind of authorisation. That is why I voted to delete the paragraph restricting the freedom of panorama.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I support many of the high-quality proposals in this report, such as factually based improvements to the legal framework; calls on the Commission to assess what measures could have a positive effect on legal certainty; the notion that copyright is effective only to the extent that the legal measures that protect them are effective; appropriate and fair remuneration for all categories of authors, etc.  However, I object to too restrictive and disproportionate Amendment 421, which recommends that painting public buildings/statues/monuments can only be justified and allowed in cases where such painting has not been undertaken for commercial purposes. In doing so, the commercial purpose would not imply journalism, nor would it be regarded as such an image in whose background the landmark is located. This Amendment directly undermines the principle of subsidiarity, and I see no purpose in attempting to install it as an area within the competence of the Union, rather than as the exclusive competence of each Member State individually.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The purpose of the Directive is to harmonising certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society. The Commission intends to modernise the copyright framework and is therefore expected to propose a revision of that directive in the autumn. Copyright reform should contribute to the further development of technologies, cultural exchange and improved legal certainty in the creative sector. It is important to ensure a high level of intellectual property security, thus encouraging investment in innovation, protecting jobs and helping to create new ones. The European People's Party supports the balance between user access and fair remuneration for creators, taking into account SMEs, which is why I supported this report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on the report on harmonisation of specific copyright aspects. We understand that there has to be a tendency to homogenize the different intra-Community laws. However, this homogenization must take into account the different pillars on which the so-called knowledge society is based, it must take care of equal opportunities and access to the content that occurs and must also protect the authors of such content by ensuring legal spaces of dissemination that do not harm consumer access. The idea of a digital single market has its good points, but it also has its bad points. With a digital single market, copyright taxation can be pursued throughout the European Union, so specificities would be lost. These specificities are criticized for limiting access, but in some cases are necessary for fair remuneration from creators (emphasis on several sections of the document (25, 26 and 27)). They are also necessary to promote the management by each country according to the needs related to their own conditions.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted to protect freedom of panorama, as I am completely opposed to obligatory authorisation for the use of images from public places. In the internet era, that is an unenforceable and backward idea.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Vigilance focuses on the introduction of concepts derived from Anglo-Saxon law such as copyright, and respect for the French and continental conception of copyright. Attention is also focused on other elements of the text such as copyright rights, the concept of originality, which is still not defined, or issues of ownership, which leave the large gap between the copyright and copyright regimes. The issue of piracy and the tax provisions are not addressed in the report or too evasively. Yet Google and others are repatriating their profits made in France to parent companies with advantageous taxation, even within the Union... This further harmonisation of European intellectual property law is unnecessary. An adaptation of the principles developed by French law is preferable.  I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on the report on harmonisation of specific copyright aspects. We understand that there has to be a tendency to homogenize the different intra-Community laws. However, this homogenization must take into account the different pillars on which the so-called knowledge society is based, it must take care of equal opportunities and access to the content that occurs and must also protect the authors of such content by ensuring legal spaces of dissemination that do not harm consumer access. The idea of a digital single market has its good points, but it also has its bad points. With a digital single market, copyright taxation can be pursued throughout the European Union, so specificities would be lost. These specificities are criticized for limiting access, but in some cases are necessary for fair remuneration from creators (emphasis on several sections of the document (25, 26 and 27)). They are also necessary to promote the management by each country according to the needs related to their own conditions.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which says 'no' at the 'Google' rate and 'yes' to freedom of panorama.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Although digital technologies have no boundaries in nature, internet users in Europe are facing a number of challenges, including the different copyright requirements. The main problem faced by millions of Internet users on a daily basis, including in Latvia, with regard to purchases and online availability of audiovisual and cultural products, is geo-blocking or limiting internet content by customer location. For example, many have been faced with a situation where selected Latvian TV shows or Youtube videos cannot be watched while abroad, while foreign TV channels or authors and performers are not available in Latvia. I believe that copyright rules need to be made simpler and clearer, freeing up unnecessary restrictions on the availability of digital content, as well as making web content and services equally accessible in all EU countries. I therefore voted in favour of the report's position on uniform rules for the cross-border availability of protected content. The benefits of common EU rules for cross-border access to content will benefit not only consumers, but also authors and performers, who will have more market opportunities in disseminating their works. Of course, legislation must ensure that authors and performers receive equally fair compensation in both the digital and analogue environments.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, first and foremost because it calls for the necessity to provide authors and performers with legal protection for their creative and artistic work. The document also recognises the important role of producers and publishers in bringing works to the market, thus calling for the need to ensure that all categories of right-holders receive appropriate remuneration. The second crucial aspect of the report concerns, on the other hand, any work in the public domain which is not subject to any copyright protection and must therefore be able to be used without any contractual barrier. This concept applies, for example, in the case of photographs, video footage or other images of works which are permanently located in public places, whose free use must be guaranteed by the EU legislator.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Copyright reform can contribute to further development of technologies and cultural exchange, and improve the legal situation of the sector. It is necessary to be able to have a balance between user access to content and the fair remuneration of creators, always taking into account the position of small and medium-sized enterprises. This report takes account of this above-mentioned balance, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists have always advocated the need to guarantee fair remuneration to authors because without it there is no sustainable cultural creation.  Europe has a thriving sector in its cultural industries, capable of continuing to create jobs in the midst of a crisis. And copyright is the basis on which cultural industries are based. Europe needs to revise its legislation to adapt it to the digital environment and harness its potential to generate new jobs and innovative industries. But copyright reform should be avoided as a clash between authors and users.  Following the profound changes made to parliamentary work, largely thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, the report is committed to ensuring fair remuneration to authors and improving their contractual position, as well as advancing citizens' better access to culture, improving the portability of legally acquired content; recognizes the importance of territorial licensing in the field of film and television, calls for reviewing the role of internet intermediaries, calls for solutions for the shift of value from content to services, and refuses to limit freedom of panorama, among other aspects. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – Whilst good copyright legislation is essential for competitiveness and entrepreneurship, the proposed paragraph on ‘freedom of panorama’ would have meant that permission would be needed to use even background or chance photos of public buildings, statues and landmarks for commercial purposes. Although this is the case in some Member States already, in the UK under Section 62 of the Copyright Designs and Patents Act photographers can freely use such photos. With my Conservative colleagues, I voted against this paragraph so that our photographers can continue to act freely rather than have other countries trying to impose their restrictive laws on us. This is a minor example of why subsidiarity and national sovereignty must be respected.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my EPLP and Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because the report is an own-initiative, but it will be important in setting out the Parliament’s views before the Commission’s copyright reform proposal, due by the end of the year. The report also stresses that copyright is only as effective as the enforcement measures in place to protect it and that in order to ensure a flourishing and innovative creative sector copyright enforcement must be robust. A lot of focus in the media and in public campaigns has been on an amendment added to the report by the Liberal group which threatened freedom of panorama – I voted with my Labour colleagues against this amendment, and it was strongly rejected in the vote. The Labour Party will vote against any amendment which negatively affects the current UK provisions on freedom of panorama.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The current copyright framework dates back to 2001 and does not take into account developments, particularly in the area of digital. Its review is due to take place by the end of the year.  This initiative report sought to assess the current framework and practices to establish a number of recommendations for review.  The debate on this issue is always very sensitive since it is a question of dealing not only with copyright itself, but also with the whole of cultural policy and the practices of Europeans with interests that may seem contradictory. The debate took time, but the result presented allowed a fair balance between the rights and interests of creators and users.  The European Parliament calls for fair and appropriate remuneration for all categories of rights holders, including (and above all) in the digital distribution of their works. At the same time, it proposes a relaxation of the rules, particularly in the area of geographical blocking, to allow everyone greater access to culture and knowledge.  So I chose to vote for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report stresses that Europe's cultural and creative industries are an engine of economic growth and job creation in the EU and make an important contribution to the EU economy, employing more than 7 million people and generating more than 4.2 % of EU GDP, according to the latest estimates, and whereas cultural industries continued to create jobs during the 2008-2012 economic crisis. The report defends the public domain and involves internet operators in the problem, points with which we agree. It advocates limiting the use of works, regards private property as a pillar of creativity and, with regard to private copying, advocates harmonisation of schemes but does not clarify in what sense, aspects with which we do not agree. It emphasizes the importance of libraries for access to knowledge, advocating the adoption of exceptions that legally allow public and research libraries to lend works in digital format to the public for personal use through the internet or library networks, as well as digitizing content for consultation, cataloging and archive purposes, and authors should receive fair compensation for loans of digital content , equivalent to that received for the loan of physical books, in accordance with national territorial restrictions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I have made my vote conditional on Amendment No 3 or the relevant paragraph on freedom of panorama. Although the amendment on this point was rejected, the original text as such was not adopted either. I voted in favour of the report because of the fact that freedom of panorama has been guaranteed. In my opinion, copyright is a particularly important aspect and it should be appropriately protectiond.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative report by MEPs in the Legal Affairs Committee. The Commission will propose a wide-ranging copyright reform by the end of this year, and the European Parliament has been at the forefront of keeping the debate going on the freedom of panorama – the  right to take photographs in public places without infringing copyright – and  other issues.  Labour MEPs supported amendments that rejected any changes to freedom of panorama in the UK. After the clear public objection to restricting freedom of panorama, we will be able to send a strong message that we do not want to see any similar measures in future proposals.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the harmonisation of certain aspects of copyright and related rights in the information society because, in connection with this area, the situation of many of the industries is quite complicated.  I welcome the rapporteur's appreciation of the Commission's commitment to further developing the EU Digital Agenda, including the objective of modernising copyright rules. Moreover, the report recognises the need to revise Directive 2001/29/EC in order to ensure the adequate remuneration of authors, performers and other copyright holders and appropriate protection of these rights, as well as to strike an appropriate balance in the European cultural economy between all parties involved, namely SMEs, consumers, users, creators and rights holders, in a digital age involving an ever-changing and evolving technological environment that generates changes in user behaviour, as well as opportunities and challenges. I have read carefully the views that have been sent to me in connection with this report and I support the urgent need to revise Directive 2001/29/EC, taking into account the full complexity of the subject.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I oppose the proposal to limit the so-called freedom of panorama and believe that the current regulation in Czech legislation is sufficient and there is no need to seek harmonisation within the European Union. I am aware that some EU Member States, such as France, Belgium, Greece and Italy, have some limited freedom of panorama, but the current situation of member states deciding on this matter should not change when amending the directive.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Digital Revolution has also brought about many changes in intellectual property law. Finding a balance between the rights and obligations of authors and users is becoming increasingly difficult but necessary. Copyright limitation, e.g. limited periods of protection or the possibility of the public freely capturing the panorama, has its social, cultural and economic justification. The passionate debate on the freedom of panorama, which, even under our copyright law, makes it possible to reproduce publicly placed works without the consent of the author, has shown that the introduction of certain exceptions should continue to be decided by the Member States themselves. The balance between authors' rights and the public has its social, cultural and economic justification, since copyright is intended to protect authors, but also to serve society.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Copyright, like the rights of every author to dispose of his or her own work, should be subject to special protection. Intellectual property, like any other property, should be protected by law and no creator should feel that his legal position is weaker and that his or her rights to dispose of and benefit from his own work are ignored or marginalised.  The digital age has created many new opportunities for creators to present their works to a wide audience, but it has also led to new forms of copyright infringement. The European Union wants and must respond to this challenge and the need for proper regulation of copyright. In my opinion, the report adopted today is a good step in the right direction, which is why I voted in favour of it. However, it is not possible, in an attempt to protect the interests of creators, to cross the line of common sense. This was the case with the 'freedom of panorama', which has been the subject of widespread debate across the EU. I believe that it is unfounded and harmful to impose very strict regulations in this area on most Member States. Citizens cannot be held accountable, for example, for photographing famous places when travelling in Europe and wanting to share these photos with friends via social media platforms. For this reason, I voted against Amendment 46 restricting 'freedom of panorama'.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. There are several points on which we agree with this report, including the defence of the public domain and the involvement of internet operators in the problem. On the other hand, the report emphasizes the importance of libraries for access to knowledge, recommending the adoption of exceptions that legally allow public libraries and research to lend works in digital format to the public for personal use through the internet or library networks, as well as digitizing content for consultation, cataloging and archive purposes, which is important to ensure more equal access to knowledge.  We voted against the part of the text that required the prior authorisation of authors for the use of works that are in the public domain, because it seems to us that this should not be necessary. However, we do not agree with a perspective that places the fruiters of cultural content as the main responsible for the remuneration of authors, which should fall mainly on the platforms that profit from the availability of such content. That is why we do not agree with perspectives that limit content sharing or statements that "glorify" private property as a superior principle to uphold. We abstained.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, I could not support the report "Evaluating the activities of the European Foundation for Democracy" because I feel that there is nothing to dissemind in the kind of democracy that is practised here in the European Union and in Parliament. So-called pluralism would be a prerequisite for democracy, i.e. for different political interests to appear, to argue with each other, etc. There is a charade going on here, but everyone who spends their time here can see that the Socialists and the People's Party agree hand in hand every time it comes to representing the interests of banks and large capital companies, multinationals, fulfilling their orders, and Mr Martin Schulz and his pals apply the procedural rules according to it, e.g. the 'blue card' or the allow for spontaneous debate. , a "catch the eye" spontaneous speeches on exactly how these interests should be served to satisfy customers. That's not what I call democracy, and I don't want to spread that, so I voted no.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Fund for Democracy (EDF) has been used over the years to fight corruption, to fight corruption, to defend justice, to defend groups of activists when they were in danger, for the development of civil society, non-governmental organisations and, all this, in countries making the transition from dictatorship to democracy. As such, for me it is a very dear tool and fund because we have used it in Romania to the full and it has helped us in establishing democracy. In April 2015, this fund amounted to EUR 4.5 million through 158 initiatives. Between them is the neighbourhood policy which, again, is very important for the European Parliament.  Romania has also benefited from this funding in the past and we are seeing real progress today. Unfortunately, there are 12 Member States that have not contributed to this fund, as evidenced by the April 2015 statistics. One last sentence: stable funding is important and not stopping funding because (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report since the conviction that 'democratisation' cannot be a pretext for interference, regime changes and interventions in favour of EU geostrategic and imperialist interests in third countries.  Convinced that the European Endowment for Democracy is a violation of international laws and treaties and the principle of non-interference enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations, I have tabled a proposal for an alternative resolution through my parliamentary group urging the abolition of the DED, since neither this mechanism nor The European Neighbourhood Policy has ever contributed to the consolidation of democracy for the peoples , but to a widespread regression of social and economic rights through the imposition of free trade agreements and the consolidation and strengthening of the power of oligarchies and authoritarian regimes. That is why I voted against this report and called through a proposal for an Alternative Resolution to create a new policy of cooperation based on equality, solidarity and mutual development, replacing current EU policies based on interference and bellicoseness.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the evaluation of the European Endowment for Democracy. The stated objective of the EED is to support civil society organisations, journalists/media, human rights activists and others who promote pro-democratic non-violent principles in countries where rights may be restricted. In principle I agree with supporting such groups in promoting human rights and democracy. However as well as civil society groups and organisations this report calls for the EED to engage with and support the emergence and consolidation of political parties. This could lead to interference by the EU in the political life of third countries by focusing on pro-EU organisations rather than pro-democracy organisations broadly speaking. I believe in the universality of human rights and democracy and I also believe in the right of all people to decide the political and economic destiny of their country. For this reason I voted abstention.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Democracy is an important pillar of the EU. It is a moral value that we must always defend and defend. However, democracy is not respected as a universal value in all parts of the world. This makes it all the more important to support this fund so that as many people as possible can benefit from the benefits of democracy. It aims to help NGOs, trade unions and other partners outside the EU consolidate democracy and the rule of law in their country. Events in Ukraine and the Arab world have shown how important and valuable the work of this fund is.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Democracy aims to "promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms".  The aim is to promote interference in the internal affairs of third countries, in the name of democracy and on the backs of European taxpayers, through the Union budget. The Fund also promotes communitarianism, to which I am opposed. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Taxpayers’ money from the Member States should not be spent in support of this endowment.  Therefore I supported the alternative motion, and voted against the resolution as a whole.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Over the past year, the EU's neighbouring countries have faced a number of political, security and economic challenges, putting considerable pressure on democratisation efforts and the aim of ensuring human rights and fundamental freedoms. I support the European Parliament's call for the EED to continue to be active in countries where external support to civil society is severely hampered or where public funding is discriminatory and is provided only to certain organisations or civil society. We also support EDF's efforts to find innovative ways to support change-driven actors operating in particularly difficult political circumstances.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text: in addition to the right-of-hommist interference that gives pride of place to communitarian demands, this report calls for the strengthening of human and financial resources of a structure that is both costly and useless, even harmful, as it appears to be a veritable propaganda tool.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Democracy (FEDEM) is an independent institution supported by EU Member States and institutions that helps actors of democratic change within the states of the European neighbourhood. The report, which I approved, highlights the role and positive results achieved by the EDF since its recent inception, including the fight against corruption, the promotion of non-violence, the incitement to social and political participation, and the protection of individuals and journalists working on the ground to ensure and accelerate the establishment of a democratic process.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The text on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (FEDEM) aims to increase the contribution of Member States to the Fund and its actions. The purpose of the EDF is to promote and support democracy, the rule of law, human rights, etc. These are all laudable goals that I can only support. However, it is clear that, as is very often the case with the European Union, declarations of principle and laudable intentions very often turn into very negative ideological consequences. France loses a lot of money each year as a net contributor to the European Union budget. It is out of the question to accept an extension that aims only to excite the enmities with our neighbours, especially with Russia, by accusing them of all evils. The rapporteur welcomes, for example, the support for Ukraine. For these reasons, I am opposed to this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Democracy Fund has helped to promote and encourage democratisation in countries where political transitions are taking place and where there are societies struggling to obtain a genuinely democratic system from in office governments. Although these are the aims of this fund and the projects it finances, which I fully support, there are some unclear passages in the text that we do not entirely agree with, which is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Endowment for Democracy (DED) is an independent private law foundation, based in Brussels and co-financed by the EU and Member States.  After two years of existence, a positive assessment of the SD, created to promote the European values of freedom and democracy, is made here, to which I have been in favour of voting in plenary. The DED provides fast and flexible funding, based on political analysis and application efficiency, complementing other EU means, with low administrative burdens and simple procedures. At the same time, the DED conducts regular consultations with the Institutions and other actors to ensure synergies, complementarity and added value with EU financial instruments and bilateral activities of Member States, the thus avoiding possible duplication. The report stresses that, in order to further maintain and develop the effectiveness of the SD, stable and transparent funding needs to be ensured in the long term. There are still 12 Member States that do not contribute.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament welcomes the experience gained to date with regard to the activities of the European Endowment for Democracy (EDF) in view of the current problem international environment and considers that the main objective of this fund is being achieved. EDF's main task is to promote and strengthen democratisation and strong and sustainable democracy in countries where political change is taking place, as well as to fight corruption in those countries, to promote social and political participation in the protection of activists and journalists who, on the ground, make every effort to ensure and accelerate the democratic process, thereby increasing the chances of achieving justice. The European Endowment for Democracy is constantly working to guarantee freedoms of expression, association and the media, to create and strengthen the rule of law, to fight corruption, to ensure social and political pluralism, a commitment aimed at helping to help develop democratic regimes in both the eastern and southern neighbourhoods of the EU. Thus, the European Parliament fully and consistently supports the European Union's various efforts to support civil society organisations, social movements and activists around the world.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report on the evaluation of the work of the European Endowment for Democracy (EED). It highlighted the fact that in order to survive and further develop the effectiveness of the EED, it is essential to ensure sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding. The amendments put a stronger emphasis on groups suffering from social exclusion or political marginalisation.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the evaluation of the European Endowment for Democracy. The stated objective of the EED is to support civil society organisations, journalists/media, human rights activists and others who promote pro-democratic non-violent principles in countries where rights may be restricted. In principle I agree with supporting such groups in promoting human rights and democracy. However as well as civil society groups and organisations this report calls for the EED to engage with and support the emergence and consolidation of political parties. This could lead to interference by the EU in the political life of third countries by focusing on pro-EU organisations rather than pro-democracy organisations broadly speaking. I believe in the universality of human rights and democracy and I also believe in the right of all people to decide the political and economic destiny of their country. For this reason I voted abstention.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the European Fund for Democracy has done a good job in promoting and encouraging democratisation and democracy rooted in countries in political transition, especially in the currently very difficult international context.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Democracy aims to promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights. Its operating budget is financed by the Commission and its promotional activities by contributions from Member States and third countries. This report calls for an increase in Member States' contributions and calls for increased efforts against "Russian propaganda" in particular. Moreover, the rapporteur is already pleased that the EDF has helped activists in Ukraine.  In addition to the right-of-hommist interference for which it is responsible, this Fund is an expensive structure (4.4 million euros), useless that serves only political propaganda purposes.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Democracy has demonstrated in the current, challenging international context that it is successfully achieving its objective of promoting and encouraging democratisation and a genuine and sustainable democracy in politically transition countries and societies fighting for democratisation. The EDF has made considerable efforts to ensure and accelerate the initiation of a democratic process, bringing justice closer to the citizen. Despite its short period of activity and limited funds, as well as the problems inherent in assessing the impact of actions to support democracy, the EDF respected Parliament's recommendations and added value to the EU's current support for democracy, helping to reduce political risks in the EU. I voted in favour of the Report on the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy – the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (EDF) since its inception, and I welcome the work undertaken by this vital EU body.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The funds are often used in a manner contrary to the purpose stated by the EED.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The promotion and support of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights are among the main objectives of the Union's foreign policy. However, in recent years, the countries in the Union's neighbourhood have faced a large number of political, economic and security problems that put pressure on democratisation efforts.  This report underlines the importance of the European Fund for Democracy, particularly in view of the changing international context. It calls on Member States and the Commission to increase their contributions to the programme in order to continue the efforts already undertaken. It calls for increased funding and human resources capacity to make it more efficient.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy, which focused on evaluating the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (EED) since its inception. As enshrined in Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the promotion and support of democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights and freedoms are fundamental objectives of the European Union. The European Democracy Fund, despite its short period of activity and limited funds, has encouraged and encouraged the process of democratisation in countries in the process of political transition by promoting dialogue in diversity and non-violence, by inciting social and political participation, by protecting activists and journalists who spend time on the territories to ensure and speed up the start of a democratic process. The resolution emphasises the uniqueness and added value of the EED and lays the foundations for the development of new innovative means and instruments for assistance to democracy. That is why I voted in favour of it today.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the evaluation of the European Endowment for Democracy. The stated objective of the EED is to support civil society organisations, journalists/media, human rights activists and others who promote pro-democratic non-violent principles in countries where rights may be restricted. In principle I agree with supporting such groups in promoting human rights and democracy. However as well as civil society groups and organisations this report calls for the EED to engage with and support the emergence and consolidation of political parties. This could lead to interference by the EU in the political life of third countries by focusing on pro-EU organisations rather than pro-democracy organisations broadly speaking. I believe in the universality of human rights and democracy and I also believe in the right of all people to decide the political and economic destiny of their country. For this reason I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Taxpayers’ money from the Member States should not be spent in support of this endowment. Therefore I supported the alternative motion, and voted against the resolution as a whole. The lack of transparency of where the funds are being spent is just one of many issues surrounding the EDD that leads me not to support it.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) role in fostering and encouraging democratisation and deep and sustainable democracy in countries in political transition and in societies struggling for democratisation. The EED aims at helping actors of change and emerging players such as political parties, NGOs, trade unions and other partners. It also strives for developing cooperation with civic activist groups related to religious communities, including persecuted religious minorities. The Report also calls for all the Member States and the Commission to enhance their contributions to the EED.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under the new European Neighbourhood Policy, the European Union decided in 2012 to allocate EUR 6 million to ensure the rapid launch of the European Democracy Fund. (EED). The added value of the EED is that it can directly collaborate with journalists, bloggers, unse recorded NGOs, political movements, particularly when these actors operate in an uncertain political context. I therefore voted in favour of the report by my colleague Andrzej Grzyb.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence and strengthening of democracy are essential objectives of the Union, both within and on its borders. Among other things, a large part of the current conflicts in situations of economic underdevelopment and, ultimately, the increase in migratory flows itself has its roots precisely in serious shortcomings and malfunctions - often linked to authoritarian dynamics - of the institutional and political systems of many States. The European Fund for Democracy (EED) - despite the short period since its inception, the fact that 12 countries (including, unfortunately, Italy) have not yet secured their contribution and some other critical issues - has played an appreciable role in promoting the development of democratic regimes in the Eastern and Southern European neighbourhood, for example by supporting, through concrete interventions, freedom of expression and association, freedom of the media and the fight against corruption. The resolution recognises the strategic role of the EED and lays the foundations for its further strengthening (including in terms of human resources), in particular by emphasising support for victims of social and/or political exclusion, women's movements, minorities, grassroots movements, trade unions, vulnerable or emerging political movements, new media activists. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy and the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (SDR) since its establishment. , in accordance with Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am convinced that this fund has achieved its objectives. Despite the difficult period in which it is operating, the short period of activity and the limited funds, its activities to promote and encourage democracy seem to have been well promoted. Democracy remains one of the EU's fundamental foreign policy principles and the right to property remains the key to promoting a true democratic culture. A large number of Member States have recently completed the process of democratization, accumulating a great deal of experience in this field. This same experience could easily be transferred to those who have yet to reach a more mature stage of their political and social stage. The work carried out by the EDD must, however, be aimed at ensuring internal and external coherence in relation to the efforts made to achieve democracy, including by informing potential beneficiaries of the fund what it is all about.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The european fund for democracy has always had the main objective of encouraging democracy and its sedimentation in the world, in particular in the countries in the southern and eastern neighbourhood of the European Union. Since its inception, the fund has funded more than 158 initiatives totaling almost €10 million in support. The report stresses, in my view, the importance of predictability that the fund needs, only in this way can ensure that its actions can produce effects that are necessarily only achieved with regular support to beneficiaries and in the long term. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, multiple political, economic and security challenges have jeopardised democratisation processes and the affirmation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in eu neighbourhood countries. I am aware that the activities of assistance to democracy are by its very nature a complex exercise, since the political changes taking place in the countries concerned are not linear. Therefore, while welcoming the EED's continued commitment to promoting democracy in complementarity with Europe's external financial instruments, I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is a positive thing to note that the EED’s track record is good seeing that the current international situation makes it very difficult to have such a positive record. It is also a good thing to see that the EED is adding value to already established democracies within the EU. We must continue supporting the EED. It is important to ensure that the Parliament and the EED continue working hand-in-hand. It is also important to ensure that the EED remains autonomous at all times. The EED must also continue working with other organisations so as to be able to have a better reach. Innovation must also be at the forefront of the EED’s agenda so as to better help in the process of democracy assistance.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report since the conviction that 'democratisation' cannot be a pretext for interference, regime changes and interventions in favour of EU geostrategic and imperialist interests in third countries.  Convinced that the European Endowment for Democracy is a violation of international laws and treaties and the principle of non-interference enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations, I have tabled a proposal for an alternative resolution through my parliamentary group urging the abolition of the DED, since neither this mechanism nor the European neighbourhood policy has ever contributed to the consolidation of democracy for the peoples , but to a widespread regression of social and economic rights through the imposition of free trade agreements and the consolidation and strengthening of the power of oligarchies and authoritarian regimes. That is why I voted against this report and called through a proposal for an Alternative Resolution to create a new policy of cooperation based on equality, solidarity and mutual development, replacing current EU policies based on interference and bellicoseness.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is appreciated that the EDF's involvement in freedom of expression and association is appreciated, freedom of the press, the creation and strengthening of the pre-eminence of the law, the fight against corruption, social and political pluralism, involvement aimed at supporting the development of democratic regimes in the eastern and southern neighbourhoods of the EU, with 158 initiatives totalling more than EUR 4.5 million in the EU's southern neighbourhood and more than EUR 4.4 million in the Eastern Neighbourhood being financed. In order to support and develop the effectiveness of the EDF, it is essential to ensure long-term, sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding. The EDF must be actively involved in countries where external support for civil society is severely obstructed or where state funding is discriminatory and is granted exclusively to certain civil organisations or societies. Member States should continue to provide financial assistance to civil society and Russian media through the EDF, given that recent events, such as restrictions on civil society organisations, the repression of the political opposition and aggressive disinformation campaigns carried out by state-controlled media appear to serve the purpose of creating an extremely nationalist political climate marked by anti-democratic rhetoric , repression and hate speech.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report makes a general positive evaluation after two years’ existence of the European Endowment for Democracy which has been created to promote the European values of freedom and democracy. The EED remains an independent private law foundation with its seat in Brussels which is co-financed by the European Union and the Member States, and it engages in regular consultations with relevant EU institutions and other actors in order to avoid duplication and ensure synergy. The report puts stronger emphasis on working with different groups suffering from social exclusion or political marginalisation like women’s movements, LGBTI human rights activists, emerging political movements, trade unions, bloggers and new media activists. As I support the idea behind this structure and agree with the proposed way forward, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an assessment of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy since its inception. In particular, the Fund helps civil society actors through the financing of initiatives to establish a pluralistic society, democracy, the promotion of the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Since 2012, the Fund has supported 158 projects, providing 4.5 million euros for the southern neighbourhood and 4.4 million for the eastern neighbourhood. The Fund has therefore been involved in supporting the processes of democratization and the establishment of stable and sustainable democratic systems in countries in transition.  Considering this balanced evaluation report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report examines the EED’s work in line with the European Union’s commitments to democracy and the rule of law, and in the context of worsening political, economic, and security situations in many of the countries in the EU’s eastern and southern neighbourhood. The report makes a series of recommendations from funding to policy coherence and grant giving.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it attempts to increase the financing of the European Fund for Democracy (EED).

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The assessment made in the document in question seeks, to the end of the eu, to present the EU as an example of democracy, the rule of law, freedoms, and how, through its foreign policy, and through this particular instrument, the European Fund for Democracy, must "evangelize" neighbouring countries or, as it says, "countries in political transition and in societies fighting for democratisation".  The mechanisms of "democratisation", of this paladin of democracy which the EU claims, and in which the majority of this Parliament is reviewed, could not be better mirrored or better exampleed than the piece of text, devoid of any modesty that we transcribe: "Welcomes the granting of grants by the Fund to Ukrainian actors, which is a good example of the rapid support provided to political activists and civil society who , later they become democratically elected representatives."  It could not be clearer how this EU intends to "democratise" the countries with which it has relations: instrumentalising, financing, creating, promoting in its favour in an act of perfidious interference, institutions and individuals in direct alignment with eu colonialist policies, compromising the sovereignty of countries and the freedom of peoples. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Endeaument for Democracy helps to reduce political and other risks. Its main objective is to promote and encourage democratisation as well as solid democracy in countries in the process of political transition, including the fight against corruption or the incitement to social and political participation. An integral part of activating the EED is engagement in favour of freedom of expression, media, building and strengthening the rule of law. I also welcome the lifting of the original geographical limitation of the EED and the extension of its mandate to ensure an east-south balance in project financing.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report cannot have my support because the EU's approach to human rights and democracy in assessing the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (EED) since its inception does not have an objective and politically balanced approach.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (EED), as it seeks to increase this funding.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Endowment for Democracy has shown, after two years’ existence, that it has fulfilled the purpose for which it was created: the promotion of European values of freedom and democracy has achieved very good results. The EED remains an independent private-law foundation that delivers through fast, flexible, bottom up and demand-driven funding. It provides these funds directly to beneficiaries in a financially efficient manner that complements other EU means, doing so with a minimal administrative burden and simple procedures. It is vital, in order to sustain and further develop the effectiveness of the EED, to ensure long-term, sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding. I support stronger emphasis on groups that suffer from social exclusion or political marginalisation by supporting, among others, groups such as women’s movements, LGBTI human rights activists, emerging political movements, trade unions, bloggers and new media activists.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the promotion and promotion of democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms are among the main objectives of EU foreign policy, as required by Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and that the principle of responsibility for the process of building democracy is of paramount importance for the promotion of a genuine democratic culture , the recommendations made in the report are correct. I supported it with a positive vote. I think it is important to note that the society of many EU Member States has undergone a successful process of democratic transformation in recent decades and has accumulated considerable experience in this area from the point of view of the activities of the European Foundation for Democracy, which can and should be used at expert and political level for the work of the European Foundation for Democracy. Its investigation has begun in the wake of the Arab Spring and events in the Eastern Neighbourhood to promote human rights and support democracy

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy and on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (EED) since its inception. I congratulate all those Member States that have completed a profound democratic transformation in their society in recent years, a sign of the primary will to fully share the values of the European Union. In this sense, the EMCA can be an instrument of strong support for activities to assist democracy, through the implementation of programmes aimed at combating corruption, respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms. I therefore welcome the results achieved so far by the EED, given not only the difficult international situation but also the limited funds at its disposal. In this respect, I hope that wider and longer-term funding will be guaranteed. I also welcome the ever closer cooperation between the EED and the European Parliament, a sign that the European Parliament's contribution is essential to achieving the objectives at European level, and I hope, finally, that the EED will continue to work together to create new instruments and to involve new actors in assisting democracy.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the evaluation of the actions of the European Fund for Democracy (FDF). The Fund supports parties, unregistered non-governmental organisations, trade unions and other social partners in a coherent and coordinated framework in order to firmly anchor democracy, especially in our eastern neighbours, and to promote respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Grzyb report on the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) given it has played a largely positive role in promoting the European values of freedom and democracy since it was set up two years ago, and is complementary to the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and other EU instruments, as it delivers through fast, flexible, bottom-up and demand-driven funding provided directly to beneficiaries.  I agree that in order to sustain and further develop the effectiveness of the EED, it is vital to ensure long-term, sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the guise of promoting and supporting "democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms", Andrzej Grzyb's report on the EDF proposes a number of measures to strengthen this mechanism, with obvious ideological and geostrategic ulterior motives. Thus, Russia is specifically targeted by this text which, not content with giving moral lessons and interfering in the relations of two sovereign states, is very clearly the defender of communitarianism (ethnic, religious, LGBT). Democracy needs to exist sovereign states and free peoples, all concepts foreign to the European Union. For its reasons, I objected to this report which uses universal values in a perfectly self-interested way.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this assessment. The activities of the European Endowment for Democracy are based on the "democratisation scheme" of the Countries of the East in the terms that the EU chooses and decides. This means it can be all or nothing. This implies a clear interference in the domestic policy of foreign countries and the willingness to implement a political, economic and social system according to the PARAMETERS dictated by the EU. In international law, the principle of non-interference is recognised by Article 2(4) of the Charter of the United Nations. Therefore, I believe that the objective of this organization is to conceive of neighbourhood policy as a violation of international laws and treaties. In Podemos we defend the right of peoples to decide their future and to decide their model of political, economic and social development.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my European Labour colleagues, I voted in favour of this report. The Socialist and Democrats group has worked tirelessly to amend this report, to ensure that a stronger emphasis is placed on groups suffering from social exclusion or political marginalisation by supporting groups including women’s movements, LGBTI rights activists, emerging political movements and trade unions.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on a new EU approach to human rights and democracy promoting the evaluation of the activities of the European Endowment for Democracy (EDF) since its establishment. I supported this report because I believe that the promotion and promotion of democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms are one of the most important objectives of EU foreign policy. The European Union must continue to support the EDF, which is working towards achieving these objectives. With this report, Parliament decided to increase EDF's funding, human resources capacity and other support to ensure the promotion of democracy and human rights.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this assessment. The activities of the European Endowment for Democracy are based on the "democratisation scheme" of the Countries of the East in the terms that the EU chooses and decides. This means it can be all or nothing. This implies a clear interference in the domestic policy of foreign countries and the willingness to implement a political, economic and social system according to the PARAMETERS dictated by the EU. In international law, the principle of non-interference is recognised by Article 2(4) of the Charter of the United Nations. Therefore, I believe that the objective of this organization is to conceive of neighbourhood policy as a violation of international laws and treaties. In Podemos we defend the right of peoples to decide their future and to decide their model of political, economic and social development.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy: an assessment of the work of the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) since its founding, given the importance of the Foundation in the process of building democracy and promoting a genuine democratic culture. For over 20 years of my political work, I have promoted democratic processes in Croatia, which especially after independence had problems in the development of the democratic social system. I supported the cooperation between the public sector and the non-governmental civil sector, which I hold extremely important not only in promoting democratic values, but also in complementing the role of public authorities in those areas where the public sector is under-involved. As prefect, I founded the Foundation for Civil Society Development of Istria County with a similar purpose. In this regard, I see the Foundation as an institution that provides added value to existing EU democratic support through fast and flexible funding provided directly to beneficiaries in a financially efficient manner, complementing other EU funds; provides ongoing support to the EU's multi-pronged efforts to support civil society organisations, social movements and activists around the world; acts in favour of freedom of expression, media freedom, building and strengthening the rule of law, fighting corruption, social and political pluralism to support the development of democratic regimes and in the EU's eastern and southern neighbourhoods.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this text dealing with the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy since its inception. The purpose of the Fund is to promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for universality and the indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Commission and the Member States are the main donors to this fund with dubious aims, as the values it claims have too often been misused and to justify various interference operations, sometimes known as 'humanitarian'. On the other hand, the report clearly defends communitarianism, so foreign and so contrary to the values of the French Republic that we, the French MePs, are the only ones to defend.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Gryb's report on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy. The European Fund for Democracy is an independent fund that provides grants to support local actors in the eu's neighbourhood, always with the aim of promoting democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental principles. The report believes that the Fund has met its main objectives. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy and on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy since its inception. This Fund supports democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, principles whose respect is one of the foundations of the European Union's foreign policy. Since its inception, the European Fund for Democracy has, among other things, provided more than EUR 10 million to help neighbouring countries. This action should not be discouraged in view of the current particularly difficult international situation. Democracy remains a common value for the majority of the world's population and the European Union must be an active defender of it.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although there are some good approaches to this report, there are also many points that have been inserted for reasons of political correctness. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 9 July 2015, I voted against the report on the new EU approach to human rights and democracy: an evaluation of the work of the European Foundation for Democracy (EED) since its inception. I must say in advance that I reject both the analyses carried out on the results of the EED and the very objective of this organisation. I do not agree with the EED's work, as it is based on the so-called democratisation regime, which means full liberalisation/privatisation at economic level. The latest example of eed democracy building is the situation in Ukraine. Under the auspices of "democratization", the main objectives of this organization are the financing of various political parties. From my point of view, this is a clear interference in the internal policies of foreign, sovereign countries, the will to implement a political, economic and social system based solely on the majority-right capitalist system. I consider both this organisation and the very objective of its neighbourhood policy to be in breach of the fundamental rules of public international law, since Article 2.4 of the UN Charter already contains the principle of non-interference. I consider it essential that we defend the right of all nations to decide independently on their future and on political, economic and social development. I only support a policy of cooperation based on equality and solidarity.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. The creation of the EDF is an example of the EU's ability to develop new solutions that respond to challenges. The challenges set out by EDF are not straightforward, especially in the areas of strengthening civil society and clarifying the information field. I believe that the Foundation can make a substantial contribution to promoting professional journalism in the Eastern Partnership countries, which bear the greatest strain of deliberately distorted information. It should be noted that the Foundation has already done a number of good work. I therefore support the call for EU countries that have not yet done so to contribute to the contributions of the Fund.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (FEDEM), simply because it is unnecessary and expensive. As recital A of the resolution points out, "the promotion and support of democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms are among the main objectives of the Union's foreign policy".
