The European Union already has sufficient resources to support democracy, namely the foreign ministers of the Member States and their respective diplomatic services, not to mention the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and its European External Action Service, whose usefulness is highly questionable. It would therefore be better to abolish the EDF.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report makes a general positive assessment after two years of the existence of the European Endowment for Democracy, which has been created to promote European values of freedom and democracy. The DED is an independent private law foundation based in Brussels, which is co-financed by the European Union and the Member States.  The report highlights the fact that in order to further maintain and develop the effectiveness of the SD, stable and transparent funding needs to be ensured in the long term. There are still 12 Member States that do not contribute. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report since the conviction that 'democratisation' cannot be a pretext for interference, regime changes and interventions in favour of EU geostrategic and imperialist interests in third countries.  Convinced that the European Endowment for Democracy is a violation of international laws and treaties and the principle of non-interference enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations, I have tabled a proposal for an alternative resolution through my parliamentary group urging the abolition of the DED, since neither this mechanism nor The European Neighbourhood Policy has ever contributed to the consolidation of democracy for the peoples , but to a widespread regression of social and economic rights through the imposition of free trade agreements and the consolidation and strengthening of the power of oligarchies and authoritarian regimes. That is why I voted against this report and called through a proposal for an Alternative Resolution to create a new policy of cooperation based on equality, solidarity and mutual development, replacing current EU policies based on interference and bellicoseness.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union was created on the basis of respect for human rights and freedoms, democracy and the rule of law, and events in recent years in the Union's neighbourhood violate these fundamental values. The European Endowment for Democracy was established to foster democratisation and ensure democracy in countries undergoing a political transition and fighting for democracy.  I supported Mp Andrzej Grzyb's report, which welcomes the achievements and efforts made by the foundation to fulfil its objective of fostering and securing democracy through activities related, inter alia, to combat corruption, to promote media freedom and dialogue on diversity and non-violence.  The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to provide more funding to the European Endowment for Democracy, as we are currently facing major foreign and security policy challenges due to conflicts in the neighbourhood where human rights are systematically violated and the rule of law and democracy do not exist. The institutions of the European Union and the Member States must lialyt with the European Endowment for Democracy to ensure shared consistent support for democracy.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was among the 395 Members who supported this report. We must make more active use of the fund's capacity so that genuine democracy develops both within and outside the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I have strong reservations about the report on the EU's new approach to the issue of human rights and democracy – an assessment of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (SDR), since its establishment for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/7/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this Report and in particular the fact that it  "Strongly encourages the EED to place stronger emphasis on groups suffering from social exclusion or political marginalisation, by supporting, inter alia, women’s movements aimed at furthering women’s rights and increasing their participation in public life, ethnic and linguistic minorities, LGBTI human rights activists, persecuted religious minorities and civic activists linked to religious communities, together with grassroots movements, vulnerable or emerging political movements, trade unions, bloggers and new media activists"

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which is merely an interference with the issue of human rights at the pan-European level. This text recognises the financing of political activities in Ukraine which implies de facto interference in political choices. We can only deplore a text in favour of the financing of communitarianism. To condone the human and financial reinforcement of an expensive propaganda tool-like structure is not acceptable.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Democracy EED promotes and encourages the implementation of sustainable democracy in countries affected by a political transition process, and in societies fighting for democratisation. I believe that the EED has worked hard for freedom of expression and association, freedom of the media, development and consolidation of the rule of law. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this document.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have abstained because it was not possible to clearly define support or rejection of the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Democracy is the EU's armed arm for destabilising neighbouring countries.  It aims to finance human rights activists, but also and above all, political foundations and political opposition in third countries. It should also be noted that unlike other Eu-Union Funds, it is officially a non-profit foundation, thus allowing it to tolerate no democratic control!  The states that contribute to its financing are of course those that have the greatest interest in destabilizing their neighbours (Poland its initiator, the Baltics, Hungary...).  Under the guise of strengthening the rule of law and democracy, it interferes in the affairs of other countries even if it means strengthening the power of authoritarian regimes and oligarchy. The report welcomes funding "to Ukrainian actors" and to "civil society and the media in Russia", calling for funding of religious communities underlining their crucial role in opposing "communist regimes".  I am opposed to any increase in this opaque Fund which continues the european Union's war-torn policy. It's a big AGAINST. I call for an end to this fund.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Democracy aims to "promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms". Apart from the fact that the name is more than dubious, it should be remembered that this Fund is partly financed by the Commission and by contributions from Member States and third countries. It is actually very clear that this fund promotes interference in the name of democracy. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the EU's new approach to human rights and democracy (evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy since its inception). I welcome the results achieved by the Fund so far, taking into account today's particular and difficult international environment. The Fund has fulfilled its main objective of fostering and promoting democratisation and a solid and lasting democracy in countries in political transition and in societies fighting for democracy with respect for human rights.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The events of spring 2011 and the uprisings in Eastern Europe have shown that there has often been too slow response to requests for urgent assistance to political actors and citizen activists in the EU's neighbourhood. To respond to this criticism, the European Fund for Democracy was set up in 2013. The EFD aims to support new political actors and citizen movements in critical and urgent circumstances, including repression by authorities. The EFD has shown strong in providing emergency aid in crisis situations. Kyiv Post's equipment was destroyed during the protests in Euromaidan Square. Because the EFD was acting as a fast lender at that time, Kyiv Post was able to re-enter the air within three days. Parliament calls for continued attention to freedom of expression and media freedom. It also wants the EFD to focus on the effects of social exclusion, to promote women's participation in politics and to further develop new actors supporting democracy. In support of the proper functioning of the EFD, it would be welcome that the Member States which have not yet contributed will now do so quickly.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcomed the report Evaluation of activities of the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) that makes a general positive evaluation after two years’ existence of the European Endowment for Democracy which has been created to promote the European values of freedom and democracy. I agree with the rapporteur of the Report that in order to sustain and further develop the effectiveness of the EED, it is vital to ensure long-term, sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding. The Report also places a stronger emphasis on groups suffering from social exclusion or political marginalisation by supporting groups such as women’s movements, LGBTI human rights activists, emerging political movements, trade unions, bloggers and new media activists.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the promotion and promotion of democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms should be among the main objectives of the European Union's foreign policy, as enshrined in Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I am voting in favour of this report which stresses the importance of a large number of Member States in recent years successfully concluded a process of democratic transformation of society and has accumulated, in this regard, extensive experience relevant to the activities of the European Fund for Democracy, which can and should be used at political and expert level for the work of the Fund. I cannot fail to warn that in many countries in which the Fund is present, the area of legitimate action of civil society and the external financing of civil society organisations is being reduced due to the use by authoritarian regimes of increasingly sophisticated means, including legislation, which limit the work of NGOs and pro-democracy actors , including beneficiaries of the Fund.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Fund for Democracy is particularly funny when we know the deeply anti-democratic attitude of some European leaders, especially on the Greek issue. Indeed, while this Fund aims to promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, Mr Schulz's words to replace a democratically elected leader with a technocratic government to punish him for daring to hold a referendum, or those of Mr Juncker for whom there can be no democracy against the treaties. , demonstrate that the European Union would need some lessons in democracy instead of giving it to the whole world!  In essence, this report constitutes a right-of-hommist interference, promotes communitarian financing and funds the fight against "pro-Russian propaganda". Under the guise of fine principles, this Fund serves particularly scandalous and undemocratic interests, such as the political activities of Ukraine (such as the neo-Nazi Pravy Sektor?).  So I obviously voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report to ensure that the EED continues to promote the European values of freedom and democracy, which has been in existence now for two years. The report makes a generally positive evaluation of the foundation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text assessing the activities of the European Fund for Democracy. The European Fund for Democracy is an independent institution that provides grants to support local actors of democratic change in the Eu's neighbourhood. It is about promoting democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental principles.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report that evaluates the European Endowment for Democracy’s track record to date given the current challenging international environment, and shows that it is fulfilling its main objective of fostering and encouraging democratisation and deep and sustainable democracy in countries in political transition and in societies struggling for democratisation.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Staon mé ar an tuarascáil maidir leis an measúnacht ar an Dearlaic Eorpach don Daonlathas (DED). Is é an cuspóir sonraithe atá ag DED ná tacú le hEagraíochtaí Sochaí Sibhialta, le hiriseoirí/na meáin, le gníomhaithe chearta an duine agus le daoine eile a dhéanann prionsabail neamhfhoréigneacha agus ar son an daonlathais a chur chun cinn i dtíortha ina bhféadfadh teorannú a bheith á dhéanamh ar chearta. Aontaím i bprionsabal le tacaíocht a thabhairt do ghrúpaí den sórt sin atá ag obair chun cearta an duine agus an daonlathas a chur chun cinn. Molann an tuarascáil seo, áfach, gur chóir do DED dul in ngleic le, agus tacú le teacht chun cinn agus comhdhlúthú páirtithe polaitíochta, comh maith leis na heagraíochtaí sochaí sibhialta. Mar thoradh air seo, d’fhéadfadh AE cur isteach ar an saol polaitiúil i dtíortha eile trí dhíriú ar eagraíochtaí atá ag obair ar son AE in áit eagraíochtaí atá ag obair ar son an daonlathais go ginearálta. Creidim in uilíocht chearta an duine agus an daonlathais agus creidim freisin go bhfuil an ceart ag gach duine an chinniúint pholaitiúil agus eacnamaíoch a roghnú dóibh féin. Is ar an gcúis seo a staon mé ón vótáil.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, I have strong concerns about the usefulness and usefulness of this fund. However, the report to be voted on does not spare any criticism of the FDF either, so I abstained in the end.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Facility has been a grateful facilitator in countries where democracy is in the process of developing. I consider it important to take this opportunity and to increase the contribution to countries such as Ukraine and Moldova, where there is now an opportunity to contribute to the development of democracy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to thank Mr Grzyb for his excellent report and also stress the need for all Member States to be involved in the granting of this fund: the best charter in Europe that has given us the opportunity to unite the continent and live in peace and harmony over the last 70 years is democracy. This concept has succeeded in breaking down the ideological barriers that separated Europe during the Cold War, and I believe that by investing the resources of the European Fund for Democracy (EDD) in the right way, it is also possible to bring other countries closer to the ideals of freedom and democracy.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Endowment for Democracy was established in 2012 with the aim of supporting political and civil society actors seeking to achieve democratic change in the EU's eastern and southern neighbourhoods. Such support is achieved through the rapid and flexible provision of user-friendly financial assistance without bureaucratic obstacles.  The Foundation's management and executive board is chaired by MEMBERS of the European Parliament. The Committee consists of representatives of Member States and EU institutions, including nine MEMBERS of the European Parliament. The European Endowment for Democracy works by supporting human rights protection, democratic reforms, political participation and representation, which are the main tasks of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. This instrument is specifically designed to achieve its objectives and finances EU EOM projects, programmes and missions. The European Instrument grants grants to civil society organisations, NGOs and human rights defenders. In addition to eradicating poverty, it also seeks to strengthen and support democracy in developing countries.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Fund for Democracy is particularly funny when we know the deeply anti-democratic attitude of some European leaders, especially on the Greek issue. Indeed, while this Fund aims to promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, Mr Schulz's words to replace a democratically elected leader with a technocratic government to punish him for daring to hold a referendum, or those of Mr Juncker for whom there can be no democracy against the treaties. , demonstrate that the European Union would need some lessons in democracy instead of giving it to the whole world!  In essence, this report constitutes a right-of-hommist interference, promotes communitarian financing and funds the fight against "pro-Russian propaganda". Under the guise of fine principles, this Fund serves particularly scandalous and undemocratic interests, such as the political activities of Ukraine (such as the neo-Nazi Pravy Sektor?).  So I obviously voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As objective and independent information needs to be promoted and media environments strengthened, including on the Internet and in social media in countries within the geographical scope of the EED's work, protecting freedom of the press and expression and combating all forms of social and political censorship, and that democratisation efforts, including strengthening the rule of law and fighting corruption, also need to be supported in these countries , I support the significance and results of the work of the EED. To date, I welcome the results achieved under the EED given the current challenging international environment. The EED fulfils its main objective of "promoting and fostering democratisation and achieving deep and sustainable democracy in states in political transition and societies fighting for democratisation", including by supporting those without it, including fighting corruption, promoting dialogue in diversity and non-violence, fostering social and political participation, and protecting activists and journalists who make the most efforts at local level to enable and accelerate the launch of the democratic process , making justice more accessible, which is why it deserves our support to continue its work.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the results achieved under the European Endowment for Democracy (EED) in view of the current challenging international environment, and I believe that the EED meets its main objective of promoting and fostering democratisation and achieving deep and sustainable democracy in countries that are in political transition and in societies struggling to democratise. The role of the EED consists, inter alia, in assisting those without it, which includes fighting corruption, promoting dialogue in diversity and non-violence, encouraging social and political participation, and protecting activists and journalists who make the utmost efforts at local level to enable and accelerate the launch of the democratic process.  I am pleased to stress that despite a short period of action, limited resources and challenges inherent in assessing the impact of activities to support democracy, the European Endowment for Democracy implements Parliament's recommendations and adds value to existing EU democratic support. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy. This text provides an overview of the activities carried out under the Fund and proposes a new European approach to human rights and democracy. This fund is used in particular to promote democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental principles in the vicinity of the Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has expressed its support for initiatives by the European Fund for Democracy (FEDEM). This fund, established in 2012, has demonstrated its unique ability to compensate for or fill gaps in cases where it has proved impossible to obtain funding from EU member states or third countries.  As a reminder, the EDF intends to promote the European values of freedom and democracy in countries in transition and in societies fighting for democratisation, based on the European neighbourhood policy. The FEDEM is not a public institution, but has the status of a private foundation of Belgian law. It is autonomous from the European Union and complements the existing EU cooperation instruments. It acts with quick and flexible financing.  The European Parliament recommends that the MEMBER States of the EDF contribute or strengthen their contributions, and in particular to Belgium, the host country of the Fund, to at least explore the possibility of using tax revenues from the EDF and its workers to finance EDF projects.  Long-term, sufficient, stable, transparent and predictable funding is essential.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Endowment for Democracy (DED) is an independent private law foundation, based in Brussels and co-financed by the EU and Member States.  After two years of existence, a positive assessment of the SD, created to promote the European values of freedom and democracy, is made here, to which I have been in favour of voting in plenary. The DED provides fast and flexible funding, based on political analysis and application efficiency, complementing other EU means, with low administrative burdens and simple procedures. At the same time, the DED conducts regular consultations with the Institutions and other actors to ensure synergies, complementarity and added value with EU financial instruments and bilateral activities of Member States, the thus avoiding possible duplication. The report stresses that, in order to further maintain and develop the effectiveness of the SD, stable and transparent funding needs to be ensured in the long term. There are still 12 Member States that do not contribute.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. As the European Union's political instrument for promoting human rights and supporting democracy, the EDF has proved particularly useful in recent years in addressing a large number of political, economic and security problems in the countries in the southern and eastern neighbourhoods of the Union. Indeed, the EDF is part of the Union's new approach to human rights and democracy, following the events of the Arab Spring and in the eastern neighbourhood of the Union. The report for which I voted today highlights in particular the importance of guaranteeing long-term funding for the EDF and developing new and innovative ways and instruments to help democracy.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Public Health and Industrial Policy, which deals with the evaluation of the activities of the European Fund for Democracy (EED). The EED is a fast and flexible financing mechanism for beneficiaries who are not supported (or are not sufficiently supported), especially for legal or administrative reasons. The evaluation carried out by the AFET Committee has revealed a very positive picture of the Fund's activities, which fulfils its main objective of promoting and encouraging democratisation and entrenched and sustainable democracy in countries in the process of political transition and in societies fighting for democratisation. The EED has shown that it is capable of meeting the commitments it has made, and that is the fundamental reason why I voted in favour of the text.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this assessment. The activities of the European Endowment for Democracy are based on the "democratisation scheme" of the Countries of the East in the terms that the EU chooses and decides. This means it can be all or nothing. This implies a clear interference in the domestic policy of foreign countries and the willingness to implement a political, economic and social system according to the PARAMETERS dictated by the EU. In international law, the principle of non-interference is recognised by Article 2(4) of the Charter of the United Nations. Therefore, I believe that the objective of this organization is to conceive of neighbourhood policy as a violation of international laws and treaties. In Podemos we defend the right of peoples to decide their future and to decide their model of political, economic and social development.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on human rights and democracy. Human rights should be upheld throughout the world, with the EU setting the standard.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because the key foreign policy objectives of the European Union are promotion and democracy, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. The Arab Spring and events related to the Eastern Neighbourhood have encouraged a reshaping of the actions of EU policy instruments, with authoritarian regimes using, both many means and legislation, to restrict the activities of NGOs and pro-democracy actors.  It is necessary to combat all forms of censorship – social and political, promote objective and independent information, the Internet and social media in order to protect freedom of the press and expression, because that is the point of democratization, as well as strengthening the rule of law and fighting corruption. EED delivers in an international environment in which it operates and supports democracy, supports civil society organisations, social movements and activists.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Endowment for Democracy promotes European values of freedom and democracy and I therefore voted in favour of this report making an overall positive evaluation of the foundation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report attempts to increase the funding of the European Fund for Democracy (SDR) from the moment it is set up;

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a champion of upto democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights and freedoms in the world. The European Fund for Democracy was created to support these rights in countries in the Eastern or Southern Neighbourhood, especially where they are threatened by authoritarian systems, economic difficulties, security threats or censorship. With this flexible instrument, the Union was able to support commendable initiatives in favour of freedom of expression and association, freedom of the press, the creation and strengthening of the pre-eminence of the law, the fight against corruption, social and political pluralism. Through the involvement of several Member States, and even external partners, it has been possible to finance a significant number of initiatives, but involving more resources and more states would create even better premises for supporting the democratisation process in the EU neighbourhood. The use of new technologies guarantees a greater penetration force of the programme, allowing support for campaigners for democracy and freedom of expression. Of course, there are many areas where the Fund can help, such as protecting minorities, promoting women, preventing social exclusion and supporting media activists. However, the results achieved so far are remarkable, which entitles the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. In passing, I would like to welcome the continued commitment of the EDF to freedom of expression and association, freedom of the media, the establishment and strengthening of the rule of law, the fight against corruption, social and political pluralism, a commitment to support the development of democratic regimes in the eastern and southern neighbourhoods of the Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this evaluation of activities of the European Endowment for Democracy. By voting for this report, I welcome the EED’s track record given the current challenging international environment. I also consider that it is fulfilling its main objective of ‘fostering and encouraging democratisation and deep and sustainable democracy in countries in political transition and in societies struggling for democratisation’. For the future, I believe that the EED should continue to develop new innovative means and instruments for democracy assistance, including for political actors or activists, and to share best practices in order to adjust to the growing climate of restriction in a number of countries with authoritarian regimes.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report that positively assesses the work of the European Endowment for Democracy, as I believe that the foundation complements the traditional state-oriented approach through direct cooperation with movements organised at local and regional level, as well as with democratic political actors.  I believe that this is how the key foreign policy objectives of the European Union are implemented, which are promoting and supporting democracy, the rule of law and respecting the universality of human rights and fundamental freedoms. In my view, despite its short work, the Foundation has demonstrated the ability to overcome or address shortcomings in cases where it is unable to obtain funding for a specific purpose. I therefore support the recommendation to ensure long-term sustainable funding for the European Endowment for Democracy so that it can continue to develop innovative ways and instruments to promote democracy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report highlights the role of the European Foundation for Democracy in its efforts to democratise and sustainably democracy in transition countries and societies where they are fighting for democracy. This institution helps actors in combat, such as political parties, NGOs, trade unions and other partners, to work with other civil groups associated with religious communities and so on.  Since April 2015, the foundation has funded 158 initiatives, with more than €4.5 million in the South and €4.4 million in the Eastern Neighbourhood. The report stresses the importance of long-term and stable funding and calls on the founders, in particular the Member States and the European Commission, to step up their contributions to the European Foundation for Democracy. As the institution worked well, I supported the report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this assessment. The activities of the European Endowment for Democracy are based on the "democratisation scheme" of the Countries of the East in the terms that the EU chooses and decides. This means it can be all or nothing. This implies a clear interference in the domestic policy of foreign countries and the willingness to implement a political, economic and social system according to the PARAMETERS dictated by the EU. In international law, the principle of non-interference is recognised by Article 2(4) of the Charter of the United Nations. Therefore, I believe that the objective of this organization is to conceive of neighbourhood policy as a violation of international laws and treaties. In Podemos we defend the right of peoples to decide their future and to decide their model of political, economic and social development.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Fund for Democracy aims to "promote and support democracy, the rule of law and respect for the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms". It is financed on a co-financing basis: its administrative budget is provided by the Commission, while field activities are financed by contributions from Member States and third countries. As an indication, as of 19 May 2015, the EDF financed 158 initiatives for a total of 4.5 million euros in the southern neighbourhood and more than 4.4 million euros in the eastern neighbourhood. Mr Grzyb's report aims in particular to increase the contribution of Member States and to encourage an increase in the actions of the EDF. The text considers that by supporting democracy, the EDF reduces "political risks". In addition to right-of-hommist interference and the financing of communitarianism, this report calls for the strengthening of human and financial resources of an expensive and unnecessary structure, which is akin to a real instrument of political propaganda. I'm voting against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this assessment. The activities of the European Endowment for Democracy are based on the "democratisation scheme" of the Countries of the East in the terms that the EU chooses and decides. This means it can be all or nothing. This implies a clear interference in the domestic policy of foreign countries and the willingness to implement a political, economic and social system according to the PARAMETERS dictated by the EU. In international law, the principle of non-interference is recognised by Article 2(4) of the Charter of the United Nations. Therefore, I believe that the objective of this organization is to conceive of neighbourhood policy as a violation of international laws and treaties. In Podemos we defend the right of peoples to decide their future and to decide their model of political, economic and social development.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though the report lacks ambition to address the complex challenges of democracy assistance in a global context of growing hostility to the liberal-democratic agenda, I voted positively in order to ensure a new approach to human rights and democracy in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report highlighting the EU's work to promote democracy in those countries that are in political transitions. This tool has developed 151 initiatives until April 2015, with a budget of about 4.5 million euros in the neighbouring countries of the south and with a budget of 4.4 million euros in the eastern neighbouring countries. The report points to the need to continue and strengthen these programmes in order to continue to promote such actions. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The "European Fund for Democracy" was established in 2012 as a foundation to provide financial support to civil society organisations such as political foundations and political movements, media and so-called independent journalists in the countries of the European neighbourhood.  Both the objective and the form seem problematic to me. Its board of directors is dominated by conservative and social-democratic political representatives (no member of the GUE/NGL has been accepted), including incidentally the rapporteur of the text in question.  Beyond the subjectivity of its author, this report shows no critical distance from the Fund's activities and falls into caricature when the Ukrainian issue is discussed ("welcomes the subsidies granted to Ukrainian actors, which provide a good example of the rapid support for political activists who then become democratically elected representatives"). Partisanship is perfectly illustrated when one reads that "the Church has played a major role in opposition to communist regimes and in the processes of democratic transformation in Central and Eastern Europe". There is no doubt that it is not democracy that is funded there, but political cuisine. So I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the European Fund for Democracy, together with other EU programmes such as the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) and the European Neighbourhood Policy Civil Society Instrument, promote the establishment of direct relations with local and regional democratic political movements and political actors. This is the most shameless imperialist interference that hand-picks some minions, some of whom have a criminal record, who are promoted to human rights defenders in countries that decide not to submit to the dictates of western powers and their multinational companies. We don't need to give examples, so extensive is the list. The only truly democratic measure this parliament could take is the extinction of this fund which promotes the destabilisation of sovereign countries and holds Europe accountable for the most barbaric crimes committed today in Libya, Iraq or Syria.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The actions of the European Fund for Democracy are a double-edged sword to me. On the one hand, it is certainly important to promote and improve democracy-specific aspects. On the other hand, I do not understand how a Ukrainian government is to be given funding under this Democracy Fund, even though there are radical and anti-democratic parties in that government. On the basis of these facts, I abstained.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the work of the European Foundation for Democracy to be very beneficial. The EED carries out its main task of promoting and insiculing democracy, in particular by combating corruption, violence and promoting dialogue on the diversity of political guidelines. The EED complies with the European Parliament's recommendations as much as possible and therefore I rate its work very positively.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The assessment made in the document in question seeks, to the end of the eu, to present the EU as an example of democracy, the rule of law, freedoms, and how, through its foreign policy, and through this particular instrument, the European Fund for Democracy, must "evangelize" neighbouring countries or, as it says, "countries in political transition and in societies fighting for democratisation".  The mechanisms of "democratisation", of this paladin of democracy which is said to be the EU, and in which the majority of this European Parliament is reviewed, could not be better mirrored or better exampleed than the piece of text, devoid of any modesty that we transcribe: "Welcomes the granting of grants by the Fund to Ukrainian actors, which is a good example of the rapid support given to political activists and civil society who , later they become democratically elected representatives." It could not be clearer how this EU intends to "democratise" the countries with which it has relations: instrumentalising, financing, creating, promoting in its favour in an act of perfidious interference, institutions and individuals, in direct alignment with the EU's colonialist policies, compromising the sovereignty of countries and the freedom of peoples. We voted against it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this proposal for a Joint Resolution on the situation in Burundi, because although the text contains aspects with which I agree, such as the description of the climate of repression that the country is experiencing, concern about human rights violations and criticism of the electoral situation, lack of transparent information and a call for dialogue and the cessation of violence , other key elements are missing as a more consistent critique of neocolonialist practices and the exposure of natural resources, as well as a deeper and more complex analysis of the origins of the country's current situation.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The current situation in the Republic of Burundi is very worrying. Democracy and human rights are being disregarded. Violent crime is on the rise amid a crisis triggered by the announcement of the re-election of current President Pierre Nkurunziza. I welcome this motion for a resolution. I call on the government in Bujumbara to respect the Cotonou Agreement. Talks should be resumed as soon as possible, paving the way for peace and tranquillity and allowing refugees to return to their homes.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Once is not customary, this resolution does not interfere in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. The crisis in Burundi since President Nkurunziza decided to run for a third term is a matter for Burundi's domestic policy, over which the Union has no right or regulatory power. It is up to Burundians to choose their leaders. The European Parliament is calling for a solution to the crisis to be found by Burundian politicians in order to avoid any flare-up of the situation in an already unstable region. He recalled that Burundi was bound by the Cotonou Agreements to respect government opposition and freedom of expression. If these agreements were not complied with, Burundi would damage its image and appear to be an unreliable partner.  So I voted in favour of this resolution

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to confirm that my vote on this subject was to abstain, and I did so on the grounds that whilst the report contained aspects which I support, I also believe that foreign policy should be the preserve of the Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The political impasse in Burundi and the deteriorating security and economic situation have serious consequences for the population and threaten the entire region, as Burundi is currently facing its worst crisis since the end of the 12-year-old civil war, which killed some 300 000 people by 2005.  The EU provides a very large part of Burundi's annual budget, about half of which is international aid, and whereas Burundi (one of the world's poorest nations) is out of 2014-2020. The EU has recently allocated EUR 432 million to the European Development Fund. This will help improve governance and the development of civil society. The European Parliament supports the  The EU Foreign Affairs Council's call on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to draw up a list of targeted restrictive measures and visa bans and travel bans for persons guilty of violent acts, repression and serious human rights violations and persons who are actively hampering the search for a political solution in line with the system proposed by the AU and the EAC, and also asks the VP/HR to take the necessary measures to freeze the assets of all these persons in the EU Member States.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which, for once, has the wisdom not to give more lessons than is necessary: it calls for respect for government opposition and freedom of expression, which is an obvious necessity.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union has an important role to play in the Great Lakes region to ensure the implementation of the Arusha Agreements. Violations of human rights and democratic principles are unfortunately still present in Burundi. The Commission and the High Representative must therefore take actions such as freezing assets or withdrawing visas from those responsible for acts of violence, repression and serious human rights violations. At the same time, we must also increase humanitarian aid and support for civil society.  A lasting political solution requires an end to repression and violence and a return to dialogue between the Burundian government, the opposition and civil society.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi reminds the Burundian government that it is bound by international agreements to respect for government opposition and freedom of expression in its country.  As is often the case, some presidents believe themselves to be untouchable, and it was President Nkurunziza's bid for a third term that triggered the events.  This proposal is a step in the right direction since it does not seek to interfere with Burundi's policies, but proposes respect for the Cotonou and Arusha agreements and a dialogue between the opposition and the government to keep democracy alive.  So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution is not critical and is acceptable. Political violence and intimidation against opponents must be brought to an immediate end in Burundi and all armed groups allied to political parties must be disarmed immediately, and impunity cannot be lifted for those responsible for the serious human rights violations taking place in that country, for all these reasons I voted for this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The situation in Burundi continues to deteriorate as President Nkurunziza has deafly heard the international community and continues its electoral plans. Legislative and local elections took place in the country on 29 June, despite the continued climate of violence, the total absence of conditions for the development of an election campaign, the lack of impartial means and the growing number of citizens who decide to leave the country for fear of the outbreak of an open civil conflict.  This joint motion for a resolution, which I voted in favour, calls for action against those responsible for the current situation and violence against civilians, including possible selective sanctions and freezing of property. In addition, in the face of continued non-compliance with democratic principles and the null and void outcome of the political dialogue between the EU and the country, it is requested to open the procedure provided for in Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement to take appropriate measures, which may lead to the suspension of development aid channeled through State actors. Finally, the text also calls for strengthening emergency assistance to meet the needs of the growing number of refugees in neighbouring countries.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on the situation in Burundi because it violates civil rights and uses violence against human rights fighters. Violence has increased in Burundi in recent months, as the police have used excessive force against peaceful protesters, resulting in the deaths of people.  The European Parliament is therefore extremely concerned about the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in Burundi and the region as a whole. We therefore call for an immediate halt to violent acts and an end to political intimidation of opponents, as well as the immediate disarmament of all armed youth groups associated with political parties. We offer our condolences to those affected by the violence and call for immediate humanitarian aid for people who have been forced to leave their homes. Parliament is also deeply concerned about the Burundian Government's decision to continue holding elections, despite the extremely difficult political and security situation, as the electoral process is greatly obscured by restrictions imposed on independent media, excessive use of force against demonstrators, an atmosphere of intimidation of opposition parties and civil society, and lack of confidence in the electoral authorities.  The European Parliament stresses that only dialogue and consensus between the Government of Burundi, the opposition and civil society, in accordance with the Arusha Agreement and the Burundian Constitution, can provide an opportunity to find a sustainable political solution.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Union should work to put an end to the violence that is currently tearing Burundi apart and to ensure that humanitarian aid is received to the local population as soon as possible.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution strongly condemns the actions of President Nkurunziza, who violated Burundi's constitution by seeking to run for a third term, calling for an internal agreement between the government and the opposition. Linked by the Cotonou Accords, President Nkurunziza is bound by respect for the government opposition and freedom of expression. Once is not customary, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which I consider balanced.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi. When we talk about human rights violations, violence and security limitations, it is to be welcomed that the European Union intervenes and reaffirms the firm commitment and determination to address the threat posed by extremist and terrorist groups which, in this case, endanger the lives of Burundin citizens. The European Union is campaigning for conflict resolution through dialogue and negotiation, and not through acts of violence, abuses and the use of weapons. The current context in Burundi is all the more serious in terms of limiting the humanitarian and medical aid that the population urgently needs. Restricting the right to liberty and medical care are the greatest abuses to which a citizen can be subjected. The situation in Burundi must continue to be overseen by both the Commission, the Council and Parliament and all international bodies empowered to prevent and penalise such abuses.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Considering that the right to freedom of expression is guaranteed by the Burundian Constitution and the international and regional treaties ratified by it, and is part of the national strategy for good governance and the fight against corruption. Calls for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opponents and for the immediate disarmament of all groups of armed youth allied to political parties and for an immediate end to the impunity of those responsible for serious human rights violations, who must be held individually responsible and held criminally accountable for their actions; particular importance is attached to the immediate deployment of human rights observers and military experts announced by the African Union.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Since April, Burundi has been in dire throes. Despite the provisions of the constitution that prohibit a president from holding this office more than twice, President Nkurunziza announced his candidacy for a third term. The announcement plunged the country into violence, leading to a coup and the deaths of seventy Burundian citizens.  The government refuses to negotiate. There is an urgent need for action. Nearly 200,000 refugees have already fled the country. The resolution calls on Member States to honour commitments to the regional action plan for Burundian refugees. It also calls for an end to violence and restrictions on access to information.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it is necessary to strongly call on the Government of Burundi to stop the repressive spiral and allow the normal holding of elections in accordance with the Constitutional Charter. The situation has deteriorated in recent weeks following the announcement of the dismissal of President Pierre Nkurunziza and the postponement of elections that triggered violent and bloody clashes in the country. Since the beginning of the protests there have been about 40 victims among the population, while in total more than 100 thousand people have fled Burundi. After the criticisms of a great many African leaders, in addition to those of the United States, we must also bring in Europe's strong voice.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution. The resolution is concerned with the current political situation in Burundi and is specifically concerned with the devastating human rights situation in Burundi and also President Pierre Nkurunziza’s eligibility to run for a third term. Despite calls from the international community to delay elections and despite being boycotted by civil society and the opposition, legislative elections took place on 29 June 2015 and presidential elections are scheduled for 15 July 2015. The provisions in this Resolution went a long way towards highlighting the egregious human rights violations and it was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Had I been present for this vote, I would have abstained on the grounds that, whilst the report contained aspects which I support, I believe that foreign policy should be the preserve of the Member States.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I am concerned about the serious political situation that has developed in Burundi. Although according to both the Constitution of Burundi and the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement a president can serve only two terms, President Nkurunziza announced that he was running for a third term, plunging the country into turmoil and triggering widespread protests and a failed military coup. This Resolution brings to the fore the deteriorating security and economic situation in Burundi, which has serious consequences for the country’s people and the region. Violations of human rights have been rampant, the currency has depreciated and unemployment has increased, whilst tax revenues have decreased. The Resolution further calls on the High Representative to prepare a list of targeted measures against the ruling class, for the Commission to urgently reassess EU aid to divert it from the central budget to support to civil society and humanitarian aid, and highlights that both parties are bound by the Cotonou agreement, in particular regarding the respect for human rights.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because the protection of human rights always has my full support.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the reasoning behind the resolution, which, among other things, emphasizes the deep concern about the deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in Burundi and the wider region. At the same time, we agree that violence and intimidation against political opponents should be put to an immediate end and that armed youth groups should be disarmed immediately. At the same time, solidarity with the victims of violence and with the relatives of the dead and the need for immediate humanitarian assistance to those forced to flee their homes is expressed.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the PPE Group resolution on the situation in Burundi. The GROUP of the European People's Party condemns all violations of human rights and calls on all parties to cease all violence. In addition, the group expresses its deep concern at the continuing exodus of refugees to neighbouring countries and calls on the European Commission and the Member States to suspend all political, military and governmental support.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe it appropriately underlines our concerns about the difficult situation that has arisen in Burundi. President Nkurunziza's decision to run for a third term in the general election has caused great dissatisfaction among opponents who have begun to rebel and protest against the outgoing President because they believe his candidacy is unconstitutional. The climax was reached on 13 May when a group of soldiers, led by General Niyombare, attempted a coup d'état, taking advantage of the president's absence. Although the coup was promptly overturned by Nkurunziza's return home, violence in the country has not stopped and the repression of protests has already claimed more than 70 lives and the flight of more than 120 000 inhabitants to neighbouring countries, with the high risk of causing a domino effect. In a context of serious economic crisis such as that of Burundi, one of the poorest countries in the world, it is important that all the parties involved can find a peaceful and lasting solution, in order to respect the Arusha Agreement and the Constitution, so that we can resume a democratic process that goes beyond personal interests and for the benefit of the people of Burundi.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decision of the Government of Burundi to hold new elections despite the general political and security critical situation has aggravated an already complex political and humanitarian situation in Burundi and the surrounding region. I am aware of the role that the international community plays in the region as guarantor of the Arusha agreements and that institutions such as the International Criminal Court are of great importance in conducting independent investigations into the violence and crimes committed in Burundi.  Therefore, considering that it was only through a dialogue with the Government of Burundi that a lasting political solution could be found in the interests of the security and democracy of that country, that I decided to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this proposal for a Joint Resolution on the situation in Burundi, because although the text contains aspects with which I agree, such as the description of the climate of repression that the country is experiencing, concern about human rights violations and criticism of the electoral situation, lack of transparent information and a call for dialogue and the cessation of violence , other key elements are missing as a more consistent critique of neocolonialist practices and the exposure of natural resources, as well as a deeper and more complex analysis of the origins of the country's current situation.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The political deadlock in Burundi and the deteriorating security and economic situation have serious consequences for the population and pose risks to the region as a whole, with Burundi facing the biggest crisis since the 12-year ethnic civil war. Only through dialogue and consensus, with the involvement of the Burundian government, the opposition and civil society, and in accordance with the Arusha Agreement and the Burundian Constitution can a lasting political solution be found in the interests of security and democracy for the Burundian people. Burundi has also signed and ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the African Charter of Human and Peoples' Rights and is therefore obliged to respect universal human rights, including freedom of expression. The Burundian government must allow for a real and open debate without fear of intimidation and refrain from misuse of the judiciary to exclude political rivals. The Commission has a duty to urgently re-evaluate the EU's assistance for its redirection, increase financial support for civil society and focus on humanitarian aid.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution calls on the European Commission and the EU’s High Representative to take appropriate actions and to prepare a list of targeted restrictive measures such as a visa ban and asset freezing against those responsible for acts of violence, repression and serious human rights violations in Burundi. It also calls for the reassessment of EU aid with a view to diverting it and increasing financial support to civil society and humanitarian assistance. I believe that a lasting political solution for Burundi can be found only through dialogue between the different parties and civil society. Meanwhile, we have to make sure that the EU helps the local communities and does not end up helping financially the parties at war. Hence I supported this resolution.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent months the political and humanitarian situation in Burundi has dramatically deteriorated and, as many non-governmental associations denounce, the protests were triggered by the decision announced by President Pierre Nkurunziza to go to the polls to obtain a third term, contrary to the provisions of the country's constitutional charter. Tensions have escalated, forcing more than 130,000 people to flee to neighbouring countries and creating an additional factor of instability in an already fragile region, prompting the government to postpone elections until a later date. The resolution for which I strongly voted in favour calls on the parties involved to respect the commitments they have made under the international and regional treaties that have long been ratified, bearing in mind that there can be no impunity for those responsible for serious human rights violations.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution calls for an immediate end to acts of violence and political intimidation against ongoing opponents in Burundi. Following the announcement at the end of April of President Nkurunziza's candidacy for a third term in power since 2005, the country is facing a serious political and humanitarian crisis that has spread throughout the region.  As such, the maintenance of the electoral calendar in a critical political and security context is of concern and the European Union should provide all necessary assistance in order to end the violence and to hold free, peaceful, transparent and credible elections.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Burundi's political and social situation has worsened further with the general elections on 29 June, when President Pierre Nkurunziza announced that he was running for a third term. Re-election would not respect the Arusha agreements between the Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups in 2000, which were designed to end the bloody seven-year civil war that claimed more than 300,000 lives. According to the country's Constitution, each president can only be elected for two terms, so the re-election of President Nkurunziza would go against the Constitution. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution in order to hope that a solution can be found to the political crisis in Burundi.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Burundi because, in a political and security context as critical as that which is experienced in that country, the maintenance of the electoral calendar by the Burundian government, despite widespread international disapproval and the boycott of the opposition, is extremely worrying.  It is clear that the electoral process has been severely compromised by restrictions on media independence, excessive use of force against demonstrators, intimidation of opposition parties and civil society, and a lack of confidence in the electoral authorities. I condemn in the strongest terms the ongoing violence in Burundi. Key elements of the Cotonou agreement, including respect for fundamental rights and democratic principles, continue to be violated. It is inconceivable that these crimes go unpunished and that the culprits will not be arrested.  That is why I support the Commission's request to freeze funding to the Burundian government and to redirect EU aid by increasing financial support to civil society and focusing on humanitarian aid.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the joint motion for a resolution as it attempts to involve the EU in the way of internal governance of a country that is not a Member State.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution, in addition to the description of the complex and unstable situation in Burundi, of the fair identification of the need to provide assistance to refugee camps, from a health point of view for epidemic control, assisting victims of a situation to which they are others, contains elements of interference (proposals for sanctions, reductions in financial support to the country, guidelines for the allocation of these funds , all supported by the presumption of an illegitimate EU foreign policy) which, in addition to being unacceptable, will not contribute to stability in the region, or to help the people freely and without external pressures determine their future. Reasons for our abstention.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Based on the submitted report, Burundi has been in crisis since the end of April. I do not consider the elections held on 29 June 2015 to be free or credible because of the serious disruption of the electoral process by the restriction of independent media, as well as the disproportionate use of force against demonstrators. I join the call for the postponement of the presidential elections scheduled for 15.7.2015 and the call for the resumption of dialogue on all contentious areas between the various stakeholders, based on compliance with the Aruš Agreement and burundi's constitution.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution calling for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opponents and for the immediate disarmament of all groups of armed youth allied to political parties.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that Burundi has been in crisis since late April over President Nkurunziza's nomination for a third term as president for a third term, in violation of the Arusha Agreement and the Burundian Constitution. I think it is important to point out that by clinging to power, it has significantly divided society and political actors; whereas another significant figure within the ruling CNDD-FDD party, the country's second vice-president, Gervais Rufykiri, urged the President to withdraw his candidacy "by putting the interests of the Burundian people ahead of his own interests, as it violates the Constitution", and subsequently sought refuge in Belgium. I believe that the elections held in Burundi on 29 June 2015 cannot be regarded as a free, fair, credible and inclusive election, as the electoral process has been severely tainted by restrictions on independent media, excessive violence against demonstrators, intimidation against opposition parties and civil society, and a lack of confidence in the electoral authorities, and urges the Burundian authorities to postpone the presidential elections of 15 July 2015. and involve all stakeholders in efforts to create an environment that promotes peaceful, credible, free and fair elections. The PpE group and the Fidesz delegation welcome the Commission's strategy in this important area.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi, as it attempts to involve the EU in the way of internal governance of a country which is not a Member State.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In Africa history repeats itself. Another President, seeing the end of his power, tries, comme d’habitude, to modify the constitution to remain Head of State. The result is a rebellion of the army and in some cases also of the population, a coup d'état or civil war. This is the time for Burundi. I would like to honour the bravery and the resilience of the journalists of the independent newspapers, especially those of the Iwacu weekly magazine who declared, in their editorial, that they must resist, never mind their destroyed newsrooms or their fleeing or murdered colleagues. This political instability in Burundi is not acceptable, neither from a geopolitical point of view nor from a humanitarian one. Internal disorders are likely to bring a population already devastated by hunger to its knees.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. The development of the situation in Burundi is extremely worrying and presents very serious human, regional and international risks. It is for this reason that I voted in favour of the joint resolution, which clearly expresses the priorities to be implemented in order to achieve a normalization of the situation.  Burundian stakeholders must return to the negotiating table as soon as possible to find a political solution through dialogue and end the violence. Nevertheless, a negotiated and consensual solution cannot go far short of the constitution and spirit of the Arusha agreements.  I welcome the clear and constructive positions, as well as the mediation efforts of the ECA and the AU. In addition, I support the call for the mobilization of Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, as violations of democratic principles and human rights continue.  Finally, I stress the regional stakes of the Burundian crisis. Beyond the humanitarian situation of refugee flows, it is crucial that a close dialogue between the countries of the region be maintained to avoid contagion in a politically and securityally fragile region, while electoral processes will follow one another in several of these countries.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on the situation in Burundi. In Burundi, one of the poorest countries in the world, violent protests against President Pierre Nkurunziza have been taking place since the end of April. More than 80 people have already died and 140,000 have fled the country. And a week before the scheduled election in Burundi, it is still unclear whether the vote will take place. Europe cannot be a zaungast here – europe must go all diplomatic ways to help.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on Burundi, given that the crisis in the country that erupted following the decision of President Nkurunziza to try to seek a third term in clear breach of the Arusha Agreement needs to be urgently addressed. The violence used by government-backed militias against peaceful demonstrators, the complete absence of possibilities for the opposition to campaign, and the attacks on media including the blowing up of radio stations, all of which render any elections to take place in the near future completely invalid, are utterly unacceptable. I acknowledge that the EU is already offering important support to Burundi – in the last EDF programme we doubled our aid to the country and the External Action Service have announced EUR 1.5 million to support the region in assisting refugees fleeing repression. Some are calling into question whether we should continue this support given the government’s behaviour, but I would argue that nor the people in Burundi, nor countries in the neighbourhood, should pay for the actions of a repressive regime. That is why I call on the Commission and High Representative to keep up current engagements, while exploring ways to make sure the funds are implemented to the direct benefit of the people of Burundi, not their irresponsible leadership.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Burundi as a sign of our concern at the worsening political and humanitarian situation in the country and the whole region; we call for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opposition members and the immediate disarmament of all groups of young armed people linked to political parties. I think it is important that the EU and its Member States fulfil all the commitments made with respect to the UN Regional Response Plan for Burundi, which needs additional funds to deal with the current crisis.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on Burundi as the crisis in the country, that erupted following the decision of President Nkurunziza to try to seek a third term, urgently needs to be addressed.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi. The deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in Burundi and throughout the region is worrying and threatening both burundians and neighbouring countries, and I therefore believe that we need to take immediate measures and seek stabilisation. The Union must use its influence to express its views in such situations, thus trying to help address the country's internal problems.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Burundi as a sign of our concern at the worsening political and humanitarian situation in the country and the whole region; we call for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opposition members and the immediate disarmament of all groups of young armed people linked to political parties. I think it is important that the EU and its Member States fulfil all the commitments made with respect to the UN Regional Response Plan for Burundi, which needs additional funds to deal with the current crisis.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's Resolution on the Situation in Burundi (2015/2723(RSP)), as the country is facing a serious political, economic and humanitarian crisis. The political stalemate in Burundi and the deteriorating security and economic situation have dire consequences for the population and pose a risk to the entire region. It is the country's biggest crisis since a 12-year ethnically marked civil war that by 2005 had caused an estimated 300,000 casualties. There is an urgent need to end the violence and political intimidation of the opposition and to disarm all armed groups with ties to political parties and to urgently launch humanitarian aid for those forced to flee their homes. It is necessary to take all measures that will lead to de-escalation of instability and initiate all previous measures intended to create a democratic environment as a precondition for the development of this one of the poorest countries in the world.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this resolution on the current situation in Burundi. The resolution, surprisingly, does not include any evidence to support interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. The crisis that this country has been experiencing since President Nkurunziza decided to run for a third term is a matter of domestic policy, over which we have no right or regulatory power: the citizens of Burundi must take their destiny into their own hands.  Parliament therefore calls for a solution to the crisis to be found by Burundian politicians in order to avoid any flare-up of the situation in an already unstable region. Finally, Parliament reiterated that Burundi was bound by the Cotonou Agreements to respect government opposition and freedom of expression. If these conditions were not met, Burundi would seriously damage its image and appear to be an unreliable partner.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Burundi. In the face of flouted democratic principles and violence against the population, the Government of Burundi must return to a constitutionally-friendly situation and act to stop violence against civil society. The European Union cannot remain passive in the face of the clear violation of human rights and must participate by encouraging dialogue and negotiation to restore and consolidate peace in the country.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It strongly condemns the election of 29 June 2015 and points to the government's subsequent human rights violations against demonstrators and opposition figures.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the plenary session in Strasbourg, on 9 July 2015, we also voted on a resolution on the current situation in Burundi. I abstained in the vote on this resolution. And that's for a few of the reasons below. The proposal lacked not only more accurate data on the people forced to flee the country, as the vague figure of more than 127,000 burundian refugees is not, according to official sources, accurate. Unfortunately, there are many more refugees. The proposal should also state, in my opinion, that the Constitutional Court of Burundi has clearly stated that the text of the Constitution clearly states that a president can only be elected for two terms. But Mr Nkurunziza does not count for his first presidential term, despite publicly promising not to exceed the constitutional limit of two terms. This should have been clearly stated in the report. The situation in Burundi is currently very difficult and many points in the proposal itself have not been sufficiently elaborated. However, this report at least informs the European public of the current, alarming situation in Burundi, yet there is still a lot of missing information, the absence of which does not render the current situation sufficiently real and up-to-date.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With support for this resolution, Parliament expresses its outrage at the decision of the Government of Burundi to proceed with the presidential elections. President Pierre Nkurunziza's third term goes against the spirit of Article 96 of burundi's Constitution and is in clear violation of the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement, which stipulate that a president can only remain in office for two terms.  The elections of 29 June were already held under a climate of intimidation, violence and restriction of the main fundamental freedoms against opponents and civil society, including freedom of expression and information. On the contrary, every day that passes, the situation is getting worse and worse in Burundi and the surrounding region. We have made a firm appeal for the postponement of the presidential elections on 15 July in the interests of the security and democracy of the Burundian people.
