We call for targeted restrictive measures, including asset freezes, visa and travel bans, to be put in place for those responsible for acts of violence and repression.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution on Burundi. This text, once is not customary, does not place itself in the logic of interference. President Nkurunziza, who violated his country's constitution by seeking a third term, is "deplored" and wants a solution to the political crisis to be found internally between the government and the opposition.  It should be remembered that Burundi is bound by the Cotonou Agreements to respect for democratic principles, including freedom of expression and respect for opposition to the government.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this proposal for a Joint Resolution on the situation in Burundi, because although the text contains aspects with which I agree, such as the description of the climate of repression that the country is experiencing, concern about human rights violations and criticism of the electoral situation, lack of transparent information and a call for dialogue and the cessation of violence , other key elements are missing as a more consistent critique of neocolonialist practices and the exposure of natural resources, as well as a deeper and more complex analysis of the origins of the country's current situation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Unrest in Burundi has been going on for the past three months since President Pierre Nkurunziza announced his third consecutive candidacy in the presidential election. The response to the announcement was protests and a failed military coup in May this year.  The state is in a chaotic state, its worst since 2005, since the 12-year civil war ended. Human rights violations are everyday in this country and all this is a reason to try to find a solution as soon as possible in accordance with the Aruša Agreement and the Burundian Constitution.  It is necessary to postpone the elections so that they can be held in a safe environment, not in an atmosphere of unrest, fear, human rights violations and the general chaos that is currently present in this country, so I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Burundi.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the joint resolution tabled by several political groups in the EP. I'm in for.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The fragile political situation in West African Burundi triggered by the presidential elections also threatens the surrounding states, in particular the border Democratic Republic of Congo. Failure to address this problem can be a focal point for further tensions, the consequences of which will also be felt by the European Union and its Member States. All diplomatic relations, international treaties and conventions must be used, both in the position of European bodies and institutions and in the position of member states' bodies and institutions, which will lead to a level easing of tensions and a stabilisation of the civil and political situation in Burundi.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Burundi, because it is complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the EU’s chief election observer I fully endorse the view in this Resolution that ‘the elections held in Burundi on 29 June 2015 cannot be considered free, fair, credible and inclusive because the election process was seriously marred by restrictions on independent media, excessive use of force against demonstrators, a climate of intimidation for opposition parties and civil society and a lack of confidence in the election authorities, and urges the Burundian authorities to postpone the presidential elections of 15 July 2015 and to involve all the stakeholders in the efforts to create an environment conducive to a peaceful, credible, free and fair electoral process.’

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this text, which, once is not customary, does not show political interference. It is indeed necessary to be vigilant about the actions of President Nkurunziza who wants to violate the constitution in order to run for a third term. It is therefore necessary that the Cotonou agreements governing freedom of expression and respect for the opposition be maintained.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have supported this report, as it is essential to condemn the elections in Burundi on 29 June 2015 and the accompanying human rights violations by the government against demonstrators and opponents.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Burundi has failed to stabilize since the 2005 civil war. The president's announcement to run for a third term, contrary to the Arusha constitution and peace accords, continues to provoke severely repressed riots and a boycott of the opposition in the last elections.  The resolution calls, like the United Nations, for the postponement of presidential elections until a climate of peace is returned, and the disarmament and dissolution of the youth militias of the ruling party. It clearly identifies the dangers of the slide into civil war and the ethnic instrumentalization of the conflict.  I of course encourage the will for a political resolution of the conflict, but I am against THE EU's sanctions policies. Finally, Burundi's problems can only be solved by addressing social inequalities, including control of fertile agricultural land, corruption and poverty, through the creation of a free, democratic and stable state. I am voting to support the request for financial support from the United Nations to help the 200,000 or so refugees in neighbouring countries.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution, surprisingly, does not include any evidence to support interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. The crisis that this country has been experiencing since President Nkurunziza decided to run for a third term is a matter of domestic policy, over which we have no right or regulatory power: the citizens of Burundi must take their destiny into their own hands.  Parliament therefore calls for a solution to the crisis to be found by Burundian politicians in order to avoid any flare-up of the situation in an already unstable region. Finally, Parliament reiterated that Burundi was bound by the Cotonou Agreements to respect government opposition and freedom of expression. If these conditions were not met, Burundi would seriously damage its image and appear to be an unreliable partner.  The congresswoman voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the situation in Burundi, as the country is experiencing one of its worst political crises since 2005. Calls for the re-infront of dialogue with a view to a lasting political solution in order to ensure the preservation and consolidation of peace.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent months the political and humanitarian situation in Burundi has deteriorated dramatically. Tensions between the government and opposition and civil organisations have been rising, with many lives lost and violence flaring up. Almost 130 000 people have now fled the country, placing great strain on neighbouring countries. The crisis now has the potential to cause huge regional instability in an already fragile region. Therefore I supported the resolution, which calls for further action against those responsible in Burundi, including possible targeted sanctions and asset freezes, as well as greater support for the humanitarian situation in the region.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. 'Burundi' s face a violent political crisis since April this year, with the announcement of the candidacy of the current President, Pierre Nkurunziza, for a third term, which second the opposition is unconstitutional and violates the peace agreement, which in 2006 ended a 13-year civil war. Since the beginning of the crisis, at least 70 people have been killed and more than 140,000 have fled to neighboring countries.  In this climate of tension and conflict, municipal and local elections were held on June 29, which, according to several international organizations, including the Union Election Observation Mission, were neither free nor credible, scarcity in a climate of fear and intimidation.  This motion for a resolution thus calls for the presidential elections, scheduled for July 15, to be postponed until a climate conducive to democratic and free elections is restored and the different Election Observation Missions return.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This european Parliament's motion for a resolution reminds the Burundian government that it is bound by international agreements to respect for government opposition and freedom of expression in its country, both of which have been badly affected by the events triggered in recent months by President Nkurunziza's announcement of a third term.  Far from placing itself in a position of systematic interference, this proposal first calls for the resolution of this serious political crisis through a sustained and in-depth dialogue between the government and its opposition, and merely calls for respect for the Cotonou and Arusha agreements, necessary for peace in a troubled region.  Respect for past peace agreements, commitment to freedom of the press and freedom of expression and internal resolution of the conflict outside the usual flaws of interference explain my vote in favour of this proposal.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – I have voted for this resolution that expresses grave concern about the worsening political and humanitarian situation in Burundi and the wider region, calls for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation of opponents and the immediate disarmament of all armed youth groups allied to political parties.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This motion questions the democratic legitimacy of the recent Burundian elections, expresses concern at the worsening political and humanitarian crisis in the nation, calls on the Arusha Agreement to be honoured, emphasises the need for dialogue and encourages consensus, expresses concern at falling human rights standards in Burundi, demands an immediate cessation in the use of youth militias and calls for the immediate freeing of the press via the lifting of state imposed restrictions. Sinn Féin therefore supported the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The deteriorating political and humanitarian situation in Burundi is also causing problems more broadly in the region and has already led to a flood of refugees in neighbouring countries. As long as Burundi's ruling president and political forces do not stop harassing, intimidating and violence, EU aid must be stopped to support Burundi's state budget and channelled to humanitarian aid.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Burundi, according to the global hunger index, is among the most hungry countries in the world. The difficult political situation and the recent violence are preventing the normal development of the country with its neighbours. The EU has already allocated EUR 1.5 million in humanitarian aid. I would like to thank my colleagues in the ECR Group for analysing the events taking place in Burundi.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Under the Aruša Peace and Reconciliation Agreement, it was stipulated that the president could serve only two terms, and President Pierre Nkurunziza has been in power since 2005 and was re-elected in 2010 in an election boycotted by the opposition after accusing the government of intimidation. On April 26, 2015, President Nkurunziza announced that he would run for a third term, claiming he was entitled to it because he was first elected by lawmakers, which resulted in unrest in the country again and triggering protests and a failed military coup in May. Following that announcement, on May 14, 2015, 17 officers were arrested for a failed coup led by former Major General Godefroid Niyombare, who fled the country, and consequently more than 70 people were killed in violence and a series of shellings and massive displacement of the population.  I support the proposal for a resolution calling for the credibility and proper conduct of the election process in a peaceful and transparent manner and condemning violence and violations of human rights and political freedoms. I also ask the Commission to present to Parliament a review of the situation in Burundi in due course, as well as a report on the fulfilment of the points of this resolution calling for concrete action.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Parliament's motion for a resolution reminds the Burundian government that it is bound by international agreements to respect for government opposition and freedom of expression in its country, both of which have been badly undermined by the events triggered in recent months by President Nkurunziza's announcement of a third term.  Far from placing itself in a position of systematic interference, this proposal first calls for the resolution of this serious political crisis through a sustained and in-depth dialogue between the government and its opposition, and merely calls for respect for the Cotonou and Arusha agreements, necessary for peace in a troubled region.  Respect for past peace agreements, commitment to freedom of the press and freedom of expression and internal resolution of the conflict outside the usual flaws of interference explain my vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I join in expressing deep concern about the growing political and humanitarian situation in Burundi and the wider region and calls for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation of opponents; I offer my condolences to the victims of violence and those who lost their lives, and call for urgent humanitarian assistance for those who have been forced to flee their homes.  A lasting political solution in the interest of security and democracy for the entire people of Burundi can only be reached through dialogue and agreement involving the Burundian government, the opposition and civil society in accordance with the Aruša Agreement and the Burundian Constitution. All participants in Burundi should relaunch the dialogue on all areas where there is disagreement, which is why it is necessary to support the mediation efforts of the African Union, the East African Community and the UN and to support the implementation of concrete measures recently announced by the African Union. Both the European Union and its members should contribute to solving this problem and disburse all commitments to the UN Regional Response Plan for Burundi refugees.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a resolution to monitor the situation in Burundi. The political situation is extremely worrying because it can lead to the escalation of new ethnic conflicts. This would be a catastrophic consequence for the security of Burundi and the region. Incumbent President Pierre Nkurunzizaj's decision to seek a third term in the presidential election is contrary to the Constitution and the 2000 Aruša Peace and Reconciliation Agreement.  I condemn the overreaction of the Nkurunzizaja state police to the protesters. It is completely inadmissible for elections to take place in an atmosphere of violence, shelling and human rights violations, without opposition involvement due to the unresolved murder of opposition chief Zedi Feruzi, and media censorship. As vice-president of the EP Foreign Affairs Committee, I call for an immediate end to violence, the return of all opposition refugees and respect for the Arus Agreement in terms of conducting democratic and transparent elections. The role of the European Union should remain on the line of view of High Representative Mogherini, who said that the EU strongly supports the efforts of a "mediating group" consisting of representatives of the UN, the African Union, the East African Community and the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region. I support the mediation group's position that dialogue between the ruling and opposition parties needs to be established quickly, and postpone elections until 31 July 2015, when citizens should be allowed to choose their legal and legitimate representatives.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am following the situation in Burundi, which is another example of the efforts of some politicians in the region to circumvent constitutional rules. President Pierre Nkurunziza's attempt to extend his government for another term has created instability in a country that has a number of conflicts and is internally ethnically divided, and is therefore a very risky move by the president. In a situation tense after the coup attempt and other violence, the government has not put off parliamentary elections, and despite domestic and international protests, it is being held in this complex political situation and a saucy atmosphere. All the steps described deserve condemnation and sustained pressure on the Burundian Government to return to constitutional compliance and help calm the situation in the country.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament strongly condemned the Burundian government's decision to hold the presidential election until 15 July. At issue, of course, is Pierre Nkurunziza's desire to run for a third term strictly excluded by the constitution. The outgoing president uses a legal pirouette to justify his guilty stubbornness, his first term would be the work of Parliament and not elections. Since then, the country has been plunged into turmoil and protest is widespread.  Shortly after a coup attempt by a former army general on 13 May, Burundi's vice-president, several magistrates and members of the independent national electoral commission fled the country, 17 officers were arrested and more than 70 people died in violence. In this context, the electoral process is severely compromised: muzzled media, harshly repressed demonstrations, bullied opposition, etc. With this resolution, MEPs call on President Nkurunziza to do everything possible to create an environment conducive to peaceful, credible, free and fair elections.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The situation in Burundi continues to deteriorate as President Nkurunziza has deafly heard the international community and continues its electoral plans. Legislative and local elections took place in the country on 29 June, despite the continued climate of violence, the total absence of conditions for the development of an election campaign, the lack of impartial means and the growing number of citizens who decide to leave the country for fear of the outbreak of an open civil conflict.  This joint motion for a resolution, which I voted in favour, calls for action against those responsible for the current situation and violence against civilians, including possible selective sanctions and freezing of property. In addition, in the face of continued non-compliance with democratic principles and the null and void outcome of the political dialogue between the EU and the country, it is requested to open the procedure provided for in Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement to take appropriate measures, which may lead to the suspension of development aid channeled through State actors. Finally, the text also calls for strengthening emergency assistance to meet the needs of the growing number of refugees in neighbouring countries.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the decision of the Burundian authorities to maintain the presidential election in July, which should have been postponed in view of the deteriorating political climate and the worsening humanitarian crisis. The text of the resolution calls for an immediate end to the violence, urges the Burundian authorities to postpone the presidential elections and calls on all parties involved in the electoral process to honour their commitments under the Arusha Agreement, which has restored peace in the country after years of civil war. The text also calls on all parties to resume dialogue and the Burundian authorities to involve all actors in the efforts required to create an environment conducive to peaceful, credible, free and fair elections. It is only through dialogue and consensus between the government, the opposition and civil society that a lasting solution can be found.  Finally, the European Parliament also called for an immediate lifting of restrictions on the media and access to the internet, as legitimate elections cannot take place without the media being able to exercise and journalists to do their job without intimidation.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The debate on the situation in Burundi was held during the June plenary session, following the attempted coup d'état on 13 May. Although the coup has failed, there is still a turbulent and tension-relied atmosphere in Burundi. The EU, condemning the attempted coup d'état, is ready to contribute to a return to stability and calls on all parties in Burundi to engage sincerely in dialogue in a spirit of compromise and reconciliation. In support of the Eu ropean Union's position, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Burundi as a sign of our concern at the worsening political and humanitarian situation in the country and the whole region; we call for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opposition members and the immediate disarmament of all groups of young armed people linked to political parties. I think it is important that the EU and its Member States fulfil all the commitments made with respect to the UN Regional Response Plan for Burundi, which needs additional funds to deal with the current crisis.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The political, security and economic situation in Burundi is critical. The deterioration will have serious consequences for the local population, which is at risk of life. It poses a risk to an already unstable region. This is the most serious crisis ever since the end of the 12-year ethnic civil war, in which some 300 000 people died by 2005. I supported the European Parliament resolution condemning the actions of the Burundian Government and the illegitimately elected President. I support the call for all actors to have a common dialogue and respect for the commitments of the Aruš Agreement, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Burundi given the continuing human rights violations and the inability to hold fair elections in that country. Also, since the African Union Commission has announced that it will not attend and observe the elections and because of the control of independent media, I consider that independent, fair and legitimate elections are not possible. Unfortunately, Burundi is grappling with its worst political crisis since the war and poses a threat that the crisis could spread to other African countries. I am deeply concerned by the number of victims and refugees from Burundi. I condemn all crimes committed against human rights in Burundi.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report attempts to involve the EU in the way of internal governance of a country which is not a Member State.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution in which the European Parliament expresses its concerns about the political and human rights situation in Burundi, because I believe that the EU cannot turn a blind eye to serious infringements which, among other sources of law, are in breach of the Cotonou Convention between that country and the Union and its Member States. I am convinced that we cannot ignore the political practices that violate the Burundian Constitution and, among other things, the Arusha Convention, in order to achieve an illegal extension of the mandate of the President of the State, the annulment of the opposition and the elimination of civil rights. In my vote, I also considered the aspect that the political crisis in Burundi and the threat of violence could destabilise the entire already precarious region, thus thwarting European and international efforts to alleviate the serious humanitarian situation. I hope that the weight of the European Parliament's resolution will have an impact on political actors in Burundi, above all on power, and will contribute to improving local political and humane conditions. I also consider it an important objective of the resolution to further motivate and strongly support our joint EU foreign policy efforts there, led by High Representative Mogherini.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has, in the course of its institutional evolution, developed high democratic standards, which put at the forefront of respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens. In this respect, the Union supports the strengthening of democratic regimes around the world, without imposing its standards on other states. However, there are certain minimum requirements for countries receiving financial aid from the Union and which must comply with certain political and decision-making transparency criteria. Burundi is one such case, being a poor African country, plagued by long internal conflicts. The European Union supported its economic development and the establishment of a democratic regime. At present, however, an unacceptable level of internal conflict has been reached, which has led to a large number of refugees and the candidacy of the President-in-Office for a third term, contrary to the provisions of the 2005 Constitution. In those circumstances, it is time for the European Union to take a stand on the situation created and adopt the necessary sanctions against an abusive regime which is no longer representative of that State. That is why I believe that it is necessary to adopt this resolution, which can help change the situation and help people affected by the unjust policies of the Government of Burundi.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. As the guarantor of the Arusha agreements, the European Union has a duty to act against crimes committed in Burundi. Through this resolution, we call on the High Representative for Foreign Policy to punish those responsible for this violence by banning them from eu membership visas and by freezing their assets placed in the Member States. We also call for a reorienting European aid by suspending all cooperation with the authorities and strengthening our support for Burundian civil society. I, of course, voted in favour of this text.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling for an immediate halt to violence, that urges the Burundian authorities to postpone the presidential election and calls on all parties involved in the electoral process. The conflict in the country needs now to come to an end and I call on all parties to resume dialogue.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ This resolution highlights the fundamental problem of burundi's current political and social crisis, which is President Nkurunziza's attempt to win a mandate for the third time even though it is contrary to the Burundian constitution.  I believe that this attempt to retain power caused serious divisions in society and as a result 70 people were killed in the protests and more than 110 000 Burundians fled to Tanzania, Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. I also support the position of the Commission, which has expressed its agitation at the growing violence and dangerous actions of pro-government police and called on the authorities to take concrete action and rein them in. The fact is that the current political and security situation does not provide the conditions necessary for free, fair and credible elections, so I support the call for the Burundian authorities to postpone the presidential elections due on 15 July 2015, in order to pave the way for a lasting political solution to deepen democracy and the rule of law by consensus and dialogue and to ensure safe conditions for refugee returns. I also support the request to continue monitoring the situation in Burundi and to consider providing additional humanitarian assistance to Burundian refugees in Rwanda in addition to the €1.5 million in aid already provided by the Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Burundi as a sign of our concern at the worsening political and humanitarian situation in the country and the whole region; we call for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opposition members and the immediate disarmament of all groups of young armed people linked to political parties. I think it is important that the EU and its Member States fulfil all the commitments made with respect to the UN Regional Response Plan for Burundi, which needs additional funds to deal with the current crisis.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Joint Resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Burundi as a sign of our concern at the worsening political and humanitarian situation in the country and the whole region; we call for an immediate end to violence and political intimidation against opposition members and the immediate disarmament of all groups of young armed people linked to political parties. I think it is important that the EU and its Member States fulfil all the commitments made with respect to the UN Regional Response Plan for Burundi, which needs additional funds to deal with the current crisis.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Burundi has plunged into a climate of great turbulence since April 2015, when its President, Pierre Nkurunziza, launched his controversial bid for a third consecutive five-year term, triggering widespread protests and a failed military coup in May. Regardless of the real problems affecting that country, we call once again for foreign powers not to meddling, implying ceasing any supply of arms to that country and calling for political dialogue between the parties, without violence and without repression.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it is essential to condemn the elections in Burundi on 29 June 2015 and the associated human rights violations by the government against demonstrators and opponents.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Burundi, the fifth poorest country in the world, is experiencing a difficult political period that can lead to an even more serious conflict. It is only ten years since the civil war there, which has claimed up to 300 000 lives. The current crisis was triggered by President Nkurunziza's third candidacy, although burundi's constitution allows him to remain in office for a maximum of two terms. Already the parliamentary elections on 29 June were held in a climate of general fear, and the conditions for free and fair presidential elections are not favourable at all. Political opponents are intimidated and subjected to violence, independent media have been red and closed since mid-May, journalists are leaving the country en masse and those who have stayed face constant threats. At least 70 people were killed in the brutally suppressed demonstrations and some 127 000 people have fled to neighbouring states for fear of their lives. The situation has an impact on the economic and social life of all Burundians who have chosen to stay. Schools are closed, the local currency has weakened, unemployment has increased and tax revenues have been reduced. Developments in the coming days may be crucial for the overall stability of the Great Lakes region. Only dialogue and consensus of all parties can lead to a lasting political solution for all the people of Burundi.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This resolution describes the complex and unstable situation in Burundi and clearly identified the need to provide assistance to refugee camps from a health point of view to control epidemics, assisting victims of a situation to which they are unrelated, which we consider to be positive. However, it contains elements of interference (proposals for sanctions, reductions in financial support to the country, guidelines for allocating these funds, all supported by the presumption of an illegitimate EU foreign policy) which, in addition to being unacceptable, will not contribute to stability in the region, or to help the People can freely and without external pressures determine their future.  For these reasons we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The motion for a resolution put to the vote is the result of the European Parliament's intention to commemorate the anniversary of the tragic events that took place in the town of Srebrenica in July 1995, when it was occupied by the army of the Republika Srpska. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution since, unfortunately, such statements are a clear manipulation of the victims of those atrocities, which were subsequently evoked to commit other crimes no less heinous on the part of Western powers in the region. Moreover, the commemoration of Srebrenica obviates other no less tragic events that occurred in the same context, such as the mass expulsion of the Serbs from Krajina in August 1995. For these reasons, therefore, I have finally abstained.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. On 11 July 1995, in the midst of the Bosnian war, Europe witnessed an inhumane crime. 8000 Bosniaks were killed in the massacre near Srebrenica, despite the presence of Blue Helmets. This massacre has gone into history as the most horrific war crime since the end of World War II. Today, 20 years after these atrocities, we are remembering the many victims in this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. It is not for the European Parliament to define the terms for describing a historical event: memorial laws do not fall within its areas of competence, especially since I denounce their very existence in France.   Barely twenty years after the events, it is far too early to see clearly in this dark episode of the Bosnian Serb war. Before the term "genocide" can be used, the hearings or trials of the many remaining protagonists would have to be completed. It should be remembered that many Serbs living in Bosnia have been expelled from their territory, without any reaction from the Union and its members.  Moreover, this resolution promotes community integration, which I do not consider healthy or desirable.  For these reasons, I objected to this motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to confirm that my vote on this subject was to abstain, and I did so on the grounds that whilst the report contained aspects which I support, I also believe that foreign policy should be the preserve of the Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. On 11 July 2015, the 20th anniversary of the Genocide Act and ethnic cleansing in Srebrenica and its surroundings, which will have to re-recall the dangers of extreme forms of nationalism and intolerance in society, which is exacerbated by war, is being celebrated. In the days of the massacre, Bosnian Serb forces led by General Mladic and paramilitary units, including militias, killed more than 8,000 Muslim faith men and boys in a protected area under the leadership of General Mladic. Almost 30 000 women, children and the elderly were forcibly deported as part of a mass campaign of ethnic cleansing, making it the greatest war crime in Europe since the end of The Second World War; condemns the genocide in Srebrenica in the strongest terms.  Political representatives in Bosnia and Herzegovina must recognise the past in order to be able to work together successfully to secure a better future for all the citizens of the country. It is important that the role of neighbouring countries, religious authorities, civil society, arts, culture, media and education systems in this complex process is recognised.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution of a Manichaean simplism that once again accuses the Serbs of all evils.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, endorsed this joint resolution by which the European Parliament first pays tribute to all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and all the atrocities committed during the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia, and specifies that it will do everything in its power to ensure that such acts cannot happen again. It underlines the role of political representatives and societal actors in Bosnia and Herzegovina in getting the past accepted and achieving a better future for all the country's citizens.  Parliament stresses the importance of the ICTY's work and reiterates that more attention must be paid to war crimes trials at the national level. It reaffirms its commitment to the European perspective and then to the accession process of all the countries of the Western Balkans and believes that regional cooperation and European integration are the best way to encourage reconciliation and overcome hatred and division. Finally, it marks its support for civil society associations such as the Mothers' Association of the Srebrenica and 'Epa' enclaves for their central role in raising awareness and consolidating the foundations on which reconciliation between all citizens must be based.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Parliament's motion for a resolution is intended to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the massacre of the Bosnian Muslim population in the Srebrenica region in the summer of 1995 during the War of Bosnia and Herzegovina.  This proposal fully enshrines the term genocide, unlike the UN Security Council. Even if these acts and what is committed in times of war is obviously reprehensible, we cannot speak of genocide here since women, children and old people have been evacuated and spared.  We also take this opportunity to remind us of the importance of the integration of the Balkan countries, in particular Bosnia and Herzegovina into the EU. As a member of the delegation for Bosnia and Kosovo, I have seen the Europeanist desire for an eu enlargement to these countries at all costs.  I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the commemoration of Srebrenica is balanced and I support it, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Council was unanimous and consistent in classifying Srebrenica's events as genocide, of which 11 July 2015 marks the 20th anniversary. This act of ethnic cleansing took place during the Bosnian War. The crimes were perpetrated by the Army of the Republika Srpska, under the command of General Mladic and the President of the Republika Srpska, Radovan Karadzic. The victims were around eight thousand people, mostly Bosnian Muslims. This killing has left profound emotional consequences in the surviving society and persistent obstacles to reconciliation among the ethnic groups of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Srebrenica massacre was declared an act of genocide by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, occurred in a united nations-established refuge zone, and is a symbol of the impotence of the international community to intervene in a conflict and effectively protect innocent civilians. The EP adopted Resolutions on this massacre in 2005 and 2009. The EU is currently maintaining a Stabilisation Agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina, signed in 2008, which entered into force last month. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because 11 July 2015 marks the anniversary of the Genocide Act and ethnic cleansing that took place during the 20th Bosnian War in Srebrenica and its surroundings, which will have to remind again of the dangers of extreme forms of nationalism and intolerance in society, which is exacerbated by the war.  The European Parliament mentions and pays tribute to all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and atrocities during the war in the former Yugoslavia and expresses its condolences and unity with the families of the victims. Parliament condemns the genocide in Srebrenica in the strongest possible terms. Such horrific crimes cannot happen again and we must do everything we can to prevent such actions from happening again in the future. The European Parliament believes that political representatives in Bosnia and Herzegovina must recognise the past in order to be able to work together successfully to secure a better future for all the citizens of the country.  In addition, the important role of neighbouring countries, religious authorities, civil society, arts, culture, media and education systems in this complex process must be recognised. The European Parliament urges the development of education and culture programmes that promote awareness of the causes of such atrocities and raise awareness of the need to uphold peace and promote human rights and mutual tolerance between religious groups.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 11 July marks the 20th anniversary of the events in Srebrenica, a massacre which led to the deaths of more than 8 000 bosnian Muslim men and women and was described by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia as an act of genocide. It is imperative for the European Union to convey the memory of this tragedy and to ensure that such horrific crimes do not happen again. The resolution I have signed calls for the European Union to continue its efforts to bring the countries and peoples of the Balkan region closer together so as to ensure a more stable future today. Economic, cultural and educational development policies have a key role to play in supporting a process that is designed to ensure peace, human rights and interreligious debate, in an area where difficult relations and delicate balances undermine the unity of civil society itself. The European Union must be ready to support this work of reconciliation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is essential that tragedies such as the Srebrenica genocide are commemorated, so as never to forget what horrors and atrocities have been committed in the past, so that they never happen again in the future. It is our task, as a bastion of democracy and tolerance, to carry this message of peace.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Reconciliation needs justice to be possible and justice needs the truth to be authentic. Even today, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs reconciliation, justice and truth. What happened twenty years ago in Srebrenica is an indelible stain on our consciences as Europeans: there is no possible justification for what was the worst crime committed in Europe since the end of the Second World War. The coordinated, systematic and planned massacre of thousands of men, women and children from above can only be defined by a single term: genocide. If the Union were to ignore a fact of this moral and political gravity that took place so soon from the capitals of our Member States, it would betray the founding principle of the very path of reconciliation: the will to ban war and ethnic and religious conflicts forever. We have a moral obligation to guarantee truth and justice for the victims and we cannot accept that there are still unpunished perpetrators of the massacre, and that is why we must support the Association of Mothers of the Enclave of Srebrenica and Zepa together with all those who work tirelessly to honour the memory of those killed and to bring their murderers to justice.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This year marks the 20th anniversary of the genocide and ethnic cleansing that took place in and around Srebrenica during the bosnian war. Thousands of citizens were then executed and more than 30,000 others were forcibly expelled in an ethnic cleansing campaign. These regrettable events must be known and brought back to the memory of all European citizens, in order to show the monstrous effects of intolerance and excessive nationalism, which are still flourishing in certain areas of Europe and the world. I voted in favour of this resolution because, first of all, this commemoration pays tribute to all the victims and reiterates the need for much-needed peace, security, tolerance, especially in the current European context.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Such a tragic episode thanks to the right memory.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the commemoration of Srebrenica. The twentieth anniversary of the genocide and ethnic cleansing that took place in Srebrenica during the Bosnian War by the Army of the Republika Srpska under the command of General Ratko Mladić and the command-in-chief of the then President of the Republika Srpska Radovan Karadžić, remind us of the danger of extreme forms of nationalism and intolerance in society, particularly in times of war. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution which, in addition to commemorating and honouring all the victims of the Srebrenica atrocities and expressing its closeness to the families of the victims, called on the European Union and the international community to commit themselves to preventing and punishing genocide and crimes against humanity. I hope that this moment of reflection will enable all the countries of the Western Balkans to recognise the past with the aim of continuing the reconciliation process with a view to a better future for all the citizens of the country.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Had I been present for this vote, I would have abstained on the grounds that, whilst the report contained aspects which I support, I believe that foreign policy should be the preserve of the Member States. I am deeply saddened that the concept of death camps, which we all hoped and prayed had finished forever after World War II, returned to the former Yugoslavia so recently.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution on the 20th anniversary of the act of genocide and ethnic cleansing that took place in and around Srebrenica during the Bosnian war and which expresses its condolences to and solidarity with the families of the victims, many of whom are living without knowing the final fate of their dear ones. This should serve as a reminder of the dangers of extreme forms of nationalism and intolerance in society, further exacerbated in the framework of war. The Resolution also urges the development of educational and cultural programmes that promote the understanding of these atrocities and raise awareness about the need to nurture peace and promote human rights and interreligious tolerance. It further commends the important work done by the ICTY and highlights the need for measures to accelerate the trials and appeals and bring them to an end.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report commemorating the Srebrenica massacre, a dark chapter of humanity that it is right to remember twenty years later.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution commemorating the Srebrenica massacre. July 11, 2015 marks the anniversary of the genocide in which 8,000 Muslim men were executed by the Serbian army under the command of General Ratko Mladić, operating under the authority of then-Republika Srpska President Radovan Karadžić. The massacre was recognised as genocide by both the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and the International Court of Justice. This resolution commemorates the victims of genocide (1 800 of whom have not yet been identified), reaffirms the EU's commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina and notes that regional cooperation and the Process of European Integration are the most appropriate approaches to promoting reconciliation in the region.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal calling for the commemoration of the Genocide in Srebrenica on the occasion of its twentieth anniversary, because I am convinced that one of the main driving forces towards European integration now, as then, is the firm condemnation of events such as this and the strenuous desire to prevent them from happening again. In Srebrenica, more than 8 000 Muslim men and boys were sum-up executed in an area which was under the control of the United Nations protection force and which should have been a safe place for them to find protection.  30 000 women, children and the elderly were forcibly expelled and thousands of women were raped. Thousands of families live ignoring what happened to their relatives, despite the efforts made in fact the bodies of 1,200 men in Srebrenica have not yet been located and identified. Commemorating the greatest war crime in Europe since the end of the Second World War is the least we can do to the families of those who have been killed and the survivors, in doing so we are committed to ensuring that such atrocities never happen again and we stand against any denial, relativisation or misinterpretation of this genocide.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Srebrenica genocide is a sad chapter in recent European history, which has left deep emotional wounds on survivors and created lasting obstacles to political reconciliation between ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The commemoration of the tragic events in Srebrenica reminds us of the danger posed by extreme forms of nationalism and intolerance in society, which can never be considered permanently slumbered. In this context, I believe that regional cooperation and, even more so, the continuation of the accession process for Bosnia and Herzegovina can promote peaceful coexistence and prevent a repetition of wars and crimes against international humanitarian law in Europe. For these reasons, I wished to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The motion for a resolution put to the vote is the result of the European Parliament's intention to commemorate the anniversary of the tragic events that took place in the town of Srebrenica in July 1995, when it was occupied by the army of the Republika Srpska. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution since, unfortunately, such statements are a clear manipulation of the victims of those atrocities, which were subsequently evoked to commit other crimes no less heinous on the part of Western powers in the region. Moreover, the commemoration of Srebrenica obviates other no less tragic events that occurred in the same context, such as the mass expulsion of the Serbs from Krajina in August 1995. For these reasons, therefore, I have finally abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ 11 July 2015 marks the 20th anniversary of the worst act of genocide and crime against humanity that took place in Europe, during the Bosnian War, since 1945. This resolution expresses its condolences to and solidarity with the families of the victims and condemns in the strongest possible terms the genocide in Srebrenica. It also solemnly declares that such horrendous crimes must never happen again and states that it will do everything in its power to prevent such acts from recurring while rejecting any denial of the genocide. Condemning what happened, admitting what it really was and vowing to do all we can to deny a repetition are the least we can do in front of such deep human suffering experienced by the affected population. I supported this resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution commemorates the 20th anniversary of the massacre and ethnic cleansing in Srebrenica during the Bosnian war, which saw more than 8,000 Muslims summarily executed by Bosnian Serb forces and nearly 30,000 women, children and elderly forcibly evicted during a campaign of mass ethnic cleansing.  The European Parliament pays tribute to all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and all the atrocities committed during the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia and reaffirms the Union's commitment to the European perspective and then to the accession process of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all the countries of the Western Balkans in the long term.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 1995 in Srebrenica, a city in eastern Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnian Serb soldiers led by General Ratko Mladić massacred about eight thousand Muslim men and boys. The Srebrenica massacre is the most serious massacre in Europe since the end of the Second World War and is regarded by international justice as an act of genocide. Twenty years after the terrible tragedy, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution because I believe that we must remind the whole world how destructive forces are always lurking, which is why it is essential to encourage our societies more to affirm a culture of compassion and solidarity.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2004 the ICTY ruled that the massacre of the enclave’s male inhabitants constituted genocide, a crime under international law. The forcible transfer of between 25 000 and 30 000 Bosniak women, children and elderly which accompanied the massacre was found to be confirming evidence of the genocidal intent of members of the VRS. A year later the then-Secretary General of the United Nations Kofi Annan said the UN’s failure to protect the people of Srebrenica would haunt the organisation forever. The ECR supports efforts to bring peace and stability to the Balkans, and to foster reconciliation between communities and religious groups.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against because the resolution is one-sided, condemns the Serbs without referring at all to the crimes of the other parties and without mentioning also the role of various European states in the civil war in Yugoslavia, in particular Germany. Also, the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia "paradoxically" has only convicted Serbs.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as it commemorates the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and the atrocities committed during the wars in the territory of the former Yugoslavia and expresses its solidarity with the families of the victims. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights recognise the right of every individual to life. This right was brutally violated against more than 8 000 Muslim men and boys, who were sum up executed by Bosnian Serb forces on 11 July 1995 in the Bosnian city of Srebrenica, which had been declared a United Nations protected area. In addition, some 30 000 women, children and the elderly have been forcibly expelled and a large number of women raped, as part of a large-scale ethnic cleansing operation that has made the events in Srebrenica the largest war crime in Europe since the end of the Second World War. I therefore believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina's decision to declare 11 July a day of national mourning in Bosnia and Herzegovina is a duty, and I hope that the UN will adopt a resolution as soon as possible in commemoration of the genocide in Srebrenica.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is a piece of ideological propaganda which, based on fragments of history, seeks to legitimize the events that led to the tragic event, laundering the responsibilities and unquestionable role that the US, NATO and THE EU have played in the whole process of dismemberment of Yugoslavia and, as well as, in the conflicts that have taken place in the Balkan region, fueling the hateful conflicts between populations , promoting, financing and imposing war, with a tragic civil dimension. This is a regrettable text of historical bleaching for which it omits, a human tragedy that goes well beyond the event it reports, and which has the imprint of the expansionist imperialist policies of the US, NATO and the EU. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the INITIATIVE of the UN Security Council to declare 11 July a world day of remembrance for the more than 8 000 victims of the massacre of Bosnian men and boys in the then UN protection zone. It is important that we keep reminding ourselves that such tragedies can happen, and we must take measures to prevent similar tragedies in the future. It is certainly very difficult for the relatives of the victims of this tragedy to watch the impossibly stretching trial of the main culprits, Bosnian Serb President Radan Karadzic and his army general Ratko Mlaladich. The authorities of the Bosnian Republic of Serbia have so far refused to define the massacre in question as genocide, despite the International Court of Justice describing the Srebrenica massacre as genocide in 2007, as well as the UN International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia during trials of several Bosnian Serb commanders.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution condemning the perpetrators of this sad page in recent European history.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative, because the resolution is one-sided; Also, the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia "paradoxically" has only convicted Serbs.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the days following Srebrenica’s fall, more than 8 000 Bosnian Muslim men and boys were systematically massacred and buried in mass graves. Thousands of women, children and elderly people were forcibly deported and a large number of women were raped. It was the greatest atrocity on European soil since the Second World War, and this is why I believe that the European Commission should, by all means, appropriately commemorate the anniversary of the Srebrenica-Potoćari act of genocide, by supporting Parliament’s recognition of 11 July as the day of commemoration of the Srebrenica genocide all over the EU, and call on all the countries of the western Balkans to do the same.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the motion pays tribute to all the victims of the Srebrenica massacre and the atrocities committed during the war in the former Yugoslavia, and expresses its condolences and sympathies to the families of the victims. I would like to stress, as well as the rapporteur, that timely prevention and effective punishment of genocide and crimes against humanity must be one of the European Union's main priorities. I think it is important that it calls on the Council, the Commission and the Member States to use all means at their disposal to ensure that such barbaric atrocities never happen again in Europe and to investigate whether EU citizens were involved in, or facilitated, genocide, crimes against humanity or war crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina between 1992 and 1995. Furthermore, it calls on the Parliamentary Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina to adopt a resolution on the genocide in Srebrenica; welcomes the UK's initiative to adopt a UN resolution on this subject.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Srebrenica massacre is a historical page that is still open and burning. Twenty years on, there are still processes under way and they must continue in such a way as to establish the truth of the facts. We must not be afraid to face reality, we have also seen with the genocide of the Armenians recently that time not only does not help to heal wounds but risks enthusing them more and more. It is a good thing that Parliament has spoken today to remember what has happened, in the hope that this debate will help heal the wounds of the past and contribute to a peaceful future.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I could only vote in favour of the joint resolution on the genocide in Srebrenica, on the eve of the sad anniversary of the twenty years since the tragedy. What happened in Srebrenica is one of the most dramatic pages in the history of the Post-War European continent and still leaves a deep and open wound in the memory of the victims and their loved ones.  The deportation and massacre of thousands of men, boys, the elderly and children and the systematic rape of women and girls, as a weapon for spreading fear among civilians, can only have a name, that is, genocide, on which there can be no different interpretations. I join in the strongest and most total condemnation of the genocide in Srebrenica and I hope that in future the strongest intervention by European and international actors will prevent and prevent the escalation of violence that has led to such a tragedy of humanity.   I call for greater awareness on the part of the Bosnian authorities in order to recognise the mistakes of the past and to re-found on this basis the ground for reconciliation of the various components of the Bosnian people.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution commemorating Srebrenica because it is important to me not only to commemorate this massacre on its 20th anniversary, but to clearly call it genocide. I regret that this has not been achieved in the UN because of Russia's blocking attitude.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We remember and pay tribute to all the victims of the wars in the former Yugoslavia and express our condolences and solidarity to the victims and their families. However, I voted against this motion for a resolution in considering it partial because it refers only to the responsibility of one side to the tragedy, thus bypassing the responsibilities of other sides, such as war crimes committed by Naser Oric. The motion for a Resolution also omits any mention of the failures of United Nations interposition forces to prevent tragedy. In order to remember and honor victims, and to ensure that tragedies like this do not happen again, we consider it essential an impartial approach that captures the responsibilities of all actors.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As we commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide, we honour the memory of the victims and pay tribute to the fortitude of their families in seeking justice. It shames the world that it failed to protect so many innocent civilians. It is disappointing that the UN failed to pass this resolution. In light of this we renew our determination never to let forces of prejudice, hatred and evil go unchecked. While we commemorate the past, we keep our eyes firmly on the future of Bosnia, and the region. Our duty is to strengthen our efforts to promote education, remembrance and research about Srebrenica and other genocides. We remain fully committed to Bosnia and Herzegovina being part of the EU, together with other Western Balkan nations. The European path is the best way to move forward beyond the tragedies of the past. We urge the leaders of Bosnia to work together to make the country a safe and prosperous place, for this will be the lasting tribute to the Srebrenica victims. Our hearts and thoughts will always be with them.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution commemorating the anniversary of the Srebrenica massacre.  Together with Parliament, I am pleased and honour all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and atrocities that took place during the war in the former Yugoslavia; families of the victims, many of whom live without final confirmation of the fate of their loved ones, express my condolences and unity with them. I also condemn the genocide in Srebrenica in the strongest possible terms and declare that such horrific crimes cannot happen again. With this report, Parliament says that it will do everything it can to prevent such action from happening again in the future; rejects any denial, relativitation or misinterpretation of genocide. I think this is very important for the people of Srebrenica.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We remember and pay tribute to all the victims of the wars in the former Yugoslavia and express our condolences and solidarity to the victims and their families. However, I voted against this motion for a resolution in considering it partial because it refers only to the responsibility of one side to the tragedy, thus bypassing the responsibilities of other sides, such as war crimes committed by Naser Oric. The motion for a Resolution also omits any mention of the failures of United Nations interposition forces to prevent tragedy. In order to remember and honor victims, and to ensure that tragedies like this do not happen again, we consider it essential an impartial approach that captures the responsibilities of all actors.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint resolution commemorating the memory of Srebrenica because I am convinced that the European Parliament must forever commemorate the horrors of the genocide that took place in Srebrenica. The suffering of innocent people and the Srebrenica war is the worst that happened after World War II on European soil. I hope that July 11th will become a day to commemorate the memory of the genocide that was carried out in Srebrenica, but unfortunately in many other places. This Resolution contains a clear view that the European Union is built on unity in diversity, and this is also a message to all the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bearing in mind that the United Nations failed to reach a resolution on Srebrenica, this European Parliament document thus gains even more importance at a time when the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina has taken a unanimous decision to commemorate the Day of Mourning in BiH on the occasion of the Srebrenica genocide. I see this resolution as an invitation to politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina to stop divisions and to take a unique European path so that all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina can finally get the right European perspective. The European Union is ready to accept all western Balkan countries in its own environment and this is an opportunity that should simply not be missed.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this motion for a resolution on the commemoration of the events in Srebrenica. Indeed, it is not Parliament's role to define the terms used to describe a historical event: memorial laws do not fall within its areas of competence. Especially given the historical proximity, it is conceivable that it will still take time for all the light to be shed on this dark episode of the Bosnian Serb war. Thus, it is not acceptable for Parliament to call these events a "genocide". The hearings or trials of several protagonists have yet to take place, it is not possible to know the full complexity of these events.  In addition, this resolution takes the opportunity to promote European integration, which in this case is not particularly healthy or desirable. It should be remembered that in 1995, Serbs living in Bosnia were also expelled from their territory, without this outrageously moved the good Western consciences.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the commemoration of Srebrenica, which pays tribute to all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide, perpetuated on 11 July 1995. This resolution strongly condemns this massacre of an unprecedented atrocity in which more than 8,000 people lost their lives. This resolution also reminds us of the atrocities of exacerbated nationalism. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the commemoration of the Srebrenica massacre. The commemoration of such an event is essential to show our support for the families of the victims and, on the other hand, to show the terrible effects of intolerance and nationalism taken to the extreme. Recognition of the Srebrenica genocide is very important and represents a major step towards reconciliation of ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am clearly voting in favour of this report. The Srebrenica massacre 20 years ago was the worst massacre in Europe since the end of the Second World War and must finally be dealt with in legal terms.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Memory and honour reports in the past are necessary to ensure that the events that took place in Srebrenica will never be undertaken again. But what is important now is the reference to the future. The country's next steps depend on the process of reconciliation between ethnic groups and collective work on the road to its integration into the European family.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 How can you deny, relativize, misinterprete what happened in Srebenica only twenty years ago? Genocide took place on our doorstep, costing the lives of more than 8 000 men and boys, an ethnic cleansing operation that saw 30 000 women, children and the elderly forcefully expelled from their city, which experienced the worst violations of human rights, especially against women and girls. Yet there are still those who, among the main culprits for maintaining international peace and security, are unable to adopt a resolution commemorating the genocide. Today, in commemorating and honouring the victims of Srebenica, this House is committed to this atrocity never happening again. Our thoughts are with the families of the victims, especially those who, after twenty years, still do not know the fate of their loved ones. I express my admiration and support for the many organisations that carry out awareness-raising campaigns and fight, every day, for the process of reconciliation between all the citizens of the country. Thanks, in particular, to the Parent associations of the enclaves of Srebrenica and Žepa.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the commemoration of Srebrenica, because I believe that the instrumentalisation of the victims of this massacre in favour of the european Union's enlargement policy is deplorable.  Indeed, paragraph 5 of the resolution "reaffirms the Union's commitment to the European perspective and then to the accession process of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all the countries of the Western Balkans; believes that regional cooperation and European integration are the best way to encourage reconciliation and overcome hatred and division."  The dead of Srebrenica and their families deserve to be honoured without any attempt at political recovery.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The motion for a resolution put to the vote is the result of the European Parliament's intention to commemorate the anniversary of the tragic events that took place in the town of Srebrenica in July 1995, when it was occupied by the army of the Republika Srpska. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution since, unfortunately, such statements are a clear manipulation of the victims of those atrocities, which were subsequently evoked to commit other crimes no less heinous on the part of Western powers in the region. Moreover, the commemoration of Srebrenica obviates other no less tragic events that occurred in the same context, such as the mass expulsion of the Serbs from Krajina in August 1995. For these reasons, therefore, I have finally abstained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. On the occasion of the 20th anniversary of commemorating the terrible crime of genocide and ethnic cleansing committed in Srebrenica, where more than 8,000 men and boys were executed, I supported the European Parliament Resolution, which expresses my deep condolences to all the victims and their families. The resolution wants to remind that such crimes must never be repeated again, calls on all participants, political representatives and civil society to create conditions for a better future for citizens and respect the convictions of international courts that have declared this crime genocide. We need to know and acknowledge the past and provide assistance to the families of the victims in their attempts to find and bury their loved ones and to find a solution for a stable and equal Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a terrible tragedy, the consequences of which we will experience for a long time to come. A number of victims of the massacre are not upset in a decent way after 20 years. I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The July 1995 massacre in Bosnian Srebrenica will forever be a black memory in Europe's modern history. The memory is all the more painful because thousands of defenceless people died despite the fact that, in the spring of 1993, the United Nations Srebrenica was declared a safe zone to protect the Muslim population. All the more so because this massacre is a failure of political, military and human, which must not happen again in Europe in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I honour the memory of all the victims and strongly condemn the genocide in Srebrenica. Furthermore, I call for educational and cultural programmes that promote an understanding of the causes of such atrocities and raise awareness of the need to foster peace and promote human rights.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this Resolution which ‘stresses that the timely prevention and effective punishment of genocides and crimes against humanity should count among the EU’s main priorities’.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which stirs up the demons of the past that this region does not need. This text serves mainly as propaganda for the Union. Through this approach, it promotes European integration with a crucial lack of objectivity.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the European Parliament is joining in condemning the horrific crime committed in Srebrenica two decades ago. In order not to repeat such crimes, their context must not be forgotten. Ripping events out of the context of the times, the idea that only one side commits crimes in the Civil War only hurts and sparks hatred. We must not forget that the real crime was the war itself, which took place throughout yugoslavia at the time. A war in which some 140,000 people were killed and four million people turned into refugees. When we talk about the crimes of Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina, we must always remind that the blame lies with specific individuals, not the nation. And let us also remember that the first ethnic cleansing of this terrible war was directed against the Serbs in Croatia. Let me express my conviction that the horrors of war in Yugoslavia would not have happened if the parties to the dispute had not been supported from abroad. And it wasn't just diplomatic support. The Balkans were filled with weapons from abroad during the war. This was done even though an embargo had been imposed. There is still a lack of truly technical and, above all, independent historical analyses of the nature of this war, including in this resolution, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 July 11, 2015 was the 20th anniversary of the genocide and ethnic cleansing that took place in Srebrenica during the Bosnian War. I believe that the European Union has a duty to reiterate its deep disappointment at actions that castrate human dignity. In particular, I welcomed the reference in the document to the need to cultivate peace and to promote human rights and interreligious tolerance within the EU's borders, with a view to averting further harmful events.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this report because the condemnation of the Srebrenica massacre 20 years ago must be remembered. The human rights crimes of that time must not be forgotten. However, I would also like to point out that the report refers only unilaterally to the situation of the Bosnian Serbs at the time and excludes other ethnic groups.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution commemorates the massacre of 8,372 Bosnians (Muslim Bosnians who formed a national group in socialist Yugoslavia) in Srebrenica.   "Political representatives in Bosnia and Herzegovina must accept the past in order to work together to forge a better future for all the citizens of the country." The resolution calls on national politicians to take their share of responsibility in the past.  However, the Union also has a responsibility and could begin by ending the foreign military presence in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Commemorating the 20th anniversary of the genocide requires the utmost seriousness. Recognition of genocide is of course an element of appeasement. All parties must therefore be judged, including on the Bosnian side, as the case of General Naser Oric is virtually cleared. This resolution does not mention it.  Finally, it maintains the ethnic division of the country initiated by the United States, unsuitable for easing tensions. It even supports the role of religions as the Vatican pushes Croatian demands and Qatar, for its part, Wahhabi Islam.  There, it is potentially new frontiers for tomorrow and a country even more fragmented.  In these circumstances, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. It is not Parliament's role to define the terms used to describe a historical event: memorial laws do not fall within its areas of competence.
