Given the historical proximity, it will still take time for all the light to be shed on this dark episode of the Bosnian Serb war. Thus, it is not acceptable for Parliament to call these events a "genocide". The hearings or trials of several protagonists have yet to take place, it is not possible to know the full complexity of these events.  In addition, this resolution takes the opportunity to promote European integration, which in this case is neither healthy nor desirable. It should be remembered that in 1995, Serbs living in Bosnia were also expelled from their territory, without this outrageously moved the good Western consciences.  The congressman voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. What happened twenty years ago in July 1995 in the Bosnian city of Srebrenica is now remembered here. I pay tribute to the victims, expressing my condolences and solidarity with the families of the victims, many of whom live without definitive confirmation of the fate of their families. I most vehemently confound the genocide of Srebrenica. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of the resolution on the commemoration of Srebrenica. 20 years ago, on 11 July 1995, when the former Yugoslavia was torn apart by war, Srebrenica was the scene of the greatest war crime committed in Europe since the Second World War.  Through this resolution, Parliament pays tribute to the victims of genocide and stresses the importance of reconciliation, remembrance, awareness of young people, respect for human rights and tolerance to prevent such atrocities from happening again. Parliament also reiterates its commitment to the prospect of accession of all the countries of the Western Balkans and recalls the role to be played by the Union as a community built, from the beginning of the process of European integration, on peace, solidarity and reconciliation between peoples. At a time when extremism is once again threatening our European society, it is vital to remember that tolerance must be defended every day and that the European Union is, and must remain, first and foremost an actor of peace both within and outside its borders.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 20 years have passed since the tragic event in Srebrenica, Bosnia, but the memory of it still freezes at heart and evokes a sense of shame for the failure of humanity on the European continent. More than 8 000 innocent victims died during the genocide in Srebrenica, which they deserve to be remembered with deep respect and act in such a way that something like this will never happen again. I therefore express my deep smours for the victims of this heinous act of barbarity and sympathy for the surviving families and loved ones. At the same time, I recall all the innocent lives lost in the Balkans during the armed conflict.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported and have co-signed the Parliament resolution condemning in the strongest possible terms the genocide in Srebrenica of 11 July 1995 saying that ‘such horrendous crimes must never happen again’. The Resolution commemorated and honoured all the victims of the massacre and ‘all the atrocities during the wars in the former Yugoslavia’ and expressed solidarity with victims’ families, many of which are still left without final confirmation of the fate of their relatives.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The genocide of 11 July 1995 in the Bosnian city of Srebrenica, declared at the time as a security zone by the United Nations, is still very much present in the memory of the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Emotional marks that still prevent the full reconciliation of different ethnic groups.  A genocide at the gates of Europe that must not be forgotten. A historical memory for the dangers of nationalism and intolerance in societies. I reiterate the Union's support in the accession process of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all the countries of the Western Balkans.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Parliament's motion for a resolution is intended to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the massacre of the Bosnian Muslim population, which formed a separate national group within the former communist Yugoslavia, from the Srebrenica region in the summer of 1995 during the War of Bosnia and Herzegovina.  Unlike the United Nations Security Council, this proposal puts the term "genocide" on these acts which are undoubtedly crimes committed against humanity, but which do not constitute a systematic eradication of an entire people in all these facets since "only" male men and teenagers of fighting age were shot when women , children and old people were evacuated: the very specific notion of genocide seems to me to be unsuitable here.  This resolution also reaffirms the Europeanist will and commitment to the accession process of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all Balkan countries. This race for integration into the Union, even though the peoples of the Member States seem particularly indisposed to new accessions, denotes the obvious cynicism of the Union, which finds in this commemoration a way to extend its power and territory a little more. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On July 11, 1995, in the Bosnian city of Srebrenica, declared a UN-protected area, the largest war crime in Europe since the end of World War II was perpetrated: 8,000 Muslim men and boys were barbarically massacred by Bosnian Serb troops in order to carry out a veritable ethnic cleansing. Not only that. About 30,000 women and children and the elderly were deported and a large number of women raped. This massacre, recognised as genocide by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, left deep wounds that affected the lives of the survivors and created lasting obstacles in the process of political reconciliation between ethnic groups in Bosnia-Herzegovina.  The European Parliament has a moral and political duty to commemorate and honour the victims of the Srebrenica massacre and to solemnly proclaim that never again such heinous crimes must be repeated. , and promote human rights and respect between religions, so as to lay a solid foundation for a better future for all citizens in the Balkan region.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this resolution that commemorates and honours all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and atrocities committed during the wars in the former Yugoslavia.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The events which took place 20 years ago on our very own continent marked that no matter the progress and prosperity some countries may enjoy, no matter how much we claim to ‘never again’ let such abominable crimes take place, we still run the risk of having such atrocities committed. The genocide was, I hope, a wake-up call for Europe, one that said history can repeat itself if we are not vigilant, if we do not spend more on peace and human rights and dignity. I voted in favour of this resolution and I think with great sympathy of all the victims’ families who are commemorating their sad losses this year.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Preventing genocide and other crimes against humanity and prosecuting those who have already happened must be a fundamental principle of the European Union's international policy of justice. In order to ensure that such heinous crimes do not happen again, every step must be made to increase people's awareness and tolerance.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Srebrenica massacre was recognised as genocide by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) and that the Bosnian Serb forces have committed multiple violations of the Geneva Convention against the civilian population, I hope that the political representatives of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be able to recognise the past in order to establish fruitful cooperation with a view to a better future for all citizens of the country. , hoping that such atrocities will not happen again.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. During the war, Srebrenica was a UN protected zone in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Despite being designated as an area "free from any armed conflicts or any other hostile acts", it was occupied by Republika Srpska Army forces led by war criminal Ratko Mladic on July 11th 1995. In the following days, over 8,000 Bosniak men and boys were systematically massacred in the largest atrocity to take place on the European continent since World War II.  For the first time, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the Srebrenica massacre and opposed any denial, relativisation or misinterpretation of events in Srebrenica. The resolution condemns genocide in Srebrenica in the strongest possible terms and states that "such horrific crimes must never happen again". A day earlier, the UN Security Council failed to do exactly the same thing because its member Russia vetoed a UN resolution that would also condemn the massacre as a "crime of genocide".  Since the EU is built on peaceful coexistence and co-operation between member states, I call on Serbia to face the truth and accept its responsibilities for the Srebrenica genocide and thus show that it respects European values.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This European Parliament's motion for a resolution is intended to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the massacre of the Bosnian Muslim population, which formed a separate national group within the former Communist Yugoslavia, from the Srebrenica region in the summer of 1995 during the Bosnia and Herzegovina war.  Unlike the United Nations Security Council, this proposal puts the term "genocide" on these acts which are undoubtedly crimes committed against humanity, but which do not constitute a systematic eradication of an entire people in all these facets since "only" male men and teenagers of fighting age were shot when women , children and old people were evacuated: the very specific notion of genocide seems to me to be unsuitable here.  This resolution also reaffirms the Europeanist will and commitment to the accession process of Bosnia and Herzegovina and all Balkan countries. This race for integration into the Union, even though the peoples of the Member States seem particularly indisposed to new accessions, denotes the obvious cynicism of the Union, which finds in this commemoration a way to extend its power and territory a little more. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 As the 11th July 2015 marks the 20th anniversary of the genocide and ethnic cleansing that took place in Srebrenica and around Srebrenica during the Bosnian war and that these crimes, committed by republika Srpska Army units under the command of General Ratko Mladic and the leadership of then Republika Srpska President Radovan Karadzic, are a new reminder of the dangers of extreme forms of nationalism and intolerance in society further exacerbated by the war. , I support the adoption of this resolution as a form of homage to the deceased, but also to their loved ones who have survived this terrible crime that we must not allow to be relativized or forgotten. Reconciliation can come through repentance and forgiveness and is crucial for the future of the region and good-minded relations for Bosnia and Herzegovina's EU European integration process. Political representatives in Bosnia and Herzegovina need to acknowledge the past to work together for a better future for all citizens in the country.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We remember these days the victims of the massacre in Srebrenica, Bosnia, because just 20 years have passed since this barbaric act. It is personally really sad for me that Russia has blocked a resolution on the Srebrenica genocide in the UN Security Council. On the other hand, I would like to appreciate the information that the Serbian Prime Minister will personally attend the tragic events, as evidenced by the efforts of the vast majority of people in the region to bring about reconciliation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Council was unanimous and consistent in classifying Srebrenica's events as genocide, of which 11 July 2015 marks the 20th anniversary. This act of ethnic cleansing took place during the Bosnian War. The crimes were perpetrated by the Army of the Republika Srpska, under the command of General Mladic and the President of the Republika Srpska, Radovan Karadzic. The victims were around eight thousand people, mostly Bosnian Muslims. This killing has left profound emotional consequences in the surviving society and persistent obstacles to reconciliation among the ethnic groups of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Srebrenica massacre was declared an act of genocide by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, occurred in a united nations-established refuge zone, and is a symbol of the impotence of the international community to intervene in a conflict and effectively protect innocent civilians. The EP adopted Resolutions on this massacre in 2005 and 2009. The EU is currently maintaining a Stabilisation Agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina, signed in 2008, which entered into force last month. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In a resolution, we commemorated in the European Parliament the senseless massacre of 8,000 men and boys in the Bosnian city of Srebrenica 20 years ago. These 1995 days were among the darkest moments in European history since the Second World War.  Even today, bereaved families are trying to find out what may have happened, but our only response to their deep pain is an admission of collective failure. The unspeakable happened. An unimaginable genocidal act that flouts not the existence of an ethnic group, but all humanity.  I would like to express my full support to the families who are remembering the tragedy that has affected them on this day. Today, the Balkans must move forward with Europe as an ally. The right path is democracy, but also recognition and reconciliation. Finally, it is our responsibility to constantly deconstruct the populisms and extremism on which the seeds of conflict are grafted.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the occasion of the twentieth anniversary of the brutal massacre of 8 000 men and boys in the Bosnian city of Srebrenica, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution precisely on the commemoration of this sad tragedy. What happened in Srebrenica was recognised as one of the worst war crimes in Europe since the Second World War, Martin Schulz declared it a 'collective failure' of Europe, a clear sign that the mistakes of the past are often too easily forgotten.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We remember and pay tribute to all the victims of the wars in the former Yugoslavia and express our condolences and solidarity to the victims and their families. However, I voted against this motion for a resolution in considering it partial because it refers only to the responsibility of one side to the tragedy, thus bypassing the responsibilities of other sides, such as war crimes committed by Naser Oric. The motion for a Resolution also omits any mention of the failures of United Nations interposition forces to prevent tragedy. In order to remember and honor victims, and to ensure that tragedies like this do not happen again, we consider it essential an impartial approach that captures the responsibilities of all actors.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament Resolution on Srebrenica. We must always remember the 8 000 innocent men and boys who were murdered in a brazen act that shocked the world.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 After 20 years since the massacre of Bosnian Serbs in Srebrenica, the wounds are not healed. Dialogue needs to be continued so that Bosnia and Herzegovina's political leaders can come to terms with the past, that perpetrators are punished in the process before the ICTY International Criminal Tribunal and that a clear perspective can be provided in the accession process for the Western Balkan countries. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. We cannot blindly pass the fact that 20 years ago, one of the greatest crimes against humanity occurred on European soil after world war II. It is necessary to pay tribute to the victims who lost their lives, and also to remember those who survived this atrocity but lost loved ones in this event. I strongly condemn the genocide that took place in Srebrenica and took the lives of many innocent people. At one point, he sow deep wounds and hatred in the country that citizens still face these days. It is necessary to condemn those responsible who have assisted in any way in the execution of genocide and the mass killing of innocent persons, thus enabling victims and their relatives to bring some kind of end to their suffering. I do not want hatred to escalate, but I believe that it is essential and our focus must be the erasure of nationalism. It is necessary to actively and enthusiastically support intercultural and inter-ethnic cooperation and education with a view to reducing ethnic segregation. Civil organisations and associations playing one of the key roles in raising awareness, education and establishing unity and cooperation among all BiH citizens are very important. I myself supported the resolution and voted in favour of its adoption in the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it important to commemorate such events so that they never happen again. The countries of the former Yugoslavia have since come a long way. Slovenia and Croatia are members of the EU, and now the other countries of the so-called Western Balkans need to be integrated.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this motion for a resolution because in July 1995 genocide was committed in the town of Srebrenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, after a United Nations Security Council resolution declared a protected zone and under the protection of UNPROFOR, genocide was committed after the city fell into the hands of the Serb army led by General Ratko Mladic. Some 30,000 women, children and the elderly were expelled during that period, while more than 8000 Muslim boys and men died in the bloodshed. Even today, many bodies have not been found, making this tragedy living and leaving traces in today's society.  The European Union aims to promote peace, which is why it is necessary to condemn crimes and pay tribute to victims and families. The main priority of the European Union and the international community is the prevention of genocide, but also their punishment, as well as the punishment of crimes against inhumanity. Regional co-operation and the European integration process should help overcome hatred and division in order for Bosnia and Herzegovina to have a European perspective.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution is one-sided, condemns the Serbs without referring at all to the crimes of the other parties and without mentioning the role of various European states in the civil war in Yugoslavia, in particular Germany. Also, the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia "paradoxically" has only convicted Serbs.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the proposal for a resolution commemorating the anniversary of the genocide in Srebrenica, commemorating innocent civilian casualties, also because, in addition to historical commemoration and mourning, I consider the message today on the threat of extreme nationalism and the responsibility of the EU as a community and of individual governments to be a particularly important element of the proposal for a resolution. As a Hungarian politician who knows the conditions of the region well, I cannot ignore the fact that there is still an EU government with its policies that incinerate hatred against other nations and minorities, incinerate its own population against immigrants and refugees with a poster campaign, colloquire with the far right in whipping up nationalist, xenophobe, Anti-Roma and other anti-minority sentiments. I trust that the lesson of Srebrenica, and today's resolution from the EP, will once again remind europe's responsible leaders, and in particular the Orban government, where politics can lead if politics plays with the fire of nationalist hatred.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 July 11, 2015 marks the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica massacre during the Bosnian War. The city, although a security zone protected by UN troops, was overrun by Bosnian Serb forces and paramilitary units, including Serbian irregular police units. More than 8,000 Muslim men and boys were murdered in the days-long carnage and nearly 30,000 women, children and the elderly were deported as part of a massive campaign of ethnic cleansing. At the heart of the process of European integration and the establishment of the European Union is the desire m.in never again allow wars and crimes in Europe, such as they did 20 years ago in the former Yugoslavia. I fully condemn the genocide in Srebrenica and therefore voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution of the five largest factions in the EP.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution of my colleagues on Srebrenica. With this text, we pay tribute to all the victims of the atrocities committed during the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia, while offering our condolences to the families of the victims and assuring them of our solidarity. Timely prevention and effective repression of genocide and crimes against humanity should be one of the European Union's top priorities.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on Srebrenica to commemorate and honour all the victims of the Srebrenica genocide and of all the atrocities during the wars in the former Yugoslavia. By this vote I also wanted to express my condolences to and solidarity with the families of the victims.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We remember and pay tribute to all the victims of the wars in the former Yugoslavia and express our condolences and solidarity to the victims and their families. However, I voted against this motion for a resolution in considering it partial because it refers only to the responsibility of one side to the tragedy, thus bypassing the responsibilities of other sides, such as war crimes committed by Naser Oric. The motion for a Resolution also omits any mention of the failures of United Nations interposition forces to prevent tragedy. In order to remember and honor victims, and to ensure that tragedies like this do not happen again, we consider it essential an impartial approach that captures the responsibilities of all actors.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We remember and pay tribute to all the victims of the wars in the former Yugoslavia and express our condolences and solidarity to the victims and their families. However, I voted against this motion for a resolution in considering it partial because it refers only to the responsibility of one side to the tragedy, thus bypassing the responsibilities of other sides, such as war crimes committed by Naser Oric. The motion for a Resolution also omits any mention of the failures of United Nations interposition forces to prevent tragedy. In order to remember and honor victims, and to ensure that tragedies like this do not happen again, we consider it essential an impartial approach that captures the responsibilities of all actors.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for a resolution on the Srebrenica genocide as it is extremely important, 20 years later, to remember the victims and express deep condolences to their families. Sadly, after all this time, victims’ families still face denial and political games including at the highest level at the UN Security Council.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which commemorates the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide, in which over 8 000 Muslim men and boys were slaughtered by Serbian armed forces led by General Ratko Mladić, and almost 30 000 women, children and elderly people were forcibly expelled in a massive-scale ethnic cleansing campaign. This tragic event represented one of the biggest atrocities committed after World War II, and it is important that 20 years later it is remembered in order to prevent such brutality from ever happening again. It is positive that the resolution stresses that the punishment of all crimes against humanity must be one of the EU’s top priorities.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to honour the memory of the victims and pay tribute to the fortitude of their families in seeking justice. This resolution highlights the necessity of future generations understanding the causes of such massacres and build societies based on trust, inclusivity and celebration of diversity.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The 11th of July 2015 marks the 20th Anniversary of the incidents that occurred in and around Srebrenica during the Bosnian war. We must always condemn the civil massacres of all parties to the conflict, be they from Serbia, Croatia or Muslims. We must use this date to recall the cynicism of the European Union and some of its members who have done everything to cynically and meticulously dismember Yugoslavia, then socialist. In a land where various cultures and ethnicities have lived together in peace for centuries, the West has decided once again to put its paw and arm one of the parties, setting fire to a conflict that would never have happened without the intervention of the usual friends of democracy. History will one day judge this dark page of European history and condemn its principal leaders.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the condemnation of the Srebrenica massacre 20 years ago must be remembered. The human rights crimes of that time must not be forgotten. However, I would also like to point out that the report refers only unilaterally to the Bosnian Serbs and excludes other ethnic groups.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is an ideological piece which, based on fractions of history, seeks to legitimize the events that led to the tragic event in question. However, it hides the responsibilities and unquestionable role that the US, NATO and the EU have played in the whole process of dismemberment of Yugoslavia, and in all the conflicts that have taken place in the Balkan region, fuelling and inciting hateful conflicts between populations, promoting, financing and imposing war, with a tragic civil dimension.   This is a regrettable historical bleaching text as it omits a human tragedy that goes well beyond the event it reports, and which has the imprint of the expansionist imperialist policies of the US, NATO and the EU.  For these reasons we voted against.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote. (The sitting was suspended at 2.45 p.m. and resumed at 3 p.m.)

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the Cambodian Draft Law on NGOs and Trade Unions (2015/2756(RSP)).

name: Ernest Maragall
text: Author. – Mr President, of course we defend and support this resolution. We do, I believe, also share with the other authors, and I hope that with all the Groups, a certain concern. Because we are already used to this: a certain repetition, a certain expression of concern or denunciation in the face of realities — facts which have already been considered and treated in this Parliament. In this case, the case of Cambodia, not a year and a half ago. More specifically, in January 2014. There seems to be an insalvable contradiction — we should consider it – between economic development, the production of prosperity and respect for human rights, the rule of law, the establishment of basic standards of social, labour regulation, etc. We are now concerned, in the case of Cambodia, with a triple legislative initiative by the Government of Cambodia which does not seem to respect at all our minimum criteria for what should be a process of participation, of social debate, precisely because it affects groups such as non-governmental organizations or trade unions, which are protagonists, which should be protagonists of these basic rights. And this happens at the same time as in the country, classic issues are repeated, in recent years, especially policies aimed, for example, at the eviction of small growers of large areas of land, usually owned by the State itself, to convert them into concessions and pre-industrial farms, etc. Or it coincides with the proliferation of small workshops, which are also protagonists of a more than dubious respect for human rights. Part of that reality, let's be clear, has to do with ourselves, with our stimuli, with our industrial demand, with our consumption habits. There is a connection between large sugarcane crops and our soft drink industry; there are among the workers of the garment workshops and our large commercial chains. That is why one might wonder whether, to this positive initiative of 'everything but arms', everything except weaponry, no other slogan should be added. All right: everything but weaponry but nothing without rights, "nothing without rights". I think it would be necessary and timely.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the basis on which we must start, when we talk about the situation in Cambodia, is that we are the main financier of all the development projects under way in Cambodia and we have often and willingly used Cambodian NGOs to take this type of development initiative forward. It therefore seems clear to me that the problem exists and it is a major problem, because if this law is passed which restricts trade union, organization and association freedoms very effectively, it undermines what is the main means at our disposal of creating development in Cambodia.  The resolution clearly aims to ensure that this law is not passed, because it would send the country 100 years back, and seeks to continue, through dialogue, to maintain development projects that will guarantee Cambodia a better future.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. Mr President, in Cambodia, the ruling party wants to restrict association life through a controversial law. The Cambodian People's Party, which has been calling the shots since 1979, wants to oblige all NGOs and trade unions to register and report extensively on their activities and on their finances. Prime Minister Hun Sen fears that NGOs and trade unions are being used as a cover for foreign powers to destabilise the regime. Civil society is, of course, not to be pleased with this initiative. It does not so much deny the need for legislation for the approximately 5 000 NGOs, but does not accept that the government has drafted the bill in secret and without a public debate and wants to chase a trot through parliament. Meanwhile, civil society is mobilizing en masse. The day before yesterday, hundreds of concerned citizens attended an information moment about the legal texts. They are, of course, afraid of a curtailment of democratic achievements. We call on the Government to review the two bills in consultation with civil society. We are pleased to be able to give them a heart thanks to this resolution.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Malmström for staying with us this afternoon. It is highly appreciated by all of us. I am very happy that we have such a strong and united position from Parliament – a strong position that basically says that where civil society flourishes, democracy flourishes, and where trade unions can work and can function properly, democracy flourishes. We have two very key messages for the Government of Cambodia. Please withdraw the law on associations and NGOs, as well as the law on trade unions. Also, please make sure that any future draft legislation in this area commits to internationally recognised fundamental freedoms and is only adopted through an inclusive process that includes dialogue with stakeholders, NGOs and civil society.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: Author. – Mr President, the European Parliament, which requires the Commission to sign aggressive trade treaties with developing countries, which facilitates the penetration of large multinationals into their economies, pretends to be surprised by their tragic consequences, which are nothing more than the expulsion of peasants from their lands and the exploitation of workers in exporting factories. We want to call on the Government of Cambodia: to ensure respect for the international labour organization's trade union and labour conventions, allowing workers to organize themselves in front of multinationals; also to curb and reverse the terrible hoarding of land by the large agro-transporters. But Europe's responsibility goes beyond recalling these fundamental principles: Europe must act to ensure that full recognition of labour rights and the right to land is included in its partnership and cooperation agreements, especially with the least developed countries. Only in this way can you avoid collaborating on the exploitation of workers that you are now denouncing.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: author. – Mr President, we are all worried that the vital role that Cambodian civil society plays – and there are around 5 000 NGOs registered – will be stifled by the proposed NGO law, which is restrictive and contradicts not only the Cambodian Constitution but also the international law commitments that the government is bound by. With our strong commitment to human rights, the EU is spending about EUR 410 million between 2014 and 2020. We call on Cambodia’s authorities not only to respect human rights but to appreciate the vital role for liberties that a flourishing civil society has and represents as an integral part of sustainable development and growth, and to appreciate that the two should go hand in hand. We urge the Cambodian Government to act accordingly and respect the freedoms and rights of association of civil society.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Cambodia is one of the most tested countries in the world.  The crimes of the Pol Pot regime, which claimed up to three million lives, still lie like a shadow over this country.  It has been a long, difficult road from the gloom of those years to more democracy, prosperity, and individual freedom. This has only been achieved in recent years. Civil society engagement is becoming increasingly important in this country.  The Hun Sen regime has also been shaken by this. It is therefore very regrettable that, right now, the space for NGOs and trade unions is being systematically restricted.  This is a phenomenon that we also know from other emerging countries. But it is precisely against the background of Cambodia that it is necessary to do everything possible to prevent the path of democratic reinvention of Cambodia from being interrupted at the very beginning.

name: Marc Tarabella
text: On behalf of the Group, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on 30 June, hundreds of activists, workers and trade unionists attempted to march through the streets of Phnom Penh to show their indignation at the new version of the bill on non-governmental organisations and associations, promulgated by the Cambodian government.  We can only join them, of course, and I, in turn, wish to express my anger at this bill which is totally contrary to freedom of expression. Beyond that, it is true that workers' rights are increasingly threatened. However, nine years ago, for the European Parliament, I led a mission to Cambodia to check, at the time, that Cambodia was making progress and continuing to make progress on the road to respect for human rights. As Mr Corrao mentioned earlier, we are Cambodia's largest donor, which is very interested in this relationship with the European Union, because we are giving it money for development policy, in particular. Is it not time to redistrict a mission to see if that country is continuing on the right track or not? Wouldn't it be time to weigh the fact that we are giving them help? Should we not go there to restore or at least help to get things back in the right direction?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am very happy for the debate I am listening to here. As a former Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic, I was responsible for the preparation of the new Civil Code, which governs association law, and It is clear to me that this is one of the key rights of every democratic rule of law. We should insist that Cambodia adopt a law that meets European parameters. This means that any association, civic association or, if you wish, an NGO, if it fulfils the basic legal conditions, can be created by mere registration and that the state cannot arbitrarily prevent such an organisation from being established and operating in Cambodia. It is very good that we are saying this here and that we are linking this to the financial assistance we provide to Cambodia. I believe that if Cambodia does not change its legislation, it should have an impact on the financial support of that country.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my worries regarding the draft laws enacted by the Cambodian Government, which will restrict freedom of association, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly and will violate the Constitution, shrinking significantly the space of civil society in Cambodia. The most urgent draft law on associations and non-governmental organisations will severely affect cooperation with grass-roots-level NGOs’ and also the bilateral cooperation of the European Union development cooperation and the European Union Member States’ development cooperation programmes.  I strongly believe that, since NGOs have made an important contribution to rehabilitation, reconstruction and development for the past 30 years in Cambodia, and since the EU is its largest partner in terms of development assistance, based on respect for the democratic principles and fundamental human rights established by the Universal Declaration on Human Rights, we need to support the call for the government to fully withdraw this law.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, after all that Cambodia has experienced, after the wars and tragedies that have been happening in Cambodia, we expected that country to progress. With these decisions, Cambodia is regressing, not advancing. Attempts to hijack the country, reduce or abolish trade union rights, all that seems to be NGOs, in terms of respect for freedoms, association and human rights, is something that clearly shows that Cambodia is backsizing. It is a country we have felt sympathy for and a country that we believe can work well with the European Union. And this is where the EU needs to set a clear principle – we must and have the right to ask that those values we share are respected and that Cambodia, if it wants to cooperate with us, must also respect the elementary values nurtured by the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is a triple attack, ladies and gentlemen, an attack on freedom and basic human rights, that of international organisations and trade union rights.  Hun Sen, cambodia's prime minister, is increasingly aiming for an authoritarian turn. This law, unfortunately, is the clearest proof of this, together with the famous cybercrime bill, the text of which is not yet known but which, along the same lines, will also affect freedom of expression online. We, as the main donor, can demand a great deal from Cambodia, but we must also demand a great deal from ourselves so that we can guarantee a coherent trade policy of ours and the behaviour of our multinationals that does not take over the lands of the Cambodians, while supporting authoritarian turns of this kind. The Covenant on Civil and Political Rights reminds us that freedom of expression, association and assembly are non-negotiable. We therefore call for strong and concrete action by the Commission to call on the Cambodian Government to withdraw immediately from this initiative.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, I am asking my fellow Members with love and really not as a provocation, and I very specifically hope that you have the interpreter on your ear – I do not see it – for the Commissioner. You can hear me, Commissioner, because I would like a specific answer from you. You can hear me, can't you? So I ask if the European Commission knows about Judit Szima's case. Judit Szima was the most important trade union leader in Hungary. He has now been sentenced to three years imprisonment in highly suspicious circumstances in connection with his trade union activities. He was the leader of the police union. He was met by the country when mass police brutality took place on the streets of Hungary in 2006, and he was the one who called on his comrades - in public - to refuse an unlawful order. Do we have to deal with Cambodia's trade union issues when something like this can happen today in Hungary, an EU Member State? I look forward to your specific answer.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think we are discussing Cambodia, so we can come back to the Hungarian situation some other time. As many of you have pointed out, Cambodia does indeed have a very vibrant civil society, and many NGOs and associations are active in various areas. The Cambodian Government has for many years argued that an overarching law on associations and NGOs was necessary to provide simple and transparent regulation to the sector. We in the European Union have been following this very closely since the idea of the legislation first surfaced many years ago. The draft laws have been a recurring topic in informal and formal meetings between the EU and the Cambodian Government. Our delegation and our ambassador there are very active and have frequent contact at different levels to make sure that our views on this are crystal clear and passed on to the government. We have made clear to them that the legislation that they are planning should enable, and not limit, freedom of association and expression in Cambodia. We have pointed out that a democratic process needs to be transparent and include meaningful consultation with all relevant stakeholders. A culture of dialogue is the basis of any democracy – dialogue with the opposition, civil society and the private sector. It is only through this dialogue that the government can take into account the needs and concerns of those who are subject to the legislation, and an inclusive process enables government to enact laws that are truly in the interest of the people. The National Assembly of Cambodia has a very important role to play here, so we welcome the decision by the National Assembly to organise consultations on the draft NGO law, and some of these have actually started to take place already. We hope that the results of this will be reflected in the text of the law. It is also important to have, as some of you do, peer-to-peer contacts between European Parliament Members and Members of the Cambodian National Assembly, in order to help them strengthen the capacity to scrutinise and to improve legislation in close contact with civil society and in a spirit of dialogue. We will continue to monitor the situation and developments, because in times when civil society and trade unions often face increasing obstacles and restrictions in many countries, Cambodia has an opportunity to prove that it is truly committed to strengthening its democratic credentials.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the Democratic Republic of congo, in particular on the two detained human rights activists Yves Makwambali and Fred Bama (2015/2757(RSP)).

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. Thank you, Commissioner, for being here with us. The European Parliament is indeed calling attention to the fate of Yves Makwambala and Fred Bauma. They are in prison in Kinshasa after being arrested as members of a youth organization demonstrating for more democracy and against the new electoral laws in Congo. The youth organisation Filimbi is trying to improve democracy in congo and is being beaten down hard. The EP calls for the immediate release of Yves Makwambala and Fred Bauma and a revocation of the charges against the activists in Kinshasa and in Goma, where they took to the streets in solidarity with their colleagues in Kinshasa. In addition, we call attention to the mass grave found in Kinshasa. In April, a number of anonymous remains were found, but according to the government in Kinshasa, not much is going on. Human Rights Watch has investigated this and believes that this could be a mass grave with bodies of activists that the government wants to get rid of. The European Parliament would like to have the bottom stone at the top and is asking the government in Kinshasa to investigate this closely and to be able to inform the relatives of missing persons about the fate of their loved ones. It is an election year in Congo and it could get incredibly out of hand. It's important that we keep our finger on the pulse. It would be terrible if the elections in Congo were to escalate further, because what we would like to see is a future for this country.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner, the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo is very similar to that in Burundi, which we have already talked about: activists who are imprisoned and those who oppose the government or the President's desire to renew his government mandate indefinitely end up disappearing or being imprisoned.  It is clear that we, with this resolution, are expressing our full support for the activists and we call on the Government of Kinshasa to release immediately the two boys who have been arrested.  I believe that, as far as the Democratic Republic of Congo is concerned, we must remind the government of the commitments it has made under the Cotonou Agreement and exert as much pressure as possible to ensure that this happens.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. Mr President, in the aftermath of the unrest in Burundi and the Central African Republic, the spirits are also stirring in congo. Large groups of young Congolese have the urge to include civil citizenship and play a role in improving life in the country. Three months ago, a simple citizens' initiative to raise awareness among young people was shut down by security services and 30 people disappeared behind bars. The foreigners have since been released, but the organisers – Yves Makwambala and Fred Bauma – are still in custody today on suspicion of treason. The Congolese government continues to grapple with an immense identity problem. On the one hand, the country has hugely talented young people, on the other hand their initiatives are colliding with a entrenched and corrupt government. Dr Mukwege's Panzi hospital, last year's laureate of the European Parliament's Sakharov Prize, faces a debt of more than half a million euros in back taxes. An unpaid invoice, totally surreal. Today's Congolese generation symbolizes the hope for change and peace. Unfortunately, popular initiatives to inform young people about their civil rights in the "Democratic" Republic of Congo can quickly cost freedom. Oh irony.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Parliament's joint resolution on the Democratic Republic of congo is an important political signal to the authorities in the country. That is why, like my colleagues, I call on them to release Fred Baema and Yves Makwambali, activists from Filimbi, a youth movement in Congo, as soon as possible. It is ironic that the Republic of Congo is referred to as Democratic, given that any manifestation of pluralism or opposition to the authorities has recently provoked a strong reaction from the governing parties. The arrest of the opposition, and in particular the activists of the youth movement, is not at the heart of the concept of democracy. As well as the restriction of freedom of expression and the right to assembly. The deaths of more than a dozen demonstrators in January this year show that the situation is really out of control for the authorities in Kinshasa, moving slowly towards what is happening in Burundi. More than a year remains until the Congo elections, so further European Union support for the electoral process in Congo will depend on the implementation of the recommendations of the monitoring mission and the improvement of the situation in the country.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, thank you for your French. Twenty-five years of dictatorship and then fifteen years of civil war exploited by neighbouring countries seeking to take control of wealth, especially mining; nearly 7 million people died according to Caritas. According to the United Nations, the illegal exploitation of gold, wood, ivory and minerals exceeds $1 billion in the east of the country alone. Most of the profits are captured by transnational criminals financing armed groups in the region.  In this bruised country, however, civil society has played an important role, especially since 2003. Some have paid with their lives, like Floribert Chebeya. A bloody crackdown took place during protests last January, sparked by Joseph Kabila's desire to change the electoral law to stay in power. The targets of the repression are first of all the activists of civil society, the youth movement, Filimbi, like many human rights defenders. Yves Makwambala and Fred Bauma are symbols of this, as evidenced by the call of 15 June for their release, supported by fifteen international NGOs and twenty Congolese organizations.  The European Union must weigh its weight in order to free them, but also, as the opposition demands, by participating in international mediation, which is essential for the restoration of a pluralistic and transparent political dialogue before the next elections.  I believe that the Congolese people are entitled to that.

name: Javier Nart
text: Author. – Thank you, Mr President, for addressing me in Spanish. Calling the Republic of Congo democracy is an oxymoron, a contradiction in terms. We are talking about a dynasty based on corruption and repression. What had to be said has already been said. I go directly to the substance of the matter. Europe can do two things: one, which is to practice democratic hypocrisy — that is, we make association agreements, Article 2, the democratic clause that we never apply; and two, implement the Cotonou Agreement, with Articles 8, 9 and 96, which have rarely been implemented. If the Democratic Republic of the Congo is not sent a clear and resounding message, what we are going to do is a resolution that will serve absolutely nothing and we all know it. I am very pleased that paragraph 13 is there, that I remind you and that I want you to be clear. Behaviour under the Cotonou Agreement, i.e. respect for human rights as a fundamental part of development, and, if not radically implemented, the procedure for Articles 9 and 96, is required. And if we do not apply it, let us not make resolutions, let us not calm our conscience and do not practice that, which I find disgusting, which is democratic hypocrisy.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Democratic Republic of Congo is a country full of instability. Human rights violations are commonplace, and the country is often preoccupied with us here in this House, most recently in May, when it came to the certification of conflict minerals, and a year ago when Doctor Mukwege was awarded the Sakharov Human Rights Prize. It was a very impressive celebration. He clarified these connections. He spoke to the public gallery, and the people from the emigration who live here cheered him. He said this country needed to change. That is precisely the situation we are in. The two human rights defenders are imprisoned, but not only them, but also many others. We call for their release, and we also call on the Commission to exert the necessary pressure and to use all its means to enable the country to have a peaceful future at the next elections in 2016.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the group, Mr. President, Fred Bauma and Yves Makwambala are two young Congolese citizens who are currently detained in Kinshasa, simply because they have met with other young Africans, other African movements, to advocate for citizenship, freedom and democracy. They are in Makala prison, after spending a few months in the dungeon of the national intelligence agency.  Their trial has just begun today. They are accused of trying to kill President Kabila simply for having met. What we are asking for here in Europe is of course their immediate release, the abandonment, by the Democratic Republic of Congo, of all the charges against them and against the Filimbi and Lucha movements, because these movements are essential in the current tense pre-election context. They must channel a form of citizenship for young people. If we do not want chaos in the Democratic Republic of Congo again, we must support democracy activists.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, a strong civil society is vital to any democratic process. In Congo, civil organisations have an exceptional role in filling the void of a state that fails to provide fully for its citizens. Peaceful and civic engagement should never be punished. Congo cannot silence the violence of its people or deny them the right to mobilise. The fact that recent violations have specifically targeted youth movements and the political opposition is additionally disturbing. As a first step towards reconciliation with its own people, Yves Makwambala, Fred Bauma and all Arab political prisoners must be released. The Congolese authorities should make use of the critical benefits brought by an active civil society. A dynamic civil society not only keeps the state in check but also brings the community the capacity to resolve common problems. It is time for the Congolese authorities to celebrate this as a virtue rather than attack it as a threat.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, we can all wonder if this is a prelude to an election campaign. Are Makwambala and Bauma new symbols of resistance in the Congo and are they the new victims of what we can expect until the Congo elections themselves.  Who's going to rob that country next? Who will continue to benefit from what is happening in the Congo in a completely undemocratic, uncivilized way? And we can also ask who perhaps in Europe can have an interest from such events in the Congo? And who in Europe can have an interest from the regime in the Congo?  I think we have to be honest among ourselves and open these issues because surely it is one thing: Europe has its own interests in the Congo, and if we have them, then let's try to put this friendly country in some way in order.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Yves Makwambala, Fred Bauma: the struggle of young Congolese must also be ours, otherwise, ladies and gentlemen – I am sorry – it makes no sense to award prizes such as the Sakharov prize to Mukwege in this House and then forget about it. It is the 20th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide and there are still violent conflicts in many sub-Saharan states, and I am also thinking of potential conflicts such as Burundi. The two activists were arrested simply because they wanted to exercise freedom of expression, freedom of expression. 425 bodies are found in a mass grave in Fula Fula and are probably other young men, other political opponents.  We must ensure, as Mr Nart said earlier, that the Cotonou Agreements and all other international commitments do not remain a dead letter. Otherwise we take turns on our own.  I want Fred Bauma's words to be heard in this House when he said, precisely, that "We will never accept that the train of freedom, of democracy, already on the road in our country, should be blocked by someone. We have committed ourselves as young citizens to the advent of democracy in our country and nothing can stop us even, arbitrary arrests". We don't have to stop either. Ne laissons pas mourir les aspirations démocratiques de la jeunesse congolaise.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, the plenary session has just found that one of our fellow Members, who belongs to the Socialist Group, was mistakenly classified as the People's Party by the president-in-office. They have joked about this, and it may be, because everyone knows that there is no significant difference, because they go hand in hand in maintaining the status quo on the really important issues. This is also the case in the fact that both of them believe that the human rights situation in Congo must be dealt with here, and that, for example, in Hungary– right – when there were mass police brutalities and otherwise arbitrary arrests in 2006, this was done by their socialist comrades. Now the police and prosecutors under the People's Party should carry out the impeachment, but it absolutely does not do so, protecting the violations of their socialist colleagues and comrades. So much for the difference between the two major factions.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is indeed a very important debate, and let me assure you that we have heard the very clear message here and we will, of course, convey it to the High Representative as well. We feel that we have strong support from this plenary to continue to pay close attention to the cases of Mr Bauma and Mr Makwambala and also the other people involved. As you know – and some Members mentioned – this year 30 people were arrested at the Filimbi workshop event in Kinshasa, the youth platform to encourage young people to get involved in civic life in a peaceful and responsible way. Most of those arrested were released or deported but two participants were detained further – the two people we are talking about here today. They were held by the National Intelligence Agency for more than 40 days without charge and without access to legal assistance. Later they were transferred to the Public Prosecutor’s Office and charged with several offences. The very little information that we have has led many to conclude that the charges are disproportionate and unsubstantiated, and there is an obvious risk in this context that the charges are politically motivated. We regret that a solution can still not be found to release those activists. A parliamentary investigation found no evidence to indicate that either the leaders or the participants at the Filimbi workshop were involved in planning terrorist or violent crimes, yet the Communication Minister of the Democratic Republic of Congo said that the Filimbi leaders were planning ʽterrorist activitiesʼ and ʽviolent insurrectionʼ – and I quote him. There is no evidence backing this, so these statements are of course without substance. Naturally we will continue to follow these cases extremely closely. Two démarches have been made to the Minister of Justice and EU Member States have been observing court hearings. Both EU Member States and our EU delegation have regular contact with human rights organisations and lawyers on the cases and you can count on our continued attention. More broadly, many of you have called for human rights to be at the centre of our dialogue with the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). It is a country with a remarkable plurality of parties, views and aspirations, and it is vital – this year more than ever – that all political and civil actors feel free to speak their minds and to submit themselves to the public through debate and discussion. Respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms are essential elements in the Cotonou Agreement. These issues are also critical for the electoral cycle between now and the end of next year. The EU wants to support that process, but we need to have the right conditions to be in place in terms of budget, calendar and political climate. In both the local statements and Council conclusions the EU has expressed concerns in the narrowing of the political space, particularly since the events accompanying the revision of the electoral law at the end of January earlier this year. We have underlined the risk of any perception that justice could be instrumentalised or serve political events. We are concerned by arbitrary detentions and arrests, especially those involving intelligence services, and by unnecessary use of force, physical threats and intimidation of journalists. Where members of the security services have carried out illegal actions, the Congolese authorities should take urgent action to investigate and prosecute cases. In our responses we have drawn on the African Charter on Democracy, Elections and Governance, which stresses the importance of a political climate free of tension, allowing for an open debate, protecting freedom of expression and the right of the opposition to ensure the independence and impartiality of justice. The EU stands ready to support the DRC in a genuine partnership. The launching of a national indicative programme of EUR 620 million stands as proof of that commitment. However, we will continue to speak up and engage where we have concerns, in this case and in many others.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate. Written declarations (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. – On 15 March 2015 Congo’s national intelligence agency arrested 30 pro-democracy activists in Kinshasa while they were attending a workshop for Filimbi, a movement to promote mobilisation in politics. Yves Makwambala and Fred Bauma were among these people. Over the following weeks, mass arrests continued in Kinshasa and Goma, where people were tortured because they were peacefully protesting the arrest of the activists. Those arrested are still detained and they do not have access to legal assistance. In the light of the provisions of the African Charter, which Congo ratified, I shall remind the Congolese authorities of their obligations to guarantee fundamental rights such as the freedom of expression and assembly, and access to justice. Freedom of expression is the vital element for a healthy society and for any individual. Human Rights are universal and inalienable; therefore they should be applied in Congo too! I condemn the extreme form of violence held against the human rights defenders and demand their immediate release. Following the Cotonou Agreement, I reaffirm that it is impunity which contributes to the preservation of cycles of violence and the cause of human rights violations. The perpetrators of violence against activists and journalists should be brought to justice!

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – It is symbolic that we are now showing an interest in human rights in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in Brussels. I don't think I'm going to offend anyone by recalling some historical facts. According to the British Encyclopedia, congo had 20 million inhabitants in 1885, when the King of Belgium acquired them as a colony. In a quarter of a century, its population has fallen to 8 million. I recall this fact because Belgium, as a constitutional monarchy, already had a model constitution containing a noble declaration of human rights. How many years did it take for the ideals of human rights to begin to apply to this colony? Two world wars took place before the Republic of Congo gained independence in 1960. Even today, many Africans, especially in the former Belgian Congo, will look with disregard at European recommendations on human rights. But I don't think we can be discouraged. We just need to act more by our own example, less by coercion and mentoring. We must honor the traditions there and commemorate the greatness of people like Patrice Lumumba. And we must also get rid of the illusion that modern civil society can be built on the basis of poverty and illiteracy. We must help in these spheres if we do not want to pave the way for power for some new Mobutu instead of improving democracy. Human rights cannot be ordered in developing countries by adjusting internal laws or forced by Western armies.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, the two activists we are talking about today represent many similar fates of people who are fighting for human rights everywhere. It is our duty to stand up for these people. Only with their help will we achieve, for example, that free elections will be preceded by a free exchange of views in a free press or the realisation of the right of assembly. Only such elections can be considered free. I therefore request the release of all persons detained in the Democratic Republic of congo for political reasons only.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Bahrain, in particular the Nabil Rajab case (2015/2758(RSP)).

name: Alyn Smith
text: author. – Mr President, Bahrain is a clear ally of the European Union and an important partner in the region, and it could be a good news story for human rights within the Middle East. There has been progress: there is ongoing dialogue, and it is important that we recognise that there are allies for progress, human rights and reforms within the Bahraini authorities. Indeed I suspect that, left to their own devices, they would come up with a considerably better solution than we see from the continuing outside interference – notably from Saudi Arabia and Iran – within their internal affairs. But where we recognise the progress being made within Bahrain, it is also important that we recognise failures and shortcomings. Nabeel Rajab’s case is emblematic, but that is the point – it is emblematic of many more cases of repression and abuse of human rights. We call for all charges to be dropped. But in the time that is available, I will address my remarks to colleagues from the EPP and the ECR colleagues. It is a matter of great regret that you did not feel fit to support this joint motion for a resolution, which is balanced and fair. I would say that this House is only so credible, and we are even less credible in the eyes of our interlocutors when we do not speak with one voice. I would urge you to support the joint motion for resolution. Human Rights Watch has already been in touch with you, and they say it better than I can: ‘a weak, divided reaction to one of the worst crackdowns on human rights defenders, political activists, journalists and religious leaders, who are threatened, persecuted and tortured simply for having peacefully exercised their freedom of expression and assembly, would be unworthy of the reputation of a major human rights watchdog built by the Parliament over the years’. I would urge you to support this balanced and fair resolution, so that we can make some progress with our friends in Bahrain.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many bahraini men who have joined terrorism and ISIS come from security institutions and these institutions were their first ideological incubator. This is Nabeel Rajad's tweet for which he was imprisoned in January.  We know very well that in 2011 Bahrain was one of those countries from which the so-called Arab Spring was born, from which those movements that sought to bring freedom of expression, freedom of expression and the freedom to oppose those who are real regimes were born. Colleagues, let's face it. It is no coincidence that the ECR and the PPE do not support this resolution. There is a very complicit silence on the part of some countries of the European Union, primarily the United Kingdom, which has quite advantageous trade agreements with Bahrain and has no intention of creating enmity and problems.  It is very sad to see that colleagues in this House, who are very crowded at the moment, are doing the same. I therefore hope that they will change their minds and support the resolution, as Mr Smith said.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. Mr President, in 2011, Bahrain had a month of massive popular protests for greater freedom and democracy. One in four Bahrainis then took to the streets. Nine-three people were killed in a brutal police crackdown. Thousands of protesters were arrested. In response to the international outcry, the king decided to set up an international commission of inquiry. At first, it seemed that the government was prepared to put the recommendations of the committee of inquiry into practice. But it soon became apparent that human rights activists and journalists were being severely abused in prison. Nabeel Rajab, the president of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights, also disappeared behind bars several times. His crime? He criticized a violent incident in prison. In the meantime, we continue to see disturbing stories that show that freedom of expression is an empty concept. Arbitrary arrests of activists are rife. There is still torture in Bahrain! I think we agree on the merits of the case. The people only want freedom, openness and democracy. And we must help them, first and foremost to implement their own recommendations of 2011.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: Author. Mr President, Nabil Rajab, a human rights defender in Bahrain, is in prison for tweeting. He was therefore punished for exercising his freedom of expression. This is the heart of the problem and it is what justifies adopting an emergency resolution to call for Mr Rajab's immediate and unconditional release. The EPP Group is now proposing a balanced resolution and, above all, centred on this particular case. I would like to remind you here that the purpose of our emergency resolutions is to take concrete action and to seek the release of the arbitrarily imprisoned human rights activists, in this case Nabil Rajab. These resolutions must not be transformed into a geopolitical analysis of the countries of the Arabian Peninsula.  The central issue is not anti-terrorism laws or arms exports, as is unfortunately the case in the resolutions proposed by some groups. That is why the EPP Group, on whose behalf I am speaking today, has refused to co-signed this joint resolution, because it is completely removed from the original mandate, which is to discuss the very serious case of Nabil Rajab, who has already been imprisoned several times since he established the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights. I therefore call on colleagues to vote in favour of the EPP Group resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, Nabil Rajab is indeed the President of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights and the Deputy Secretary-General of FIDH, an organisation to which I have belonged for more than thirty years.  Detained for the fifth time in less than three years, he has spent twenty-eight of the last thirty-six months in prison. Since the 2011 uprising, in which nearly 300,000 people are reported to have taken to the streets in this small country of just over a million people, repression has been severe. Moreover, let us not forget that it was the armed intervention of Saudi Arabia that allowed the Al Khalifa dynasty to remain in power.  Shiite and Sunni political opponents, as evidenced by the arrests of Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the moderate Shiite opposition, that of Ibrahim Sharif, leader of the Sunni opposition, journalists, human rights activists, trade unionists who denounce the exploitation of migrant workers and women bear the brunt. Attempts at national dialogue fail one after the other. The regime's hard factions seem to have regained control. The deterioration of the human rights situation is clear.  Bahrainis bear the brunt of the clash between general powers and the instrumentalization of them. The United States has just announced the resumption of its military aid, which was suspended in 2011, not to mention arms deliveries from some Member States. This situation must therefore be strongly denounced in order to support all NGOs, without concession.  Finally, I would like the EPP Group to have the same spirit when it comes to looking at all countries. It seems that there are countries where there is political analysis and others in which we focus on human rights. That is not my way of looking at it. I regret this attitude of the EPP group.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: Author. – Mr President, almost a year ago, on 24 September 2014, Nabil Rajab visited the Subcommittee on Human Rights of this Parliament and told us about the situation in Bahrain. That day Rajab confided two very specific tasks to us. The first: that we would never fail to highlight the human rights violations that are taking place in countries like Bahrain; the second is that we showed the Kingdom of Bahrain that Europe was not going to reach out to it as long as the human rights and fundamental rights of its citizens were violated. Seven days later, when Rajab landed in Bahrain, he was arrested, once again, on charges of publicly insulting official state institutions and, this time, sentenced to ten years in prison. I have a bittersweet taste today, President. This resolution that we adopt today shows how our commitment to human rights, wherever they are violated, is clear, but to this day we have not been able to accomplish the second task and we continue to reach out to countries like Bahrain, which has 4,000 political prisoners with a population of just over one million. Rajab told us, "I'm going to continue my fight for democracy." Today, from my seat and from the Liberal Group, I say, "You're right, I'll fight."

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very pleased that we are finally discussing Bahrain today. At last! We have often tried to do this because human rights are indivisible. They apply to Russia, to China, to Africa, also to us, also to allies or so-called allies. We must be concerned about the situation in Bahrain.  One is the case of Nabil Radschab, who spoke to us here in Parliament in the Committee on Human Rights, was subsequently imprisoned and has been imprisoned ever since – like many others, such as hundreds of activists, such as the opposition leader Sheikh Ali Salman, who has been in prison for four years without trial. We cannot accept this, not only because human rights are universal, but also because it is also about stability in a very unstable region. We have to see these connections, we have to show them. I am afraid that if the situation continues in this way, it will be like a pressure cooker. The longer it is heated, the faster it will explode at some point. It is therefore important to look now at respect for human rights in Bahrain.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Nabeel Rajab, President of the Bahrain Human Rights Centre, was sentenced to six months in prison for Twitter postings. It seems incredible. but Nabeel is in jail! On Twitter he wrote "many citizens of Bahrain who joined the terrorist group Isis come from Bahrain's security institutions, and these institutions have played the role of an ideological incubator." So he expressed his opinion on Twitter. Freedom of expression is a foundation of the sovereignty and freedom of any people and individuals. Very briefly: I demand the immediate release of Nabeel Rajab! Let us consider whether perhaps it would not be appropriate to suspend the export of arms to Bahrain until human rights are respected, at least at a decent level, in this country.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the Government of Bahrain continues to use repressive methods to silence all those who fight for fundamental rights and freedoms for the majority of the people. It is intolerable that Nabeel Rajab is arrested for a twit, right after he visited us here in the European Parliament, as well as the arrest, continued imprisonment, of personalities such as Mr Ebrahim Sharif or the Danish-French citizen Abdulhadi al-Khawaja. This in a country that claims to be making reforms to improve human rights.  It is also unacceptable for the Bahraini government to be engaged in a process of national reconciliation when it has arrested the leader of Al-Wefaq, the main opposition party Sheikh Ali Salman, sentenced to four years. The European Union must do much more, and more audibly, for human rights in Bahrain, demanding an end to repression, including the abominable use of the withdrawal of nationality from oppositionists. Silence makes accomplices of the European Union, its Member States and ePP members, and whatever the justification, today they did not vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner and colleagues, human rights defender Nabil Rajab is in prison and in fact was arrested right after we, as Members of the European Parliament, met with him in Brussels. The general human rights situation in Bahrain remains dire. Thousands are in arbitrary arrest, citizenships are taken away from people and the tensions have been going on for years, and that has been bad; it is bad enough as it is. The EU and this House have been taking a lead role in addressing the tensions in Bahrain, not letting it be swept under other problems in the Middle East, and I think we have to continue, especially as the US has resumed military aid. But even so, the State Department has condemned the human rights violations in Bahrain, and now I want to ask: are we really in a situation where the European People’s Party is not going to participate in a joint motion for resolution addressing the human rights violations in Bahrain today?

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is important to place the case of Nabil Rajab in its true context: the political repression that followed the events of 2011 under the leadership of Saudi Arabia, with the acescence of the United States. In the Gulf States geopolitical reason imposes iron stability and the result is precisely the repression of political opposition, social rights and civic freedoms, workers and activists fighting for a democratic Bahrain.
