Europe must ensure recognition of international human rights conventions in Bahrain and also international labour standards, from which migrant workers cannot be excluded. Because it is only with the recognition of fundamental rights that the stability of the Gulf can be guaranteed in the medium term.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it is quite clear that the events in Bahrain have been – and continue to be – disturbing, creating a climate of fear: fear of prosecution and fear of violence – and some fear for their lives. Yet the European Union is doing nothing to stop these events but is in fact funding and supporting their continuation. Over the past years the people of Bahrain have been calling out for fair democracy, a fair voting system and free speech – many people, including this individual that we are talking about today. He, like others, has faced imprisonment, loss of citizenship and police brutality. The EU should not be supporting these acts but, regretfully, it does, via the Member States’ trade policies. Last year the European Union Member States – not just the United Kingdom – was involved with over EUR 2.6 billion worth of trade with Bahrain, despite the mass mistreatment of the people and the complete avoidance of recognisable democratic progress. These trade figures are bad enough but, if you look further, there is an additional EUR 15 million alone worth of arms and ammunition sales. Collectively the European Union stands upon its moral high horse, as usual, on one hand, whilst perversely facilitating the climate of fear to continue. We may well grandstand, condemning the actions and events happening in this country, but it is the European Union that is effectively supporting those horrible acts and this prosecution case. (The Speaker refused to take a blue card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – In Uachtaráin, agus muid ag caint faoi Nabeel Rajab caithfear a rá ar dtús gur duine mór le rá é. I know ina uachtarán ar Ionad Bhairéin do Chearta an Duine agus ina Leas-Ard-Rúnaí ar an gCumann Idirnáisiúnta um Chearta an Duine.  Dar ndóigh, tá sé i bpríosún toisc gur scríobh sé tweets faoi ISIS agus faoi fhórsaí slándála Bhairéin. Ní coir mór é sin agus ní ceart go mbeadh sé i bpríosún. Tá a fhios againn go léir nach bhfuil and tweets ach comhrá scríofa sóisialta. Dá bhrí sin caithfimid gach brú is féidir linn a chur ar fórsaí agus údaráis Bhairéin é a ligean saor chomh luath agus is féidir, mar tá amhras ann nach bhfuil sé ag fáil, nó nó nach bhfaighidh sé cothrom na Féinne.  Freisin, ba chóir dúinn grúpa oibre a bhunú idir an Bhairéin agus an tAontas chun féachaint ar chúrsaí chearta an duine, agus go háirithe saoirse an phreasa nach bhfuil ann and mBairéin ach oiread.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is a pleasure to have a president as polyglot as you are. The truth is that we always have a responsibility to all human rights defenders, but with those who have had the courage to come and visit us, as is the case of Nabil Rajab, who very few months ago was with us, telling the situation of his country and clearly jeopardizing his safety when he came to see us, we have a double obligation. Upon returning from Brussels, Rajab was arrested again and is in prison. It is distressing, regrettable, that we will be able to invite a human rights defender into our house, then go to his country, imprison him, and we do not move a finger to change our relations with a country that behaves in this way.  I believe that these are the things that cause us to lose credibility and to call into question our true commitment to human rights. It is time to send a clear message to Bahrain, and I tell the People's Group, because Nabil Rajab is in prison because he lives in Bahrain; otherwise I'd be free. So of course the request for release is accompanied by a conviction to Bahrain's regime.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, colleagues, Nabeel Rajab’s case is an emblematic example of the overall situation of human rights defenders in Bahrain. I am seriously concerned that people are being arbitrarily detained, tortured and stripped of their citizenship, merely for their work related to defending human rights in the country. The public sphere – both online and offline – cannot be subject to prior authorisation. It is a forum where citizens should be entitled to enjoy the rights of association, assembly and freedom of speech. Thus I hope that this resolution, following on from the previous pledges of such institutions as the UN, will give a strong push to the Bahraini authorities to commit themselves to undertaking necessary reforms. I believe that the Bahraini authorities, instead of suppressing civil society and political opposition, should engage in a genuine partnership so that, through their combined efforts, they will be able to tackle political crises without sliding into violent confrontations and political unrest.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Nabeel Rajab, once again imprisoned and, moreover, shortly after visiting the Subcommittee on Human Rights in this European Parliament. This imprisonment offends the dignity of this Parliament and offends those European values that we represent and protect. We cannot remain silent, by addressing this subject and this urgency, the very serious situation in bahrain as a whole: the fact that 70% of Shiite inhabitants are in fact excluded from the management and institutions of power; the fact that the royal house has centralized power by preventing the normal exercise of institutional freedoms. We cannot allow this state, the only state in the Gulf where there have been forms of protest, to become yet another battleground between Iran and Saudi Arabia.  I say, ladies and gentlemen, that the principle of conditionality for the European Union must be a categorical imperative and not an optional one. Our partners must respect this, otherwise they are no longer our partners and all the groups in this Parliament must also say so and should vote for this resolution.  Nabeel must be released and visit us here in Strasbourg. Nabeel free, Bahrain democratic!

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Bahrain, where it is becoming increasingly difficult to fight for human rights, is of particular concern. According to a report by the Observatory for the Protection of Human Rights, at least 97 people have died since 2011 as a result of torture and ill-treatment during their detention. The same report points out that as many as 10 human rights defenders in Bahrain have been spoiled, tried and detained without due cause in the last 4 years. This is the case, among others, with Nabeel Rajab, president of bahrain's Human Rights Centre, who has been imprisoned almost continuously since 2012 on a number of unfounded charges, such as accusing a public institution of criticizing in a tweet the aggregation of members of the Bahraini Security Forces to ISIS. Rajab, despite the legal persecution, has continued to denounce and today risks another ten years in prison for writing an article in which he pointed out the continuing violence suffered by the more than 2000 prisoners in Jaw, Bahrain's toughest prison. Rajab's case is just the most striking case: many other people are fighting for justice and being treated as criminals by a government that does not respect human rights.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there are clear links between the sporting, business and defence interests of certain governments – such as my own – and the lack of strong action to condemn human rights abuses in Bahrain and elsewhere. So we find ourselves here as people who can speak – and we must speak – not only to expose the human rights abuses themselves, but also to expose the hypocrisy of governments, political groups, the defence industry and sporting organisations whose own interests seem to ride roughshod over those who might be imprisoned or tortured for speaking out. The Bahraini Government would do well to listen to us, because the more they crack down on the freedom of speech, the more we will speak up about what they are doing. They risk Nabeel Rajab becoming a cause célèbre, because there is a move afoot to put his name forward for the Sakharov Prize. So I would urge the Bahraini authorities to listen to the voices from this House today and to do the right thing.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Ladies and Gentlemen, the External Action Service and the European Union are engaged with local and national authorities at all levels to try to have wider contact with different stakeholders and activists in Bahrain. We will, of course, continue to support stability and development, but this can only be done if there is a process of national reconciliation, without preconditions, leading to gradual political and socio-economic reforms based on compromise by all political actors. We are also following the cases of a number of peaceful activists, including Mr Nabeel Rajab, but also Mr al—Khawaja, a Danish—Bahraini citizen who has also been in prison for a long time. The External Action Service and Member States are following those cases and are trying to be present at all court cases. We have consistently said, over the past four years, that a lasting reconciliation process must include a combination of modernisation and confidence-building steps – including the release of all those arrested in the context of peaceful political activities – in order to overcome the polarisation in Bahraini society. We had a visit in May, for the second time this year, by the EU representative for fundamental rights, the special representative – whom many of you know very well as he is a former MEP – Mr Stavros Lamprinidis. He passed this message very clearly to his interlocutors. He was able to meet with some activists in detention, as well as with the families of some of the detainees. We also believe that opposition parties are fundamental to any democracy. We have publicly voiced our dismay, on 17 June, at the sentencing of Ali Salman, the Secretary-General of al-Wefaq, to four years in jail. Such moves run counter to the efforts promoting a lasting and inclusive national reconciliation, and we hope that the sentences can be reconsidered in appeal. Many steps taken by the Bahraini authorities to implement the recommendations of the Bahraini independent commissions of inquiry are positive, as some of you have also mentioned, and have the potential to improve the human rights situation in the country. The Minister of the Interior’s Ombudsman, the Prisoners’ and Detainees’ Rights Commission and the National Institution for Human Rights have an important and very proactive role to play in this regard, fulfilling their mandate in full independence. The bold recommendations issued by these institutions must now be fully implemented and produce concrete results, in order to win the confidence of the public. So I want to encourage you to maintain contact with the recently-elected parliamentary bodies in Bahrain, and we appreciate the strong interest that the European Parliament is taking in this regard.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the situation of two Christian pastors in Sudan (2015/2766(RSP)).

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: Author. – I have been following the case of two Christian pastors in Sudan from the very beginning and I am very glad that sufficient support has been found to talk about it here in the European Parliament. As is already known, the pastor of Sudan's Presbyterian Church, Michael Yat, was detained by secret service members immediately after the service, during which he allegedly condemned the controversial sale of church land as well as the cruel treatment of Christians in Sudan. After Pastor Peter Yein Reith became interested in the circumstances of pastor Michael's imprisonment, he found himself imprisoned for no reason. Subsequently, several charges were brought against both pastors, some of which face the death penalty. The next hearing date is five days from now, and I firmly believe that, thanks to international pressure from the European Parliament, the African Union or the UN, the Sudanese authorities will drop the charges against the pastors in question, and not just against them. Just two weeks ago, 12 girls were arrested while leaving a Baptist church. They have been accused of wearing inappropriate clothing and face incredible punishment by flogging. Many people are pausing over why the European Parliament is dealing with cases of individuals who are being persecuted, imprisoned in countries outside the Union. However, past experience shows that this makes sense. Just like this a year ago, with a happy ending, we called for freedom for Meriam Ibrahim. That happy ending is proof that, through international cooperation and joint pressure, we can influence the development of events in a country such as Sudan.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: Author. – Thank you very much, Mr President, for addressing me in Spanish, a language which I very much love. When I have a moment I will teach you to say it in Catalan and so, when language freedom comes to this House, you and I will be able to use it. I welcome this statement and the unanimity achieved. Arrests, trial and accusations against Presbyterian pastors Michael Yat and Peter Yen Reith in Sudan are further a sign of the Sudanese government's drift towards totalitarianism. Arbitrary accusations which, as the previous speaker has said, may end up in the application of the death penalty. The European Union cannot remain impassive in the face of these facts. It must clearly condemn religious persecution in Sudan and must also condemn the existence of the death penalty in Sudanese law. And I say this because some Members of this House still believe that the death penalty can solve something. South Sudan's independence has further intensified the radicalization of the Sudanese regime and the violation of human rights. We must give a clear message of support to Pastors Yat and Yen Reith. Let them feel they're not alone. That the European Union is at your side. He believes in the values of religious freedom and is not going to turn his back on them. But, as other Members have said, these statements, without political pressure and without economic pressure, have little value.

name: Jaromír Štětina
text: Author. – Mr President, I am glad that we have managed to find a consensus with the other political factions, and today we are presenting a common strong text that reflects our position and our determination to assist pastors Michael Yat and Peter Yen Reith, who face the death penalty in the event of convictions because of their Christian faith. Thank you for the initiative on this text to Mr Tőkés. In the 1990s, during the struggle of South Sudanese Christians against the Khartoum regime, I visited South Sudan several times. It was during the famine, at a time when the Christian Dina tribe was fighting for independence, at a time when Khartoum was using Soviet tanks and armored personnel transporters in the Civil War, at a time when Arab invaders were taking black Christians into slavery in large numbers and selling them to other Arab states. Even the resistance of the international public has not made the Khartoum regime not violate human rights. The case of two pastors is just the tip of the iceberg. Let's help save Michael and Peter's life.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, our resolution is essentially centred on the case of two Christian pastors. I regret this, because it could have been an opportunity to reaffirm our overall condemnation of the regime after the elections last April.  Never in this country has the opposition been so united. We are a number of us who saw this at the conference held here on 9 June, in which some of the signatories of Sudan's appeal were prevented from participating, including Amin Mekki Medani, President of the Confederation of Sudanese Civil Society Organizations, which was at the centre of the resolution we adopted last December. and Mr. Farouk Abu Isa, President of the National Council Forces.  Since these rigged elections, in which Mr. al-Bashir won more than 94% of the vote, that is to say, repression is increasing. The risk of death sentences for Michael Yat and Peter Yen Reith is just one sad example. The Sudanese authorities must respect the freedom of thought, conscience and religion, regardless of the religion concerned, the freedom to believe or not to believe, but also the freedom to express themselves freely in all areas. On Monday, two opposition leaders were sentenced to 20 lashes, a sentence immediately carried out in court. A humiliation, an unprecedented verdict since the 1989 coup. A new provocation from the regime. Omar al-Bashir, under an arrest warrant from the International Criminal Court, has even made a new nose to the international community by attending an African Union summit in South Africa. Military forces continue to bomb civilians, humanitarian aid is blocked. The situation of women, regardless of their religion, is catastrophic.  It is therefore the overall human rights situation that must be denounced. I regret once again that the European Union has embarked on a process of negotiations with such a regime within the framework of migration policies. The European Union has nothing to expect from this. Omar al-Bashir will find just an international recognition after which he runs and which he knows very well how to use.  We must denounce globally the violations of human rights in Sudan, as elsewhere, and draw the political consequences.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: Developer. " Mr. President, free thinking the people of Sudan rightly expect our support. Two pastors who have been wrongfully imprisoned rightly expect our support. And we really need to act concretely. Because today's Sudan is a country where not only people are imprisoned, which is of course the worst, but symbols are further destroyed.  Churches are being destroyed, no new churches are allowed to be built. The human spirit is being destroyed. The right to religion is being destroyed. The right to believe in your faith.  And as a man who has always and everywhere fought for freedom to religion, whatever faith someone may be, I condemn in the strongest possible terms what happened in Sudan and I want to believe that we are capable enough and strong enough to help pastors get out of prison.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the case of two Christian pastors who are now being persecution in Sudan is not the only one. Unfortunately, over the past five years, there have been dozens of these cases of persecuted Christians, specifically in Sudan. Hundreds of people have left their homes since the civil war, and there is a real need to stand up for Christians in Sudan. It cannot be tolerated that a minority, which is now only 3%, does not have rights and cannot normally profess their faith in a free country. I therefore call for the Commission to go beyond inaction and really start to act immediately not only in the case of these two pastors, but in the case of all christians persecuted in Sudan. In the case of Marjam Yahya Ibrahíma in 2014, the assistance of the European Parliament, the European Union was effective. That is why I believe it will be effective today.

name: Kashetu Kyenge
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, christian pastors Michael Yat and Peter Reith are perhaps paying with their lives for access to a universal human right: freedom of religion, conscience and belief. They are accused in their country, Sudan, of the worst crimes, subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment. And, if convicted, they will be sentenced to the death penalty. We call for the two Reverends to be released immediately and unconditionally, just as all forms of human rights violations and all forms of persecution and intimidation of Christian communities cease. Let us get out of the logic of exploiting religion for political purposes and purposes. We can no longer tolerate regimes that violate the free exercise of human rights and fundamental freedoms, even in clear violation of the international treaties ratified and signed, nor those regimes that provide for the death penalty.  The universal moratorium on the death penalty, which aims to abolish it completely, remains one of our main objectives. I would like to express our support for the work of civil society, humanitarian organisations and opposition parties.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the With an 80-point rating, Sudan ranks 6th on the 2015 Christian Persecution Index. It is becoming increasingly difficult for Christians in Sudan to live their faith. The fate of Pastor Michael Yat and Pastor Peter Yen Reith is painful for this persecution. I am therefore grateful that, together with my colleagues in the ECR Group, I have managed to give the initiative for this resolution. It is an appeal against the persecution of Christians. Especially for the two priests, as for any other of the approximately one hundred million persecuted Christians worldwide: religious freedom is a fundamental right. I am glad that we have heard this on several occasions today.  We, as a Europe of values, must stand up for it worldwide, and fight for it worldwide. We must not tolerate the persecution of Christians. We must not look away when people are discriminated against because they live their faith peacefully. On the part of my group, therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I would ask you to stand up with us against the persecution of Christians. Stand up with us for Pastor Yat and Pastor Reith! Let us help these men to freedom and to live a life of peace and justice for all persecuted Christians!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a member of the EPP—subtitled Christian Democrats, any type of religious discrimination – especially against Christians – grates very heavily. This is particularly the case here with the two church leaders, Pastors Yat Michael and Peter Yen, who were arrested and who now possibly face the death penalty merely for professing their Christian faith. This is appalling, and we must certainly do everything we can to get these two eminent and wonderful pastors freed, especially as Sudan has ratified the relevant UN and African Union conventions guaranteeing religious freedom. But, of course, it is totally ignoring them. This is something that we in the European Parliament and the Commission must really do something about as quickly as we can. Also, we should not ignore the situation in Darfur, where similar discrimination is carried out, where 2.5 million people are dispatched, and where 4.5 million people need humanitarian aid. Sudan really needs our assistance.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Pastors Yat and Reith are not victims of imaginary Islamists, but of the specific government and social intolerance on which this government is based. Their situation is a very concrete cause for Christian-Muslim relations in the 21st century. This is our right and our duty as people with public responsibility, responsibility for others.  But no country in Europe is harassing Muslims because of the sermons that are delivered in mosques or because of their religious practices. In this Parliament, in this House, European Muslims are free to speak of their grievances, their social expectations, and we always discuss these appeals, we always respond to them. We therefore have a duty to demand for Christians the same in all Muslim countries, the same as we give ourselves. In order to demand this, we must first identify with these brothers, because unfortunately they very often suffer from our indifference.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, much has already been said about the disastrous human rights situation in Sudan, and I will not repeat it. But we also have rays of hope, because exactly a year ago, shortly after our resolution was passed, a convicted Christian, Marjam Yahya Ibrahím, was released to her death in Sudan. So our efforts are not in vain. The European Union should recall the Council recommendation of June 2013 and consider providing development aid where freedom of religion is not respected. In view of the case of Marjam Yahya Ibrahíma, I believe that our resolution today and our efforts can be as successful as they were a year ago.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – If a country accuses two Christian pastors of leading a war against a state, we can be sure that this is a fabricated accusation. On the contrary, it is states such as Sudan that are waging war against Christianity and Christians. This war begins with the denial of civil rights, the demolition of churches and church buildings, followed by the suppression of human rights, unfair processes and, often, death. The least we can do in these cases is to strongly warn the governments of these countries and their representatives that the EU is following their actions and will use all means to protect the innocent. I therefore considered it my duty to join the proponents of this resolution. Dear friends, but I cannot add that I consider it the pinnacle of arrogance when we are now talking about the persecution of Christians in Sudan, and three hours ago we were unable to leave words on the persecution of Christians in the report on neighbourhood policy.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I was on missions of this Parliament in Sudan in 2004, in Darfur in 2010 and 2011, in observation of elections. They're a gross fabrication, as were this year's.  No wonder that the Omar al-Bashir regime is now attacking representatives of Christian communities, such as these priests who have now been arrested and are at risk of the death penalty, as well as torture. It is a regime that oppresses and violently oppresses its people, and the European Union has to understand this and not go into fabricated, Khartoum-like processes on immigration with the regime which, effectively by exploiting and oppressing its people, manufactures migrants. The Khartoum process can't go anywhere.  The European Union has to be vocal with the last protector of the Regime of Omar al-Bashir, which is the regime of President Zuma in South Africa, who let him escape the mandate of the International Criminal Court. The European Union and South Africa cannot be complicit in a regime, they have to speak for the victims of that regime.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I, too, would like to thank the authors of this resolution very warmly. Indeed, I really share here the view of my colleague Jurek that we should look very deeply and with care at the situation of Christians in Muslim countries. But I would also like to express, and also referring to this statement, to express my concern and the need for some other discussion. The discussion is about the source of this indifference, which colleague Jurek is talking about. Indifference to the fate of Christians persecuted in different parts of the world. Sometimes there is a kind of resistance to acknowledging these sufferings and paying attention to the situation of Christians in these countries. And I think we would also need to discuss the issue of the marginalisation of Christians in public life in Europe someday in this Parliament.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this report is not perfect, but the principle is vital. I hope that I stand with everyone else in this Chamber when I say that the death penalty for practising Christians anywhere in the world is completely unacceptable. You know that I am a UKIP Member of the European Parliament, and you know that I am opposed to the European Union, so my next words may surprise you. I will be voting in favour of this resolution, and I urge the whole of this Chamber to do likewise.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a good opportunity, on behalf of the High Representative, to have this debate on the ongoing trials against the two pastors we have discussed today –Pastor Yat Michael Ruot and Pastor Peter Yein Reith in Sudan. Both pastors had been preaching in the Evangelical and Presbyterian Church in Khartoum. They spoke out against the demolition of this church, following the dubious sale of the land on which it stands, and their arrests were carried out by the National Intelligence and Security Services of Sudan. They face seven different charges, including undermining the constitutional system and espionage which – as you have pointed out – could lead to the death penalty. The preliminary hearing closed on 2 July and we had been hoping to come with some positive news, especially as the evidence presented was so weak. Unfortunately, the judge decided to admit the case and the full trial is now set for 14 July. You can rest assured that we will be following this very closely. The EU delegation in Khartoum has been in close contact with the pastors’ lawyers throughout the whole procedure and, following their advice, has been observing the hearings in collaboration with Member States. We continue to do so. We believe that this sends a strong political signal of the importance that we attach to the process, most importantly to the freedom of religion, freedom of belief, freedom of expression and the right to a fair trial. This illustrates, once again, the deeply worrying situation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in general in Sudan, as well as the tight grip that the security forces have on state institutions. Let us not forget – as some of you have mentioned – that the situation in Darfur, South Kordofan and Blue Nile continues to cause endless drama and a lot of suffering for so many people. We will continue to work for the release of the two pastors and prioritise human rights and peace in all our contacts with Sudanese stakeholders.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, I learned last night that three Sudanese opposition leaders from the Congress party had been sentenced to 20 lashes last Monday. The sentence was immediately carried out in court. I think that this country is a particular humiliation, and I therefore ask the European Parliament to incorporate this new fact into the resolution. It seems to me that there is a consensus on that.
